column2: The national spirit of compassion has been weakened as a result of the present- method of administering relief; the Rev. Leon M.Flander, the pastor, said yesterday morning in his sermon in the Tremont Presbyterian Church, Grand Concourse and 178th Street, the Bronx. Unless the policy is changed,

" Democracy has the only approach to human relationships that can make for a free flow of life forces," declared Dr. Frank Kingdon, president of the University of Newark, in an address yesterday morning at the Free Synagogue in Carnegie Hall.

ACKERMAN-Louise, on Sunday, March 20. 1938, daughter of the late William G. and Caroline Stilwell Ackerman of Kingsbridge, New York City. Funeral service at her residence, 30 Hamilton Ave., Yonkers, on Wednesday, March 23, at 2:30 P. M. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

European war talk last week failed to result in a material increase in speculative interest in the grain markets. Average daily sales of all grain futures on the Board of Trade were 26,100,000 bushels,

Right will prevail over might when it faces the controversy with clean hands, a pure heart, a willingness to sacrifice material desires and a learning to value the life of the other man seriously; the Rev. Dr. Samuel Goldenson declared yesterday before the Congregation Emanu-El in the temple at Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

Jack Doyle, New York betting commissioner, passed the word before his departure for home today that it will be the Yankees again in the American League by odds of 1 to 2. Behind the Yanks, in Doyle's opinion, came Cleveland, Detroit and Chicago, all at about 5 to 1. At the bottom of the list, he placed Washington, Philadelphia and St. Louis in that order.
The German wholesale price index for March 9 was 105.8, unchanged from that of a week before. Among components of the index, prices of metals and rubber have fallen sharply.

Edward H. Dann, widely known business man and civic worker, died this morning in Memorial Hospital here after a short illness, at the age of 69. Mr. Dann was born in Kirkville, a son of Edward H. and Amelia Dann. His mother later became Mrs. Andrew J. De Mott.

A lack of adequate labor organizations is one of the principal reasons why women in business and industry have-failed to receive the remuneration they deserve, according to a study by the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor on "Differences in the Earnings of Women and Men," made public today by Secretary Perkins.
Alexander Malinoff, former Premier, died today while being applauded by crowds during a spirited election-campaign address.

Martin Burrell, Parliamenrary Librarian. and Minister in the Borden wartime Cabinet, died at his home here today after an illness of three weeks. His age was 79. Born at Farington, Berks, England, Oct. 15, 1858, Mr. Burrell was educated at St. John's College, Hurstpierpont.

By any other name, "The Little Tailor," which was presented at the Second Avenue Theatre on Saturday night, would still be a secondhand garment worn by a generation of downtown playwrights, including the author, Louis Freiman.

Nation-wide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 32 per cent of capacity, up one point in a week and two points in a fortnight from the rate that had obtrained for five consecutive weeks.

The New Friends of Music gave the sixteenth and last concert of its second season yesterday afternoon in Town Hall For this final event of the series a program had been arranged composed of familiar works by Mozart and Schubert.

Supported by a group of eleven actors, Laurette Taylor will appear as guest artist this afternoon at the Plymouth Theatre in the sixth audition conducted by the Apprentice Theatre of the American Theatre Council. They will be seen in the first half of the first act of Miss Taylor's play, "At the Theatre."

Persistent pressure of veterans' organizations for extending pensions has resulted in a number of bills being favorably reported by House committees, the aggregate cost of which would exceed $75,000,000 a year.
Today is the first day of Spring. The last day of Winter, yesterday, was the warmest day of the year so far, with a high temperature of 66, 1 degree above the reading for Saturday.

Continuing his drive to relieve midtown traffic congestion, Police Commiisioner Valentine announced yesterday that after Sept. 15 commercial vehicles transporting merchandise will not be allowed to stop at an angle to the curb in any of the streets between

Mrs. Peter J. Schweitzer, active in the international Zionist movement and recently elected to the National Council for Palestine, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital following an emergency operation. She was 57 years old and made her home at 270 West End Avenue.

The navy's Problem 19, second big-scale war game in the mid-Pacific sector within a year, is now under way beginning with the departure of the fleet from San Pedro last Tuesday. An armada of 150 fighting ships plus 500 modern aircraft,

The four-story industrial building at 43-20 Thirty-fourth Street, Long Island City, was sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Loomis J. Grossman, operator, for cash over a first mortgage of $124,000. It was leased recently to Peerless of America, Inc.,

Two tries in the first half and another in the second gave the New York Rugby Club a 9-to-O decision over the Pilgrims at Central Park yesterday. It was the first victory in two starts for the New York team. The fine work of the backs was the chief factor in the triumph.

Public offering of $500,000 of Transcontinental Petroleum Cor- 1 portion 6 per cent convertible first mortgage sinking fund gold bonds will be made today by Leach Brothers, Inc.; Johnston, Lemon Co., Washington, D. C., and Gilbert F. Brooks Co., Providence, R. I.

Lester David O'Dell, a 35-year-old letter-writer of unusual attainments, whose suavely threatening notes to President Roosevelt, coupled with demands for money, caused the Chief Executive to take action against him, was arraigned yesterday in Yorkville Court before Magistrate Irving Ben Cooper.

The fresh rise to in the Bank of France's loans to to the State, which appeared in the pr weekly report dated March 10, passed almost unnoticed in the financial market where attention was turned to foreign affairs.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

Even during a relatively mild Winter there are moments when the return of Spring seems impossible. Rain has turned to sleet, sleet to snow, snow to mud, mud to ice. Storms have sneaked in from the Northwest and also from the Southeast.
The North American Light and Power Company reported gross revenues of $15,477,344 in 1937, against $14,684,309 in 1936. Net income was $1,329,070, against $478,877.
Not for many years has the City received such a shock as was administered by Germany's seizure of Austria. Bewilderment and fear, and something very like panic followed in quick succession.

The Bourse and the foreign exchange market were violently shaken by the sudden critical turn of the international situation after the German coup de force in Austria. Moreover, the formation of a Cabinet presided over by Leon Blum caused profound disappointment among financial circles,

Two new courses in housing management will be conducted by the New York University Division of General Education starting Thursday evening, March 24. and continuing for ten weeks at the Washington Square Center. They will treat the problems of tenant relations and building superintendence in public and private housing projects.

The growing persecution of the Jews in Europe may have tragic consequences but it cannot affect their faith in the ultimate survival of Jewish ideals, Louis P. Rocker, national president of Young Judaea, an American Jewish youth organization, declared last night at a dinner given by the society in his honor at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. About 400 persons attended.

Ambassador Josephus Daniels asserted today that the United States Government had been caught completely napping on the Mexican Government's plan to expropriate the foreign oil companies, but indicated that the State Department would not take diplomatic action until the eleven United States companies that have lost their $250,000,000 stake in Mexico had exhausted all legal recourses.

Members of the Drama Critics Circle will vote April 18 their choices as to the best new American play of the 1937-38 season and also give an honorable citation to the best new foreign play seen since last Autumn.

With a total value of $575,027,000 for the first eleven weeks of this year, major engineering construction awards are 22 'per cent above the total of $470,056,000 for the corresponding period last year. The awards so far this year. are the highest for any similar period since 1929.
A. F. Streelman took high-- gun honors in the first fifty at the North Jersey Gun Club traps today. In the second event, H. Higgs won on a draw.
The Confessional Synod Protestant churches continued today to warn Germany she may be paying too high a price for foreign successes in terms of liberty and standards of justice.

The first force of the Rebel drive apparently has spent itself on this vital part of the front. The government at last has had a chance to pull itself together and dig in strongly in excellent positions.

The Misses Ruth Anne and Jean Rensenhouse, daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Proctor D. Rensenhouse of this place, have selected the evening of April 13 for their double wedding at the home of their parents here.

Employment in the constructional field in New York State continued its downward trend from January to February with a decrease of 8.4 per cent, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, reported today. Payrolls declined 6.7 per cent and man-hours were off 9.4 per cent.
The resignation of the -Rev. William M. MacInnis as pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Succasunna to accept a call from the First Presbyterian Church of Endicott, N. Y., was announced today.

Mrs. Elinor White Frost, wife of Robert Frost, the poet, died here this afternoon of heart disease at the age of 64. She and her husband had been spending the Winter in Gainesville. For some years their home has been at South Shaftsbury, Vt.

A tea will be given this afternoon at Sherry's to launch the drive of the women's division of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity which, this year for the first time, will assist in the 1938 Catholic Charities appeal.
Scotland Yard detectives were called out today in a vain search for scores that Yehudi Menuhin's accompanist had left on a bus two hours before a concert at Albert Hall.

Another cloud, at present "no bigger than a man's hand," is seen by some observers here in what the Journal de Geneve calls the Giornale d'Italia's "sensational" comment on the report that Switzerland is to hold army manoeuvres from March 21 to 26 in its Italian canton of Ticino. The Fascist comment is reported as follows:

Following the modification of the State's capital gains and losses tax by the Legislature yesterday, State Controller Morris S. Tremaine appealed today to Congress to "repeal or drastically modify" the Federal capital gains and losses tax and undistributed profits levy.

Army Spring sports schedules announced today by Lieut. Col. Jacob L. Devers, graduate manager of athletics, show that the varsity baseball, track, lacrosse, polo, golf and tennis teams will meet twentysix college rivals in forty-nine matches, the majority of which will be played here.

After fluctuating only narrowly through Thursday, active future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange lost 30 to 35 points on Friday. In the early trading on Saturday they recovered almost all their losses, but later in the short session gave up part of the recovery.

Conditions in Europe and the resulting unfavorable effect upon the markets here and abroad, coupled with erratic fluctuations in outside commodities and the general trade recession, kept the cotton market here nervous last week, with alternating periods of extreme dullness and moderate activity.

The Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company earned only $2,480,508 last year, before allowing for rental payments due to the franchiseowning underlying companies, according to the annual report made public today by Ralph T. Senter, president.

Arthur H. Samuels, executive prokucer of station WOR and a former newspaper man and editor of sevral magazines, died in Doctors hospital yesterday morning after a three-day illness. His age was 49. n Thursday Mr. Samuels, whose ome was at 50 East Seventy-second treet and who had been associated Pith the radio station for only six months, became ill at his office.

Well-known members of society are actively interested in the recently organized Tower Theatre Club, under the direction of Leighton Rollins, which opened last night at the Beekman Tower with the presentation of "Castle Irish," a new play by Mary Manning (Mrs. Mark De Wolfe Howe).

Existing gifts of $51,000,000, distributed to date by the.Rockefeller Foundation, and $148,000,000 distributed by the General Education Board out of Rockefeller funds, were freed from. previous restrictions by announcement of the trustees yesterday.

Reaching Tom Baker for four hits and four runs in the first inning, the Jersey City Giants defeated the New York Giants' second team today, 6 to 4, for a sweep of the twogame exhibition series. It was Jersey City's third straight victory.

Plans have been completed by Miss Frances Louise Townley, daughter of the Rev. Dr. Frank M. Townley, rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, and Mrs. Townley, for her marriage to Dr. Donald

Westport players won four of the six metropolitan badminton championships as form prevailed with two exceptions, one major and one minor, in the finals of the sixth annual tournament on the courts of the Old Sixty-ninth Badminton Club in the 165th Infantry Armory yesterday.
Last month's uproarious conference of "little business men" developed today into a permanent organization known as the Nation's Smaller Business Council.

Waging an inspired battle after they had yielded two goals in the first period, the New York Americans dealt the Toronto Maple Leafs a 4-to-2 defeat in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.
A printers' strike which forced five newspapers to suspend publication ended today when the strikers agreed to return to work pending arbitration of their demands for increased wages.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edgar H. Tinsman of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Louise Tinsman, to Karl C. Speh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman A. Speh of Binghamton, N. Y.

Supreme Court Justice John McGeehan, Miss Moira Archbold, Mrs. Alien McMartin, Mrs. A. G. Olney, Mrs. William Deveboise, Lawrence Colwell. in Hampshire House, 150 Central Park S.; Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers. Joseph A. Nicolini, in 299 W. 12th St; Harry A. Miller. In 225 E 73d St; Mrs.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, arriving today from Southampton and Cherbourg, has as passengers the Countess of Granard, sister of the late Odgen L. Mills, accompanied by her son, Viscount Forbes.

The American Labor party was called upon to refute publicly the charge that it acts as a "cloak" for the Communist faction in labor in an address yesterday by Jeremiah F. Cross, State Commander of the American Legion.

Sales of Electric power by the Commonwealth Edison group of properties and the earnings of the system in 1937 were substantially larger than in the preceding year, according to the company's annual statement to stockholders today.

Declaring that some factors in the raw cotton situation deserve more emphasis that they have received in recent analyses of the Crop Control Act, Dr. claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute, in a statement issued for publication today,

Hope that the liftboard dispute which has paralyzed shipping in this port for a week could be ended by compromise vanished today when directors of the Waterfront Employers Association. turned down all three proposals submitted by the joint labor relations committee of longshoremen and employers.

New art exhibitions of the week make up in variety for any numerical falling off. Recent paintings and drawings by Jon Corbino are to go on view today at the Macbeth Galleries. Water-colors and drawings by Jules Pascin are to be shown at Valentine's.

The general election in South Australia yesterday apparently resuited in a stalemate because of losses by the government party. In the last Legislative Assembly the Country-Liberal League, under Premier R. L. Butler, had 28 seats, the Labor party 13 and Independents 5. In this election there was a redistribution of seats under which 19 multiple member electorates, returning 46 members, were replaced by 39 single member electorates.
Chuji Egawa, organizer and president of Japan's Suicide Club, died today of tuberculosis, but even his natural death troubled Tokyo police.

Apart from the Austrian developments, the week's business interest has continued to be concentrated upon the banks. The explanation of this is that private investment capital is gradually withdrawing from the socalled real industrial values owing to the conviction that the government will not permit a reasonable

The relief expressed in Western European capitals at the subsidence of the Polish-Lithuanian crisis as a result of Lithuania's acceptance of Poland's ultimatum is not shared in Moscow, according to editorials of a similar tone in leading Soviet organs today.

The Senate will continue this week its long debate on the government reorganization bill. The House is slated to bring the $1,200,000,000 Naval Expansion Bill to a vote and take up the army appropriation bill.

Frank Moore of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club, Mamaroneck, N. Y., and Bobby Dunkelberger, rising star of High Point, N. C., defeated Jimmy Thomson of Shawnee, Pa., and Carl M. Dann Jr. of Orlando, Fla., in the 36-hole final of the fourth annual national amateur-professional best-ball match play championship on St. Augustine Links today. Moore and Dunkelberger played par-shattering golf to win by 3 and 2.

Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the School of Journalism of Columbia University discussed at a community vesper service here today the significance of the. suggestion of the. German press chief, Otto Dietrich, that all governments negotiate treaties with Germany for official control of the press.

The one-story taxpayer on a plot 50 by 100-feet at 319-23 Broad Avenue, corner of Bellview Place, Palisades, N. J., has been sold by Croydon Realty, Inc., to Samuel Horowitz, operator. Rubin Nason beat Were the brokers.

The indications are for fair weather with moderate temperatures today and for increasing cloudiness tomorrow, followed by showers in the afternoon or at night and mild temperatures, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

The British freighter Lycia docked at Philadelphia today after a fortyfive-day crossing of the Atlantic marked by storms, disabled engines, dwindling food and water supplies and miles of towing by a tug.

Continued slight increases in the buying of steel, particularly in heavier lines, gives encouragement in the trade, the magazine Steel reports in a summary this week, adding that "how much is seasonal and how much business revival is difficult to determine."

Mrs. Louise Bryan Dorr of Ocean Grove died here yesterday in a private hospital after a long illness at the age of 85. She was the widow of Russell Ripley Dorr, founder of the Bankers Life Insurance Company of St. Paul, Minn.

Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Garrigue Wright of this city and Cherry Valley, N. Y., announced today at a tea given in their home the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Garrigue Wright, to H. Paul Buckingham, son of Mrs. Lawrence McCoy and the late

Derrick De Marney, who was seen last season on the New York stage in "Young Mr. Disraeli," has been engaged by R.-K.-O. to appear opposite Joan Fontaine in the role originally acheduled for Louis Hayward in "The Muddled Deal," by Alder Ladsziow.
" March Winds of 1938," the annual charity revue of the Two Hundred Club of Upper Montclair, will -be given Friday and Saturday evenings in the auditorium of Mount Hebron School.

John Legg, a retired woolen manufacturer of Worcester, Mass., died at his home here today in his eighty-seventh year. Born in Trowbridge, England, he came to this country as a child. In 1892 he succeeded his father, James Legg, as president of the Worcester Woolen Mill Corporation.

American shipping will face a state of chaos if some restriction is not placed on petty union actions that frustrate the smooth movement of commerce, it was declared in a letter sent by the Propeller Club of the United States -to Thomas W. Woodward, member of the United States Maritime Commission.

Father Ignatius W. Cox, Professor of Ethics at Fordham University, told a meeting of 1,200 parishioners of six Catholic churches in Brooklyn last night that if the Catholic doctrine on peace and war were taught properly, "20,000,000 American Catholics may be lined up with the Quakers as conscientious objectors," if this country became involved in a war.
The Riviera has become a retiring place for British statesmen and celebrities who, for the most part, are keeping apart.

Plans for an apartment house in the Fordham section of the Bronx west were announced in connection with Milto the sale by Mary E. Ryan to Philip for o Herschowsky of 2,615 Grand Concourse, a plot 100 by 100 feet, a block north of Fordham Road and Stree facing Poe Park. Held at $65,000, The the property was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $25,000.

Father Ignatius W. Cox, Professor of Ethics at Fordham University, told a meeting of 1,200 parishioners of six Catholic churches in Brooklyn last night that if the Catholic doctrine on peace and war were taught properly, "20,000,000 American Catholics may be lined up with the Quakers as conscientious objectors," if this country became involved in a war.
The Riviera has become a retiring place for British statesmen and celebrities who, for the most part, are keeping apart.

Plans for an apartment house in the Fordham section of the Bronx west were announced in connection with Milto the sale by Mary E. Ryan to Philip for o Herschowsky of 2,615 Grand Concourse, a plot 100 by 100 feet, a block north of Fordham Road and Stree facing Poe Park. Held at $65,000, The the property was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $25,000.

Lefty Vernon Gomez and Charley (Red) Ruffing collaborated in a masterful pitching piece against the Cards this afternoon before another banner crowd at Waterfront Park, and not only pulled the Yankees even with the Frisch clan, but gave the world champions the distinction of their second shutout triumph in three games.

Chiefly through orders for the manufacture of rolling stock, Pullman, Inc., had net earnings in 1937 nearly double those in 1936, David A. Crawford, president, said yesterday in his annual report. Net income was $12,275,950, or $3.17 a share of capital' stock, against $6,347,106, or $1.64 a share, in 1936.

The sincerity of churchgoers is measured by the "way members and their friends invest their means and talent" for the needs of the community, declared the Rev. Dr. A. J. MacKenzie, new minister of the Union Congregational Church, 115th Street near Jamaica Avenue, Queens, yesterday morning in his first sermon.

Dr. Albert S. Hyman, prominent heart specialist, has purchased, through CuLver, Hollyday Co., Inc., and Herman Morris, cobrokers, the five-story American basement dwelling at 46 East Seventy-third Street, from the Aldoral Holding Corporation, for $35,000.
The international stock market indices for March 19, with comparisons, are as 'follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

By an overwhelming majority the House of Representatives passed today the Administration's $1,121,546,000 Naval Construction Bill, the second largest peace-time naval authorization in the history of the United States.

The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted today a rule which will enable the San Francisco Curb Exchange and Stock Exchange to retain unlisted trading privileges when their contemplated merger takes place.

Excavators, doing a grade-crossing elimination job for the Central Railroad of New Jersey at Elizabeth Avenue in downtown Elizabeth, were stymied today by irate property owners who parked two moving vans, a hearse and a flower car directly in the path of their operations.

Word was received yesterday by Percy Prince, catering superintendent of Cunard White Star Line, of the death of his brother, Ernest F. Prince, who died suddenly on Saturday while on a vacation in San Francisco.

At the annual meeting of shareholders of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, held yesterday afternoon at the utility's headquarters in Irving Place, Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board, told those in attendance-numbering about 500-that earnings of the Edison system so far this year were running ahead of those in the comparable period of last year.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following Reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC, is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name: 1st Lt. Aaron Weiner, Med.-Res., Oct. 4. Capt. Richard L, Bohannon, Med.-Res., Oct. 21. Capt. Clark W. Pennington, Engr.-Res., Oct. 31.

Chicago's business with Mexico estimated at about $10,900,000 for 1937, has been seriously affected by recent events in that country, including the seizure of foreign oil companies there and suspension of all transaction in foreign exchange, Chicago business and trade officials said today.

A new issue of $23,500,000 of fiveyear 2 per cent consolidated debentures, Series D, of the Federal Home Loan Banks will be offered to the public today, according to an announcement yesterday by Preston Delano, governor of the Home Loan Bank System.

Secretary of Commerce Daniel C. Roper and nine nationally known business leaders, in a radio symposium at 9:30 o'clock last night on the "Spring Outlook for Business," said there was no prospect of a quick recovery from the current slump but declared that conditions important to increasing activity were appearing on the trade horizon.

The New York State Bankers Retirement System, a pension plan organized by the New York State Bankers Association, has received from Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance, a certificate authorizing it to begin operations, it was announced yesterday by Raymond F. Leinen, chairman of the trustees of the system and executive vice president of the Lincoln-Alliance Bank and Trust Company of Rochester.

An exhibition of historic wedding and period gowns dating from 1844 to the present time will be a feature of the Spring fashion show and tea of the Women's National Republican Club which will be held this afternoon in the George Washington Assembly Room of the clubhouse at 3 West Fifty-first Street.

A fire that did little damage routed forty kitchen workers and fifty diners from the restaurant of the Union News Company on the mezzanine of Grand Central Terminal yesterday afternoon, caused the huge waiting room of the station to fill with dense smoke and disrupted traffic in the area.

Traffic accidents, fatalities and the number of injuries in the city dropped sharply last week and week-end as compared with the corresponding periods of last year, it was announced yesterday by the Safety Bureau of the Police Deapartment.

Mr. and Mrs. William J. Murray gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for their daughter, Miss Vesta Murray, a student at Sweet Briar College. Other guests were the Misses Janet MacFarlan,

Holders of common stock of the Certain-teed Products Corporation at their meeting on March 26 will be asked to consider changing the voting rights of the preference stock so that it will vote for directors whenever the company is in arrears in the payment of six quarterly dividends on the stock, irrespective of whether the quarterly periods in respect of which the default occurred were consecutive.

The Census Bureau reported today final ginning figures of the 1937 cotton crop, placing production at 18,241,726 running bales, or 18,934,153 equivalent 500-pound bales, exclusive of linters. The crop is the largest ever produced.
Secretary of State Cordell Hull today informed Representative Charles A. Buckley of New York that steps had been taken to give prompt attention to applications for immigration visas in Vienna.

Advertising men who attended the Lanham bill hearings in Washington last week predicted yesterday that this proposal to revise national trade-mark legislation probably would not be passed at the current session of Congress.

Trial of three members of the crew of the steamship Algic on an indictment charging conspiracy to incite mutiny while the vessel was at Montevideo, Uruguay, on Sept. 10, was adjourned yesterday until Sept. 7 by Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn Federal Court after defense counsel reported that five witnesses were at sea.

Three entire floors consisting of about 48,000 square feet of space have been leased in the building at 475 Tenth Avenue for the Division of Women's and Professional Projects and the Research and Clerical Projects of the Works Progress Administration,
While being taken in a patrol wagon yesterday. to Brooklyn Felony Court, Jack Cooper, 32 years old, of 101 Bowery, slashed both wrists and his throat with a razor blade. he had concealed in a shoe.
Joe Platak of Chicago began his defense of the National A. A. U. handball championship tonight by trouncing Eddie Sloan of Charlotte, N. C., 21 to 13 and 21 to 3.
An entry list of eight teams was completed tonight in the nineteenth annual Eastern States basketball tournament with the acceptance of an invitation by the Lynn, Mass., English High School.

The Silver Cross Day Nursery will be aided by a Spring card party to be held on April 28 at the Plaza. There also will be a sale of useful and decorative articles and candy. Mrs. Daniel Daney Miller heads the bridge committee, and Mrs. William Gage Brady is in charge of the candy booth.

Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, heard yesterday testimony on the applications of three public utility companies for authorization to issue for refunding purposes securities amounting to more than $70,000,000. The applications were taken under advisement.

Following a conference at City Hall yesterday with Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, a group of thirty persons interested in continuation of the Philharmonic Symphony concerts this Summer made plans to raise $75,000 by popular subscription to meet an expected Summer deficit.

The annual card party for the benefit of the Immaculate Conception Day Nursery in Brooklyn will take place April 18 at the headquarters of the Columbus Club, Brooklyn. Mrs. Thomas F. Casey, former president of the nursery, heads the committee in charge.

The Montreal Canadiens, preparing for de their twelfth National Hockey ha League play-off series in thirteen years, skated through a fast twohour practice today and at the in finish Manager, Cecil Hart announced his team would go "all be out" in an attempt to complete the third-place series with the Chicago Black Hawks in two straight a games.

J. J. Anzalone, controller of the Alleghany Corporation, agreed today in response to a question from counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission that a $15,965,201 liability assumed by the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company in 1930 should have appeared on its subsequent financial statements.

An order granting the application of the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration the certificates of deposit representing ten-year secured 61/2 per cent sinking-fund gold bonds due on April 1, 1934, of-Botany Consolidated Mills, Inc.,

Reduction of taxi fares and a stagger system whereby not all cabs would be on the streets of the city at once were two suggestions made yesterday at a City Hall hearing of the special committee of the City Council investigating all phases of the taxicab industry in the city.
State Controller Tremaine announced today that he would sell tomorrow an issue of $100,000,000 of short-term notes maturing on June 28.

With a fortnight of indoor work behind them, Princeton's varsity baseball men took to University Field today for the first time this Spring and ran through a two-hour session under the direction of Coach Bill Clarke. The Tigers open against Dickinson here March 30.

Thirty-five Americans and fifty-four Britons connected with the oil business were today being rushed out of the lonely Isthmus of Tehuantepec, in Southern Mexico, because of threats against their lives.

Trading was mostly fair. Steer hinds and ribs and lamb carcasses were weak to 50c below last Friday's early market and veal hindsaddles mostly $1 below. Fresh pork cuts are steady to $1 higher. Early trading in kosher meats indicated veal and calf to be weak, beef and lamb weak to slightly lower, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
The general level of wholesale commodity prices last week was at the lowest reached in the current recession, according to the index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association.

Shipments of $2,985,000 gold arrived here yesterday as the first consignments of the new gold influx which began last week. Additional engagements of gold abroad for transfer here, aggregating $5,530,000 were reported to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, bringing the total known movement up to $13,355,000.

Mickey Farber, 136, of the East Side gained an eight-round decision over Victor Troise, 134, Harlem, in the feature bout at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. In the semi-final eight-rounder Nick Camarata, 1341/2, outpointed Ray Ingram, 1331/2, of Washington.
Professor ARTHUR W. Ryder, head of the Department of Sanskrit at the University of California, died while leading a class today. His age was 61.

Despite the seizure of their properties in Mexico, the stocks of the United States concerns involved have been holding steady. Yesterday the stock of Standard Oil of New Jersey, which had an advance of more than a point on Saturday, lost only 1/4 point, while Standard of California gained that much.
Convict labor will be more extensively employed in drainage and 'other land improvement projects, Dr. Friedrich Syrup, president of the Reich Labor Office, announced today.

Charles C. King, former vice president of the Crown Fastener Company of New York, died yesterday at his home at the age of 64. He retired on Jan. 1 after three years with the Crown Company. He formerly was associated with the Talon Fastener Company and Abercrombie Fitch.

A report on additional transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations in January, supplementing an earlier report for the same period was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

At the annual meeting-yesterday of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, Inc., James H. McGraw Jr., president, told stockholders that net earnings for the first quarter of this year will be about twothirds of those reported for the same period in 1937.

The economic theory that the wheels of industry can turn only if the public buys, and the public can buy-only if prices are pushed downward, was cheered at a consumers rally at Madison Square Garden arranged by the Hearn Department Stores yesterday afternoon.

After losing the first four bouts in a row the Chicago Golden Gloves amateur boxing team rallied to register a 9-7 triumph over the New York Golden Gloves aggregation at Madison Square Garden last night.

Spring may have arrived in the States today, but from the looks of the thermometer here one would think that Winter had just arrived. The temperature is 21 below zero, with a strong north wind blowing, filling the air with snow.

Despite her admission that she killed her husband, Patrolman Michael Ryan, a Bronx County Court jury containing three women acquitted Mrs. Patricia Ryan early this morning six hours after it had received the case.
The rng feud within the Tennessee Valy Authority moved swiftly to a limax today when President Rooseelt handed down an ultimatum lat Chairman Arthur E. Morgan

Representatives of many of the leading clubs of the city met yesterday afternoon at the Cavendish Club, 341 Park Avenue, and agreed to accept, with one minor clarification, the rules and scoring that had already been promulgated by the American cardplaying companies for five-suited bridge.
Members of the Cardinals' Gas House Gang were most disorderly during their visit. to the Dodgers today in this normally serene West Coast resort.

Mr. and Mrs. William Whitney Rasmussen of Westport, Conn., today announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Muriel Chase Rasmussen, to Clifford Kemp, New Zealand pianist. The wedding will take place soon.

Governor Lehman, in a letter to Chairman Harrison of the Senate Finance Committee, which is holding hearings on the revenue bill, sharply criticized today the Federal taxation policy as ignoring States' rights and in some respects monopolizing the tax field in a way that was si "truly alarming."
The committee created by the Republicancontrolled Assembly to investigate charges that the election of Governor Moore, a Democrat, was accompilshed by ballot frauds in Hudson County,
Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe dismissed kidnap and extortion indictments today against James Sweeney, 34, last of thirteen accused as members of the O'Connell kidnap gang.

Burgess Meredith, head of the Federal Arts Committee, declared yesterday that Dr. Walter Damrosch, in his attacks on the current movement to establish a Federal Bureau of Fine Arts, was "fighting at windmills."

One brilliant singles game was contributed to the American Bowling Congress records tonight. Jack Stahl of Detroit, scoring consistently-at well over a 200-clip, rolled up a grand total of 713 in the individual event and went into second place.
Dorothy Dow Premo of 69 Ridgewood Avenue, Brooklyn, filed objections yesterday in Surrogate's Court to the will of Margaret J. Pitou, who died on Oct. 30 last.

Steps taken by the Vargas government against German organizations in Brazil brought a reproof today from the Diplomatische Korrespondenz, which faintly hints that a continuation of such steps could not remain without effect on German-Brazilian relations.
Members of the Southern Women's National Democratic organization will hold a card party followed by dancing next Saturday afternoon in the Starlight roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

A heavy volume or mall orders, reflecting good business in stores throughout the country on Friday and Saturday of last week, was received in the local merchandise markets yesterday and was regarded as highly encouraging to manufacturers and resident offices.
Four persons were fined $1 each in Essex Market Court yesterday for failure to keep muzzles on their dogs when they walked through Washington Square Park with the animals last Saturday.
The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today a temporary exemption from the Public Utility Holding Company Act to the General Electric Company and two subsidiaries.
Stocks closed irregularly higher after early strength; turnover,. 542,230 shares. Bonds generally higher, foreign advances featured; transactions, $5,334,980.

Plans have been completed by Miss Gertrude Mehling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer Mehling of this city, for her marriage to Dr. Philip F. Partington, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Partington of East Orange, N. J.

On motion of Senator Clifford R. Powell of Burlington County, seconded by Assemblyman Homer Zink of Essex County, the State House Commission rejected today the application of Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, former Superintendent of the State Police Department, for a pension of $4,000 a year.
Ten more games were decided last night in the preliminary play of the United States chess tournament at the Marshall, Manhattan and West Side Clubs.

William D. Nolan, who served three terms as a member of the New Jersey Civil Service Commission, died today in his home here after a long illness. His age was 57. He had been a Republican leader in Somerset County for many years.

The women's division of the special gifts section of Cardinal Hayes's Committee of the Laity started a drive yesterday for at least $100,000 in the annual appeal of the Catholie Charities, which has a goal this year of $1,300,000.

Sixteen California-bred 2-yearolds have been nominated for the $1,500 four furlong juvenile dash at Bay Meadows tomorrow. Included are Montecito, Timberland, Don't Forget, Tonopah Queen, Crystal Lou, Jan, Nancy Rogge, Hetch Hetchy, Kayel, Early Dade.

Rome still may bid for the 1944 Olympic Games, it developed today. There was considerable surprise when Rome was not among the cities announced as seeking the 1944 games, but Olympic officials pointed out that the Italian city could enter its bid at any time prior to the I. O. C. meeting in London next year.

Debutantes attired in gayly colored peasant costumes, will comprise a special reception committee for the luncheon and fashion show, "Paris et Nous," to be held today in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria as a benefit for the West Side Thrift Shop.
Sixty-six candidates, one of the biggest turnouts in years, answered the Spring football call at Pennsylvania today as head coach George Munger and an entire new staff made their debut.
Although the almanac is on the side of Clare Kummer's "Spring Thaw," which opened at the Martin Beck last evening, the audience is on the other side of the footlights.

The stock market here was active and generally cheerful today, and most sections went ahead. The gilt-edge list was firm while among the foreign bonds French issues showed substantial improvement and Austrian securities were stronger.
President Cardenas's policy of penalizing foreign interests, culminating in the expropriation by executive decree of American and British oil properties valued at $450,000,000, is self-defeating.
Dean Detton, 205, Salt Lake City, pinned Chief Thunderbird, 218, with a crotch hold and body slam in 18:22 of the feature wrestling bout at the Hippodrome last night. A crowd of 2,000 was present.

Failing only once on any called shot, Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia overwhelmed Willie Mosconi, also of Philadelphia, 125 to 3, in the second game of the three-way play-off series for the pocket billiard championship of the world last night at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy. Thus the victor kept himself in the running for the crown.
Three men were hanged tonight in West Virginia's first execution for kidnapping after one of a them plunged prematurely through the death trap before the rope had been put about his neck.

Spring arrived officially yesterday, and the weather followed the calendar. At 4 P. M. in Manhattan the thermometer reached 74 degrees, within six degrees of the all-time high mark and the second highest temperature ever recorded in the city for a March 21.
Lady Flash, owned by Miles and Kover a quitter in her last two performances, did not stop today and easily defeated seven rivals in the feature for 3-year-olds at the Fair Grounds.

A change of the Constitution to permit State ratification of amendments by popular vote as well as by the Legislatures or by State conventions may be approved by Congress at this session, Senator Norris, Nebraska Independent, declared today.

When the historians of the future try to recreate the fashionable New York decor of the Eighteen Eighties, now all but extinct, they will have at least one important authentic example in two rooms from the residence of the late John D. Rockefeller, just installed in the Museum of the City of New York.

Efforts of Senator Byrd to commit President Roosevelt to a policy of reducing regular Federal expenditures by at least 10 per cent were defeated in the Senate today when his amendment to the Reorganization Bill was defeated by a vote of 56 to 28.

Mayor La Guardia demanded a special session of the Legislature yesterday to ease the tightness of city relief financing, in a statement in which he roundly criticized the legislators for failing to adopt bills important to the city at the session that ended last Saturday.

The four-story theatre structure, formerly known as the President and more recently called the Airerican Show Shop, at 247-49 West Forty-eighth Street, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. It was bought in by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, trustee, as plaintiff, for $122,500.

Packy Paul of Richdale, Alta., was scheduled to fight Jack Fitzpatrick, former amateur heavyweight champion of Wales tonight. But Packy was ill with influenza so his brother, Danny Paul, stepped into the gap and soundly trounced the Welshman.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 18: CAPTAINS Donald, H. G., Charleston, S. C.. to Bureau of Engineering, Washington, D. C., Aug. 15. Ross, C. C., Washington, D. C., to Charleston, S. C., as manager, navy yard, Aug. 1. O'Mara, J. F.. Pensacola, Fla., to Norfolk Navy Yard, Va., May 10.
The Franklin Society for Home Building and Savings, of which HI William J. Dwyer is president, is celebrating today the fiftieth anniversary of its founding.
With great military pomp and official ceremony, the first detachment of 10,000 Austrian workers invited by the German Labor Front to tour Nazi Germany free of charge entrained today.
The text of Governor Lehman's letter to Senator Harrison, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, on the subject of tax policies, follows:

In denying the petition of the Staten Island Edison Corporation for approval of its merger with the Richmond Light.and Railroad Company, the Public Service Commission, suggested yesterday that the latter company be eliminated "through dissolution proceedings" instead.

Appearance of a second division team in the final for the Scottish Football Cup was assured by the draw for the semi-finals made today. St. Bernard's will meet either East Fife or Raith Rovers at Tynecastle Park, Edinburgh, in one semi-final. The other, scheduled for Hampden Park, Glasgow, will be between the Rangers and the winner of the KilmarnockAyer United fourth-round match.

One of the more adroit pieces of story concoction is to be attempted by Metro, where negotiations are being carried on with Dale Carnegie for the film rights to his "How to Win Friends and Influence People." If the book is bought, the material will be merged with Irving Treslar's saga, "How to Lose Friends and Alienate People."

Irving C. Krewson Corporation, resident buyers, has added the F. W. Lawrence Company, Malone, N. Y., to its list of accounts. The Young Printing Executives: Club will hold a dinner meeting tonight at the Hotel Dixie.
The problem of finding a place to train your dog for the field is a difficult one to solve these days, but N. L. Kiel of Ridgefield, N. J., has come forward with a suggestion that has possibilities.

Frederick W. Krueger, vice president of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, associate chairman of the business division of the committee in charge of the annual campaign for $50,000 for maintenance of Boy Scout activities in Brooklyn, received the Silver Beaver Award at a luncheon yesterday in Brooklyn.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading ties shows the following principal ??anges for the week ended on March 16: Decreases of $122,000,000 loans to brokers and dealers in securities, $179,000,000 in demand ??eposits-adjusted and $35,000,000 in me deposits.

The fifth concert of the season by the National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin, conductor, brought a large audience last night to Carnegie Hall. The soloists of the occasion were Mack Harrell, baritone, and Anton Bilotti, pianist, who appeared in the first performance anywhere of his piano concerto.

The marriage of David Hearst, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Randolph Hearst, and Miss Hope Chandler, former show girl, is expected to take place this week,-it was disclosed yesterday. Their engagement has been rumored for some time, but not until Sunday night at the Paradise Restaurant,

Mrs. Norma Loewenstein Drabkin of 20 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, Assistant Professor of Classics in Brooklyn College, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital, after a brief illness, in her thirty-second year.
Flying Officer A. E. Clouston and Victor Ricketts hopped off for England at 5:39 P. M. Greenwich mean time (12:39 P. M. Eastern standard time) today in quest of new air records.

Funeral services were conducted today for Major Gen. Franklin W. Ward, former Adjutant General of the State National Guard, who died Thursday. Tonight the body was sent to Washington for burial tomorrow at Arlington National Cemetery.

The commander of the Chinese Red Army today asserted that 40,000 Japanese troops in Southern Shansi Province were cut off from their supply bases and in greatest danger of defeat since the Chinese-Japanese war started.

Regardless of whether or not the President has power under the law to demand the resignation of Chairman Morgan of TVA-and this is a point on which opinion differs-it is clear that Mr. Roosevelt has chosen the worst possible way of attempting to dispose of a case which has become a national cause celebre.

Miss Virginia Dunne and Miss Rosamond Murray head a group of young women who are arranging the annual fashion show and tea of Marymount School to be held tomorrow afternoon at the headquar-. ters of the school, 1,028 Fifth Avenue.

Mr. Denny reported yesterday another arrest in Moscow. This time it was not one of Lenin's close associates in the founding of the Soviet State or one of Joseph Stalin's late collaborators in the work of Socialist construction. In the present instance it is a young woman who for the last two years has worked as secretary in the Moscow bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

President Roosevelt conferred again with Chairman Morgan of the TVA.and gave him until 2:30 P. M. tomorrow to retract his charges against his two fellowdirectors or show cause why he should not resign or be removed or suspended.

Members of the New York-New Jersey Chapter of the Maryland College Alumnae Association will hold a card party next Saturday afternoon at the Lombardy. Mrs. John W. Holian of Jamaica, L. I., is president of the chapter. Miss Dorothy M. Chevalier of Tarrytown, N. Y., and Miss Constance W.
The manuscript of a new book by Granville Hicks, "I Like America," has been delivered to Modern Age Books, Inc., which has scheduled the volume for publication on May 16.
Jack Rutherfurd of Palm Beach broke his own world record twice with the Gold Cup boat Juno today, and his wife, Maude, not to be outdone, borrowed a 225-class hydroplane and drove it to a new record.

Dr. John Bates Clark, Professor Emeritus of Political Economy at Columbia University and former director of the division of economics and history of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, died yesterday of penumonia at his home, 420 Riverside Drive. He was 91 years old.

The Yale-Harvard varsity race this year will be rowed upstream on the Thames River at New London, June 24, because of tidal coneditions, the Yale Athletic Association announced today. It will start at 6:10 P. M. daylight saving time, about an hour earlier than usual.

A banking group composed of Blyth Co., Inc.; Kaiser Co. and Swabacher Co. received yesterday the award of an issue of $2,000,000 of registered warrants of the State of California on a 0.75 per cent interest basis, plus a premium of $1,442.

Forrester Scott, Philadelphia lawyer and sportsman, who was acused of attempting a seaplane kidnapping of his two young daughters here last week, pleaded guilty to two minor charges before a magistrate here today while an investigation of the kidnapping continued.

Everything in Governor Lehman's career encourages the hope that he will reject the McNaboe bill with a ringing veto. Passed in the last day of the session in the final rush to adjournment, without possibility of adequate consideration, the McNaboe bill seeks to bar persons advocating subversive doctrines from holding public positions, civil service jobs or positions in schools throughout the State.
Monte Pearson did about everything he shouldn't have done at Waterfront Park today and the consequence was the Yankees dropped their exhibition to the Reds, 9 to 6, before a gathering of 1,506.

Bond Stores, Inc., manufacturers and distributors of men's wear, will open the latest addition to their chain of units in Chicago during the latter part of this month, it was announced today. The new store, located at 3,250 Lincoln Avenue, expands the group here to five. The addition bf a students' department will mark an innovation for the company, but there will also be a men's shoe section.

The wedding of Miss Nancy Trowbridge Barker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Barker, to Charles Noyes Loveland Jr. of Cumberland Mills, Me., is to take place at the First Congregational Church, Pittsfield, the afternoon of April 8. The Rev. John Gratton will officiate. Mr.

Steve (Crusher) Casey, 225, Ireland, defeated George Koverly, 215, Hollywood, in the feature of a wrestling show tonight. The bout was scheduled for three falls, but Koverly dived from the ring to the floor after 27 minutes 20 seconds and was unable to return for the second fall.

It looks-a little like Paul Dean may be back "fogging" them across for the Cardinals within a month. Paul, younger and slightly less voluble brother of the Great Diz' has been off the firing line for the better part of two seasons with a "catch" in his right arm. It's gone now, he says. Manager Frankie Frisch is dubious, but hopes Paul is right.

Frank G. Shattuck Co., Gerald Shattuck, president, leased from estate of Eugene A. Hoffman, Inc., William M. V. Hoffman, president, the four-story building on the s. e. cor. of 5th Ave. and 13th St., 25 ft. on the avenue and 100 ft. on the street, for twenty and one-half years from April 1, 1938, at the annual rent. of $5,000, plus all taxes, water charges, assessments, etc.

A 161-pound white marlin caught off Miami Beach by L. F. Hooper of Essex Fells, N. J., was said by fishing experts today to be a world's record for the species. Hooper boated the hard-fighting fish yesterday in the Gulf Stream. Only three days earlier Carl Badenhausen of Newark,

Only 105 miles tonight separated two Japanese armies pressing upon Suchow, strategic junction of the Lung-Hai and Tientsin-Pukow railways. General Juichi Terauchi's armies, pressing from the north, hold a spearhead point only nineteen miles north of Suchow,

The Rev. Dr. Leighton Parks, rector emeritus of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York, of which he was the active head until his retirement nearly a decade and a half ago, died here today at the age of 86.

James Blake Rogers, son of the late Will Rogers, and his-fiancee, Miss Marguerite Astrea Kemmler, walked into the Los Angeles County, Clerk's office today. arm in arm and made application for a marriage license.

A group of investors known as the Broad and Jersey Corporation purchased the three-story business building at 1,166-70 East Jersey Street, in the uptown shopping area. The transaction is said to have involved $135,000.

Speculation as to the procedure to be followed in liquidating Austria's' League of Nations connection was set at rest tonight when the League published a communication received earlier in the day from the'German Foreign Office. It cites textually Austria's federal constitutional law,
William Eichhorst, 34 years old, a seaman of Hoboken, entered a plea of guilty to second degree murder in the Hudson County Court of Oyer and Terminer here today just before his trial was to begin.

A solemn mass will be celebrated at 10:30 A. M. today at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 139 West Forty-sixth Street, for the Rev. Dr. Frank Stanton Burns Gavin, Professor of Ecclesiastical History at the General Theological Seminary.

Cambridge's Rugby team arrived here yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary for its five-game tour of the East which starts tomorrow against Yale at New Haven. Also on the boat was the Cambridge squash racquets team.

The debutante committee for the Butterfly Ball, which will take place on April 22 at the Ritz-Carlton, met yesterday afternoon at the home of the committee chairman, Miss Helen L. Michalis, of 455 Madison Avenue. Mrs. Henry Leroy Finch, chairman of the ball, presided at the meeting, which was followed by a tea.

MANHATTAN ANDREWS, ALBERT GUILFORD (Nov. 8, 1937). Gross assets, $4,164; net, $3,000. To Helene Andrews Taylor, daughter. Chief assets, real estate, $3,000. Hartman, Sheridan Tekulsky, attorneys, 285 Madison Ave.

In recognition of their activity in operating the Grand Opera House for the past twenty-one years. Morris Taub and associates will be honored at a luncheon meeting of the Twenty-third Street Association at Cavanagh's Restaurant tomorrow. A cottage on Jefferson Ave, corner of Harold St, Mamaroneck, has been leased by Harold Brown through Edward Block, broker.

The big drums spun again in Dublin yesterday in the annual draw for the first of the year's Irish Hospital Sweepstakes, spilling half a million dollars' worth of tickets into the laps of 713 Americans, of whom 343 are from metropolitan New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

Many eminent and noneminent persons, caught in print as saying something which they regret to have said, if their remarks have been criticized, immediately make the reporter responsible. These denials, too often sneered at by an unbelieving generation, may sometimes have a queer element of sincerity. Man is a forgetful animal.

The B. M. O. Corporation, owner and operator of the International Casino, which opened its doors at 1,514 Broadway last September as one of the most elaborate theatrerestaurants in the world, filed a petition yesterday in Federal Court seeking permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

Philatelists who have spent the past home, two weeks mastering the new set-up of stamp designs and denominations as announced by Postmaster General Farley will be obliged to commit a few more to memory following the announcement today of two new stamps and the abandonment of two proposed issues.

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, due today from a cruise to Rio de Janeiro and the West Indies, includes Mrs. Charles B. Knox, Mr. and Mrs. James McCulloh, Mr. and Mrs. L. W. Sutherland, Mrs. John T. Dorrance, Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Reford, Judge and Mrs. John W. Green,

An increase of almost 23 per cent in the export of American apples between July 1 and December 31, 1937, as compared to the corresponding period of 1936 was attributed by the State Department today largely to the beneficial effect of the trade agreements program. Commenting on an export of 5,275,700 bushels during the July-December period of last year,

The Soviet Customs Administration reported with satisfaction today a favorable foreign trade balance of more than $77,000,000 for 1937 coincident with a heavy fall in the German export trade and .unfavorable balances in the foreign trade of Great Britain, Japan, Italy and Poland.

Dates for seven long-distance runs for this year were announced by Thomas J. Kanaly, chairman of the National Amateur Athletic Union's long-distance running committee, yesterday. The first event on the list is the lifteen-kilometer contest at Norwich, Conn., to be staged on May 30.

The Ohio Oil Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday in the annual statement for 1937 a net profit of $11,862,107 after depreciation, depletion, interest, inventory losses of $75,919, Federal income taxes, minority interest and other deductions.

The Cluett gardens were the scene today for the annual benefit bridge tea by the Women's Guild of Bethesda-by-the-Sea. Patronesses taking tables included. Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse, Mrs. J. Terry West, Mrs. John Elliott, Mrs. Charles Lewis Harding, Mrs. A. Kinna Tod, Mrs. G. Horton Glover, Mrs. Norman E. Ditman,

An engineer and a fireman were killed and several persons were injured here today when a commuters' train of the Central Railroad of New Jersey plowed into a loaded gasoline truck at the West Avenue grade crossing of the Carteret-Perth Amboy Road.

Six recommendations for constitutional amendments on housing, to be presented to the coming State Constitutional Convention, were proposed yesterday at a meeting of the Citizens Housing Council of New York at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street.

The regional office of the National Labor Relations Board is studying evidence in a complaint of the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association against the. Socony Vacuum Oil Company, in which the company was accused of having sponsored a union of officers of its ships, it was announced yesterday.

The annual report of Stern Broth??and its wholly owned subsidi??ies for the year ended on Jan. 31, leased yesterday, shows a net in??ome of $257,833 after deductions ?? depreciation, interest, Federal come taxes and other charges. after dividend requirements on 13,??7 shares of no-par $4 cumulative ??articipating Class A stock,

An increase of 5 per cent in the average sale in an individual department may increase the net profit per transaction by from 5.5 g to 8.2 cents, a study issued by the National Retail Dry Goods Association yesterday showed. The report, prepared by the Controllers'

The long-awaited Spring pick-up in grocery volume made its appearance last week with slight gains in many cities, better buying in the farming country and generally more active buying by retailers themselves. the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc., pointed out yesterday in its weekly report on trade activity.

Alba B. Johnson Jr., associated with the export sales department of the Atlantic Refining Company, died in Bryn Mawr Hospital last night after a week's illness. He was 51 years old. His home was in Villanova.

The largest receipts since January broke the fat steer market today, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Steers with weight predominated in the crop, attracted by recent upturns.

Twenty-six more names were suggested to the nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange as those of possible members of the new board of governors in the third and last of its meetings yesterday.

While North American wheat markets showed some resistance to pronounced weakness in Liverpool, where prices were 2 1/8 to 2 7/8 cents lower and below $1 a bushel for the first time since July 15, 1936, there was no snap to the buying.

Pensioned The following member of the force is retired from the police force and is placed on the roll of the Pension Fund: On his own application, to take effect 12 midnight, March 19: PATROLMAN--Joseph J. McKenna, 22d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 24, 1912.

The chief statements made today at President Roosevelt's investigation of the dispute within the Tennessee Valley Authority directorate follow: The President--"I think that probably the most practical thing to do is for me to read again the questions I asked at the close of Friday's meeting:
A shake-up involving about sixty officers of the Department of Sanitation was announced yesterday by William F. Carey, Commissioner of Sanitation.

Mr. and Mrs. Peter W. Miller of New York will give a dinner on Thursday at the last informal midweek dance of the season in the Surf Club. Miss Gwendolyn Humphreys of Greenwich, Conn., is visiting Mr. and Mrs. C. Alan Hudson of New York at their home here.

Among the exhibitions that opened yesterday or will open today are three in which we find presented work by artists affiliated with the modern School of Paris. Only one of these men, however, is really French-Balthus--and even he is of direct Polish descent on his father's side. Paul Klee is Swiss.
Industrial production in the United States fell 30 per cent in January, 1938, compared with January, 1937, according to the League of Nations monthly statistical bulletin.
Three jockeys were injured and another badly shaken as a result of a spectacular spill in the last race at Tropical Park today. Four horses went down. Johnny Jaegle of Buffalo sustained a broken leg,

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco held today that securities offered only to a company's stockholders were not exempt from the registration reuirements of the Securities Act of 1933, the Securities and Exchange At Commission announced here this afternoon.

Sixty candidates for the New York University varsity football team reported to Coach Mal Stevens for the first Spring practice yesterday on University Heights. The Violet mentor began the drill with a half-hour session at the blackboard and then sent his charges to the field.

The Rev. James Everett Frame of the Union Theological Seminary and Mrs. Frame have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Dorothy Loomis Frame, to Charles Billings England, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac William England of Passaic, N. J.

Following is the complete list of those from metropolitan New York, New Jersey and Connecticut who drew horses still slated to start in the race, with the current odds quoted against the horses, which are carried in the order of their favoritism:

Philip Dunning, absent from Broadway for a couple of years, is coming back tonight as the producer of an item about the education of the Hollywood young. Call it "Schoolhouse on the Lot," and the work of Joseph A. Fields and Jerome Chodorov, with Robert H. Harris, Onslow Stevens, Mary Mason, Betty Philson, Eda Heinemann, Averell Harris, Nancy Sheridan, Buford Armitage and many more to play the parts.

Young women in society will act as manikins in a fashion show to be held in conjunction with a special luncheon tomorrow in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. The event has been arranged in behalf of the Nancy Hatch Free Beauty Clinic of the Jacob A. Riis Neighborhood Settlement.

The rates declined on both series of Treasury bills this week with the regular ninety-one-day paper selling at an average price of 0.067 per cent, compared with 0.070 per cent last week and the special series of "new money" bills at an average of 0.059 per cent, compared with 0.068 per cent last week, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight.

Opposition to the proposed Federal chain store tax bill was voiced yesterday by the Thirty-fourth Street Midtown Association in a resolution made public by J. C. Messer, secretary. The resolution declared that the bill would cause the elimination of many chain store units.

For improvement with a six-story apartment house, a plot of approximately 20,000 square feet on the north side of Clinton Place, 81 feet north of North Avenue, New Rochelle, Westchester County, has been purchased by the Heggie Realty Company, Inc.
Parallel action by Washington in the Mexican oil seizures is expected in some quarters if Great Britain protests

Led by Captain Don Bradman, Australia's test cricket team sailed for England today aboard the liner Orontes. The sixteen players were given a great send-off by a large crowd at this West Australian port.

The first Americans to return from Europe and tell of being searched by Nazi soldiers at the Austrian frontier were Mr. and Mrs. Max Spiegel of McKeesport, Pa., passengers on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary yesterday.

Federal Judge John C. Knox, overruling exceptions taken by a group of employee of the Schulte Retail Stores Corporation to a settlement of their demands for higher wages as recommended by Max Meyer, arbitrator, blamed the "extortionate demands of labor" for the business recession.

Marketable securities for which the Chesapeake Ohio Railway or wholly owned subsidiaries paid $99,452,488 had a market or appraised value of $15,199,284 on Dec. 31 last, the C. O.'s annual report showed today.

Johnny Gaudes of Winnipeg defeated Norman (Baby) Yack of Toronto, Canadian bantamweight champion, in a non-title boxing bout tonight. Gaudes took the decision after ten fast rounds. Both fighters were overweight, Gaudes at 119 pounds and Yack 120.

Foreign trade cannot be valued purely in terms of volume, Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton Textile Institute, declared today in opposing reductions in duties on cotton textiles under the proposed British trade pact.

Competition much closer than in past years marked opening play tonight in the women's national A. A. U. basketball tournament, with one of the ranking favorites, the thrice-champion Tulsa Stenos, getting a real scare.

To thousands of professional beautifiers from all parts of the country who thronged yesterday to the Hotel Pennsylvania for the opening of the four-day International Beauty Show the latest modes in make-up styles were presented, including coiffures that are edible as well as ornamental and a "World's Fair 1939" hair-dress that utilizes all the colors of the rainbow.

This evening's performance of "Our Town" has been taken over by the Stuyvesant Group of Hadassah to raise funds for -Hadassah's medical work in Palestine, where four hospitals give natal and prenatal care regardless of race or creed.

The Marquess of Normanby of London and Mulgrave Castle, Yorkshire, England, and his mother, the Dowager Marchioness of Normanby, are at the Savoy-Plaza. Mrs. Le Brun Rhinelander and her son, T. J. Oakley Rhinelander 2d, are at the St. Regis.
Mrs. Camille Clifford Evans's Royal Mail, the 1937 winner, and Arthur Sainsbury's Blue Shirt, today were joint favorites for the Grand National at Aintree on Friday.
Three persons were killed, three others perhaps fatally injured and two less seriously hurt in a head-on automobile collision near here just before last midnight.

Henry A. Scandrett, president and trustee of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad, estimated today that the road would have a net operating deficit of $482,000 for the first six months of 1938, in contrast to a net operating income of $4,361,369 for the first half of 1937.

The report of the Engineers Publie Service Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Jan. 31, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses and charges of $3,814,186, compared with $3,018,819 in the twelve months to Jan. 31, 1937, an increase of $795,367.

The proposal that Jews in America adopt a ten-year plan of giving, in order to safeguard Palestine against partition, was made yesterday by Rabbi Solomon Goldman of Chicago at the tenth annual luncheon of the Brooklyn Chapter of Hadassah, held in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

Strong enforcemement of the anti-trust laws was promised by Thurman W. Arnold, who was sworn in as assistant attorney general today to succeed Robert H. Jackson, now Solicitor General. Dr. Arnold said he proposed to "pursue a policy of enforcement of the anti-trust laws which will be both fair and vigorous."

The Cunard White Star Line in a statement to its agents announced yesterday the withdrawal from service of the liner Berengaria for the remainder of the year and the adjustment of its sailing list which will permit other liners to accommodate her passengers.

Miss Marie Normandeau, 59 years old, who lived with relatives at 167 Longview Avenue, fell or jumped to her death here this afternoon from the roof of a six-story apartment building at 177 Grand Street.
The Newark Tidewater Terminal Company announced yesterday that a lease had been made with the Paraffine Company for 112,000 square feet of space in Warehouse I No. 4, Port Newark, N. J.

Security and commodity markets tended yesterday to nullify some of the price changes of last week caused by the erstwhile war scares. Stocks closed irregular, slightly higher on the average, bonds were up, and commodities were mostly lower.

A State transfer tax amounting to $3,059,826 has been levied in the estate of Colonel Henry H. Rogers of Manhattan and Southampton under a decree signed here today by Surrogate Richard W. Hawkins of Suffolk County.

Business and commercial failures in the United States for the week ended March 17 totaled 229, compared with 269 in the week preceding and 198 in the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The total was the lowest for any week this year.

Jose Alcala Zamora, 25 years old, a son of the former President of Spain, died in Valencia tonight of illness contracted at the war front. He and an older brother, Luis, 26 years old, joined the government cause last June against the wishes of their father, then in exile in Paris.

Miss Louise Bertram and Stewart Reburn, Canada's leading pair skaters, and the Ottawa Twelve arrived here yesterday to take part in the fifth annual carnival of the Skating Club of New York which opens tomorrow evening in Madison Square Garden. The show will also be given Friday, Saturday and Monday evenings.

Death Announced Fireman 1st Grade William R. McManus of H. L. Co. 20; which occurred March 19. Funeral will take place from the W. B. Cooke Funeral Parlor, 347 Willis Ave., Bronx, at 10:30 A. M.. Tuesday, March 22. Interment at St. Raymond's Cemetery.

The Senate Judiciary Committee decided today to report without endorsement the equal rights amendment to the Constitution for which the National Woman's party and allied organizations have been working for more than fifteen years.

A nominal increase was registered in automobile production last week, when a larger gain was anticipated seasonally, and the adjusted index has eased to a new "low" for the year. It now stands at 54.3, compared with 55.5 for the previous week and 93.7 for the week ended March 20, 1937.

The Austrian Catholic Episcopate has been in session for the last two days under the presidency of Cardinal Innitzer to discuss-its attitude toward the new regime, with special reference to the April 10 plebiscite.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Color in French Chinaware," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.; European decorative arts (general tour), noon; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Design in Wall Coverings," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.; "Genghis Khan's Invasion," Mabel Harrison Duncan, 4 P. M.

The Child Study Association of America will be aided by a performance at the Martin Beck Theatre of "Spring Thaw," a new comedy by Clare Kummer, starring Roland Young, which has been taken over by the association for the evening of April 5.
Relatively steady foreign markets, following last week's European political developments, stimulated an early improvement in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday.

Three new directors were elected to the board of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities at a meeting yesterday at the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway. They will take the places vacated by the deaths of Darwin R. James and James H. Post

On the last lap of an inspection tour that has taken him around the world, the Most Rev. Martin Stanislaus Gillet, Master General of the Order of Preachers (Dominican Fathers) and international head of the Holy Name Society, arrived here yesterday from Washington.

Richard Whitney was subjected yesterday to the public questioning against which his counsel protested U last week, as being forestalled by his pleas of guilty to grand larceny. During an hour and forty minutes he repeated three times that he alone was responsible for the illegal pledging of securities belonging to customers of Richard Whitney Co.

State officials and realty experts in New Jersey are making a close study of the detailed report just completed by the New Jersey State Planning Board showing the broad extent of rural tax delinquency in that State.
The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to liberalize death compensation benefits for widows and children of World War veterans.
Mrs. Warren Beard of Boston ?? the pace for a field of more than twoscore shotmakers today and captured medal honors in the eight renewal of the Augusta women golf tournament.

The first formal Summer season openings in the better dress field were launched yesterday by members and affiliates of the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc. Of the 115 houses presenting new lines during the week,

The newly formed Army and Navy Club of New York is negotiating for a lease of the former home of Admiral Dewey at 64 West Fifty-fifth Street, with the intention of occupying the historic building as a clubhouse for members; it was announced yesterday.
Oxford oarsmen began their final fortnight's boat race practice today by equaling their own 17-year-old record for the row from Mile Post to Hammersmith Bridge.

Executive offices of the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company will be moved to Rockefeller Center this Fall, according to an announcement yesterday. The company will occupy the thirty-eighth and thirtyninth floors of the International Building.

An accounting filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday by the executors of the estate of Mrs. Clara Jay Keech, former wife of Colonel Frank B. Keech, founder of the brokerage firm of F. B. Keech Co., disclosed an estate of $3,504,937 and that decreases from the original inventory on unsold assets totaled $764,893.

Leaders in the fields of publishing, entertainment and the fine arts crowded the chapel of the Funeral Church, Broadway and Sixty-sixth Street, yesterday at services for Arthur H. Samuels,executive producer of station WOR and a former editor, who died on Sunday at the age of 49.

The Tarrytown Hospital will be the beneficiary of a dinner and fashion revue, which will open the Hudson House Club's Spring season on March 31. Members of society residing in or near here and Irvington are planning the event. Young women in this group will act as manikins in the fashion revue.

Members of the Drama League will attend a tea to be given this afternoon by Mr. and Mrs. Roy Sarles Durstine at their home, 340 Park Avenue, in honor of the visiting Irish playwright Paul Vincent Carroll.

A bridge party will be held on Saturday afternoon in the Music Room of the Biltmore by the Ladies Auxiliary of the Misericordia Hospital. The proceeds will be used to support the free service which is given every day to destitute mothers and babies in the maternity ward and clinic of the hospital.

The ability of the building industry of the Far West to show definite signs of recovery in the first two months of 1938 is the most encouraging development in current business statistics, according to the February business review of the Bank of America (California), which has just been issued.

Onkel Franz Frisch, still nursing a sore foot, waved a hand toward the Cardinal players cavorting around Waterfront Park and said: "That bird with No. 21 on his back at third base. That's Sammy Baugh."

Poland's hope, as a result of her rapprochement with Lithuania, of forming a "neutral belt" of Eastern European nations "extending from the Baltic to the Black Sea" was described at a press conference here tonight by Count Jerzy Potocki, the Polish Ambassador.
The Red Sox today sent Ted Williams, young outfielder purchased for $25,000 from San Diego, to their Minneapolis farm on option.
