Greater cooperation between the manufacturers of printing equipment and supplies and printers of the metropolitan area was urged yesterday by Nathan Goldmann, president of Isaac Goldman Company and president of the New York Employing Printers Association, Inc., at a luncheon meeting, held in conjunction with the association's annual exhibition of "Modern Trends in Printing and New Developments in Equipment," at the Hotel Astor.

The three-story store and apartment building at 589 Fifteenth Street, West New York, N. J., was sold by the Town of Union Building and Loan Association to Henrietta Schmidt, who will hold the structure for investment. J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker, negotiated the deal.
The sophomores stole the show from the freshmen and the seniors in the national hockey league season just closed and if it weren't for the Thompson boys the trend would be just about a runaway.
The pre United States Government tonight declined a Canadian request for a separate treaty to permit diversion of water controlled by treaty with Canada for power development in Ontario.

A son, their second, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Forrester Jr. of this place on Wednesday at the Valley Hospital, Sewickley, Pa. Mrs. Forrester is the former Miss Katherine E. Collin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Welch Collin Jr. of Sewickley.

On the flats at 63 E 115th St. 25x101. the Lander Holding Corp. Regina Lander president, gave a mortgage to Gertrude Streppone for $8.000, due in five years at 5 per cent, with $400 paid off quarterly.

William (Biff) Glassford, assistant line coach of football at Manhattan College, was operated on for acute appendicitis at St. Elizabeth's Hospital yesterday. The operation was performed by Dr. Francis J. Sweeny, the Jaspers' physician, and Dr. Walter McCann.

A total of 312 journalists, representing daily newspapers in forty-four States, have applied for the Nieman fellowships in journalism at Harvard University. These fellowships, established under a bequest of about $1,000.000 by Mrs. Agnes

The defending Long Island University A. A. gained the quarterfinal round of the Metropolitan A. A. U. basketball championship by defeating Foley's Five of Tarrytown, N. Y., 54 to 43, last night at Union Temple in Brooklyn.
Conservative opinion drifted back today toward its accustomed attitude that Britain should neither intervene nor interfere in Central or Eastern Europe.

The chief obstacle to the passage of the Byrnes Federal Reorganization Bill is not to be found in the terms of that measure so much as in the growing resistance of Congress to the expansion of this particular President's powers.

North China's currency situation, badly tangled as the result of the opening of the new Federal Reserve Bank, is said to be further. complicated by the fact that the Tientsin foreign banks have agreed to accept the new currency only for deposit in special accounts, agreeing to pay out only in the same medium.

GAY and florid Samuel Ward was one of the sights of New York and Washington seventy or eighty years ago. A striking picture of the man he was is to be had from Maud Howe Elliott's "Uncle Sam Ward and His Circle."*

Secretary of State Cordell Hull today expressed the "sense of horror" felt by all the American people at the bombing of the noncombatant population of Barcelona by Insurgent planes. At a State Department press conference, he said official reports had verified the extent of the casualties and expressed the view that "the loss of life among innocent noncombatants is perhaps greater than ever before in history."

Steel operations for the week beginning yesterday are scheduled at 33.7 per cent of ingot capacity, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. This represents an increase of 1.6 points, or 5 per cent, over the rate of 32.1 per cent last week. This week's rate is the highest since Nov. 15.

Chancellor Hitler near the tow of Hersbruck today inspected a ful size model of part of the world largest stadium, which is to be build on the party congress grounds here The model was erected especially for his inspection so that he could decide whether the proportions an architecture pleased him. Another 'model had-previously been prepare at Nuremberg but evidently did no satisfy him.
I am sure that the whole of the United States will have shuddered with horror on reading the news of the most recent bombardments of Barcelona.
Fifteen tiny army pursuit planes based here caught seven "flying fortresses" out of Orlando trying to. bomb Tampa today in mimic warfare.

British Embassy officials tonight asserted that the drafting of an Anglo-Italian friendship accord was under way as negotiations virtually were completed. Informed sources predicted the pact, which would ease tension between the two countries, would be concluded by Saturday.

Herbie Katz, 169, New York, won by a technical knockout over Al Zappala, 173, Jersey City, in the seventh round of a scheduled eightround bout at Laurel Gardens tonight. Referee Hymie Kugel stopped the contest because' of an injury to Zappala's nose. Katz won every round, but Zappala slowed up the bout with his holding tactics.
With 120,000 feet of floor space dedicated to gardens and woodland scenes, the annual Philadelphia Flower Show was opened today at the Commercial Museum.

The six-story apartment house at 1,410 Plimpton Avenue, Bronx, was sold by the State Mortgage Commission to a client of Edgar P. Goodwin, broker. The building is on a plot 100 by 96 feet, on the southeast corner of Boscobel Avenue, and has a reported annual rental of $23,500.

That the buyers of $225,000 worth of Alleghany Corporation securities whose identities a Senate investigating committee headed by Senator Burton K. Wheeler sought unsuccessfully to bare are friends of the syndicate headed 'by Robert R. Young which controls the holding agency was indicated yesterday when a statement in defense of this secrecy was issued through Mr. Young.

John Theofel, 65 years old, former Queens Democratic leader, who was taken to Flushing Hospital on March 13 suffering from stab wounds, was discharged from the hospital late yesterday and taken to his home at 35-06 165th Street, Flushing. Mr. Theofel is chief clerk of the Queens Surrogate's Court.

A list of proposed trade practice rules for the infants' and children's knitted outerwear industry were unanimously approved, with a few slight amendments, by about 100 members of the industry at a conference conducted by the Federal Trade Commission yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker. The approved rules, which were suggested by the infants' and children's outerwear division of the National Knitted Outerwear Association, will be submitted to the commission for consideration.

Frank E. McCormick, who rose from telegraph operator at Pierrepont Manor in Jefferson County to become general superintendent of the New York Central Railroad, died in a Nyack hospital today at the age of 70.

A group of executives of the United States Steel Corporation is making an inspection tour of the main operating plants of the company, it was announced here yesterday. The first stop was Birmingham, Ala., where the executives are today.
Ten more streets in the midtown area were closed to parking yesterday, in accordance with a recent announcement by Police Commissioner Valentine.

This country's newest and biggest ship, the Nieuw Amsterdam, built for the HollandAmerica Line, left Rotterdam early this morning for three days of trials in the English Channel with 400 guests aboard.

The interest of the late Julian S. Stein in Stein Brothers Boyce ceased on Feb. 15. Dome Mines, Ltd., has notified the New York Stock Exchange of a proposed increase from 1,000,000 to 2,000,000 shares of the authorized capital stock. Each present share would be exchanged for two new shares.

A quiet buying movement, stemming from current war scares in Europe and from the fact that some inventories have been depleted to the danger point, has started among industrial purchasing agents in this area, according to an unofficial survey among the buyers yesterday. Because buying policies of individual corporations are highly confidential,

Back from the New Orleans battlefront, where they managed to make off with an even break in their first two games with the Indians, the Giants went through a light breather today in preparation for an even more strenuous campaign. In fact, with seven straight games on the schedule before the next open date, Colonel Bill Terry let the boys merely go through the motions of a workout before calling it a day.

The Insurgent authorities here tonight estimated that at least 3,000 foreigners belonging to the government's International Brigades had been killed and nearly 2,000 had been taken prisoner in eight days of hard fighting on the Aragon front that ended with the capture of Caspe Thursday.
Frank Beggi, 78 years old, died of heart disease yesterday at his home, 216 East Eighty-third Street. For some of his neighbors, his passing marked the end of a humble saga of Fifth Avenue.
Announcement has been made by Mrs. H. N. Van Deusen of this city of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Dorothy Van Deusen, to A. William Christopher Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher.

Further recovery extended over a broad list of bonds yesterday in sharply restricted trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange. Virtually all classifications of issues participated in the upswing as sentiment continued to improve with the easing of tension over the European situation. The trading pace, however,
Ruth and Zina Dickstein, two New York City girls arrested March 7 on charges of "insulting Polish officials" were released today on bail of 1,000 zlotys, which relatives had cabled from America.

Reductions of an average of 17.3 per cent in the prices of Mazda lamps ranging from 75 to 500 watts in size, effective April 1, were announced yesterday by the General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company.

MANHATTAN BURCHELL, KATE E. (March 5). Estate, more than $10,000. To Arthur V. Burchell. son. 357 81st St.. Brooklyn, and Samuel C. Burchell, husband, executor, 37 E. 27th St., one-half residue each. CRITTENTON, MYRA PERKINS (March 4). Estate, more than $10,000.
Albert L. Ward, assistant State manager for the Home Owners Loan Corporation, announced today that district offices at Albany, Syracuse, Rochester and Buffalo would be abolished before May 1.
Woodward Babcock, a broker, died suddenly yesterday morning at his home, 158 East Seventieth Street, of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.

Lieut. Col. Herbert Molson, president of the Molson Brewery Company, died here tonight. Illness forced Colonel Molson, who would have been sixtythree years old March 29, to resign from the presidency of Montreal General Hospital whose affairs he had guided since 1922.

Organization of a national associtation of appliance retailers which will work for price maintenance, elimination of unfair trade practices, descriptive labeling and uniform trade-in allowances on all appliances was completed at a meeting of dealers in the Hotel Commodore yesterday. The new group, headed by Russell A. Atkinson,

Operations last year of the Superheater Company and its affiliated Canadian company resulted in a net profit of $2,085,989 after depreciation, Federal, Dominion and foreign income taxes and minority interests. This is equivalent to $2.30 a share on 904,855

The Securitiess and Exchange Commis??ion authorized the American Light and Traction Company today to sell ?? institutional investors $3,270,000 ?? first-mortgage and refunding ??old bonds, Series B, 5 per cent, ?? on Jan. 1, 1958, of its subsid??ary, the San Antonio Public Serv??ce Company.

The annual revue of the Junior Assembly of Yonkers will be known this year as the Junior Jollities and will be presented the evenings of April 29 and 30 at the Hawthorne Junior High School. The assembly will donate the proceeds to its Fresh Air Camp Fund.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 19: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Wooten, R. H. (Air Corps), General Staff Corps, 17 days' leave, March 28. Rose, W. C., Adjutant General's Department, now on temporary duty in Washington, D: C., relieved from duty in the Philippine Department March 23, and ordered to duty in the office of the Adjutant General's Department, Washington, D. C.
Accused of accepting fees from a number of Brooklyn housewives on the promise of collecting their bad debts, Msr. Viola Dobowski, 29, of 4,011 Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn,
The Market Street Railway Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, filed yesterday an application with the California Railroad Commission for a 7-cent fare in San Francisco,

The battle for the right to play for the Stanley Cup and its attendant honor, the hockey championship of the world, will start on two Acting fronts tonight. At Madison Square Garden New York's representatives in the National Hockey League, the Rangers and the Americans, will square off against each other, while in Montreal the Canadiens of that city will oppose the Chicago Black Hawks.

The Premier's office today issued a number of decrees aimed to "coordinate" various government services to achieve greater efficiency required for coping with present day problems. Besides bringing the different Ministerial offices in closer touch with the Premier, thus centralizing authority,

Sanders Maxwell of Trenton, N. J., has been elected president and orchestra leader of Princeton University Triangle .Club, musical comedy group, it was announced today by William J. Watson of Trenton, retiring president. Mr. Maxwell succeeds Ralph H. Mengel 2d of Reading, Pa., as orchestra leader.

Business itself, because its own house "is not in order," was blamed today by Joseph T. Meek of Chicago, executive secretary of the Illinois Federation of Retail Associations, for most of the "restrictive and costly legislation that we rant and rave about."
Cambridge's rugby team had its first workout in this country at Columbia's South Field yesterday and created a fine impression in the way the players handled themselves.

Hundreds of persons prominent in society who have taken boxes and seats for the opening performance of the International Skating Carnival tonight at Madison Square Garden will attend a special dinner dance in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Export sales of General Motors cars and trucks in February were reported by the corporation yesterday at 30,335 units, the highest February on record and 10 per cent above the figure for the same month last year.

Conflicting price movements characterized slightly more active trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Pronounced firmness in United States Government obligations and most foreign dollar bonds was offset by fresh weakness in pivotal issues in the domestic corporate section.

Twentieth Century-Fox, the last major holdout against color, today succumbed to the tinted urge and announced that "Jesse James," a history of the colorful bandit of the Middle West, will be filmed late this Summer. In the leading role will go Tyrone Power.

Another Japanese - sponsored government will be set up in China tomorrow. This one, in Central China, will have its capital at Nanking and, though affiliated with the Peiping regime, will be autonomous. Premier Konoye told the Tokyo Diet yesterday that Japan would not yield an inch of conquered territory. [Page 1.]
Henry deVere Stacpoole, 74-year-old Irish author, and his late wife's sister, Miss Florence Robson, were married last night at the Register Office in Newport, Isle of Wight.

Trying to steal a submarine is no crime, the judges of the local tribunal ruled today, but possessing and carrying firearms without a license is, so the court sentenced three of the four men involved in last year's attempt to capture forcibly the Spanish submarine C-2 for General Francisco Franco's cause to six months and five days in prison each on the latter counts.
Fifty years from now, in the obituary notice of a distinguished American scholar, will mention be made of his fruitful

Colonel Jacob Ruppert, owner of the New York Yankees, 'announced today that the Stadium in the Bronx will have a Ladies' Day once a week in the future. Thus the Yankees are adopting a custom established by the Giants at the Polo Grounds several years ago.

Spokesmen for the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization disagreed before the Senate Committee on Education and Labor today on the major provision of Senator Wagner's bill to guarantee collective bargaining in Federal contracts or on work done through Federal grants or loans.

Staging. what they considered a new picketing. technique, a group of pickets varying in number during the afternoon and-evening from twenty to several hundred started yesterday afternoon to demonstrate in mass formation for two consecutive days before the offices of the WPA .Federal Project 1 at 95 Madison Avenue.

A funeral service for Dr. John Bates Clark, Professor Emeritus of Political Economy at Columbia University, will be held in St. Paul's Chapel at the university today at 2 P. M. The Rev. Raymond C. Knox, chaplain of Columbia, will officiate.

Frosty ocean breezes today gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a taste of Winter while they were being shut out, 5 to 0, by the San Francisco Seals. The Seal hurlers, with Sam Gibson working six innings, yielded but three singles and a double by Johnny Rizzo, while their mates pounded Bauers, Blanton and Tobin for ten safeties.

The International Beauty Shop Owners' convention completed its second day yesterday, at the Hotel Pennsylvania. An exercise demonstration by a 67-year-old woman and her 19-year-old granddaughter was one of the afternoon's stunts.
A course in labor relations and collective bargaining was proposed for Pennsylvania high schools by the State Labor Relations Board today. In a letter to Dr. Lester K.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are March 22, unless specified: Asheville, Manila, to Amoy, March 21. Blue, Navy Yard, Boston to Navy Yard, Norfolk, via New York. Bushnell, at Canal Zone. Edsail. Manila, to Shanghal, March 21.

Guests of T. O. M. Sopwith, English yachtsman, who arrived with him and Mrs. Sopwith today aboard their steam yacht Philante include Mr. and Mrs. Nigel Bengough and Mrs. Kathleen Strickland, all of London, and Captain Michael Tremayne of Cornwall, England.

Oscar Pasbach of 735 Boulevard East, Weehawken, N. J., died early yesterday morning in Christ Hospital, Jersey City, after a lingering illness due to a paralytic stroke. He was born seventy-one years ago in Hoboken, where he lived until moving to Weehawken about ten years ago.

The eighteenth annual field day of the Bond Club of New York will be held this year at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club on Friday, June 10, it was announced yesterday by A. Glen Acheson, chairman of the Field Day Executive Committee.
The City Council planned tonight a twoweek "birthday party" for Henry Ford, during which he will be honored as a philanthropist and humanitarian."
Dissolution of the Allendale Corporation of Delaware, a holding corporation, was accomplished today at a special stockholders' meeting at company headquarters here.

Austria will henceforth share in the boycott previously declared here against German goods by the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League to Champion Human Rights. The league's president, Samuel Untermyer, telegraphed the stand of the group yesterday as he started home from Palm Springs, Calif.

A transport plane on which the retractable landing gear had become locked was landed safely here shortly after noon today when a Roosevelt Field radio operator guided the ship to the ground by communicating with the-pilot until the jammed apparatus was sufficiently level to permit an emergency landing.

During .his press conference today President Roosevelt discussed the problem of building up an adequate merchant marine, putting stress on the troubles of large ships in the service between the East and West coasts.

A capable pianist from Brazil, Noemi Bittencourt, turned up yesterday afternoon at Town Hall to give her first New York recital. Among other things, she played some Bach, Beethoven and Chopin, in which she employed firm, agile and accurate fingers at the bidding of a lively and spontaneous musical feeling.

A Moscow court will shortly review the story of a "rugged individualist" who persisted in carrying on various private enterprises, from dyeing women's slippers to running a gambling house, until his illegal activities finally resulted in the burning to death of eight persons, most of whom were children.

Down on the West Side where most of the youngsters live in drab, overcrowded apartments and spend their play time dodging heavy trucks in the streets, a group of boys and girls gathered yesterday afternoon for an old-fashioned "house-warming" that offered a glimpse into their dreams about their future homes.

For the first time since the consolidation of the school system forty years ago, the average size of classes in the New York elementary education division has fallen below thirty-five, Rufus A. Vance, assistant superintendent of schools, announced yesterday. Estimated class size for the Spring term has been placed at 34.8, he disclosed.

An $18,000,000 bond issue, designed to refund existing issues and to provide money for improvements to the Rockaway Beach area, was announced yesterday by the New York City Parkways Authority, created at the recent session of the State Legislature.

MANHATTAN ALLEN, ETHEL T. (June 8. 1937). Gross assets, $72,196; net, $66,492. To Elizabeth Campbell, $2,000; eight specific bequests; House of the Holy Comforter, Church Home for Incurables, Salvation Army, Little Missionary's Day Nursery, one-third residue each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $51,305. Mitchell,

The need for continued voluntary contributions to enable the girls' branch of the Public Schools Athletie League to carry on its extracurricular activities among public school girls was stressed yesterday by Dr. Joseph P. Warren, president of the High School Principals Association.

Sears, Roebuck Co. had the largest sales and profits in their history in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, 1938, General Robert E. Wood, president, reported today in his annual statement to stockholders.
Plans to combat the book clubs launched by department stores here were discussed yesterday at a meeting of booksellers and publishers held in the offices of a lawyer here.

Joseph A. C. Avenol, Secretary-General of the League of Nations, replied noncommitally today to Germany's note yesterday declaring that Austria had ceased to be a member of the League when Anschluss was proclaimed March 13.

Tonight it is "Whiteoaks," or Mazo de la Roche's dramatization of her Canadian story, "Whiteoaks of Jalna." Ethel Barrymore and Stephen Haggard-the latter from the company which played it in London-are in the cast and the Hudson is the theatre.
Chairman Vinson of the House Naval Committee' said today that unless the navy's promotion system is revised, 1,600 officers would be forced out 'of the service in- the next seven years.

The second day of Spring brought to this city more balmy weather yesterday and made Winter wraps superfluous as the mercury rose again to 74 degrees, equaling Monday's high mark for the year. Summer temperatures were reported over a wide area from the Atlantic seaboard to the Mississippi and south to the Gulf of Mexico.

Fourteen, possibly fifteen, Italian generals and a "military consul" now command 60,000 organized Italian troops and direct Generalissimo Francisco Franco's campaign on the eastern front, according to information in the hands of the Barcelona War Ministry.
De Forest Grant has returned from the Boca Raton (Fla.) Club to his home at 962 Fifth Avenue. Mrs. Grant will return early next month.

President Roosevelt left Washington tonight for a ten-day vacation at Warm Springs, taking with him the largest bundle of unfinished official business which has accompanied him to his health retreat in several years.

Manhattan Alterations 1st Ave, 84; to 5-story tenement and stores; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank. 51 Chambers St. owner; Voorhees, Gmelin Walker, architects; cost. $8,000. 9th Ave, 494; to 5-story tenement and stores; Louise C. Steets and Helen S. Saner. 492 9th Ave, owners; J. H. Knubel, architect; cost, $3,000.
The Western Air Express Corporation, Burbank, Calif., has filed a registration under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 149,484 common shares of $1 par value for estimated cash proceeds of $298,968.

The annual dinner-meeting of the Handicap Class Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, held in the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street last night, resolved itself into a testimonial remembrance of the late Walter S. Sullivan, for sixteen years president of the association.

Spokesmen for the Women Investors in America and other groups today assailed the Borah-O'Mahoney Federal Corporation Licensing Bill before a Senate Judiciary Subcommittee as adding another nonproductive overhead burden to the "already staggering load" imposed by government on industry.

The Jefferson Memorial Commission, which met much criticism last year on its plan for a $3,000,000 memorial to Thomas Jefferson in Potomac Park, announced agreement today on a new site believed to meet objections to the original one, but it was unable to make public the new building plan as it hoped.

Preparation for payment of a 35 per cent dividend of $38,000,000 to depositors of the Union Trust Company, now in liquidation, and issuance of creditors' notes for the remaining 20 per cent that will be due depositors whose claims are for more than $50 will be started at once, it was announced today.

Slow liquidation, aided perhaps by a small volume of short selling, sent share prices lower yesterday. From a steady opening, stocks turned lower in the late morning and continued lower in easy stages to closing. Final prices were at or near the lows of the day.

Governor Earle of Pennsylvania is a great moral leader. He had the Democratic nomination for Senator in his pocket. Senator Guffey said that nothing should sever him from the Governor so long as he maintained a decent neutrality in the row over the State ticket and didn't mobilize the army of State officeholders against Tom Kennedy, John Lewis and Mr. Guffey. In the cause of virtue the Governor dared greatly.

Two swastikas, facing east and west about 300 feet above the East River between Seventieth and Seventy-first Streets, on the smokestack of New York Hospi-tal's power plant, have received the hospital's official interest and will be removed if some one will contribute $1,000, it was learned last night.

To repeated demands from the Right for a yes or no answer to the question whether French armaments are being sent to Spain, Defense Minister Edouard Daladier refused to give a direct answer during a somewhat stormy debate in the Chamber of Deputies this morning on a bill providing for general organization of the nation in time of war.

The report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $14,077,319 after all expenses and charges.

Bringing about another triple deadlock for first place, Willie Mosconi of Philadelphia triumphed over Jimmy Caras of Wilmington, Del., 125 to 75, in the final game of the first play-off series for the pocket billiard championship of the world last night at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy.

The Austro-German union has had repercussions in Hungary bystrengthening extreme Rightist tendencies, not only among the various groups of Hungarian Nazis, but also to the detriment of the government Parties.

Ralph F. Meeks of 10 Argyle Road, Brooklyn, proprietor of the R. F. Meeks Company of 50 Pine Street, dealer in over-the-counter securities, was enjoined temporarily yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Philip McCook from further transaction of his business on the complaint of Attorney General Bennett.
Craig Baker, engineer employed by the Texas Oil Company in Colombia, returned yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Elena after a narrow escape from maurauding Indians at a pipeline camp.

A life size portrait of Cardinal Hayes, by Sir John Lavery, the Irish-English artist, was presented to Fordham University yesterday afternoon by Clarence H. Mackay, chairman of the board of the Postal Telegraph Companv.

McKesson Robbins, Inc., show consolidated net earnings for 1937 of $3,667,324 after provision for interest, depreciation, all Federal and State taxes, $53,832 surtax on undistributed profits and all other charges including minority interest, according to the annual report released today by F. Donald Coster, president.

The stock market here continued today the strong and active movement which began yesterday, and most sections advanced further. Gilt-edge issues were in good demand but foreign bonds behaved irregularly.

The Bees battered Bradenton's most famous citizens, Paul and Dizzy Dean, all over the lot today while overwhelming the Cardinals, 13-9. Most of the seventeen Boston hits were made off the brothers, and in the third inning alone Paul was belted for nine hits that resulted in that many runs.

Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels opened the Austro-German unification plebiscite campaign here today with an announcement that the vote was being taken simply to convince other nations that Austria wants to come to Germany and that the latter wants Austria.

The three sisters of King Zog of Albania, the Princesses Myzejen, Ruhie and Maxhide, will sail for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary at noon today after their first visit to this country.

Liquidation was under way in the wheat market early today, in sympathy with continued weakness in Liverpool, and the May declined 1 1/3 cents at the extreme to 84 3/4 cents, a new low price for the season and the lowest for this season of the year since 1934. The new-crop months weakened at the start, but held above their previous lows.

Expressing deep concern over the fate of scholars in many parts of Europe, Dr. Alvin S. Johnson, head of the New School for Social Research, indicated yesterday that it might be necessary soon to bring to this country some of the Austrian professors being displaced- by the Nazi government.

The changed situation in Central Europe, and especially the strained relations between Czechoslovakia and Germany, have brought about a crisis among the German political parties that for the last ten years have supported the Prague government.

Major Gen. T. Q. Ashburn, president of the government-owned Inland Waterways Corporation, said today that repeal of the long-andshort-haul clause of the Interstate Commerce Act would destroy inland water shipping.

Cambridge University of England today was defeated by Yale, 3 to 2, in the opening match of its American squash racquets tour. Two of the Yale victors, Captain George Cookman and George Harding, won their contests in straight games, while the third, Bob Houk, was forced to travel five to win from Basil Fisher.

The doom of runaway marriages "over the anvil" of the famous blacksmith at Gretna Green, Scotland, was sounded today when a bill was introduced in the House of Commons to amend the Scottish Marriage Law so as to substitute the prosaic Registry Office for the famous smithy.

Football is a costly proposition to smaller colleges-not a source of revenue-President Ernest H. Wilkins of Oberlin said today as he completed a survey of twenty-two institutions scattered from Maine to California.
Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. announced today nine conditions that World's Fair exhibitors from outside the State must meet to avoid State taxation.

Satisfactory progress was made over the weekend in the conversations that have gone on uninterruptedly between British and Italian experts and it is thought the negotiations may be headed definitely toward an agreement when the Earl of Perth, the British Ambassador, calls on Foreign Minister Galiazzo Ciano.

The rivalry between American Export Lines and its aviation subsidiary, American Export Airlines, and Pan American Airways for future operations over the North Atlantic was aired before the House Merchant Marine Committee today when witnesses from the two companies appeared to offer testimony concerning a section of the proposed amendments to the Merchant Marine Act.

The Chicago Club of New York announced yesterday that Jack Lait, author, had been elected president of the group. Other new officers are Edward Doherty, associate editor of Liberty Magazine, vice president; Thyra Sarnter Winslow,

Mrs. Alice C. Moore, wife of Frank E. Moore, retired canal employee, and mother of Lewis B. Moore, canal office engineer, and Frank E. Moore Jr. of Washington, D. C., died today in Gorgas Hospital at the age of 69.

For the first time yesterday real estate against which foreclosure proceedings were brought by the Federal Home Owners Loan Corporation in the United States District Court in Brooklyn was sold at public auction. The sales, conducted by a deputy United States marshal, took place in the rotunda of the Supreme Court House in Brooklyn.
Brazilians were irritated today by German press comment accusing President Getulio Vargas of having curbed the activities of Germans in Brazil because of internal political difficulties.

President Roosevelt removed Dr. Arthur E. Morgan as chairman and member of the Tennessee Valley Authority, discussed at his press conference methods of curbing and punishing mob violence, but indicated that he would not press for enactment of the Wagner-Van Nuys Anti-Lynching Bill; conferred with William H. Kelly,

The Cambridge varsity crew was seen in the unusual role of pace-maker today from Hammersmith to Mortlake for their reserve "Goldie" crew, who pulled the full course in 20 minutes 9 seconds, training for the Head-of-the-River races Saturday.

The National Labor Relations Board issued a complaint today against Armour Co. Leonard C. Bajork, regional director for the NLRB, said the company was charged with "creating and dominating a labor organization among its employes known as the Employes Mutual Association.

Major John Jacob Astor, principal owner of The Times of London; the Duke and Duchess of Leuchtenberg, Lord and Lady Ashburton, the Earl of Cawdor, Viscount Cowdray, Viscount Elibank, Lord Iliffe, the Marquis and Marchioness of Normanby, and Sir Frederick Pascoe-Rutter will be among the passengers sailing today for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

Merchandise buyers must take a more definite stand on goods commitments in a number of major lines because prices now represent "lows" that go back as far as 1933 in more than a few instances, and indications are that "we are at the bottom zone of production and consumption," according to the economic adviser of a leading store here.

A set of revised fair-trade-practice rules for the knitted outerwear industry, which has been operating since 1930 under rules approved at that time by the Federal Trade Commission, was submitted to the board of the National Knitted Outerwear Association by Its legislative committee at the association's annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

Displaying a new-born desire for harmony, the twenty-six members of the City Council voted unanimously yesterday to retain Councilmen Michael J. Quill, Hugh Quinn and Joseph Clark Baldwin as members after their right to sit had been under investigation for weeks.

A broken thirty-inch water main, discovered when a taxicab broke through the undermined pavement, inundated several blocks near 325 Ashland Place, Brooklyn, shortly after 9 o'clock last night, halting Salvation Army services, flooding cellars and subways, and partly disrupting a motion picture theatre performance.

A claim of $2,214,007.36 was submitted to the Japanese Government today by the United States for property losses and damages resulting from deaths and personal injuries of Americans in the attack by Japanese bombing planes on the American gunboat Panay and her convoy of three Standard Oil tankers on Dec. 12, 1937, on the Yangtze River above Nanking.

Edward H. Hilt, editor, died yesterday at his home after a brief illness. His age was 69. He was a former managing editor of The Youngstown Telegram, The Columbus Citizen, The Ohio State Journal of Columbus and The Lorain News, and editor of The Homestead (Pa.) Messenger.
Arnold Stuart Durrant, honorary vice president of the International General Electric Company, died on Monday night in his home at the Hotel Woodstock after a short illness. He was 67 years old.

GOVERNORS ISLAND So much of Paragraph 5, Special Orders 62, dated March 16, 1938, as continues Capt. Harry P. R. Hansen, F.A.-Res., on active duty with the CCC until Sept. 20, 1938, is amended so as to continue him on active duty until May 26, 1938.

Although officials of the British Amateur Athletic Association suggested that England should refuse to participate in the 1940 Olympic Games because they are to be held in Tokyo, American public sentiment is strongly against a boycott of the Olympics by the United States.

Representatives of rival labor unions, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization, joined today in demanding tariff protection for the aluminum, pottery and glass industries.

The British international hockey team tonight defeated the United States, 6 to 4. A previous meeting between the teams, in the recent Prague world championship tournament won by Canada resulted in a 2-2 tie.

Mrs. Davidina M. Lowden, member of the first graduating class of Hunter College, which opened in 1870, died yesterday at the age of 84 in a private hospital at Belleville, N. J., after a year's illness.

Many exporters shipping merchandise to Mexico clamped down yesterday on additional orders for that market unless the orders were accompanied by cash or payment was covered by an irrevocable letter of credit.

Robert Sherwood's "Idiot's -Delight" met with a mixed reception at the London premiere in the Apollo Theatre tonight. The only completely favorable voice is that of W. A. Darlington of The Daily Telegraph, who predicts a repetition of its Broadway success.

Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis turned in a 38, 37-75 today in leading a field of sixty women golfers in the Midsouth tournament at the end of the first eighteen-hole round of the fiftyfourth-hole medal meet.

Appointments The following probationary patrolmen are appointed patrolmen, effective March 20, their conduct and capacity while on probation having been satisfactory: James A. Corcoran, 19th Precinct; Alex Kuscsik, 110th Precinct.
The Senate Agricultural Committee approved today a bill to exempt from sale because of loans owed Federal agencies such seeds as are needed by farmers for planting.
At long last a list has been issued of some of the well-known Austrians arrested by the Nazis and taken into "protective custody." It does not by any means cover all the well-known persons arrested.

With only relatives and a few close friends present, private fu- pr neral services for Byron R. New- ca ton, Tax Cbmmissioner of Queens and former Collector of the Port of New York, were held at 2 P. M. yesterday at the Newton home, 21815 Fortieth Avenue, Bayside, Queens. Services were conducted by the Rev. Richard Trapnell of All Saints Church, Bayside.

One of the largest realty transactions to be made in Hoboken in recent years took place yesterday when the Hudson Realty Company, an affiliate of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, sold to the General Foods Corporation the property formerly owned by the Ocean Steamship Company.

Charles H. Remington, president of the Underwriters Brokers Corporation, a New York insurance firm, and former vice president, treasurer and director of the Aetna Life Insurance Company, died yesterday in his home here after a three-day illness. He was 62 years old.

The five-story remodeled American basement house at 1 East Ninety-second Street has been sold by Thomas G. Cook to a client of Douglas L. Elliman, Inc. The property is on a plot 21.2 by 100.8 feet and adjoins the Felix Warburg residence on the corner of Fifth Avenue.

In an exciting contest the New York Athletic Club A team, composed of Dr. John R. Huffman, Samuel Stewart and Ralph Marson, successfully defended its national senior saber team championship by defeating the Salle Santelli A team of Jose and Miguel de Capriles and George Worth, 5--4, on the strips of the N. Y. A. C. last night.

The annual edition of. The Film Daily Year Book will be out today. One of the leading guide books of the industry, it will contain the usual statistics for the year 1937. Interesting among the statistics are the facts that 16,251 motion pieture theatres were reported open in this country on Jan. 1 of this year, as against 16,055 on the same date last year;

John Harlan Amen, Special Assistant to the United States Attorney General, announced yesterday that he was investigating Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers of America.

Frocks of American and of Parisian inspiration were teamed yesterday for comparison by hundreds of women attending the annual fashion show and luncheon at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the West Side Thrift Shop.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The American Labor party and its sympathizers oppose the rezoning of the district along the East River from Fourteenth Street to the Brooklyn Bridge into a predominantly residential area.

A policy opposing the principle of exemption of cooperatives from taxation and condemning "any form of taxation whose objective is punitive or destructive, rather than for revenue only" was adopted yesterday by the board of directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, which met here yesterday.
On one of the most inviting days for golf that Washington has seen this Spring Congress today worked with closer attention to business than has been noted since the session began.

The Senate committee investigating railroad financing developed today that the Van Sweringen railroads had contributed heavily to organizations headed by Milton W. Harrison of New York, a railroad consultant, who actively opposed the inquiry.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith was the guest of honor last night at a dinner held to celebrate the opening of the eleventh and the largest restaurant in the Longchamps chain.

The 1937 annual report of Stone Webster, Inc., and subsidiaries, which is being forwarded to shareholders today, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses and charges of $861,640. This compares with a net of $1,102,132 in 1936.

A request for $1,000,000 to renovate the six public baths under his jurisdiction will be submitted tomorrow by Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan Borough President, to the Board of Estimate. Mr. Isaacs will ask the amount be added to the 1938 capital outlay budget.

Now that he has reversed the process for removal of a TVA director as carefully set forth by Congress in the statute, the President indignantly repudiates any statement that he ever opposed a Congressional investigation of the controversy that centers about Dr. Arthur E. Morgan.
The two four-story apartment houses on a plot 76 by 180 irregular, with ten garages in the rear, at 35-15 and 35-17 146th Street, Flushing, Queens, were purchased by David S. Meister. operator.

How TO USE YOUR HEAD, by William J. Reilly. (Harper, $1.98.) A discussion of ways to solve problems. THE EDUCATION OF A DIPLOMAT, by HughWilson. (Longmans, Green, $2.50.) Memoirs of the present Ambassador to Germany.

Lou Brouillard, Worcester boxer who once held the welterweight and middleweight championships of the world, will oppose Gus Lesnevich of Jersey City in the feature bout of ten rounds at the New York Hippodrome tonight.
The first amendment to clarify and implement the Federal Trade Commission Act since it was enacted in 1914 became law today when President Roosevelt signed the so-called Lea bill.

Barbara Schubert, 5-month-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren F. Schubert of 416 Claremont Avenue, Brooklyn, won the "perfect baby" contest yesterday at the Keep-Well Clinic of the Methodist Episcopal Hospital, Sixth Street and Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn. Fifty-one Brooklyn babies were entered.

In contrast to other newspaper advertising classifications last month, rotogravure advertising continued to register gains chiefly from the sudden growth of local roto copy. The latest Kimberly-Clark figures show that the total rise was 9.9 per cent, with local spurting 24.2 per cent and national 1.5 per cent.

The final rehearsal was held yesterday of the elaborate figure skating carnival for the benefit of the Bellevue Hospital Social Relief Service and the Carroll Club to be presented at Madison Square Garden tonight.
President Roosevelt dismissed Dr. Arthur E. Morgan today from his office as chairman and member of the board of the Tennessee Valley Authority, effective tomorrow.

Registration of out-of-town buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday was well above the preceding week and the corresponding week a year ago,- according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week the arrivals numbered 905, as against 795 in the previous week and 623 in the same period last year.

Mrs. Earl B. Thomas of Pelham Manor, N. Y., died yesterday afternoon in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center at the age of 46. She was born in this city, a daughter of the late Frederick Fay and a descendant on both sides of her family of Colonial ancestors.

An issue of $100,000,000 in short-term notes for general State financing was sold to eighty-four banks today by Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller. The notes, dated March 23, will mature on June 28.

Steel ingot production increased last week, running counter to the normal seasonal trend, and the adjusted index has advanced to 42.5. This compares with 40.7 for the preceding week, and 120.4 for the week ended March 20, 1937.

Henry T. Blair gave a luncheon yesterday in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Lord and Lady Sackville, who are sailing soon for England. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Watson, Mr. and Mrs. Andre de Coppet, Mr. and Mrs. Griswold A. Thompson, Mrs. Charles A. Frueauff and Richard Newton Jr.

The four-story apartment and store building at 2,127 Pitkin Avenue, Brooklyn, was purchased by a client of Max Bayer, attorney, from Charles Isola. Sale of the building, which contains five stores and six apartments, was for cash above a $15,000 mortgage.

The Bureau of Mines reported today the Portland Cement industry produced 3,916,000 barrels in February, shipped 4,575,000 barrels from the mills, and had 24,364,000 barrels in stock at the end of the month.

Students of Adelphi Academy will give a performance of Gilbert and Sullivan's operetta "The Pirates of Penzance" Friday night at the headquarters of the school, 282 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn. Sixtyfive members of the school glebe club will take part in the prodviction, which will be given under the direction of Miss Winifred Marshall.
WITH THE COMMUNIST EIGHTH ROUTE ARMY, in North China, March 22.--A Communist State of 7,000,000 Chinese farmers is mobilizing in Hopeh Province a huge guerrilla army to fight the Japanese.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey yesterday appointed John F. O'Connell, 33 years old, chief of his staff of investigators. Mr. O'Connell, who is a graduate of Boston College and Boston University Law School, between June, 1930, and August, 1934, was attached to the Federal Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice. He received his law degree in 1930.
Mrs. Leslie Owners' Thorne Pierce obtained a divorce second today from Dewey L. Pierce, vice Pennsyl, president of the F. O. Pierce Com- station pany, New York City. The charge and her was cruelty.

Refusing to become discouraged in the face of a goal registered by the Rangers in less than two minutes, the New York Americans waged a courageous battle against their city rivals in the first game of their play-off series at Madison Square Garden last night.

Although a license has been granted to the American 'Zeppelin Transport, Inc., agent for the German Zeppelin Company. for the export of helium to Germany, the Interior Department states that no contract for the sale has been made vet.

John Bates Clark, who has just died at the age of 91, was generally acknowledged to be the greatest economic theorist ever produced in America. Drawn into economics after an original interest in philosophy, studying first in America and later at Heidelberg under Karl Knies, he early decided that what the economics of his day chiefly needed was "heroic theoretical treatment" and that its reconstruction must be sought along that line.

With his majority slightly diminished by the desertiorf of some twenty Radical Socialists, Premier Leon Blum this evening obtained, by a vote of 343 to 243, the assent of the Chamber of Deputies to increase the amount that the Treasury can borrow from the Bank of France by 5,000,000,000 francs.

The State Mediation Board began a final effort yesterday to avert the threatened strike of 15,000 fur workers in this city by calling a conference of representatives of the employers and employes for tomorrow at 10 A. M. at the board's offices, 366 Broadway.

Sales of General Motors cars and trucks to dealers overseas in February totaled 30,335, the highest on record for the month and 10.3 per cent more than a year before. The figures include the products of the corporation's American, Canadian, English and German factories sold outside the United States and Canada.

The Dodgers are still the Dodgers as far as the Yankees are concerned, irrespective of climate or locality. Burleigh Grimes led his hapless crew into Waterfront Park this afternoon for their first clash of the grapefruit league season with the world champions, and the expected happened.

Connie Mack, the Grand Old Man of the Tower, descended upon Louisiana's capital today and proceeded to roll a series of nines that utterly flabbergasted our own Colonel Bill Terry. He assigned Harry Kelley to pitch nine full innings, which Harry did with great gusto.
Sydney Rayner, Metropolitan Opera tenor, and. his wife narrowly escaped death and serious injury in an automobile accident near Lynchburg, Va., about noon yesterday.

At least a score of the turf's best campaigners will go to the post tomorrow in the first big handicap of the flat racing season, the Lincolnshire. Twenty-seven of the thirty-three entries, headed by the 17-2 favorite, Charles Jarvis's Galsonia, were listed as probable si starters.

In a further move to speed up the rearmament program, Sir Thomas Inskip, Minister for the Coordination of Defense, has invited union leaders representing more than 500,000 workers in the shipbuilding and iron and steel industries to confer with him Thursday, it was learned tonight.
Approval of the Safe Driver Reward Plan of automobile insurance, which provides for the return of 15 per cent of a year's premium to safe drivers, has been granted by the State of Pennsylvania.
All the favorites, including Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta and Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R. I., turned in victories today as the Augusta women's golf tournament moved into the second round.

The average senior in Columbia College, who is 21 years old, 5 feet 11 inches tall and has a weakness for steak, tennis and Barnard students, thinks the United States is still in the depression, but expects to be earning $5,000 five years after graduation.

Outfielder Augie Galan hit a home run, triple, double and single today to lead the Cubs to their second straight victory over the White Sox. The score was 13 to 1. Tex Carleton and Clay Bryant, sharing the Cub pitching assignment, permitted the American Leaguers only six hits, five of them coming off Bryant in the last five innings. Bill Cox, George Gick and Jess Dobernic, rookie hurlers, each pitched three innings for the Sox.
The Thomas J. Lynch Boosters of Wilmette, Ill., turned in a 2,950 count in the team event in the American Bowling Congress tonight and tied for fifth position.

The action definitely taken by the trustees of the Rockefeller endowments is indicative of a philosophy that must commend itself to all who have the privilege of making gifts to the future. This philosophy is summarized in the belief "that the wisdom of this generation cannot be substituted for the wisdom of the next in the solution of problems hidden from our eyes."
Armando Sicilia, 129, Chicago, and Joey Fontana, 131, Bensonhurst, fought eight fast rounds to a draw in the main event at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night before 4000 spectators.

Business rentals reported yesterday involved a number of contracts for stores and for full-floor units. A new concern, headed by Arthur G. Peterson and John W. Madden, which will engage in the retail cutlery business, took a store adjoining the Forty-second Street entrance to the Chanin Building, 122 East Forty-second Street, through Chanin Management, Inc., agent, and Cushman Wakefield, Inc., brokers.

The Southern States Industrial Council, reporting a 1.5 per cent employment gain in fourteen Southern States during February, compared to January, said this was "evidence that the downward trend of business activity has been checked and that perhaps the bottom has been reached."

The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 21: COLONELS Scott, W. R., Inf., Fort Benning, Ga., to Hawaiian Dept.; to sail from Charleston, S. C., about July 18. Kumpe, G. E., Signal Corps; 1 month extension of leave.

A Democratic preponderance of 832,268 in enrollment in New York State is shown by a tabulation of the returns from each of the sixtytwo counties. The total Democratic enrollment is 2,562,002, the Republican enrollment 1,729,734, the American Labor party enrollment 217,138 and the Socialist enrollment 12,412.

Orson Welles, Oliver LaFarge, Marc Blitzstein, Alfred Kreymborg, Frances Farmer, Will Geer, Arthur Kober and others will be auctioneers Friday night when the League of American Writers sells 175 manuscripts and letters at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel for medical aid for the Spanish Loyalists.

Twenty attempts to limit Presidential authority under the government reorganization bill resulted in defeat today for a Democratic-Republican coalition, indicating quite definitely that the Senate would eventually approve the bill without major amendment. Today's tests included seven roll-call votes, of which two ended in ties.

The Engineers Public Service Company, Inc., New York, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application for approval of its organization and conduct as a mutual service company for the holding company system of Engineers Public Service Company, which has registered under the Public Utility Holding Company Act.
In addition to recommending eight additional taxes to the City Council yesterday, Mayor La Guardia urged strict enforcement of collections of sales taxes and other city levies.

In an effort to alleviate the severest price war in the history of the grocery industry, some manufacturers are considering the use of fair-trade contracts in a few of the markets where competition is keenest, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., yesterday told the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.
Today's major events: Schola Cantorum, "St. John Passion," Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Louis Kaufman, violinist, Town Hall, evening; Albert Montrose, violinist, Town Hall, afternoon.
A claim of "a manifest denial of justice" in the expropriation of oil properties in Mexico was made at the State Department today by the American oil companies affected.

The Best Garage team of Ilion held today the Class A championship of the State women's bowling tournament. The garagers won late last night when no other team overtook their record-breaking total of 2,612, rolled Sunday.

The Japanese cherry trees around the Potomac River basin are bursting their buds and will be in full bloom before the end of the week. The Summer heat of the last few days advanced the - blossoming far beyond the prediction of April 1.

Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson reserved decision yesterday on a petition presented by the Manhattan Railway Corporation to compel the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, which is in receivership, to pay enough back to stave off possible tax foreclosure and sale by the city.

Mr. and Mrs. Everard N. Whetsel of Fortville, Ind., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Elizabeth Whetsel of this city, to George Rodney Wick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Wick of Westfield, N. J.

The National Maritime Union, C. I. O. affiliate of unlicensed seamen, protested yesterday to Secretary of State Hull against the proposed shipment of scrap iron to Japan in the freighter City of Rayville, a government-owned vessel operated by the Roosevelt Steamship Company.
Adjourned games occupied the at- tI tention of the competitors in Group ec A of the United States chess cham- o: pionship preliminaries lastnight at l the Marshall Club.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 19: COMMANDERS Ebert, E. C., Med. Corps, San Diego, Calif., to the Relief, in June. Funk, W. H., Med. Corps, Great Lakes, Ill., to the Houston, in June.

ABERT-Isaac, beloved husband of Minnie (nee Eisenberg), devoted father of Theresa and the late Benjamin L., brother of Annie Cohen, Florence Mendel and the late Benjamin W. Abert. Services Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St., Amsterdam Ave., Thursday, March 24, at 11 A. M.

Oscar C. Apfel, movie director and character actor, died of a heart attack last night at his home here. Mr. Apfel, whose career began as producer and director at the Chicago Opera House, made "The Squaw Man," one of the first motion pictures ever filmed.

Hog prices continued to work lower today because of liberal receipts buying, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Interests maintained a bearish attitude and purchased sparingly even at the decline.

A general unwillingness to allow the case of Richard Whitney Co. to be closed by Whitney's pleas of sole guilt in the larceny of his customers' securities was revealed yesterday by William 0. Douglas, chairman of the Federal Securities and Exchange Commission, by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. and by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey.

The economic problem of adjustment between government and industry is universal and as great as that which existed immediately after the French Revolution, Bjorn G. Pryntz, recently appointed Swedish Minister to Great Britain, declared yesterday at the thirty-second annual meeting and luncheon of the Swedish Chamber of Commerce at the Hotel Roosevelt.
Joe Platak, southpaw champion from Chicago, brushed aside George Di Re, a fellow townsman, today in his campaign for a fourth consecutive national A. A. U. handball title.

Another world's record went out and a new one came in the other day when L. F. Hooper of Essex Fells, N. J., boated a white marlin weighing 161 pounds. This just about assures Hooper of the white marlin prize in the Metropolitan Miami Tournament.

For a consideration of $400 the trustees of the will of Mary Gerdes Moller assigned to Raymond W. Oviatt a mortgage for $8,000 on 66 New Chambers St that was given Jan 24, 1913. An interest of $6,000 in a mortgage for $75,000 on the n e cor of Prince and Thompson Sts was assigned for a consideration...

Former Police captain Daniel F. O'Connor, who commanded the Hamilton Avenue Precinct, Brooklyn, died on Monday in his home at 99 Adelphi Street, Brooklyn, Police Headquarters reported yesterday. He was 66 years old.

Larry White, manager of Fred Apostoli, deposited a check for $2,000 with the New York State Athletic Commission at its meeting yesterday to back up a challenge for a bout with Freddie Steele for the latter's middleweight championship of the world.

Judge L. Barron Hill imposed a sentence of ten to twenty years on Salvatore Graffagaino, 26 years old, of 2,334 Eighty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, when he pleaded guilty in county court here today on a charge of participating in the robbery on March 11 of the Mattituck National Bank and Trust Company.

220th St (16-4654); s s, 230 ft e of Carpenter Ave, 85x114; Charles H. Edel to Marie E. MacDonnell, 211 W 56th St. Swinton Ave (18-5306); a s, 205 ft n of Eastern Blvd, 27x90; Alfred E. Herz, referee, to Railroad Federal Savings and Loan Assn, 441 Lexington Ave.

A revised list of German products from which has been pruned approximately one-third of the goods formerly eligible for purchase from "inland accounts" created in Germany through the sale there of American cotton reached import houses here yesterday.

The city's 456 radio patrol cars, now dependent solely on screaming sirens to obtain right of way to the scenes of crimes, will soon flash a ,vivid warning-to the eye also. Their plain green dress was ordered changed yesterday to green, black and white after Commissioner Valentine had held a Spring motor vehicle show in front of Police Headquarters.

Responding to what he said were 200 telephone calls from commuters asking that something be done to protest the announced curtailment of train service on the Northern Valley branch of the Erie Railroad, Mayor Edward T. Lovatt today called a mass meeting for tomorrow night in Nyack Village Hall to consider the problem.

When the big drums used in Dublin in the annual draw for the Irish Hospitals Sweepstake resumed rolling yesterday they spelled good Fortune for some four hundred more winners in the metropolitan area in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

Such care is being taken to guard against reproduction of the portraits of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, painted during their recent visit to this country by Robert Brackman, that the canvases will not even be reproduced in the catalogue of an exhibition of American art in Paris next Summer, to which they have been lent, it was learned yesterday.

In a reversal of attitude, the Administration in Washington has decided to oppose any change in the American neutrality policy at present. While the House Foreign Affairs Committee postponed neutrality hearings, Secretary Hull announced that the embargo against shipment of arms to Spain would not be lifted. [Page 1.]

Big Babe, Siebert and. Cliff Goupille filled a wide breach in the Montreal Canadiens' defense and Toe Blake did a first-class pinch-hitting job to bring the Habitants a 6-4 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks as the third-place National Hockey League teams began their Stanley Cup play-off series tonight.

Quintets representing Bishop Loughlin and De La Salle gained the semi-final round of the metropolitan Catholic high schools basketball tournament last night at the Columbus Club of the Knights of Columbus in Brooklyn.

Thirty-six recommendations for improvement of service on the Brighton. Sea Beach, Fourth Avenue and Fourteenth Street-Canarsie rapid transit lines of the B. M. T. were made yesterday by the Transit Commission at a hearing in its offices, 270 Madison Avenue, attended by representatives of civic organizations from the areas served by the lines.
Friends of Dr. A. E. Morgan, chairman of the TVA, read from his background today an explanation of his defiance of the President.

The House defeated today by a vote of 186 to 157 a plan to appropriate $2,613,000 to begin construction on the Gilbertsville Dam in Kentucky, one of the largest projects in the Tennessee Valley Authority's program for development of flood control, navigation and power along the Tennessee River.

The number of new cases of measles in this city increased by almost 50 per cent for the week ended last Saturday over the previous week, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

Auditing Committee An Auditing Committee, consisting of Captain Paul T. McGill, Engine 302; Lieutenant John B. Trainor, Engine 233; Captain John J. Dougherty (1), (retired); has been appointed by the Mayor for the purpose of examining into and auditing the accounts of the New York Fire Department Relief Fund, in compliance with Title B.
A surplus of [Pound]11,598,749, with two weeks to go before the end of the financial year, was shown in the Exchequer tonight. At the same time last year there was a deficit of [Pound]15,656,227.

The $1,270,000,000 Cities Service Company, one of the largest holding companies in the United States, announced yesterday that it will request shareholders at the annual meeting in Dover, Del., on April 26, for authority to reduce the aggregate amount of outstanding common shares from 37,455,670 to 3,745,567, or in effect to exchange each ten shares of common stock now held for one new share.
Paul McEachan, 21-year-old Oberlin College sophomore, was among fifteen Lincoln-Washington Brigade members captured near Belchite on March 10, it was learned here today.

The Department of Agriculture's crop-reporting board estimated today that production of burley tobacco in 1937 was 402,673,000 pounds. This yield, the board said, was 84 per cent larger than the 1936 crop of 218,252,000 pounds, but 5 per cent less than the record crop of 424,751,000 pounds in 1931.

Additional engagements of gold abroad for shipment here, aggregating $5,619,000, were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. All of these engagements were made at some previous date, but not reported previously.

Income tax collections for the first twenty-one days of March were $685,689,564, an increase of $33,382,042 over the comparable period of last year, the Treasury reported today. This was a 5.1 per cent gain.

Thomas Davis Day Jr., New York attorney for more than fifty years, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home at 501 Lexington Avenue. He was 73 years old. Mr. Day was born in New Orleans, the son of Thomas Davis Day and Frances Helm Day.
The New York Hospital, Westchester division, at White Plains, formerly Bloomingdale Hospital, admitted 342 patients in 1937, the largest number in its 145 years of caring for mental cases.

No lampoons having been discharged at Hollywood for some time, Joseph A. Fields and Jerome Chodorov have pulled themselves together and written "Schoolhouse on the Lot," which was fought out at the Ritz last evening.
Shirley Temple has won $10,000 in settlement of a libel action based on an article that appeared Oct. 28, 1937, in Night and Day, a London journal, which has since discontinued publication.

Twenty of the twenty-six Brooklyn shopkeepers charged with salestax evasion by the office of William F. X. Geoghan, Kings County Disstrict Attorney, pleaded guilty yesterday afternoon before Justices Thomas J. Brady, Alfred J. Hofmann and William A. Walling in the Brooklyn Special Sessions Court.

The rescinding of a decision of Jan. 26 to close Bard College at Annandale-on-Hudson on June 30 and the election of Acting Dean Harold Mestre as dean at a meeting of the college's board of trustees with Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, of which Bard College is a part. was announced last night.

Cash income to farmers from the sale of farm products in February totaled $456,000,000, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimated today. This compared with cash farm income of $603,000,000 in January and $505,000,000 in February, 1937, the bureau said.
The scheduled airlines of the United States flew 1,839,799 miles per accident, and 10,618,964 passengermiles per passenger fatality in the last half of 1937, according to the Bureau of Air Commerce.

Because 1,200 women were turned away on Monday and even more yesterday, at the series of "customers' conferences" at the Hotel St. Regis arranged under the auspices of Bonwit-Teller, attempts are being made by the store to get larger quarters for a continuance of the series next week.

Just ten months after the arrival at Southampton of a ship bringing 3,800 Basque children to England and to safety from the advancing Spanish Insurgent troops, 400 of the children left Victoria Station today to rejoin their parents in Bilbao.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday in Miami, Fla., of Miss Belle Norton, first woman deputy sheriff of New York County. Miss Norton, who lived at 112 East Ninetieth Street, had been in Miami since October.

In recent years the Federal Government has encroached one after another upon the powers and functions previously belonging to the States. What has been remarkable in this process is less the growing appetite of the Federal Government for more power than the ease with which the States have yielded this power to it.
First-round play in the women's National A. A. U. basketball tournament was completed late tonight with all seeded teams still in the field, and sextets from eleven States among the survivors.

Stocks closed with losses of 1 to 3 points; rails lowest since 1932; industrials lowest this year; turnover, 692,680 shares. United States Government and foreign bonds higher, others irregular; transactions, $6,039,125.

A manifesto of protest against "oppressive legislation and government-inspired propaganda of hatred" in Austria under Nazi rule, signed by ninety-nine Protestant, Catholic and Jewish religious leaders, was made public yesterday through the National Conference of Jews and Christians, 300 Fourth Avenue.

Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and Farwell, Chapman Co. received the award of a new issue of $400,000 of relief bonds of Kenosha County, Wis., on their bid of 100.30 for 3 1/2s. The bonds will be dated April 1, 1938, and will mature serially from April 1, 1939 to 1957, optional for call after 1943.

The wholesale trade in freshwater fish at Fulton Fish Market was tied up for the second day yesterday as a result of a strike of sixty-five members of the United Sea Food Workers Union, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.

Miss Mildred Cartwright, Miss Eileen Herrick and Miss Marguerite Ballantine will appear as manikins in a fashion show to be held tomorrow at the Park Lane for the benefit of the Stony Wold Sanitarium.

Mr. and Mrs. John Eastman Woodruff of 829 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eugenie Gray Woodruff, to Sayre MacLeod Jr. of this city, son of Sayre MacLeod and the late Mrs. MacLeod, who was the former Miss Martha Tibbits Lane of Troy, N. Y.
Henry Trowbridge Seymour, vice president for forty years of Dodge Seymour, Ltd., exporters, died on Monday in his home at 26 East Eighty-first Street after a short illnegs. He was 77 years old.
A new Insurgent offensive was started today from Huesca, supported by huge aviation and artillery forces, it is stated in tonight's government war communique.

The development of a new vaccine that has proved effective against yellow fever in actual applications in South America was announced yesterday by the Rockefeller Foundation in a report by its president, Dr. Raymond B. Fosdick.

The brilliant concert given last night in Carnegie Hall by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting, presented a striking novelty, the "Triple concerto for flute, harp and 'cello with orchestra." by Bernard. Wagenaar.

" These times of stress are peculiarly an occasion when we should fall in with the views of the President of the United States." In these words Arthur Slaght, friend and representative of Premier Hepburn of Ontario in the Canadian Parliament, accepted today President Roosevelt's veto of the import of Canadian power into the United States and of Ontario's proposal to divert water into the Great Lakes and take it out again at Niagara.

Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. B. Widener 2d and Joseph E. Widener entertained tonight with a dinner at Ii Palmetto. A. Atwater Kent and A. Atwater Kent Jr. gave a large dinner at The Towers. Later motion pictures were shown.

A collection of 140 letters by Joseph Conrad, written in the last twelve years of his life, was sold for $480 yesterday at the American Art Association - Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the first of three sessions devoted to the auction of selections from the libiaries of Crosby Gaige,
F. W. Seymour, president of the Birmingham Gas Company, reported yesterday that favorable progress was being made on the plan of reorganization for the company.

More than 300 faculty members and students of Barnard College and Columbia University were among 500 visitors who attended a Pan-American exhibition presented by the Spanish Department at Barnard yesterday afternoon.

Maxie Berger, Canadian star, scored a thrilling eight-round victory over Enrico Venturi of Italy last night in the feature contest at the New York Coliseum before a crowd of 12,000 persons. Each fighter weighed 141 pounds.

Mayor La Guardia spent more than an hour in the Bronx yesterday morning, first inspecting anew health station at Gun Hill Road and White Plains Avenue, and then visiting Macombs Dam Park to consider the possibility -of using part of- it as the site for a new public school.

In a surprising upset, Squadron A's No. 2 team came through with a victory over its No. 1 combination in the final round of the Sherman Memorial Manhattan eliminations at their Armory yesterday. The score was 10 to 9.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson announced today that he would ask for an investigatioh by the Federal Court of Appeals of the award of $3,000,000 to companies underlying- the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company.
Charlie Weems, one of the Scottsboro case prisoners, was slashed twice today by a Kilby Prison guard, once across the face and once across the chest.

The House of Commons today refused to permit the introduction of a Laborite bill relaxing the present immigration restrictions for six months for Austrian refugees from the Hitler government and providing for the extension of British citizenship to the same number of Austrians as would be deprived of Austrian citizenship.

Richard B. Harding, '39, of Brooklyn, 126-pound intercollegiate champion, has been elected captain of the 1938-39 Princeton wrestling team, it was announced last night by Coach James J. Reed. The awarding of two honorary trophies also was announced.

I DON'T know enough about the achievements of our foreign service to say outright whether or not Hugh Wilson's "Education of a Diplomat"* is unprecedented, but surely few other American Ambassadors have written more amiably of their early experience than our present envoy to Berlin.

The committee of three members of the Interstate Commerce Commission that was appointed last week by President Roosevelt to prepare by Thursday of this week a plan for solution of the railroad problem, spent several hours yesterday hearing the wishes of railroad executives and today listened to shippers' representatives.
Bonwit Teller, Inc., had increased earnings and sales in the year ended on Jan. 31 last, according to the annual statement to be released today by Mrs. Hortense M. Odlum, president.
Ludwig Wuellner, veteran actor, concert hall artist and elocutionist, died today at the age of 80. He had toured in the United States before the World War.

Basing his views on findings in laboratory researches, Dr. Oliver Lohr, Michigan pathologist, who came here to attend the American College of Surgeons' convention, said today: "More people are drinking themselves to death today-than ever.
Viscountess Elibank told The Daily Sketch that she had offered a home in England to Baron Franckensteln, for eighteen years Austrian Minister to London.
The Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimated today that farmers received in February $456,000,000 from sale of farm products and an additional $31,000,000 in government benefit payments.

Representatives of more than 100 civic, trade and taxpayers' associations have been invited to attend the organization meeting to be held at 4 P. M. today for the purpose of forming a "real estate union" of New York taxpayers to work for realty tax relief.

The McNaboe-Devany bill barring from public office those who favor the overthrow of the government by force was condemned and supported in communications sent yesterday to Governor Lehman, whole has the measure before him for signature.

A final accounting approved today by Judge Prall in Mercer Orphans Court here disclosed that a personal estate of. $52,689 was left by Mrs. Elsa Einstein, wife of Professor Albert Einstein of Princeton, who died in 1936.
Taxation and housing continue to be the primary topics wherever realty men and those in allied lines of work gather for a serious discussion of their problems.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,433,550 barrels, compared to 3,382,100 in the previous week, an increase of 51,450, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 41,950 barrels more than the calculation of 3,391,600 daily by the Bureau of Mines for March.

Prompted by the liberal terms afforded by the amended National Housing Act providing for insurance of mortgages on large-scale housing projects, the Tri-State Construction Company has purchased a large tract of land for improvement with several six-story apartment houses in the Jackson Heights-Elmhurst section of Queens.

123d St, 434-436 E, 37.6x101; also 424 E 123d St. 37.6x101: L. Hemmerdinger Co, Inc, to Lester and Arthur Hemmerdinger, 424 E 123d St. 93d St, 170 E, 20x100.81/2; Baldwin Maull to himself and wife, Flora D. 170 E 93d St; mtg $17,500.
A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Willard Ingham Emerson of the Barclay, this city, and Greens Farms, Conn., on March 18 at the Lying-In Hospital. Mrs. Emerson is the former Miss Ethel Mole.

After several months of study a subcommittee of the law committee of the New York Stock Exchange is expected to recommend soon a further revision of the constitution which would permit firms holding membership in the Exchange to incorporate.

James W. McCulloch, for fortyfive years an adviser of the late Anson Phelps Stokes and an executive in several Stokes corporations, died on Monday in his home at 446 South Centre Street, Orange, N. J. He was 80 years of age.

Westchester County business men and housewives who make art an avocation were among the 150 exhibitors of paintings, etchings, wood carvings, pottery, sculpture and jewelry at an art show which opened tonight at the Contemporary Club on Ridgeway Avenue here.

Competition was better in the wool auction today, with the domestic and continental trade buying freely. There were fewer withdrawals. Offerings of 9,543 bales included 1,056 of Falkland Islands wool. Sales were 7,761 bales.

James F. Cosgrove, veteran newspaper man, died in Bridgeport Hospital today of pneumonia at the age of 77. Mr. Cosgrove, who had spent more than sixty-two years in newspaper work in the State, was a member of the staff of The Bridgeport Post.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that in the list, made public on Monday, of persons suggested to the nominating committee for offices to be filled at the annual election of the Exchange, the name of W. W. Lyons Jr. of W. W. Lyons Co., Louisville, Ky., was incorrectly included.
