MANHATTAN BAXTER, EDWARD J. (March 14). Estate, not more than $2.500. To James McGarrett, nephew, petitioner, 3,114 85th St., Jackson Heights, residue; one specific bequest. BYINGTON, GEORGE R. (March 13). Estate, less than $10,000. To Emma M. Byington, widow, executrix, 418 Central Park West.

H. V. Noyes, Commissioner of Agriculture, urged State residents today to eat more apples to help "agriculture, industry, business in general and their health" as more than fifty executives of chain stores, growers,

Money in circulation on Feb. 28 amounted to $6,334,029,781, or $48.79 per capital, which was $13,830,167 more than at the end of January and $64,977,264 less than on Feb. 28, 1937, the Treasury announced today. The following table, showing the classifications of currency and comparisons with earlier periods, was made public by the Treasury:

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, today advised Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing Administrator, of the terms under which the National Mortgage Association, owned and operated by the RFC, will purchase mortgages under the new National Housing Act.

Replying to an attack made upon him in a radio debate on Sunday, Frank E. Gannett of Rochester, N. Y., newspaper publisher and chairman of the National Committee to Uphold Constitutional Government, denounced the Senate Lobby Committee last night for "its vicious and unlawful activities."

Cal Rainey regained top form and dealt a severe blow to favorite players in the featured fifth race at Tropical Park today. The Orienta Stable's representative, trained by Pat Knebelkamp, defeated Happy Code, odds-on choice, by half a length.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended March 17 was higher in three out of five trade divisions compared with the correspending week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

The garden-type apartment house containing ninety-five apartments at 115 East Mosholu Parkway, cor ner of Steuben Avenue; the Bronx, has been purchased by Kahan Miller, operators, it was announced yesterday.

The Sunshine City is all agog, as it were, over the approaching debut of that famous screen idol, Two-Gun Gehrig, in what is widely advertised here as a "world premiere" of that dashing, smashing, crashing film play called "Rawhide." It's a Western, home-on-the-range riot with rootin', tootin',
Two young men and a girl from South Bend, Ind., were killed tonight when their airplane crashed and burst into flames in a swamp half a mile from the Benton Harbor Airport.

The Hungarian General Savings Bank, Ltd., of Budapest has called an extraordinary general meeting of shareholders for March 29 to act upon a proposal of its board of directors to merge the bank with the Hungarian General Credit Bank, it was announced here yesterday.

More than 500 proprietors of restaurants in New York and vicinity attended the opening yesterday of a two-day Spring Restaurant Exposition in Jaeger's Ballroom, Eighty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue, under the auspices of the Society of Restaurateurs.

Autocracy of the worst possible kind will result in the administration of customs matters if an amendment increasing the scope of the United States Treasury Department's authority over tariff controversies is included in the pending Customs Administration Bill now before Congress, according to a resolution adopted yesterday at a special meeting of directors of the Association of the Customs Bar.
At the request of Palestine Jewish doctors the government has agreed to grant immigration certificates to Professors Sigmund Freud and Heinrich Neumann from Vienna.
Shipments of pneumatic casings in February were estimated at 2,348,949, against 2,489,589 in January, a decrease of 5.6 per cent, and against 4,370,630 in February, 1937, a drop of 46.3 per cent.

The great strides made by the packaging industry and pleas for "all the facts" on packing labels were voiced in addresses today before the opening sessions of the eighth annual packaging conference. More than 5,000 packaging,

The need for extending help to the unfortunate is increasing rather than decreasing, General Hugh S. Johnson said last night at a dinner at the Hotel Pierre at which the Salvation Army opened its drive for a $600,000 supplementary fund for New York.

Moses Pendleton, president of the American Woolen Company, told stockholders at their annual meeting at Springfield, Mass., yesterday that inventory had been reduced from $22,000,000 as of Dec. 31, to $18,000,000 as of March 1, and on that date was as low as it had been in many years.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Bronze," Ethelwyn Bradish. 11 A. M.; the collection of paintings (general tour), 2 P. M.; "Characteristics of German Gothic Architecture" (Mathews Lecture), Leopold Arnaud, 4 P. M.

Representatives of department stores, chains and manufacturers conferred yesterday on cotton fabric shrinkage problems with the members of the Consumers Advisory Committee on Textiles at the Hotel Biltmore.

Counter-attacking fiercely on the north bank of the Grand Canal, neneteen miles north of Suchnow, Chinese troops have driven the Japanese from Hanchwang and are pushing on toward Tenghsien, along the Tientsin-Pukow Railway,

Agreement was reached today between Senate and Assembly Republicans on a program to provide $19,430,000 this year for unemployment relief. If the necessary bills can be drafted in time they will be introduced tomorrow night and possibly passed by the Senate.
The Edison Institute, in charge of Henry Ford's Greenfield Village, announced plans today for dedication of the home and workshop of Orville and Wilbur Wright, aviation pioneers, on April 16.

Chairman Ramspeck said today that the House Labor subcommittee drafting a new wage-hour bill had virtually agreed on a starting minimum wage of 20 or 25 cents an hour, but was deadlocked on whether to make the annual increases mandatory.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Goddard Leach gave a dinner last night at the American Museum of Natural History to inaugurate the Spring series of "natural science evenings" being conducted in the interests of the ten-year development plan of the institution.

Dr. Roswell Magill, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, appearing as the only witness before the Senate Finance Committee at its final hearing on the 1938 Revenue Bill, asserted today that the Treasury favored retention of the undistributed profits tax "as a means of equalizing the distribution of the total tax burden."

Mayor La Guardia moved yesterday to wipe out the 10 per cent cut in home relief allowances scheduled to become effective on April 1 when he asked the City Council to impose new emergency taxes to raise $9,250,000 a year specifically for relief.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Marjorie FitzGerald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. FitzGerald of Jersey City, to George F. Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Murphy, also of Jersey City.

Emanuel Jarmon and Louis Lefkowitz, both juniors, have been elected co-captains of next season's City College basketball team, it was announced yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, faculty manager of athletics.

Actors Equity's executive committee and a League of New York Theatres committee will meet at 12:30 P. M. today in the Astor to discuss the possibility of a basic agreement or code of fair practices, one feature of which might be regulation of ticket speculation.
The British Cabinet decided today that neither Czechoslovakia nor any other country east of the Rhine could count on British help in case of aggression.

Some members of Congress criticized the removal of Chairman Morgan as dictatorial today, while others approved it as necessary. The opinion was generally expressed that, irrespective of the President's action, Congress would authorize an investigation.

Miss Virginia Anne Hickox, daughter of Mrs. Louis D. H. Weld of this city and the late William Hickox of Boston, has completed plans for her marriage to Eric Adamson, son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Adamson. of Mamaroneck.
President Roosevelt had under consideration tonight appointment of John E. Manning, Newark (N. J.) broker, to succeed William H. Kelly as Internal Revenue Collector for Northern New Jersey.
The Rew, consistent 5-year-old gelding racing for Miss Margie Hodge, beat five other sprinters in the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds today.

The President has posed the issue in the case of TVA and Dr. Morgan. Why has Mr. Roosevelt resorted to somewhat doubtful legal authoritydoubtful in the sense that it is questioned by many members of Congress--in order to remove from office an executive of his own selection?

Work by sculptors of the WPA Federal Art Project Sculpture Division was shown yesterday afternoon at a preview in the Federal Art Gallery, 225 West Fifty-seventh Street. Beginning today, and through April 16, this work way be seen by the public.

Mrs. Alice Hardin Mason, daughter of Mrs. John R. Hardin of Baltimore and the late Mr. Hardin, was married here this morning in All Saints Protestant Episcopal Church to James Howard Magee of this city by the Rev. J. Daniel Stover.
A comprehensive program of recreation, from ping-pong to symphony concerts, was announced yesterday by the Department of Parks to be offered to the public between April and next September.
Dealers of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., will introduce the new Willys Clipper tomorrow, a five-passenger family sedan, priced at $549 f.o.b. Toledo, not including Federal or State taxes.
Hans Adolf von Moltke, Ambassador to Warsaw since 1931, will succeed Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop as Ambassador to London.

The writer has succeeded in finding and talking to a priest who is active in the Barcelona Roman Catholic diocese. He is the Rev. Dr. Jose Maria Torrens of the Congregation of the Oratory, more commonly called the Oratory of St. Felipe Neri.
Jacola, leading money-winning filly last year, tops a list of sixty-one fillies named today for the fifteenth renewal of the Pimlico Oaks to be run May 7 for $7,500 added money.

President Roosevelt proposed today that either the legislative or executive branch of the Federal Government provide some permanent mar chinery to investigate lynching and incidents of mob violence and indicated that he would not insist on passage by Congress of the pending Anti-Lynching Bill.
Mrs. Arthur A. Fowler was a luncheon hostess yesterday at Hampshire House to Lady Ribblesdale, Mrs. Charles Marshall, Charles Baskerville, Terence Philip and A. Algara-Romero-de Terreros.

The Knickerbocker Village Cooperative, Inc., plans to open on April 6 what is expected to prove the largest retail food cooperative in the East, with sales of $4,000 weekly, it was announced yesterday by Milton Goldsmith, president of the cooperative, which has a membership of 400 of the 1,600 families in the Knickerbocker Village development at 16 Monroe Street.
The sixth meeting of the House Labor subcommittee on the proposed wages and hours bill today found the members deadlocked over the basic nature of the legislation.

A gift of $25,000 for a scholarship has been received from the Charles Hayden Foundation of New York City, it was announced tonight at a dinner opening the $1,000,000 endowment campaign of Newark University. The dinner,

Miss Kate Holladay Claghorn, author and sociologist, who was a member of the faculty of the New York School of Social Work from 1912 to 1932, died Tuesday night at her home in Greenwich, Conn. Born in Aurora, Ill., she had lived in New York almost all her life.

Wyatt St (15-3906), n s, 100 ft e of Devoe Ave, 100x92; Wyatt St Realty Co to Harry Silberstein, 1,329 49th St, Brooklyn; 1 year, 6 per cent; $11,000. 170th St (11-2842) s s, 235 ft w of Grand Concourse 201x90; E 170th St Realty Corp to Meyer Schulman, 825 West End Ave extends mtg to be paid as per agreement, at 6 per cent; $122,500.

Secretary Perkins of the Department of Labor reported today a decline of 100,000 non-agricultural workers in February, compared with a falling-off of 1,400,000 workers in the preceding month. Last month's reduction in working forces was much smaller than any of the shrinkages in the three previous months, she said.

Transfer of the New York Curb Exchange membership of Robert H. Cox to John L. Julian of Fenner Beane has been approved by the governors of the Exchange. M. Livingston Delafield of Delafield Delafield has been elected to associate membership on the Curb.

The Schola Cantorum, Hugh Ross conductor, performed Bach's "Passion According to St. John" last night in Carnegie Hall. The work was performed last season by the Schola, which seldom repeats in its programs of successive years.

Frank Beggi, peanut vendor whose stand was situated opposite the Metropolitan Museum of Art for twenty-seven years before being razed for a modern apartment, left an estate of $12,000. His will was filed yesterday in Surrogates' Court.

A new seaplane base in Corsica, linking the main Marseilles base at Berre with the Mediterranean aviation port at Bizerte in Tunisia, is fast nearing completion, according to the Marine Ministry. The new-base,

When it comes to conditioning ball players in the Spring, Burleigh Grimes and Bill McKechnie are agreed on one point-that a lot of running is good for their athletes. So today they either directed such a demonstration or stood helplessly by while the assorted Reds and Dodgers gave it, with the result that Grimes's boys outran the Rhinelanders, 14 to 13, in their first meeting of the year.

March 23 (Canadian Press)-Vernon Spencer, former New York Giants outfielder, was committed for trial after a preliminary hearing today on a charge of murder resulting from the death of Helen Grier in a Northern Ontario hunting lodge Oct. 28.

Harry Rene Lee, former commander in chief of the United Confederate Veterans and the Southern member of the commission arranging for the joint Blue-Gray reunion at Gettysburg, Pa., this year, died today after a long illness. He was 92 years old.
Senator Guffey charged tonight that Governor Earle's pledge against coercion of State employes in Pennsylvania's Democratic primary campaign was "being violated every hour of the day."

The Salvation Army has chosen as its song of faith "Lead, Kindly Light." It does not ask to see the distant scene but merely seeks enough light to take the next step in helpfulness to those who are "down" in the darkness of despair.

The Yankees couldn't do much with the National League ball when they resumed Grapefruit League relations with Casey Stengel's Boston Bees today. They didn't do too much with the young Hub pitchers, either, considering the sparse eight hits they made.

Mayor La Guardia was the guest of honor last night at a benefit performance of the new play, "Schoolhouse on the Lot," at the Ritz Theatre, 225 West Forty-eighth Street. The benefit was arranged by the Committee of Sponsors, headed by Lillian D. Wald, social service leader, and Maurice P. Davidson, leader in the support for Mayor La Guardia in his two campaigns.

Charles Holmes Pettee, dean emeritus and historian of the University of New Hampshire, died in his home here early today from a heart attack. He was 85 years old. Dr. Pettee had been with the institution since it was a department of Dartmouth College at Hanover, joining the faculty as an instructor sixty-two years ago.
The Maharajah of Patiala, one of India's richest princes and a stanch friend of Great Britain, who had served on almost every front during the World War, died today at the age of 46.

Plans for the construction and operation of a minicipally owned power plant approved at referendum in this village more than two years ago were abandoned today by unanimous vote of the same village board that originally proposed the project.

More international action instead of less, revision of the Neutrality Law, and settlement of the World War debts are among the "concrete measures" which the United States is urged to support in a report which, as an expression of American policy, will be presented for consideration and action to the Conference on World Economic Cooperation. which opens here tomorrow for a three-day session.

Mack Goldsmith has purchased from M. D. Lieberman the twofamily house, containing apartments of five and six rooms, at 107 Thirty-third Street, Union City, N. J., through J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker. The new owner will modernize the building.

Williaim O. Rowland 3d of Torresdale, Pa., a senior and crew manager at Kent School, died here last night of injuries suffered in traffic accident Tuesday. on Rowland, who had been in an iron lung, died of a broken neck and fractured skull suffered when the motor cycle on which he was riding was in collision with an automobile near East Fishkill.

Miss Muriel Bache Richards, daughter of Mrs. Frederic Beckman of 791 Park Avenue and of Frederick Lloyd Richards, also of this city, and Francis Warren Pershing, only son of General John J. Pershing, took out a marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Building. The ceremony will take place on April 22 in St. Thomas Church.

The Lincoln Savings Bank has awarded to Charles R. Krieg, Inc., the contract amounting to about $300,000 for alterations to their bank building at 525-45 Broadway, Brooklyn, according to Brown's Letters, Inc. Plans for the work were prepared by Adolph Goldberg.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on March 12 amounted to 305,566,000 barrels, the Bureau of Mines. reported today. Compared with a week before, this total represented a rise of 1,039,000 barrels, comprising increases of 836,000 and 203,000 barrels in stocks of domestic and foreign crude, resDectivelv.

Senate opponents of the Byrnes Reorganization Bill mustered a multitude of arguments today in an effort to win the third test on the measure tomorrow, when a vote will be taken to decide whether the Controller General and his office are to be replaced by an Auditor General with considerably curtailed powers.

Pope Plus has twice urged Generalissimo Franco to abandon aerial bombing of open cities in Spain, the Vatican organ revealed yesterday. One appeal was made in February, the other last Monday. [Page 1.] Here in New York Cardinal Hayes said he was praying for a Franco victory.
10th St, 389: 25x94.9; Isidor Blum to Central Savings Bank; consideration, $18,800 foreclosure. Mercer St. 43: 25x100; Elizabeth Gavriles to Constantine N. Cassis, 4,225 Vernon Blvd, Queens ($1).

A. DeOliveria Aguas of the Austin Nichols Company will head the trade school sponsored by Beverage Retailer Weekly to teach the historical background, service and correct use of alcoholic beverages to members of all divisions of the liquor industry, it was announced yesterday. H. Weller

W. Ledyard Mitchell, chairman of the Chrysler Export Corporation, said he looked for the international business of Chrysler Corporation in 1938 to equal that of 1937, which set new high records, upon arriving on the Rex yesterday.
The Crescent A. C. of Brooklyn defeated the University Club of Stamford, 47 to 41, in the State Armory tonight to win the Eastern Athletic Club Basketball League championship.
Mr. and Mrs. James M. Wadsworth of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betsy Wadsworth, to Harvey W. Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. H. Harris of Raleigh, N. C.

Harcourt A. Morgan took over the chairmanship of the Tennessee Valley Authority today with the phrase "business as usual." The new chairman indicated that there would be no change of policies or shifting of directions in the course of the Authority.

Unionport Rd (15-4256), ne cor of Sagamore St, 125x100; Gibraltar Credit Corp to Sanat Realty Corp, 16 Court St, Brooklyn. Creston Ave, 2,307 (11-3172); 1,301 Inwood Ave Corp to H. H. Realty Co, Inc; mtge, $8,500. Dare P1 (18-5529), s s, 175 ft e of Pennyfield Ave. 66x50; Edward A. Cunningham to Hunt Estate Holding Corp.
The other day John A. Sperry of Munnsville, N. Y., got up early and dropped in at the Onondaga Skeet Club at Syracuse. He brought his gun along and started a round of skeet.

The special committee named by the City Council to investigate the taxicab industry voted yesterday, in executive session, to subpoena, if necessary, the books and records of the principal taxicab fleet operators in an effort to determine whether a further reduction of the number of cabs on the. city's streets is required to stabilize the industry.
Miss Ann Miller, Fred Wharton and George V. Hepler Jr., all of South Bend, died last night in the crash of their four-seat chartered airplane in a swamp two miles north of Benton Harbor.

Small pleasure craft, beginning April 1, will have the same advantages as larger vessels in receiving weather reports and other emergency information by radio. under a new service to be started by the Federal Government.

A revision of the financial projects that would reduce from nearly 9,000,000,000 francs to 5,000,000,000 francs the funds voted to the Blum Cabinet by the Chamber of Deputies yesterday was decided upon in the Senate Finance Committee today.

Miss Sallie Loraine Mellon will be married to Darragh A. Park Jr. on the afternoon of May 4 in St. Thomas Church with her sister-inlaw, Mrs. C. Henry Mellon Jr., the former Miss Katharine H. Moss, as her matron of. honor, and Miss Nancy Hoguet as her maid of honor.

Astronomers at the Griffith Observatory reported today that they had just caught sight of two sun spots which either formed or grew to prominence while their area on the sun was turned away from the earth during the last two weeks and that "no other one pair of spots has been as beautiful."

Huskie Boy, sporting the blue and white silks of W. C. Stroube, ran as his short odds would indicate to capture the Melbourne Purse, a five-and-a-half-furlong dash for 3-year-olds that served as the chief attraction today at Tropical Park.

Net earnings for 1937 of the Air Reduction Company, Inc., and wholly owned subsidiaries amounting to $7,326,835 after depreciation, and all other operating reserves, including Federal taxes, were the largest in the history of the company, according to the annual statement, to be made public today jointly by C. E. Adams, chairman, and Charles S. Munson. president.

The opening yesterday of a new traffic court for Brooklyn at 495 Gates Avenue, near Throop Avenue, makes it possible for drivers who have received summonses for parking violations, and wish to plead guilty, to do so without waiting hours in the congested court at Bedford and Lafayette Avenues.

With a rise of 2 points to 34 per cent of capacity, the steel industry is producing ingots at the highest rate since mid-November, according to Iron Age, which says that probably for the first time since the first half of 1937 orders are running in excess of shipments.

The first mass protest against the recent elections occurred tonight at Matanzas, where 5,000 persons marched to Liberty Park and heard speakers accuse the electoral board of favoritism and demand that courts decide the contests.

Informed sources said today a twoway race was on to supply arms to warring factions in Spain. They pictured Italy and Germany as rushing munitions to the Insurgents, and Russia, and to a lesser extent France, sending arms to the Spanish Government forces.
The second and last of the afterdinner dances of this season will take place Saturday in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. Subscribers include young matrons and debutantes of former years. Mrs.

The Louisville Nashville Railroad announced today that steps to reduce forces and expenses over the entire system were being taken. Decreased revenue and increased operating expenses were cited as causes for the curtailment.

Swarthmore College and the University of Pennsylvania will ultimately receive the bulk of the $200,000 estate left by Dr. Edward Martin, president of the Philadelphia Board of Education, under his will probated today.

Although Ethel Barrymore has definitely retired, it's a good job that she appears on the stage occasionally. Just now she has the good fortune to be appearing in Mazo de la Roche's "Whiteoaks," which was put on at the Hudson last evening.

His speed on the hard turf undiminished by an old knee injury, Edward Esmond's Phakos, bay son of Pharos and Phi-Phi, today overcame a faltering start to win the Lincolnshire Handicap in near-record time.

Senate investigators contended today that "pressure" by financial interests seeking to forestall government ownership of railroads in 1934 induced executives to form the Association of American Railroads.

The Bermuda Kennel Club's fourteenth annual bench show for the Visitors' Cup for the best dog owned by a visitor was held today, the trophy being won by the entry of Miss H. G. Pearce of Haverford, Pa., the dachshund Ollo of Whitehead. Second best visitors' dog was the Pekingese Bonzo, owned by Colonel J. L. Miller of Chester, N. S.
For the fifth successive year, Chancellor Hitler, President Roosevelt and Premier Mussolini were named by students of journalism at New York University as the outstanding news figures of the world.
Two powerful new motor cars, designed especially for the Secret Service, were put into use for the parade in honor of President Roosevelt here today.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Clayton E. Freeman of Glen Ridge of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorcas Freeman, to Dr. Harrison Rawlings Wesson, son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Wesson of Lawrenceville. Va.,

Trading was generally slow in local markets yesterday. Cow beef sold steady; hinds and ribs and lamb carcasses mostly unchanged; other classes weak to lower. Early trading in kosher meats indicated all classes to be weak to lower, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

It is not so very long since President Roosevelt claimed for his Administration entire credit for the recovery of business which was then in progress. "We planned it that way," he said, "and don't let anybody tell you differently."

Disavowing any objection to a Congressional investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority, President Roosevelt notified Congress today in a special message that he had removed Dr. Arthur E. Morgan from the TVA's board.
James Lin, foster son of President Lin Sen of China, who married a Columbus (Ohio) shopgirl, was reported from Hanko` today to have been killed in action in the conflict with Japan.

Charles E. Read, New Jersey Superintendent of Weights and Measures, announced today revocation of the solid-fuel licenses of four dealers on charges of selling bootleg coal. One of those penalized, he said, was Charles E. Monaghan of 3,601 Avenue J. Brooklyn.

Mrs. Amorette E. Fraser, dean of American clubwomen, will celebrate her 102d birthday today in the South. She preferred seclusion this year to the mounting excitement of the occasion at her home, 226 Quincy Street, Brooklyn.
Anheuser Busch, Inc., declared a dividend of 30 cents a share on the new $20-par stock. Recently the stock was split on a basis of five new shares of $20 par for one share of $100 par.

They are relighting the Fulton tonight to receive "All the Living," the play that Hardie Albright has dramatized from "I Knew 3,000 Lunatics," by Victor R. Small. Acting a story of life in a State institution in the South will be Sanford Meisner, Leif Erickson, Elizabeth Young, Sheila Trent, John Alexander, Charles Dingle, Alice John, Thomas Coffin Cooke and many others.

Marjorie Bemis, president of the Vassar seniors, today selected these sophomores to carry the daisy chain for the senior class day exercises in June: Eleanor V. Ainslie of Waban, Mass. Mary L. Benson of Minneapolis.

The strong Stuyvesant High fencing team clinched the team championship in the first division of the P. S. A. L. foils competition at Washington Irving last night by coming through for its seventh victory.

The inner City of Vienna today witnessed its first outrage against Jews, who were forced to act as cleaning squads and remove all traces of the Dollfuss crosses the Fatherland Front painted on the pavement a fortnight ago in preparation for former Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's Prevented plebiscite.

Cooperation between the New York Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission in carrying forward the proposed program for reorganization of the Emchange was indicated strongly tonight after William O. Douglas, chairman of the SEC, had conferred more than two hours with Robert B. Flinn, chairman, and Robert J. Hamershlag and John W. Walters, members of the Exchange's nomi-nating committee.

Mrs. Anne Wolcott Williams, pianist, singer and vocal teacher, who for the last twenty years was accompanist for the Paulist Choristers and chief coach of their solo boys, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at her home, 304 West Seventy-fifth Street. Her age was 45.

The Earl of Perth, the British Ambassador, called on Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano this evening for the fifth time since the official opening of the Anglo-Italian negotiations and definite progress toward a final agreement is understood to have been made in a half-hour conversation.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today an order dismissing the proceedings instituted against Joseph H. Van Dorn, a public accountant in New York, to determine whether his admission to practice as an agent before the commission should be suspended or cancelled.

An unprecedented drive on racetrack tipsters was started here yesterday by United States Attorney Lamar Hardy. Raids organized in advance on a zero-hour basis netted eighty-three persons, including a few women, as the Federal mail fraud statute was invoked against a group conservatively estimated as having defrauded the -public of more than $80,000,000 in the last eighteen years.

An executive decree creates a sixman national cotton board to promote the development of the domestic cotton growing and yarn industries. The board is composed of the Ministers of Finance, Industries, Agriculture and Commerce and one representative each of the industries affected.

P. E. O. Bennett, best-known American in Brazil, died today at the age of 60. A native of California, he had been a newspaper man, promoter and landowner here since he first visited Brazil in 1904 representing a New York newspaper to cover a Pan-American conference.

A committee of holders of stock of the New York Title and Mortgage Company has been organized under the chairmanship of Rodney Hitt a director of the Rossia Insurance Company of America, to oppose the plan for reorganization of the title company that has been recommended to the Supreme Court here by its referee. The plan excludes stockholders from any par-I ticipation in the reorganized company.

Officials of the New York Towboat Exchange left last night for Washington to explain their opposition to legislation in the hands of a House committee which would establish an eight-hour day for men employed on State Barge Canal craft.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation was ordered today by Chancellor Josiah 0. Wolcott to explain on April 8 why an injunction should not be granted restraining a vote on a proposed amendment to a management stock ownership plan of the former New Jersey Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

Orders totaling approximately $3,000,000 have been placed with more than 200 manufacturers during the last six weeks on surplus stocks and for future production by Hearn Department Stores, Inc., for a sale which begins today as part of its "Consumer Campaign for Lower Prices," it was said yesterday by Leonard Ginsberg, president and general manager of Hearn's.

Mrs. Edith Willis Grinnell, daughter of Nathaniel P. Willis, the poet, and sister of Bailey Willis, Professer Emeritus of Geology at Stanford University, died today at her home in Brookline, after a long illness.
The two Brooklyn blocks bounded by Thirty-third and Thirty-fifth Streets, between First and Second Avenues, are undergoing a decided change.

Eight Brooklyn lathing contrators pleaded guilty yesterday in Special Sessions Court, Brooklyn, to charges of falsely certifying their payrolls to reduce insurance premiums as part of an alleged city-wide workmen's compensation insurance fraud said to have cost the State Insurance Fund and private insurance companies about $1,000,000 annually.
The more recent history of yellow fever is largely the history of the Rockefeller Foundation's support of research and preventive tropical medicine.

The Gatineau Power Company, as a result of unsettled market conditions, will not file at this time a registration statement with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission covering contemplated refinancing operations, it was learned today.
The Compania Swift Internacional and subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1937 a net profit of $7,155,890

Arthur Sainsbury's little gelding Blue Shirt, now a clear favorite to win Friday's one hundredth running of the Grand National Steeplechase, threatened today to stir the wildest betting panic in recent British racing history.

With unemployment nearly 250,000 higher than a year ago, the House of Commons turned tonight from the troubled international situation to consider what the government is doing to prevent a depression.

The Midwest Publishing Company of Chicago and Walter H. Gorham, owner of the company, have been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to cease and desist from making false and misleading represepitations concerning the Modern American Encyclopedia, the commission announced today.

Roy Leu and Bob McGuire, representing the Olympic Club of San Francisco, defeated Ben Moore and Louis Byall of Memphis in the opening round of doubles competition in the national A. A. U. handball tournament today. The score was 21-3, 21-9.

By suddenly shifting the brunt of their attack from central to upper Aragon, the Insurgents today freed Huesca from its almost complete encirclement by government troops since the beginning of the civil war.

Bulge in Excess Reserves Local banks have experienced a considerable bulge in their excess reserves in the last week as a result of the Treasury's operations incident to and following the March 15 tax date. As is usual in such periods, the Treasury's out-payments in the New York money market here exceeded its in-payments.

One hundred and fiftytwo swimmers from thirty-four colleges and universities throughout the nation are registered to compete in the fifteenth annual national collegiate championships Friday and Saturday in the Rutgers pool, Jim Reilly, coach of the Rutgers mermen and official host of the meet, announced today.

The Anchor Line, which has leased the new municipal Pier 45, North River, at the foot of Tenth Street, from the Department of Docks, will use the new facilities for the first time today when the liner Transylvania-arrives from a cruise to Havana.

Mr. and Mrs. David T. Layman Jr. were luncheon hosts yesterday in the Gold Room at Sherry's to many of the figure skaters who are participating in the international skating carnival which opened last night at Madison Sauare Garden.

When a lady of fashion strolls down the avenue on Easter Sunday, resplendent in the latest attire, her coiffure will be the exact opposite of that of today; it will be a throwback, in fact, to the Gay Nineties, when the pompadour was all the rage.

Complete elimination of thirdshift operations in cotton mills, an objective toward which leaders in the industry have been working since prior to the NRA, was said yesterday to be virtually assured by July 1.

Harry Bradley, a banker, public utilities executive and president of the Wellsville Board of Education, died here today of pneumonia after a long illness. Mr. Bradley was president of the Empire Gas and Fuel Company, Ltd.;

Nine suits have been started by April Productions, Inc., against Harms, Inc., music publishers, for alleged profits from radio broadcasts of songs and music from eleven Shubert shows. In the nine actions the plaintiff seeks damages totaling $990,000.

Revision of the existing plans for the Board of Education headquarters in the Elks Club Building, Brooklyn, to provide more than twice the space fixed in the original estimate, was adopted yesterday by the board at its regular meeting. The new plans call for an appropriation of $1,366,770 instead of $650,000.

Bowater's 's of Newfoundland, Ltd., subsidiary of Bowater's, Ltd., British newsprint company, has negotiated a contract with the Reid Newfoundland Company for the purchase of a large tract of forest on the east coast of Newfoundland.

BUNTING, MINNIE H. (Jan. 7, 1938). Gross assets, $9,011; net, $7,981. To sisters, Annie E. and Ida I. Bunting, onehalf of residuary estate each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $239: mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $8,598; miscellaneous property, $174. Patterson Brinckerhoff, attorneys, 11 Broadway, Manhattan.

Holding anti-Catholic prejudice responsible for much of the American support of the Spanish Loyalists, Cardinal' Hayes, in an interview yesterday, said he was "praying that General Franco will win" and thus bring a speedy end to the civil war in Spain.

New Yorkers went coatless again yesterday as the Spring "heat wave" continued throughout the eastern half of the country. In Paterson, N. J., a man collapsed from the heat, the first victim of the year. In Oregon the most severe snow storm this year was reported by The Associated Press.

Relocation of immigrants in the more sparsely settled agricultural districts, with special attention to preventing large concentrations of one nationality at any point, is among measures under consideration by the administration of President Getulio Vargas.

Forrester Scott, Philadelphia lawyer, and Stanley Boynton, aviator, were held today in [Pound]5,000 bail for trial in the Supreme Court on. a charge of attempting to abduct Mr. Scott's two children from his divorced wife last Wednesday.

By GABRIEL WISHBOW 22d St. 132-4 W. 12-story left and store, 39.7x98.9: Harlem Savings Bank against 132 W 22d Street Realty Co; due, $139, 892; to plaintiff for $2,000. By JAMES R. MURPHY 54th St, 127-9 E, two 5 and 6 story dwellings and 2-story rear studio, 33.8x100.5; Guaranty Trust Co of N Y against Henry S. Redmond; due, $141,677; to plaintiff for $135.000.

Although defeated for the first time in Group B at the Manhattan Chess Club last night, W. B. Suesman of Cranston, R. I., only representative of New England in the United States championship preliminaries, retained his hold on first place in that section with a score of 5-1.

Municipal POLICEWOMAN This list will also be certified as appropriate for other positions requiring women of a high degree of physical ability and mental alertness. Persons receiving permanent positions as a result of such certification will be removed from the eligible list for Policewoman.

Approval was given today by the State Municipal Finance Commission to a $10,735,199 bond issue to refinance Asbury Park's indebtedness. The bonds are to bear 4 per cent interest and mature on Dec. 1, 1966.

Government tariff experts concluded today public hearings on a proposed reciprocal trade agreement with the United Kingdom after listening to lace manufacturers blame the French treaty for the plight of their industry.
The Hershey Bears tonight clinched the Eastern Amateur Hockey League championship by defeating the Atlantic City Sea Gulls, 2 to 1, in overtime.
The 1938 Legislature set a record in its closing hours last week by sending 926 bills to Governor Lehman for signature or veto, official count showed today.

Three youthful stars and the medalist today moved into the semifinals of the Augusta women's golf tournament with easy triumphs. Victorious by identical scores of 5 and 4 were Miss Helen Dettweiler of Washington, D. C.; Miss Dorothy Kirby,

Germany has officially threatened to launch a violent press campaign against Czechoslovakia unless the Czechoslovak Government curbs the "antiGerman" dispatches of foreign correspondents in Prague, it was learned on the most reliable authority here today.
Benjamin Gordon, 24 years old, salesman of 30 John Street, New Brunswick, was shot and wounded critically this afternoon by a hitchhiking hold-up man, apparently because Gordon had no money with him.

President Roosevelt's message to Congress on his removal of Arthur E. Morgan as chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, and Solicitor General Jackson's opinion as Acting Attorney General in support of the action, were as follows:
The stock brokerage firm of F. W. Garber Co. was suspended today from the Philadelphia Stock Exchange, following a voluntary declaration of insolvency.
China's "foreign legion of the air" has been disbanded and its members. discharged. The aviation commission said that "in the interest of homogeneity" the fourteenth bombardment squadron,

Aiming at use of new furniture in every new house constructed under the Federal and State housing programs, the Furniture Manufacturers Representatives Association will meet tonight in the Hotel Picadilly to draft a program for setting up credits on furniture.

The State Labor Relations Board yesterday accused the B. M. T. of maintaining a company union among its ticket agents. The charge, made upon a complaint filed some time ago by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, will be the subject of a public hearing next Thursday.

A contra-seasonal increase in electric power production last week has advanced the adjusted index to 93.3 from 92.6. It stood at 108.5 for the week ended March 20, 1937. The week's output, as reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute, was 2,017,653,000 kilowatthours, compared with 2,014,729,000 for the previous week and 2,211,052,000 for the corresponding week a year ago.

A young woman who said she lived in Brooklyn, but could not remember her name walked into police headquarters here at 3:30 A. M. today and was taken to Grasslands Hospital, Eastview, as a possible victim of amnesia.

A sidelight on the anxiety of the Mexican Government to sell abroad oil from the expropriated foreign-owned fields was provided yesterday by an exchange of messages between a New Orleans broker and several independent British oil concerns.

Hawaii's defense system stirred into sudden activity today for its most crucial test thus far against an attacking fleet. Warships appeared on the horizon, giving the civilian population a "zero hour" thrill until naval authorities explained they were arriving to join the defense.

Theft of an "antique iron bench" from a cemetery plot and its sale to an up-State antique dealer is charged against Henry J. Fitzgerald, 38 years old, of 524 West 134th Street, in an indictment for grand larceny handed up by the Queens grand jury yesterday.

The following is the introduction to an appraisal of community improvements brought about by the Federal work relief program in New York City prepared by Mayor La Guardia as his contribution to the Unitec States Community Improvement Appraisal,

Speaking before the Polish Senate, with the Latvian and Estonian envoys in the diplomatic box and the Cabinet on the government benches, Colonel Josef Beck, the Polish Foreign Minister, today summed up the events leading to the re-establishment of diplomatic relations between Poland and Lithuania.

Miss Cecile Beatrice Paine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold William Paine of this place and West Dennis, Mass., has chosen April 12 for her wedding to John Donovan Simmons, son of Mr. and Mrs. John George Simmons of Canton, Mass., and Miami Beach.

Properties on the East Side that had been held in one ownership for many years passed to new control in deals reported yesterday. In its first transfer in forty years the five-story store and dwelling at 134 East Sixtieth Street was sold by Gladys Pell Rogers to the the Eighty-fourth Street and Second Avenue Corporation.

Warners are to continue their relentless pursuit of the military theme in "Wings Over the Navy," which will deal with the aerial division of the navy and the flying school at Pensacola, Fla. Michael Fessier, who has written the script, has returned from Washington,
Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, who was removed yesterday by President Roosevelt as chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, left little doubt here today that he still considered himself a public official.

The schedules for Columbia varsity rowing, track and tennis were announced yesterday by Reynolds Benson, athletics manager. The track team, which recently won the indoor I. C. A. A. A. A. championship for the second consecutive time, will seek the outdoor crown at Randalls Island June 3 and 4 in its final meet.
A prose lyric of flowering trees and shrubs that soon will burst into colorful bloom along the parkways in New York City was the Park Department's compliment to the season 'yesterday.

Walter Scott, first Premier of Saskatchewan, died in a hospital here early today of a heart ailment. He was 70 years old. One of the outstanding Liberal leaders in the West at the turn of the century, Mr. Scott fought in the House of Commons for the Autonomy Bill, as the result of which Saskatchewan and Alberta came into being in 1905.

Durr Freedley, a Newport artist, and Thomas H. Austin, a secondclass seaman on the Coast Guard cutter Harriet Lane, were fatally 'injured early this morning when their automobile swerved from the highway in East Lexington, and crashed-into a tree.

The second defiance of the Senate Lobby Committee within a week was voiced today by officials of the National Committee to Uphold Constitutional Government, of which Frank E. Gannett, newspaper publisher, is chairman.

Victor Ghezzi, the Deal (N. J.) sharpshooter, who has been an on and off golfer this year, struck his stride today and blasted Pinehurst's stubborn No. 2 course with a sizzling, sub-par 68 to take the lead in the first round of the thirty-sixth North and South open golf championship.

Several houses on the upper West Side figured in transactions announced yesterday. Two five-story renovated buildings, accommodating twenty families, at 6 and 8 West 104th Street, near Central Park West, were resold after a brief ownership by John P. Finneran.
At a meeting of major suppliers here today a committee was appointed to work with the management of the Graham-Paige Motors Corporation in planning refinancing for the company.

The stock market seemed to suffer from a case of nerves yesterday. Certainly the news of the day hardly justified the heavy selling in the forenoon when leading issues at their worst were down 1 to 6 points. A late rally cut the day's net losses

The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill sponsored by the Labor Committee, permitting the enrollment in each Civilian Conservation Corps company of five men who are older than the present age limit of 23. It also enables the government to discharge an enrollee within thirty days of the end of his enlistment period.
The plea "Woodman, spare that tree" was not needed today to save a twelve-year-old pear tree standing in the path of a $5,000,000 construction program. at. Pennsylvania State College.

The government soon will spend nearly $2,500,000 to reconstruct the Grand Central postoffice building on Lexington Avenue, north of the Grand Central Terminal, Postmaster Albert Goldman said yesterday.

Frank Stranahan, a Toledo, Ohio, golfer playing in the Dixie amateur tournament, had 16 clubs in his bag today instead of the limit of 14 imposed by new U. S. G. A. rules. The result was the first disqualification, in this section at least, for exceeding the club limit.
Wheat prices on the Board of Trade fluctuated erratically today within a range of about 1 cent a bushel and closed 1/8 cent higher to 1/4 cent lower, the former on the May.

The House Appropriations Committee reported favorably today the army's 1989 supply bill, carrying $447,808,555, which included the supplemental budget requests of President Rooseevlt designed to place the land forces on a more efficient basis.

Nicholas Dietz, a lawyer in Brooklyn for forty-five years, died on Tuesday at his home, 1,108 Bushwick Avenue, at the age of 68. He was a member of the Knights of Columbus, the Arion Singing Society, the Brooklyn Bar Association and the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.
Red-haired Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis, cracked out a pretty 76 today for a score of 151 and an eight-stroke lead at the 36hole mark of the 54-hole women's mid-South golf tournament.

BEAM, LULU J. (Feb. 16). Estate, $1,100. To George J. Chase, nephew, executor, 141 E. 44th St. BEGGI, FRANK (March 21). Estate, $12,000. To Leo H. Beggi, 216 E. 83d St.; Louis J. Beggi. 216 E. 83d St.; Ida Beggi, same address; Emma Galvin, 307 E. 85th St.; Catherine Parr, 35-16 98th St., Corona, L. I.; William Beggi.
No Parking Streets The following is a list of additional "No Parking" streets which were established by the Police Department, for a temporary period, effective 8 A. M., March 21:

Miss Doris Bothwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Ewing Bothwell of Yonkers, N. Y., has completed plans for her marriage to Henry Evans Heydt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Heydt of Bronxville and Westport, Conn., which will take place the afternoon of April 22 in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Bronxville.
Use of tin throughout the world in January amounted to 13,800 tons, compared with 16,800 in January, last year, according to the International Tin Research and Development Council.
Bob Allman, blind 118-pound wrestler, tonight was elected captain of the University of Pennsylvania team for next season. Allman holds the Middle Atlantic A. A. U. title.

Presentation of the Irwin D. Wolf awards for ingenuity in package design featured the sessions today of the Eighth Annual Packaging Conference and Exposition, held here under the sponsorship of the American Management Association.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am concerned not with the direct thought of the editorial "A Dangerous Bill," with which I am inclined to agree. but rather with its implications. It is my belief that the teachers in our schools are employes of the State which, up to the present at least, is a constitutional democracy.

The Jewish colonization of Palestine is "no longer an idealistic scheme but a desperate emergency," Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland declared yesterday in his first New York address as national chairman of the United Palestine Appeal.
Be it ever so humble, there's no place like a seat on the City Council. A man's home may oscillate between Suffolk County outside of New York City and Queens County inside of New York City;

The statement that there is nothing wrong with America, that the war crisis in Europe is psychological and that the situation there will soon change for the better was made by H. Gordon Selfridge Jr., executive of the Selfridge Department Stores in England, guest in Boston today of Louis E. Kirstein of Filene's.

As a prelude Britain had nc to his declaration on foreign policy and rearmament tomorrow, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain met leaders of Great Britain's trade unions at Downing Street today to seek their help in speeding up the nation's zigantic defense program.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York in a report of its condition as of March 7, issued in response to the call of the Federal Reserve authorities, showed total deposits of $1,303,953,080 and total assets of $1,626,539,303. The report,

The continued popularity of the "mannish" two-piece suit, mentioned by a number of manufacturers as a major factor in enabling them to approach or meet 1937 sales figures, was confirmed yesterday by suit buyers in local retail stores.

More than 200,000 triumphant Mexican workers marched before President Lazaro Cardenas today in a vast demonstration against "imperialism" and in approval of his expropriation of foreign-owned oil companies.

The secret political police of the Nazis seem finally to have got on the trail of the "German Liberty Party," whose mysterious declarations against the regime have been sent through the post from various points within and without the Reich.

Housewives soon may buy foods in silver-lined cans which kill germs, the National Bureau of Standards said today. The bureau's research, financed by the silver producers of America, has developed such a can, which can be produced "relatively inexpensively."

After a firm start, the stock market here turned easier this afternoon and most sections yielded ground. Giltedged issues were in small demand, while among the foreign loans, German, Austrian and Czechoslovak issues lost early gains.

Edward Hook Van Ingen 2d of 4 East Seventy-third Street died yesterday morning in Roosevelt Hospital after a brief illness at the age of 39. He was graduated from Yale in 1921 and played on the varsity hockey team.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 21: COMMANDERS Keliher, T. J. Jr., Naval War College, in May, to staff, Naval War College, Newport. R. L Larson, W. J., to duty Secretary Academic Board and Aide, Superintendent Naval Academy.

Edward Davison of the University of Colorado is in New York this week at .the Hotel Bradford, 210 West Seventieth Street, completing arrangements for the ninth Writers Conference to be held at the University of Colorado in Boulder from July 25 to Aug. 12.

A campaign to raise $263,990 to "democratize birth control information so that every married couple in need of it can obtain accurate medical advice," will be started on April 5 in the metropolitan New York area by the Citizens Committee for Planned Parenthood,
The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for twelve months ended on Feb. 28, issued yesterday, shows a net income after all expenses and charges, of $23,842,993.

The prepared text of President Roosevelt's speech here today was as follows: "This celebration, the outward and visible commemoration of the rebirth of Gainesville, is more than a symbol of the fine courage which has made it possible for this city to come back after it was in great part destroyed by the tornado of 1936.
The women's fencing team of Hofstra College. defeated the Brooklyn College foilswomen, 5 to 4, on the losers' strips yesterday. The summaries:
Edward J. Reilly, attorney for the defense in the Hauptmann case, obtained his release from the Kings Park State Hospital this afternoon after a jury in Suffolk County Court had adjudged him sane.

In its first action affecting insurance companies, the State Labor Relations Board ordered an election yesterday among more than 2,500 industrial insurance agents employed by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in New York City, Westchester and Long Island.

An agreement for the sale of a large part of the surplus oil products of Mexico to Japan is considered a distinct probability by oil executives, who pointed out here yesterday that Japan for years had been much concerned over her oil supply.

Cambridge's Rugby team opened its invasion of the United States today and had an easy time winning from Yale, 40-0, in the Yale Bowl. The invaders lived up to all advance notices and gave a performance equally as impressive as that turned in by the Light Blue fifteen which visited America in 1934.

The twenty-second annual exhibition of the Society of Independent Artists will be held at Grand Central Palace from April 27 until May 18, and is open to all artists. As in other years, there is no jury and no prizes will be awarded.
A client of Netter Netter, at torneys, has purchased the twostory taxpayer at 103-9 Wolf's Lanes Pelham, Westchester, from the New Style Realty Corporation.

Locations in midtown Manhattan predominated in the lists of business leases submitted yesterday. New quarters were taken by many firms in the apparel trades and allied businesses. Otto Goldstein Fur Dyeing Corporation leased a full floor in 13242 West Twenty-seventh Street;

Speaker Bankhead forwarded to the House Rivers and Harbors Committee today a report from the Board of Army Engineers disapproving the proposed Lake Champlain seaway to connect the St. Lawrence and Hudson Rivers.
The bond market on the New York Stock Exchange took its cue from the stock list yesterday and under the weight of heavy liquidation prices in many instances were pushed to new lows.

Richard Whitney admitted yesterday on the witness stand that he and the firm of Richard Whitney Co. were attempting to carry $5,524,000 in loans when they were suspended by the New York Stock Exchange on March 8.

The Tennessee Valley Authority pushed aside the intricate problems of one of the country's greatest engineering projects long enough today to unravel the mystery of a jackass. The jackass is now deceased but its memory has lingered stubbornly on, causing swift and unexpected oral "kicks" from members of Congress who have charged the TVA with extravagance.

The amendments to the Federal Trade Commission Act, which will become effective on May 21, will require increased caution in thousands of daily business operations, Gilbert H. Montague, chairman of the committee on Federal Trade Commission and anti-trust laws of the Merchants Association of New York, said yesterday.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Leni Riccius Ingster, daughter of Mrs. Erich M. Riccius of Berlin, to Robert A. Scott, son of Mrs. Leonie M. Scott of this city and the late Robert A. Scott, which took place here last Saturday in All Souls Unitarian Church.
The Children's Theatre of Columbia University announced yesterday that the schedule for its Spring marionette festival on Saturday afternoons would be on March 26, "Cinderella"; April 2,

A most surprising band of Athletics celebrated Connie Mack Day in a manner that must have warmed the cockles of the 75-yearold pilot's heart today, but they came perilously close to breaking Colonel Bill Terry's.

Major Gen. co Hugh Wharton Myddleton Watson who returned recently on sick leave from Iraq where he was head of the British Military Mission and Inspector General of the Iraq Army was found shot dead today on a roadside near Leamington.
Only in parts does "Flood Tide," the adaptation by William Boehnel of New York of A. P. Herbert's novel, produced at the Phoenix tonight, come to life.

Graduating exercises of the Yeshiva, which includes the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary and Yeshiva College, will be held today at 4 P. M. in the auditorium at Amsterdam Avenue and 187th Street. Today is the 125th anniversary of the birth of Rabbi Elchanan, whose name the Yeshiva bears. The anniversary is being observed in many parts of the world.

Approval of a new plan for extending rural electric lines of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation and the Pennsylvania Power Company was announced today by the Public Service Commission, effective next Friday.

Five of the country's first six ranking singles players are included on the team named yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association to defend the Wightman Cup against England at Wimbledon on June 10 and 11.

The prospect of the League of New York Theatres and the Actors Equity Association agreeing to a code of fair practices under which ticket speculation would be checked was "improved" at yesterday's meeting of committees from the two organizations, according to a statement by Burgess Meredith, acting Equity president, and Brock Pembrton of the league.

Incorporation of Austria in the German Reich has generally evoked the comment that the gain of Germany would be in man power and perhaps political prestige, not In the economic field. It remains to be seen how far this judgment is correct.

Prices showing reductions of from 37 1/2 to 55 cents from a year ago were named on Fall suitings yesterday by Samuel Hird Sons, Inc., and it was expected that other wool goods producers would make similar reductions today or tomorrow. The reductions were about in line with market expectations.
By LINCOLN A. WERDEN The latest edition of the Skating Club of New York's annual carnivals was presented last night at Madison Square Garden before a gathering of 14,000.

John A. Hidden, who seeks ratification by the Interstate Commerce Commission of his court appointment as a trustee of the Erie Railroad Company, filed today with the commission a supplemental petition for ratification containing additional information.

The Broadway Press Agents Chapter of the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union met in emergency session last night at the Hotel Algonquin and rejected the demand of the League of New York Theatres that producers who have served as their own press agents within a specified period in the past be allowed to continue to do so. The T. M.

AMPHITRYON '38, by Jean Giraudoux and S. N. Behrmann. (Random House, $2.) A comedy in a prologue and three acts. DIDEROT, SELECTED WRITINGS. (International Publishers, $2.50.) Translated by Jean Stewart and Jonathan Kemp.

On his own application, to take effect 12 midnight March 23: PATROLMAN-James P. Connor, 46th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed April 1, 1907. On police surgeon's certificate, to take effect 12 midnight March 22: PATROLMAN-John J. Melbourne, 18th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Oct. 18, 1917.

The Senate asked today for a new conference with the House on a $2,613,000 appropriation for construction of a Tennessee Valley Authority dam at Gilbertsville,. Ky. The House refused yesterday to approve the item in the Independent Offices Supply Bill.
The Interstate Commerce Commission heard today arguments on a plan for reorganization of the Chicago Great Western Railroad. Homer H. Kirby, an examiner for the I. C. C., who prepared the plan,

The strike of fresh-water fish workers at Fulton Fish- Market was called off yesterday pending adjustment of grievances under a truce reached between the Fresh Water Fish Merchants Association and the United Sea Food Workers Union, A. F. of L. affiliate.

The Greater New York Fund, Inc., 52 Broadway, returned yesterday a contribution of $5, the first it received, with an explanation that acceptance of gifts from individuals was against the organization's policy of soliciting only business and employee groups.

A House of Commons committee late today recommended a bill which would enable the governments of Ontario and New York State to undertake the erection of a bridge below Niagara Falls. The bill goes to the House for third reading and then to the Senate.

The contract for the 360-foot bridge which will carry the West Side Express Highway over Canal Street was awarded yesterday to James Stewart Co. on a low bid of $446,170. Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan Borough President, said the bid was under the appropriation for the bridge.

Count and Countess Giuseppe Cippicco have returned to the WaldorfAstoria from Nassau, B. W. I. Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Short of Washington and members of their family, who had been at 14 East Sixtieth Street, have gone to Hyde Park, N. Y., to visit Mrs. James Roosevelt.

The bill of Senator Lendrum McNeans of Winnipeg, which aims at broadening grounds. for divorce, was approved today by the Senate's special committee. The measure now is ready for third reading, whence it will be referred to the House of Commons.
Influenced by lower quotations for cotton abroad and weakness in the stock markets here, prices on the Cotton Exchange went into new low territory at one time yesterday.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are March 23, unless specified: At Pearl Harbor: Kanawha, Louisville. Guantanamo to Canal Zone: Cassin, Sirius, Guam to Pearl Harbor: Memphis, Milwaukee: Trenton.

Lammot du Pont, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., said today that he hadn't. "the slightest doubt" business could find work-for all who "want a job" and if it received "reasonable certainty" conditions would remain "reasonably stable."

Stanley Ogilvy sailed his Western Long Island Sound boat Jay to victory today as the annual International Star Class competition started in-Montagu Bay. Harry G. Nye in Gale, the Southern Lake Michigan fleet representative, was home second, with Commodore R. T. Symonette's new boat, Nassau Star, third. Nine craft started.

Carrying several amendments adopted despite the opposition of the government, the bill continuing the present quota system of protection for the British film industry was passed by the House of Lords tonight.

General Hugh S. Johnson, former NRA Administrator, and Alexander F. Kerensky, Premier of Russia after the fall of the Czar and before the Bolshevist revolution, agreed in speeches here last night that the outlook for business depends upon a restoration of private enterprise under free democratic institutions and upon a halt in the trend toward totalitarianism, whether fascistic or communistic.

When High Commissioner Paul V. McNutt returns to the Philippines tomorrow he will find here one of the most peculiar psychological crises in the history of the archipelago. There remains no doubt that a change of sentiment toward independence,

Clark Williams of Greenwich, Conn., a New York banker, is to entertain for ten days twelve members of the Williams College faculty at his estate, the Cedars and the Pines, in Camden, S. C. Mr. Williams was graduated from the college in 1892.

The United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company and its subsidiaries showed a net profit for 1937 of $6,653,324 after Federal income taxes, depreciation, depletion, amortization and other charges, according to the preliminary annual report released yesterday.

A committee of women of the Coconut Grove colony received at the dedication this afternoon of the Fairchild Tropical Garden, a new beauty spot of eighty-three acres, given to the public by Colonel Robert H. Montgomery of Greenwich, Conn.
The Osservatore Romano, authoritative Vatican organ, prints an article today dated Freiburg, March 22, giving "painful details of the religious situation in Austria."

Leftist university students organized demonstrations here today against the government's allegedly Italophile and Germanophile policy. Nationalist students clashed with the demonstrators and one student was seriously injured before police intervened to restore order.

A campaign to obtain contracts covering wages and working conditions for all local salesmen employed by distillers is being pushed here by Local 20376, Wholesale Licensed Alcoholic Beverage Salesmen's Union of the State of New York, an A. F. of L. affiliate.

A group of coal producers in Pennsylvania today petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission to clarify its recent rate decision as it affects freight charges on coal and to prohibit the railroads from filing tariffs which would increase rates on anthracite by 20 cents a ton, d which, it alleged, was their intention.

John W. Delaney of 27-02 Humphries Street, East Elmhurst, Queens, for more than ten years an inspector of the United States Customs Service, died early yesterday at the Astoria Sanitarium. He became ill on Tuesday night and was taken to the hospital.

About 3,000 Jews, many foreign residents, and even natives, of Danzig have left the city during the last few weeks. The exodus increased after the Austrian invasion, which Danzig Nazis noisily celebrated.
Manhattan College has granted athletic awards to fifty members of the student body who participated in the Winter sports program, in was announced yesterday by Herbert M. Kopf, director of athletics.

Bruno Walter, regarded by many as one of the world's best conductors, has declined to participate in the Florentine festival, "Musical May," it was announced today. His strong feeling regarding Germany's annexation of Austria was said in musical circles to have prompted his decision.

Miss Hope Chandler, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Coley of this city, was married to David Whitmire Hearst, son of Willam Randolph Hearst, the publisher, and Mrs. Hearst, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning in the chantry of Grace Church, Broadway at Tenth Street.

Vigorous opposition to Mayor La Guardia's $9,250,000 emergency tax program was expressed yesterday by spokesmen for the restaurant, liquor, hotel, tobacco, and public utility interests who would be affected by it. Many of them asserted that the added burden would be disastrous to business.
Federal Judge William H. Kirkpatrick approved today the payment of $165,638 to the three receivers of the Philadelphia Company for Guaranteeing Mortgages, which collapsed in 1933.

Before Congress begins its TVA inquiry and Dr. Arthur E. Morgan's case reaches the courts it may be useful to list in some detail the political and legal issues raised by the controversy among the Directors of the Authority, which attained its first climax with the President's removal of Dr. Morgan.

The best that can be said about the emergency relief taxes proposed by Mayor La Guardia is that their weight does not fall on the necessities of the poor, and that they may add something like $9,250,000 to the amount that can be spent to aid our needy fellow-citizens.

The Wamego (Kan., Sextet, sparked by Miss Beldora Schultz, led the way into the quarter-finals of the Women's National A. A. U. Basketball Tournament today with a 24-to19 victory over the Tampa (Fla.) team. Nashville, Tenn., recorded a 32-to-13 triumph over Baltimore University; Des Moines, Iowa,

Ely Ave, 4,417, dwelling, 25x97.5; Home Owners Loan Corp. against Katherine Fagan; due, $4,895; to plaintiff for $2,000. By HENRY G. WALTEMADE Morris Ave, 1,497, dwelling 40.8x132.11x irreg; Home Owners Loan Corp. against Jacob Leikow; due, $16,945; to plaintiff for $2,200.

A statutory court of three Federal judges handed down a decision yesterday upholding the Interstate Commerce Commission's order directing seven railroads to stop giving special warehouse privileges to shippers.
Pope Pius XI has elevated to the rank of domestic prelate two priest of the Archdiocese of New York, it was announced yesterday by Cardinal Hayes.

Major Albert F. Volgenau completed last night his last night's work at Night Court, where he has been chief clerk for twenty years. He will take over the duties of the chief clerk of the Municipal Term Court today.

One of the outstanding fashion pageants of the early Spring, a revue entitled "Masterpieces of 1938," will be given in connection with a special luncheon today in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event will aid the Generosity Thrift Shop, beneficiary of last year's "Dawn to Dusk" fashion show.

A Senate Finance Subcommittee, of which Senator Connally is chairman, recommended today that the war profits bill introduced by Senator Connally last month be attached to the new tax bill as a "rider."

The White House transmitted to Congress President Roosevelt's notification of his dismissal of Dr. Arthur E. Morgan from the Board of the Tennessee Valley Authority, together with an opinion of Robert H. Jackson, Acting Attorney General, upholding the President's legal right to take such action.

Work relief is preferable to home relief, even though relief work is only 60 per cent as efficient as that done under private contract standards, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in a 103-page evaluation of the work done in this city by the Works Progress Administration and the Public Works Administration.

Joining with the Association of the Customs Bar, which yesterday protested a proposed amendment to the Customs Administrative Act giving authority to the Treasury Department to decide tariff complaints by declaratory rulings which would not be reviewable as to facts by the United States Customs Court, the Merchants Association yesterday sent telegraphic protests against the measure to Washington.

The House Judiciary Committee approved bills today for the creation of twenty-six new Federal judgeships. The measure authorizes the President to name two for the Third Circuit Court of Appeals, comprising New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware, and one each for the second circuit, New York, Vermont and Connecticut; the fifth, Georgia,

In a lively session which had much of the air of the "small business men's conferences" of a few weeks ago, representatives of realty and taxpayers' associations from all parts of the city laid the groundwork yesterday for what they hope will be a coordinated organization to fight against the "mounting burden of taxation" borne by real property.

A claim for one-third of the $36,000,000 estate of Rodman Wanamaker, filed by administrators of the estate of his son, Captain John Wanamaker Jr., was dismissed by Judge J. Burnett Holland in Montgomery County Orphans Court today.

Mayor La Guardia joined last night with twenty-five women of the city administration in paying tribute to Miss Dorothy Kenyon, formerly First Deputy Commissioner of Licenses, on the eve of her departure for Geneva, where she will be the only American member of a commission to study the legal status of women in many countries.

Cash prizes totaling more than $7,500 were awarded by the C. I. T. Safety Foundation at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria last night to twenty-five persons who promoted automobile traffic safety in 1937, including twenty-three newspaper men.
The National Hockey League bestowed its official 1937-38 scoring crown tonight on Gordie Drillon of the Toronto Maple Leafs.

Although the fighting in China has now lasted for more than eight months, the Japanese Government has steadily refrained from making a clear-cut statement of its objectives or of the conditions under which it would negotiate peace.

President Roosevelt arrived here late today for a vacation stay a few hours after making a fighting speech to about 20,000 persons at Gainesville, in which he called for higher wages in the South and struck at "feudalism," fascism and communism.

Detroit came from behind today to defeat Washington, 9 to 4, in a teninning Grapefruit League game. Trailing, 4 to 0, in the sixth, the Tigers made three runs on two doubles and two singles. They tied the game in the ninth on Rookie Cristman's hit and then scored five more in the tenth.

Michael Fackenthal, a director of the Bushwick Savings Bank of Brooklyn and the father of Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, provost of Columbia University, died yesterday in his home at 930 St. Marks Avenue, Brooklyn, after a short illness. He was 88 years old.

WITH "An Almanac for Moderns," published in 1935, Donald Culross Peattie first became generally known as a naturalist who wrote with a poet's pen. Since that time he has been undergoing a slow transformation-not for the better, so far as this reviewer's tastes are concerned-and now emerges as a poet who writes with a naturalist's pen. The evidence is in "A Prairie Grove,"* published today.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 22: COLONELS Fuqua, S. O. (Inf) Ord. Dep't,

Merchandise stocks of fifty-four out of sixty-four departments of large department stores in the Second Federal Reserve District showed declines in February from the same month last year, according to the monthly comparison of sales and stocks issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

A further engagement of $1,316,000 of gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The metal was purchased at some previous date, the price of gold in- London yesterday having been above the gold-shipping parity.

Governor Earle tonight invited America to join in Pennsylvania's 300th anniversary celebration of the arrival of the first Swedish colonists on the banks of the Delaware. In a nation-wide radio address he reviewed the preparations the State is making to entertain 1,000 visitors from Sweden at the ceremonies.

Soon after District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey told Judge Morris Koenig in General Sessions yesterday that Patrolman Theodore Steinblinck of the Clinton Street Station had framed evidence on which a young Negro was convicted last Dec. 21 by a jury on a pistol charge, Steinblinck was arrested for subornation of perjury.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Paintings by Rubens in the Metropolitan Museum," Roberta M. Fansler, 11 A. M.; American Wing (general tour), 2 P. M. Women's City Club of New York;, 20 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "Taylor, Girdler, Green and LewisContrasting Personalities in the Industrial Scene." Dr. J. Raymond Walsh.

Distinguished economists and educators were among 200 persons who yesterday afternoon attended funeral services for Dr. John Bates Clark, one of the foremost American contributors to economic theory, in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

The crew of the governmentowned freighter City of Rayville, which is scheduled to sail at noon today for Japan with a shipment of scrap iron and general cargo, signed articles yesterday. The ship will stop at Norfolk and the Pacific Coast on her way to the Far East.

Twenty - nine - year - old Jimmy Caras of Wilmington, Del., regained the world pocket billiard championship last night by overwhelming Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia, 125-22, in sixteen innings in the final game of a second play-off series at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy.

The Guaranty Trust Company will receive until April 1 written offers for the sale to it, as sinking fund trustee, of Interborough Rapid Transit Company first and refunding mortgage 5 per cent gold bonds due Jan. 1, 1966.

The Senate early today completed passage of a series of four bills making more than $19,000,000 available for relief and a companion measure creating a commission of nine to recommend a permanent program. The Assembly is expected to pass the legislation when it convenes next Monday night and prompt signing by Governor Moore is said to be assured.

The list of the French motorship Lafayette, leaving today for a cruise to the West Indies, includes Mr. and Mrs. Hinson Stiles, Mr. and Mrs. John E. McCauley, Henry D. Boenning Jr., H. Dickson Boenning, James W. Curley, Mr. and Mrs. James Brennan, Mr. and Mrs. J. J. Siegel, D. S. Bowers and Dr. and Mrs. Warren T. O'Hara.

Lieutenant E. Plagge of the Meridian Conservation Corps camp identified today the army officer killed yesterday in a plane crash as Major Robert H. Finley of Mitchel Field, N. Y. Officers from Montgomery, Ala., came here today to investigate the crash.

Close to $5,000 for medical and relief work in Loyalist Spain was raised last night at an emergency conference called by the Medical Bureau and North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy at Mecca Temple, 130 West Fiftysixth Street.

A new American record by a Lion quartet in the 400-yard breast-stroke relay was one of the highlights of Columbia's fourth annual water carnival in the Morningside Heights pool last night. Eric Winston,

New York State has received $5,179,030 from the Social Security Board to cover the administrative costs of unemployment insurance for the first nine months of the Federal fiscal year, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, disclosed last night.
Mr. and Mrs. Jay O'Brien entertained tonight with a large dinner at Villa del Sarmiento, where her mother, Mrs. Louise Leach, and the Countess Edith di Zoppola are guests.

A last-minute field goal by Gene Kozlowski gave the Standard Oil Packers victory over Eighth Avenue Temple, 39 to 38, at Union Temple in Brooklyn in one of six Metropolitan A. A. U. basketball title' tourney games last night.

Thomas E.
