Knowles, aeronautical engineer representing the American Zeppelin Transport Corporation, urged today before the House Merchant Marine Committee the retention in proposed amendments to the Merchant Marine Act of a provision for the extension of some of the benefits of the act to aircraft in overseas commerce.

Hogs and cattle sold higher, but the market was rather a forced affair with the principal bullish factor a reduction in receipts, the United States Department of Agriculture reported. Fed steers and yearlings were generally 10-15c higher and heifers strong to 25c up.

Jacques A. Mitchell, manager of the credit department of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for the last six years, died Tuesday at his home in Crestwood, N. Y., after a long illness, at the age of 59. Joining the bank in 1927, he was manager of its loan and discount department until 1932.

Harry Cohen, head of the Harry Cohen Dress Corporation and president of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, has been named executive vice president of the Apparel and Accessories Associates, Inc., of the New York World's Fair, 1939, it was announced yesterday by Joseph Love, chairman of the organization.

Power Memorial Academy and De La Salle Institute, both of Manhattan, gained the final of the ninth annual metropolitan Catholic High Schools' invitation basketball tournament at the Columbus Club in Brooklyn last night.

Led by Captain Dante Cetrulo, the Rollins College fencers triumphed, 12-9, over Princeton tonight. The Blue and Gold captain swept his three epee bouts and won two foil decisions as his team handed the Tigers their third straight defeat.

In a sweeping denunciation of the St. Louis Cardinals' system of "working agreements" with minor league clubs, Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis made free agents today of an estimated 100 players belonging to six Midwest teams and fined offending owners $2,176.

Dr. George H. Whipple, dean of the Medical School of the University of Rochester and co-winner of the 1984 Nobel Prize in Medicine, was announced today the recipient of the 1937 Charles Mickle Fellowship nf the Universitv of Toronto.

Mrs. Jacqueline Pushee Vale of Southern Pines, N. C., daughter of Mrs. J. Edward Tompkins of Long Ridge, Conn., and of Roy E. Pushee of Boston, was married here yesterday afternoon at the Barclay to Frederick Hall Burke of 47 East Sixty-first Street.

A step characterized as assuring peace in the hotel industry of the city was taken yesterday under the auspices of the State Labor Relations Board with the signing of an agreement providing for arbitration of differences between the Hotel Association of New York City and a group of A. F. of L. unions affiliated with the Hotel Employes Organization Commitee.

Congress learned today that the army's official military salutes cost $124,500 a year, more than four times as much as the fund available. Major Gen. W. H. Tschappat, ordnance chief, told a House Appropriations subcommittee that the War Department budget has listed only $28,580 for salute ammunition.

There is some color left in the Dodgers. They are still wearing their green caps, and Business Manager Leland Stanford MacPhail, called Laughing Larry, has red hair. When encountered Mr. MacPhail was wearing no hat, but he had on a green suit and wine-colored sun-glasses.

The transatlantic air conference, attended by technical experts of the governments of the United States, Britain, Canada and Ireland with representatives of Pan American Airways and Imeprial Airways, concluded its second day's sitting here tonight.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:
March 24.-Strong Chinese counterattacks yesterday continued to keep the Japanese north of the Grand Canal above Suchow, according to military reports arriving in Hankow.

The changing demand for United States Government securities is emphasized in a review of government financing for 1937 contained in the new edition of the annual survey published by C. J. Devine Co., Inc.

Dr. James W. Putman, neurologist and expert witness for the State in the trial of Leon Czolgosz for the assassination of President McKinley, died here tonight. He was 77 years old. Dr. Putman had been ill for six months.

Equipped with shoulder- length black hoods, shiny chains with 1-inch links, padlocks, a blank pistol and a decrepit rifle, two more chiselerss" were under arrest in the Levine kidnapping case last night.

After two years of futile efforts to get jobs for veterans on the World's Fair staff, a delegation headed by Clyde R. Hunt, first commander of the American Legion in Queens, called on Grover A. Whalen, president of the corporation, at his offices in the Empire State Building yesterday and obtained from him an agreement to give preference to veterans wherever possible.

Imperial Airways will move the Unofficial o United States terminus of its Bermuda airline from Baltimore back to Port Washington, N. Y., in about ten days. The line established the terminal here last Fall.

Leo Reisman, in 400 E 52d St: Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc. Brokers. S. V. V. Huntington, in 21 E 66th St; Fredrick Hesel through Burne Bowman, Inc. in 114 E 84th St; Miriam Wain-wright, Nat Haberman, in 355 E 86th St: Renee Harvey, in 1.141 Park Ave; Duff Conger, Inc, brokers.

Harry Lucacher of 2,407 Davidson Avenue, the Bronx, superintendent of the Hebrew National Orphan Home at 407 Tuckahoe Road, here, died this morning of a heart attack in the office of the home. He was 54 years old.

The American ORT Federation at a meeting in the Advertising Club organized yesterday a labor committee to participate in the ORT's $450,000 campaign to provide technical and agricultural training for Jewish victims of anti-Semitism and economic discrimination in Poland, Germany, Rumania and other European countries.
The city of Boston will be in the market tomorrow with an issue of $5,000,000 of notes dated March 28 and due Nov. 7.

Gus Lesnevich of Edgewater, N. J., gained a decision over Lou Brouillard of Worcester, Mass., former world middleweight champion,-in ten rounds at the Hippodrome last night. A crowd of 2,000 saw him outbox the Bay State boxer to win by a wide margin.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue's report for February and the first eight months of the current fiscal year, made public today, showed sharp decreases in revenue from business, reflecting recent depressed conditions.

Two appointments carrying $6,000 salaries were approved yesterday by the Board of Education. They were the positions of assistant directors of health education. Charles Deegan, in charge of the health work in the continuation and vocational schools, and Miss Loretta C. Ryan, first assistant of health education, were appointed to these posts.

McLane Van Ingen, head of E. H. Van Ingen Co., Inc., 160 Fifth Avenue, woolen merchants, died yesterday afternoon, after a long illness, in his home, 903 Park Avenue. He was 67 years old. A son of the late Edward H. and Mary McLane Van Ingen, on his graduation in 1893 from the Sheffield Scientific School,

Chancellor Adolf Hitler today ordered AdmiralGeneral Erich Raeder, Naval Chief of Staff, to create a German war fleet on the Danube, which through Anschluss has become not only Germany's longest river but also her waterway to all the countries of Central and Eastern Europe--Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Rumania-down to the Black Sea.

The combined net operating income of the first nine railroads to report for February was 77.7 per cent, lower than in February, 1937. Of these companies, the Bangor Aroostook and Kansas City Southern reported higher net earnings for February, while the Southern Pacific, Erie and Pere Marquette showed operating deficits.

Still jubilant over their initial victory, the New York Americans will oppose the New York Rangers in the second game of their secondplace Stanley Cup play-off series tonight at Madison Square Garden. Facing elimination, the Rangers are determined to even the score and then hope for a triumph in the "rubber" game.

Stocks declined 1 to 3 points to lowest levels in three years; t?? over, 1,468,400 shares, fifth ?urgest trading of the year. Bonds generally lower, secondary rails and Central European issues weakest; transactions, $7,261,450..

Paul B. Wes., 14, of New York, president of the. Association of National Advertisers; Carroll A Wilson, '07, of New York, counsel for Guggenheim Brothers; Stanley P. Benton of Pittsfield, president of E. D. Jones Sons Co.; Chester D. Heywood of Worcester and E. Kent
Southern California, Stanford, California and the University of California at Los Angeles plan to enter the I. C. A. A. A. A. track and field championships after a two-year absence.
Sale of the first portion of the world-famous library assembled by the late Mortimer L. Schiff of New York brought bibliophiles of two continents to Sotheby's today.

Weingarten's of Houston, Texas, with a total of 2,947 pins, led the coast-tocoast squads in the American Bowling Congress tonight. The Weingarten five advanced to seventh place in the A. B. C. standing.
At a meeting of directors of the New York Dock Company yesterday it was decided to extend to March 30 the time for deposit of notes under the modified plan of recapitalization.

The original manuscript of Richard Jeffries's "The Story of My Heart" was bought by H. S. Mott for $475 yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of selections from the libraries of Crosby Gaige, the Rev. Franklin Joiner of Philadelphia and others.
In the cool of the evening Manager Joe McCarthy settles himself in his favorite chair in a corner of the hotel lobby and smokes a mild cigar. Sometimes Colonel Ruppert sits there with him.
Chicago's scrappy Black Hawks, with big Earl Seibert getting two sensational "billiard shot" goals, shut out the Montreal Canadiens, 4 to 0, tonight to stay in the National Hockey League play-offs.

A moderate increase in contracts for residential building in February compared with the previous month and a "considerable further increase" in the first two weeks of March was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board in its summary of general business and financial conditions.
J. Ferguson Reed of Greenwich, Conn., arrived here without his dinner jacket and wired his secretary to go to his Greenwich home to get it and forward it to Bermuda.

Miss Dorothy Brockway, headmistress of the Spence School, war married yesterday at noon in the chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest,to Harold S. Osborne of Upper Montclair, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington.
Purchases of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on March 19 exceeded sales by 137,883 shares, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
The Scottish Union and National Insurance Company, Hall Henshaw, agents, and the Standard Insurance Company of New York were all found guilty yesterday of "willful violations of the insurance laws."

Rain fell here overnight, gave way to Old Sol during the early afternoon, then broke out again before today's program began, with the result that the Tropical Park racing strip was well covered with slop after the opening event. Late scratches were numerous.

Three views of the legal status of rival claimants for the vice"chairmanship of the City Council were presented yesterday to the Appellate Division. It was contended in behalf of John Cashmore, Brooklyn Democrat, that he had been elected to the post on Jan. 3 and still holds office; on behalf of James A.

After a three-day session, the Transatlantic Air Conference attended by representatives of the Governments of the United States, Great Britain, Canada and Ireland and of PanAmerican Airways and Imperial Airways was concluded here this evening.

The Federal Alcohol Administration to-day set hearings for April 25, 26 and 27 in the Mayflower Hotel here on proposed amendments to regulations relating to labeling and advertising of wine and malt beverages, and the proposed establishment of maximum periods of credit which may be offered to retailers by the liquor industry.

Drawing on the knowledge he has gained from his talks with the rulers of Great Britain and other insiders since his arrival a month ago, Joseph P. Kennedy, the United States Ambassador, tonight assured Americans that there would be no general European war "for the rest of this year at least."

Charles Franklin, counsel for the Manhattan Railway Company, owner of the elevated lines operated by the Interborough Rapid Trar-sit Company under a 999-year least yesterday notified Federal ?? Robert P. Paterson that Manhattan directors holding a majority of the company's stock had authorized him to demand the return of the lines by the Interborough for alleged breach of the lease contract.

About fifty big bombing planes roared off to sea today in an effort to prevent a "surprise attack" upon Hawaii by an "enemy" fleet much more powerful than the consolidated defenses of America's most vital Pacific base.

The organization of a nation-wide "Cured Cancer Club," in which more than 25,000 persons are eligible for membership, each member a living testimonial to the fact that cancer is curable if treated in its early stages, was announced yesterday by the American Society for the Control of Cancer.

Miss Miriam R. Booth of Fairlawn, this place, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Fred Booth, was married here this morning in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church to Watkin Williams Kneath of Rochester, by the rector, the Rev. Hugh Farnsworth.

A youthful romance of two years' standing ended in tragedy yesterday when Charlotte Matthiesen, 18 years old, was shot and killed by Donald Carroll Jr., 16, son of a retired army, officer, in the Carroll home at 37-37 Seventy-eighth Street, Jackson Heights..

The Pennsylvania Democratic alliance of John L. Lewis and Senator Joseph F. Guffey virtually completed its slate-making today with the selection of Mrs. Edith B. Dewitt, Deputy Secretary of Welfare under Governor Earle, as the antiState Committee candidate for State Secretary of Internal Affairs.

The increase of $100,000,000 in the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System, reported yesterday, is strikingly large in view of the fact that actual reserves of the banks went up only $5,000,000.

Strength in foreign wheat markets lifted prices in North America today, but there was no snap to the buying, and most traders showed a disposition to remain on the side lines pending further developments in the European political situation and in the outlook for the new crop in the Southwest.

Barnard College's annual water pageant was given in the college swimming pool last night with student swimmers portraying a visit of the navy to Hawaii. Swimming formations and races represented the manoeuvres of the ships. Competitive diving into circular targets was the target practice of the fleet.

Joseph Buerckel, Nazi leader from the Saar, who is in charge of the Anschluss plebiscite in Austria, April 10, opened the plebiscite campaign tonight with a speech delivered, at the Vienna Konzerthaus.

Samuel B. Moore, 52 years old, an advertising salesman for the Conde Nast publications, killed himself with a pocket knife yesterday in a washroom of the Graybar Building at 420 Lexington Avenue, where the publishing company has offices.

The report of the Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates for the twelve months to Feb. 28, issued yesterday, shows a net income after taxes and charges of $3,013,178. This compares with a net of $2,602,362 in the twelve months to Feb. 28, 1937.

The report of the International Holding and Investment Company, Ltd., of Canada (controlled by the Societe Generale de Belgique), shows a net asset value of $2.87 a share on the common stock on Dec. 31, compared with $3.10 a share at the end of 1936.

Representatives of the Association of American Railroads and the Railway Labor Executives Associations conferred here today on proposed wage reductions for railway workers but decided to defer further discussions until the report on the railroad situation, which President Roosevelt has asked three members of the Interstate Commerce Commission to prepare. is made public.

CONSTANTINE, MARY E. (March 18). Estate, more than $10,000. To Sanford H. Lane Jr., grandson, and Elizabeth Constantine Lane, granddaughter, of Middlebury, Vt., and Darien, Conn., respectively. $10,000 each, equal interests in real and personal property and temporary and surviving estates in residue with right to portions of principal at varying ages and balance of principal at 40;

The net profit of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation for the fiscal year ended on Dec. 25 amounted to $8,617,114, equal, after preferred dividends paid in the year, to $4.12 each on 1,741,683 common shares, Sidney R. Kent, president, reported yesterday.
The meager Japanese reports reaching Peiping regarding the fighting in the Tientsin-Pukow sector suggest, without giving details, that the fighting has been extremely severe.

The newest notion brewing in the Frederick W. Ayer office concerns a revival of Galsworthy's "Justice," with Glenn Hunter taking the role played here by John Barrymore in 1916. Practice sessions would begin the week of April 4, looking toward a tryout the week of May 2 and a Broadway opening the week after that.

Oswald Jacoby of New York and Dallas, Texas, for the fourth successive year has been named the No. 1 contract bridge player of the United States in the all-America ratings made annually for. Collier's magazine by Shepard Barclay.

A policy of inflexible isolation from European affairs based on past experience and knowledge was urged by Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota in a debate last night with Dorothy Thompson of The New York Herald Tribune at the National Broadcasting Company's "America's Town Meeting of the Air" program at the Town Hall.
Sometimes the President calls them economic royalistst and sometimes he calls them feudalists, but only a few very

Mr. and Mrs. M. Watson Bingham of Rydal, Pa., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Besbord Bingham, to Dr. Allen Ledyard de Camp of Fayetteville, N. C., son of the late Rev. and Mrs. Allen Ford de Camp of Boonton, N. J.
Stocks closed fractionally higher after early irregularity; turnover, 890,160 shares. Bonds showed mixed trends; transactions, $5,936,100.

All right, title and interest to all the lands lying e of the westerly side of East River Drive between n a of E 14th St and s s of E 15th St; Consolidated Edison Co of New York, Inc. R. H. Tapscott, president, to City of New. York, reserving, however, its right to any sub-surface structures within or outside of the lines of East River Drive (quitclaim).

Danger of a flood was removed here today after a mile-long ice-jam in the Passumpsic River was dynamited. Immediately after a channel was blasted through the ice, water which had backed up and surrounded homes in St. Johnsbury Center began to recede.

More than 1,000 persons, including many prominent in charitable work, attended funeral services yesterday for Harry Lucacher, superintendent of the Hebrew National Orphan Home, in the funeral chapel at 153 East Broadway. Mr. Lucacher died Wednesday.
After voting, 47 to 36, to abolish the office of Controller General, the Senate agreed today to vote finally on the Byrnes Reorganization Bill on Monday.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated irregularly over a 10point range yesterday to end with a loss of 1 to a gain of 5 points. A slight improvement in foreign quotations, and an upturn in the stock market exerted a steadying influence and liquidation during the recent decline of almost $5 a bale reduced selling pressure at the lower level.
The two New York teams in the Eastern States Catholic invitation basketball tournament which opened tonight had to wait until the final game before they met.

The Senate agreed to a vote at 5 P. M. Monday on the Byrnes Governmental Reorganization Bill, received Senator Barkley's proposal for a joint Congressional committee to investigate the Tennessee Valley Authority as a substitute for Senator Norris's motion for a Senate investigation, and recessed at 4:59 P. M. until noon tomorrow.

Mrs. Maxwell Hyde of 935 Park Avenue has announced the engagerment of her daughter, Miss Virginia Trotter Hyde, to W. Radford Bascome Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Radford Bascome of this city, formerly of St. Louis.

Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division forgot to put out the lights once too often yesterday .and received a rebuke from Mayor La Guardia, whom he was escorting through the Bronx County court house.

Harold G. Hoffman, former Governer of New Jersey, and seven other persons were sued in Federal court here today for $450,000 damages collectively by Paul H. Wendel, former Trenton attorney, who accused Mr. Hoffman of playing a leading part in a plot to kidnap him and force him by torture to confess falsely to the abduction of the Lindbergh baby.

Convoking by the United States of a world conference, while there is yet time to avert the "next war" by undoing the injustices bred by the last one, was urged tonight by Walter W. Van Kirk, director of the National Peace Conference, at the dinner session of the Conference on World Economic Cooperation which opened here today.

Michigan, defending titleholder in the fifteenth annual national collegiate swimming championships, opening in the Rutgers pool tomorrow morning at 10 o'clock, is conceded by coaches and swimming experts gathered here on the eve of the meet to have little chance of retaining its team title won last year at Minneapolis.

A plan of educational service described as taking the museum to the public and entailing the furnishing of lectures, slides, exhibits and other material to club and school groups was announced yesterday by the American Museum- of Natural History at a luncheon of women club representatives at the museum, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West.

By HENRY G. WALTEMADE Wilkinson Ave, 2,873; dwelling. 25x100: Home Owners Loan Corp against Francesco Nigro; due, $10,533; to plaintiff for $500. By B. HOLLANDER SON Longfellow Ave, 1,153; 2-story dwelling, 25x100; .Home Owners Loan Corp against

The following Marine Corps changes, dated March 23, were announced today: CAPTAINS Fox, C. E., Quantico, Va., to Marine Detachment, Naval Prison, Portsmouth, N. H. O'Brien, W. M., to Aircraft 1, First Marine Brigade, Quantico, Va.

Miss Patty Berg, queen of the Winter golfing circuit, finished with a sub-par 73 today in winning the women's Mid-South tournament with a sensational 54hole score of 224, seventeen strokes ahead of the field.

The New York Stock Exchange has requested member firms whose membership certificates bear the signature of Richard Whitney, president of the Exchange from 1930 to 1935, to return the documents for exchange, it became known yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Jane Elizabeth Treglown, daughter of Mrs. Glen Seymour Treglown of this place and the late Mr. Treglown, to William Sillo MacFarlane of Port Washington, L. I., took place this afternoon in the chapel of the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian, Church.

Facing charges of blackmail and attempted extortion for complicating the Levine kidnapping case with a threatening demand for $30,000, Werner Fred Luck, 23 years old, and John Penn, 18, waived examination yesterday before City Judge John N. Fasso in New Rochelle and were held without bail for the grand jury, which will consider indictments today.

Paintings from the collections of the late Mr. and Mrs. Percy A. Rockefeller, Henry T. Sloane and the Union League Club of New York brought $37,340 last night at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc.

A first edition' of "Les Precieuses Ridicules" that brought [Pound]880, said to be the highest price ever paid for a Mohere play, was the feature item of the second day of the sale of fine books and engravings collected by the late Mortimer L. Schiff
Mrs. Alice Roosevelt Longworth, who for years has refused to speak in public, confirmed reports today that she would begin a lecture tour in October.

Problems of floor coverings retailers who are seeking a ninetyday guarantee against price declines on rug stocks will be carried direct to the mills through joint committees of wholesalers and retailers, according to a decision reached yesterday at a conference between officials of the Wholesale Floor Coverings Distributors Association and spokesmen for the retailers.

Contract lettings for engineering construction this week are fractionally higher than in the same week in 1937, with a total of $49,149,000, as compared with.$49,006,000 last year, according to The Engineering News-Record.

British authorities have forwarded to Tokyo, it was learned today, claims of approximately $540,000 indemnity for bombings similar to that of the American gunboat Panay, for which the United States has asked $2,214,007.36.

Representatives of more than forty-five contracting, building materials and surety firms, together with officials of several associations composed of persons in those fields, met yesterday to discuss the possibility of getting the city to revive the practice of requiring performance bonds on all city contracts and to complement these with payment bonds.

Representative Bacon of New York charged in the House today that President Roosevelt's civil service selection system for postmasters was not being carried out by Postmaster General. Farley. He said it amounted to a "demoralizing national scandal."

Because the March income-tax collections did not come up to the Treasury's expectations by from $20,000,000 to $50,000,000, the Treasury will borrow an additional $50,000,000 through its current series of special "new money" bills, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

Two men were arrested yesterday on a Felony Court warrant charging them with extorting $250 from the manager of a midtown tea room as a bribe for removing pickets of Local 677 of the Soda Fountain and Luncheonette Employes Union from in front of the store. They posed as representatives of officers of the union.

The former residence of William Goadby Loew, a four-story brick and brownstone house at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, has been purchased by the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service. The buyers will move executive offices to this building shortly, after remodeling the structure to meet their needs.
The Barcelona Government announced today that it possesses an overwhelming amount of information regarding the German and Italian intervention that is going on now.

The United States liner American Trader will sail today for London. Passengers include William H. Brown, Herbert Hynd, Mr. and Mrs. William Mueller, Mrs. L. W. Shortlidge, Ernest Fones, Dr. Edward J. McKaig, Mrs. Denis O'Sullivan, and Lieut. Col. and Mrs. Thurlow R. Ubsdell.

Sir Frederick Marquis, managing director of Lewiss, Ltd., which has large department stores in Manchester, Liverpool, Birmingham, Leeds and Leicester, has recalled the company's trade buyers from Germany and Austria.
John Both, former Lawrence, L. I., contractor and a resident of the Rockaways for the last sixty years, died Wednesday at his home, 1,145 Nameoke Street, Far Rockaway, at the age of 75.
Miss Helen Dettweiler of Washington, D. C., will meet Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R. I., in the eighteen-hole final of the Augusta women's open golf tournament tomorrow afternoon.
Mokena, 5-year-old daughter of Brilliant, owned by D. Campbell, won her second race in ten starts this year when she accounted for the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds today.

Roy R. Quinn, who shot his common law wife to death in their home, 504 Fourteenth Avenue, here, on Jan. 3, was convicted of manslaughter today by a jury before Judge Robert H. Davidson in the Court of Oyer and Terminer. Sentence will be pronounced tomorrow. The penalty is one to ten years in prison.
Mrs. Nellie E. Hinds, sister of United States Senator Burton K. Wheeler (Democrat, Mont.), died today at the home in which she had lived for the last thirty-five years. Her age was 81.

Twenty-seven graduates-- of' the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Seminary of Yeshiva College received their "Smicha" or traditional orthodox rabbinical ordinations yesterday at exercises in the auditorium of the college, 187th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Declaring that the United States is being flooded with literature "describing un-American doctrines of racial hatred," Dr. Marius Ranson of East Orange, N. J., rabbi, urged Americans tonight to "fight more vigorously for one another's religious ideals."

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering issuance and sale of $60,000,000 of fifteen-year 3 1/2 per cent debentures, due April 1, 1953.

Insurgent troops continued to advance on four fronts today. General Juan Yague's troops, which crossed the Ebro River near Quinto yesterday, cut the Saragossa-Lerida road today near Montes de Farlete, twenty-five miles east of Saragossa. At this writing they were approaching Bujaraloz, fifteen miles farther east.
Resignation of the Lithuanian Cabinet amid widespread bitterness over the nation's capitulation to Poland was announced officially tonight.

The complete elimination of the undistributed profits tax by the Senate Finance Committee, and by the decisive vote of 17 to 4, is the most reassuring single piece of news that has come out of Washington in many months.
Cruger Ave (16-4546), new cor of Arnow Ave, 33x82; Julia F. Knopfelmacher to Fourth Federal Savings and Loan Association, 1,338 1st Ave: installments, 5 1/2 per cent, $12,000.

Factory sales of automobiles manufactured in the United States in February consisted of 186,806 units, compared with 210,120 vehicles in January, 364,193 in February, 1937, and 287;542 in February, 1936, the Department of Commerce reported today.
The Manhattan College varsity tennis team will play eleven matches this Spring, it was announced yesterday by Herbert M. Kopf, director of athletics. Ten of the tests are scheduled away from home.

The Senate Finance Committee today eliminated the undistributed profits tax principle from the 1938 revenue bill, as passed by the House, and modified the capital gains tax from its complicated form to a simplified basis stripped of confusing provisions.
Dr. William Kemble Walker, a psychiatrist, who formerly was a professor in the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, died in the University of Pennsylvania Hospital today at the age of 70.
A comprehensive appraisal of the State Unemployment insurance Law, with a view to its simplification and improvement, was authorized yesterday by the State Advisory Council on Unemployment Insurance.

Arthur H. Ballantine of New York, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, declared today that government borrowing had produced "a scale of expenditures that is repressive to employment and industry."

J. S. Pyeatt of Denver, president of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad, was elected today to the chairmanship of the Missouri Pacific, the New Orleans, Texas Mexico and the International Great Northern Railroads.

The Mexican Government has been compelled to reduce operations at the foreign-owned oil properties seized last Saturday by about 50 per cent from the rate prevailing just prior to their seizure, according to information received here yesterday from Mexico. The government had been operating the refineries at full tilt and permitting the oil wells to produce at their former rate.

The United States was praised for its "main preoccupation" in using its organized force in the service of peace by Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, Brazilian Minister of Foreign Affairs, in a radio address last night from Rio de Janeiro.

During the week ended March 23 member bank reserve balances increased $5,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $3,000,000 in money in circulation, $5,000,000 in Treasury cash

For the first time since the United States chess championship preliminaries started, Milton Hanauer, former State champion, failed to win his game in Group A at the Marshall Chess Club last night. His sixth-round game with A. Edward Santasiere, another ex-champion, resulted in a hard-fought draw lasting forty moves.

It took the Giants quite a long time today to shake off the stupor into which they seemed to have fallen after those two thrashings inflicted upon them two days previously by a the Athletics. In fact some of them have not shaken it off yet.
Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain today kept Germany and the rest of the world guessing as to whether Britain would fight in case of a German onslaught upon Czechoslovakia.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes. in pounds sterling:

Many new low levels were established, particularly among the railroad issues, in highly confused bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Despite the sharp falling-off in trading volume, some abrupt declines by pivotal loans forced the domestic averages to the lowest level since 1933.

At a stormy public hearing here today on the 1938 municipal budget representatives of real estate interests and civic organizations protested a proposed tax rise of $1.77 for each $100 of assessed valuation over the tax rate of last year.

Miss Anne Evangeline Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. D. Brooke Johnson of Ambler, was married this morning to Captain Harry this morning to Captain Harry Coleman Drayton, Air Corps, U.S.A. (retired), son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Drayton of Penllyn.

Walter Kramer of Detroit and Mrs. Dei Barkhuff of Seattle, Wash., defending men's and women's singles champions, moved into the fourth round of their divisions in the national badminton championships tonight after scoring decisive victories in earlier rounds.

Operations last year of the Otis Elevator Company and its domestic subsidiaries resulted in a net income for 1937 of $3,592,325 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and $23,300 surtax on undistributed profits.

Dr. Daniel Webster Hering, Professor Emeritus of Physics at New York University, senior faculty member and curator of the James Arthur collection of timepieces of the university, died yesterday at his home at 2,208 Andrews Avenue, the Bronx, at the age of 88.
It is a long road that leads from the early post-war faith in a system of collective security to the address which the Prime Minister of Great Britain made in the House of Commons yesterday.

Further deterioration occurred in the world economic outlook during January, and indications accumulated that the world as a whole is entering upon a definite recession, according to the monthly review of work economic conditions in the current issue of The Annalist.

Judge Nott in General Sessions yesterday postponed until next Tuesday decision on a motion to suspend Sing Sing sentences he had passed in May, 1936, on Clark G. Kuney and Edward A. Sauter, former officials of the Commonwealth Bond Corporation.

Prominent members of the society of Beaux-Arts Architects, who in past years have combined their respective talents to produce New York's famous Beaux-Arts Ball, presented a Mi-Careme supper dance last night in the exhibition hall of the Beaux-Arts Institute of Design at 304 East Forty-fourth Street.
Professor Lloyd P. Rice of the Deapartment of Economics at Dartmouth College has accepted an appointment as financial adviser to the Philippine Government for fifteen months, starting this June.

With machines in the central offices of the Social Security Board processing wage-record cards at the rate of 850,000 a day, the Federal old-age insurance system expects by June 30 to begin submitting reports to any of its 38,000,000 "policy holders" who wish to have them.
Richard Whitney spent yesterday morning with the Securities and Exchange Commission and yesterday afternoon with a board of psychiatrists.

Charles Offenburger, 19 years old, of Water Street here, was arrested late last night as the man who shot and critically wounded Benjamin Gordon, 24, of New Brunswick, in an attempted holdup yesterday afternoon after Gordon had given him a lift in his automobile near here.

Active consumer response featured the opening of the sale yesterday by Hearn Department Stores, Inc., held as part of its "Consumer Campaign for Lower Prices." Officials said the business done at the Fourteenth Street, Bronx and Newark stores was the "largest for a single Spring day in meany years."

Resales of various descriptions of hides by traders this week have de pressed the packer hide market, and the moderate business packers have been able to book this week has been at declines of 1/2 cent a pound, it was reported yesterday.
Pensioned On His Own Application-To take effect 12 midnight, March 24: PATROLMAN-Joseph P. Crawford, 71st Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed April 19, 1910.

Mrs. Noah MacDowell gave a luncheon yesterday at the Beekman for Mrs. Edward W. Robinson of St. James, L. I. Among the other guests were Mrs. Frederic H. McCoun, Mrs. Shepard Dillingham, Mrs. Frederick P. Palen, Mrs. Maud W. Cameron, Mrs. Arthur R. Manice, Mrs. Linn M. A. Evans, Mrs. Robert Tighe, McGusty and Mrs. Homer L. Loomis.

Two books by H. G. Wells are announced for publication during the first week in April. "The Brothers," which Viking will publish on April 4, is a novelette on the theme of communism versus capitalism.

The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated March 23: COLONEL Householder,- E.- R., Adjutant General's Deapartment, three days' leave, March 29. LIEUTENANT COLONEL Cook, C. E., Veterinary Corps, two months' leave, May 15.
A further change in plans is announced by the field trial committee of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club for the Spring meeting. Instead of opening

Ultra-feminine fashions in every type of apparel from tea gowns to evening costumes comprised the units of a smartly paced spectacle staged yesterday in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, where more than 1,000 women at- in tended the annual luncheon and style review under auspices of Generosity Thrift House, 1,237 Third Avenue.

Representative Snyder of Pennsylvania, opening debate today on the $447,808,555 appropriation bill for the army, told the House that it contained provision for only one-tenth of the critical items of equipment needed for an emergency.
A sharp drop in agricultural commodcities caused a fractional decline in the general level of wholesale prices in the week ended on March 19, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

The Little Rock, Flyers, defending champions, entered the semi-finals of the women's naitonal A. A. U. basketball tournament tonight by defeating Nashville, 37 to 12. They were preceded into the round by the Galveston Anicos, prime favorites, who turned back Wamego, Kan., 28 to 5.

Branch Rickey continued to spar for time today without opposition to an order by Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis turning loose some 100 young players. Rickey's chief second, owner Sam Breadon of the Cardinals, was reliably reported to have advised him to lay off the clouting commissioner, who never has lost a baseball decision.

A certificate was filed yesterday at Jersey City whereby the Chase National Bank of New York and Wilson L. Hemingway certify that the mortgage made by the National Bearing Metals Corporation, May 1, 1927, to secure an issue of twentyyear 6 per cent bonds amounting to $2,500,000 on its plants in Jersey City,. Allegheny and Crawford Counties, Pa.; St. Louis, Mo.;

THE GIRL OF THE GOLDEN WEST, based on the play by David Belasco; screen play by Isabel Dawn and Boyce DeGaw; music by Sigmund Romberg, with lyrics by Gus Kahn; orchestra and vocal arrangement by Leonid Raab, Leo Arnaud. Murray Cutter and Paul Marquardt; musical direction by Herbert Stothart; dances and ensembles created by Albertina Rasch: directed by Robert Z. Leonard; produced by William Anthony McGuire for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. At the Capitol.

Although most of the members of the Boards of Estimate predicted yesterday that the proposed new Appellate Division court house on Park Avenue at Thirty-ninth Street would not be built for years, the board voted an issue of corporate stock amounting to $1,379,630 to pay for the site.

Notes are being drafted in Washington and London in which the United States and Great Britain will formally accuse Japan of exceeding the 1936 naval treaty limits and will invoke the escalator clause to increase the size of their own warships.

Trading was slow. The cow market was weak to lower, lamb steady to higher, other classes mostly unchanged. Trading in kosher meats was very light and mostly in lamb at irregular prices as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
A mad scramble is promised for tomorrow when many of the nation's crack pros and amateurs reel off the thirty-six-hole final of the North and South open golf tournament.

Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for numerous alterations in Manhattan and Brooklyn. Architects also filed for homes in Brooklyn and Queens. A Middle Village project will provide one-family homes for fifty-six families.
The Board of Tax Appeals fixed $403,053 plus interest today as the amount of 1931 income taxes owed by the late Andrew W. Mellon for 1931.

The Foreign Office's semi-official organ, the Diplomatische Korrespondenz, praises Dr. Kamil Krofta, Czechoslovak Foreign Minister, today for having warned foreign correspondents in Prague against unfavorable reporting on neighboring countries.

The sharp price declines announced this week on Fall lines of wool goods for men's wear are likely to stimulate the market during the coming months, but the outlook for increased business over the next few weeks is none too bright, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

C. William Meinecke, president of the New York hospital supply house of Meinecke Co., died today In Orange Memorial Hospital after a brief illness. He was 80 years old on Monday. He invented many hospital and sickroom articles.

Fifty-five candidates reported to Coach Benny Friedman yesterday as Spring football practice at City College began at Lewisohn Stadium. Friedman intends to hold drills on Monday, Wednesdays and Fridays for the next six weeks.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Irelan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Singer B. Irelan of Forest Hills, to Jack Wells Clarke, son of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Clarke, also of Forest Hills, formerly of Virginia, took place here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Church of the Transfiguration.

In a bruising, tense struggle which held a crowd of 16,000 fans in a grip of frenzied excitement, the New York Rangers evened matters with their city rivals, the Americans, at Madison Square Garden last night.
ALWAYS ANOTHER SPRING, by Adelaide Humphries. (Arcadia, $2.) A light novel. APRIL SERENADE, by Ruth Rosemary Corby. (Arcadia, $2.) A light novel.

Cardinal Hayes observed yesterday the fourteenth anniversary of his membership in the Sacred College. He worked at his desk virtually all day. He offered mass in the private chapel of his residence, 452 Madison Avenue, at 8 A. M. After breakfast he went to his office.

Britain's freak Summer ended tonight with a slight, almost imperceptible shower-the first rain for twentyfour days. Under the influence of the unusual sunshine flowers and plants are ahead of schedule.

An issue of $35,000,000 of short term revenue bills of New York City was sold yesterday by Joseph D. McGoldrick, Controller, at an in terest rate of 0.50 per cent. Some twenty-six banks and trust corn panies shared in the distribution of the bills, dated March 25 and pay able on May 4 out of revenue from the April tax installments. The money will be used for payrolls and redemptions.

Professor Lloyd P. Rice of the Department of Economics at Dartmouth College today accepted an appointment as financial adviser to the Philippine Government for a period of fifteen months, beginning in June.
In an address broadcast to Australia on the large new defense program, Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons declared today that recent events had indicated a need for even greater preparedness.

The unfamiliar "Corsair" overture of Berlioz made a particular impression on the audience as the introduction of the concert given last night under John Barbirolli's direction by the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall.

Protests against the bombing of Barcelona, the threat of fascism and Japanese aggression in China were staged by nearly 8,000 college and high school students in behalf of "peace and democracy" yesterday on various campuses of the city.

New bids on three Westchester Counter sections of the Delaware water project opened yesterday by the Board of Water Supply brought an indicated saving of only $1,433,671 as compared with bids submitted in November.

Final plans for a home-building center at the New York World's Fair, which will occupy ten acres in the shelter zone and will cost about $1,500,000, were announced yesterday by Grover Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.
There may be doubt as to whether happy days have come again .to the country at large, but they do come to Warm Springs, Ga., when our ruralminded President goes down there for his vacation.

Secretary Morgenthau and other fiscal officials of the government are exploring the possibilities of providing government aid in the form of loans to business, both large and small, in accordance with a request by President Roosevelt before he left for Warm Springs.
Westchester County urged the Supreme Court today to review a Second Circuit Court order to pay the Montrose Contracting Company $580,450 for work done on a sewer tunnel in the city of Yonkers.

No true scientist thinks of himself or his country when he pursues his researches. Newton and Darwin were not concerned with benefiting England when they evolved their respective theories of gravitation and natural selection.

The New York Yacht Club will go aroving on its annual cruise next August. The dates and squadron runs, as well as the special events, were read last night by Commodore W. A. W. Stewart at the March meeting in the clubhouse, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

B. Charney Vladeck, majority leader of the City Council, announced yesterday that a tax of one twenty-fifth of 1 per cent on all commercial bank deposits, as distinct from savings accounts, to raise an estimated $5,000,000 would be put before the Council finance committee when it meets in City Hall at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

Appointment of a trustee for the Continental Securities Corporation; an investment trust, coincided yesterday with the revelation that activities of the concern are being investigated by the office of Thomas E. Dewey, District Attorney for New York County.

The Our Lady of Refuge quintet of the Bronx topped St. Gabriel's of Manhattan, 31-29, in a senior division game in the play-offs of the Catholic Youth Organization basketball tournament at the Fordham gymnasium last night.
With farm and food products again declining the Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices receded to 82.4 on Wednesday from 82.8 (revised) a week before.

The Rev. Dr. James Henry MaoDonald of Plainfield, N. J., a retired Methodist minister, died yesterday in Brooklyn Methodist Episcopal Hospital after an operation for intestinal trouble. He was 73 years old.
Cattle and lambs sold powerr today from the start and at the close the early upturn on hogs had been erased. according to the Department of Agriculture report.

While Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain was defining Britain's positions as to Czechoslovakia today, discussion was going forward in the French Chamber's Foreign Affairs Committee here as to what France would do if Germany should serve the same kind of ultimatum to the Czech Government as she did to the Austrian.

Mr. and Mrs. Peter W. Miller of Orford, N. H., and New York, were among those entertaining tonight at an informal dinner dance at the Surf Club. Mr. and Mrs. John Humphrey Crawford of New York were also hosts there.

Fred Corcoran, P. G. A. tournament bureau manager, announced today the following tournament dates: March 26-28. Greensboro, N.. C., Purse $5,000. April 1-3, Masters, Augusta, Ga., $5,000. May 12-14, Metropolitan open, Long Island district; 26-29, Inverness, Toledo, $5,000.

The Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation, which handles about 22 per cent of the telegraph communications business in this country, announced yesterday that wage increases of $600,000 annually had been granted to 15,000 employes, effective April 1.

George Brokaw Compton, leader of the successful campaign for adoption of the new City Charter and one of the organizers of the American Legion, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital, Amsterdam Avenue and 113th Street, after a brief illness. He was 54 years old.

President Roosevelt began his tenday Spring vacation under a warm sun today as political observers considered the implications, in regard to the coming primary campaigns, of his Gainesville speech calling for the election to Congress of Senators and Representatives subscribing to his program of social and economic reform.

Patrolman Theodore Steinblinck was indicted yesterday by the New York County grand jury on charges of perjury and subornation of perjury in connection with the arrest and prosecution by him of Tim Smith, 19 years old, a Negro, on a pistol charge. The indictment was handed up to Judge Owen W. Bohan in General Sessions and Steinblinck is expected to be arraigned for pleading today.
Earnings of the Agfa Ansco Corporation for 1937 were the largest in the history of the company, according to the annual report made public today by Dr. Ernst Schwarz, president.
No one questions the right of the Mexican Government to expropriate property, whether owned by its citizens or by foreigners. That is a right which our own Government exercises frequently.

Park Avenue loomed yesterday as a possible rival of Washington Square as a center of outdoor art activity. Now that the painters have established their two annual shows in the streets around the downtown park the sculptors have decided to embellish mid-Manhattan with an outdoor exhibition.

An action was started yesterday in Supreme Court to compel the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs to accept the Highway Transport Association as the collective bargaining agent for its eleven members, each of whom has a contract with the union covering its employes.
Herbert Hoover and more than 260 other passengers sailed for New York on the liner Normandie today after chasing after her from Southampton, where a Channel fog had caused them to miss the boat.
Joseph Paul-Boncour, the Foreign Minister, told the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Chamber of Deputies today that Nazi Germany was conducting a large propaganda campaign in Alsace and Lorraine.
The statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday shows the ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities as 55.97 per cent, against 55.80 the week before. The statement:

The stock markets here improved generally this afternoon and most sections advanced. Gilt-edge issues were in demand, while a feature among the foreign bonds was a sharp rally in Czechoslovakian loans. Transatlantic shares attracted firm support and United States Steel and International Nickel went ahead.
Miss Elizabeth Surbrug, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Surbrug of this place, has chosen April 1 for her wedding to Joseph Simmons, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph I. Simmons of Montclair.

Admittedly as thrilled as when she prepared for her first trip abroad many years ago, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody looked forward today to a tennis comeback which will carry her through tournaments in England, Continental Europe and the United States.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury."
Joe Platak, Chicago, defeated Joe Gordon, Los Angeles, Pacific Coast champion, today to enter the semifinals of the national A. A. U. handball tournament. The score was 18-21, 21-13, 21-10.

Charles J. Chapman, secretary of the British Schools and Universities Club of New York and for thirty years Eastern manager of the trade journals The Drug Bulletin, The Medical Standard and The National Jeweler, died yesterday in the Polyclinic Hospital after an operation. He was 78 ears old.
Lumber production increased last week, but the gain was smaller than anticipated seasonally, and the adjusted index has declined to 63.2 from 64.6. It was 81.5 for the week ended March 20, 1937.

Robert Bottcher, 22-year-old Western Union messenger, of 651 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, received a gold medal of valor last night along with Patrolman George C. Pramuk of the Snyder Avenue station and Fire Lieutenant Frank Brannigan of Engine 281 from the Flatbush Chamber of Commerce at its twenty-third annual dinner and dance in the Knights of Columbus clubhouse at 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. Five hundred persons attended.
Dr. Luis H. De Bayle of Leon, father of Sen??ora Anastasia Somoza, the President's wife, and of Dr. Leon De Bayle, Minister to Washington, died early this morning at the age of 73.

I cannot imagine any events in Europe which would change the fundamental basis of British foreign policy, which is the maintenance and preservation of peace. However, that does not mean nothing would make us fight.

Construction of a merchant marine capable of transporting at least one-half of the nation's foreign commerce was urged by Rear Admiral Clark H. Woodward, commandant of the Third Naval District, in an address yesterday before the Propeller Club.
The level of business in the Pittsburgh district was almost unchanged last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. As in the past month,

Long residence in the South and familiarity with its problems combine to suggest some difficulties in achieving the President's econornic program for that section which he did not mention in his speech at Gainesville, Ga.

On the eve of relinquishing the helm of the United States Steel Corporation which he has held for ten years, Myron C. Taylor tonight expressed "full confidence" in the future of his organization and his country.

The rules committee of the National Football League will hold its annual meeting in Pittsburgh on Sunday, April 10, it was announced yesterday by President Joe F. Carr, The committee likely will adopt the forward-passing rule change made by the college rules body, calling an incompleted pass in the end zone a touchback only on a fourthdown try.
N. Y. U. triumphed over Temple at Conwell Hall pool today, 37-20, in the first girls' swim meet between teams from the two institutions in eleven years.
Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers humbled the hitherto undefeated Tigers today, but it took a tenth-inning home run by Cookie Lavagetto to win, 6-5, and give them what may be a costly victory.

The dollar value of sales on all registered securities Exchanges in February dropped to $794,078,054, the lowest figure for any month since the Securities and Exchange Commission began the compilation of such data in March, 1935, it reported today.

Deposits of the National City Bank of New York amounted on March 7 to $1,692,189,347, according to the bank's condensed statement of condition issued yesterday. This compared with $1,711,552,124 on Dec. 31 and $1,688,450,920 on March 31, 1937, the date of the nearest comparable statement last year.

The index of deliveries of rayon woven fabrics in the greige for February stood at 113, compared with 82 in January and 175 in February, 1937, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by the National Rayon Weavers Association, Inc.
Because Adolf Hitler invaded Austria a. little hill near this quiet village regained its Yankee name today. Henceforth "Fish Hill" will be called just that and not "The Arlberg Slope."

For the nineteenth consecutive time, the volume of bank transactions at twenty-two leading cities remained substantially under that for the similar week of the previous year in the week ended Wednesday.

The commission appointed last August to examine Robert Irwin, 29 years old, sculptor, who is under first-degree murder indictments for the triple Gedeon slaying last Easter, reported to Judge John J. Freschi in General Sessions yesterday that Irwin is sane and was sane at the time of the killings.

In our valued contemporary, theCongressional Record of March 22, appears, late but welcome, a reconstruction of history made at a Jackson-Jefferson dinner in the Pennsylvania York on March 2. The maker is the Hon.

Governor Cross today settled the protracted row about bridges over and under the Merritt Parkway by arranging with John A. MacDonald, Highway Commissioner, to change the approaches to several of the bridges already constructed and alter the width of three of six bridges awaiting award of contract.

Attacks on business for political purposes were assailed here today by Orval W. Adams, president of the American Bankers Association, in an address opening the third regional banking conference of the association today. .

The well-known Hellman Mayonnaise Building at 34-18 to 34-28 Northern Boulevard, Long Island City, a four-story and basement structure with a railroad siding, has been leased from Best Foods, Inc., for a long term with a purchase option.

George E. Scott, president of American Steel Foundries, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that the company operated at only 11 per cent of capacity in February and that virtually no inquiries for new equipment were being received.

Harry F. Wolf of the Montclair A. C., who demonstrated once more during the past season that he is still the outstanding man in squash tennis, was ranked for the ninth successive time as the No. 1 player in the list announced last night by the National Squash Tennis Association.

Lieutenant Melvin W. Woods, 25year-old naval officer found shot to death yesterday in a Virginia woods overlooking the Potomac River, had suffered a nervous breakdown from overwork, Captain Frank W. Rockwell, his father-in-law, said today.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following second lieutenants, Infantry Reserve, is relieved from assignment to the 1st Division: Samuel Colman, 315 Central Park West, New York, N. Y. Philip H. Spitzhoff, 242 E. Tremont Ave., New York, N. Y. Martin Menter, 200 Euclid Ave., Syracuse, N. Y.
Michael Strauss Jacobs, New York boxing promoter, inspected Detroit today as a possible site for the Joe Louis-Max Schmeling heavyweight title bout.

ALL THE LIVING, a play in three acts, by Hardie Albright, derived from Victor R. Small's book, "I Knew 3,000 Lunatics." Staged by Lee Strasberg; settings by Harry Horner; produced by Cheryl Crawford, In association with John Stillman Jr. At the Fulton Theatre.
One upset marked the opening of play in the national table tennis championships tonight as the favorites advanced to the third round.

Transfer of a New York Stock Exchange seat for $56,000, down $4,000 from the previous transaction, was reported yesterday. The Exchange's committee on admissions will ballot on April 7 on transfer of the membership of Sidney Forsch to David Warner and that of L. Paul Lynch to Herman Gordon.

An air raid tower, as a new departure in shelters against bomb attacks is being developed here. It is a gasproof, reinforced concrete tower, constructed in the form of a cone and painted brown and green to make it difficult for aviators to see.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

Despite slight declines in certain cities, the cost of putting up a fairsized building in most communities last month was practically the same as in January, and still is higher than it was a year ago.

Dr. A. Hamilton Rice, president of the French Institute, will give a reception for the French Ambassador to the United States, Count Reme Doynel de Saint-Quentin, on Monday afternoon at the institute.

The New York Curb Exchange has been notified of a stock dividend of two-fifths of a share on each share held on the common stock of F. L. Jacobs Company, payable on April 30 to stock of record of April 15. Script will be issued instead of fractional shares.

William Davis Ticknor, president and chairman of the-board of directors of the Commercial Solvents Corporation, with offices at 230 Park Avenue in New York, died today of a heart ailment at his home, 53 Beech Road. He was 57 years old.

The three-man committee of the Interstate Commerce Commission appointed last week by President Roosevelt to prepare a plan for solution of the railroad problem delivered it to the White House today. The document was sent by air mail to Warm Springs.

Semi-annual meeting, Academy of Political Science, Hotel Astor, 10 A. M. Luncheon, 1 P. M. Afternoon session, 3 P. M. Speakers, morning: Leo Wolman, Arthur E. Morgan, I. L. Sharfman, Winfield William Riefler, Isador Lubin,

Supreme Court Justice Brower in Brooklyn approved yesterday the six-year plan, with modifications, submitted by William M. Parke, referee, in connection with the reorganization of the Home Title Insurance Company, which has been in the custody of the State Superintendent of Insurance, Louis H. Pink, for rehabilitation, since Aug. 4, 1933.
Ten days in Puerto Rico have convinced former Senator Hiram Bingham that the best way to obtain rest here is not to talk. Sailing for New York

The American-born Countess of Carrick won an undefended divorce today from the Earl of Carrick on charges of misconduct. The Countess of Carrick is the former Mrs. Marion C. Edwards of Philadelphia, Pa., daughter of Daniel C. Donoghue.

Turpentine firm, 24-24 3/4c; sales, 35 barrels; receipts, 60 barrels; shipments, 473 barrels; stock, 22,608 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 91; receipts, 949; shipments, 1,336; stock, 63,149. Quote: B, $3.50; D. $3.80; E, $4.00; F, $4.75: G, H, I, K, M. $4.82 1/2; N, $5.20; WG, $5.85; WW-X, $6.50.

It appears that teachers live too long in the New York City school system, or at any rate live longer than they should, as far as carefully prepared mortality tables are concerned. As a result of this longevity, a problem has been created for the Teachers Retirement Board, and the tables upon which pension fund contributions are based may now have to be revised.

Morton Co., grain brokers, notified the St. Louis Merchants Exchange today that they were unable to meet immediate obligations. Most of their business has been in the cash grain market. The volume of transactions was reported not large.

The German Christian Social Party today passed a resolution to secede from the government coalition and cooperate with the Henlein [Sudeten German] party. M. Zajicek, German Clerical Minister in the Cabinet, resigned.

Beaten in the Senate on his financial proposals by a vote of 193 to 88, Premier Leon Blum and his Cabinet are considering tonight whether to resign or to fight the matter out between the Chamber majority on the one side and the Senate majority on the other.

Transfer of Aides Effective from 12:01 A. M. April 1, members detailed as aides to deputy and battalion chiefs will be transferred from their companies to the division or battalion, as the case may be, instead of being detailed to an individual chief officer, and they will be carried on the division payroll.

SOMERSET MAUGHAM'S "The Summing Up"* gives light without warmth. It is a frosty, shrewd, sparkling and revealing-though not entirely revealing-record of Mr. Maugham's lifetime adventure in disenchantment.
Additional gold amounting to $4,300,000 was engaged abroad yesterday for shipment here, bringing to $25,100,000 the total known gold flow toward the United States since March 15.

The 1938 charity figure-skating carnival, presented for the first time at Madison Square Garden Wednesday-night, will resume its run at the arena tonight. Another performance will be given tomorrow and the final is set for Monday night.

A series of two-base hits, coupled with fairly steady mound work, today gave the Red Sox a 7-to-4 victory over the Cardinals. Pitcher Johnny Wilson, after allowing the Gas House Gang four runs in the first inning, steadied and held them until he was relieved by Archie McKain.

The Long Island University basketball team downed the Virginia Union University tossers of Richmond, 57 to 40, in a game played for the benefit of the New YorkUrban League at the Renaissance Casino last night. A crowd of 1,200 was present.
Fordham's Spring schedules in varsity track and tennis and freshman baseball were announced yesterday by John F. Coffey, graduate manager of athletics.

With 2,707 graduates listed in the current edition of "Who's Who in America," comprising almost 9 per cent of the 31,081 distinguished Americans in the volume, Columbia University is represented by more alumni than any other university, according to The Columbia Alumni News, weekly publication out today.
Great Britain's tennis officials decided today to give the younger crop of players a chance to regain the Davis Cup, lost last Summer to the United States.

The program of the Rockefeller Foundation, which for twenty-five years has been engaged in "pushing out the boundaries of knowledge," now finds itself "stopped at some frontiers" because certain governments are engaged in circumscribing intellectual liberty and imposing uniform ideologies upon their
The passenger ship Transylvania of the Anchor Line nosed into the north berth of the city's newest pier, No. 45, North River, at the foot of Tenth Street, late yesterday afternoon.

Membership of the joint committee for the advancement of manufacturer-wholesaler, relations, appointed at the suggestion of manufacturers who participated in the January convention, was made public yesterday by Henry Matter, executive secretary of the Wholesale Dry Gocas Institute.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed, as of March 22, 1928, upon the eligible list of persons licensed for service as teacher of swimming in day schools, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license:

It would not be fair to say that if Jon-Corbino's bright new canvases could be fed into some fabulous aging machine they would be mistaken, when they came out of it, for old masters. His works sound a contemporary as well as personal note.

A new musical setting of "The Road to Golgotha" by Pietro Yon will be given tonight at St. Patrick's Cathedral. The meditations for the devotion have been written by the Rev. Henry F. Hammer, assistant director of the cathedral.

Chaffce Ave (18-5521), n s, 215 ft a of Pennyfield Ave, 37x100; Locust Point Estate, Inc., to Hubert Time, 3,088 Mullan St. 165th St, 763 E' (10-2660): Guaranty Trust Co of New York trustee, to David Edson, 5,002 4th Ave, Brooklyn.

Charges of suspicion of homicide against James Cox, 27 years old, of 994 Intervale Avenue, the Bronx, and Irving Kaplan, 48, of 233 West Ninety-ninth Street, were dismissed yesterday in Homicide Court by Magistrate Overton Harris.

A mortgage for $13,800 on 715 10th Ave held by the Benefit Board of the Northern Baptist Convention from the committee of Vincent Romano, an incompetent, was extended to Feb. 1. 1941. interest reduced from 5 1/2 to 5 per cent, $125 to be paid off quarterly.

Officers of campus organizations at Mount Holyoke College for the coming academic year were announced today. Miss Anne Shroyer of New York City will head the undergraduate International Relations Club and Miss Nina Purington of East Cleveland will serve as president of the athletic association. The Fellowship of Faiths.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the magazine Liberty dated March 26 is an article, "The New Deal and the Press," by President Roosevelt. In the introductory paragraph he says:
Werner Janssen was named regular conductor of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra tonight to succeed Ernest Schelling, who resiened last week.

Edward M. Poons of Kobe, Japan, and New York, long an importer of straw braid for hats, died. on Wednesday in his apartment in the Hotel Bretton Hall, 2,350 Broadway, after a year's illness. His age was 53.

Protests from medical bodies caused Warner Brothers today to abandon "Your Life Is in Their Hands," an expose of quack practitioners. The story by William Rankin and Eleanor Griffin- was announced some weeks ago.

Conceding that the facts revealed by the recent Russian trials "were a great shock to all of us," Alexander A. Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, defended last night the "elimination" of the "conspirators" and said that the fate of Austria showed the folly of weakness or tolerance toward fascism.

The Right Rev. Philip CooK, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Delaware, died early today at the Johns Hopkins Hospital at the age of 62. His wife, a brother and his children were at his bed- side.

Mrs. Charles Harrington Chadwick entertained with a dinner at her villa today for the Marquess and Marchioness Georges de Cuevas. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. William F. Kenny Jr., Captain and Mrs. Percy Lawson-Johnston, Mr.

Wesleyan University has received from an anonymous donor 1,500 prints, valued at more than $250,000. The gift includes the salary of a curator of prints, and Gustave von Groschitz, a graduate of Columbia, has been appointed to the post.

More than 450 persons attended a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Astor marking the opening of the Greater New York campaign of the United Palestine Appeal, the $4,500,000 national campaign for the settlement in Palestine of Jews of Germany, Austria, Poland, Rumania and other lands.

General Prince'Maurizio Gonzaga, Marquess of Vodice and former Fascist militia commander, died today at the age of 77. Premier Benito Mussolini ordered a state funeral for the prince, who won three silver and two gold medals in the World War.

A further decline of $152,000,000 in holdings of direct obligations of the United States Government was reported for the week ended on Wednesday by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, in their condition statement issued yesterday.

Plans for erecting on the former Mali estate in Plainfield, N. J., houses for 176 families have been announced by Harry A. Taylor of Frank H. Taylor Son, brokers. The buildings, which will contain a total of 700 rooms,

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York is the largest bank in the English-speaking world, according to the annual list of the 150 largest American, British, colonial and dominion banks which is compiled by the California Bank, Los Angeles.
Although Northern New England has just experienced its first warm spell of the season there still were places to ski for those who want to keep at it and get a sunburn in the bargain.

The Yankees had a mild form of a workout today in the first of their family battles with the Newark Bears before a select crowd of 752 at Waterfront Park. For five innings the world champions' attack was comparatively quiet against their International League farm club.

Total sales of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company for the fiscal year ended March 1 were $884,000,000, compared with 1936 sales of $907,000,000, a decrease of 2 1/2 per cent, according to the preliminary estimate of operations, issued yesterday by the company.
Mrs. Charlotte Griffin Pangburn Farrington of Rensselaer, veteran employee of the fingerprint division of the State Correction Department, died today after a three-month illness. Her age was 45.

An urgent appeal to twenty-nine countries embracing most of the civilized world was made by the United States Government today for a cooperative. effort to facilitate the emigration of political refugees from Austria and Germany.

Robert R. Young, chairman of the Chesapeake Corporation, told stockholders today that the "fundamental issue" in the current fight for control of the railroad holding company is whether an "untried management" should be placed in charge of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway.

In an opinion handed down here this afternoon United States Judge Albert W. Johnson dismissed the petit tion filed on March 4 by six bondholders of the Hudson Coal Company, who asked that the company be reorganized under Section 77B of the Federal Bankruptcy Laws and that a trustee be appointed to manage its affairs.

Airtemp, Inc. subsidiary of Chrysler Corporation, is opening air-conditioning sales-training schools in twenty-eight cities. J. Labovitz Department Stores, Baltimore, Annapolis and Frederick, Md., is now represented by Ben F. Levis, Inc., resident buyers.
What is bad news to the groceryman is often good news to the housewife. Price-cutting is wider now than it has been for several years, food dealers report. This means-many "bargains" for shoppers.

Brokers yesterday reported a numof leasing transactions involving large units of space in various parts of the city. Gordon-Pew Fisheries, Ltd., of Gloucester, Mass., took the three lower floors in the warehouse building at 32 Beach Street, running through to 39 North Moore Street,

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended March 23 were announced today: COMMANDER Cairnes, G. W., promoted to captain (engineering). LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Perkins, L. W., promoted to commander. Kossler. W. J., Charleston, S. C., to Hall Aluminum Aircraft Corporation, Bristol, Pa., as inspector of Coast Guard aircraft.
Leading scores in the American Bowling Congress withstood another onslaught today as bowlers from the Atlantic to the Pacific failed to roll their way into championship consideration.

K. T. Keller, president of the Chrysler Corporation, announced yesterday that A. vanDerZee, who has long been vice president and general sales manager of the Dodge division of the corporation, had been appointed to the newly created position of vice president of the parent corporation in charge of sales development for both passenger cars and commercial vehicles.
Dr. Paul Leland Haworth died at his home here today at the age of 61. He was an orchardist, mountain climber, author and head of the history department at Butler University.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Hugh A. Laidlaw of New York and San Francisco of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Laidlaw, to Russell E. Pierce, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Bacon Pierce of this city.

Six thousand holders of $19,000,000 in notes against the Corporation Securities Company probably will divide $1,000,000, it was indicated today when Samuel Howard, trustee, sought Federal Judge Wilkerson's permission to pay a 5 per cent dividend.
Plans for modernizing houses in Yorkville and Harlem were announced yesterday when brokers reported sales of the properties.

Paul H. Smart's boat Melody, representing the Central Long Island Sound fleet, took the lead in the Spring championship series for the Santa Maria Trophy by winning today's opening contest in Montagu Bay. This is an International Star Class Yacht Racing Association event.

Young George Parsons, who has shuttled between the minor leagues and majors a half-dozen times this season, broke up the first game of the National Hockey League championship series tonight with a goal that gave the Maple Leafs a 1-0 overtime victory over the Boston Bruins.

The findings of the State Labor Relations Board on facts involved in industrial disputes are final and conclusive when supported by substantial evidence, it was held yesterday in decisions handed down by Supreme Court Justices Charles B. McLaughlin and Bernard L. Shientag.

David Low, Great Britain's irrepressible cartoonist, not only knows what British foreign policy is but has discovered where it comes from. He announced the result of his discovery in an Evening Standard cartoon, picturing a celebration at Cliveden. [the country estate of Viscount and Lady Astor] "to mark our leader's recent successes."
The tournament committee of the Indoor Polo Association added another night of play and completed the draw and schedule for the remaining indoor championships at its meeting yesterday.
Thirty-nine grandmothers, each active in business' or in a profession, have organized the Grandmothers Club, and as such they are out to prove that it is not exclusively a man's world.

Soviet purchases in this country last year reached the highest total for any similar period since 1930, according to a statement issued yesterday by D. A. Rosoff, chairman of the board of the Amtorg Trading Corporation, Russian trading representative here for the U.S.S.R. Mr. Rosoff said 1937 purchases here by Russia amounted to $75,000,000, compared with $35,000,000 the year before.

A 33 1/2 per cent increase in taxes and a large increase in operating expenses, due to enforced increases in wages, were the conspicuous features of the condensed annual report of the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad Company for 1937, made public yesterday by Matthew S. Sloan, president and chairman of the board.

A merger of the two leading telegraph communications companies operating in the United States was called for yesterday by two bondholders' protective committees engaged in the reorganization proceedings of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation.

In an effort to raise money and credits for purchases abroad during the present crisis, the Chinese Government has created a commission which is developing every possibility for exports, according to Julian Arnold, Commercial Attache of the United States Department of Commerce at Shanghai. Mr. Arnold spoke at the twenty-first annual convention of the American Brush Manufacturers Association in the Hotel Traymore today.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 22: COMMANDERS Perlman, B., 12th Naval District, to the San Francisco as executive officer. Smith, L. P., Battleships, Battle Force, to Bureau of Engineering, Washington, D. C., June 18. Berge, M. A., Med. Corps, the Cincinnati, to Naval Training Station, Great Lakes, Ill., in May or June.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changers, in francs:

Lee Pressman, general counsel for the Committee for Industrial Organization, testified before a Senate labor and education subcommittee today that an amendment suggested by the American Federation of Labor to the Wagner bill, guaranteeing collective bargaining on government contracts, would eliminate the effectiveness of the act.
ANDREWS, HELEN M. (April 4, 1937). Gross assets. $505,974: net; $469,814. To Carlisle Presbytery, Carlisle, Pa., dwelling and $5,000; Winfield Day Nursery,
