Dr. John A. Robinson, prominent otologist and 'honorary assistant senior surgeon at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, died yesterday morning at his home, 535 West End Avenue, after a twoweek illness, at the age of 63.
Royal Mail ruled one of the favorites under unusual circumstances tonight on the eve of the 100th running of the Grand National, generally regarded as the world's most difficult steeplechase.

The old Chesapeake and Ohio Canal, which according to legend was surveyed by George Washington, will be bought by the Federal Government and a part of it restored for recreational purposes, Secretary Ickes stated today. The canal runs 186 miles from Washington to Cumberland, Md.

A frank admission that Canada would depend for security in the Pacific on the presence of a friendly American fleet, just as it depended on the British fleet for the security of its Atlantic coasts, was made in Parliament today by the Dominion Minister of Defense, Ian Mackenzie.

The Legislature voted tonight to send Don C. Brown, a reporter for The Edmonton Journal, to jail "during the pleasure of the Assembly" because he wrote two paragraphs which were declared to be "scandalous misrepresentation."

The Senate decided today to vote on a proposal for a full inquiry into the Tennessee Valley Authority. It was believed likely that any investigation decided on would include private power companies in their relation with the TVA.

Directors of the Texas Pacific Railroad today elected V. J. Kurzweg of Plaquemine, La., and Joseph K. Walker of Shreveport, La., to the board. They succeeded George A. Tomlinson and John Sherwin Jr., both of Cleveland, who resigned.

The city lost a total of $127,000 by its failure to accept the lowest bid on a contract for electrical work in construction of the Independent subway in 1936, according to evidence produced yesterday in the injunction suit of electrical equipment manufacturers against Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.
All favorites advanced to the second round as the sixth annual metropolitan mixed doubles squash recquets championship got under way on the courts of the Heights Casino last night.

The concerted raids on race-track tip-sheet operations staged by United States Attorney Lamar Hardy with the cooperation of the Police Department resulted yesterday in the holding of sixty-eight men on charges of using the mails to defraud.

A definite increase in local community advertising in New York State will develop this year if counties take advantage of a bill passed by the Legislature and now awaiting the Governor's signature, it was pointed out in advertising circles yesterday.

Contending that decentralization of trading activity was in the public interest, Henry E. Tracy, secretary of the Boston Stock Exchange, appeared today at a public hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission to oppose an application by the Adams Express Company to withdraw its common stock from listing and registration on that Exchange.

Despite the fact that it is a long way off, New York State sportsmen will be interested to learn that a special six-day deer season is slated in five of the Southern counties, due to the great increase in deer herds.

William Eichorst, 34 years old, was sentenced, today to serve twenty to thirty years in prison for the slaying of Mrs. Emma Kumbartsky, 37, with whom he had been living at 153 Fourteenth Street, Hoboken.

Characterizing the European situation today as "immeasurably better and safer than it was a fortnight ago," Dr. H. H. Dieckhoff, German Ambassador to Washington, declared last night that the "Austrian cloud," which had been hanging. over Europe since the peace treaties of 1919, had disappeared definitely and without a thunderstorm.

Expressing his conviction that immediate launching of Federal, State and local housing drives will provide a market for furniture of proportions so large that both furniture factories and the "eighty or ninety other industries serving ours" will be revived, Nathan Sachs of Sachs Quality Furniture, Inc., issued a warning last night against too liberal credits which might tend to cause low-income families to take on obligations beyond their capacity to pay.

The addition of 800 actors, artists, musicians, writers and archivists to the rolls of the five WPA Federal Arts Projects in this city was authorized yesterday by the national heads of the Works Progress Administration.

UN CARNET DE BAL, written and directed by Julien Duvivier: dialogue by Henri Jeanson, Jean Sariment and Bernard Zimmer; music by Jaubert; produced by the Studio Francois I. in France; released by the A. F. E. Corporation.

Instead of attempting to teach twenty-four different subjects each week as is done at present, "with resulting inefficiency and unnecessary waste of time," the New York City elementary school division should revise its curriculum on the basis of four major categories, it was proposed yesterday.
After weeks of debate the Senate has now fixed Monday for a final vote on the Reorganization Bill, and in these circumstances it is essential to re-examine this important measure in its present form.

President Roosevelt's move through Secretary of State Hull to enlist twenty-nine nations in providing aid and asylum for political refugees from Austria, Germany and other European countries was hailed here yesterday by religious, charitable and relief organizations, Christian and Jewish, which pledged their cooperation.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's declaration of foreign policy in London has received a respectful hearing in German quarters. While early reaction reflects considerable reserve, it is far from unfriendly.
Mayor S. Davis Wilson, who has been insisting since last Summer that he would run for Governor this year, may become a rival of Governor Earle for the Democratic Senatorial nomination.

Black River, consistent 6-year-old sprinter representing Mrs. R. Sullivan, raced to his second score in a row when he defeated a field of $4,500 top and $4,000 bottom players in the six-furlong Daytona Purse today at Tropical Park.

Favorable weather conditions, the nearer approach of Easter, and special promotions aided retail trade here during the week. Apparel and accessory purchases moved at a somewhat faster pace than in recent weeks.

Claudia Morgan, daughter of Ralph Morgan, will return to the screen under the auspices of Metro. As soon as she abandons the role of the glamorous Wilda Doran in "Wine of Choice," she is to report at the studio which may feature her with her uncle, Frank Morgan.

Frank H. Robertson, a pioneer of American aviation and one of the backers of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh on his historic transatlantic flight in 1927, died today at the age of 42. He came to Arizona in ill health three years ago.
E. W. Judy of Pittsburgh, vice president and general manager of Duquesne Light Company, died last night after a heart attack in Vera Beach, Fla. He was 56 years old.

The New York alumni of Washington and Lee University held their annual dinner dance last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. The event was preceded by a reception in the Silver Room of the hotel.
The British Government told General Francisco Franco today that it was holding the Spanish Insurgent authorities responsible for the sinking of the British ship Endymion off Cartagena on Jan. 31.

State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $13,199,300, to be represented by one State and 130 municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $16,308,590 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $27,960,950.

Miss Evelyn Garnaut Smalley, social worker who received a decoration of the Legion of Honor for her bravery under fire in the World War, died yesterday in Pau, France, according to word received here.

Maintaining the high level of prices that prevailed on the two previous days eager buyers at Sotheby's today paid [Pound]8,631 and brought the sale of the late Mortimer L. Schiff's famous library to a close.

Today's major events: Three- "Hol Choir Festival, Temple Emanu-El, "Try 10:30 A. M.; National Orchestral Mr. Association, Carnegie Hall, after- ades, noon; Philharmonic - Symphony, phra: Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; Yale playS Glee Club, Town Hall, evening; conc] Katherine Bacon, pianist, Town pian( Hall, afternoon. Mr.

Senator Glass introduced in the Senate late today a bill which would restore to the RFC authority to make loans on self-liquidating projects to public bodies, make possible the lengthening of maturity on loans to industry and broaden Section 5D of the RFC Act so as to include in those industries to which loans may be made any business enterprise.

Francis George Lawder Bertram, air mail pioneer and for many years Deputy Director of Civil Aviation, died today at the age of 62. Mr. Bertram, once a mathematical lecturer, assisted the late Sir Sefton Brancker in the original survey of empire air routes.

Senator Josiah W. Bailey of North Carolina, one of the leading conservative Democrats in Congress, in an address yesterday at the semiannual meeting of the Academy of Political Science, urged repeal of the undivided profits and capital gains taxes,

The National Piano Manufacturers Association announced today that a census indicated there are 5,865,296 pianos in active use in the United States. It was found that 53.4 per cent of American families in the higher income brackets own pianos.

The pamphlet report of the United Gas Improvement Company and subsidiaries for 1937 shows a consolidated net income of $29,105,379, equal after preferred dividends to $1.087 a share on 23,262,010 common shares, as compared to $29,116,226, or $1.088 a share, in 1936.

The story of Philip Davis's aching feet and lack of a seat on a train trip here from Albany, which has been in the courts periodically for nearly two years, ended yesterday in a victory for the embattled lawyer.

MATTISON, MARY DALE (June 20, 1935). Gross assets, $44,675; net, $41,692. To Mary Mattison Van Schaik, Graham D. Mattison,- Everitt Mattison and Katherine Mattison, children, personal effects, life estate in one-fourth residue each and contingent remainders in three trusts each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $22,557. White Case. attorneys. 14 Wall St.

Trading in steer hinds and ribs and fresh pork cuts active, other classes slow. Steer hinds and ribs were strong to higher and other classes mostly steady with Thursday. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef and lamb to be higher, veal uneven, mostly steady, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

On the steamer deck, that moving sidewalk that connects and separates two worlds, the homecoming traveler looks back upon five months spent shuttling back and forth among the crises and alarms of Europe and tries to sort out the conglomerate impressions stamped upon one's reeling brain.

Trading by members for their own accounts on the New York Stock Exchange was 20.51 per cent of the total volume in the week ended on Feb. 26, compared with 20.97 per cent in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. Total volume was 4,337,180 shares sold, compared with 3,572,370.
Stocks lost 1 to 5 points, scoring new lows since 1934; turnover, 1,677,340 shares, second largest trading of year. Bonds generally lower, rails lowest in six years; transactions, $7,468,650.

Nearly $300,000 remains from profits of wartime canteens and the sale of the army newspaper, Stars and Stripes, it was disclosed today in a Congressional proposal to divide the money among three organizations.

Privately financed building construction contracts in Northern Jersey in February, with a total of $1,812,000, equaled the January figure for the same type of work, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.

Virginio Gayda today devotes six of the eight columns of the front page of the Giornale d'Italia to an editorial in which he seeks to prove that the resistance to Generalissimo Francisco Franco in Spain is being kept alive only by French and Russian aid.
Daniel J. Keleher, for twenty-six years engineer of the Pennsylvania Railroad's Congressional Limited, died today at the Jersey City Medical Center after a brief illness. His age was 63.

Another consignment of gold, $588,000, has been engaged in England for shipment to this country, it was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This made the total of gold engaged abroad for shipment here since March 15 $25,700,000, of which $15,100,000 has been taken in England.

American Equitable Assurance Company-As of Dec. 31: Total admitted assets, $8,904,679, compared with $13,633,693 at end of 1936; premiums earned, $4,107,438 against $3,806,232; surplus, $2,709,739, compared with $6,263,703; unearned premiums, $4,430,055, against $4,167,427.

Value of retail sales of new passenger automobiles increased substantially in February as compared with January, the Department of Commerce reported today. The adjusted index, which makes allowances for the number of days as well as for seasonal movements, it stated, was 74 in February on the basis of the 1929-1931 average as 100, compared with 65 in January and 78 in December.

The Indians defeated the Atmenties 7--1, today, amassing fifteen hits while Mel Harder, Denny Galehouse and Al Milnar were holding the Mackmen to three. The Indians started scoring in the first, when Campbell's triple brought in Lary and Weatherly, and Trosky's single scored Campbell.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 19 amounted to 540,332 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 16,332 cars, or 2.9 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week;

Judge James Austin Jr., who served for forty years in civic and judicial capacities, died in his home today after a long illness. He was 81 years old. At various times he was justice of the peace, police judge, Common Pleas Court judge and was the first judge of the Domestic Relations Court in Lucas County.
Pensioned women teachers in New York live longer than expected, though not, of course. longer than desired.

By unanimous adoption of a resolution tonight, the Alberta Legislature released Don C. Brown, reporter' of The Edmonton Journal, from charges of "scandalous misrepresentation" of statements by Dr. J. L. Robinson, a Social Credit member, and breach of the privileges of the House.
Full realization of the gravity of the crisis in Czechoslovakia and a determination to solve it fairly were expressed by Premier Milan Hodza in an interview today.

Before a capacity gathering of 16,000 the figure skating carnival for the benefit of the Bellevue Hospital Social Relief Service and Carroll Club was presented for the second time at Madison Square Garden last night.

Field Marshal Hermann Goering arrived today for a ten-day tour of Austrian provinces, during which he will speak and study economic conditions, with special reference to the German Four-Year Plan. He was accompanied by Economics Minister Walther Funk, army and air force officers, secretaries and military aides.

Funeral services for Dr. Daniel Webster Hering, senior member of the faculty of New York University, who died Thursday, one day after his eighty-eighth birthday, will be held at 2:30 P. M. tomorrow in the University Heights Presbyterian Church, University Avenue and Hall of Fame Terrace, the Bronx.
The Coast Guard predicted today that 1938 would be a nearly normal year on the North Atlantic Ocean and that shipping would have to dodge not more than about 500 icebergs.

By HENRY BRADY Broadway, 2,160; 4-story offices and stores, 26.4x83xirreg; Seamen's Bank for Savings against 2,160 Broadway Corp; due $152,678; to plaintiff for $100,000. By THOMAS F. BURCHILL 63d St, 33 W; 5-story tenement, 37.6x100.5; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank against Mary E. Kenney; due $45,363; taxes, etc., $124; to plaintiff for $1,000.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are March 25, unless specified: At Shanghai: Edsall, March 24; Oahu, March 14. Acushnet, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk.
Richard Kriese of Buffalo, N. Y., carried his partner, Sam Vanini, into the doubles lead in the American Bowling Congress tonight. They scored 1,322, topping the best previous figure by 30 pins.

Benjamin Welles 2d, 21, a Harvard student and son of Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, was convicted today of driving an automobile dangerously and fined $75. He appealed. Mr. Welles was acquitted of knowingly leaving the scene of an accident. David L.

The French liner Normandie, now en route to New York after a long delay off Southampton Harbor in a thick fog, will arrive on Tuesday morning, a day behind her schedule, officials of the company announced yesterday.

A mortgage for $525,000 on the apartment building on the northeast corner of Amsterdam Ave and 120th St held by Sterling National Bank Trust Co, as trustee, from the Edmund Francis Court Corp, Herbert L. Williams, president, was extended to March 1, 1943, the mortgagee waiving all claim to due and unpaid interest prior to March 1, 1938.

New freight cars on order on March 1 numbered 5,568, compared with 6,563 on Feb. and 42,212 on March 1, 1937, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday. In the first two months of this year 3,478 new cars were installed in service, against 6,135 in the similar period a year ago.

Miss Helen Elizabeth Van Cleaf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Conover Van Cleaf of this place, was married here tonight to Walter Crawford Bachman, son of Mrs. C. E. Bachman of Nazareth, Pa., and the late Mr. Bachman, at the Maplewood Country Club.

A tract of sixty-five acres, which contains the eighteen-acre Jesters' Lake, in Milton, Morris County, N. J., has been purchased by Margaret V. Merner of Clifton from the Hillcrest Building and Loan Association. Connolly Connolly were the brokers.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 1,203,000 bales, against 1,214,000 a week ago, 1,203,000 two weeks ago, 1,209,000 three weeks ago and 969,000 a year ago; of which American 794,000 bales, against 789,000 a week ago, 794,000 two weeks ago, 781,000 three weeks ago and 423,000 a year ago.

In an action coupled to some extent with the movement for investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority, the House Rivers and Harbors Committee today rejected President Roosevelt's program for six other regional power development and

The First Baptist Church in Shaker Heights was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Mary Adelle Eaton and Dr. Fay Atkinson LeFevre, with the pastor, the Rev. Harold C. Phillips, performing the ceremony.

Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Halpern of 245 West 107th Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Selma Cynthia Halpern, to Abraham Abbott Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Friedman, also of this city.
The Most Rev. Bartholomew J. Eustace, for twenty-two years a professor at St. Joseph's Theological Seminary, Dunwoodie, N. Y., was elevated yesterday to the rank of Bishop at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Two floors in the Silversmith Building, 15 Maiden Lane, have been leased by the Schultheis Art Gallery, which has been fifty years in the downtown area. The gallery also leased the store at 168 Water Street for store-room purposes.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 23: CAPTAIN Boone, J. T., Med. Corps, San Diego, Calif., to Asiatic station, in May.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the Baltimore Ohio Railroad to use $2,233,000 of a loan of $8,233,000 obtained from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for maintenance payrolls in March and April.

Direct White House action to insure passage of the Byrnes Reorganization Bill by means of private assurances to interested groups came today as Administration leaders carried on a cloakroom campaign for votes.

The Guardian Loan Company, 131 West Fortysecond Street, New York, has filed an application to transact business as a licensed lender at 160 West Thirty-fourth Street, the State Banking Department's weekly bulletin announced today.

Collective action for security and to make armed aggression more difficult was approved today over neutrality without distinction between aggressor and aggrieved nations in a plenary round-table session of the Conference on World Economic Cooperation convened here this week by the National Peace Conference.

Battleship, an 11-year-old son of Man o' War from Quarantaine, is well known in this country as one of the best horses to be raced through the field in recent years. He was bred in Kentucky by Walter J. Salmon and raced for him on the flat during his 2, 3 and 4-yearold seasons.

Turpentine firm 24c; sales 227 barrels; receipts 250 barrels; shipments 130 barrels; stock 22.728 barrels. Resin firm; sales 708; receipts 565; shipments 15; stock 64,199. Quote: B. $3.50; D, $3.80; E, $4.00; F, $4.75; G, H. I, K, $4.871/2; M, $5.00; N, $5.20; WG, $5.90; WW and X, $6.50.

In winning a divorce today Claire Dodd, film actress, reversed the old story of the tired husband who comes home at night to a wife who wants to dress up and go places. Miss Dodd said she often came home tired from the studio and her husband, Jack Milton Strauss, real estate broker, wanted to step out.
Walter Kramer of Detroit, the defending champion, and William Markham of New York tonight advanced into the final of the men's singles in the national badminton championships.
Each day the need for a comprehensive program to meet the problems brought about by the constantly mounting number of refugees from Germany and Austria becomes more urgent.
A Novosibirsk newspaper reaching Moscow today reported that eleven confessed wreckers of a Siberian railway and coal mines had been sentenced to death in two trials.

In a political atmosphere that is becoming every day more tense, with nearly 25,000 strikers in the Paris district and the Citroen factories still occupied by strikers, Premier Leon Blum accepted this afternoon the rebuff administered by the Senate yesterday

The intercollegiate indoor polo championship will open on two fronts tonight. With games also scheduled for tomorrow, Wednesday and Thursday and the following Saturday and Sunday, titles will be decided in the college play and in the three divisions of the club championships.

The will of Dr. Norman P. Geis, gynecologist, of Greenwich, was admitted to probate here by Judge Harold L. Knapp today. Dr. Geis died Feb. 5, leaving real estate in excess of $10,000, according to the petition.

Implementing its order of March 12 that member firms of the New York Stock Exchange must make available to customers information relative to their financial condition, the business conduct committee of that institution prescribed yesterday a condensed form of financial statement which may be used.

Mr. and Mrs. Chester Dale of New York recently have added to their well known collection of modern art a painting by Cezanne. The acquisition is announced in the annual supplement of The Art News published today.
United States exports in February were 13 per cent greater than in February, 1937, while imports decreased 41 per cent, the Department of Commerce said today in its monthly foreign trade summary.

Funeral services were held last evening by Brooklyn Lodge of Elks for Dr. Philip Henry Berlenbach of 87-69 109th Street, Richmond Hill, who died in Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, on Wednesday evening at the age of 73.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Adams Ashforth entertained at dinner in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Honour Dickerman and her fiance, James Oliver Brown, and for Miss Mary Anne Vietor and George Draper Arthur Jr., whose engagement has also been announced. Other guests were Mr.
Announcement is expected today of the merger of the New York Stock Exchange firms of Winthrop, Mitchell Co. and Harriman Keech, to be consummated within three weeks.

Complete coverage of a particular market was believed by more than one-third of 338 space buyers and advertising managers to be the one outstanding point of superiority of newspaper advertising over other media, according to a study just completed by the Ross Federal Research Corporation. Of 338 executives queried, 119, or 35.21 per cent, rated coverage as the most important factor.

Colonel Bill Terry, the hard-riding taskmaster, became the easy-going professor today when he decided to give practically his entire varsity squad the day off to fish, play golf or follow any other recreational pursuits that appealed to them.

Assurances were given to the United States tonight by the Japanese Government that it would stop its vessels from salmon fishing in Alaskan waters, thus concluding a year of active diplomatic negotiations over an issue that had intensely aroused the Pacific Coast.

A painting of the coronation of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth--a gift from Canada, Australia, New Zealand and South Africawas presented at Buckingham Palace today by the High Commissioners of the Dominions, acting for their respective Prime Ministers.

The Senate Finance Committee today completed its revision of major sections of the House's revenue bill by eliminating proposed new estate and gift taxes and restoring those which have been in effect since 1932. Governor Lehman of New York had protested that the new schedules were a threatening invasion by the Federal Government of the States' revenue field.

Victor Ghezzi, hard-hitting Deal (N. J.) professional, today won his first golf tournament of the year when he bagged the thirty-sixth annual North and South open with a seventy-two-hole score of 279, three strokes over the record set by Paul Runyan of White Plains, N. Y., 1935 victor.

Little Neck Investors, Inc., have purchased, through Bryce Rea, broker, the four-story apartment house on the southwest corner of Roosevelt Avenue and Parsons Boulevard, Flushing. There are 165 rooms in the house, divided into forty apartments, all of which are occupied, it is reported.

Prentice Brady will be dissolved on April 1 instead of March 25, as previously announced. Robertson Georgeson will be dissolved on April 1. On that date Cohu Brothers propose to admit Lloyd W. Georgeson, Henry Evans Gray and C. Edwin Warner and to change the firm name to Cohu Brothers Georgeson.

Manhattan Alterations 80th St, 306 E; to 4-story tenement; Minnie Ohmer, 315 E 74th St, owner; J. Bleich, architect; cost, $6,000. 9th Ave, 709; to 5-story tenement and stores; Lester Harrison, as successor trustee, 225 Broadway, owner; C. F. Mink, architect; cost, $4,500. 115th St, 442 E: to 5-story tenement and stores; Frank T. D'Onofrio, 545 5th Ave. owner; T. R. Feinberg, architect; cost, $3,000.

Exports of crude petroleum from the United States last year established a new high record of 67,179,000 barrels, the metals and minerals division of the Department of Commerce has reported. These exports were 33.5 percent above 1936 and 154.5 per cent greater than in 1929.

William A. Magee, twice Mayor of Pittsburgh, former member of the Pennsylvania Public Service Commission, former State Senator, and twice a Councilman, died today of pneumonia in West Penn Hospital. He would have been 65 years old on May 4.

Mrs. Henry S. Morgan of New York would not discuss today the forced landing of her plane last night near Manati, about thirty miles short of the Pan American airport, for which the plane was presumably heading.

Meeting of the Association of Social Studies Teachers of the City of New York in The Herald Tribune Building Auditorium, 230 West Fortyfirst Street, 10:30 A. M. "Measurement of Public Opinion," Dr. George Gallup and Dr. Clyde B. Miller.

Major John Charles James Hoby, British Army bandmaster, died today at the age of 69. Like Sousa, he was a fertile composer of inspiring marches and in 1925 succeeded in massing almost all the first-class army bands in the Wembley Exhibition stadium.

Directors of Bloomingdale Brotl ers, Inc., yesterday voted a dividen of 18 3/4 cents to its common stock holders, payable on April 25 to stock of record of April 15. A year ago dividend of 37 1/2 cents was disbursed.

Results of a series of traffic tests made in New York during the past week as a part of the National Safety Campaign of the Elks were broadcast last night from an automobile parked in Times Square, while a dozen traffic policemen held back 200 puzzled pedestrians.
Further evidence tending to support the charge that German warships help convoy troops and war material for Generalissimo Francisco Franco was presented by the Barcelona War Ministry today.

Captain Andre Morton Proctor, United States Navy, retired, of the Hotel Windsor, veteran of the Spanish-American and World Wars, died on Thursday of a heart ailment at the Brooklyn Naval Hospital after a short illness. His age was 64.

Sir Hubert Wilkins and his pilot, Herbert Hollick-Kenyon, who left New York last November to search the Arctic region for Sigismund Levanevsky and five Russian companions lost while on a flight to the United States, landed soon after 6:30 o'clock last night at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn.

The State Legislature adjourned without action on the much-discussed proposals For "tapering off" the moratorium on mortgage foreclosures, and left the layman in a rather confused state of mind as to what was accomplished on the moratorium extension and deficiency judgment measures.

Bishop Thomas C. O'Reilly, head of the Scranton (Pa.) Catholic Diocese, died tonight of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 65 years old. Stricken this morning, Bishop O'Reilly. grew steadily weaker through the day.
One of these days we're going to have a long talk with Jack Brawley, another rod and gun writer, and try to discover just what methods he uses to escape his jinx.

H. G. Christie's Phillippi Junior won the Seagram Cup race today at Montagu Park. The winner carried 115 pounds. Star Marie, owned by the Bahamian Club Stables, ran second, with the Hon. R. G. Collins's Blue Cloud third.

Brlggs Ave (12-3298), secor of 201st St, 100x70; Olos Corp to Manufacturers Trust Co: one year, 6 per cent; $97,500. Grant Ave (9-2444), e s, 55 ft s of 162d St, 59x105; Zelmor Realty Co to State Mortgage Commission; extends mtg to March 24, 1943, at 4 to 41/2 per cent; $36,500.

Virtual completion of plans for the sale of the Hearst Radio Station WINS, New York, for $250,000 to Colonel Arthur O'Brien, Seattle lawyer, was confirmed yesterday by Joseph V. Connolly, chairman of the board of Hearst Radio, Inc.
The Wheeler-Lea act, just signed by the President, is designed to clarify and implement the Federal Trade Commission Act passed in 1914. It consists of two main parts.

The daily double at the Aintree race track today paid the fabulous sum of [Pound]5,062 ($25,310) for a ten-shilling ($2.50) ticket. Only one man, whose name was not made public, bought a ticket coupling Battleship, winner of the Grand National, and Barbadeche, who won the Bickerstaffe plate on the same program.

It is estimated that nearly 25,000 Polish Jews in Austria may be deprived of Polish citizenship under a law that the Sejm (Parliament) voted today. The measure was submitted by the government immediately after the annexation of Austria by Germany.
Facsimiles of the ballots to be employed in the coming plebiscite appeared here today. The ballot carries the heading: "Plebiscite and Greater German Reichstag."

The oldest school house in Newark, built here more than 150 years ago, was dedicated this afternoon in the Newark Museum garden. The one-room, brownstone building formerly stood at the corner of Elizabeth and Chancellor Avenues.

Ogden H. Hammond, United States Ambassador to Spain from 1925 to 1929, in an address here tonight predicted victory for General Franco and declared the Rebel leader would let the Spanish people decide what kind of government they wanted after he had established law and order.

Is a Mexican divorce valid in the case of an American residing in France? Mrs. Enrique de Paats, the former Gertrude Grace Rothschild of New York, is requesting the Paris civil tribunal to set aside the "in absentia" divorce decree that her husband,

Prices of listed bonds were scaled down to their lowest levels in five and six years yesterday as a result of the decline in domestic corporate issues continuing unabated against little or no resistance.
Colonel Jake Ruppert's freshman squad squared accounts with the varsity today, to the intense delight of some 700 natives.

The document offered for probate as the last will and testament of Miss Louisa Herle, 79-year-old recluse in Brooklyn, who died on Oct. 30, 1934, leaving an estate valued at more than $1,000,000 in cash and mortgage bonds, was rejected yesterday by Kings County Surrogate George Albert Wingate with the observation that the witnesses of the document "are unworthy of any belief at all."

The typewritten manuscript of Van Wyck Brooks's "Flowering of New England," autographed and with hand - written corrections, brought $800 last night at an auction sale of manuscripts and letters of leading writers, arranged by the League of American Writers for the benefit of the Medical Bureau of the North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy.

Mexico today seriously considered selling part of her oil production to Japan as the need for outside markets became increasingly imperative. The government was forced to draw on the Bank of Mexico for money to pay 18,000 oil workers tomorrow after six days' operation of plants expropriated from American and British companies.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: In reply to a recent article printed in THE TIMES, headed "Park Recreation Planned for All," I would like to ask "What has the Park Department done for cycling?"

Alfred S. Nichols, vice president and general manager of the Jamaica Public Service Company, Ltd., Kingston, Jamaica, B. W. I., died Thursday night at Doctors Hospital after a three-year illness. His age was 58.

A unique method of floodwater dam control characterized as "upside down" harnessing of waters which meet at different stream junctions was described by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company here today.
Seventy-seven per cent of the 336 students of Hamilton College participating in a recent poll said they would not participate in a war abroad.

De La Salle Institute's basketball team, rallied in the second half to score a surprise 25-to-22 victory over Power Memorial Academy last night in the final of the metropolitan Catholic high schools invitation tourney at the Columbus Council, K. of C.,in Brooklyn.
Battleship, a son of Man o' War, owned by Mrs. Marion Scott of Montpelier, Va., won the 100th Grand National Steeplechase today by a scant head and paid 40 to 1and slightly better in the mutuels.

Record-breaking is getting to be quite a habit with the great Princeton medley relay team. The swift-moving, sons of Old Nassau again cracked the American mark for the 300-yard distance tonight in the Rutgers University pool at the National Collegiate A. A. swimming championships.

ALRICH --Herbert Ware, suddenly, at Syracuse, N. Y., March 25: beloved husband of Jessie V. C., father of Mrs. Herberta Dempewolff, D. Clinton Alrich and Mrs. Jessie C. Regelmann. Services at the Chapel of the Intercession, Broadway and 155th St., New York City, Monday, 2 P. M.

Chancellor Hitler delivered his first speech in the plebiscite campaign here tonight in a distinctly threatening tone, warning again that the Reich was going to watch over the fate of Germans on the other side of its frontiers and act again if he thinks it necessary.

William Green told the House Labor Subcommittee on Wages and Hours today that he believed the American Federation of Labor would support a 30-cents-an-hour wage minimum, if coupled with a plan for mandatory annual increases until a 40-cent minimum is reached for all workers in interstate commerce.
Scribners are rushing through their presses Stark Young's new translation of "The Sea Gull," by Chekov. The play will be produced shortly by the Theatre Guild with the Lunts in the leading roles.

The marriage of Miss Eloise Fuller, daughter of Mrs. Z. Preston Fuller and the late Dr. Fuller, to Professor Francisco S. Cespedes of Panama City, took place here at noon today at the home of her mother. The Rev. Frank M. Kerr performed the ceremony.

Plans were announced yesterday for a six-story apartment house to occupy the former site of All Souls Church, at the southeast corner of Fourth Avenue and Twentieth Street, which has just been purchased from the church by Samuel Barkin Sons, builders.

Miss Emily Fuller of Bethlehem, Pa., and Miss Dolores Kuenz of St. Louis tonight won the women's national doubles table tennis championship by defeating Miss Sylvia Maisel of Buffalo and Miss Helen Ovenden, Chicago, 21-10, 21-15, 21-11.

Henry Goelet, operator, has purchased from the Bronx Trustees the five-and-a-half-story apartment house for thirty-eight families at 2,133 Daly Avenue, northwest corner of 181st Street, the Bronx. He bought it subject to a new first mortgage of $94,500 at 4% per cent. Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., were the brokers.

Crippled though they may be, the New York Rangers are confident that they will take the measure of their city rivals, the New York Americans, when the teams collide in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night. The game will be the third and deciding one in the playoffs between the opposing sextets, who finished in second place in their respective groups of the National Hockey League.
The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The interest in wool has continued rather light but the trade may possibly be a bit more optimistic. Trading has been limited with prices steady.

Long drives and sure putts brought victory today to Miss Helen Dettweiler of Washington, D. C., in the final of the eighth annual Augusta's women's open golf tournament. She defeated Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R. I., 3 and 2, in the scheduled 18-hole round. Miss Bauer, 1934 winner here, was troubled with hooks and slices and was unsteady on the greens.

Allerton Ave (16-4508), n w cor White Plains Rd, 100x100; Tremont Improvement Corp to W. P. Realty Corp, 1,615 Grand Ave. 147th St, 546 E (9-2273); The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to E. B. L. Realty Co, Inc, 105 W 40th St. Waring Ave (16-4369), s s, 100 e of Yates Ave, 35x100; Angel Pizzuto to Esplanade Construction Corp, 368 E 149th St.
Bequests of $40,000 to twelve institutions are made in the will of Mrs. Libbie Y. Grant, probated in Surrogate's Court today.
Premier Mussolini promised tonight to safeguard the interests of Trieste, former Austrian seaport, which has been alarmed by economic difficulties growing out of the union of Austria and Germany.

Harry S. Nye Jr.'s Gale of the Southern Lake Michigan fleet today won the second race of the international Star Class sloops for the Johnnie Walker Trophy, defeating the second craft to finish, Stanley Ogilvy's Jay of Western Long Island Sound, by 4 minutes and 6 seconds over nine miles.

George Whitney, partner of J. P. Morgan Co., was questioned yesterday afternoon by the Securities and Exchange Commission concerning the failure of his brother, Richard, and the brokerage firm of Richard Whitney Co., which he headed.

Lewis H. Brown, president of the Johns-Manville Corporation, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders that, while he hesitated to make predictions, he believed the dividend would be reduced this year in line with present economic conditions.

The nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the receipt of fourteen additional suggestions for members of the board of governors, to be elected on May 9, bringing the total of such suggestions to 230, in addition to seven suggestions for chairman of the board. Edwin G.

Daily average sales of general merchandise in small towns and rural areas for February increased in all regions but the Far West, as compared with January, although the changes were less than the usual seasonal amount, the Department of Commerce reported today.

A banking group composed of the First Boston Corporation, Brown, Harriman Co., Inc., and F. S. Moseley Co., won yesterday the award of $5,000,000 of short-term notes of the city of Boston at 0.97 per cent, plus a premium of $63.

Two freshmen hurled the Dodgers to a 4-2 victory over the Reds today and ran the Flatbush winning streak in the grapefruit circuit to three games, putting Brooklyn over the .500 mark for the first time.

The Senate adopted the Barkley resolution for a TVA inquiry by a joint Congressional committee of ten, approved the nomination of Nellie Tayloe Ross as Director of the Mint and recessed at 5:51 P. M. until noon Monday.

Graham Shiels Hlislop, Tormer merchant here, died this morning at Home Memorial Hospital. He was 55 years old. A native of this city, Mr. Hislop was born June 15, 1882, the son of James Hislon and Annie M. Hislop.

Far-flung Chinese aerial activity featured the warfare along the North China front today. One Chinese squadron bombed Japanese positions at Lingeheng, on the Tientsin-Pukow Railway, in Shantung Province.

Final allotment of championship regatta dates of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound was made last night at the general meeting held in the Yale Club. There were several changes from the tentative schedule.

Many pastors will devote parts of their sermons tomorrow to a discussion of the world affairs and urge non-participation by the United States in the international disputes. Tomorrow, the fourth Sunday in Lent in the ritualistic calendar, is known as Laetare Sunday.

Favorites continued to advance as all but one match was completed in the first round of the sixth annual metropolitan squash racquets mixed doubles championship on the courts of the Heights Casino last night.

Singing Sam Breadon, owner of the St. Louis Cardinals, has shoved off for the North. Between the Gas House Gang and Judge Landis, Singing Sam said, somewhat in a daze, that he had a fine time. But he limped a little as he walked toward hi car.

North American wheat markets were firm at the start but easier at the close today. They advanced around three-quarters cent a bushel early in sympathy with Liverpool and the independent strength in corn, only to weaken toward the last, when securities declined sharply, and closing trades were at the lows with net losses at 7/8 to 1 cent.

Two favorites, the rangy St. Xavier team of Louisville, Ky., and Fenwick's defending champion from Oak Park, Ill., today led the way into the third round of the 1938 national Catholic scholastic basketball championship.

Department store saves in week ended March 19 were about 16 per cent smaller than in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board said today. The board attributed part of the decrease to the fact that Easter occurs three weeks later this year than it did last year.

Congress has unquestioned power over the Port of New York Authority and thus the salaries of the Authority officials are subject to a Federal income tax, Robert H. Jackson, the Solicitor General, asserted to the Supreme Court today.
Although most of Europe found something to praise in Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's speech of yesterday it was denounced in scathing terms today by the united Labor movement of Great Britain.
Lemuel B. Churchill Sr., head of a shirt manufacturing company bearing his name here for many years, died this morning at the Alexian Brothers Hospital following a long illness. He was 76 years old.

Cotton-mill activity eased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index receded to 90.1 from 91.6, the revised figure for the previous week. For the week ended March 20, 1937, the figure was 137.9.

Six Japanese fishermen arrested by marine authorities in the Bay of Jiquilisco were released today, according to the Diario de Hoy. They were held pending investigation of their presence in the bay without permission.

A slight decline in the volume of traffic using the Lincoln Tunnel betweer Weehawken and New York was reported yesterday by the Port of New York Authority. A daily average of 4,684 vehicles used the tunnel during the last seven days as compared with 4,881 for the last reported seven-day period.

A general survey of the entire millinery industry will start next week when the women's division of the United States Department of Labor begins a study of conditions in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut areas.

Following is a summary of a statement made on Nov. 22 by the American Government to the Japanese Government in connection with the Alaska salmon fishery situation and given out tonight by the State Department:

The Federal Trade Commission appealed to the Supreme Court today to uphold a 1933 order against Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, prohibiting price discrimination in the sale of tires to Sears Roebuck Co.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday a new set of regulations, effective April 15, designed to carry out Mayor La Guardia's recently announced plan to require interstate buses to take on and dischargepassengers only at designated bus terminals and other stops on allotted routes.

A symposium on "Art and the f Problem Child" will be held this afternoon at 2:30 o'clock at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street. It is presented in conjunction with the exhibition of paintings by children of the Hawthorne-Cedar Knolls School. The speakers will be Dr. Bertram Pollens, Jacob Panken and Dr. J. M. Papurt.

Southwood was the setting for a dinner dance given by Mrs. Woodward Vietor for her house guests, the Hon. and Mrs. Patrick Herbert Bellew and Mr. and Mrs. Errol Flynn. Tables were placed around the pool in the patio overlooking the lake.

New York, pioneer in reforestation work, will set out 13,000,000 trees on 15,000 acres throughout the State in an intensive Spring planting program to begin April 15. Members of the Civilian Conservation Corps will supply the labor.

The stock markets here today reacted favorably to the speech of Prime Minister Chamberlain yesterday, and although business was on a small scale, most sections improved. Gilt-edged issues were in demand, although in some cases the full gains were not held.

BERETS, CARL H. (Feb. 28). Estate, more than $10,000. To Evelyn L. Berets, widow, executrix, 440 West End Ave., household, personal effects and life estate in residue; Donald J. Berets, son, same address, remainder in residue. Commercial National Bank and Trust Co., 56 William St., executor.
Mendel L. Smith, son of the late Judge Mendel Smith, has started suit in Circuit Court at Columbia against Alvin E. Ivie of Brooklyn, an executive of the F. W. Woolworth Company, for $100,000.

Mr. and Mrs. John Barry Ryan have come to the Ritz Tower from their Winter home in Palm Beach. Dr.. and Mrs. John A. Vietor of the Matchbox, Oyster Bay, are at the Vanderbilt. Commander and Mrs. Delavan B. Downer of Washington are at the Delmonico.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson, rabbi of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, will be 60 years old today. The front page of The Bulletin, official weekly leaflet of the temple, announces its rabbi's birthday in a box at the bottom of the page, saying:

President Roosevelt, in an interview with correspondents, held out the United States as a refuge for oppressed and persecuted persons from all nations. He said that this country had no intention of revising its immigration quotas.

Because they said they were "embarrassed and nervously upset" by the presence of a recording machine in the examining room, ten candidates who failed in the oral tests for licenses as first assistants in modern languages are to get further tests, Dr. Joseph K. Van Denburg announced yesterday.

Mrs. DeWitt Knox has refused renomination for the presidency of the Women's Board of Foreign Missions of the Reformed Church in America, the headquarters of which are at 25 East Twenty-second Street, this city.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had: PATENTS 3871-Ex parte Louis J. Eppinger; 3897-Ex parte Charles L. Hall; and 3989-Mishawaka Rubber Woolen Mfg. Co. v. Bradstone Rubber Co. Petitions of appellants for rehearing denied. 3865-The Bon Ami Co. v. McKesson Robbins, Inc. Petition of appellee for rehearing denied.

Bearishness was the keynote in the live hog and cattle market today, unsatisfactory wholesale dressed meat markets suggesting further declines in these branches unless receipts of live cattle and hogs show some contraction, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. The trend in fat lamb prices reversed itself today, the market being fairly active and somewhat higher.
The United States liner President Roosevelt, arriving today from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh, has on board Paul Muni, returning with his wife after an extended foreign tour; Lieut. Comdr.
The Reichsbank's statement as of March 23 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

The proposal to place a tax upon commercial bank deposits here is another example of taxation which is likely to have consequences beyond the mere question of revenue. The outstanding examples of such taxation are, of course, the capitalgains tax and the undistributedprofits tax. Precisely how a tax on bank deposits in New York would work, it is not possible to say.

The Department of Akershus, Norway, has announced through Brown Brothers Harriman Co., fiscal agents, that it will redeem at par on May 1 all its outstanding thirty-five-year 5 per cent bonds due in 1963.
The American Federation of Labor today approved the plan of the government to facilitate the emigration of political refugees from Austria and Germany.

In a decision handed down yesterday Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo allowed attorneys and other representatives of bondholders and other creditors a total of $103,235 for their services in connection with the financial reorganization of the Hotel Drake at Fiftysixth Street and Park Avenue Fees
Oklahoma A. and M.'s chances of retaining its national collegiate wrestling championship were reduced tonight and rested on four men as Princeton, with three spectacular triumphs, came to the fore.
Ben Schlossberg, Inc., was the broker in the recent sale of the Hoboken waterfront property by the Lackawanna Railroad to the General Foods Corporation.

Without the formality of a roll-call and with only a few scattering "no's," the Senate today adopted a resolution providing for a joint Congressional investigation into the Tennessee Valley Authority. House approval is expected early next week.

This correspondent today received a second and final order of expulsion from Austria and from Germany. The first order was issued exactly a week ago but was rescinded on the following day on the understanding that no objection would be taken to his reporting fully any incidents he might witness or could verify,

Government aid to approximately 4,000,000 farmers who participated in the 1936 agricultural conservation program totaled $398,280,333, including national, State and county administrative costs, the AAA announced today.

Dr. James Ewing, director of Memorial Hospital and dean of America's cancer authorities, declared last night that "some new methods of approach must be found if any substantial results are to be achieved." He was the principal speaker at the dinner at the Hotel Ambassador in celebration of the twenty -fifth anniversary of the founding of the American Society for the Control of Cancer.

Registration statements covering securities with gross proceeds of $206,698,000 became effective in February under the Securities Act of 1933, compared to $78,838,000 in January, the SEC reported today.

Inquiries from many foreign countries for the purchase of American-made merchandise, ranging from bird cages to heavy industrial machinery, have been reported by American Government representatives abroad and further information may be obtained by application to its Bureau of Domestic and Foreign Commerce here, the Commerce Department reported today.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Emanuel Sternheim of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Naomi Sternheim, to Eugene S. Zemans, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Zemans of Goshen. Ind., formerly of Chicago.

Percy S. Brown, an associate of the late E. A. Filene for many years, was elected president and treasurer of the Consumer Distribution Corporation at a meeting of the board of directors held here yesterday.

All railroads operating in the State appealed to the Public Service Commission today to authorize an increase in intrastate freight rates on the same basis as the increase in interstate rates granted by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The Spring book survey of the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee, consisting of 100 approved books in all fields of literature and including many noteworthy titles, was announced yesterday by the committee at its headquarters, 23 East Fifty-first Street, as follows:

After listening to six witnesses yesterday the Westchester County grand jury in White Plains voted an indictment charging Werner Fred Luck, 23 years old, and Edward John Penn, 18, with blackmail in their abortive attempt to collect a $30,000 ransom from the parents of Peter D. Levine, 12-yearold New Rochelle boy, who disappeared Feb. 24.
William Robert Odell, treasurer of the Kerr Bleaching Company, a pioneer textile manufacturer of North Carolina and well known in New York, died today at his home in Concord, N. C., at the age of 83.

Bench warrants were issued here today for Ellis H. Parker, former Burlington County detective, and his son, Ellis H. Parker Jr., when they failed to appear before Federal Court Judge William Clark in proceedings to remove them to Brooklyn, where they were recently indicted for allegedly kidnapping Paul Wendel.
With Governor Richard C. McMullen and members of his family and his official staff in attendance, Delaware Day was observed at the Philadelphia Flower Show today.
The order of finish in the onehundredth running of the Grand National today, weights of finishers, owners. riders and odds follow:

Winirfed Christie, Scottish pianist, gave a recital at Town Hall last night. As usual, she played her program on the double-keyboard piano invented by her husband, Dr. Emanuel Moor, the composer. The two manuals of this instrument are arranged like those of a harpsichord or organ.
An American Legion post in honor of the late Adolph S. Ochs, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, has been formed in the Bronx and now has more than 100 members, it was announced yesterday.

Except for the appearance of a ne, issue of $23,500,000 of Federal Home Loan Banks 2 per cent consolidated debentures, due 1943, the market for new bonds experienced this week one of the quietest periods of the year.

The British Government is expected to announce within a few days its full acceptance of Secretary of State Cordell Hull's proposal for a special international committee to deal with the problem of political refugees.

Dr. Alva Burton Burris, former superintendent of the Maryland State's Pine Bluff Sanitarium at Salisbury, Md., and for years prominent in medical and athletic circles, died in a Salisbury hospital today at the age of 64.

Willem Holst, an authority on oriental art, who had galleries at 19 East Forty-eighth Street, died of a heart ailment Thursday night in the Harkness Pavilion of the Presbyterian Medical Center, after an illness of several weeks, at the age of 59.

Edward T. Kelly, an Alderman from the Twentieth Aldermanic District, 1921-29, and since 1931 deputy clerk of the Eighth Municipal Court of Manhattan, died yesterday at Lutheran Hospital following an operation. He was 41 years old.
Mrs. Benjamin Rogers, Arthur W. Crawford, Mrs. Frank Bradsby, Joseph C. Houck, Morris Legendre, in Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc. agents.

Civil service employes in the office of Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, yesterday designated six rank and file members of the staff as a personnel rating board. Of the 1,000 employes in the office 578 voted.

Mrs. John S. Childs of Manchester and Newcastle, N. H., has announced here the engagement of her niece, Miss Elizabeth Fellows, to Edward Glassmeyer Jr. of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Glassmeyer of Jersey City.

The first two concerts of the third annual Three Choir Festival under the auspices of the Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York were given yesterday in the assembly hall of the temple, which was crowded with the largest audience that these festivals have attracted. The programs of yesterday were wider in their scope than ever before.

John Haskell, executive secretary of the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange, ??tlined today at a hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission the policy of the Exchange in connection with the delisting of certain types of securities which it considers are no longer eligible for trading on the Exchange.

Herbert W. Alrich of New York, an engineer employed by the Consolidated Edison Company, died on a New York Central train as it neared Syracuse today. His son, D. C. Alrich, was accompanying him home from San Francisco.

Next week's only opening takes place on Monday, when the Lunts, plus the Theatre Guild, will be bringing a revival of "The Sea Gull" to the Shubert Theatre. Associated are Richard Whorf, Margaret Webster, Uta Hagen, Sydney Greenstreet, Harold Moffet and 0. Z. Whitehead; the version of Chekhov is a new one by Stark Young.

Milton Hanauer of Manhattan strengthened. his hold on first place in Group A of the United States championship preliminaries at the Marshall Chess Club when he drew his seventh-round match with S. S. Cohen of the Manhattan Chess Club. The former State champion had the black pieces in a Nimzowitsch defense.
Real estate trading in Manhattan was marked yesterday by a variety of scattered deals, including sales and leases of dwellings, flats and commercial property.

Mr. and Mrs. John Marshall Eaton of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Isabella Eaton, to John Griswold Webb, son of Mrs. J. Griswold Webb of Meadow Rock Farm, Wilton, Conn., and the late New York State Senator Webb.
Parishioners from over 200 churches in the New York area will attend a general Lutheran "Rally Service" tomorrow at 3 P. M. in Immanuel Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Eighty-eighth Street.

Two young people, one just out of high school, one still a student, fall in love and, as the saying goes, get into trouble. It is an old story--as old, at least, as the institution of marriage. The boy and girl are desperate.

Miss Carolyn Williams Calla- Wes nan of this city, daughter of the Ro late Mr. and Mrs. James Henry Callanan, was married to Andrew Pierce Kellogg, son of Mrs. James Warner Kellogg, also of Schenectady, and the late Mr. Kellogg, here this morning in her home.

Sabotage resulting in the loss of "thousands of dollars," the theft of tools and equipment and collusion with contractors in an attempt to destroy the business of a former member was charged yesterday against Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

The effort of the State, County and Municipal Workers of America, C. I. O., to organize civil service workers here was aided yesterday by the creation of a citizens' advisory committee, headed by Miss Dorothy Kenyon, formerly First Deputy Commissioner of Licenses.

Mayor La Guardia's efforts to finance relief without imposing a 10 per cent general cut by April 1 seemed doomed to failure yesterday after the Finance Committee of the City Council had heard twenty speakers oppose the Mayor's supplemental tax program of $9,250,000.
Spanish Insurgent troops broke through the government's defenses today and advanced to within twenty-five miles of Catalonia, target of the northeastern campaign.
Brig. Gen. Henry H. Arnold, assistant chief of the Army Air Corps, made the first official military landing today at the new E. Davis Wilson Airport, which will be dedicated tomorrow.
Henry Armstrong, featherweight champion of the world, scored a technical knockout over Eddie Zivic, Pittsburgh lightweight, in the fourth round of their scheduled ten-round engagement tonight.

In contrast to weakness in the securities markets, prices of cotton stiffened yesterday on the Cotton Exchange to end with gains of 4 to 6 points after displaying the most pronounced resistance of the last three weeks.
Inauguration of the Peiping government, which has been delayed by the need for further clarification of its relations to other autonomous areas of China, will probably take place Monday.
Baroness Eva Dickson von BlixenFinecke, a noted Swedish racing motorist, was killed in an auto accident near Baghdad, Iraq, according to a private message received here.

Pope Pius has sent what the Vatican describes as a "generous money grant" to the family of the famous German scientist, Heinrich Rudolf Hertz, whose discoveries were the forerunner of wireless and whose widow and two daughters fled from Germany some time ago to England and now live there in dire want.

A rift in the membership of the National Maritime Union, C. I. 0. unit of unlicensed merchant seamen, culminated last night in the expulsion of Octave Loones, a member of the stewards' department, at a meeting of the union at 126 Eleventh Avenue.

Gustave Wilhelm Kunze, organizer of the German-American Bund whose efforts last night to address a meeting in Philadelphia ended in a near riot, had a similar experience here tonight when his audience turned out to be almost entirely anti-Nazi.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I take this opportunity to endorse and commend your editorial "The Issue in the Morgan Case." This should be carefully read and its considered reasoning applied by every American citizen interested in the preservation of our constitutional form of representative government. The time to check autocracy is now.

Arrival of real Spring weather this week brought some retailers their largest sales for the year thus far, lifting the average of retail distribution 3 to 8 per cent over the previous week, but the decline from the same week last year deepened to 10 to 20 per cent, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

The pamphlet report of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation and its subsidiaries for 1937 shows a net profit of $2,360,417 after depreciation, interest, Federal and State income taxes, surtax on undistributed profits, net loss of William Bonifas Lumber Company and other deductions.
Senate investigators of railroad finances heard testimony today that railroads helped finance the distribution of "educational" material in Ohio schools.
Arthur Wallace Rice, retired architect and member of the firm of Parker, Thomas Rice, which built the Chamber of Commerce Building, died today at his home in Milton.
One of these days we're going to have a long talk with Jack Brawley, another rod and gun writer, and try to discover just what methods he uses to escape his jinx.

This country's fiscal problem, at the end of five years of "steady and bold experimentation," has become "harder and not easier to solve," Dr. Leo Wolman, Professor of Economics at Columbia University, said tonight at the annual Wharton Institute of the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce, University of Pennsylvania.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 24: BRIGADIER GENERAL Tracy, J. P., Presidio of San Francisco, Calif., to home and await retirement, to sail from San Francisco about June 18 for New York, N. Y.

In the more or less bewildering action of the stock market, especially during the last two weeks of political misgiving in Europe, it has been difficult at times to be sure how far the declines reflected the European situation and how far the absence of distinct recovery in our own business situation. Both influences have undoubtedly played their part.

This country's fiscal problem, at the end of five years of "steady and bold experimentation," has become "harder and not easier to solve," Dr. Leo Wolman, Professor of Economics at Columbia University, said tonight at the annual Wharton Institute of the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce, University of Pennsylvania.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 24: BRIGADIER GENERAL Tracy, J. P., Presidio of San Francisco, Calif., to home and await retirement, to sail from San Francisco about June 18 for New York, N. Y.

In the more or less bewildering action of the stock market, especially during the last two weeks of political misgiving in Europe, it has been difficult at times to be sure how far the declines reflected the European situation and how far the absence of distinct recovery in our own business situation. Both influences have undoubtedly played their part.

A contract between the management of The Newark Sunday Call and the Newspaper Guild affecting employes in the commercial department of the newspaper was signed this afternoon, it .was announced tonight by Miss Agnes Fahy, president of the Guild.

A New and simple test for the detection of oxidation in wool has been Discovered by Henry A. Rutherford and Milton Harris, research associates of the American Association of Textile Chemists and Colorists at the National Bureau of Standards, the Department of Commerce announced yesterday.

Lawrence, Blake Jewell, Inc, have arranged a building and permanent loan of $155,000 on the six-story apartment under construction at 240 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, for the 240 Ocean Parkway Corp; Max Freed, president..

Sam Breadon, president of the St. Louis Cardinals, intimated tonight that the decision of Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis making free agents of some 100 Cardinal farm club players was "the last word,"

You look at a distant hill or at yonder hump of rock. Which is the older? A mere academic question to the city man. But not to the miner. The more he knows about the rocks the more successful is his drilling and blasting likely to be.

After three years of normal academic routine of required courses and limited cuts from scheduled classes and lectures, eight Dartmouth undergraduates are soon to go on their own and organize individual programs for the final college year.

Dr. Irvin Abell of Louisville, president-elect of the American Medical Association, will receive the Laetare medal for 1938, the Rev. John F. O'Hara, president of the University of Notre Dame, announced today. The university has bestowed the award annually since 1883 upon a leading member of the Catholic laity.

Last week THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks touched a new low for the year at 75.56, automatically breaking through the resistance level of the last four months, that. of 82.07 established on Nov. 24, and through the previous low of 77.92 of March 18, 1935.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's week-end visit to the home of Viscount and Viscountess Astor at Cliveden, Buckinghamshire, has aroused considerable interest in view of reports that the Astor country mansion has displaced the Carlton Club as the source of the Conservative party's inspiration.

Lines for the battle of "culture vs. the simple life," which were drawn at a stormy session of the Board of Zoning Appeals in the Town Hall last night, tightened today when the board denied the application of Longshore Estate, Inc., for permission to erect a dock and stage off the Longshore Club property on Long Island Sound as a prelude to the building of a $100,000 amphitheatre for concerts.

Pledging themselves to fight for the freedom of their native country, if such' action is necessary, more than 200 Lithuanian liberals yesterday morning staged a mass demonstration in front -of the Polish Consulate, 151 East Sixty-seventh Street, protesting "Polish fascist aggression" in Lithuania.
Mexico is extremely anxious at the present time to propitiate the United States in respect to the expropriation of the foreign oil companies.

A delegation of realty men from New York and vicinity will attend the sessions in the National Association of Real Estate Boards' Central Atlantic conference, to be held in Richmond, Va., May 6 and 7.
WITH the first signs of Spring, there come also the announcements of the increasingly large annual crop of festivals of dance and convenings of dance educators more or less all over the country.

The annual Spring entertainment of the New York Women's Auxillary Bible Society will take place on April 8 in the main ballroom of the Pierre. A color film of the Oberammergau Passion Play, with explanatory remarks by Mark Haight and symphonic musical accompaniment, will feature the entertainment.

The lecture program at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, which was scheduled to endThursday with an address by Dorothy Thompson on "Essentials of Democracy," will be extended through April because of continued interest in problems facing America, it was announced yesterday by George. V.

WHEN the lights are turned out this evening in the old Grand Opera House, corner of Twenty-third Street and Eighth Avenue-when the projection booth has been locked and the last yawning doorman has gone home,

Announcement has been made to friends here of the engagement of Miss Deborah Allen Owens, daughter of Mrs. Jean Owens of Hazleton, Pa., and the late Dr. Harry J. Owens, to William Lauderbach Dyson, son of Dr. John R. Dyson and the late Mrs. Dyson, also of Hazleton.

The Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, and the League of New York Theatres, organization of producers, signed an agreement yesterday afternoon under which the union wins a closed shop.

According to The Daily Telegraph, an agency is to be established in London for the benefit of the German population, with the slogan "home goods for Germans abroad." It is expected the Germans will henceforth buy automobiles, domestic appliances, books, musical instruments, clothes and cosmetics from Germany and pay in foreign currencies, which Germany needs.

At the meeting of the Conference on World Economic Cooperation, held in Washington Friday, the resolution adopted praising President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Hull for their leadership in proposing asylum for political refugees from other countries

Miss Evelyn Margaret Chard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Davis Chard of Greenwich, was married to George Morton Billings of Stamford, son of Mr. and Mrs Samuel P. Billings of Deerfield, Mass., in the First Methodist Episcopal Church this afternoon by the Rev. Andrew F. Chamberlain, the pastor.

E. Robert Willcox, real estate lawyer, will discuss the "tapering off" of the' mortgage moratorium at the meeting of the realty brokerage class at Havemeyer Hall, Columbia University, tomorrow eveing.

Teachers of surveying from twenty-four Northeastern colleges and engineers, attending a regional conference at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, rallied today to the defense of the beleaguered American inch.

Former President Herbert Hoover. who is aboard the French liner Normandie, due to arrive here from Europe on Tuesday morning, is scheduled to speak on Thursday evening at a dinner of the Council on Foreign Relations, an organization "for the study of international affairs," at the Hotel Ritz-Carlton.

A small supper dance will be given at the Montparnasse on April 28 under the auspices of the American Friends of Russian Children in Exile, a committee organized in New York last year to give assistance to children of impoverished Russian emigres.
The quoted sidehead which indents this paragraph is from Lewis Gannett's book column in The Herald Tribune of day before yesterday.

Prices established by the National Bituminous Coal Commission have not been declared invalid by the courts nor has the commission declared price schedules and orders invalid, according to an opinion given today by Robert W. Knox,

STATISTICS and questionnaires are always suspect, but there is a certain pertinence about the survey recently undertaken by the Filmarte Theatre to determine whether its patrons prefer foreign films to the Hollywood product.

Economic and diplomatic coercion rather than a military coup on the Austrian pattern was forecast yesterday as Chancellor Hitler's future policy toward Czechoslovakia by Dr. Thomas Capek Jr., secretary to the late President Thomas G. Masaryk of Czechoslakia, speaking at a forum at the Rand School of Social Science, 7 East Fifteenth Street.

Miss Christine Finn of Waterbury, Conn., has been elected president of the senior class of the College of St. Elizabeth here for next year, it was announced today. Other class officers are Miss Mary Rita Bermingham, vice president; Miss Anastasia Magovern, secretary, and Miss Rose Delia, treasurer.

Letters from American missionaries in the Japanese-occupied city of Hwaiyuan, in Anhwei Province, brought out by a bean curd peddler who passed through the Japanese and Chinese lines outside Hwaiyuan, have reached Miss Anna Moffett, Presbyterian missionary in Hankow.

The Fairfield County extraordinary grand jury which has been investigating land transactions for the Merritt Parkway has climaxed eight weeks of hearing witnesses by handing up indictments against three men.

The Department of Commerce estimated today the national income was $4,850,000,000 in February, smallest total for any month since February, 1936. The total included $3,415,000,000 in wages, the smallest since July, 1936;

St. Peter's High School of New Brunswick, N. J., tonight won the Eastern States Catholic basketball tournament by defeating De La Salle Academy of Newport, 24-23, in a game which was deadlocked 3 minutes before the final whistle.

Sixty native vocational school students, whose average age is 17 years, have completed and launched the Mazie C., a 65-foot Diesel work boat, at Kahoolawe, Territory of Hawaii. Before starting work on the vessel,

Mrs. Parker O. Griffith, president of the Essex County Symphony Society, announced today. the appointment of Alexander Smallens of New York as conductor of the society's orchestra for the coming season.
The Salvation Army has launched a campaign to raise $600,000 in individual subscriptions to carry on its welfare and institutional services for the next twelve months.

Writing the newest chapter in the history of transatlantic cables, begun in 1858 by Cyrus W. Field, the cable ship Lord Kelvin will sail Tuesday from New York to plow ocean cables into the Atlantic Ocean, to protect them from submarine damage, it was announced yesterday by the Western Union Telegraph Company.

A new WPA school for adults, sponsored by the Board of Education, will be opened tomorrow in the Ninth Street Day Nursery and Orphan Home, 393 East Eighth Street. English for the foreign born and courses in cooking, home-making, child care and citizenship aid will be available.
FIRST-HAND KNOWLEDGE: Georgia, once famous for its chain gangs, is working out a new penal system, and last week the State obtained the

A protective committee for prior-lien bonds of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission today for a six-month postponement of hearings in the railroad's reorganization proceedings.

Mrs. Maria L. Card, who conducted a farming school for orphans in France during the World War with her own funds and was made an officer in the French Legion of Honor for this service, died Friday in Nice, France, according to word received here yesterday. Mrs. Card, who was in her eighties, was a former resident of Pittsburgh, but had lived abroad since 1915.

Britain's rejection of Foreign Commissar Maxim M. Litvinoff's proposal for an international conference of nonaggressive nations to deal with the new crisis occasioned by the German and Polish threats to Czechoslovakia and Lithuania, respectively, occasioned no surprise here either in Soviet circles or among foreign diplomats.

Contending that present statistics covering the trend of import and export trade fail to give the layman a clear concept of current developments and trends, Harry S. Radcliffe, executive secretary of the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc., yesterday urged the United States Department of Commerce to revamp its presentations of statistical data on both exports and imports.

Fifteen hundred firemen and their guests attended last night the eighteenth annual dance of the New York Fire Department Post of the American Legion at the Hotel Capitol, Fifty-first Street and Eighth Avenue. Other organizations represented included the Uniformed

GOODBYE, WEST COUNTRY. By Henry Williamson. Illustrated. 369 pp. Boston: Little, Brown Co. $3. HENRY WILLIAMSON, author of some of the most distinguished and sensitive prose of our time, is perhaps best known in this country for "Salar the Salmon"

Joshua Smith, portrait artist, died in a hospital here today after an illness of several months. He was injured in an automobile accident at Christmas, following which complications set in. His age was 58.

The Domino Dramatic Organization of Albright College will observe its third annual Passion Sunday Drama Festival with the presentation of Charles Rann Kennedy's "The Terrible Meek" in the college chapel, Sunday, April 3.
Collectors' Exhibition. Newark Museum, until April 30. Four collectors show antique crucifixes and crosses, Oriental rugs, porcelains and furniture, and American paintings, respectively.

NOT only are new playgrounds, scenic highways, de luxe desert resorts and improved mountain trails giving impetus to the American desire to see more of one's native land, but recent realignments in Europe, close to favorite travel paths, are causing a shift of vacation plans.
A Federal court jury here today convicted Peter Janus of Warren, Ohio, and Anton Sikich and Anthony Zietz, both of the Bronx, New York City, of counterfeiting.

The Curtis Publishing Company earned $4,120,510 in 1937, against $6,291,454 in 1936, Samuel D. Fuller, president, reported yesterday to stockholders. Earnings were equal to $4.78 each on 862,178 shares of $7 preferred stock outstanding, on which at the close of last year there were unpaid accumulated dividends of $9.50 a share.

The Budapest Quartet gave the first of its series of five concerts, at which all of the string quartets of Beethoven will be performed, at the Ninety-second Street Y. M. H. A. last night before a large and appreciative gathering.

In an attempt to meet the rising costs of city government, officials should make every effort to modernize and reclaim unrentable property for its potential tax value, states George S. Horton, president of the Bulkley Horton Company, Brooklyn real estate firm.

Winning the parallel bars event and finishing third in the long horse, horizontal bars and rings contests, August Messerschmidt of the Deutsch-American Turn Verein won all-around honors in the metropolitan A. A. U. junior gymnastics championships at the Flushing Y. M. C. A. last night.
REFERENCE has already, of course, been made to the extremely fine group of prints that forms part of the 113th annual show of the National Academy.
