A registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 has been filed by the Whitney Blake Company, Hamden, Conn., manufacturer of insulated wires and cables covering 22,000 shares of -$5 par value common stock to be offered by Henri

Even with the annexation of Austria, Germany still is short of food. The Four-Year Plan is as much concerned with eggs, butter and Rindfleisch (beef to John Bull and Uncle Sam) as it is with substitutes for foreign gasoline and nickel.

The success of last year's first "Fashion Show Your Own" has given added impetus to a second event of this kind to be held on April 7 at Delmonico's. The show presents the novel idea of displaying clothes from the personal wardrobes of young women interested
Now that the latest Moscow treason trial is only a memory the ordinary day-byday life of the country and its capital emerges from the shadow.

A wonderful mine underneath New York City that gives up cut and polished diamonds as well as gold and other precious things, was described yesterday by three young Italians. They were told to stay out of the mine in future, and sent home.

As Rebel strategy unfolds in Aragon, the danger to the Spanish Republic becomes more and more evident. This week an already wide front was extended all the way up to Huesca. Now, it is one of the axioms of war that wide fronts favor the more mobile forces, and Generalissimo Francisco Franco has been supplied with mechanical means to make his army highly manoeuvrable while reducing his need of manpower at particular points.
Out of the roundhouse, out of their massive stable, Slowly the engines came and ominous, Done with their oily hostlers. Pistons smooth

To deepen their understanding of the social and economic implications of their work, five young industrial executives will receive fellowships for a year's graduate study at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology next year.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora defended his acceptance of the presidency of the National Lawyers Guild yesterday as a means of promoting the best interests of the legal profession. He addressed an informal meeting of women lawyers held at the home of Mrs.
The final session of the third annual Three Choir Festival, sponsored by the Congregation EmanuEl of the City of New York and its choir committee, was held yesterday morning at Temple Emanu-El.
The furnishings from Elmhurst, the home of the late Mr. and Mrs. S. S. Bloch of Wheeling, W. Va., brought $12,795 at auction yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries.

OF making of books about New York there is no probable end. And for good and sufficient reasons. Not only is New York our biggest city and intensest mixing bowl; it is incomparably the nation's premier show place, never static, always offering something new to its people and its visitors.

Calling attention to the various efforts in many municipalities during recent years to demolish structures proved to be uninhabitable or worthless from other causes, Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, cites Milwaukee as a notable example.

A SUPERB chance for the pho tographer to try some outdoor detail work becomes available as the cherry trees begin to blossom. Tightly clustered, the light blossoms and the dark branches form patterns that make worth-while subjects. And to the rim of the Tidal Basin in Washington or the East Drive, near the reservoir, in Central Park, thousands of photographers make an annual pilgrimage to take advantage of the all-too-short season.

A comparatively unexplored area of the possibilities of radio, a fundamentally auditory field, is being investigated in an experiment by Ohio State University in which the medium is being used in the almost completely visual field of art and art education.
IT is not news that the classic American lumberjack was a tough hombre. The saga of Paul Bunyan, though undoubtedly not free from exaggeration, was based on a firm factual foundation.

VAUDEVILLE is the spice of variety that radio showmen are sprinkling into the Spring air to flavor broadcasting. Diversity from day to day breaks up the ethereal routine; it is the bait that is believed to lure the greatest number of "escapists" Into the Hippodrome of the Air.
John P. Draney, architect, who designed many churches and public buildings in the Hudson Valley, died last night of a heart attack at the age of 58.

CORTLANDT FIELD BISHOP was not only a champion collector of auction houses. He was also an inveterate book collector in the grand manner. For thirty-five years, beginning at the turn of the century, he bought lavishly from the bookshops and at important sales, but often so unobtrusively that the whereabouts of many of his unique treasures was unknown.
Miss Dorothy M. Morton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert W. Morton of Chestnut Hill, was married this evening to Forrest Garfield Pearson Jr., son of Forrest Garfield Pearson of Chestnut Hill.

More than 350 members of the younger set attended the second vacation dance held at the Greenwich Country Club tonight, arranged by a committee of juniors. Miss Marie Abbett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Abbett, was chairman of the the girls' committee, and Edward MacFarlan Jr. was chairman of the boys' committee.

The Mount Washington Lacrosse Club administered a severe beating today to the Swarthmore stickmen, 11-3, in the Garnet's first contest of the season. The visitors' superior stickwork and smoother team play gave them an easy victory over the Little Quaker squad.

The Manhattanville College Women's basketball team closed its season with a 24-to-12 victory over St. Joseph's College yesterday afternoon on the winners' court. Miss Mary Cohalan scored 10 field goals and 2 fouls for 22 points.
President Roosevelt's strength has dropped sharply in the last monthly Presidential index of the American Institute .of Public Opinion.
FOR the setting of her unusual and in many ways very beautiful novel Joan Grant has gone back through the mists of time
Georgia again is seeking expert aid in carrying forward its prison-reform program designed to supplant chain gangs with a progressive system of penology.

After eleven weeks of back-fence bickering, the twenty-six members of the City Council got together last Tuesday and completed their roster by voting to seat three members whose right to sit had been questioned on the ground of improper residence.

A copy of the Bible announced by Bruce Rogers in 1935 as the supreme book of his career as a printer and made to last 500 years, will repose permanently on the lectern of the First Presbyterian Church in Lake Forest. It will be a memorial to Mrs. W. H. Winterwood, who died in 1936.

Hostilities in Southern Shantung have reached a new stage of intensity with the Chinese forces continuing to oppose strong resistance to Japanese efforts to sweep across the Grand Canal and capture Suchow.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Ann Schreiber, daughter of Professor Carl F. Schreiber of Yale University and Mrs. Schreiber, to George Sullivan Stearns Jr. of New Britain, took place in Marquand E Chapel of the Yale Divinity School a tonight. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. A. Grant Noble E of Williamstown, Mass.

MANHATTAN GRADWOHL, MEYER H. (March 22). Estate, more than $20.000. To Rebecca Gradwohl, sister, executrix, Philadelphia, life estate: Rose Simons, 473 West End Ave., Carrie Lam, Philadelphia. nieces, equal shares in remainder. Mark H. Simons, Albert M. Lam, nephews, executors.

MR. O'HARA'S talents deserve to be well known, and are. Few other writers have a better ear, a crisper style, a swifter punch. Few do a more businesslike job, treat the reader more kindly so far as riveting his interest from start to finish.

Minor reshuffling of the five leaders in the various American Bowling Congress championships took place today, but the division leaders managed to hang on. Salvatore D'Angelo of Tarrytown, N. Y., bobbed up in second place in the all events with a total of 1,926 pins.

Governor Cone said today that, acting on "a lot of complaints," he had issued stop orders against gambling in Dade, Palm Beach and Broward Counties, tourist resorts of Florida's lower east coast. Sheriffs had replied, the Governor said, that they had closed all gambling houses in their counties.
William H. Harkness, a senior purser of the Cunard White Star Line, has retired at the age of 52 on a disability pension because of weakness of the heart.
Embattled Government troops numbering between 10,000 and 20,000 were reported trapped in the Alcubierre Mountains early today by Insurgent hordes sweeping eastward toward the Mediterranean.

UP on the Brenner Pass, one of Europe's historical gateways, German and Italian frontier guards are fraternizing. Less than a month ago the Brenner stood on the boundary line between little Austria and her "protector," Italy. Now it divides, or, as II Duce and the Fuehrer like to put it, binds together, 74,000,000 Germans and 43,000,000 Italians.

A large plot fronting on Queens Boulevard in Forest Hills has been purchased by the Long Island City building firm of Brecher Parker for immediate improvement with a six-story apartment house to accommodate sixty-five families.

Plans have been completed for a food show in conjunction with the Westchester Home Show of 1938 to be held in the Westchester County Center, White Plains, June 8 to 15 inclusive, it was announced yesterday by Leo H. Fuller,

Five Woonsocket men, one the father of seven children, were crushed to death and a sixth probably fatally injured early today when their speeding automobile skidded 300 feet and crashed into a tree as they were returning from a midnight drinking party in a roadhouse.

A hint of the battle cries which will ring through the country this Fall in congressional election campaigns testing the President's prestige came today from Senator Bridges of New Hampshire and Representative Randolph of West Virginia.

BALTIMORS. SCENIC beauty as well as utility and greater safety are provided in a radical program for improving Eastern seaboard highway communication linking the North and South which is part of a new plan for scientific development of the Baltimore-Washington-Annapolis area.

Miss Shirley Cortelyou Brown, daughter of Mrs. Charles E. Lane of Gedney Farms, White Plains, N. Y., and Burr Rapalje Brown of 220 East Seventy-third Street, this city, was married to Frank Foote Winters of Williamsport, Pa.. yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Resurrection, 115 East Seventyfourth Street. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Gordon Wadhams.

THE World Theatre in West Forty-ninth Street had its own Polish problem last week when Jan Kiepura, tenor star of its current production, "The Charm of La Boheme," kept coming into the theatre, insisting on personally regulating the sound.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Herman A. Prosser of 14 East Seventy-sixth Street, this city and Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Miss Ethel Prosser to David Sherman Baker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Baker of Greenwich and of Whale Rock Point, Narragansett, R. I.

The Columbia varsity fencing team conquered the Princton swordsmen by a score of 14 to 13 on the Morningside Heights strips last night. Although the visitors captured the foil and epee competitio?? the Lion bladesmen swept thr??h the saber matches, winning seven of nine encounters.
James Martin Perkins, retired lawyer, who gained prominence for his activity in the formation of college Republican clubs, died Thursday at Daytona Beach, Fla. His age was 79.

Manager Billy Southworth of Memphis in the Southern Association received word today that Ed Heusser, big right-handed pitcher obtained from the St. Louis Cardinal farm system, was declared a free agent last night by Judge W. G. Bramham,

The Roosevelt plan for shelter for world refugees is merely another indication of the humanitarian attitude of the Government of the United States toward the suffering, Postmaster General James A. Farley declared last night at the thirtyfourth annual convention of the Jewish Consumptives Relief Society in the Hotel Astor. The convention, which began yesterday, will continue through tomorrow.
Communists proposed tonight the organization of nation-wide general strikes as the best means of backing the Popular Front Government's fight for life.

John Davis, 17-year-old Negro youth from Brooklyn, broke the metropolitan and New York State records for the two-hand military press in capturing the metropolitan junior A. A. U. heavyweight weightlifting championship at the German American Athletic Club's new clubhouse in Yorkville last night.

Whether it is better to be beautiful than good-a topic on which the earliest women's clubs clashed earnestly in debate- will be argued again before .the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs on Thursday afternoon.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Ira Cooper of this city gave a luncheon at their home today to announce the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susanne Lee Cooper, to George Burgess Fisher 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Burgess Fisher of Hartford, Conn.
Wrestlers from the Ninety-second Street Y. M. H. A. took all six events in the metropolitan Y. M. H. A. championships at the winners' gymnasium last night.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 25: BRIGADIER GENERAL Schull, H. W., Assistant to the Chief of Ordnance, Washington, D. C., to retirement, upon own application.

RUTH GREEN HARRIS, in a recent article, does much to bring the problems of the sculptor to light. Her attitude is sympathetic. I hope she will investigate more thoroughly the possibilities of a wider use of sculpture in our urban background.

The attitude of the engineering union toward rearmament speed-up was explained tonight by Frederick A. Smith, its general secretary. The 340,000 engineers, he said, are "not prepared to provide arms to bolster up dictatorships in any part of the world" and that they would need "strong guarantees to insure that those who have served their apprenticeship will not be swallowed up [by unskilled labor] when employment is not prevalent."
Shanghai is now approaching the climax of the visitations that began on Aug. 13, 1937, when Sino-Japanese hostilities spread to the Shanghai area.
Authorities tonight investigated reports that sabotage was responsible for the train Wreck early this morning twenty miles south of Wanganul that resulted in six known deaths and injuries to thirty.

The two most famous skulls in the world are probably those of Pithecanthropus Erectus (Java Man) and Sinanthropus Pekingensis (Chinese or Peking Man). The Java Man was discovered in 1891 by Dr. Dubois; the Peking Man about twenty years ago near Peking, China. Professor F. Weidenreich.

The Bulgarian Government today extended de facto recognition of Italy's conquest of Ethiopia when King Boris III accepted a new Italian Minister with credentials from the King of Italy and Emperor of Ethiopia.
Spring moving activity throughout the city probably will be brought to a virtual standstill tomorrow by a strike of union workers in this field.

Clifford L. McMillen, general agent of the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York City, has purchased several acres of land at Hanover Springs, in the Hanover Hills section of Newtown, Conn., and will erect a home there.

Army won from Navy today by 29 to 25 and took the Eastern Intercollegiate Gymnastic League team championship in a dual match held in connection with the individual contests of the circuit. First places in the individual championships were evenly divided among Army, Navy and Temple, each of which took two.

A review of the Seventy-first Infantry Regiment of the New York National Guard will be held in its armory at Park Avenue and Thirtyfourth Street Saturday evening at 8:30 o'clock in honor of Brig. Gen. Walter A. Delamater, Colonel George F. Terry, commanding officer of the regiment, announced yesterday.

With the seizure of the $450,000,000 foreign-owned oil properties by the Mexican Government, the "good-neighbor" policy enunciated by President Roosevelt at the opening of the Pan-American conference in Buenos Aires in December,

SAFETY work of importance is about to be undertaken in New Jersey, with the installation of a safety island on the Brunswick Pike, dividing the roadway into two lanes for a distance of five miles from Penns Neck traffic circle, near Princeton, to Bakers Basin,

Despite the denials which come from all sides, there seems no doubt that as the conflict in Spain becomes more and more critical help to both sides is. being poured in by the partisans in ever greater quantities.

Eleven weary and downcast Chinese were detained under guard on Ellis Island yesterday after having been routed from the hold of a British freighter, in which they apparently had traveled from Shanghai, a journey by the 5,600-ton vessel that lasted seventy-six days.

A CHANGE in the location of the 1938 Vanderbilt Cup tournament has been announced. Originally scheduled for the Park Central Hotel, the tournament will instead take place at the Ambassador Hotel. It will begin Monday night, April 18.

RECENTLY a lecturer maintained that during the last two centuries first collectors and later museums have established a cinquecento and Greek fifth-century B. C. standard by which all art has been measured.

Glenn Cunningham, the old master of the milers, proved it again tonight before a roaring crowd of 10,000 spectators by conquering his newest rival, sturdy Chuck Fenske of Wisconsin, by about a foot after a steaming battle in the famous Bankers' Mile, in 4 minutes 9.9 seconds.

Nutrition, tuberculosis, rural population and gonorrhea control will be subjects of round-table discussions among the 100 public health experts who will attend the Sixteenth Annual Conference of the Milbank Memorial Fund at the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday.

The maintenance of Roosevelt House at 28 East Twentieth Street, birthplace of the late President Theodore Roosevelt, and the educational work conducted by the Women's Roosevelt Memorial Association, will be benefited by a lecture on "Some Voices of Spring," to be given on Wednesday morning by Co Dr. G. Kingsley Noble, curator of reptiles and amphibians at the of American Museum of Natural History, in the Roosevelt Memorial Building, Central Park West at Seventy-ninth Street.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity is unchanged at 79.2 for the week ended March 19. It was 106.6 for the corresponding week last year. Contra-seasonal increases in activity were responsible for gains in the components for electric power output and steel ingot production.

SPEAKING as a proponent of radio and the concert hall and as an opponent of neither, John Barbirolli, conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, at a recent meeting of the Contemporary Club of Philadelphia scorned what he termed the oldfashioned idea that broadcasting reduces concert attendance. Mr.

Arthur Plaut Jr., 15 years old, of Long Beach, L. I., one of the most promising young horse show riders, last night added new laurels to those already gained by taking first place for the Metropolitan Equestrian Club Horsemanship Challenge Trophy,

Consumer response to the Hearn campaign for "lower prices to revive production and increase employment" since the drive opened last Thursday has been such as amply to justify the belief motivating it, according to officials of Hearn's. The large sales totals, they asserted yesterday, demonstrated the correctness of the contention that the consumer is ready to buy if there is sufficient price inducement.

The Dodgers are becoming a positive menace to the peace and quiet of tourist life on the West Coast. Today, aided and abetted by Ray Blades's Rochester Red Wings, they raised a terrific din on Clearwater Field for two hours and thirty-eight minutes

Mr. and Mrs. George A. Easley gave a small tea this afternoon at Three Gables Farm, their home here, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Jane Easley, to John E. Larkin, son of Mrs. W. H. Larkin of Arlington, Mass., and the late Mr. Larkin.

With the approach of warmer weather, the managing committee of the Brown University Outing Reservation is looking to increased use of the 100-acre wooded tract in the hill country of Central Rhode Island, where completely equipped cabins, a lake and trails are available to all students and faculty members.

OF all historical ages, this is perhaps the nosiest. Scientific nut-crackers squeeze life out of the atom; anthropologists whack the bushes looking for the average American, inquiring reporters catalogue opinion on everything from the single standard to the triple feature and small business men loudly demand to know what's what.

Recent sales by the .real estate department of the State Mortgage Commission indicate, states James R. Murphy, vice. president of the commission's servicing corporation, a substantial demand for small apartment houses and individual homes.

Miss Patricia MacManus is chairman and Miss Mildred Nicoll treasurer of the junior committee of the Fiftieth Anniversary Fund of Barnard College that has arranged a dinner dance to be known as an April Fool's Day Party to be held Friday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin.

Howard L. Jones of Glen Ridge, one of the Commissioners on New Jersey's State Board of Commerce and Navigation, is mustering interest among yacht clubs of his State to the end that Assemblyman Wickham's bill in the Legislature regulating power boats may be studied instead of condemned blindly.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Augustus Eustis of this place have announced the engagement of Mr. Eustis's daughter, Miss Eleanor Tileston Eustis, to Theodore Stephen Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lyon Jones of Wellesley Hills.

EMPLOYES of the British Broadcasting Corporation, which serves 8,500,000 licensed listeners, now total 3,600 engaged in an enterprise described as "the development for a' social purpose of what may lay claim to being considered the outstanding invention of the century."

ASECRET of the beauty of eighteenth century interiors, the professional decorator is well aware, lies in the unifying of furniture with interior architecture through materials, color schemes and other decorative details, especially in the more formal rooms.

The stability of real estate should be the concern of all residents of the city, as property is the principal support of local government, declares Henry G. Waltemade, president of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx.

Field Marshal Hermann Goering warned Jews tonight that they must get out of Austria. In a smashing campaign speech for the plebiscite April 10 to 25,000 Austrians who welcomed him to Vienna as "our Hermann," he declared:

With the question of deciding whether men and women shall have equal rights now resting with the Senate as a whole, the movement to enlist women throughout the countryy in opposition to the Equal Rights Amendment enters briskly nto the educational phase of its work.

Quotations on domestic corporations bonds were forced again to record low levels yesterday in fairly active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Secondary railroad issues again bore the brunt of the selling to register losses of 1 to more than 4 points over a fairly broad front.

A national conference of medical, indusrial, agricultural and other groups to develop a "national health program" will be called here this Spring or early Fall, Miss Josephine Roche, chairman of the President's Interdepartmental committee, announced today.
MR. PEATTIE touches many traditions: that is one way we recognize his richness. He is fellow to Fabre and Hudson, literary naturalists, who added imagination and style to exact knowledge.

The Conservation Department's order covering the spearing of mullet, carp, dogfish, catfish, bullheads, suckers and eels in all waters of this State, went into effect yesterday and will continue through Nov. 30. The order permits the taking of these species in all waters not inhabited by trout.

Dr. Emma P. Carr, noted woman chemist and winner of the Francis P. Garvan gold medal to be awarded by the American Chemical Society next month, was honored yesterday by the Mount Holyoke College Club at a luncheon in the New Weston Hotel, Fiftieth Street and Madison Avenue.

The simplicity and appeal of such scenes as that of a young girl releasing a dove on its first flight and that of a frightened rabbit scurrying from danger constitutes some of the best advertising art of the year, according to an announcement yesterday of the winners in the forthcoming exhibition of the Art Directors Club.

The following Foreign Service changes since March 18 were announced today by the State Department: The assignment of Alexander C. Kirk of Chicago as Consul General at Barcelona has been canceled and he has been assigned as Counselor of Embassy and Consul General at Moscow.

Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons does not expect the new defense program to require a large increase in taxation, as much of the expenditure will be charged to loan funds. The program will cost [Pound]43,000,000 over a three-year period.
THREE TO GET READY. By Margaret Herzog. 295 pp. Garden City, N. Y.: Doubleday, Doran Co. $2. THIS story of a Park Avenue girl and her social success is smartly written and easily read.

The fourth and last concert of the special series presented by the National Orchestral Association, under Leon Barzin, with Emanuel Feuermann, the eminent 'cellist, as soloist, was given yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall.

Count Rene de Saint-Quentin, French Ambassador to the United States, will be the guest of honor at the reception and tea which will mark the opening tomorrow of the benefit exhibition of paintings by Paul Cezanne at the Durand-Ruel Galleries, 12 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Whatever has been the real cause of the delay in establishing a new Central China Government in this area, repeated postponements have indirectly played into Japan's hands, because now nearly all foreigners and most Chinese here would welcome any new government that could end the present phase of uncertainty and trade paralysis.

Amendment to the National Bankruptcy Act to make it possible for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, through reorganization, to shake off the 999-year lease of its elevated lines is urged in a brief sent to the Judiciary Committee of the United States Senate yesterday by Louis Boehm, counsel for a committee of holders of the Interborough's 7 per cent secured notes.

Four members of the Westchester County Park Commission, in session here today, withdrew the resignations they had tendered March 5 because the County Board of Supervisors had, without consulting them, approved a bill for transfer of title to the BronxRiver Parkway from the county to the State of New York.

By the infinitesimal margin of a touch, Harvard edged out Ohio State for second place in the 400yard relay that brought to a dramatic conclusion the National Collegiate A. A. swimming championships in the Rutgers pool tonight.
ANDREW JACKSON'S home near Nashville stands today just as it was when he died there in 1845. The Hermitage escaped "by the narrowest of margins," says the author of this history of the house,

Many measures affecting mortgage holdings and extending the field of investments for low-cost housing are awaiting action by Governor Lehman, following their passage at the recent session of the State Legislature.

Miss Sarah Keith Robertson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Robertson of this city and South Norwalk, Conn., was married this afternoon to Lyman Emerson Russell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Russell, also of White Plains, in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church here.

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Drexel God N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Godfrey, to John Scott Walker, son of Mrs. Joseph H. Walker of Carnegie, Pa., and the late Mr. Walker.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Annette Sacks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Sacks of Brooklyn, to Sidney O. Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Friedman, also of Brooklyn.
The Federated Garden Clubs of Connecticut has announced that its annual lecture course will be given, for its seventy-five member clubs, in Stamford on three successive Tuesday, beginning this week.
Tom Thorp of New York today was named a steward at Narragansett Park this season by the Rhode Island Division of Racing. The announcement was made by Francis J. Kiernan, chief of the division.

Residents of the old Chelsea district of the city are cooperating in planning for a "Bobbies' Ball" to be given on April 16 in the Elizabeth Flynn Grill at London Terrace as a means to establish an emergency fund for families of the 125 uniformed attendants, or "bobbies," in service at London Terrace.

Sir William Grenfell Max-Muller and Lady Max-Muller of London have left the St. Regis for a week's visit in Washington. Mr. and Mrs. James Russell Lowell gave a dinner last night at Larue for Mr. and Mrs. W. Roosevelt Thompson.

A gallant flock of Chicago Black Hawks reached the Stanley Cup semi-final round tonight when Paul Thompson fired a goal after 11 minutes 49 seconds of sudden-death overtime to defeat the Montreal Canadiens, 3-2, in the third game of the series between the National Hockey League's third-place clubs.
ORPHEUS IN PARIS. By S. Kracauer. Translated from the German by Gwenda David and Eric Moshbacher. Illustrated. 387 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $4.
Herbert Knox Wallace, treasurer of the Essex Title Guaranty and Trust Company, died yesterday at his home at the age of 51. He suffered a heart attack last May and had been on a leave of absence.

As an essential to raising the standards of nursing to a uniform professional basis, the National League of Nursing Education, cooperating with the American Nurses Association and the National Organization of Public Health Nurses,

With nearly all the nation's schools of electrical engineering on the side of private utilities interests, 'students learn to favor private ownership as against public ownership, Morris Llewellyn Cooke, formerly a trustee of the New York State Power Authority, said yesterday in an address at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street.

Flora is in rehearsal these days out on the New York World's Fair grounds. Thousands of flowering plants are abloom. Spaces about buildings completed or under construction are aglow with tulips and pansies and Spring performers.

THE SEA GULL--Tomorrow evening at the Shubert Theatre. A revival of the Chekhov play in a new version by Stark Young. In it are Alfred Lunt, Lynn Fontanne, Margaret Webster, Richard Whorf, John Barclay, Uta Hagen, Sydney Greenstreet, Edith King, Harold Moffet and O. Z. Whitehead.

Plebiscites are one of the most psychologically interesting institutions of the Third Reich. Recently the various national votes taken under the National Socialist regime had all been opened with the announcement that there was no practical reason for them. In the words of Propaganda Minister Goebbels they are to "show" the doubting world.
More than 400 persons, including many out-of-town guests, attended the annual Gnomes' Ball, which a was held in Delta Kappa Epsilon House at Yale tonight.
The touring Cambridge University Rugby team scored its second straight American shut-out victory during a driving rainstorm in the Stadium today, defeating the Harvard team, 50 to 0.

The annual report of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company for 1937, forwarded yesterday to shareholders, showed a net income of $24,663,450 after all operating expenses and charges. This was equal, after full preferred dividend requirements, to $2.71 each on the 6,261,

Chicago's Joe Platak wrote handball history today with a smashing 21-8, 21-8 victory over Jack Clements of San Francisco, and ran his string of National A. A. U. singles championships to four in a row. The blond Lithuanian took commanding leads early, in both games and was never headed.

Mrs. Isabelle Dives Clarke, wife of Frederick H. Clarke, retired advertising man, died late Friday night in St. Vincent's Hospital after a long illness. Mrs. Clarke, who was 59 years old and lived at Short Hills, N. J., rode and exhibited in many horse shows in the East.

A dance will be given for the Cambridge Rugby team, members of which arrived recently on the Queen Mary, by the New York Rugby Football Club and the New York Branch of the English-Speaking Union on the night of April 9 at the union's headquarters here, 30 Rockefeller Plaza. Mr. and Mrs.

After overruling a contention that the smiles of a pair of twins should be measured collectively rather than individually, judges in the Boys Athletic League's annual "smiles" contest yesterday named Jimmy O'Brien, 4 years old, and Rosie Rushit, 7, as the possessors of the biggest smiles in New York.

William S. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, announced yesterday that he would address his annual report to the listening public as well as to the stockholders, to whom the report will be sent in the usual way.

Archaeological discoveries expected to shed light on the life, customs and general history of the Holy Land of 2,000 years ago were listed yesterday by Edward M. M. Warburg of the executive committee of the American Friends of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem.

The Holy See's interests encircle the globe, and therefore there is no part of the world which is not within the province of the ecclesiastical organizations whose duty it is to safeguard and promote activities with which the Vatican is identified.

The Rev. Lawrence C. Gorman, dean of Loyola College, has announced the following as qualifying for the dean's list of distinguished students for the third quarter: J. Harold Grady and William W. Mahoney, seniors; J. Carroll O'Neill, junior; Maurice E. Baker, J. Charles Baummer, Mario T. Cichelli.

Distribution of more than $6,500,000 in State unemployment insurance to 200,000 jobless persons in this city has reduced the city's home-relief burden by less than 3 per cent, it was learned last night.

Heavy doses of insulin produce coma in a schizophrenic. Sugar restores him. Sometimes he so far recovers his mind that he can be discharged. Coma is a sleep that may end in death. Still, it is sleep. What if those who are not insane but who cannot sleep were slightly shocked with insulin?

The original farmhouse erected more than a century ago with two acres comprising part of the Mrs. Arthur Lawrence estate in the town of Bedford in the northern section of Westchester County has been purchased by an investing client of the Kenneth H. Clapp Company of Bedford Village, local brokers in the sale acting for Previews, Inc. The tract was formerly the Rector Fox property.
Dr. Paul Martin Pearson, former Governor of the Virgin Islands, died at Stanford Hospital here tonight. His age was 66. Dr. Pearson had been at the hospital since Feb. 28, when he suffered a stroke.

A model house will be opened today in the Juniper Park development at Eliot Avenue and Seventyninth Street, Elmhurst, L. I., where fifty-six houses are under construction by Stewart Willey and Alexander Sjursen, developers.

Since the Hitler coup in Austria, two weeks ago, holders of approximately $170,000,000 face amount of bonds of Central European countries have seen the value of their investments decrease about $28,000,000.

The Cargill Grain Company of Illinois prepared today to press its charge that the Chicago Board of Trade was guilty of violating the Federal Commodity Exchange Act in its han- co dling of the "squeeze" in the corn market last September.

Commenting on some of the problems at.. present confronting real estate, I. Jerome Riker, president of the realty firm bearing his name, denounces the Patman bill which calls for a Federal chain store tax and deplores the new tax rate for New York City.

Judge and Mrs. Charles A. Hallock of this city gave a tea today at their home at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maylah Grace Hallock of Hartford, Conn., to Richard Bartlett Park of West Hartford, son of Mrs. Nathan Rogers Park of Cincinnati and the late Mr. Park.
Two patrolmen dispatched to investigate a grocery store hold-up were shot and killed in their cruiser car and fellow-officers fatally wounded a Negro gunman tonight.

IN the South a new potato harvest is on. Mechanical diggers are in the fields, mechanical graders in the packing sheds, long lines of motor trucks are racing the freshly dug product to sidings and city markets. Slowly at first, then rapidly the harvest marches up the Southern tier.

Elaborate and detailed plans have been formulated by the Japanese Government, the Manchukuo Government and the South Manchurian Railway Company whereby it is hoped that during the next twenty years 1,000,000 Japanese families will be moved from Japan proper and settled on the land in North Manchukuo.

After three performances, the cast of the charity figure skating carnival, which is being presented at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the Bellevue Hospital Social Relief Service and the Carroll Club will take a day off today from their activities. The concluding show will be given tomorrow night.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended March 23, aggregated $7,614,000,000, or 10 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 27 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

BROADCASTS from "Radio Nations" at Geneva, heard throughout the Winter on Friday evenings over the 32-meter wave, will shift to Sundays from 7 to 7:45 P. M., beginning April 3. The wave will then be 26.31 meters or 11.40 megacycles. On this Spring schedule music will be interspersed with talks concerning the League of Nations and the International Labor Office.

A substantial increase for the year 1937 over the preceding year in mortgages accepted for FHA insurance through the building and loan associations of the country was announced yesterday by C. Wylie Allen, chief of the savings and loan section of the FHA.

A new fraternity trophy, to be awarded in June after the University of Pittsburgh's Interfraternity Council has balanced its score sheets, has appeared on the campus. Forty other trophies are awarded annually by the council, made up of the thirteen chapters of national

Charting the career cycles of criminals and forecasting the results of court and clinic treatment of juvenile offenders with what has been described as "healthy and stimulating skepticism," Dr. Eleanor Touroff Glueck, Barnard College alumna, has set a new standard in penologic research.
Senator Bone, Democrat, of Washington suggested today that President Roosevelt might use the proposed $1,100,000,000 naval-expansion program to effect a reduction in world armaments.

The clatter of the riveter's hammer will be missing when workmen start putting up the steel framework this week for the tall apartment house to rise at the southwest corner of Twentieth Street and Seventh Avenue.
STATION WGY's new 625-foot tower, considered in radio circles as one of the latest marvels in aerial engineering, will be on the air at Schenectady within a month.

The value of building permits for all kinds of construction issued during February, outside of New York City, was 28 per cent greater than that of January, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins announced yesterday.
ASH-FREUND-Mr. and Mrs. J. D. Freund, 220 West 93d St., announce the engagement of their daughter, Roslyn, to Mr. Arthur L. Ash, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joe Ash of Brooklyn.

U. S . 1 POEMS. By Muriel Rukeyser. 147 pp. New York: Covici Friede. $2. IN her second volume of poetry, Muriel Rukeyser avoids the pitfalls of her earlier work. Her language and syntax is greatly clarified, her imagery is simplified.
April is a month of garden tours in the South, when historic towns of ante-bellum days will welcome visitors to old boxwood gardens and plantation grounds shadowed by old live-oaks.

Raymond Leslie Buell, president of the Foreign Policy Association, has written a letter to Secretary of State Cordel Hull criticizing this country's neutrality policy as doing a "grave injustice" to Spain and asserting that "if Spain becomes a second Austria" it will be partly due to that policy.

SHIP OF THE LINE. By C. S. Forester. 323 pp. Boston: Little, Brown Co. $2.50. To readers of Mr. Forester's "Beat to Quarters" "Ship of the Line," which continues the story of Captain Hornblower, needs no introduction. For others it should be said that the new novel stands by itself.

The Administration has been obliged to exert strong pressure to get within sight of attaining about one-half the authority to reorganize the Federal Government which originally it sought. Nothing could illustrate more plainly the sinking estate of the President's influence over Congress or the growing reassertion of the independence of that body.

Instructions have been given by the Paris police to local authorities throughout Alsace to watch attentively for any attempt to foment and organize German Nationalist feeling in this department of France. So far there has been little outward sign of the spread of "German fever" westward, but it is felt that precautions must be taken.

WHEN a newspaper interview is a real interview--that is to say, when it is not the mere transcript of a screed concocted beforehand by the person who is supposed to be under examination-it has one specific merit.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler continued at Leipzig tonight his series of plebiscite campaign speeches, once again referring to "10,000,000 Germans" who suffered or still suffer from the frontiers created by the Treaty of Versailles. He said:
The official Spring opening of the Hudson House Club here will be celebrated Thursday evening with a dinner and fashion show. Part of the proceeds will go toward the Tarrytown Hospital.

The Rangers and the Americans, New York's rivals for the favor of local hockey fans, will engage in a last-ditch struggle tonight. They will meet in the third and deciding match of a best two-out-of-three game series to determine which sextet goes on to greater glory in the National League's post-season race for the championship of the world.

Structural steel orders for February were 49,780 tons, compared with 71,619 tons in January and to 101,710 tons booked in February, 1937, according to the American Institute of Steel Construction. For two months, orders were 121,399 tons, against 255,516 tons in the same period of 1937.

" Man's struggle for truth and his willingness to die in its defense are evidences of his sharing the divine," declared Dr. John H. Finley, editor in chief of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in giving the Don Mellett Memorial Address last night at the convention of the Southwestern Journalism Congress at Baylor University. His topic was "The Printed Word."

THERE is a story at least ten years old behind the recent change in the seating of the Philharmonic - Symphony at Carnegie Hall. According to Maurice Van Praag, personnel manager for more than a decade, complaints from laymen and musicians have been made against the undue aural prominence of the brass section.

Team and individual honors in the New England division of the national intercollegiate rifle match went to Lehigh University marksmen today as they topped a field of seventeen squads with a total score of 1,343.
EGYPT issued two silver commemorative coins on Jan. 20 in honor of the wedding of King Farouk and Queen Farida. The denominations are 2 and 10 piastre, the designs of which are similar.

If your want a house lined with stee call a paper hanger and put him to work, provided he is familiar with a new process described last week at the Western Metal Congress by James H. Spade. The Process makes it possible to stick chromium steel on plaster as if it were wallpeper.

The salient fact emerging from Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's speech in the House of Commons Thursday is, of course, that Great Britain is as unprepared to use force to prevent Germany from dominating Europe as she has been to prevent Japan from dominating China.

A PRACTICAL joke, wherever played, is never very funny to the victim. But if you are an actor in the midst of a scene, with several hundred people looking on as a fellow-player makes you the butt of his twisted sense of humor, the results are likely to be devastating.

Brittany spaniels were placed on exhibition before St. Louis dog fanciers for the first time in history today as the Mississippi Valley Kennel Club opened its 1938 show, and a New Yorker, George F. Ryan, had the winners of two prizes.
The Furness Bermuda Line opened its rush season to Bermuda yesterday with the departure of the liner Georgic, under charter, and the Monarch of Bermuda.

In sharp contrast to the effort some two years ago on the part of C. G. Grey to paint a favorable picture of British civil aviation by comparing the top speed of British civil types with the "block-to-block" running time of American types in airline service, the report of Lord Cadman and his committee to the British Government frankly admits the superiority of the United States in this fundamentally most important category of aviation.

A cable has been received here from London announcing the marriage there on March 19 of Miss Edith Ross, daughter of Mrs. Blanche A. Ross of 171 West Fiftyseventh Street, this city, to Horace Eliascheff of London.

At the request of the traffic committee of the Bronx Board of Trade, Borough President Lyons is having a survey made by his engineering staff to ascertain the feasibility of constructing a pedestrian underpass from the east side of Sedgwick Avenue at 161st Street to connect with the Sedgwick Avenue
After a very busy month "looking into things," His Excellency the American Ambassador to the Court of St. James has decided that there is a real job to be done in London and he has started doing it.

Two teachers and a newly appointed principal were honored yesterday at a testimonial luncheon given by the Staten Island Teachers Association at the Hotel Astor. Miss Mary E. Fitzpatrick, a teacher-clerk who is retiring after fiftythree years of service, was acclaimed for her "loyal service" by the educators.

In the second stage of its preparation, the new revenue bill is showing definite indications of a considerate attitude for the welfare of business. The elimination of the "third basket" by the Ways and Means Committee as a whole and the decisive rejection

ASTOR--In Old Chicago, closing tonight; The Call: Jean Yonnel, opens tomorrow night. BELMONT--Un Carnet de Bal: Harry Baur, Francoise Rosay. CAMEO--The Ski Battalion;* Lenin in October, opens Thursday. CAPITOL--The Girl of the Golden West: Jeanette MacDonald, Nelson Eddy. CENTRAL--Cassidy of Bar 20 and Taming the Wild. CONTINENTAL--Children Must Laugh, Yiddish film.

A cable dispatch from England to Sheldon M. Stewart of Montclair, N. J., from Bob Barlow brought the news that on Thursday Mr. Stewart's famous Airedale terrier, Champion Shelterock Merry Sovereign had captured the bestin-show award at the Manchester show, the leading canine event in the north of England.

President Roosevelt's call for a higher standard of living for the South expressed a need which is both readily apparent and incapable of contradiction, but the immediate objective should be to raise the number of people employed, the number of people employed, rather than the wage rates of the limited number who are working, in the view of leaders in industries with large plant capacity in that area.

Control of Burco, Inc., an investment trust with headquarters at 15 Exchange Place, Jersey City, was sold a few weeks ago by George H. Burr and associates of New York to Howard F. Hansell Jr. of Toronto, it became known yesterday.
The $2,500 Antonia Trophy, emblematic of the world Moth Class sailing championship, came back today to its first winner-59-year-old Captain Harry Andrews of Atlantic City, N. J.

Carnival attractions for young people as well as their elders, games of all kinds, novel dancing contests and bridge will be features of the varied entertainment known as an April Fools' Frolic which will take place Friday night at the headquarters of the Willoughby House Settlement,
Mr. and Mrs. Burton Craige of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Boyden Craige, to Gordon Gray, publisher of The WinstonSalem Journal and The Twin City Sentinel.

Plans are being completed for the Spring ball under the auspices of the Women's Committee of Cathedral House, of which Mrs. S. Cliffton Mabon is chairman, to be held the night of April 23 at the Garden City Hotel. Masses of forsythia blossoms will be used in the decorations for the event. Proceeds will be used to furnish Cathedral House.

Nine thoroughbreds, headed by Seabiscuit, were named today to run in the mile and one-eighth $12,500 added renewal of the classic Agua Caliente Handicap tomorrow. The handicap champion of 1937 will pack top weight of 130 pounds.
" Marcia Gets Her Own Back," a new comedy by W. A. Darlington, The Daily Telegraph's theatre critic, will be given a Sunday night tryout by the Repertory Players at the Aldwych Theatre.

HOT SPRINGS, Va.-Spring has very definitely arrived in the Warm Springs Valley. Some equestrians are following the last few hunts of the Bath County Hounds upon invitation of the Master, Mrs. Fay Ingalls; the trails are thronged with horseback riders, and the golf courses with golfers.
The presence of some 90,000 to 100,000 German troops in Austria is perhaps the most spectacular but not immediately the most serious aspect of Anschluss for the Republic of Czechoslovakia.

The annual flower show of the students of botany at Connecticut College this week-end includes demonstrations of experimental work in addition to arrangements of plants and flowers. The students have forced dogwoods, Japanese quince and several other kinds of plants...

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Surbrug, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Surbrug of this place, to Joseph Simmons, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph I. Simmons of Montclair, will take place on April 16 in the First Congregational Church, Montclair.

The Chicago Corporation has arranged to purchase 8,000 shares capital stock of the City National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago from the Central Republic Company, securities underwriter and distributor, at $130 a share.
The radio operator of a tuna clipper off the Mexican coast, who reported that he feared "death aboard soon," was instructed today to request assistance from Mexican authorities.

ONE of the most important literary genres which have developed in the last twenty years is "history as literature." Among the French writers who have raised history and biography to excellence, by insight into character, skill in the painting of manners,

With the Mayor remaining firm in his contention that the 10 per cent cut in home relief could not be rescinded until the Council had voted new relief taxes, and with little prospect that the Finance Committee of the Council would expedite his tax program Tuesday, the first reduced payments to families already on relief were mailed out yesterday.

THE executive offices in Albany have been occupied, within the memory of the present generation, by a series of men of vastly different personal and political types. The dignified Hughes, the erratic Sulzer, the coldly and brilliantly legalistic Nathan Miller,

Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation joined Deputy United States Marshals today in a search for Ellis H. Parker Sr., former chief of Burlington County detectives, and his son, Ellis, Jr., both of Mount Holly, who failed to appear voluntarily yesterday before Federal Judge William Clark here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On April 5 168 delegates will meet at Albany, empowered to draft a new Constitution for the State of New York. What the convention will bring forth cannot be known.

The Maple Leafs took a stranglehold on the National Hockey League championship tonight by defeating the Boston Bruins, 2-1, for their second straight victory in the best-of-five play-off series for the first place teams of the circuit's two divisions.

NOW it is Brock Pemberton, patriot, who thinks the public should improve its knowledge -- at box-office prices--of Abraham Lincoln. For it turns out that Paul Horgan's "Follow Me Ever," announced three weeks ago by Mr. Pemberton as "a drama on an historical theme,"

Five American and two foreign women students were announced yesterday as the winners of next year's fellowships of the American Association of University Women, which at present is raising a fund of $1,000,000 to promote such special researches in science, literature and the fine arts as the recipients will carry forward.

Investigations by the Securities and Exchange Commission into the affairs of the Continental Securities Corporation (of Maryland) and the Reynolds Investing Company have taken a formal turn with the appointment by the commission of an attorney to superintend its studies.
" PEGGOTTY'S COTTAGE," at Gravesend, made memorable by Dickens in "David Copperfield" but placed by him in fancy at Yarmouth Sands, is to be transformed into a workman's messroom.

An unusual musical program will be broadcast to America over 2RO, the Rome station, on a wavelength of 25.4 meters between 7:30 and 9 P. M. E. S. T., April 1. It will be a concert of orchestral and vocal music composed by Kent Kennan,

Apparently concerned over recent stock market declines, unsettled conditions in Europe and new signs of Congressional independence in its handling of the Administration's legislative program, President Roosevelt today kept in close touch with Washington officials, particularly his legislative helmsmen.

The percentage of vacancies during the first week of March this year in residential units of all types in six New Jersey communities showed a decrease when compared with the same period last year, according to a survey conducted by the Board of Realtors of the Oranges and Maplewood.

Explaining some of the new or improved policies governing property appraisal methods of the present day, Walter J. Henry, New York broker, pointed out yesterday that the increased public interest in this important factor of realty activity is largely due to the formation of appraisers' societies and the numerous special courses of instruction in appraising offered by many universities, colleges and other institutions of learning.

" I don't think I am afraid. But I have never analyzed myself to find out. I have never had time," was the laughing explanation of Mme. Chiang Kaishek, in an interview, of her own bravery under the fire of Japanese guns and bombs.

James Blake Rogers, son of Mrs. Will Rogers of Santa Monica and the late humorist, married here this evening Miss Marguerite Astrea Kemmler, daughter of Mrs. Charles Harold Weldon of Los Angeles and Charles William Kemmler of New York.

The Gdynia America Line announced yesterday that two ships which are under construction for its cargo service between Poland and Gulf ports of the United States have been named for the cities of Lodz and Bielsko, the principal Polish textile centers.

POSTMASTER GENERAL FARLEY'S announcement last week that part of the promised new regular series of stamps had been revised prompted philatelists to speculate as to whether further changes will be made before the Bureau of Engrav-ing and Printing starts production.

Robert Gardiner gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Peggy Sykes and her fiance, Walter P. Chrysler Jr. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. J. Randall Creel, Mr. and Mrs. Hans Spitzer, Mr. and Mrs. George L. de Peyster, Mrs. Amos Tuck French, Mr. and Mrs. Hyatt R. Dehn and Mr. and Mrs. John Delafield.

Ernest G. Howes, president of the Bath and Tennis Club, and Mrs. Howes, today entertained board members, their wives and a few additional guests with a dinner at the Everglades Club, featured by a mock trial. Members, charged with malfeasance, were defendants, with Jack W. Salisbury as defense counsel and J. Kenneth Williamson as prosecuting attorney. Their wives comprised the jury and Mrs. George Angue Dobyne was judge.

The National Labor Relations Board, which has often been accused of increasing industrial strife, reported today that more than half of the cases acted upon since its establishment in the Fall of 1935 have been closed by agreement of both parties to the dispute.

Representatives of women's clubs committed to a "truth in fabrics" campaign will attend the all-day hearing at Washington on Tuesday when the labeling of wool and partwool products will be discussed before the Federal Trade Commission.

Miss Emily L. Charles of Rye, N. Y., gave a luncheon yesterday at the Pierre to announce the engagement of her adopted daughter, Miss Janet Ewing Charles, to Robert Hine Reynolds, son of Dr. and B Mrs; Rollo G. Reynolds of this city.

The National Labor Relations Board dismissed today a certification petition of the American Radio Telegraphists' Association, which is affiliated with the C. I. O., on behalf of radio technicians at Station WABC in New York.

The text of the Glass bill to broaden the lending powers of the RFC is as follows: A bill to amend Section 5d of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation Act, as amended, to authorize loans to public agencies, to provide credit facilities for business enterprises and for other purposes.

TRAFFIC in the corridors of Radio City is expected to be heavy tonight, with Jack Benny, here from Hollywood, scheduled for a one-time performance in the 1,200-seat auditorium where Fred Allen, Kate Smith, Robert L. Ripley and Abe Lyman's band will join the parade.

Dr. Harold A. Abramson, New York, reports in Science that unfelt low electrical currents can carry pollen powder in and out of the pores of the human skin. It is now possible to test patients for sensitivity to pollens, dust and other allergens without scratching the skin.

THE National Park Service and the Forest Service recently recommended the addition of thousands of acres of virgin forest to the Mount Olympus National Monument, in the State of Washington, and the establishment there of a national park of more than 1,500 square miles.
TRADE volume last week began to cut down the margin of decline from a year ago. In the previous week the drop probably averaged about 15 per cent for the country.
Those of you who have sympathy to spare can feel sorry for thousands of California anglers whose streams have been seriously damaged by the recent floods.

Adding epee honors to' the foil and saber championships won yesterday, Seton Hall College won the three-weapon championship of the first annual Eastern Intercollegiate Fencing Conference at Panzer College today by a comfortable margin. Lehigh was second and Panzer third.
Merchant vessels and ice-breakers carrying 800 Russians were reported in a wireless message today to be in a critical position, drifting helplessly in the polar sea off Siberia.

LOS ANGELES. DEVELOPMENT of simpler, stronger, sleeker metals than are currently in use for the world's aircraft was described to delegates to the annual conference of the American Society for Metals here last week. Papers delivered by aeronautical and industrial researchists indicated that metal alloys, forging methods and basic plane construction face virtual revolution.

Terming the recently announced traffic regulations which will prohibit interstate buses from taking on or discharging passengers in New York City streets after April 15 "an unnecessary interference with business," the West Side Association of Commerce, Inc., warned yesterday that enforcement of such measures might cost Manhattan theatre and store owners the patronage of 1,000,000 persons yearly.

A huge oak tree which served as a background for love scenes was blown into bits today. The tree, thirty feet around and an estimated 1,200 years old, was one of the prized possessions of the Warner Studio ranch.

Mr. and Mrs. Olin Downes of 1 West Seventy-second Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Downes, to George Rockwell Smith, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Smith of this city and Locust, N. J.

Stocks of apparel and accessories for pre-Easter selling will be "peaked" by most retailers by the end of this week and, aided by favorable weather conditions, they hope during the next three weeks to achieve sales totals on a par with or slightly ahead of the same period last year.

Many British and American residents and visitors to Nassau, in the Bahamas, witnessed the recent cornerstone laying for the new home to be known as Shore Acres which Sir Frederick and Lady Williams-Taylor are building in the Vimy Ridge section.

Instructions have been given by the Paris police to local authorities throughout Alsace to watch attentively for any attempt to foment and organize German Nationalist feeling in this department of France. So far there has been little outward sign of the spread of "German fever" westward, but it is felt that precautions must be taken.
The little $50,000,000 "TVA" here in Nebraska has been involved in a series of difficulties, some of which at least roughly parallel those of its big prototype in Tennessee.

A proposal that the Iranian Government levy a 2 per cent export tax on rugs and augment the receipts by an appropriation of $25,000 to be used in publicizing Persian rugs in this country has met with approval there, importers of oriental rugs were informed yesterday. As soon as the preliminaries, ineluding government-sponsored legisolation, have been accomplished, the impost will be put into effect.

Without further reference to the disputed issue of collective security versus strict neutrality, the Conference on World Economic Cooperation at its final session here today adopted with minor changes the other recommendations of the committee of experts.

Mrs. Helen Fuerth Harlow, widow M of James Hoatsen Harlow and daughter of Mrs. Otto Herbert Fuerth of Paris, was married to is Alfred Percy Walker Jr. yesterday is in her home at 28 East Seventieth of Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Benjamin F. Farber, pastor of the Fourth Presbyterian Church.

The building at 66 Fifth Avenue contains a motion-picture theatre and two schools for the education of girl minors. This complicates matters for the operators of the theatre, because their lease contains some unusual restrictions.

A dark-haired young woman about 26 years old was seen to jump into the Hudson River from the Dyckman Street ferry slip yesterday morning. Charles Ruff, the ferry ticket agent, said he saw her remove her coat and shoes, jump in, and swim out into the river,

Housing costs in many cities are higher than they should be due to the operation of antiquated - building codes, declares D. Knickerbacker Boyd, fellow of the American Institute of Architects, in a report he recently prepared for that organization.

William S. Murray, Republican State chairman, predicted today a harmonious organization of the Republican majority at the State Constitutional Convention, with probable agreement on key positions well ahead of the session's opening April 5.

The eighth round of the United States chess championship preliminaries was contested in Group A at the Marshall Club yesterday. Milton Hanauer of Manhattan, former New York State champion, who failed to finish his game with T. E. Knorr of Hillside, N. J., still retains his hold on first place.

In 1931 H. H. Sokal produced a film in St. Anton am Arlberg, Austria, entitled "The Ski Chase." This film starred Hannes Schneider, who was recently imprisoned by the Nazis in Austria. It also has in its cast Leni Riefenstahl, who at that time was hired by Sokal as an actress and has nothing whatsoever to do with the production of the film.

The Navy opened its season on the diamond today by losing to the University of Vermont, 1 to 0, in a wellplayed game. It was the first performance of a Navy nine under Max Bishop, former second baseman of the Athletics.

Each evening nearly 100,000 men and women, ranging in age from 17 to 70, representing many walks of life, attend New York City's evening schools. In hundreds of classrooms in the five boroughs, they can be found poring over textbooks, listening to lectures on economics,

Princeton's Rugby Club opened its season today by blanking Long Island University, 6-0, on Bedford Field. Ed Olsan and Captain Jim Salsich shared. the Tiger scoring with a try and penalty kick, respectively.

Bertram B. Tate, chairman of the board of the Anchor Post Fence Company, sent a telegram yesterday to all directors of the company requesting authority to buy in the open market 5 per cent of the outstanding capital stock of the company, to be sold to employes on a time-payment plan.

St. Xavier High of Louisville, Ky., twice winner of the national Catholic High School basketball tdurnament, stood out tonight as a heavy favorite to achieve its third crown after overpowering La Salle of Cumberland, Md., 40 to 22,
ACCORDING to an announce ment given out by Little, Brown Co., that firm has for the past two years had in its safe a translation of a biography of Gabriele D'Annunzio by Tom.

Cash payments to members of the various savings and loan associations in the country amounted to $485,000,000 during the final half of 1937, reports the United States Building and Loan League. For the entire year the payments aggregated about one billion dollars.

Improved retail buying in response to warmer weather last week helped to "cushion" the drop in store sales according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. "In the apparel lines," the report continues, "coat and suit sections continued to make a better showing than dress departments.

THE musical success of the week, despite undue length and the fact that its material was not of the most weighty, was that of Bernard Wagenaar's triple concerto for flute, 'cello and harp, played by Messrs. Barrere, Britt and Salzedo, at concerts of the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra.

The St. George Dragon Club, with 37 points, won the third of the Associated Swimming Clubs of New York quadrangular meets in the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. pool last night. The Park Central A. A., with 28, was second, followed by Brooklyn Central, with 24; and the Boys Club of New York, with 20.

Britain's rejection of Foreign Commissar Maxim M. Litvinoff's proposal for an international conference of nonaggressive nations to deal with the new crisis occasioned by the German and Polish threats to Czechoslovakia and Lithuania, respectively, occasioned no surprise here either in Soviet circles or among foreign diplomats.

Former President Herbert Hoover. who is aboard the French liner Normandie, due to arrive here from Europe on Tuesday morning, is scheduled to speak on Thursday evening at a dinner of the Council on Foreign Relations, an organization "for the study of international affairs," at the Hotel Ritz-Carlton.
COLONEL CHARLES A. LINDBERGH hopped back into aviation news last week when he flew from Croydon, England, to Dublin, Ireland, to attend the British Empire's conference on transatlantic flying.

M. G. Wines of Mattituck; Codling Hawkins, and Edward Biala of Northport bid in many of the plots offered last week at the annual tax sale in Northport incorporated village. Mr. Wines bought in several which he had bought at previous sales, and the other two were protecting the interests of their clients.

ONE may rave about music or rhapsodize about painting and be regarded by the unthinking as a complete esthete, but if an intelligent enthusiasm is shown about food one is immediately labeled a gourmandizer.

Mrs. Edmund Magrath of East Orange, chairman of the art department of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs, will head the receiving line Thursday at a reception at the Newark Museum which will mark the opening of an exhibition of about eighty paintings by club women artists.
Robert Howard Beattie, rug and carpet manufacturer, died early yesterday in his apartment at the Hotel Plaza after a brief illness. He was 63 years old.
Katherine Bacon's annual piano recital, yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, was attended by a good-sized audience of her admirers who enjoyed again her substantial and dependable artistry.
Lord Digby was revealed today as the man who picked Battleship to win the Grand National and Barbadeche to take the Bickerstaffe Plate at Aintree Yesterday.

EACH time a stage play is transferred to the screen assurances are given that the film version is not deviating in any respect from the original--an avouchment which generally holds until the preview.

The Soviet Government is reported to have lodged a strong protest with the Manuchukuoan and Japanese Governments over the alleged failure of Manchukuo to observe her final commitment on the Chinese Eastern Railway.

The organization of the Navy Deapartment has often been in the past the subject of controversy, but rarely, if ever, has its efficient operation been a matter of more concern to the country than today.

Before the International Leprosy Conference meeting in Cairo, Egypt, Dr. H. E. Hasseltine of the United States Public Health Service described a plan to establish a leprosy preventorium, in the vicinity of the National Leprosarium, to which children of leprous parents may be admitted, cared for and educated at government expense until they reach their majority.

The Defense Ministry today denied charges appearing in the Osservatore Romano of Vatican City that priests who had been taken prisoner at Teruel had been executed in Barcelona in reprisal for recent aerial bombardments.

Letters written by Chinese women educated in America, from the battle sectors of their own country, graphically conveyed last week to members of the Columbia Dames of Columbia University some of the horrors experienced by their friends in those areas.

In his Gainesville speech last week the President returned to his favorite thesis that the great need of the country, if it wishes to restore prosperity, is to "raise the purchasing power" of the "ill-fed, ill-clad and ill-housed onethird" of our population.

A year ago less than one-fifth of the normal total of 218,000 New Hampshire voters decided by a bare majority that the State must have another of its long series of constitutional conventions. Two weeks ago the towns and cities elected the 477 delegates who are to meet in May.
I, WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE. do appoint Thomas Russell, Esquire . . . By Leslie Hotson. With illustrations, maps and charts. 296 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $3.

Efforts to prevent unemployment by granting preferential unemployment insurance tax rates to employers with stable employment records are "unsound" when applied to State laws providing for a pooled tax fund, Harry Weiss, senior technical adviser of the Social Security Board in Washington, writes in the current issue of The Political Science Quarterly.
Administration officials and others who frequently confer with President Roosevelt at the White House have an accepted method of making known his disposition without incurring his displeasure.

Dr. Nancy Bayley Reid, research assistant in the Institute of Child Welfare of the University of California, went from hospital to hospital in Berkeley, Calif., measuring the intelligence of new-born babies.

A reduction of one-half cent a quart in the consumer price of milk, effective with the door-step deliveries of tomorrow morning, was announced yesterday by Sheffield Farms and the Farm Products Division of the Borden Company.
NOW we know what bombing can mean to the big cities of the world. The World War had given only a foretaste of what was to come. Neither planes nor bombs were so effective then.

A strong finish gave Paulie Walker, 151 1/2, Trenton, the decision over Cal Holmes, 146 1/2, Harlem, in the ten-round feature of the boxing show at Rockland Palace last night. A crowd of 2,500 saw the New. Jersey middleweight floor his rival twice in the last round to gain the verdict after a close battle.
NEW YORK chess circles are particularly busy just now and the season is referred to as "momentous." The second open tournament for the championship of the United States is in progress.
NEXT in importance to the Paris openings themselves is the choice made from them by those style experts who go over from this country to cull what they think will most please American women.

1--Florence Hardeman. violinist, William Beller, pianist, Hotel Plaza, 11:30 A. M. 1--Philharmonic - Symphony, afternoon, Carnegie Hall. 1--Kneisel-Alden-Turner Trio, evening. Town Hall. 1--Manhattan Chorus, evening, 47 East Twelfth Street. 2--Boston Symphony, afternoon, Carnegie Hall.,

THIN black borders for prints, in place of the conventional white border, are finding favor with many photographers. The black is frequently more interesting and distinctive than the conventional white border, and many workers are attempting the trick.

Acting Battalion Chief William J. Lennon, chief of staff to Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott, died in St. Francis Hospital, Brook Avenue and East 142d Street, the Bronx, early yesterday after a six weeks illness. He was 64 years old.

Wheat prices on the Board of Trade here today held within a range of about 1 cent a bushel, with the market showing an easy undertone due mainly to sympathy with securities and on predictions that the dry sections in the Southwest might receive moisture overnight.

Novel ideas will be incorporated in a home planned by McClelland Barclay, artist, on the ocean front at East Hampton, L. I. They include a seaward wall of plate glass for the entire studio living room measuring 17 by 33 feet and large unbroken areas with no window muntins to break the view.

Men and women of varied callings will discuss what part each can play in directing the nation's foreign policy when they meet in July for the two-week session of the Summer Institute for Social Progress at Wellesley College.

NOT VALJEAN: Victor Hugo's immortal Jean Valjean went to the galleys for stealing a loaf of bread. Last week in Long Island City Magistrate Soffer had before him a prisoner accused of stealing twelve hot cross buns and eight cup cakes. The accused escaped punishment, receiving a suspended sentence.

Stocks closed from fractions to 2 points net lower in largest turnover for a Saturday since Oct. 23, 1937; turnover, 1,383,370 shares. Bonds generally lower in heaviest Saturday's trading this year; secondary rails weakest; transactions, $4,730,600.

Divertissements appropriate to the occasion will be features of the, dinner dance to be known as "A Night In Capri," which has been arranged for April 8 in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Welfare Fund of La Margherita Society.

Although a recent poll of Princeton University seniors showed the graduating class to be in accord with the university's educational system, it also revealed a general dissatisfaction with the lecturing ability of Princeton professors.
John J. Hefferon, former Representative of the Third Legislative District, died at his home in Pittston last night following a heart attack. He was 55 years old.

Creation of a Federal Capital Insurance Corporation by the United States Government to guarantee the senior obligations of industrial banks, formed to supply long-term capital to small enterprises, was suggested yesterday by Raymond L. Wise, New York attorney, and formerly deputy assistant attorney general, Bureau of Securities, State of New York, as a solution to the current problem of financial aid to small business.
Roderick Stephens, president of the Bronx Board of Trade, has asked Governor Lehman to sign two bills designed to promote parkway construction in New York City.

A detachment of 205 second classmen of the United States Military Academy came to New York yesterday afternoon to see the 3 o'clock demonstration at the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History.

The fortieth anniversary of the death of Anton Seidl, Hungarian conductor and protege of Richard Wagner, will be commemorated at Columbia University with an exhibition of books, manuscripts and music from the Seidl collection, beginning tomorrow in South Hall.

Every election year since the Eighties has been marked by the passage of or a proposal for more liberal veteran legislation. Two years ago the full prepayment of the bonus, originally set for 1945, was enacted, and the nation believed that attempts for further benefits would not be undertaken for several years.

Yale University will spend nearly $200,000 to modernize Welch, Lawrance and Farnam Halls, three of the dormitories built some fifty years ago. Changes will be made in accordance with a plan recently announced to house all the freshmen of the academic department on the Old Campus in the future.

The engagement of Miss Charlotte Blake, daughter of Mrs. Edward C. Blake of this city and the late Mr. Blake, to John Morse Tippett, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Tippett of New Rochelle and Middletown, Del., has been announced.

Harold (Jug) McSpaden of Winchester, Mass., and Sammy Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., shot subpar rounds of 66 today to tie for the lead in the first round of the $5,000 Greater Greensboro Golf Tournament.
Pensioned On His Own Application--To take effect 12 midnight. March 25: SERGEANT--Johnston Humphries, 122d Precinct, at $1,750 per annum. Appointed Aug. 12, 1903.

The forthcoming Congressional investigation by the Tennessee Valley Authority bids more than fair to claim large share in the spotlight which will be turned with increasing brightness on the national scene as the country moves toward the Congressional elections next Fall.

Flashing smoother teamwork and superb hitting, Army began its quest for the intercollegiate indoor polo title in triumphant style last night by dethroning Cornell, last year's champion, by 17 to 4, at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn.
Lou Salica, 119, New York, outpointed Jimmy Urso, 121, Ridgewood, in the eight-round feature contest at the Ridgewood Grove last night before a crowd of 3,500.

SCOUTING is perhaps the most important hobby of more than a quarter of a million American men. Since the movement began twenty-eightyears ago, 1,594,308 men have voluntarily served as Scoutmasters, Assistant Scoutmasters, Cub leaders, Scout Commissioners and in administrative and supervisory capacities. Closest to the heart of the Scout program are the 34,430 Scoutmasters and 41,660 Assistant Scoutmasters who give an average of six hours a week to boys under their leadership.
ONCE in a blue moon comes an epic legislative battle when politicians almost forget pork, patronage and re-election, lay their ears back and fight for principle.

Two more companies belonging to the Atlas-Liberty Taxicab Owners Association, which on March 5 locked out its employes, resumed operation of their cabs yesterday, according to Eugene P. Connolly, head of the taxicab division of the Transport Workers Union.
