Out of a student caucus in which history and political science majors argued and compromised and finally wrote for themselves a set of examination questions, a new type of general examination has evolved at Mount Holyoke College. Frankly experimental,

DESPERATELY the man told the story. Two days before his young son had been fighting in the street with another boy. A woman separated them and they ran away, but one boy turned and shook his fist at the peacemaker.
Prime Minister Fumimaro Konoye's final words as the session of Parliament closed at midnight were a warning that the China affair was far from over.

The sophomores are leading the freshmen by 1 point in the preliminary score of the thirty-sixth annual Greek Games at Barnard College. This lead was obtained because the lyric reader, Reine Tracy, was chosen from the sophomore class, making the score 4 to 3.

AWIDE assortment of fishing tackle will be spread today over the living room, attic, dining room, cellar and dinette in thousands of homes. For this is the last week-end in which to prepare for New York State's trout season, which opens next Saturday and officially brings Spring to the sportsman.

Winning five out of six matches, the Sewanhaka High School Team A fencers won the first Long Islandinterscholastic team fencing championship and the Miguel De Caprilles Trophy today in Calkins gymnasium, Hofstra College. Seven teams were entered in the meet.
Political circles tonight saw a possibility that the Czech Government and Konrad Henlein, Sudeten German leader, might form a working agreement.

The fifteen-room house with six acres of land, formerly owned by Eugene D.Alexander of New York City, at Litchfield, Conn., has been sold to Mrs. Emily C. Osborne of Litchfield, reports Previews, Inc.
Marjorie Dunton's new midsummer hat collection is featuring flowers in many new ways. There's aravishing group for gardenparty or cocktail wear. Lifesized Victorian bouquets make hats.
DNARBORN, Mich. PROMINENT airmen throughout the United States have been invited to Henry Ford's Greenfield Village here April 16 for the dedication of the Wright brothers' buildings,

Miss Dorothy Jayne Dow will be married to Robert C. Mervine Jr. on the evening of April 30, the twenty-fifth anniversary of the marriage of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jay L. Dow of East Orange. The ceremony will be performed in the Munn Avenue Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Robert Brewster Beattie.

Certain plants from the Winter indoor garden are usually discarded in the Spring. These include the cyclamens, primroses, cinerarias, shrubs for which there is no permanent garden space, and any ailing or overgrown units that are no longer decorative.

WITH the eyes of the world focused on the small countries of Central Europe, Samuel Goldwyn believes that audiences now are in the right frame of mind -to receive a picture dealing with beautiful princess who reigns over a mythical kingdom.

The Earl of Derby's St. Magnus, a 5-year-old by the 1924 Derby winner, Sansoving and out of the 1930 Thousand Guineas winner Fair Isle, today won the Liverpool Spring Cup over 1 mile 2 furlongs 170 yards.
MONTREAL, March 26

The assistant superintendents of schools will meet Thursday at 10:30 A. M. in the board room of the Board of Education headquarters, 500 Park Avenue. Mark McCloskey, director of the bureau of recreational and community activities, will speak on the use of school buildings for other than regular school activities.

ARENTS must shoulder some responsibility and not put radio program planning entirely up to the broadcasters or the selection of programs entirely up to the children, Margaret Harrison of the Progressive Education Association warned in a recent lecture in the course of "Story Telling" at New York University.

Horace Albert Thomson of Richmond, Calif., a pharmacists' mate on duty at the Regimental Hospital of the a Fourth Marines at Shanghai, was officially commended by Secretary Swanson today for having contributd blood for Sir Hughe

TRIPOLITANIA'S first postal paper for 1938 commemorates the "XII Fiera, Campionaria Tripoli"--the Twelfth Trade Samples Fair, at Tripoli--and comprises eight values in three designs. Under each picture is inscribed "1938" and "A--XVI" (sixteenth year of Italian fascism). A broad plaza flanked with columns illustrates 5-centesimi brown, 25c green and 75c carmine.

Two hundred and thirty-three probationary patrolmen were graduated from the recruit school of the Police Department in exercises last night at the 165th Infantry Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, and as an example of what may be in store for them witnessed the promotion of 18 officers to higher rank and the elevation of 14 patrolmen to sergeancies.

Economic and diplomatic coercion rather than a military coup on the Austrian pattern was forecast yesterday as Chancellor Hitler's future policy toward Czechoslovakia by Dr. Thomas Capek Jr., secretary to the late President Thomas G. Masaryk of Czechoslakia, speaking at a forum at the Rand School of Social Science, 7 East Fifteenth Street.

Two northern counties will be represented in the English football cup final to be played at Wembley Stadium April 30. Yorkshire's bid for the famous trophy rests with Huddersfield Town, victor by 3-1 over Sunderland in the semi-final round today,

Sponsored by Alton L. Kolpien, president of Home Center, Inc., of 580 Fifth Avenue, Manhattan, for Greystone Gardens, Inc., of which Mr. Kolpien also is president, plans are underway for the erection on the Kaltenbach estate in South Avenue of a ten-unit apartment building containing 300 suites and 1,300
VIENNA. By Edward Crankshaw. With photographs and plan. 253 pp. New York: The Macmillan Company. $3. THIS book, as its author sums up in the subtitle, shows "the image of a culture in decline."

The Senate Finance Committee turned its attention today to proposals to strengthen provisions of the tax laws that penalize corporations for accumulating unreasonable surpluses, but deferred any decisions until Monday.

Thirty-five girl students of the American School of Design staged a fashion show yesterday afternoon in the forum of Bloomingdale's department store. The girls themselves modeled the clothes they had designed and executed.
" A Business Girl's Share in Democracy" will be explored in the eleventh annual nation-wide observance of business girls' day in the Young Women's Christian Association on Tuesday.

The parents of Charlotte Matthiesen, 18 years old, slain by her 16year-old sweetheart, Donald Carroll Jr. in a suicide pact which the boy failed to carry out, will do all in their power to aid the boy, his attorney, Sydney Rosenthal, said yesterday.

Poland must create her own political system in Eastern Europe following Austria's reunion with Germany. It is her historical destiny in view of her territory lying between the Russian and German Empires from the Black Sea to the Baltic. Such is the view expressed in the widest circles in Poland after the Austrian and Lithuanian crises.

A survey of city-owned buildings and of space rented by the city which will result in a large-scale shifting of many departments, particularly in the Municipal Building, is being conducted by Lee Thompson Smith, head of the new Bureau of Real Estate, in cooperation with the Department of Public Works.

Growing realization that individual prosperity is largely dependent upon the prosperity of all is "one very hopeful sign of progress in this country," Sidney J. Weinberg of Goldman, Sachs Co. declared yesterday in a radio address over the Columbia Broadcasting System.
The first days of Spring have brought out New York's shoppers, a bobbing mass of women, each presumably in search of just the right coat, the right handbag for the new Spring outfit.

Now that the soil has sufficiently dried out after Spring thaws, the gardener can turn his attention to the lawn. Unless local conditions are exceptionally favorable, there will be much to be done to put the lawn back into first-class form for the coming season.

The WPA Board of Education projects in New York City have reached an all-time high for service to children and adults despite a 21 per cent reduction in staff, with 533,062 individuals participating last month in the sixteen projects. These include literacy and naturalization education, public forums,
Plans for the opening of a twenty-twoacre development, eventually to contain about 135 one-family dwellings, are being drafted by the American Housing Company of Linden.

WASHINGTON-It will take from 30,000,000 to 40,000,000 words, not to mention many maps and sketches, to tell the story of the American Expeditionary Forces in the World War. Army historians, twenty years afterward, are still working on the records of our units overseas in 1917 and 1918.

Aviation has changed much since 1927 when Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh crossed the Atlantic, but a letter disclosed today that he still has nostalgic memories of the old days of the O. X. 5 Standards and the early air-mail.

Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation, yesterday foresaw the possibility of a "peace table," with sixty-four nations discussing avenues to peace when the exposition beginsnextyear.
With ten new flying records to their credit, Flying Officer Arthur E. Clouston and Victor Ricketts, journalist, landed in London tonight after a 24,000-mile flight to New Zealand and back.

DIVISION 1 Boys 10, Port Richmond 2 Toberoff, Boys, defeated Matericeck, 5-0, and Mantredi, 5-2: Alexander, Boys, defeated Sager, 5--3; Kaplan, Boys, defeated Taylor, 5--4; Schieber, Boys, defeated Matericeck, 5-2; Smith, Boys, defeated Sager, 5--2; Hoppe, Boys, defeated Taylor, 5--0. and Dawson. 5--1 Slavin,
Senator Bridges said today that the proposed Congressional inquiry into the TVA could be "a whitewash, a farce, or a real investigation, depending upon the personnel of the investigating committee."

Dr. John Edgar Park, president of Wheaton College here, and Mrs. Park gave a tea at their home this afternoon at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beatrice Grace Park, to Robert Leland, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Leland of Rye, N. Y.

Forty-second annual communion breakfast of Marquette Council, No. 157, Knights of Columbus, Midston House, 9 A. M. Speakers: the Rev. Francis P. Le Buffe, Cornelius J. Keleher, Thomas I. Fitzgerald, Eugene M. McCarthy, James J. Bradock.

The value of an active export business during periods of declining sales in the domestic market will be emphasized in speeches and group discussions featuring the annual get-together meeting of the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc., on Tuesday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Brooklyn Supreme Court has awarded $141,429 to owners of seventy-five parcels of land taken by the city for the general improvement of the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn. The owners asked $177,468, and the city's realty experts valued the property at $114,944.

WAS Abraham Lincoln a romantic figure? The question is asked in these columns because E. P. Conkle has held him up to romantic treatment in "Prologue to Glory" and Stephen Courtleigh obediently plays the part in that vein.

Fighting further the government's charge that they conspired to raise and peg gasoline prices in violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act, sixteen major oil companies and thirty of their executives will make arguments Monday to vacate a verdict of conviction handed down

Miss Birdella Virginia Murdock, daughter of Charles W. Murdock of New Haven, Conn., was married here yesterday afternoon in the Broadway Tabernacle to Dr. David S. Bayer, son of Mr. and Mrs. David S. Bayer of Nashville, Tenn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Allen Knight Chalmers.

The Hunter College fencing team scored its fourth victory in four starts this season by defeating the New York University women, 5 to 4, yesterday in the East Building at N. Y. U.'s Washington Square center. It was only the second loss in nine dual matches for the Violet co-eds.

The large group of garden apartment buildings on Gramatan Avenue and Cross County Parkway in Fleetwood, Westchester County, formerly known as Chestercrest, has been renamed. Henceforth this project will be known as the Colonial Village of Fleetwood.

Miss Daphne Jean Stewart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Stewart, was married to Herbert Bell Urquhart, who arrived from England on Monday with his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Urquhart, here this afternoon in St. Paul's Church.

Marion County's high school walkout was called off today as the strikers decided to talk things over with Governor Homer A. Holt to see if a shortening of their term can be avoided, at least next year.

An afternoon recital for the benefit of the work conducted by the New York Women's League for Animals will be given by Kirsten Flagstad of the Metropolitan Opera and Bruno Eisner, Viennese pianist, on April 11 at the home of James Speyer, 1,058 Fifth Avenue.

Paul Engel, poet and member of the faculty of the State University of Iowa, will be the speaker at an open meeting of the Manor Club of Pelham Manor, Tuesday at 3 P. M: A second discussion of poetry scheduled for the week in Westchester is a talk to be given to members of the literature section of the Larchmont Woman's Club, Friday at 10:30 A. M.

The Newark Bears defeated the Indianapolis Indians of the American Association today, 7 to 2. Spittler, Russo and Haley held the Hoosiers to five blows, while the Bears reached Page, who went the route for the visitors, for twelve.

Every day the news from the Philippines indicates that the fever-stirred by fears of extension of Japanese aggression-for "re-examination" of the islands' independence program is assuming epidemic proportions.
Public hearings into transactions in stock of the Interstate Hosiery Mills by the corporation's officers and directors will be resumed tomorrow morning in the office of Attorney General Bennett,

Sporadic evidences that business has touched bottom in the current recession are reported in the summary of current industrial conditions made yesterday by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents. There is general agreement, it was added, that recovery from the present level will be slow and difficult, but widely divergent opinions exist regarding the time when the upward movement is likely to get under way.

President Lazaro Cardenas is going to stake the success of his administration on the outcome of Government-labor operation of Mexico's huge oil industry. Despite diplomatic efforts and economic difficulties, Mexico's strong man has determined to hold the vast United States and British companies which were expropriated last week.

Mrs. Bertha Kaplan Spector, bacteriologist and an authority on amebic dysentery, died today in the Billings Hospital at the age of 44. A graduate of the University of Chicago, where she obtained three degrees, Mrs. Spector had been a research associate.

A GLANCE over musical events in Paris during the past few weeks reveals less of importance than the corresponding period last season. Except for a few novelties and important revivals in the operatic repertories and for some truly exceptional performances of Ravel's music during the frequent concerts which followed his death, there has been little worthy of especial note.
Sabariel, owned by the Three D's Stock Farm, won the $2,000 added Jackson Handicap for 2-year-olds at the Fair Grounds today. Sabariel paid $14.40, $6.20 and $4.60 for $2 across the board.

Ligaroti, Argentine-bred horse, galloped to an easy victory in the $5,000 added handicap feature at Bay Meadows today, winning by three lengths over Sweepalot, and covering the mile course in 1:40, Advocator was third.

Aided by a three-base smash by Jimmy Ripple and a home run by Luigi Chiozza, the Giants did a bit of earnest bearing down behind their customarily tight defense today as they resumed hostilities with the Indians.

FOR those who tire occasionally of the inevitable swank and formality at the-highly exploited stops on the night club circuit and now and then yearn for a spot to get unashamedly gay (sic) with folk who still have energy after seeing the double feature down the street, consider Manhattan's neighborhood bistros where a guy can take a gal without surrendering a life insurance policy or mortgaging the old homestead.
A six-run drive in the ninth inning gave the New Orleans Pelicans a victory, 11-6, over the Jersey City Giants in an exhibition game today.

Proving once again the wisdom of the old turf axiom, "Horses for courses," Mucho Gusto, representing the Ramsey and Coppage partnership, easily annexed Coral Gables Spring Handicap before a cheering crowd of 10,000 at Tropical Park today.
The annual Aiken horse show in Hitchcock woods will open Wednesday afternoon with jumping classes open to all, and continue Thursday with seventeen classes entered. Prizes have been donated

Prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday again moved contrary to most outside markets, and, as the result of stubborn resistance, ended the session with gains of 3 to 8 points. Although lower quotations in Bombay widened differences and drew in scattered selling early, a scarcity of contracts proved the dominant feature of later trading.

The Ridgewood Polo Club, national junior titleholder, retained its New Jersey junior championship tonight when it crushed the Evergreen Farms trio of Red Bank, 16 to 9, before 3,000 at Essex Troop Armory.
BURDENSOME inventories of both wholesalers and retailers coupled with unsettled prices are blamed by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., for retarding the radio trade.

Rolland J. Hamilton, president of the American Radiator Company, will be honorary chairman of the luncheon meeting on Tuesday of the New York Building Congress at the Hotel Commodore. The chief topic for discussion will be investment housing for operating profit.

The three upper floors of the tenstory structure at 667 Madison Avenue, southeast corner of Sixty-first Street, which, until recently, were occupied by the Harbor Sanitarium, are to undergo alterations which will convert them into a number of one to three room housekeeping suites.
Scarlett O'Hara, red, and Rose Marie, pink, are newest competitors of the Heavenly Blue morningglory. The Scarlett O'Hara is announced for next year.

Fifty special chairmen on the issues of the Constitutional Convention have been appointed throughout the State by the New York League of Women Voters to inform the electorate on proposed changes in the basic code.

SEVERAL works new to New York will be performed on programs of the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra this week. They include Samuel Barber's "The School for Scandal"; the suite from "Facade," by William Walton, done for the first time in this country with the addition of several new numbers; Quincy Porter's First symphony, and Delius's "Irmelin."
A convict who admittedly "never had the courage to live decently" has left behind a 650-word indictment of society and the penal system which sent him to the electric chair.

Eleven horses eligible for the Preakness were among forty 3-year-olds nominated today for the $2,500 added, six-furlong Rennert Handicap, being revived May 3 at Pimlico after a lapse of seven years. Pimlico's Spring meet opens May 2.

ERNEST BLOCH'S opera, "Macbeth," successfully revived at the Teatro San Carlo here after a generation of neglect, confirmed itself to be what acute critics proclaimed it at its Parisian premiere in 1910: an outstanding milestone in the history of music drama.

The Labor Department's report on employment during February, if not greatly encouraging, is at any rate more reassuring than the comparisons of other recent months. The department's compilations show that, whereas 1,400,000 non-agricultural workers were laid off during January and 870,000 during the two preceding months, the decrease in February was only 100,000.

THE most indefatigable Shakespearean researcher on the Continent is Clara Longworth de Chambrun. This American-born countess, sister of the late Nicholas Longworth and wife of a great-grandson of Lafayette,

Putting Governor Earle "on the spot" is becoming a pastime not limited to Republicans. It has been taken up also by certain Democratic leaders who, before Mayor S. Davis Wilson of Philadelphia belatedly entered the picture as the Governor's possible C. I. O.-supported rival for the Senatorial nomination, felt that circumstances would force them to support Mr. Earle himself in his Senatorial fight.
The National Student Conference broke up in confusion here yesterday when a group of fifty youths tramped into the conference during the initial session.

F. Ambrose Clark's Bachelor Philip, an aged bay gelding, took an early lead today and held it throughout the grueling two-mile course to capture the inaugural running of Aiken's $1,000 Imperial Cup Steeplechase.

Germany's annexation of Austria was no surprise to Benito Mussolini, but was part of a bargain he made with Adolf Hitler some time before the Nazis took control of Vienna, three speakers held yesterday at the Foreign Policy Association's final regular luncheon discussion of the season at the Hotel Astor.

Harry Newton Hempstead, who was president of the New York Giants National League baseball club from 1912 to 1919, died yesterday at his residence, Mayfair House, Sixty-fifth Street and Park Avenue, after an illness of ten days.

Air-cooling installations using water-cooled refrigeration to temper Summer heat showed only slight increases last year in the fifty-one communities served by the Hackensack Water Company in the northeastern section of New Jersey, according to the company's committee on air conditioning.

Fifty-eight groups will be represented in the Brooklyn meeting of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations, to be held at the Jewish Center, 667 Eastern Parkway, on Thuisday. The general meeting, opening at 1:30 P. M., will hear Dr. Isreol H. Levinthal, rabbi of the Brooklyn Jewish Center.

The marriage of Miss Helene Elizabeth Neu, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Frederick Neu of Crestwood and Lake George, N. Y., to Leon Ellis Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis E. Jones of Joliet, Ill., took place here this afternoon in the Asbury Methodist Episcopal Church.

CHALMERS CLIFTON, New York director for the Federal Music Project, will be guest conductor with the Virginia Symphony Orchestra tomorrow at a concert at the University of Virginia. His program will include Schubert's symphony in B minor, Mozart's "Eine kleine Nachtmusik" and compositions ,by John Powell.
The Seventeenth Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries, which opens at noon tomorrow in Grand Central Palace, will feature housing displays of interest to women.

A preliminary announcement this week on the Institute of Labor, to be conducted at Rutgers University June 13-16, indicated that the institute will consider subjects refleeting current national interest.

Joe Louis will defend his championship again this week. The busiest fighter ever to hold the world heavyweight title, Louis will risk his crown for the third time since he lifted it from James J. Braddock last July by meeting Harry Thomas, wild-swinging battler from Eagle Bend, Minn., in a fifteen-round bout in the Chicago Stadium on Friday. night.

The Detroit Tigers finished more than a dozen games behind the Yankees last year and Black Mike the Tiger man--Gordon S, Cochrane to the income tax collector-hasn't forgotten it even though he spent a large part of last Summer in a mild daze. It was Bump Hadley who bumped him on the head at the Yankee Stadium, but Black Mike bears no grudge. He got a trip to Europe out of it, eventually.

The attitude of the engineering union toward rearmament speed-up was explained tonight by Frederick A. Smith, its general secretary. The 340,000 engineers, he said, are "not prepared to provide arms to bolster up dictatorships in any part of the world" and that they would need "strong guarantees to insure that those who have served their apprenticeship will not be swallowed up [by unskilled labor] when employment is not prevalent."

While attending to its business intelligently and competently, the State Planning and Development Commission of New Hampshire has a soul for the arts and a sense of fun. Its monthly organ is delightfully named The New Hampshire Troubadour.

APRIL 2--Sandor-Sorel Ballet, WashingtonIrving High School. 2--(Afternoon) William Matons, Alles Gilmour and group, Brooklyn Museum. 3--(Afternoon) Edouard du Buron, Y. M. H. A. 3--Seenie Roether, 621 Steinway Hall. 3--Scottish Folk Dances (Folk Festival Council), New School.

Roger Conti, the French expert, today won the world championship at three-cushion billiards, defeating Welker Cochran of San Francisco, the defending titleholder, in the deciding match of a tournament in which four European stars besides Conti, and Jake Schaefer of Chicago also competed.

LONDON. MESSAGES in bottles washed up by the sea are more numerous than is usually imagined, and some of them sound tragic-"Ship sinking, say goodbye to all friends," followed by the name of the ship and the date. Coast Guards, when they pick up such a bottle message,

Open air pushcart markets constitute a traffic and fire hazard as well as a menace to public health, the Department of Sanitation reported yesterday following a survey of 4,700 pushcarts in Manhattan and 1,200 in Brooklyn.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Two public officials have recently made striking statements concerning the Philippines. The Chief of Operations of the Navy, Admiral Leahy, formally gave to the Vinson Naval Committee his professional judgment that "the navy which America now has and the navy
Events of the past weeks have shown once more that the British Government would rather watch the continuance of Fascist triumphs in Europe than fight a war which might bring those triumphs to an end.

In one of the most keenly waged finals ever conducted in the city senior high Public Schools Athletic League basketball tournament, Benjamin Franklin High's smartly drilled quintet captured the 1937-38 city championship by turning back a plucky Newtown High five, 29 to 27, at the 102d Engineers Armory yesterday.

Howard Hanson conducted the program given by the NBC Symphony Orchestra last night in Radio City. On this occasion his Third symphony was announced as being played for the first time anywhere in its entirety.
SAILING FOR GOLD. By Clifton Johnson. Illustrations by James Reid. 264 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $2.

In wet and soggy going out in the harbor here, the largest sailing fleet ever gathered competed today in the national championships of the North American Dinghy Association, held by the Larchmont Yacht Club.

A 112-page, handsomely printed and illustrated survey of "Rural Youth on Relief," just published by the Works Progress Administration, was cited today by Aubrey Williams, Acting WPA Administrator, as offering proof that Federal aid to such youth must be continued and extended.

The bill introduced by Senator Glass broadening the authority of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to extend aid to industry and permitting it to resume self-liquidating loans to public bodies has the approval of President Roosevelt, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC, stated in a letter to Senator Glass which the latter made public today.

Miss Henrietta Szold, 77-year-old founder of Hadassah, the Woman's Zionist Organiaztion of America, is endeavoring to arrange for the transfer of Jewish children from Austria to Palestine, she has cabled from Jerusalem to Hadassah headquarters, 1,800 Broadway.

Voelkischer Beobachter, in a front-page editorial entitled "Weak in Geography," pours ridicule on a dispatch published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 24 reporting Chancellor Hitler's order, for the creation of a German Danube fleet and a suggestion in diplomatic quarters that such a fleet, added to the new Berlin-Baghdad passenger airline, raises the possibility of Germany's turning the flank of the British Fleet despite her contractual naval inferioritvy.

The metallurgists have learned the lesson of the rat which has teeth coated with hard enamel. But the rat's tooth is not completely enameled so that the softer parts of the tooth wear away faster than the enamel.

Improvement of the Bronx River, which has been sought for sometime by the Bronx Board of Trade as an aid to industrial and other properties along that waterway's banks, may be started this Fall, Roderick Stephens, president of the board, revealed yesterday.
Recent achievements of younger members of the Yale faculty in scientific research are being brought to the attention of the university and the public by Sigma Xi, the honorary scientific society.

DETROTT. IN a plan to aid sales and increase highway safety, the Ford Motor Company has resumed partially its program of junking obsolete and unsafe vehicles. At present it is impossible to predict how widespread the campaign will become,

Miss Isabel Ramsey Nisbet, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Nisbet, was married this afternoon to Dr. Francis Edward Reinhart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Reinhart, in the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. Dr. Frank Hofmer of New Haven.

Miss Jean Lamont of Bayonne, president of the junior class at New Jersey College for Women, has been elected president of the Cooperative Government Association for the coming year. Students, faculty and administrative officers make up the association.

The Gross-Morton Corporation, builder of the Bayside Hills development at Bell Boulevard and Forty-eighth Avenue, Bayside, L. I., will open five new model homes today -to demonstrate the type of construction and equipment used in fifty-six dwellings now under erection.

Members of eleven garden clubs will attend a series of lectures sponsored by the Federated Garden Clubs of Connecticut in Stamford, Conn., opening Tuesday with a talk by Montague Free of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. His subject will be "The Romance of Plant Life."

New York alumnae of Wheaton College will hold their fourth annual dance on the evening of April in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador. Proceeds from the dance will augment the student loan fund, which aids deserving students at Wheaton.

The nation will begin on Monday to pay higher rates on freight handled by railroads and trucks. However, the Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the railroads to reduce by 3 cents a 100 pounds freight rates on newsprint shipments from International Falls, Minn., and Fort Frances.

Issues of particular interest to women in the State Constitutional Convention will be reviewed by Assemblywoman Jane Todd at a meeting, 8:30 P. M. Wednesday, at the American Woman's Association, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Feminine leadership will be utilized in promoting the interest of the States in the New York World's Fair of 1939, according to an announcement by Grover A. Whalen, president of the corporation. A national advisory committee on women's participation has been formed.

The first victory for a representative of Nassau in the current series among International Star class yachts was registered today by Harry Knowles, who sailed his boat Sandy Mac to first place in the second contest for the Spring championship and the Santa Maria Trophy.

A recent investigation by a Chicago investment concern showed that water systems depreciate less than any other public utility and therefore are one of the best municipal investments for bondholders. The survey revealed that as a large part of the value of a water-works

PARIS. IN Paris, just now, smart women are very busy over their new, Spring clothes. They are pleasantly filling in the Lenten lull in social activities by flitting hither and yon: to the couturier for a fitting; to the modiste to see if that hat really suits the newt hair-do;
Lloyd Coulthard got 60,000,000 votes in a good-will contest here when he trundled into town with an ancient twenty-ton steam tractor and a huge load of junk.

Word was received here of the death of heart disease today in Okahumpka, Fla., of William Werner Trimpi of this place, president of the Newark Rivet Works and a director of the Fidelity Union Trust Company and Franklin Savings Bank in Newark. He was 78 years old.
TAKING Mr. Maugham at his word and summing him up, we find that he has a clear and logical brain but not a very subtle nor a very powerful, one.
The Yankees tonight are confronted with the strange experience of running second to a National League club in this sector of the Grapefruit League, or, at best, breaking even.
SAFE it would seem to postulate that the human mind swarms always with questions--questions to which answers may or may not be expected, may or may not be had.

After twenty-five years as president of the American Criterion Society, Mrs. Leonard L. Hill will preside for the last time at the club's final program of the season on Friday at the Hotel Plaza. In 1913, at the close of a difficult first year, with a treasury deficit and many members in favor of abandoning the organization, the club elected Mrs. Hill president,

Oklahoma A. and M.'s orangeclad Cowboys tonight captured their ninth National Collegiate A. A. wrestling championship in eleven years and had one of their number, Tiny Joe McDaniels, named best in the tournament.

Leading American authors will gather at a writers' conference as a part of the University of New Hampshire's Summer program, Aug. 1 to 11. Discussions of writing and marketing of manuscripts will be held in small "workshop" groups, roundtables and individual conferences.
The annual luncheon, bridge and musical of the Godmothers League, a non-sectarian nursery now in its twentieth year of service, will be held Wednesday, April 6, at 11 A. M. at the Hotel Astor.

Young women who will act as manikins at the two-day sale for the benefit of the Children's Village on April 5 and 6 at Arnold Constable Co. will meet tomorrow at a luncheon to be given by Miss Barbara Hoge at the Stork Club. Further plans for their part in the benefit will then be discussed by members of the group.

Seventy-three girls have been pledged to sororities at New York University this semester, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Dorothy McSparran Arnold, dean of women at the Washington Square College and faculty adviser to the university's Pan-Hellenic Congress.
The annual luncheon, bridge and musical of the Godmothers League, a non-sectarian nursery now in its twentieth year of service, will be held Wednesday, April 6, at 11 A. M. at the Hotel Astor.

THERE is, on the face of it, something attractive in the attempts made now and then to write a full-length play for two characters only. What is nowadays called "full-length" is, in fact, a very short play.
The interior of the Windsor Apartments, a $500,000 structure at Grace Avenue and Barstow Road in Great Neck Plaza, was swept by fire tonight and fifty-three families were left homeless.

Nine new courses will be offered to Hunter College students by six departments at preliminary registration for the Fall semester on April 13. The innovation is in line with the policy of the Curriculum Study Committee.

Familiar items of the domestic scene rivaling for feminine attention with such new fields as public health and housing are combined this week in the Grand Central Palace, where the Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries presents a composite survey of feminine activities.

National Director of the Amelia Earhart Foundation Great interest was aroused at the recent luncheon meeting at the White House, given by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt to organize the Amelia Earhart Foundation, in the proposal to establish scholarships in sociology for women graduates of accredited American colleges, such scholarships to be tenable at the leading settlement houses of the country.

BALL--Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Ball announce the arrival of a daughter, March 23, at Park West Hospital. BERMAN--Mr. and Mrs. A. Toby (nee Ruth Bandler), joyfully announce the birth of Richard's sister, Lynn Sara, on March 20, at Doctors Hospital.

A SCORE of paintings by Gino Severini, who has been closely associated with Italian futurism and French cubism in turn, are on view (till April 9) at the Comet Art Gallery. Carlo Levi, another well-known contemporary Italian painter, is still more numerously represented, and works by six other Italian artists of today are also to be seen.

According to the text of his first election speech at Koenigsberg yesterday and issued today, Chancellor Hitler also replied, though without mentioning names, to Secretary of State Cordell Hull's proposal to organize an international committee for refugees from Germany and Austria.

MEET Spring halfway is the siren call from the great Midsouth resorts where the air is now fragrant with blossoming flowers and the cry of "Fore!" is heard in the land from morning until night. Those who answer this call will find unusually fast, frequent and comfortable trains ready to speed them there.

According to the text of his first election speech at Koenigsberg yesterday and issued today, Chancellor Hitler also replied, though without mentioning names, to Secretary of State Cordell Hull's proposal to organize an international committee for refugees from Germany and Austria.

Today Girls' Service Club-Tea. Paul Allen speaker, on "War and Literature," 6 P. M., clubhouse. Hoboken (N. J.) Junior LeagueInternational relations department tea, 3 P. M., Y. W. C. A. Dr. Mu Sheng Lin, speaker. National Council of Jewish Women (Hoboken, N. J., Section)--Variety show, 8 P. M., Waldheim-Stevens Forum, Hoboken.
The University Club squash racquets aces proved too much for the visitors from Cambridge University, England, yesterday and made a clean sweep of the five exhibition singles matches that were played.

Returns by the first thirty-seven railroads to report for February indicated a possibility that the railroads as a whole might show a net operating deficit for the month, which would be the first such result since February, 1921. The thirtyseven companies had a net operating deficit of $1,083,000 last month, compared with a net operating income of $27,424,000 in February, 1937.

The sixth meeting since the official opening of the Anglo-Italian negotiations occurred this evening when the Earl of Perth, the British Ambassador, again called on Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Secretary, and they remained in conversation for an hour and a quarter.

LAMOIGNON DE MALESHERBES. By John M. S. Allison. 12mo. New Haven, Conn.: Yale University Press. $2.50. A biography of the eighteenthcentury defender and reformer of the French monarchy. FROM STORES OF MEMORY. By Irving Bacheller. 12mo. New York: Farrar Rinehart. $2.50. A volume of memoirs.

The Assembly resolution creating the committee investigating last November's election in Hudson County, Democratic stronghold of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, was unconstitutional and void because it attempted to usurp judicial functions, Vice Chancellor Henry T. Kays ruled here today.

The Commonweal, American Catholic weekly edited by laymen, has passed from the legal ownership of the Calvert Publishing Corporation to the newly organized Commonweal Publishing Company, Inc., it was announced in the April 1 issue placed in circulation yesterday.

For some years the scientists in the General Electric Laboratories have been turning the X-rays on seeds and, as geneticists expected, getting strange mutations. Twoheaded calves and four-leaved clovers are natural mutations. They breed true.

Aviation and Transportation Corporation (formerly Cord Corporation) capital stock, $1 par value, will be admitted tomorrow to dealings on the New York Curb Exchange. At the same time dealings in Cord Corporation capital stock, $6 par value, will be suspended.

Krikor A. Telian, 35 years old, an Armenian who was exiled from Turkey in 1915, arrived yesterday on the steamship President Roosevelt of the United States Lines at the foot of West Eighteenth Street for a reunion with his brother, Arman, a photographer of Corning, N. Y. They were separated twentyfive years ago.

Mrs. Alfred W. Paine and her new partner, Frederick B. Alexander Jr., won an easy first-round contest in the sixth annual rhetropolitan mixed doubles squash racquets championship when they defeated Mrs. Armitage Crawford of the Junior League and B. B. Adams

" The Magic Voice," a musical play in two acts, was presented last night by the Dramatic Club of the Hunter College Model School at the Wise Memorial Hall of Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

Public links golfers who are anxious to get a start on the season will have to wait until April 16, according to word from the Department of Parks, which controls the Van Cortlandt, Mosholu, Split Rock and Pelham layouts in the Bronx; Dyker Beach in Brooklyn;

Events of recent days have convinced officials that present neutrality legislation will remain on the statute books untouched for this session. Possibly further developments in China and Spain will provide an opportunity for something to be done about it next year;

ADMITING with engaging frankness that despite his best effort to present the case for and against eugenics unemotionally and objectively he may himself exhibit bias, Professor Haldane proceeds to examine eugenics

Mrs. James Harper Littell of Xenia, Ohio, has announced here the engagement of her niece, Miss Betty Kingsbury, who is now making her home in this city, to George J. Brady, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis S. Brady of 42 Walworth Avenue, Scarsdale.
Featured by Miss Emily Fuller of Bethlehem, Pa., who won three titles, and Laszlo Bellak of Hungary, who retained his singles crown, the national table tennis championships ended today.

A new steel and concrete roadway is to be laid on the lower deck of the Manhattan Bridge, it was learned yesterday at the Department of Public Works. Advertisements for contracts will be placed Thursday and the job, estimated to cost $750,000, is scheduled for completion within the year.

Dates, quotas and instructors for the active-duty training of organized reserve units of the Second Corps Area during the coming training season were announced here today by Colonel Arthur Polllon, cavalry, commanding this wartime training center.

Miss Anne Rankin Brown, daughter of Mrs. Ralph M. Brown of this @place and the late Mr. Brown, had eight attendants for her marriage today to Clement Olmsted Davidson, son of Mrs. Edward Crawford Davidson, also of Elizabeth, and the late Mr. Davidson. The ceremony was performed in the Westminster Presbyterian Church here by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. O. W. Buschgen.
The heart of Baron Pierre de Fredi Coubertin, founder of the modern Olympics, was buried today with solemn ceremony at the ancient Olympia Stadium.
Individual contracts signed by the Williams Shoe Manufacturing Company of Portsmouth with its employes were obtained by "threats and coercion" in violation of the Wagner Labor Relations Act,
FOG ON THE MOUNTAIN. By Frederica de Laguna. 275 pp. New York: Published for the Crime Club, Inc., by Doubleday, Doran Co. $2. IN Miss de Laguna's earlier mystery story, "The Arrow Points to Murder,"

The marriage of Miss Elisabeth Stearns Bradford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Bradford of this place, to Robert Duane Handley, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Handley, also of Scarsdale, took place here tonight in the Church of St. James the Less. The Rev. James Harry Price performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Alan R. Chalmers.

Women are the "actual purchase ers or the motivating force behind approximately 85 per cent of all merchandise sold at retail," declares Mark Levy, head of the Chicago realty firm bearing his name and treasurer of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

Murray Levine, whose 12-year-old son Peter was kidnapped on Feb. 24, said yesterday he was considering another appeal to the abductors to let him have some indication that the boy is alive. There has been no word from those holding the child since a note early in the case bearing "insignia" which the father said proved it came from the kidnappers.
Mayor S. Davis Wilson of Philadelphia is planning to announce his candidacy on Monday for the Demo. cratic nomination for Senator in opposition to Governor Earle.

THE simplicity and charm of the Cape Cod style of architecture has been combined with modern conveniences in the new home of Mr. and Mrs. E. R. Hansell at New Providence, N. J. It was designed by Matthew M. Simpson, architect, of Summit.

A heavy demand for home financing facilities as a result of the 1938 own-a-home campaign has been reported by the ninety-one savings and loan associations in New York State, Bugent Fallon, general manager of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, said today.
Nearly 15 per cent of Pennsylvania's 10,000,000 men, women and children, the largest number in two years, lived on State and Federal relief during February, State records showed today.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler continued at Leipzig tonight his series of plebiscite campaign speeches, once again referring to "10,000,000 Germans" who suffered or still suffer from the frontiers created by the Treaty of Versailles. He said:

Miss Helen Carolyn Dunn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Randolph Dunn of Maplewood, was married this evening to Dr. Frank Albert Disney, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Disney of Rockville Center, L. I. The ceremony was performed in Prospect Presbyterian Church here by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Arthur Nelson Butz.

Dr. Thomas James Orbison, psychiatrist who figured in many murder trials, died today at the National Military Home, Sawtelle, at the age of 71. He was an expert witness at the trials of Thomas Massie, naval officer, in Honolulu; William Edward Hickman, convicted kidnapper of a Glendale girl, and others.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With many of the conclusions reached by Dean William F. Russell in his article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine most informed educators will agree.

The nineteenth annual New York Catholic Charities appeal will be opened today in 370 parishes in Manhattan, the Bronx, Staten Island and Westchester, Sullivan, Dutchess, Putnam, Ulster, Roclkland and Orange Counties. The appeal will continue until April 4.

Yale, carrying on as had been expected before the opening of the tournament, drew first blood in the intercollegiate championship as the final week of the indoor polo season started off in Squadron A Armory last night.

CHARLESTON'S gardens, famous the world over, are now in full bloom. Azaleas, in flame-color, deep red and orange, magenta, white and lavender, are reflected in the still black waters of her pools and streams.

The Riverside Baptist Church here, decorated with dogwood trees and southern smilax, was the setting today for the marriage of Miss Lulu Clifford Pace to Roland Burke Hennessy Jr. of New Rochelle, N. Y. The ceremony was performed in a candle-lit chancel by the Rev. Dr. Marvin M. MacFerrin.
Three dairymen were sentenced to fifteen days at hard labor today on roads for adulterating milk with water. The judge said that heavier penalties would be inflicted in the future.

The announcement last week by the United States Lawn Tennis Association of the selection of six star women players as members of the 1938 Wightman Cup team was read with interest. This year the American team will go to England for the matches.

Mrs. Helen Byrne Armstrong of 14 East Eighty-first Street, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Byrne of this city, was married yesterday to Walter Lippmann, special writer for The New York Herald Tribune, by Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti.

Walter Kramer of Detroit tonight retained his national singles badminton championship by beating Walter Markham of New York, 15--12, 17--15. Mrs. Del Barkhuff of Seattle, made a successful defense of her women's singles title by beating Miss Mary Whittemore of Boston, 7--11, 11--6, 11--4.

Not with fanfare of trumpets but rather in whispers do the heralds of Spring announce her arrival. So quiet and so gradual is her coming that many a tree, shrub and flower has begun to paint hidden spots of color in nature's garden before Jack Frost has laid on his last coat of whitewash.
Seward H. Mott, chief of the land planning section of the Federal Housing Administration, reports that his staff is receiving many requests for cooperation from various sections of the country.

ALTHOUGH Leon Trotsky has virtually been on trial in absentia at Moscow, his life in Mexico in recent months has gone on almost unchanged. The recent death of his son, Leon Sedoff, in Paris, however, was a severe shock to him, and in the past few weeks he has outwardly aged considerably.

An amendment which would per mit application of a proportional representation plan in the election of members of the Legislature will be presented to the Constitutional Convention which will open at Albany on April 5, soon after it has met and effected organization.

THE board of directors of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York recently elected the following officers for the year of 1938: President, William D. Stewart, president of the Chrysler New York Company; first vice president, Edward P. Mauder,

Horses from the California and Florida campaigns loomed tonight as favorites in tomorrow's renewal of the Louisiana Derby at a mile and an eighth for 3-year-olds, with an added value of $12,000. Ten seemed certain starters with the possibility twelve might go to the post.

The work of the Child Study Association of America in promoting better family life and a deeper understanding of childhood will be aided by the performance of "School House on the Lot" the evening of April 5 at the Ritz Theatre.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia, and the Italian Ambassador and Mrs. de Suvich are among the patrons and patronesses of the card party in aid of the Little Sisters of the Assumption which will take place the night of April 8 at the Commodore.

The second income tax action against an electrical contracting company started since a special grand jury began to inquire into a building trades racket said to have centered around Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an A. F. of L. organization, was revealed yesterday in the, office of Thomas E. Dewey, District Attorney.

Retail trade, although beginning to feel the influence of the approach of Easter, was sharply behind a year ago last week, largely because of the later holiday this year. The drop for the country averaged 8 to 10 per cent, with only a few gains reported and with losses ranging as high as 22 per cent.

New Utrecht High clinched first place in the second division of the P. S. A. L. round-robin team fenc??ng competition and won the right to face Stuyvesant in the final for the city championship on the strips of Washington Irving yesterday by sweeping to an 11-1 victory over George Washington.
Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe's attempted pitching comeback with the Tigers struck a snag today and, as a result, the Reds handed the Detroiters an 8-to-3 defeat in an exhibition game.

Remarking that the real estate market in Harlem is improving, Joseph H. Lopin, president of the realty brokerage firm of that name, points out that this condition has been brought about chiefly through extensive modernization and repair work undertaken in that section within the past few years.

ENGEL--UNTERMAN--Mr. and Mrs. Harry Unterman of St. Paul, Minn., announce the marriage of their daughter, Ann, to Ralph Engel, son of the late Max and Johanna Engel of New York, on March 23.

The Lea act, signed by President Roosevelt on Tuesday, as viewed by members of the Federal Trade Commission, incorporates a number of amendments to the Federal Trade Commission Act which have been found essential to adequate administration of this law after nearly a quarter century of experience.

WITH his eightieth birthday approaching in June, King Gustav V of Sweden began another tennis year by playing in most of the season's tournaments on the Riviera. Ten years ago it was thought remarkable that he was playing at the age of 70, for tournament tennis, as they play it on the Riviera, is supposed to be a young man's game. Yet King Gustav is still going strong.

There is a temporary lull on the European front. How long it will last nobody--unless it is Adolf Hitler or Benito Mussolini--can tell. This lull provides an opportunity to look over the European battlefield, seared with centuries of hatreds. In any attempt to understand future developments on this field, certain fundamental, though conflicting, factors must be taken into consideration.
The "great circle" route between America and Europe was ordered today moved ninety miles southward by the Hydrographic Office because of the early appearance of icebergs off Newfoundland.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed on the eligible list of holders of license for service as teacher of geography in junior high schools, as of March 24, 1938, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license:
St. Louis Symphony--Music for the Final Days of March

Election of seven members to the University Gateway Club, upperclass eating club; of thirty-three members to the Triangle Club, student musical comedy group, and of managers for the Triangle Club's eight business departments was announced here this week.

A SUCCESSFUL play in Paris rarely lasts as long as it would in London or New York, and by the end of February most of the Autumn produetions have run their course. There are three which made a mark-Bernstein's "Cap des Tempetes," Sacha Guitry's "Quadrille" and Francois Mauriac's "Asmodee."
Indian tribes in the Northern Argentine Chaco area were reported today on the verge of an uprising against police trying to capture a notorious band of highwaymen.
Government counsel told the Supreme Court today that a decision invalidating the revised Municipal Bankruptcy Act "would have a catastrophic effect upon the constitutional development of the nation.

For months to come Czechoslovakia promises to be one of the important news centers of Europe. What is the educational background of this country of more than fifteen million people and how does it bear on the present situation?

ALRICH -- Herbert Ware, suddenly, at Syracuse, N. Y., March 25; beloved husband of Jessie V. C., father of Mrs. Herberta Dempewolff, D. Clinton Alrich and Mrs. Jessie C. Regelmann. Services at the Chapel of the Intercession, Broadway and 155th St., New York City, Monday, 2 P. M.

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls established an amateur season scoring record and two of their players broke Eastern League marks tonight as they downed the New York Rovers, 8 to 6. The victory gave the Gulls the Walker Cup and concluded the Eastern Hockey League campaign.

Z. G. Simmons excelled at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday, beginning his good work by taking the highover-all scratch cup with 95 out of 100. He added a leg on the distance prize, breaking 23 out of 25 from the 21-yard mark. and finished the day by topping the scratch list at 155 targets, returning a card of 137.
The luxurious furnishings of one of the landmarks of ever-changing Fifth Avenue, the Ogden L. Mills residence at Sixty-ninth Street, will be offered to the public at auction this week.

One of the largest apartment house operations in Englewood, N. J., in some time is about to be started by Anthony Paterno on a plot of about four and one-half acres within the center of the city area east of Eagle Street, which he has just purchased through the Teaneck realty firm of Alexander Summer.

The forty-fourth annual Columbia varsity show, "You've Got Something There" by Isidore Diamond, a 17-year-old freshman, will be presented at the Hotel Astor next Thursday and Friday evenings. A special performance for alumni will be given Saturday night

IDLE workers, able and willing to work, continue to be the dominating problem before the American people. The problem is not new; it has been with us a long time. The country has been seriously grappling with it for the past six years, and it is a problem which seems destined to remain with us-in some degree of severity-for a number of years to come.
While I find great promise in TVA, I feel that for the permanent raising of levels we cannot depend on the great and big things, but rather on small moral and ethical forces.

Galveston's Anicos tonight captured the women's national A. A. U. basketball championship by defeating the Wichita Thurstons in the tournament final, 13 to 8. Galveston succeeds Little Rock as titleholder.
Dropping its fourth straight game this season, the Pilgrim Rugby Club was defeated by Hofstra College, 17--0, at the Hofstra field this afternoon. Hofstra led, 11--0, at half time.
Miss Frances Paxson Gilman, daughter of the late Theodore Gilman, banker, died here today at her home, 30 Fairview Street.

The 4 per cent mortgage on the Fifth Avenue property of Best Co., Inc., was reduced in 1937 from $800,000 to $650,000, with a resultant annual interest saving of $6,000, Philip Le Boutillier, president, said in his annual report.
Tomorrow morning the newspaper L'Echo de Paris will be merged with Leon Bailby's Le Jour which will carry the double title Le Jour-L'Echo de Paris.
The new monetary crisis in Mexico was brought to a head by the action of the Mexican Government in seizing British and American oil properties. In this move,
A turnkey at the Chemung County jail lost his life in a jail break this afternoon, and two inmates of the institution were arrested several hours later and charged with firstdegree murder.

Exports of the United States to Soviet Russia last year increased to $42,903,000 from $33,427,000 in 1936, while general imports of $30,752,000 compared with $20,517,000, the Department of .Commerce announced today.

The next meeting of the International Sugar Council will be held on April 27, it was announced yesterday coincident with the official declaration that total quotas for the current year have been reduced from 3,611,000 to 3,508,500 metric tons. The council expects to be notified of other releases soon and will consider the whole statistical situation at the next meeting.

Spills and hard riding marked the first polo game for the Howell L. Howard Cup today as a side of Dunbar Bostwick, Seymour Knox, Barney Balding and Conrad Ruckelhaus defeated a team led by Louis Stoddard Jr., 9 to 5.

Luke Appling, White Sox star shortstop, suffered a fractured leg today as the Chicago American Leaguers defeated the Cubs, 10 to 9, in an exhibition game. The injury deals a-heavy blow to the Sox hopes for the season, as Appling was one of the hardest and most consistent hibters on the squad.

Michigan stretched its luck to the breaking point in the National Collegiate A. A. swimming championships in the Rutgers pool last night and by the completion of what amounted to an impossible parlay in the last event made off with the team championship.

In the face of efforts by leaders of the American Federation of Labor to turn their followers against the Lewis-Guffey ticket in Pennsylvania's Democratic primary election, Mayor S. Davis Wilson, with the blessing of the Committee for Industrial Organization, will enter his name on that slate tomorrow to run against Governor Earle for the Senate nomination.

Alberta, that Province of inspired projectors, is truer than ever to Social Credit and the future in the distance. Early this month the Social Credit Act was disallowed by the Supreme Court of Canada as ultra vires, but it still occupies its proud place on the statute book. and a bill, Social Credit Measure
One effect of the recent European crisis has been the sharp acceleration of international gold movements. The war fears started a fresh strong flow of capital toward the United States.

Nation-wide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 34 per cent of capacity, up 2 points in a week and up 5 points in three weeks from the rate that had obtained for five consecutive weeks.

Dr. Joseph Quincy Adams, director, announced today the purchase by the Folger Shakespeare Library of the Harmsworth collection of books printed in England between 1475 and 1640. The collection of about
Movement of freight by motor truck in February was 17.84 per cent under the volume reported for the same month of last year, the American Trucking Associations, Inc., announced today.
The demand for Nicaraguan ipecac has become so great that to avoid its extinction President Anastasio Somoza has issued a decree forbidding digging up of the plant during March, April and May.

Mrs. Harry Clark Boden of Wilmington, Del., sailed today aboard the steamship North Star for Miami with the two children her former husband, Forrester Scott of Philadelphia, is accused of attempting to kidnap.

The present Federal relief program must be revised. For it suffers from a grave defect that the American people, once they have understood its nature and extent, will not continue to tolerate. It establishes a class discrimination, based on a fictitious standard, among the families on relief.

What is believed to be another case of deliberate damage to bombing planes being rushed to completion by the Fairey Aviation Company revived reports tonight that the Air Ministry would station secret anti-sabotage agents in all British airplane factories.

When the Norwegian-American liner Bergensfjord nudged her way into her berth at Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, she carried among her 189 passengers a blue-eyed, blonde baby who had been specially popular.

A meeting between advertising managers of various food companies and lawyers will be held on April E at the Hotel Commodore to determine procedure for working under the recently enacted Wheeler-Lea act, according to Paul S. Willis president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc.

Timely intervention by the police quelled a riot yesterday at Starlight Park as the. New York Americans conquered the St. Mary's Celtics of Brooklyn, 2-1, in the first game of their two-game, total-goal soccer series in the Eastern final for the National Challenge Cup.

The inseparable relationship between government and business should be mutual and cooperative, Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky declared here tonight at a dinner of the Atlantic County League of Retail Merchants.

At the Little Theatre last evening Cecilia Loftus reopened that portfolio of distinguished portraits and impressions and from now until further notice there will be something to do around here on Sunday nights. From 9 o'clock until 11,

With the Finance Committee of the City Council scheduled to meet at City Hall at 2 P. M. today for a second public hearing on Mayor La Guardians relief.tax program, most of the Mayor's, supporters were admittedly gloomy last night about the possibility of obtaining favorable action on the program at tomorrow's general session of the Council.
The first detailed description has become available of Field Marshal Hermann Goering's new ninety-five foot yacht Karin II, which has a solid teak outer hull and is luxuriously outfitted.

A strike of 4,000 van drivers and helpers in Manhattan and the Bronx, effective this morning, was voted yesterday by 650 members of Local 817 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters at a meeting in the Labor Temple, 243 East Eighty-fourth Street.

" International brotherhood will never be achieved by a union of people individually suspicious and prejudiced," said the Rev. Dr. Albert W. Beaven, president of the Colgate-Rochester Divinity School, Rochester, N. Y., in his sermon yesterday morning in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

In a note in the Informazione Diplomatica, official Foreign Ministry organ, Premier Mussolini issued a strong and clear warning to France today that French armed intervention in Spain would almost certainly be the signal for the outbreak of a European war.

Affiliation of the Federation of WPA Supervisors Councils of New York with the United Federal Workers has been approved by the C. I. O. union of government employes, Miss Luella Henkel, treasurer of the WPA group, announced last night.

Americans here who have been active in the Shensi relief work have contributed money to purchase a special back support for General Lin Piao, famed divisional commander of the Eighth Route Army, who was wounded recently in Shansi.
Helen Frederick, young pianist from Indiana, who made her New York. debut last season, gave a recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Her- program comprised two

The German wholesale price index on March 16 stood at 105.8, unchanged from a week before. In the first two months of this year the highest point reached by the German wholesale price index was 105.7, on Feb. 23; the lowest

Under the ostentatious but somewhat absurd title of "Reformed Government of the Republic of China," the long-planned new Central China regime was formally installed at Nanking this morning under the leadership of Liang Heng-chi, Wen Tsung-yao and others whose names mean little even to the Chinese general public.

A general-alarm fire, believed of incendiary origin, destroyed two houses and a boat builder's shop at North Brighton Avenue and the A Back Bay here early this morning. Loss was estimated at $10,000. The screaming of sirens and clanging of bells brought a large crowd to the scene.

Christianity frequently falls into the peril of "becoming a vague, impracticable generality," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, the pastor, said in his sermon yesterday morning in the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street. He warned that vague idealism "is a real danger."

Resplendent in new, light blue, white and gold uniforms, the Queens Rugby Club vanquished the New York Rugby Club, 3 to O, at Astoria Field yesterday. A superb placement kick of 45 yards from a sharp angle by Pat Shelly gave Queens its winning margin. The triumph was the third in as many starts.

Avelino Gonzalez Mallada, identified as the Mayor of Gijon, Spain, and a man listed by police as "Segura," an interpreter, were killed today when an automobile in which they were riding crashed into a truck near here.

Prices of corn for future delivery showed independent strength last week on the Board of Trade here. Export demand from Europe was the dominating influence. For several weeks houses with export connections have been persistent buyers of corn futures and the trade has an impression that a much larger business has been put through with Europe than has been reported.

The seventeenth running of the Louisiana Derby, like the fifteenth, was all Canadian bacon. Wise Fox, sprightly 3-year-old son of the immortal Gallant Fox, won the $12,000-added stake by a scant head from E. K. Bryson's game little filly, Bunny Baby, after a
Some fallacies die hard, and among the toughest is the belief that increased governmental spending necessarily means "increased purchasing power" in the country and therefore more "prosperity."

Frank J. Wilson, chief of the Secret Service, will open in New York tomorrow a drive against counterfeiting which will include education of the public in how to detect spurious money. Under the plans the campaign will eventually be made country-wide.

Troll V. Engelsburg, a Doberman pinscher owned by E. Bornstein of Peoria, Ill., was named best in show as the Mississippi Valley Kennel Club's two-day exhibition closed tonight. It marked the second time in three years that a dog of this breed took the premier award here.
Professor Ismar Boas, noted physician who originated the clinical treatment of stomach and intestinal diseases, died today at the age of 80. He was formerly professor at the University of Berlin.

Gorham H. Harter, former State highway engineer, died yesterday at his home at the age of 61. He was engineer in charge of maintenance and construction in Broome County, a position he held for twenty-five years, retiring last year because of ill health. Mr.
Avenue A, 83, 23.8x100; Julia Rosenthal to Emigrant Bank, mtg $19,000, held by bank. Same property and 216 6th St, 25x97; Louis M. Rosenthal to Julia Rosenthal.

Dr. and Mrs. Henry Haskell Rightor of Helena, Ark., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Pillow Rightor, to Frederick Billings Lee, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederic S. Lee of 125 East Sixty-fifth Street.
The first distribution of State lands to tenant farmers was made today in Pina del Rio Province. Two hundred and fifty farmers received fifty acres each.

The forty-sixth annual report of the General Electric Company, issued for publication today, shows a net income for 1937 of $63,546,762, compared with $43,947,166 in 1936, an increase of 45 per cent. Earnings for 1937 were at the rate of $2.21 a share on the outstanding common stock, against $1.52 a common share earned in the preceding year.

Shouldering part of the university's ambitious $7,750,000 president's program, Princeton's Undergraduate Council is staging a $100,000 campus drive to raise funds specifically for the proposed university library.

Adolph Frankel has been named merchandising manager of the Westinghouse lamp division and will establish the first regional field office, in Boston, for handling the distribution of the new Westinghouse Sterilamp, according to announcement issued for publication today by A. E. Snyder, executive sales manager of this division of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company.

The police of Yonkers announced today that burglars who broke into the home of David L. Saunders, member of a family of tool manufacturers, at 44 Park Avenue, Yonkers, found a veritable arsenal there and stole a dozen firearms and a quantity of swords. The burglary occurred some time on Saturday.

Charles P. Howard, C. I. 0. secretary, and Frank Morrison, secretary of the A. F. of L., cried "dictatorship" today in a debate. Both belong to the International Typographical Union, whose Washington local arranged the debate.

Joseph Jablonower, lone survivor of 114 candidates for what is believed to be the highest paid civil service job. in the country-examiner for the Board of Education at $11,000 a year-replied yesterday morning to criticism of his liberal tendencies.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As I recall at the time unemployment insurance was first put into effect, loud protestations came from headquarters that there was no obligation for the insured to give his religious and political affiliations, despite the fact that the blanks available called for such information.
The week's stock market was predominantly firm, favorable influences being dividend increases and Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's intimation that leading Reich securities henceforth will be quoted in Vienna.

Thirty-eight prisoners dynamited their way out of a coal mine at the Brushy Mountain prison today. Seventeen were captured. Warden Scott Swafford said the break was discovered shortly after dawn when fewer than fifty of eighty-five miners who had been working in the prison's No. 4 mine came to the surface.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 81.9, which compares with 82.3 a week ago, 82.8 two weeks ago, 83 three weeks ago and 83 four weeks ago.

Ordered by Chancery Court to give up his pulpit in the Collingswood Presbyterian Church, the Rev. Carl McIntire, young Fundamentalist pastor, preachedhisfarewell sermon to a large congregation tonight. As he finished,

The general trend of business is slightly better compared with a month ago, according to the current issue of. Banking, official publication of the American Bankers Association, which will be published today. A survey among bank

Mr. and Mrs. E. Cantelo White of Riverdale, this city, have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Barbara Sherman White, to Gibson Fuller Dailey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarke Gibson Dailey, also of Riverdale.
Waves of Insurgent fighters today slashed through government defenses to enter Catalonia and carry their advance to a point less than 100 miles from Barcelona, coastal capital of republican Spain.

Dr. Clarence Edmund Meleney, former Associate Superintendent of Schools of New York City, died last night following a short illness of pneumonia at his home here at 200 Chatterton Avenue. His age was 84.

The engagement of Miss Edith Adelaide Quinlan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Quinlan of this place, to Edson Bly Snow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Edson Snow of New York and Jamestown, N. Y., has been announced by her parents.

Manchukuo has declined to pay the final '5,980,000-yen installment on the Chinese Eastern Railroad, and Foreign Minister Koki Hirota has rejected Russia's request that Japan carry out the guarantee regarding payment that' she gave when the railway was sold.

Retaliation for Mexico's recent actions against American interests was seen in a decision by the Treasury at Washington yesterday ending monthly purchases of silver from that country. Secretary Morgenthau announced the move was made "in view of the decision of the Government of the United States to re-examine certain of the financial and commercial relationships with Mexico." [Page 1.]

Determined to put through a rapid-transit unification program independently of the Transit Commission, the La Guardia administration has already begun work on a draft of a constitutional amendment which would permit the city to issue, outside the debt limit, enough of its own bonds or corporate stock to purchase the Interborough and B. M. T. system properties, it was disclosed yesterday.

Alfred H. Benjamin Jr. gave a tea yesterday at the Sherry-Netherland for members of committees sponsoring a series of "connoisseur teas" to be given at the hotel for the benefit of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

Althrough some nervousness preceded Premier Neville Chamberlain's declaration to Parliament on Britain's Czech policy, there was no disposition to avoid commitments, the war scare played no role in the week's business calculations and stocks were distinctly firmer.

The full restrictive force of the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938 will be put into operation this season with respect to cotton and tobacco crops, the Guaranty Survey, published by the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, says in
AFTER MIDNIGHT, by Irmgard Keun. (Knopf, $2.) A novel of Nazi Germany. AMERICAN WINGS, by Captain Burr Leyson. (Dutton, $2.) An account of flying in the United States.

Displaying courage that carried them ever onward, even when their strength was failing them, the New York Americans eliminated their city rivals, the Rangers, from the post-season play-offs for the right to battle for the world's hockey championship in a long-drawn-out game which ended at 1:25 this morning on the Madison Square Garden ice.

On the foreign exchange market here this week transactions were relatively moderate. Generally speaking, the franc declined whenever the market received the impression that the Blum Ministry would remain in power some time longer, but recovered when it seemed that there would soon be another government.

Changes in China's strategic situation, resulting from the Japanese invasion, have focused attention of the central government at Hankow on Yunnan, the southwesternmost province, producing friction between the central and provincial authorities.

Although the movement in Wall Street is unfavorably commented on here, the tendency is to predict a moderate industrial recovery owing to the assumed depletion of stocks of goods. The banks' view is that the advance in railroad rates promises little improvement to the heavy industries.

Mrs. Margaret Hughes of 340 East Fifty-seventh Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Regina Marie Therry, to Theodore Stanton Friedberger, son of Mrs. Theodore A. Friedberger of 325 East Seventyninth Street.

Miss Jean Lovell Gregory, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Dymond Gregory of Montacute, Oakville, Ont., has chosen the afternoon of April 9 for her marriage to William Dunn Richmond of this city, son of Mrs. Arthur L. Walker of Dongan Hills, S. I., and of the late Stacy C. Richmond.

Wall Street clearly has its eyes trained on Europe. It seems to have little cause at present to look inward- for guidance. Neither business nor politics in the United States affords any ground for definite action in the market.

It is in our daily life that the religion we profess, is tested, the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers, the pastor, said yesterday morning in his sermon at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street. He declared that it is there we should look for miracles.

The establishment of a national representative body with a membership made up of delegates of the Kuomintang and Communist parties and omer prominent political groups is one of the vital questions slated for discussion at the meeting of the Kuomintang National Congress this week.
Acceleration of rearmament may bring important changes in Great Britain's domestic trade, but meanwhile the slacker conditions which have developed in the last few months continue.

Prices of cotton moved irregularly during the past week. In the early dealings prices declined, but subsequently they recovered a part of their losses. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines for the week of 2 to 6 points.

President Lazaro Cardenas declared that the United States Government had informed the Mexican Government that it will cancel its silver purchases from Mexico on April 1, in a manifesto to the nation, issued in the early hours today and published by the entire local press. Mexico from that date will put its silver on the world market, its strong man t said.

The success of the 1938 "Almanac for New Yorkers," written and edited by the New York City WPA Federal Writers Project, will resuit in the continuation of the series for the third year, 1939, project officials announced last week. The Almanac made its initial appearance in 1937 under the imprint of Simon Schuster.
Tibor Eckhardt, head of the Agricultural party, while asserting that Hungary must maintain her independence and internal freedom, advised the nation today to come to terms with Germany.

An open letter protesting against the war mobilization bill now pending before Congress and signed by 500 persons active in church, labor, educational and social work was sent yesterday to President Roosevelt and members of Congress by the National Peace Conference.

Jews must not rely upon any alliances or adopt new interpretations of Judaism, Rabbi Samuel H. Goldenson warned in his last Sunday morning sermon of-the season yesterday at Temple Emanu-E1, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

Organization of the National Labor Standards Committee to seek adoption of fair labor standards by Congress was announced yesterday from the office of the committee, 156 Fifth Avenue. Hundreds of men and women in public life and representing two-thirds of the States have signed a statement approving the committee's purpose.
Father Charles E. Coughlin said in a radio address today that passage by the Senate tomorrow of the Government Reorganization Bill "eventually will mean repudiation of all debts or a revolution."
