A posse of 130 men searched the Ramapo Mountains tonight for a sex maniac who struck two boys with an iron pipe, then seized a third and fled into the hills north of here. The kidnapped child was released two hours later unharmed after struggling with his assailant.

Mrs. Loretto Agnes Cain, wife of Patrick J. Cain, retired proprietor of the theatrical warehouse which bore his name, died yesterday morning at her home, 33-35 168th Street, Flushing, Queens, of a cerebral hemorrhage. She was 58 years old.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,341,990,650. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills.
Eleven Federal savings and loan associations in the New York area reported the receipt of $3,855,298 in savings in the first two months of this year, a high record, they reported yesterday.

Frank Campbell of Larchmont, Bill Dodge of Mystic, Conn., Howard M. Smith of the Thames Yacht Club, New London, Conn., and Miss Charlotte Reed of Pawtucket, R. I., are the national sailing dinghy champions.

The Women's City Club of New York urged yesterday that the Constitutional Convention at Albany next month provide for a unicameral Legislature, for the adoption of the proportional representation method of voting, and for the elimination of the four months' county residence requirement for voters.
The statement of the Bank of France for March 17 showed that the currency ratio had fallen from 47.76 to 47.38 per cent. The gold reserve remained unchanged.
Extending its winning streak to six games, the Philadelphia Passon soccer team ended its regular American League schedule -with a 2-0 victory over Baltimore today.

The need for better business and accounting methods in the fiscal management of American cities will be stressed tomorrow at the national conference of the American Institute of Accountants, in the Stevens Hotel.

If Christianity is to play its part in the world of today, "we need a creed," the Rev. Dr. William P. Merrill said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Eightyfifth Street. He declared we should be vitally interested in "fewer and bigger things."
James MacPherson, an architect, son of Malcolm MacPherson of Manhasset, died today in the Nassau Hospital at the age of 43. He was a graduate of Cornell University.

At home the Japanese military have again been victorious, but on the Chinese front they can report no corresponding recent gain. Exercising relentless pressure and at the last critical moment utilizing an imperial rescript to extend for one day the life of the Diet, the army forced both houses,

A woman who registered at the Hotel Pennsylvania as Mrs. L. H. Rogers of 2,108 North Cherry Street, Chicago, slashed her wrists with a razor blade and jumped to her death from the window of her room on the twelfth floor of the hotel shortly after 3 o'clock yesterday morning, according to the police.

J. Stewart Baker, president of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York, announced yesterday that a special gifts division has been formed for the organization's $275,000 campaign. The unit is headed by Gerald F. Beal, president of the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation.
The 136 W 111th St Corp, Louis Schweitzer, president, bought from the Title Guarantee and Trust Co the five-story flats

BACK in those happy days when Masaryk was still alive, Austria free and Italy's beautiful patience with her "Aryan" ally untested, a little book called "Watch Czechoslovakia!" appeared in England. The author was Richard Freund, a journalist who had written "Zero Hour" and recently returned from Prague.
Lord Ashburton, one of Britain's foremost yachtsmen, died of a heart attack aboard the Queen Mary today while returning from a two-month stay in New York. His age was 71.

More than 1,100 members of the 165th Infantry of the New York National Guard and veterans of the "Old Sixty-ninth" attended communion mass yesterday at Holy Cross Church in West Forty-second Street and then paraded along Forty-second Street to a communion breakfast at the Hotel Commodore.
Railroad stocks slumped to worst levels since 1932 and other issues to lowest prices since 1934, in the heaviest trading for a week since the one ended on Jan. 15; turnover, 6,654,180 shares.

Charles Edward Gauthier, naval architect, died yesterday at his residence, 32 East Eighty-first Street, at the age of 46. He was born at 32 Fifth Avenue, a son of Charles Edward Gauthier, a descendant of Huguenots.
James P. Kilby, who served two terms as Mayor of Nyack and was postmaster from 1918 to 1933, died at his home here today following a long illness at the age of 79.

With the opening of the nineteenth annual drive of Catholic Charities throughout the Archdiocese of New York, former Governor Alfred E. Smith broadcast an appeal yesterday over Station WABC. Mr. Smith said that the charities performed a community service that the community could not afford to be without and that the government should not be expected to do and could not do.

Those who knew Paul M. Pearson will remember him as a self-effacing, shy man, but persistent in his purposes in whatever he undertook. He was primarily a teacher, for years a Professor of Public Speaking in a Quaker college, where, it is to be assumed, only those speak who are moved by the spirit to do so.
The wholesale price index on March 19 was 619, against 614 a week previously and 611 two weeks earlier. The further rise in prices is chiefly ascribable to the depreciation of the franc.
The Anatolia news agency publishes a telegram from Berlin announcing that Franz von Papen will be appointed German Ambassador to Turkey. The news,

David T. Warden, who retired in 1935 as a member of the New York ship brokerage firm of Sieling Warden, died here today after a long illness at his home, 387 Upper Mountain Avenue. Born in Borthwick, Scotland, sixty-nine years ago, he had lived in Montclair since coming to the United States in 1900.

More than a score of new exhibitions, with a range from work by old and modern masters to the products of the latest abstractionist, are on the art calendar as the week opens. Heading the list are two shows arranged as benefits for philanthropic enterprises, both opening tomorrow.

The Giants continued to enjoy a sweeping uplift movement today when, in the presence of a capacity crowd of 4,500, they brought down the Indians, 6 to 0, to record a clean sweep of the two games here and take a 3-to-1 lead in the eighteen-game exhibition series. The bare figures, however, describe only half of it.

Miss Esther Jane Parsons, daughter of Walter Taylor Parsons of this city, was married to James Garven Killin Dalglish, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Dalglish of New York and Glasgow, Scotland, yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

The Bourse and the foreign exchange market were rather unsettled this week, under the influence of the uncertainty of the domestic political situation, the government's financial plans and the threats of war.
A Yankee record that has been jealously guarded in the local sector of the Grapefruit League was unceremoniously swept into the discard today before a gathering of 3,041 natives and tourists.
Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, will open the seventeenth annual Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries at noon today at the Grand Central Palace. She will cut a tape at 12

The reredos of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, a majestic piece of sculpture rising fifty feet behind the altar and framing the rose window, was unveiled at a special dedication service yesterday afternoon.

Seabiscuit, Charles S. Howard's handicap king of 1937, today shook the jinx that had cost him the Santa Anita Handicap and two previous races to capture the $12,500 added Agua Caliente Handicap before a crowd exceeding 20,000. Gray Jack was second and Little Nymph third.

Off to a fast start last Winter, Princeton athletic teams faltered during the final month, but still managed to ring up a .514 average, considerably better than the alltime low of .481 for the same period last year. The varsities were the only group that failed to clear the .500 mark.

Dr. Paul Dineen, in 116 E. 63d St. from Samuel A. Harzog, J. J. Kelly Service, Sigman Ward, Blanche Adler, Joseph Roth, American Earphone Co., L. W. Newman Co., Jere H. Wheelwright, Cosmopolitar Translation Service, R. H. Jaffray Co., Personnel Associates, Inc., in 10 E. 43d St.; Thomas J. O'Reilly, broker.

Alfred Lunt, Lynn Fontanne and Chekhov's "The Sea Gull" meet tonight at the Shubert Theatre in the Theatre Guild's sixth New York production of the season. Others concerned with the event are Stark Young, who has supplied a new translation: Robert Milton, who has

The Metropolitan Section of the Jewish Welfare Board held its senior forum assembly yesterday at Temple Emanu-EI, 1 East Sixtyfifth Street, where representatives from twenty-one organizations participated in a symposium on the community center movement. More than 900 persons attended.

Kachi Wataru, Left-wing Japanese author, denounced the Japanese invasion of China at a meeting here today of Chinese literary leaders. Mr. Wataru declared that the Far Eastern problem was one of defending not only China against the Japanese militarists, but Japan as well.
Eddie Dowling, theatrical producer, disclosed yesterday on his return from a brief vacation in Havana that he will present Eva Le Gallienne next season in "Madame Capet." Miss Le Gallienne,

Lieutenant Albert V. Pitt, head of the safety bureau of the Nassau County police, will begin an investigation tomorrow to determine the cause of the fire that resulted in estimated damage of $250,000 at the Windsor Apartments in Great Neck Plaza last night.

Apparel and accessories accounted for the bulk of orders received in the New York wholesale market last week as retailers prepared to "peak" stocks for pre-Easter selling. New dress lines met with good response and good quantities of sheer frocks were purchased in black, navy and pastels.

Because the "preservation of democracy is conditional upon the preservation of religion," the "greatest strain on American democracy today is non-religious education," Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Fundamental Theology at the Catholic University of America, Washington, declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

American and British-bred dogs divided honors today in the Spring field trial meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club at Kilsyth Farm, the estate of Gerald M. Livingston. The homebreds had a shade the better of the competition, placing first and third, both having been bred on Long Island.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Margaret Schieffelin Pardee, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving H. Pardee of 133 East Eightieth Street and of Lawrence, L. 1., to Talcott Bates, son of Mrs. Willard Travell, also of New York and of the late Rev. H. Roswell Bates.

Funeral services for 18-year-old Charlotte Matthiesen, killed by her sweetheart, Donald Carroll Jr., 16, in a suicide pact which he failed to carry out, were held yesterday in the Cooke Funeral Home, 158-14 n Northern Boulevard, Flushing.

Opposition to proposed Federal wa legislation affecting registry of Va ships in foreign trade and the regunation of rates on freight moving on the State Barge Canal was an nounced yesterday by two associations.
One somewhat noteworthy characteristic of last week's markets was that stocks at New York declined on days when prices on the London Stock Exchange were holding firm or recovering.

The not-too-affluent Dodgers met Tom Yawkey's wealthy Red Sox on the grounds of their Florida estate today and the proceedings were an apt illustration of that old song which sets forth that "the rich get richer and the poor get poorer."

Services marking the-twenty-fifth anniversary of the Fort Washington Presbyterian Church, Broadway and 174th Street, were held yesterday morning before 600 members of the congregation and of West Park Church, the parent body.
" Murder in Massachusetts" has been purchased by Columbia from Samuel Goldwyn and will be directed by Rouben Mamoulian. Anthony Vellier is to write the screen play.

Opening a nation-wide campaign to bring about a closer relationship between authors, booksellers and the reading public, the American Booksellers Association will hold the first in a series of monthly "book and author luncheons" at 12:30 P. M. Wednesday at Essex House. Professor William Lyon

The inherent soundness of the common people is one great cause for confidence despite the crisis throughout the world today, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman said yesterday in his morning sermon at Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

Leaving Manager Stanley Raymond Harris to run the Washington team, President Clark Calvin Griffith has been bustling about the citrus circuit searching high and low for a catcher. His mail-order purchase of Angelo Giuliano of the Browns slowed him up only a trifle.

Supply contracts valued at $2,411,273 were awarded in the week ended on March 24 by eleven Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor has announced. Of the seventy-nine orders placed, twenty-six, valued at $1,057,316, went to bidders in New York State;

Thirty inspectors of the State Department of Labor toured restaurants and night clubs throughout New Jersey from midnight to 3 A. M. today and found many violations of the almost forgotten 1937 law forbidding night work for women in restaurants. night clubs,

Salem Bros. of 329 Fifth Avenue, Manhattan, bought from Merchants Industries, Inc., a brick building on East Elizabeth Avenue, Linden, N. J. They manufacture lamps and sought other quarters when the building in which they were located was taken over by the City of New York. The Fifth Avenue showrooms will be maintained.

The Corn Products Refining Company has entered into a stipulation to discontinue advertising that Linit, a starch product, if used in the bath will relax the nerves or result in skin charm or feminine loveliness or that use of Linit protects the hands against the coarsening effects of dishwashing,

A dozen long range naval bombing planes bucked heavy rain squalls, whitecaps and poor visibility to reach Pearl Harbor today and perhaps herald the expected "attack" on Hawaii by a powerful "enemy" fleet.

Lard futures on the Board of Trade were on the down grade last week in sympathy with hogs, grain and other commodities. With both the domestic and foreign demand for the cash product on a hand-tomouth scale, packing interests were fairly persistent sellers, hedging against the current make.

Two baskets in the last minute of overtime by Harold Firkser, freshman forward, gave Brooklyn College a 46-to-45 victory over the Brooklyn Jewish Center in the quarter-finals of the Metropolitan A. A. U. basketball championship at St. Teresa's Auditorium yesterday. In another game, the Crescent

The market for credit here is firmer owing to the approach of the month-end. Day loans were quoted yesterday at 23/4 to 3 per cent. After the stringency caused by the Reich loan in January, the balance sheet total of all banks in February increased by 857,000,000 marks, with discounts, loans and deposits all rising.

The sixty-one Methodist and Protestant Episcopal Bishops who a week ago signed an open letter to the Roran Catholia hierarchy asking the use of influence with General Francisco Franco against further bombing of noncombatants, were challenged yesterday to make "a dignified apology" by Dr. Joseph Thorning of Mount St. Mary College, Emmitsburg, Md., a Roman Catholic institution.

Miss Edith Mae Kirby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Kirby of Richmond Hill, Queens, has completed plans for her marriage to Robert Bacon Nichols, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clayton W. Nichols of Richmond Hill and Brewster, N. Y., which will take place on the evening of April 23 in the Union Congregational Church, Richmond Hill.

Pelham Parkway North (1-4365), n s at s e side of Esplanade, 118x143; Fanny Silverman to Gussie Katz, 1,011 Pelham Pkwy. 3d Ave (9-2314) e s. 27 ft s of 139th St. 27x103 ; Frederick Katz, referee, to Edgar T. Appleby, 1,155 Park Ave.
Wilberforce Van Slyke died here yesterday in his ninetieth year from the effects of a hip fracture suffered in a fall at his home on Friday.

Governor Lehman begins work this week on the task of signing. or vetoing the thousand-odd bills left in his hands by the Legislature, which adjourned on March 18. He can, of course, use the "pocket veto," merely letting thirty days expire without acting, but this is a prerogative that he, in contrast to some of his pred- tl ecessors, has rarely used.

Gilmore D. Clarke, distinguished landscape architect, chairman of the National Commission of Fine Arts and Professor of City and Regional Planning at Cornell University since 1935, has been appointed dean

An exhibition of more than 100 paintings by members of art organizations in centers near New York was opened yesterday afternoon at the National Arts Club, 119 East Nineteenth Street. The opening was marked by a tea given by the National Alliance of Art and Industry.
The charity figure skating carnival staged for the benefit of the Bellevue Hospital Social Relief Service and the Carroll Club will close at Madison Square Garden tonight.

The Providence Reds clinched first place-in the Eastern Division of the International-American Hockey League tonight, trouncing the New Haven Eagles, 6 to 3. The contest closed the regular season and pitted the Eagles against the Philadelphia Ramblers in the opening game of the play-offs which start Tuesday.

With indignation high because of an attack on a nurse, a 17-year-old youth who, Patrolman Clifton F. Keyes said, confessed the assault, today was rushed 15 miles to Plymouth police headquarters "for safekeeping."
Kai Lo of Dah Lyn, Pekingese owned by John B. Royce of Brookline, Mass., was chosen as best dog in the alltoy-breeds show of the City Kennel Club tonight.

Stressing the need for new school buildings in the city, the Public Education Association in its current monthly bulletin attacks Mayor La Guardia for providing only $8,000,000 for new schools in the 1938 capital-outlay budget.

The directors of the Commonweal Publishing Company, which recently took over publication of The Commonweal, Catholic weekly magCommonweal, Catholic weekly magazine, issued a statement yesterday clarifying news reports of the change of ownership.
Mrs. Rebecca Chase Cunningham of 305 West Hazelwood Avenue, Rahway, N. J., died of a heart attack Saturday night at the Hotel Pennsylvania, Manhattan. Mrs.

The Haywood Management Corporation, Abraham Weinstein, president, has sold to Harry L. Hackett, operator, the six-story apartment house for fifty-eight families at 105 Pinehurst Avenue, between 178th and 179th Streets. Assessed at $255,000, the building is on a plot 150 by 105 feet and was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $243,000 held by the United States Trust Company.

Andrew Michalakopoulos, Premier of Greece in 1924-25, died today. He was 62 years old. Both before and after his Premiership he held Cabinet posts. He had the Foreign Affair portfolio in a number of Ministries.

The Earl and Countess Rosse have returned from the West and are at the Ambassador. They will depart Wednesday for their home in London. Mr. and Mrs. H. Edward Manville, who passed the Winter in Hawaii, will arrive today on the Pennsylvania and go to Hi-Esmaro, their home in Pleasantville, N. Y., to pass the Spring.

With the opening of the overseas road and toll bridge system connecting the Florida mainland with the keys for the first time since a hurricane swept out the old railroad bridge in 1935, motorists will be able to drive from Miami to Key West in about four hours, the Public Works Administration announced today. The distance is about 175 miles.

The report for 1937 of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $31,387,862 after all charges, taxes and reserves, except deductions for mine depletion, equal to $3.62 each on the 8,674,238 shares of capital stock outstanding.

Harlem police raided yesterday the first cockfight reported in Manhattan in many years. Lieutenant Nicholas Pisarra and aides in the Sixth Division quietly entered a seven-room fourth-floor flat at 137 West 110th Street at 11:45 A. M. Within an hour a shuttle-like patrol wagon made three trips between the apartment building and the West 123d Street station. It transported forty-eight

A total of 170 floats have been entered to date in the World's Fair "motorcade" procession to be held on April 30 from Manhattan to the fair site in Flushing Meadow Park, Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, announced yesterday. It is expected that there will be at least 300 floats in the procession and a similar number of other types of vehicles.
BARTHOLDI-Anne Elizabeth (nee Eldemuller), beloved mother of Mrs. Elizabeth A. Jabureck, in ninety-third year. Services and funeral Tuesday, March 29, 2 P. M., at late residence, 2,355 Valentine Ave.

Hundreds of Sudeten German mass meetings today defiantly demanded new elections and autonomy for Czechoslovakia's German minority of 3,500,000. Konrad Henlein, leader of the German front, remained in the background, but his lieutenants stirred big crowds in the regions bordering Germany to a high pitch of Nazi enthusiasm.

Chuck Kleirr's double, scoring Heinie Mueller in the last half of the ninth, enabled the Phillies to nose out the Athletics, 6 to 5, today and gain a 3-to-1 advantage in the exhibition series between the Philadelphia rivals.

Exports and imports of the United States by classified groups of merchandise during February, as announced by the Department of Commerce, are compared herewith with those of January. 1938, and February, 1937.

Gregor Piatigorsky, Russian 'cellist, was again soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, John Barbirolli conducting. Mr. Piatigorsky was heard in Schumann's concerto in A minor, which he had played with the orchestra the preceding evening. His performance was warmly applauded.

Chinese dollars took a headlong dive this morning when the banks reopened. American branch banks here were selling limited quantities of Chinese dollars at between 400 and 410 against 100 United States dollars.

Two women, a 7-year-old girl and four members of the crew of the Coast Guard cutter George W. Campbell were rescued at 5 P. M. yesterday after a twenty-foot lifeboat in which they had been cruising Upper New York Bay capsized off Pier 15, Stapleton, S. I.

A firmer undertone developed in the world wheat market late last week and, while the rally from the low point on Tuesday was not maintained, the trade generally expressed the belief that, had it not been for the drastic decline in securities, the showing would have been impressive.

That the Czechs themselves are less dismayed than many Americans by the British refusal to make advance commitments to defends Czechoslovakia against aggression is another illustration of two phenomena that keep pressing in on the observer who sees this country afresh after a long absence.

Major events today: Ariana Bronstein, violinist, evening, Carnegie Hall; Edward Bredshall, pianist, afternoon, Town Hall; Carmen Reuben, soprano, evening, Town Hall.; Richard Baldwin, pianist, evening, Steinway Hall.

Industry in the Reich is more active and an increasing retail demand for textiles and household articles is reported. The shortage of skilled labor in the iron-wares branches of industry has recently become more acute.

Fifteen matches have been arranged for the Penn varsity tennis team, it was announced today by H. Jamison Swarts, director of athletics. Dartmouth, Albright, Drexel, Virginia and Lehigh are newcomers on the list.
Stanley Rakel and Louis Felix of Cincinnati, scoring 1,293, took second place in the two-man team standings at the American Bowling Congress today.

Cuba's foreign trade in 1937 amounted to $315,643,000, an increase of 22.3 per cent over the $258,062,000 in 1936, according to a report from the American commercial attache in Havana. This was the highest annual value reached since 1930.
More than 180,000 persons viewed Washington's famed cherry blossoms today, according to estimates of the National Park police.

When the last audience filed out and the lights on the marquee were dimmed shortly after 11 o'clock last night another chapter in the colorful seventy-year history of the Grand Opera House at Twenty-third Street and Eighth Avenue was brought to a close.
Young men and women of Ecuador are rallying to the defense of democracy and organizing to participate in- the coming Congressional election. They-want to return to constitutional government.

Sammy Snead, the long-driving sensation from White Sulphur Springs, W; Va., and Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., the leading moneywinner on the Winter and Spring golf tour, were leading the field today after the second round of the $5,000 Greater Greensboro.open.

Four men invaded the home of Charles Milgrim at 80 Willow Road here today and took six pieces of jewelry valued at $93,000 and $1,700 cash. They tortured Mr. Milgrim by burning the soles of his feet with cigarettes to make him tell where one ring, valued at $50,000, was hidden.

Lotte Lehmann, the Metropolitan soprano, gave her last recital of the season last night at Town Hall under the auspices of the Central Synagogue Sisterhood. Miss Lehmann was in her best voice from the start of the evening and never has her singing been more genuinely communicative.
Holmeric, handsome puppy dog, owned by Charles E. Hummer of Brookville, L. I., was named the best in show at the specialty event

The May bill, providing for mobilization of the nation's industrial resources in the event of war, was opposed in a resolution adopted by delegates of the New York East Conference of Methodist Youth, closing a three-day session in the Methodist Episcopal Church here today.
The Right Rev. Mgr. John T. Slattery, widely known student of Dante, died of a heart attack today in the rectory of St. Joseph's Church, where he had been pastor since 1922. He was 72 years old.

Under the Federal assistance program of the National Youth Administration, which is aiding one-third fewer college and graduate students this year than last, the New York State quota for the current school year is $1,058,511, of which $684,240 goes to New York City, Aubrey Williams, executive director, said today.

Pope Pius XI, who is generally regarded as the organizer of Catholic Action throughout the World, told the Most Rev. Martin S. Gillet, Master General of the Order of Preachers (Dominican Fathers) that it was St. Paul who was the real organizer of the movement.

The New South Wales general election yesterday resulted in the return of Premier B. S. B. Stevens at the head of a coalition of the United Australia and Country parties for a third successive three-year term.

Suspicion has been aroused and is finding expression in the Paris press concerning the large numbers of young Germans who recently have crossed the frontier into France and asked to enlist in the French Foreign Legion.

After long deliberation the Austrian Catholic Bishops issued today a declaration that urged their flocks to vote for union with Germany in the forthcoming plebiscite and blessed National Socialist activities for preventing the spread of the Communist "menace."

The forst reactions in London's financial circles to Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's announcement of Great Britain's foreign policy have been favorable, although intelligent anticipation of the Cabinet's course robbed the statement of some of its importance as a stock market factor.

HALPERIN-Mr. and Mrs. Harold (nee Helen P. Spiegel), 789 St. Mark's Ave., Brooklyn, announce birth of a daughter, at Jewish Hospital, March 26. HARRIS-Mr. and Mrs. Harold, 3,633 Greystone Ave., happily announce the arrival of a second son, on Saturday, March 26, at Professional Hospital, Yonkers.

President Roosevelt today was just one of a number of private citizens who bowed their heads and from prayed at a simple Episcopal service that marked the dedication of the new non-sectarian chapel at Georgia Warm Springs Foundation.

Six outstanding foreign stars, three of them just credited with world records, have been asked to compete in the Princeton Invitation Track Meet at Palmer Stadium on June 18, it was announced yesterday by Asa S. Bushnell, director of the games, from his New York headquarters, the Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics.
The value of bullion produced by Ontario's forty-four producing gold mines in February was $7,171,597, compared with $7,638,375 in January, which was the second best month in the Province's history.

John Sanchuck, 52 years old, a farm laborer, was arrested today and charged with the murder early this morning of Michael Cocunnuzs, 47, also known as Michael Malek, another farm hand with whom Sanchuck lived in an old farmhouse on Woodbury Road east of this village.

Two dance recitals, markedly different in almost every way, were to be seen last night when Elna Lillback and her group gave their first performance of the season at the Guild Theatre, and Ted Shawn and his ensemble of men dancers closed their series of five performances at the Majestic.

Southern Natural Gas CompanyFor 1937: Net income after all expenses and charges, $1,329,812, compared with $842,737 in 1936; gross revenues, $6,303,282, against $5,650,083. C. P. Rather, president, says in the report:

Dr. Edward F. Sullivan of Boston, a pioneer in children's dentistry and formerly assistant professor at Tufts College Dental School, died today at Soldiers Home at the age of 42. In 1923 and 1925 he made trips to Labrador with the medical missionary, Dr. Wilfred T. Grenfell.
Mr. and Mrs. Millard C. Griffin of East Granby have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Hayes Griffin, to Henry Gilder Conklin, son of Grover C. Conklin of New London.

The Connecticut sportsmen, according to a resolution adopted by the advisory council of the State Board of Fisheries and Game, are growing tired of the "great waste of public funds and damage to all wild life caused by the drainage operations of the so-called mosquito control projects." Three cheers for the advisory council.

The spirit of religion will atrophy, just like other human faculties, with lack of use, the Right Rev. Dr. H. P. Almon Abbott, Bishop of Lexington, Ky., declared yesterday morning at St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at Seventy-first Street.

World conditions have caused Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska, long an opponent of big navies, to believe that the United States should keep armed to a greater extent than Japan, Germany or Italy, according to an interview which will appear in tomorrow's edition of The United States News, an independent weekly magazine of national affairs published here.

Two young New Yorkers, the latest American operatic "finds," stood at the pinnacle of their singing careers yesterday when they were presented to a nation-wide radio audience as the winners in the Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air and the newest members of the Metropolitan Opera Company.

Now is the time for all good men to take sulphur and molasses. Alas! few doing are it, because the druggists have forgotten how to mix the dose, and those who sampled the brimstone and treacle of their youth remember only too well not to ask for it. But in its day it was
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

Robert McQueen Grant of this place and New York has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Elizabeth Chatterton Grant, to J. Dudley Clark Jr., son of Mr. Clark of Boston and the late Mrs. Clark.

The fourth of the series of public meetings arranged by the Citizens Housing Council will take up the preliminary report of the committee on city planning and zoning at the Town Hall Club this afternoon.

Jackie (Kid) Berg and Frankie Wallace are ready for their eightround battle which will feature the program at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn tomorrow night. Both are veterans and their meeting is expected to attract a capacity crowd.

Skiing at full speed down the Wild Cat Trail in Pinkham Notch, Walter Averrill 2d, 21, of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., president of the Dartmouth College Outing Club, today smashed into a tree and suffered a compound fracture of the skull.

Two automobiles crashed head-on this afternoon on the Lincoln Highway west of Villanova, killing a young man and a young woman, injuring six other persons and entangling highway traffic for nearly an hour. The dead were Carl H.
Chancellor Hitler turned his attention today to the military situation in Northeastern Europe as he took a day off from oratory in the AustroGerman plebiscite campaign.

The ship Manuel Arnus, 7,000-ton Spanish merchant steamer, which has been held in port by Cuban authorities since October, 1936, sailed from Havana for Vera Cruz this morning flying the colors of a Spanish Loyalist warship.

Miss Gloria Baker, American heiress, who interrupted a world cruise here two days ago to obtain medical attention, said today she was "feeling fine-much better" and expected to sail for Honolulu tomorrow.

Successfully defending her senior metropolitan A. A. U. 100-yard freestyle championship and anchoring a record-shattering medley relay trio, Miss Elizabeth Ryan enjoyed a banner afternoon in the Women's Swimming Association's seventyfive-foot pool yesterday.

The fundamentalist has the advantage over the modernist in that his hope for the future is clearer and more concise, and his objective for the consummation of his labors more definite, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, the pastor, said yesterday morning in his sermon at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Emphatic opposition to indiscriminate weight reduction was voiced today by members of the wrestling rules committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association in raising the limits of three classes.

Headed by War Admiral, champion 3-year-old of last year and winner of the recent Widener Challenge Cup race, most of the turf stars of the country have been nominated for the various stake events that will be run during the Spring meeting at Belmont Park and the Summer meeting at Saratoga.

Former Mayor George J. Zimmermann, indicted on nine counts in a city affairs investigation, is seriously ill; his brother, Dr. Edward J. Zimmermann, reported tonight. Special Prosecutor Frank G. Raichle has announced he will ask for immediate trial of the former Mayor when the Supreme Court holds a preliminary hearing tomorrow. Dr.

A St. Xavier High School team of Louisville, Ky., thwarted two years ago in an attempt to defend successfully its 1935 national Catholic high school basketball honors as sophomores, came back tonight as seniors to win the fifteenth annual event.

J. A. Higgins Jr. of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange will talk on sugar under the auspices of the Commodity Club of New York in the Great Hall of the New York State Chamber of Commerce on Thursday at 3:30 P. M. This will be the seventh of a series of lectures on commodities.

An exceptionally large field took part in the final shoot of the month over the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. Among the number was Captain J. B. Grier, a visitor, who broke 98 out of 100.

Plans to erect ten or more new buildings and develop existing facilities at Columbia University, requiring in all an endowment of $50,000,000, were made public yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

Mrs. George Murnane, whose husband is a partner in the investment banking firm of Lee, Higginson Co., is in. the North Country Community Hospital here with a fractured spine received yesterday in a fall from- her horse in the Meadow Brook Hunt.

Trade practice rules for the wool goods industry proposed by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers and scheduled to come before the Federal Trade Commission hearing in Washington tomorrow were released in a statement issued by that organization for publication today.

Miss Gloria Baker, American heiress, who interrupted a world cruise here two days ago to obtain medical attention, said today she was "feeling fine-much better" and expected to sail for Honolulu tomorrow.

Successfully defending her senior metropolitan A. A. U. 100-yard freestyle championship and anchoring a record-shattering medley relay trio, Miss Elizabeth Ryan enjoyed a banner afternoon in the Women's Swimming Association's seventyfive-foot pool yesterday.

Domei, Japanese news agency, reported today that it had learned that the Japanese Government had decided to pay the full amount of the indemnity asked by the United States for the sinking last December of the gunboat Panay.

Miss Constance Catherine Caraway of 44 Gramercy Park, daughter of Herbert A. Caraway of Billings, Mont., was married to Richard Preston Yeatman, son of Mrs. R. P. Yeatman of Houston, Texas, and the late Mr. Yeatman, yesterday afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Scholle of 43 Fifth Avenue.

The Marine Museum of the City of New York will be moved in the late Summer or early Fall from the Museum of the City of New-York to quarters four times as large in the enlarged building of the New York Historical Society at 170 Central Park West.
The selection of five newspaper editorial writers and four reporters for the first Nieman Fellowships was announced by Harvard University today.

Frank D. Comerford, chairman of the board of the New England Power Association, announced yesterday that on April 1 the salaries of all officers and employes of companies in the New England system receiving more than $3,000 a year will be reduced in amounts ranging from 71/2 per cent to 121/2 per cent. No action is being taken at

The financial measures proposed this week by the government are mere expedients. Inasmuch as the Blum Ministry lacks the confidence of the owners of the nation's wealth, it can have no hope of getting the public to take up the loans for extraordinary budget expenditure, and particularly for national defense.
The International Leprosy Conference was told today that experiments on a rat had produced "probably the greatest step in- many years in the struggle against leprosy."

Iron and steel exports from the United States were 46 per cent greater in volume and 28.5 per cent greater in value in February than in the same month last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Agreement on Senator Robert F. r Wagner for Democratic leader of the coming Constitutional Convention was reached yesterday at a conference between Governor Lehman and Postmaster General Farley. Mr. Farley acted in his capacity of State chairman after consulta- Cl tion -with party leaders and con- th vention delegates.

In the National Wild Life Week shoot at the North Jersey Gun Club today, the Class A winner in the first fifty-target event was W. M. Frederick. Other victors were: F. Storms, Class B; F. A. Landis, Class C; H. C. McClosky, Class D, and W. D. Hogan, Class E.

Germain G. Glidden, national titleholder, heads the ranking of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association for the second year in a row, according to the list announced yesterday by John K. Weeks, chairman of the ranking committee.

An offering will be made to the public today by a banking group headed by W. E. Hutton Co. and Goldman, Sachs Co. of a new issue of $5,500,000 of 43/4 per cent debentures of the Champion Paper and Fibre Company.
The proposed investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority, the Byrnes Reorganization Bill and the Revenue Bill are to be the chief topics of interest on Capitol Hill this week.

With Winston Guest flashing the same blazing polo that made him in the past the best of the indoor players, the Optimists galloped to victory in the opening match of the Eastern senior championship at Squadron A last night.

Schedules of matches in Group B of the United States chess championship preliminaries were completed yesterday at the Manhattan Club. Two games, both affecting the leaders, were left over in Group A at the Marshall Club.
Miss Helen Maria Winslow, author and editor, died in Shirley, near here, today at the home of her sister, Mrs. Mary Winslow Hazen. Her age was 87.

Semi-official Central News Agency reports today say the Chinese forces in Southern Shantung Province have retaken Hanchwang and 'Tsaochwang and are about to recapture Yihsien in their concerted drive to checkmate the Japanese forces that are seeking to occupy the strategic Suchow Railway junctinn.

Two men were killed almost instantly and another was injured severely in a collision of a sedan and a delivery truck on a curve of Central Avenue, near Palmer Road, here, about 4 o'clock this morning. Police said the sedan sidewiped the truck, which was traveling in the opposite direction, and then overturned and burst into flames.

A. A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, blamed New England industry for its own "decline" today and bluntly asserted that it needed "imagination and a new approach." Mr. Berle spoke at a convention launching Labor's Nonpartisan League as a "political force" in Massachusetts.

Authorization to call a strike to enforce demands affecting wage and working conditions in the cleaning and dyeing industry was voted by 2,500 members of the Cleaners and Dyers Union, Local 239, at a meeting in Cooper Union yesterday.

Using a ruse, two young and nervous gunmen lured a trolley and bus company cashier from a burglar alarm today, bound and gagged him and escaped with week-end receipts estimated by officials of the system at almost $3,000. Ammiel Dill,

Graduate studies at the University of Chicago concerning the effect of Nazi dictatorship on German education show that various faculties, reverenced for their scholarship throughout the world, have been disbanded and that the great University of Berlin, a center for world scholars until less than a decade ago, now has a former slaughterhouse official as its rector.

The Northern. California Newspaper Guild voted tonight to empower its negotiating committee to call a strike against any or all of four San Francisco newspapers and one in Oakland "if further negotiations with the publishers are hopeless." The vote was 247.to 16.

German and Austrian residents of Costa Rica have been directed to vote on April 10 for the election of members of the Reichstag and in the plebiscite to approve the annexation of Austria by the Reich.
Ralph Farwell Blanchard, partner in the Blanchard-Nichols advertising firm, Western representative for national magazines, died yesterday at his home here at the age of 54.

Dr. Stanley Harry Holmes, retired Superintendent of Public Schools in New Britain, Conn., died here today at the age of 71. Born in Augusta, Me., he was graduated from Colby College in 1890. He held the New Britain
Representatives of 4,000 Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company miners voted today to end a week-long strike and return to work tomorrow at four collieries and the Locust Summit breaker.

Professor Louis William Stern, psychologist, died today at the age of 67. A former director of the Psychological Institute at Hamburg, Germany, he had been Professor of Psychology at Duke University since 1934.

Amid the popping of firecrackers and chanting of a new "national. anthem" the new government for Central China, Chinese in personnel but thoroughly dominated by Japan, was inaugurated today in Nanking.

Senator Harrison, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, announced today that the committee planned to finish its consideration of the 1938 revenue bill tomorrow and, if necessary, might hold a night session.

Scores of householders in Manhattan and the Bronx were unable to move to other quarters yesterday as a result of a strike called by Local 814 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters--the Packers and Furniture Handlers Union--to enforce wage demands upon two associations of small moving companies.

A resolution providing for a standing commission composed of members of both houses of Congress to study all proposals to amend the Federal Constitution was introduced in the House today by Representative Emanuel Celler of New York, a member of the Judiciary Committee.

The American Lumbermen's Mutual Casualty Company of Illinois, whose headquarters are in Chicago, has leased a unit of about 20,000 square feet of space, comprising the entire seventeenth floor of the Canadian Pacific Building, at 342 Madison Avenue.
Alexander Speer, president or Virginia Public Service Company, will have to carry on his fight with the Associated Gas and Electric Company without the support of his board.

The power of New York City to impose a 3 per cent levy on the gross income of public utilities for unemployment relief was upheld by the Supreme Court today in a unanimous opinion rendered by Justice Reed.

At least two persons were killed and ten injured tonight when a tornado struck a farming community four miles northeast of here. The swirling storm roared in from the northwest just after 7 P. M., accompanied by heavy rain and electrical display. It sheared a halfmile path about 200 feet wide.
Herr Goebbels, whom Hitler has entrusted with the spiritual life of the German people, including the annexed

A decline in world silver prices and in the quotations of currencies linked to silver yesterday followed the announcement by the United States Treasury that it would terminate its monthly purchases of silver from Mexico.

Westport residents who have fought construction of a $100,000 "music bowl" here announced today that they had requested of the War Department a public hearing on any request filed by the Longshore Club for permission to erect a stage-dock on Long Island Sound.

The New Deal achieved a striking victory today when the Supreme Court by a vote of six to one in the Electric Bond and Share case held constitutional the sections of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 forcing utility holding corporations to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission or lose the privilege of the mails and other channels of interstate commerce.

President Roosevelt pausea in the middle of his Spring vacation here today to lead the nation in a final tribute to Colonel Edward M. House and to express his own sorrow at the passing of "a great and unique figure" whose "sagacity, prudence, patriotism and integrity made his counsels invaluable in one of the most critical periods of world history."
DILLON, MARY (March 2). Estate, about $7,000. To Lizzie Coll, sister, Kilmallock, Biure, County Limerick, Ireland, $1,000; three specific bequests; Mary V. Conway, 101 W. 77th St., residue.

Informed persons said today that the Costa Rican Congress shortly would be asked to approve a contract between the government and the United Fruit Company involvipg a new investment of $10,000,000 by the United States concern.

The very existence of the Erie's Northern Railroad of New Jersey is threatened by the continued drop in passenger traffic and leaves no alternative to the proposed curtailment in commuter service, A. L. Rogers, Erie representative, said at a citizens meeting held here tonight in protest against the changes.

Two important loan exhibitions opened with previews yesterday afternoon: paintings by Paul Cezanne at the Durand-Ruel Galleries, 12 East Fifty-seventh Street, and portraits by Sir Henry Raeburn at the Seligmann 3 East Fifty-first Street.

The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, a subsidiary of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, is offering to individuals residing in its franchise territories $2,295,000 of its ten-year 5 per cent notes due on March 1, 1948.

The State Mediation Board will hold a conference today of representatives of employers and employes in an effort to avert the threatened strike in the cleaning and dyeing industry. Approximately 25,000 retailers and workers are affected by the situation directly and indirectly.

The sentencing of Richard Whitney for appropriating $214,000 in securities in the safekeeping of Richard Whitney Co. was postponed for two more weeks yesterday morning in General Sessions. Judge Owen W. Bohan, before whom he had pleaded guilty two weeks ago,

The city yesterday fixed June 30 as the date for public sale of its $9,722,000 tax lien against the franchise rights and real estate of the Manhattan Railway Company, owner of the elevated lines and power plants operated under lease by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company.
Walloping three pitchers for twenty-one hits, the Newark Bears of the International League routed the Louisville Colonels of the American Association today in an exhibition game, 12-6.
The British Government is planning to provide trenches in London's quiet parks and squares as refuges from air raids, it was learned from an authoritative source tonight.

With the help of a spirited rally by John Hope Doeg that brought him a victory over the Cambridge No. 1 man, M. B. Baring, the Union League squash racquets team defeated the visiting Cambridge University combination, 4 to 2, at the Union League courts yesterday.

Two building and permanent loans aggregating $360,000 on the two 6-story apartment houses now under erection at the n w cor of Ryer Ave and E 181st St have been placed for the owners, the Ryecroft Realty Corp, Gabriel Besner. president. Ackman Co. Inc, was the broker. The loans run for ten years with interest at 4 1/2 to 5%.

A strange experiment in film making has produced a stranger result in "The Call," a French biography of Charles de Foucauld, the "hermit of the Sahara," which had its premiere last night at the Astor and will continue on a two-a-day basis.

In his most detailed statement since the kidnapping of his son, Peter, on Feb. 24, Murray Levine told yesterday of futile attempts to pay the ransom, insisted he had attempted to keep the boy's disappearance a secret pending a contact and reiterated that the abductors could still deal with him

The 1937 annual report of the Western Union Telegraph Company, which is being forwarded to shareholders today, shows a net income after all operating expenses and charges, of $3,325,769. This was equal to $3.18 a share on the 1,045,278 shares of capital stock outstanding, and compares with a net of $7,199,120, or $6.89 a capital share, earned in 1936.

To the great surprise of Austrian Catholics the Vienna edition of the Voelkischer Beobachter today carried a facsimile of a letter that Cardinal Innitzer wrote to Nazi Organizer Joseph Buerckel under the archiespiscopal letterhead.

In announcing that our Government will buy no more silver from Mexico after April 1 until further notice, Secretary Morgenthau has made one point clear. If our Government has not yet protested officially against the expropriation of American property by Mexico, at least it has brought to a halt the actual subsidizing of the Mexican regime by our own Government through the ridiculous silver-purchasing policy.

In these days of knock-down-and- a drag-out methods of adjusting differences of opinion it may seem quaint and old-fashioned to suggest that voluntary arbitration is still capable of doing wonders. Yet, within limits.

Christie R. Bohnsack, director of Station VNYC from its opening in 1924 until last January, was the guest of honor at a dinner at the National Democratic Club, 233 Madison Avenue, last night. More than 300 men active in politics, radio and the newspaper field attended.

Miss Jane Rose' Stern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton F. Stern of 88 Central Park West, was married to Lawrence Marx Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Marx of New Rochelle, N. Y., last evening in the Garden of the Ambassador.

Arthur G. Jaeger, former Sheriff of Queens County and present treasurer of the Queens County Democratic Committee, was sworn in yesterday by Judge Marcus B. Campbell in Brooklyn Federal Court as United States Marshal for the Eastern District of New York, comprising Kings, Queens, Nassau, Suffolk and Richmond Counties.

The large vacant plot, 100 by 200 feet. on the south side of Twentysixth Avenue, corner of Eighth Street, Long Island City, L. I., was sold by the estate of Edward W. Browning to the R. C. Brown Company, contractors, who will improve the property for use as a shop and storage yard. The RomanCaswell Company, broker, negotiated the deal.

With the first quarter of the year scheduled to wind up with fairly sharp decreases in most advertising media, advertisers and agencies are looking to April and May for some sort of improvement. The current month, chiefly because Easter does not occur until April 17 this year, made an extremely poor showing for both newspapers and magazines, in contrast with a year ago, but April figures should reduce the unfavorable gap somewhat.

Arraigned on charges growing out of an attempted holdup which resulted in the death of their father, Raymond Hammersten Jr., 19, and his brother, Henry, 16, were sentenced today to indeterminate terms in Elmira Reformatory by County Judge Ezra Hanagan.

Mrs. Louis de Bebian Moore gave a luncheon yesterday in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for her brother-in-law and sister, Baron and Baroness Torphichen; Lady Susan Auckland, the Hon. Susan Constance Eden and the Hon. James Bruce Sandilands.

Despite sharply abridged runs there was no dependable outlet on strictly fat steers and yearlings today, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Receipts were smallest of the year to date. At the same time, the hog market worked lower, but rebounding from last week's decline fat lambs sold 25-50c higher.

The annual convention and exhibit of the Metropolitan Conference of Roofing, Sheet Metal and Air-Conditioning Contractors will open at noon today at the Hotel Astor. Richard H. Freyberg, former NRA Regional Administrator for the industry, will preside. Persons prominent in the building field will speak during the three-day session.
Arthur Winslow, formerly a leading gold and silver mining engineer, president of the Boston Petroleum Company and associated with several other firms, died today at his home, at the age of 77.

The National City Bank of New York bought yesterday an issue of $1,000,000 of certificates of indebtedness of the city of Utica, N. Y., on a 0.26 per cent interest basis. The certificates will be dated March 29, and will become due and payable on July 29, 1938.
Following is a semi-official summary of the Governmental Reorganization Bill as it passed the Senate:
The Treasury reduced its price for foreign silver from 45 to 44 cents an ounce today. This was the first reduction in price since Jan. 20, 1936.

Regular operation of. airplanes carrying as many as a hundred passengers each over the North .Pole between the Soviet Union-and the United States within the next five years was prey dicied by President Mikhaill Kalinin in awarding decorations to Ivan Papanin and his three companions of the ice floe expedition in a ceremony at the Kremlin.

Liquidation of the Pierce-Arrow Motor Corporation was forecast today when trustees admitted that the company was insolvent. The admission was incorporated in an order to show cause why the company should not be declared insolvent.

Miss Margaret Ungrich Gregory was married to Richard Monroe Cukor yesterday afternoon in the apartment at the Beekman of her mother, Mrs. E. Ungrich Gregory. The Rev. Willard Edward Rice, associate minister of the Marble Collegiate Church, performed the ceremony in the presence ot the two families.

Debating the $447,000,000 War Department Appropriation Bill for amendment, the House today turned down half a dozen motions by members seeking additional funds for their districts, including one from Delegate Dimond of Alaska for a $2,000,000 air base there.

Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. B. Widener 2d and Joseph E. Widener gave a dinner tonight at II Palmetto for Mr. and Mrs. T. O. M. Sopwith of London, who arrived today on their yacht Philante. James Thayer of Philadelphia is visiting the Wideners.
Further expansion of marriage aid loans and subsidies to large families was announced today by Dr. Fritz Reinhardt, State Secretary in the Finance Ministry.

Withdrawal of the Panama Pacific Line from the intercoastal passenger and freight service was started yesterday morning when the liner Pennsylvania arrived at Pier 61, North River, at the foot of West Twenty-first Street. She was tied up with no immediate plans for future service, after passengers had been discharged and freight unloaded.

Members of the women's division of Cardinal Hayes's Committee of the Laity will meet at noon today at Sherry's to report on the progress of their campaign to raise $100,000 on behalf of New York Catholic Charities.

The British Empire's suggestion that Davis Cup competition be held on a biennial instead of an annual basis will receive little support from European countries when it is submitted to the meeting of Davis Cup tennis representatives in London on June 30.

Charles C. Burlingham, president of the Welfare Council of New York City, announced yesterday that twelve members of the organization's central admission and distribution committee would assist the Greater New York Fund, Inc., in its campaign for $10,000,000 to supplement finances of private health and welfare agencies.

J. Whitney Beals, Boston stock broker for forty years and said to have been the importer of the first motion picture ever brought to this country, died at the Milford Hospital here today after an illness of several months at the age of 71.

American exporters marked time yesterday awaiting developments in the Mexican situation. While watching the trend of events there, they continued curbing shipments to that market and have established a sharp check on credits there. At the offices of Stewart, James Co., appointed official purchasing agents for the Mexican Government last month,

For the relief of orphaned Spanish children, a progressive "Nickelodeon Horse and Buggy Party" will be held next Monday at the Beekman Towers Theatre, Fortyninth Street and First Avenue, and at Le Coq Rouge.

Steel production in the United States is scheduled at 35.7 per cent of capacity this week, the fourth consecutive week of gain, and the best rate of operations since the 36.4 per cent in the week of Nov. 15, 1937. The rate is two points, or 5.9 per cent, over last week.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on March 19 amounted to 306,308,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

Dr. Benjamin White of New York died here this morning of a heart attack. His age was 59. Surviving are his widow, Mrs. Nona Solari White. Funeral services will be held at Emanuel Episcopal Church here tomorrow afternoon, with the Rev. F. Craighill Brown officiating. The body will be sent to Cooperstown, N. Y., for burial.

The House Rules Committee laid plans at a meeting today to write its own version of legislation for a Congressional investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority, eliminating the necessity for Presidential approval in the process.

" Lift the Embargo on Spain" was the slogan of a mass meeting at Union Square yesterday afternoon, held under the auspices of the Medical Bureau and the North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy.

Spanish Rebels approached Lerida, key city in Catalonia, yesterday and made further gains on the 135-mile front. An important operation was the capture of Barbastro, assuring almost complete conquest of upper Aragon.

An effort by the defense to show that one of the prisoners was beaten by policemen after his arrest interrupted testimony for the prosecution yesterday at the trial in General Sessions of five young men accused of murdering a detective during a restaurant hold-up at 144 Second Avenue last April 10.

Automobile output eased last week, running counter to the normal seasonal trend, and the adjusted index sank to its lowest point in two and one half years. It now stands at 52.6, compared with 54.3 for the previous week and 93.3 for the week ended March 27, 1937.

Members of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association and other holders of the association's certificates of indebtedness will receive interest and debt reduction payments amounting to $3,100,000 in the next few weeks, according to an announcement yesterday by J. A. Coulter of Watertown, N. Y., treasurer of the association.

Former President Herbert Hoover will return today from a tour of fifteen European nations on the French liner Normandie. Others coming here on the ship from Havre vie. Southampton include Gordon Ordas, Spanish Ambassador to Mexico, and Senora Ordas; Charles A. Davila,

The navy announced today that the battleships Texas, Arkansas and New York, the demilitarized battleship Wyoming and twelve destroyers would make the 1938 training cruises for naval reserve units of the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.

A proposal of the establishment of a "body to express the will of the people," composed of representatives of the masses, the army and all the country's political parties was contained in an editorial in today's Hsin Hua Jih Pao, official Communist daily.
Sir Vansittart Bowater, former Lord Mayor of London, whose family has been associated with the City of London since the seventeenth century, died at his home in Kensington today at the age of 75.

April 1 has been set as the date for the exchange of old for new shares of Langendorf United Bakeries, Inc., as approved by stockholders at a special meeting on March 1, S. S. Langendorf, president, announced in San Francisco yesterday.

Park Row, s w cor James St, 16.9 1/2x73.3xirreg; also 182 Park Row, 23.7x80.1: also 16 Bowery, 24.111/2xlO1.2xirreg; also 184 2d Ave, 20.8x100; also 29 Oliver St, 21.10x77.2; Frank Licato and wife to Chatham Collateral Corp, 125 Bowery, subject to all liens. (All five deeds dated July 1, 1933.)

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Howard Teller of this place of the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Katherine Louisa Teller, to Harry Charles Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Brown Sr., also of Maplewood.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:
Stocks recovered, closing fractions to 2 points higher in less active trading; turnover, 1,249,400 shares. Bonds generally lower; transactions, $6,228,100.

Mayor La Guardia renewed his demand upon Governor Lehman yesterday for restoration of $12,000,000 in city utility taxes to finance relief after the Supreme Court had upheld the constitutionality of the city's 3 per cent utility tax.

Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone decided today to hear arguments in the Government's gasoline pricefixing case on motions to set aside convictions of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation, Continental Oil Company and Pure Oil Company.

While Loyalist troops held determinedly along the line of the Cinca River and further south, where all Insurgent attacks were reported thrown back, the government prepared for a supreme effort to save the cause for which it has been fighting for twenty months.

Newspapers here and on the Continent record the death in the United States of Colonel Edward M. House. Many of them recall the leading incidents of his career as the personal representative of President Woodrow Wilson in Europe and also as a representative of the United States on several wartime interallied committees.

Fifteen officials of the Ohio Fuel Gas Company and the Columbus Gas and Fuel Company, subsidiaries of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, were indicted today by the Franklin County grand jury on charges of making false reports to the Ohio Public Utilities Commission and defrauding the Columbus Board of Education and the city of Columbus.

Will H. Hays permitted the film industry to plead guilty yesterday to the frequently leveled accusation that it is unreal and "escapist" in its product. In his annual report as head of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors the movie "czar" said the screen could afford such a "soft impeachment" as long as 85,00,000 persons indicated by their presence in the nation's theatres each week that all they required was entertainment and relaxation.

The National Safety Council credited the nation's newspapers today with a leading role in highway safety efforts which saved 1,800 lives since last November. Sidney J. Williams, director of the council's public safety- division,
Head Coach Ducky Pond of Yale said tonight amateur football will suffer "if steps are not taken to correct the evil of semi-professionalism" in college football.
Joe Cascarella and Paul Derringer pitched Cincinnati to a 3-to-O victory over the Senators today, the Reds' first shutout of the Grapefruit League season.

The Society for the Advancement of Young Musicians presented Miss Ariana Bronstein, 13-year-old violinist, in a debut recital last night in Carnegie Hall. The young musician, thus advanced has unquestionable talent. She has enthusiasm, sincerity and sensitiveness.

The Faculty-Student Social Relations Committee at Hunter College will give a series of concerts of recorded classical music, starting today with the playing of Mozart's "Jupiter" symphony at noon in the 2 Park Avenue building of the college. The concerts will include the music of Bach, Brahms, Beethoven and Debussy.

With an eye on the business done by Broadway shows at Sunday night benefits, Philip Dunning is substituting Sunday evening performances of "Schoolhouse on the Lot" for the customary Monday night showing.

The Cargill Grain Company of Illinois and John H. MacMillan Jr., president, and Edward J. Grimes and Philip C. Sayles, vice presidents of the concern, were expelled from membership on the Chicago Board of Trade- at midnight tonight, the deadline given to the concern by the directors of the Exchange to close out -or transfer its uncompleted grain future contracts..
General Giuseppe Valle, Italy's Under Secretary for Air, told Premier Benito Mussolini today that the nation's aviation forces were ready to be pUt to the "supreme" test.

SCIENTIFIC AID (PARASITOLOGY), $1,800 a year; Bureau of Animal Industry, Department of Agriculture. Applications must be on file not later than April 28 if received from Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho. Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington and Wyoming, and not later than April 25 from all other States.

Former President Herbert Hoover, after more than a month abroad, returned to New York early today on the French liner Normandie with the observation that "the only problem not-acute in Europe is that of parking space."

The combination of a fairly good retail trade in some sections of the country on Saturday and the necessity of peaking stocks for Easter promotion brought in a substantial volume of mail orders to the local merchandise markets yesterday, according to manufacturers and resident offices.

Tamekichi Nakamizo, mystery man of Tokyo's "March on Rome Without Mussolini," of Feb. 18, gave himself up to the police last night saying that if he had surrendered during the Diet session certain quarters would have got into trouble.

The listing of eleven new minor leagues and the selection of an alltime all-star team by Editor John B. Foster are added features of the Spalding Baseball Guide, which made its annual appearance yesterday.

Many persons prominent in New York politics, including Mayor La Guardia, attended the funeral yesterday afternoon of George Brokaw Compton, attorney, one of the founders of the American Legion and a proponent of the new city charter.

The text of the Supreme Court's opinion in the Electric Bond and Share case reads as follows: SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES Electric Bond and Share Company, et al., vs. Securities and Exchange Commission, et al.
The State Commission of Correction, reporting on the Bronx County Jail, recommended today that the jailors and matrons wear a prescribed uniform.

An army of 10,000 precinct workers, largest in Kansas City's political history, will go into action at sunrise tomorrow to get out 215,000 voters. The city election will determine if Tom Pendergast's Democratic organization is to add four more years to its unbroken twelve-year hold on the City Hall and may also show whether he is to remain dominant in State politics.

Connecticut River Power Company--For 1937: Net income $1,453,825, after expenses and charges, compared with a net of $1,448,912 in 1936; gross revenues aggregated $4,086,543, against $3,981,439 in the preceding year.
Today's open date in the exhibition schedule came near to being a real holiday for the Dodgers. Burleigh Grimes relieved his butfielders and some of the pitchers through a light workout.

Deals involving renovations and alterations to a number of dwelling properties in the city were reported yesterday by brokers. Frances Farr, whose family has appeared as the owner of record since 1918, closed a contract of sale with the Fourteen Ten Corporation, Eugene Schoen, president, for the four-story private dwelling at 14 West Tenth Street, which is on a plot 36 by 92 feet.

Harry G. Nye, sailing Gale, representative of the Southern Lake Michigan fleet, took the third and last race in the Johnnie Walker trophy series for International Star Class yachts today, capturing the prize with 26 of a possible 27 points.

The Galveston, Houston Henderson Railroad Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to borrow $2,122,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporatior and to issue $2,817,000 of its first-mortgage 4 per cent bonds, Series B, due on April 1, 1963 which would be pledged as collateral for the loan.

Establishment of a municipal lottery selling shares at $2.50 each which would raise $3,000,000 a year for relief was suggested to the City Council yesterday by James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx.

Max Baer, who began his fistic comeback with a decision over Tommy Farr, received official recognition today when the National Boxing Association rated him second among the challengers to Joe Louis, heavyweight titleholder.
The Bureau ot Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 25: COMMANDER McGuigan, J. L., Washington. D. C., to Navy Yard, Mare Island, Calif., April 15.

Mrs. Lorena Underwood, 47 years old, a teacher in Textile High School, 351 West Eighteenth Street, was found dead from gas poisoning yesterday afternoon in her one-room apartment at 28 West Eighty-seventh Street. Police listed the case as a suicide after finding a note in the room requesting cremation.

Walter E. O'Hara, former managing director of Narragansett Race Track and former publisher, publicly apologized today to Governor Quinn, with whom he engaged in a long and bitter controversy before resigning as a track official and selling his newspaper.

Jim Londos, 210 pounds, Greece, defeated Dean Detton, 205, Salt Lake City, last night at the Hippodrome before 5,000 persons. Detton attempted an airplane spin near the ropes and both wrestlers toppled. Detton landed outside the ring and was counted out in 45:54.

A net income of $1,813,707 was reported for 1937 yesterday by the Allegheny Steel Corporation, after deducting depreciation, depletion, interest, Federal and State income taxes including $34,302 surtax on undistributed profits.

Charles A. Angell, who was president of the Cranford Company, subway contractors, left an estate with a gross value of $514,547, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn. The net value of the estate is $423,988. Mr. Angell lived at 560 Third Street, Brooklyn, and died on Aug. 26, 1933.

Dr. Edward Delevan Perry, Jay Professor Emeritus of Greek at Columbia University and a member of the faculty for fifty-eight years, died yesterday morning in St. Luke's Hospital of chronic myocarditis after a brief illness. He was 83 years old.

C. T. Chenery, president of the Federal Water Service Corporation, says in his annual report that "the building of competitive municipal plants to date has not been great, but the fact that it has been held to be legal,

The cessation of silver purchases from Mexico, coupled with the reduction yesterday by our Treasury of the price paid for foreign silver, which had been pegged at 45 cents since Jan. 20, 1936, naturally gave rise to conjecture in financial circles over the possible abandonment of the international phases of our silver program.

The Port of New York Authority purchased from Emil Feustel for $69,000 the three-story flat with store, on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 601 Bergenline Avenue, Union City, and from the Good Value Realty affiliate of the Hudson County National Bank, the two flats at 606-608 Central Avenue, Union City, for $13.500.

CASTLES, BURTON 8. (Feb. 4, 1936). Gross assets, $435,195; net, $39,189. To Mary Frances, $3,000; Henry Cooze, clothing and $10,000; Anabelle Pearson, $3,000; Frances C. Lockwood, niece, one-half jewelry and three-eighths residue; Thomas Castles and Juliet C. Barnes, one-eighth residue each; John Wesley Castles, nephew, one-half jewelry and three-eighths residue. Chief assets, real estate, $379,700. Lord, Day Lord, attorneys, 25 Broadway.

Authors of books in the currently popular "How to --" category will be guests on Thursday of the Fashion Group at a luncheon in the Hotel Biltmore. Speakers will be Gelett Burgess, who wrote "How to Look Eleven Years Younger," and Dale Carnegie, author of "How to Win Friends and Influence People." Miss Clare Elliott of N. W. Ayer Son, Inc., will preside.

Miss Margaret Bostwick and David McElroy, the defending champions, advanced to the semi-final round of the sixth annual metropolitan mixed doubles squash racquets championship at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn, yesterday.

An exhibition of paintings by Mrs. Irving T. Bush was opened yesterday afternoon with a reception at the Fifth Avenue branch of the Grand Central Art Galleries, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street. Today the exhibition will be opened to the public and will continue through April 16.

All deliveries of wheat declined more than 1 cent a bushel in the early trading today to a new low level for the season because of fairly general rains in the Winter wheat belt in the Southwest over the week-end.
Reconstruction of the Cabinet tomorrow is expected, as the Lib- eral party is withdrawing from it. However, the final decision lies in King Carol's hands.

Christopher Cordley, through Wm. A. White Sons, in 135 1/2 E 62d St; Helen Masters Bunting, broker. Dr. Stanley Truex, in 305 Riverside Dr: Peter White, in 900 West End Ave; C. Simpson, in 360 Central Park W: Judith Shayne, in 41 W 72d St; Apartment Renting Co, Inc, broker.

Sweeping Chinese victories in Shantung Province were announced by the military headquarters bere yesterday. Recapture of Tsining, Lincheng and Tawenkow on Sunday afternoon and night and the repulse of Japanese attacks on Lini were claimed.

The firm of Dillon, Vandewater Moore, 120 Broadway, was formed yesterday to specialize in examining the validity of bonds and securities of municipal, public and private corporations. The partners are Milton S. Dillon, Edwin Vandewater, Alonzo C. Heckler and Frank C. Moore.
Although Colonel Edward M. House outlived most of his famous contemporaries in this country, he was still remembered as one of the wisest emissaries who ever came to Europe from the United States.
Full of confidence, the Toronto Maple Leafs left tonight for Boston to resume battling there with the bruising Bruins for a National Hockey League title almost within their grasp.

A plan for the reorganization of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, now in liquidation, which is backed by substantial creditor interests was attacked yesterday in State Supreme Court as unlawful and inequitable by representatives of stockholders.

Arab terrorism is again widespread in Palestine, and scarcely a day passes without casualties among Jews and Arabs alike as a result of attacks on buses, private automobiles and individuals walking along city streets.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today, Ralph M. Carson, Fred S. Weltzner. Henry Lichtig, John A. Sullivan, Harold W. Conroy, Warner W. Gardner and Allen W. Dulles of New York were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:
Dr. Joseph A. Sileo fought for his life in Lutheran Hospital yesterday, the victim of an attack as he lay in bed in his home at 8 Norwood Avenue, Brooklyn, early Sunday morning.
The international stock market indices for March 26, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

So much stress has been put upon the fact that the Federal Housing Administration now will insure 90 per cent loans on new construction that some property owners have gained the impression no more mortgages on old houses are being insured.

Random- House has announced for publication on April 28 the first volumes of the long-heralded "Public Papers and Addresses of Franklin D. Roosevelt." These volumes, of which there are five, will cover the period from 1928 to 1932. Additional volumes, covering the second administration, will appear next year.

Members of Auxiliary No. 5 of Stony Wold Sanatorium will hold their fourth annual Tip Top Ball on May 6 in the ballroom of the Plaza. As in previous years, proceeds of the benefit will aid young women and girls suffering from pulmonary tuberculosis.

Several parties were given last night for juniors in society who are at home from colleges and schools for the Spring recess. Some of the dances were in continuation of series begun during the Thanksgiving or Christmas holidays.

Turpentine steady, 24c; sales, 115 barrels; receipts, 273 barrels; shipments, 360 barrels; stock, 22,846 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 717 barrels; receipts, 1,486 barrels; shipments, 3,268 barrels; stock, 63,453 barrels; stock, 63,453 barrels. Quote: B. $3.50; D, 53.75; E, $3.80:

If the trend of rising taxes and other costs continues, it will result either in a higher level of prices of finished goods, which of course means a diminished real income for consumers, or a further reduction of profit margins, P. W. Litchfield, president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in Akron. Ohio.

Colonel Edward Mandell House, unique figure of American politics and the quiet adviser who stood behind President Woodrow Wilson throughout his administration, died yesterday morning at his home, 104 East Sixty-eighth Street. He would have been 80 years old next July 26.

Cecil B. De Mille announced today that "Union Pacific," the story of the railroad's building, will be his next, supplanting the previously announced "Hudson Bay Company." This will be the producer's sixtyfifth film.
