Anthony Edward Santasiere, exchampion of the Marshall Chess Club and New York State champion in 1928 and 1930, last night defeated Ted S. Barron of Flushing in twenty-nine moves in their postponed seventh-round game of the United States championship preliminaries in Group A at the Marshall Club.

Ben M. Jerome, retired composer, died on Saturday in the Huntington Hospital after an illness of four days. His age was 56. Mr. Jerome, who was born in New York, composed a score or more of songs which were popular some years ago.

President Roosevelt received today an enthusiastic endorsement of the Tennessee Valley program when a delegation headed by Governor Browning of Tennessee called and invited him and Mrs. Roosevelt to attend ceremonies marking the seventy-fifth anniversary of four Civil War battles fought in that area.

China's main aviation training center is now situated in this capital of the country's southwestern Yunnan Province to which most of the staff and equipment of the main branches of the Central Aviation Schools at Hangchow and Nanchao have been removed.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Color in Dress Fabrics," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.; Egyptian collection (general tour), noon; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Design in Wood," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.: "The Mining Emperors," Mabel Harrison Duncan, 4 P. M.

Bonds were lower in quiet but confused trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Some groups, notably a few selected railroad issues, showed moderate rallies, but those were offset by further declines in other sections of the corporate list, and the combined price average for that group eased off 0.06 point

The Port of New York Authority will continue its study of suburban transit problems tomorrow with a poll of persons using the ferries from Staten Island to Manhattan. A similar poll of persons on their way from New Jersey was made last week.

Harry W. Parker, retired chief of the Stamford Fire Department, was found dead at his home in Bridgeport this morning an hour after he had seemed in good health while talking with neighbors. Death was attributed to a heart attack. His age was 78.
The following are appointed to the position of patrolman on probation at $2,000 per annum, effective March 26: To Recruits Training School, Police Academy:

Miss Viola Winmill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Winmill of this city and Warrenton, Va., has chosen May 3 as the date for her marriage to Randolph Duffey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Duffey of Middleburg, Va. The wedding will take place in St. James Episcopal Church. Warrenton.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended March 24 was 256 against 229 for the preceding week and 189 for the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet Inc.
Commonwealth President Manuel L. Quezon invited Datu Ombra Amilbangsa to surrender his title of Sultan as the Moro chief became Governor of Sulu today.

The remarkable New York Americans will launch their drive toward the Stanley Cup hockey finals against the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden tonight. The semi-final series will be contested on a two-out-of-three basis, with the second game at Chicago on Thursday and the third, if necessary, at the Garden on Sunday.
Packing a double threat at right wing through a tie vote, The Canadian Press eighth annual National Hockey League all-star teams were announced tonight.
Concerts today: Ann Jamison, coloratura soprano, evening, Town Hall; the Augustana College Choir from Illinois, evening, Carnegie Hall; Youry Bilstin, 'cellist, evening, the Barbizon.

Complete and immediate revision of New York City's zoning regulations and the development of the city's residential areas into selfcontained neighborhood communities was recommended in the preliminary report presented yesterday to the Citizens Housing Council by its committee on planning and zoning.
It is not too much to say that the career of Colonel House was unique in history. An idealist and dreamer, he at the same time outdistanced the most practical masters of the art of politics.

Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page, women's national golf champion scored an astonishing 69 in the North-and-South tournament today for what golf experts described as a new American record for women in qualifying for a major tournament. Mrs. Page won this tourney last year.
The funeral of the Right Rev. Phillip Cook, D. D., Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal diocese of Delaware, was held today. The Bishop died Friday.

The Second Corps headquarters of the United States Army at Governors Island announced yesterday the appointment of a board of army officers to conduct a practical test of applicants for the eligible list for brigadier general of the line, reserve.

The first arrest of a person linked to the fraudulent passport ring uncovered after the disappearance of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph A. Rubens, alias the Donald L. Robinsons, was made last night by Federal officers and city detectives. The Rubenses are now under arrest in Russia.

Despite a slight increase in the number of traffic accidents last week, compared with that of the corresponding week last year, figures compiled by the safety bureau of the Police Department yesterday showed declines in the number killed or injured in traffic. For the week the tabulated returns showed:

Mrs. Jane Howard Woodend, widow, of Dr. William E. Woodend of New York, died Friday in Oklahoma City at the age of 63 and was buried here today. She was a daughter of the late Dr. F. F. Howard of New York, president of the old Fourteenth Street Bank. A brother, Watson Howard, died in Oklahoma City in 1934. No immediate relatives survive.

Eieetric Advisers, Inc., New York, has filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Holding Company Act for approval of its organization and conduct of business as a mutual service company for certain companies in the Cities Service Power and Light Company, a registered holding company, the SEC announced today.

The Supreme Court decision today in the Electric Bond and Share case started a prompt movement by waiting utility holding companies to comply with the requirements of the law that they register with the Securities and Exchange Commission. About 100 holding companies, it was estimated, had not registered before the decision.
Mike (Kid) Frattini, 149, Italy gained a decisive six-round verdict over Augustin Arellano, 149, East Side, in the feature bout before 2,000 persons at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

A new low point for the current recession in wholesale commodity prices was reached last week, according to the price index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association. This index in the week ended March 26 dropped to 75.8 per cent of the 1926-28 average, the lowest point recorded since June, 1936.

Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., burned up the greens and fairways of the Valley Brook course today to win the first annual $5,000 Greater Greensboro golf tournament with a brilliant seventy-two-hole score of 271.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had: CUSTOMS 4099-Picker X-ray Corporation v. United States. Opinion by Judge Garrett. The United States Customs Court Judgment is affirmed.
The Erskine Lakes Preserve, over in New Jersey, is offering the fly fisherman who yearns for the society of other fly fishermen several stretches of water where the bait man may not tread.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange continued to improve yesterday and ended 2 points higher to 3 points lower. Mill calling disclosed relatively few contracts hanging over the market and the May sold at 8.78 cents a pound, or $1.50 a bale above the low made last Week.

The Eighth Avenue Coach Corporation asked the courts yesterday to enjoin the city and Police Commissioner Valentine from enforcing the proposed new traffic regulation, effective April 4, which would convert Eighth and Ninth Avenues into one-way streets for all motor traffic.

THE SEA GULL, a play in four acts, by Anton Chekhov. Translated from the Russian by Stark Young. Staged by Robert Mllton. Settings and costumes designed by Robert Edmond Jones. Revived by the Theatre Guild. At the Shubert Theatre.
Colonel Byard Sneed, U.S.A. (Retired), died yesterday from injuries sustained in a fall at his home in this city a few hours earlier. He was 56 years old.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 26: COLONELS Danford. R. M., F.A., appointed as chief of F.A., with rank of major general, March 26. Herr, J. K., Cav., appointed as chief of Cav., with rank of major general, March 26..

Thirty-four candidates have been retained on the New York University baseball squad, it was announced yesterday by Coach Bill McCarthy at the conclusion of the regular practice session at Ohio Field. The group includes eight letter men, none of whom played regularly last season.

The stock market here reflected today the weakness that Wall Street has been showing, and most sections lost ground. Gilt-edge issues were steady at first but fell off in the late afternoon. Foreign bonds were good in general. Transatlantic stocks sagged
Suit for divorce was filed here today by Mrs. Agnes P. Bacon against Robert Ogden Bacon Jr., of New York and Newport, R. I. They were married at Princeton, N. J., on June 9, 1934.

A petition of the American Radio Telegraphists Association, a C. I. O. affiliate, seeking to have itself recognized as sole bargaining agent with the Columbia Broadcasting System in New York, has been denied by the National Labor Relations Board.

Charging unfair labor practices, coercion and discrimination against its members, the Furriers Joint Council of the International Fur Workers Union yesterday filed a complaint with the- State Labor Relations Board against the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc.

A Brooklyn housewife who was the inside informant for three gunmen who held up ten women and a man at a poker party on Feb. 19 and escaped with $3,000 worth of jewelry and $600 in cash, received a suspended sentence yesterday and was placed on probation for two years, with the stipulation that if she gambles during that period she will be sent to the Women's Reformatory at Bedford, N. Y., for five years.

The estimated additional revenues to the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company resulting from the -recent increase in freight rates authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission, will fall far short of the increased costs of labor and material, Howard S. Palmer, president, states in the carrier's annual report to stockholders for 1937.

The Rev. Dr. Robert Parmelee Wilder, who was a founder of the Student Volunteer Movement for Foreign Missions in 1886 and represented the organization throughout the world for many years, died Sunday of pneumonia in Osio, Norway, according to word received by friends here yesterday. He -was born in Kolhapur, India, seventyfour years ago.
Joe Louis will start his final training manoeuvres tomorrow in preparation for his fifteen-round heavyweight title battle with wild swinging Harry Thomas at the Chicago Stadium Friday night.

A. G. Tarn, the Winnipeg horseman whose Winter purchase, Wise Fox, won yesterday's Louisiana Derby at the Fair Grounds, again basked in the spotlight at Tropical Park today when his 5-year-old Faust easily accounted for the feature. Paying $11.20 for $2,

Virtually complete returns; from Sunday's Presidential election tonight gave General Alfredo Baldomir 109,388 votes. The two other candidates, Juan Jose Arteage and Dr. Eduardo Blanco Acevedo, received 98,081 and 88,525 votes. respectively.

Carl Krack, 27 years old, of 315 East Eighty-fourth Street, who was arrested on Feb. 23 while handing out pamphlets announcing a Nazi mass meeting, was fined $25 on a charge of disorderly conduct in Yorkville Court yesterday after he had admitted insulting Mrs. Esther Eichel of 317 East Eighty-fifth Street, a passer-by.

With shoe manufacturers reconciled to a drop of about 10 per cent in total retail volume for 1938 as compared with 1937, the opening showing of Fall leathers by the Tanners Council of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday was heavily attended, but sales of leathers were disappointing to the sixty-five exhibitors. In conjunction with the showing, the National Shoe Retailers Association held its semi-annual style conference,

The engagement of $1,148,000 of gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of .New York. The gold, which had been obtained at some previous date, lifted the total of the metal taken in London for United States account since March 15 to $16,200,000.
The stock market had to contend with far more than its usual quota of news yesterday, and finished the day irregularly higher, with recoveries ranging from fractions to 2 points.
Fifty candidates for the 1938 Army football team reported to Captain Gar Davidson today to begin Spring practice. Another group of about thirty is expected to join the squad tomorrow.

The death of two Bishops of the Anglican Church occurred today. They were the Rt. Rev. John Harold Greig and the Rt. Rev. John Taylor D Smith. Dr. Greig became the first Bishop of the See of Guilford in 1927 and previously served as Bishop of Gibraltar.

C. R. Smith, president of American Airlines, Inc., reports the carrying of 300,571 passengers in 1937, an increase of 17.7 per cent over 255,324 passengers transported in 1936, compared to a gain of 8 per cent for the industry as a whole.

Mr. and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt and Mrs. Vanderbilt's daughter, Miss Rosemary Warburton, who have been on a Caribbean cruise aboard the Vanderbilt yacht Alva, on which they departed from Miami on Feb. 7, returned today to the Vanderbilt estate on Terminal Island, where they will remain for several weeks.

Justice H. Thornton Lorimer approved d today as "reasonable and proper" settlement of a suit entered by four minority stockholders against the Nashua Manufacturing company, its officers and directors. Litigation thereby is avoided.

Logan Wood, Detroit industrialist and brother of Gar Wood, the speed boat builder and racer, died here today from a heart ailment and pneumonia. His age was 51. Mr. Wood, who was head of the Gar Wood Industries of Detroit, entered a hospital several days ago after becoming ill at the San Mateo home of a sister, Mrs. James C. Work. Burial will be at Detroit.

Edward Bredshall, young American pianist, gave his first New York recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. He played Haydn's Andante con Variazioni, Mozart's sonata in F (K. 332), Beethoven's sonata in A flat, Op. 110; Scriabin's sonata No. 9 and shorter items by Ravel and Debussy.

In all friendliness and unofficially, first David Lloyd George, and during the past three days Winston Churchill, have been visiting in turn all the leaders of French political life' and urging that in the interests of peace and not of war something must be done

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustment.

President Butlerl is still looking ahead for Columbia University. Last year he said in his address to the graduates that the university had disappeared in every totalitarian State, that for the time being university life began west of the Rhine,

The seventieth anniversary of the birth of Maxim Gorky, whose death on June 18, 1936, was attributed to murder by physicians at the behest of Henry G. Yagoda, as head of the Soviet secret police, was celebrated throughout the Soviet Union today.

Malcolm E. Kennedy, 38 years .old, who stole $60,000 in securities last year from customers of his brokerage concern under conditions similar to those used by Richard Whitney, pleaded guilty in General Sessions yesterday to a first-degree grand larceny indictment.
Trouncing the University of Vermont, 16 to 4, in a seven-inning game, the University of Maryland baseball team opened its season auspiciously today.
Colonel Bill Terry sent his Giant junior varsity against Travis Jackson's Little Giants of Jersey City today and the result left him with a divided opinion.

Mayor Wilson formally entered the contest for the Democratic nomination for Senator today against Governor Earle. His announcement, consisting only of the bare fact of his candidacy, was made at the headquarters of Lieut.

Shrieks, let groans and cries of rage accompanied the climax of Chancellor Hitler's plebiscite speech in the Berlin Sportpalast tonight after he had made another triumphant ride from the Chancellery through thronged streets and reviewed honor companies of police, bodyguards and party organizations.

The Senate adopted today the Reorganization Bill giving the President wide powers to alter the executive branch of the government. The vote was 49 to 42, and the measure was sent to the House for consideration.

According to building plans-filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings, a fourteenstory and penthouse apartment building is to rise on the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

A man known only as "Izzy," who participated in the robbery of the home of J. Edward Meyer in Great Neck last January, was being sought by the police today in connection with the theft of more than $90,000 in jewelry by men
With four days of training ahead for its annual race with Cambridge Saturday, the Oxford crew today showed top form in practice spins.

What amounted to exchange restrictions went into force here today as local banks refused to sell any large sum of dollars. They limited themselves to reselling at a margin only dollars bought during the day.

Mrs. Arthur Ryle returned on the Columbus after a cruise of several weeks to South America and is at 101 East Seventy-second Street. Mr. and Mrs. Woodson P. Houghton of Washington are at the Ritz-Carlton.

The death of Acting Battalion Chief William J. Lennon (2) of H. and L. Co. 48, which occurred March 26, is announced to the department. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 611 W. 156th St., Manhattan, at 10:30 A. M., Tuesday, March 29. Interment will be at St. Raymond's Cemetery.

The Administration has won its fight in the Senate for the Reorganization Bill, but won it only by making concessions which have substantially improved the original plan and greatly limited the authority which that plan proposed to confer upon the President.

After spending three days here and delivering an important speech on reconstruction, Field Marshal Hermann Goering left today for Wiener Neustadt amid echoes of the usual enthusiastic Nazi demonstration.

A return of the reduced tariff rate on certain tobaccos under the reciprocal trade agreement with Cuba to the levels which were in force during the life of the AAA has been proposed by the Cigar Manufacturers Association, and prospects for success of the proposal are excellent, the board of directors were told at a meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt last night.

The Hungarian Government's request for a settlement of its post-war relief debt to the United States was transmitted to Congress today by President Roosevelt with a request that it receive "the most careful consideration."

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Morgan Farrell in his letter to THE TIMES on the question of rezoning the East Side misrepresents the views of those he criticizes. The American Labor party and other organizations were not opposed to rezoning along East River.

The Supreme Court ruled today that an ordinance of Griffin, Ga., requiring persons distributing circulars or advertisements to obtain a license from the City Manager, violated constitutional guarantees of freedom of the press.

Foreign Minister Oswaldo Aranha gave "full support" today to the United States Government's suggestion for international aid to political refugees. Mr. Aranha said he had advised Secretary of State Cordell Hull that he would facilitate the entry of Austrian refugees into Brazil.
The Rev. William T. Hooper, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church of West Hartford, was found dead early today in his automobile which was standing in a closed garage, its motor running.

A pushcart vendor who has a fixed stand and does not move from place to place is not a "peddler" in the eyes of the law, Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag held yesterday in ordering the Department of Markets to restore the license of Joseph Forest.

No comprehensive legislative program for regulation of the taxicab industry should be undertaken until after the World's Fair ends, Harold Riegelman, counsel for the Terminal System, Inc., declared yesterday at an adjourned hearing of the special committee of the City Council, now studying the problem of taxicab control.

DEATH CANCELS THE EVIDENCE, by Robert H. Leitfred. (Green Circle, $2.) A mystery novel. FIFTY SOUTH TO FFTY SOUTH, by Warwick M. Tompkins. (Norton, $3.) The story of a voyage around Cape Horn in a schooner.

The 6-to-1 decision of the Supreme Court upholding the registration and penalty provisions of the Public Utilities Holding Company Act will deserve careful study. It is immediately important to notice, however,

So the lamb slew the butcher. At least that's approximately what happened on the Madison Square Garden rink the other night-no, early yesterday morning-when the star-spangled Americans blew the illustrious Rangers out of any further participation in the play-offs for the Stanley Cup, the world series of hockey.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended on March 23: decreases of $29,000,000

Miss Marian Newcomet, daughter of Horace E. Newcomet, a vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, was killed today in an automobile accident seven miles southwest of Waukegan. Her mother, who was with her, was seriously injured.

Public interest in housing attracted many visitors yesterday to the exhibit of slum clearance projects at the opening of the seventeenth annual Women's Exposition of Arts and Industries at the Grand Central Palace.

Mr. and Mrs. Achilles H. Kohn of 1,000 Park Avenue and Whitefence, Harrison, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Anne Kohn, to Jack Tarkington Cassaday of this city, formerly of Danville, Ky.
Official Luxembourg quarters disclosed tonight that Germany had warned the tiny grand duchy that the Nazis would not tolerate press attacks such as followed Germany's absorption of Austria.

The West Orange Planning Board was ordered today by the New Jersey Supreme Court to reconsider the board's refusal to approve a real estate development known as "Shadowlawn," on a four-and-ahalf-acre tract, at Gregory Avenue and Northfield Road.

Headed by Seabiscuit, twentyfour thoroughbreds were nominated today for the $15,000 added Bay Meadows Handicap on April 16. Seabiscuit automatically became the favorite for the mile and a furlong race.
Stung by their three setbacks in a row, the Yankees made merry today at the expense of their Kansas City farm club in a game that developed into a travesty for a gathering of 725 natives.

Atlantic City's Million Dollar Pier, one of the major attractions of the seashore resort, has been leased for a long term by George A. Hamid, noted figure in the amusement field, for a long term from the Associated Realties Corporation, owner.

A smashing 1,094 in their third game brought first place in the American Bowling Congress standings to the five-man team representing Isaac Baker and son of Erie, Pa., tonight. Its score of 3,087 bettered the previous high by 52 pins.

The House Rivers and Harbors Committee reported today with two minor amendments the bill it agreed upon last week, trimming President Roosevelt's proposal for "seven TVA's" to a plan for an advisory national resources development board.

President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nomination of Alexander Kirk of Chicago, veteran in the diplomatic service, as the new counselor of the Embassy at Moscow. Mr. Kirk was formerly Assistant Secretary of State.

The fourth and final performance of the 1938 charity figure skating carnival was presented by the Skating Club of New York last night at Madison Square Garden. A gathering of 14,500 witnessed the concluding presentation of the elaborate ice show staged as a benefit for the Bellevue Hospital Social Relief Service and Carroll Club.

Viscount St. Davids, one of the city's most prominent figures, especially noted for his connection with British interests in South America, died here today at the age of 71. The Viscount was best known for his management of the Buenos Aires' and Pacific Railway in the Argentine,

For use as another unit in its chain of restaurants and retail bakeshops, the Horn Hardart Company has leased the store and basement at 173 East Eighty-sixth Street, corner of Third Avenue, it was announced yesterday.

A special committee to supervise the publication of The Bawl Street Journal, issued each year in connection with the annual field day of the Bond Club of New York, was appointed yesterday by Nevil Ford, president of the club.

With only three days remaining before the expiration of the present Film Quota Act, the House of Commons rejected tonight an important amendment to the new quota bill just voted by the House of Lords.

Governor Lehman returned to the Executive Mansion on his sixtieth birthday today to find his desk laden with telegrams and letters, many urging him to sign the McNaboe bill to bar radicals from public service and an almost equal number urging him to veto the measure.

Federal Judge John Boyd Avis issued a "show cause" rule here today which, in effect, provides that if Federal bench warrants are served upon Ellis Parker and his son, Ellis Jr., the two men must be taken before the nearest United States commissioner or Federal judge.

Count Rene Doynel de SaintQuentin, French Ambasasdor, was guest of honor at a reception yesterday afternoon at the Museum of French Art and the French Institute in the United States, 22 East Sixtieth Street.

The Supreme Court ruled today that the National Labor Relations Act was applicable to the Santa Cruz Fruit Packing Company of Oakland, Cal., which ships less than 40 per cent of its product into interstate commerce.

The Affiliated Fund, Inc., investment trust of Jersey City, N. J., filed today a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering an issue of 2,178,500 shares of $1.25-par value common stock to be marketed for an aggregate of $9,367,550 at current market value.

Wilmington will celebrate tomorrow the 300th anniversary of its purchase from the Indians for a few trinkets brought from Sweden by Peter Minuit. Minuit landed March 29, 1688, at The Rocks--now Wilmington--on the Christiana River.

An issue of $600,000 of first-mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds due on March 1, 1963, of the Bangor Hydro Electric Company of Bangor, Me., has been placed privately through a group of investment firms, including Smith, Barney Co., E. W. Clark Co. and Hornblower Weeks, acting as agents for the company.

CESAR SAERCHINGER'S "Hello America!"* is an astonishingly good book. I had no idea that any one could write informally about broadcasts and broadcasting without spending at least half his space talking baby-talk to the children, by. whom radio audiences are generally supposed to be ruled.

The United States Court of Appeals ruled today against the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries, Inc., which sought to enjoin Postmaster General Farley from barring from the mails a contest called "Selection Sweepstakes."
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are March 28, unless specified: Arctic, at La Haina, March 26. Cormorant, Yorktown, to Navy Yard, Washington. Claxton, Gibraltar.
The Tide Water Associated Oil Company in its report for 1937, covering the first complete year of the company as an operating unit

Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, announced yesterday that young women of exceptional talents desiring to qualify for special detective work in the Police Department, must file their applications with the commission by 4 P. M., April 13, the deadline for the new policewoman test.

Warships converging on Hawaii in a simulated invasion were sighted for the first time today by patrol craft of the defense forces stationed on strategic Oahu Island. The "enemy" was reported still some distance from the islands, around which planes and surface craft have patrolled since Thursday.

Announcement was made yesterday that a new board of directors of the Reynolds Investing Company, Inc., which, with the Continental Securities Corporation of Maryland is being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, was elected on March 18 at the behest of the new Continental Securities interests.

The last of the current series of the Treasury's "new money" bills was sold today at an average price of 0.081 per cent, compared with 0.059 per cent for the issue sold a week ago, the Treasury announced tonight.

Progressively declining sales volume in retail liquor package stores of the city was blamed by distillers here yesterday for the outbreak of a price war in which as much as $1 was sheared from the price of imported liquors and 36 cents from the fixed prices of G. W. domestic ryes yesterday afternoon.

Though enough Democratic votes were available to assure passage, the leaders of the Republican majority in the Assembly refused tonight to move the series of Senate bills providing upward of $19,00,000 for unemployment relief.
Germany's demands on Czechoslovakia, according to a letter from Berlin published by Emile Bure. in the Ordre, a newspaper of the Right Centre, today are as follows:

The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, in its annual report for the year ended Jan. 29, made public last night by Oswald W. Knauth, president, shows consolidated net sales increased 4.9 per cent to $58,456,570 from $55,703,921 in the preceding fiscal year.

Police Department officials discovered yesterday that unless tentative plans are changed the United May Day parade and the World's Fair motorcade will pass within hailing distance of each other on April 30.

An airplane pilot and a student flier were marooned on East Island in Jamaica Bay, a half mile from the seaplane base at Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, for eight hours last night after they had been forced down by motor trouble.

Mrs. Harry Clark Boden returned from Nassau, Bahamas, today with her two children and said she did not plan to go back there to testify at the trial of her divorced first husband, Forrester Scott of Philadelphia, charged with attempting to kidnap the little girls by airplane.

Although "blacker days still may come," those at Geneva who support the League of Nations as an instrument for peaceful change "have every confidence that in the end it will triumph over the enemies of reaction and indifference," Arthur Sweetser, an American member of the League secretariat, declared last night at the annual dinner of the League of Nations Association at the Town Hall Club.

Announcement was made yesterday by the Long Island State Park Commission that the golfing season at Bethpage, the State's fine layout at Farmingdale, L. I., would be officially opened for play Saturday.
ANDERSON--Robert S., of 92-32 54th Ave., Elmhurst, L. I., on Sunday. March 27. 1938: survived by his wife, Mary C.. and family. Funeral private. Ridgefield Park, N. J., papers please copy.

An excellent illustration of how greatly political values were distorted by some opponents of the Federal Reorganization Bill was provided this morning by the news-ticker that serves this office. From New York came this sentence in a report of trading on the Exchange:

The need for $12,500 to meet a deficit this year in the operation of the Booth Memorial Home and Hospital, 312 East Fifteenth Street, was stressed yesterday by Mrs. Douglas L. Elliman, chairman of the women's committee of the 1938 Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army. She made the appeal following an inspection of the home.

This capital is about to lose an institution regarded as possessing almost the permanency of the Washington Monument. Jules Henry, perennial Counselor and frequent Charge d'Affaires of the French Embassy,

The White Sox will be without the services of their star shortstop, Luke Appling, for three months. Manager Jimmy Dykes heard the bad news today from Dr. Robert W. King of the Golden State Hospital, where Appling was taken yesterday after injuring his right leg in a game against the Chicago Cubs.
John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, declared here tonight that the 1938 Congressional elections would be the last fight for the Republican party if it was defeated.
The women's division of the United Palestine Appeal launched yesterday its campaign to raise $175,000 for the settlement in Palestine of Jews from Germany, Poland, Rumania and other countries.

Notwithstanding increases in wage rates and prices of materials, the Canadian National Railways in 1937 handled its traffic at a lower operating ratio than in 1936, S. J. Hungerford, chairman and president, said today in the annual report presented to the House of Commons.
Stocks closed weak with losses of 1 to 5 points; turnover, 1,721,750 shares. Bonds declined to lowest levels in several years in much heavier trading; transactions, $8,835,000.
Clark-Robinson Co., Inc., report the following sales of properties in Brooklyn: The four-story apartment at 2,220 Bath Avenue to Joseph Roth for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $12,250;
A bulletin to clarify the taxability of amounts paid to retired railroad employes by the Railroad Retirement Board was issued today by Cortland A. Wilber, director of the State Income Bureau.

The First Boston Corporation won yesterday the award of $1,000,000 of highway debentures of the State of New Mexico, on a bid of 100.044 for $250,000 as 2 3/4s, and $750,000 as 3s. The net interest cost to the State on the successful bid was 2.92 per cent. The bonds will be dated April 1, 1938, and will mature from Oct. 1, 1949, to 1950.
Silas W. Howland, chairman of the committee of the National Chess Federation in charge of the United States championship tournament, which will get under way Saturday, afternoon in the R. C. A.

A decision is to be handed down by the Federal Communications Commission within the next few days which, according to reports, will show a reversal of the attitude of the majority of that body against further acquisition or development of radio broadcasting facilities by newspapers.

The Federal Trade Commission today show im announced it will hold a trade practice conference for the automobile industry on April 26 at Detroit. The announcement came as a surprise in view of the lack of accord in several branches of the industry, some of which had only recently been the subject of attention by President Roosevelt.

Robert R. Young, chairman of the Chesapeake Corporation, is about to start court action to obtain proxies to vote the 780,000 shares of this company's stock now impounded with the Guaranty Trust Company as collateral behind Alleghany Corporation bonds, it was disclosed yesterday.

Mrs. Mary Binney Davey, wife of James A. G. Davey, native of Old Greenwich, died at the Deaconess Hospital in St. Louis of pneumonia yesterday at the age of 46. Mr. and Mrs. Davey had been making their home at Waynesville, N. C., and before that time had lived in Old Greenwich.

George Lawyer of 200 West Fiftyeighth Street, a retired merchant formerly an executive of the John V. Farwell Company, Chicago dry goods concern, died on Monday night in the Post-Graduate fospital of pneumonia after a brief illness.

The American Museum of Natural History will send an automobile trailer to Florida this Spring to erve as a mobile base camp and laboratory for a new experiment in field collecting, it was announced yesterday . Dr. Harold E. Anthony, urator of the department of mamnals, said the trailer will leave within the next fortnight with a taff of three men.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Helen Margaret Gennert, daughter of Mrs. Maurice Gennert of 300 Riverside Drive and the late Mr. Gennert, to Robert Edward du Vergey of this City and Chattanooga, Tenn., which took place on Thursday at the home of her mother. The Rev. Lawrence Gibbons performed the ceremony.

The Senate Finance Committee, in a three and a half hour night session, voted to liberalize the present requirement for liquidating personal holding companies by extending the liquidation period from two to three years, struck from the measure the House amendment placing additional import taxes on pork, and turned down proposed Senate amendments calling for additional import taxes on canned beef and ham.

Current seasonal requirements accounted for a large percentage of the business booked by tanners at the second and concluding day of the Fall leather opening at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday The total volume, although showing some improvement over the first day, was described as small, but several tanners booked more business than they had anticipated in view of the weakness in hide futures and the widespread tendency of shoe manufacturers to buy closely.

A possibility that medical science had developed a vaccine that would immunize sufferers from boils, sinusitis, pimples, acne and certain shaving troubles was indicated today in a "progress report" of research begun in the laboratories of the Massachusetts General Hospital and continued at London.

Herbert Hoover, then President of the United States, lent an encouraging word to the Canadian Government during the financial crisis following Great Britain's departure from the gold standard in 1931, R. B. Bennett told the House of Commons today. He said he disclosed this for the first time because he wished to pay tribute to a man who was no longer in public life.
Educational authorities in the State of Rio Grande do Sul, following the example of Santa Catharina, have taken over private schools operated by German, Italian and Polish groups.

The Panama Pacific Line, in a statement yesterday to the 442 men who constituted the crew of its liner Pennsylvania before the withdrawal of the ship from service on Monday, said heavy financial losses had been suffered since 1981, necessitating the cancellation of the service.
Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda, told an audience of 25,000 here tonight that Germany no longer feared France.

Ralph Wright, 38 years old, of 320 West Thirty-fourth Street, New York, who is being held by the Orange police on a charge of attempting to obtain money under false pretenses, was found today trying to mutilate his fingerprints by scraping his hands on the concrete floor of his cell.
After charging Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers with sabotage, discrimination and theft, Isaac Penner, contractor and former union member,

Three hundred years after the Kalmar Nyckel. a little Swedish sailing ship, brought the first Swedish and Finnish colonists to Pennsylvania, the Commonwealth's newest airplane was named the Kalmar Nyckel at a ceremony today at the Philadelphia Navy Yard.

Dr. Sigmund Freud, who had intended to come here to live, cannot leave Vienna, as the authorities refuse to give him a passport, according to a member of a small delegation that went to Vienna to offer him hospitality on behalf of Netherland admirers. The delegation included Princess Marie Bonaparte.

BACK STAGE, by Melbert Cary (Field, $2.) A novel about an actress and her mother. NEW SWEDEN ON THE DELAWARE, by Christopher Ward. (University of Pennsylvania Press, $1.50.) Issued in honor of the New Sweden Tercentenary to be celebrated in June.

Sixteen inmates of the Philadelphia County Prison at Holmesburg are named in documentary information collected by the Ruth Legislative Commission as operators of narcotic drug, liquor and gambling concessions at the institution, it was disclosed today.
Jeremiah Bingham, Toledo manufacturer, inventor and sportsman, died of pneumonia today in his home in Miami, Fla., at the age of 69, relatives were informed.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Henry C. Turner, president of the Board of Education, has been reported as favoring a larger board membership "to ease the work of the present seven members."

A number of uptown properties figured in the Manhattan realty transactions announced yesterday. A client of Porter Co., Inc., purchased from the Phoenix Park Company, Inc., and Thomas J. Hallahan the seven-story Huntington a apartment house at 218-22 West 112th Street for cash above a mortgage which was extended for five years.

Puerto Rico wants to participate in President Roosevelt's new navy. Senator Alfonso Valdes, who is a staff captain in the National Guard, has introduced a bill authorizing the appropriation of $250,000 as the island's contribution toward the nation's new battleships.

Rose point lace, which had enhanced the wedding gown of her mother, was used to trim the bridal costume of Miss Elizabeth Hubbard Allen for her marriage yesterday afternoon to Richard Hull Fay of New York.

Branch Rickey may next take up the St. Louis Cardinals' rebuttal of Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis's recent decision criticizing the team's "gentlemen's agreements" with minor league clubs.

Dernell Every, Nickolas Muray and Dr. John R. Huffman, comprising the New York A. C. first fencing trio, captured the national senior three-weapon team championship last night on the strips of the Fencers Club. A 2 to 1 triumph in the final over the Salle Santelli first team clinched the crown for the Winged Foot group.

Decision to push promotions for Father's Day, June 19, on the widest national scale since that day was inaugurated was reached yesterday at a preliminary meeting held at the offices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Plans for celebration of Child Health Day over the May 1 week-end and a slogan for the observance, "Speed Children on the Road to Health," were announced today by Miss Katharine F. Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor. This year is the tenth anniversary of the observance of Child Health Day.
Turpentine firm, 23c; sales, 173 barrels; receipts, 434 barrels; shipments, 50 barrels; stock, 23,230 barrels. Resin steady; no sales; receipts, 1,694; shipments, 1,068; stock. 64.079.

Encouraged by spokesmen for consumer groups and members of the Federal Trade Commission, representatives of the wool textile industry at a hearing today gave tentative approval to trade practice rules submitted by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers

The twenty-eighth in the series of exhibitions arranged by resident artists of New York City and held at the Municipal Art Galleries, 3 East Sixty-seventh Street under the auspices of the Municipal Art Committee, opens today with four groups, numbering in all forty-nine artists displaying a total of eightyfive pictures.
Nathan H. Weil, a New York insurance agent, died here today during a visit. He was 56 years old.
Income tax collections in March temporarily have reduced both the Federal deficit and debt, the Treasury said today.

Loans and discounts of insured commercial banks were 5 per cent larger in amount on Dec. 31 than a year earlier, but 2 per cent less than on June 30, 1937, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today.

A statement of the conditions under which the National Mortgage Association, an RFC subsidiary, will make housing loans and buy mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration, was sent today by the FHA to more than 10,000 banks,
A new method of surgical treatment of peripheral nerve paralysis was demonstrated today at Walter Reed Hospital before the staff of the hospital and the Army Medical School.

Three hundred years ago yesterday, according to the reckoning, Peter Minuit, earlier director general of New Netherland, landed on the site of what is now Wilmington, Delaware, and there established a Swedish settlement.

Hordes of human beings are fleeing to Barcelona from the bombed and fallen towns and villages on the eastern front and from broken cities between here and Valencia. Like sheep in a storm they crowd into every available nook and cranny.

The Rev. Dr. John Floyd Steen, rector emeritus of Ascension Memorial Protestant Episcopal Church, 249 West Forty-third Street, the oldest clergyman of his denomination in the New York Diocese, died early yesterday morning in his apartment in the Hotel Milburn, 242 West Seventy-sixth Street, at the age of 93.

A tentative draft of a fluid milk marketing agreement for New York City area producers was outlined today at a conference of representatives of the Metropolitan Producers Bargaining Agency and the Agricultural Adjustment. Administration.

Among the leases of apartment space reported by brokers yesterday was one for eleven rooms and five baths in the multi-family house at 1 Gracie Square taken by Mrs. D. L. Whitney through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., broker. Details of other leases follow:

The charge that during the last week ten Japanese planes have dropped loads of typhoid germs over a wide area in Northeastern Shensi, including Yenan, Communist headquarters, is contained in an urgent telegram sent here, signed by General Chu Teh and General Peng Teh-huai, commander and vice commander of the Eighth Route Army.

Four memberships in the Chicago Board of Trade were sold today at $2,500 each, the lowest since 1915. They included three seats relinquished by officials of Cargill Grain Company of Illinois, who were expelled from the board last week after an investigation of the "squeeze" in September corn last year.
ABRAHAMS--arfe (nee Wolfermann), beloved wife of Julius, devoted mother of Ruth Hiller and Sylvia Heilbraun, sister of Louis, on March 29. Funeral notice later.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

The current sharp price-cutting in the food and grocery industry may cause some food manufacturers to institute price maintenance contracts under the Fair Trade Laws in the particular markets where the cutting is severe, Paul S. Willis,

With their goal tender, Bert Gardiner, putting up an impregnable defense, the Philadelphia Ramblers tonight defeated the New Haven Eagles, 2-0, in a first-round playoff game of the Eastern division of the International-American Hockey League.

The series of Spring parties for future debutantes and young men home from schools and colleges were continued last night with the Middle Holiday Dance, under the direction of Mrs. Huntington Tappin, in the main ballroom of the Plaza.
E. S. Phillips, president of the Devoe Raynolds Company, Inc., announced yesterday that a consolidation of his company and the Jones-Dabney Company, Inc., of Louisville, Ky., was under way.

Ireland's first attempt to elect a vocational Senate as envisaged by its Constitution has been unsuccessful. When the elections were concluded here tonight with the return of forty-nine Senators, the country was presented with a body more notable for its strong political party complexion than its vocational character.
Spotting their rivals a one-goal lead in the first period, the New York Americans again came from behind to score a play-off triumph last night.

Featuring a wild animal bill headed by Gargantua the Great, "the largest and most ferocious gorilla ever held in captivity"how Dexter Fellows would have relished these superlatives!-the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey combined circus will open its annual Spring engagement in Madison Square Garden on Friday night. April 8.

Forty theatrical managers and producers have expressed approval of a proposed basic agreement between the League of New York Theatres and the Actors Equity Association under which ticket speculation would be checked, it was disclosed last night by Brock Pemberton, league spokesman.

Net sales of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and subsidiary companies in the year ended on Jan. 31, were the largest in six years, according to the annual statement made public today by Bernard F. Gimbel, president.

Mr. Justice Reed did not participate in the Supreme Court decision in which sections of the Holding Company Act of 1935 were sustained. His reason for not doing so was that he had signed perfunctory briefs in the case, while serving as Solicitor General.

Before Representative Hancock anti Federal and local Housing Authority officials, the contract for a loan of $3,930,000 for a low-cost housing and slum-clearance project in Syracuse was signed today in the office of Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority.

The new plan of supervision in the Boy Scout movement within the city was discussed last night in the Union League Club, Park Avenue at Thirty-seventh Street, at the first joint meeting and dinner given to the leaders of the Boy Scout Federation of Greater New York by William H. Pouch, commissioner of the federation.
Bobby Riggs of Chicago, second national ranking player, advanced in the River Oaks tennis tournament today, taking his third-round match with Sidney Nachlas of Houston. 6-4. 6-4.

The Senate Banking and Currency Committee reported favorably today the bill introduced last week by Senator Glass and supported by President Roosevelt, broadening the authority of the Reconstruction Finance-Corporation to extend aid to industry, and permitting it to resume selfliquidating loans to public bodies.

Mrs. Henry B. Thompson Jr. of Old Brookville heads a committee in charge of plans for the second annual ball of the Buckram Beagles at the Piping Rock Club, Locust Valley, on Saturday. Mr. Thompson is master of the beagles and chairman of the hunt committee. Several dinners at the club will be given before the dance and many members will have house guests for the week-end.

Three hundred invitations have been sent out for the wedding of Miss Suzanne Moseley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Moseley, to Major Frederic A. Wanklyn, M. C., Royal Artillery, Montreal, which will take place on April 11 in St. Andrew's Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Andrew Douglas will perform the ceremony. A reception will be given at the home of the bride's parents.

Oil circles here yesterday were more confident that Secretary of State Cordell Hull was fully aware of the gravity of the seizure of the $450,000,000 foreign-owned oil properties by the Mexican Government and that he was prepared to make a strong stand.

The Park West Hospital, eightstory structure at 168-70 West Seventy-sixth Street, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. It was bought in by the Continental Bank and Trust Company of New York, trustee, as plaintiff, for $50,000.
Merwyn Heald, executive of two manufacturing companies, killed himself by poison at his home in River Forest today.

The twenty-first season of the Lewisohn Stadium Summer Concerts will begin Thursday evening, June 23, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman. The announcement also contained a plea for a fund of $75,000 to support the eightweek season, which last year drew more than 300,000 people.

A prayer of thanksgiving, citing the reasons why he is grateful he lives in the United States, written by a 16-year-old schoolboy who came to this country as a refugee three years ago, made such a vivid impression upon Superintendent of Schools Harold G. Campbell that it is being sent to President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

Judge William J. Lindsay granted an uncontested divorce today to John Jerome Finlay, an advertising executive, on the ground of desertion and thus ended three years of court action between Finlay and his wife, the former Jane Scriven, now of Scarsborough, N. Y..

Opposition by Senator Clark in a oneman filibuster forced the Senate late tonight to postpone until tomorrow a vote on the $549,000,000 Navy Appropriation Bill. Earlier today the Senate had passed the "Four-Department" Appropriation Bill.

A block of $741,000 New York City 4 per cent bonds issued for various purposes headed a list of forty-six bond issues upon which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today the receipt of bids. Four bids on the New York issue were received, ranging from $1,061.10 to $1,083.17 for each $1,000 of face amount, with Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., the highest bidder.

For "distinguished service" to Poland, in war and in peace, the Grand Cross of Gold, highest grade of the Polish Order of Merit, was awarded today to Edward Weintal, former attache of the Polish Embassy here and now in charge of the Polish Information Service in this country.
Reginald F. Sedgley, firearms manufacturer and inventor, died of a heart ailment in his home here today. He was 61 years old.

The United States has proposed that the first meeting of the intergovernmental committee for facilitating the emigration of political refugees from Austria and Germany be held in a Swiss city, it was disclosed today when France commented favorably on the proposal in a note agreeing to cooperate. Italy, meanwhile, declined to do so.

The involved situation surrounding the outdoor-season activities of Barney Ross, Lou Ambers and Henry Armstrong was cleared up to the satisfaction of all concerned at the meeting of the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday.

House leaders handling the Reorganization Bill passed yesterday by the Senate laid plans today to revise the measure to retain the office of Controller General in name but recast its authority in a manner which would virtually give President Roosevelt the changes he desires concerning it.
A decree issued today increases the German Army from fourteen to eighteen army corps, which means an eventual increase of more than onefifth in its size.

Senator Copeland proposed in a resolution today that this government assert jurisdiction over parts of the Bering Sea off Alaska. Mr. Copeland said the shallow depths of Bering Sea must be regarded as a slightly submerged margin of Alaska and that preservation of mineral deposits and of salmon and other fisheries demanded that the United States declare its jurisdiction.

Constructive training in industrial and agricultural fields rather than the "concentration of Jewish endeavor in the middleman class" would greatly relieve the economic distress of Jews in Eastern and Central Europe,

Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page, Chapel kill, who holds the women's national golf title, breezed into the second round of the thirty-sixth North and South tournament today with a 9-and-8 victory over Miss Elizabeth Sutherland of Chicago.

Commander Benjamin C. Thorn, United States Coast Guard, and Mrs. Thorn of Belmont Hills, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Elizabeth Thorn, to Ensign Russell R. Waesche Jr., U. S. C. G.

Coming close on the heels of Germany's tremendous victory in annexing Austria without more than a protest from France and Great Britain, France finds herself today facing the prospect of two more defeats.
Several public utility holding companies which are incorporated in Delaware but which have maintained their headquarters in Chicago are moving their main offices to the

It is more necessary than usual, in so disordered a securities market as that of the last few days, for the prudent investor to keep his head, appraise carefully the real influences assumed to be at work financially, and, in particular, not to give way impulsively to excited imagination.
R. H. Bruce Lockhart, famous British agent in Russia in World War days, today received a conditional divorce on the grounds of his wife's alleged misconduct.

More than fifty students participated in the Spring demonstration of modern, tap and folk dancing held yesterday afternoon at Barnard College. This recital is given annually by members of the dancing classes, conducted by Miss Marion Streng, Miss Margaret Holland and Miss Jane Harting of the Physical Education Department, to demonstrate the work done by the classes during the year.

More than 500 officers and men of the aircraft carrier Lexington, were stricken today with a throat disorder, described as tonsillitis, and the gigantic vessel was forced to withdraw from the intensive war manoeuvres in Hawaiian waters.

The provisional government here today issued a statement regarding the attempted assassination of Wang Keh-min, chairman of the executive council of the North China provisional government, exhorting the people to remain calm and threatening severe punishment of the assailants and of all others attempting to disrupt or endanger the government.

Closeness in form and performance in training has made Oxford and Cambridge oarsmen even-money choices for their annual race Saturday. Cambridge, after a long week-end layoff, rowed a full minute against its reserve "Goldie" crew today, but was unable to make up a halflength lead.

With uneasiness here growing over the economic future in Great Britain and the United States, Joseph P. Kennedy, the United States Ambassador, invited twenty-two leading British bankers to dine with him at the embassy tonight to discuss the outlook in both countries.
Basic rubber export quotas in a proposed five-year continuation of a control program were revised upward in final recommendations made today by the International Rubber Regulation Committee.
Raymond Kenny, 25-year-old parolee, of 106-03 Liberty Avenue, Ozone Park, was acquitted in his trial on hold-up charges at 2:30 A. M. today, after the jury had been out nine and one-half hours.

Ossip Garber. the important witness who knew the mysterious Rubens-Robinson couple arrested in Russia with fraudulent American passports, was held as a material witness yesterday for a criminal trial that was predicted as the outcome of a Federal grand jury inquiry.

The British Government today took an important step toward settlement of its long-standing dispute with the Union of South Africa over the control of the native "protectorates" of Basutoland, Bechuanaland and Swaziland.

The recent amendments of the National Housing Act, particularly that providing for insurance by the FHA of mortgages on large-scale rental properties, were pictured yesterday as a boon to the construction of low-cost residential units by speakers at a meeting of the New York Building Congress.
The War De apartment released the following orders to day, dated March 28: COLONELS Strong, G. V., Inf., General Staff Corps three days leave, March 29.

A protest by a union of Remington-Rand employes that the National Labor Relations Board was trying to force them out of. jobs has been received by President Roosevelt and referred to the board and to the Department of Labor.
Premier Leon Blum will submit his financial proposals Friday; Parliament will deliberate over the week-end and if the texts are not adopted by Monday the Bourse will be closed.

The Senate passed the Appropriation Bill for State, Justice, Commerce and Labor Departments; debated the Navy Department Appropriation Bill, agreed to vote on it at 12:30 P. M. tomorrow, and recessed at 5:46 P. M. until noon tomorrow.

Governor Lehman today signed fifty-two of the bills left in his hands by the Legislature and vetoed four. On none of the bills did he issue a memorandum explaining his action, as none might be regarded as really controversial.

Key West welcomed tonight the first visitors ever to reach here directly by automobiles. The Overseas Highway, $3,600,000 PWA project spanning eighty miles of coral keys and long water gaps between here and the Florida mainland, was thrown open to traffic, although still incomplete.

Members of the family of Colonel Edward M. House, adviser to President Woodrow Wilson before and during the World War, who died Monday at the age of 79, left yesterday afternoon for Houston, Texas, where funeral services will be held tomorrow afternoon.
Miss M. Louise McCreary, former principal of the Misses McCreary School in Flatbush, died on Monday at the Congregational Home for the Aged, 123 Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn, in her eighty-fifth year.
Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain refused today to accept Generalissimo Francisco Franco's reply to the recent British protest on the bombing of Barcelona.

Under a new ruling of the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange brokerage houses which have not received instructions from actual owners of United States Rubber Company preferred stock may give proxies on it.

Miss Carol Crane Lucas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver G. Lucas, was married this evening to Morton Qvistgaard Petersen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aage Qvistgaard Petersen, in Trinity Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Robert S. Coupland.

What is claimed to be the most extensive electric refrigeration paign ever conducted in this area will be launched in newspapers here this morning and will run fourteen weeks, it was announced last night at a dealer meeting sponsored by the Electric Refrigerator Association of New York, at the Center Theatre.

The Edison Electric Institute announced yesterday that its 1938 annual convention will be held in to Atlantic City from June 6 to 9, inClusive. The Atlantic City Auditorium will serve as headquarters for the meeting.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United states for the week ended March 24 increased in three out of five grade divisions compared with the correspondingg week last year, according to a compilation issued yeserday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Weakness of silver, rubber and securities influenced trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices declined 16 to 19 points. Unsettled foreign markets brought selling pressure here and, although trade covering furnished buying power on recessions, final quotations proved the lowest of the day.

Despite a noisy demonstration by about thirty women members of the Workers Alliance who shouted demands for immediate rescinding of the 10 per cent relief cut, the City Council deferred action yesterday on Mayor La Guardia's supplemental relief tax program until its April 5 meeting.

A talented young soprano, Ann Jamison, made her New York recital debut at the Town Hall last night. She disclosed a lyric voice of agreeable quality and ample range, and she used it as if she were aware that the voice is but an instrument and that the music is the thing.

Harry G. Nye Jr. sailed Gale or the Southern Lake Michigan fleet to a clean sweep in the annual international Star Class races here today, taking the final contest of the Spring championship series over a twelve-mile windward and leeward course on Montagu Bay.
Four firemen were overcome by smoke, another was cut by glass and a truck driver was injured yesterday at three fires in Queens. Three of the firemen had to be taken to Flushing Hospital.

Frank G. Ferguson, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, assured members of the Bond Club of New Jersey yesterday that Port Authority bonds, now totaling $205,000,000, were likely to remain "immune" from Federal taxation.

Although total operating revenues increased 7 per cent, a rise of 20 per cent in taxes and increases in other expenses of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation brought operating income for 1937 down 2 per cent under 1936, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

Major G. F. Eliot, co-author with Major E. R. Dupuy of "If War Comes" (Macmillan), and Margery Sharp, author of "The Nutmeg Tree" (Little, Brown), will be guest speakers at the Authors Club Dinner tomorrow evening at the Coffee House Club.

Authorization for listing 8,703,252 shares of United States Steel Corporation common stock, no par value, has been voted by the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange. This does not mean that the stock necessarily will be admitted to dealings immediately.

On the eve of Mitzi Green's arrival at RKO-she is to arrive from New York on Saturday-the studio assigned to her the leading feminine role in "Room Service," which will star the Marx brothers. The picture is the third on Miss Green's schedule; it will be preceded by "Carefree" and "Fiddlesticks."

The "free lunch" counter set up on Capitol Hill from time to time by members of Congress to advertise the products of their States promises this year to include a more varied assortment of viands than in any previous session.

The fighting for Lerida went on with extraordinary intensity today with the Insurgents thrusting from two directions. They appear to have been halted on their right wing, where they struck along the road from Fraga, fifteen miles southwest, for the writer has just returned from the other side of Alcarraz, nine miles west of Lerida, after spending the day at the front.

Domestic corporation bonds plunged yesterday to the lowest levels in several years in more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Railroad issues again were victims of an aggressive attack as values in that list declined 1 to 4 points,"
Rudolfo Elias Calles, son of Plutarco Elias Calles, former dictator of Mexico, has booked passage on tomorrow's plane for. Los Angeles, Calif.

Man o' war, America's desiknown thoroughbred, was 21 years old yesterday as breeders and turf followers throughout this country and abroad celebrated. Samuel D. Riddle of Philadelphia, owner of the horse whose sons and daughters have earned approximately $2,500,000, said over the long-distance telenhone from Lexington, Ky.:

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., April 1: LIEUTENANTS-Patrick J. McGreevy, from 10th Division to 18th Division, assignment to desk duty discontinued. Walter E. Klotzback, from 13th Division to Emergency Service Division. assignment changed from desk duty to Supervisor in uniform.

The list of the steamship President Roosevelt of the United States Lines, leaving today for Channel ports, includes Mrs. Ernest L. Ives, Captain Kenner F. Hertford, Easton T. Kelsey, Hubert Roemer, K. H. Fisher, Miss Dorothy Root, Dr. and Mrs. Glen W. Tuttle, Miss Ruth Tuttle, Albert Friedman, Mrs. F. E. Gridley and Mr. and Mrs. R. E. Enstrom.

Edmond O'Connor, one of the most famous criminal lawyers in London, will appeal a sentence of seven years' penal servitude meted out to him in Old Bailey Court today for allegedly forging a will of the late Willie Clarkson, theatrical costumer.

Amid a deal of acrimonious discussion as to whether the type of baseball played by the American League is superior to that of the National, Colonel Bill Terry gave by action more eloquently than words today an unequivocal endorsement of the McGravian system, of which he stands as his circuit's outstanding disciple.
Hugh Howell, aide of former Governor Eugene Talmadge in the latter's fight against the New Deal, entered the race for the Georgia Governorship today but without the support of his one-time chief.

MANHATTAN FRANKS, ROBERT AUGUSTUS (Sept. 1, 1935). Gross assets, $581,455; net, $480,305. To Carnegie Corporation of New York, $2,500; Thetta Quay Franks, widow, personalty and one-half residue; J. A. Franks, Ralph C. Franks and Robert A. Franks Jr., one-sixth residue each, Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $516,214.

The National Independent Pharmacists, Inc., has elected the following officers: Marcus Kaye, Yale Drug Company, Inc., president; Bernard Feldman, Beck Drug Company, Inc., vice president; Hyman Goldberg, Rival Drug Company, Inc., treasurer, and Albert W. Donn, Ethical Pharmacy, secretary.

City officials of this industrial community of 46,000 people were pondering tonight the issue of secession from Chautauqua County. Their action followed a series of disputes with the County Board of Supervisors over tax levies and representation.
Mrs. William Gibson Borland of Beverly Farms, Mass., has announced here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Rosamond Borland, to Peter Desmond White of this city.

Judge Peter J. Brancato collapsed on the bench in Kings County Court, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon as he prepared to begin the trial of a murder case. He was carried to the chambers of County Judge George W. Martin.

Premier Mussolini's warning that armed intervention by France in Spain is likely to precipitate European war was ironically underlined, in the same issue of Informazione Diplomatica, organ of the Foreign Office, by an official report of the present numerical strength of the Italian forces in General Franco's army.

Featuring what is said to be the New York premiere of "Duty," a one-act play by Seumas O'Brien, the Irish Repertory Players will present a triple bill of short plays on Friday night at the Heckscher Theatre.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today dismissed a complaint of Braniff Airways, Inc., against Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., that certain activities of TWA were unreasonable competition under the terms of the Air Mail Act.

The Harvard Club's squash racquets team, led by Germain G. Glidden, national amateur champion, administered a 3-2 defeat to the visiting British players from Cambridge University yesterday at the Harvard Club.

Roland Dufton, New York Athletic Club pro and one of the favorites, came through to victory as the world open squash tennis championship tournament got under way on the courts of the Hotel Shelton last night.

The Dress Returns Control Bureau requested the Federal Trade Commission yesterday to investigate certain business practices of Lerner Stores, Inc., of 384 Fourth Avenue, which the bureau charged were in violation of the Clayton Act as amended by the Robinson-Patman law, according to announcement by Louis Rubin, chairman of the bureau.

The Browns hung up their ninth straight exhibition victory by defeating the University of Texas, 5 to 1, before Governor James V. Allred and a near-capacity crowd of collegians today. The Governor gave Manager Gabby Street of the Browns a lieutenant colonel's commission.

Flushing High's nine downed Textile High, 11 to 8, in the initial baseball game of the 1938 season for both schools at Flushing Memorial Field yesterday. Each team scored seven runs in the first two innings but two-run outbursts by the Red Devils in the third and sixth clinched the contest for the home nine.
Dr. Ira M. Garrison of East Greenbush, who made his rounds in Rensselaer County with a horse and buggy, died today after a two-day illness. He was 82 years old.

Round table conference, Jewish Vacation Association, Hotel Commodore, 10 A. M., to be followed by luncheon, 1 P. M. "Camp as a Factor in Individual Personality Growth," Professor Jay B. Nash, Mark A. McCloskey, Ida Oppenheimer.

The American Civil Liberties Union and the C. I. O. served notice today they would resume their fight with Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City through distribution-of leaflets on the city streets. The announcement came as a result of yesterday's ruling by the United States Supreme Court on the Griffin (Ga.) circular case.

The Lithuanian red, yellow and green flag was hoisted for the first time in the Polish capital tonight when it was displayed on the balcony of an apartment of a leading Warsaw hotel-the apartment occupied by the Lithuanian envoy, Casimir Skirpa, who arrived tonight via Koenigsberg.

Dean Carl E. Ladd of the College of Agriculture, Cornell University, and Mrs. Ladd have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Marie Ladd, to Lieutenant Ferdinand J. Tate, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Ferdinand Tate of Eunice, La.

Settlement of the strike of. 4,000 moving men appeared in sight yesterday when representatives of the strikers and companies involved agreed to submit their wage dispute to adjudication by the State Mediation Board if they were unable o reach an accord by direct negotiation.
Freedom of the press is the right to publish a big, well-printed newspaper enjoying a large circulation. But even more is it the

The Rev. Albert M. Quigley, pastor of the Baptist Church of Mariners Harbor, S. I., for the last eleven years, died yesterday at his home, 58 Van Name Avenue, after a heart attack. He was 55 years old.

For two hours yesterday manikins were on parade and hundreds of guests strolled through the new women's shop of Lord Taylor at a preview signalizing completion of the final unit in the modernization of the store's entire fourth floor.

MANHATTAN BEINECKE, JOHANNA E. (March 21). Estate, more than $20,000. To Alice Weickert, daughter, 2 Mothes Strasse, Eutritsch, Leipsig, Germany, specific stock in trust; Theodora Strong, daughter, 805 Main St., Hartford. Conn., one-half personal effects art objects. etc. and one-fifth residue; Linda L. Beinecke, daughter-in-law, 812 Park Ave., one-half personal effects art objects, etc.:

Champion Joe Louis fired one righthand punch after another today as he stepped through his last heavy drill in preparation for his heavyweight title bout at the Stadium Friday night with challenger Harry Thomas.
Police twice broke a picket line at the Federal Screw Works today to escort non-striking employes in and out.

Two Curb Exchange brokers who specialized in shares of the Distilled Liquors Corporation will be subpoenaed, along with other witnesses, for further private hearings in the investigation by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. into the affairs of Richard Whitney, head of the bankrupt brokerage firm of Richard Whitney Co.

Earnings and sales last year of the American Rolling Mill Company and its subsidiaries established new high records, according to the annual report for 1937 made public yesterday by George M. Verity, chairman, and Charles R. Hook, president.

Miss Margaret Helen Harrison, for many years supervisor of the operating rooms at Mountainside Hospital and of recent years in charge of X-ray work for several Montclain physicians, died today of a heart malady in the hospital.

The stock market, after a firm opening today, turned dull as business failed to develop and most sections lost ground. Gilt-edge issues weakened, but among the foreign bonds Austrian and Czechoslovak loans were firm. In late trading transatlantic stocks had a setback following the receipt of disappointing news from Wall Street.

The threatened strike in the cleaning and dyeing industry, affecting directly and indirectly 25,000 retailers and employes, was averted for at least two weeks yesterday when representatives of the Cleaners and Dyers Board of Trade,

United States Attorney Lamar Hardy plans to resign about July 1, it was learned last night from a reliable source, to become the head of a Wall Street law firm. It was reported that Mr. Hardy, after spending little more than two years in the post of Federal prosecutor here, has decided out of consideration for his family that his salary of $10,000 represents too great a sacrifice.

Marian Anderson, Negro contralto, will be heard in her first Town Hall recital tonight, concluding the season's endowment fund series. The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli conducting, will play works of Barber, Sibelius, Walton and Rimsky-Korsakoff in Carnegie Hall tonight.
Steel ingot production increased more than seasonally last week and the index advanced to 45.2. This compares with 42.5 for the previous week, and 122.5 for the week ended March 27, 1937.
After a rather slow start, New York: and New Jersey communities now are setting up the machinery which will permit them to benefit from Federal subsidies for low-rent housing.

Balli Bunti, bay mare owned by the Sundown Stables of Rumson, N. J., and ridden by Mrs. Fred Wilmshurst, placed first in the lightweight class for hunters, feature event of the annual Pinehurst Horse Show today. The event drew twelve entries, including some of the finest-bred horses training in the South.

Mrs. Alfred W. Paine, president of the Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, and her new partner, Frederick B. Alexander Jr., reached the semi-finals of the sixth annual metropolitan squash racquets mixed doubles championship at the Heights Casino yesterday.

Mikhail Slavutsky, the Soviet Ambassador, protested last night to Foreign Minister Koki Hirota against Japan's refusal to implement her undertakings regarding payment by Manchukuo for the Chinese Eastern Railroad, and the Foreign Office here issued a further statement containing details of Manchukuo's claims against the Soviet.

Unreported more than ten hours, a school bus driven by Mrs. K. Brown was sought in the blizzardswept district of Parkland, seventy-five miles south of here, tonight. Mrs. Brown was to have picked up twelve pupils.

Encouraged by the passage of the Reorganization Bill by the Senate President Roosevelt took occasion today to rebuke opponents of his policies, and then revealed plans to send in additional legislative proposals which might cause indefinite postponement of the adjournment of Congress.
The most important of the year's award for competitors in the numerous obedience tests at leading dog shows in the East in the Country Life and Sportsman's Perpetual Trophy.
A. E. Jones, art dealer, and A. E. Yorston, formerly connected with a New York art gallery, reported to police today the apparent theft of fifteen paintings valued at $80,000.
Dr. Irving Busch, New York surgeon, returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie from Loyalist Spain where he was surgeon in charge of the American Hospital in Barcelona.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today Russell L. Snodgrass of New York was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 566-Guaranty Trust Co. of New York, petr., v. the United States. Argued for both. Leave granted petitioner to file additional brief within five days.
A national campaign for $400,000 to build a George Daley memorial athletic building on the Union College campus will be launched at the college's annual "Block U" dinner tomorrow night.
The Archbishop of Canterbury, head of England's Established Church, today followed the example of the Roman Catholic hierarchy in Vienna by giving his blessing to the union of Germany and Austria.

The French liner Normandie arrived yesterday nearly twenty-four hours behind her schedule because of fog in the English Channel. Former President Herbert Hoover, returning from a European tour, left the liner at her quarantine anchorage on a government cutter before 1 A. M.

The long dearth of corporate bond financing will be broken today when a banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., offers to the public $28,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds of the Duluth, Missabe Iron Range Railway Company.

A jury had been chosen in General Sessions yesterday for the holdup trial of two girls and four youths when one of the girls and three of the youths pleaded guilty. Judge Donnellan remanded them for sentence on April 8.

Miss Josephine Hoyt, president of the board of managers of the Stamford Home for the Aged, died in her home here on Sunday. She was born in Stamford, daughter of the late Harvey and Emily Selleck Hoyt, whose families were among the early settlers of Stamford.

Senator Wheeler of Montana today termed the Association of American Railroads "a high-class lobbyist." His remark drew from J. J.
