Pelley, president of the association, who was testifying before the Senate Railroad Finance Committee, the reply that the association lobbied "if presenting facts is lobbying."

After all these years, it is Beginning to look as though the market gunner is about to make his departure from the scene. Over the past week-end more than forty market gunners, scattered throughout Arkansas, Mississippi and Tennessee, were arrested by Federal game wardens.

Mr. and Mrs. Alexander M. Hadden entertained with a luncheon' at the Everglades Club for Dr. and Mrs. Daniel J. McCarthy, Dr. and Mrs. George A. Waterman, Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Henderson, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Pelham Robbins, Mr. and Mrs. J. Brooks Fenno, Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse, the Hon. Mrs. Frederick E. Guest, Mrs. John A. Chapman and Mrs. Marc Sevastopoulo.

A distance record for seaplanes was established today when Captain Hans Werner von Engle, German commercial aviator, landed at Caravellas, Brazil, after a 5,278-mile flight from a catapult ship anchored off Dartmouth, England. His time was forty-two hours.
The Senate Finance Committee decided today that the government should spare the income taxpayer the annoyance and expense of swearing before a notary public to the honesty of his return.

Plans for the new $2,800,000 William Howard Taft High School in the Bronx have been rejected by the Municipal Art Commission, it was learned yesterday. The commission, in a memorandum to Henry C. Turner, president of the Board of Education, charged that the proposed structure would duplicate Lafayette High School of Brooklyn.
The United States made strong diplomatic representations to the Mexican Government today over its expropriation of United States and British petroleum companies.

George Brooks's bloodhounds quickly solved the robbery of the Burgess Lumber Company office here. Mr. Brooks lives in La Crosse, Wis., but Sheriff Albert T. Pederson appealed to him for use of his dogs in tracking the robber.

The $1,400 Le Brun Traveling Scholarship of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects has been awarded for 1938 to Harvey P. Clarkson of 225 East. Thirty-ninth Street. Mr. Clarkson is draftsman for the board of design of the New York World's Fair and is Assistant Instructor of History at New York University.

Jackie (Kid) Berg, 145, London, former featherweight champion, continued his comeback successfully by defeating Frankie Wallace, 140 1/2, of Cleveland in the main eight-round bout at the Broadway Arena last night before 3,500 spectators.

Though "Who's Who" didn't capture any revue records hereabouts, its career is by no means over. In a week or so it will be packing up its belongings, moving toward San Francisco (playing four weeks on the way), moving from there to Honolulu (four more weeks) and then, in June, opening in Sydney, Australia.

The House today passed and sent to the Senate the largest War Department appropriation bill since 1921, carrying a total of $448,116,280. This is $32,853,130 more than last year's grant and $5,222,551 less than was asked by the Administration.

Annexing five of the six events the Savage women's swimming team easily vanquished the Hunter College aggregation, 37 to 16, yesterday in the Hunter pool. Miss Constance Deimling was the star for the winners, triumphing in the 50-yard back-stroke and the 50 yard breast-stroke.

Miss Elsa Voorhees, a descendant of William L. Dayton, former United States Minister to France, and of Captain George Denison of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, was married here yesterday afternoon to Theodore Spaeth Hauschka of Chestnut Hill, Pa.
As an expression of French remembrance of the friendship of the wartime United States Ambassador, Paris has decided to name a street "Avenue Myron T. Herrick."

With the first Western team that has ever tried for the title going into action for the first time, the year's intercollegiate indoor polo championship moves through its semi-final rounds tonight with the two matches at Squadron A Armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue.

That Edward W. Marshall Farns- ed worth Hatch, former New York in broker missing since his indictment in 1931 for a securities fraud, was Marshall F. Hatch, until recently a salesman for the Hartford, Conn., Better Business Bureau, was revealed yesterday with the arrest of the man at the office of Attorney General Bennett.
With two out in the ninth and the score even, Pinch-Hitter Bill Terry Jr. smacked out a sizzling winning single this afternoon to help Virginia defeat the University of Vermont, 9 to 8.

The expansion of the tennis team's schedule from seven to ten matches features the cards of the City College varsity tennis, lacrosse and track and the junior varsity baseball teams released yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics.

The Long Island University A. A. team, defending champion, and the Union Temple tossers gained the final round of the annual metropolitan A. A. U. basketball tournament by scoring victories at the Union Temple in Brooklyn last night.

Wade D. Holland of 270 Park Avenue, former president of the Continental Baking Corporation, died yesterday in the Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, Medical Center, after an illness of two weeks. He was 54 years old.

Rutgers St, 46, 25x100.1: Samuel Berman et al to Citizens Savings Bank; ' mtg $19,000 held by bank. 10th St. 9 E. 24.5x94.9x73.3 at rear: Robert Bancker Talbot to Nannie W. B. Talbot, his mother, 60 Broadway, care Wickes N. Riddell (quitclaim).

GOVERNORS ISLAND A board of officers is appointed to meet at Camp Dix, N. J., on or about May 24, 1938, or at the call of the president thereof, for the purpose of conducting the practical test of such applicants as may be properly ordered before it, to determine their fitness for the eligible list for appointment as Brigadier General of the Line, Reserve.

On technical grounds, Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag dismissed yesterday a legal action for $25,087 brought by Representative Charles A. Buckley of the Bronx against the city for legal expenses allegedly incurred in defending himself in four suits based on his actions as City Chamberlain between 1929 and 1933.

In a very rough race the Chilean 7-year-old Vitelio, ridden by the Panama jockey, G. Moore, owned by the Dalia Stable of A. A. Ruiz of Cuba and trained by J. Simon Healey, scored a head victory in the Medina Purse at Tropical Park today.

More than 200 adult patients in the dispensary of Bronx Hospital, on Fulton Avenue near 169th Street, were driven from the twostory frame structure yesterday by a smoky fire that burned the tar from the rear wall of the Eichler Brewery, about fifty feet behind the dispensary.

The finance bureau of the Interstate Commerce Commission began final consideration today of the applications of Charles E. Denney and John Hadden for approval of their appointment as trustees of the Erie Railroad. now in receivership. Mr.
Football players in chorus girl tights tonight for the first time turned the annual show of Harvard's Hasty Pudding Club into a political satire.

Hogs continued to decline today, but all interests bought freely at the downturn, and closing prices were firm, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Meanwhile the steer trade continued slow and no better than steady even though receipts were small. Fat steers predominated.

Rehabilitation of Rockaway Beach was advanced yesterday with the sale of $18,000,000 in new 3 1/2 per cent revenue bonds by -the New York City Parkway Authority. The bond sale will be followed immediately by the letting of a contract for the widening of Cross Bay Boulevard and construction of a new drawbridge, Robert Moses, sole member of the Authority, announced.
Industrial payrolls in Pennsylvania showed an increase in February for the first time since October, Ralph M. Bashore, Secretary of Labor and Industry, asserted today.

The latest proposal for a new tax on the banks, advanced by City Councilman B. Charney Vladeck, helped yesterday afternoon to speed the sharp decline in shares of local bank stocks. The break in the bank-stock market was the most severe in months.

Benjamin B. Rosenwasser, vice president and treasurer of the Benrose Silk Corporation, 1,450 Broadway, manufacturers of silk and rayon fabrics, died on Monday night in his home, 411 West End Avenue, after a lingering illness. He was- a former professional violinist. His age was 47.

General Sessions Judge Charles C. Nott Jr. decreed yesterday that the Sing Sing sentences he imposed in May, 1936, must be served by the two former officers of the defunct Commonwealth Bond Corporation who were convicted of looting the corporation of more than $300,000 in 1932.

With the last of the preliminary arrangements now completed the United States, Great Britain and France in a few days will invoke the escalator clause of the 1936 naval treaty and thus free themselves to match the super-battleships Japan is now assumed to be building.
Vice President Garner said today hat Congress might speed its york if members could hear a collegee glee club concert every day.

A jury of ten men and two women in Supreme Court freed James Roosevelt, oldest son of the President, yesterday from any liability for injuries received by Police Sergeant William Seubert and his wife, Anna, in an automobile accident on Sept. 15, 1935.

Seventy water-colors by Henri Chardon, member of--the- French Academy of Moral and Political Sciences, have been given by the artist to Columbia University in memory of Alexis de Tocqueville, nineteenth century liberal who wrote "Democracy in America," it was announced yesterday.

The actual worth of municipal credit depends on its measurements by investors, and municipalities should go to accountants and also to security dealers for help in presenting their financial condition in a better way.

The Song Writers Protective Association, numbering 657 popular composers and lyric writers, voted unanimously yesterday afternoon at its annual meeting at the Hotel Victoria to endorse a plan to alleviate the plight of German and Austrian composers.
The Securities and Exchange Commission set hearings today in the applications of the Engineers Public Service Company, Inc.,

The Senate resolution providing for a joint Congressional investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority and activities of private power companies in connection with the TVA program was reported favorably to the House today by its Rules Committee, which made several changes designed to strengthen the investigating committee's hands.

The Northern Sea Route Administration, under whose direction last year Soviet aviators flew over the North Pole to America and Soviet scientists established an ice-floe camp at the North Pole, was ominously criticized today by the Council of People's Commissars.

The general death rate for this city rose to 11.9 per 1,000 population, the high for the year so far, during the week ended last Saturday, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner.
Death Announced Retired Lieutenant John A. Leonard, formerly a member of H. L. Co. 129, residing at 89-31 184th St., Hollis, L. I., died March 27.

The minority statue that Premier Milan Hodza of Czechoslovakia announced yesterday, in which the present regulations governing the Sudeten German and other minorities would be legally codified but without substantial changes,

North American wheat markets were on the upgrade today under the leadership of Winnipeg. An effort by shorts to cover commitments in the May, plus the development of a strong cash position, lifted that delivery at Winnipeg the full 5 cents a bushel limit for one day's advance. The close was at the top.

The land and building at 126 Delancey St were leased by the trustees of the estate of Solomon Shapiro to Lancey Cafeteria, Inc., Max Zankel. president, for 21 years from May 1, 1937, at annual rentals graduated from $11.000 for the first three years to $15,000 for the last seven years, for the conduct of a restaurant or cafeteria business,

While several hundred firemen waited yesterday morning outside of St. Catherine's Catholic Church, 153d Street and Amsterdam Avenue, which was crowded, a high mass of requiem was celebrated in the church for William J. Lennon, acting battalion chief and chief of staff of the Fire Commissioner, who died on Saturday at the age of 64.

Miss Dorothy Helene Pagenstecher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albrecht Pagenstecher of this city and Huntington, L. I., has completed plans for her marriage to Charles Augustus Frank Jr., which will take place on April 22 in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

Robert C. Stanley, chairman and president of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in Toronto that the company was prepared to withstand another period of trade recession or to continue its expansion of recent years.

Funeral services for Dr. Edward Delavan Perry, Jay Professor Emeritus of Greek and the oldest member of the faculty at Columbia University, who died Monday at the age of 83, will be held at 10 o'clock this morning in St. Paul's Chapel on the university campus.

The lists of business leases submitted yesterday by brokers included several contracts for large retail units. J. S. Inskip, Inc., distributors in the United States of Rolls-Royce and Bentley motor cars, have taken the ground floor, second floor and basement in the Rolls-Royce Building, at 32-4 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Waite Hoyt, the pitcher, and the rest of the Dodgers today doublecrossed Waite Hoyt, the author. After perusing Author Hoyt's opus on "Why the American League Wins," in the current issue of a magazine, the Flatbush representatives in the National League went out to collect 18 hits, including four home runs, off three Detroit pitchers.

Clarence K. McGuire was elected president of the Nassau Boat Club yesterday at the New York A. C. This was the seventy-third annual meeting of the organization. Other officers chosen are Paul Kolisch, vice president; William T. Patterson, treasurer;

The New York City Tunnel Authority reported yesterday a low bid of $2,228,000 for the land tunnel at the Queens end of the mid-town vehicular tunnel. This bid was about $700,000 lower than the estimate on the contract made by the authority's chief engineer.
Counterattacking Japanese forces have succeeded in retaking control of Tsining and Lincheng in Shantung, military reports to Hankow from the front admitted today.

Tom Pendergast, one of the most powerful political bosses in the nation, won today a heavily guarded and heavily voted city election which saw a newcomer in politics whittle down somewhat the majority heretofore enjoyed by the Democratic organization founded in the Eighties.

The three Cambridge rugby players who were unable to make the trip with the rest of the squad last week on account of the Triple Crown games in England arrived here yesterday on the Normandie of the- French Line to give the visiting fifteen reinforcements for the remaining games on their schedule.

A man was killed and a young woman injured early this morning when the automobile in which they were riding crashed into a steel guard rail on the Hendrik Hudson Highway at West Seventy-second Street.

Easy going Vienna, which delights in banqueting, was reproved today in a proclamation by Nazi organizer Joseph Buerckel asking for harder work and suggesting that money spent on banquets be applied to creating jobs for the unemployed.

Francis X. McGuirk sold to Mathilde Pfluger Haslauer the house at 249 W 13th St, 20.10x75, and took back a purchasemoney mortgage for $5,000, due $1,000 next July 1, and $500 annually beginning March 28, 1943, 3 per cent, the price being $9,000. Mr. McGuirk bought this house last May 28 from Annie D. Ferree at a price shown as $5,000.
Public sentiment on the New Deal policy of reporting corporation salaries is about evenly divided with a slight majority opposed. according to a survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion.

Presiding Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court yesterday admitted William J. Graham and James C. McKay, Reno gamblers, to bail of $75,000 each pending appeal from their recent conviction on an indictment charging mail fraud growing out of the operations of a ring of confidence men.
From villages, cities and outlying districts more than 5,000 women gathered here today in the first conference of the rural-urban women of Georgia.

An average of 461,000 persons was on the payrolls of the steel industry in February, compared to 475,000 in January, a decline of 3 per cent, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The figure is 17 per cent-below February last year, when the average was 556.000.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday in the Episcopal Hospital, Philadelphia, of Mrs. Julia Waring Parks, widow of the Rev. Dr. J. Lewis Parks, former rector of Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, this city.
Mr. and Mrs. Walter W. Birge Jr. gave a luncheon yesterday at Le Coq Rouge. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Valentin BlacqueBey, Mrs. Harold Whitfield Carhart and Mrs. Fosdick Ryle.
Colonel Tillinghast L'H. Huston, who was co-owner of the New York Yankees baseball club before retiring to a Georgia plantation, died in his home today. He was 71 years old.

Samuel Kurzman, a former member of M. Kurzman's Sons, 385 Fifth Avenue, a women's specialty shop, died yesterday in his apartment in the Hotel Lombardy after a long illness at the age of 75. He retired from business in 1925 after selling his interest in the firm.
Spring tornadoes left seven persons dead and more than a score injured in the deep South today. Property damage was estimated unofficially at about $100,000.

The Supreme Court has upheld the power of New York City to impose a 3 per cent tax on the gross income of public utilities. But the court, it must not be forgotten, passes on the constitutionality of laws and not on their wisdom.

To stop war in China and to assure peace the world over, America must lift the appeal for peace to a moral level above selfish commercialism and apprehensive preparedness, the Rev. Dr. Emory W. Luccock, pastor of the interdenominational Community Church in Shanghai, said yesterday at a luncheon of thirty members of the Clergy Association of New York and Vicinity, held in the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue.

The Building and Construction Trades Council of New York has adopted a resolution which would prevent wage increases on the Red Hook and Queensbridge low rent housing projects while under construction, Nathan Straus, administrator of the United States Housing Authority, announced today.

Garfield Charles, a lawyer, was appointed today by Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson to act as special referee in bankruptcy to facilitate the liquidation of the three bankrupt Insull utility investment companies that are still in the Federal courts.

In the presence of 30,000 workers, among whom were 10,000 Austrians, Chancellor Adolf Hitler gave the new 25,000-ton workers' ship the name Robert Ley [Dr. Robert Ley is the leader of the German Labor Front] at the launching here today.

Henry Armstrong, with twentynine consecutive victories to his credit, will face Lew Feldman of Brownsville in a ten-round bout at the Hippodrome tonight. Although Armstrong's featherweight championship of the world will not be at stake, the battle promises to attract a large crowd.

Pat McLaughlin, whose 697 series boosted the Isaac Baker Son team of Erie, Pa., into first place last night, finished his American Bowling Congress schedule today by taking second in the all-events with a score of 1,933.
Mayor S. Davis Wilson charged today that a "hidden group of persons" was plotting to get rid of the new municipal airport named in his honor.

The daily average crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,405,600 barrels, compared to 3,433,550 in the preceding week, a decline of 27,950, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Mrs. George Platt Brett of Fairfield, Conn., entertained tonight with a dinner dance for members of the young set here from Northern schools on Spring vacation in compliment to her granddaughter, Miss Louise Brett McKinney of Pittsburgh, and the latter's classmates at Vassar College, Miss Jean Field of Bridgeport, Conn., and Miss Jane Stevenson of Middleburg, Va., at Journey's End, her estate in Coconut Grove.

On orders of Governor Earle an investigation was begun today into charges by Lieut. Gov. Thomas Kennedy, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, that State employes were being coerced by representatives of the Democratic State Committee.

A "blind date" which Jamieson H. B. Newell, 19, University of Wisconsin freshman from Lancaster, Wis., had a month ago with Barbara A. Brooks, 17, of White Plains, N. Y., also a freshman, resulted in their eloping today.

Lightweight Polo Ponies (Open to Army)First, Alicia, Captain R. H. Selway Fort Bragg; second, Pluto, Mrs. P. R. Miller. Middle and heavyweight Polo Ponies (Open to Army)-First, Rob Roy, Captain Selway; second, Guapo, Selway; third, Leilehua, Captain P. R. Miller, Fort Bragg.

This country's pending reciprocal trade treaty with England and the revised pact with Canada will be signed together on June 1, in all probability, Dr. Henry F. Grady, vice chairman of the United States Tariff Commission and chairman of the Committee for Reciprocity Information, told 800 exporters gathered at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday to attend the annual gettogether meeting of the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc.

WE have to thank a set of false teeth for one of the most toothsome items of Americana in many a month: "One Man in His Time,"* a book partly by, partly about, Harry Watkins. And we have to thank Otis Skinner and the late Mrs. Skinner for writing that considerable portion of the book which Harry Watkins didn't write, and for exchanging dentures for that portion which he did.
Senator Robert F. Wagner, mentioned in published reports as President Roosevelt's choice for the Democratic nomination for Governor of New York, told reporters today he "knew nothing about it."
The decision of the Supreme Court in the case of the Holding Company Act of 1935 has settled one important point for the utilities, but necessarily left other major questions hanging in midair.

One of the most significant results of the Japanese invasion of China is the economic rediscovery of Yunnan Province. Until necessity turned the Central Government's attention to Yunnan recently no thorough economic survey had been made of the resources of this "forgotten province."

Development of a new type of movie projector for use in television operation was announced today by the Farnsworth Company, which has been experimenting with the now completed apparatus for more than a year, in the belief that when commercial television becomes a reality in this country, transmission by means of films will constitute a "substantial part" of any television program.
The Senate Civil Liberties Committee heard testimony today that "most of the detective agencies of the country" had destroyed records because of investigations in Washington.
The Maritime Commission announced tonight that on Thursday it will seek permission in the Southern District Court of New York to foreclose mortgages on four Munson liners.
The Reynard Corporation is in effect nothing more than Fontaine Fox in corporate form and must pay a surtax deficiency assessment of $21,375.08, the Board of Tax Appeals decided today.

Two officers and two members of the crew of the British steamship Lossiebank of the Bank Line pleaded not guilty yesterday before United States Commissioner Martin C. Epstein in Brooklyn Federal Building on a complaint charging them with attempting to smuggle eleven Chinese into this country.

Trading was fair to slow. The lamb and veal markets were strong to higher, bull lower, other classes mostly steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated prices to be about in line with Monday's close as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Rainfall in New Jersey tonight diminished forest fire hazards after Division Fire Warden Bernard W. Bartlett, in charge of the Northern New Jersey District, had reported there had been 107 forest fires in his area in the last week.

172d St (11-2966), w s, 150 ft s of Boston Post Ed, 40x100; Joseph Sibrava to Anna Sibrava, 856 E 172d St. Adee Ave, 1.517 (16-4766); William J. Stevenson to Home Owners Loan Corp. 169th St, 282 E (9-2439); East River Savings Bank to Israel Fox, 258 E Burnside Ave.
Steve (Crusher) Casey and Dan O'Mahoney, two of Ireland's leading wrestlers, will exchange holds in the feature grappling exhibition at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Ten Broeck M. Terhune, 50 years ld,. formerly prominent realty broker of 45 East Sixty-sixth Street, leaded guilty yesterday in General sessionss to a grand larceny indictnent to cover a series of thefts of about $50,000 in jewelry entrusted to him on memorandum for sale to friends. Judge Owen W. Bohan demandedd him to the Tombs, pendng sentence April 12.
Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Moncrieffe Livingston have returned from Quitman, Ga., and are at the Madison. Sir George Prescott, Bart., and Lady Prescott have arrived from London and are at the Ritz-Carlton.

Federal Judge Alexander Akerman ruled today that he lacked jurisdiction in a suit for an injunction to restrain a bondholders' protective committee from further action in liquidating approximately $10,000,000 of indebtedness of the Everglades Drainage District or from receiving further salaries or expenses.

Leo B. Lebovitz, counsel for Albert Marinelli, former clerk of New York County, filed a brief yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, on a motion to quash an indictment charging Marinelli with having harbored a fugitive from justice.

Sealed proposals for the sale to the- Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company of Kings County Elevated Railroad Company first mortgage 4s, due on Aug. 1, 1949, in an amount sufficient to use the sum of $99,170 will be received. until April 22 at the office of the bank as trustee.

AT the end of the World War he was Lieut. Col. Tillinghast L'Hommedieu Huston, but that didn't go in baseball. He still was Cap Huston, the Man in the Iron Hat. It was W. O. McGeehan who crowned him with the descriptive phrase. The military prefix came from the fact that he had been a captain of engineers in Cuba during the Spanish-American War.

THE LIE OF NINA PETROVNA, from a screen play by Hans Szekely and T. H. Robert, with dialogue by Henri Jeanson; music by Michel Levine and Joe Hajos; directed by V. Tourjansky; produced by J. Konigfest for Solar Films, Paris, France: distributed by Lenauer International Films. At the Filmarte.

The sixto-one Supreme Court decision in the Electric Bond and Share case recalls two attitudes which were responsible for some of the ill-feeling that used to exist between the Administration and the court and still affect the relations of the New Deal and business.

The Museum of the City of New York, Mayor La Guardia and Grover Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation, yesterday received Sets 1, 2 and 3 respectively of the "first edition" Wedgwood plates issued by R. H. Macy Co., Inc., in joint observation of the inauguration of. George Washington in 1789 and the 1939 New York World's Fair.

The trustees of the Prudence Company, Inc., which is now being reorganized in the Federal court, have written to Governor Lehman asking him to veto a bill providing for a change in the Civil Practices Act that would prohibit the collection of more than 10 per cent of salaries garnished, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Jefferson Memorial Commission has agreed on a new design, as well as a new site, for the $3,000,000 memorial to Thomas Jefferson on the Tidal Basin. The action involved a reconsideration of the original plan of the late John Russell Pope which aroused opposition last year, partly because it would require removal of many Japanese cherry trees.

For the second successive day the Treasury reduced its buying price for foreign silver by 1 cent, making the "New York price" 43 cents an ounce today, compared with the 45-cent price maintained from Jan. 20, 1936, until yesterday. It was cut yesterday from 45 cents to 44 cents per ounce.

The Yankees wound up their exhibition activities for 1938 at Waterfront Park today, and, if the truth must be known, the curtain dropped without regrets. It has been a trying experience for Marse Joe McCarthy, whose business it is to mold another champion American League squad for Colonel Jake Ruppert.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Eleanor May Adams of this city, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles C. Adams of Cairo, Egypt, to Ralph Hubert Bain, also of New York,'son of Mrs. Ethel Bain of Hancock, Mass., and the late Frederick J. P. Bain of Hoosick Falls, N. Y.

University of Maryland opened its lacrosse season today with an easy 8-3 victory over Swarthmore. Not long after the game got under way Rip Hewitt scored the first of five goals made by him and from then on the Terps remained in front.

The City Commission adopted today a municipal budget of $6,231,353 for 1938. Of the total, $3,334,906 is to be raised by taxation. The tax rate will be about $5.61 for each $100 assessed valuation, an increase of 62 cents over last year.

Declaring that the combined efforts of the government, labor and industry to speed the process of recovery were the chief reasons for the current setback, W. B. Burrus of the Norge Refrigerator Company yesterday urged the Sales Executives Club of New York at its weekly luncheon at the Hotel Roosevelt to combat the slump by building sales enthusiasm.

The smoothclicking Toronto Maple Leafs overcame Boston's furious power for the third straight time tonight in their National Hockey League playoff series, winning by 3-2 in an overtime session before 16,523 fans at the Boston Garden. The triumph gave the Leafs the league championship and a place in the Stanley Cup finals.

Tamekichi Nakamizo's confession of how he organized his Tokyo version of the "March on Rome" of Feb. 18 should be filed as an example of the mixture of hokum and gangsterism that flourishes on the fringe of Japanese politics.
The city's principal elevated lines were officially offered for sale for back taxes yesterday amid a chorus of angry protests from elevated company officials.

In a continuance of the rush to register under the Holding Company Act, which started yesterday with the Supreme Court's decision in the Electric Bond and Share case, two more holding companies, the United Gas Improvement Company of Philadelphia and the $1,000,000,000 Associated Gas and Electric Company of Ithaca, N. Y., filed registration statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

French and Italian etchings of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, unofficially valued at $15,000, were stolen last week from the Summer home of Charles A. Whelan, head of the Whelan drug chain, police of this borough disclosed today.

Nicotinic acid, which within the last few months has been found of great therapeutic value in the treatment of pellagra, is now being produced chemically at a very low cost, which will make it additionally useful in fighting what is often known as "the poor man's disease," it was reported yesterday at the opening of the sixteenth annual conference of the Milbank Memorial Fund at the New York Academy of Medicine.

The condition of Dr. Joseph Sileo, 39 years old, of 8 Norwood Avenue, Brooklyn, who was attacked by an assailant in his home early last Sunday, was reported improved last night at Lutheran Hospital, Brooklyn.
Over the opposition of a teachers' lobby to certain sections of the bill, the New Jersey unemployment relief program measure was adopted by the House of Assembly tonight.

A large dinner was given by Colonel Cornelius W. Wickersham last night In connection with the second in the Spring series of "natural science evenings" at the American Museum of Natural History. The dinner meetings are being conducted in the interests of the ten-year development program of the museum.

Representatives in Puerto Rico's Legislature stand to a ma against a lone woman, Emma Gelpi, clerk of the District Court at Mayaguez, in demanding that she resign or be dismissed for alleged aspersions cas on Speaker Miguel Angel Garcia Mendez. She says she will not resign.

The Universal Oil Products Company announced today that the SoconyVacuum Oil Company, Inc., had purchased full operating rights under all of Universal's pyrolytic cracking patents. The purchase price, Universal announced, was "several million dollars."

A petition to review and set aside the cease and desist order of the Federal Trade Commission on the brokerage clause of the RobinsonPatman act has been filed by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the third circuit.

Film programs to be shown' tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:
With a view to fostering a permanent municipal symphony orchestra, a series of six Sunday afternoon concerts, to be broadcast by WNYC, will be inaugurated Sunday by the Federal Music Project.
Germany, March 30.-Ill luck continues to beset the German Zeppelin service. A hangar under construction here partly collapsed this afternoon killing six workers and seriously injuring six.

Frank Hedley, sole surviving voting trustee of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, announced yesterday that he will defer the deposit of I. R. T. capital stock voting trust certificates with a bank or trust company until May 31 in order to permit holders of voting trust certificates to exchange them for stock certificates. Mr.
Production of lisle hosiery, which was given considerable impetus by the movement to boycott Japanese products some months ago, has been sharply reduced, it was learned yesterday.

Department stores were drawn yesterday into the price competition on imported liquors and prices for well-known brands of Scotch fell 15 to 20 cents below the levels of Tuesday in package liquor stores in the downtown and midtown sections as a result.
The Interstate Commerce Commission decided today that present commutation and supplemental railroad fares between New York and South Amboy and Perth Amboy. N. J., were reasonable.

Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday kept pace with the moves made in the stock market, and prices ended unchanged to 4 points lower. During most of the session cotton changed hands at slight gains, but a selling wave the last hour erased most of the early improvement.
Because of the strike of the City Movers Association and the Upper New York Movers Association, the furnishings of the residence of the late Ogden L. Mills, 2 East Sixtyninth Street,
The proposed amendment to the Tax Bill to lighten the burden on holding companies forced to liquidate under the law is as follows: On page 95, after line 25, insert the following:

The day is long past when museums were either cabinets of curiosities or storehouses of scientific, artistic or industrial material. Whether the collections comprise works of art or butterflies, machines or rocks, wise directors see to it that they now serve an educational purpose.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 28: COMMANDERS Gates, J. W., San Diego, Calif., to the Portland as executive officer. Todd, C. C. Jr., to commander Destroyer Div'n No. 1 instead the Portland as executive officer; previous orders modified.

Capitalizing on eight hits, the same number registered by its rival, Princeton's varsity baseball nine overwhelmed Dickinson College, 14-1, in seven innings to launch the season for both teams on University Field today. The Tigers crossed the plate in all innings except the fourth.

A textbook on contemporary Russian history might properly remark of many an outstanding Soviet leader: "As the head of one of the chief branches of Soviet enterprise he set up a record which brought great prestige
Hereafter British sailors are expected to have no occasion to complain about the films that the Admiralty will provide for their amusement.

Ten competitors, including Mrs. Adele Rivero of New York, current holder of the Hazel Allen championship trophy, are ready for the women's championship tournament of the National Chess Federation, to be held concurrently with the men's national championship in the R. C. A. Building, Rockefeller Center, beginning Saturday afternoon, according to Mrs. Caroline Marshall, who will be tournament manager.

Federal Advisers, Inc., New York City, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a declaration under the Holding Company Act with respect to its organization as a subsidiary service company for subsidiaries of the Federal Light

A campaign to have New York State prevent, by constitutional provision, the diversion after 1941 of motor vehicle and motor fuel taxes to other than highway uses was launched yesterday at a meeting at the New York Athletic Club.

The Senate passed the $549,227,842 Navy Department Appropriation Bill today as it came from committee, after hearing Senator Clark, Democrat of Missouri, denounce it as a demonstration along with the proposed naval building program, of "colossal, stupendous and incredible folly."

Leonor F. Loree, veteran railroader and a redoubtable skirmisher in the consolidation battles of the pre1929 era, ended yesterday his colorful career in transport and in the security markets.. He severed his remaining connections with these fields by resigning as president of the Delaware Hudson Company,

BUSSE, GEORGE (Feb. 9). Estate, more than $10,000. To Emma Tautz. niece, Berlin-Wilmersdorf ,Bernherostr, 16, Germany, $20,000; Max Busse, nephew, 154 W. Glenarm St., Pasadena, Calif., $10,000: Martha Meyerhoefer, niece, 60 Rotherwick Rd., London N. W. 11, England; Paul Goepel, nephew, Berlin, 0112, Weichselstrasse 5, Germany;

Governor Lehman signed the Rapp bill today requiring motor cycle manufacturers, selling motor cycles in this State. after Jan. 1, to have muffiers or other similar devices on the machines to eliminate unnecessary noise, and also prohibiting the use of cut-outs on those machines.

Net profit of the Hearn Department Stores, Inc., and subsidiaries for the year ended on Jan. 31 amounted to $141,486 after depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes, $3,000 surtax on undistributed income and other charges, according to the annual statement issued yesterday by Leonard Ginsberg, president.
Favored players today marched into the quarter-finals of the North and South golf tournament for women. Six of the eight third-round. matches were decided by scores of 5 and 4 or better.

Motion pictures made in Japan, Australia, Germany, Canada, Scotland, England, Czechoslovakia and the United States have been entered in the International Amateur Movie Show, to be held next Wednesday night at Columbia University under the auspices of the Division of Film Study.

The initial financing by the newly created New York City Parkway Authority, begun on Tuesday but done formally yesterday with the official offering of the bonds to the public, proved a complete success for all concerned. The Authority obtained its funds at a net interest cost of 3.4985 per cent,
THE AULD SINNER, by Cowan Harper. (Macmillan, $1.75.) The story of an Ulster Scot of a generation ago. THE BABY GIANT PANDA, by Ruth Harkness. (Garrick Evans, $2.)
Boat racing history was made today when the Oxford oarsmen, in the final stages of training for their annual race with Cambridge Saturday, were paced in a trial spin by the Cambridge reserve crew.

In keeping with the growing emphasis on swimming as a major sport Princeton has let down the bars of its major letter and major numeral requirements in regard to natators, according to an announcement today by Professor Burnham N. Dell, '12, chairman of the University Council on Athletics.

Gano Dunn, as trustee for the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation, held 404,326 shares, or 55 per cent, of the common stock of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company at the close of the latter' concern's most recent fiscal year, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Seven additional replies were received by the State Department today to the proposal for the creation of an intergovernmental committee to facilitate the emigration of political refugees from Austria and Germany.
Speaking in his capacity as Minister of the State's armed forces Premier Mussolini in the Senate this afternoon painted a vivid picture of Italian armed strength and Italian military preparedness.

The United Rubber Workers of American local of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company won a National Labor Relations Board election today and became the collective bargaining agency at the Firestone factory.

Efforts by members of the Workers Defense League to distribute circulars in Jersey City were thwarted by the police today for the second time since the United States Supreme Court ruled that an ordinance requiring a permit for such distribution was a violation of the free press principle.

THE GAIETY GIRLS, from a screen play by Arthur Macrae: lyrics by William Kernell, with musical score by Michael Spolianski; directed by Thornton Freeland; a Gunther Stapenhorst production: presented by Alexander Korda; released by United Artists. At the Rivoli.

Judge Freschi in General Sessions yesterday imposed a five-to-tenyear term in the women's prison at Bedford Hills on Mrs. Louise Plessen, 37 years old, of 248 West Sixtysecond Street, who alleged she was the divorced wife of a Danish baron, for the sale of $5 worth of heroin to an agent for the Society for the Suppression of Crime and a detective.

Twenty-two new judgeships are authorized in a bill passed in the Senate today by a vote of 70 to 7 and sent to the House. Opposing the program were Senators Capper, Copeland, Frazier, Holt, Lee, McNary and Norris.

Recommendations that brokerage firms having membership in the New York Stock Exchange be incorporated for the better protection of the public were filed yesterday with that institution's law committee by a special committee of three, headed by Philip W. Russell, senior partner in Fenner Beane.

Two New York Stock Exchange seats were sold yesterday at $52,000 apiece, down $3,000 from the previous transaction on Tuesday. The new price, like its predecessor, was the lowest since 1918, when $45,000, the bottom since 1915, was reported.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange, by a ruling of the committee of arrangements yesterday, were prohibited from combining the odd-lot orders of several different customers in the same stock into round-lot orders.

On the eve of House consideration of the reorganization bill, Senators who on Monday lost their fight against the measure bitterly denounced today the statement made by President Roosevelt that the passage of the bill by that body "proves that the Senate cannot be purchased by organized telegrams based on direct misrepresentation."

In line with Field Marshal Hermann Goering's economic program proclaimed in Vienna recently, the Bavarian State government today announced new administrative units to speed up construction of the Rhine-MainDanube canal, which will connect the Ruhr industrial district with the Danube countries and the North Sea with the Black Sea.

Tom Iannicelli, Short Hills Club pro and defending champion, made his first appearance in the world open squash tennis championship tournament at the Hotel Shelton last night and scored a secondround victory.
Thirty-five strikers and sympathizers and five policemen were injured today when members of the United Automobile Workers Union tried to keep

Miss Barbara Winlock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Eustis Winlock, gave a luncheon yesterday in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for her committee for Harvard's Hasty Pudding show, to be given here next week.
Hampden-Sydney scored two runs in the ninth inning today to defeat the University of Delaware, 7 to 6. It was the season's opener for the Virginians.
Tommy Atkins, a bay gelding owned by Mrs. George Y. MacMurtry of New York, won the opening event at the twenty-third annual Aiken Horse Show today. Only one class was contested, an open jumping test.
Increases in the number of child offenders and of suicides and attempted suicides are disquieting features of the criminal statistics for England and Wales for 1936, issued tonight.

Banks figured as the sellers in several Bronx apartment deals reported yesterday. Joseph Chinich, operator, bought the five-story apartment house at 2,096 Daly Avenue, corner of 186th Street, subject to a first mortgage of $60,000, which was extended by the North Side Savings Bank for five years with interest at 5 per cent.

Electric power production declined last week, running counter to the normal seasonal and longterm trends, and the adjusted index has dropped to 91.0, its lowest point since the week ended April 27, 1935. The figure for the previous week was 93.3, while for the week ended March 27, 1937, the index stood at 106.9.

A declaration by the Penn Western Gas and Electric Company, covering the reduction of the par value of its common stock from $12 to $5 a share and of a partial liquidating dividend to be paid out of surplus was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

After more than seven weeks of lockout in the industry, affecting some 2,500 workers, the Furriers Joint Council of the International Fur Workers Union yesterday called a general strike of 15,000 employes in an effort to enforce the union's demands upon the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc.

Beau Joe, 6-year-old chestnut gelding owned by the Sundown Stables of Rumson, N. J., and ridden by Fred Wilmshurst, was named champion hunter of the twenty-first annual Pinehurst Horse Show, concluded today.

In cooperation with the American Guild for German Cultural Freedom and four foreign publishers, Little, Brown Co. announces that plans have been completed for a $4,500 Exile Prize Contest with the closing date set for Oct. 1, 1938.

Memories of early farming days on Long Island, when acreage sold at prices below what single lots now bring and homes were chiefly of frame construction, are inspired by the news that a small estate in historic surroundings has just changed hands on Old Westbury Road in East Hills, Old Westbury.

HE way the star-spangled Americans have been acting in the hockey play-offs to date is a terrific blow at the Townsend Plan. "Help the aged!" That was a stirring plea until these gay gaffers on skates, the Dutton Dusters, began cutting capers on ice and knocking youngsters for a loop in the post-season scramble for the Stanley Cup.

Assemblyman Meyer Goldberg, sponsor of the bill broadening the provisions of the Private Detectives and Investigators License Law, joined Nathan R. Sobel, counsel to Governor Lehman, yesterday in denying that the statute, which the Governor is expected to sign, was intended to apply to newspaper men or publicity agents.

Magistrate Myles A. Paige in Yorkville Court adjourned yesterday until April 12 a hearing in the case of Lester David O'Dell, 35 years old, of 148 East Forty-sixth Street, accused of sending annoying and threatening letters to President Roosevelt, Mrs. Roosevelt, Postmaster General James A. Farley and others.

W. F. Severa, founder and for many years president of W. F. Severa Company, manufacturers of proprietary remedies, and philanthropist to hundreds of war orphans in his native Bohemia, Is dead. He was 84 years old. His widow and two children survive.
The United States has demanded effective compensation from Mexico for her expropriation of Americanowned oil properties and is now awaiting a reply from Mexico City.

A new exhibition place, to be called the Arista Gallery, at 30 Lexington Avenue, will open tomorrow with paintings by William C. Seitz on view. The purpose of the gallery is to show meritorious work by known and unknown artists without expense to the artist.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick withdrew his earlier opposition to a $2,800,000 appropriation for a new Appellate Division court house in Manhattan at an executive meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday and asked his colleagues to vote for inclusion of the item in the capital outlay budget.

If advance reports are verified next month when the statements of the larger investment trusts for the first quarter of the year appear, some liquidations of large blocks of stocks held in portfolios will be revealed, with a resultant marked increase in the cash positions of the trusts.

Albert Schacheman of the New York A. C., 18 years old, showed himself an improved and promising wrestler in the invitation A. A. U. program sponsored by the N. Y. A. C. Post of the American Legion at the Winged Foot clubhouse last night.
Alexander Graham Armstrong, who retired as the assistant cashier of the Irving Trust Company of New York in 1930, died Tuesday night at his home in Jersey City. He was 68 yars old.
Mrs. Hattie M. Clark, wife of William W. Clark, retired Supreme Court justice of the Seventh Judicial District, died at the age of 80 in her home here today after a long illness.

Out-of-town promotions of men's Spring clothing and furnishings are apparently pulling somewhat better than in this city, mail orders coming into the market this week revealed. A consistent demand for both Spring and Summer suits is a feature of the requests, according to manufacturers.

Mexico is operating under a strict censorship and the press there is unable to communicate to the Mexican people the full facts concerning the international controversy over the seizure of the foreignowned oil properties and the definite stand in the matter taken by the United States Government.

Real estate holdings of the Federal Land Banks dropped sharply in 1937 for the first time since 1929, according to Charles R. Dunn, fiscal agent of the land banks, who yesterday announced the results of the system's operations for 1937.

Accused of stealing a wallet said to have been a gift from Kermit Roosevelt, son of President Theodore Roosevelt, Arthur Russell, 40, of 487 East 156th Street, the Bronx, was convicted by a jury before Kings County Judge William O'Dwyer yesterday of second-degree robbery, grand larceny and assault.

The city was charged with bad faith yesterday in advertising on Tuesday a tax lien sale of the Manhattan elevated properties. Theodore S. Watson, vice president of the Manhattan Railway Company, and Charles Franklin, general counsel, declared that the Corporation Counsel had given assurance three
The General Land Office ruled today that the Federal Government and not private oil companies was the rightful owner of another section of oil lands in the Elk Hills Naval Reserve in California.

Louis Woodson Curtis, director of music in the Los Angeles public schools, was elected president of Music Educators National Conference today for a two-year term. He succeeds Joseph E. Maddy of Ann Arbor, Mich., who automatically becomes first vice president.
William Fulton Kurtz, president of the Transylvania Company of Philadelphia, was elected today president of the Reserve City Bankers Association.

Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, denied today reports that he was contemplating resigning to head a new law firm. Mr. Hardy came to Hot Springs "to get a much needed rest after I had tried a case that lasted for a considerable time." He made the following statement:

Another round of holiday parties was given last night for younger members of society now in town for the Spring recess from schools and colleges. The annual senior Spring dinner dance under the direction of Miss Adeline King Robinson took place in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
Walter H. Gidley-Lake, a retired public accountant, died early this morning here at the home of Mr. and Mrs. C. William Hansen, 160 West Merrick Road, after a brief illness. He was 81 years old.

Lazard Freres Co., Inc., and B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., obtained yesterday a new issue of $465,000 of school bonds of Glen Cove, L. I., on their bid of 100.327 for 2.20s. The bonds, dated March 1, 1938, and maturing March 1, 1941 to 1949, were reoffered at prices to yield from 1.30 to 2.25 per cent, according to maturity.

Of some standing as an actor and impressario of the local Italian stage, Clemente Giglio undertook a novel approach to the drama last night at the Bayes Theatre by having his own play, "Pasquale Never Knew," originally written in Italian, performed in English by Italian players.

With the time almost at land for the Giants to pull up stakes and begin their long trek northward, a tour that will take them through seven States with the Indians in tow, Colonel Bill Terry today received word from two sources assuring him that he will have his National League champions up to full man-power before many more weeks roll by.
Charles Macomb Flandrau, essayist, died here on Monday after a year's illness at the age of 66. He served as music and dramatic critic of The St. Paul Pioneer Press and Dispatch from 1915 to 1920.

The marriage of Miss Ellenor Brigham Colgate to Benjamin Loring Young Jr. will take place on April 23 in St. John's Episcopal Church, Flushing, Queens, and will be followed by a reception at the Oakland Country Club, Bayside.

Steve (Crusher) Casey, claimant of the world heavyweight wrestling crown, pinned the shoulders of Danno O'Mahoney to the mat at Madison Square Garden last night in 40:04 of an interesting finish encounter. Casey scored with a ?? hold and body slam.
Housing properties on the upper West Side and in Harlem proved attractive to buyers, in deals reported yesterday. Most of the buyers were investors.

The National Maritime Union, C.I.O. affiliate of unlicensed merchant seamen, assigned pickets yesterday to the offices of the Federal Maritime Commission at 45 Broadway and in Washington in protest against alleged unfair treatment of the union's members on government-owned ships.

Another demonstration of American League superiority blew up with a resounding bang in the ninth inning today as the rampant Dodgers chased four runs across the plate to humble the world champion Yankees by a 5-4 score. Cookie Lavagetto closed out a perfect batting day with a line single to left off young Joe Beggs that brought Kiki Cuyler home with the important tally.

The Federal Food and Drug Administration ordered an investigation today into the deaths at Orlando. Dr. J. J. Durrett, chief of the drug division of the administration, said the administration would seize all the drug that could be found in. this country.

Residents of Brooklyn Heights, overlooking the bay, appeared before the City Planning Commission at City Hall yesterday to urge the preservation of their locality as one of the choicest residential sections in the city.

Basil A. Barron, controller of the Educational Films Corporation, died on Tuesday night at Roosevelt Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 41. Funeral services will be held this afternoon at 1 o'clock in Riverside Chapel.

Charles Godchaux, president of Godchaux Sugars, Inc., told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that, while profits in February were fairly satisfactory, "earnings, however, are not as good as last year." So far this year the company has held its own in production and distribution, he said.

Strict enforcement of the principles of international law "generally accepted by all civilized nations for many years as representing fair play and justice between nations" was urged in a report filed yesterday by the Committee on Marine Insurance and Inland Marine Insurance of the insurance section of the American Bar Association.

In the first speech ever made by a Propaganda Minister of France, the new holder of that office, Louis-Oscar Frossard, broadcast tonight the assurance that France was not going to try to convert the world to French ideas.

Archaeologists engaged in the eighth season of excavation in the American zone of the Athenian Agora have uncovered a significant boundary stone which determined the limits of the ancient Grecian market place in the sixth century B. C., it was learned here today from Dr. T. Leslie Shear,

The annual report of the NovadelAgene Corporation and its subsidiaries for 1937 made public yesterday, showed a net profit of $1,447,797 after depreciation, amortization of patents, Federal and Canadian income taxes and surtax on undistributed earnings.

Champion Joe Louis gave three spar-mates a terrific "bombing" today as he concluded heavy work in preparation for his heavyweight title bout at the Stadium Friday night with Harry Thomas, the burly Minnesotan.
Frank J. Irving, Kings County commander of the American Legion in 1932, died early yesterday morning in his home at 719 Neck Road, Brooklyn, after an illness of six months He was 42 years old.

Services performed in the employment of a credit union organized under the laws of the State of New Jersey are not excluded from the tax provisions of the Social Security Act, the Bureau of Internal Revenue ruled today.

The interesting program given by Mr. Barbirolli and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall began with Samuel Barber's overture, "School for Scandal," suggested by Sheridan's comedy.

Harvard astronomers have discovered in the southern sky a gigantic cluster of stars which apparently belongs to no known class of cosmic systems and which may thus reveal the existence of a new group of star systems.
Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Lamont are at the Villa Aurelia in Rome with Miss Amey Aldrich and Chester Aldrich, director of the American Academy there.

Funeral services for Dr. Edward Delavan Perry, Jay Professor Emeritus of Greek at Columbia University, who died Monday at the age of 83, were held yesterday morning in St. Paul's Chapel on the campus. One hundred former colleagues and students were present.

President Roosevelt, under the most dramatic circumstances, said this morning: "I have no inclination to be a dictator." He added, "I have none of the qualifications which would make me a successful dictator."

The J. Paul Getty interests are considering consolidation of the properties of the Pacific Western Oil Corporation and possibly those of other Getty interests into the Mission Corporation, it was stated here yesterday.

The work accomplished by the Musicians Emergency Fund since its organization in 1932 was summarized by Mrs. John Sloane at the fina' luncheon of the season at the St. Regis Hotel yesterday. She listed some of the practical achievements as follows:
The lowest death rate for a February among industrial policy holders of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company was established last month, the company announced yesterday.

Mrs. Kate Delefield, in 157 E 72d St: Nellie C. Stewart, Minnie A. Buckley, in 1,331 Madison Ave; Dr. Leonard Mandel, in 190 E 125th St; Duff Conger, Inc, broker. Israel Bell, in 415 Central Park West; Axel G. Turnquist, in 400 Riverside Drive; Karl A. Blaustein, in 845 West End Ave;
A controversy between Bette Davis and Warner Brothers broke out today when the actress refused to appear in Faith Baldwin's "Comet Over Broadway," which is scheduled to start next Monday.

An appeal to American business men to encourage and finance a nationa organization of little business men pledged to fight "to make democracy safe for the United States" was voiced by leaders of the National Little Business Men's Association, at a luncheon meeting sponsored by the Merchants Association in the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

A "battle of millions," with control of the only remaining profitable segment of the $2,000,000,000 Van Sweringen railroad empire at stake, moved yesterday into the courts when Robert R. Young, head of the syndicate that controls the Alleghany Corporation,

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook discharged yesterday the fourth extraordinary grand jury impaneled by him at the request of Governor Lehman to investigate racketeering and its political ramifications.
A national system of unemployment insurance, applicable to approximately 1,000,000 railroad employes, will be pressed for early enactment in Congress by the Railway Labor Executives Association.

A serious political situation in Hungary-created by a steadily growing extreme Rightist movement under the influence of the Austro-German union-was described in Parliament today by the Liberal leader, Charles Rassay, as requiring immediate government action.

While a spokesman for the ruling coalition in Prague assailed the Slovak autonomy demand yesterday as inconsistent with the nation's democratic setup. other capitals discussed the plan, attributed to Berlin, for cantonizing Czechoslovakia on ethnical lines.

Special Notice Pending the preparation and issuance of new official forms for company fire reports, company officers shall not be required to account for each member of their respective companies in the manner prescribed on the back of the present official forms for company fire reports.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Adriaen Brouwer," Roberta M. Fansler, 11 A. M.; medieval collection (general tour), 2 P. M. Town Hall, "What Is Going On Behind the European Scene," Anne O'Hare McCormick, 11 A. M.; "The Theory of Production for Use," Henry Pratt Fairchild, 5:30 P. M.

David M. Dow, Official Secretary for Australia in the United States since 1924, will retire today, according to an announcement from the Australian Government office, 25 Broadway. He will remain in New York through April.
Andrew Ponzi cut deeply into the lead Jimmy Caras holds in their twelve-block pocket billiard exhibition by capturing the fifth and sixth sessions at- the Strand Academy yesterday.

The General Motors Corporation announced today the election of David O. Thomas, general manager of its malleable iron division at Saginaw, Mich., and of Edwin R. Palmer, assistant controller of the corporation, as vice presidents of the Bendix Aviation Corporation at South Bend, Ind.

Lafayette opened its Spring sport season today with the lacrosse team bowing to Williams, 7 to 4. Starting with a rush, Lafayette got away to a three-goal lead in the first quarter, but Williams knotted the count, 3-3, at half-time and went on to triumph in the closing periods.

A group of Brooklyn juniors, under the chairmanship of Mrs. John G. Surpless, will be among those selling candy and programs at the twenty-sixth annual performance of the Blind Players Club tonight at the Academy of Music, Brooklyn. The play this year is "The Little Clown" by Avery Hopwood.

ARCHIBALD MACLEISH'S latest book* is a striking but not altogether successful stunt. Like the recent "You Have Seen Their Faces," it is a combination of words and pictures, but this time the words are in blank verse rather than Erskine Caldwell's earnest prose, and the pictures from other cameras than Margaret BourkeWhite's alone.

The chairman's subcommittee of the NonIntervention Committee will meet tomorrow for the first time in seven weeks to continue discussions on how "volunteers" in Spain are to be withdrawn and at what stage of this withdrawal belligerent rights shall be accorded.

Again the impassioned crusader she was during the campaign for woman suffrage, Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, now in her eightieth year, brought a cheering audience to its feet yesterday in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor at the fifth annual luncheon of the women's division of the American Jewish Congress.

With the first annual exhibition of one; two and three sheet posters, sponsored- by Transit Advertisers, clearly revealing the superiority of the foreign posters over the American product, definite steps will be undertaken in the near future to remedy the situation, it was learned yesterday.
While the ink on the registration statement of the United Corporation has hardly had time to dry, new plans of a radical nature are being formulated for the vast public utility holding company.

In the United States Supreme Court today the following proceedings were had: 514-United States and Interstate Commerce Commission, applts., v. Pan American Petroleum Corp., et al., and 530--United States and Interstate Commerce Commission, applts., vs. Humble Oil and Refg. Co., et al. Argument continued and concluded for appellants; continued for appellees.
Final individual scoring figures for the International-American Hockey League season, released today, showed Jack Markle of the Syracuse Stars at the top of the list.

Sinclair Lewis appealed yesterday for preservation of the "ivory tower," far from the world and its cares, where learning might be sought. Too many persons, he suggested, attempt to make thinkers feel "guilty" and so drive them into the world of events.
Meeting in New York on Tuesday, shareholders of the W. T. Grant Company will consider amending and extending the profit-sharing plan for executives of the company, originally made effective in 1933.

Unless American colleges and universities abandon the "standard brands" of curriculums they now offer and learn to put specialties on the educational market, 450 of them are doomed to extinction by 1960, Walter B. Pitkin, author and Professor of Journalism at Columbia University, warns in the current number of The Columbia Alumni News, just issued.

A finding that the Stutz Motor Company of America, Inc., is insolvent and that no reorganization plan can be found which is acceptable to two-thirds of the creditors was made public today by Albert S. Ward, special master in chancery of the Federal District Court here.

Political conferences and negotiations between Premier Leon Blum and his Radical Socialist Cabinet members today caused some changes in the government's program for financial debate over this week-end.

Coming within four-fifths of a second of Mr. Sponge's track record for five and a half furlongs, Gene Wagers carried J. Van Winkle's colors to a breezing triumph in the feature at Tropical Park today.
Devastating tornadoes originating in Oklahoma spread death and havoc across five Midwestern States late today and leveled all but two builldings in South Pekin, Central Illlinois town of 1,500.

The provisions covering deceptive trademarks and misleading descriptive terms for simulated furs were the only regulations seriously opposed at the hearings today on the Federal Trade Commission's proposed rules for the fur industry.

The Barkley resolution proposing a joint Congressional investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority and the activities of private utilities relating to the TVA program, was adopted unanimously by the House today.

Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone told attorneys in the Federal Government's gasoline price-fixing conspiracy case today that he would reserve decision on motions of the defense to set aside the conviction of sixteen oil companies and thirty executives pending exhaustive study of their arguments.

A total of $20,000 was contributed Tuesday night to the Youth Aliyah (immigration) fund of Hadassah to remove children from Austria as well as Germany and Poland, it was announced yesterdayy by Mrs. Joseph Stroock, a member of the national Youth Aliyah committee of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America.
Stocks closed irregularly lower erasing earlier gains; turnover, 1,667,260 shares. Bonds generally lower in third busiest day of year; transactions, $10,107,450.

Approval for the listing of 90,000 shares of new Class A and 120,000 shares of new Class B stock, no par value, of Langendorf United Bakeries, Inc., was voted yesterday by the governors of the New York Curb Exchange.
The Bees pounded the cream of the Red Sox' younger pitchers for sixteen hits today while taking a 2-1 lead in the six-game intracity Spring series with an 11-3 victory.

Union College officially launched its national campaign to raise funds with which to erect a suitable memorial for the late George H. Daley, class of 1892, and former sports editor of The New York Herald Tribune, at the eleventh annual Block U dinner tonight to honor 216 athletes in intercollegiate and intramural sports.

Henry Milo Erkins, retired New York architect and decorator, died on Saturday night at his home in Lake Worth, Fla., after a long illness, according to word received here yesterday. He was 73 years old.
A confident band of New York Americans arrived here today, prepared to sweep the Chicago Black Hawks out of the semi-final round of the National Hockey League play-offs in two straight games.

Some weeks ago we became a unit of a small luncheon club which meets once a week to talk over the current problems of the fishing world. This group, although small, is a fairly good representation of the various types of American angling, as there's hardly a game fish that some member hasn't caught.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 29: COLONEL Fulton, W. S., Inf., orders detailing in Inspector General's Dept., effective June 19 and from Ft. Douglas, Utah, to Philippine Dent revoked.

A materful 717 in singles competition today by Joe Fliger of Chicage served the dual purpose of placing him second in both the individual and the all-events standing in the American Bowling Congress tournament.

Mr. and Mrs. D. Dulany Hunter were hosts at a dinner at the Everglades Club tonight. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Dillman, Mr. and Mrs. Jay O'Brien, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Alger Jr., Mr. and Mrs. William Rhinelander Stewart, the Hon. and Mrs.

The break in prices on Wall Street yesterday had a depressing effect on the stock market here today and most sections weakened. Gilt-edge issues were sold in general, although most of the ground they lost was recovered by the close.
Officials of the Eastern States interscholastic basketball tournament opening here tomorrow night announced today the first night's pairings, They are:

Charles G. Barkaus, captain of the 1934 Manhattan football team, has been retained as coach of freshman baseball at Manhattan College, it was announced yesterday by Herbert M. Kopf, director of athletics. Barkaus, who handled the yearling nine last season, played three years of varsity baseball at the uptown institution.
The laboratory of Dr. Hendry Connell, where "ensol" is manufactured, will be inspected by officials of the Federal Department of Health.
A tract of 122 lots in Riverview Manor adjacent to the Villard Hill Development in Hastings and Dobbs Ferry, Westchester, has been purchased by William Kaufman from the Netherson Realty Corporation.

Trading was fair to slow. Steer hinds and ribs were steady to strong and steer cuts mostly steady to higher, in local markets yesterday. The lamb market was strong to slightly higher, fresh pork cuts steady to lower, other classes mostly unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef prices to be steady to strong, other classes weak, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Perley A. Pitcher, who represents the counties of Jefferson and Oswego and is leader of the Republican minority in the State Senate, is the selection for Republican floor leader of the Constitutional Convention which will open in Albany on Tuesday.
Turpentine firm, 23c; sales, 89 barrels; receipts, 269 barrels; shipments, 25 barrels; stock, 23,474 barrels. Resin nominal; no sales; receipts, 872; shipments, 71: stock. 64,880.

A formidable all-New York rugby football team, which will meet the touring Cambridge University fifteen at the Randalls Island Stadium on Saturday, has been chosen by the Eastern Rugby Union, it was announced yesterday.

The government's difficulties in getting at the roots of the RubensRobinson passport ring that operated through the office of former County Clerk Albert Marinelli were emphasized for the second time in two days yesterday when Arthur (Aaron) Sharfin, 26-year-old former office boy in the Egyptian Consulate here, was threatened with contempt of court as a recalcitrant witness.

The text of President Roosevelt's statement early today, making public his letter of disavowal of "inclination to be a dictator," was as follows: During the past ten days the President received comparatively few letters and telegrams relating to the Reorganization Bill now pending in Congress. The pros and cons were about equally-divided.

The Long Island Lighting Company was authorized yesterday by the Public Service Commission to issue $2,300,000 of first refunding mortgage gold bonds, Series C, 4 per cent. The bonds are to be dated June 1, 1935, and to mature on June 1, 1960. They are to be sold not later than April 20 at not less than par and accrued interest.

Wheat prices were lower today on scattered selling, a less active export demand and the failure of the pubic to take the buying side. Net losses on the Board of Trade here were 7/8 to 1 1/8 cents a bushel, the former on May, which received some support from houses with export and foreign connections.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The breakdown of State unemployment insurance at its very start is something that should engage public attention, and that of Governor Lehman and the State administration.

William Loeb, a director of the Reo Motor Car Company, has asked for proxies in preparation for a campaign at the annual stockholders' meeting to gain control and bring about a complete reorganization of the company.
The Netherlands -this morning suddenly for an unannounced destination. His secretary issued this statement:

Bonds were pressed to new low levels over a broad front yesterday in more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The persistence of the decline in values generally has brought forth, according to traders, considerable forced liquidation by holders who are compelled to cash in on their holdings, regardless of the market price, to protect other interests.

The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today an application by the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration on the Exchange 2,500,000 shares of the no-par value common stock of the Mother Lode Coalition Mines Company.

False propaganda has greatly exaggerated the effectiveness of gas warfare, Dr. Ralph H. Bullard, Professor of Chemistry at Hobart College, said last night at the annual dinner of the Hobart Club of New York at the Hotel Shelton.

It was difficult to find any one here today among the friends of the President who did not deplore his comment at Warm Springs yesterday on the Senate's passage of the Federal Reorganization Bill: "It proves that the Senate cannot be purchased by organized telegrams based on direct misrepresentation."

Fed steers and yearlings arrived in liberal numbers and with this increase in beef tonnage the market on better grades of mediumweight and weighty steers closed fully 25c lower, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

A demand that President Federico Laredo Bru immediately inform the nation when the Constituent Assembly will be called was made this afternoon by various oppositionist parties in a letter to the Chief Executive.

Princeton's self-coached rugby team, eastern champion last Spring, has run through its stiffest workouts of the season this week in order to match its brawn with the finesse of the barnstorming Cambridge University ruggers when the two meet on University Field tomorrow afternoon.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., April 1: CAPTAIN - Charles Humbeutel, from Traffic Precinct L to 42d Precinct. LIEUTENANTS-Vincent J. Kiernan, from 18th Precint to 18th Division, assignment to desk duty discontinued.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Vandenberg, daughter of the Republican Senator from Michigan, to Edward Pfeiffer in this city on Tuesday was announced yesterday by the Senator in Washington about the time that the couple were sailing from here on the Monarch of Bermuda for a wedding trip in Bermuda.

South Africa has won the King George V trophy for miniature rifle shooting for boys of the empire for the eighth time, it was announced today. The South Africans' score was 86.847 points out of a possible 100.

The recent rise in customs collections, due to greatly increased imports, is ascribed not to sudden prosperity but to the conviction of Costa Rican merchants that an early conflict in Europe is inevitable.

Judge Frank J. Lausche overruled late today a motion in behalf of the Republic Steel Corporation whereby the company's attorneys sought to throw out of court a stockholders' suit demanding an accounting for $6,000,000 which it is alleged was misspent.

The Serafini Construction Company, Inc., of Binghamton, N. Y., submitted a low bid of $585,555 on a contract providing for the completion of all parkway grading, drainage and paving on the southerly two miles of the Wantagh State Parkway extension between Hempstead Turnpike and the Southern State Parkway, it was announced yesterday by the Long Island State Park Commission.

The Chicago Stock Exchange will begin operating tomorrow under its new constitution, which provides for a full-time paid president and replacement of the old system of management by membership committees with a more flexible form of organization built around a powerful board of governors.

Elmer Sherwood Joyce, dean of Bridgeport organists and composer, who for more than forty years was a teacher of Bridgeport musicians, died last night in Bridgeport Hospital after an illness of four months.

St. Peters Ave, 1,631, dwelling, 27.10x92.11; Home Owners Loan Corp against Fannie Rueger, due, $9,290; to plaintiff for $1,400. By HENRY G. WALTEMADE Holland Ave. 1,840, dwelling, 25x100; Home Owners Loan Corp against Anna Kramer, due. $7,041, taxes, , $106; to plaintiff for $500.

The Senate Finance Committee is preparing a tax bill that is not only much better in nearly every respect than the one which came from the House, but promises at last to remove some of the most serious obstacles that have stood in the way of business expansion.

The Department of Commerce is holding a conference of business and banking interests in an effort to stimulate commercial loans by private financial agencies, Secretary Roper said this afternoon at his press conferenre.
Business rentals reported yesterday included several leases of space to furriers. Leases of stores and entire floors also figured in the activity, which centered largely in the midtown area.

The Rev. Dr. Charles Michael Jacobs, a distinguished theologian. who for more than a decade had been president of the Mount Airy Lutheran Theological Seminary, died this afternoon in Lankenau Hospital here. He was in his sixtythird year.
Mr. and Mrs. S. Hart Green of Winnipeg, Man., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Audrey Green, to Gilbert M. England of New York and Pittsfield.

Two retiring non-commissioned officers of the Sixteenth Infantry, First Division, Regular Army, will watch the officers and men of the regiment parade in their honor at a review to be held at 8:15 A. M. today on Governors Island.
