A drive against a "chiseling minority" of employers who have withheld about $5,000,000 from the State Unemployment Insurance Fund was begun yesterday by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. The first prosecution will be started this morning before Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in the Municipal Term Court by Assistant Attorney General Isidore Lazarus.

Two of the oldest rivals of American college sport will meet Saturday night at the Squadron A Armory in the final of this year's intercollegiate indoor polo championship. Yale and Harvard came through in their semi-final matches at the armory last night, the Elis triumphing in a blistering match with West Point, 11 to 10,

Jules Henry, Counselor of the French Embassy to the United States; Colonel Norbert Champsaur, French air attache to the embassy in Washington, and Bernard Hardion, secretary of the French Embassy in Berlin, are among the passengers due to sail today for Havre via Southampton on the French liner Normandie.
The Association of American Railroads announced today that the Class I railroads had an operating deficit in February for the first time in seventeen years.
Patriarch Miron Cristea today presented the collective resignation of his Cabinet to King Carol, who entrusted him with the task of forming a new one, which was sworn in this evening.

Realizing fully what the loss of Lerida would mean, the government forces today offered strenuous redistance in the doomed city. This, it was stated, was to give the bulk of their retreating army a few more precious hours to establish new defense lines on the other side of the Segre River.

GOVERNORS ISLAND The following Reserve officers having completed the record course, pistol, dismounted, their final qualification in pistol marksmanship is announced: Salz, Louis C., 1st Lt., MI., 96.6, expert. Smith, Charles W., 1st Lt., MI., 95.0, expert. Riddell, Richard J., 2d Lt., MI., 89.7, expert. Dyer Kenneth B., 2d Lt., MI., 86.0, expect. Milks, Harold K., 2d Lt., MI., 81.9, sharp- pt shooter.

Daly Ave (11-3127), s e cor of 180th St. 100x51; Mendel Herman to Consolidated Funding Corp, 152 W 42d St. mtge $60,000. Metcalf Ave (15-3869). w s, 175 ft n of 172d St, 125x100; Joseph Weinberg to Edward Goldman, 137 E 28th St.

Memphis, Tenn., won the Grand Prize today in the national traffic safety contest conducted by the National Safety Council. Memphis won first among cities of 250,000 to 500,000 population and captured the Grand Award for cities regardless of size.

Collecting nineteen hits Toronto moundsmen, the Newark Bears defeated their International League rivals in an exhibition contest today, 13 to 1. Lindell and Russell drew the pitching assignment for the Bears and limited Toronto to four safeties.

President Roosevelt motored 120 miles through the red clay hills of Southwest Georgia today to tell the cheering populace of Columbus that, "if you and I have anything to do with it," there would be an indefinite continuation of "the improved processes of living," which he attributed to his recovery program. He continued by automobile to Fort Benning to review the mechanized units of the second largest military garrison of the country.

More determined and comprehensive efforts to combat the "brazenly punitive legislation which threatens the extinction of the chains," with particular emphasis on training of retail and wholesale salesmen to bring home to the consumer the adverse effects of the "political moves" against the chains, was urged yesterday by Hunter C. Phelan, head of the David Pender Grocery Company and former president of the National Food and Grocery Chain Stores Association.

Lieut. Col. Joseph H. Levey, acting chairman of the British ORT Federation, who is here to aid the American ORT Federation campaign to raise $450,000 made public yesterday a plea made by Lord Rothschild, president of the British ORT, urging American Jews to assist in the campaign.

Miss Elsie Burke Foster of Dixie Lake, Plainfield, has completed plans for her marriage to Stuart Warren Don of Saratoga, N. Y., and Louisville, Ky. The ceremony will take place on May 9 in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church here.

Manhattan 4th Ave, 132-8; 115x40, for 1-story gas station; Augustus Chesebrough et al, 33 84 Howard St, owners; J. M. Berlinger, architect; cost $15,000. Alterations 49th St, 212 East; to 4-story tenement; Michael Hare, 114 East 84th St, owner; L. E. Elder, architect; cost S14,000.

Leaders of American golf took warm-up swings today for the Augusta national tournament, the all-star show featuring the only competitive appearance of Robert Tyre Jones Jr., ex-emperor of the fairways.

Charles Closson Adams, chairman of the board, a founder and a former president of the Peninsula National Bank of Cedarhurst, died here today at his home on Ocean Avenue from a heart attack which occurred yesterday morning. He was 79 years old.

In what was described as an unprecedented exercise of censorship over a student publication at New York University, Dr. Charles Del Notre Winning, faculty adviser, yesterday forbade publication of an editorial in The New York University Commerce Bulletin attacking the Catholic Church's stand on birth control.

Broadway, 1,178; 5-story office building, 26.6x85.1xirreg; Seamens Bank for Savings against Gerardus P. Herrick; due $230,024; to plaintiff for $150,000. 17th St, 445 W; 3-story tenement and stores, 25x92; Leathem Mehaffey against Colin M. Eadie; due $12,655; taxes, etc, $873; to plaintiff for S1.000.

Mario de Pimentel Brandao, Ambassador-designate to Washington, was the guest of honor at a farewell luncheon given today by the American Chamber of Commerce in Brazil in the Gold Room of the Jockey Club. United States Ambassador Jefferson Caffery, honorary president of the chamber, presided.

A sentence of thirty to sixty years in State prison was imposed by Judge Koenig in General Sessions yesterday on James Dougherty, 32 year old, a second offender, who, with two other gunmen not yet arrested, seized a $12,035 payroll from two employes of the liquidation department of the Bank of United States at 111 Duane Street on April 14, 1937.

A few days ago Generalissimo Francisco Franco said the war had really been won in the North and was now being wound up in Aragon. Scarcely has a traveler crossed the frontier than chaotic heaps of stones that once were public buildings in Irun remind him that this northern coast has had its share of the war.

Mark Ethridge, general manager of The Louisville Courier - Journal and Times, was elected today president of the National Association of Broadcasters. He will serve until his successor is selected, according to an announcement by the board of the association.

While continuance of the city's 10 per cent relief cut remained uncertain because of the conflict between the City Council and Mayor La Guardia over new tax bills, examination of the first printed copies of the bills yesterday showed that all four conflicted with the City Charter and that the bank tax bill required revision and reprinting.

Steel ingot production has risen for the third consecutive week under the stimulus of seasonal improvement, and output this week is estimated at 35 1/2 per cent of capacity, or 5 1/2 points above the level at the beginning of March and 1 1/2 points higher than last week's pace according to the summary made by Iron Age.

The Nazis are working overtime to prove that Austria was only a lost province of Germany. Every speech in the plebiscite campaign makes it appear that Austria was iniquitously wrested from the Reich by the Treaty of Versailles. The orators speak blandly of "reunion."

Frankie Crosetti today faced the prospect of inactivity for the road exhibition trip of the Yankees which opens Friday in Tallahassee. The veteran shortstop did not accompany the champions to near-by Clearwater for their second skirmish with the Dodgers, the last exhibition before the team takes to the road.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, will be heard tonight in Carnegie Hall. The New School Chorus, under the direction of Arthur Lief, will present Haydn's "Seasons" and music by Byrd, Palestrina, Vittoria, Morley, Ford, Lassus and others tonight at the New School for Social Research.

Congress has authorized President Anastasio Somoza to give sufficient land to the United States Government to build a new legation in the western section of this city in exchange for land now occupied by the present legation.

The Senate Finance Committee approved today an amendment suggested by William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to exempt from the capital gains tax securities transferred or forced into sale by reason of the operation of Section 11, the "death sentence," of the Holding Company Act.
Fred Apostoli of San Francisco and Glen Lee of Omaha, Neb., concluded training yesterday at Stillman's gymnasium for their return match at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.
John Carle Anderson, former president of the Estey Wire Works Company of New York, with which he had been associated for many years, died Monday in Havana. He was born in Wellsburg, W. Va., Oct. 1,

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Dickinson of this city and Sheffield, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cornelia Kissam Dickinson, to Everitt Hamilton Pell, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. E. Pell of Great Barrington, Mass.

The Government's silver policy, which now seems to be disintegrating gently, deserves to be studied as an example of what happens when a well-intentioned but capricious Administration, egged on by considerations of politics, stumbles into a large commitment without giving the matter very much thought or paying much attention to the risks involved.
Today M. Jules Henry, one of the most popular and most efficient of foreign diplomats accredited to our Government, returns home after seventeen years' continuous service as a member
A naval bombing plane crashed at sea today with a probable loss of five lives, lending a note of tragic realism to a great mock battle for the control of Hawaii.

A confident prediction that tuberculosis in this country would be wiped out in the next half century was advanced yesterday by Dr. Edward S. Godfrey Jr., Health Commissioner of New York State, who is presiding over the round table discussion of tuberculosis at the sixteenth annual conference the Milbank Memorial Fund.

Over a period of twenty-one years, the proportion of students taking foreign languages in New York City high schools has decreased steadily, Lawrence A. Wilkins, director of the Foreign Language Department, disclosed yesterday.

Drawing even with ten seconds to go in the fourth period, and then triumphing in the overtime session, Squadron C defeated Squadron A by 10 to 9 last night at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn to win the junior division laurels in the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League.
A cryptic message, believed to have been addressed to the kidnappers of Peter D. Levine, 12-year-old New Rochelle schoolboy who vanished Feb. 24, was broadcast by station WABC last night.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today that 120,321 short tons, raw value, of Puerto Rico's refined sugar quota for entry into this country had been allotted to seven Puerto Rican processors.

Tuesday's election in Kansas City must have saddened old-timers. Nobody was killed. Nobody was beaten up. The boys were cautioned to be good. "No rough stuff," was the order. Governor Stark's bipartisan election board stood in the way of the familiar tricks.

A lecture in aid of the Duchesne Placement Bureau will be given by Hildreth Meiere, former president of the National Society of Mural Painting, tomorrow morning in the ballroom of the Sacred Heart Academy, 1 East Ninety-first Street. His subject will be "Modern Murals."

Drawing even with ten seconds to go in the fourth period, and then triumphing in the overtime session, Squadron C defeated Squadron A by 10 to 9 last night at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn to win the junior division laurels in the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League.
A cryptic message, believed to have been addressed to the kidnappers of Peter D. Levine, 12-year-old New Rochelle schoolboy who vanished Feb. 24, was broadcast by station WABC last night.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today that 120,321 short tons, raw value, of Puerto Rico's refined sugar quota for entry into this country had been allotted to seven Puerto Rican processors.

A motion for a temporary injunction brought by a group of stockholders against the directors of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, seeking to restrain them from proceeding at the annual meeting on April 12 to cancel purchase agreements covering 200,120 shares of stock at $91.60 each without first telling the stockholders "the full facts behind the proposed cancellation,"
Work on the New York State exhibit building and marine amphitheatre for the 1939 World's Fair, which is to dominate the amusement area, will be officially started at a ceremony this afternoon.
Governor Lehman vetoed tonight the McNaboe bill which would have barred Communists and other radicals from the civil service and the teaching staffs of schools.

The New York Hospital and Cornell University Medical College, which jointly occupy the great medical center bounded by Sixty-eighth and Seventy-first Streets, York Avenue and the East River, begin today a campaign for an endowment of $17,000,000.
While he has not yet reached a definite decision about it, Eddie Dowling admitted yesterday a possibility that his one-act play project, "At Long Last," might be postponed until next season.

A fundamental change in the basis of real estate taxation is necessary if New York City is to escape eventual calamity, Peter Grimm, president of William A. White Sons and vice president of the Citizens Budget Commission,

MANHATTAN BECKER, SIMON (Nov. 7, 1935). Gross assets, $276,113; net, $265,754. To Rose 1 S. Becker, widow, personal property and life estate in residue; Hazel B. Kolman, daughter, $7,500 and remainder in onethird residue; William R. Rose 2d, grandson, $2,500 and contingent remainder in one-third residue: Virginia K. Greenbaum.

General Carl Vaugoin, former War Minister, Chancellor for a brief period in 1930 and Christian Social politician and the creator of Austria's post-war army, was arrested today on his return from a long vacation in Italy. General Vaugoin, who had refused to remain abroad as an emigre, saying, "My conscience is clear," was taken into custody on alighting from his train here.

Henry Armstrong, the dynamics featherweight champion of the world, added another knockout to his long list at the Hippodrome last night when he stopped Lew Feldman of Brooklyn in 1 minute 51 seconds of the fifth in a scheduled ten-round fight. Armstrong's title was not at stake.

Successful retail advertising copy must be able to answer one of three questions, Kenneth Collins, vice president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., declared last night at the Retail Advertising Course of THE NEW YORK TIMES. These questions are: "Will it bring volume?"; "Will it add prestige?", or "Will it help build a price line?", he said.

George D. Simon has purchased an interest in Betty Wales, Inc., and has become president of that corporation, according to announcement yesterday. Mr. Simon headed Franklin Simon Co. from 1927 until it was purchased by the Atlas Corporation on Sept. 30, 1936.

W. J. O'Neil, vice president and general manager of the Dodge division of the Chrysler Corporation, announced yesterday the appointment of W. M. Purves as general sales manager, succeeding A. vanDerZee, recently appointed a vice president of the corporation. Mr.

Warren Van Dyke, Pennsylyania's Secretary of Highways, died in Johns Hopkins Hospital tonight of uremic poisoning, aftermath of pneumonia and a heart malady. He would have been 61 years old on April 23.

Securities and Exchange Commission announced today an amendment to its rule AN 21, the effect of which is to continue until June 1 the exemption from registration of such bonds as the 4 1/2 per cent public-works bonds of the Machado government of Cuba now outstanding. The exemption was to have expired tomorrow.
The annual report of the Eastern Gas and Electric Fuel Associates for 1937, issued today, shows a consolidated net income of $3,107,816 after expenses and charges.

College boxers from many parts of the nation rested tonight for tomorrow's preliminary bouts in the national tournament. Fifty-four contestants from the country's top-flight ring squads will weigh in tomorrow morning for the bouts beginning at 3 P. M.

The Right Rev. Robert L. Paddock, retired Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Oregon and chairman of the American Friends of Spanish Democracy, replied yesterday to Dr. Joseph Thorning of Mount St. Mary College, Emmitsburg, Md., who called upon sixty-one Methodist and Episcopal Bishops recently to make "a dignified apology" for signing an open letter to the Roman Catholic hierarchy urging a protest to General Francisco Franco against further bombing of non-combatants.

Animals kept alive and still growing at an age corresponding to 107 years in the life of man, through strict scientific control of the rate of growth in early life by restrictions on the calory intake of the diet, were described here today before the annual meeting of the American Institute of Nutrition.

Six women died today from tetanus after they had received injections of a serum for the treatment of cancer. Five other women are in hospitals with serious cases of tetanus. They too had received injections.

Thirteen jurors, the last an alternate, were selected yesterday in General Sessions from a blue-ribbon panel of talesmen for the firstdegree murder trial of Mounted Patrolman Arthur H. Chalmers, 34 years old, in the shooting of a woman in his automobile on the Harlem Speedway last July 20.

The broad language of the "unfair methods" clause of the Lea Act "leaves the door wide open to almost any construction which the Federal Trade Commission, and in the last instance the courts, may put upon this phrase and again throws upon industry the burden of defining what is an unfair or deactive act,"

Contracts granting recognition to the Wholesale Licensed Alcoholic Beverage Salesmen's Union of the State of New York, Local 20376, an A. F. of L. affiliate, were signed yesterday by five distilling companies here.

Relief recipients were advised last night by Oscar R. Fuss, vice president of the Workers Alliance, to take their 10 per cent relief cuts out of the rentals paid to their landlords, rather than diminish their food allowances by that much.

Richard Whitney admitted yesterday, at a hearing before Irwin Kurtz, Federal referee in bankruptcy, that he had told his brother, George Whitney, last November, that he had been using his customers' securities improperly.
Bangor and Belfast Celtic became finalists for the Irish Football Cup today. In semi-final replays, Bangor defeated Derry City, 3-1, and Celtic eliminated Glentoran by the same score.
Purchase of the Bear Mountain vehicular bridge across the Hudson River at L about $3,200,000 would save the State nearly $1,000,000, Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, asserted today.
Elderly Prince Franz I handed over the governmental reins of this tiny independent principality tonight to his heir, Prince Franz Joseph.

For an indicated consideration of $35.000 the Emigrant Bank sold to the 180 Rivington Street Corp, Minnie Waonlak, pres, the six-story tenement with stores on the for of Rivington and Attorney Sts, 25x100, and took back two demand mortgages, a purchase money for $35,274 and a building Loan for S25,000.

E. Truman Wright, for the last two years manager of the hotel promotion department of Western Union Telegraph Company, has been appointed assistant to Joseph P. Hoenig, convention manager of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
Chinese and Japanese forces were, deadlocked at most points in the major conflict on the Tientsin-Pukow Railway front yesterday, according to military reports reaching here today.

Picturing the radio as a Frankenstein monster that has entered the home and usurped the leisure time of the school children, Dr. Jay B. Nash, chairman of the Physical Education Department of New York University, urged parents yesterday to throw off the "strangling" influence of Tarzan, Buck Rogers and other "moronic" children's programs.

The Mexican official version of today's United States statement on the expropriation of foreign-owned oil properties in this country was read to wildly cheering delegates to a "Constituent Assembly" that met to form a new government party composed of industrial unionists, farm workers and soldiers.

National Distiller Products Corporation ten-year 4 1/2 per cent debentures in the principal amount of $516,000 have been called by the Chase National Bank, fiscal agent, for redemption through the sinking fund at 104 on May 1.
The stock markets here were generally quiet today, but most sections were firm. Gilt-edge issues were well supported, while among the foreign bonds European issues rallied.

EXAMINER, BOARDS OF EDUCATION. Salary: $11,000 per annum; pension. Vacancies: One, one appointment made from last list. Ages: No restrictions; no one will be appointed who is over the minimum retirement age of 55 when certified. Applications: Open to residents of the State of New York. Received 9 A. M.,
The French police are trying to solve the mystery of the identity of "Radio National," a station that broadcasts daily on a 250-meter wave length between 12:15 and 12:30 P. M. The station,

W. T. Stamm, former president of the Columbia Bank and Savings Company, died at his home here today at the age of 77. Mr. Stamm's banking career began more than sixty years ago when he became associated with the accounting department of a private bank founded by the Seasongood family.

Amid the wildest scene of this session, punctuated by boos, laughter and sarcastic comment, the House began debate today on the Reorganization Bill. This was not until opponents had forced a delay of two and one-half hours by invoking every parliamentary device permitted under the rules.

Governor Lehman today signed the Feld bill under which the State accepts $2,777,770 of Port of New York Authority 3 per cent bonds as a settlement of the money due the State as a result of its having advanced a portion of the funds for the construction of the George Washington Bridge.

Residential properties figured in a majority of the sales in near-by New Jersey announced yesterday. The four-story apartment building at 257 Grove Street, Jersey City, was sold by the Home Owners Loan Corporation to John Michalkowski, through Ben Schlossberg, Inc., brokers.

Paced by Si Boardman, N. Y. U. star during the past season, the Union Temple five captured the Metropolitan A. A. U. basketball championship when it turned back the defending champion, Long Island University A. A., 47 to 43, last night in a thrilling encounter at the New York Hippodrome.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Perry of 139 East Sixty-sixth Street, this city, and Washington, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane H. T. Perry, to John W. Vandercook of New York.

Senator Logan of Kentucky proposed today to put upon the Federal Reserve Board the duty of regulating the value of the dollar and fixing the national price level. He told the Senate that he would introduce a bill which also would make the board obedient only to Congress.

Finalists in two more divisions of the Eastern indoor polo championships were decided at Squadron A Armory last night when the Ridgewood Polo Club of New Jersey and the Blue Hill Farms team of Pennsylvania won semi-final matches.

President Roosevelt believes it is "sensible" to construct United States merchant ships abroad when the cost of building them at home is twice as much, Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy, who had made this recommendation as chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, told the Chamber of Shipping of the United Kingdom tonight.

Manufacturers desiring to maintain resale prices under the provisions of the Feld-Crawford Act are barred from entering into price competition with their distributors, according to the decision handed down by Supreme Court Justice Koch, the text of which attracted widespread interest yesterday in drug and allied lines.

Miss Muriel Kerr, pianist with the Gordon String Quartet, will be married today to Naoum Benditzky, 'cellist for the same group, at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Kerr, 32-28 Eighty-first Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.

The Bureau of Emergency Taxes will be reorganized immediately on a civil service basis, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday. The Bureau administers emergency relief levies. The reorganization will be effected with the cooperation of Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, under whose jurisdiction some of the employes come, and the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

A long, high goal by Charley Mason shortly after the third overtime period started enabled the Philadelphia Ramblers to conquer the New Haven Eagles, 3 to 2, tonight in an International American Hockey League play-off game.
The Senate passed today the Maloney bill for regulation of over-thecounter markets and sent it to the House. It was approved unanimously.
Brown Prep of Philadelphia defeated Lawrenceville tonight in the nineteenth annual Eastern States basketball tournament, 56-45.
Japanese troops are slowly pounding their way through Taierhchwang in Southern Shantung in their drive along the Grand Canal toward the Lung-Hai Railway, military reports reaching Hankow indicated.

The Association of American Railroads will oppose the Federal unemployment compensation plan sponsored by the standard railway unions, it was announced today by J. J. Pelley, president of the association.

Beginning today, registration for State unemployment insurance benefits must be made in person by jobless- workers who live in this city or in any other community in which there is an office of the State Employment Service, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, announced last night.
Daniel J. Cahill, a retired captain of the New York Fire Department, died on Wednesday at his home, 265 Eleventh Street, Brooklyn, at the age of 77. Captain Cahill,

Irregular fluctuations over an unusually wide range again featured trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, and after the May position had touched 8 1/2 cents at one time, the list recovered to end with gains of 8 to 15 points.
His shears whetted to a razor edge, Colonel Bill Terry today settled down to the task of pruning his extensive squad of Giants, which tomorrow will conclude its five weeks of hard training here.
Negotiations looking toward purchase of the Memphis Power and Light Company by the city's municipal light and water division will start at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow.
The Rev. Dr. Louis Tinning, for the last six years associate pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Hollywood, was found dead of a heart attack today in his home. He was 65 years old.
The Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers of America announced tonight that they had signed an agreement to continue for one year their present contract, which expires at midnight.

Ambrose V. McCall, Assistant Attorney General, announced yesterday that he would fix a date today for the resumption of public hearings into the affairs of Richard Whitney, in order to determine whether he violated the Martin Act provisions against stock manipulation and market rigging in the sale of Distilled Liquor. Corporation stock. Whitney has admitted that

A fatherland his son reached the quarter-final round in the world open squash tennis championship at the Shelton courts last night. James Reid Sr., professional at the Crescent A. C., set an example for his 21-year-old son Jimmy by scoring an impressive victory over F. B. Ryan Jr., Short Hills amateur who is ranked No. 3 in the national list.
Bonds called prior to maturity for payment in March, although in larger volume than in the preceding montt., were in the smallest amount for March since 1935.
President Federico Laredo Bru has accepted the resignation of General Rafael Montalvo, Secretary of National Defense, it was announced tonight.

Frederick Thomas Moore, first vice president, general works manager and director of Colt's Patent Fire Arms Company, died early today at the Hartford Hospital at the age of 62. He underwent an operation on March 15. His home was in West Hartford.
The aggregate of dividends declared in March was the smallest for any month since April, 1936. The amount, $203,626,918, declared by 1,272 companies, compared with
The Federal Government moved today to offset any possible price arrangement in the cement industry by concentrating all government buying of cement in the Procurement Division of the Treasury.

Keen bidding for contracts to supply meat to city institutions is being developed by tightening up on specifications of quality and by a sharper inspection by the Controller's office, Russell Forbes, Commissioner of Purchase, said yesterday.
The six-story apartment house containing 240 rooms and ten stores at 1,707-9 Boston Road, the Bronx, was sold by N. K. Winston Co. to a client of William Rosan.
The Hebrew University on Mount Scopus, Jerusalem, marks its thirteenth anniversary today, it was announced yesterday by the American Friends of the Hebrew University.

Eight men whose arrests were said by District Attorney Charles S. Tracy to mark the "end of a widely sought arson ring" were lodged in jail here today, awaiting arraignment on attempted arson charges.
Mrs. Loretta Hines, widow of Edward Hines, lumber merchant who died in 1931, died early today in Michael Reese Hospital of pneumonia. She was 65 years old.

Prime Minister Eamon de Valera announced tonight his eleven nominees for the new Senate of Ireland. They included Dr. Douglas Hyde, founder of the Gaelic League; Sir John Keane, member of the old Senate from 1922 until it was abolished in 1936; Frank MacDermott,

As the toll of dead mounted to thirty-six in areas laid waste in four States by yesterday's tornadoes, a new storm drove through four counties in Kentucky today, injuring several persons, demolishing buildings and destroying livestock.

Architects and engineers from all parts of the United States and from many foreign countries have submitted drawings in the competition for "the most suitable structural and architectural design of an elevated highway," under sponsorship of the American Institute of Steel Construction.

In the Chamber of Deputies today a spokesman of the Sudeten German [Nazi] party, M. Hodina, replied to yesterday's declaration of the coalition parties in the Senate repudiating various claims for autonomy.

Miss Freda Scharmen of the Junior League and William J. McQueeney of the University Club became the new metropolitan squash. racquets mixed doubles champions by defeating Miss Eileen Beresford of Short. ills and Samuel Cochran of the University Club, 9-15, 15-11, 14-17, 18-14, I5-9, as the sixth annual tourney closed at the Heights Casino last night:

Ideal conditions are indicated for the opening Saturday of New York's trout season, the Conservation Department reported today. "The hot and dry weather of the past few weeks has cleared nearly all the streams of ice and snow," said Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne, himself an Izaak Walton disciple.
Pensioned On their own applications. To take effect 12 midnight, March 31: PATROLMEN--Maurice Shanahan, Traffic Precinct B. at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Feb. 10. 1913.

Mrs. Crawford Hill Jr. gave a tea yesterday at her home, 10 Gracie Square, for members of various committees assisting in the arrangements for the fifth annual gift-horse party, which will be given in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria on the afternoon of April 25 for the benefit of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work.

The Alumni Association of the Juilliard Graduate School, an autonomous group independent of the school, has been organized, it was announced yesterday. Its purpose is the "development of well-trained musicians capable of carrying their art into the innermost corners of this country * * and to aid music in America by publication, recording and repeated performance of the works of our native composers."

Wayne Sabin of Hollywood, Calif., and Bobby Riggs of Chicago entered the semi-finals of the River Oaks tennis tournament today as the veteran Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, and Arthur Hendrix of Iakeland, Fla., fell before their Savage play.

The Netherlands adhered "fully" today In a note to the State Department to the - United States proposal to create an international governmental committee to facilitate the emigration of political refugees from Austria and Germany.
110th St, 216 E; to two 5-story schools; Board of Education. 500 Park Ave, owner; Walter C. Martin, architect; cost, 25,000.

Lester Weil, 18-year-old student, of 414 McDonough Street, Brooklyn, who cashed a $560 forged check at the First National Bank here on Tuesday, was exonerated on a grand larceny charge tonight when he convinced Police Justice Spencer A. Studwell that

John F. McConnell, deputy chief of this city's Fire Department, died here today in St. James Hospital. He underwent an operation a week ago. Mr. McConnell, 49 years old, had been a lifelong resident of Newark.

William Randolph Hearst and associates will relinquish ownership of the Ritz Tower, luxurious skyscraper apartment hotel at the northeast corner of Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, under a plan by which the bondholders will gain control of the property, it was learned last night.
Albany Crescent (12-3266), e s, 119 s of 231st St, 46x134; Moepel Holding Co, Inc, to Morris Spring, 1,678 Grand Ave; mtg $42,000.

Trading in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on March 26 again showed a preponderance of buying over selling, with the number of customers' orders to buy exceeding those to sell by 16,489 and the number of shares purchased 167,800 more than the number sold.

George B. Hendrick, former president of the Rudge Printing Company of New York, died here today at the home of his son, Allen, at the age of 58. He had been ill three months. His widow and a daughter also survive.
Funeral services were held here today for Colonel Tillinghast L'H. Huston, formerly half owner of the New York Yarkees, who died Tuesday at his Butler Island plantation. Services were conducted
Greta Garbo, the movie actress, and Leopold Stokowski, the symphony conductor, departed tonight for Tunis on the steamer Citta di Palermo.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Setting a new high mark, motor vehicle registrations in New York State totaled 2,590 974 in 1937, a gain of 5.6 per cent over 1936, William J. Gottlieb, president of the Automobile Club of New York reported yesterday.

The Pennsylvania Railroad today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to pledge some of the stock of Pittsburgh, Cincinnati, Chicago St. Louis, or Big Four, Railroad as additional collateral for its 28-year, 4 per cent secured bonds in the principal amount of $49,000,000.
The Senate Finance Committee today finished its study and revision of the 1938 revenue bill and plans to report it to the Senate on Monday.

ASHLAND, Ohio--Morganstern's; A. Morganstern, topper coats; 421 7th Ave. (United Garment Buyers). ATHENS Ga.-Monsky Style Shop; Miss Fitzgerland, rayon dresses; 225 W. 34th (Mandel Buying Service). BALTIMORE--chleisner Co.: L. M. Hess, coats, suits; 450 7th Ave. (J. Braunstein).
Benjamin Chew Sr., Radnor sportsman and member of an old Philadelphia family, died last night after an illness of several weeks at his Winter home in Boca Grande, Ala. He was 59 years old.

A regisgration statement covering an issue of $2,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, Series A, due May 1, 1968, was filed today by the Fall River Electric Light Company, Fall River, Mass., under the Securities Act of 1933.

An increase of 48 per cent in public building this week over the same week in 1937 raised the total for all awards 7 per cent over the figure for the 1937 week, according to The Engineering News-Record.

Two players of the Buffalo International League club, Pitcher Charles Stanceu and Outfielder Myron W. McCormick, were declared free agents today by Baseball Commissioner K. M. Landis, whose statement said Buffalo had "covered up" both players for the Cleveland Indians throughout the 1937 season.

Counsel for the defense in the Federal gasoline price-fixing case contended today that the jury that convicted thirty individuals and sixteen major oil companies of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act could not have considered the case of each individual separately as it was out only seven hours.

Mr. and Mrs. William B. Avery of Aurora, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Imogen Avery, to William Linden Wagner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Wagner of 239 Central Park West.

This commuting community of 22,000 population should be a paradise for the confection business, judging from the amount of money the student body of the Teaneck High School spends yearly to appease its collective sweet-tooth.

Acting on a petition filed by Arthur A. Ballantine, trustee in reorganization proceedings for the Continental Securities Corporation, Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson yesterday signed an order directing Prentice Brady, 25 Broadway, to surrender 1,000,000 shares of securities held by the brokerage house for the account of Continental Securities.

The dollar volume of wholesale trade declined 15 per cent in February compared with the same month last year, and manufacturers' sales declined 22 per cent, the Department of Commerce and National Association of Credit Men announced today in a joint report.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in March was more active than in the preceding month. Sales, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, amounted to 23,000,335 shares, compared with 14,524,824 in February and 50,344,350 shares in March, 1937.

Twenty-four men and women accused of injuring the reputation of Dr. Francis E. Townsend and other members of his old-age pension movement were named in a $27,000,000 damage suit filed in Federal Court today.

Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor, who have been in Europe for several weeks, will arrive Monday on the Queen Mary and will be at the St. Regis. Dimitrius Sicilianos, the Greek Minister, has come from Washington to the St. Moritz.

The Senate accepted House amendments to the Barkley resolution providing a joint Congressional investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority and related private utility matters and sent it to the White House today.
Legislation authorizing a Trade Commission investigation of manufacturer-dealer relations in the automobile industry received final Congresisonal approval today.

Miss Mary Ralston Anderberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Anderberg of this city, was married to Richard Pinkerton Heppner, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Heppner, also of White Plains, this evening in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church here.

A further contraction of their outstanding credit, due chiefly to reduced holdings of government securities and declining brokers' loans, was reported for the week ended on Wednesday by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, in their condition statement issued yesterday.

The development for the first time of a synthetic human guinea pig, which responds to infections due to bacteria and viruses in a manner closely parallel to a living human being making it possible to study at first hand a number of serious human diseases that could not be produced in laboratory animals, was reported here today before the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.

M. La Montagne Saint-Hubert, French artist, who has given lectures in more than forty cities of this country under the auspices of the French Foreign Ministry, was the guest speaker yesterday at a meeting of. the Architectural League of New York.

The New York Stock Exchange membership of Jack O. Straus has been transferred to Oakes E. Bishop of Morgan Davis Co. The Exchange's committee on admissions will ballot on April 14 on the transfer of the seat of Edward E. MacCrone to Harold R. Colvin, who will become a general partner in the new firm of Colvin Co.;

First Sergeant Roy C. Moseley and Master Sergeant Andrew Weiman stood with their colonel in a driving rain on Morris Memorial Field at Governors Island yesterday morning and watched their comrades of the Sixteenth Infantry parade in their honor.

Today's major events: KneiselAlden-Turner Trio, Town Hall, evening; "Faust," Hippodrome Opera Company, evening; Nadia Boulanger, lecture, Cosmopolitan Club, evening; Louise Foote, violinist, Steinway Hall, 3 P. M.

Cordell Hull, Frances Perkins, Harold L. Ickes, Aubrey Williams and a scorer of other government officials are contributors to "The Federal Government Today," a book to be issued by the American Council on Public Affairs, 20 Vesey Street, next week. Subtitled

Forest 0. March, formerly head of F. O. March, investment securities, has been appointed -special representative of the Hotel WaldorfAstoria. George Best Mackey has been named Southwestern district manager of the Westinghouse lamp division.
A violent attack on the French Ambassador, Paul Bargeton, today caused a tumult in the Chamber of Deputies here.

Gilbert D. Boyd, vice president and one of the two founders of the Wallingford Steel Company, died at his home last night of a heart ailment at the age of 52. He was a director of the local savings bank and one of the owners of the Ludlum Steel Company of this borough. He was a former chairman
Governor Lehman's veto of the McNaboe bill barring persons known to have radical beliefs from civil service and teaching positions in the State met with widely divergent comment here yesterday.
William Lueck of Milwaukee put together a 688 series to tie for seventh place in the singles, the only change today in the American bowling congress standings.

Mrs. Anna Schoonmaker Hiscox, wife of Guy Dudley Hiscox, died yesterday at her home here at the age of 65. She formerly was president of the Charlotte Emerson Brown Club here and was a member of the board of governors of the Visiting Nurses Association of the Oranges, the Woman's Club of Orange and the Society of Daughters of Holland Dames, New York.

The field for the Derby at Epsom June 6 today was reduced to sixty-nine horses, including William Woodward's American-owned Olympus and Valerian III, both sons of Gallant Fox, and Joseph E. Widener's American-owned Unbreakable and Silver Spear II.

Despite the low opening prices on Fall wool goods lines, business was small this week, as buyers had not had a chance as yet to view offerings of the entire market and make comparisons, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by
Senator Pittman told the Senate today that he had never known so much lobbying as had been done for the confirmation of Ebert K. Burlew as Assistant Secretary of the Interior.

Mrs. Joel Ellis Fisher entertained with a dinner last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for the Misses Fifi Fisher, Jane Darlington and Vieva Fisher Banks, who are students at the Chapin School, this city, and for J. Ellis Fisher 3d, Frank Hoffstot Hammond and Peter Darlington, classmates at St. Paul's School in Concord, N. H.

The New York university Heights Daily News, a student publication, protested yesterday the action of the university authorities in prohibiting the publication in The New York University Commerce Bulletin, another student paper, of an editorial attacking the Catholic Church for its stand on birth control.

The four-day strike of van drivers and their helpers, which affected some 4,000 men, was settled by compromise last night after an all-day conference at the Hotel Center, 108 West Forty-third Street, between employers and union officials. The strikers were instructed to return to work at 8 o'clock this morning.

First quarter results of the American Encaustic Tiling Company, Inc., will show an improvement over the corresponding period last year, Malcolm A. Schweiker, president, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday.

Approximately 1,200 Jews entered Palestine in the last week, indicating a sharp increase in emigration from Austria, according to an announcement yesterday by Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, chairman of the executive committee of the United
The Lotos Club last night gave a dinner to the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra of New York and to John Barbirolli, who has completed his first year as regular conductor of the orchestra.

Railroad loadings of freight in the three months to be ended on June 30 will be about 17.7 per cent lower than the total for the same period last year, according to an estimate by thirteen shippers' advisory boards issued yesterday.

Fred Apostoli of San Francisco and Glen Lee of Edison, Neb., will meeting Madison Square Garden tonight in a return bout of fifteen rounds that should determine the next challenger for the middleweight championship, now held by Freddie Steele.

The Tower Theatre, First Avenue and Forty-ninth Street, will present the first in a series of Nickelodeon Nights on Monday evening. Among the early films to be revived are "The Kiss," with May Irwin and John C. Rice; "Fifth Avenue, 1899," "The Great Train Robbery,"

Miss Jean Bauer, Providence, R. I., interrupted the calm in the women's North and South golf championship today with a surprising 3-and-2 victory over Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page, Chapel Hill, N. C., the national chnampion.

Dr. Lewis Haney, Professor of Economics at New York University, asserted yesterday that "along with political claptrap and economic quackery, we have turned 'relief' into vote buying and have relegated charity to the horse and buggy days." Dr. Haney spoke at the first
Duties collected on liquor and wines in January were $2,230,006, a decrease of $574,890 from January, 1937, according to James H. Moyle, Commissioner of Customs.

Limited supplies and a small beef tonnage helped today to sustain cattle prices at the low point established Wednesday, but there was a- general tone of bearishness in the trade, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Notwithstanding a small run of hogs the market was weak to lower. The lamb market showed some

The play of super-fountains and jets of flame, with color effects, special music and sound, and fireworks, will be utilized at the 1939 World's Fair for nightly spectaclesthat will be "extravaganzas of beauty and fury," Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, announced yesterday.
Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., were the brokers in the recent lease of quarters in 32-4 East Fiftyseventh Street to J. S. Inskip, Inc.
Mr. and Mrs. James Childs Rea of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Rea, to Alfred H. Howell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred C. Howell of New York.

The National Union of War Veterans, an organization of more than 1,000,000 members, is circulating a petition calling upon President Albert Lebrun to form a "public safety" Cabinet with himself at the head.

Attributing the decline in prices of commodities to the influence of depressed markets for securities, The Annalist announced yesterday that its index of wholesale commodity prices had fallen to 81.7 on Wednesday from 82.3 a week before and was at the lowest point since June, 1936.
The first prosecution in Attorney General Bennett's drive against employers who have not paid payroll taxes under the State Unemployment Law was successful yesterday.

In spite of heavy borrowings and unprecedented peacetime expenditures upon armaments, Britain ended her financial year tonight with her national accounts only 4 per cent out of balance.

Publication of the President's letter on the Reorganization Bill is to be welcomed as a reassuring step, not only because of what this letter says about dictatorships, and the President's dislike for them, but because there is a reasonable statement here of the case for the enactment of legislation in this field.
President Roosevelt's "dictatorship" letter was more than a mere tactical manoeuvre to help push the Executive Reorganization Bill through the House, according to some observers here.

Eddie Cantor, screen and radio comedian, declaring that Adolf Hitler "has made it his business to exterminate Jewry," told a dinner audience last night that his life had been threatened and that he had a bodyguard in Hollywood.

In a considerable perspective of orchestral concerts this chronicler remembers few if any occasions when a Haydn symphony was applauded as last night after the opening performance of the concert given by Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall.
Additional engagements of $2,500,000 gold abroad for shipment here, $2,000,000 in Belgium and $500,000 in England, were reported yesterlay to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
The general level of wholesale prices dedined in the week ended on March 26, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

The volume of bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday was the smallest with one exception since the week ended on Nov. 24, 1934, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The exception was for the week of Feb. 9.

Edward F. Barrett, president of the Long Island Lighting Company, revealed yesterday that the executive offices and virtually all departments of the company, now at 50 Church Street, will be Loved into a five-story office building to be erected by the company in Mineola, L. I.

The New York Evening Journal, Inc, conveyed to Hearst Magazines, Inc, Harry G. Huberth vice president, the six-story International Magazine Building, on the west side of 8th Ave from 56th to 57th St, at an indicated valuation of $3,253,000, subject to existing encumbrances.

Visiting Broadway as a leading player in "Shadow and Substance," Sir Cedric Hardwicke is reported hoping to turn producer here next season. The play would be Jacques Deval's "Lorelei," and Sir Cedric would direct but not act in it hence no conflict with his current vehicle. No contracts signed yet, but definite word expected soon.
Dan W. Hill of Asheville resigned today as a member of the National Association of Baseball Leagues executive committee, saying he was doing so "for business reasons."
The auction of art property contained in the residence of Ogden L. Mills, 2 East Sixty-ninth Street, began yesterday afternoon at the house.

The report of the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore for the first two months of this year, issued yesterday, showed a net income of $1,166,907, after all expenses, taxes and charges.
Baseball's No. 1 holdout, Joe DiMaggio, fired back at the Yankee management tonight with the reiteration that "I won't play ball for the Yanks until they meet my demands for more money."
The House Interstate Commerce Committee killed today a Senate bill which would limit the length of freight trains to seventy cars.

Among the many month-end changes announced yesterday by Wall Street firms was the admission of Middleton Rose as a general partner in Lapham, Davis Bianchi, members of the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Rose was senior partner of Rose, Cammann Co., dissolution of which firm took effect yesterday.
Dr. D. Nathan Ryno Smith, of a family of several generations of physicians and surgeons, died yesterday at his home here at the age of 74.

Mrs. Evelyn A. Davis, for many years active in Brooklyn charities, and widow of James Sherlock Davis, wholesale lumber dealer and former president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, died early yesterday after an illness of several months. Mrs. Davis, who lived at
Ninth Spring meeting of the American Psychological Association will open at Hotel Commodore. this morning at 11 o'clock and continue tomorrow on the New York University Campus, University Heights.
Weakness in securities and in foreign grain markets kept wheat prices on the North American Exchanges on the downgrade today.

Charles Dunning, Dominion Minister of Finance, announced today that, effective tomorrow, the Bank of Canada will act as agent of the government "in payment of interest on and principal of Dominion Government securities payable in Canadian currency, in other words, the domestic debt of the Dominion."

Last night's decree dissolving all political parties has had an unfavorable reception among the Liberals and National Peasants. It is now learned that one cause of the Cabinet crisis was that almost all the former Ministers refused to sign the dissolution decree.

One of the worst fogs in many years blanketed. New York all day yesterday and early today, delaying two huge Atlantic liners, causing one ferryboat to. run aground and another to collide with two other craft and disrupting shipping generally in the upper and lower bays. Late at night auto traffic in the city was also impeded.

Construction contracts totaling $690,804 were awarded by the War Department today, as follows: George Hess, Honolulu, T. H., for outfall sewer at Hickam Field, T. H., $30,847. Union Paving Company, San Francisco, for runways and drainage at Sacramento Air Depot, $201,500.

An interne and four nurses swore at the trial in General Sessions yesterday of five young men accused Of the murder of Detective Michael J. Foley last April 10 in the hold-up of a restaurant at 144 Second Avenue that torture was not used by detectives to obtain a confession from one of the defendants in Gouverneur and Bellevue Hospitals.

Infantry, 5-year-old veteran of the handicap ware that races in the Chicago-owned silks of M. L. Emerich's Millsdale Stable, broke loose from a losing streak today and annexed the six-furlong featured race at Tropical Park.

Dr. Charles Basil Murray, for more than fifty years a practicing physician in the Yorkville section, died Wednesday afternoon at his home, 154 East Seventy-fourth Street, at the age of 74. Dr. Murray had been in poor health for a year.
Senator H. Styles Bridges of New Hampshire summoned Republicans today to battle for decentralization of Federal Government and to wage a party war on President Roosevelt and the New Deal.

The establishment of an aviation school at North Beach Airport, Queens, to offer high school students advanced training in aviation mechanics, was recommended yesterday by the Aeronautic Educational Commission of the Advisory Board on Industrial Education.

Suggestions that New York Stock Exchange firms be allowed to incorporate received a mixed reception in Wall Street yesterday. The plan, advanced by a special subcommittee of the Exchange headed by Philip W. Russell of Fenner Beane, was contained in a brief filed with the law committee of the trading institution in response to a request for a report made ten months ago.

The university that was a party to the first game of intercollegiate football. struck a healthy blow for American Rugby today as the Princeton Rugby Club held the touring Cambridge University side to a 19-to-0 score on fog-bound University Field.

The 244-foot Diesel cruiser Ares, owned by Hugh Chisholm, paper manufacturer of Portland, Me., and New York, has ripped her hull running on the rocks of Ceralbo Island near Cape San Lucas at the tip of Lower California.
Insurgent pressure in the eastern battle zone has led to several developments within the last few days calculated to strengthen the government's political and military fronts.

The number of telephones in service in the .New England Telephone and Telegraph Company system at the' end of February totaled 1,214,997, an increase of 600 since the first of the year, it was announced yesterday by J. J. Robinson, president of the company.

Half a division of Spanish Loyalist troops, about 6,000 men, crossed the French frontier yesterday in flight from advancing Rebels. Many civilian refugees were reported following them through snow-covered mountains. Insurgents were still held

Captain Rogelio, secretary of the Governor General of Aragon, offered today additional information relative to priests captured at Teruel, the execution of whom was reported by the Vatican City paper Osservatore Romano.

4th St, 143-145 W. 46.4x96.2: Frank Alberti to Katherine Alberti, 74 Washington P1; first mtg $63,000, second mtg $3,500. 18th St, n s, 210 ft e of 2d Ave, 40x92; 221 West 133d Street Corp to Vicmar Apartments, Inc, 580 5th Ave; mtg $83,000 (50 cents).

Twentieth Century-Fox will produce fifty-two feature-length pictures during the 1938-39 season, it was announced here yesterday coincident- with the opening of the company's annual sales convention at the Muehlbach Hotel in Kansas City. In addition Fox will release

John J. (Dasher) Troy, second baseman of the New York National League baseball team when it first was organized in 1883, died Wednesday in his home, 120-21 Van Wyck Boulevard, South Ozone Park, Queens, at the age of 82.

Funeral services ?ere held today for the Most Rev. Thomas Charles O'Reilly, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Scranton for ten years. Denis Cardinal Dougherty of Philadelphia celebrated the funeral mass in St. Peter's Cathedral. Bishop Bernard J. Mahoney of Sioux Falls, S. D., preached the sermon.

A story of how they drifted helplessly for five hours aboard a small fishing vessel, disabled in a storm in the Gulf of Mexico, was told today by -three Cincinnati Reds as they returned to baseball Spring training quarters.
Senator Burke, Democrat, of Nebraska, declared tonight that defects in the Wagner labor law and its administration were "a potent cause of the depression which has engulfed the country."
Prince Franz Joseph, new sovereign of Liechtenstein, in whose favor his aged uncle, Prince Franz I, abdicated yesterday, has already changed the government and given several Nazis Cabinet portfolios.

Although several casualties were reported in today's parliamentary elections in Upper Egypt they went off far more quietly than expected. Six were killed and about thirty were injured as the result of scuffiles between supporters of opposing candidates.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a recent letter to THE TIMES Frederic Drew Bond states that the jobber and not the banker should finance the retailer. In my experience as a credit man for a number of years I have found there is a crying need for the local banker to understand the problems of' the local merchant.

Colonel Louis F. Schultze, since 1933 receiver for S. W. Straus Co., Inc., 565 Fifth Avenue, dealers in real estate mortgage bonds, died Wednesday night of a heart attack at his home at the Hotel Dryden. He was 52 years old.
The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a summary of transactions by officers, directors and principal stockholders in equity securities in February.

Bowing to the authority of the United States Supreme Court, Corporation Counsel James A. Hamill of Jersey City announced tonight, with Mayor Hague's approval, that Jersey City would permit the distribution of circulars on the streets in the future, if it is done in an orderly manner.
Pay reductions for all salaried employes in the United States of the B. F. Goodrich Company, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber company and the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company were announced today.

Funeral services for Michael D. Fitzgerald, leader in several Irish societies and an uncle of Sheriff Maurice J. Fitzgerald of Queens, will be held at his home, 1,800Lexington Avenue, this morning and a high mass of requiem will be celebrated at Our Lady Queen of Angels Catholic Church, 228 East 113th Street. Mr. Fitzgerald had served

Viscount Halifax, Britain's Foreign Secretary, warned aggressors today not to abuse Britain's "sweet reasonableness," declaring he saw nothing "weak" in this country's "desire to avoid war by exhausting every means that diplomacy may offer."

A contract affecting about 30,000 production employee in six cities was signed yesterday by the General Electric Company with the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, C. I. O. affiliate.

The list of the Washington of the United States Lines, due today from the Channel ports, includes Sir Granville Bantock, British composer; Brigham Young 5th, Herbert Morrison, M. P., leader of the London County Council; Vernon Howe Bailey, William P. Simms, Mr. and Mrs. S. J. Jackson, Mr. and Mrs. R. Stuart Goldey, Mrs. Elize Galambos and Irving J. Woodin.

William Wyer, treasurer of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company, testified today he had changed his opinion since last Fall concerning the nature of an alleged Missouri Pacific liability of $15,000,000.
Out of more than a quarter of a million high school pupils in New York the boys and girls studying Greek are just eighty-six. If one wished

The executive board of Local 802 of the Musicians Union met yesterday at the union's offices, 1,265 Sixth Avenue, and for nearly two hours heard charges against Dr. Walter Damrosch, conductor and composer, involving alleged violation of union rules.
The Cambridge University squash racquets team today recorded the first victory of its American tour, defeating Penn, 4--1. The Britons had dropped seven straight.

Frankie Frisch and Burleigh Grimes went in for considerable experimentation today and the Gas House Gang boss had the greater success. His Cardinals beat the Dodgers again, this time by 3 to 0, to the great enjoyment of 1,064 paying guests at Waterfront Park.

The two-story taxpayer at 123-05 Liberty Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens, has been sold by the Lincoln Savings Bank to an investing client of Henry Brinsley for cash above a purchase-money mortgage or $19,000 which the bank took back.

Pending a judicial determination of the city's right to restrict Eighth and Ninth Avenues to one-way traffic, Lewis J. Valentine, Police Commissioner, and other officials agreed yesterday that they would make no attempt to put into effect a proposal limiting Eighth Avenue to southbound vehicles and Ninth Avenue to northbound vehicles.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Bergstein of 210 West Seventieth Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Bergstein, to Monroe Geller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Geller of 115 Central Park West.
Headquarters Staff A Headquarters' Staff, consisting of the following members, is organized, effective at 12:01 A. M. April 1: All chiefs' aides other than those assigned to battalions and divisions.

If the New York Americans reach the final round of the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup play-offs against the Toronto Maple Leafs, they will play only one game of the best-of-five series for hockey's chief prize on their home ice.

The Arkansas Bondholders Protective Committee of St. Louis, in a letter sent yesterday to Governor Bailey of Arkansas, again urged his veto of bills reducing the gasoline tax, changing the basis for truck license fees and freezing the auto license tax at the 1937 level.
The Bank of Canada's statement for the week ended yesterday issued today showed that its ratio of net reserve to deposit liabilities was 55.60 per cent, against 55.98 last week.

A delivery jam which has developed in wash goods, because of a sudden rise in production of house dresses to meet distributors' demand, has brought an unusual situation where some printers yesterday were selling Fall goods, prior to Fall openings, for the current needs of the dress manufacturers.

A coordinated "See America First" campaign by the hotels, so that they might obtain their share of the tourist dollar and divert some of the heavy foreign travel to this country, was urged by speakers at the eleventh annual convention of the Hotel Sales Managers Association in Chalfonte-Haddon Hall here today.

A first mortgage of $135,000 has been placed for the Romean Realty Corp on the recently completed 6-story apartment on the northeast corner of Bronx Park East and Thwaites Pl, Bronx. The loan will run ten years, with interest at 5 per cent for five years and 4 1/2 per cent for the remaining five years.

Joe Louis is ready to defend his heavyweight championship against Harry Thomas tomorrow night. The Detroit Bomber, who won the world title, by stopping James J. Braddock here in July, will be risking his crown for the third time when he engages the Eagle Bend (Minn.) battler in the Chicago Stadium.
The Sul tan of Selangor, Fir Ala Idin Suleiman Shah, died in Klana Palace today at the age of 74.

Louis Johnson, Assistant Secretary of War, forwarded to .Congress today a report of the army engineers recommending improvement of the Hudson River from Albany to Waterford, N. Y., at a cost of $3,102,000.

BASHWITZ, HENRIETTA (March 23). Esstate, more than $10.000. To Hattie B. Finn, also known as Finkelstein, 270 West End Ave., and Lillian B. Shiers, 110 Riverside Drive, daughters, residue equally. Herbert Shiers, 110 Riverside Drive, and Fred Finn, also known as Finkelstein, 270 West End Ave., executors.

Retirement of Leonor F. Loree from the Delaware Hudson presidency, which he had occupied for thirty years, removes from the active railway scene one of its picturesque figures. Loree was personally an old-fashioned transportation executive;

After serving his country nineteen years at the French Embassy in Washington, Jules Henry, retiring Minister Plenipotentiary, sailed yesterday for home on the French liner Normandie, expressing his regret at leaving old friends and the hope to visit them again.
Scoring four runs in the ninth without making a hit, the Phillies beat Jersey City of the International League today, 8 to 7. Five bases on balls and a wild throw helped the Phils in this rally.

Despite reports of small upturns in certain consumer goods lines, collections continue to be very slow and there is no immediate prospect of any substantial improvement. credit executives of manufacturing companies reported yesterday.

Prospects for the adoption of Mayor La Guardia's three new relief tax bills at Tuesday's meeting of the Council brightened yesterday as the Council's Finance Committee heard George V. McLaughlin of the Brooklyn Trust Company predict that the bank tax included in the fourth bill would be passed on to depositors if enacted.

Denis Mulligan, one of the two assistant directors of the Bureau of Air Commerce, has been appointed director of the- bureau to succeed Fred D. Fagg Jr., effective April 16, Secretary Roper said today.

A bitter struggle for Lerida was going on a few miles outside that city this afternoon. There will be no rout, for some of Loyalist Spain's best soldiers are holding the line, but the danger was great, nevertheless.

Trading was generally fair to good. Lamb sold strong to slightly higher, fresh pork cuts steady to weak, other classes steady. Early trading in kosher meats was light, with beef strong and lamb steady, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

No little concern was manifested yesterday in financial quarters over the action of the market for government bonds at times in the trading period. Only substantial "official" support stemmed the decline, it was said, after some issues had recorded losses of about 3/4 point.

The marriage of Miss Frances Louise Townley, daughter of the Rev. Dr. Frank M. Townley, rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, and Mrs. Townley, to Dr. Donald R. Keller of this city and Westhampton Beach, L. I., took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 1,227 Pacific Street, Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by Dr. Townley in the presence of the immediate families.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustment.

Out of an all-star cast that will tee off tomorrow in the Bobby Jones golfing spectacle, the fifth annual Augusta national tournament, Rookie Sam Snead is the choice of big Ed Dudley,- host professional of the Streamlined course.

The enthusiasm of preview audiences over the association of Myrna Loy and Clark Gable in "Test Pilot" has caused Metro to assign Miss Loy to Gable's next, "Too Hot to Handle," a story of a newsreel camera man. It is expected that

A commission to execute the sculpture for the French village to be built by the French Government at the New York World's Fair, was awarded yesterday afternoon to Miss Liliane Grunwald, American sculptor, by Count de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, French Consul General.
Secretary Ickes stated today that a referendum would be arranged to give the Chippewa Indians in Minnesota an opportunity to choose for themselves the location of the Consolidated Chippewa Agency.

The sum of exhibitions newly current can provide contrasts sharp enough-quite irrespective of the quality of an individual - artist's work-to make a tour of the galderies exhilarating. As evidence, a small segment of the week's largess will do today.

The Chicago Black Hawks contributed another surprise to the already quite amazing National Hockey League play-offs by conquering the New York Americans in an overtime struggle which was decided by a "sudden-death" goal early this morning.

Despite the general trade slump, the convention and visitors business in New York City promises to be somewhat better during April, 1938, than it was in the same month last year, according to C. N. Nichols,

Daniel P. Adam, for the last twelve years treasurer of the Kerr Steamship Company, 17 Battery Place, died wednesday night at the Broad Street Hospital of a heart attack. Mr. Adam lived at 10 Tennis Place, Montclair, N. J. A native of Dumbarton, Scotland, Mr. Adam was educated in Scotland and came to this country as a young man. He had been associated with

Awards of major insignia to ten Fordham varsity trackmen, minor F's to eight members of the varsity rifle team and six sets of numerals in freshman track were announced yesterday by John F. Coffey, graduate manager of athletics.

With scattered indications that the building industry is launched on an uptrend, advertising in the field should start to expand somewhat this month, according to comment by agency executives yesterday. Companies, making

A big transaction for the purchase of Mexican oil produced by the government as a result of the expropriation of American and British oil companies was discussed by President Lazaro Cardenas today with Francis W. Rickett, who negotiated a contract for an Ethiopian oil concession just before the Italian conquest, and with Bernard E. Smith, a New York stock broker.
United States Government obligations assumed market leadership in the continued decline in bond values yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Lower cost of living is no longer "just around the corner," judging from current prices in the food markets. It has arrived. Food bills for the average family are about 9 per cent lower than they were the middle of last September-that is, providing that such a family has undergone no change of appetite.

The Smaller Business Association, Inc., has decided to set up a loan bureau to survey the credit and financial needs of small business concerns in the Second Federal Reserve District, as part of a program for obtaining emergency short and long-term financing for such companies through the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Henry Modell, treasurer of the association.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and total bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

The Treasury today gave notice that bids would be accepted by Federal Reserve Banks or their branches up to 2 P. M., Eastern standard time, on Monday on $100,000,000 of ninety-one-day bills to be sold on the usual discount basis to the highest bidders.

The United States Rubber Company will sell $45,000,000 of new 4 1/4 per cent, twenty-year, first mortgage bonds, authorized by seveneighths of the stockholders at a special meeting held in Jersey City yesterday, to institutional investors within the next few days. The new bonds will be dated July 1, 1938.
Fortyeight days of Maryland Spring racing, which will send the speedy thoroughbreds after $153,000 in purses in twenty-one feature stakes, open here tomorrow.

Fordham seniors consider Alexander F. Wojciechowicz, 1936-37 AllAmerican center, their "most prominent" classmate, and the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, the one who has "done most for Fordham," according to the annual senior preference poll by the Maroon yearbook.

The increase in activity in cotton garments in February over January was sufficient to bring an increase of 19.7 per cent in payrolls for the latest month, according to statistics made public yesterday by A. F. Allison, secretary of the International Association of Garment Manufacturers.
The United States Navy is accused today- by the newspaper Hochi of practicing landing operations and training for a transpacific war, with Japan as the hypothetical enemy in the present manoeuvres.

If the five boroughs of Greater New York were virgin territory and it were deemed desirable to provide therein facilities for the work, play and rest of nearly eight million people, the city planner, with sufficient billions at his disposal, could certainly produce a happier, more comfortable, more healthful city than the one that now exists.

The Swarthmore lacrosse team triumphed over Williams today for its second victory of the season, scoring by 10 to 6. The-Little Quakers opened the scoring in the first quarter with three tallies and led, 4 to 2, at half-time.
Hope for six navy fliers aboard a missing bomber was almost abandoned tonight by naval officials directing an unprecedented search amid the casualty-strewn Pacific manoeuvres.

The Alleghany Corporation, top holding company of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway structure, reported today for 1937 a net profit of $9,780,560 to earned surplus, in contrast with a net loss of $158,382 in the preceding year.
Mrs. William Francis Whitman of Chicago entertained 200 at a picnic party in the gardens of her home tonight. Dancing in the patio was followed by a buffet supper.
Mrs. Samaria Anna Goforth, civic leader and retired school principal, died Tuesday night at the Swenson Nursing Home here after a brief illness. She was 65 years old.

During the week ended March 30 member bank reserve balances decreased $21,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $4,000,000 in money in circulation, $6,000,000 in Treasury cash,

Tomorrow is "the day." Throughout New York State there will be few runs of water without anglers, and brook, brown and rainbow trout will be sizzling in pans on thousands of stoves tomorrow night. That, however,

Cicero is quoted in the foreword of the book about the New York Hospital as saying that "in no other act does man approach so near the gods as when he is restoring the sick to the blessings of health." There should be put with this quotation what Elizabeth Barrett Browning made one of her characters in "Aurora Leigh" say:
Stocks closed from fractions to 2 points net lower, despite rally at close; turnover, 1,271,030 shares. Bonds generally lower, United States Government issues weak; transactions, $9,783,000.

The Fourteenth Street neighborhood is about to lose another of its landmarks. After a checkered career dating back almost three-quarters of a century, the old Civic Repertory Theatre.on that street just west of Sixth Avenue is to be demolished.
It is reported now in diplomatic circles here that Franz von Papen, Chancellor Hitler's special Ambassador at Large, has finally been appointed Ambassador to Turkey.
Three additional public utility companies, all of Wilmington, Del., and the trustees for the common stock of another registered under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 today as follows:

GOVERNORS ISLAND Paragraph 4, Special Orders 57, dated March 10, 1938, relating to Captain Grover G. Tucker, Inf.-Res., is revoked. First Lieut. Alphonse E. D'Elia, Med.Res, now on active duty with CCC Co. 1242, Camp SP-12, Englewood, N. J., is continued on active duty with the CCC until Oct. 23. 1938. bate of rank: July 8. 1937.
Flotations of new securities here in March totaled $180,587,000, of which $178,678,000 represented thirty-eight bond issues and $1,909,000 two stock issues.

Deaths of seven women and the illness of four other persons, all patients at a clinic where a serum was injected for the treatment of cancer, were under investigation by county, State and Federal health authorities today.

The only equality of opportunity left today in a United States whose frontier is closed is "through the schoolhouse door" declared Dr. Frank P. Graham, president of the University of North Carolina, at the dinner last night closing the sixteenth annual conference of the Milbank Memorial Fund.

Plans for moving one of the three Fifth Avenue stores of Peck Peck were announced yesterday when brokers leased 8,500 square feet of space at 475 Fifth Avenue to the retailers of women's sportswear. Although moving only half a block south from its present location at 501 Fifth Avenue, where it has been for twenty years, the concern

George W. Wickersham, former Attorney General of the United States and chairman of President Hoover's National Commission on Law Observance and Enforcement, who died on Jan. 25, 1936, left a net estate of $738,454, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. His widow,

The Senate completed Congressional action on the resolution for an investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority, approved a resolution for a Federal Trade Commission investigation of alleged monopolistic practices by automobile companies, considered the

In accordance with the plan adopted at a meeting of representatives of nearly 125 realty and civic organizations last week in the Hotel Commodore Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, has named a committee of twenty-three men to draft a program for organization of a "realty union" in New York.

The long drought at the Music Hall has ended and, with London Film's "The Divorce of Lady X," a screen that had grown sere from Hollywood's neglect is being delightfully watered by a gay and urbane comedy written by Lajos Biro and Robert E. Sherwood.
The Shell Union Oil Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1937 a net operating income of $20,668,880.

Fox St, 819 (10-2709); Em-Jo Realty Corp to Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co, installments, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent; $15,000. Bronx Park E (16-4340); n e cor of Thwalte Pl, 100x100; Romean Realty Corp to Anny Alkoff, 1,825 Harrison Ave, installments, 6 per cent; $15,000.

The marriage of Mrs. Fredericka Frelinghuysen Carleton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter H. B. Frelinghuysen of New York, Morristown, N. J., and Palm Beach, to Huntington D. Sheldon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Sheldon of Biarritz, will take place on Saturday afternoon at Casa Primavera, the home of her parents. Dr. Francis Morton Nox, retired pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, will officiate.
