The volume of trading on the Chicago Stock Exchange for March totaled 693,000 shares compared with 407,000 shares last month and 1,631,000 shares in March, 1937. The average daily volume for March was 25,667 shares, compared with 18,500 shares in February and 62,731 shares in March, 1937.
Lumber production declined more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index receded to 61.9 from 63.2. The figure was 83.6 for the week ended March 27, 1937.

The underliers of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company, last week called the crux of the whole transit-reorganization plan, flatly refused today to aid the Public Utility Commission in its reorganization studies.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler was solemnly received in the coronation hall of Roemerberg here today by Frankfort's Mayor as the first ruler of Germany since medieval times who has united all the German provinces.
The liquor price war involving Scotch whiskies, which started Monday in downtown Manhattan and spread later to the midtown area, had expanded into Brooklyn and Forest Hills by last night.

Governor Lehman's disapproval of the McNaboe bill was more than a veto of a dangerous measure; it was a brief but eloquent restatement of the basic principles of constitutional government. "Although I am unreservedly'
The wealthy Sultan Ibraham of Johore, who divorced his beautiful Scottish wife, announced today that he planned to spend his birthday, Sept. 9, in the United States with "my many American friends."

The completion of two years as president of Lord Taylor was marked by Walter Hoving yesterday at a meeting with the 2,300 employes of that organization, on the main floor of the store building at Fifth Avenue and Thirtyeighth Street. Mr. Hoving thanked his staff briefly for their loyalty.

Guy W. S. Castle, 23-year-old veteran of General Francisco Franco's Foreign Legion, returned yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia accompanied by his mother, Mrs. Harriet Castle. He was wounded in the leg on the Teruel front. Mrs. Castle took her son to their home in Oxon Hill, Md., a suburb of Washington.

Gross assets, $9,065; net, $7,253. To Kate Pees, Addie Hampton, Mary Huhn, Hannah Applegate, aunts; Correll, Theodore and N. Walter Bennett, uncles, oneseventh residue each. Chief assets, miscellaneous property, $9,062. Smith Smith, attorneys, 191 Joralemon St., Brooklyn.

Miss Daisy Woodruff Rowley, president of the Westchester County Woman's Christian Temperance Union and former head of the Mount Vernon chapter, died here yesterday at the home of a niece, Mrs. William L. Bowman, where she had been living for six years.
Fulton County, of which Atlanta is county seat, joined ten other Georgia counties today in approving legal sale and manufacture -of liquor under a new State local option law.

River Mist, a bay mare owned and shown by Miss Dolly Von Stade of Westbury, L. I., today won the hunter championship of the twenty-third annual Aiken Horse Show in the Hitchcock woods. The reserve award went to Bally Black, a bay gelding ridden and owned by Rigan McKinney of New York and Aiken.

Seven hundred employes of the Sloane-Blabon Corporation, linoleum manufacturers in Hamilton Township, near here, were on strike today to protest wage reductions which the plant management had ordered effective April 17. William C. Weigle,
Appointment of John Wanhope, former Albany newspaperman, as publicity director of the New York State Apple Industries Committee was announced today by Webster J. Birdsall, chairman. The committee,

In an effort to avoid conflict with maritime labor unions engaged in controversies with employer ship lines along the Atlantic Coast, the Maritime Commission has organized its own employment agency under the direction of John J. Daly, Federal Shipping Commission, it was learned yesterday.

The subsistence garden project sponsored by the WPA has been discontinued, leaving up to the city the problem of providing funds for its re-establishment, it was announced yesterday. Home and work relief gardeners raised 1,215,270 pounds of vegetables on 5,000 farm plots in Brooklyn, the Bronx, Queens and Staten Island last year.

Jacqueline Dawson and Doris Milman have received two graduate fellowships given each year by the faculty of Barnard College to members of the graduating class who show most promise in their chosen fields of work.

The annual statement of the Superintendent of Banks lists the capital reserves of Lima's commercial and savings banks at the end of the year at 46,724,011 soles, against 43,433,512 the year before and 40,120,667 at the end of 1934.

Alumnae of Hunter College will hold their annual bridge party tomorrow in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. Proceeds will benefit the Lenox Hill Settlement House, which feeds hundreds of children daily; the Unemployed Graduate Fund and the Northrup Memorial Camp at Mount Washington, Mass.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

The action of Recorder Frank Romance of Hoboken in imposing a $100 fine on James De Lauro of Weehawken and causing the revocation of his driving privileges on a charge of possessing sweepstakes tickets
The President knocked down a straw man at Warm Springs early this morning. But, contrary to usual circumstances, it was not of his own making.

Fourteen thousand neatly uniformed members of the Austrian Legion crossed the former Austro-German. border and entered this city today. The men, who had fled from Austria in 1934 and 1935 to escape punishment in the Austrian courts, returned in trucks during a chilly rainstorm.

Honorary life membership in the Associated Musicians of Greater New York, Local 802, was conferred upon Arturo Toscanini when a gold card was delivered yesterday to the National Broadcasting Company, over whose networks the Italian maestro directed a series of concerts during the past Winter.

Southern schools showed supremacy in the preliminary rounds of the annual National Collegiate A. A. boxing tournament at the University of Virginia today, sending seventeen fighters through a series of knockout-studded bouts to the semi-finals tomorrow night.

The Harris Trust and Savings Bank, Chicago, received the award yesterday of a new issue of $251,000 of school bonds of Central School District 1 of the towns of Red Hook, Milan, Rhinebeck and Clermont, N. Y.
The Wembley Lions and the Wembley Monarchs tied 3-3, tonight in the firsts game of their national tournament second-place play-off series.
Total resources of $122,233,906 on Dec 31, 1937, were reported yesterday by the sixty-four Federal Savings and Loan Associations in New York State.

Mrs. Annie M. Michener, past national president of the Ladies of the Grand Army of the Republic, died this afternoon at her home here. She was the widow of Reuben Michener, former executive of the Crucible Steel Company.

A municipal small boat basin in the Hudson River off Seventy-ninth Street will be opened to public use without ceremony by the Park Department today. The cost of the facility was about $73,000, Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, said last night.

The Ellis H. Parkers, father and son, were held under bail of $5,000 each in United States District Court here today after they had surrendered to Judge John Boyd Avis to answer an indictment returned in the Eastern District of New York in connection with the Wendel kidnapping.

Merlin H. Aylesworth, organizer and first president of the National Broadcasting Company and for the last thirteen months a member of the Scripps-Howard newspapers' executive staff, yesterday was named publisher of The World-Telegram, the chain's New York paper.
The markets continued dispirited yesterday, commodities as well as securities, save for the higher closing in cotton. The stock market worked higher until early afternoon when prices gave way easily.

Pension payments to 3,214 retired employes of the General Electric Company amounted to $2,449,893 during 1937, according to the annual report of the pension board made public yesterday. During the year 144 employes retired from active service, while 222 died.
The text of the address delivered here last night by Herbert Hoover before the Council on Foreign Relations follows:
City real estate taxes for the first half of 1938 are due today. They may be paid without penalty throughout this month.

An Episcopal minister was officially revealed last night as an intermediary who might have recovered 12-year-old Peter D. Levine of New Rochelle from his kidnappers if police had not intervened in his activities.

Thaddeus R. Benson was elected today chairman of the board of governors and appointed president pro tem of the Chicago Stock Exchange at the first meeting of the board of governors under the Exchange's new constitution. Mr. Benson will serve as chairman until the annual election on June 6.

The first three Diesel motor railway coaches in an order for ninety-nine units of this equipment were recently delivered for use on the Buenos Aires Southern and Western Railways, according to a consular report from the Argentine capital made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The eight and sixteen story warehouse on the southeast corner of Wythe Avenue and South First Street, Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Sweet Life Food Products Company, of which Harry Socoloff is president.

Business activity in the Pittsburgh district improved in the week ended March 26, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The bureau's weekly index advanced from 67.7 per cent of the 1923-25 average in the week ended March 19 to 68.6 last week.

The Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association, suddenly prosperous as a result of the national the invitation tournament it sponsored a fortnight ago, presented watches to N. Y. U.'s metropolitan champions and certificates to the allmetropolitan team at a dinner at the Hotel Lincoln last night.

The first Lithuanian Minister to Poland, Casimir Skirpa, presented his credentials to President Ignace Moscicki this morning a few hours before the time limit contained in the Polish ultimatum accepted by Lithuania on March 19.

President Roosevelt shifted today his attack on critics of his objectives from those opposed to the Government Reorganization Bill to people who "ridicule" the Administration's methods for improving the lot of the "underprivileged third" of agriculture.

A BUCOLIC mood again dominates the Bookof-the-Month Club. Perhaps it's the season. Anyway, they seem bent on ruthlessly undermining confidence in the superior glories of city life. Last month they lit on Charles Allen Smart's eloquent midland pastoral, "R. F. D.," and Isak Dinesen's tapestried memoir of plantation days in Kenya, "Out of Africa." The scene varies widely, you see. But it's almost a tendency we have here.

The blandishments of Mae West and an offer of Hollywood contracts convert Hitler, Mussolini and Stalin to democracy and bring peace to a world burlesqued in "You've Got Something There," the forty-fourth annual Columbia University varsity show, which opened last night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor.

In a letter sent yesterday to Nathan L. Amster, president of the Manhattan Railway Company, Mayor La Guardia indicated that he planned early action to compel improvement in the "physical condition" of the company's elevated structures, now under 999-year lease to the Interborough Rapid Transit Company.

Making his first public address since his return on Tuesday from an intensive survey of the European situation, former President Herbert Hoover last night emphatically warned the Unifed States to keep out of war and especially to avoid any alliance with other democratic nations in a war against the fascist powers.
Senate investigators charged today that railroads were "parading behind the skirts" of taxpayers' leagues and similar associations in seeking State legislation against competing motor trucks.

With the visiting Cambridge University Rugby team and some 2,000 New Yorkers as onlookers, the first of several hundred piles, which will support New York State's building at the 1939 World's Fair, was driven yesterday on the fair grounds in Flushing Meadow Park.

SMITH, HIRAM (Aug. 19. 1937). Gross assets, $209,452; net, $198,613. To Mary L. Smith. aunt, $1,000; Lewis Condit Smith and Robert Sherrard Smith, brothers, one-half residue each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $174,476. Osborn, Fleming Whittlesey, attorneys, 20 Exchange Place.
Henry W. Bull, Ferry K. Heath, William J. Cunningham, George F. Brennan and Malcolm S. McConihe Jr. are the five partners in Harriman Keech who will join Winthrop, Mitchell Co. on April 15,
H. W. Prentis Jr., president of the Armstrong Cork Company, announced today that the concern had decided to purchase the plant of the Whitall-Tatum Company of Millville and Keyport, N. J.,
NEWS OF THE COMMODITY MARKETS

In a dispatch on the new importance of the Danube, now that Austria and Germany are one, our Berlin correspondent corrects a possible misinterpretation of Hitler's decision to create a war fleet on what is now the longest of German waterways.

Humpty Dumpty, victim of one of the most famous falls in history, has been enlisted by the police safety bureau of the West 152d Street station to remind children of that precinct, comminded by Captain Bernard Moore, to be careful crossing the streets.
The Alumni Association of the Horace Mann School held a reunion and dance last night at the Plaza.

Four pickets of the National Maritime Union walked back and forth before the Department of Commerce Building today carrying banners which proclaimed the Maritime Commission "a shipowners' unionbreaking agency."
The Department of Commerce reported today that $6,660,364 of gold was: imported in the week ended on March 25. The amount included $2,284,771 from England and $1,743,058 from Mexico.

Miss Jane Cothran of Palm Beach, Fla., and Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta won semi-final matches today and will meet tomorrow for the championship in the thirty-sixth women's North and South golf tournament.
Representatives of civic associations protested yesterday that the line of march proposed for this year's united May Day parade would interfere with business, the theatre and traffic generally.

Squibb Plan, Inc., New York, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 72,600 shares of $3 cumulative distributors preferred no-par value stock to be offered at $50 a share for an aggregate of $3,630,000, the proceeds to be used to buy common stock of E. R. Squibb Sons.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Winfred Everett Reynolds of this city of the engagement of Mrs. Reynolds's daughter, Miss Ada Everett Waddell, to Kenneth Fuller Rolph, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philo Fuller Rolph, also of New York.
The five-acre estate of Miss Eleanor Oliver, on West Neck Avenue, Lloyds Harbor, Huntington, L. I., has been sold to a client of Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers, for occupancy when alterations

Those temperamental figures in the public eye, who feel constrained to explain their actions over nation-wide radio hook-ups for fear they will be "misquoted" in the press, and the recent rapid multiplication of picture magazines, were among the subjects chosen for vigorous lampooning by the Dutch Treat Club at its annual dinner and show last night.
Once more the voice of the keynoter is heard in the land. Senator Bridges of New Hampshire, ever young and fair and forward, is speaking to the Maine Republican Convention. Let us adopt, he says,

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As one who is interested in the preservation of our democracy I wish to express my appreciation for the fortitude shown by Governor Lehman in vetoing the McNaboe-Devanny bill. I am not a radical nor do I sympathize with such tendencies, but I am a foe of any one who tries to infringe on our Bill of Rights.
Secretary of War Harry H. Woodring gave a dinner tonight at Patio Moresque for Colonel and Mrs. M. Robert Guggenheim, The Woodrings,

William Franklin Dunspaugh, founder of the American Vitrified Clay Products Company and the Compiling- Tabulating Company, which later became the International Business Machine Company, died in a hospital today after a week's illness. His age was 84.

Mr. Hoover, as he appeared before the Council on Foreign Relations, became the man Hoover, without title, whom the world adored and loved after the World War as its greatest benefactor and especially as the friend of the children of all peoples. In his major service to humanity there were no national borders or prejudices.

The first violence in the strike of fur workers here was reported yesterday when five men attacked a fur dealer as he entered his place of business. With more than 100 patrolmen and scores of detectives on duty in the fur district, two arrests were made in a few minutes.
Joe Louis weighed 202 1/2 pounds and Harry Thomas 196 for the fight in the Stadium tonight. Dave Miller was the referee and Dr. E. A. Frankel and Rube Metz were the judges.

Mrs. Lydia Perry Baldwin, for many years active in social and charitable work in New York and the wife of William M. Baldwin, retired president of a number of manufacturing firms, died yesterday at their home, 40 East Eighty-eighth Street.

Art property from the residence of the late Ogden L. Mills, 2 East Sixty-ninth Street, brought $26,242.50 yesterday afternoon at the second of three auction sessions. The total yield to date is $41,952.50.

The report of the El Paso Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $1,957,401 after all charges, including provision for retirements, interest, amortization and taxes, compared with $1,205,407 in the twelve months to Feb. 28, 1937, an increase of $751,994, or approximately 62 per cent.

Mr. and Mrs. Auguste Richard gave a dinner yesterday in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for their niece Miss Evelyn Mills, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Mills of Boston, a debutante of next season.
The long-awaited report of the Federal Communications Commission's investigation of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company system was indicated yesterday, but in unusual circumstances.
Major Gen. Harry Lee Steele, who climbed from army private to chief of coast artillery at Washington, D. C., died here yesterday at the age of 63.

Secretary Ickes granted a license to Pan American Airways today to use Canton Island in the South Pacific Ocean as an air base. The island's eight miles of lagoon will become a stop on commercial transpacific air transport service between California and Australia.

An electrical contractor, who previously had reported his life was threatened when he ignored the dictates of his rivals, testified yesterday that he had operated collusively with other contractors in an attempt to "break up the ring," at the suggestion of an assistant of Thomas E. Dewey when the latter was Special Prosecutor.

President Cardenas promised in a note to the State Department at Washington yesterday that "Mexico will know how to honor its obligations of today and its obligations of yesterday." He expressed warm friendship for the United States.

IT isn't that Onkel Franz Frisch agrees with those who say that he has reached the slippered age through a natural accumulation of years. It's just that his foot is sore. That's why he is directing the Cardinals with carpet slippers instead of the conventional spiked shoes on his feet.

The question whether the affairs of the Prudence Company, Inc., real-estate servicing corporation and guarantors of mortgages and mortgage certificates, will continue in reorganization proceedings or be liquidated in bankruptcy was discussed yesterday at a hearing before Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Federal Court, Brooklyn.

Members of the Utility Workers Organizing Committee, a C. I. O. union, took complete possession tonight of Consumers Power Company plants in the Saginaw Valley, following the collapse this afternoon of negotiations with the company for a new contract.

Criticizing Neville Chamberlain, Britain's Prime Minister, for what he called a "drifting" policy, Herbert Morrison, prominent in the British Labor party, declared yesterday that a combination of the peaceful, democratic nations against the fascist powers was necessary, in his opinion, to prevent a general war.

Results of operations of banks for the first quarter of the year were made available for publication today by three of the larger New York banking institutions. Individual statements of condition as of March 31 follow:
A syndicate headed by Jacob Feder, Bronx builder, has purchased from the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank the six six-story elevator apartment houses at 806 to 840 Bronx River Road, YonKers.

Although he threw his jockey at the starting line, bolted and ran away for almost a mile, William Woodward's American-owned Derby candidate, Olympus, was beaten only a neck today by the Aga Khan's Mirza II in the $5,000 Greenham Plate, a one-mile test for 3year-olds.
Dr. Ernest Albert Chapman, re- at tired New York physician, died today in the Yonkers General Hospital after an illness of a year. He was 77 years old and lived at Dobbs Ferry.

We dropped in at several sporting goods stores yesterday, just to check up on the last-minute sales, and to see whether the interest among fishermen is as great as last year. In four or five of the stores we were not required to question clerks as to business.

F. W. Rickett, colorful negotiator of big international oil deals, announced today that he and Bernard E. Smith, New York stock market operator, had arrived at an understanding for the sale of Mexican oil to unidentified interests represented by them.

There is a great new crop of wealthy people, and hotels should aim their promotional efforts at them, Bernard Lichtenberg, New York, president of the Institute of Public Relations, told the eleventh annual convention of the Hotel Sales Managers Association in the Hotel Chelsea here today.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
The Mother Lode Coalition Mines Company's no-par capital stock will be stricken from the Exchange's listing and registration on April 9.

Seldon Rodman has delivered tohis publishers the complete text of "The Random House anthology of Modern Poetry," which will con-tain works of the last decade and include such poets as T. S. Eliot; Spender, Auden, Jeffers, Frost, MacLeish, Joyce and Crane.

George J. Whitney, a detective attached to the Fifth Avenue squad, who had been in the service of the New York City Police Department S for the last thirty-three years, died on Thursday at his home, 150-03 Eighty-fourth Avenue. Briarwood.

An increasing interest in Quaker doctrines was reported yesterday at the first business meeting of the 243d session of the New York Yearly Meeting of the Religious Society of -Friends.at the Friends Meeting House, 221 East Fifteenth Street.

The Bell System could cut telephone rates about 25 per cent "without interrupting existing net earnings," Paul A. Walker of the Federal Communications Commission asserted today in a report based on a three-year investigation of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company which he supervised.
The Maine Central Railroad Company notified the Interstate Commerce Commission today that the road planned to borrow $1,250,000, partly to meet a $750,000 note.

The Rev. Ivan Q. Spencer, head of the Elim Bible School here, said today he had been informed by cable that three of the organization's American missionaries had been ordered by the Italian Government to leave Ethiopia "within twenty-four hours."

Flushing High and Adelphi Academy turned in victories in nonleague baseball games yesterday. Flushing scored its second straight victory by downing the Queens College nine, the first in the history of the institution, 8-2, at Flushing Memorial Field, while Adelphi beat Newtown High, 9-3, in the season's opener for both on Adelphi's diamond in Queens Village.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 1,203,000 bales, against 1,203,000 a week ago, 1,214,000 two weeks ago, 1,203,000 three weeks ago and 1,020,000 a year ago; of which American 797,000 bales, against 794,000 a week ago, 789,000 two weeks ago, 794,000 three weeks ago and 443,000 a year ago.

Schedules for Princeton's varsity and freshman outdoor polo teams were announced today by David H. K. Flagg, '39, president of the Princeton Polo Association. The polo card of five varsity and three cub tests completes the Nassau 148-game Spring schedule.

A provisional estimate of British and foreign investments in Canada on Dec. 31, last, places the amount at $6,848,000,000, an increase of $14,000,000 in the year, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today to the House of Commons.

Ivor Knoll Nick, liver and white pointer owned by W. Lippincott Colket of Villanova, Pa., romped off with first place today in the junior all-age class as the annual three-day trials of the South Jersey Field Club got under way.
Tonight's only Broadway closing is that of the Marc Blitzstein "opera," "The Cradle Will Rock," which is leaving the Mercury Theatre after giving 123 performances there and elsewhere.

Lispenard St. 46-48, 47.11x93.8; Rerman Falk to trustees of Alletta M. MacDonald, care Fulton Trust Co; consideration $25,000; foreclosure. 66th St, 153 W, 39.9x100.4: Philip Menschel and wife to Abraham Pollack, 241 W 97th St; mtg $31,500. 85thvSt, 311 W, 16x102.2; excrs will of Gina Ciaparelli Viafora to Aida Gainotti, Rome, Italy; mtg $18,000.
Bryan (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta, Ga., the country's fourth ranking tennis player, underwent an operation for acute appendicitis today. Surgeons said he was resting well.

Oxford was the slight favorite over Cambridge tonight as the crews of the two British universities went early and nervously to bed in preparation for tomorrow's test in the most grueling and famous intercollegiate boat race in the world.

The decision of Great Britain and the United States to resort to the escalator provision in the London Naval treaty of 1936 and build battleships larger than 35,000 tons was announced in an exchange of notes, the texts of which were made public tonight.

Passion Sunday will be observed in the churches tomorrow, Palm Sunday a week from tomorrow and Easter on April 17. Pastors tomorrow will preach on "The Passion of Jesus Christ" and oratorios will be on the same theme. Passion Sunday is the fifth Sunday in Lent.
Mark Eisner, a member of the Board of Higher Education for twelve years, and its chairman for the last six, has resigned from the board, it was announced yesterday.
Monte Pearson's April Fool's Day joke on Marse Joe McCarthy was a pleasant surprise as the Yankees interrupted their flight northward today to tangle with the Tallahassee Capitals.
Secretary Ickes has named seven New York State men to help the National Park Service draft policies and practices for recreational areas throughout the United States.

Today, when the willows are their tenderest green and hardwood boughs, so long stark and sharply etched, make a haze of swollen buds against the sky, thousands of eager sportsmen will be whipping the streams of the Empire State. For the trout season opened this morning.

New bond financing this week was in the largest volume and presented the most diversified list of new issues to reach the market in almost two months. Three major classifications were represented in the week's new offerings, which together lifted the total flotations to $59,202,000.
Harry F. Wolf, national amateur titleholder from the Montclair Athletic Club, gained the quarter-final round of the world's open squash tennis championship last night at the Shelton Club.

Two unarmed thugs held up a messenger, carrying a payroll of $878, in an elevator at 105 East Sixteenth Street yesterday afternoon, and in a free-for-all fight that followed one suspect was captured and the other escaped with the money.

Realty interests will play a part in the forthcoming State Constitutional Convention, and they are hoping that steps may be taken during the deliberations of that body 'to effect new safeguards for real property, particularly with respect to taxation.

The Art Directors Club's seventeenth annual exhibition of adver timing art was opened with a preview yesterday afternoon in, the mezzanine galleries of the International Building, Rockefellere Center. The show will be open to the public beginning today and contin uing through April 24.

Mrs. Elizabeth Harding Prince Thayer, widow of Eugene Van Rensselaer Thayer, former president of the Chase National Bank of New York, was married at noon yesterday at her home, 1 East Sixty-fourth Street, to Vadim S. Makaroff, yachtsman and importer of this city and Oyster Bay, L. I.

Charging that deliberate efforts were being made abroad to have it appear that Canida desired to break away from the British Empire, Prime Minister Mackenzie King reiterated in Parliament today the Dominion's allegiance to Britain and the common purpose of the British Commonwealth.
Approval was given by the War Department today to an application of New York City for reconstruction of the bridge across Beach Channel in Jamaica Bay on Cross Bay Boulevard.
The Stinson Aircraft Corporation announced today the appointment of Albert I. Lodwick as its president, succeeding B. D. De Weese, who resigned yesterday.
The State Unemployment Insurance Fund had sent 1,086,533 weekly benefit checks amounting to $12,472,217 up to the close of business March 28, Commissioner Andrews said today.

Miss Vivian J. Nichols of New Milford, bursar of Kent School and formerly secretary to the Rev. Frederick H. Sill, headmaster of the school, died yesterday In Grace Hospital, New Haven, after a short illness. She was stricken with a streptococcus infection while visiting relatives here.

C. E. Forstmann, executive vice president of the Forstmann Woolen Company, Passaic, N. J., urged a Senate subcommittee today to approve bill to require designation of wool contents and percentages of virgin and reclaimed wool in fabrics to protect the consumer.
Dr. Henry H. Donaldson, director of neurological research at the Wistar Institute, left an estate of $118,213 on his death in January, an inventory disclosed today.

Declaring himself eminently. satisfied with the results of his fiveweek training siege in Louisiana's capital, Colonel Bill Terry broke camp with his Giants tonight amid no end of bustle and a shower of announcements that for a time proved difficult to follow with the naked eye.

Franklin Stephen Crossin, who served on the, Mexican border and in the World War and who ford was the membership representative of the New York Credit Men's Association, died today at his home of a heart attack. His age was 46.

Retired Captain Daniel J. Cahill, formerly a member of H. L. Co. 114, residing at 2865 11th St., Brooklyn, died March 3D. Funeral will take place from his late residence at 9:30 A. M., Saturday, April 2. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery.

After a presentment had been returned here today by the Essex County grand jury in which the Newark Excise Board was criticized for alleged laxity in carrying out the retail liquor laws, D. Frederick Burnett, State Alcoholic Beverage Commissioner, announced that the local board would be stripped of disciplinary power.

Dr. Joseph F. Thorning, Professor of Sociology and Social History at Mount St. Mary's College, Emmitsburg, Md., said last night at the Spanish Symposium held at Fordham University that "the time has come for the State Department to consider recognition of the Franco government of Nationalist Spain."
It may not be the whole truth about the Sultan of Johore to say that he divorced his European wife by simply repeating four
Frank A. Vanderlip and Charles G. Sinclair Jr. have resigned as directors of the Reo Motor Car Company, according to Rowland Campbell, chairman of the board.

White, Weld Co., fiscal agents for the city of Cordoba, Argentina, 7 per cent dollar bonds, due in 1957, have been advised by their Argentine counsel that a decision has been rendered in their favor by the Federal court in Cordoba in their suit for interest and sinking fund on the bonds due on Aug. 1, 1987.

The directors of the United States Rubber Company recommended yesterday in letters to its stockholders that a new long-term employment contract be granted to F. B. Davis Jr., chairman' of the board and president.

Business continued at a relatively low level in March, with declines of approximately seasonal proportions in the generation of electric power and in the shipment of bulk freight over the railroads, while merchandise and miscellaneous freight carloadings increased less than is usual at this time of year, according to the monthly review of credit and business conditions issued by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

With seven internationalists, who helped to bring world supremacy in chess to this country, among the seventeen entrants, the biennial tournament of the National Chess Federation for the championship of the United States and custody of the Frank J. Marshall Challenge Trophy will get under way at 2 o'clock today.

Mayor La Guardia put a $9,863,980 relief appropriation for April through the Board of Estimate yesterday, with a proviso which he St said would restrict the 10 per cent cut voted by the board on March 14 to a single payment.
The 1937 class of the Graduate School of Banking will hold its reunion today at the Manhattan Club, Louis C. Holl, chairman, and second vice president of the Chase National Bank, announced yesterday.

A battered old typewriter with a keyboard in Hebrew characters was selected yesterday by a trio of judges considering unique contributions in recent weeks to Thrift House, at 7 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Fight for control of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway system, which was to have come to a showdown on next Monday at a scheduled meeting of stockholders of the Chesapeake Corporation, will be delayed until April 8.

Napoleon's famous adage that "a marshal's baton is in the knapsack of every worthy soldier" was illustrated once again yesterday in the United States Army when a former enlisted private became a brigadier general of the line at Morris Memoral Field, Governors Island.
Awards of thirty-five fellowships and scholarships in the Graduate School of Cornell University for the academic year 1938-39, amounting to $20,800, were announced today.
Thirty-five students at Hunter College have been elected class officers this term, according to Joyce Gale, president of the Student Self-Government Association at the college.

Yesterday's commercial rentals list contained a number of leases for space in the financial district. Stern, Lauer Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, have taken the entire fifth floor in 30 Pine Street, through Schlang Brothers Co.

Rumson Farm Dawn, a white and black pointer dog owned by Raymond Hoagland of Cartersville, Ga., and formerly of Rumson, N. J., today was placed first in the open Spring derby stake, initial event of the annual field trial meeting of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club. He was handled by Earl C. Crangle of Waynesboro, Ga.

In a falling market with the turnover extremely light, member trading in round lots for their own accounts on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on March 5 fell to 19.07 per cent of the total volume, compared with 20.51 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
Robert Wallace, who was, supervising architect for the Buffalo PanAmerican Exposition in 1901, died here yesterday. He was 65 years old.
Mrs. Lilian Zilbermann Talbot, wife of Henry D. Talbot, until recently a New York Stock Exchange member, died on Thursday at their home, 152 East Ninety-fourth Street. at the age of 52.

President Roosevelt's expression of satisfaction with the progress of negotiations with Mexico for the settlement of oil, land and other claims and the disclosure by an official source of the formula on which this country is proceeding in the matter combined today to ease the tension that has surrounded relations between the two nations since expropriation of the oil properties and suspension of silver purchases by this country.

Chief John T. Farrell of the Thirty-eighth Fire Department Battalion, Herkimer Street, Brooklyn, who is 75 years old and known as the dean of battalion chiefs, retired yesterday after fifty-one years of fire-fighting.

P. M. Macklin, executive vice president of the Wickwire Spencer Steel Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that net loss in the first two months of 1938 was $248,000, contrasted with a net profit of $88,900 in the 1937 period.

Paced by Harry Williams, New York State 100-yard free-style champion, the New York Athletic Club defeated the Duquesne Dolphins from the Rio Diablo Club of Duquesne, Pa., 8 to 5, last night in the Winged Foot pool in the opening match of the senior national A. A. U. hard-ball water polo championship.
Contracts for textile supplies were awarded today at the local Quartermaster Depot as follows: Invitation 190, for the manufacture from government cloth and findings, in part,

With Ostend, Mrs. Frank M. Gould's capable post and rail jumper, carrying the heaviest impost of 169 pounds, nine timber toppers are scheduled to start in the ninth running of the Carolina Cup test which will feature the six-event card here tomorrow.
Lerida was still holding out late yesterday afternoon despite Spanish Rebel reports that it had been abandoned by its defenders. A correspondent ...

Commending the expanded movement to promote Father's Day on June 19, Saul Cohn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Assocaition and head of the City Stores Company, said yesterday it is "vital that business unite to accomplish in any sound way the accelerated movement of goods and an expansion of purchasing power."

A Royal Commission report on the Canadian textile industry, submitted to the government, calls on Parliament to amend the customs tariff so that protected industries might lose their protection if they fix unfair prices.

A survey comparing men and women in their attitudes toward women, showing a remarkable agreement in favor of equal social rights for both sexes and a wide disagreement in evaluating the emotional stability and originality of women, was presented yesterday by Philip M. Kitay of Teachers College, Columbia University.

An Intensive campaign to establish a definite selling season for Summer millinery, with the express purpose of encouraging retailers to maintain prices at "normal" levels for the period following Easter, was announced yesterday by Walter K. Marks, chairman of the trade promotion committee of the Millinery Stabilization Commission, Inc.,

Senator Joseph F. Guffey, who recently broke with the Democratic State organization he had headed for a quarter of a century, announced his support today of S. Davis Wilson, Philadelphia's nonpartisan Mayor, as a candidate for the Senatorial nomination.
A world in which national isolation leads only to war was painted here today as the Academy of Political and Social Science opened its annual meeting.

The first brigade of the Austrian Legion arrived here today and was received with frantic enthusiasm by Vienna National Socialists. It had come by train. Two other brigades coming by truck are expected tomorrow.

Opposition to President Roosevelt's Reorganization Bill was expressed yesterday by the National Small Business Men's Association in letters signed by J. Raymond Tiffany, its general counsel, and sent to all members of Congress.

Fred Apostoli, the fighting bellhop of San Francisco, again outpointed Glen Lee of Edison, Neb., in a slashing fifteen-round fight in Madison Square Garden last night. This time he won decisively enough to please a crowd of 16,000.

The second of the Colony Dances for this season took place last night in the main ballroom of the RitzCarlton. These dances are given in a series each year for girls who will not be introduced to society for the next two or three years and for, boys of "prep" school and early college years.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Although, on the whole, the writer enjoyed the motion picture, "A Yank at- Oxford," yet he suspects that even the movie-lot Oxonians who had to support Robert Taylor must have become tired of the "Yank's" sustained braggadocio. The matter gives rise to some interesting reflections.

Federal Judge John C. Knox, who was asked recently by the Circuit Court of Appeals to clarify an opinion in which he disbarred Aaron Sapiro. New York and Chicago attorney, from practice in Federal court because of alleged misconduct in mail fraud case, did so yesterday with another disbarment order.

Magistrate David L. Malbin of Brooklyn turned in his resignation to Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday, with the explanation that he wanted to enter private law practice. His term still has twenty months to run.
Following a smashing victory in the general elections in Upper Egypt, the government tonight dispatched troops to strategic centers in Lower Egypt, which votes tomorrow.

Encouraged by the fine showing of Princeton against the touring Cambridge Rugby team Thursday, the All-New York fifteen which will face the invaders at Randalls Island today is looking forward to the game with high hopes of upsetting the Light Blues.

Edward A. Gartner, for fifteen years property man for Richard Mansfield, and who had been in charge of the stage properties in the old Park Theatre, Brooklyn, died today at the Brunswick General Hospital here. He was 69 years old on March 8 last.

Sir Granville Bantock, British composer and conductor and chairman of the Trinity College for Music in London, arrived yesterday on the United States. liner Washington to conduct examinations in various parts of the United States for students who seek to qualify for Trinity College diplomas in music. He gives examinations here every year.

The Glass bill giving the Reconstruction Finance Corporation wider powers to lend to corporations was passed unanimously today by the Senate and sent to the House, where speedy action was promised by leaders.
Alfred Renard, Belgian airplane constructor, saw his stratosphere plane, designed for long-distance flights, crash on its first flight here today, killing the pilot.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $165,000 of relief bonds of Medford, Mass., on a bid of 100.136 for 2 1/4s. The bonds, dated April 1, 1938, and maturing April 1, 1939 to 1948, were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.60 to 2.30 per cent, according to maturity.

Reassuring budget figures had a cheering effect on the stock markets here today. Prices generally made a good showing, with gilt-edge issues leading the rise. Among the foreign bonds Austrian and Czechoslovak loans were firmer.
An allotment of $1,278,000 was made by the War Department today for carrying on the project for improving the New York and New Jersey channels.

The British Government welcomes the prospect of the swift ending of the civil war in Spain. Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain is relieved at the impending disappearance of a question the existence of which has for so long furnished the opposition in the House of Commons with a means for obstructing the conclusion of an agreement with Italy, considered by Mr. Chamberlain as absolutely necessary from the viewpoint of essential British interests.

The National Electric Range Spring Showing, April 11 to 30, sponsored by the Modern Kitchen Bureau, will be supported by full pages in six national magazines and a special tabloid newspaper promotion section to be handled locally by utilities and newspapers throughout the country.

Supreme Court Justice Algeron I. Nova, most of whose $25,000 annual salary is sought. by two creditors, told Justice James T. Hallinan, in an affidavit filed yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court, that he needed $20,835 for living expenses for the year.
The Pirates hit their batting stride today when they scored five runs on five hits in the fourth inning to beat a Fresno independent team, 6 to 0.

Cotton-mill activity was unchanged for the third successive week, although an increase was called for by the seasonal factor, and the adjusted index has eased to 91.1 from 91.6, the revised figure for the previous week. It was 136.9 for the week ended March 27, 1937.
The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "There is a steadier undertone in the market and a somewhat broader business, so that prices are maintained on a steady basis.
A fair trade contract covering "Deities-Mayfair Blend," a new cigarette being launched in this market by the P. Lorillard Company, maker of Old Golds, was signed here yesterday.

Raymond Kenny, 24 years old, who was acquitted on Wednesday of a charge of attempted hold-up when a jury in Queens County Court believed, a "lie-detector" had proved him innocent, was released yesterday from the Queens County Jail on the orders of the State Parole Board.

A bill to provide a Federal system of unemployment insurance for railroad workers was introduced today by Senators Wheeler and Wagner, who said prompt enactment of the measure would help solve unemployment in railroad workers ranks.

J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, announced today that on March 30 the receiver of the Ozone Park National Bank of New York was authorized to pay a third dividend of 8 per cent-to creditors of the receivership.
Realty deals in Manhattan reported yesterday included several sales and leases of properties on the upper West Side.

One of the largest realty transactions to be made in Jersey City this year took place yesterday when the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey sold to Tankport Terminals, Inc., of 96 Pine Street, Jersey City,
In farewell to their friends before returning to New York Sunday after several weeks at Brazilian Court, Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran entertained with a dinner tonight at the Beach Club.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler styled himself a "dictator" today for the first time in a public address. The term was applied ironically, however, in a discussion of his historic Berchtesgaden meeting on Feb. 12 with former Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria.

Hans Lagerloef of New York won the Atlantic City Kiwanis Club's Silver Trophy, outstanding honor in the annual philatelio exhibition sponsored-by the National Federation of Stamp Clubs in the Hotel Colton Manor here today.

Chevrolet has appointed T. H. Keating assistant general manager in charge of new cars in the Eastern half of the United States. W. G. Lewellen succeeds Mr. Keating in charge of used cars in the Eastern half, and J. E. Johnson replaces Mr. Lewellen in charge of used cars in the Western half. Roy W. Hill has been named Southwestern regional manager.

Town House, the twenty-sevenstory apartment hotel at 108 East Thirty-eighth Street, Was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street Rooms by Edwin J. McDonald, auctioneer, on a bid of $1,050,000 to the Bankers Trust Company, plaintiff in foreclosure proceedings against the Property Holding Corporation to- recover on a judgment of $1,163,950. The hotel occupies a plot 89.6 by 98.9. feet.

Harold floor. S. Maddock, broker and sales promotion expert and former pottery manufacturer and member of one of Trenton's most prominent families, died this morning at St. Francis Hospital after an illness of several months. He was 47 years old.

The Board of Education has asked Governor Lehman to veto eighteen of the twenty bills affecting the New York City school system that were passed in the closing days of the Albany session, it was learned yesterday.

Shelling two pitchers off the mound with a barrage of six hits, Princeton scored ten runs in the sixth inning to come from behind and conquer the Villanova baseball team, 11--3, on University Field today.
Retail trade improved here during the week, but the percentage comparison with a year ago continued unfavorable, according to department store executives.
Eighteenth annual convention of the Eastern Osteopathic Association begins at the Hotel Pennsylvania this morning at 9 o'clock and continues tomorrow. Morning and afternoon sessions.
James L. Eadie, for forty years a leader in the textile field in New England and New York State, died of heart disease this morning in his home in Waterford. He was 71 years old.

The Continental Bank and Trust I Company began yesterday directing the affairs of the Ritz Tower Hotel for the benefit of the bondholders, Iin pursuance of the plan whereby William Randolph Hearst and asso- v ciates have relinquished ownership of the forty-one-story apartment hotel.

Su-Lin, the baby giant panda who was born in a hollow tree near the SzechuenTibetan border in western China and became a great zoological drawing card, died today in the Brookfield Zoo, a victim of her curiosity.

Marion Koegell, young singer and actress, a recent refugee from Germany, will give her first American recital tomorrow night in the L. Napoleon Levy Auditorium of the Portuguese Synagogue, Seventieth Street and Central Park West. The recital will be sponsored by the Shearith Israel League.

When a symphony orchestra's violins begin to flutter above the undertones of the basses; when the horns, dying away, announce the flute, or whentall the instruments together praise God in a Beethoven symphony or lament the tragedy of mankind in one of Tschaikovsky's--at such a time man comes nearest to what we may imagine to be the emotional as well as the musical harmony of the angels.

Stevens Tech vanquished Williams, 10--5, at lacrosse today as Gene Rockwell starred. Williams, checked by the Red and Gray defense, was held to one point through the first three periods, giving Stevens an 8-1 advantage. In the fourth Williams scored four time against Coach Sims's second team.

PATROLMEN--William Koch, from 32d Precinct to 19th Division, duty in raided premises squad, for 14 days, from 8 A. M., April 2. Clinton C. Warren, from 32d Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, N. Y. County, for 1 day, from 4 P. M., March 30.
The stock market yesterday had its first worthwhile rally since March 15, and the recovery was actually the best since Jan. 5. Leading issues closed with net gains running from fractions to 3 points.

Sales by department stores during the week ended March 26 were 17 per cent below -the sales in the same week one year ago and for the four weeks ended March 26 the decline was about 16 per cent, as compared with -the same period in 1937, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Captain James M. Mangan, district director of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau and of the State Income Tax Bureau, died today of a heart attack. He was 54 years old.

While its steel mills and machine shops are busy making guns and shells and military authorities are occupied with creating prison camps for the thousands of captured men pouring in from the front, this manufacturing and shipping center of North Spain already has begun to repair the ravages of war and even undertake local improvements.
Norman E. Gatens, former NewYork City assistant corporation counsel, died at his home here yesterday after a brief illness at the age of 44. Until Mayor La Guardia took office Mr. Gatens had been on

World lead production in February amounted to 147,295 tons, compared with 161,036 in January, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. Stocks of lead at United States smelters and refiners on March 1 were 216,070 tons, compared with 211,087 on Feb. 1 arid 228,285 on March 1, 1937.

United States oil companies, whose properties in Mexico recently-were seized by the government of that country, yesterday formally requested the State Department in Washington to take steps to prevent the sale and movement in international trade of .the crude oil and its products ,derived from the seized properties.

The report by Commissioner Paul A. Walker of the Federal Communications Commission, made public yesterday, on the commission's sweeping investigation of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company system follows about three years of work by commission investigators. According to estimates the cost of the inquiry was nearly $5,000,000.

The report covering last year's Operations of the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc. Issued yesterday, shows a consoli dated net income of $3,878,267 after all operating expenses, depreciation amortization, taxes and other charges.
Gounod's "Faust" was given last night by the New York Hippodrome Opera Company before a fair-sized but customarily enthusiastic audience. Arcady Dubensky conducted.

IF you haven't been reading too many of those. "I-said-to-Hitler-and - Mussolini-said-tome"' books by the foreign correspondents lately, you may want to look into Vernon Bartlett's "Intermission in Europe."
John F. Brady, former president of the Holy Name Society of St. Francis of Assisi Church, Brooklyn, died on Thursday of pneumonia at his home, 301 Lefferts Avenue, Brooklyn, at the age of 62.
A plan of reorganization for the Erie Railroad, which went into bankruptcy on Jan. 18, is in preparation, C. E. Denney, president, said in the annual report issued yesterday.

Red Dutton and his New York Americans left for home this afternoon, but not before the Star-Spangled skaters had given full voice to their dissatisfaction with the ruling made by Referee Clarence Campbell which cost them a goal in their game with the Chicago Black Hawks last night.

Today's major events: Boston Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; PhilharmonicSymphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; Helvetia Maennerchor, Town Hall, evening; Dorothy Gordon, soprano, Town Hall, 3 P. M.

Dr. Herbert von Dirksen, former German Ambassador to Tokyo, has been appointed Ambassador to London to succeed Joachim von Ribbentrop, now Foreign Minister. He will be succeeded in Tokyo by the present military attach, Major Gen. Eugene Ott.

The discussion of international economics by former President Hoover in his speech in New York last night is regarded by Secretary of State Cordell Hull as emphasizing the "profound need for. the program of economic appeasement now carried forward by this government."

The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today to the Los Angeles Stock Exchange the unlisted trading privileges in both round lots and odd lots in ten securities, giving recognition, in its opinion, to the belief that it is in the public interest to maintain local Exchange facilities for local issues and that the additional business obtained would help the smaller exchanges to continue in existence.
Four schools-West Virginia, Catholic University, Idaho and the University of Virginia-furnished two winners each in the semi-finals tonight of the fourth annual national collegiate boxing tournament.

Rain played an April fool joke on contestants in the fifth annual Masters' tournament at the Augusta National Golf Club today. After more than half the field had started on the opening round, play had to be called off because most of the greens were in an unplayable conedition.

Hampered by cold, rain and curtailed employment, retail distribution of Spring goods got off to a slow start this week and dropped 6 to 17 per cent below the corresponding period last year, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, announced yesterday that salaries of all full-time employes of the company earning more than $2,000 a year will be reduced, effective April 11.
An illustrated lecture by Dr. Sigmund Epstein, "Baths and Bathers, Ancient and Modern," will be given this evening at 8:30 o'clock at the Leonardo Da Vinci Art School, 149 East Thirty-fourth Street.
Bette Davis's controversy with the Warners, which reached a critical point last night when she was suspended by .the studio for refusing to appear in "Comet Over Broadway." adapted by Mark Hellinger
Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, will celebrate his seventy-sixth birthday today by playing a game of golf with friends.

Transatlantic shipping and harbor traffic returned to normal yesterday after the dense fog that shrouded the entire city area on Thursday and Thursday night had been dispelled before a freshening breeze.
Frank G. Tallman, vice president of the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., who was widely known as a philanthropist and a collector of Lincolniana, died here today at the age of 87.

More than 100 national leaders in representative fields appealed to President Roosevelt, in a petition made public here last night, to discountenance the forced annexation of Austria by Germany and to make "an affirmative declaration of non-recognition as a diplomatic policy applied to the annexation."
Community Water Service Company and Subsidiaries-For 1937: Net income $61,578 after all expenses and charges, compared with a net of $38,669 in 1936.

Stocks closed from fractions to 3 points higher in reduced trading; turnover, 859,220 shares. Bonds mostly higher, with rails strong but United States Government issues irregularly lower; transactions, $7,936,200.
Thomas M. Halsey, until his retirement. six years ago manager of the safety deposit vaults at the Manufacturers Trust Company branch at 774 Broadway, and a descendant of the Thomas Halsey
Jack Hoerner of Chicago and Alex Welsh of Rockford, Ill., each fired a 71 today to tie for the lead at the end- of the first eighteen holes of the Midwest amateur golf tournament.

The Holy See reaffirmed today that a war admitting no possibility of compronse exists between itself and the Nazis, by printing a notice in the Osservatore Romano, authoritative Vatican organ, announcing to the world that it was without its knowledge or consent that the Austrian Episcopacy had advised Catholic voters in Austria to declare themselves in favor of Anschluss in the plebiscite April 10.
Oklahoma A. and M., national collegiate champion, Franklin and Marshall College and the Baltimore Y. M. C. A. dominated the opening rounds of the National A. A. U. wrestling championships tonight.

In a unanimous decision without an opinion the Appellate Division in Brooklyn ordered yesterday that Scott Sanders, Jamaica attorney, be disbarred from the practice of law on the basis of "ambulance chasing" charges filed against him by the Queens County Bar Association.
An interesting addition to the year's rowing schedule is in prospect with the shaping of plans for a visit of the California crews to Cornell shortly prior to the Poughkeepsie regatta.
George Salley Jones, former vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company in New York, died at his home here today at the age of 66. He had been ill for a month.

Frank (The Bull) Giordano of 2,135 Bolton Avenue, the Bronx, alleged head of a $3,000,000 bootleg ring, three New York City policemen and a Federal alcohol tax unit inspector were among twenty-nine members of the ring found guilty last night of conspiracy to violate the internal revenue tax laws.
Sir John T. Davies, private secretary to Pre- REV. mier David Lloyd George throughout the World War and early reconstruction period, died today at the age of 56.

Chinese reported today that they had killed 3,000 Japanese treops in heavy fighting in Southern Shantung Province. The center of the fighting was said to be the city of Taierhchwang on the Grand Canal, fifteen miles north of the Lung-Hai Railway.

A method that provides a high degree of artificial immunity to animals against cancer-producing chemicals, and thus may open a new approach in the fight against cancer in human beings, was described here today before the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.

Mayor La Guardia consented yesterday to serve as an honorary sponsor of the outdoor exhibition of contemporary American sculpture to be opened under the auspices of the Sculptors Guild, on April 12, the northeast corner of Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street.

Trading generally fair to good. Steer hinds and ribs strong, lamb strong to slightly higher, fresh pork cuts uneven. other classes steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be sharply higher. Other classes steady to strong, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Holdings of United States Government bonds by the Kansas City Southern Railway were reduced from $3,028,091 to $100,000 in 1937, try according to the annual report is- am sued yesterday. Cash declined from $1,281,923 to $14,580. Holdings of United States Government notes were increased from $400,000 to $1,170,381.

On the day before Franklin D. Roosevelt entered the White House in 1933 Congress adopted a Reorganization Bill strikingly similar at many points to the bill which is now being fought so vigorously in the House of Representatives.

The recent liquidation of a group of clergymen on the ground that they were "a gang of Fascist agents" had an interesting sequel today in a remarkable statement by Nikolas Platonoff, until lately Metropolitan of Leningrad, in the so-called Living Church sect, published in the atheist newspaper Bezbozhnik.

Although an upturn in the stock market exerted a steadying influence on cotton trading for several hours yesterday, near months on the Cotton Exchange eased in the last hour to end one point higher to 6 points lower.

Dr. H. Aurelia Gill of Greensboro, N. C., and Dr. Richard B. Nicholls of Norfolk, Va., whose engagement was announced recently, were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Buford Aurelius Gill.
The House Ways and Means Committee bill simplifying tariff regulations was passed by the Senate today with amendments and returned to the House.

Laval The Rev. William E. Simpson, who at until his retirement last Fall was for fifteen years pastor of the Ramapo Reformed Church in Mahwah, died here today at his home, 308 Grove Street, of a heart attack following a short illness. He was 61 years old.

ABORN, ROBERT W. (March 17). Estate, more than $10,000. To Dorcas Aborn Hope, 943 Olive Ave., Coronado, Calif.; Mary Aborn Turner, same address; Georgiana Aborn. 1,151 CGeneva -St.. Glendale, Calif., and Robert H. Aborn, P. O. Box 27, Short Hills. N. J., children, one-sixth residue each:

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Firmness In foreign markets and in securities dominated the action of wheat on the domestic exchanges today and resulted in a slightly higher price level. Closing sales on the Board of Trade here and at Minneapolis showed net gains of 1/2 to 5/3 cent a bushel.

Mrs. Champe S. Andrews gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Frances Jennings Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Carter Hall, and Albert O'Beirne Andrews, son of the hostess, whose marriage will take place today in the First Presbyterian Church.
Additional engagements of gold yesterday for shipment to this country brought to $50,000,000 the amount involved in the present movement, according to figures

In the Supreme Court of the United States today the following proceedings were had: 60--Lincoln Engrg. Co. of Illinois v. Stewart Warner Corp. Motion that the mandate issue forthwith and in the alternative to suspend the injunction or for leave to apply to the District Court to suspend the injunction submitted for the petitioner.
Following are the conclusions and recommendations made in the report proposed for the Federal Communications Commission by Commissioner Paul A. Walker as a result of its telephone investigations
A transaction involving properties in the Bronx and Bronxville, Westchester County, valued at about $1,000,000 was announced yesterday. Scott Stewart bought for investment from Samuel Brener

The proposal of the British Lawn Tennis Association to hold the Davis Cup matches every other year instead of annually has challenged the stern opposition of the United States, the nation which put the trophy in competition in 1900 for a dual competition with England.
Miss Marjorie Moffat Charlock, a student at Stuart Hall, Boston, and a member of an old Elizabeth family, died today at the Elizabeth General Hospital following a long illness.
Associate Justice Cardozo of the Supreme Court was sufficiently recovered today from a serious attack of heart disease to take a twentyminute automobile ride through Rock Creek Park.

During his press conference today, President Roosevelt said that the report made to him recently on the railroad problem by Interstate Commerce Commissioners Splawn, Eastman and Mahaffie would not be made public until after his return to Washington on Sunday.

The Democratic House of Representatives rebelled tonight at efforts to push through the Reorganization Bill by tomorrow night and angrily voted down its own leaders by the large margin of 191 to 149, on a motion to close debate.

This was a distinctly unpleasant day for Burleigh Grimes and his Dodgers. In addition to the minor taster of blowing a game to Casey Stengel's Boston Bees, 12-11, in ten innings, they suffered the calamity at an injury to their star shortstop.

The Studebaker Corporation, automobile manufacturer, announced today that salaries and wages of employes would be cut 10 to 25 per cent, executives in the higher brackets taking the larger reductions.

A $19.750 mortgage on the five-story flat at 531 W 156th St was assigned by the Mortgage Corp of New York, P. E. Bennett, pres, to the B. M. Servicing Corp. Brewster Properties, Inc, assigned to the Monterey Holding Corp two mortgages aggregating $27,100. on 100-108 W 227th St.

Turpentine firm, 24c; sales, 58 barrels, receipts, 440 barrels; shipments, 169 barrels; stock, 23,621 barrels. Resin firm: sales, 243; receipts, 656; shipments. 747; stock, 64,369. Quote: B, $3.50; D, $3.75; E, $3.80; F, G. H, I, K, M, $4.70; N, $5.15; WG, $5.85; WW, X, X,$6.50.

A dinner was given in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador yesterday by Miss Jessie Beadles for Miss Anne Elizabeth Heiss and Carroll A. Boynton, whose marriage will take place in June, Among the other guests
In a coma since he crashed into a tree Sunday while skiing at Pinkham Notch, N. H., Walter Averill 2d, 21, of Poughkeepsie, underwent treatment today at Boston City Hospital.

High School lost its opportunity to play for nineteenth annual Eastern States basketball championship tonight when it bowed to the Vincentian Institute of Albany in the first game of the semi-finals, 24 to 17.

A general strike of coal workers was averted today when employes agreed to maintain present wages pending a magisterial investigation as to whether the financial status of collieries justified a proposed 5 per cent cut ordered for April 3.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Hartman Wagner of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Wagner, to Walter Lee Schwenk of Elizabeth, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Schwenk of Baldwin, L. I.
The Boston Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Dr. Serge Koussevitsky, closed its fifty-second season last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. A capacity audience attended.

Due to restricted loadings with .active shipper demand, fat lambs staged a comeback today, top going to $9, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. A basically weak undertone featured the hog market and the top was forced below $9, this comparing with $9.50 exactly a week earlier. It was a clean up trade In the cattle market, higher prices on steers hardly reflecting the week's dull and unevenly lower trade.

The National Maritime Union, C. I. O. unit of unlicensed merchant seamen, announced yesterday that it had filed charges of unfair labor practices against the Federal Maritime Commission at the local regional offices of the National Labor Relations Board, 233 Broadway.

The New York Police Department Holy Name Society will attend the 8 A. M. mass tomorrow in St. Patrick's Cathedral, receiving annual corporate communion. The Rev. celebrant of the mass will be Cardinal Hayes. The twentieth annual communion breakfast at the Hotel Astor will be attended by more than 5,700 members.

Charles Edwin Dudley, retired actor of the legitimate stage, died today in St. Luke's Hospital at the age of 83. Born in Charleston, S. C., son of Olive and Gilbert Dudley, Mr. Dudley came to this city as a child.

The marriage of Miss Muriel Kerr, pianist, and Naoum Benditzky, cellist, will take place at 12:30 P. M. today at the home of Miss Kerr's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Kerr, 33-28 Eighty-first Street. Jackson Heights. Queens.
Major Gen. John J. Phelan, chairman of the State Athletic Commission, sailed last night on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia for Rome to attend the International Boxing Union conference.

The creation of a permanent trade union committee composed of both A. F. of L. and C. I. O. members to investigate cases of industrial espionage was voted last night by representatives of seventy-three unions operating in New York,

The threatened strike of workers in the live poultry business was averted at least temporarily yesterday when the two unions involved agreed to a thirty-day delay, during which their grievances will be submitted to arbitration.
The State 4 per cent' tax on income of unincorporated businesses is due by April 15, Deputy State Tax Commissioner Cortland A. Wilbur said today.
Carroll Davies of Milwaukee, with a backlog of 743 pins accumulated in the team event last night, added 631 and 570 this afternoon to take second place in the A. B. C. all-events standing.
Three jockeys narrowly escaped serious injury today when three horses fell during the running of the second race at Tropical Park.
Colin Campbell Taylor, actor, director and playwright, who retired twenty years ago, died of pneumonia at his home here yesterday. His age was 74. He came here ten years ago from New York.
Immediate enrollment of 59,000 new members of the Civilian Conservation Corps was ordered today by Robert Fechner, Director of Emergency Conservation Work.

Sir Yeshwant Rao Holkar, the 31-year-old Maharajah of Indore, reputed to be one of the richest men in the world, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, accompanied by a registered nurse, four valets and 100 pieces of baggage.
Mr. Hoover's survey of Europe evidently strengthened the views he held before he left home. The Europe he returned to in 1938 is very different from the war-exhausted continent he left in 1919.

Charley Maloney, '33, has been appointed assistant baseball coach to Samuel Winograd at City College, it was announced yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics. Maloney captained the C. C. N. Y. varsity nine in 1933.

The forty-one. employes of the Marriage License Bureau were destined yesterday to lose their pay as the first result of an action by the Municipal Civil Service Commission designed to take away their jobs, but it was April Fool's Day.

A funeral service for the Rev. Dr. John Floyd Steen, oldest Protestant Episcopal clergyman in the New 1936, York diocese, was held yesterday in St. Ansgarius Chapel of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Week-end shopping gave. added impetus yesterday to the liquor-price war among local retailers and by last night well-known brands of scotch were being offered consumers at 60 cents to $1 below regular prices.
Bartex Realty Company, Inc., has purchased from the Structural Management Corporation the five-story apartment building at 855-57 Broad Avenue, Ridgefield, N. J.

The Eastern racing season began here today before 10,000 persons, with Charlotte Girl, best filly development of the Florida Winter season, demonstrating conclusively that she still is in the first flight.
Governor Lehman today signed the Feld bill which gives to Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, former Police Commissioner of New York City, a $6,000a-year State pension.

Final matches in the Eastern junior and intercollegiate championships tonight and the title round in the Sherman Memorial tournament and the second game of the highgoal championship tomorrow night at Squadron A Armory, Manhattan, offer indoor polo fans an interesting week-end.

Isidore Markowitz of 1,921 Sixtyseventh Street, Brooklyn, one of seventeen contractors on trial with Martin (Buggsy) Goldstein and Seymour Magoon, notorious Brooklyn gangsters, for conspiracy to violate the State labor laws and maintain a $1,500,000 monopoly of painting and decorating work in Brooklyn and Queens public schools, was convicted yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions in Brooklyn.

" Jungles Calling," a graphic history of the photographic explorations by the late Martin Johnson and his wife, Mrs. Osa Johnson, was presented in Carnegie Hall last night by Mrs. Johnson as a memorial to her husband.
Yale's Rugby team, which will be here for Bermuda Rugby Week from April 4-7, played a practice game with the Bermuda Athletic Association today and emerged with a 3-3 tie.

An "entirely new field of study" in the prevention of disease is being opened up by the growing realization of the importance of atmospheric changes to man's physical well being, members of the American Therapeutic Society were told yesterday at the opening of their thirty-ninth annual meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Pamphleteers had a field day today in this political capital of Mayor Frank Hague. For the last ten years, at least, the distribution of political pamphlets on the streets of Jersey City has been banned for all practical purposes under a local ordinance requiring permits.

An exhibition of mosaic pictures, religious and secular, made at the Vatican Studio of Mosaic, Vatican City, will be opened today, under the patronage of Cardinal Hayes, in the quarters of the Catholic Club at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Collapsing on the stage of the Lobero Theatre here during the latter part of the first act of a play tonight, Joseph Greenwald, 60-yearold American actor, died within ten minutes as a capacity audience of Santa Barbara and Montecito residents was dismissed.

Harold E. Wolf, real estate broker, has removed his offices to 420 Lexington Avenue. Samuel Roth, architect, has been retained by George Gottlieb Co. to prepare plans for alterations costing about $35,000 to the two apartment houses at 151-53 and 155

The Senate resolution providing a joint Congressional investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority and of private utilities' alleged interference with TVA affairs was signed today by Speaker Bankhead and Vice President Garner and was sent to President Roosevelt at Warm Springs.
The Right Rev. Joseph J. Rice, Catholic Bishop of Burlington since 1910, died here tonight at the age of 66. He was born in Leister, Mass., the son of Henry J. and Catherine E. Donnelly Rice.
A youthful ensemble consisting of Frank Kneisel, violin; John Alden, 'cello, and Robert Turner, piano, offered a program of trios before a sizable and cordial audience last night at Town Hall.

An interna- wae tional convention "concerning .the use .. broadcasting in the cause of peace" went into force today, the necessary ratification by seven States having been deposited with the League of Nations. The seven are the United Kingdom, France, Denmark, Brazil, Luxembourg, New Zealand and India.
Eight executives of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, whose total years of service amount to 440, an average of 55 each, retired yesterday. Their names, ages and terms of service follow:

Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone took under advisement today motions to reverse the verdict or grant new trials for the sixteen major oil companies and thirty individuals convicted last January of a gasoline price-fixing conspiracy.

Several names were announced yesterday for the new yachts which Sparkman Stephens have designed and several of which will be seen on Long Island Sound early this Summer. A. L. Loomis's twelve-meter will be called Northern Light and E. T. Bedford's "twelve" Nyala. Henry S. Morgan decided to call his six-meter sloop Djinn.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 21 amounted to 572,952 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 32,620 cars,

Joe Louis enjoyed a brisk workout tonight as he successfully defended his heavyweight championship of the world against the challenge of Harry Thomas, Eagle Bend (Minn.) battler, in the Chicago Stadium. The Detroit Negro had little trouble, except for a few brief instances, with his foe and knocked him out with a left hook to the jaw in 2 minutes 50 seconds of the fifth round of a scheduled fifteen-round fight.

Paragraph 3, Special Orders 73, date March 29, 1938, relating to Captain Grover G. Tucker, Inf.-Res., is revoked. The verbal orders of the Commanding General. Second Corps Area, March 10, 1938, revoking Paragraph 4, Special Orders 57, dated March 10, 1938, relating to Captain Grover G. Tucker, Inf.-Rea., are confirmed and made of record.
Most classes of bonds, In company with stocks, rebounded sharply yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, and the trading pace was slacker than recently.

The Aluminum Company of America and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1937 a net income of $27,622,749, compared with $20,866,936 for the preceding year. After dividends on the preferred stock amounting to $17,186,843

The constant arrival of Spanish Loyalist army deserters on the French border at Bagneres-de-Luchon is placing the government in a difficult position with regard to their disposition, particularly in view of the fact that the entire Forty-third Division, included in an estimated 30,000 men, is. cut off in the Nestle Valley and is now reported heading for France.

Mr. and Mrs. Hans S. Rothschild of Green Gables, Port Chester, N. Y., have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Mary Rothschild, to Frederick William Mayer, son of Mrs. J. H. Mayer of Mamaroneck, N. Y. The wedding will take place April 20 at the country home of the prospective bride's parents.
Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Vail Brokaw Jr., who had been at the Waldorf-Astoria, have gone to their country home in Glen Cove for the rest of the Spring and Summer.

The identity of seventy-three baseball players whom he declared free agents after an investigation of the relationship between the Cardinals of the National League and the-Cedar Rapids (Iowa) team was disclosed today by the sport's commissioner, Kenesaw M. Landis.

Leighton P. Slack, first associate justice of the Vermont Supreme Court and former Lieutenant Governor, died today after failing to rally from a heart attack which he suffered yesterday. He was 70 years old.

WITH the cooperation of fifty-nine American piano manufacturers, piano sup ply manufacturers and accessories supply houses, the National Piano Manufacturers Association has just issued a sixty-page report on "consumer investigation" of, naturally, pianos.

A half million Bavarians today cheered Adolf Hitler's appearance in this birthplace of the Nazi movement.
