Speaking in behalf of the plebiscite April 10 on the union of Germany and Austria, the Fuehrer again summed up the achievements of his five years of power, declaring, "The hopes of our enemies of 1918 have been annihilated."

The proposals of the Communist party for the Constitutional Convention, which meets at Albany Tuesday, were sent yesterday to the Secretary of State by Charles Krumbein, State secretary, with a request for transmission to the convention.

William J. Brede, title research director of the New York Title Insurance Company, will address the Nassau County chapter of the American Institute of Banking on Wednesday evening in the court house at Mineola.

Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Sweet Patrice, acknowledged queen of the 2-year-old fillies in training here, raced to her fourth straight victory in the Viscaya Purse, chief juvenile event of the Tropical Park meeting, which had its penultimate Saturday program today.

A three-day institute on social and mental hygiene, designed to link the nursing profession with other agencies active in the preventive program in the same fields, opens tomorrow at 2 P. M. under direction of the New York Counties Registered Nurses Association. Afternoon and evening sessions will be held at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Compared with January, February showed a 6.3 per cent increase in money borrowed from savings, building and loan associations throughout the country, the United States Building and Loan League reports. The February total of $66,501,800, however, was 19.8 per cent behind February a year ago, the league points out.

When the British sovereigns pay a state visit to Paris in June they will be housed on the Qual d'Orsay, and the King will occupy Napoleon's bed, while the Queen will sleep in the bed formerly used by Marie Antoinette.

The National Bankruptcy Conference, which for six years has been steadily whipping an acceptable revision of the Bankruptcy Law into shape, in conjunction with Congress, forms an ideal model for government and business cooperation and might well be adopted for other types of legislation, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, pointed out yesterday.
BERNSTEIN - Mr. and Mrs. Philip 8. (nee Helen Slote), announce the birth of a son, April 1. BROWDER--Mr. and Mrs. Lesley H., announce birth of a son, March 25, 1938, at Polyclinic Hospital.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Eugenia P. Fischer, daughter of Paul M. Fischer of this place and the late Mrs. Fischer, to Alvar B. Sindin, son of Mrs. Carl Sindin of New Bedford, Mass. The wedding will take place in August.

Estrin is a female hormone extracted from the ovary. Two years ago Drs. W. Cramer and E. Horning of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund startled their profession by announcing that estrin could produce cancer in the breasts of mice.

So wrote a man with green eyes and a red beard But he was an English poet welcoming Spring to England. In our somewhat later scheme of development, April showers bring May flowers, and somewhere in the interim even the dweller in the canyons of a great city realizes that Spring is here. .

Joe DiMaggio, hold-out outfielder of the Yankees, was among nearly 40,000 fans who helped usher in the Pacific Coast League baseball season today. He watched his old team, the San Francisco Seals, defeat Portland, 6 to 4. The score by innings:
WHEN the Old Testament is taken solely as literature there is no more dramatic collection of short stories in the world. And the story of Saul, King of Israel, is one of the greatest of them all.

The FHA has issued to its various offices throughout the country amended regulations for its multifamily and group housing program of mortgage insurance, it was announced yesterday. The changes simplify the procedure for handling mortgage insurance applications involving the purchase of these properties.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Sheafe Jr. of New Haven, Conn., formerly of Rye, N. Y., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Molly Sheafe, to Charles Wood Jewett of Lyme, Conn., son of Mrs. Frederick L. Jewett and the late Mr. Jewett.

This city's grip on the Scottish Football Cup, held for the past eight years, has been broken and the lion's share of the credit goes to Jimmy McGrory, who performed before Glasgow crowds for more than a decade.

Definite steps to counteract German economic aggression directed against American export sales in Central and Southern European countries are imperative if these markets, which furnished $121,000,000 in orders last year, are to be retained, Samuel C. Lamport, head of the cotton goods exporting house which bears his name, asserted yesterday.
Climaxing six months of preparation, students of the art department of the College of New Rochelle will present three one-act marionette plays tomorrow evening in the college art building.
APPLEBAUM-FRANK-Announcement is made of the engagement of Muriel Frank, daughter of Mrs. Anna Frank and the late Dr. Austin C. Frank, to Dr. Edmund Applebaum . .
Charley (Red) Ruffing had everything but his earmuffs and mittens today. Arriving here with his fellow-Yankees and a 25 degree drop in temperature, the husky from Nokomis, Ill.,
After twenty years' continuous service in the office of the District Attorney of New York County, James T. Neary, Assistant District Attorney, retired yesterday on a pension.

Miss Muriel Boelsen of Elmhurst, L. I., 13 years old, carried away the major honors at the Wall Street Riding Club's horse show at the Riding and Polo Club yesterday. This young rider scored in the Good Hands and Macelay Trophy events and was the first rider to take both of these contests at a single show this year.

Most important of the field trial meetings for pointers and setters during the Spring season along the Atlantic seaboard is the series of competitions held annually by the English Setter Club of America.

The Jersey City Giants were beaten by the Beaumont Oilers of the Texas League in an exhibition game today, 7 to 6. The Oilers came from behind to win in the closing innings at the expense of Meketi, the second hurler sent to the mound by Manager Travis Jackson.

A three-run attack in the first inning at the expense of Dizzy Dean enabled the Detroit Tigers to defeat the St. Louis Cardinals, 3 to 2, in an exhibition baseball game today. Vernon Kennedy, pitcher, who was acquired from the Chicago White Sox, hurled the opening innings for Detroit and held the Cardinals scoreless.

The bond market again moved upward on a broad front yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Railroad loans took the lead, and established gains of as much as 3 points among the secondary issues.

The opposition of converters, expressed last week, to the proposal of rayon greige goods mills to shorten sales terms to net 30 days, from the net 60 days which has been the general practice, is not likely to change the mills' decision, it was indicated yesterday.
FOR fifty years Dr. William N. Macartney has been practicing medicine in a little town with a population of fewer than a thousand in Northern New York State, half a mile from the Canadian border.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary Elizabeth Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Elmer Brown Jr. of Ventnor, to Caleb Paine, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ernest T. Paine of Laurelwood, Ithaca, N. Y.

The trait of "bossiness" in women usually is associated with economic security and close friendship with the father during a girl's adolescence, according to a report submitted yesterday at the final session of the two-day conference of the Eastern branch of the American Psychological Association.

One of Manhattan's pioneer apartments of the "luxury" type, whose embellished facade and palatial furnishings once attracted many wealthy families as tenants, is being rebuilt in unusual style to meet modern needs.

In the Tennessee Valley last week the slogan was "business as usual." The approximately 11,000 TVA employes pushed ahead with their work, laboring on the dams at Guntersville, at Chickamauga, at Pickwick Landing and on the Hiwassee. In laboratories and in the field men carried on the fertilizer program, the soil-erosion program. In headquarters at Knoxville records were filed, memos written and reports prepared.

Dean John T. Madden of New York University's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance announced yesterday the names of 167 students in the day division of the school who had attained the honor roll for the first semester.

Striking utility workers affiliated with the C. I. O. continued tonight to hold control of all electric power facilities in the Saginaw Valley area of Michigan, with nearly 1,900,000 men, women and children dependent upon the promise of strike leaders that power would not be cut off pending a conference in Detroit Monday.
Stringent regulations to prevent private exploitation of the nation's oil reserves in the Teapot Dome, Elk Hills and other naval oil and helium reserves were issued today by Secretary Ickes.
With a view to forcing the enlistment of foreigners, the Spanish Insurgents are making life intolerable for those living in La Linea and neighboring towns.
ABRAM CHASINS will be soloist Thursday night, Friday and next Sunday, when the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra performs, in revised form, his piano concerto No. 2, in F sharp minor.

While conceding that the post-Easter period will have its difficulties from a merchandising standpoint, retailers here do not believe the drop in dollar volume will exceed 12 per cent or so for May and June.

Miss Margaret Hamilton Rust, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Breckenridge Cabell Rust, will be married to Charles p Leon Schucker on April 16 in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd, Ruxton, near Baltimore.
Two important exhibits were opened tonight at the Four Arts with a preview for members, to which officers of they organization and. of the Florida Federation of Art were hosts.

Rumors in foreign banking and exchange circles that Hankow is flirting with the idea of adopting a scorched earth" financial policy in all Chinese territory captured by the Japanese are being given most serious consideration here.
RETROSPECT: A statesman of France, a man whose long career has been filled with brilliance and sensation, reached 75 last week. The birthday gave Joseph

THE revival of "Otello" at the Opera is in every way a success. The settings are effective in color and design and the cyclorama is judiciously utilized, especially in the setting for the courtyard of Otello's palace, from which you can look far out to sea.

A batch of freshmen came to Cobweb College; the Spider looked them over, frowned and said, "These boys are ghosts of boys, cracked wide with knowledge their dreams dried out and left the dreamers dead.

With George Fissler and Harry Williams each scoring two goals, the New York Athletic Club captured the national senior A. A. U. hard-ball water polo championship for the sixth straight year when it defeated the Illinois A. C. by 5 to 3 last night in the Winged Foot pool.
Cleveland (Tiny) Peterson of the New York Athletic Club tonight retained his 112-pound national A. A. U. wrestling championship by getting a perfect mark under the Olympic scoring system.

For the first time in seventy-five years the sound of the Indian war whoop was heard in Minnesota this past week, but nothing more serious came of the "uprising" than the beating of a superintendent of the agency.

March brought despair and April a rally to the stock market. In the month just completed THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks showed a net loss of 21.66 points, the widest March decline since the compilation was started nearly thirty years ago.

WITH a fine relish for romantic adventure and an easy way with a story, Mr. Murray has warmed our hearts again with the story of Bonnie Prince Charlie. It is an ill-fated story and it has been much sentimentalized, but here its characterization is interesting because it really has character. .

Admissions in the House of Commons in the last few days that cases of sabotage have occurred in connection with airplanes intended for the Royal Air Force have focused public attention on the whole question of pacifist propaganda in this country and alleged activities of foreign spy organizations.

President Alfonso Lopez has transferred Antonio Rocha from the post of Minister of Industries in his Cabinet to Foreign Relations, replacing Dr. Gabriel Tourbay, 'resigned. Gonzalo Restrepo has been changed from Finance to Industries and Nicolas Liinas Vega from Agriculture to Mails and Telegraphs, succeeding Jorge Restrepo Hoyos, resigned.

Indications are that Father Charles E. Coughlin, pastor of the Roman Catholic Shrine of the Little Flower at Royal Oak, has regained much of the following he had before he attempted to organize a third party in 1936 ?? suffered such a bitter defeat that he announced his retirement from the air "forever."

Despite the industrial recession, farm foreclosures in the last quarter of 1937 were fewer by nearly a fourth than in the same period of 1936 and 40 per cent fewer than in the like period of 1934, W. I. Myers, governor of the Farm Credit Administration, estimated today.
With the continued influx of refugees to this country from Germany and Austria, many new problems have arisen in the New York City educational system.

General liquidation developed in American wheat markets today and all deliveries on the Board of Trade here dropped to new low levels for the season, with the July selling at 80 1/3 cents a bushel at the extreme, a figure that had not been equaled previously by any future since July, 1935.

WARRENTON, Va.-Plans are being completed for the racing season here. The outstanding Spring event will be the seventeenth annual Virginia Gold Cup Race meeting, which will be called at 2:30 P. M. on Saturday, May 7, on the Broadview course, one mile from Warrenton.

Women may be skilled in the art of preparing a meal, but a man's apploval of a fancy recipe constitutes the proof of the pudding, according to Georgian Court College students. This week, with the dedication of a new foods laboratory costing $2,500. undergraduates decided to conduct a survey as to whether the expenditure was justified.

NEXT Friday evening there will be a big gathering of Americans of Swedish blood in Philadelphia and lesser gatherings in scores of other American cities and towns. Professors and scientists and writers and engineers will be there, and farmers and lumbermen and merchants and bankers, representatives of nearly 2,000,000 Americans of direct Swedish descent and other millions who have the Swedish strain.

John T. Hunt, 28 years old, licensed private pilot and aeronautical engineer, of 1,249 Simpson Street, the Bronx, was killed instantly today when the monoplane he had rented crashed near Mitchel Field. The plane hit about 100 feet north of Stewart Avenue in a vacant field. It was demolished.

WITH Mozart's Symphony No. 25, in G minor (K. 183), Alfred Wallenstein and his Sinfonietta make their first appearance on records. From inquiries received by this department it is to be gathered that the debut has been unduly postponed.

The death of Rear Admiral Norman Jerome Blackwood, distinguished in naval and medical circles, became known here today. He was 72 years old. He died yesterday at the Cottage Hospital, of which he became superintendent only three months ago.
Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas G. Rutgers gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Alice Noel, the party going later to the Metropolitan Dance at the Ritz-Carlton.

Rollins College eight-oared crews made a clean sweep today of races with Washington and Lee University and Marietta College. The Rollins varsity Blues, including six veterans, rowed the nine-tenths of a mile course on Lake Maitland in 4 minutes 48 seconds to beat the Ohio oarsmen by three-quarters of a length.

Settlement of the ten-day strike in aviation and metallurgical plants ran into a snag tonight when the management of the Citroen Automobile Factory refused to accept government arbitration on the strikers' demands.

Approach of Easter brought some seasonal increase in the volume of trade over the nation, but in some areas the improvement was disappointing, and for the country as a whole volume was still well under that of 1937.

Bungalow rentals at Manhattan Beach during the first three months of this year rose 40 per cent, when compared with those of the same period last year, the management of Manhattan Beach Baths announces. About 75 per cent of the 1938 occupants, it is stated, will be professional people.

New officers of the West of Central Park Association were elected at its seventeenth annual meeting last week. Edward B. Bell, general manager of the Empire Hotel, was elected president; Walter LaM. Sparry of Wood, Dolson Company, and Fred A. Burdett were elected vice presidents. Andrew B. Rose, treasurer,

NOW in the first few weeks of Spring the office worker can get home after the day's work to find the sun still above the horizon. Yet for a little while the trees will still be bare of leaves. It is an ideal season for the amateur photographer's first experiments with silhouettes.

Faced with the necessity of finding out just where France stands in this new Europe that has been created by Germany's tearing up of the old map as it was established by the Versailles treaty and the League of Nations Covenant, Foreign Minister Joseph Paul-Boncour has been holding a series of conferences with French Ambassadors and with Ambassadors of other countries.

With the trains of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus due to arrive tonight at Jersey City, plans were completed yesterday for a memorial performance for Dexter Fellows at the opening of the circus season on Friday night at Madison Square Garden.

On his way back to the capital after a ten-day vacation President Roosevelt was mapping with Administration officials aboard his special train tonight legislative proposals regarding anti-monopoly procedure and further appropriation for relief.

Mr. and Mrs. Boyden Sparkes of New York and Wilmington, N. C., have announced the prospective marriage of their daughter, Miss Betty Led-ford Sparkes, to Joseph Colin Eagles Jr., son of State Senator and Mrs. J. C. Eagles of Wilson.
WE are happy to inform the public that there is now on foot a movement to locate the exact spot in Brooklyn where Sigrid Gurie, the Norwegian glamour girl, was born.
Edwin O. Schildberg of Chicago played par golf today to card 143 and take a one-stroke lead in the second round of the Midwest amateur tournament. He scored 71 on the valley course.
Dr. Johannes Baptist Dietz, Catholic co-Bishop of Fulda, today issued a formal appeal to his diocese to support the union of Austria and Germany in the April 10 plebiscite. The appeal follows:

LONDON.-The Home Office has just issued a new pamphlet, of which half a million copies already have been distributed. In the next few months millions more will be printed. This booklet is to go into every home in the British Isles. It is titled "The Protection of Your Home Against Air Raids" and at the bottom of the cover is the admonition, "Read this book through, then keep it carefully."

Evidences of improving conditions in the real estate field in and around Philadelphia are indicated in the recent report of the public relations committee of the Federal Savings and Loan Association of the Philadelphia district on the business done by those associations in January and February, this year.

Offers of compromise today by a chastened House leadership stemmed the threat of revolt which flared up last night when a majority of the members refused to vote to stop debate on the Reorganization Bill.

A field of nearly one hundred members of North Shore society met this morning at the West Hills race course, on the estate of Colonel and Mrs. Henry L. Stimson, near Woodbury, for one of the thrice-weekly fox hunts that,
Major candidates in Pennsylvania's bitter primary campaigns among Democrats and Republicans stuck to their guns today as the hour passed for withdrawing nominating petitions.
THIS book is more than the biography of a fiery popular tribune; it is the history of a class and to a great extent of a section. Both as a biography and as a history it is a tragic

On the eve of the New York State Constitutional Convention which will meet in Albany this week, citizens interested in education are being encouraged to discuss possible amendments of provisions in the Constitution relating to the system of public schools.
IT took the authorities nearly eight years to reach even an unofficial agreement on the proper bidding system for contract bridge.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and six affiliated companies appealed to the Supreme Court today from a Federal Circuit Court decision that they were subject to the National Labor Relations Act.

Contention that the educational process should be unified and coordinated "from the kindergarten to the university" were attacked today by Dr. Thomas S. Gates, president of the University Of Pennsylvania.

The Dramatics Department of Swarthmore College has instituted a laboratory method of instruction for members of the undergraduate body who aspire to become actors, producers, playwrights and directors.
PARIS. - European Chancelleries may be disturbed by current claims to colonies, but that is only half the story. Travelers returning from Togo and Cameroon, for instance, tell the other half.

In a tribute to the late Gabriel d'Annunzio, poet-soldier of Italy, the Dante Allghieri Society of New York presented last night one of his plays. "Light Under the Bushel," at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. More than 1,500 persons were present.

The recent decline of the stock market (which the upward movement Friday and yesterday failed to equalize) followed upon the slightly more favorable business signs of recent weeks; those signs continue. Do they forecast a real upturn or only a false recovery, to be followed by a new slump?

Two of the divisions of play in the indoor polo championships came to a close at Squadron A Armory last night, with intercollegiate and Eastern junior titles being decided in final matches that furnished the most exciting polo the season has seen.

A satirical musical revue entitled "In the Groove," which is to be presented for three performances on April 21, 22 and 23 at the Pauline Edwards Theatre of the City College School of Business and Civic Administration, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, will be the annual Spring production of the Dramatic Society at the college.

Mrs. H. Edward Manville is chairman of the patronesses for the annual Pleasantville Musical Festival to be held at the school here next Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. Frederick F. Quinlan is director of the festival.

Mr. and Mrs. Eugene A. Brillinger of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Brillinger, to Derrick A. Sherman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond D. Sherman, also of Flushing.

Chinese culture and higher education have been forced to seek refuge in the comparative peace and safety of this province, Yunnan, where more than two-thirds of the scattered population of 12,000,000 is composed of aboriginal tribesmen, who are virtually without culture of any sort.

Rising before the Chicago Neurological Society Dr. Theodore J. Case of the University of Chicago reported recently that the electrical waves given off by the brain can be used to "detect tumors and scars in the brain.

About two months after the Spanish civil war broke out in July, 1936, there met in London the Non-Intervention Committee on Spain, composed of delegates from twenty-seven nations. Its function came to be not so much to prevent international intervention in Spain as to prevent international war over Spain.

The Department of Parks announced yesterday that the first minimum speed regulation on a parkway in the city became effective at 8 A. M. yesterday on the Grand Central Parkway extension, between Northern Boulevard and Horace Harding Boulevard, in Queens.

Overdue payroll taxes have been "pouring" into the State Unemployment Insurance Fund since the fining of a delinquent employer last Thursday in Magistrates' Court, it was reported yesterday by Assistant Attorney General Isidore Lazarus.
MAY I point out certain respects in which Mr. Elliott Bell's review of my book, "The Promises Men Live By." is correctible?
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-The Palm Sunday "Preview" of the Easter parade will compete with a variety of other events' for the attention of visitors here for the coming week.

The title "Tsung Tsai" [leader], together with, virtual dictatorial powers in the Kuomintang [Nationalist party], was bestowed on Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek by the Extraordinary National Congress of the Kuomintang, which concluded its sessions early this morning.

Active promotion of early Summer merchandise immediately after Easter offers retail merchants an opportunity to avert or reduce the sharp let-down in volume which normally follows the Easter selling period, Thomas C. Cooper, general manager and director of Butler Brothers, dry goods and general merchandise wholesalers, said yesterday.

The barracks at Woellersdorf concentration camp, where for the last five years thousands of Nazis, Socialists and Communists were interned, were solemnly burned today in the course of a manifestation organized by the National Socialist party in memory of comrades who passed through the camp.

Dramatic results from use of a new synthetic male sex hormone that is as effective for undeveloped boys as it is in the postponement of senescence were reported yesterday by Dr. Henry H. Turner of Oklahoma City, at the thirty-ninth annual meeting of the American Therapeutic Society at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

True to the best Rose Hill traditions, Fordham opened it 1938 baseball campaign with a victory yesterday. Behind Art Sattler's masterful hurling Coach Jack Coffey's seventeenth edition of Rams defeated St. Peter's College of Jersey City, 8 to 2, in the damp and frigid setting of Fordham Field.

Reports that a British aircraft factory now being built near Liverpool is to be one of the largest in the world with a daily production capacity of about forty planes have been received here, it was learned yesterday.
" Around the World in New York" was the subject of the costume-song recital given yesterday afternoon at Town Hall by Dorothy Gordon, long a specialist in the field of child entertainment.

TODAY'S schedule of recitals consists entirely of events outside the Broadway area, a fact which makes doubly clear that Spring is here. Eduard Du Buron, dancer from Boston, will give his first performance here this afternoon in the Dance Theatre series at the Y. M. H. A. .

Artur Rodzinski, conductor of the Cleveland Symphony Orchestra, who selected the personnel of the NBC Symphony Orchestra and whipped it Into a functioning organization, returned to Radio City to direct last night's weekly broadcast.

THE fortieth anniversary of the death of Anton Seidl, the celebrated conductor, will be commemorated at Columbia University with an exhibition of books, manuscripts and music from the Seidl collection.

Production of shoes for the first quarter of this year were estimated in the trade yesterday at approximately 87,000,000 pairs, which, although showing a decrease of 28.4 per cent from the corresponding period last year, was higher than earlier expectations.

THE coin collector can cover almost all history in the field of his chosen hobby--and yet it isn't necessarily the old coins that are the most valuable. You can buy a 2,000-year-old Roman coin for 50 cents, but "an uncirculated Lincoln-head 1914 D cent is valued as high as $5." On the other hand,

Mrs. Rae Schwid Tobenkin, wife of Elias Tobenkin, writer and a member of the staff of the North American Newspaper Alliance, died yesterday at Israel Zion Hospital, Brooklyn, after an illness of nine months. She was 48 years old,

The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Newton Cromwell Fetter of Cambridge, Mass., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Katherine Fetter, to Kenneth William Bergen, son of Mrs. Edward B. Bergen of Harlingen, N. J., and the late Mr. Bergen.
A large dinner will be given tomorrow evening at the Apawamis Club preceding the appearance of Cornelia Otis Skinner.

Announcement has been made to friends here by Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. Northrop of Belmont, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Northrop, to William Lovejoy Shannon, son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Shannon of Seattle, Wash.

Now fully convinced that the recession will take too long a time to cure itself, the Administration for safety's sake-political and economic-is preparing a set of stimulants and remedies. These and their details will soon be made known. They will amount to a tacit acknowledgment that the theory the business slump would soon correct itself was wrong. .
Mrs. Mary Morley Williams, widow of Joseph M. Williams, a wellknown New York lawyer, died today in the Homeopathic Hospital, East Orange, at the age of 88. She had been ill for a week.

Senator Wagner, a member of the Interstate Commerce Committee, indicated today his approval of the suggestion of Commissioner Walker of the Federal Communications Commission, that supervisory power over the operations of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company be entrusted to the FCC.

The engagement of Miss Emeroy Vilas Burton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Brown Burton of the Little House, this place, and of Chazy, N. Y., to Donald Lord Bartlett Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bartlett of New Britain, has been announced by her parents.

Thirteen years ago in Jerusalem the Hebrew University was launched. It was financed entirely by voluntary contributions. Its funds at the outset were meager, and its strongest asset was a faith in its future. .

Miss Marion McKean of Beverly, Mass., a member of the International Skiing Federation team, today won the women's Eastern downhill ski championship with a fast run on the hazardous wildcat trail at Pinkham Notch.

THE much-heralded "unknown" violin concerto of Robert Schumann has been played here at a B. B. C. concert and, lest anything should have escaped the listener at the first hearing, broadcast again a few days later.

Nationalist [Insurgent] troops commanded by General Garcia Valino and incorporating two mixed Spanish and Italian divisions, today occupied Gandesa, twenty-one miles northeast of Tortosa, where the Ebro River flows into the Mediterranean.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 1: BRIGADIER GENERAL Rowell, F. W., appointed as major general. COLONELS Truesdell, K., lnf., appointed as brigadier general.

Miss May N. Karff of Boston, who represented Palestine in the last world's women's championship tournament at Stockholm, was the first victor in the second championship congress of the National Chess Federation yesterday.
Fire of undetermined origin early today razed the No. 1 hangar at the Municipal Airport, destroyed fourteen planes and caused loss estimated at $700,000.

ALL this month work by nearly two score artists associated with the Rehn Galleries will be on view in the group exhibition entitled "Spring 1938." Almost all the pictures are being shown for the first time and most of them are characteristic of the artists exhibiting.

The college fencing season will close officially with the annual intercollegiate meet at William and Mary College, Williamsburg, Va., Friday and Saturday. The Women's Intercollegiate Fencing Association, which sponsors this championship,

Infuriated over the defeat thrust upon them in Chicago on Thursday night, the New York Americans returned yesterday determined to win their deciding National Hockey League semi-final round battle with the Black Hawks in Madison Square Garden tonight.
The city's plan to turn Eighth and Ninth Avenues into one-way thoroughfares as a traffic experiment is opposed by the West Side Taxpayers Association.

Three boys, who sought with two companions to traverse the swift currents of the Harlem River Ship Canal in a rowboat, were listed by the police as missing and probably drowned last night after their craft had sunk near 220th Street.

In Harlem, in the underprivileged neighborhoods of Brooklyn and in other parts of the city where poverty is the partner of illiteracy 2,000 foreign-born New Yorkers who have yet to become citizens are today learning English, American history and culture in small classes held in their own homes.

Standardization of can sizes through legislation will probably not be achieved during the present session of Congress, executives in the field indicated here yesterday. Congressional hearings on a bill to standardize tin can sizes will not be reopened immediately and, accordingly, the present bill, H. R. 6964, probably will not be passed at this session of Congress, it was said.
The fifth anniversary of the re-legalization of the sale of beer will be observed on Tuesday by brewers and others who benefited from the revival of the brewing industry.

The marriage of Miss Nancy Nightingale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Nightingale of 227 East Eighty-third Street, to Eugene Deffaa, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Deffaa also of this city, took place yesterday afternoon in the Phillips Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

School building construction in State municipalities of less than 50,000 population jumped more than $20,000,000 since last July 1 over the preceding twelve months, the State Education Department said today.

Eleven firemen were injured today in checking a fire which destroyed a building housing the Thomas C. Mee Hardware Store and a Chinese restaurant. Fire department officials said the damage probably would be more than $100,000.

THE first of six Sunday afternoon radio symphony concerts under the auspices of the Federal Music Project will be on the air today through WNYC, with Willem van Hoogstraten, for sixteen years conductor of the Philharmonic Stadium concerts, directing.
The annual New York University Varsity Show, which this year has been titled "That's Life," will be held on April 20 at the Royal Windsor Palace, 69 West Sixty sixth Street.
Supreme Court Justices turned their attention today to the question whether William Heller of Easton, Conn., has a right to bathe in a brook on his thirty-eight-acre property.
The Panama Pacific Line has proceeded with its plans for withdrawal from the intercoastal service by discharging about twenty members of its shore personnel, it was learned yesterday.

Breaking 98 out of 100, Tracy H. Lewis, a Class A gunner, won the high-over-all cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. Lewis also scored on the doubles scratch and handicap prizes with 30 straight and dominated the 155-target shot with a total of 150.
A total of $85,000 had been raised at noon yesterday in the 1938 Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army, it was reported by Robert E. Strawbridge Jr., chairman of the campaign. The goal is $600,000.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William B. Falconer of Brooklyn and Westhampton Beach of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Falconer, to George Cook 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Cook Jr. of Brooklyn and Scarsdale.
A habeas corpus petition seeking the release of Al Capone from Alcatraz Prison was filed today in the United States. District Court.

Trinity College has received a grant of $5,000 a year for two years from the Carnegie Corporation of New York for further experimentation and study of a course in linguistics, which was started here in 1936.

More than 500 faculty members and alumni of New York University's Washington Square College at Washington Square East, gathered at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel last night to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the school.

Germany's advancement in Central Europe appeared today as the topic likely to dominate the twelfth Annual Assembly of the Model League of Nations, Middle Atlantic Division, meeting at Rutgers University next Thursday, Friday and Saturday.
France, last stronghold of democracy in Continental Europe, is on the brink of profound changes which can affect the whole course of history now being made at a dizzy pace throughout the world.

Miss Ann Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roland Gerry Brown of this city, was married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas to Charles Putman Pruyn Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Pruyn of New York and Chicago.
The arrival late on Friday of $2,638,000 gold from abroad, including $1,620,000 from England and $1,018,000 from India, was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Professor Sirarpie Der Nersessian, chairman of the department of art at Wellesley College and a world authority on Byzantine art, has just received the Prix Fould, awarded biennially by the Institut de France to the author of the best book on the history of art.
Soviet Russia, having explored the Far North from its ice floes and skies, disclosed plans today to send scientists into its depths.

ELEVEN O'CLOCK in the morning. It seems so simple: Walk that narrow gangplank under the faded striped awning, and those few strides bridge the difference between Manhattan and what is coming to us-France, Holland, Italy, the Far East, Australia and through the South Seas of romantic reputation, back to Uncle Sam's solid soil. The very implications of that first half-dozen steps are a little disturbing. .

ALREADY published by Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings are two novels and innumerable short stories about the isolated, backwoods people who live in the wild heart of the farflung Florida scrub. Her name is identified with the region.

Leaders of religious, civic and social groups in Harlem agreed yesterday to promote further agitation for the passage of the Anti-Lynching Bill, which was sidetracked by the United States Senate earlier in this session after it had been passed by the House of Representatives.
Manhattan College opened its 1938 baseball season yesterday afternoon by tying Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, 4--4, in a contest that went seven innings. game was called because of darkness.

The strong Stuyvesant High School fencing team, which clinched the team championship in Division 1 of the P. S. A. L. last week, completed the round-robin tournament without the loss of a match by defeating Richmond Hill, 10-2, on the strips of the Washington Irving High School yesterday morning.

PROFESSOR BRIDGMAN aims to reach the mind of "the intelligent individual" in general by a thoroughly frank exposure of the state of his own mind and of the processes by which the state of his own mind was generated.

Having finished on the wrong end of a 2-1 count in last week's battle, the St. Mary's Celtics set out yesterday to erase that deficit in the second and final game of the total-goal series against the New York Americans.

CAIRO.-Dogs living in Moslem countries may have reason to be grateful for the Fetwa (a ruling on the interpretation of Moslem religious law) which has been issued by authorities of the University of Al Azhar in response to queries from an Indian Prince who asked:
With an even more overwhelming victory than it scored yesterday and Thursday, when Upper Egypt went to the polls, the government today won the Parliamentary elections in Lower Egypt and the Delta.
There is less support for a third term for President Roosevelt among rank and file voters today than at any time since his re-election in 1936.

Thirty-four seniors in the Simmons College School of English have been released this Spring from their regular assignments in the publishing course to undertake projects in which they will utilize their training in graphic arts design, editing, writing and other publishing and advertising techniques.

The great growth of air mail service was pictured last night by Postmaster General James A. Farley in a radio speech preliminary to the celebration by the Postoffice Department of the twentieth anniversary of the start of air mail service by National Air Mail Week, May 15-21. Mr. Farley spoke over the Columbia broadcasting company network.

Mrs. Alice White Hawthorne, widow of Bayard Hawthorne, New York insurance broker, died here yesterday at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Robert P. Jutson. Mrs. Hawthorne, who was 68 years old, lived at the Madison Square Hotel in New York and owned an estate at Milford, Pa.
The Blue Hill Troupe, a widely known company of amateur players, is planning another benefit Spring production of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas.

Talbot Jones Taylor, former New York stock broker, died Friday night of pneumonia at his home in Nice, France, it was learned yesterday by a son, Foxhall Keene Taylor of New York. The retired broker, who until several years ago headed the firm bearing his name, was 72 years old.

A proposal for a more business-like government financial balance sheet, which would list fixed assets as offsets to the national debt and paint the government's fiscal picture in more favorable colors, is reported to be regarded with interest by President Roosevelt. There is said to be considerable sentiment for it in Administration quarters.

Expressing his views on the present method under which hearings on overassessments are held before the Tax Department, A. N. Gitterman, managing director of the Realty Advisory Service, at a recent meeting of the Long Island Real Estate Board, advanced a plan whereby such practice could be eliminated.

Having voted the undistributedprofits tax out of the House Revenue Bill, it is quite natural that the Senate Finance Committee would seek to strengthen the present surtax upon unreasonable accumulations of surplus.

THERE will be many changes in the Austrian musical world, aside from the loss of Toscaninl and Bruno Walter to Vienna and Salzburg. Josef Krips and Carl Alwin were dismissed as soon as the Nazi party took control of the State Opera.

PRELIMINARY sessions of the Music Education League's series of auditions, in which students have received criticism only, closed last week. Borough sessions where participants will receive their first rating of the season will be held at Steinway Hall as follows:

Rededicating themselves to a policy of pacifism and "conscientious objection," the Religious Society of Friends yesterday adopted resolutions along those lines, following the report of the Quakers Peace and Social Order Committee, which was read at the 243d session of the New York yearly meeting.

More than 80,000 visitors attended the third annual New Jersey National Home Show, held in the Sussex Avenue Armory, Newark, during the week of March 19 to 26, reports Samuel D. Walker of Keansburg, general chairman.

The South is the most favored part of the country for folksong material because its people have been least affected by industrial civilization, Dr. George Herzog ,of Columbia University said in an address today before the Southeastern Folklore Society at the University of North Carolina.

Al Davis, 131 1/2, Brownsville, scored his twenty-first straight victory last night when he defeated Jack Sharkey Jr., 134 1/2, Union City, in the feature six-round bout before 5,000 at the Ridgewood Grove.

The Hamburg-American liner New York will return today from an eight-day cruise to Nassau and Havana. Passengers are former Governor Joseph B. Ely of Massachusetts; Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich, wife of the banker, accompanied by Alexander, Lucy and Elizabeth Aldrich;

One of the few bright spots in the French outlook on the swift Germanization of Central Europe has been, in these past weeks, the fact that Alsace has not shown any signs of succumbing to the siren strains of Josef Goebbels's Nazi propaganda.

Approval of several measures passed in the recent session of the State Legislature is expressed by the committee of housing of the Charity Organization Society. Those approved are the Demolition Bill, the Minkoff bill, the bills containing Governor Lehman's three constitutional amendments,

Dr. Rafael Santos Jiminez took over the portfolio of Secretary of the Interior this afternoon to replace Colonel Emiliano Amiel. Although reports had been circulated concerning a Cabinet shake-up after Colonel Rafael Montalvo had resigned as Secretary of National Defense several days ago, no official announcement of Colonel Amiel's resignation was made.

Drs. Henry G. Barbour, Edgar Allen, W. U. Gardner, L. C. Strong, James B. Hamilton, Arthur Kirschbaum and Paul H. Barbour Jr., all of Yale, announce in The American Journal of Cancer that when cancerous mice drink heavy water their tumors do not grow at the normal

Three one-act plays will be presented on Wednesday and Thursday evenings at the Lighthouse Little Theatre, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, by the Lighthouse Players, a group of six young blind women secretaries, as the twelfth Spring benefit conducted by the group.

Theo De Luca, 8 years old, of 29 Park Place, Brooklyn, died of a fractured skull and other injuries at 4 P. M. yesterday in Methodist Episcopal Hospital, Brooklyn, an hour after he had been struck by an automobile driven by Mrs. Rose Solomon of 9 Prospect Park West, according to the police.
At the request of the board of trustees of the Margate Trust Company of Margate City, Louis A. Reilly, State Banking Commissioner, today took over the institution, it was announced here.

The Democratic primary, to be held on April 12, has developed into a seemingly implacable conflict between the Governor of Illinois and the Mayor of Chicago, neither of whom is a candidate, but each of whom has espoused a ticket for nomination.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity advanced to 80.1 for the week ended March 26. This compares with 79.3 (revised) for the previous week and 106.6 for the corresponding week last year.

Early action is expected on a proposal of Governor Blanton Winship of Puerto Rico requesting funds from the insular Legislature for a new survey of the island's economic and social conditions by the Brookings Institution, it was announced yesterday by the Puerto Rican Trade Council.

The average price of real estate bonds declined 4.6 per cent in the first quarter of 1938, according to the Amott-Baker realty bond price averages, covering 200 selected issues of properties in New York, Buffalo, Boston, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and other Eastern cities.

The American Federation of Labor, through its council and William Green, president, strongly advised its officials and members today to withdraw all support from Labor's Non-Partisan League and to set up their own Non-partisan political committees to work for candidates in the coming elections pledged to policies advocated by the federation.
Walter E. O'Hara's apology to Governor Robert E. Quinn may or may not end his power in Rhode Island. He is "down," but he has a knack of coming back.

To the Drama Editor: I have just had a magnificent flop on Broadway. The critics, with beautiful unanimity, condemned "Censored" as a lousy show. I am in complete agreement with them: it was a lousy show, a terrible show, a show to make one despair of the theatre.

Sales of floor coverings in retail stores last month were down 10 to 20 per cent, reports reaching mill executives here yesterday indicated. In some districts of the South the disparity between March sales this year and those of the corresponding month in' 1937 was slight, but such localities were exceptions.

Debutantes of the season in this city have organized a committee under the direction of Miss Barbara Winlock and Miss Margaret Mabon to assist the Harvard University undergraduates in plans for the New York presentation of the Hasty Pudding Club show,

Sleet, rain and snow flurries struck the city a little before noon yesterday, coming in from the sea and moving up the Hudson Valley. The precipitation lasted about ten minutes in each sector. The Newark Airport also reported snow.

Push-downs mingled with knockdowns and plenty of laughs today when the Naval Academy's big little junior boxers-ages 2 to 14 years-battled through the forty bouts of their ninteenth annual championship tournament.

With the Assembly Hall on the seventh floor of the R. C. A. Building, Rockefeller Center, crowded with several hundred enthusiasts representative of the leading chess centers throughout the metropolitan area, the second biennial congress of the National Chess Federation was opened yesterday.

Plans have been put under way by Temple University for the building of a completely equipped experimental laboratory on the campus of the Stella Elkins Tyler School of Fine Arts, where students next year may grind their own paints, make their own canvases and varnishes and test for quality the commercial brands of artists' materials now on the market.
Penniless, all but forgotten, George Melies, the father of the story film, died at 76 in a pension for indigent actors near Paris on Jan. 21.
George Buchanan was remanded to jail today after a police court hearing on a charge of having written a letter in which he threatened to "shoot an American Ambassador."

A fund of $140,952,766 would be provided for the exchange of students between the United States and Europe if the proposal by former President Hoover, in his speech Thursday night at New York, were adopted, some officials said today.
Rugged fighters from the universities of Virginia and West Virginia captured four of eight individual titles in rousing finals of the fourth annual national collegiate boxing tournament tonight.

Based on the growing conception of education on a broad inter-departmental basis, the four-year sequence in Spanish-American relations, introduced in Syracuse University last Fall, has created wide interest among educators and interested business men.
The Boston Symphony Orchestra, Dr. Serge Koussevitzky conductor, closed its New York season of 193738 yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, and this in a memorable way.

The Maritime Commission announced today it would allow increased rates on cotton, grain and grain products, and bags and bagging between Gulf and North Atlantic ports, the schedule to become effective on Monday.

A FLURRY of excitement broke out on the night club front the past few days, the bonifaces, proprietors, genial hosts and maitre de joints greeting Spring with stuff generally above the bistro-cabaret-supper club-retreat-oasis norm.
Haruko Ichikawa, the novelist, is of the opinion the United States is a "woman's country" and it is "too bad to be an American man."

Miss Virginia Holden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell John Holden of this place, was married to Henry Keep Jr. son of Colonel and Mrs. Henry Keep of Elizabeth, today in Trinity Episcopal Church here.
If Europe is to maintain its world leadership it cannot allow itself to be divided into two camps, said Andre Siegfried, noted economist and historian, in a lecture here today.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. E. Hoban of Forest Hills, Queens, and Daytona Beach, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence Kendrick Hoban, to George Neall Bartlett, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. George G. Bartlett of Mount Airy, Philadelphia.

After scrupulously completing the routine duties of his command, Police Captain Charles R. Lewis, In charge of the Mercer Street station, retired to his office opposite the main desk of the station house at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, threw himself on his bed and shot and killed himself.

Criticism of Bronx detectives for arresting sleepers in subway and elevated terminals was expressed yesterday from the bench of Bronx Felony Court by Magistrate Bernard Mogilesky, who said the police might better be chasing criminals.

The situation in Czechoslovakia is already rendered precarious by the German-Austrian Anschluss, which puts this last Central European democracy at the mercy of National Socialist Germany strategically and economically.

Italy's air force intends to stage "the greatest aerial display ever seen" for the benefit of Chancellor Adolf Hitler when he visits Premier Benito Mussolini in May. Officials said the exhibition would be "essentially warlike."

Fully recovered from the injury which shackled him during most of the indoor campaign, Archie San Romani of the New York Curb Exchange ran one of the finest miles in his brilliant career last night to provide the feature of the indoor track meet at the 369th Regiment Armory.
With unanimity indicating a common inspiration. the press announces the Japanese Navy must re-examine its building plans following the British-American decision to escalate.

Announcement has been made By Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Dukes Blyth of Dongan Hills, S. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beatrice Hamilton Blyth, to John Wesley Mayhew Whiting, son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnson Whiting of West Tisbury, Martha's Vineyard.
MARIETTA is ready and waiting for the arrival of the "Pioneers," the band of young men re-enacting the 1788 trek from New England which opened up the whole Ohio country for settlement.

Johns Hopkins' powerful lacrosse team made a brilliant start on its 1938 schedule yesterday when it defeated a veteran City College ten, 13--4, at Lewisohn Stadium. The game, which also marked the first appearance this season for the Lavender,

MEETING after meeting is held in an effort to solve the riddle of radio's role in education. Each parley usually adjourns with a motion for the participants to go home from the discussion to think things over.

Dr. Horace Asa Day, president of the Orange County Medical Society, stated today that laboratory experiments had proved that tetanus toxin was present in two vials selected at random from a shipment of cancer serum received here by Dr. T. A. Neal, ten of whose patients had died in four days.

A roll-call of all Germans staying in Great Britain longer than three months is being made by the German Embassy under the German registration act of Feb. 3, which has been extended to include all former Austrian nationals.

The unusual relations of Colonel House with President Wilson came strongly back to every one's mind with last Monday's news of House's death. Possibly, now that both are dead, some hitherto obscure questions regarding that relationship may be cleared up.

Although the State Legislature at its recent session failed to approve the plan for establishment of a State system of mortgage banks, the proposal will be kept alive and the same or a similar bill will be presented at the next session,

The "Billy," her sides coated with yellow river mud, waited today to carry A. O. Engel, 58 years old, former ship carpenter, on his voyage down the Mississippi to a little "outin' place" in the deep South.

ROB ROY PEERY, Merion, Pa., and Louis Scarmolin, Union City, N. J., were the prize winners in the nation-wide contest for an original song for the dedication of the Benjamin Franklin Memorial in Philadelphia, May 19-21.

First United States visitors to reach Quebec City by automobile this year arrived yesterday from New Jersey. Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Kennedy and William Munday drove their car over South Shore roads and reported finding snowbanks on the highway at several points.

Dr. Willis Alonzo Dewey, retired Vermont physician, died late ??ast night at the Plaza Hotel here. A native of Middlebury, Vt., and well known as an expert on mental and nervous disorders, Dr. Dewey retired in 1922. His age was 79.

The marriage of Miss Catherine Lydia Robbins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis L. Robbins of Newton, Iowa, to James H. Snowden 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Snowden of East Orange, took place this afternoon in Arlington Avenue Presbyterian Church here.

The engagement of Miss Mary Hope Fedden, daughter of Mrs. John H. Fedden of this place and the late Mr. Fedden, to Arthur Davies Wingebach, son of Mr. and Mrs. August Wingebach, also of Bronxville, has been announced by her mother.

THERE is only one presentation copy of the First Folio of Shakespeare known. It was presented, not by the author, who had been dead for seven years, but by the printer. Nor is that strictly accurate either, for the man who printed it and thereby sent his own name down to posterity, William Jaggard, had died just before the book was published.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Barth of Forest Hills, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Winnogene Kathryn Barth, to John Henry Treiber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Treiber of Kew Gardens, L. I.

The Seventy-first Infantry Regiment, New York National Guard, marched in review at its armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, last night before Brig. Gen. Walter A. Delamater, in honor of the commander of the Eighty-seventh Brigade, National Guard, who had risen from the rank of private in the regiment to the post of colonel in command of it.

Edward McIver, 33 years old, a Negro, of 678 Rockaway Avenue, Brooklyn, was shot dead in his apartment at 10 o'clock last night by one of two patrolmen who had gone there to arrest him for an alleged assault upon another Negro.
PLEBISCITE postal paper will re-enter the philatelic picture next Friday when special stamps appear in connection with the Austrian plebiscite to be held one week from today.
BERLAND--SPECTOR-Jean. daughter of Mr. Isidore Spector and the late Augusta Spector, to Seymour Berland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Berland, on March 27, 1938.

PITCAIRN ISLAND, eighteenth century refuge of the mutineers of H. M. S. Bounty, now has a radio voice. This new station, using the call VR6AY, was tuned in this area recently during the early evening as contact was mad with amateurs in Providence,
Whatever may be the political functions of the Supreme Soviet, elected under the new Constitution last December, its 1,143 Deputies are among the most useful and busiest people in all Russia.
Real estate tax collections for Friday, the first day on which they were due, totaled $3;598,532 more than were collected April 1 last year, Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, announced yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. John A. McDonald of this city have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Rita McDonald, to Charles D. McGratty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. McGratty of Brooklyn. The ceremony will take place here on April 18.

Questions of improved riding qualities and greater passenger comfort in motor cars were to the fore last week at the passenger car meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers at Detroit. Parts of two papers on the subject will be found below.

Appraising the operation of unemployment insurance laws in various parts of the nation, the American Association for Social Security reports that delays and administrative difficulties have led many persons to conclude that "the systems as now set up are impossible

Sales of several tracts of undeveloped properties in various sections of Queens last week to building syndicates added strength to the views expressed by realty interests on Long Island that the more liberalized provisions of the National

OXFORD has banned radios, and most colleges at Cambridge permit only restricted use. From London comes a report that university authorities are convinced that background listening for brainworkers is pernicious.

The keynote of the last Lily Year Book, issued by the Royal Horticultural Society of Great Britain, seems to be "lilies for every situation and every garden." Suggestions on lilies for beginners, for the herbaceous border and for soils of various textures and acidity content are included in its articles.

Shakespeare's "As You Like It," the love story of Orlando and Rosalind, was presented yesterday, with variations, in Pennsylvania Avenue Court, Brooklyn. The role of the importunate Orlando was faithfully played by David Lloyd Brother, 24 years old. But Rosalind,

The Jersey Reds won the first game in the play-off for the American Basketball League title tonight at Columbia Park, defeating the New York Jewels, 35-34. The second game of the series will be held tonight at Arcadia Hall, Brooklyn.

The twenty-first anniversary of the United States' entrance into the World War, April 6, will be celebrated next week by New York City and the nation, with the city's main celebration reserved for Saturday.

Mrs. Charles M. Hughson of this city, and Wanakah, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jane Carla Hughson, to Howard George Schmitt, son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Schmitt of Hamburg, N. Y.

Mrs. Jesse Fuller Jr. of this city gave a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's, at which she announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Catherine Fuller, to Charles McNair Magnuson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark G. Magnuson, also of New York.

Announcement has been made by the Rev. and Mrs. Thomas Travis of this place of the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Mary Wilson Travis, to Robert Allen Arny, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Vinecome Arny, also of Montclair.

Every capital in Europe heard the thunder of guns this week as the Spanish Insurgent army swept into Catalonia. Like another drive to the sea in another even more desperate civil war, Generalissimo Francisco Franco's drive toward Barcelona marks the beginning of the end.

IN the Spring of 1634 Henry Lawes was in his prime--a member of the King's "private musick" a gentleman of the Chapel Royal, the leading composer in all England, and music master to the children of his friend and patron, the Earl of Bridgewater,

FIRST MILITARY AREA The following Reserve officers recently released to the 1st Military Area are assigned as indicated: 367th Field Artillery-Maj. Robert R. Litehiser, F. A.-Res., Rm. 1005, 75 State St., Albany, N. Y. 323d Engineers-2d Lt. Ace E. Faulkner, Engr-Res., 2,413 Pine Ave., Niagara Falls, N. Y.

The urge to have gay bloom and abundant color in the garden at all times often results in disregarding the true background of the garden, foliage. Since foliage is the best of foils for color, this neglect may impair the beauty of the garden all through the season and prevent color compositions from being truly effective.

THE folklore of the French Renaissance seems to be suffering now and again as some new Thrasymachus digs into the roots of its standardized mythological foundations. The latest, mutato nomine, is Henry Dwight Sedgwick, who, after forty years of intermittent investigations,

IN recent weeks New York has been staging a debate about bread and particularly about the weight of the loaf sold to the housewife. Bakers, the Department of Markets and the consumers have said a word on the subject, and now William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner

Detailed plans for the proposed Sprain Brook Parkway between Yonkers and Hawthorne, a distance of thirteen and a half miles, were being drawn here today by the Westchester County Park Commission in the expectation that New York State will undertake the construction work.

Geraniums, once considered the least temperamental of house plants, are actually satisfied-only with a sunny location. Lacking a fairly steady flood of the brightest Winter sunshine, they set but few buds. Where conditions are suitable, however, they are the gayest blossoming plant available, and certainly the easiest to grow.

Among the annual meetings scheduled for the week among Connecticut clubs are those of the Stamford Woman's Club, to be held Wednesday, with Miss Sara M. Webb presiding, and of the Greenwich Travel Club on Friday, with Mrs. William H. Pullen presiding.

Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Brokaw gave a large dinner at the Beach Club tonight. Their guests included Dr. and Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer, Mr. and Mrs. Pierre L. Barbey, Colonel and Mrs. Francis L. V. Hoppin,

Interest rates on new mortgage investments in Manhattan have shown a modest trend upward in recent months, according to figures compiled by the Mortgage Conference of New York, which includes many large savings banks and other lending agencies.
THE Dodd, Mead-Redbook $10,000 Prize for a first novel has been awarded to Elizabeth Seifert of Moberly, Mo., for her novel. "Young Doctor Galahad."

The rally in the stock market that started late on Thursday and continued through Friday was extended further during the half-day trading period yesterday. As a result, losses of earlier in the week were nullified.
Frank Charcot Jr., 54 years old, Paterson clubman and New York securities broker, was found dead at 6:30 A. M. today on a blanket spread on the ground behind his automobile. Arthur Greenfield,

Rebellious stars have found a new weapon with which to thwack producers. For some months Gene Autrey, Number One Western star in the box office poll, has been at loggerheads with Republic which holds his contract.

Miss Doris Constance Mann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Haskell Mann of St. Louis, was married here this afternoon to William Parker Kennedy, son of Mrs. William Holman Kennedy Jr., of Nashua, N. H., and the late Mr. Kennedy, in the chapel of the Arlington Street Church by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Dana McLean Greeley.
Mrs. Miriam Hostetter Young of New York and William Z. Breed of Cleveland are planning to marry. Mr. Breed's parents, the Rev. and Mrs. Walter R. Breed, confirmed their engagement today.

SLOWLY, it seems to me, Paul Cezanne is coming home; slowly but surely coming home to the people, entering their wide province out of the clouds of critical exegesis that for so long a time-with singular pertinacity of learned passion, though of course without malign intent--had helped obscure him from the common view.

Anglers who have been accustomed to snow flurries on the opening day of the trout season had no complaints to make on today's weather, and almost every hotel and rooming house in this section of the Catskills had its quota of anglers.

A feeling of joy was aroused yesterday among the spice merchants of Water Street by the receipt of reliable information that their old friend Marmaduke M. Mizzle, the adventurous, wandering caraway seed merchant of Mincing Lane, London, was still alive and well at Khatmandu, the capital of Nepal, where he is living under the protection of the kindly maharajah.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elisabeth Raglan Miller, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Raglan Miller of this city, to Richard Sprague Atwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Winslow Atwood of West Hartford.

Since Hitler came into power there has been a marked falling off in the number of students at universities and technical schools. The government at first professed to be pleased. There were too many students anyway, it was argued-too many men and women overeducated for the positions available.
ONE of the Industry's more serious problems of the moment is the retention of the foreign market. Morale and employment in Hollywood are at their lowest point in years.

Delegations from both export and import trade groups as well as from the American Tariff League will leave here tonight for Washington to attend public hearings on the pending revision of this country's trade agreement with Canada.

Some 3,000 physicians from all parts of the United States, Canada, Central and South America and a number of other countries are expected to attend the twenty-second annual session of the American College of Physicians, which opens tomorrow afternoon at the WaldorfAstoria for a five-day meeting.

A new chapter in Mexico's checkered monetary history has been opened up by the seizure of the foreign oil properties and the subsequent termination by the United States Treasury of its agreement to buy 5,000,000 ounces of silver every month from the Mexican Government.

Though the diplomatic notes exchanged by Britain, France and the United States are formal announcement that a naval race in the size of capital ships is on and that Britain is in it, the British taxpayer can take some consolation from the fact that it might have been worse and that cruisers are out of it-for the present at least.

A May Day music festival on May 1, presenting an afternoon pageant by more than a thousand dancers and musicians and an evening performance of the Beethoven Ninth symphony with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Dr. Walter Damrosch, was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair 1939, as part of the fair's preview of "The World of Tomorrow."

Easter Sunday, when the weather cooperates, is a day to rejoice in the warmth of Spring, the newly green grass, the chartreuse haze in the young maple trees. That day, too, sees many breakfast tables festive with little gifts at each place--gifts that are often thoughtful tokens rather than presents of intrinsic value.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Clarissa Pauline Moriarty, daughter of Thaddeus Oswald Moriarty of this city and the late Mrs. Moriarty, to Chandler Shaw Mackey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chandler Alexander Mackey of Brooklyn.

WHEN Dr. Arthur E. Morgan got home from Washington the other day, following his dismissal by President Roosevelt from his post as chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, he went immediately to the plain stone Summer house which he owns, near Yellow Springs, Ohio.

John W. Hubbard, Pittsburgh manufacturer, was under a doctor's care and his son-in-law, John C. Williams of Grosse Pointe Farms, was held by police following an argument in the board room of a downtown stock brokerage firm today.

Sun Egret, wiry, nervous 3-year-old chestnut colt with eyes trained on the Kentucky Derby, dashed over a slow track through the mist today to a length and a half victory in the $6,000 Rowe Memorial Handicap.
Italian volunteers fighting in Spain, according to the best information available here, number about 35,000, having decreased about 7,000 from the maximum of 42,000 reached last Summer.
These are paint-brush days at yacht clubs and boat yards, and there is many a skipper who vows this is the best part of the season. Spring descended on New York yachtdom last week without warning.

COMES word of plans for a late Spring revival of George Kelly's "The Torch Bearers" -not by Milton Shubert, though the latter did inquire of Mr. Kelly about the chances of bringing back his classic satire on the Little Theatre Movement.

A WEEK or two ago the Treasury Department announced a competition for the decoration of two great towers on the main facade of the United States Government Building at the World's Fair. Let me state as briefly as possible the conditions of the competition.

Miss Hilda Wood Lynde, daughter of Dean Lester E. Lynde of Phillips Andover Academy. was married today to Donal P. Wylie of Upper Montclair, N. J. The ceremony was performed at the bride's home by the Rev. A. Graham Baldwin, chaplin of Andover Academy.
An automobile found abandoned in the West Texas hills sent officers on a search today for Mrs. Weston G. Frome, 46 years old, Berkeley, Calif., and her daughter, Nancy, 23.

PROMOTION: Congressmen in the present session have done their utmost to boost their States among their colleagues. New Jersey was represented by free champagne; Washington by canned salmon; Texas by grapefruit. Last week it was disclosed that as souvenirs of Florida Representative Petersen had distributed baby alligators among his colleagues.

Income taxes collected in March as a first quarterly installment amounted to $723,002,013, somewhat under earlier government estimates which, although never officially announced, were said to have been for $750,000,000.

There was little activity in the foreign exchange market here today. The franc was up slightly to 161 5/8 francs to the pound, but forward positions weakened, the three-month and one-month discounts slipping to 3 11-16 and 1 3/8 francs, respectively.
Four Chinese girls between the ages of 6 and 11 years shyly went through the ceremony yesterday afternoon of presenting $460 to Beckman Street Hospital, Beckman and Water Streets.

WITH King Leopold III himself in attendance, the world-famous floral games of Ghent, which are still conducted with the ritual, the ceremonial and the pageantry of bygone centuries, will be inaugurated on April 14 in the magnificent Palais des Floralies (Flower Palace) constructed for this purpose.

AN army of farmers moves through the New England uplands these days-an army equipped with sap buckets and spiles-as the "sugaring-off" and its associated festivities are acted out before thousands of visitors from other points of the East who come to enjoy this American spectacle. e.

IN the loveliest part of Yugoslavia--the Dalmatian region surrounding the Bay of Cattaro--the ancient practice of vendetta is still preserved. In other districts of Yugoslavia the custom has been stamped out by modern government, but the folk of Cattaro cling stubbornly to old tribal laws, refusing to replace them with new legal codes. al codes.
The man behind the flat-topped mahogany desk in the Governor's office at Albany was 60 years old last Monday, but it was just another workday for him. Mr. Lehman began the formidable

An indication of a capacity attendance at the motion-picture preview and supper dance to be held April 21 at the Waldorf-Astoria in behalf of the Cooperative Committee of Big Sisters is given by the large advance sale of tickets and the many table reservations reported by the benefit committees.

Residents are returning daily for the Spring season, among them Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Lorillard, who passed the Winter at Jekyl Island and have now opened their house here. Mr. and Mrs. J. Insley Blair are expected home from Jekyl Island shortly.

Prospects of a price war on electric shavers have been definitely averted for the time being, with the reports last week that both Gillette and the American Safety Razor Company will charge $15 for their models when they are introduced.

Oxford beat Cambridge by two lengths in the ninetieth annual boat race between the two British universities today. Oxford's time was 20 minutes 30 seconds, 2 minutes 27 seconds slower tha the record established by Cambridge in 1934.
Passage of Mayor La Guardia's three bills for $9,250,000 in supplemental relief taxes at the Council meeting next Tuesday morning was predicted yesterday at City Hall.

David Swope, son of Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, has gone into the realty development business. He is one of the chief sponsors of one of the largest new small-home colonies in Westchester County.

The shipment of 20,000 air bombs which were taken by the German freighter Kellerwald when she cleared from Wilmington. Del.. on March 8 for Bremen were destined for China. Reports had been current that they were destined for Spain.

The scale of the art property of the late Ogden L. Mills was completed yesterday, realizing a total of $94,717.50. The sale, which was conducted at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, began on Thursday and was continued Friday and yesterday, the final session alone bringing $52,765.

Six thousand qualified young men residing in New York, New Jersey and Delaware enrolled in the first month of registration for the eighteenth annual citizens military training camps, it was announced yesterday at the army's Second Corps Area headquarters on Governors Island. The quota for the three States is 6,800.

Striking with the stabbing speed and facility of a high-geared football machine, the Cambridge University Rugby team rolled up another top-heavy score yesterday to defeat the All-New York fifteen before 2,500 spectators at Randalls Island Stadium, 38-6.

Means by which Mexico can make adequate compensation for the expropriated American oil properties were discussed by Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Dr. Francisco Castillo Najera, the Mexican Ambassador, at a conference at the State Department today.
Tennessee's 1935 statute authorizing municipalities to go into the power business was upheld today by the State Supreme Court.
Accidents killed 9,438 persons in New York during 1937, according to Dr. J. V. de Porte, State Health Department statistician.

Union Turnpike, laid out a decade ago as a likely arterial highway to link Nassau County with the city, will be completed this year under a special appropriation of $400,000 for materials, Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens announced today.

Bolivia and Chile replied favorably today to the American proposal for the creation of an intergovernmental committee to facilitate the emigration of political refugees from Austria and Germany. Thus far twenty-one governments have replied to the proposal out of thirty-three invited to participate. Only Italy has rejected the suggestion.
Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Barnett of 415 Central Park West have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Shelley Barnett, to Henry Umans of this city.

Louis N. Donnatin Jr., son of the Recorder of Mecca Temple of the Mystic Shrine, died suddenly of a heart attack early yesterday morning at his home, 89-62 211th Street, Bellaire, Queens, at the age of 39.

IS the modern trend in fiction decadent? This question has been mooted in one of our religious weeklies, which invited an opinion on the subject from Victor Murray, Professor of Education on University College. .
The Constitutional Convention which is to suggest changes in the New York State Constitution for submission to the voters next November will begin its sessions next Tuesday at Albany.

Early diagnosis of cancer, to be achieved through public education, should reduce the annual mortality due to the disease by half, in the opinion of Dr. Frank E. Adair, secretary of the American Society for Control of Cancer who spoke yesterday afternoon before a forum at the Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries at the Grand Central Palace.

Somewhere on the highway between Albion and Oakfield, Clark Porter slept in his covered wagon tonight while his mules rested-a second step completed in his forty-year-old dream of a trek to Missouri by mule train.

Severance of the Philippine Islands from the United States will produce desperate economic conditions in the islands, with possible revolutions and disorders, Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, Former Governor General of the Philippines, told the American Academy of Political and Social Science today.

WILL H. HAYS is in office and all's right with Hollywood--at least, he devoutly hopes so. In his annual report, issued last week, he manfully restates his faith in the film industry. The quality of our films continues to improve.

To the largest women's division of any police department in the world New York City will make a substantial addition as a result of civil service examinations for which applications are now being filed.

The marriage ,of Miss Katherine Rawling Wilcox, daughter of Mrs. Frank Schlesinger of New Haven, Conn., and the late Philip Wakeman Wilcox of New York, to William Wright Matthews of New York, son of Mrs. George Witteman of Bethlehem, Pa., and of the late William Hall Matthews of Cleveland, took place here yesterday noon -in the chapel of the First Presbyterian Church, Twelfth Street and Fifth Avenue.
