TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a quiet atmosphere historians calmly divided the records of time into three eras of history. The period of Roman supremacy was regarded as ancient, then followed the Dark Ages of medievalism, but we of the present were proudly modern.

ADELSON-Julius, at Tampa, Fla., Saturday, April 2, beloved husband of Millie Rosenwasser, devoted father of Irving, Edgar, Samuel, Theresa Walzer and Leila Morris. Services Tuesday, 2:30 P. M., Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1,250 Central Ave., Far Rockaway. Kindly omit flowers.
The Soviet Russian Government today protested to Japan that the Japanese Charged' Affaires at Kabul, Afghanistan, attempted to enlist the new Soviet Minister to Afghanistan as a Japanese spy.

EVER since civil war began in Spain there has been confusion in philatelic circles regarding the "legitimacy" of a majority of the postal items, estimated to be 1,500 in number, released by Loyalists and Rebels. A letter received from Arthur Barger of Flushing, Long Island, a stamp dealer who has been in Barcelona as postal adviser to the Loyalist forces, says: :
Purchase by the Guy M. Rush interests of New York City was announced yesterday of the thirty two acre tract at Union, Union County, known as the Headley farm.

The real estate market is showing greater activity this season than in many years, and there is increased activity not only in sales but rentals. More than $500,000 worth of property has exchanged hands recently, including some large estates owned by prominent New Yorkers.

George Washington University won the national intercollegiate rifle championship today with a score of 1,367. A compilation by the National Rifle Association of four sectional 'events showed Minnesota second with 1,360 and Pittsburgh third with 1,359.

Annual communion breakfast of San Salvador Council 174, K. of C., the Croydon, 12 East Eighty-sixth Street, 9 A. M. Speakers: The Rev. Charles H. C. McAuliffe, the Rev. John L. Farge, Alexander I. Rorke.
The first International Photographic Exposition, which is to be held in Grand Central Palace from April 18 to 24, promises to offer New York its largest photographic show.

Music composed hundreds of years ago for medical purposes has been unearthed, translated and readapted for modern instruments at the Johns Hopkins University Institute of the History of Medicine, and will be played by a group of students and faculty members as a feature of the annual Graduate Week in Medical History, April 18-23.
George H. Knutson and Harry Reid, both of New York, were elected by Class A stockholders early today as members of the board of directors of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation.

With a motorcycle escort and the Mayor of Yonkers in the van, twenty-five automobiles will transfer Monday afternoon the blind men, women and children from the old home of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind. at St. Johns and Crotty Avenues here, to the newly constructed quarters at 75 Stratton Street on the Saw Mill River Parkway at Palmer Avenue.

Sustaining the opinion of admirers who rate him the country's greatest timber horse, Ostend, 11-year old son of Sandmole, today captured the ninth running for the Carolina Cup by three length over the stiff three-mile course.
William Ashley Sunday Jr., son of the late Billy Sunday, evangelist, died here today of pneumonia in the Queen of The Angels Hospital. His age was 37.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., April 4: PATROLMEN-Charles S. Kuhn, 10th Precinct, assigned to clerical duty. John C. Bealler, from 83d Precinct to Police Academy, for duty in Technical Research Laboratory.

Walter Atkinson Rush, vice president and secretary of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, 40 Wall Street, New York, died in his home here this morning after a heart attack at the age of 51. He had been with the Bank of the Manhattan Company for thirty-two years.

THE Soviet cinema's traditions of uncompromising realism were rocked to their foundadations not so long ago when the Mosfilm Studios prepared to make "Lenin in October," the first film made with Lenin as a character. For the young director, Mikhail Romm (remembered best in these parts for his earlier film, "The Thirteen"), learned to his acute distress that nothing fibs more than a news camera.

Officers of nine clubs at Barnard College were elected by undergraduate club members last week in the annual Spring elections, and twelve delegates at large to the college's Representative Assembly were chosen by the student body by a new system of proportional representation.

Quartz, which looks like glass and is a sort of glass, is the last material most of us would use to make a spring. But the scientists in the General Research laboratories find that nothing but quartz will do for springs in making precise measurements.

AT the Seligmann Gallery, where it is being shown until April 16 for the benefit of the Adopt a Family Committee of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, you will find a representative--but beyond that, at times, a peculiarly revealing-group of portraits by Sir Henry Raeburn (1756-1823).

Announcement has been made by William H. McMaster, president of Mount Union College here, and Mrs. McMaster of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Isabella Thoburn McMaster, to Craig' Ringwald Thompson of Ithaca, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan D. Thompson of Carlisle, Pa.

In Czechoslovakia the demand for autonomy is raised most loudly by the Sudeten Germans and with such success that almost all minor German parties which hitherto supported the governmental coalition withdrew. their representatives from the Cabinet and joined the Henlein movement.

Gardening topics hold the attention of several Westchester clubs this week. Henry Wilde will speak on annuals and perennials to the garden department of the Bronxville Women's Club tomorrow at 2:30 P. M. On Wednesday he will speak to members of the same group of the Scarsdale Woman's Club.

After the most jittery week it has spent in a decade, Mexico interpreted Secretary Hull's statement of Friday evening to mean that the United States had accepted Mexico's promise to pay for all United States properties expropriated in the past several years, and breathed a hearty sigh of relief.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Sevin of Forest Hills, Queens, of the engagement of their 'daughter, Miss Edith Irene Sevin, to Dr. Samuel S. Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Cohen of Brooklyn.

Announcement has been made of the engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Marjorie Call, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Carl Elmo Call of Roachdale, Ind., to Carlos Salzedo, harpist and composer. The marriage will take place on April 21 at the home of Miss Call's parents.
The Continental Oil Company reported yesterday the best annual earnings in its history, its financial statement for 1937 showing net earnings of $13,948,460 after depreciation, depletion and taxes.

ONE of the more visible accomplishments of the annual Film Congress held here early this month was the laying of the cornerstone for the National German Film Academy by Dr. Joseph Goebbels, for which a spacious edifice is to be erected at the newly baptized Ufastadt-Babelsberg, about half an hour outside of Berlin.

A Yesterday's meeting of the Eastern Branch of the American Psychological Association Dr. D. O. Hebb of the Montreal Neurological Institute and McGill University told psychologists what happens when parts of the frontal lobes of the human brain are removed as a matter of surgical necessity. Four cases were described.

Mr. and Mrs. Amos Tuck French will return from Arizona tomorrow and will be at the Savoy-Plaza. Mrs. Carey Etnier of York, Pa., has joined her son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Etnier, at the Madison.

Imperial Airways claimed for its flying boat Cavalier the distinction today of being the first airplane to fly to Bermuda and back in a day. The Cavalier made the 1,600-mile trip yesterday in 12 hours 5 minutes.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ford will celebrate their golden wedding on April 11, and on that day they will be cheered with a signed tribute from half a million or more of Mr. Ford's admirers from every part of the country.
Mrs. Frederica Frelinghuysen Carleton was married here this afternoon in the presence of near relatives to Huntington D. Sheldon, president of the Petroleum Corporation of America.
Miss Betty Rhodes of the Newark A. C. captured the national junior women's high board diving championship last night at the Newark A. C. pool, where three State A. A. U. swimming records were broken.

The engagement of Miss Marianne Elizabeth Monroe, daughter of Cressy H. Monroe of Old Greenwich, Conn., and-the late Mrs. Elsie Emily Monroe, to Harris Shipman Wells, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Wells of Kingston, R. I., has been announced here by her father.
Four officials of a Leningrad lantern factory, including Manager I. Krassin, have been arrested for trial on charges of manufacturing defective lanterns.

Five lectures on the general topic, "The Safety and Skill of Driving," are to be given at Smith College, primarily for the seventy-five seniors, who may have automobiles on the campus after the Spring vacation.

Part 1 of the library formed by the late Cortlandt F. Bishop, comprising illuminated manuscripts, fine and rare books, association books, fine bindings and other items, will be sold at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., in six sessions.

American foreign policy in the changing scene will be considered Thursday at the tenth annual conference of the New Jersey Committee on the Cause and Cure of War in the McCarter Theatre, Princeton, under the chairmanship of Mrs. Clayton J. Harcourt. On the preceding day a leadership institute will be conducted in Nassau Tavern by Mrs. Frederic Beggs.

In commemoration of the bimillennium of Augustus Caesar, the Department of Latin at Vassar College is conducting a celebration designed to revivify for the college community the contributions to art and literature made by the peace which Augustus gave to the Roman world.

That the building industry is becoming increasingly interested in the possibilities of erecting lowcost housing which may be operated at a profit is indicated in expressions on the subject by several men prominent in that field.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board points out that during 1937 in Muncie, Ind., which was selected several months ago as a typical small American city by two sociologists, savings and loan associations there made 68.3 per cent of all loans obtained by its citizens for home financing.

The marriage of Miss Elfie Baltzley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Edwin Baltzley of Glen Ridge, to Richard Emmins Boise, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Boise, also of Glen Ridge, took place at noon today in the Glen Ridge Congregational Church. The pastor, the Rev. Dr. William Weston Patton, officiated.

WHEN Mr. de Valera recently introduced a new Constitution for that major part of Ireland whose government he heads and then reopened the question of the partition of the country (which many had assumed was settled seventeen years ago),
For the next few days West Fulham will forget that it is just another square mile of dreary brick houses in London and will steal some of the political spotlight from Parliament itself.

MANUFACTURERS of automobiles are well advised to keep a close eye on the agricultural market, if one can judge from a survey conducted by the Bureau of Home Economics of the Department of Agriculture and made public last week.

A luncheon and fashion showing of the latest costumes for Spring wear will follow a board meeting of the Little Mothers Aid Association, of which Mrs. Frank Oliver Hall is president, to be held Saturday morning at the WaldorfAstoria.

Lessons learned during the 1929 to 1932 period are serving retailers well in the current recession and probably of all business groups retail distributors are "least paralyzed by fear or lack of confidence," according to comments in well-informed quarters here yesterday.

Population experts Drs. Warren S. Thompson and P. K. Whelpton of the Scripps Foundation for Research in Population Problems appeared before the American Academy of Political and Social Sciences in Philadelphia yesterday to report that the unrest which leads to war is caused by the social Inability to stay within fixed boundary lines.

CECIL B. DE MILLE's next picture -- his sixty-fifth--will be "Union Pacific." The story about the laying of the railroad track connecting Omaha and Ogden, Utah, will be told through the lives of a young married couple.

Miss Elinore Stanley Warner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Olmsted Warner of Penn Valley, was married this afternoon to John Wyeth Sailer of this city, son of Mrs. William Augustus Sailer of Roland Park, Md., and of the late Mr. Sailer.

Twelve thousand miles of the United States will be the classroom of a group of traveling high school teachers enrolling in the Summer session of New Jersey State Teachers College at Montclair. The two-month tour, to start July 1, is being supported from a $13,850 grant of the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, Inc., to the college's bureau of field studies.

The model house at North Sixth Street, one block north of Jericho Turnpike in New Hyde Park, L. I., built in conjunction with the Long Island National Home Show, is attracting considerable attention, reports John H. Morris, president of the Long Island Real Estate

Chronological examples of liturgical and other forms of church music swill be presented at a concert to be given be Sunday night, May 8, at Carnegie Hall, 'as part of the Church Choir Festival which will be held here May 1-8 under the auspices of the Municipal Art Committee of the City of New York.

As a feature of its Spring appeal for funds for continued service to communities throughout Greater New York, the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies is arranging a benefit performance of "Whiteoaks," the new play starring Ethel Barrymore at the Hudson Theatre, for the night of April 19.

The asset value of the National Investors Corporation on March 31 was equivalent to $3.99 a share ex-dividend, against $4.80 a share on Dec. 31, a decline of 81 cents, or 16.9 per cent, compared with declines of 19.4 per cent-in the Standard Statistics ninety-stock
The anti-fascist press in Buenos Aires today opened a new attack on German Nazi influence in Argentina in connection with the plebiscite April 10 on union of Germany and Austria.

Mrs. Peter J. Kane of Brooklyn has announced the engagement of her niece, Miss Claire M. Foy, to Harold B. Macy, son of Lieut. Col. Frederick S. Macy (U.S.A., Medical Corps), retired, and Mrs. Macy of Brooklyn and Madison, N. H.

Mayor F. H. La Guardia announced yesterday that he would appoint Frank P. Walsh, widely known labor attorney and chairman of the State Power Authority, to fill the vacancy on the Board of Higher Education left by the resignation of Mark Eisner.

The Rhode Island House of Representatives, after eleven hours of debate which wound up in confusion and physical violence, passed Governor Robert E. Quinn's fiscal program just before midnight and adjourned.
HOLDING its gain but not improving it by much, retail trade last week through the country probably ran about 9 per cent or so under a year ago.

BARSKY -- Mr. and Mrs. Philip H. Barsky are happy to announce the bar mitzvah of their son, Marvin, Saturday, April 9, Temple Adath Jeshurun. KLEIN--Mr. and Mrs. Harry. of Woodmere, L. I., announce the bar mitzvah of their son, Edward, on Saturday, April 9, at 10 o'clock, at Temple Beth-El, Cedar-hurst, L. I.
Frank Brown, 22-year-old Medford milk man, today won the Presentation Club 10-mile road run, a recognized tune-up for the Boston Marathon on April 19.

Officials of the Home Owners Loan Corporation will address a luncheon meeting of real estate men of Queens in the Jackson Heights clubhouse on Tuesday to explain the sales plan and policies of the HOLC. Frank S. O'Hara,

Action in the wholesale market was rather spotty last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. Apparel and accessories for pre-Easter selling held the center of attention. The report continues:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Able observers of the European political situation are urging the United States to take a strong stand for democracy as against dictatorships. They point out that if Britain had made her position clear before the outbreak of hostilities in 1914, the World War might have been averted.
A "Sales Idea Book" has just been published by the brokers' division of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

Nearly half of the young men and women in this city are suffering from lack of economic opportunity, the Greater New York Fund reported yesterday on the basis of a study just completed by the Welfare Council.

Lord Mackenzie, Scottish judge and one of the leading barristers of his time, died today at the age of 81. He sat on the highest Scottish bench for seventeen years as a Lord of Sessions and had served on a large number of government committees.
Vincentian Institute of Albany won the nineteenth annual .Eastern States interscholastic basketball tournament tonight by defeating Atlantic City High, 31 to 27.

The open junior all-age stake, second richest event on the program of the annual Spring meeting of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club, today went to Raymond Hoagland of Cartersville, Ga., owner of the white and liver pointer bitch Shore's Wild Lady,

Miss Doris Buckingham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leroy A. Buckingham, was married here this afternoon at the home of her parents to William Roberts Candelent, son of Mr. and Mrs., Harry Candelent of Meriden.

New York City conventions will draw more than 14,000 delegates from various parts of the country during April, according to a survey by the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau of the Merchants Association.
The reign of terror in Vienna that began with the fall of Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg and still continues has been none the less severe because it has been conducted discreetly and methodically.

A new chemical for the relief of pain in angina pectoris, described as more suitable in the treatment of this dread disease than similar substances now available, was reported here today before the closing sessions of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.

Ray Haines and Art Felton, members of the Rintoul Five from Baltimore, today bowled what was announced as a world's doubles record of 918 in the national duckpin tournament. Haines had the. highest game of the two sets, a 178 in the third.

A jacket of rose point lace was a feature of the bridal costume worn by Miss Frances Jennings Hall for her marriage to Albert O'Beirne Andrews which took place yesterday afternoon in the First Prebyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. J.

The strong interest of business men throughout the country in the relationships of government and business is reflected in proposals submitted for adoption as resolutions by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States at its annual meeting here from May 2 to 5.

With retail trade last week hampered by the weather, men's wear stores here are looking for the coming two weeks to bring in a substantial volume of pre-Easter business, retail executives reported yesterday.
The United Palestine Appeal has announced that veterans of the Jewish stage in America will pay tribute to Professor Albert Einstein at a special performance Thursday night at the Public Theatre.

Army and Columbia fenced to a 13 1/2-to-13 1/2 tie today. West Point captured both the foil and saber events, 5 to 4, with Columbia tying the match by winning the epee event, 5 1/2 to 3 1/2 Wallis, Columbia's star with the epee, made a clean sweep of his matches.

Preparations for the most impressive schedule of foreign trade, events ever attempted since the first observance of Foreign Trade Week here two years ago were completed here yesterday by a committee headed by George F. Bauer, manager of the export division of the Automobile Manufacturers Association.
Rehearsals for the second annual revue of the Junior Assembly of Yonkers will begin the evening of April 11 and will continue every night until the dates scheduled for the event. April 29 and 30.
A THERMOMETER built to stand the hard usage of darkroom manipulation has recently received the attention of photographers who had been discouraged by more fragile instruments of measurement.

The number of world unemployed was greater in the first quarter of this year than in the corresponding period of last year, according to figures that the International Labor Office has just issued for twenty-four countries, including all the great powers except Italy and Russia.

The Bureau of Air Commerce reported today that "fire and explosion associated with the dumping of fuel" probably caused the flaming crash of Pan American Airways' Samoan Clipper in the South Seas Jan. 11.

A slight decline in .the wholesale cost of building materials during February, as compared with both January of this year and February, 1937, was announced yesterday--by the division of research and statistics of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

The State Labor Relations Board accepted jurisdiction yesterday over a dispute between a custodian-engineer employed by the Board of Education and a helper hired by him to perform janitorial functions in the Washington Irving High School, 40 Irving Place.

Members of the Eastern Osteopathic Association, opening their eighteenth annual convention in the Hotel Pennsylvania, voted unanimous endorsement yesterday of the measures being put forth "for the control of, and the eventual elimination of, the scourge of syphilis."

FILM press agents spatter good white paper with drivel about their bosses. This is always an effort. to butter their betters. In real life a producer is usually a dynamo who, dervishlike, whirls himself into a sanatorium with worry and work.

To clamp down on fraudulent immigration which has been increasingly entering Brazil lately, President Getulio Vargas has enacted a law that affects thousands of foreigners who came in on tourist visas and remained illegally after the expiration of the six months' time allowance.

While the French Government will not decide before Monday the action to be taken with regard to Spanish Loyalist militiamen who have been crossing the frontier at Bagneres de Luchon since Thursday, it is now considered most likely that they will be returned to Spain after receiving the opportunity to decide which side they wish to join.
Miss Edna Helen Johnston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Claude L. Johnston of South Orange, was married this afternoon to Richard Edmund Bishop Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bishop of New York.

THIS story of the people of a Labrador village is an unusual novel for boys and girls in their teens which, in its mature conception, its strength and flavor, deserves the attention of adult readers as well.

The Terry-Holden expedition that left New York last September to explore the Guiana-Brazil jungle has completed six months' exploration work, during which it made a scientific and photographic record of British Guiana from the Atlantic coast to the Sierra Acarai Mountains, on the Brazilian border.
WASHINGTON. -- Mechanical devices are driving the old-fashioned lighthouse with its resident keeper out of existence, according to statistics recently presented to a House committee.

Not only do the sporting goods manufacturers showe a nice profit from the excitement coincident with opening day, but the druggists as well, for many a bottle of liniment was packed away with the leaders and fly boxes yesterday. Eight or ten hours of slipping and sliding in a stream, five or six hours of cold water and the almost constant movement of the wrist has resulted in many stiff joints this morning.

NOT every one is going home at 5 o'clock these afternoons from the Department of Justice. The stupendous new building in which the mural paintings are almost as attention-arresting as J. Edgar Hoover is the scene of more after-hours work than usual.

While Manager Burleigh Grimes and Secretary John McDonald were rambling around the Florida West Coast today, possibly in search of more ball players, the Dodgers submitted to the worst drubbing they've undergone since the Cards beat 'em, 20 to 2, at Ebbets Field last Summer.

The engagement of Miss Cynthia Patrice Flannery, daughter of Edward Pearson Flannery of Glyntaff, this place, and the late Mrs. Flannery, to John Evans Stine of Philadelphia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Stine of Hanover, has been announced by her father.

Statistically and historically, the Invasion by women of the "seats of the mighty" at the seventh of the constitutional conventions held by New York State, which opens Tuesday at Albany, is not the least of the peaks of attention and interest certain to be concentrated on the proceedings.

Special cooperation and active interest are being applied to preparations for this year's Butterfly Ball dinner dance because of the fact that the beneficiary of the annual party-the House of Rest at Sprain Ridge-is in great need of a diagnostic laboratory.

The imposing residence at 4 East Seventy-ninth Street, a part of the interesting group comprising the "Cook block," has been sold by the estate of the late Gilbert W. Keech of Tuxedo, represented by the executors, H. T. Richardson and E. R. Early, to a "well-known New Yorker" who will occupy the house. Pease Elliman acted as brokers in the deal.

AFTER forty years Chekhov has become intelligible on the American stage. Although that sounds grotesque, it is true. Russia did not understand his plotless and truncated style until the Moscow Art Theatre learned how to adumbrate a dramatic background for "The Sea Gull" in 1896.
A minute examination of the giant panda quarters at Brookfield zoo was ordered today as a result of the death of Su-Lin, leading attraction at the park, from a mysterious ailment.

WARNING that censorship in broadcasting "is undesirable and perhaps impossible, beyond the limits of decency," L. W. Brockington, chairman of the board of governors of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, presented the attitude of that body on the "vexed and topical subject of freedom of speech" in recent report to the Canadian House of Commons. ommons.

Dr. William J. Robbins, recently appointed director of the New York Botanical Garden, will address members of the City Gardens Club on "The Background of Gardening" at the club's annual meeting on Tuesday at 3 P. M. at the home of Mrs. Schuyler Schieffelin.

In the current issue of the Physical Review Dr. Ira Freeman of Chicago allies himself with those who believe that the "heavy" electron discovered in recent cosmicray experiments is just an ordinary electron which has gained mass with speed in accordance with Einstein's principle.
A pre-Easter sale of clothing and household articles for the benefit of the New York Diet Kitchen Association will be held next Saturday at the Nearly New Shop, 917 Eighth Avenue.

This department is deigned to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

MANHATTAN BLOCH. ROSE S. (March 7). Estate, more than $20,000. To Solomon M. Bloch. husband, executor, 65 W. 54th St., $5,000 and one-third residue; Monroe Percy Bloch, son, executor, 10 E. 85th St.. and Marjorie B. Levy, daughter, Rome, Italy, $5,000 and one-third residue each; Monte-fiore Hospital, Gun Hill Road. Bronx, $2,000; Muriel B. Bloch. 10 E. 85th St., and Barbara Bloch, same address. $5,000 each; David M. Levy, Rome, $1,000.

At the closing session of the eleventh annual convention of the Hotel Sales Managers Association here today Hugh J. Connor, New York, was re-elected president and John F. Bowman, Chicago, treasurer. John Daniels Jr., Buffalo, and John F. Schlotterbeck, Miami, Fla., were chosen vice presidents.

SEALING is a brutal business, but extenuation may lie in the bravery of the men who go into the White Sea after the skins. This is a book about men who dare death every time they go north in the Spring, mostly Norwegians, reckless, powerful men.
General Shunroku Hata today rejected British Protests against reported Japanese threats and discourtesies to British nationals.
MANY who spend their leisure hours at bridge tables discover that the playing cards used have a historical and artistic significance wholly apart from their role of game symbols.

Animals and birds ranging from turtles and lion cubs to snipe and doves were cared for last year at the five New York shelters of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, according to the seventy-second annual report, just issued. Many of the animals and birds received treatment for injuries or exposure.
NOEL COWARD'S "Operette," an elaborate entertainment at His Majesty's, is a disappointment to Mr. Coward's admirers. That it will fail instantly is improbable.

President Anastasio Somoza announced today that the directorate of the National Bank of Nicaragua, 40 Wall Street, New York, would be transferred to Managua this month. The house was incorporated in Connecticut more than twenty-six years ago, but the board was established in New York later, because 51 per cent of the stock was owned by important banking groups in New York.

Alton "Spike" Draper, an Adirondack guide in whose veins flows the blood of the Seneca Indian tribe, plans to set of tomorrow on a month's stay in the "green timber" section of .the Adirondack Mountains with his hunting knife as his only weapon and tool.
Four years of experiment have convinced Harvard that one of its important tasks in the future will be to provide Summer courses for adult men and women who want to use their vacation time for study.

ONE of the hockey tourists who came back with the star-spangled Americans from Chicago said that Mervyn the Red Dutton sat up all night on the train to tell, in part, what he thought of Referee Clarence Campbell.

Ignoring a defense of good samaritanism, a jury in County Court here today found Mrs. Ottilie Gordon, owner of a small private hospital at Port Jefferson Station, guilty of kidnapping Mrs. Anna Johnson, 55-year-old widow, of Selden, L. I., a year ago. County Judge James W. Liddle of Schenectady, who presided at the trial, immediately sentenced Mrs. Gordon, who is 58 and also a widow, to from twenty years to life imprisonment at Bedford.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Much of our economic thinking today, as always, is confused because of arguments from different viewpoints. What may very well be beneficial policies from the point of view of a particular industry may be harmful to society; and policies which are beneficial to all groups today may, by their very nature, result in undue hardships tomorrow.

The Chrysler Corporation filed suit in Federal District Court here today for a declaratory judgment that its contracts with dealers for financing automobiles sold on time payments do not violate the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.

The dedication of a stone fireplace by the Lehigh University chapter of Alpha Phi Omega, national Eagle Scout fraternity, adds another attraction to the top of South Mountain,- the upper part of the Lehigh campus.
EMIL GANSO returns to Weyhe's (until April 16) with oils and water-colors in his familiar vein--a vein so familiar that one may call it a personal idiom, or even a definite style.

One of the features of the annual kettledrum to be held on Friday at the Plaza for the benefit of the Samaritan Home for the Aged will be a tea dance under the direction of Miss Margery P. Stoddard and her junior committee.

Miss Marjorie MacCubbin, daughter of Thomas MacCubbin of Montclair and the late Mrs. MacCubbin, was married to Edward Dodge Rohn of Ferguson, Mo., near St. Louis, son of Mrs. E. B. Rohn of New York, this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church here.

First among the great Western democracies and in sharp contrast with her stand on Ethiopia, Great Britain today formally recognized Austrian Anschluss and notified Berlin that in as much as "Austria has ceased to exist as a sovereign and independent State," the British Legation in Vienna was being converted into a consulate general.

BOWLING GREEN, where Dutch burghers used to play bowls in the early days of New Amsterdam, has been restored by the Department of Parks and will be rededicated on Wednesday. It is one of New York's oldest historic sites.

THE name of Franz Salmhofer has appeared a number of times in these letters, not be cause what he writes has any particular merit or distinction, but for the reason that it keeps cropping up in Vienna, where his principal business is to supply incidental music for the plays at the Burgtheater. .
Before an audience of more than 800 Westchester alumni and guests, the Columbia University musical show "You've Got Something There" was presented at the Westchester County Center here tonight.
One additional company, the National Public Utilities Corporation, registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.
Under the surface of Canadian politics, virtually unperceived as yet by the general public, an interesting realignment of forces has been going on.

Dr. Ernest M. Hopkins, president of Dartmouth College, will speak Tuesday night at the opening of the new Dartmouth Club of New York, at 30 East Thirty-seventh Street. The club recently moved from its old quarters at 22 East Thirty-eighth Street.

IT has always been our idea that dealers in rare books are gentle, scholarly persons who would not hurt a fly unless perhaps it threatened to mar the immaculateness of a First Folio Shakespeare or something of that sort.

Frederick J. H. Kracke, chairman of the Board of Assessors, reported to Mayor La Guardia in a letter yesterday that the board in the first three months of the year had saved the city $487,825 in fixing damages resulting from public improvements.

A benefit amateur boxing program will be held under the auspices of the New York Post Office Clerks Association 1 at the St. Nicholas Palace on Saturday night. Proceeds from the event will be donated to the clerks' sick and death benefit fund.

The second in a series of three seminars on "Germany and Her Neighbors" will be held Tuesday, 10:30 A. M., by the governing committee of the New Jersey Federation of Women's Clubs, according to an announcement by Mrs. Stephen Francisco, international relations chairman.

The King's approval was announced by the Royal Commission this week and the new Film Quota Bill, the British Government's second attempt to bolster up the native film industry, became law. At the last minute the House of Lords was induced to withdraw several harsh amendments.

Certificates of superior craftsmanship and gold buttons will be awarded by the New York Building Congress Tuesday morning to sixteen mechanics for their work on the new apartment house nearing completion at 25 East Eighty-third Street, near Madison Avenue. The awards will be made at the building by Thomas S. Holden, president of the congress.

The marriage of Miss Rosalie Jeannie Hanwell, daughter of Mrs. Richard William Hanwell of Montclair and the late Mr. Hanwell, to Ernest Alan Fentzlaff, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Eugene Fentzlaff of East Orange, took place this afternoon at First Reformed Church, East Orange.
Scoring six runs in the first two innings, the St. John's freshman baseball team went on to defeat Brooklyn College Evening, 8 to 4, in its opening game of the season yesterday at Carey Field.

Miss Elizabeth W. Starbuck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Macy Starbuck of 307 East Fifty-seventh Street, has set the date for her marriage to Edward W. Burr Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Burr of Riverside, Greenwich, Conn., for May 21.

Saved from two years' imprisonment in Germany for "race defilement," Mrs. Charlotte Israel looked at her 4-day-old son today, lying next to her in a bed in Irvington General Hospital, and said: "Hitler shall never have him now--he shall be an American."

More than 10,000 disputes over eligibility for State unemployment insurance benefits have been cleared up through the "short-cut" procedure devised by the State Labor Department .to speed the handling of disputed claims, the division of placement and unemployment insurance announced last night.
Weather research scientists said today that they believed they had found a way to predict thunderstorms twenty-four to thirty-six hours in advance.
A further sharp recovery in outside markets offset the influence of lower foreign quotations and prices on the Cotton Exchange gained 9 to 11 points yesterday.

Turpentine firm, 23 3/4-24c; sales, 72 barrels; receipts, 342 barrels; shipments, 627 barrels; stock, 23,336 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 253; receipts, 2,082: shipments. 3,073; stock, 63,378. Quote: B. $3.50; D, $3.75; E,. $4; F, $4.70; G, H, I, K, $4.90; M, $5; N, $5.35; WG, $5.85; WW, X, $6.50.

The Stage Relief Fund will be augmented by an "Easter Bonnet and Top Hat Luncheon" on Easter Sunday at the Sherry-Netherland. A feature will be a contest for the best ensembles worn by the guests with a jury of men and women passing judgment on the merits of their respective groups.
The current programs of the Library Committees of the Senate and House call for action on the Pepper-Coffee bill to establish an independent Federal Bureau of Fine Arts.
The most extensive series of army manoeuvres since the World War will be held in various parts of the United States from now until next Fall, it became known yesterday.

Without adding to his statement and speech on returning from a European trip a few days ago, former President Herbert Hoover left on the Twentieth Century Limited at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon for California.
Following the discovery of numerous cases of wholesale smuggling into Chilean ports, Argentine business circles here have pointed out that police measures are insufficient to cope with the situation.

Plans are under way for a card party and tea for the benefit of the scholarship and building fund of Marymount College, Tarrytown, which will take place April 27 at the Marymount School, 1,028 Fifth Avenue.

Mayor La Guardia and Park Commissioner Robert Moses will be speakers at the rededication exercises Wednesday at Bowling Green Park, which has been restored by the Department of Parks. The announcement was made yesterday by the Bowling Green Celebrations Committee, which is planning the event and has arranged for a historical pageant.

Without adding to his statement and speech on returning from a European trip a few days ago, former President Herbert Hoover left on the Twentieth Century Limited at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon for California.
Following the discovery of numerous cases of wholesale smuggling into Chilean ports, Argentine business circles here have pointed out that police measures are insufficient to cope with the situation.

Plans are under way for a card party and tea for the benefit of the scholarship and building fund of Marymount College, Tarrytown, which will take place April 27 at the Marymount School, 1,028 Fifth Avenue.

Mayor La Guardia and Park Commissioner Robert Moses will be speakers at the rededication exercises Wednesday at Bowling Green Park, which has been restored by the Department of Parks. The announcement was made yesterday by the Bowling Green Celebrations Committee, which is planning the event and has arranged for a historical pageant.

A DOCUMENT which has become famous in Mexican history because parts of it form the basis of the republic's Constitution of today is recalled with six stamps inscribed "Conmemorativo Plan de Guadalupe-Marzo 26 de 1913."

THE village, Francis Brett Young insists, is wholly imaginary. And he handles his characters with the novelist's touch from first to last. But the chief merit and sound value of his delightfully written book lie nevertheless in its realism. .

Heroically withstanding a biting gale from the north, frostbite and the desperate efforts of a sorely harassed band of Indians, the airtight defenses of the Giants chalked up another notable triumph today as Colonel Bill Terry's troops began their long trek home.

Lack of social vision and a narrow viewpoint on the question of trade unionism were factors that helped eliminate some of the 114 candidates who had applied for the two Board of Examiners' positions, Paul Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, indicated yesterday.
Society needs "the engineer plus" to meet the modern challenge of drought, dust and floods, John C. Page, United States Reclamation Commissioner, told the Nebraska Engineering Society here tonight.

The junior classes of the New York University Washington Square College and School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance last night held their annual promenades. The Washington Square College prom took place at the Plaza Hotel and the School of Commerce event was held at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended March 30, aggregated $7,146,000,000, or 7 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 24 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

The Federal Housing Administration points out that in view of the expected increase in the number of mortgage applications involving the construction of new houses costing $6,000 or less, the submission of adequate plans and specifications is of great importance.

AMERIT badge In coin collecting has just been added to the Boy Scout merit badge program, which embraces more than 100 subjects in hobby, craft and vocational fields. Many lads in khaki will undoubtedly join the ranks of America's ten to twenty thousand coin collectors.

Although slow to break from the barrier, Lighthorse Harry Cooper came like the wind in the fifth annual running of the Masters' golf tournament today and at the quarter-pole was leading by two lengths.

The John Marshall College of Law will debate with Harvard University tomorrow evening at the Law School in Jersey City on the subject: "Resolved, That Congress Should Adopt a Regional Power Program Embodying the Basic Principles of the TVA."

Bulletin, the Hunter College weekly newspaper, is conducting a survey of college opinion to ascertain the sentiment of students and staff with regard to the publication. The campaign is being conducted through questionnaires distributed to representative groups, discussions held by clubs and interviews with students in the columns of the paper.
More than five hundred members of society of the North Shore colonies attended the second annual ball of the Buckram Beagles, tonight, at the Piping Rock Club and the many dinners which preceded it.

Dejay Shriner, New Rochelle High School captain, won the annual invitation interscholastic foils competition sponsored by the America, Fencers League of America, on the strips of the Salle d'Armes Vince yesterday.

" Stop the march of dictators," said Joseph Jacobs of Amsterdam, regional treasurer of the Young People's League of the United Synagogues of America, in an address at the annual convention here today.
Mrs. Andrew Saks, widow of one of the founders of Saks Co., died yesterday in her apartment in the Hotel Surrey, 20 East Seventysixth Street, at the age of 77.

DARWIN L. TEILHET after making a considerable reputation as a mystery story writer, has now turned to what the publishers, for lack of a better word, most inexactly call a serious novel. As a matter of fact, it is anything but serious.

Without winning a single race, Corny Shields tied with his dinghy Prudence today for the Class B point lead in the regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club. He wound up with 94 points. the same as Eddie Maxwell, who had won three out of the five contests in Tu Yung Tu.

Miss Gertrude Mehling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer F. Mehling of this city, was married this evening at her parents' home to Dr. Philip F. Partington, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Partington of East Orange, N. J. Only the families and close friends were present.
Mrs. Joseph Kennedy, wife of the United States Ambassador, was the guest of honor at a luncheon at the American Women's Club Wednesday which was given to welcome her as the new honorary president.

Declaring that the New York World's Fair of 1939 would be an important factor in maintaining world-wide peace, Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, in an address last night at the annual dinner of the Long Island Association at the Hotel Commodore, asserted that with sixtyfive nations taking part in it it would represent a "League of Nations" which through the exposition would work in harmony and cooperation toward promoting international good-will.

Mrs. Agnes L. Dana won an uncontested divorce from Charles A. Dana, New York manufacturer, at Yerington Wednesday, it was learned here today. She charged cruelty. District Judge Clark J. Guild ordered all records sealed.

THE broadcasters have stepped into the newspaper field to find a president for the National Association of Broadcasters and named Mark Foster Ethridge, general manager of The Courier Journal and Times of Louisville, Ky.
A fine headline over a cheerful news item: "USHA Announces Labor Pact Here-Nathan Straus, United States Housing

PAN AMERICAN AND IMPERIAL AIRWAYS will resume stops at Port Washington, L. I., next Wednesday on the United States-Bermuda flying boat service, the companies recently announced. Pan American will retain its operating base at Baltimore and thus serve both Baltimore and New York with passenger and mail service. Planes bound for Bermuda will leave Port Washington at 10:30 A. M. on Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday. .

A concert and reception will be given at 3 o'clock this afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria in honor of Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President. The occasion will be the presentation of the Albert Einstein Medal for Humanitaritanism to Mrs. Roosevelt, who will be the fifth recipient.

PALM BEACH, Fla.--The most obvious reason for the recent large exodus of yachts and chartered boats to the keys is the approaching close to the annual fishing contest of the Sailfish Club on Tuesday. For it is in the waters surrounding Cat Cay. Walker Key and West End that the heavy-tackle fish such as marlin, tuna and tarpon abound in greatest size and numbers. mbers.
Frank Yerse of Cleveland topped a highrolling group in the American Bowling Congress today by scoring 725 in the singles and taking second place.

JUST seventy-eight years ago today a wiry young rider, dressed in the regulation red shirt, blue trousers and buckskin jacket, swung aboard his mount and amid cheers and cannon roar tore off from St. Joseph, Mo., toward the foothills of the Sierras. s.

Miss Queena Mario, soprano, of the Metropolitan Opera House, and Eugene Speicher, New York artist, have accepted the invitation of the Ulster County Apple Blossom Festival committee to serve as judges in selecting the apple blossom queen.

Automobile fatalities in 129 leading cities during the first twelve weeks of 1938 were 22 per cent fewer than a year ago, the Census Bureau said today. The toll in these cities was 1,832, as compared with 2,340 in the similar 1937 period.

May Yohe won. the right today to become an American citizen once again. The actress, who owned the Hope diamond in other years, completed at the Naturalization Office all preliminaries to being repatriated and will take the oath on Monday.

For the first time since the Austrian events the French today had an opportunity to cheer their army-and it was cheered to the echo. Thirty thousand wildly enthusiastic spectators were brought to their feet and cried themselves hoarse with "Vive I'Armee, Vive La France!" this afternoon at a cavalry demonstration staged by the Ministry of War in connection with the annual horse show at the Grand Palais.

Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Bailwitz of Great Neck, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Virginia Cavanagh, to William Andrew Pollard Jr. of Garden City, L. I., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Andrew Pollard of Norfolk, Va., and Miami Beach, Fla.
The first annual Glasgow speaking contest for students at Stevens Institute of Technology will be held on April 13.

Eight Summer cabins are nearing completion for occupancy this season at Highland Lakes, near Stockholm, in the upper section of Sussex County, N. J., and plans are being made by several owners of property overlooking the lake to construct cottages for Summer use.

More than 200 young persons, including those home from schools and colleges for the vacation, attended a cotillion at the Milbrook Country Club tonight. The house was decorated with forsythia and other Spring flowers. Mrs. Daniel J. Bradley Jr. was chairman of the committee.

Mrs. Willetta Courter Gildersleeve, wife of the Rev. Nelson Burroughs Gildersleeve, rector of St. Agnes Episcopal Church here, died today at the rectory at the age of 40. Mrs. Gildersleeve was secretary of the Orange district of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark and had been organist at the church since last September.

Dr. Frederic S. Lee, Research Professor of Physiology, and Dr. Wendell T. Bush, Professor of Philosophy, will retire from the faculty of Columbia University on June 30, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler. president of the university, said yesterday in an announcement of retirements, promotions and leaves of absense.

Larry White, manager of Fred Apostoli, San Francisco middleweight title contender, who defeated Glen Lee at Madison Square Garden Friday night, said yesterday his fighter will leave the city this week for a rest.

Ohio State University At one of the recent large Spring shows a display of "four seasons in a border" attracted much attention. Many observers were appatently astonished to see the succession of lovely pictures which could be created in such a limited area. .

WHEN American shipping men established the Black Ball Line of Atlantic packets, in 1816, they made definite provision for the comfort of passengers. And between that year and 1830 the passenger could begin to feel himself really an important person aboard ship.

Ground was broken last week on the former estate of the late Mrs. Alice Grace d'Oench, in the Flower Hill section of Manhasset, L. I., for the development of a North Shore community of medium-priced homes by Mott Brothers, builders. They plan to erect 300 residences there.

After a lapse of twenty-three years since the last attempt at a general revision of the State Constitution was made, another Constitutional Convention, the eighth in the history of the State since 1777, will assemble in Albany at noon on Tuesday.

Taking advantage of the sharp decreases in liquor prices, caused by the week-old price war, customers crowded into retail liquor stores throughout the city yesterday and bought up stock for the week-end.
The regular Board of Education meeting will be held on Wednesday at 4 P. M. at 500 Park Avenue. Action on the appointment of several high school principals is expected at this time.

Pope Plus has created a central office in Rome to supervise the Catholic Action movement throughout the world, the Osservatore Romano discloses. The Pope named Giuseppe Cardinal Pizzardo, long active in the Catholic Action movement in Italy, to head the office.

With two persons dead and six injured, one seriously, after a fire in an old-fashioned three-story brick rooming house at 369-371 West Thirty-fifth Street, near Ninth Avenue, Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy and his staff were pushing an investigation yesterday into the cause of the blaze, which started just before dawn.

Alfred W. Abrams, until 1934 director of the visual instruction division of the State Education Department, died today. He was 70 years old and had served in the Education Department for twenty-five years.

Hardy Mersey-side shipworkers tossing red-hot rivets along the sky-high field of steel that will be the sundeck of the new 33,000-ton Mauretania, call her "the mystery ship." These workers in Cammell Laird's famous yard have just completed the remarkable aircraft carrier Ark Royal.

Kansas City elected this week a Mayor, eight Councilmen and two municipal judges. The ticket supported by the Democratic boss, Tom Pendergast, made a clean sweep with the exception of one Councilman, who lost to Charles (Tod) Woodbury,

Charging that Britain is losing the air-armaments race to Germany, J. L. Garvin urges the government in The Observer today to invoke the manufacturing resources of Canada and make large purchases of planes in the United States.

Herbert Morrison, member of Parliament, a leader of the British Labor party and of the London City Council, told more than 1,200 members of the American Labor party here yesterday that the establishment and growth of their party had been "received with pleasure and enthusiasm in Great Britain.
Cuyler Ten Eyck, a brother of former State Agriculture Commissioner Peter G. Ten Eyck, died today at his home here after a year's illness. He was 72 years old.

In the Court of Claims of the United States today the following calendar for Monday, April 4, was announced: Call of the April Calendar Rule to show cause. Plaintiffs to show cause why the following cases should not be dismissed:

Because placement of its own graduates in home economics work has been outstandingly successful when positions were scarce in almost all professional fields, New Jersey College for Women will bring educational possibilities in this field to the attention of high school students at a conference on April 12.

Another death today brought the Illinois toll of the midweek tonado to thirteen, while forty-eight residents of Tazewell County still were confined in hospitals at Pekin and Peoria. Mrs. Mary Jones, the latest victim, died of injuries caused when the storm destroyed her home.
The engagement of Miss Mary Jane Pelley, daughter of John J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, and Mrs. Pelley, to Willem Dirkse-van-Schalkwyk,

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is gratifying to note the interest in soil conservation manifested by Thomas C. Spelling in his letter in THE TIMES of March 27. As chairman of the State Soil Conservation Committee of New Jersey, however, I feel that certain phases of the present soil conservation program should be clarified.

The National Labor Relations Board today announced certification of the National Maritime Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, as the Sole bargaining agency for unlicensed personnel on vessels operated out of Atlantic and Gulf ports by three New York shipping concerns.

Playing during showers today, the Navy nine won from Dartmouth by 7 to 2. The Middies tallied five runs in the fourth on four singles registered against Pyrtex, who had just succeeded Litchfield on the mound, three passes by the same pitcher, and Salvia's sacrifice.

The Anschluss and the consolidation of the Austrian economy with the German raised the German currency circulation almost 1,000,000,000 marks last week to a record total of 7,571,000,000 as of March 31.

Rising to defend the consumer in a period of increasing prices, the Consumers League of New York has adopted a program calling for a series of investigations on the distribution of present higher production costs.

To improve the atmosphere during the negotiations with Czechoslovakia's minorities, an amnesty for political offenders will be proclaimed shortly, it was announced today. The Sudeten Germans will chiefly benefit from this act, the scope of which, however, is not yet known.
WITH the advent of Spring, rooms are taking on a gayer air, which is quite in line with the trend toward a lighter touch in interior decoration.

The price of old iron for export has become so thigh that La Noticia, one of Managua's leading newspapers, says today that iron crosses from tombstones and iron fences around graves have been stolen from some cemeteries and sold to metal dealers.
Closing with a rush on the inside, Sir Oracle won the $3,000 added Stockton Mandicap at Bay Meadows today. It was a six-furlong dash, clocked in 1:111-5.

STATION WMCA is now broadcasting from new sound-proof, air-conditioned studios and through new equipment in the Hollywood Theatre Building, 1,657 Broadway, at Fifty-second Street, but complete occupancy will not be in effect until the middle of the month.

Mr. and Mrs. William G. Jopson of this city, formerly of Nottingham, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Madge Jopson, to Soren J. W. Graae, son of G. F. A. H. Graae, Permanent Secretary of Art and Education in Denmark, and Mrs. Graae of Copenhagen.

George N. Jesse, former Republican Assemblyman from the Twenty-third Assembly District and an authority on housing and rent laws, died yesterday at his home, 35-63 Eightieth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 72 years old.

Even Mayor Hague and the Jersey City police have had to bow to last Monday's decision of the Supreme Court of the United States that "the liberty of the press is not confined to newspapers and periodicals," but "necessarily embraces pamphlets and leaflets."
It takes stout hearts to retreat in good order without losing courage or determination. You cannot expect it from every soldier or group of soldiers, for it is a terrifying, disheartening business.

Mr. and Mrs. James J. Pender have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rosalie Elizabeth Pender, to Norman Barrett Hollister, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Hollister. The marriage is to take place in June.

The Parke-Bernet Galleries will sell on Friday and Saturday afternoons English and French furniture and decorations, including table appointments, Oriental art, tapestries and Oriental rugs, comprising property collected by Mrs. Leonard Elmhirst, property of the late Mrs. S. K. Pendleton and of Mrs, Nathan Straus.

It is not often possible to prove beyond doubt from statistics that a given economic policy has been sound or unsound. The economic forces at work are so numerous that a given result may be plausibly attributed to any among several or to a combination of them.

WE left Spain with overwhelming memories of the war's desolation and not a little relief. From the heated compartment of the Toulouse train we looked out at cattle grazing in the fields and at peaceful, contented villages sand thought of what we had seen south of the French border.

Although it is too early to gather a complete statistical picture, the indications from a preliminary survey of the country are that the outlook for jobs for college graduates next June is considerably poorer than that of a year ago.

Fordham College will return to the "old-fashioned" type of graduation this June by holding the college commencement exercises apart from those of the other schools and colleges of Fordham University and by dispensing with outside speakers.

MR. SAERCHINGER is a pioneer in a type of journalism now so familiar that it is a part of everyday life. He did not invent the wireless telephone, nor was he the first to talk over it, but he was the first to organize and systematize transatlantic broadcasting.

Consideration of objectives and methods in college publicity, including a discussion of the newspaper as an educational medium, will be the theme of the second district conference of the American College Publicity Association at Drew University next Saturday, F. Taylor Jones, Drew registrar and conference chairman, announced today.
Governor Lehman's vetoes exceeded his approvals today, as he acted on thirteen bills left in his hands by the Legislature. The Governor vetoed-seven of the bills and signed six.
Administration leaders discussed today a proposal to make "employment" loans to selected railroads to spur industrial production and to meet temporarily the problem of financing the railroads.
The Newark Bears scored their ninth victory in a row in Grapefruit League competition today, turning back their Yankee farm team comrades from the American Association, the Kansas City Blues, 4 to 2.

Construction has just started on a six-story apartment house on the southeast corner of Hudson and Grove Streets, in the westerly section of Greenwich Village. Three five-story tenements, among the oldest of that type in the locality, have been torn down.

The Princeton University Glee Club will make a Southern trip of five concerts next week as a part of the college's Spring vacation activities, and the varsity debate panel has scheduled simultaneous tours through the South and West. Spring recess began today and will last until next Sunday.

A NEW and crucial chapter in our naval annals is being written at Washington with President Roosevelt as author in chief. For the President-often rated as more "big navy" than the admirals--is pushing vigorously the authorization in Congress of a 20 per cent increase in the navy,

SAILORS have curious ways, and none more curious than the measurements they use. When they measure depths at sea they do their measuring in fathoms, one fathom being six feet. When they measure speed, they do it in knots, one knot being a speed of one nautical mile per hour.

Tow-headed Fred Wolcott, Rice Institute's 6-foot 2-inch sophomore, bettered the accepted world 120yard high hurdles record with a downwind burst of 13.9 seconds at the eleventh annual Texas. Relays today.
An early lead of four lengths enabled Mrs. Ethel V. Mars's highly rated Tiger to stave off a final challenge and win the third running of the $5,000 added Arkansas Derby as Oaklawn Park closed today.

When the Executive Reorganization Bill is enacted into law--assuming that it will be--it will bear about as much relationship to the original proposals sponsored by the President's committee as a peanut to an elephant, but even in its emasculated form it will serve as an instrument to coordinate one of the most loosely knit governmental organizations in modern history.
Finalists for the Grady Oratorical Contest to be held Campus Day, May 1, at Manhattan College, have been selected by Professor Donald J. Carty, head of the Department of Public Speaking.
The League of Nations Secretariat has announced the opening of a worldwide competition for scenarios for two educational sound movies on the League of Nations.
Closing with a rush on the inside, Sir Oracle won the $3,000 added Stockton Mandicap at Bay Meadows today. It was a six-furlong dash, clocked in 1:111-5.

STATION WMCA is now broadcasting from new sound-proof, air-conditioned studios and through new equipment in the Hollywood Theatre Building, 1,657 Broadway, at Fifty-second Street, but complete occupancy will not be in effect until the middle of the month.

Mr. and Mrs. William G. Jopson of this city, formerly of Nottingham, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Madge Jopson, to Soren J. W. Graae, son of G. F. A. H. Graae, Permanent Secretary of Art and Education in Denmark, and Mrs. Graae of Copenhagen.

George N. Jesse, former Republican Assemblyman from the Twenty-third Assembly District and an authority on housing and rent laws, died yesterday at his home, 35-63 Eightieth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 72 years old.
