Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge of Madison, N. J., tonight chose the old English sheep dog Champion Ideal Weather, owned by Leonard Collins of Toronto and handled by Alf Loveridge, as best in show at the International Kennel Club of Chicago exhibition in the International Amphitheatre at the Union Stock Yards.
Mr. and Mrs. J. Macy Willets have come from Cassilis House, New Marlboro, Mass., and have joined Mr. and Mrs. J. Macy Willets Jr. at the Berkshire.

The gold medal of the American Arbitration Association for "the promotion of international good-will and distinguished service in commercial peace" will be awarded this year to Juan T. Trippe, president of the Pan American Airways, according to the joint announcement issued for publication today by the American Arbitration Association and the New York Foreign Trade Week Committee.

The net asset value of the Phoenix Securities Corporation on Feb. 28 was $5,981,733, compared with $10,862,996 on Aug. 31, 1937, according to the company's financial statement for the six. months through February, issued for publication today by Wallace Groves, chairman.

In a report on the pneumonia control activities of the Health Department, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner, announced yesterday there were 40 per cent fewer deaths From the disease during the first quarter of this year than occurred in the same periods in 1936 and 1937.

The following dispatch is from a staff correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES who has just finished a motor trip through Italian Tyrol, over the Brenner Pass and into Austria. This is the first of three articles.

With everybody talking about the necessity for forming "a strong government of national union" and nobody having a clear idea how to create it Premier Leon Blum tomorrow will present his plans for restoration of the French financial position to his Cabinet and to Chamber of Deputies commissions and groups.

The Jewish Education Association gave a reception last night at the Hotel Commodore to certified teachers in the Jewish Schools of New York City at which forty-five teachers received permanent, and ninetytwo temporary, licenses.

The Civilian Conservation Corps' expenditure of $1,920,000,000 thus far on its program has been "a good investment of public funds," Robert Fechner, director of the corps, said today in a fifth anniversary report.

A request by Japan for information concerning the governmentowned railroad connecting this city with the Pacific port of Puntarenas has been refused by the railroad's manager, Claudio Cortes Castro, brother of President Leon Cortes Castro.

The Newark City Commission will resume its budget hearings tomorrow, with at least three of the five commissioners ready to pare their staffs to help reduce a tax rate now set at $5.34 to each $100 of assessed value. The 1937 rate was $3.69.
According to Edna St. Vincent Millay in a moment of depression, "April comes like an idiot, babbling and strewing flowers."

Beatrice Handel bought from the New fork Savings Bank, 543-545 W 16th St, L00x100, for a consideration shown as 5157.iOO and gave back a purchase money mortage for $122,500, due according to the bond, she simultaneously conveying the propertyy to the Wadswalt Holding Corp., .475 Broadway. care M. S. Meyers.

Miss Ruth Mary Burdette, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert U. Burdette of this place, will have Miss Isabella E. Laidlaw of Englewood for maid of honor at her marriage to Anson Boulton Herrick of Woodmere, L. I., which will take place here on the afternoon of April 29.
Floyd Tangier Smith, American big game hunter, arrived here today with four giant pandas from the wilds of Western Szechuan Province.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 81.2, which compares with 81.9 a week ago, 82.3 two weeks ago 82.8 three weeks ago and 83 four weeks ago.

Praise of President Roosevelt's action in extending a welcome to refugees of European nations was given yesterday by the Rev. C. Everett Wagher in a sermon at the Union Methodist Church, 233 West Forty-eighth Street.

In recognition of "a lifetime of devoted service to every communal cause in the country," Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, received the Albert Einstein medal for humanitarianism yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The Right Rev. W. H. Frere, Bishop of Truro from 1923 to 1935, who said he had been the only member of a Church of England religious order to be made a Bishop since the Reformation, died in the House of the Resurrection at Mirfield, Yorkshire, yesterday, at the age of 74. He had been in failing health for some time.

At last due honor is to be paid to one of the most ancient, useful, wise and frugal of workers. Columbia, capital of Maury County in Mid-Tennessee, is the world's largest Rialto, curb exchange and street market for mules.

A series of one-act plays, enacted and directed by the members of the play direction course of the College of New Rochelle, will be presented in a final rehearsal at an open meeting of the class Wednesday evening in Chidwick Auditorium. Miss Miriam Little Simons, head of the Speech Department, conducts the course.
After the quietest week-end since Germany's annexation of Austria the House of Commons tomorrow will debate another Labor vote of censure, which contends Prime Minister Neville

Broadway box-office treasurers were reported yesterday to be angered over the clause in the contract between the League of New York Theatres and the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union which forbids treasurers, managers and producers to accept gratuities from theatre ticket brokers.

The Japanese tobacco monopoly will not be in the market for American leaf tobacco for the next eighteen months, the Department of Commerce has announced. Size of stocks and restricted consumption were given as the causes.
The possibility that New York's turf enthusiasts will see Seabiscuit and War Admiral meet this season was disclosed by the State Racing Commission yesterday.

The Republican leaders who are expected to furnish the leadership for the majority in the State's eighth Constitutional Convention began arriving here tonight, in advance of the actual opening of the convention's session on Tuesday in the Assembly Chamber.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor left Cap d'Antibes this morning for Paris. Last night they entertained at dinner David Lloyd George and Herman Rogers.

Speaking at a meeting sponsored by Roman Catholic parishes at Holy Name Auditorium, Dr. Joseph F. Thorning, Professor of Sociology and Social History at Mount St. Mary's College, Emmitsburg, Md., appealed for the the recognition by this country of the Insurgents in Spain because of the "widely recognized ability and determination of General Franco to respect international obligations."

Leghorn Trading Co., oLive oil importers. in 21 West St.; Vaughn Panchaud. cargo surveyors, in 24. Stone St.: Commercial Telegraphers Union. in 15 Whitehall St.: Helen Merchant. investment counsel, in 30 Broad St.; Boukstein Clark, attorneys, in 50 Broad St.; Cushman Wakefield. brokers.

The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe was one of the few railroads to increase its mileage by the construction of new line in 1937, according to the report for the twelve months issued yesterday by S. T. Bledsoe, president.
On the money market here the call money rate has hardened from 1 7/8 per cent to 2 3/4 per cent because of the end-ofthe-month expansion in business requirements. Nevertheless,
Dr. Henry W. Ring, retired eye and ear specialist and a former opthalmologist at Yale, died today at his apartment here at the age of 81.

The fourteenth annual awards of fellowships of the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation for 1938 were announced yesterday. Grants totaling $135,000 were awarded to fifty-eight scholars and artists chosen from nearly 1,000 applicants as the most likely to add to the "scholarly and artistic power" of this country. The fund,
The Public Service Fellowship, given annually by Barnard College, has been awarded to Miss Elizabeth Watson Deuel of Pueblo, Col., Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve announced yesterday.

The body of Henry W. Putnam, builder of Putnam Memorial Hospital here, who died Wednesday at Miami Beach, Fla., arrived here by special train from New York last night and is lying in state at the Nurses' Home. The funeral will be held at the Second Congregational Church tomorrow afternoon.

Creation of a central planning board to direct the renovation and expansion of hospital and related health services in the New York metropolitan area, the estimated costs of which will be $441,000,000 to 1960, is urged by Dr. Haven Emerson of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University in an article in the April issue of Better Times, publication of the Welfare Council of New York City.

Jack Kirkland, playwright, and Hails Stoddard, actress, were married today in Springtown by Justice of the Peace L. D. Stever, despite Miss Stoddard's statement in Montreal yesterday that they were already married.

Four trainloads of refugee militiamen were repatriated to republican territory at Cerhere today after a referendum held yesterday in which the Spanish soldiers received the choice of whether they would return via Hendaye or Cerbere-that is to say whether Insurgent or Loyalist Spain.

Prices of cotton futures fluctuated in a narrow range last week. The low point was at the 8.50-cent level for May contracts, or about the same as in the previous week. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines of 1 to 6 points, making the fourth successive week in which net changes have been on the down side.

The Cardinals defeated the Reds, 7 to 2, in the final game for the Rhinelanders of the Grapefruit League training season today. Pepper Martin led the hitting attack with a homer, two triples and a single, driving in three Cardinal runs and scoring two.

More than 500 persons attended the cornerstone laying of the Bayside Jewish Center, 207th Street and Crocheron Avenue, Bayside, Queens, yesterday. Delegations were present from Jewish centers in Jamaica, Flushing and Long Island City.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, demanded yesterday the support of Catholics in his fight against the Committee for Industrial Organization-a group which he represented as opening the way for Communist
On the Stock Exchange, last week was marked by a decline of 61/4 points in the averages, follow d by recovery before the week-end of all the earlier loss.

Not since Burke broke with Fox has there been a sadder hour. Guffey and Earle, the Democratic twins of Pennsylvania, have parted company. In the eighteenth century quarrel Burke was at fault. In the Keystone row Governor Earle is the original transgressor.

The route of the motor parade or Review of the New York World's Fair 1939 was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, who estimated that the sixteen-mile route would enable between 1,000,000 and 1,500,000 persons to see the spectacle.

Van Vilet Place arranged a martgage of $5,500 for three years on the dwelling at 340 West 27th St. The estate of Alfred Michaels sold through Moyse Goldsticker, Inc., a $20,000 second mortgage on the apartment house at 325 West 93d St.

Mrs. Elizabeth Perham Moore, widow of Albert H. Moore and known for years on the stage as Juno Burbank, died Saturday after a long illness at the home of a sister, Mrs. Addie Ray, at 605 West 113th Street.

Miss Gracyn Wheeler of Santa Monica, Calif., United States Wightman Cup team member, defeated Miss A. G. Curtis of Great Britain, 6--2, 6--0, today in the final of the women's singles in the international lawn tennis championships.

Immediate evacuation of the plants seized forty-eight hours ago by members of the Committee for Industrial Organization utility workers union will be the first and major demand tomorrow by the spokesmen for the Consumers Power Company at the conference in Detroit called by Governor Murphy.

Nothing is likely to happen tomorrow that will be quite so important to the citizens of New York State as the opening of our eighth State Constitutional Convention at Albany. The questions that will come before the convention during the next four or five months will touch all our lives.

Mrs. Weston G. Frome of Berkeley, Calif., and her 23-year-old daughter, Nancy, were found beaten to death today. The bodies, stripped to underwear and shoes, were found by members of a searching party six miles east of Van Horn.

Nineteen branch offices of New York Stock Exchange firms have been discontinued recently, according to the weekly bulletin of that institution. In the same week six new offices were opened and several moved to new addresses. The firms and locations of the closed offices were listed as follows:

No let-up in the number of exhibitions in the art galleries is indicated as April opens. Some thirty new attractions are on the calendar of the current week and, although no museum or large group shows figure, a number of well-known artists are represented and subjects and media of wide variety are in evidence.
The Czechoslovakian trade agreement is a "poor example of Yankee trading," the American Tariff League holds in an analysis issued for publication today.
ADVENTURE WITH WOMEN, by Sophie Kerr. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.) A novel by the author of "Fine to Look At."

THE cruelest and most stimulating novel of the season is Henry de Montherlant's "Pity for Women."* At least I have seen nothing to compare with it. It is in two parts, the first, translated by Thomas McGreevy, called "Young Girls"; the second, translated by John Rodker, providing the common title.

One hundred and forty members and managers of Princeton athletic teams have been awarded official university insignia for participation in Winter sports, according to the list announced today by R. Kenneth Fairman, '34, acting graduate manager of athletics.

THE open roadster rolled to a stop and Mr. Al Schacht leaped out. He was bronzed like an Indian from his exercises in various baseball training camps in the South. The Clown Prince of Baseball advanced and said in part:
Barton Lee Mallory, a leader in Southern business circles, died at his home this afternoon after an illness of four days. He was 72 years old.
Despite the continued foreign exchange restrictions, many Reich industrial leaders have left for Austria.
Ten persons were killed and thirtytwo injured today in crashes of two cars participating in Italy's annual 1,000-mile auto race classic.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull has been asked to make formal protest to the Japanese Government against the continued occupation of American-owned mission. property by the Japanese Army in the lower Yangtze Valley, it was announced yesterday by the Committee on Relief in China of the Foreign Missions Conference of North America.

The police force of Mayor Frank J. Hague made it plain today that it would not even tolerate guards on strike-breakers' trucks passing through the city. Strike-breaking has been taboo in Jersey City for a long time past.
Insurgent siege guns at the gates of Madrid blasted at the former government capital today in the worst shelling of the civil war.

The foreign-exchange market here has been quiet and fairly evenly balanced, with transactions relatively small. Purchases of foreign exchange still are being made by trade and industry by reason of the deficit in the trade balance, but there is little exporting of capital. Furthermore,

The Society of Designing Engineers, an independent organization of 2,000 automobile engineers, has voted to join the Federation of Architects, Engineers, Chemists and Technicians, an affiliate of the C. I. O., it was announced yesterday by Marcel Scherer, national organizational director of the federation.

George W. Johnston, chairman of the board of the Johnston Collins Co., an insurance agency at 80 John Street, died yesterday morning of pneumonia at his home in Yorktown Heights, N. Y., after a brief illness. His age was 75.
The week's stock market opened on an uncertain note, with some demand for potashes and specialties connected with Austria, developed irregularly and closed predominantly firm.

Our foreign trade in February, as reported by the Department of Commerce, reflected in most regards the influence of business reaction, which had already, in January and December, shaped the course both of imports and of exports, as contrasted with a year ago. It has always been an

Increased realty activity in the Bronx was indicated by the large number of sales and leases reported over the week-end. The trading showed a demand for apartment houses, banks figuring as the sellers in some of the deals.

Violations of the biblical commandment "Thou shalt not steal" are of several varieties, for which, in turn, there are several varieties of reasons, the Rev. Dr. George Caleb Moor said in his sermon yesterday at the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, at Thirty-first Street.

Behind the brilliant pitching of Lefty Tom Ananicz and Larry Shea, the St. John's University baseball team shut out the Brooklyn College nine, 14 to 0, in its opening game of the season at Dexter Park yesterday.
The seven deadly sins of modern times, as selected by three authors, were listed yesterday by the Rev. Harold S. Rambo, pastor of the Adams Memorial Presbyterian Church, 207 East Thirtieth Street.

The Federation of German-American Clubs, in convention here tonight, called on Americans to "eliminate all side issues from the fundamental thesis of sound democracy versus criminally unsound fascism."

An automobile and a truck were in collision near here today and Leroy Barkin, 31, a lawyer of New York, was killed. Mr. Barkin was riding in the car with Irving K. Fabrikant, diamond importer of New York, who was cut about the head and face but not seriously hurt.
The chief purpose of Jesus's life was death, the Rev. Dr. William Hubert Rogers said yesterday in his morning sermon at the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventyninth Street.

Egbert Moxham, sailing Sandpiper, defeated Bob Fraser, in Hot Spot, by one point in the Class B one-design group, and Lenny Romagna cleaned up as usual in Class D in the weekly regatta of the Manhasset Bay dinghy fleet today.
Representatives of Irish-American cultural and social groups will honor Paul Vincent Carroll, Sara Allgood and Dudley Digges at a dinner at the Hotel Astor Sunday night. Mr. Carroll is the author

Homer De Wilton Brookins, who was associated with The WatchmanExaminer, national Baptist periodical, from 1888 until his resignation in 1935, died here today at his home, 27 Mount Airy Road, at the age of 82.

Some idea of the severity of the fall in security prices that occurred while the panicky conditions prevailed early in March can be gathered from the Bankers Magazine's calculation that in the month ended on March 18, the depreciation of 365 representative securities aggregated almost f271,000,000, or 4 per cent.

The kingdom of God is a present, personal, priceless and permanent reality, and these characteristics furnish the key for the proper understanding of His kingdom, the Rev. Richard P. Mallery, pastor of the Fourth Reformed Church of Philadelphia, declared yesterday in his sermon before the congregation of the East Eighty-ninth Street Reformed Church, between Park and Madison Avenues.

Kerry defeated Cork by 3--2 as the Gaelic football season opened before 1,000 fans at Innisfail Park yesterday. The game was a senior league semi-final and Kerry will meet the winner of the KildareMayo contest next Sunday in the final for the 1938 championship on April 17.

Miss Jane Cothran of Greenville, S. C., and West Palm Beach, Fla., won the women's North and South golf championship today by defeating Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta, 3 and 2, in the final round of the thirty-sixth annual tournament.

More than 300 persons, many of them prominent in stage, screen and political circles, last night attended a party given by the' Grand Street Boys Association to Bill Robinson, the Negro tap dancer, on his sixtieth birthday.

A new symphony by an American, Quincy Porter, Professor of Music at Vassar College, was performed at yesterday afternoon's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, with the composer conducting.

Mayor La Guardia made a double plea yesterday for tolerance on the part of all Americans and for nonpartisan cooperation "for the next two-years at least" by all politically minded people "for the salvation of this country."
The New York Infirmary for Women and Children will be the beneficiary of a Spring fashion show to be held the evening of April 21 at Bergdorf Goodman, 754 Fifth Avenue.

The Jersey City Giants turned the tables on the Beaumont Oilers of the Texas League today, winning another closely contested battle, 6 to 5. Tom Ferrick went the route for the victors, and while reached for nine hits, kept them scattered.

Followers of the Rev. Carl McIntire, who was ousted from the pulpit of the Collingswood Presbyterian Church by a recent court order, partook of holy communion from paper cups and pie plates today in the first Sunday service held in the Chautauqua tent erected last week as a temporary church. The number of participants was announced as 1.223.

Cooperation of every physician and resident of the State in the national tuberculosis "early diagnosis" campaign being conducted this month was sought today by Dr. Robert E. Plunkett, tuberculosis hospital superintendent of the State Health Department.
C. J. Keppel, headmaster of rome School here, announced today that the preparatory institution would be sold July 1 to a group Whom he identified only as "alumni and friends."

National membership in the Girl Scouts reached 441,964 on Dec. 31, 1937, a gain of 47,598 over 1936, according to the 1937 annual report of Mrs. J. Babington Macaulay, chairman of the board of directors, made public yesterday.

Asbury Park's plan for refunding its $10,400,000 bonded debt, on which it has been in default for several year, has been formally approved and is now in effect, Supreme Court Justice Joseph B. Perskie made known here today.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 36 per cent of capacity, up 2 points from the preceding report and 4 points higher than the average for February.

Chancellor HarryWoodburn Chase of New York University announced yesterday that the university had purchased an eight-story structure adjoining the Washington Square College at Washington Square East, which, with additions, will provide approximately 30,000 square feet of new space for the Washington Square Library and the School of Law.
The issue of collective security or isolation as a means of peace. was discussed yesterday afternoon at a meeting in the Pennsylvania Hotel sponsored by the New York Teachers Guild.
Quotations last month on the Paris stock market declined heavily as a consequence of the Anschluss in Austria and consequent fears of war.
WillysOverland Motors, Inc., of Toledo, Ohio, has been charged by the Federal Trade Commission with unfair methods of competition in advertising the prices of its cars.
Secretary Hull opposed a stay-at-home policy for the United States Navy today, contending it must be left free to defend the rights of American citizens in any part of the world.
Miss Beverly Waring has completed plans for her marriage to Earle Newton Cutler Jr. of Morristown on May 6. The ceremony will be performed in Grace Episcopal Church here by the Rev. Henry

Official quarters here confirm that a note has been sent to the Czechoslovak Government protesting alleged anti-Polish activities by the Communist International in Czechoslovakia that are known and tolerated by the Czech authorities. The Polish envoy at Prague was instructed to request the Czech Government to put an end to these activities.

Alfred Rottenberg, Brooklyn drug manufacturer, bought the Casler farm adjoining the Monmouth County Club on the Eatontown-Freehold Road, Shrewsbury Township, Monmouth County, N. J. Charles E. Sweeney was the broker in the sale of the property, which consists of a fourteen-room house and fifty acres. The buyer will alter

This Styrian Nazi stronghold gave Chancellor Adolf Hitler a reception today that surpassed even his triumphal entry into Vienna a fortnight ago, and the hurricane of "Heils" that greeted his arrival was the final outlet of the Styrian longing for unification with Germany.

Fifteen-year-old Loretta Wilson of 3,232 Tierney Place, the Bronx, became a neighborhood heroine yesterday after saving the life of Lorraine Webb, 3, who had fallen into Eastchester Bay while playing on a dock near her home on the lower floor of the Tierney Place address.

The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin advocated teday that each Congressional district send to Washington a delegation to urge Senators and House members to oppose adoption of a compromise Government Reorganization Bill after the House has disposed of the present measure.
Nose dives by the leaders today turned the Masters' golf tournament into a jig-saw puzzle so complicated that it may take days to put the pieces together.
The United Light and Power Company and subsidiaries reported for 1937 a consolidated net income of $5,182,602, an increase of $674,340, or 14.96 per cent, from that of 1936. The non-consolidated net

Jack Hoerner of Chicago came from behind today by virtue of steady shooting and a last-minute stroke of luck to win the seventh annual Midwest amateur golf tournament with 220 strokes for fifty-four holes.

The Federal Social Security Board has approved a budget of $968,117 for administration of the New York State Unemployment Insurance Law in the quarter ending June 30, but it appeared last night that a deficiency appropriation by Congress would be necessary to assure payment of the full.amount.

A lieutenant was killed, three other firemen were seriously injured and 121 horses were believed to have been burned to death or so badly injured they would have to be destroyed in a spectacular fire last night that swept the Liberty Boarding Stable at 238 Cherry Street on the lower East Side.

The lowest levels for wheat futures on AmerIcan grain exchanges since July, 1935, were reached last week. The shadow of a bumper Winter wheat crop and liquidation by scattered holders of futures were responsible for the decline.

The XB-15, the United States Army's super-bomber, made its first flight over New York City today as part of the program opening Army Week. While high over Manhattan, the plane's commander, Major Oscar Westover, chief of the air corps, talked over radio station WJZ and an NBC network.

On the eve of a scheduled conference with President Roosevelt, representatives of railroad manage- ont and labor were agreed tonight on a proposal calling for direct Federal subsidization of the industry to the extent necessary to maintain employment and payrolls at present levels.

The Labor party, which has been in power in the Queensland Parliament for twenty-four years, except between 1929 and 1932, won the general election yesterday with a surprising majority under the leadership of William Forgan Smith, who has been Premier since 1932.

Roger Fawcett won the high-overall scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday, breaking 100 straight for the fifth time this season. The Winged Foot gunner also set a new 155-target scratch mark of 153 for the year.

That Britain is to lose heavily on her investments in Mexico without having anything effective to. say about the matter was the growing impression in diplomatic circles here today as Mexicans began a campaign for scaling down the debts due the oil companies under President Lazaro Cardenas's expropriation decree.

Winding up the cold-weather racing season today at the Larchmont Yacht Club, Mrs. Helen Hill's Class X boat Dunker and Frank Campbell's B craft Felix recorded top scores for the local dinghy championship.

The Intercollegiate Fencing Association will stage its forty-fifth annual championships in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Astor on Friday and Saturday, April 15 and 16, it was announced yesterday. For the first time since 1934 the full membership will participate, with

Money is the towering concern and obsession of our age, and all our problems from insanity to utopias are conceived in economic terms, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive at 122d Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

Fighting off a bitter last-period offensive in which their opponents played 59 seconds without a goal tender, the Chicago Black Hawks last night' blasted the New York Americans' hopes of gaining the right to battle for the Stanley Cup and the hockey championship of the world.

In an astonishing reversal of form, the New York Athletic Club upset the Optimists last night in the feature of the indoor polo double-header at the Squadron A Armory, 16 to 11, and tied the final scores for the Eastern senior championship.

General Franco's Insurgents finally captured Lerida last evening after savage fighting. Some Loyalists held out in the lower part of the city. Many prisoners were captured. The southern wing penetrated within six miles of Tortosa, where the road between Barcelona and Valencia can be cut.

A statistician attached to the Council of State Governments has been at work on the output of American State Legislatures during 1937. He finds that 7,466 State Senators and Representatives passed 17,194 new laws, an average of about two and one-half laws apiece. They tried unsuccessfully to pass 37,000 other bills, an average of about five apiece.

The Princeton cast of eleven for "The Beaux' Stratagem," fourth annual collaboration of the Princeton University Theatre Intime and the Finch Junior College of New York, was announced today by Richard A. Baer of Washington, president of the Student Theatre.
Virtually every quarter of the entertainment industry rallied to aid the charitable work of the Jewish Theatrical Guild, which gave its annual benefit last night at the Imperial Theatre.
Sharp recoveries in stocks in the last two days of the week eliminated their earlier losses; turnover, 7,372,510 shares.

Corn futures on the Board of Trade here showed independent strength last week and went contrary to the action of other grains, the May delivery selling early yesterday at the highest price since early in January and closing 1/4 cent a bushel net higher for the week. The July was 1/2 cent lower

Six Americans, all of whom served more than six months in international brigades [of the Spanish Loyalist army] and were taken prisoner by the Nationalists [Insurgents] in the Gandesa sector, discussed this morning their reasons for coming

After more than seven hours of grueling competition, the eight men who will represent this section in the semi-finals of the national senior foils championship later in the month were decided upon yesterday on the New York Athletic Club strips. The Salle Santelli team
Members of the Lake Superior Newspaper Guild, C. I. 0. affiliate, voted late tonight to call a strike at the Duluth News-Tribune and Herald, effective immediately.
Two young men were killed and three other youths and a girl were injured when their automobile crashed into a tree on Wilmot Road, near Sprague Avenue, here about 9:30 o'clock tonight.

The church was described as an instrument of social control yesterday by the Rev. Dr. James Palmer of the Biblical Seminary in a sermon at the North New York Congregational Church, East 143d Street near Willis Avenue, the Bronx.

The buildings and grounds of the Knoll Golf Club, one of the most exclusive havens of wealthy men in the metropolitan area in the early 1930's, have been purchased by Thomas A. Desmond of Short Hills, it was revealed today.

Mr. and Mrs. F. Miller Fargo Jr. gave a tea today at Out-of-Bounds, their home here, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Lillian Fargo, to Gleed Thompson of Denver, Col., son of Mrs. Cornelia Gleed Thompson of St. Paul, Minn., and of Roy S. Thompson of Denver.

Former President David Toro, who left the country following the revolution, is reported to have returned to the Chaco in an effort to foment a revolution against the government of Lieut. Col. German Busch.

The "vanishing American" is a myth, officials of the Indian Bureau said today. Bureau officials even expressed concern because the increase of the native Americans was not accompanied by a corresponding increase in their land and resources.
The number of unemployed persons receiving home relief in upState communities more than doubled in six months, the State Department of Social Welfare reported yesterday.

There is little evidence of improvement in trade and industry except where seasonal gains have occurred, and these in most cases have been less than hoped for, the National City Bank says in its monthly letter on economic conditions, which will be published today.
Robert Graves has completed the manuscript of his new book, "Count Belisarius," a long novel set in the Middle Ages and centering around the court of the Empress Theodora.
Dale J. Crittenberger, Indiana Democratic leader and for thirty years editor and publisher of The Anderson Daily Bulletin, died in his home here today of a heart ailment. His age was 83.
John Edward Menzies, 25, of Paterson, N. J., died in a hospital here today from injuries suffered when he was struck by an automobile and left in the road.

American youth believe the government should provide jobs for the unemployed, but only about 55 per cent of the "typical" young men and women who expressed this view made a practice of voting, according to a survey in Maryland of 13,528 between the ages of 16 and 24. The study was conducted by the American Youth Commission.
Coming from behind in the last five minutes, the unbeaten Queens Rugby Club defeated Long Island University, 18 to 13, at Astoria Park yesterday for its fourth victory in a row.

In a statement condemning the proposed 1-cent tax on each package of cigarettes sold in the city, the Retail Tobacco Dealers of America, Inc., described the levy yesterday as "wholly unsound" and predicted it would result in a marked falling-off of the city's cigarette. business. Sales would be diverted
The 1938 budget will show a deficit of 35,000,000,000 to 40,000,000,000 francs. If inflation is to be avoided borrowing will have to be resorted to to cover the deficit.

A goal by Murray Patrick in the second overtime period tonight gave the Philadelphia Ramblers a 1-0 victory over the Providence Reds in the second game of the final play-off series in the Eastern division of the International-American Hockey League.

Invitations have been sent out for the wedding of Miss Florence Colt Brigham, elder daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Brigham, to John Wallace Wales, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Wales of Newton, Mass. The ceremony will take place at the Brigham home on the afternoon of April 23.

America, with justice, can be said to be "money mad," lacking a sense of Christian responsibility, and given to placing a greater emphasis upon material deeds than acts of love, the Rev. Charles C. Cole, pastor of Grace Methodist Church, 131 West 104th Street, declared in his morning sermon yesterday.
The streamlined Twentieth Century Limited, now under construction in the Pullman shops in South Chicago, will be placed in service

The Cardinal Hayes Library erected on the campus of Manhattan College will be dedicated Tuesday, April 26, by Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of New York, it was announced yesterday by Brother Patrick, president of the college.

Liquidation by holders of May lard contracts developed last week on the Board of Trade, and with aggressive support missing, prices declined to the lowest level since August, 1934, when processing taxes were imposed.

The Rev. Dr. Leighton Parks, rector of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church from 1904 to 1925, who died last March 21 in England, was praised for interpreting the gospel in the new light of learning of his day by the Right Rev. William Lawrence, retired Bishop of Massachusetts, in a sermon yesterday in the church, Park Avenue at FiftyFirst Street.

The New York Research Corporation, 302 Eastern Parkway, New York, has agreed to discontinue certain "false and misleading representations" in advertising its product, Melvite, according to the Federal Trade Commission.
Dr. Benjamin Nadel died yesterday at his home, 199 Ross Street, Brooklyn, of a heart attack. He was 52 years old and was graduated from Long Island College Hospital in 1912.

Dr. Edward A. Ward-of Saginaw, Mich., president of the American Osteopathic Association, called on members of the profession yesterday to "lead the way and give direction and support to any reasonable plan of medical and economic reform which can be safely inaugurated." He added that it "must

Dresses, millinery, blouses and costume accessories led in wholesale market action last week. Calls for coats and suits eased off somewhat in spite of active retail buying, although the medium price brackets continued quite busy.
The resignation of Dr. Melville D. Dickinson, district State health officer for Nassau and Suffolk Counties, was announced today by the State Health Department. Dr. C. A.

Germany's desire to divide the world with Britain into "spheres of influence" is disclosed in a new book by the Marquess of Londonderry, the most active although not the most influential of Germany's friends in high places in this country.

Another obstacle to passage of the Reorganization Bill in the House was removed today when President Roosevelt told House leaders that he was not opposed to the compromise amendment that would let Congress by. a simple majority vote veto reorganization orders issued by the Executive.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was very much interested in THE TIMES editorial "Less Red Tape." If the Navy Department is in need of an overhauling, the State Department would bear even closer attention.

A midget racing automobile crashed through a guard rail, turned over three or four times and then crashed into a bleacher on the east turn of the Nutley Velodrome this afternoon, injuring ten spectators and the driver. Three spectators were hurt seriously.

Pacifism at any cost was decried as "effeminate indifference" by the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, in an address at the annual service of the Sons of the American Revolution yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street. He declared that "tolerance" was a quality still "worth fighting for."

Trading in the cotton market here last week was mostly quiet, but values held up fairly well considering the weakness in the stock and outside commodity markets, coupled with evidences of recession in general trade. The steady undertone

The National Maritime Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, announced yesterday that 51,000 members, the unlicensed personnel on some 1,200 vessels in the Atlantic, Gulf and Great Lakes districts, would begin voting today on nine constitutional amendments and for national, district and division officers.

The course of the pound in the exchange market this week provided confirmation that dollar-sterling exchange had also to bear the burden of withdrawals of European capital from America. Continental Europe, like

Seven years ago the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor joined with the Charity Organization Society in setting up the Boys' Bureau to care for "homeless and unattached boys" between the ages of 16 and 21. Their experiences led them to make a study of adolescent delinquency, the results of which have recently been published under the title of "Youth in the Toils." Leonard V. Harrison and
Europe was a heavy seller of stocks this week, large parcels of United States and domestic securities being thrown onto the market.

The film "The Birth of a Baby," for which a general release in New York is being sought in an appeal to the Board of Regents from an adverse ruling by Commissioner Frank P. Graves, was declared by the Legion of Decency to be "unsuited for entertainment and inappropriate for general theatrical exhibition" in a statement yesterday.

A new immigration law is now in the hands of President Getulio Vargas. Although its contents are not divulged, it is believed to favor agricultural immigration and to set its entry quota at 80 per cent but to maintain otherwise the 2 per cent restriction.
Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, asserted tonight that fascism was "the deadly and insidious foe that we must prepare to combat without loss of time;"
Generally lower figures compared with three months ago were shown in the statements of condition as of March 31 published over the week-end by local banks and trust companies. The one noteworthy

For the first time in the eighteen years of his regency, Admiral Nicholas Horthy- addressed the Hungarian people today in a broadcast. He declared firmly that constitutional liberties would be upheld and peace and order maintained throughout the country and urged the people to hold together in this time of stress.

The Chattanooga Times says that the Chattanooga Typographical Union voted down today a plan by friends of Senator George L. Berry to obtain finances and votes from organized labor for his campaign for re-election.

A. Steve Nance, labor leader, died here today after an illness of several months. He was 43 years old. Mr. Nance served for six years as president of the Atlanta Federation of Trades and for three years as president of the Georgia Federation of Labor.

The engagement of Miss Margaret Christie Seckel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Seckel of Brooklyn, to Robert Grayson Taylor of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Taylor Jr. of Kansas City, has been announced by her parents.

Frank A. Ready, manager of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, announced yesterday the appointment of John Gooddy, former business promotion manager of the Savoy Hotel in London, as British representative of the Waldorf-Astoria, with headquarters in London.
Supply contracts valued at $3,872,579 were awarded in the week ended on March 31 by ten Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor has announced.

Thirteen-year-old Miss Geraldine Larkin, one of the Women's Swimming Association's most promising young contestants, won her first championship yesterday to share the spotlight with three comparatively veteran men swimmers in an aquatic meet in the Park Central Hotel's 75-foot pool.

State Commander Thomas P. Layer of the Veterans of Foreign Wars defended veterans' organizations against alleged charges of "militarism" in a speech made yesterday before 350 members of the Brooklyn Council at Borough Hall, Brooklyn. Commander Layer, who addressed members of forty-one posts in Kings County, said:

The Paterson Caledonians turned back the New York Americans in an American Soccer League match today, 1-0. The lone goal was recorded midway in the second half when Graziani netted the ball on a pass from De Viva. The line-up:
The national convention of the Young People's League of the United Synagogue of America ended tonight with an assembly and informal buffet.

A reproduction of the central medallion of what is said to be the most intricate and colorful chenille rug ever woven on a power loom in America will be on display in the rug department of L. Bamberger Co. here for a week, starting Wednesday.

Capital moved out of the United States during the final quarter of 1937 at the rate of about $40,000,000 weekly, amounting in the aggregate to $516,554,000, according to the Treasury Department's quarterly statement of international capital movements, made public today.

The New York Society for the Suppression of Vice announced in its annual report yesterday that it had confiscated more than a ton of obscene literature and several thousand obscene pictures, postcards, films and other matter in 1937.

Governor Lehman announced today his approval of the Fitzgerald Demolition bill which would permit the New York City Department of Housing and Buildings to tear down vacated' tenements after obtaining a court order declaring the building to be a fire hazard or detrimental to the public health and morals.

The report that Franz von Papen was slated for the post of German Ambassador to Turkey still awaits official confirmation. At the Foreign Office it, was stated that while the Angora post was vacant through the pensioning of Friedrich von Keller the question of a successor still awaited Chancellor Adolf Hitler's decision.
Wall Street's violent break this week finally dissipated any lingering hopes for either a Spring or Summer business recovery. It clearly reflects,

Sharp curtailment continues in the production of rayon woven cloths, according to the survey of loom activity for the week ending March 26, issued for publication today by the National Rayon Weavers Association, Inc.

In Jewish synagogues and temples throughout the country rabbis will read a special Passover prayer next Friday evening and Saturday morning asking divine help for a care-torn world whose pains Israel is especially made to feel.

A bust of the inventor Guglielmo Marconi was presented last night to David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, by the Italian Professional Women of America. The presentation took place during the intermission of a concert, which the Italian women sponsored at the Town Hall in honor of the inventor.

Michael F. Gaffney, 96-year-old veteran of the Civil War, died here last night at the home of his daughter, Mrs. William Conner of 28 Llewellyn Avenue, after a week's illness. Born in Dublin, Ireland,

Searchers found the body of Coleman Tew, 21, in Six Run River today nearly twelve hours after he shot and wounded his sweetheart, 17-year-old Grace Carter, and Rudulph Smolka, who until a few weeks ago played in an orchestra at a New York theatre.

Senator Harrison, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, which completed its revision of the 1938 revenue bill Thursday, asserted tonight in a radio talk that the committee had "translated the House proposal into what I confidently believe will be a business recovery bill."

The gospel of the Christian church is a great one of hope, said the Rev. Dr. Malcolm James MacLeod, retired pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, in his sermon yesterday at the Middle Collegiate Reformed Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street.

What the Christian church needs for power today is "fuller, clearer and stronger faith in the Lord Jesus Himself and greater faithfulness to Him," declared Bishop William T. Manning yesterday morning at St. Margaret's Episcopal Church, 940 East 156th Street, the Bronx.
The Brookhattan Soccer. Club defeated an all-star team from New York State by a score of 4-1 before 2,500 fans at Starlight Park yesterday. Brookhattan led, 1-0, at half-time.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

Lerida was captured last evening, but some. Loyalist forces were fighting in the lower part of the city. Many prisoners were taken. The southern wing approached Cherta, only six miles from Tortosa, where the road between Barcelona and Valencia could be cut. Another force crossed the Ebro River and took Mora. A third was close to Morella.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Grace Martin, daughter of Mrs. James Martin of this city, and the late Mr. Martin, to Carl A. Philippi of New York, son of the late Mrs. Anna Trauvetter Philippi and the late Frederick Philippi, took place yesterday afternoon in the Spiritual Science Mother Church, Inc.

A preferential collective bargaining agreement affecting 280 service employes in twenty-five buildings has been signed between New York University and the Building Service Employes Union, Local 32 B, it was announced yesterday.

Because of possible interference with a current construction program, the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics will -not hold its usual Aircraft Engineering Research Conference at its Langley Field laboratories in May.

Dr. Paul B. Sears of the University of Oklahoma is one of the appointees to the faculty of Oberlin College. He is to become Professor of Bottany. Dr. Edna Schrick of the University of Nebraska is named assistant college physician, Miss Dorothy M. Bell of Columbia as
A strong breeze from the northwest favored skippers in today's dinghy races sailed over the threequarter mile course of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

A reversal of the downtrend in automotive advertising, chiefly as the result of National Used Car Exchange Week, pushed linage in that classification for New York newspapers 40.2 per cent higher last month than March of 1937. according to a compilation based on Media Records figures.

As an influence on business, international questions fell into the background this week, and Austria became a mere election issue. Spanish developments were regarded principally from the viewpoint that they probably soon will bring an end to the war.
The French wholesale price index on March 26 was 617, compared with 619 and 614, respectively, in the two previous weeks.

Bernard F. Hogan, president of the Greater New York Savings Bank, Brooklyn, was named yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement. Mr. Hogan is a director of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce and of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.
Demonstrating that baseball is never a game to run smoothly even when so finely calculated by a Colonel Bill Terry, things turned out badly for the Giants today.

Great Britain's fiscal year ended with a budget surplus of almost [Pound]29,000,000 for the government. This compares with a deficit of f5,597,000 in the previous fiscal year, and it is the largest surplus since 1934.
The security markets here are struggling, against considerable odds, to fight their way back to something approaching confidence.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,392,117,650. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills.

Four seniors and a junior in Columbia College have, been chosen through elimination trials to compete in the annual contest for the George William Curtis Medals in Oratory this afternoon at 4 o'clock in the McMillin Academic Theatre, Broadway at 116th Street.

Henry E. Taylor, veteran Adirondack guide who personally escorted the late John D. Rockefeller on hunting trips through the Adirondacks and who was also in the employ of the J. P. Morgan and S. D. Fairchild families, died today at the home of his daughter-in-law, Mrs. John Courtney of Wilmington, N. Y. His age was 78.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the General Motors Corporation, has been eliminated at his own request from further participation in the profits under the company's bonus plan, the annual report, to be issued today, says. The elimination will apply to participation in profits for 1937.
Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "Where Is the Federal Policy Taking Us?" Dr. Harley L. Lutz; "The President's Handling of Public Relief," Edward Corsi.

Now that the official rush is over, the streams will quiet down a bit and the trout will be able to enjoy a fairly normal existence until the first warm day brings out a good fly hatch and a legion of fly-casters at the same time.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Philip Stevenson of Aiken and Glen Cove, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Stevenson, to George Whitney Jr., son of Mr. and

Foreign trade exports of the Department of Agriculture have received reports that Japan was attempting to establish a banking system in Chinese cotton-growing sections in an attempt to obtain larger supplies for her mils.
Philip Goodman, truant from the Broadway theatre since 1931, will return as the author of "The Lady at Large," which Milton Shubert will place in rehearsal this week, it was learned yesterday.

The Chinese now claim complete control at Taierhchwang, southern Shantung walled city, forty-five miles northeast of Suchow, following the withdrawal yesterday of Japanese northeast toward Hsiangchen.

Justification of the. force of the individual's conscience as a guide to human behavior was seen as a special need of the present at the annual First-Day worship yesterday of the general conference of the New York Yearly Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends. More than 800 persons attended in the Friends Meeting House, 221 East Fifteenth Street.
The public works program of the Administration of President Oscar Raimundes Benavides has been further extended with a proposed expenditure of 1,550,000 soles, approximately $390.000.

Deborah Ann Delaney passed her ninth day of life here today, tipping the scales at 1 pound 11 1/2 ounces, and her attending physician said her chances of living "looked pretty good." Dr. Charles M. O'Connor said the baby was born to Mrs. Thomas J. Delaney three months ahead of normal time and weighed 1 pound 14 ounces at birth and was perfectly formed.

Officials of New York Hospital, 525 East Sixty-eighth Street, announced yesterday the receipt of an anonymous gift of $10,000 for "unrestricted use," in connection with the institution's campaign to raise $17,000,000 for endowment purposes.

Mrs. Joseph Warren Burden, daughter of the late John A. Griswold, a Representative in Congress during the Civil War, died yesterday morning from coronary thrombosis at her home, 28 East Sixtythird Street. She had been ill for a year. Her age was 83.

A name written often in field trial reports will be engraved on the Owner's Trophy, the prized plate which was awarded today to the winner of the open all-age stake in the most important event in the annual Spring meeting of the Jockey Hollow Club.
Dr. Rudolph N. Schullinger, in 1,175 Park Ave.; Rodman Wanamaker, in 116 E. 53d St.; Dr. K. Winfield Ney, in 25 E. 83d St.; Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers.
Because a hobo did not know how to ride a streamlined train, the Twentieth Century Limited was delayed ten minutes here early today.
Liquidation developed in oats and rye last week on the Board of Trade here, largely because of the generally favorable outlook for the new crops.

Miss Harriette Alper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Alper of this place, was married to Lawrence B. Kaskowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Kaskowitz of New York, this afternoon at the home of her parents by the Rev. Dr. Edward T. Sandrow of Cedarhurst.
Although reports today from the London Stock Exchange mentioned a slight recovery among American industrial securities, comments here on the situation in the United States are unfavorable in general.
The admonition of Cardinal Hayes in his annual appeal for Catholic Charities is one that should have a wider hearing even than among his own parishioners:

The British chemical industry trailed the iron and steel, automobile, engineering, rayon and other major British industrial groups last year, according to the Department of Commerce, but still made striking advances. Production was generally 10 per cent above 1936.
The world champion Yankees closed their first exhibition appearance here in fourteen years by bowing to the New Orleans Pelicans at Heinemann Park today, 13 to 8.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 74.1 on March 30. compared with 74.8 a fortnight before, 75.6 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.
The German trade press tends more and more to impute to Washington irresolution and ambiguity.

Some of the telegraphic protests on the Reorganization Bill last week contained jocular references to President Roosevelt's statement that the Senate's passage of the bill proved that body could not be bought by organized telegrams.

Mr. Gedye's report of the first days of the occupation of Vienna gives a picture of Germany as a conqueror which grimly underlines the arguments of those who have pleaded for a policy of magnanimity toward Germany. If ever there was occasion for generosity, not to say gratitude, on the part of a victor, surely it was after this annexation, accomplished, as the Nazi leaders truly boast, without a show of resistance.
Since it is obvious that the Insurgents' main thrust is to the sea somewhere between Castellon -and Tarragona, the writer spent today testing the roads leading up from the coast.

Maria Maximovitch, RussianAmerican soprano, will give her final recital of the season tonight at Town Hall. Shortly thereafter she will sail for Holland, where she will be heard in programs of songs by Johan Franco, Dutch composer, before the Royal Music Society.

German Catholic Bishops, whose representatives met here over the weekend at the grave of Saint Bonaface-the first missionary to the Germans-left today without apparently having reached any decision as to what to do about the Austrian plebiscite.
The German wholesale price index on March 30 stood at 105.7, against 105.8 on March 23.
Burleigh Grimes wasn't smiling tonight, but George Weiss and Johnny Neun wore grins as broad as the field upon which today's disaster occurred--which is quite broad.

Six persons, including Saleh Pasha Lamloum, one of the most popular Bedouin chieftains in Egypt of the El Fawayed tribe, and his brother, Abdul Rahman Bey Lamloum, were killed this afternoon in an electioneering fight in Minia Province, Upper Egypt.

The Gdynia America Line will transfer its terminal today to a new pier at the foot of Eighth Street, Hoboken, where it will have the largest wharf space used by a single line in this port, it was announced yesterday.

Liquidation by holders of wheat and deliveries other than corn resulted in larger business in grain futures last week. Average daily sales of 24,400,000 bushels compared with 19,700,000 in the preceding week and 63,000,000 in the same period in 1937.

Representatives of Dick Powell will confer tomorrow with Warner studio executives over the refusal of the actor to appear in "Garden of the Moon." Powell advised Warners last week that he would not do the part, a decision that followed numerous protests that he had made over recent pictures.
Drastic revision of the curriculum of the Boston University School of Law in an effort to synchronize the study of law with the evolution of economic and social conditions is announced.

Arthur C. Unger, formerly sales manager of the General Foods Sales Company, Inc., has been appointed to a new position in which he will have supervision over trade relations, Clarence Francis, president of the General Foods Corporation, announced yesterday.

Pine St, s w cor of Water St, 97.98x863.101/2; John H. Breen to Seamen's Bank for Savings; consideration $100,000, foreclosure. Greenwich St, n w cor of Beach St, 25x 79.8; Laurence A. Tanzer to trustees will of Lorillard Spencer 1st, care of Bank of New York and Trust Co; consideration $34.000. foreclosure.

A total of 210,075 cases were disposed of in the city's five traffic courts in the period from Jan. 1, 1938, to March 31, an increase of 29,255, or 16.2 per cent, over the same period in 1937, according to a report made public yesterday by Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr.
Jerry Kral of Shawano, Wis., continued on a piece-work basis today toward what may be one of the ranking all-events totals in American Bowling Congress history.

Forgetful of the. true nature of freedom, which is truth, this country is in danger of becoming a democracy of indifference, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Fundamental Theology at Catholic University, declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

With only two more games remaining on its American tour, Cambridge will play the New York Rugby Club at Randall's Island Stadium tomorrow at 3 P. M. The tour will end on Saturday at the Polo Grounds against the pick of the East's Rugby. stars at 3 P. M.

The Utility Workers Organizing Committee, a C. I. O. affiliate, whose members took possession of thirteen Consumers Power Company plants in Northeastern Michigan last Friday, relinquished them tonight under an argeement reached at a conference arranged by Governor Frank Murphy.
Clarence (Red) Burman, Baltimore heavyweight, took a decision tonight from Eddy Mader, New York, in a ten-round bout. Burman floored the New Yorker but was unable to put over a knockout.

The Phillips Jones Corporation today was awarded an army contract for 220,000 cotton drawers (shorts) on their bid of 19.05 cents each, less one-twentieth of 1 per cent, 20-days, under Invitation 198. Other awards made today at the local Quartermaster Depot were:

The six-family house at 92 Burr Avenue, Hempstead, L. I., was sold by the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company to George L. Seifert. Sale was cash above a first mortgage of $15,300 and was arranged through Harry G. Gebhard, Inc., mortgage correspondent for the seller, and William J. O'Neill,

The suit to set aside the will of Princess Josephine del Drago, entered by her granddaughter, Mrs. Paula Murray Coudert of 988 Fifth Avenue, has been settled under a compromise agreement by which the contestant receives $60,000 for withdrawing her action and a diamond tiara which she received under the disputed will.

ANNUALS FOR YOUR GARDEN, by Daniel J. Foley. (Macmillan, $1.) Information on how to grow them. BEFORE THE STORM, by Baroness Sophie Buxhoeveden. (Macmillan, $4.50.) Recollections of country life in Russia in the years preceding the great war.

Hogs and lambs sold lower, weakness in the former trade being a carry-over from bearish sentiment generated by an unsatisfactory fresh pork market, the United States Department of Agriculture reported today. Lambs arrived in liberal numbers which proved to be sufficient to break prices.

A complaint against Grand National Films, Inc., 1,270 Sixth Avenue, New York, charging unfair methods of competition in marketing a film titled "In His Steps," has been filed by the Federal Trade Commission.

A group of books sponsored by the New Bauhaus, Chicago, of which Dr. Walter Gropius is general adviser and L. Moholy-Nagy is director, will be published by Norton. The first book in the series, to be published this Autumn, will be a new edition of "The New Vision"

John Tamweber, in 519 W 147th St; Leo Schachno, Jean Hoornbeek, in 3,671 Broadway; Samuel Silverman, in 560 W 163d St; Louis Hennefeld, in 248 Audubon Ave; Thaddeus Slonczweki, Alice A. Murphy, in 561 W 141st St; Theresa Smith, Harry Goldstein, Willy Heisel, Patrick Fleming, in 534 W 152d St; Francis Moy, in 520 W 184th St; George R. Read Co, broker.

While the State Labor Relations Board resumed its efforts yesterday to bring about a settlement in the strike of 15,000 fur workers, persons believed to be strikers engineered a coup that tied up for several hours the twenty-story building at 333 Seventh Avenue, occupied by several firms whose employes are on strike.

Pointing out that rents are governed by supply and demand and emphasizing the necessity of a fair return on the capital invested, Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, urged last night that sufficient construction be encouraged to keep the supply of apartments adequate to the demand.

Mr. and Mrs. T. O. M. Sopwith arrived today from the West Indies on their motor yacht Philante. Also on board were Captain Tremayne, Mrs. Kay Strickland, Mrs. Sopwith's sister; Dr. Adams and Miss Morris, all of London.
The Home Insurance Company has adopted a policy of investing all new funds in United States Government bonds and municipal securities, Wilfred Kurth, chairman, said at the annual meeting yesterday.

UNITED STATES JUNIOR AGRONOMIST (OPTIONAL BRANCHES: GENERAL AGRONOMY OR COTTON), JUNIOR ANIMAL FIBER TECHNOLOGIST. JUNIOR IN ANIMAL NUTRITION (OPTIONAL BRANCHES: FARM ANIMALS OR POULTRY), JUNIOR BIOLOGIST (WILDLIFE RESEARCH), $2,000 a year; Department of Agriculture.

Certain New Yorkers were treated to an unusual sight last night. They saw the circus hiding its light under a bushel, and it isn't often that an organization that lives on superlatives will do such a thing.

The New York State Labor Relations Board will hold an election on Friday among 2,300 employes of Abraham Straus, Brooklyn department store, to determine whether or not they wish to be represented by the Department Store Organizing Committee, C. I. O. affiliate.

The Textile Quality League, Inc., informed its members yesterday that it had requested a general list of dress manufacturers to sign an agreement pledging themselves not to purchase prints, jacquards, laces or embroideries which copy or imitate designs or fabrics registered with the Industrial Design Registration Bureau of the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., or patented in the United States Patent Office.
Frank Strafaci of New York led a field of 175 today in the qualifying round of the thirty-eighth annual North and South amateur golf championship with 32. 38-70, two under par.

Miss Helen Howe of Boston dropped by at the Little last evening with a new portfolio of characters and caricatures. "These People" is the title she has chosen for them. Some of them are the female megalomaniacs whom it is easy to ridicule in clever mimicry,
The bodies of Roger Henshaw, 42, film whiter and former director, his actress wife, Dale Henshaw, and their fox terrier dog were found today in a closed automobile at their North Hollywood home.
The Osservatore Romano, Vatican newspaper, said today that Friday night's Vatican station broadcast on "political Catholicism" was "neither official nor semi-official nnr inspired."

The Greater New York Fund announced yesterday the names of persons prominent in all walks of community life who will assist in its campaign to raise $10,000,000 in May for private health and welfare agencies.

At the recent dinner of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association a questionnaire was submitted to about 200 sportsmen. The object of this questionnaire was to determine the exact feeling of the average sportsman on the present regulations concerning trout fishing.

Under gray skies and with a chill wind which had more then a little of Winter left in it and made the Hudson too rough for work yesterday, the little band. of men who are keeping rowing alive at Columbia went through another workout on the Harlem yesterday.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-By KARL EICHE, restaurant worker, 223 E. 88th St.-Liabilities $1,405, no assets. JOHN K. MANNION, machinist, 212 Winnikee Ave., Poughkeepsie - Liabilities $1,866, no assets. CHARLES OSTONE, also known as CHARLES ASTONE, tailor, 4,230 Burner Ave.-- Liabilities $1,349, no assets.

Donald S. Carroll Jr., 16-year-old student, was indicted for murder in the first degree yesterday in the shooting of Charlotte Matthiesen, 18, in a suicide compact in the Carroll home at 37-37 Seventy-eighth Street, Jackson Heights, on March 24.
The League of Nations committee for the study of the legal status of women throughout the world began work here today. Judge Dorothy Kenyon of New York is the American among its seven members.

The engagement of $3,700,000 of gold in England for shipment to this country was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This brought the total of gold engaged abroad for United States account since Feb. 24 to $53,700,000, of which $25,000,000 has been bought in Great Britain.

The Florida Supreme Court today ordered Mayor Robert R. Williams of Miami to stand trial on a charge of attempting to exact a $250,000 bribe from the Florida Power and Light Company. On a charge that he conspired with other
Continued weakness in wholesale commodity prices resulted in the index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association declining in the week ended April 2 to the lowest point reached since May, 1936.

The ninety-one day bills sold by the Treasury today were allotted at an average price of 99.965, or 0.139 per cent, compared with 99.978, or 0.087 per cent, for the same series paper last week, according to a Treasury announcement tonight.

Several properties in Westchester County were reported yesterday sold through the Dudley D. Doern-berg Company, Mamaroneck brokers. Among them was a tract of twenty-three acres on Kensico Road in Mount Pleasant which was sold by Prime, Hallock Paul, trustees of Series 68-B, to Charles R. Blenis.

Miss Maria Virginia Zimbalist, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Efrem Zimbalist, has chosen April 19 as the date for her marriage to Ogden Goelet, son of Robert Goelet and of Mrs. Henry' Clews of Cannes, France.
The Student Loan Fund of Wheaton College will be aided by the annual dance under the auspices of the Wheaton Club of New York on Saturday night in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador.

The current trip through the Citrus Belt has brought nothing but disaster to Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers. Today they dropped their fifthstraight when Lou Fette, first Boston hurler to go nine innings, set then down with four hits to give Casey Stengel's Bees a 5-1 victory.
The House passed and sent to the White House today amendments to the new Farm Act intended to improve the cotton and tobacco programs.

Further discussion of plans for the formation of a "real estate union" and of the need for a central organization to fight against increased realty taxes featured a meeting yesterday of the committee recently named by Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, to map out the details of organization.
The domestic price of zinc was lowered yesterday from 4.25 cents to 4.15 cents a pound at East St. Louis. Only a moderate amount of business was reported at the lower level.
A bill to permit the City Court of New York City to naturalize aliens was offered today by Representative Barry of New York:
John E. Bradley, formerly president of the Osgood Bradley Car Company, died today in Bermuda, according to word received by family members here. His age was 78.

Pensioned The following members of the force On their own applications: To take effect 12 midnight, April 2: PATROLMAN Philip T. O'Leary. 72d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 24. 1912. To take effect 12 midnight, April 3: PATROLMAN-Percival Bulger, 18th Division. Manhattan, Borough Detectives, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 3, 1912.
The Little Mothers Aid Association, of which Mrs. Frank Oliver Hall is president, will be aided by a luncheon and fashion show Thursday morning on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
Mrs. Helen B. Darcy of Newark lost her fight in Orphans Court today for a half share of the $4,000,000 estate of J. Dundas Lippincott

The American ORT Federation announced yesterday that it had received a letter from Governor Lehman endorsing its campaign to raise $450,000 to provide technical and agricultural training for Jewish victims of anti-Semitism and economic discrimination in Poland, Germany, Rumania and other European countries.

Completing plans for their forthcoming campaigns, leading gin producers will shortly launch a hard drive to prevent any further inroads into their hold on the Summer drink market, such as the manufacturers of rum made last year, it was indicated here yesterday.

To celebrate the twenty-third anniversary of the founding of the Auxiliary of the Brooklyn Children's Museum, officers and members of that organization will give a luncheon April 22'at the WaldorfAstoria. A meeting will precede the luncheon. Mrs. Dean C. Osborne,

Administration leaders in the House retreated a step further on the Reorganization Bill today by agreeing informally to accept an amendment specifically exempting the Veterans Bureau from the reorganization authority which the bill would vest in the President.

Canada and Russia purchased almost half of the war materials exported from the United States in March, according to statistics on export licenses made public today by the State Department. They purchased almost equal amounts. Licensed exports for the month totaled $5,456,319.38.

J. Richard (Dixie) Davis, George Weinberg and five others accused with them of directing a huge policy racket will go on trial before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora starting Monday, May 16, it was decided yesterday.

With the stage set for the opening at noon tomorrow of the, Constitutional Convention, eighth in the history of the State, delegates have been flocking into the city all day, and most of the 168 men and women who will participate in the work of revising the State's organic law are now here waiting for the opening gavel.

Stocks closed mixed in trends, with steel shares heavy, rail group higher and A. T. T. strong; turnover, 687,060 shares. Second-grle rail bonds strong, United States Government issues' higher, other loans irregular; transactions, $6,411,675.

In the United States Supreme Court today the following proceedings were had: 458-Milton Coverdale, Sheriff and exofficio tax collector, applt., v. ArkansasLouisiana Pipe Line Co. Appeal from the United States Western District Court of Louisiana. Decree reversed and cause rehanded. Opinion by Justice Reed. Dissenting, Justice McReynolds. Justice Cardozo took no part in this case.

Henry Alexander Campbell of 103 Central Avenue, a close friend of the late Thomas A. Edison, and an assistant at Mr. Edison's Menlo Park laboratories during his experiments there, died at the Muhlenberg Hospital in Plainfield this morning. He was 84 years old.

The Princess Beatrix, for the first time since her birth some two months ago, left Soestdijk Castle today, when her mother, Princess Juliana, took her to The Hague,. where she will remain at Queen Wilhelmina's palace until the christening on May 12.
Jascha Heifetz, violinist, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star Liner Queen Mary from a concert tour in Europe. He said that

A co-ordinated scheme of national development to combat unemployment was pictured to the Commons today by Norzman Rogers, Minister of Labor. The program, following the recommendations of the National Employment Commission, whose report was tabled last Friday, involves efforts to increase the $300,000,000
Miss Elizabeth Maxwell Calvin Chestnut, daughter of Judge and Mrs. W. Calvin Chestnut, will be married on April 30 to Wilson King Barnes, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Barnes.

By a vote of 325 to 6 the House today approved an additional appropriation of $50,000,000 to continue the present number of Civilian Conservation Corps camps in operation through the next fiscal year and the balance of this one.

Ten students from Princeton University's School of Public and International Affairs have received scholarships to study the mechanics of government in Washington this week, it was announced today by Professor De Witt Clinton Poole, director of the school.
Joseph H. Millar Jr., president of the Cleveland Stock Exchange, died of a heart attack this morning at his home a few minutes after he had Mr. risen from the breakfast table.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 2: BRIGADIER GENERAL McCloskey, M., Fort Bragg, N. C., to retirement. COLONEL Emith, E. K., C.A.C., Panama, to University of New Hampshire, Durham, N. H. LIEUTENANT COLONEL Walker, C. A., Jr., Ordnance Department, two months leave, June 18, with permission to visit foreign countries.

Every kind of proposal for raising money, from a tax on capital to an additional passport charge for French tourists going abroad and an increase in import duties to compensate for the fallen value of the franc, is packed into the preamble to a demand that Premier Leon Blum's government will make tomorrow in the Chamber of Deputies for full powers for four months to rehabilitate the French financial situation.

As a result of a compromise between studio and actor following the refusal of Dick Powell to appear in "Garden of the Moon," the star today was placed on the Warners' lay-off list, a technical -term that indicates a more harmonious condition than had his suspension been announced.

Jim Londos, 210, Greece, pinned Dean Dettoni, 205, Salt Lake City, with an airplane spin and body hold in the feature bout at the New York Hippodrome last night before a crowd of 3,500. The winning hold came in 31:17.

Flying Wild, in the colors of Mrs. Anthony Pelleteri, came through with a smashing victory in the Anne Arundel Purse before 8,000 spectators today. With Charlie Corbett in the saddle, Flying Wild gained a neck decision over Ghost Queen, owned by W. H. Denham and making her first start of the season.

The Canadian radio receiver set license fee has been increased from $2 to $2.50 per set because of the need of the Canadian Broadcasting Company for additional revenues, according to a consular report from Ottawa made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The number of unemployed in Britain during March decreased by more than 60,000 compared with February, according to a report issued by the Labor Ministry tonight. The total of unemployed is at present listed as 1,748,981, against 1,810,421 in February, a gain in employment of 61,440.

Six seamen were drowned and nine were rescued when five coal boats sank in a storm yesterday off the mouth of the Brenta River in the Gulf of Venice. Reports received here said another vessel, the steamer Carnero, plying between Venice and East Africa, had gone down in the Red Sea.

President Roosevelt's first regular working day at the White House after his vacation at Warm Springs was a busy one, embracing discussion of the railroad and farm problems, the legislative situation, general business conditions and foreign affairs.

The Harvard freshmen defeated the Tome School nine today, 15 to 5, in the season's first game for each team. The Harvard men outhit their rivals, 9 to 6, but Tome's ten errors were the big factor in the defeat, the college team making only one misplay. Lovett of Harvard was the heavy hitter of the game, getting three hits in four times at bat..
The foreign petroleum industry today launched the first legal effort of a three-way drive to recover its $400,000,000 properties expropriated by the government.

The Standard Oil Company of California said today that for several years it had been shipping large quantities of refined oil and gasoline to Vladivostok, Soviet Russia's great Siberian military base. A company spokesman said the shipments, although not publicized, were not "secret."

J. H. Ottley of Locust Valley, rived L. I., and party arrived here on his yacht, Nautilus, from New York this afternoon. In the party were Mrs. Ottley, Mr. and Mrs. GibbonsFord of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Mr. and Mrs. W. Rexford Daniels of Camden, Me. After a stay of two weeks the visitors will return to New York.

Steel operations in the United States are scheduled at 32.6 per cent of ingot capacity this week, compared to 35.7 per cent last week, a drop of 3.1 points, or 8.7 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports.

In the United States Court of Claims today the following proceedings were had: Annuoncements E-344-The Klamath and Moadoc Tribes and Yahooskin Band of Snake Indians. Petition dismissed.
