Opinion by Judge Williams. K-376-The Chickasaw Nation. Petition dismissed. Opinion by Judge Green. 42519A-John Schmoll, assignee. Judgment for plaintiff of $4,423.93. Opinion by Chief Justice Booth.

Harry Cooper of Chicopee, Mass., who finished in a tie with Ralph Guldahl of Chicago for second place in the Augusta tourney, led the money winners of the 1938 Winter circuit, which came to a close today, with total earnings of $4,448. Henry Picard, winner here, ranked third for the season's winnings.

Edward Dean Sullivan, newspaper man, author and screen writer, died today in his home of a heart attack at the age of 49. Mr. Sullivan began his newspaper career in New Haven, and later was associated with newspapers in New York, Boston and Chicago.
Josef Hofmann, in a special appearance with the Philadelphia Orchestra tonight, marked the golden jubilee of his first local piano recital, given as a boy of 11.

Myron C. Taylor delivered his farewell address as chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation at the annual meeting of stockholders in Hoboken, N. J., yesterday afternoon. He will resign formally today, and will be succeeded by Edward R. Stettinius Jr.,

Factories on sugar estates at Usine, Ste. Madeleine, Caroni and Waterloo were shut down today as the sugar workers' union called strikes for higher wages. The workers are demanding from 15 to 20 per cent increases in wages and employers argue that they are unable to afford this because of low returns. The strikes were called without notice while all sugar factories were working.

A survey of the changes the Federal Government has undergone in the last five years, signed by four Cabinet members and twenty-five executives of Federal agencies and bureaus, was made public yesterday by the American Council on Public Affairs, 20 Vesey Street, under the title, "The Federal Government Today."

In the first match of the fourth annual international Rugby week today Yale was beaten by a team from the cruiser Orion, 6 to 3. The Elis reduced the naval team's 6-to-0 lead immediately before the final whistle.

The Spring benefit bridge party and fashion show of Colony House will be held on May 2 at the Plaza with Mrs. Alfred L. Fawcett as chairman. Proceeds will provide days in the country for children from Colony House, 297 Dean Street, Brooklyn.

Major Charles R. Olberg, hydraulic engineer who designed the Roosevelt and Coolidge Dams in Arizona and who had charge of the Indian irrigation services for the Department of Commerce with headquarters in Los Angeles, died here today at the age of 60.

To guard against "political patronage, favoritism, bribery and graft," managers and staffs of all public housing projects should be put under competitive civil service, it was urged yesterday at a meeting of the Citizens Housing Council at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street.

Seven young men known to the Brooklyn 'police as the boloneyy bandits" because they almost always ordered bologna a minute before holding up a delicatessen or butcher shop were under arrest last night on charges of assault and robery after they had been trapped by the police.

A suit of clothes made of wood pulp was shown today at the luncheon meeting of the Salesmen's Association of the Paper Industry by George Gibson, Chicago representative of the Mosinee Paper Mills, Mosinee, Wis., Mr. Gibson's shirt, tie, socks and underclothing also were made of wood-pulp fabrics imported from Germany, where the fabric is known as Zellwolle and is being used as a substitute for cotton, which must be imported. Mr. Gibson said

Ernst Toller, exiled German author and playwright, declared last night that an invitation to lecture on "Social Drama" at Queens College with John Gassner and Brock Pemberton had been withdrawn by Dr. Paul Klapper, president of the college, for "political and racial reasons."

Washington St, 135-9; to three 6-story tenements and stores; Frederick A. Scouthworth, 49 Wall St, owner; Joseph Lau, architect: cost $21,000. 8th Ave, 2,100-2; to two 5-story tenements; Emil Hantsche Jr, 725 1st Ave, owner; same architect; cost $8.000.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey revealed action yesterday against an alleged taxicab racket through which owners of four fleets, numbering about 5,000 taxicabs, have been forced since 1933 to pay tribute of nearly $1,000,000 for "protection."

The 243d New York yearly meeting of the Religious Society of Friends yesterday closed its fiveday assembly with short business sessions in the morning and afternoon, at which committee reports for 1937-38 and programs for the coming year were discussed.

The fair trade practice laws are the public's bulwark against monopoly, and failure of business to make use of these laws to suppress monopoly will lead either to government regulation of manufacturing, selling and distribution or to the destruction of the profit system, three United States Senators warned about 600 business leaders last night at the Hotel Astor.

Spanish Insurgents smashing eastward toward the Mediterranean today were reported on the outskirts of Tortosa, control point on the last remaining highway connecting Barcelona with the rest of Government Spain.

Maria Maximovitch, the soprano who had given an admirable account of herself earlier in the season, gave a second recital last night in Town Hall. Again her program asked much in point of differentiation of mood and style.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain again proved his complete mastery over the well-disciplined Conservative party tonight when the House of Commons rejected by a vote of 359 to 152 the Labor party's demand for an immediate general election on foreign policy.
Indicative of the prospects of continued close cooperation between the Kuomintang and the Communist party in China are the pronouncements made today by Kuomintang and Communist spokesmen.
John Ridgely of Hampton, member of an old Maryland family, died last night on the Dulany Valley estate which has been owned by his family for two hundred years.

Mrs. Eugene A. Philbin entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Mrs. Schuyler N. Warren, Mrs. Henry Graff Trevor, Mrs. Eliot Tuckerman, Mrs. Charles J. Welch, Mrs. J. William Kilbreth and Mrs. Stephen H. Philbin.

The list of the French liner Paris, due today from Havre via Southampton, includes Sir James German, Baron R. de Luze, Mr. and Mrs. B. B. Barr, Mrs. A. F. Sinclair, Julien Benda, Fernand Gravet, French actor; Eva Le Gallienne, actress; Marion Evensen, actress; Dr. and Mrs. Marcel Paillon, Lucien Breffort, French vice consul in New York; Jean Legasse, Marco F. Hellman, Mrs. E. K. Cohan and Paul Charrin.

After a lapse of several years, the manufacture of Kolb sectional buildings will be resumed by Milton B. Kolb, who has formed the Kolb Building Company, with offices at 250 West Fifty-seventh Street. Peters Gray, Inc., were cobrokers in the sale of the former residence of the late Gilbert W. Keech at 4 East Seventy-ninth Street.

Nine British schoolboys from the Betteshanger School at Eastry, near Dover, arrived here yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary for a tour of boys' schools in this country to demonstrate "basic physical training."

Moderate declines in deposits and in most important asset items, including total assets, were shown in the statements as of March 31 issued yesterday by local banks and trust companies. Holdings of United States Government securities were down from the end of the year in most cases.

Governor Lehman today acted on a number of the more important bills passed at the recent session of the Legislature. Heading the list of measures approved was the Moffat bill extending until July 1, 1939, the present emergency taxing powers of New York City.

The medical profession in America was thoroughly examined yesterday at the opening session of the annual meeting of the American College of Physicians, one of the "big three" among the country's national medical organizations, and found to be seriously ill and requiring a radical change in its present

Brooklyn College vs. Seton Hall, at Brooklyn College Field, Bedford Avenue andAvenue H, Brooklyn ...........3:30 P. M. BOXING New York Coliseum, East 177th Street and Boston Road, Bronx ..........8:30 P. M. Broadway Arena, Halsey Street near Broadway, Brooklyn ..........8:30 P. M.

On his seventy-sixth birthday Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler said that he had more important things to do than work. What the perennially active president of Columbia meant, of course, was that he had other work to do, more important than the daily routine.

The Whiting property at 62 East Fifty-fifth Street was reported sold yesterday, and the building will be remodeled in modernistic style as the new home of Kreinick Modes, Inc., women's apparel, the buyers of the parcel. Douglas L. Elliman Co. acted as brokers in the deal.

The University of Wisconsin tonight laid claim to the mythical national collegiate boxing championship by defeating Washington State, 51/2 to 21/2. A crowd of 14,250 packed the Badger field house to watch Wisconsin boxers complete their season's schedule of seven matches undefeated. Previously Wisconsin won from St. Norbert's, Tulane, Louisiana State, Syracuse, Penn State and West Virginia.
A barnstorming trip to Sweden in October loomed today as a reward for seven of the nine national A. A. U wrestling champions crowned in the tournament won by the Oklahoma A. and M. team.

Police of two States and Sheriff's officers were united in a wide-flung search tonight for the torturers and slayers of Mrs. Weston G. Frome, 46, and her 23-year-old daughter, Nancy, whose bodies were found yesterday amid the mesquite and cacti of West Texas.

Captain J. D. Moshkovsky made a roundtrip flight to the North Pole from Rudolf Island today in fruitless search for Sigismund Levanevsky and five companions, lost last August in an attempted transpolar flight to the United States.

Utilization of the undeveloped Sprain Brook Parkway right-ofway for an arterial State highway between Yonkers and Hawthorne would cause irreparable damage to near-by homes and estates, Yonkers Supervisors declared here today in announcing their opposition to a proposal being studied by the State Council of Parks.

Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia, former world pocket billiard champion, ran 125 to defeat Jimmy Caras of Wilmington, Del., crowned champion at the recent New York tournament, in the second block of an exhibition match today.
John Lyon Houston, pioneer resident of this community and retired New York insurance man, died last night in Winter Park, Fla., where he had lived since leaving here five years ago. His age was 69.
George H. Cowle, who retired in December, 1934, after forty-one years as an assistant corporation counsel of the City of New York, died here today at his home, 269 Elm Avenue. His age was 65.

The further examination of Richard Whitney was postponed yesterday by Irwin Kurtz, Federal referee in bankruptcy, to enable Whitney to assemble complete data as to his personal loans and the loans of his firm.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Color in Dress," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.: collection of paintings (general tour), noon; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Design in Metal," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.; "The Manchu Patrons," Mabel Harrison Duncan, 4 P. M.

The Brazilian Government has not remitted funds sufficient for the payment of the interest coupons due on April 1, 1938, on its 5 per cent twenty-year bonds of 1931, according to a statement yesterday by Dillon, Read Co., paying agents for the loan. Payment of the coupons will not- be made at this time, it was declared.

The better tone in Wall Street at the weekend caused a cheerful reaction on the stock market here today and most sections advanced. Gilt-edge issues were in active demand while foreign bonds were firm. Transatlantic stocks changed hands briskly and, despite a slight weakening of prices in late trading, the section closed strong.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had: CUSTOMS 4128 and 4129-The 'United States v. H. J. Heinz Co. The H. J. Heinz Co. v. the United States. Opinion by Judge Garrett. The United States Customs Court judgment is affirmed.
Treasurers in the Shubert playhouses here have been instructed not to accept gratuities from theatre ticket brokers in return for desirable seat locations, it became known yesterday.

A number of Bronx apartment houses were reported by brokers yesterday as having been sold. Among them was the six-story structure at 940 East 178th Street, which was purchased by Sam Reznick, operator, from the Bronx Trustees. A. Robinson Co., Inc., was the broker.

Samuel Reshevsky, chess champion of the United States, and Reuben Fine, believed to be his most dangerous rival for chief honors, assumed the lead n the third round of the biennial title tournament of the National Chess Federation last

The last in a series of four lectures will be given this morning at the Convent of The Sacred Heart, 1 East Ninety-first Street, to assist the Duchesne Placement Bureau, located at the Carroll Club of this city.

Subscribers to the three-cents-aday hospital plan of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, 370 Lexington Avenue, will receive increased benefits beginning today, it was announced last night by Frank Van Dyk, executive director of the organization.

Miss June Marie Mendillo, daughter r of Dr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Mendillo of this city, has completed plans for her marriage to Hubert r M. Greist Jr., son of Mrs. Hubert M. Greist, also of New Haven, which will take place here the afternoon t of April 22 in St. Joseph's Church.

Revocation of countervailing duties imposed on certain German agricultural products was announced today by the Treasury. The countervailing duty is equivalent to the amount of bounty which was paid on these products until September by the German Government.
Legislation proposing temporary government operation of three large liners in the intercoastal trade won House approval n less than three minutes today.

The residence of Mrs. Edward Bruch, in Field Point Park, has been sold to Harry M. Newington and his son, John C. Newington. It was held at $65,000. Eva M. Seaman was the broker in the sale. Alterations have been started and the estate will be named Villa Serena.
A 17-year-old girl made a hole-inone today but missed a six-foot putt on the eighteenth green and lost her match in the North Jersey Scholastic Conference golf tournament.

The Walt Disney film "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" is the first sound picture to be translated into a "Talking Book"' for blind audiences, according to an announcement yesterday by the American Foundation for the Blind.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is unfortunate that a dispute has arisen over the Reorganization Bill. But since it has, I trust the President will achieve a complete victory. The delay in the House of Representatives can only bring out more clearly, I believe, that there is no constitutional question involved, and that the ardor of many people in this matter is misplaced.

Mrs. Lois Buhrer Barstow, widow of Frank Quarles Barstow, an land. associate of the late John D. Rockefeller on the original board of directors of the Standard Oil Company, died of a heart attack today at her home here. Her age was 84.

Buyers were attracted yesterday by the investment possibilities of houses in Manhattan which they plan to modernize. In the first sale of the property in more than twenty-five years, the five-storyAmerican basement dwelling on a lot 18 by 102.2 feet at 117

City College bowed, 21-5, to the Princeton baseball team on University Field today. It was the Lavender's first game this season. Displaying greater strength on the mound and at bat the Tigers ran up the largest number of runs in a decade of Princeton baseball.

A demonstration by hundreds of American Federation of Labor pickets at a Missouri River bridge was shortlived today as a general strike involving 6,000 A. F. of L. workmen protesting against non-union labor on the bridge repair project became effective here.

Pennies were as scarce as pre-New Deal $20 gold pieces here today, after students from Rensselaer; Polytechnic Institute, bent on staging a protest against "hidden taxes," 'had swooped down on banks and stores and gained a virtual stranglehold on the copper coins market.

Trustees of the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company declared today a liquidating dividend of $1 a share, payable on and after April 11. This dividend will make a total of $4 a share to date in liquidation of the textile concern which filed a petition in bankruptcy on Christmas Eve, 1935.

The Virginian Railway completed repairs to 1,519 coal cars in 1937 under a ruling of the Interstate Commerce Commission permitting the company to spread the cost over a period of five years, Carl Bucholtz, president, said in his annual report, issued yesterday.

Nine patient draft horses, their coats seared by flames and sprayed with water for many hours, were carefully hoisted yesterday from their precarious footing on the seeond floor of the Liberty Boarding Stables at 238 Cherry Street on the East River.
Foster Mother. No. 1 was the title given to Mrs. Sara Rosen of 626 East 179th Street, the Bronx, yesterday as she settled down to making a home for a 2-month-old- baby whose name is Tillie.

The German Government has abolished the Austrian State Tourist Department, 630 Fifth Avenue, Rudolf Mattesich, manager of the department, announced yesterday. He said that the organization had been entirely liquidated and its effects appropriated by the German Railroads Information Office, 665 Fifth Avenue.

Memories of nickelodeon "thrillers" of the past were revived last night at a progressive "nickelodeon horse and buggy party" in the Beekman Towers Theatre, Fortyninth Street and First Avenue, which marked the theatre's inauguration of a revival of some of the earliest motion pictures.
With plans now complete to equip the entire British adult population with gas masks, the Home Office announced tonight that a "gas bag" had been invented for infants.

Members of the City Council Finance Committee who have been studying Mayor La Guardia's new relief tax bills were unable to agree yesterday on supporting the 1-centa-package tax on cigarettes and decided to hold another meeting this morning before the Council convenes to act on the tax bills.

The National Labor Relations Board announced today that it had certified the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, Local 13, as the exclusive collective bargaining agency for employes of Stephen Ransom, Inc., New York.
The Fall exhibition and fashion show sponsored by the National Authority for the Ladies' Handbag Industry will be held at the Hotel Pennsylvania from Aug. 1 to 5.
Four men were killed and twenty others injured, several critically, by a terrific explosion of grain dust late today that wrecked the inside of the nine-story State owned public grain elevator here.

A United Automobile Workers "flying squadron" of Briggs Manufacturing Company Local held a dues-collecting drive at the company's Meldrum Avenue plant gates today and refused to admit several of the 800 employes when they would not pay up. Some workers paid their dues,

John W. O'Leary, chairman of the executive committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, filed a statement today with the Senate Labor Committee in opposition to Senator Wagner's bill to enforce the Labor Relations Act on contractors with and borrowers from the government.

In the wake of the popular enthusiasm aroused by Austrian Anschluss and creation of the greater German Reich, the government announced today another 1,000,000,000-mark public loan, in which, for the first time, Austria is to participate.

The president of the New York State Historical Association (Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox, president of Union College) tells in a brief article (in the publication of the Rochester Museum of Arts and Sciences) of his wanderings last Summer in the footsteps of Herodotus over a large part of the ancient world.

After having held prospective building sites for many years to await a propitious time to begin operations, the Forest Hills Heights Corporation, of which D. M. -Sarkisian is president, has broken ground for the first unit in a group of garden apartments

Trenton Ave (16-4476), w s, 497 s of Allerton Ave, 80x100; Brim Realty Corp to Brim Ideal Homes, Inc, 391 E 149th St. Tinton Ave, 1,000 (10,2669), Irene M. Roche to Home Owners Loan Corp. Roberts Ave (15-4163), n s, 50 w of Edison Ave, 45x100; H. Edwin Goldberg, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp.

Equity's nominating committee for the organization's election late next month or early June has selected Arthur Byron as candidate for the presidency and Bert Lytell as its nominee for vice president. Mr. Byron is now serving as third vice president.

Mike (Kid) Frattini of Italy defeated Vincent Pimpinella of Brooklyn in a hard-fought eight-round bout at St. Nicholas Palace last night before a crowd of 2,500. Frattini weighed 148 and his opponent was three pounds heavier.

A newspaper article removed today any possible doubt that serious charges are faced by Nikolai Krylenko, one of the cruelest of the early revolutionary leaders and a relentless prosecutor in the early trials of "wreckers," and Eugeni B. Pashukanis, until a year ago regarded as chief theoretician of Soviet justice.

A Central Rumanian Relief Campaign Committee to assist the Jews of Rumania was organized last night by a group of prominent Jews of Rumanian descent at a meeting at the Hotel Sharon, 227 West Fortysixth Street. It will cooperate with the American Joint Distribution Committee and adopted a resolution to set $50,000 as the quota for the committee.

The Inland Boatmen's Union, the C. I. O. organization of river and harbor employes, in a letter yesterday to Secretary of War Woodring demanded that Major Gen. T. Q. Ashburn be removed as president of the Inland Waterways Corporation, for alleged "strike-breaking" activities.

Ten thousand men and women gathered in Madison Square Garden last night at a mass meeting organized by the Committee for Peace Through World Cooperation heard Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of the Free Synagogue denounce prelates who have prayed for the success of General Franco in Spain or defended the invasion of Austria by Hitler.

About 500 stockholders and others trekked yesterday to Hoboken for the thirty-sixth annual meeting of United States Steel-one gentleman for the thirty-fourth time-but found scarcely room for 300. Others stood in the narrow aisles or peered through open doorways,

The British Admiralty today ordered the 42,100-ton battle cruiser Hood to proceed to Barcelona, Spain, to help in any evacuation of that capital that may be necessary. The British Government today intervened with Generalissimo Francisco Franco on behalf of the captains of five British ships in Tarragona harbor who reported Spanish planes were dropping bombs around the vessels every day.
Lord and Lady Hotham, who have been visiting in Canada, are at the Ambassador. They will sail tomorrow on the Queen Mary for their home in England.
Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels announced tonight that in the grand finale for the Austrian plebiscite campaign he intended to surpass previous demonstrations anywhere.

Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday plans for a new $50,000,000 housing project, privately financed, as an important factor in his general program of new housing. He summoned leading contractors and union representatives in the building field to a City Hall conference. At his suggestion the two...

Earl Roche, veteran center of the Cleveland Barons of the International-American Hockey League, remained under observation in a hospital tonight while physicians tried to determine whether he would lose the sight of one eye.

Eight hundred women of Spanish descent, and friends who swelled their ranks to 2,000, came by special train from New York today to ask the government to lift the embargo on arms exports to the Spanish Loyalists. They marched in an orderly parade to the State Department and the Capitol, where small delegations conferred with officials, who told them that their requests could be met only by amendment of the Neutrality Act.

Dr. and Mrs. John Munroe of Rockville Centre, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marian Munroe, to Angus A. MacInnes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. A. A. MacInnes of Little Neck Hills, L. I.

Edwin A. de Lima sold to William P. Churchill and his wife, who live there, the house at 14 E 129th St, 18.9x100. at a price shown as $8,000, and took back a purchase money mortgage for $6,500, due in five years at 5 per cent, amortized $75 quarterly.
Auomobile output gained only nominally last week, when a spurt was seasonal, and the adjusted index declined again, falling to 50.5 from 52.6. The figure was 84.1 for the week ended April 3, 1937.

The Brooklyn Bar Association's committee on constitutional convention made public yesterday an intermediate report recommending that the judges in the higher courts either be appointed or elected without party designation for terms ending when they reach the age of 70. A special meeting

Municipal officials here held their breath and crossed their fingers this afternoon when representatives of the State Quartermaster General called for bids at public auction of the Dumont National Guard Armory, but they relaxed a few moments later as it became apparent that no private offers were to be made.

The body of a man, identified through papers in his clothing as George Lewis, 43 years old, of 531 East Lincoln Avenue, Mount Vernon, an automobile salesman, was found late last night in the northbound roadway at Boston Post Road and Dyre Avenue, the Bronx.
Asserting that the anniversary of the United States' entrance into the World War provides a "fitting annual occasion," Governor Lehman tonight proclaimed Wednesday as Army Day.

Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Frank of 221 West Eighty-second Street will celebrate their fiftieth wedding anniversary with a family gathering at their home on Friday. Both Mr. and Mrs. Frank have been active in Jewish philanthropic work.

Highway, safety and automobile engineers will gather in Detroit tomorrow night for the opening of what is said to be the first stretch of American highway ever to be illuminated by indirect lighting. The visitors, who will make a trial run over the experimental road, will be the guests of Murray D. Van Wagoner, State Highway Commissioner.

Dr. George A. Reisner, world-famous Egyptologist of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, has for some time been working under the handicap of almost total blindness, Dr. George H. Edgell, director of the museum, revealed today.

The Senate Appropriations Committee completed work on the biggest Army Appropriations Bill in peacetime history today, approving outlays approximating $490,000,000 for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

A banking group composed of the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, Bankers Trust Company and the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company received yesterday the award of a new issue of $737,000 of advancement fund bonds of Marion County, Ind., on a bid of 100.939 for 2 1/4s.

The Montreal Canadiens and the Detroit Red Wings of the National Hockey League will leave Montreal tomorrow night for the Maritime Provinces, where they will play three exhibition games before sailing from Halifax next Saturday for their European tour. The teams will return about the middle of May.

Commercial and industrial fallures in the United States for the week ended March 31 totaled 271, compared with 256 for the preceding week and 185 for the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The movieconscious Massachusetts House of Representatives today pondered the possibility of forcing entertainers to stop using "phony names" and discussed with equal impartiality the relative merits of Mae West and Mickey Mouse before deciding

If any movie patron interested in foreign productions has doubts regarding the ability of the Greeks to find words for everything, a visit to the Miami Theatre in Sixth Avenue will dispel them in a hurry.

The first cash." period of Cuba's seventeenth Congress was opened by the Senate this afternoon. The House of Representatives, however, failed to muster a quorum, and its opening was postponed until Thursday.

Kenneth H. Campbell has been named manager of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau of the National Association of Credit Men, succeeding William S. Swingle, who became vice president of the National Foreign Trade Council on April 1. Mr. Campbell has served as service manager for the foreign trade division of the credit group for more than ten years and has a wide acquaintanceship among export managers and credit men in all parts of the country.

Despondency over a decision against him by the National Labor Relations Board was advanced today by the family of Arthur L. Colten, clothing manufacturer, as the motive for his suicide yesterday. Near Mr. Colten, when he was found fatally shot, was a copy of an NLRB ruling which b received
Representative May, chairman of the House Military Affairs Committee, announced today that the committee would open hearings on April 26 on a bill to provide $2,000,000 for autogiro development.

Trading was fair to good. Steer beef sold strong to slightly higher, veal steady to higher, fresh pork steady to lower, other Classes steady with Friday. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef prices to be strong to higher, veal weak to lower, Lamb about steady, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

OF the three books* this morning, the relation is that each has more or less to say about shipboard life. Ben Lucien Burman's "Blow for a Landing" is a novel about shantyboat folk on the lower Mississippi; Rolph Malloch's "Peace Tour," an account of a voyage to and through Japan; August Mencken's "First-Class Passenger," a portfolio of travelers' tales from 750 B. C. to the present.
Richard Wallace, display director for B. Altman Co., died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at his residence, 128 East Thirty-fifth Street, in his forty-first year.

Mrs. Mary A. Donegan, former newspaper woman and wife of James J. Donegan, former night mechanical superintendent for The New York Journal and American, died Saturday at her home, 1,578 Hollywood Avenue, the Bronx.

The current decline in dollar sales volume among retail grocers hit city establishments more severely than rural stores last week, the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc., reported yesterday.

Half a million Americans are permanently disabled, so seriously as to be incapable of self support or school attendance, and more than 2,000,000 others have suffered crippling injuries or diseases which have left them handicapped for life, the Publie Health Service announced today.
Reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission today showed several corporations increased the compensation of their executives last year, while a few disclosed cuts. The figures follow:

BARTLETT, WILLIAM C. (Nov. 20, 1937). Gross assets, $4,890: net, $4,243. To brother, Edward E. Bartlett, specific realty and contents; sister, Susan E. Bartlett, residuary estate. Chief assets, real estate, $2,025; stocks and bonds, $1,037; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance. $1,547; miscellaneous property $280. Manning Manning, attorneys, 66 Court St.

United States Ambassador Joseph C. Grew delivered today a memorandum to the Japanese Foreign Office on the question of American nationals in China. He conferred for a half hour with Kensuke Horinouchi, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey will reduce today the price of domestic bunker fuel oil in this and other North Atlantic ports by 10 cents a barrel. Bonded bunker fuel oil will be reduced 5 cents a barrel.

An AngloItalian treaty, with protocols, is now ready and the only thing regaining is to establish the precise wording of mutual obligations and the exact date when it will be signed, sealed and delivered. The principal points of agreement follow.

Notice has been received from the Manufacturers Trust Company that funds have been deposited for payment of the April 1, 1938, coupons of city of Santa Fe, Argentina, 7 per cent bonds, due on April 1, 1945, at the rate of $20 for each $1,000 bond.

weveing only once or twice from the pressure of being the "front runner" in the final round, Henry Picard, tall Hershey (Pa.) pro, today won the fifth annual Masters' tournament, one of golf's most Prized events.

In a decision viewed by observers as relaxing restrictions of the interstate commerce clause of the Constitution, the Supreme Court in a seven-to-one division today upheld a Louisiana tax on booster pumps used to speed the flow of natural gas from that State into Texas and Arkansas.

The Insurgents were approaching Tortosa today, being apparently somewhere around Cherta, about five miles north, this afternoon when this correspondent visited the ruined town at the mouth of the Ebro River.

At a meeting of the East Orange Board of Education tonight, George C. Shotwell, star center of the Uni versity of Pittsburgh football team in 1934, was appointed coach of the East Orange High School gridiron squad. Shotwell also will teach history and other academic subjects, it was announced.

The five-story loft building at 116 Elizabeth Street, on a plot 25 by 100 feet between Grand and Broome Streets has been leased by Kupferberg's Lighting Fixture Company for a long term from the Amesland Corporation through the Bulkley Horton Company.

3:00-4:00 P. M.-United States Marine Band Concert-WJZ. 4:00-4:15 P.M.-From Denmark: "International Science," Professor Niels Bohr, Nobel Prize Winner-WJZ. 4:45-5:00 P. M.--"Democracies Versus Dictatorships,"-Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts-WABC. 6:45-7:00 P. M.-"Airships for National Defense," Commander Charles E. Rosendahl, U. S. N.-WOR. 7:45-8:00 P. H.-"America's Job," Representative Ralph O. Brewster of Maine-WMCA.

George O. May, senior partner in the accounting firm of Price, Water-house Co., has been subpoenaed by the Securities and Exchange Commission to testify on Thursday concerning the alleged omission from reports of the Missouri Pacific Railroad for the years 1934 to 1936, inclusive, of any reference to a

Within a month the city will start building a railroad terminal at the Bronx Terminal Market with facilities for receiving and distributing about 95 per cent of the produce consumed in that borough, it was disclosed yesterday by Carl W. Kimball, First Deputy Commissioner of Public Markets, Weights and Measures.

The practicability of extra fare charges that would break five-cent subway and elevated rides at four key points in New York City that are not covered by the existing fare contracts was discussed yesterday at an Interborough Rapid Transit Company receivership hearing in Federal court.

The bitterly defended Chinese lines north of the Lung-Hai Railway were pierced at dawn yesterday when Japanese forces completed the capture of the strategic city of Taierhchwang, in Southern Shantung, forty-five miles northeast of Suchow.
The Fordham College senior class voted almost unanimously yesterday to include a class day in the senior week activities at Fordham College. The day will be held Monday, June 13.

Work by three water-colorists, each of whom is about as accomplished a technician as you could find, was placed on view yesterday. Two of these artists, Eliot O'Hara and John Whorf, are American, while the third exhibitor is BritishW. Russell Flint, R.A., president of the Royal Society of Painters in Water-Colours.

An official press release of the Sudeten German (pro-Nazi) party declared today that unless a Jewish boycott in the United States against Sudeten German goods was stopped, the Germans in Czechoslovakia that the party- represents would cancel their orders for United States cotton.

Lennox Robinson's one-act play, "Crabbed Youth and Age," will be acted by the Irish Repertory Players today at the Hotel Astor as a feature of the annual Spring luncheon of the Jewish Consumptive Relief Society, New York Auxiliary.

John tions-i D. Rockefeller Jr. declared himself here tonight to be vigorously opposed to the doctrine of high-pressure spending that is now advocated "in various quarters." He pleaded for neighborly cooperation in solving the problems that confront society.

An entire floor consisting of 15,000 square feet of space in the building at 1,650 Broadway has been taken by the Wine and Liquor Club of America, Inc., for a long term at an aggregate rental of $70,000. The club is a newly formed organization consisting of persons engaged in the liquor industry.

The Public Affairs Committee of the New York Socialist party proposed twenty-three amendments to the State Constitution in a letter sent yesterday to Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane of the Court of Appeals, who is president of the Constitutional Convention opening today in Albany.
President Roosevelt is expected to recommend an immediate and long-range program for aiding the nation's railroads in a message to Congress which he has indicated he would send up this week.

Charging "bad faith" and a "gross breach of trust" on the part of the Guaranty Trust Company, Carl E. Newton, counsel for Robert R. Young, chairman of the board of the Alleghany Corporation, told Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe yesterday that he would demand the removal of the bank as trustee of Alleghany bond issues amounting to $77,514,000.

Tom Iannicelli, three-time world champion, and Jim Reid Sr. of the Crescent A. C. advanced to the semi-final round of the world open squash tennis championship tournament at the Shelton Club last night. Iarnnicelli, Short Hills professional, disposed of Tom Doyle, assistant pro at the Crescent A. C., 15-4, 15-9, 15-8, while Reid eliminated Ed Standing, Yale Club pro, 18-16, 15-11, 15-8.
The Hudson County grand jury handed up an indictment this afternoon against a Jersey City district election board charging violation of the election laws. The members,

The report on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company by Paul A. Walker of the Federal Communications Commission is said to be a document of 1,000 pages. Its preparation has covered a period of three years. Congress appropriated for the FCC $1,500,000 to cover its cost, and it has cost the telephone company itself some $3,000,000.

In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday the Rev. Herman F. Reissig, executive secretary of the Medical Bureau and North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy, reiterated the denial he made last year before a House of Representatives committee that his organization had ever solicited enlistments or sent volunteers to aid the Loyalist forces in Spain.

C. O. Miller, president of the Pacific Lighting Corporation, states in his 1937 annual report to shareholders, released today, that a contradictory situation exists "wherein the Federal Government, by outright gifts and unsecured loans, encourages the construction of unnecessary duplicate utility plants and thereby eliminates tax-paying utility systems."

Basketball, the nations leading indoor sport, is streamlined enough for those who teach it. That was the consensus of the National Association of Basketball Coaches tonight after a round of committee reports.
The death of the Hon. Mrs. Joan Verena Hamilton-Russell, friend of the royal family, whose 4-year-old daughter was killed in a Coronation Day accident, was announced today.

Two men, accused of defrauding more than forty job seekers of $40 each as a fee for employment on the construction of the Midtown Vehicular Tunnel, which they never obtained, were held in $1,000 bail each for trial May 2 by County Judge Charles S. Colden in Long Island City, Queens, yesterday, on charges of petty larceny and conspiracy.

A one-year contract, retroactive as of March 31, and affecting 3,500 workers, has been signed by the United Shoe Workers of America, C. I. O. affiliate, with stitchdown manufacturers in this city, Powers Hapgood, national organizer of the upnion, announced yesterday.

The White Sox reduced the exhibition series advantage of their hometown rivals, the Cubs, to one game today by blasting an 11-to-9 victory. The White Sox scored all their runs and all but two of their-fifteen hits off Rookie Clyde Epperly in the first four innings.

Major Benjamin H. Namm, president of Namm's department store, Brooklyn, will give a luncheon today at the store to more than 100 national, city and borough officials in connection with the store's twentieth semi-annual Brooklyn Day celebration.

Light-heavyweight champion John Henry Lewis of Pittsburgh won a ten-round decision from Bob Tow, 202, of Alexandria, Va., protege of former heavyweight champion Jim Braddock, in a non-title bout before 7,500 fans tonight. Lewis weighed 183.

Four hundred thousand-nearly half--of Greater New York's young men and women between the ages of 16 and 24, willing and able to work, cannot find work. These young people do not include those who are in school, those who are living at home and not seeking employment,

Stocks of burlap in Calcutta at the end of March reached the highest level on record, according to cables received in the market yesterday. The figure was 353,400,000 yards, and the previous high prior to this year was established at the end of February, 1931, with 259,183,000 yards.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday that the- department had approved the plans for the World's Fair motorcade to be held April 30. He said, however, that he had not received any recommendation regarding the application for the United May Day parade from Deputy Chief Inspector Louis F.- Costuma, in command of Manhattan, who held a hearing last week on the subject.

Calling the proposed Federal Reorganization Bill "tyrannical, an infringement on personal liberties, a departure from democratic government and a step toward dictatorship," residents of Scarsdale, East Chester, Greenburgh and Yonkers met in Dyckman Hall-here tonight and adopted a resolution urging Congress to defeat the measure.

The opening of 419 school playgrounds for the Spring, Summer and early Fall season was announced yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools. These recreation centers for children will be open until 6 P. M. on school days and from 10 A. M. to 6 P. M. on Saturdays and holidays.

Spurgeon Chandler flashed a superb exhibition of pitching for seven innings today at Buffalo Stadium, but as far as the game was concerned, it was a wasted effort. The Yankees were stampeded by the Houston Buffs when the Class A minor league club staged a ninthinning rally in which they rocked Ivy Paul Andrews for four runs and romped off with the game by a count of 7 to 6.

United States Attorney Harold St. L. O'Dougherty filed a brief yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court in opposition to a motion to quash an indictment charging Albert Marinelli, former New York County Clerk, with having harbored a fugitive from justice. Judge Robert A. Inch reserved decision. The indictment charges the former County Clerk with harboring Charles Falci between 1933 and 1936.

CLASSIFIED BY OFFICE Allied Stores Corp., 1,440 Bway BOSTON-Jordan Marsh Co.: A. A. Burns, wash goods, woolens; Miss E. Redman, blouses, skirts, knitwear: Miss G. Carney, millinery: Miss V. Stansfield, asst. misses' dresses; Miss R. Murphy, Miss P. Donnell, representing; basement, Miss B. Redman, misses' dresses C. Lovejoy, asst. R. J. Trimble, lingerie: Miss A. E. Bell, children's wear Miss M. R. Duffy ,women's,
El Salvador's presumed matching of the Dionne quintuplets with five boys is now proved to be a hoax by a personal investigation by this correspondent.

Statistics show that 1,791 Germans have been deprived of citizenship since 1933 for having criticized the National Socialist regime abroad. Such charges were brought against 998 persons; the 793 others were members of their families.

Mrs. T. L. Bates of Groveland, who became gravely ill Friday after receiving injections of a cancer serum, died at a hospital here late tonight. It was the eleventh death since Tuesday from symptoms which, doctors said. resembled those

In a brief filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today by Hudson County municipalities, a fivecent fare is asked on the uptown and downtown lines of the Hudson Manhattan tubes. This is the answer of the municipalities to the railroad's request for a fare increase from 6 to 10 cents between Jersey City, Hoboken and Cortlandt Street, New York.

Dr. Fernando de los Rios, Spanish Ambassador to the United States, tonight termed "calumny" and "all insidious lies" the assertions of the Rev. Dr. Joseph B. Code. Professor of History at the Catholic University of America, that Dr. de los Rios had spent more than $13,000,000 in America to win sympathy for "the Communist-dominated Spanish Leftist Government."

The committee which will solicit contributions from realty interests and their employes for the $10,000,000 Greater New York Fund will be headed by Lawrence B. Elliman, president of Pease Elliman, Inc.

Clarence Chamberlin, who flew non-stop from New York to Germany in 1927, discussed yesterday at a luncheon of the Advertising Post of the American Legion his plans for a stratosphere flight this Fall from New York to London or Paris.
Hugh Harbison, assistant secretary of the Travelers Insurance Company of this city, and Miss Elizabeth Blanchard Telford of Tucson, Ariz., were married today in Tucson.

Mrs. Marion duPont Scott, owner of Battleship, who surprised the racing world by his notable victory in the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree, returned from England on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary yesterday. She confirmed earlier reports that Battleship would be retired for breeding purposes.

The Yale Club squash racquets combination administered another setback to the touring Cambridge University players yesterday, the Eli clubmen vanquishing the Britons, 5 to 1. In spite of the onesidedness of the score the English collegians put up a stern battle, but finally suffered the eighth defeat of their visit.
Continuing his Austrian tour, Chancellor Adolf Hitler arrived in this capital of Carinthia today. Carinthia, like the neighboring Styria, was an Austrian Nazi center.

Glowing reports regarding the outlook for the new wheat, rye and oats crops, and messages from local crop experts from the Southwest indicating last week's frost did not damage wheat in that area, led to general

Movements of vessels follow. all dates are April 4, unless specified: Manila to Southern Philippines: Alden, Paul Jones, Parrott. At Hong Kong: Black Hawk, Mindanao. Chaumont, Honolulu to San Francisco. Cincinnati, Mare Island to San Diego. Cuyama, San Pedro to Navy Yard, Pearl Harbor.

Former President Hoover asserted today that the Administration's Reorganization Bill meant "the reintroduction of the spoils system after seventy-five years of battle to set up the Civil Service Commission."

Addressed by Governor Wilbur L. Cross, Dr. Charles Seymour, president of Yale University; Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Automotive Safety Foundation; Mayor John W. Murphy and a score of others, including specialists in the fields of enforcement, engineering and education for highway safety, Connecticut's first State-wide highway safety conference was held here today.

The possibility that the Federal Alcohol Administration may adopt the plan now in force in Kentucky which prohibits extension of credit to retailers of liquor is discussed in an article analyzing the so-called "Twenty-one-Day Credit Rule," enforced by the New York State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board by William Walker Orr, secretary of the New York Credit Men's Associtation, in Credit Executive, the association's monthly magazine, to be published April 15.

Net profit of Hiram WalkerGooderham Worts, Ltd., and its subsidiaries for the six months ended on Feb. 28 amounted to $3,923,338 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges but before United States surtax on undistributed income.

Mrs. Lee A. Ault gave a tea yesterday afternoon at Sherry's for members of the entertainment and G debutante committees interested in the success of "Pandora's Box," a preview of Easter fashions which will be presented in the Louis Sherry Room on Thursday at the luncheon hour for the benefit of the Sunnvysid Day Nursery.

The navy asked today for authorization to construct three 45,000-ton battleships designed to be the most powerful of their type in the world instead of the three 35,000-ton dreadnoughts provided in the House bill.
Proponents of the undistributed profits tax principle will try to restore this provision to the 1938 revenue measure when it gets into conference, reports on Capitol Hill indicated today.

Acquisition by the New Jersey Power and Light Company of all common stock of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company was revealed today when the former company asked the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners to approve the transaction.
Mrs. Mary Stang of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marian Lucille Stang of New York, to Leonard John Lewis of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Lewis of Ithaca, N. Y.
Melvin Jones of Chicago, founder of the Lions Club movement in this country and abroad, was honored here today by members of all of the clubs of Greater New York and Long Island.

It hardly seems possible that Chicago and Toronto will start a three-out-offive series for the Stanley Cup at Maple Leaf Gardens tomorrow night. It Is hard to figure which is more surprising, seeing the Black Hawks or the Maple Leafs in the finals for the world hockey title.
Governor Moore signed today a series of bills making $10,090,398 of State funds available for relief and creating a commission to seek a permanent solution of the problem.
Death Reported Retired fireman Michael C. Shea, formerly a member of Engine Co. 203, residing at 199 Hoyt St., Brooklyn, died March 30.
Flanked by an overflow gathering of about 7,000 Texans, all of whom seemed bent upon seeing plenty of baseball, the Giants and Indians really started swinging today.
The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday the award of two contracts totaling $1,107,833 for improvements to the approaches to the Lincoln Tunnel and the George Washington Bridge.

The bill extending powers of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to finance "solvent" businesses and lend to State and local governmental agencies for the developmeant of public works was passed by the House today after two hours of debate by a vote of 336 to 6.

By dismissing eighty-eight employes, consolidating two departments and reduring appropriations for several others, City Commissioner Pearce Franklin, Director of Public Works, has cut his 1938 budget by $208,027, he announced today at a hearing in City Hall.

The possibility that the Federal Alcohol Administration may adopt the plan now in force in Kentucky which prohibits extension of credit to retailers of liquor is discussed in an article analyzing the so-called "Twenty-one-Day Credit Rule," enforced by the New York State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board by William Walker Orr, secretary of the New York Credit Men's Associtation, in Credit Executive, the association's monthly magazine, to be published April 15.

Net profit of Hiram WalkerGooderham Worts, Ltd., and its subsidiaries for the six months ended on Feb. 28 amounted to $3,923,338 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges but before United States surtax on undistributed income.

Mrs. Lee A. Ault gave a tea yesterday afternoon at Sherry's for members of the entertainment and G debutante committees interested in the success of "Pandora's Box," a preview of Easter fashions which will be presented in the Louis Sherry Room on Thursday at the luncheon hour for the benefit of the Sunnvysid Day Nursery.

The navy asked today for authorization to construct three 45,000-ton battleships designed to be the most powerful of their type in the world instead of the three 35,000-ton dreadnoughts provided in the House bill.
Proponents of the undistributed profits tax principle will try to restore this provision to the 1938 revenue measure when it gets into conference, reports on Capitol Hill indicated today.

Acquisition by the New Jersey Power and Light Company of all common stock of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company was revealed today when the former company asked the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners to approve the transaction.
Mrs. Mary Stang of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marian Lucille Stang of New York, to Leonard John Lewis of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Lewis of Ithaca, N. Y.
Melvin Jones of Chicago, founder of the Lions Club movement in this country and abroad, was honored here today by members of all of the clubs of Greater New York and Long Island.

It hardly seems possible that Chicago and Toronto will start a three-out-offive series for the Stanley Cup at Maple Leaf Gardens tomorrow night. It Is hard to figure which is more surprising, seeing the Black Hawks or the Maple Leafs in the finals for the world hockey title.
Governor Moore signed today a series of bills making $10,090,398 of State funds available for relief and creating a commission to seek a permanent solution of the problem.

Joseph Peyser, inventor and manufacturer of machinery used in the canning industry, died here today at his home at the age of 51. He was president of the PeyserHansen Machine Company which for twenty-two years shipped canning machinery to many parts of this country, Europe and Asia.

Dr. Price Brown, physician, who turned to writing historical novels twenty years ago when he became blind, died here yesterday at the age of 94. He was the first medical student at the University of Toronto to be a double gold medalist. He was graduated in 1868.

The Public Affairs Council of the American Labor party, an agency designed to promote "liberalism" among the people, was formed yesterday at a meeting at the Hotel New Yorker. Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick was elected chairman, Langdon W. Post vice chairman and Mrs. Pearl Willen secretary.

Grand Concourse, 2,805 (12-3315); Apex Realty Corp to Rismar Buildings, Inc, 11 W 42d St, installments, 6 per cent; $20,000. Eagle Ave, 676-680 (10-2624); Salvatore Pietronuto to Empire City Savings Bank, 231 W 125th St, due Apr. 1, 1943, 4 per cent: $20,000.

A card party under the auspices of the Junior Aid League of the Lenox Hill Hospital will be given the afternoon of April 23 in the Rainbow Grill of Rockefeller Center for the benefit of the hospital. Later in the afternoon there will be a showing of the latest Spring costumes.

Downward revision of prices on standard brands of sheets and pillowcases, begun yesterday, was designed, according to selling agents, to provide lower basis on which retailers may stage May-and June promotions. The new net prices were achieved either by lengthening of discounts, reduction of base prices, or by increasing base prices and lengthening discounts.
Steve Czerwinski and Ray Schultz of Buffalo broke a scoring lull in the American Bowling Congress tournament today by moving into second place in the doubles ratings with a total of 1,308.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended on March 30: A decrease of $41,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities, a decrease of $98,000,000

Joshua A. Burgee, assistant superintendent of transportation for the Chicago Surface Lines, collapsed and died in the secretary's room of the City Council Chambers today. He was 76 years old and had been an employe of the Surface Lines and its predecessor companies for fifty-two years.

There are a good many people in Washington who apparently believe that the time has come for the President to draw another rabbit from the hat which produced so many rabbits during his first Administration. They are urging him to perform some feat of magic which will startle and impress the country. Some of them think that

Ecuador has signed a barter treaty with Germany which provides for unlimited exports with payments in aski marks, usable only for the purchase of German goods. Exports of cocoa were limited to 4,000 tons and of Panama hats to 60,000 aski marks under the former treaty.
President Roosevelt signed the resolution for a joint Congressional investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

The story of the shooting last July 20 of Miss Irma L. Pradier, 42 years old, a domestic, that Mounted Patrolman Arthur H. Chalmers was alleged to have told to a prosecutor after his arrest as her slayer on Aug. 7 was read yesterday
James Carew, veteran actor and third husband of the late Dame Ellen Terry, died here today at the age of 62. He had been on the stage for forty years
National Socialist action against Freemasonry continues. Following the arrest of leading Vienna Masons, members of the Linz Lodge were seized today.

Charles Rickleef, 41 years old, of 35 West Seventy-fourth Street, New York, and Joseph Fulton, 39, of 163 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn, were sentenced today by County Judge L. Barron Hill to serve fifteen to thirty years in Sing Sing for the hold-up of the Mattituck National Bank and Trust Company on March 11.

The Federal grand jury investigation of the Rubens-Robinson false passport ring that operated through the office of former County Clerk Albert Marinelli ended yesterday with the finding of one secret and two open indictments.

Bonds moved forward over a broad front yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, extending the recovery movement that got under way last Friday. Secondary rail and selected industrial loans were buoyant at times during the session, with the general improvement in values being marred only by the weakness in a few highgrade corporate issues.

The final week of Florida's rod a racing season started- at Tropical the Park today with the feature named after and witnessed by Governor Fred P. Cone. The purse and a trophy went to Mrs. H. O.:Simmons, whose 4-year-old Saunderstown easily rewarded favorite players at 19 to 10 in the five-and-a-half-furlong dash.

In the Third Reich the secret police is supreme. That the orders of the civil authorities are of no avail against the actions of the Nazi Gestapo is shown by the prolonged imprisonment of Pastor Niemoeller. Though on March 2 this

A two-day benefit for the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., will open this morning at the Fifth Avenue store of Arnold Constable Co., where on both days members of the benefit committees will act as hostesses or manikins in various departments.

The Soviet Government today categorically denied sending any military detachments or individuals to fight in China, but at the same time asserted its right to send munitions of all kinds to China if it wished.

The annual program of one-act plays offered in competition by members of the four classes of the College of St. Elizabeth here will be given on Wednesday evening under the auspices of the college dramatic association.

The Association of Master Plumbers of Brooklyn started suit in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday to restrain Locad 1 of the United Association of Plumbers, Gasfitters, Steamfitters and Helpers of the United States and Canada from calling and participating in a strike which allegedly would affect $10,

The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross has received thus far $20,519.44 for the Chinese Civilian Relief Fund, General Robert C. Davis, executive director, announced yesterday. The largest recent gift to the fund was one totaling $1,214.25 from members of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. Other recent gifts included $176 from Dorothy W. Owen.

Here Brownie, a white and liver pointer, won the shooting dog stake at the eighth annual Spring fixture of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club today. This brought to a close a meeting marked by the large number of entries, including nationally known favorites from all over the country.

H. W. Prentis Jr., president of the Armstrong Cork Company, said today the purchase of the Millville and Keyport, N. J., plants of the Whitall-Tatum Glass Company, announced last week, would enable the Lancaster company to offer its customers a complete glass packaging service.

THE ice has gone out and the dream is over. A stern bill collector, the Old Gentleman with the Scythe, finally caught up with those star-spangled Americans who were out there playing a furious game of hockey on borrowed time. The record runs that the Chicago Black

Capturing first places in five of the eight events, the St. George Dragon Club scored 38 points to carry off the honors in the last of a series of four swimming meets conducted by the Associated Swimming Clubs of New York in the Hotel St. George pool, Brooklyn, last night.

Patrolman William Manning, 27 years old, attached to the Williamsbridge Precinct, in the Bronx, was removed to Fordham Hospital yesterday in a critical condition after being stabbed in what police said was an altercation with his younger brother, Thomas, 26.

Seven players representing four colleges, two each from Harvard, Yale and Princeton and one from Dartmouth, will start play this morning in the annual tournanient for the individual championship of the H. Y. P. D. College Chess League at the Marshall C. C.

Trudi Schoop brought her company of "dancing comedians" to Carnegie Hall (of all places) last night for their only Manhattan performance of the season in a new work called "All for Love," with music by Lothar Perl.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 1: CAPTAIN Jenkins, H. E., Med. Corps,Great Lakes, Ill., to instruction, Naval War College, Newport, R. I., June 1. COMMANDERS Ragsdale, V. H., Oakland.. Calif.. to instruction, Naval War College, Newport, R. I., in June.
Joseph W. Gosling, for sixteen years executive designer of the General Electric Illuminating Laboratory, died today in Ellis Hospital after a brief illness. He was 58 years old.

ADELSON--Julius, at Tampa, Fla., Saturday, April 2, beloved husband of Millie Rosenwasser, devoted father of Irving, Edgar, Samuel, Theresa Walzer and Leila Morris. Services Tuesday, 2:30 P. M., Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1,250 Central Ave., Far Rockaway. Kindly omit flowers.

Mr. and Mrs. W. Romeyn Benjamin of 154 West Eighty-eighth Street have announced that the engagement of their daughter, Miss Yolanda Ricasoli Benjamin, to Crawford E. 'L. Donohugh, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Thomas S. Donohugh of this city and White Plains, N. Y., has been broken by mutual consent.

The word most frequently employed today in connection with the World War and the peace treaties is "irony." There was a time not so long ago when much harsher terms were in use. The peace settlements were quite often "criminal" and at the mildest

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $9,314,399,664 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price per share of all listed stocks on April 1 was $22.32, compared with $28.94 at the beginning of March.

The two-family dwelling at 428 Twenty-sixth Street, Guttenberg, N. J., was purchased by Steven Bozovich, who will occupy one of the apartments. The Town of Union Building and Loan Association was the seller. J. I. Kislak, Inc., brokers, negotiated the sale.

ANDERSON, AMOS (Feb. 18). Estate, $2,500. To Abyssinian Baptist Church, W. 138th St., residue; nine specific bequests. A. Clayton Powell Jr., 132 W. 138th St., executor. FORSYTH, RUTH ELLA (April 1). Estate, more than $10,000. To Kenneth Pomeroy. friend, address not given, $1,000; Ruth Adams. niece, 6 Colon St., Brighton, Mass., $5,000; one specific bequest; James Calder, friend and executor, 252 W. 76th St., residue.

How greatly the balances of political power and government function have shifted in the past year is excellently demonstrated by the week-end concessions of Administration leaders on the Federal Reorganization Bill.
A high official in the Works Progress Administration disclosed today that the WPA had agreed to help. Pennsylvania finance a $53,000,000 fourlane toll road from Harrisburg to Pittsburigh.

Barney Ross of Chicago, world welterweight champion, won on a technical knockout tonight from Henry Schaft of Minneapolis, in 1:12 of the fourth round after flooring his opponent twice, once for a count of nine, before a powerful right ended the match.

Sales of the Brunswick-Balke-Collender Company in the first quarter ran 18 per cent ahead of the 1937 period, R. F. Bensinger, president, said at the annual meeting of stockholders in Chicago yesterday.

With the ho city officially represented by Assistant Corporation Counsel Morris Rosenwasser, twenty-five automobiles transferred seventy-five inmates this afternoon from the old Home of New York Guild for Jewish Blind on St. John's Avenue, Yonkers, to the new institution.

The der regulations Fiat Company, Italy's large automobile company with a capital stock of approximately $20,800,000, has announced it will introduce two new models in the current year, one with a 2,000-horsepower motor, and the other with a motor of 1,100 horsepower, according to a consular report from Rome made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The Maritime Commission invited bids today for the construction of four cargo vessels for American Export Lines, Inc. The ships are to be built under the terms of an operating subsidy contract signed recently by the company with

The State's eighth Constitutional Convention brought to Albany tonight many familiar figures; heroes of many a legislative battle, high ranking members of the State judiciary, members of the present Legislature. Interspersed with them were run-of-the-mine figures, picked because of the favor of some district leader, as well as ranking members of civic organizations selected to represent the civic body in the redrafting of the State's fundamental law.

Police Captain Byron Sackett, one of the few remaining "Roosevelt policemen" left in the department, made application yesterday to be retired on a pension at mid-night April 15, when his annual vacation' will be ended.
Sir Nevile Henderson, the British Ambassador in Berlin, has been instructed to express the British Government's "concern" over the manner in which G. E. R. Gedye was expelled from Austria.
Albert L. Kull, pioneer automobile dealer and racer and former steel and ammunitions manufacturer, died today of a heart ailment at his home here. His age was 74.

Nearly 1,100 persons, thrown out of work when the RemingtonRand, Inc., factory here shut down today, stormed the Town Hall to file notices that they were unemployed and thus eligible for State unemployment compensation.
The East's standard-bearers, led by thirteen New Yorkers, dominated the trials of the three-day National A. A. U. boxing championships tonight at the Boston Garden.

Paul A. Frank, Akron rubber machinery expert, lost an effort to prevent the National Rubber Machinery Company from holding its annual meeting today. A temporary injunction which had been issued to Mr. Frank, who charged the company's working capital was being dissipated, was dismissed shortly before meeting time.

The Federal Trade Commission has issued an order closing its case against National Modes, Inc., National Modes Holding Corporation and John Block, an officer in both companies, all of 130 West Thirtyfirst Street, it was announced to day.

Although traffic accidents and the number of persons injured in them increased last week and over the week-end, compared- with the corresponding periods last year, deaths declined, according to figures made public yesterday by the safety bureau of the Police Department. For the week the table read:

The phenomenal in-again-out-again gold movement of 1937 is attributed in the annual report of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, made public today, to the nervous traveling of "floating money," sometimes called "hot money."
Small beef tonnage continued to feature the cattle trade and fat steers sold 10-15c higher today, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Prime offerings with wheat reached
Favorites scored victories all along the line today in first-round matches of the North and South amateur golf tournament.

Ralph Glen, a B. M. T. trainman, testified yesterday before the New York State Labor Relations Board at its offices at 366 Broadway that the B. M. T. paid him his salary while he put in full time as a union official.

Charles R. Haffenden, coordinator of the Executives Association of New York, has been named New York State Director of the American Federation of Little Business, it was announced yesterday following a conference at the Hotel Astor.

Dr. O. B. Kiel, chairman of the Texas State Board of Medical Examiners and war-time friend of Mayor La Guardia, announced here last night that Mr. La Guardia would address the West Texas Chamber of Commerce April 26 at Wichita Falls.

Miss Barbara Hope Gatins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin K. Gatins of 1,155 Park Avenue, was married to James Freeman Curtis Jr. yesterday afternoon in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's. The Rev. James Gillis, editor of The Catholic World, performed the ceremony.

A statement denying that the Joint Boycott Council of the American Jewish Congress and the Jewish Labor Committee had ever instituted a boycott against Czechoslovak products was issued by the council yesterday.
Percy F. Griffin, former village counsel here, died this morning of a heart attack while receiving an emergency treatment in the Professional Building for a nasal hemorrhage.
The large six-story garage at 207-11 West Seventy-sixth Street, nea. Amsterdam Avenue, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms.
Thomas F. McQuade, assistant engineer with the Board of Transportation for the last eleven years, died yesterday at his home, 24 Fifth Avenue. He had been ill for a month. His age was 61.

The marriage of Miss Theodora Douglas MacGregor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. S. MacGregor of White Plains, N. Y., to Lewis Foster Day, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Day of Greenwich, will take place in the Second Congregational Church, Greenwich, on Saturday afternoon.
ADVERTISING AND SELLING THROUGH BUSINESS PUBLICATIONS, by Mabel Potter Hanford. (Harper, $2.50.) A study of the use of trade papers as aids in merchandising campaigns.
Eight arrests and the introduction of an innovation in strike violence marked the walkout of 15,000 fur workers yesterday.

Fingerprinting of Federal marshals and their deputies over the country has disclosed to the-Department of Justice that five or six of the 250 to 300 officers have criminal or at least dubious records and as a result one of them has been asked to resign. Further investigation of the records of the others is being made.

Thomas Mann, German novelist, was announced today as the recipient of the Cardinal Newman award for 1937 by Dr. John A. O'Brien, director of the Newman Foundation on the University of Illinois campus.

THE distinguished visitors at the Cornell Club yesterday, a husky set of chaps wearing light blue jackets, turned out to be the Cambridge University rugby team that recently kicked the stuffing out of Harvard, Yale and Princeton in Rugby games.
Three steeplechase stakes during the Spring meeting at Aqueduct from June 6 to 29 were announced yesterday by the Queens County Jockey Club.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Evelyn Micou, daughter of Mrs. Morgan T. Micou and the late Dr. Micou, to Henry Bell Laidlaw, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Carter Rutherford Laidlaw of Plainfield, N. J., and a grandson of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Milton Colton of Philadelphia and the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bell Laidlaw of New York.

Naturalization and immigration conference, National Council of Jewish Women, Essex House, 10 A. M. Speakers: Mrs. Sydney B. Erlanger, Marion Schibsby, Mrs. Benjamin Spitzer, Professor Francis James Brown, Cecilia Razovsky.

The existence of the fur dyeing industry, which employs about 350,000 residents of New York City, would be "seriously threatened" by any measurable reduction in existing tariffs on processed furs, Representative Bruce Barton told

An instance of the use of a city detective on active duty to escort strikebreakers to their work was cited yesterday by Magistrate Charles Solomon in Bridge Plaza Court, Brooklyn, as something that should be brought to the personal attention of Mayor La Guardia and high police officials.

Severe measures to cope with espionage, which recent events have demonstrated to be a problem quite as important as the military one, have just been taken by the Spanish Government and will be put into effect immediately.
Bonds continued yesterday their recovery on the New York Stock Exchange under the leadership of secondary railroad issues.

Bringing to a close their annual Winter's fishing contest, members of the Sailfish Club, their wives and guests gathered tonight at the clubhouse for a dinner at which forty trophies were awarded by the president, Elmer Rich. Donors of orizes included Mr. Rich, Mrs.
Governor Martin L. Davey, Democrat, announced tonight his candidacy for a third term. Before a large audience he said: "I do choose to run right here and now.

Executives of the United States oil companies whose properties recently were expropriated by the Mexican Government do not believe that it would be fair to their stockholders to accept in payment for these properties only the amount of their original investment less depreciation.

The text of Chief Judge Crane's address, opening the State Constitutional Convention, was as follows: "As you all know, we have met here as representatives of the people of this State, pursuant to the mandate of the present Constitution, Article XIV, Section 2.

Stricter enforcement of sanitary regulations for storekeepers above West Fifty-ninth Street will be sought by members of the West End Association, according to a committee report submitted at the annual meeting yesterday at the RiversidePlaza Hotel, Seventy-third Street near West End Avenue.
Frank Nordell, cross-country runner who won distinction as an athlete at New York University, died last week in California, according to word received here today. He was 29 years old.

Legislation was recommended by President Roosevelt in a message to Congress today to permit the lending of officers and employes of the government to South American countries for aid in highway construction, public health work,

Lodewick Vroom, president of the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union, an American Federation of Labor affiliate, announced yesterday that he was prepared to resign that position upon official notification that he had been deprived of the emergency powers granted him last Winter as executive director of the union.
Francis Ralston Welsh, an investment broker, died in his home at Devon today. He had belonged to the Union League, Philadelphia Club and Philadelphia Cricket Club.

Tonight's major events: Henry Hadley memorial concert, Carnegie Hall; "Abduction From the Seraglio," Juilliard School. Music by Hanns Eisler and Ruth Crawford will be heard in tonight's session of the Composers' Forum-Laboratory.

A five-run attack in the ninth climaxed Seton Hall's 17-to-11 victory over Brooklyn College yesterday. A crowd of 500 braved the chilling winds to see Brooklyn College open its new athletic field to intercollegiate baseball competition.

Accaused of leaving his elderly parents, his wife and their three children without food for three days when he left home and spent the $30 proceeds of two old-age pension checks which he cashed for his parents, Russell Counterman.
Members of the City Council voted unanimously yesterday to make Good Friday, April 15, a holiday- for all city employes, upon the motion of Councilmen John Cashmore and John P. Nugent.
A scar-faced, 29-year-old ex-convict held attention tonight in the investigation of the torturing and slaying of Mrs. Weston G. Frome and her daughter, Nancy, of Berkeley, Calif.

Resolutions asserting that there is a growing attack under way on legitimate labor organizations "by anti-labor employer interests" and charging that Senator Copeland's resolution for an investigation of the maritime industry was adopted unanimously by the United States Senate "by use of a legislative trick" were made public yesterday by the American Newspaper Guild.

The Japanese Government has found it necessary to strengthen existing measures against profiteering and a conference of provincial officials met today to receive instructions from the Minister of Commerce.
Turpentine firm, 22 1/2c; sales 101 barrels; receipts 416 barrels; shipments 107 barrels; stock 23,781 barrels.

French Mobile Guards have already arrived at the Franco-Catalan border in anticipation of an early Loyalist collapse. To cope with the expected influx of Spanish soldiers and refugees the French guards have been distributed at the principal frontier points from Andorra to the sea.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Schmidt, Poole Co. of Philadelphia obtained yesterday $500,000 of road bonds of the State of West Virginia on their bid of 100.058 for 2 1/2s. The bonds, to be dated May 1,

Insurgent shock troops hammered at the defenses of Tortosa yesterday while other contingents. spread out to blanket the east coast network of roads. Barcelona's power supply was interrupted, presumably because of capture or bombardment of a hydroelectric station. [Page 1.]
MICHAEL BOGDANOFF, jewelry, 140 W. 57th St.-By Jacob Ferber, for $500; Abe Richmond, $250; Hertz Cohen, $250.

Consolidated Chemical Industries, Inc., San Francisco, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 40,000 shares of $1.50 cumulative Class A participating preference stock, no-par value, to be offered through warrants to stockholders at $20 a share.

In the officed States Supreme Court today Max Schoop of New York was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 856-Quick Action Ignition Co., petr., v. Briggs Stratton Corp. Motion to withhold order denying petition for certiorari submitted for the petitioner.

This throbbing collegiate hamlet on the broad plains of Texas packed the A. and M. ball park today with more than 4,000 fans to see its first ball game between two major league clubs, but a young man.

Football star Sammy Baugh and Paul Dean, erstwhile pitching ace, have been released to minor league clubs, the Cardinals' management disclosed today. Baugh, an infielder, goes to. Columbus in the American Association while Dean has been optioned to Houston, another Cardinal farm.
The measure sponsored by Senator Clifford R. Powell, Republican, of Burlington County, appropriating $29,579 to the New Jersey Legislature for expenses, was vetoed by Governor Moore today.

Former Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg is still in Belvedere Palace, his home, despite all rumors to the contrary. This correspondent today saw him walking in the garden accompanied by Countess Fugger, whose marriage to him has often been reported but always denied.
