We are face to face with the loss of liberty, Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, told about 450 persons last night at a dinner in The Towers in Brooklyn commemorating the seventyfifth anniversary of the founding of Adelphi Academy.

The German and Czech Social Democratic parties today requested in the Chamber of Deputies that the government borrow 500,000,000 crowns for the construction of public works in Sudeten German districts.

Several hundred colonists turned out this afternoon for the benefit matinee races at the race track. Six racing events and several features were staged. Mrs. Lawrence B. Smith of Millbrook, N. C., was among those driving harness horses. Mrs. Hoyt E. Hayes of Bay City, Mich., daughter of Mrs.

Austrians exiled here today formed the "Austrian Aid Association." These former subjects of Austria do not wish to become Germans and are applying to the French Government to give them a legal status and permit them to call themselves "Austrians."

Miss Sadie Rutherfoord Harvie Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Hall, was married here tonight to Richard Ollerton Howe of Belmont, Mass., son of Mrs. Reginald Heber Howe, in the Epiphany Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Norvell E. Wicker Jr.

The Fourth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today upheld a lower court's conviction of fourteen seamen of the steamship Algic for "endeavoring to make a revolt" aboard that vessel in the harbor of Montevideo, Uruguay, in September, 1937.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's foreign policy will undergo its first popular test in the shabby streets of West Fulham in western London tomorrow when about 50,000 voters will troop to the polls

Competing for the first time this season, Miss Dorothy Locke, three times women's national foil champion, paced six fencers who qualified last night in the individual preliminaries for the national championship finals on the strips of the Fencers Club.

Edward N. Jackson, 27-year-old Washington Negro, was arrested early today on charges of robbery and speeding after allegedly forcing a New York City schoolgirl's automobile from the road between Four Corners and Wheaton, Md.

Within six hours today the British Government obtained through Berlin withdrawal of an order, as far as it applied to British subjects, which forbade foreigners to leave Austria without police permission and specifically warned that "nonAryan" foreigners would have to wait about three days while their applications were considered.

A friendship of many years ended in tragedy yesterday afternoon when Mrs. Elizabeth McGivney, 65 years old, widow of a former Fire Department officer, fell two stories to her death while performing a deed of kindness for Mrs. Alexander

A new government was formed tonight, pledged to carry on the war to the end and without vacillation. Juan Negrin remains as President of the Council of Ministers and in addition takes on the portfolio of National Defense.

A throng, including ecclesiastical dignitaries from all parts of New England and Eastern Canada, filled the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception here today at funeral services for the Most Rev. Dr. Joseph J. Rice, Catholic Bishop of Burlington.
President Roosevelt is being pressed daily for a decision whether to propose large-scale public spending to arrest the. continuing business recession or hold expenditures to the minimum relief needs:

Charles E. Lane of Glen Ridge, N. J., a member of the building firm of Barr Lane, New York, has been appointed as special consultant to the United States Housing Authority by Nathan Straus, administrator.

Cambridge University's Rugby team, which has been making a tour of the East for a series of games, was officially welcomed to this country at a luncheon tendered the Light Blues at the Cornell Club yesterday.

Mrs. Nathaniel A. Campbell and Miss Ethel Stetson gave a luncheon and bridge yesterday at Sherry's for Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff, Mrs. Horace Barnard, Mrs. Cortlandt Godwin, Miss Sara Lippincott Richards, Mrs. William J. Hutchinson, Mrs. Homer L. Loomis and Mrs. Frederick J. Fuller.
The Japanese Government today asked the United States for a more fully itemized account of the damages of $2,214,007.36 requested for the Panay sinking.
Henry F. Young, who had been employed by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. at their Gibbstown dynamite manufacturing plant for fifty-one years, died here on Saturday after a long illness.

The Whitney Museum of American Art will hold an exhibition of forty-five paintings by Frank Duveneck from April 13 through May 5. The event will be the first large and representative showing of Duveneck's paintings to be held in the East.

Slawson Hobbs has obtained from a client of Samuel Landow a first mortgage of $37,500 at 5 per cent for 5 years on the new taxpayer at the southeast corner of Mamaroneck and Livingston Aves, White Plains.

The 1938 budget for the municipal Deapartment of Public Affairs will total $2,184,777, $80,000 less than the original 1938 budget and $250,365 less than the 1937 budget, Mayor Meyer Ellenstein, director of the department, announced here today at a public hearing in City Hall.

Gene Sarazen tonight fired a bombshell into the ranks of the Professional Golfers Association, striking particularly at President George Jacobus by vowing he never again would compete on the American Ryder Cup team because he never had been honored with the team captaincy.

Pietro D'Angelo, 25 years old, of 1,642 West Eighth Street, Coney Island, appeared in Federal court in Brooklyn yesterday as one of four men who had pleaded guilty to charges of operating an unregistered still seized last Nov. 17 in Farmingdale, L. I.

The Federal Reserve Bulletin for April, made public today, points to the "necessity of paying for the excess of merchandise exports from this country, amounting to $600,000,000 during the six months ending February,"

Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders that he did not anticipate that profits for the first quarter would show any decline from a year ago.

The artificial production of a major form of heart disease, hardening of the arteries, stomach ulcers and other serious disturbances of the digestive organs in animals by overstimulating their nervous system with a drug secreted by the nerves of all animals,

President Roosevelt, at a press conference, said he was opposed to Federal subsidies to railroads or other private capitalistic enterprises, and stated that his message on the railroad situation would not be sent to Congress until next week.

Solly Krieger of Brooklyn, one of the. best of the local middleweights who have been aiming toward a title fight, will meet Izzy Jannazzo of the East Side at the Hippodrome tonight in a twelve-round bout that promises plenty of action.

On Friday of last week the Utility Workers Organizing Committee--a C. I. O. affiliate--took possession of thirteen power plants in Michigan, ousted the foremen and the supervisors, and settled down to hold the property which it had seized until its terms were met. Having forced by these tactics

The provisions of the Bankruptcy Law which permit a railroad to default interest payments without fear of foreclosure were denounced yesterday by Freeman Co., dealers in equipment trust certificates, as ruinous to investors in bonds. The Bankruptcy Law was amended

The annual report of the Engineers Public Service Company for 1937, which is to be sent to shareholders today, reveals that last year total additions to plant throughout the system amounted to $11,728,000, compared with $9,008,000 in 1936.
Discussions of new leases on apartments in Boulevard Gardens, Woodside, Queens, built in 1935 with an FHA loan, have developed a dispute over dogs, cats and other pets except goldfish and canaries

Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Dwight Olmsted of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Hutchison'Olmsted, to Carleton Walker Borden, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Borden of Fall River. Mass., and Mystic, Conn.

The British Empire exhibit at the World's Fair may cost more than $2,000,000 for buildings and display, official representatives declared yesterday after being entertained by Grover Whalen, president of the fair corporation.

Major Irving V. A. Huie, who was appointed by Mayor La Guardia as a deputy commissioner of the new Department of Public Works, was designated yesterday by Major Gen. Edward M. Markham, Commissioner, as chief engineer and acting deputy commissioner at a salary of $10,500.
FRANKENHEIMER, FANNY F. (Nov. 14, 1937).
President Roosevelt today publicly disclosed his opposition to a proposal by railroad management and labor that the Federal Government temporarily subsidize the carriers to keep men at work.
A campaign to raise $263,990 to finance the work of the American Birth Control League was started last night at a dinner of the Citizens Committee for Planned Parenthood in the Plaza Hotel.
Yale's navy cruised back into Winter on the upper Housatonic late this afternoon as Ed Leader, Don Grant and Bob Butler sent their big fleets through the second of a vacation day double workout.

Japanese claims that Taierhchwang in Southern Shantung had been captured were denied by the publicity board of the Military Commission last night in a communique which stressed that a Japanese force southeast of the city faced annihilation.
General Sessions Judge Nott deferred yesterday until April 18 the commitment to Sing Sing of Clark G. Kuney and Edward A. Sauter, former officers of the defunct Commonwealth Bond Corporation.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York is making arrangements to obtain from investment bankers and dealers here additional information concerning new financing by means of a periodic questionnaire.
A rush for pure silk fabrics for use in seasonal production of dresses has brought a moderately sharp advance in silk greige goods, it was reported yesterday.
All who passed the windows of a certain department store yesterday morning must have been impressed by the artistry of the display. Inside the store a great flock of birds were singing in cages.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The readers of THE TIMES rightfully expect news that has been carefully culled to eliminate propaganda. It is common knowledge that many newspapers color the news in accordance with this or that policy. With few exceptions, THE TIMES has disdained such a practice.

The United Hospital Fund's distributing committee will consider today at the fund's headquarters, 370 Lexington Avenue, a proposal by Mrs. F. Meredith Blagden, vice president of the fund and general chairman of women's activities, that a grant of $510,605 be made to the women's committees of the ninety-two voluntary member hospitals of the fund.

Thirty-seven parcels of real estate were sold in the first quarter of 1938 by the sales division of the title and mortgage liquidation bureau of the State Insurance Department, it was announced yesterday.
Hoxie Wilber Smith, prominent in business in the Southern Tier, died at a hospital here today after a month's illness. His age was 70.
According to an announcement made yesterday, Cuba is planning to enter a team in the international tuna angling matches scheduled to be held in Nova Scotia this Summer.

Constitutionality of the RobinsonPatman Act, which prohibits payment of commissions to intermediaries by buyers or sellers, was attacked yesterday in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals when Adrian Busick, counsel for the Biddle Purchasing Company

With the registration today of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, Chicago, the Securities and Exchange Commission announces that holding companies having book assets of about $13,500,000,000, or 98 per cent of the total assets of $38,500,000,000

Favorite players had no anxious moments in the Shoreham Hotel Handicap, $1,200 added feature, before 8,000 spectators today. Now Then, owned by F. J. Buchanan of Washington, was installed the 7-to-20 choice in a field of five for the six-furlong

The United Shipyards, Inc., sold to the Aimee Corporation the property at the southeast corner of Fifty-sixth Street and First Avenue, Brooklyn, measuring 150 by 200 feet, through Frank R. Fischer, broker.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States increased in four out of five trade divisions during the week ended March 31, compared with the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company announced today the award of $1,640,000 of 3 3/4 per cent equipment trust certificates to a syndicate headed by Solomon Brothers Hutzler of New York, who bid 99.0562.

A summary of the Senate Finance Committee's report on its revenue bill and some excerpts from it follow: The House bill proposes a complete revision of the corporate income taxes imposed by existing law, and, in the committee's opinion, represents a vast improvement over that law.
Rene Fraus, author and former member of the Press Department of the Schuschnigg government, who declared himself to be a monarchist and Roman Catholic, arrived last night on the French liner Paris.

The Boston Bruins, winners of the Prince of Wales Cup as the American champions in the National Hockey League, tonight received the cabled personal congratulations of the Duke of Windsor, now at Versailles, France. Windsor put up the trophy when he was Prince of Wales.

The Rev. Theopolus Price, former Baptist minister and head of the Tuckerton Railroad Company, is dead here at the age of 82. After graduation from Haverford College, he taught at Peddie Institute, Hightstown, for a year and then entered the grain business here.

W. M. Jeffers of Omaha, president of the Union Pacific Railway, proposed W. A. Harriman, New York railroad executive, to the Federal Department of Commerce Business Advisory Council today as a 1940 Presidential candidate. Mr.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,367,250 barrels, compared with 3,405,600 in the previous week, a decline of 38,350, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Keen competition marked the opening round of the annual tournament for the individual championship of the H. Y. P. D. College Chess League at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday, when four games were decided. Harvard, Yale and Princeton each had two players and Dartmouth one in the competition.

The political atmosphere in Texas was cleared considerably today so far as State affairs are concerned, by an official announcement by former Governor James E. Ferguson and his wife, former Governor Miriam A. Ferguson, that neither would ever again be a candidate for public office.

Clear thinking, simplification of government activities and the discouraging of small pressure groups seeking "largesse" were urged yesterday to combat the "trend toward collectivism" as reflected in government by Ward Melville, president of the Melville Shoe Corporation and chairman of the board of the Institute of Distribution.

Lieutenant Thomas Meehan of Engine Co. 9 died April 3 in the discharge of duty from injuries sustained while operating at Station 218, at 5:05 P. M., fire in premises 238-40 Cherry St., Manhattan. Funeral will take place from funeral parlors of Peter Hughes, 45-05 Forty-eighth Ave., Woodside, Queens,

Mrs. Eleanor Patterson, publisher of The Washington Herald, told President Roosevelt, in an open letter which will appear in tomorrow's edition of The Herald, that it is the fear of him and his policies which is depressing industry, and that by eliminating this fear he could put business "back on its feet."
When President Roosevelt greeted the 150 newspaper correspondents at his White House press conference today a beautifully engraved but very treacherous-looking knife lay on his desk.
J. Fred Stephenson, former president of the People's National Bank of Lakewood, died this morning at the Paul Kimball Hospital. He was 74 years old.

After a dull opening, the stock market here rallied today and most sections closed higher. Gilt-edge issues were in demand, while among the foreign bonds. German issues made further gains. Transatlantic stocks had a fair turnover and their prices were slightly better.

Asserting that a particularly acute form of labor movement exists in Mexico, Francis H. Brownell, chairman of the Amercian Smelting and Refining Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting in Jersey City yesterday that the labor organizations in Mexico have sought regulation which virtually assumes control of personnel and plant operations.
The Consolidated Mining and Smelting Company of Canada, Ltd., reported today the first quarter of 1937 a production of 51,422 tons of lead, against 55,904 a year ago, a decrease of 7.3 per cent.

Dr. and Mrs. Fielding Lewis Taylor, who passed the Winter and early Spring at Winter Park, Fla., have returned to their home at 950 Fifth Avenue. Mrs. Roger G. Alexander, - wife of Lieut. Col. Alexander, U. S. A., has come from West Point to .the Waldorf-Astoria.
Commercial renting activity reported yesterday by brokers consisted largely of leases for full floors and stores. A number were for units in buildings downtown.

Accusing the Communist party press of "Red baiting" in its attacks upon Trotskyists, the New York Socialist party made known yesterday that it would seek to arrange an independent May Day demonstration this year.

A further decline in prices of cotton in India threw contracts on the market 'here yesterday and prices declined 10 points or more before resistance developed on the Cotton Exchange and brought a partial recovery.
Conrad Veidt, German film actor, and Paul Czinner, Austrian film director and husband of Elisabeth Bergner, have applied for British citizenship, the Home Office announced tonight.

Ten students of architecture from various parts of the country were selected yesterday as finalists and second medal winners in the thirtyfirst Paris Prize architectural competition, conducted by the Society of Beaux Arts Architects.

The will of Colonel E. M. House, filed for probate here and giving a probable estate value of $25,000, directs that the net income be paid to his widow, Mrs. Lulie Hunter House, after deduction of specific bequests.

After 148 years of isolation from the world, the 200 residents of Pitcairn Island, home of the mutineers of the Bounty, will be linked with this country tonight from 8 to 8:10 o'clock in a radio broadcast over a hookup of the National Broadcasting Company.

The executive committee of the National Association of Bank Supervisors went on record at its quarterly meeting today in favor of loans to small businesses and industries when the loans are "in line with good banking, as well as being in step with the national policy."
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hof of Forest Hills of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathryn Hof, to Robert Anderson Watson Jr., son of the Rev. and Mrs. Watson of Jamaica.
Through an error a portion of a Moscow dispatch from Harold Denny, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES March 14, was incorrect.
Miss Mabel E. Simpson, former director of elementary grades in the Rochester public schools and a past president of the New York Teachers Association, died in a hospital here today.

A teacher, principal or some other member of the school system should sit with the judges in the Children's Courtss and act as adviser in juvenile delinquency cases, Theodore Fred Kuper, law secretary of the Board of Education, recommended yesterday.

Gerson to Helena Gershowitz, 3,231 Rochambeau Ave.
Caroline Maddocks Beard, who for more than twenty years conducted a cookery department in The Chicago Tribune under the pen name of Jane Eddington, died here today at the age of 73 years.
Mrs. Oscar Homolka, formerly Baroness Vally Hatvany, Hungarian actress, died of blood poisoning today. She was 24 years old.
Differences of opinion over the threat of foreign war almost brought war to the Senate today as Democrats assailed the action of an appropriations subcommittee,

A staff of nine design experts from the art teaching division of the WPA Federal Art Project moved into one of the stores at the Williamsburg Housing Development in Brooklyn yesterday, prepared to make available tO the development's 1,622 tenant families up-to-date instruction In interior design.

Despite the talk of nonpartisanship that has come from the leading figures in the Constitutional Convention to date, the intention of the Republican majority to have firm control of the important committees was clearly shown today when the personnel of the first four committees became known.

With plenty of time on their hands these days for tasks other than transacting stock-brokerage business, members and firm partners of the New York Stock Exchange are debating hotly the roster of the new board of governors and chairman, since the selections of the nominating committee are scheduled to be posted on Monday.

WHY did we go to war with Germany twentyone years ago today? On account of submarines? Or our economic stake in an allied victory? Or because of munition makers, Wall Street bankers, shippers, Woodrow Wilson?
After almost seven years of uneasy freedom, Dewey Terry, fugitive from a North Carolina chain gang, is ready to go back. Arrested in his home

The board of directors of Spiegel, Inc., took no action yesterday on the common dividend that normally would be payable on May 1. On Feb. 1 a quarterly dividend of 25 cents on the common was disbursed.
Theodor Cardinal Innitzer, Archibishop of Vienna, arrived in Rome this evening, having been summoned by Pope Pius to explain his dealings with the new Nazi masters of Austria.
Princeton triumphed over the Bermuda Athletic Association fifteen by 6--0 today in the second game of the island's annual Rugby Week.

Two veteran city employes will retire soon from the Department of Public Works after an aggregate of more than eighty years of service. Both are native New Yorkers, both saw the Brooklyn Bridge built and both declare its has played an important part in their lives.
Sponsors of the Reorganization Bill planned tonight to force the issue in the House tomorrow by moving to close debate and proceed to consideration of amendments.

The report of 141 Class I railways to the Interstate Commerce Commission showed that in January they had an aggregate net loss of $33,475,907 after all charges, against a net loss of $4,502,006 in January, 1937.

John R. Huhn, secretary of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today of an active campaign by that Exchange to keep trading originating in this vicinity from going to the markets in New York.

The international convention of the American Federation of Labor Railway Employes Department today called for a program of rehiring unemployed railroad workers and stabilizing employment throughout the industry.

Lyman T. Austin, veteran of - the Union Army and a native of the Bronx, N. Y., who as a youth of 25 assisted in the search for John Wilkes Booth, slayer of Abraham Lincoln, died this afternoon at his home here. He was 98.

The possibility that independent candidates would be posted for governors and chairman of the board of the New York Stock Exchange after the slate of the nominating committee is made public on Monday morning was a step nearer

Secrecy was imposed again yesterday on the government's investigation of the Rubens-Robinson false passport case as a widespread search was started for five persons whose names were used by members of the ring indicted as John Does on Monday.

The Internal Revenue Bureau decided today that Maine liquor taxes were deductible by consumers figuring their Federal income taxes. The bureau approved the deduction both for the flat 10 per cent liquor sales

Lt. Col. Douglas C. Cordiner, Quartermaster Corps, will proceed on or about April 12, from Governors Island, N. Y., to Wilmington, Del., for temporary duty In connection with Organized Reserves activities, and upon completion of this temporary duty he will return to his proper station, Governors Island, N. Y.
The Central do Brasil Railway recently ordered five Diesel trains from the Fiat Company of Italy, according to a consular report from Rio de Janiero made public today by the Department of Commerce.
The Ford Motor Company asked the Sixth United States Circuit Court of Appeals today to set aside an order of the National Labor Relations Board requiring its compliance with the Wagner Labor Act.
Three men were killed and another was critically injured early this morning when an Erie Railroad gasoline engine hit their automobile at Oak Tree crossing here. The engine carried the car 810 feet.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence L. Lee of 1,112 Park Avenue and Stratford, Conn., to James Norvell Banks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Banks of Vandalia, Mo., formerly of St. Louis, took place last night in the Cottage Suite of Hampshire House. The Rev. Dr. Wendell Phillips performed the ceremony.

A triumvirate will guide the destinies of the United States Steel Corporation for the second time in its history, as a result of action taken at the regular meeting of the directors yesterday, following the resignation of Myron C. Taylor as chairman and chief executive.

Dr. Charles W. Ballard, dean of the College of Pharmacy at Columbia University, lost his legal fight for a pension from the city when Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin held yesterday that his failure to comply with the local residence law and his refusal to perform chemical analyses for the Health Department in the latter's laboratories amounted to a "fault or delinquency."
American Newspaper Guild pickets marched around The Duluth NewsTribune and Herald plant for the second day in their strike for a Guild shop. Officials of the papers

The prospect of another harbor tie-up loomed late today with all waterfront workers out demanding the discharge of Francis Crocco, assistant port captain of the New York-Puerto Rico Line and the reinstatement of a single workman, G. Prado, a dock electrician employed by the line.

The American Surety Company and its affiliate, New York Casualty Company, are launching 420-line copy in forty-four newspapers in large cities from coast to coast to introduce to employers their new "Discovery Bond," which affords insurance protection against past acts of employee dishonesty not yet discovered.

WATER TENDER, U. S. Engineer Department at Large, $1,320 a year, leas $420 a year for quarters and subsistence. Applications must be on file with the secretary, Board U. S. Civil Service Examiners, Engineer Department at Large, 39 Whitehall St., New York, N. Y., not later than April 15.
The Nicaraguan Congress has approved a contract made between the government and the American Road Building Company and its American engineer associates to construct highways throughout the republic.
It is repressions that make us civilized, Dr. Holan D. C. Lewis told more than 400 nurses yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania,

The first local performances of Malipiero's Second symphony, Delius's "Appalachia" and Ireland's "London Overture" are among the items of unusual interest to be offered in the programs of the last four weeks of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra season under the direction of John Barbirolli.

The Federal Government in the first quarter of the current year awarded $400,489,861 of contracts containing agreements to comply with the provisions of the Walsh-Healy Public Contracts Act, Secretary Perkins announced today.

President Roosevelt today proclaimed May 1 as Child Health Day. In doing so he called on the people of the country to consider whether the children in their families and in each community are receiving the full benefit of our knowledge of how. to promote the health of mothers and babies at the time of birth and of children throughout the period of growth and development,"

Cash registers of local merchants were flooded here this afternoon as students of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute started to pay off 25 per cent of their purchases in pennies in protest of "hidden" taxes.

The gallant Chicago Black Hawks, without a regular goalkeeper, fought from behind to defeat Toronto's National Hockey League champions, 3 to 1, in the first game of the three-outof-five final series for the Stanley Cup and the world professional title at Mape Leaf Gardens tonight.

Thirty-six brush fires burned yesterday on Long Island and in New Jersey as New Jersey officials took drastic steps to reduce the number of fires by giving orders-for the summary arrest of all violators of the forest fire law in the State.
Mrs. Lidie Hibberd Evans of 146 Walnut Street, Montclair, died yesterday of a heart ailment in a private sanitarium at Essex Fells after a short Illness.

Ellis H. Parker and his son, Ellis Jr., lost their fight today to keep from being arraigned before Federal Judge William Clark at Newark in connection with a Brobklyn indictment linking them with the alleged kidnapping of Paul H. Wendell.

Brook Ave, 1,464; 4-story tenement, 25x 100.7; Theresa Sidenberg against Joseph Lucks; dud $13,030; taxes, etc, $2,045; to plaintiff for $10,000. By RALPH W. LONG Lawton Ave, 2,887; 25x102.1; Marine Midland Trust Co of New York against Lester Wallace Hale; due $7,407; taxes, etc, $115; to plaintiff for $4,400.

For proficient work on the new apartment house nearing completion at 25 East Eighty-third Street sixteen mechanics received yesterday certificates of superior craftsmanship and gold buttons from the New York Building Congress.

Mike Belloise, 128, and Al Reid, 127 3/4, battled to a draw in the feature eight-round bout before 12,000 persons at the New York Coliseum last night. It was the second draw between the neighborhood rivals from the Bronx.

Ernst Toller, exiled German playwright who was-barred from speaking at Queens College next Friday for what he declared "racial and political reasons," will deliver his original address on "Social Drama"
The North Carolina tennis team scored its second straight victory today, defeating Yale, 8 to 3. In the feature match Carl Rood of Carolina beat How Stephens, 9-11, 6-3, 7-5.
Frederick Melville, sole lessee of the Lyceum Theatre, Great Britain's home of melodrama, died of a heart attack today at the age of 63.

The death of Harry G. Smith of Los Angeles of typhus fever was reported today from Chungking by Reuters News Agency. He was a pilot on a commercial airline between Chungking and Hankow, temporary seats of the Chinese Government. He formerly was the personal pilot of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

The wide range in the cost of building a small home in various parts of the country and the sharp variations in the recent changes in the cost of such a house are emphasized in figures recently compiled by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

LIEUTENANT James B. Leggett, from 104th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. Office, Queens, for 5 days, from 8 A. M., April 1. SERGEANTS-Francis Miele, from 32d Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, Bronx, for 1 day, from 4 P. M., April 4.

An Anglo-Saxon manuscript, parts of which probably were more than a century old when William the Conqueror invaded England, was sold for $38,000 last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc.
Peter J. Kasper, a former wholesale grocer here, died yesterday in Ravenswood Hospital. He was 84 years old. Mr. Kasper was born on a farm near St. Johns, Ind., and came to Chicago at the age of 14.
Michael J. (Mike) Donovan, veteran welterweight of nearly 150 fights with the great and neargreat boxers of three decades ago, died here tonight after an illness of four weeks. He was 56 years old.

Warning of the possibility that the trend of processors going direct to finished fabric users, eliminating converters, will spread un- mo less definite steps are taken to prevent such an eventuality, Edmund cent Wright, executive director of the Textile Converters Association of America, Inc., yesterday issued a notice to all converters of intention to call a meeting to discuss possible action.

A Federal railroad equipment corporation, empowered to issue its own debentures and build rolling stock and locomotives to be rented to the railroads as needed is proposed in a confidential memorandum
The Southern Pacific Company filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission a modification of its application for a $14,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
A new merchandising plan designed to provide sales and service facilities for the farm tractor comparable to those available for passenger cars was announced today by Graham-Paige Motors Corporation.

Representatives of the paper industry opposed today further tariff concessions to Canada, contending that any reduction in duties would benefit other competing countries more than the British Dominion.

A delegation of four pro-Loyalist Spaniards was enthusiastically greeted last night by 600 persons at a dinner of the Aldine Club which was organized by the Medical Bureau and North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy.

The New York Curb Exchange has received notice that holders of common stock of the Harvard Brewing Company of record yesterday are to be offered rights to subscribe at $100 each to one share of 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock, par value $100, for each 550 shares of common stock held.

The military situation along the east coast has not changed in any vital respect today. It is clear that Tortosa is the Insurgents' next objective, but when this correspondent visited the front today it was to find the Insurgents, although infiltrating and spreading out steadily, were still well back from the coast.

Four structural steel workers were injured at 10:10 A. M. yesterday when the fifty-foot boom of a derrick lost its mooring and one end of it toppled onto the fourteenth floor of a building under construction at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street.

The following dispatch is from a staff correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES who has just completed a motor trip through Italian Tyrol, over the Brenner Pass and into Austria. This is the second of three articles.
The Senate confirmed the nomination of Ebert K. Burlew of Pennsylvania today to be first assistant secretary of the interior. Mr. Burlew is now administrative assistant to Secretary Ickes.
Funeral services for Ryerson H. Smith, formerly in the lumber business in New York and a brother of former Supreme Court Justice George Smith, who died here Saturday, were held today in his home.
Columbia University has established a Melvil Dewey Professorship of Library Service with an endowment of $150,000 by the Carnegie Corporation of New York

President Roosevelt and President Manuel L. Quezon of the Commonwealth Government of the Philippines have reached an understanding to have the preferential trade relationship between the two countries terminated gradually over a period of years ending in 1960,
Emanuel, Stanley E. and LeRoy W. Glauber, realty operators, have moved to larger quarters in 565 Fifth Avenue.

The government's coal bill, which provides for the nationalization of all coal mine royalties in Great Britain and the compulsory merger of collieries, passed its third reading in the House of Commons tonight without a division and was sent to the House of Lords.

Retail deliveries of Buick cars March totaled 15,359, an increase of 64 per cent over February delivseries of 9,344, but a decrease of 26 per cent, compared to 20,966 cars delivered in March, 1937, according to William Hufstader, general sales manager.
The opening day ticket sale for the Dodgers-Giants game at Ebbets Field on April 22 has gone beyond expectations, the Brooklyn club has announced through Executive Vice President L. S. MacPhail.

A gold medal officially awarded twenty-seven years ago and held all this time for the recipient to call at Havana was displayed yesterday by Dr. George B. Winter of St. Louis, former president of the American Dental- Association.

Lawrence Taylor, 34 years old, of Laurel, L. I., pleaded guilty today to a charge of first-degree robbery and was immediately sentenced to ten to twenty years in Sing Sing by County Judge L. Barron Hill.

A decision by the Chamber of Deputies on Premier Leon Blum's far-reaching proposals for solving the financial situation was postponed today until tomorrow in an atmosphere of conflict and strained nerves.

One top-flight Kentucky Derby candidate was reliably reported today to be out of the race and three other eligibiles arrived at Churchill Downs to begin training on the track where the classic will be run May 7.
Another apartment house will rise in the Chelsea section of Manhattan as the result of the sale of the two buildings at 313 and 315 West Twenty-first Street by Mary C. Ruddy to Irving 0. Freedman.

The regular slate of candidates for the council of the Actors Equity Association was announced yesterday afternoon after Burgess Meredith, acting president, presiding at his last meeting of the council, pleaded for an end to the intraEquity strife.

With Easter trade now beginning to hit its stride, the last few days have seen a sharp improvement in the volume of wholesale reorders placed for women's apparel and some accessories, particularly millinery, reports here yesterday indicated.

Miss Mildred Ann Braun, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Braun of this city, was married yesterday afternoon at the Carlyle to Kenneth S. Hogg Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hogg of Scarsdale, N. Y., by the Rev. Charles Carroll Albertson.

The joint Congressional committee which will investigate the Tennessee Valley Authority was named today by the two presiding officers, but the refusal of two Republican Senators to serve created confusion.
Herman Whitman, manager of the Earle Theatre in this city for the last three years, died in his apartment at the Hotel Sylvania last night. His age was 37.

The President is entirely right in rejecting the joint proposal of the railway unions and managers for a Government subsidy to the railroads. A subsidy, outright or disguised, would be the wrong way out of a bad situation.
The 269th annual report of the Hudson's Bay Company, made public today, announced a 4 per cent dividend on ordinary shares, the first since July, 1930.

" You must give the cattle a chance to put on fat," said one of the President's visitors to him yesterday. The advice was in answer to the question Mr. Roosevelt is frequently asking these days: "What can I do to revive business?"

Charles S. Howard, owner of Seabiscuit, the handicap champion last year, yesterday agreed to send his 5-year-old champion against Samuel D. Riddle's War Admiral in a match race for a purse of $100,000 at a mile and a quarter some time during the Autumn meeting at Belmont Park Sept. 15 to Oct. 1.
Mrs. Alice Updegrove Leslie, clubwoman and charity worker, died today at her home here after a long Illness. Her age was 68. She was the widow

At the close of an all-day argument Judge Cornelius F. Collins in General Sessions denied defense motions for dismissal of the conspiracy and grand larceny indictment on which two women and ten men have been on trial for nine weeks in the alleged $2,000,000 Slovak Manor land fraud racket.

Governor man signed today a State antilynching bill, sponsored by Assemblyman Kreinheder, Buffalo Republican. The bill defines as a mob an assemblage of three or more persons which attempts to exercise any power of correction or punishment.

Sir Peter Britton, bay horse owned and driven by Mrs. Laurence B. Smith of Millbrook, N. Y., won two straight heats today and took top laurels in the mixed gait amateur race. Sir Peter is by Peter Volo,

General liquidation developed in the grain markets early today and all deliveries of wheat, oats and rye dedined to new low levels since the middle of 1936, while July and October soy beans sold at new lows for the season.

Eighty persons were killed and more than 200 were injured Monday in a train collision on the Peiping-Hankow Railway at Yencheng, about eightyfive miles south of Chengehow, according to information brought to Hankow today by foreign travelers from Chengchow.

Operations last year of the Ingersoll-Rand Company and its subsidiaries resulted in a net income of $9,726,411 after deductions for depreciation, loss on foreign exchange, Federal income and excess profits taxes and surtax on undistributed profits, the concern reported yesterday.
Two runs in the seventh inning enabled Newark to turn back its International League rival Montreal, 7 to 6, today. The winners entered the seventh trailing, 6 to 5.
Additional local banking institutions yesterday issued statements of their condition as of March 31, in response to the call for reports announced by William R. White, State Superintendent of Banks.

Thirty-five members of the Yonkers Icor, a group sympathetic to Jewish refugees, made public today a protest adopted last night against the leasing of the County Center here to the United German-American Societies of Westchester County and Connecticut.

Judge Frederick E. Crane went to the heart of the matter when he opened the State Constitutional Convention yesterday with the declaration that we must "prove to the world" that democracy is "the best system devised for the ruling of all the people."

The French franc fell again in the foreign exchange market yesterday, following its sharp rally on Monday. The widespread opinion that the Cabinet of Premier Leon Blum would fall and be replaced quickly by a national government, which had been a factor in strengthening the franc on the previous day, gave way yesterday to uncertainty about the outcome of the sweeping financial proposals which M. Blum had introduced.

A "sound-power" telephone, which requires neither batteries nor other regular power, but "runs" through electricity generated by the voice waves of the speaker, has been perfected by technicians of the Bell Telephone Laboratorles, it was learned yesterday.

A dozen owners of Week-enders, 35-foot over-all auxiliaries which will make their appearance in Long Island Sound racing this season, held an organization meeting at the Hotel Commodore yesterday and elected a class committee made up of Warren Brewster, chairman; Donald Abbott and Drake H. Sparkman.

Voters of 116 municipalities located in twenty-seven States approved during March municipal bond issues aggregating $12,132,590, as compared with $4,000,600 bonds approved in February, according to The Daily Bond Buyer.

Exports are particularly helpful now because they are making up, in part, for the declines in domestic business. Bradford A. Warner, representative of the New York Foreign Trade Week Committee, said last night at a dinner of the Keystone Club in the Central Y. M. C; A., Brooklyn.
August Derleth, who recently received a Guggenheim fellowship for 1938, is the author of a novel, "Wind Over Wisconsin," which Scribner will publish on April 22.
A seafaring track fan, who sailed away nine years ago before he had a chance to cash his winning $5 mutuel ticket at Pimlico, returned today and got his money-$14.70-without interest.

Mrs. Anne Taylor Thomas, widow of Ben F. Thomas, a leading business man of this city, died this afternoon in her home here. The daughter of George and Jane Tibbatts Jones, she was born in Cincinnati and was married to Mr. Thomas in 1894. For nearly a halfcentury she was prominent in social and civic undertakings.

Richard Count du Moulin-Eckart, historian and publicist, died today at the age of 74. He was a godson of Richard Wagner. Count du Moulin-Eckart was a lecturer in history at the University of Heidelberg before he was appointed full Professor of History at the Technical High School in Munich in 1900.

The Illinois Industrial Commission decided today that Mrs. Catherine Wolf Donohue of Ottawa, Ill., was entitled to compensation for a poisoning she claimed to have contracted while employed by the Radium Dial Company in that city.

The 1938 Constitutional Convention opened today on a note of firm belief in and adherence to the democratic form of government which has prevailed in this country since the adoption of the Constitution of the United States in 1787. This note was sounded by Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane...

The tenth meeting between the Earl of Perth, British Ambassador, and Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, since the official beginning of the Anglo-Italian negotiations March 8 took place this evening.

Andrew J. Haire, president of the Haire Publishing Company, was last night elected president of the Rotary Club, succeeding Charles S. Morris, president of the Metropolitan Fireproof Warehouse, who continues as a director. William E.

Mrs. Marion L. Gorton, in 277 Park Ave; Henry Kohlman, through Duff Conger, in 308 E 79th St; Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc. Brokers. C. E. C. Freyvogel, in 14 E 75th St; William H. Meyer, broker. Frederick Lonsdale, in Hotel Savoy-Plaza, 5th Ave and 58th St.
The Detroit Gold Hats won the Western senior indoor polo championship tonight with a three-goal last chukker rally that beat the Chicago Ramblers, 7 to 6.

Albert Melville Troyer, 71, a graduate of the University of Nebraska and an expert on citrus fruits, is in a Russian prison camp on a charge of being concerned in a counter-revolutionary plot and his wife, Mrs. Elva Dempster Troyer,

Inflated debt structure, interest rates as high as 7 per cent on Interborough Rapid Transit securities, and "the most burdensome debt retirement scheme in financial history" were responsible for the financial plight of the I. R. T.Manhattan subway-elevated system, William G. Mulligan Jr., Assistant Corporation Counsel, said yesterday at a Federal court I. R. T. receivership hearing.

At the annual meeting of shareholders of the Radio Corporation of America, held yesterday in one of the studios of the National Broadcasting Company at Radio City, David Sarnoff, president, disclosed that R. C. A.

George C. Priestley, veteran oil operator and refinery official, national finance chairman of the Bull Moose campaign of Theodore Roosevelt in 1912, died suddenly in his apartment here today. He was 78.

The Providence Reds tonight advanced to the final of the International-American Hockey League championship play by defeating the Philadelphia Ramblers, 3 to 2, in the third game of their final series in the Eastern Division.
Spectacular playing by Gil Zimmerman, substitute outside home, enabled Pennsylvania to defeat the Harvard lacrosse team on River Field today, 6-3. It was the opening collegiate contest for each team.

Captain Leopold McLaglen, brother of the screen actor Victor McLaglen, was banished from the United States today for five years for attempting to extort $20,000 from Philip M. Chancellor of Hollywood.

Pitcher Pete Murphy carried the Princeton baseball team through eight innings of three-hit ball against Vermont on University Field today, but faltered in the ninth when a five-hit uprising, combined with Tiger errors, gave the visitors the game, 5-2. It was the first defeat in four starts for the Tigers.
An American edition of ex-Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's book, "Dreimal Oesterreich," is being rushed into type by Alfred A. Knopf. The English text of the

The general death rate in this city for the first thirteen weeks of 1938 was 10.9 per 1,000 population, the lowest rate for any first quarter of a year in the city's records, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

When delegates to the Constituional Convention representing Senatorial districts in New York City arrived today they found awaiting them personal letters from Mayor La Guardia inviting their cooperation in obtaining amendments to promote the interests of the city.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William H. Marsh of South Orange of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Patricia Marsh, to George F. McInnes, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John A. McInnes of Cambridge, Mass.
Smashing all American Bowling Congress records, the Birk Brothers Brewing Company of Chicago took first place tonight with a score of 3,234.
Dr. Frank Raymond Sandt, pathologist at the Paterson General Hospital since 1902, died this morning at his home after a heart attack. He was 61.

Raynold J. Whitney, Village Manager here since 1931, was discharged last night by the Village Board of Trustees by a vote of 3 to 2. He was accused of being un-cooperative and of establishing a "dictatorship," but the Village Manager League stood firmly behind him and said today that during his tenure the tax rate was lowered 20 per cent.

Proposals for two radical changes in the operating machinery of the Chicago Stock Exchange designed to increase the volume of trading were submitted to members today in a letter from Thaddeus R. Benson, president of the Exchange. He asked members the Exchange.

Harry F. Wolf, national amateur titleholder from the Montclair A. C., and Rowland Dufton, head professional at the New York A.-C., gained the two remaining brackets in the semi-final round of the world's open squash tennis championship at the Shelton Club last night.

Even with the expansion provided for in the bill now pending before Congress, the United States Navy "is not sufficiently strong to insure our being successful against foreign attack, but it is believed to be sufficient to provide reasonable assurance," Admiral William D. Leahy,

The Senate Finance Committee's Revenue Bill of 1938 was introduced today by Senator Harrison, chairman, who also made public a fifty-two-page report describing it. He obtained unanimous consent to open debate tomorrow afternoon on the measure as "unfinished business."
The East's standard-bearers in the National A. A. U. boxing championships got off to a flying start in the quarterfinals tonight at the Boston Garden.

This may be a city of lakes to the Tigers and the tourists but it's only a "slough of despond" to Grimes and the Dodgers. Today the grim lord of Burleigh tossed the veteran knuckle ball artist, Freddy Fitzsimmons,

Louis Gorelick, 35 years old, a salesman, of 78-04 Sixty-seventh Drive, Middle Village, Queens, brought suit yesterday in Supreme Court, Queens, against Joseph Rose, relief recipient who charged last day year that Gorelick had stolen from him diamonds valued at $200,000.
Yesterday's uproar in the French Chamber of Deputies over Premier Blum's demand for drastic powers to meet the country's fiscal crisis by Ministerial decrees ended in suspension of the session.

John Henry Thomas, who was decorated in his youth by Queen Victoria for his operatic ability and who later became vice president of three American companies, died of pneumonia yesterday at his home here after a brief illness. His age was 69.

Twenty-nine men, including three policemen and an inspector of the Alcohol Tax Unit, all convicted members of a bootleg syndicate that made and sold diluted and colored alcohol for five cents a drink under the name of King Kong whisky, received prison sentences ranging from six months to two years each when they appeared yesterday before Federal Judge John C. Knox.

Mae West can remain Mae West in Massachusetts, and the bright lights of theatre marquees can continue to blink "phony" names, for the House today dumped into the legislative ash can a bill aimed at the practice of-giving entertainers "glamorous names."

Mexico has "gone Communist" and is attempting to destroy religion, James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, declared last night at the seventieth annual dinner of the Associates of the Engineers Corps and Company K of the old Seventh Regiment, New York National Guard, at the Yale Club.
Rachelle Shubow gave a recital last night at Town Hall in which she played a program of "dance music for the pianoforte from the sixteenth to twentieth centuries."
Spanish civilian refugees who have received a haven in France are being distribute in different cities of France, which formerly harbored refugees from San Sebastian and Bilbao.

The two-story business building at 67-05-9 Fresh Pond Road, Ridgewood, Queens, has been sold by the Oswego County Savings Bank to the 67-05 Fresh Pond Corporation for cash above a mortgage of $24,000. The transfer involved the sale by the Malvia Realty Corporation of a contract which it held to purchase the structure.
In Connecticut, Illinois, Michigan, Wisconsin and New Hampshire engaged couples must pass a syphilis test before they receive a license to marry. In six other States the man alone

Adjourned games occupied players in the United States championship tournament of the National Chess Federation last night, when the scene shifted temporarily from the R. C. A. Building Assembly Hall to the rooms of the Marshall Chess Club, 23 West Tenth Street.

Reporting to the public and to shareholders at the same time, William S. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasfing System, Inc., in his 1937 annual report delivered last night over the entire Columbia

The new city taxes voted yesterday to go into effect next Monday follow: CIGARETTE TAX--The first move toward putting the new relief tax program into effect will be taken today when Purchase Commissioner Russell Forbes orders 100,000,000 one-cent -revenue stamps and 1,000,000 three-cent revenue stamps, to be affixed to packages and cartons of cigarettes. Each stamp carries the lettering "N. Y. C." and the word "Relief,"
Bringing to a close their American invasion, the Cambridge University squash racquets players scored a 4-2 triumph over the Union Club on the latter's courts yesterday.
When the Insurgents occupied Lerida our correspondent spoke with half a dozen Franco supporters who for many months had lain hidden in cellars.
" General Markham Night" will be celebrated by veterans of the Seventy-eighth Division at their reunion to be held at the Top Hat in Union City, N. J., on Saturday evening, April 30.

The first-degree murder count in the indictment on which Mounted Patrolman Arthur H. Chalmers is being tried in General Sessions for the shooting of Miss Irma L. Pradier in his automobile on the Harlem Speedway was eliminated yesterday on the motion of Assistant District Attorney Jacob Grumet.

In a continuance of its program for stimulating self-regulation of advertising by business groups, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today made public a report of its domestic distribution committee recommending methods for maintaining advertising standards by industry.

The increased enthusiasm for athletes in Latin America, where they were unknown a quarter of a century ago, was shown today by the declaration of a national holiday in honor of the Ecuadorian swimmers, who won the championship of South America at Lima recently.

Certificates of election were refused today by the New Jersey Supreme Court to August Ziegener and Jennie C. Smith, candidates for the Republican State Committee in Hudson County last September, on the ground the Hudson Circuit Court had declared the election null and void. Mr. Ziegener and Mrs.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday an increase of 36,000 telephones in service in the principal telephone subsidiaries of the Bell System in March, compared with a gain of 104,900 instruments in March, 1937.
