Kemball. cotton dresses, aprons, uniforms; Miss E. Ingalls, women's, misses' dresses; Miss C. Adams sportswear;

In a "solemn appeal to the conscience of Britain and France," who were the authors of the non-intervention agreement, the Barcelona Government today begged for permission to buy arms and war material with which to resist the Insurgent offensive.

The Warners will satisfy an ambition long harbored by James Cagney to star in a historical Western. E. E. Paramore Jr. has been engaged by the studio to fashion a screen play around a good bad-man character of the Eighteen Seventies.

Manhattan Thompson St, 160, and West Houston St, 89-105; 131.8x43.2; for 1-story market; Department of Markets, City of New York, owner; J. W. Linton, engineer; cost, $45,000. Alterations Alterations 14th St, 514 E; to two 5-story tenements and stores; Salvator Sottile, 225 Lafayette St, owner; Philip Bardes, architect; cost, $10,000.

James Rennie and Glenda Farrell will have the two leading roles of "Lady at Large," the Philip Goodman play which Milton Shubert will be showing to the folks in New Haven on April 28, and to the folks of Broadway early next month. A romantic farce, with action in Switzerland, it will begin practicing tomorrow.

George R. Dilkes, retired president of the Southern Steamship Company of Philadelphia, died of uremia yesterday in the French Hospital. He was 78 years old. Of late years Mr. Dilkes had made his home at Avon, N. J., residing when in the city at the Hotel Imperial.

Dr. Eugene Underhill, physician, writer and lecturer, died at his home in Chancellor Hall here last night after an illness of eight years. Death resulted from uremic poisoning, which developed three days ago. His age was 78.
The first international inquiry ever made into the legal status of women was inaugurated in Geneva on Monday under the auspices of the League of Nations. At the opening session M.

Mayor La Guardia rescinded yesterday the 10 per cent cut in relief allowances immediately after the City Council and the Board of Estimate had enacted three new tax bills that will raise a supplemental relief fund of nearly $10,000,000 a year.
Our touring Yankees touched a new low at La Grave Field today. For the third straight day the world champions bowed to minor league opposition, creating a situation that is being viewed with alarm.

Having jumped from seventh to fourth position in automotive registrations since the start of the year and experiencing the smallest percentage loss of any major producer, the Buick Motor Car Company is launching an extensive campaign in newspapers for April and May.

DOMMERICH, OTTO L. (March 8). Estate, more than $20,000. To Caroline C. Dommerich, widow, executrix, Rumson, N. J., household, personal effects, real property and income from trusts making up residuary estate; Julie D. Okie, 1,172 Park Ave., and Carola D. Elliott. 1,225 Park Ave.. daughters,
The Chicago Cubs increased their training series edge over their city rivals to two games today by beating the White Sox, 6-1. Tex Carleton and Charley Root kept seven Sox safeties scattered.
Basketball, which roared into high speed this past season with its center jump relegated to the junk pile, may get the "brakes" next Winter.

Archbishop Garibi y Rivera of Guadalajara today called upon Mexican Catholics to raise a fund to help pay seventeen American and British oil companies for their $400,000,000 holdings expropriated by the government on March 18.

Foreign Ministers P. R. Munch of Denmark, Rickard J. Sandler of Sweden and Rudolf Holsti of Finland arrived in Oslo today-and immediately proceeded to the Norwegian Foreign Ministry for a conference with Dr. Halvdan Koht that will continue tomorrow.

Veteran shipping men commenting yesterday on the passage by the House of Representatives on Monday of the Welch amendment authorizing the Federal Government to operate three passenger ships in the intercoastal service said that government operation or government subsidy of a privately owned line was the only way of assuring passenger service in the intercoastal trade.

Trading was fair. The cow and bull markets were higher, other classes mostly unchanged from Monday. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef prices to be stronger and other kosher classes weak, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
The sale by the Westchester County Savings Bank of Tarrytown of thirty-three parcels of land for $530,000 was announced today by Isaac Requa, president.
Van Ness Denton, a former public school teacher here and former justice of the peace and former tax assessor of Pawling, died Sunday at his residence here.
A contra-seasonal increase in steel ingot production last week sent the adjusted index forward to its highest point since the week ended Nov. 20, 1937.
Railway Commissar Alexei Bakulyn was removed from office tonight after seven months of attempting to improve the efficiency of Soviet railroads.

Highest officials of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry here, as well as business men especially conversant with foreign trade, assert that Franco-Spain has, on the whole, paid for imports with exports and consequently has had no need of extensive credits abroad for the conduct of the war.

Among those booked to sail for Europe today on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary are the Countess of Granard and her sons, Viscount Forbes and Colonel the Hon. Bertram Forbes; the Duke of Manchester, Countess Cittadini, the Hon. Audrey Pauncefote, the Hon. Pamela Berry, and Lily Pons, soprano, of the Metropolitan Opera Company.

Spruille Braden, New York financier, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be Minister to Colombia, a post now vacant. Mr. Braden is in Buenos Aires as member of the Chaco Mission for the adjustment of questions resulting from the warfare between Bolivia and Paraguay.

Retired Fireman Myles Morris, formerly a member of Engine Co. 235, residing at 73-27 Seventieth St:, Glendale, Queens, died April 3. Retired Fireman James J. Hassett, formerely a member of Engine Co. 49, residing at 210 East 75th St., Manhattan, died April 5.
A few spectators shivered through today's baseball game to watch Harvard win from the Navy by 7 to 4, the visitors clinching the contest with a rally in the ninth that netted three runs.

The East and Midwest shared the National A. A. U. boxing championship honors tonight when eight new titleholders, including four Negro battlers, were crowned in the Boston Garden ring after three long nights of slam-bang slugging.

Two four-man committees were appointed today by the Federal Communications Commission to conduct investigations ordered for its information and guidance on matters of administration of radio broadcasting.
Dr. Harry H. Satchwell, a heart specialist and member of the New Jersey State Board of Medical Examiners, died here today in his home after an illness of four months. He was 54 years old.

Glendora B. Murphy bought the house she lives in at 119 W 81st St, 17 ft wide, from the East River Savings Bank for $13,500, and gave back a purchase money mortgage for $12,000, due five years hence at 4 per cent, with $60 paid off quarterly during the last three years.
Wheat declined about 1 cent a bushel in the early trading today to new low levels for the season, the May selling at 80 7/8 cents, the lowest price quoted for that delivery since 1934.

Sales by savings banks of houses in the East and West Side areas and a resale in Harlem featured realty activity in Manhattan yesterday. The East River Savings Bank sold to a client of the Wood, Dolson Company the four-story and basement dwelling at 119 West Eightyfirst Street.

Employment on Class I railroads in the United States was 15.78 per cent lower in March than in the same month last year, and declined 1.31 per cent from February, the Interstate Commerce Commission announced today.
The Bankers Trust Company reported, as of March 31, total deposits of $835,193,433 and total, assets of $955,504,512, compared, respectively, with $852,796,841 and $975,069,368 on Dec. 31 last.
It cannot have happened very often in the history of war reporting that two correspondents for the same newspaper operated as near

Plans for the purchase of land to establish a Leon Blum colony in Palestine were approved yesterday at a luncheon attended by more than 300 persons at the Perroquet Club, 134 East Sixty-first Street. The colony is to be a refuge for Jews seeking escape from Nazi Germany and other dictatorial countries.

Operation of regular airmail service between the United States and Bermuda under a contract with the United States Postoffice Department was started today by the Bermuda Clipper, flying boat of the Pan American Airways, with the renewal of flights from the Pan American air base here.

Construction activity in Germany during 1937 reached the highest level for any post-war year with a valuation of $3,600,000,000, compared with a low of $966,000,000 in 1932, according to a consular report from Berlin made public today by the Department of Commerce.
Longview got its first view of major league baseball today and immediately became so tremendously enthused over the spectacle that it decided to take an active part in it with most amazing results.

The maintenance of naval parity with Great Britain and a five-to-three ratio with Japan will make war unlikely as far as the United States is concerned, and, in the event that there is a war, it will mean a shorter and a less costly one,

A memorial concert was given by the Henry Hadley Foundation and the National Association for American Composers and Conductors last night in Carnegie Hall. A very representative audience attended, and there were few present without personal memories of the composer.

Although Premier Leon Blum's demand for dictatorial powers to remedy the French financial situation was granted by the Chamber of Deputies today, there were indications tonight that his Cabinet would resign tomorrow.
Joseph Stalin made one of his infrequent and unheralded public appearances last night and received one of the warmest spontaneous ovations of his career.
The Newark Bears of the International League were stopped today after eleven straight exhibition triumphs by Indianapolis of the American Association, 7 to 2.

For the first time since the opening of the championship of the National Chess Federation in the R. C. A. Building, Rockefeller Center, Samuel Reshevsky, titleholder, failed to win his game last night. He had a narrow escape under the time-limit regulations, for, when play stopped at 11 o'clock, he had barely managed to beat the clock after making fifteen moves in five minutes.

The newspaper Dagbladet, in an article concerning fortifications that Germany is reported to be constructing in South Jutland, declared today that 3,000 laborers were now working to convert the Island of Sylt into a naval and air base.
Mayor La Guardia signed yesterday, after a public-hearing in his office, a bill recently passed by the City Council; extending g two months, to May 31, the expiration date of taxicab licenses.

The Public Service Company of Colorado, successor to the Denver Gas and Electric Light Company, announced yesterday through the Bankers Trust Company, trustee, that $66,800 of Denver Gas and Electric first and refunding mortgage bonds due in 1951 had been drawn for purchase out of sinking

New York Stock Exchange members holding shares of Clark Equipment Company common stock in "Street names" have been requested to have it transferred into their names or those of their nominees to facilitate collection of proxies.

A fair initial response to the reductions in prices on branded sheets was reported yesterday. Retailers, it was said, were impressed by the possibilities for price promotions in the usually slack post-Easter season and, since their stocks are low, they were placing fair borders.

After General Sessions Judge Morris Koenig had sentenced Jose Rivera, 38 years old, a Filipino, to life imprisonment yesterday for the hold-up killing of a restaurant manager by whom he was employed, Rivera declared: "The jury found me guilty, but I am innocent.
Trustees of the Michigan Sanitarium and Benevolent Association, operating the Battle Creek Sanitarium, sought today to work out a reorganization plan acceptable to bondholders and other creditors.
The debate on the 1938 revenue bill, scheduled to start in the Senate today, was postponed until tomorrow to permit action on two amendments to the army appropriations measure. Senator Harrison,

Twenty-five per cent of the books now owned by the New York public libraries are in an "atrocious condition," almost unfit to be brought into a respectable home, Franklin F. Hopper, chief of the circulation department of the public libraries, charged yesterday.

In a decision acclaimed by labor leaders as precedent-making as soon as it was handed down today in the case of the Inland Steel Company of Chicago, the National Labor Relations Board ruled that refusal by an employer to sign an agreement embodying an understanding with a union amounted, in effect, to a refusal to bargain collectively, contrary to the provisions of the Labor Relations Act.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Oatman, daughter of Mrs. Alva Oatman of 103 East Seventy-fifth Street and the late Mr. Oatman, to K. Randolph Dunnell of Brooklyn and East Greenwich, R. I., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. T. Drew Dunnell.

Consolidated net sales of the Federated Department Stores, Inc., for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 increased 4.32 per cent to $107,672,940 from $103,209,532 in the previous fiscal year, according to the annual report to be made public today by Lincoln Filene, chairman of the board.

A copy of the first edition of Robert Burns's "Poems, chiefly in the Scottish Dialect" brought $3,400 last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of the library of the late Cortlandt F. Bishop.

Steps to help speed up retail trade during the latter months of this year will dominate the meetings of eight groups of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the midyear convention of the association in Cincinnati from June 27 to July 1, it was announced yesterday by Lew Hahn, general manager.

Konrad Henlein, leader of the Sudeten German (Nazi) party, presided today at a meeting of the political committee of his party, at which the conversations between three of its members and Prime Minister Milan Hodza on April 1 were discussed.

Sales of the American Tobacco Company in the first quarter of 1938 were ahead of those in the corresponding period of last year, Paul M. Hahn, vice president, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in Jersey City.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 4: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS McMahon, F. W., VS-3, the Saratoga, to the Lexington. Poole, E. D., Navy Dept., to command the Claxton. Harris, J. H., Med. Corps, Birmingham, Ala., to treatment Norfolk Naval Hospital, Portsmouth, Va.
Dr. and Mrs. Nevil Monroe Hopkins gave a dinner last night at the National Arts Club for Dr. Hopkins's cousin, Mrs. William Veazie Pratt, wife of Rear Admiral Pratt, U.S.N., retired.

The appointment of Joseph Chapman as co-trustee of the Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie Railway Company was attacked today in a brief filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission by George M. Harrison, chairman of the Railway Labor Executives Association.

Front St, n e cor Beekman St, 26.6x37.2; trustee will of Heman C. Drake to 212 Front St, Inc. 212 Front St: consideration $7,500 over mtg for $5,500. 3d St, 344 E, 20x56.1; Anna Adler to Metropolitan Savings Bank quitclaim) ($1). St Marks Pl, 70, 25x97.6; Eva Rosenblum to Emigrant Bank; bank mtg, $21,250.

Paced by Don Kelly, who scored four points, the Baltimore Athletic Club handed Princeton a 6-to-3 defeat in lacrosse today. Kelly, playing at first attack, scored twice in the opening period and rammed home two more markers in the third.

While thousands of New York children were busy in their classrooms conjugating verbs, extracting square roots and probing the causes of the Punic Wars, about fifty boys stole away from school yesterday to bid for various unclaimed articles at the 282d semiannual public auction of the Police Department.

Frank L. Swigert, manager of the media-contract department of N. W. Ayer Son, Inc., advertising agency, with which he had been associated for twenty-eight years, died at his home here today after being ill for months. His age was 59.

Members of the board of governors of the League of New York Theatres informally protested yesterday the plan of the Works Progress Administration to lease the St. James Theatre for a Federal theatre production.

The old, familiar menagerie odors, the helter-skelter maze of guy ropes overhead and all the other circus ingredients were evident in Madison Square Garden yesterday as the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey show began setting up for its New York opening tomorrow night, but there seemed to be something different, something new, in the picture.

The development of a store-wide policy to serve as a guide for all merchandising and advertising of the store was emphasized as the first and most important point in a ten-point "Formula for Retail Advertising," by Hugo Sonnenschein, advertising manager of Bloomingdale's, in an address last night before the Retail Advertising Course of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration reported today that sugar charged against import quotas of all off-shore producing areas in the first three months of 1938 amounted to 1,145,673 short tons, raw value.

Spring jumped its lease yesterday as wintry weather cut a path 200 to 300 miles wide across the country from the Rocky Mountains to the Atlantic seaboard, bringing to this city sub-freezing temperatures and a three-inch snowfall by 10 P. M., hampering street traffic, grounding airplanes, interfering with radio communication and nipping early blooms in gardens and parks.

John W. Gassner, member of the New York Drama Critic Circle and play reader for the Theatre Guild, announced yesterday that he had declined an invitation of Queens College to lecture there because of the college's withdrawal of its invitation to Ernst Toller to speak on the same platform.

In the present mood of financial markets, stress has been occasionally laid on the decline in staple prices, which to some minds has appeared to indicate reaction similar to that which characterized the trend of 1932.

The presidents of eighty-eight women's organizations in the metropolitan area unanimously adopted a resolution yesterday condemning "every manifestation of racial or religious prejudice" and pledging themselves "to work unceasingly for a land of religious liberty and good-will to all mankind such as is guaranteed by the United States Constitution."

President Roosevelt led the nation today in observance of the twenty-first anniversary of its entry into the World War. In a small reviewing stand opposite Washington Monument on Constitution Avenue he
About seventy so-called "middle high schools" in New York State will be gradually eliminated, beginning July 1, Dr. George M. Wiley, Associate Education Commissioner, announced today.
Vice President Garner today appointed Senators Capper and Frazier to the Tennessee Valley Authority investigating committee in place of Senators McNary and Borah, Republicans, who declined to serve.

Exports from the United States to Mexico in February were nearly $800,000 less than in the corresponding month last year and imports from that country were down $1,267,000, according to the Department of Commerce's analysis of foreign trade in February, made public today.
Dr. Walter Spencer Fleming, a practicing physician for fifty-five years and former medical executive at hospitals for mental patients, died last night in the Mount Vernon Hospital at the age of 75.

Mr. and Mrs. Stanley M. Rumbough and Stanley M. Rumbough Jr. have returned from Bermuda to the Waldorf-Astoria, where they will be until going to Elstan Oaks, their country home in Huntington, L. I., next month.

Putting a one-cent revenue stamp on each of the 1,150,000 or more packages of cigarettes New York turns into smoke and ashes each day is a tedious, expensive operation that will raise jobbers' labor costs $250,000 to $1,000,000 a year and, it was predicted yesterday, advance the consumer price from one to one and one-half cents a package.

The San Antonio Public Service Company, San Antonio, Texas, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering the issuance and sale of $17,000,000 of first mortgage 4 per cent bonds due in 1963 and $2,500,000 of 4 per cent serial notes due on April 15, 1939 to 1948.

Dr. Harry Woodburn Clise announced yesterday that New York University, of which he is chancellor, has received a gift of $50,000 from the Charles Hayden Foundation to provide scholarships for needy and promising students of the Boston and metropolitan New York areas.

An increase of 16 per cent over February in motor vehicle shipments for March was indicated in the preliminary estimate of the industry's operations made public yesterday by the Automobile Manufacturers Association following a meeting here of its board of directors.

In notes to Germany yesterday the United States said it found itself "under the necessity as a practical measure" of recognizing the absorption of Austria and called upon the Reich to assume that country's debts owed here. [Page 1.]

Forty-two paintings from the collection of the late Harris Whittemore have been lent through the courtesy of Miss Gertrude B. Whittemore Mrs. Harris Whittemore and the J. H. Whittemore Company to form an 'exhibition that is being held this week at the Tuttle House in Naugatuck, Conn., for the benefit of the Children's Center at New Haven.

Predicting that real recovery and prosperity will be general in this country within six months, Harry Boyd Brown, merchandising manager of the Philco Radio and Television Corporation, said that the companies which expand sales and advertising activity now will get the largest profits from the upswing.

The arrest of fifteen persons on charges of security frauds, the obtaining of fifteen injunctions against suspected security dealers and the successful prosecution of eight violators of the business law in March constituted a new monthly record for activity by the city Bureau of Securities, it was announced yesterday by Attorney General Bennett.

Fred Apostoli was yesterday named the No. 1 challenger for the middleweight title held by Freddie Steele when his manager, Larry White, appeared before the New York State Athletic Commission demanding recognition of the challenge and at the same time posting a check for $2,000 to bind the transaction.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is as easy to change the spots on a leopard as to change a free-trader, masquerading under the policy of "reciprocal trade," into a protector of American industry by the equalization process of tariffs-but your editorial
The tax stamp which will be affixed to every pack, tin and carton of cigarettes is manufactured by an intricate process of building up layers of waterproof inks on a specially prepared paper base.

Many merchants, weary of counting pennies showered upon them by Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute students bent upon giving the public an object lesson in "hidden taxes," refused today to accept more than 25 cents in pennies on a single purchase.
The best of the amateurs was not good enough for a leading professional in the world open .squash tennis championship at the Shelton Club last night.
Robert T. Jones Jr., retired golf champion, said today that "under no circumstances" would he resume the status of a regular competitor in the national open tournament.

Eighty persons have been invited by Mrs. Robert H. Montgomery of Greenwich, Conn., to a luncheon, bridge and pool swimming party she is giving tomorrow at the Montgomery estate in Coconut Grove for Mrs. Robert E. Warren of Cleveland.

With the entrance of Leo Y. Chertok into the Mexican oil conflict, all the international elements interested in the large Ethiopian concessions freely obtained from the late Emperor Haile Selassie just prior to Italian invasion of his empire, now are actively competing for a prominent position in the Mexican oil picture.

Sharp-shooting Charles Clare of New Haven, Conn., today gained a 3-and-2 victory over Bobby Dunkelberger of High Point, N. C., the defending champion, in the second round of the North and South amateur golf tournament.

Richard Whitney was informed yesterday by Irwin Kurtz, Federal bankruptcy referee, that his public hearings were complete unless some details were found to need further examination. He was told to hold himself in readiness for any such supplementary questioning Saturday morning at 10 o'clock.

On the twenty-first anniversary of America's entrance into the World War, the Senate passed today the largest War Department appropriation bill since 1921, carrying $491,225,313 and including more than $32,000,000 of ordnance and seacoast defense funds added by the Senate over sharp opposition.

With the French Cabinet tottering. Joseph Paul-Boncour, Foreign Minister, let it be known tonight that he was engaged in negotiations on which might depend the fate of Czechoslovakia and Central Europe.

Holdings of Selection Trust, Ltd., of London and C. M. Loeb Co. of New York in the American Metals Company, Ltd., have been increased since last year, according to figures made public by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Abram Chasins will be soloist in his Second Piano Concerto at tonight's concert of the PhilharmonicSymphony at Carnegie Hall under John Barbirolli. There also will be music by Vivaldi-Mistowski,- Faure and Elgan. In the PhilharmonicSymphony concerts of April 13, 14 and 17 Norman Cordon will take the part of Titurel in the first act of "Parsifal."

With prices depressed in most waste material lines, collections have begun to fall off sharply, with the result that, in some instances, shortages are appearing, dealers reported yesterday. As yet, this scarcity has not affected prices because of the lack of buying. It is,

According to our Washington dispatches President Roosevelt is being pressed daily for a decision whether to propose large-scale public spending to arrest the continuing business recession, or hold expenditures to the minimum relief needs.

The three-point decline in the steel rate to 32 1/2 per cent of capacity reflects the irregular flow of business under present uncertain conditions, according to Iron Age, which adds that "the moderate improvement in orders during a part of March has not been accelerated, but on the contrary has in some respects flattened out."

The saving effected through the 10 per cent cut in home-relief allowances, which Mayor La Guardia rescinded on Tuesday after it had been in force for three weeks, was estimated yesterday at about $400,000. The city's share of this saving was $240,000, the rest accruing to the State.

The Federal Trade Commission has become the most powerful agency for the regulation of business operations in the country today, a fact which business men to date have not recognized, Charles Wesley Dunn, general counsel to the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., warned yesterday at a special meeting of the group at the Hotel Commodore.

Fair weather or foul, it makes no difference to Rumson Farm Dawn. He just goes hunting for game and in so doing he accumulates cash and cups for his owner, Raymond Hoagland of Cartersville, Ga. Dawn, a white and black pointer dog, today annexed the member's derby stake which inaugurated the thirty-fifth annual meeting of the English Setter Club of America.
Manufacturing equipment of the Rossie Manufacturing Company mills was sold at auction today to numerous out-of-town bidders.
Alfred J. Ripley, heraldic and commercial artist, died last night in his home here. He was 82 years old. Born in Manchester, England, he had lived in this city about fiftyfive years.

Insurgent members of the National Maritime Union of the C. I. O., who recently attacked certain union executives on the ground that they were associated with the Communist movement, announced yesterday that they would support Joseph Curran for president.

State and municipal financing for March aggregated $231,622,491, as compared with $92,712,663 for March, 1937, according to The Daily Bond Buyer of New York. For the first three months of the year the total was $346,262,473.
Marking the first substantial improvement in motor car sales this year, Ford dealers reported a sharp increase in new car sales during the last ten days of March, the company announced yesterday.

Governor Earle lunched with the President today, which served to draw the capital's attention once more to the internecine war among the Democrats of Pennsylvania, waged so soon after in union they had captured this Republican Verdun.

Michael Schapp, president of Bloomingdale Bros., Inc., in his annual report to stockholders for the year ended on Jan. 31, 1938, made public yesterday, reveals an increase of 2.18 per cent in net sales over the previous year.

Endowing a Professorship of Library Service at Columbia the Carnegie Corportion of New York has happily named it in honor of Melvil Dewey, a practical enthusiast and born organizer who was the first to understand the necessity of giving a professional training to librarians in a nation of libraries.

Plans were announced yesterday for one of the largest housing developments undertaken in Queens in recent years. They call for eighteen units of the garden-apartment type to accommodate 540 families in 1,890 rooms on two blocks of the Thorneycroft tract on the north side of Queens Boulevard between Webb Street and Sixty-fifth Road.

The Mexican Government indicated publicly and officially today for the first time that it expects to pay indemnity for the expropriated United States and British oil companies from the proceeds of oil produced in the companies' former plants.
German boys and girls leaving school in poor health will be put through invigorating courses in camps maintained by the Social Insurance System.

Sculptors, who probably refuse to dig the garden for their wives in fine weather, dug in the lot at the northeast corner of Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street in a snowstorm yesterday afternoon for the sake of their art. They were preparing for the outdoor show of the Sculptors Guild which will open next Tuesday.

Paul Philip Le Boutilliere, fiance of Miss Grace May Badaracco, daughter of Mrs. John Repetto of 11 Elysian Park South, Hoboken, died on Tuesday at his home in Bordeaux, France, according to word received here last night. Mr. Ls Boutilliere,

Although shareholders of the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois have approved an amendment changing the present $60 par value stock into an equal number of shares without par value, the company has notified the New York Curb Exchange that the concern will not make an application to list the issue because of the small number of shares in the hands of the public.

Harold L. Crane of Princeton, gaining another victory in a sharply contested game with William M. Murphy of Harvard, held his lead yesterday in the third round of the annual individual championship tournament of the H. Y. P. D. College Chess League at the Marshall Chess Club.

German and Austrian refugees fleeing Nazi activities have increased State adult education class enrollment by about 4,500 students, according to Miss Caroline Whipple, adult education bureau supervisor.

ALBANY-Jonn G. Myers Co.; Mrs. F. Spenard, jewelry; 11 W. 42d (F. Atkins). ALTOONA, Pa.--Wm. F. Gable Co.; R. H. Beers, men's wear; 50 W. 35th (Syndicate-Alliance). ANTIGO, Wis. - Leroy's; S. Silverstein, close-outs, coats; 505 8th Ave. (Golden Trading, Inc.).
The battle of Taierhchwang continued yesterday with the Chinese remaining in control of the southwest corner of the walled town as well as in positions outside the southwest wall.
Alvin McCaslin Higgins, New York attorney, author and former telephone company executive, died here today at his estate, Orchard Hill, after an illness of ten days. He was 71 years old.

The strike of fur workers again was marked by violence yesterday when three men assaulted a fur dealer outside his place of business at 330 Seventh Avenue. The fur dealer, Jack Biegeleisen of 44-14 Newton Road, Astoria, Queens, was pummeled for several minutes, but was not seriously hurt.

Establishment of a national interest rate of 4 per cent for refinancing all outstanding obligations instead of the present 6 per cent basis was advocated here yesterday by Larry J. Margulies of Air Conditioning Textiles, Inc., who said that recent temporary policies by institutions and Federal agencies have shown that a 4 per cent rate has developed willingness to create employment and increased the stability of underlying obligations.
The engagement of Miss Priscilla Lawrence Young, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Everett T. Young, to Thomas Niblo Creed, son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Creed, has been announced.
Joe Traubenik, member of the Birk Brothers brewing team of Chicagol which set a new American bowling congress high last night in team competition, went on to individual honors today.

A suit has been instituted in the State Supreme Court by Baron Eugene de Rothschild against his brother, Baron Louis Rothschild, head of the famous banking house in Vienna, and against the banking house itself, it was disclosed yesterday. On the basis of the suit,

The Atlantic Coast Line Company, holding company which controls the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad, reported yesterday a net income of $690,481 in 1937, or $2.93 a share on its capital stock, against $509,699, or $2.17 a share, inb 1936. Total income was $984,711, against $800,204.
Arthur W. Guyer, president of the Dartmouth National Bank and State Senator, died suddenly here today of coronary thrombosis at the age of 65.

Merchants of Fifth Avenue and other shopping centers of the city will cooperate in the World's Fair preview on April 30 by having special displays in fair colors and designs and by decorating with flags and banners, fair officials announced yesterday. The preview will include a colorful motorcade.
A talkwearied House which finally agreed today by unanimous consent to stop general debate on the Reorganization Bill will proceed to a test vote tomorrow soon after it convenes.

The Rev. Edgar Morrison Wilson, retired missionary, who was long attached to the Western India Mission of the Presbyterian Church of the United States of America, died on Saturday in California, according to word received here yesterday by the church's board of foreign missions. His age was 69.

" Realism" is a much disputed, loosely applied and often perhaps misunderstood term. In general use it replaces the term "naturalism," and does so quite irrespective of period. Distinctions need not at this time be drawn.

A Bronx corner figured yesterday in a transaction which is expected to result in a resale and the erection of a modern apartment house. Charles Walzer, operator, bought 401 to 409 East 151st Street and 614 to 620 Melrose-Avenue, two threestory and three two-story buildings containing stores and apartments and occupying a plot 114 by 95 feet at the northeast corner.
A new Wages-and-Hours Bill, some of its terms modified from those of a measure killed during the special session last year, was reported today to the House Labor Committee by a subcommittee.

A correctional court here has condemned Boris Toedtli to three months' imprisonment-one month more than the prosecutor had demanded-and fined him 500 francs' damages for supplying to the German Nazi party forbidden information, notably information prejudicial to various Swiss citizens.

A man identified as the Rev. Alfred J. Hogg, 58 years old, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church at New Castle, N. B., jumped to his death today from the roof garden of the nine-story Jefferson Hotel at South Kentucky Avenue and the Boardwalk.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are April 6, unless specified: At Philadelphia: Philadelphia, Shaw. Algorma, at San Pedro, April 5. Black Hawk, Hong Song to Southern Philippines. J. D. Edwards, Manila to Southern Philippines.
State regulation of the anthracite industry as a public utility was recommended today in the final report of a commission appointed a year ago to study the problems of the hard-coal fields.

Accompanied by a decline in the share market, bond prices dropped yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, with the volume of sales off to the smallest since March 24. The turnover amounted to $6,105,200, compared with $7,074,975 on the preceding day.

Yale's tennis team and North Carolina, national champion for the past two years, today battled to a 5-5 tie. In the feature contests, Mel Dalrymple, Yale, beat Carl Rood, 9-7, 6-4, and Johnny Foreman, N. C., subdued Jimmy Hinchliff, 6-0, 4-6, 6-3.

An agreement between the New York City Tunnel Authority and Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, on the acquisition of property for the easterly approach to the proposed midtown underpass between the Lincoln and the East River Tunnels, will be placed before the Board of Estimate today by Mr. Isaacs.
Spring tornadoes struck sections of Louisiana and Alabama today as reports of flood damage, torrential rains and forecasts of freezing weather came from other areas of the South.
The Maritime Commission reported to Congress today that President Roosevelt desired that the proposed Nicaraguan Canal be studied further before any commitment was made.

Charles Walzer, operator, has purchased the six-story apartment at 1,400 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, from a client of Louis N. Jaffe, attorney. The house is on the corner of Avenue I on a plot 130 by 100 feet. It contains 178 rooms,

Robert M. Sweitzer, who for twenty-five years was a power in Democratic politics of Cook County, died tonight in St. Anne's Hospital. He was 69 years old and had been in failing health more than a year.

The establishing of Federal Government corporations which would exchange their debentures for railroad bonds, with interest on the debentures guaranteed by the government, was recommended yesterday by Oscar Lasdon, associate editor of The Bankers Magazine.

Professor James H. Means of the Harvard Medical School, president of the American College of Physicians, in his presidential address last night at the annual convocation of the college at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria called upon all those physicians "who believe in popular government to bestir themselves" and organize "an effective opposition party" to the American Medical Association.

Enzo Baccante, painter, sculptor and former opera singer in Italy, was found dead of heart disease Tuesday night in his apartment at 353 West Twenty-fourth Street when his wife, also an artist, telephoned from Washington, where she had gone to execute a commission.

The list of Christians interned in concentration camps either in Upper Austria or at Dachau near Munich now includes Robert Danneberg, Socialist leader; Desider Friedmann, head of Vienna's Jewish community; Robert Stricker, a prominent Jew, and Jakob Ehrlich, Jewish member of Vienna's City Council.

Walter Samuels, Inc., have arranged first mortgages as follows: $37,500 on the property at 583 Bergenline Avenue, West New York, N. J., for William Mayer Jr., as trustee, and $27,500 on the taxpayer at 30-76 Steinway Street, Astoria, Queens, for the Cara Realty Corporation.

IT'S getting worse and worse. The cosmic urge seems to be toward more wars all the time. Ethiopia, China, Spain, Austria-and now this country! No official declaration of war has come out of Washington, D. C. No official declaration of war came out of Nippon, either.

Miscellaneous aircraft operators flew 102,996,355 miles and carried 1,580,412 passengers during 1937, experiencing one accident on the average of every 53,894 miles flown during the last half of the year, the Bureau of Air Commerce announced today.

The government's investigation of a German spy organization that employed two renegade American soldiers, conducted in strict secrecy since it was uncovered on Feb. 26, was considerably widened yesterday with the arraignment of three material witnesses, including two members of a uniformed Nazi corps in this country. Also,

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:
The rules committee of the National Association of Basketball Coaches today applied two "brakes" to last season's "racehorse" game.

Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek clarified today the phenomenon that has puzzled an impressed worldthe extraordinary spectacle of a united China fighting the Japanese to a standstill for nine months in a war the Japanese thought would be a three weeks' walkover.

For the third consecutive year the General Motors Corporation in 1937 was the largest user of newspapers, according to an analysis of the advertising of 357 companies by Media Records, appearing today in Printers' Ink. The total for last year was 22,246,315 lines, against 23,787,789 lines in 1936.

Tim Smith, 19-year-old Negro whose conviction last September on a pistol charge led recently to the indictment of his accuser, Patrolman Theodore Steinblinck of the Clinton Street station, on a perjury charge, was discharged yesterday by Judge Koenig on the recommendation of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey.

The Labor party gave Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain an embarrassing defeat at the polls tonight by winning a hard fought by-election in the West Fulham division of London and capturing a vital Parliamentary seat from the Conservatives.
According to the London Daily Mail's correspondent at Cerbere, France, on the Spanish border, a flight of Spanish Government and embassy officials from Catalonia has started.
What is believed to be the largest sawfish ever caught alive has been placed in the Marine Studio Aquarium here. It measures 14 feet 8 1/2 inches and is thought to weigh more than a thousand pounds.

In a bleak, wintry setting almost entirely foreign to its competitive experience at home, the Cambridge University fifteen buried the New York Rugby Club under a canopy of falling snow at Randalls Island Stadium yesterday, 35 to 0.

R. H. Macy Co., Inc., reported yesterday total sales of $90,980,960 for the fiscal year of fifty-two weeks ended on Jan. 29, compared with $87,239,606 in the preceding year, while the company and its affiliated stores showed sales of $135,871,800, against $130,441,311 a year before. The increases were 4.3 and 4.1 per cent, respectively.

Miss Joan P. Lusk, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. William B. Lusk of this city, will have two matrons of honor for her marriage to Charles H Tenney, which takes place on May 14. They will be her sister,

Charges of contempt of court against Walter Gordon Merritt, counsel for the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, were made yesterday before John Kirkland Clark, special master in the injunction suit brought by the association against Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

Prince Bernhard of The Netherlands is cruising off the south coast of Italy aboard the 5,000-ton Yugoslav freighter Galeb, according to The Daily Mail's Hague correspondent, and is due to return to The Netherlands April 25.

Spanish Government troops, manoeuvring to relieve pressure on Catalonia, today launched a surprise offensive on the central front which carried them well up toward the Badajoz highway about 100 miles southwest of Madrid.
Several New Yorkers attended the party to celebrate the fiftieth wedding anniversary of Mr. and Mrs. H. M. Atkinson of Atlanta, Ga., today at their Tuckers Town home, Atlanta.

R. A. Falk, vice president of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., and E. W. Thornley were elected directors at the annual meeting of the company in Baltimore. E. W. Debevoise has succeeded the late S. Parker Gilbert as a director of the Lehigh Valley Coal Corporation.

Thomas E. Fitzsimmons, former counsel, vice president and director of the South Orange Trust, Company of South Orange, was sentenced to serve fifteen to. thirty years in State prison for embezzlement by Judge Richard Hartshorne in Common Pleas Court- here today.
A court order ended the stormy life of the Pennsylvania Oil Investigation Commission today unless a decision by the Dauphin County court is reversed on appeal.

The report of the American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28, issued yesterday, shows a net income after all operating expenses and charges, of $13,181,943. This was equal,

The Bronx Zoo has just acquired C a new inhabitant. On view in the C reptile house in a bower of dampened leaves and evergreen boughs C after the' voyage from its native Trinidad, it is a bushmaster, nearly seven feet long. The bushmaster is a leading contender for the title of n the world's most venomous snake.
Fear of what the Administration may do next is one of the factors in the psychological attitude of business and industry which retards recovery, Secretary Roper said today at a press conference.

Dr. Albert Einstein was the guest of honor last night at a special performance at the Public Theatre, 66 Second Avenue, where Jewish stars presented their most popular roles in a tribute to the scientist, who urged support of Palestine as a haven for refugees.

The engagement of $600,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This transaction brought the total of gold purchased in England for United States account since March 15 to $25,600,000.

The plan agreed upon by President Roosevelt and President Quezon to extend our preferential trade agreement with the Philippine Commonwealth from 1946 to 1960 may not meet the approval of those who fear the competition of Philippine sugar or coconut. oil. Yet,

Adams Mueller, Newark, N. J., purchased yesterday at a price of 100.027 for 2 1/4s $442,000 of a new Issue of $672,000 of general bonds of Bergen County, N. J. The remainder of the bonds was taken by the County Sinking Fund at the same rate and price. The bonds are dated April 1, 1938, and mature serially from April 1, 1939 to 1948.

President Roosevelt reviewed the Army Day parade- and discussed with Governor Earle of Pennsylvania the latter's proposal for a $9,000,000,000 program of low-cost housing construction, highway building, flood control, soil erosion and rural electrification as a means of restoring prosperity.

The Optimists have obtained the services of Michael Phipps for the final contest of the three-game high-goal indoor polo championship series with the formidable New York Athletic Club on Saturday night at the Squadron A Armory.

Chilled and dampened by an unseasonal snowstorm but gallantly endeavoring to show a festive spirit, Mayor La Guardia, Park Commissioner Robert Moses and other civic leaders, and a group of men and women in picturesque but unprotecting Colonial costumes rededicated Bowling Green Park yesterday.

BECKERMAN, FANNIE (Nov. 19, 1936). Gross assets, $12,025; net, $11,705. To sons, Benjamin Beckerman, $1; Samuel Beckerman, residuary estate. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $140; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $11,568; miscellaneous property, 5317. Samuel Beckerman, attorney, 3,620 Bedford Ave.

Women members of the New York branch of the Army Relief Society at the branch's annual meeting, held yesterday at the home of Mrs. William N. Haskell, 975 Park Avenue, re-elected presiding officers and reported the raising of $2,800 in the year ended on April 1.

The probability of a match race between War Admiral and Seabiscuit for a purse of $100,000 at Belmont Park next September became stronger yesterday when Chairman Herbert Bayard Swope of the New York State Racing Commission received word by telegram that Samuel D. Riddle, owner of War Admiral, would make a special trip to New York to confer on details.

Cole Smith, 30 years old, a snake handler at Frank Buck's jungle camp here, was bitten on the finger by a venomous cotton-mouth water moccasin in the reptile house of the camp today. He was taken to the Reed General Hospital here, where serum was administered.

Mrs. LeBrun Rhinelander gave a luncheon yesterday in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Mrs. Charles de Rham, Mrs. Donald 0. MacRae, Mrs. M. Taylor Pyne Jr., Mrs. Robert R. Young, Mrs. Jorge R. Andre, Mrs. Reginald Townsend, Mrs. Dudley P. Gilbert and Mrs. Morris de Peyster.

Fred A. Gilbert of Hampden, former vice president of the Great Northern Paper Company, died today in a Bangor hospital after an operation. He was manager of the firm's timberland and lumbering interests from 1900 to 1930 He was 72 years old.

Harvard University skiers today took the Big Three slalom race, twice postponed this week because of blizzard conditions. Although Serge Gagarin of Yale was the individual winner, Harvard's four-man team had a combined time of 278.8 seconds to 349.4 for Yale and 582 for Princeton.
The appointment of Dr. F. S. Horne of New York as assistant advisor on Negro relations of the United States Housing Authority was announced today by Nathan Straus, administrator.

The Lawyers Mortgage Guarantee Corporation has amended its charter and now is authorized to act as trustee in behalf of certificate holders and to continue the servicing of mortgages and certificate series amounting to more than $100,000,000, according to an announcement made yesterday by Richard M. Hurd, chairman.

Mrs. Lina Pease Teeple, widow of John Edgar Teeple, chemical engineer, died of a stroke last night at her home here after a short illness. Born in Mundy, Mich., Mrs. Teeple had been a resident of Montclair for thirty-two years. In 1936,

Shouldering a 122-pound assignment, H. J. Bundscho's Great Haste came from out of the pack to annex the Sandy Springs Handicap, today's feature on the midweek program. Winner of one race in seven starts in Florida last Winter, Great Haste put on a stretch rush that turned back W. E; Johnson's Master Lad by a neck.

General American Investors Company, Inc.-As of March 31: Net assets, $21,282,407, equivalent to $5.46 a share for common stock, compared with $24,727,698, or $8.09 a share, on Dec. 31. Net income for quarter, $139,038; net loss on sales of securities, $394,626. Cash, $7,711,265,

BARRON, BASEL A. (March 29). Estate, less than $10,000. To Yetta Miller, executrix, 850 7th Ave. BRADNLY, BARBARA (March 15). Estate, not more than $5,000. To Anna Schmitt, 304 E. 162d St., and Elizabeth Rock, executrix, 160 E. 108th St., daughters, residue equally.
Reversal of straddle accounts between foreign markets and New York continued the liquidating movement on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, so prices here lost 6 to 7 points.

A five-point program designed to bring about a concerted drive to wipe out the dress returns evil has been adopted by representatives of leading chain stores and buying offices following a conference with the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Group and the Dress Returns Control Bureau, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Louis Rubin, chairman of the latter organizations.

Excellency: I am directed by my government to inform Your Excellency as follows: On March 17, 1938, the Minister of the Republic of Austria, Mr. Edgar Prochnik, informed the Department of State that, as a result of the developments which had occurred in Austria, that country had ceased to exist as an independent nation and had been incorporated in the German Reich;

Peace and the spirit of forgiveness were in the air today as the Chicago Black Hawks and Toronto Maple Leafs, rivals for the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup, prepared to resume their battle for the battered trophy that represents the world professional hockey championship.

SOME time ago, you may remember, there appeared a took suggesting that Edwin M. Stanton, Secretary of War in 1865, was connected with the murder of Abraham Lincoln. The author, Otto Eisenschiml, couldn't begin to prove the fact, but he hinted at it, talked around it, probed, investigated and examined for a space of 500 pages. It was an astonishing book, and it left the reader more or less up in the air.
William G. Stiegler, dramatic editor of The Cincinnati Times Star, died at Good Samaritan Hospital today of a cerebral hemorrhage.

After having held the position of president of Congregation EmanuEl for more than eight years, Judge Irving Lehman of the Court of Appeals resigned at a trustees' meeting on Tuesday night and was succeeded by Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the congregation's finance committee and partner in the banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co.

The judgment of the National Labor Relations Board that action of the Inland Steel Company, in refusing to sign a contract with a labor union, constituted a refusal to bargain collectively is contained in the following excerpts from the board's decision:

Through the exercise of an option by the City of New York, Hunter College will continue to occupy four floors in the Two Park Avenue Building, where for some time an annex of the college has been operated.

Mrs. Lillian A. Harrigan, widow of Battalion Chief George F. Harrigan and active in many organizations, died on Tuesday at her home, 8,018 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn, at the age of 58. She was the first vice president of Fort Hamilton Memorial Unit,
The current edition of Harvard's varsity crew put in an impressive bit of rowing tonight at the end of the hardest day's work it has done this season.

Closer Pan-American cooperation and means of meeting the Nazi propaganda menace are believed to be the most important subjects planned for discussion in the four-day visit to Brazil of the newly appointed Argentine Foreign Minister, Jose Maria Castilo.

After a dramatic conversation lasting almost two hours with Pope Pius this morning, Theodor Cardinal Innitzer, Archbishop of Vienna, who had been summoned to Rome to explain his acts of obeisance to the Nazi rulers of Austria, virtually retracted the declaration of the Austrian Episcopate March 18 in which Austrian Catholics were urged to vote for Anschluss.

We've always wanted to meet a man who would put back a fivepound trout, and yesterday we missed the opportunity. William Mackey one of the active members of the Anglers Club, did this very thing, but he may have been guided by the fact that the twelve-pounder he had in the creel left no room for another fish.

The City Council and the Board of Estimate having passed the new city tax bills, the immediate and most important effect is that the 10 per cent cut in relief allowances has been rescinded. There is no doubt regarding the Mayor's signature, and the new taxes are to to into effect Monday.

Whether or not a majority of Austrians were genuinely enthusiastic for Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Anschluss in mid-March, a trip through the country from Innsbruck west to Switzerland has left no doubt that at the end of March there was very little enthusiasm remaining in Western Austria except among children.

Germans resident in Brazil who will vote in the plebiscite are asked to declare what language they speak, whether they can drive automobiles, what their education has been, if they are "pure Aryan" and whether they have received military training.

Alleged attempts by their superiors to persuade them to shun the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, and join an independent union on the company's system were related by B. M. T. workers yesterday at an adjourned hearing before the State Labor Relations Board.

Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel granted yesterday a temporary injunction restraining the Ilsa Wine and Liquor Corporation of 575 Seventh Avenue from selling G. W. whiskies and other liquor products below the retail prices fixed by Gooderham Worts, Inc., distributors.
Reorganization of the chemistry and physics courses offered in the New York, City high schools to place them on an up-to-date basis was proposed in a survey made public yesterday.

The Theatre Guild-Actors Repertory "Washington Jitters" won't be along on April 18. The official premiere will be on May 4, and accordingly the series of previews scheduled to start this week has been postponed to next week. Some script revision is taking place.

Manager Pie Traynor hurled a bombshell among his Pirates today when he herded them together on short notice, fined several of them for breaking training rules and sent Russell Bauers by airplane to St. Louis for treatment of an injury suffered in a scuffle.

Dr. Herman Liu, president of the American-supported Shanghai College, was shot to death today by gunmen as he walked along an International Settlement street with his wife. Settlement police immediately arrested a Chinese, who told them he had been "hired to kill Liu because he was a traitor to China."
It really isn't safe to tease a tiger when he is on the loose and today, as they wound up their Grapefruit League season, the Dodgers finally found that out.

Members of the International Typographical Union began voting throughout the country today on five points of "basic policy," four of which deal with the union's affiliation with the American Federation of Labor.

The Byllesby Corporation, Wilmington, Del., has filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Holding Company Act for an order declaring it not to be a holding company.
Colonel Edgar Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association, told a Sen-
The development at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology of a series of substances that have "yielded some remarkable results in the cure of athlete's foot and pyorrhea,"
Issuance of a new 6-cent air mail stamp in connection with the celebration of National Air Mail Week, May 15-21, was announced today by Postmaster General Parley.

Until the Austrian plebiscite has been held the status of emigration from that country is in a state of confusion, Miss Cecelia Razovsky told members of the National Council of Jewish Women yesterday at Essex House, where they had gathered to discuss immigration activities of the organization, which are under her charge.

Marion B. Folsom, treasurer of the Eastman Kodak Company of Rochester, has been appointed a director of the Buffalo branch of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System announced today. His term will expire on Dec. 31, 1938.
Eleven records in a fourteen-event competition were broken today as Princeton's track and field team defeated North Carolina, 76 to 50.

Disruption of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company's unified system of subway and elevated lines, now operating for a single five-cent fare, should come, if at all, through foreclosure action by the bondholders, rather than by direction of the court to the Interborough receiver, Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson was told yesterday.

Until the Austrian plebiscite has been held the status of emigration from that country is in a state of confusion, Miss Cecelia Razovsky told members of the National Council of Jewish Women yesterday at Essex House, where they had gathered to discuss immigration activities of the organization, which are under her charge.
Robert Wilkie, 12 years old, of 870 James Street, Pelham Manor, was drowned this evening off Fort Slocum Island after a borrowed rowboat overturned with him and a companion.
Electric power production showed a contra-seasonal increase last week and the index advanced to 91.5 from 91.0. The figure was 105.5 for the week ended April 3, 1937.

Men's matching slacks and polo shirts, generally made of synthetics, which have been introduced in the last month, are beginning to sell well, according to manufacturers yesterday. A popular price range is the $5.95 bracket, with the more expensive lines slower to move.

The stock market was generally firm today, although there was a dearth of business, which caused prices to decline slightly in late trading. Giltedge issues were in some demand, while among the foreign bonds the Austrian 7 per cents were a good feature. Transatlantic shares,

The Securities and Exchange Commission is planning to hold public hearings early in May on the affairs of the United Founders group in connection with its study of investment trusts and investment companies, it became known today.
The old notion that monetary management can be employed effectively to stabilize the price level has appeared again in a bill introduced yesterday in the Senate by Senator Logan.

The Commission of Fine Arts announced today that it "heartily approves" the South Shore Tidal Basin site selected for - the proposed Thomas Jefferson Memorial but that it had "consistently opposed" the erection there of a pantheon type of building in the form designed for it by the late John Russell -Pope.

Multi-family dwellings formed the bulk of the trading in New Jersey announced yesterday. Wasyl Chelak bought from the estate of Anna Harty the four-family house at 158 St. Paul's Avenue, Jersey City, for cash, through J. I. Kislak, Inc., brokers. The new owner plans to modernize the building.
Sol Schiff of New York retained top spot in the men's national table tennis ranking lists announced today, while Miss Emily Fuller of Bethlehem, Pa., rose a notch to stand first among the women.

The removal of restrictions that have for some years forbidden the compulsory teaching of religion in Christian schools in China was announced here today by Madame Chiang Kai-shek in an address before a gathering of 150 British and American missionaries.

The nominating committee of the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday selected Frank J. Knell for president to serve for one year. If elected at the annual meeting on June 6 he will succeed John C. Botts. Mr. Knell, who is with Lehman Brothers, is now vice president of the Cotton Exchange.

The Commission of Fine Arts announced today that it "heartily approves" the South Shore Tidal Basin site selected for - the proposed Thomas Jefferson Memorial but that it had "consistently opposed" the erection there of a pantheon type of building in the form designed for it by the late John Russell -Pope.

Multi-family dwellings formed the bulk of the trading in New Jersey announced yesterday. Wasyl Chelak bought from the estate of Anna Harty the four-family house at 158 St. Paul's Avenue, Jersey City, for cash, through J. I. Kislak, Inc., brokers. The new owner plans to modernize the building.
Sol Schiff of New York retained top spot in the men's national table tennis ranking lists announced today, while Miss Emily Fuller of Bethlehem, Pa., rose a notch to stand first among the women.

The removal of restrictions that have for some years forbidden the compulsory teaching of religion in Christian schools in China was announced here today by Madame Chiang Kai-shek in an address before a gathering of 150 British and American missionaries.

The nominating committee of the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday selected Frank J. Knell for president to serve for one year. If elected at the annual meeting on June 6 he will succeed John C. Botts. Mr. Knell, who is with Lehman Brothers, is now vice president of the Cotton Exchange.

Convinced at. long last that drastic measures were necessary to circumvent further humiliation of his champion Yankees, Joe McCarthy today gave the Ruppert forces a slight shaking up and shook out a neat but not gaudy victory.
A proposal by the West Shore Railroad to increase fares on ferryboats between Weehawken, N. J., and New York City, disclosed today by the Interstate Commerce Commission, quickly ran into opposition.

Juan T. Trippe, president and general manager of Pan American Airways, received last night the gold medal of the Holland Society of New York, given annually for outstanding achievement. The presentation was made by Walter M. Meserole, president, at the annual meeting of the society at the Hotel Astor, and was the first made by the group for achievements in air transport.

Irving E. Grosso, comedian, vaudeville actor and master of ceremonies, whose stage name was Irving Edwards, died on Monday night of a heart ailment in his home, 83-01 St. James Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens. He was 36 years old.

After one hour and eight minutes of deliberation last evening, a "blueribbon" jury convicted Mounted Patrolman Arthur H. Chalmers of second degree murder for the shooting of Miss Irma L. Pradier in his automobile on Harlem Speedway on July 20.

The government is expected to accept without demur the sweeping recommendations signed tonight by its investigating committee that there shall be a week's paid holiday each year for every British worker.

Twenty-seven hundred Boy Scouts will begin at 9 A. M., Saturday a search for Peter D. Levine, 12 years old, who was 'kidnapped near his home, 11 Slocum Street, New Rochelle, six weeks ago this afternoon.
Plans have been completed by Miss Christina Whitehouse Boardman for her marriage to Julian Gerard Buckley, which will take place here on the afternoon of April 26 in St. James Church.

The three-story garage building at 406-8 East Seventy-ninth Street, on p a plot 50 by 100 feet, has been leased by the Berbrow Garage Corportion, Meyer Berlin, president. Joseph G. Platzner negotiated the deal in cooperation with the Garage Trading Corporation.

The Union Bag and Paper Corporation may show for the first quarter of 1938 profits even larger than the $326,917 earned in the correspending period of 1937, according to Alexander Calder, president, who said yesterday that the bag business was holding up in volume at the levels which prevailed a year ago.

Governor Lehman today signed the Savings Bank Life Insurance Bill, for which he fought vigorously at the recent session of the Legislature, and hailed it as "a great social experiment which should be helpful to the lower income groups who now have to depend solely on industrial insurance."

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Ausonia, leaving today for London via Plymouth, includes Louis Armstrong, Mrs. Elsie Amelia Beer, Phillippe L. Dubois, Mrs. G. A. Cornish, Miss Georgia Cowan, H. R. Rogers and Mrs. H. A. Stanier.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 5: MAJOR GENERAL Conley, E. T., the Adjutant General, retired effective April 30, at age of 64 years. BRIGADIER GENERAL Truesdell, K., Fort Jay, N. Y., to command 12th Infantry Brigade, Fort Sheridan, Ill.
A strike which would tie up operations of Detroit's municipal street car and bus system was called tonight to begin at 4 A. M. (Eastern standard time) tomorrow.

The Insurgent occupation of Lerida and virtually the whole western bank of the Segre River foreshadows the early victorious termination of Spain's civil war, Generalissimo Francisco 'Franco declared following a meeting yesterday of his Cabinet at Burgos.

The new Negrin government has announced its determination to "continue to fight for the independence of Spain until it has been freed of the presence on the national soil of those who have attacked and invaded it in the most monstrous international complicity that has ever occurred."
The Hon. Justice Henry Hanna of the High Court of Ireland will be unable to make the trip to judge at the Morris and Essex Kennel Club show at Madison, N. J., on May 28, it was announced yesterday.
Thirteen members of the City Council, including its President, Newbold Morris, made a first-hand study of the seamy side of the housing situation on the East Side yesterday.

Production of steel ingots in the United States totaled 5,447,351gross tons in the first quarter of 1938, or 31.57 per cent of effective capacity. The output was the lowest for a three-month period since the final quarter of 1934, when production totaled 5,056,784 gross tons.

The first race of a series among Long Island Sound International Class sloops and one-design craft of the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club ended in a drifting match today, with none of the four contestants able to finish the eleven-mile course within the time limit of three and a half hours. Two contests are slated for tomorrow.

Harry Snyder, leader of the Snyder-African Expedition for the American Museum of Natural History, sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, accompanied by Mrs. Snyder and Colonel A. J. MacNab Jr., explorer, big-game hunter and former president of the Camp Fire Club of America.
Snow caused the postponement of two college baseball games scheduled to be played here yesterday and forced the cancellation of a third.

William Kay has been appointed sales director for Piel Brothers Brewery, succeeding K. D. Twyman, who has resigned, according to an announcement yesterday by William Piel, president. Mr. Kay has been divisional sales manager for the Joseph A. Schlitz Brewing Company of Milwaukee.

Trading was fair to slow. The lamb market, though somewhat uneven, was mostly weak to lower. Veal hindsaddles were steady to higher, fresh pork prices steady to lower, other classes steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef prices to be strong to higher; veal uneven, mostly steady; lamb weak, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The "Three Little Pigs," most popular of all the Walt Disney shorts is to be followed by a sequel, "The Practical Pig," which will feature not only the original cast but three newcomers, the three little wolves. Disney will continue his fairy tale series with "The Brave Little Tailor or Seven at One Blow," starring Mickey and Minnie Mouse.

Dr. Paul David Shafer of Milford, Conn., has been appointed principal of the Packer Collegiate Institute, Brooklyn, to succeed Dr. John H. Denbigh, it-was announced yesterday by Lewis W. Francis, president. He is 36 years old and will be the youngest head in the history of one of the oldest private schools in the city.

Wells A. Hall, Superintendent of Schools here for thirty-one years and a former president of the Massachusetts School Superintendents Association, died today at his home. His age was 60. He recently returned from the Emerson Hospital after an illness of several weeks.

The Co United States Trucking Corporation and its subsidiary, John J. Casale, Inc., applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue up to $300,000 each of equipment trust obligations, a total of $600,000.

Julius Streicher, Germany's No. 1 antiSemite, today issued his "First Reader," which he said in his newspaper, the Stuermer, was intended to instruct Germans in the Jewish question by pictures and stories easy to understand. It follows his "Primer" of last year.

Seasonal exports of Valencia oranges to the. United Kingdom-North Europe range, expected to approximate 2,000,000 boxes, were started from San Pedro today when the Donaldson Liner Parthenia took out 20,000 boxes.
An operation for appendicitis was performed at Doctors Hospital Tuesday on Henry A. Wise Wood, 74-year-old inventor and chairman of the board of directors of the Wood Newspaper Machinery Corporation.

Mrs. Marion R. Stern, in 1,120 Park Ave; Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc, brokers. Stephen V. Duffy, in 911 Park Ave.; Mrs. Stephen Conran, in 117 E 77th St; Virginia E. Kirkpatrick, in 249 E 56th St; Albert B. Ashforth, Inc, broker.

All livestock sold higher today on a market strengthened by snowstorms which curtailed receipts, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. In cattle, weighty fed steers gained most, top reaching $10.75 on weighty bullocks. Up to $9 was paid for hogs and lambs.

Attorney General Charles J. Margiotti served formal notice today on David L. Lawrence, chairman of the Democratic State Committee, that levying political assessments on State employes was "still criminal" in Pennsylvania. He added that the people "will not stand for it."

Even before the Constitutional Convention machinery has begun moving to turn out its grist of changes in the organic law of the State, leaders of both major parties in the body of delegates are giving thought to procedure which will insure a happy ending to the work of revising the State's charter.
Miss N. May Karff of Boston won her third-round game in the women's chess championship tournament at the R. C. A. Building last night, defeating Mrs. Edna Harrison, in twenty-three moves.

Solly Krieger of Brooklyn took another stride toward a chance at the middleweight title last night when he scored a technical knockout over Izzy Jannazzo of the East Side in the eleventh round of their scheduled twelve-round bout at the Hippodrome.

German steel production in the month of January passed for the first time that of the United States, according to the Reich statistical office. It gives the figures as Germany, 1,812,000 tons; United States, 1,760,000.
Mr. and Mrs. William F. Kenny today gave a farewell cocktail party at their home for their sonin-law and daughter, Captain and Mrs. Percy Lawson-Johnston, who will leave Monday for New York.

Eugene Quigley, lawyer, died suddenly here today while consulting a doctor about a heart ailment. His age was 60. He was senior partner of Quigley Byrnes. Mr. Quigley was a newspaper reporter before graduating from law school in 1903.

More than three hundred bundles of used articles have already been exchanged for tickets for the fashion show and tea to be held this afternoon at Delmonico's for the Mr. benefit of the Irvington House Thrift Shop.

The reappointment of Edward A. Kelleher as coach of Fordham varsity basketball was announced yesterday by John F. Coffey, graduate manager of athletics. He succeeds Vincent T. Cavanagh, former Fordham forward,

It cannot be said that Secretary Roper's reply to the questionnaire of visiting college students, on the cause and cure for the business reaction, added much to information already possessed by the business public.

Plans for numerous houses in Queens were filed yesterday. The largest of the projects will be undertaken in Rego Park, where a site on Queens Boulevard will be improved with four flats for 150 families to cost $2,502,000.

Two of the three men seized on Wednesday as material witnesses in the government's investigation of a German spy ring were identified yesterday by John F. Dailey, Acting United States Attorney, as members- of the - Ordnungsdienst, uniformed Nazi "service" corps of the German-American Bund, which was known as the Friends of the New Germany before it was investigated for un-American activities by a Congressional committee.

Sergeant Harley Palmerton, Company E, Sixteenth United States Infantry, died on Wednesday in the Station Hospital at Governors Island after a brief illness at the age of 49. Having served almost thirty years in the army, during the World War Sergeant Palmerton was a first sergeant with numerous high non-commissioned grades.

When the Dodgers check out of this West Coast training ground tomorrow at noon for another year--or perhaps longer--they will have in their midst the new John Thomas Winsett. By his own admissions or assertions, the lanky outfielder

City Relief Commissioner Frank E. Bubna released figures today indicating that nearly one-third of Cleveland's population was on relief, working with the WPA or in the process of getting into one category or the other.

The Rutgers rowing schedule will open on April 16, when the Scarlet varsity, junior varsity and freshman eights race the crews of Columbia and Manhattan on the Harlem River in New York, beginning at 2:30 P. M., George E. Little, director of athletics, announced today. Three other-regattas are on the list.
Austria was today ordered placed on the government's tariff "black list," effective May 6, by President Roosevelt in view of her absorption by Germany.

A double-edged emergency recovery program, intended to end the present business recession, and involving the transfusion of $1,500,000,000 more of public funds into the arteries of trade and industry, is expected to be disclosed by President Roosevelt in a series of recommendations to Congress within a few days.

The Rev. Martin Niemoeller, dissident Protestant pastor, is no longer in a concentration camp. He was removed Monday from a camp at Sachsenhausen to Alexanderplatz police prison and will be released or transferred to honorable "fortress imprisonment."

Judge Robert A. Inch, in the Federal Court, Brooklyn, denied yesterday a motion of Leo B. Lebovitz, attorney representing Albert Marinelli, former County Clerk of New York County, for a dismissal of an indictment against Marinelli charging him with harboring Charles

Mr. and Mrs. Robert De Vecchi of 120 East End Avenue and Miss Gigiotta Bertalli gave a dinner last night at the De Vecchi home for the Misses Muriel Gerli, Peggy Sykes and Diana Gerli, and their respective fiances, Nelson Macy Jr., Walter P. Chrysler Jr. and Daniel

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended April 6 were announced today: COLONELS Berry, B. S., Philadelphia, Pa., to Quantico, Va., June 20. Wells, C. H., on Aug. 1 ordered from Philadelphia, Pa., to home, to retire Oct. 1.

Ten "reading copies" of Charles Dickens's works, from which he gave his public readings, brought $29,875 yesterday afternoon at the auction of the library of the late Cortlandt F. Bishop at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries. Inc.

Earnings of the Consolidated Oil Corporation last year were the largest in the history of the company. The 1937 net profit amounted to $20,809,295, an increase of -$4,080,366 over the preceding year, according to H. F. Sinclair, chairman of the executive committee, who submitted the annual statement to stockholders.

The best way for Americans to strengthen the peace structure of the world, Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick, editorial writer of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said last night in a symposium on "Is There a Way to World Peace?" at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, "is to- strengthen our own democracy and make it work."

Michael J. Kobrin, formerly manager of the Chicago office of Calvert Distilling Corporation, has been appointed vice president and general sales manager of Hunter Baltimore Rye Distillery, Inc., Baltimore, Md., effective May 1,

On April 21 the hundredth anniversary of the birth of the American naturalist, John Muir, will be celebrated. To commemorate the centenary, Houghton Mifflin will publish on May 3 "John Muir of the Mountains," Muir's hitherto unpublished journals covering a fortytwo-year period from 1869 to 1911.
Lumber output declined slightly less than seasonally last week and the adjusted index rose to 62.4 from 61.9. The figure was 85.3 for the week ended April 3, 1937.

Two reels of "Beloved Enemy," a motion picture about the Irish rebellion of 1916, were stolen today from a messenger by armed men. It was the second effort within a month by gun-carrying movie "censors" to prevent a film from playing in Ireland.

Heavy rains which greeted the Giant-Indian entourage as it moved in here during the night wiped out one game of this blistering exhibition series today, ands that was extremely unfortunate in many respects.
