The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

Princeton retained the intervarsity championship trophy in the annual Rugby week finale today by defeating Yale, 6--0. Princeton is the only team to win two years in succession, Captain Salsich scored a penalty goal in the first half and in the second session Bokum made an unconaverted try.

The United States ought to take up colonizing, according to Dr. Charles T. Loram, who is head of the Yale University Department of Race Relations and who for thirty years was in the British colonial service.

During the five weeks of March awards for engineering construction showed a weekly average 32 per cent greater than for the four weeks of the same month last year, according to the Engineering News-Record.

After more than twelve hours of jumbled, noisy rehearsals and a final dress rehearsal at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon and night, the necessary tempo of clocklike precision had been established for tonight's opening of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus.

Japanese interests have offered to buy into a strategic Mexican oil company, it was disclosed tonight. Jorge Viesca y Palma, an attorney who. said he was the principal stockholder of the Chontla Company which he organized two years ago, said Japanese had offered to buy all or part of his holdings.
New York's freakish April snowstorm, which brought sorrow and hunger to the robins and joy to New Jersey and Long Island fire wardens, was rapidly disappearing down the sewers last night.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent of the voting trust certificates for the Class B stock of the Fifth Madison Corporation. W. T. Bonn Co. has been formed at 120 Broadway to transact a general brokerage and investment business.

Dr. Pacific George W. Geyer, who had practiced medicine in this city twentyeight years, died at his home in West Philadelphia last night. His age was 57. Born in Pittsburgh, he was graduated from the University of Pennsylvania Medical School in 1902.

For the second time this year the New York Curb Exchange is cutting the salaries of its employes. Effective tomorrow, employes earning more than $25 a week will take a 10 per cent reduction. Earlier this year all salaries larger than $15 a week were cut by 10 to 15 per cent.

With suburbanites still affected by the weather handicaps resulting from Wednesday's snowfall, retail trade here did not "snap back" appreciably yesterday. However, the the situation is not expected to have material effect on trade tomorrow,
Senator Van Nuys, Deinocrat, of Indiana, said today that he had "practically decided"' to ignore the Indiana Demrocratic primary and seek re-election as a straight-out' independent.
Blue Zip a gray gelding owned and ridden by Miss Bruna Hunneman of Philadelphia, today captured the hunter championship, opening-day feature of the annual Aiken Fair and Horse Show.

Ira E. Goldstein, former vice president of A. Robinson Co., has become associated with L. V. Hoffman Co., Inc., as vice president in charge of sales and management. Arthur A. Jones, who will specialize in FHA insured mortgages and building loans has opened offices at 330 West Forty-second Street.
The Long Island Sound International Class sloops and the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club one-design craft finished all square today in the first two races of their best-offive series.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated April.6: COLONELS Somers, R. H., Ordnance Dept., two months' leave, Sept. 16, with permission to visit foreign countries.
The four-story dwelling at 62 West Eighty-third Street, between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue, was leased by Emil Scharf to a client of E. C. Whittington, broker.

After several weeks of erratic price movements, the bond market yesterday lapsed into the doldrums with the volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange dwindling to the smallest turnover of the year for a five-hour session.

Miss Nancy Phillips, daughter of Thomas Wharton Sampson Phillips of this place, was married this afternoon to Dr. Alvin Wilcox Howland of Philadelphia, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Alvin Howland of Adrian, Mich., at the home of her father here. The Rev. Dr. William T.

Plans for "the largest garden apartment community in the country," to occupy a site of 120 acres in the Bronx, were announced yesterday by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, sponsors of the project.

Pensioned On his own application-To take effect 12 midnight, April 15: CAPTAIN Byron R. Sackett, 50th Precinct, at $2,950 per annum. Appointed Oct. 31, 1896. Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., April 8: PATROLMEN from precincts indicated to Emergency Service Division:

A large group of visitors watched 212 students of the New York Institute for- the Education of the Blind, 999 Pelham Parkway, the Bronx, demonstrate yesterday their skill in molding objects of a wide variety and their artistry in music, dance and sculpture.
A tornado cut a path of death. suffering and tremendous property damage across a wide area along the Alabama-Mississippi boundary today while a cold wave and floods beset other section of the South.

During the week ended April 6 member bank reserve balances decreased $16,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $65,000,000 in money in circulation, $3,000,000 in Treasury cash and $15,000,000 in non-member deposits

Relief recipients who had been hoping for a refund of their 10 per cent cut by the city were disappointed yesterday when the Board of Estimate voted down a resolution to that effect offered by James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx.

Reluctantly but definitely the Japanese people are beginning to realize the results of their .naval policy of secrecy and non-cooperation. Secretary of State Cordell Hull's letter to the Naval Affairs Committee of the United States Senate is being read along with his speech of March 17 and combined they furnished unmistakable evidence of what the press calls a new, more positive policy.

Reorganization of the committee of steamship executives which has functioned for the last six years in the administration of welfare work among merchant seamen was effected yesterday afternoon at a meeting in the office of Herbert L. Satterlee, 40 Wall Street.
Mr. Miss and Mrs. Louis V. Keeler of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty P. Keeler, to Harry H. Kuck Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Kuck of Savannah, Ga.

MANHATTAN BORMANN, EMMA M. (March 22). Estate, $30,000. To Emma Louisa Price, 130 W. 227th St., $8,000; Anna M. Darran, sister, 38 Van Corlear Pl., household, personal effects, $8,000 and residue; Mary E. Selfried, niece, Virginia Ave., Easton, Pa.; Harry E. Seibel, nephew, 2,068 Bathgate Ave., Bronx, $2,000 each; Charles J. Seibel, nephew, 427 Cattell St., Easton, Pa., and Elizabeth Seibel,
Miss Helen Hull Jacobs revealed tonight she recently had published a novel, "Barry Cort," under the pen name of H. Braxton Hull-and there isn't a single word about tennis in it.

George Bonar, Scottish industrialist and philanthropist, died on Wednesday in Dundee, Scotland, according to word received here yesterday. He was 687 years old. Prominent in the burlap and linen industry, Mr. Bonar was president of White Lamb Finlay, Inc., linen importers, of New York, and was titular head of Low Bonar, Ltd.,

That the Yankees are ready to start the season without Joe DiMaggio, their star center fielder, and that the club's offer of a $25,000 salary will not be changed were the declaration of Colonel Jacob Ruppert, club president, yesterday when his attention was called to a news dispatch from San Francisco

All the zip went out of the livestock market today. Shipping demand faded away on fed steers and yearlings as well as hogs, and prices closed at the low point of the session. Downturns on fed steers and yearlings about wiped out Wednesday's advance and the recent bearish attitude again prevailed, the United States Department of Agriculture reported.

The men's clothing division of the Joint Distribution and United Palestine Appeal, beginning a campaign for funds for the relief of European Jews and their rehabilitation in Palestine, raised $35,000 at a luncheon conference in the Aldine Club yesterday.

One of the many concerti gross" of Vivaldi for strings, heard for the first time here, opened the program of the concert given by John Barbirolli and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall.

Plans are being made to liquidate the affairs of Wrenn Brothers Co., Wall Street brokerage house. No date for dissolution of the firm has been set and arrangements to have partners go with other concerns are not yet in final form.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, Wilmington, Del., asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for an order declaring it and certain of its subsidiary companies not to be subsidiaries of the United Corporation within the meaning of the Public Utility Holding Company Art of 1935.

German authorities throughout South America are feverishly completing arrangements for German and Austrian nationals to participate in Sunday's plebiscite in favor of the Reich's annexation of Austria.

Senator Austin of Vermont is to be congratulated for persuading the Senate to strike out the whole "punitive" section of the air mail law which has ostracized pioneers and leaders in air transport from activity in that field since 1934.
Nicolas Petrescu-Comnen, the new Foreign Minister, outlined his policy to the foreign press today.

John J. Orpheus, retired lieutenant of the New York City Police Department, died Wednesday at his home, 34-34 Thirty-fourth Street, Astoria, Queens. Mr. Orpheus was assigned to the Glendale precinct fifteen years ago when he retired after twenty-five years on the force.

J. L. Kraft, president of the Kraft-Phenix Cheese Corporation, has been appointed a director of Stokely Bros. Co., Inc., of Indianapolis for the unexpired term of John W. Hanes, who recently was appointed to the SEC.

Testifying yesterday in the injunction suit against Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Isaac Penner, electrical contractor, told of appealing in vain to city officials to stop the sabotage and discrimination he had suffered "at the hands of Local 3."

The increase of $65,000,000 in the total of money in circulation reported in this week's Federal Reserve figures is considerably in excess of normal and undoubtedly will be taken as supporting the reports of a renewal of hoarding in certain sections of the country.

The Rev. Dr. U. Franklin Smiley, pastor of the Dormont Presbyterian Church and chairman of the executive committee of the Pittsburgh Presbytery, died tonight after an illness of several weeks. He was 69 years old.
Great Britain accepted today the proposal of the United States for the creation of an intergovernmental committee to facilitate the emigration of political refugees from Austria and Germany.

The Bank of the Manhattan Company reported, as of March 31, total deposits of $55,477,944 and total assets of $612,951,711, compared, respectively, with $504,800,925 and $566,271,489 on Dec. 31, last.

Dissolution of the firm of -Blake Brothers. Co. and the decision of Howland S. Davis, its senior partner, to make himself available to the New York Stock Exchange as a paid executive of its business conduct committee were announced yesterday.

Brooklyn trading yesterday consisted of deals involving several residential properties. Quincy Housing Corporation sold the five-story house on a plot 50 by 100 feet, at 281 Quincy Street, to the Mutual Housing Corporation. The building accommodates twentyfive families, and carries an assessed valuation of $48,000.

The Official Gazette publishes today the "Fuehrer's list for the election of the Greater German Reichstag on April 10, 1938"--the only list to be submitted to the voter, which he must endorse in its entirety,

Guy Dudley Hiscox, purchasing agent and former director of the Pacific Coast Borax Company of New York, died yesterday at his home here after a three-week illness. His age was 71. His wife, Mrs. Anna S. Hiscox, died a week ago.

More than 140 swimming stars from sixteen States and the District of Columbia splashed through Ohio State University's pool today in final tune-up jaunts for the national A. A. U. senior championships tomorrow and Saturday.
Stockholders of the Camden Safe Deposit and Trust Company and the West Jersey Trust Company approved today a merger under the name of the Camden Trust Company.

Paul Fielden, president of the National Association of Credit Men, said tonight that there is plenty of credit available in the United States. What business needs now is not more credit but the opportunity to use the available credit, he said.
Sponsors of the Sunnyside Day Nursery gave the first benefit of any kind to be held by the organization in its fifty-six years of existence yesterday in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's.

An increase of almost $2,000,000 in notes in circulation was shown today in the statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday. The ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities was 56.46 per cent, against 55.60 a week before.

The "Good Neighbor" idea as a reciprocal policy was advocated by Secretary Hull tonight in extending greetings to the republics of the Western Hemisphere at a musical at the Pan American Union held in observance of the annual Pan American Day.

Mrs. Robert M. Glenn, widow of a former treasurer of the Academy of the New Church, Bryn Athyn, and mother-in-law of Raymond Pitcairn, lawyer, architect and national chairman of the Sentinels of the Republic, died at her home in Bryn Athyn yesterday. Her age was 73.

The large number of unnecessary deaths from appendicitis despite the fact that it is an easily recognizable disease and the methods for treating it are becoming increasingly satisfactory, was criticized yesterday before the annual meeting of the American College of Physicians, at the Waldorf Astoria, by Professor Reginald Fitz of the Boston University School of Medicine.

George R. Jacobus, president of the Professional Golfers Association, returned from the South yesterday with a soft denial to Gene Sarazen's charge that politics and favoritism kept him from being captain of the Ryder Cup team.
Miss Rosalyn Aminta Pate was Din married to Lieutenant Thomas Herbert Beck here last night by Episcopal Bishop Harry Beal in St. Luke's Cathedral at Ancon.

American Association for Social Security, eleventh annual national conference will begin at Hotel Astor this morning at 10 o'clock and continue tomorrow. Morning, afternoon and evening sessions today.

Sir Abe Bailey, 73-year-old South African mining man, announced today that an emergency operation performed on him Tuesday had been for amputation of his second leg. His general condition is satisfactory.

The Newark Evening News was announced here today as the winner of the Francis Wayland Ayer Cup, offered annually by N. W. Ayer Son, Inc., to the daily newspaper chosen as the most outstanding for typographical excellence.

The First Boston Corporation received the award yesterday of a new issue of $430,000 of school district bonds of Allentown, Pa., on a bid of 100.381 for 1 3/4s. The bonds, which will mature serially from. May 2, 1939 to 1943, have been placed privately.

The ice is out on Sebago Lake, up in Maine, and the Spring exodus is on. We received word yesterday that ideal fishing conditions should prevail on Sebago over this weekend, but those who had planned to drive up will be delayed a bit by the snow.

Dr. Herman Chen-en Liu, president of Shanghai University, who was shot to death in Shanghai yesterday by gunmen, knew that his life was in danger as early as last November, it was revealed yesterday at the headquarters here of the Northern Baptist Convention.

Developments yesterday in the proposal for a $100,000 match race between War Admiral and Seabiscuit, the two outstanding thoroughbreds of the country, indicated that the New York area had veto power on the meeting, and that if the race is to be held at all it will be in the metropolitan district.
Three more Senators, including one Republican, agreed today to serve on the Congressional committee to investigate the TVA, but one vacancy continued to delay Organization of the inquiry.

Massachusetts Institute of Technology is heading toward a new season of rowing under the direction of a new coach and with new hopes for a return of the winning crews which have worn the colors of the great engineering school in the past.

Compulsory incorporation of trade unions, long opposed by organized labor, will go into effect in Quebec Province as a result of a bill introduced by Premier Maurice Duplessis himself and passed today by the Legislative Assembly after a heated debate.

For the fifth successive year, the Radio City Music Hall converted its stage into a medieval cathedral for the presentation of the religious spectacle, "The Glory of Easter," which is the feature of its holiday stage show. The pageant, produced by Leon Leonidoff,

Competing with more than 270 designs submitted by architectural designers and engineers of this country, Canada, Great Britain, France, the Netherlands, Sweden and other countries, Walter W. W. Jones, 33 years old, a designer in the office of the Borough President of Manhattan, won yesterday a $1,000 third prize in a contest sponscored by the American Institute of Steel Construction.

With a clean-cut victory over Walter B. Suesman of Cranston, R./I., last night in the fifth round of the United States chess championship in progress at Rockefeller Center, Samuel Reshevsky, title-holder, maintained his lead at the head of seventeen competitors with a score of 4 1/2 points out of 5.

Strong words were used by Dr. James H. Means of Harvard in his presidential address to the American College of Physicians in disapproving the American Medical Association's social outlook. "The behavior of the Association is political."

The University of Maryland's lacrosse squad scored its eighteenth straight collegiate victory today with an easy 11-2 triumph over Harvard on a wet field. Both of the Crimson markers came in the third quarter on singlehanded shots by Halstead and Hunsaker.

Hospital Liquids, Inc. medications, in 531535 5th Ave; the Cross Brown Co, broker. John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Co., in 342 Madison Ave: Herbert McLean Purdy Management Corp, broker. James A. Drilling Co, precious stones, Lustig Bailey, jewelers, in 2 W 46th St; Albert M. Greenfield Co, Inc, brokers. Four Walls, Inc. interior decorator, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc, store in 685 Madison Ave; Mrs. Edward Stout. Inc. broker.

Total carloadings in twenty-nine major commodity lines in the second quarter of this year will be 589,381 originating in the States of New York, New Jersey, Pensylvania, Maryland, Delaware and the Eastern Shore of Virginia, a decrease of-16.2 per cent from a year

The S. S. Kresge Company, Detroit, filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1932 covering 1,200,000 shares of $10 par value common stock. No public offering is contemplated at this time.

The design on the 1-cent George Washington stamp of the new series was disclosed today by Postmaster General Parley. Vertical in form, and printed in greer ink with a flat background with no border, the stamp is 0.75 by 0.87 inches in size.

No more intense struggle has been waged in this Administration's history than over the contention that new Federal money was required to combat the recession. For months the President has sat in judgment on the battle of viewpoints, reluctant from first to last to ask Congress to authorize a new government

Financial difficulties have involved the Alexander Hamilton Hotel of this city in two court actions. Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan in Jersey City Chancery Court yesterday appointed Daniel O'Regan, prosecutor of Hudson County, and Harry B. Haines,

It is comforting, somehow, to realize that, no matter what we might think about April snows and raw winds, -the Rockefellers still are bullish about Easter. Either with more imagination than we had credited them with, or with less, they formally opened the Eastertide at the Music Hall yesterday.

As soon as the Department of Sanitation can purchase new welltype scows it will begin to dump refuse at Jamaica Bay and will stop operations on Riker's Island, whose dump heaps are to be landescaped for the World's Fair. This was announced yesterday by John B. Morton, acting commissioner.

Seventeen defendants were sentenced to jail terms or fined today in the Federal Government's case against a bootleg liquor ring that worked through the Eastern States. Benjamin R. Fogel, described during the trial as the leader of the ring which was charged with defrauding the Federal Government of $20,000,000 in taxes, was sentenced by Judge Albert B. Maris to eighteen months in the Federal Penitentiary at Lewisburg and was fined $10,000.

Flower Hujer and Ivan Kashkevich, two young dancers from the Pacific Coast, made their New York debut on Wednesday evening in a recital at the Town Hall. In spite of the foreign flavor of their names, they are both American born and pa received their training in this country at the hands of Theodore Kosloff and Michio Ito.

High scool courses in shop work, typewriting, cooking and sewing today were unanimously raised to the academic dignity of Latin, history and mathematics in so far as the, standings of the 2,728 high schools of twenty Central States holding membership in the North Central Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools are concerned.
A value of $1,500,884 was set on the estate of Louis Blaustein, a leader in the oil industry, in inventories filed today in the Orphans Court. His will provided for a $500,000 charitable foundation,
First-of-the-month settlements bolstered bank clearings in the opening week of April. Although the volume was 24.7 per cent

Mr. and Mrs. Henry K. Harding entertained with a dinner tonight at their residence. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Fatio, Mr. and Mrs. Aksel Wichfeld, Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Huntington, Mr. and Mrs. George Ryan, Mrs. Wesson Seyburn and Paulding Fosdick.

Street manifestations with several thousand militant adherents of the Socialist Party shouting and parading as near as they could get to the Senate Building added another complication today to France's already complicated political situation.

The Senate voted approval today of most of the important provisions of the 1938 revenue bill as drafted by its finance committee. Under the guidance of Senator Harrison, chairman of the committee, the chamber voted overwhelmingly to eliminate the undistributed profits tax, to put a flat tax on capital gains, to leave untouched the present law as to gift and estate taxes and to exempt securities

Federal funds amounting to $70,920,000 were earmarked today by Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, for thirteen cities participating in the government's $500,000,000 slum clearance and low-rent housing program.

Jockey Johnny Adams of Iola, Kan., established a California record for consecutive victories today when he rode the winners in six successive races at Bay Meadows. Adams, the nation's leading jockey last year, started his parade of winners in the third race with Miss Amie, paying $19.60.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, called upon organized labor in Pennsylvania today to defeat Thomas Kennedy, candidate for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination, on the ground that the Lieutenant Governor was John L. Lewis's "Charlie McCarthy."

Plans for nation-wide programs to foster travel, under the direction of the United States Tourist Bureau, and for a United States Travel Board to advise on these programs, were outlined yesterday in a statement by James W. Gerard, collaborator of the National Park Service in the work of the Tourist Bureau.

Barcelona's largest power plant fell to General Franco's forces yesterday when Tremp was occupied. A dash of five miles won this success before sluice gates could be opened to flood the Rebels. Other columns pushed toward three remaining plants.

The Yankees arrived today, stopped here long enough to enjoy breakfast, then moved right on to Tulsa, where they are scheduled to resume their exhibition program tomorrow. Overnight mist, snow and a rain and sleet storm, accompanied by a sharp drop in temperature, forced cancellation of today's scheduled

Net sales of Russeks Fifth Avenue, Inc., -for the twelve months ended on Feb. 26 increased to $5,928,930 from $5,658,007 for the thirteen months ended on Feb. 27, 1937, according to the annual pamphlet report to be made public today by Max Weinstein, president.

Representatives of fifty foreign trade associations and industrial groups of the city met at a luncheon in India House yesterday and decided to focus this year's observance of National Foreign Trade Week, May 22 to 28, on a city wide recognition of the Port of New York.

A long and precise catalogue of German and Italian siege artillery, mounted on both sides of the Strait of Gibraltar, was given to the House of Lords today by Lord Faringdon, Laborite, who said he had received the information from an authoritative and reliable source.

Mrs. Christina Matthiesen, whose 18-year-old daughter, Charlotte, was killed, in an unfulfilled double suicide pact, agreed yesterday to testify for the defense in the trial of Donald Carroll Jr., 16, for the murder of her daughter.
Police Commissioner Valentine said yesterday that it would be impossible to grant the Socialist party a permit to hold a May Day meeting at the north end of Union Square from 11 A. M. to 3 P. M.

Retail prices of food rose in the month ended on March 15, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1923-1925 average as 100, was 78.6, compared with 78.4 on Feb. 15 and 85.4 on March 16, 1937.
Net asset value of the Lehman Corporation on March 31 was $51,880,317, equivalent to $24.92 a share on 2,081,580 capital shares, compared with $60,942,826, or $29.28 a share, on Dec. 31, 1937,

New capital stock of the Babcock Wilcox Company will be admitted to unlisted trading on the New York Curb Exchange today in substitution for the old capital stock, which will be suspended from dealings at the opening of the market.

Mayor Richard W. Reading announced early today that the strike of operators of the Municipal Street Car System has been settled. The Mayor said that he expected trolley service to be restored before noon and that buses would continue to run.

The Wadsworth-Livingston bill removing age limitations on civil service jobs probably will double the number of applicants for examinations for many city jobs, and will make New York a refuge for persons turned out by private industry because of age, Paul J. Kern,

Two men convicted on March 30 of conspiracy to violate the Sanitary Code by selling artificially colored cottonseed oil labeled as "pure olive oil," were sentenced yesterday in Special Sessions Court, Brooklyn.

Warren W. Clute, president of the Watkins Salt Company and the Watkins Glen National Bank, died at his Winter home in Miami Beach, Fla., early today of a heart attack, according to reports reaching here. His age was 73. Mr.
Senator Duffy of Wisconsin named today these five plans by which, he said, the government was trying to end the business recession:

Lester Patrick, manager of the New York Rangers, said today he had given Butch Keeling, veteran left winger, his unconditional release. Keeling played ten seasons with the Rangers in the National Hockey League.

Washington ended an eight-game losing streak to major-league teams today, beating the Boston Bees, 5 to 4. Although he was the losing pitcher, Jim Turner allowed only one Senator to reach base after the second inning, and then he picked him off. Wesley Ferrell hurled eight innings for Washington and gave nine hits.

Negotiations were completed yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company for the engagement of Hans W. Steinberg, one of the conductors of the Palestine Orchestra Association and a Jewish exile from Germany, to aid Arturo Toscanini next season in preparing the NBC Symphony Orchestra for the which Italian maestro's broadcasts, it was announced.

James S. Burke head of the Third Order of St. Francis at the Church of St. Francis of Assisi, 135 West Thirty-first Street, died suddenly yesterday in the order's offices. Mr. Burke, who lived at 100 East Eighth Street, Brooklyn, was 53 years old.

Having each won two games and drawn two others, Harold L. Crane, Princeton, '40, and Edward N. Lorenz, Dartmouth, '38, were tied for the lead with totals of 3--1 at the close of play in the annual tournament for the individual championship of the H. Y. P. D. College Chess League at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Eadie Way, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis G. Way of East Glastonbury, to Richard Gordon Williams, son of Richard S. Williams of Glastonbury, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The Rey.

The United States Golf Association is thinking over a proposal to exempt former national open champions from sectional qualifying rounds, but can do nothing about it before this year's open in Denver, June 9-11, The Associated Press reports.

ACTS OF BLACK NIGHT, by Kathleen Moore Knight. (Crime Club, $2.) A mystery novel. AIDS TO HORSEMANSHIP, by C. H. Burns. (McBride, $2.50.) Information and advice on training, managing and riding horses.

A practice round-robin polo tournament was held at Squadron A Armory last night in which the Optimists, preparing for the final of their three-game high-goal championship series with the New York A. C. tomorrow night, played against the Hussars and Squadron A.

The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Lee Boyce, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Heyward E. Boyce of Roland Park, to Charles Clough, son of Mrs. Charles S. Clough and the late Clough of Jacksonville, Fla., has been announced.

L. O. Head, president of the Railway Express Agency, Inc., reported at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that the agency's business was holding up remarkably well considering general business conditions. The company is handling virtually as many shipments each month as it was a year ago, he said, but revenue is about 10 per cent below last year's receipts.
The Pabst Blue Ribbon Beer team of Chicago rolled a 3,036 game tonight in the American Bowling Congress and moved into fourth place in the five-man team standings.

Charles Izard, 18 years old, of 33 Central Avenue, St. George, S. I., a runner for the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, and an ardent amateur chess player, committed suicide by drinking poison yesterday in the woods behind 355 Ridgewood Avenue, Eltingville, S.I., according to the police. The motive was not determined.

The navy announced today that the new submarine Salmon would sail April 18 from New London, Conn., on its shakedown cruise. Under command of Lieutenant M. M. Stephens, the submarine will visit New York, Guantanamo, Cuba; Curacao, West Indies; Brownsville, Texas; Mobile, Ala.; Havana, Annapolis, Md.;

Suzanne Valadon, mother of the impressionist painter Maurice Utrillo and herself a noted painter, died today. Suzanne Valadon was born in Paris in 1869 and as a young girl ran away from home to become an acrobat and artist's model in the Latin Quarter.

Stephen Yerkes McNair, formerly cashier of the Home Title Guaranty Company and secretary of the Fifth Avenue Savings and Loan Association, died yesterday in Brooklyn Hospital of pneumonia. He was 72 years old.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler broke ground today near the frontier town of Wals for the first Austro-German automobile road. After listening to speeches by local Nazi authorities and Chief Engineer Todt, in charge of the construction of the road, he told the latter:

At the Cruising Club's dinner in the Yale Club last night Herbert L. Stone chairman of the Bermuda race committee, listed an indicated record fleet for the contest across the Gulf Stream which will start from Newport on June 20.
An unbroken series of Administration victories by margins sometimes small marked the preliminary skirmishes in the House today over the Reorganization Bill.

As of April 5, holders of $1,547,500 of city of Cordoba 7s, due on Oct. 1, 1957, or 36.4 per cent of the total outstanding, had signed an authorization to demand the advancement of the maturity of the bonds, according to the bondholders' committee headed by Fred J. Young of F. J. Young Co., Inc.

Radu Irimescu, new Rumanian Minister to the United States, arrived yesterday on the Italian liner Saturnia with Mme. Irimescu. They proceeded later to Washington. The diplomat denied that any special movement against the Jews was being carried on in Rumania.

Columbia University received cash gifts in March totaling $401,601, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, announced yesterday. The largest contribution, made public last Tuesday, was $250,000 from the Carnegie Corporation to the School of Library Service,

The New York University freshman football team will engage in four games next Fall, it was announced yesterday by Albert B. Nixon, graduate manager of athletics. Three of the contests will be played at home with yearling teams from Lafayette, Rutgers and Fordham providing the opposition at Ohio Field.

After a tense two-hour meeting that was frequently interrupted by jeers, heckling and name-calling, the united front of New York City's 40,000 teachers, formed in 1924, came to an end yesterday afternoon when the joint committee of teachers' organizations voted to oust the Teachers Union from its ranks. The meeting was held at the Hotel Commodore.
The modern Briton's so-called "passive resistance" to war has spelled failure for the voluntary system of recruiting for air-raid defense.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today the following proceedings were had: 843-Harry Cohen, petr., v. State of Maryland. Motion to withhold order denying petition for writ of certiorari submitted for the petr.

Under pressure of the steadily growing fascist movement, the Cabinet has decided to introduce Wednesday a bill regulating the employment of Jews. It will establish a ratio-believed to be eighty to twenty--between non-Jews and Jews in all occupations.

Making his first start of the year today, H. P. Metcalf's High Velocity answered Charlie Corbett's urging to open a gap in the stretch and go on to annex the featured La Plata Handicap, Opposed by six horses in the mile-and-seventy-yard contest, High -Velocity finished three lengths ahead of A. C. Compton's Vicar, the favorite, and another length in advance of Mrs. Emil Denemark's Swahili.

Compilation of a list of ten "unfair" independent. millinery jobbers who have refused to cooperate in the drive to eliminate "sweatshop conditions" in the industry and the inauguration of a move to have the retail syndicates pledge themselves in writing to buy only from those
The Windsor Company today was awarded an army contract for 270,000 cotton huck towels under Invitation 205, at 7.43 cents each net. Under the same invitation,
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt went Easter shopping yesterday morning and bought two ensembles. She wasted no time doing it. A speedy shopper, Mrs. Roosevelt made her purchases within fifty minutes.

North Carolina defeated Cornell's tennis team, 5 to 0, today in a match cut short by rain. It was the New Yorkers' first defeat on their Southern trip. Previously they had beaten North Carolina State and Wake Forest.

Mrs. Maryon Cooper Hewitt of 7 Park Avenue filed a petition in bankruptcy in Federal court yesterday, listing liabilities of $693,000 and assets of $250, exclusive of assets of unknown value and her exempt interest in the estate of the late Peter Cooper Hewitt.

The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today an application of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company for a loan for railroad maintenance not to exceed $778,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation on condition that the money be used only for the purposes specified.
Arnaud C. Marts of New York and Plainfield, N. J., today accepted the presidency of Bucknell University, which he has served two and a half years as acting president.

SECOND MILITARY AREA Each of the following reserve officers, unassigned, is assigned to the organization indicated: 77th Division-2d Lt. Karl E. Osenlund, Inf.-Res., 217 E. 176th St., New York City; 2d Lt. Joseph A. Callahan, Inf.Res., 91-43 79th St., Woodhaven, L. I. Coast Artillery Reserves-2d Lt. Richard E. Nodell, C.A.-Res., 64 Pansy Ave., Floral Park, L. I.

Secretary Hull's program for reciprocal trade agreements offers the only practicable alternative to economic and political isolationism, Which would lead ultimately to totalitarianism, Dr. Henry F. Grady,
Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal: Deposit Insurance Corporation, announced tonight that the corporation's surplus had passed $100,000,000.

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh today flew to France on an undisclosed mission. They flew from Lympne airport to St. Inglebert, in Brittany, and took off from there after a brief stop for an unannounced destination.

Reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City bought $96,000,000 of United States Government securities in the week ended on Wednesday, according to their weekly condition statement, issued yesterday. The increase followed five successive weeks of declines in the reporting banks' holdings of "governments" and was the largest single week's advance in the item in many months.
Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt returned yesterday from Miami. Mrs. William Bowne Parsons will give a luncheon today in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre.

The Federal Trade Commission issued a complaint today against Merck Co., Inc., laboratory. and chemical manufacturer, alleging that it discriminated in price between different purchasers buying its products
Repeal of a rule covering the publication of bond quotations was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange's committee on bonds.

Climaxing a long quarrel with the Third Avenue Railway Company over fare reductions and the substitution of buses for all trolley cars, the city of New Rochelle moved today on three fronts to have the fares cut in two and to terminate the virtual monopoly the company has held for more than fifty years through its "perpetual" franchises.

" Please help my buddies out of Spain." Having succeeded in escaping across the frontier at Cerbere, John Gordon Honeycombe, 37 years old, of Ilion, N. Y., twice wounded, made this plea today on behalf of those of his American comrades who have survived the offensive of General Francisco Franco.

Miss Dorothie E. Berry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Berry of New Brunswick, Canada, has chosen April 16 as the date of her marriage to Ernest A. Knoblauch Jr. of this place, son of Mrs. Ernest A. Knoblauch of Washington and Miami and the late Mr. Knoblauch. he late Mr. Knoblauch.

The engagement of $2,100,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank. This lifted the total of gold taken in England since to March 15 to $27,700,000, and increased the aggregate of engagements of the metal from all countries since Feb. 24, $62,200,000.
With a high northeast wind blowing over the covers of the English Setter Club of America grounds today, there was little enthusiasm on the part of the limited gallery on the hilltop for field trials.

The will of henry Ware Putnam, Chambers Street hardware merchant, who died at Miami Beach, Fla., aged 73, on March 30 last, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday, disclosed a bequest of $3,000,000 to the Henry W. Putnam Memorial Hospital at Bennington, Vt., which was founded by his father. He was unmarried.

Nickolas Muray, Dr. Ervin Acel, Bela de Nagy and Ralph Marson, home club stars, gained four of the eight places in the semi-final round at the metropolitan qualifying trials for the national saber championship at the New York Athletic Club last night.

One fireman was fatally stricken at a fire today which drove out eighty-five nuns and children and razed the Holy Family Institute, home convent of the Sisters of the Presentation. Sparks, driven by a high wind, menaced neighboring property and started a forest fire half a mile away. An investigation by the State Fire Marshal's office is in progress.
The Commerce Department reported today that the total sales of chain men's wear stores in 1937 were about 1 per cent lower than in 1936.

Two of New York's leading accountants differed today at a hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission as to proper methods of entering items on railroad balance sheets, thus raising a question of the adequacy of certain widely used accounting methods which must be passed upon by the commission.

President Roosevelt conferred with J. J. Pelley of the American Association of Railroads on the railroad situation and with Harry L. Hopkins and Aubrey Williams of the Works Progress Administration on the relief program.

In 1935 the vote in the West Fulham parliamentary division of London stood: For Cobb, Conservative, 18,461; Follick, Labor, 14,978; Johnson, Liberal, 1,132. In Wednesday's election of a successor to Cobb, deceased, the vote was: Summerskill, Labor, 16,583; Busby, Conservative, 15,162.

An amendment to the State. Unemployment Insurance Law, signed by Governor Lehman last -week, will lead to distribution this year of $1,500,000 in what are, in effect, duplicate insurance payments to jobless persons, according to an estimate-yesterday by the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department.

The Newark Bears went back into the winning column today, after losing their first start in twelve games yesterday. They turned back the Montreal Royals, 9 to 5, and the losers did not get a run until the ninth inning, when they gave Manager Johnny Neun some anxious moments.

Yale University sold to the Co-Operative Builders of Newark the tract known as Sunnyfield in Linden, N. J. The property adjoins the Sunnyfield golf course and was sold through Franklin F. Wagner. Louis Gordon, president of the Cooperative Builders, announced plans for five houses on the property.

The Treasury gave notice today that tenders will be accepted at Federal Reserve Banks or their branches up to 2 P. M., Eastern standard time, on Monday, on $100,000,000 of ninety-one day bills to be sold on the usual discount basis to the highest bidders.

His Majesty's Air Flow, a Derby candidate, was beaten threequarters of a length today in the Craven Stakes, important earlyseason race for 3-year-olds. The winner was Sir Laurence Phillips's Challenge, who started at 3 to 1, against 7 to 1 quoted for the royal colt. J. E. Widener's

Mrs. Sidney C. Borg gave a tea yesterday afternoon at the Chatham for members of the executive committee for the preview supper dance, which will be held in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria on April 21 for the benefit of the cooperative committee of the Big Sisters.

Declines of 1/2 to 3/4 cent were registered in moderate sales of calfskins in the last two days, and both cow and steer hides in the domestic market have remained quiet for the -third week in. succession.

The marriage of Miss Emily Brudno, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ezra Brudno of Cleveland, to Carl S. Leeds, also of Cleveland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sylvester Liebenthal, took place here yesterday afternoon at the Park Lane.
The most comprehensive exhibition of American art ever assembled for showing abroad is being collected, at the invitation of the French Government, by the Museum of Modern Art, for showing in Paris.
Seventeen acres surrounding Anne Hathaway's cottage at Shottery, in the heart of the Shakespeare country, will never be built on

Purchases of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on April 2 again exceeded sales, with 244,966 shares bought on balance, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. This was against the price trend which on the basis of THE NEW YORK TIMES averages for fifty stocks showed a net decline of 0.7 of a point.
James G. Blaine, chairman of the campaign committee of the Greater New York Fund, Inc., announced yesterday the names of additional business and professional leaders who will aid in the drive.

The Providence Reds, after wiping out a three-goal lead, opened their International-American Hockey League championship series with a 5-4 victory over the Syracuse Stars tonight when Buddy Jarvis scored a sudden death tally during the seventeenth minute of the second overtime period.

A cold wave in the Southwest, which led to apprehension of possible damage to the wheat crop, and firmness in Liverpool resulted in a moderate rally in the domestic markets today. Shorts were credited with having been the best buyers.
Plans for the expansion of the facilities of the Beth Abraham Home for Incurables were announced yesterday by Mrs. Samuel Zahn, president of the board of that institution.

Boston and nine other New England cities today banned sale of the weekly picture magazine, Life, unless four pages depicting the birth of a child were torn out. The other cities are Lynn, Northampton, Lawrence, Fall River, Worcester, Pittsfield and Springfield, Mass.; Providence, R. I.,

After a conference with the chief officials of the Quai d'Orsay today Foreign Miniser Joseph Paul-Boncour instructed French Ambassadors to allies in Central and Eastern Europe to ?? out the governments to which they are accredited on the Question of the independence of czechoslovakia.

Former President Herbert Hoover came home today with the announcement that he would "help elect a larger Republican Congressional representation" in the 1938 political campaign. He did not elaborate on his plans.

Justice Norman Scarth Macdonnell of the Ontario Court of Appeal died at his home here today. He was 51. A native of Toronto, Justice Macdonnell was appointed to the bench in October, 1933, but he had been unable to fill the position for the last year because of ill health.

Today's major events: Malcolm and Godden, duo-pianists, Town Hall, evening; Riverdale Country School concert, Town Hall, afternoon; New York Civic Orchestra, Federal Music Theatre, evening; Benjamin De Loache, baritone, Cosmopolitan Club, evening.

In the event the United States became involved in war all the private aircraft manufacturing plants in the United States, plus the government owned and operated plant in Philadelphia, could not turn out more than 50 per cent of the aircraft that would be necessary to provide an adequate air defense, Rear Admiral Arthur B. Cook, Chief of the Naval Bureau of Aeronautics, asserted today before the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs.

A total of 147 merchant ships of 406,895 gross tons was under construction in United States shipyards on April 1, according to a report published yesterday by the American Bureau of Shipping. The yards a year ago were building 244 shins of 326,506 tons.

Student demonstrations for the restoration of Slovakia to Hungary here tonight ended stormily. Turul--the largest student organization--held the meeting at which Deputy Vegvary described Czechoslovakia as in a state of disintegration and urged Hungarians to prepare for eventualities.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad retains its stock control of the Reading Company with holdings of 600,800 common, 345,600 second preferred and 235,065 first preferred shares of the latter, according to the Reading's annual report for 1937 filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission and made public here yesterday.
The New York City Tunnel Authority announced yesterday that it has awarded contract 7 for the land section at the Queens end of the midtown, vehicular tunnel to Charles F. Vachris, Inc.,
Miss Pearl Bernstein, Secretary of the Board of Estimate since Jan. 1, 1934, resigned yesterday to fill the newly created post of Administrative Officer in the Board of Higher Education.

Rivington St, n e cor Suffolk St. 104x100; Rose Pechter et al to Aron Streit, Inc, 150 Rivington St ($56). 66th St. 153 W, 39.9x100.4; Abraham Pollack to Philip Menschel and wife, 820 West End Ave; mtg $31,500. 130th St, 109-17 E, 122.6x100; Mary Z. Miller to Beryl X. Strong, Springfield, Mass. 119th St. 205 W. 37.6x101: Sara Parkowitz to Leah Bushel, 38 E 85th St; mtg $26,800 ($3.50).

George Blumenthal, financier and philanthropist, retired yesterday as president of Mount Sinai Hospital, a post he has held for twenty-seven years. The announcement was made last night at a dinner given in his honor by the hospital's trustees at the Hotel Pierre on the occasion of his eightieth birthday.

Once more the Federal Wage-Hour Bill emerges, in still another form. The present draft, prepared by a subcommittee of the House Labor Committee, and to be voted upon by that body next Tuesday, seems more cautious on the surface than any of its predecessors. Its purpose would be to apply the new Federal maximum hour, minimum wage standards gradually.

Less emphasis on team sports and more on individual sports, such as golf, tennis and swimming, was recommended to colleges and high schools by two speakers today at the Eastern District Convention of the American Association for Health and Physical Education at the Hotel Ambassador here.

The number of new incorporations in March continued below the corresponding figures for 1937, according to an announcement today through the Secretary of State's office. A total of 1,434 corporations received charters in the month, and for the quarter the figure was 4,226, compared with 5,301 in 1937.

The Square Deal Realty Corporation, representing interests that have been investing in Bronx properties, acquired another parcel yesterday through the purchase from the Sun Management Corporation of the sixty-four-family apartment house at 2,206 Valenitine Avenue. The property was acquired subject to a first mortgage held by the Equitable Life Assurance Society. Karl Propper, attorney, represented the buyer.

Deferred from April 18, "Washington Jitters" will open on May 2--not on May 4 as stated here yesterday. In any case, a farily lengthy postponement for a show which, it was announced, was being set back to a void conflict with "The Circle" on April 18.

IT seems a long time ago. Yet it was only last Winter that many of the most informedd observers were telling us to watch Hiter's attitude toward Czechoslovakia. That was to be the next step in his gun-driven revival of the Drang nach Osten, the old Prussian drive to the east, with dreams of Berlin -and Baghdad linked through conquered States like a string of sausages, and all the rest of it.
The stability in Canadian industry which became noticeable late in February extended over a larger area in March, according to A. E. Arscott, general manager of the Canadian Bank of Commerce.

Speaking at the second annual convention of the Workers Alliance of Greater New York, at the Hippodrome last night, Mayor La Guardia gave assurance that as long as he was chief executive of the city, relief would be given the unemployed and the needy.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES published on March 31 a report on the number of students in New York City high schools who study foreign languages. According to this report the proportion of such students has decreased steadily, and -this, according to the Director of the Foreign Language Department. is "indeed deplorable."

170th St (11-2964), n s, 28 ft e of Bristow St, 36x90; William J. Jones, referes, to Hirshhorn Realty Corp, 288 Southern Blvd. Valhalla Dr (18-5408), s s, 461 ft s of Siegfried Pl, 37x90; Frank P. Novotny to Eleanor Nagy, 2,877 Randall Av. Loring Pl, 2,261 (11-3225); Bronx Savings Bank to Victoria F. Tarantino, 2,261 Loring Pl.

Governor Lehman, in acting today on a series of measures dealing with the mortgage moratorium and deficiency judgment situation, indicated disagreement with the recommendations of the Nunan-Parsons Legislative Commission which put through the Legislature a series of bills designed to taper off the emergency provisions now existing.

Fordham's varsity golf and freshman tennis schedules were announced yesterday by John F. Coffey, graduate manager of athletics. Led by Captain Leo Tully, the Ram linksmen will start a sevenmatch campaign against Villanova April 22.

James C. McCormick, Inc, broker, has arranged a first mortgage of $8,000, running five years, on the 2-story building at 43-16 Greenpoint Ave, Woodside, Queens. The first mortgage of $5,000 on the dwelling at 41-18 Denman St, Elmhurst, has been sold by Eva Satinsky, also through the McCormick firm.

" Birds are of all animals nearest to man," said the late Laureate of England. They have no rival but man, and even now in their "free voyaging" surpass his most "desperate daring." They were also the earlier artists "schooling leisure to enliven life."

SOME Dodger fans are worrying because Dolf Camilli has an anemic batting average as a Brooklyn hitter to date. Dark Dolf was purchased from the Phillies for $50,000 mainly on the strength of his .339 batting average last season along with the fact that he tapped out twenty-seven home runs.

Walter Bertrand Walker, a leading financial lawyer in New York for thirty years, died yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after an illness of a week. Mr. Walker, whose home was at Ardsley-onHudson, was 57 years old.

MUNICIPAL CIVIL SERVICE EXAMINER--(a) civil engineering; (b) mechanical engineering; (c) electrical engineering; (d) architecture. Salary-$3,600 to, but not including $5,000 per annum; pension; fair sick leave. Vacancies--One, in the office of the Municipal Civil Service Commission in mechanical engineering at $3,500.

With original equipment sales scheduled to be sharply cut this year, leading manufacturers of automobile tires are launching intensive campaigns to increase their share of the replacement markets, agency executives pointed out yesterday.

21st St, 145 W, 5-story loft store, 19.5x 98.9; Union Dime Savings Bank against George C. Jaeger; due, $16,400; to plaintiff for $5,000. By NAT V. ROTHENBERG Madison Ave, 166, 7-story office store, 24x53; Dry Dock Savings Institution against Schulte Real Estate Co; due, $73.472; taxes, etc, $896; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Deaths Announced Fireman 1st Grade Joseph P. Cavanagh, of H. L. Co 21, died April 6. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 49-04 94th St., Elmhurst, Queens, at 9:30 A. M., Monday, April 11. Interment at St. John's Cemetery.

The Federal Power Commission declined today to dismiss a complaint charging the Philadelphia Electric Company with selling power to the Delaware Power and Light Company below cost.' The commission said it found "reasonable ground for further investigation" and asked Philadelphia Electric to submit additional evidence.

After losing their fight in the lower court to restrain the Guaranty Trust Company from its alleged intention to seize control of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad, the Alleghany Corporation and Robert R.. Young, its chairman, went yesterday to the United States Circuit Court of Appeals and obtrained an order similar to one which Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe had in effect nullified.
New York City is having its full quota of housing conferences and meetings to promote slum clearance, but up-State cities have not been so actively discussing the problem.

The annual report of the MidContinent Petroleum Corporation and its subsidiaries, issued yesterday, shows a net income for 1937 of $5,304,877 after deductions for depreciation, depletion, leaseholds surrendered and abandoned, Federal and State income taxes and surtax on undistributed profits.

Trading was active to fair. Steer beef sold strong to higher and some fresh pork cuts higher. The veal market was about steady, other classes strong. Trading in Kosher meats was light, with prices mostly unchanged from Wednesday, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

In a colorful ceremony sharply etched against the unexpected white of the April snow, Hussein Sabry Pasha, Egyptian commissioner general to the 1939 World's Fair and uncle of King Farouk, officiated yesterday at the laying of the first cornerstone in the foreign exhibit section of the fair.

KINGS GOMBERS, LIZZIE K. (Feb. 7. 1936). Gross assets, $80,454: net. $75,652. To sisters, Alice Fetters and Jessie Kimber, life income from one-half of residuary estate each and one-half interest each in specific jewelry; friend, Alice R. Miller, specific jewelry; niece, Margaret D. Hillman, balance of jewelry and one-sixth remainder interest in life estate;
Chinese military leaders claim to have delivered a crushing blow to the Japanese forces in Southern Shantung Province, forty-five miles northeast of Suchow, at Taierhchwang.

William J. Gerrity, newsstand proprietor for more than thirty-five years, died on Tuesday at the home of a friend at 2,181 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, of a heart attack. He was 50 years old and lived at 269 East 194th Street, the Bronx. At his death he had a stand at Twenty-third Street and Third Avenue and previously had been at Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue.

After a lull of a few days Arab terrorists this afternoon committed a double murder in Northern Palestine. The victims were two young Jewish pioneers, Ephraim Tiktin, 24 years old, of Detroit, and Eliezer Korngold, 21, of Toronto, Canada, both members of the American commune of Ein Hashofet near Yokonam.

Porters at Washington Market put on their hip boots again yesterday morning, and their heavy sweaters and mackinaws. Their breath was steaming as they stomped on the slushy pavement and now and then huddled around blazing bonfires of discarded fruit and vegetable crates.

Montgomery Ward Co. reported today that its sales last month were 11.84 per cent smaller than those in March, 1937. For February and March, the first two months of the company's fiscal year, sales were 7.94 per cent below the corresponding period of last year.

Miss Elimina Brewster, well-known equestrienne, was married here this afternoon at Edgerton, the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Foster Brewster, to Marshall Christopher Sewall of New York.

Former Justice Joseph Rosch of the Supreme Court, president of the New York State Bar Association, today named members of three committees. Walbridge S. Taft of New York is chairman of the committee on professional ethics to study disciplinary legislation.
A group of American silver producing companies decided this week to finance for another year a research project which experts say may remove the only excuse for the government's silver-buying policy.

Fully recovored, the young Maple Leafs broke down the weakened defenses of the Chicago Black Hawks in the third period tonight, rapped ih three swift goals and won, 5-1, to tie the Stanley Cup hockey series at one game each:

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury."

Contending that it must have about $1,000,000 additional in gross revenue to meet increasing operating expenses and taxes and pay interest. on its bonds, the Hudson Manhattan Railroad filed a brief today urging the Interstate Commerce Commission to lift an order of Aug. 17, 1937, by which a proposed fare increase was suspended.

Announcing that more than 13,000 undergraduates of forty-four colleges in twenty-one States opposed participation by the United States in foreign wars, the. Brown University Daily Herald made public a preliminary report today of. a nation-wide poll of 1,000,000 undergraduates.

M. Ernest Townsend, president of the State Teachers College at Newark, was elected president of the Eastern States Association of Professional Schools for Teachers at the thirteenth annual Spring conference of the association, which opened last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Richard Whitney will be questioned publicly here today by the Securities and Exchange Commission on an order from Washington. directing "that an investigation be made of the facts, conditions, practices and matters antecedent to and culminating in the failure of Richard Whitney Co."

Two dwellings on a plot 100 by 100 feet on the west side of Steinway Street, 350 feet north of Nineteenth Street, Astoria, L. I., were bought by the Alimy Realty, Inc., from Henry W. T. Steinway, who has owned the property since 1878. R. E. Motl was the broker.

For its third production in the reconditioned foundry in Twentieth Street the Play Room Club has selected Richard Hughes's "A Comedy of Good and Evil," which opened to members only last evening. It is a roguishly scribbled fable of spiritual hanky-panky in Wales and it fits the Play Room Club like an Easter suit. For Mr.
Marvin H. McIntyre, White House secretary, has entered Naval Hospital here for a rest. Associates said he would be there about a week.

Real estate deals in Manhattan reported yesterday included sales of houses in Harlem. A syndicate formed by John Blumenthal, attorney, bought the two five-story buildings containing twenty apartments and four stores at 1,470 and 1,472 Fifth Avenue, adjoining the southwest corner of West 119th Street, near Mount Morris Park.

Traffic through the Panama Canal increased last month, the War Department announced today. During March 506 commercial vessels passed through the waterway and paid tolls of $2,015,585,34, as compared with 436 vessels and tolls of $1.786,611.45 in February.

With both old-crop deliveries on the Cotton Exchange selling nearer prices in Liverpool and at a greater premium over Bombay than before this season, profit-taking on straddles continued to depress quotations yesterday.
George T. Dunlap Jr. of Pinehurst and Frank Strafaci of New York, former national public links champion, co-favorites in the North and South amateur tournament, advanced today to the semi-finals.

Amri To Galli-Campi, who once sang in the choir of her father's church near Scranton, Pa., made her debut with the Metropolitan Opera Company on the stage of the huge public hall here tonight and a crowd of 7,800 cheered, whistled and applauded for four minutes. The coloratura soprano sang Gilda in Verdi's "Rigoletto" opposite Jan Kiepura as the Duke.

The office of White Lamb Finlay, Inc., 54 Worth Street, will be closed today out of respect to George Bonar, president of the concern, who. died yesterday in Scotland. Paul Salmon has been appointed manager of the newest shop of the Roger Kent chain,

Miss Frederica Ballard, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Ballard of Rushford, N. Y., was married yesterday to Philip Wylie, son of the Rev. Edmund M. Wylie, associate minister of the Brick Church, Park Avenue and Eightyfifth Street, and the late Mrs. Edna Edwards Wylie.

The executive board of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians adopted a decision yesterday reprimanding Dr. Walter Damrosch "for conduct injurious to" the union as a result of several speeches he recently made in which he said that some members of the union were incompetent and that the union was causing unemployment by the establishment of high wage scales.

The firms of Hubbard Brothers Co. and. Berg, Eyre Kerr will consolidate on May 1, under the name of Hubbard Brothers Co., with new and larger offices at 60 Beaver Street, it was announced yesterday. The partners in the new firm will be Samuel T. Hubbard Jr., Joseph A. Russell, Beverley M. Eyre, John Kerr and William M. Newson.

Harry F. Wolf, national amateur squash tennis champion since 1930, is giving thought to retiring after one more season of competition. At the annual squash dinner of the New York A. C. last night, the perennial titleholder revealed that if he should win the crown again in 1939 for his tenth successive victory he probably will give up championship play thereafter.

Trading in wool goods markets this week was spotty, as buyers continued to view the- new Fall lines of men's suitings and overcoatings without placing much business, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.
At a meeting yesterday of the board of managers of the New York Cotton Exchange Good Friday and the following Saturday were declared legal holidays for the Cotton Exchange.

What is described as the Federal Theatre Project's most ambitious program for children will be offered at the Hippodrome on the afternoons of April 19, 20, 21 and 22. Beginning at 2:30 P. M., the threehour programs will comprise "Pierre Patelin," "Folk Dances of All Nations" and "The Birthday Party," a puppet show.

The nature of the new or amended State Constitution which will be submitted to the voters next Fall can as yet only be guessed at. It is no guess, however, that it will contain a variety of proposals, some of which will be highly controversial, but most of which will not.

Senator George L. Berry of Tennessee, the International Printing Pressmen and Assistapts Union of North America, of which he is president, and seven Chicago officers of the union were charged with conspiracy to seize and control the union in a suit filed in the Federal District Court here today by twenty-three members of Franklin Union 4 of Chicago.

A Negro interested in the Reorganization Bill debate in the House lost his way in the Capitol today and wandered into the Democratic cloakroom. Stopped by doorkeepers and informed that only members of Congress were permitted in the cloakroom, he backed apologetically out of the door.
The stock markets here, although quiet, were generally firm today and most sections advanced. Gilt-edge issues improved, but foreign bonds were dull and Austrian, German and Polish loans fell.

Reuniting the combination that made "The Informer," RKO will film "The Coffin Ship." The story by Anthony Coldeway and Henry Robert Symonds will be produced by Robert Sisk with Victor McLaglen -as the star and John Ford as director. The tale deals with a sailing vessel on which cholera rages.

Using a sub-machine gun and three revolvers, four men held up the First National Bank here this afternoon and escaped in an automobile believed to have been driven by a fifth man, with a sum estimated at between $10,000 and $15,000. Determination of the exact amount taken awaits a check-up by bank officials.

Catholic churches and buildings throughout Austria flew the swastika flag today. Newspapers did not print or comment upon Theodor Cardinal Innitzer's retraction in the Osservatore Romano, and there is not the slightest indication that the major part of the public will ever learn anything about it.
About the circus, we have it from the highest authority--namely, from the press representative himself--that
The Church of the Holy Sepulchre, the basilica of which has been trussed with steel since 1935, is to be closed to the public before Sunday as it is deemed unsafe.

Seeking unlisted trading in sixteen securities, one registered on the New York Curb Exchange and the others on the New York Stock Exchange, the Boston Stock Exchange, at a hearing today before Charles S. Moore, examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission,

After allowance for seasonal changes, business in the Pittsburgh district in the week ended April 2 lost all the gain recorded in the two preceding weeks, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

James E. Suiter, senior from Jersey City, is the winner of the Cooper Logic Prize at Rutgers University, it was announced today by Dr. Walter,T. Marvin, dean of the College of Arts and Sciences. The prize, carrying a cash award of $200, is the most valuable offered at the university.
Mayor La Guardia will ask President Roosevelt in Washington this morning for an allocation of at least $150,000,000 to New York City on city projects out of the new $1,500,000,000 Federal fund.

Formation of a marketing policy committee composed of company executives was announced yesterday by the Schenley Products Company. The new committee is headed by Marion Harper, merchandising and advertising specialist. Associated with him will be Louis E.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 5: CAPTAIN Ancrum, W., 5th Naval District, to home, relieved all active duty, in May or June.

At J. B. Neumann's New Art Circle, 509 Madison Avenue, a oneman show of paintings by Henry Billings is in progress. As a matter of fact, this artist has himself been in progress undivulged and unreported since the year 1933, when his last previous show was held at the Marie Harriman Gallery.

The development of the American potash industry to the point where it produces 50 per cent of the nation's consumption will be described in thirteen papers to be presented at a symposium of the division of physical and inorganic chemistry of the American Chemical Society

Fred Harrington, secretary of the Edwin Farnham Greene-McCord Corporation, textile brokers, of 51 Madison Avenue, Manhattan, ended his life by inhaling gas in the kitchen of his home at 257 Park Avenue here today. He was 56 years old.

Cambridge University's Rugby team will close its invasion of the East this afternoon in meeting an all-East fifteen at the Polo Grounds at 3 o'clock. The game will be played regardless of weather conditions.
The Reorganization Bill which the House sidetracked tonight was intended to grant powers asked by the President.
Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler gave a dinner last night at their home, 60 Morningside Drive, for Sir William and Lady MaxMuller and Alexander Kerensky.

Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, now chief of the Bureau of Navigation, will relieve Vice Admiral William T. Tarrant as commander of the scouting force of the fleet in June and July, the Navy Department announced today.
The residence of Mrs. William C. Fisher was the setting today for a tea and musical, at which she was both hostess and artist.

Martin (Buggsy) Goldstein and Seymour Magoon, Brooklyn gangsters, and fifteen contractors were convicted yesterday in Special Sessions Court, Brooklyn, of conspiracy to violate the State labor laws by maintaining a $1,500,000 monopoly of painting and decorating work in Brooklyn and Queens public schools. Goldstein and Magoon were remanded and the others were continued in $1,000 bail each, all for sentencing on April 18.

Urging that the Administration's $1,121,000,000 Naval Construction Bill be defeated, Major Gen. Smedley D. Butler, retired, told the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs today that the bill was a "grand bluff" and that no such force as contemplated was necessary for the adequate defense of the United States.

What is the matter with France? Since the French have only gone farther, faster and with more sudden jolts along the American road, with the same objectives in view, perhaps they have an equal right to ask: What is the matter with the United States?

Conversion of Eighth and Ninth Avenues into one-way thoroughfares will speed up traffic and decrease the danger of automobile accidents, Assistant Corporation Counsel Herman Horowitz argued yesterday in Supreme Court.

Although Johnny Lanning was touched for twelve hits, he was never in danger today and he became the fourth pitcher of the Bees to go the full distance as his mates turned back the Savannah club, 9--1.

As part of an expansion program, Peck Peck, creators of women's sport and tailored clothes, will open a fourth suburban store in Greenwich, Conn., on Monday. Peck Peck already have stores in White Plains, N. Y.; Garden City, L. I., and East Orange, N. J.

Edouard Daladier's last venture as French Premier ended disastrously on Feb. 7, 1934, the day following the stormy riots that resuited from the disputes centering in the Stavisky scandal. This was his second Cabinet, and it had lasted only a few days. In 1933,

Receipt of more than $35,000,000, including a clear profit of more than $12,000,000 for the Federal Government, from PWA bond sales and interest on securities was reported today to Secretary Ickes by the PWA's division of accounts.

Colonel Bill Terry's proverbial good luck in Spring training weather ran out on him for the second successive time when the Giants and Indians arrived today only to learn they had made another long train ride for no purpose.
Clement Foster Burnap of Chappaqua, N. Y., an associate of the realty firm of Malcom E. Smith, Inc., 185 Madison Avenue, died yesterday in Polyclinic Hospital after an operation. His age was 54.

President Roosevelt is more than a boss to Marvin H. McIntyre, his secretary. He is also his adviser and "physician." Reporting on the condition of Mr. McIntyre, who has been ordered to a local hospital for rest, the President said at his press conference that his secretary was extremely cheerful this morning and had insisted on attending the dinner of the Gridiron Club tomorrow night.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "A moderate and more or less erratic demand for wool is reported this week. Some business has been done in the seaboard markets and some in the West, mainly in the Southwest. Considerable wool was sold in New Mexico this week in the range of 15 to 20 cents.

Broad Street Hospital, which has been an asylum for the sick in New York's financial district since 1917, when it was founded, and has relied during that time on Wall Street charity for support, is ready to close its doors.
Today's major events: Josef Hofmann, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Hilda Kutsukian Kosta, contralto, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Neighborhood Music School Concert, Town Hall, 3 P. M.

A contract for air conditioning the largest and fastest passenger vessel built in the United States, the new transatiantic liner of the United States Lines, has been awarded to the Carrier Corporation, according to an announcement today by L. R. Bouiware,
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

John Welsh, 19 years old, of 438 West Fifty-eighth Street, and Emil siroky, 21, of 25-76 Forty-first Street, Astoria, Queens, two accomplices in the so-called "thrill" hold-up of a bar at 705 Third Avenue on Sept. 21, were sentenced to Elmira Reformatory yesterday in t General Sessions. Charles Chiodo,
Prince Giovanni Torlonia, Prince of Fucino, Duke of Ceri, Marquess of Romavecchia, Senator of the Kingdom and landlord to Premier Mussolini, died today. He was 64 years old.
Miss Marjorie Henningsen, daughter of Mrs. Anken P. Henningsen of Shanghai, China, and Portland, Ore., was married this evening to Earl Sidney Willis of Cleveland in Christ Episcopal Church here.
Supporters of the Reorganization Bill generally were silent tonight on its defeat, but opponents were quick to voice their satisfaction. Senator Byrd of Virginia issued a statement saying:

Eight representatives of groups of persons interested in assisting the emigration of political refugees from Austria and Germany were invited by President Roosevelt to meet with him at the White House Wednesday to consider ways for cooperating with the United States and the.intergovernmental committee. that is to be created to facilitate the work.

Union workers at the Tropical Oil Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, and the crews of the company's Magdalena River fleet struck today after negotiations for higher pay failed.

Packers yesterday were holding prices on calf skins firmly at the levels of a week ago, and declined to meet reductions which-had been made earlier in the week by collectors. The packers realized 13 cents in some sales yesterday on March take-off of Northern skins ranging from 9 1/2 to 15 pounds, and on light skins under 9 1/2 pounds were holding for 14 to 14 0/2 cents.

For the fourth successive year Thomas Iannicelli won the world open squash tennis championship last night. In the final round of the tournament at the Hotel Shelton the sturdy little professional of the Short Hills Club defeated Rowland Dufton, coach of the New York A. C. and runner-up last year also.

Trading was mostly fair to good. Entire beef market strong to higher; lamb and fresh pork cuts also strong to higher; veal about steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef and veal to be strong to higher, lamb steady, as reported by The United States Department of Agriculture.

After Fannie Brice finished testifying yesterday in a crowded court room in Supreme Court, Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo dismissed a $34,000 suit brought against her by Edgar Allen, theatrical agent, for commissions allegedly due him for obtaining for her a contract to appear with the Ziegfeld Follies in 1933.

Publishers of News Review, a weekly news magazine, announced today the Federation of London Wholesale News Dealers had banned all copies of the current issue, presumably because it contained extracts from a book about Premier Benito Mussolini.

Wage reductions will be opposed by the seven union organizations belonging to the Railway Employes Department of the American Federation of Labor, B. M. Jewell, president, announced today at the conclusion of the ninth annual convention of the association.

Japan's advance in China is being conducted by bankers and industrialists as well as by battle and blockade. A few major items selected from the financial pages of today's newspapers show how the military and economic fronts in Japan's campaign to make all East Asia her economic domain, march together.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is regrettable that the inscription on the tablet unveiled in Bowling Green in commemoration of the establishment of this park in 1733 includes the statement that Bowling Green is the "first public park established in New York." This statement I believe to be erroneous.
Jimmy Adamick, Midland (Mich.) heavyweight protege of Jack Kearns, hammered his way to a 10-round decision over Al Ettore, veteran Philadelphian, at Olympia Stadium tonight. Each weighed 192 pounds.

Mark Graves, Tax Commissioner, urged taxpayers today to make income tax returns by check, postal or express money order. He explained that "payment by check or money order not only proves helpful to the department in disposing of mail and getting receipts to banks of deposit, but fully protects the taxpayer as well against any possible loss as a result of failure of the department to properly credit his payment."

A MINOR-LEAGUE club, Albany, slapped Dizzy Dean for six runs in five innings the other day, but, after 01' Dizz departed, a rookie pitcher by the name of Lanier took the mound for the Cardinals and blanked the opposition the rest of the way.

A second unit in the United Cigars-Whelan Drug chain in the Rockefeller Center district will be opened on the southwest corner of Fifty-second Street and Sixth Avenue as soon as alterations are completed.
