Declaring that the railroads could lead the nation out of the business slump, George M. Harrison urged the government today to guarantee to them a fair net profit by setting up a $300,000,000 "contingent liability account." Mr. Harrison, president of the Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks,
Alf Perry, 1935 British open champion, today won The Daily Mail's $10,000 golf tourney with a seventy-two-hole total of 284. Perry's victory was worth $2,500.

Two shows, both of them deserving-since they gave more than one hundred performances-the title of success, will be leaving town tonight. The one which has been around the longest time is "The Star Wagon,"

National Youth Administration funds for New York State exclusive of New York City have been increased to permit the employment of 1,000 more young people, 18 to 25 years old, in need of relief, the NYA announced yesterday.

Rain played havoc with the college baseball program yesterday, all games scheduled in this section being washed out and cancellations resulting. Contests listed for New York City fields and called off were those between Upsala and Fordham, Panzer and Brooklyn College, and Newark University and Long Island University.

Department store sales for the week ended April 2 were 2 per cent lower than for the same week one year ago, the Federal Reserve reported today. For the previous week, ending March 26, sales were 17 per cent lower than for the same week last year. For the four weeks ending April 2 sales were 13 per cent under the same four weeks in 1937.
A 3,700-pound carpet known as the "Wheel of Life," because of its figured pattern depicting human existence from birth to death, is to be placed in the Park Avenue foyer of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Having attempted to emulate the large food companies, which have been enjoying considerable success with their radio programs, smaller manufacturers in the grocery field are gradually switching back to newspapers as their primary medium, according to merchandising experts in the industry.

For having been "too inquisitive" about border events the prefecture today notified Felipe Bellotti, special correspondent for Milan's Regima Fascista, that an expulsion order had been issued against him.

The Chihese announced today that their forces were cleaning out Japanese remnants in outlying districts of Taierhchwang and enveloping larger Japanese contingents which broke through the Chinese cordon inclosing Taierhchwang Thursday and retreated toward Chihsien and Lini.

Gross assets, $18,879; net, $17,435. To Betty Halem, widow. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $11,379. George B. Tepper, attorney, 29 Broadway. KARLINSKY, RAY (Jan. 6, 1938). Gross assets, $27,798; net, $3,168. To Charlotte Mertens, daughter. Chief assets, real estate, $27,500. Max J. Hamberger, attorney, 233 Broadway.

John J. Baumer has sold his property on Glen Alpine Road, New Vernon, consisting of several acres of land, with a three-story dwelling, garage and barn, to Edwin E. Ebel. The buyer plans to remodel all of the buildings in preparation for early occupancy.

Japanese newspapers In Shanghai announced today that regular traffic, open to everybody, including Chinese, would be resumed Sunday on the Shanghai-Nanking, Shanghai-Hangchow and Soochow-Kaishing Railways, but the announcement carried a curious joker.

On the question of "economy" versus "more spending," the President has yet to announce a final decision. But Harry Hopkins has implied a greatly extended spending program in asking, in the face of what would be rising relief needs in any case, for a Federal program to put every employable jobless person on work relief.

213th St, 911 E, 1710X100: Minnie A. Langbein against Antonio Doria, due $6,288; taxes, etc., $468; to plaintiff for $1,000. By THOMAS J. LUNNEY Boston Rd, 2,121, also Pelham Parkway, 675-7, also Olinville Ave, 53.1X90.10X irreg; Bronx Savings Bank against Sadie Berkwit; $71, 419; taxes, etc, $2,263; to plaintiff for $60,000.

The Catholic weekly newspapers of the Berlin and Breslau dioceses have published appeals to Catholics to support the Nazi regime in Sunday's plebiscite -on Austro-German union. The Berlin appeal said nothing directly regarding the union of Austria and Germany.

Harry N. Kinn Co., Inc., have moved to 163 Remsen Street, Brooklyn. Daniel Shaw has been placed in charge of the department servicing FHA insured apartment-house mortgages, and Robert Silverman will be general counsel for the firm.

David Goldstein, counsel for Thomas N. Cooke, Greenwich real estate broker, who is under indictment for conspiracy on' Merritt Parkway land sales, filed a motion in Superior Court today asking that the indictment be dismissed on grounds that the parkway grand jury was illegally constituted and that the charges in the indictment "are insufficient in law."

Dr. Thomas B. Turner, who retired from the practice of medicine in 1881 because of "poor health" and had seen every Princeton-Rutgers football game since the first contest in 1869, died Wedensday in his home here. He was 90 years old.
The proposal that the Federal Government tax the salaries of three officers of the Port of New York Authority was debated before the Supreme Court today and then taken under advisement.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustment.

Their plans for a ball game spoiled for the second straight day, the snowbound Yankees moved on tonight to Little Rock, Ark., without having tackled the Tulsa Oilers of the Texas League. What is more,
The Gatineau Power Company, in its annual report for 1937, issued yesterday, showed net earnings of $1,641,767. after interest, depreciation and income taxes, compared with $999,396 in 1936.

The prices of most classes of bonds strengthened in slightly more active trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Inflation ideas seemed to be the stimulating force behind the fresh upswing among the more speculative issues. On the other hand,

A new principle of taxation was established when the Alberta Legislature, led by a Social Credit government, approved the n production tax. The law, authorizing a 7 per cent tax on agricultural products, replaces certain land taxes and provides a system of crop insurance.

Governor Herbert .H. Lehman signed yesterday the bill passed by the Legislature, authorizing corporations this year to make donations for the betterment of social and economic conditions and, with the exception of public utilities, to charge such amounts to expenses.

Construction of the Perisphere, the theme of the World's Fair, was begun officially yesterday afternoon in Flushing Meadows in a driving rainstorm. Sheltered by umbrellas and with the chilled and bedraggled audience huddled under a small tent, Grover Whalen, president of the fair corporation, and Edward R. Stettinius Jr., chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, began formal construction of the huge globe.

As Burleigh Grimes and his Dodgers rolled in here early tonight prepared (they fondly hope) to wallop the Jacksonville Tars tomorrow and Sunday, it became evident there are numerous loose ends to be tied together in developing the team, but whether that can be done is another question.

George A. Schenk, 49 years old, of 657 South Seventh Avenue, here, an insurance agent, died tonight in Mount Vernon Hospital of shotgun wounds of the chest suffered in the attic of his home yesterday. Dr. Amos 0. Squire, Westchester County Medical Examiner, listed the case as a suicide. According to Dr.

Syd Chaplin in "Charlie's Aunt," made in 1925, is the feature to be shown today on the "Movie Caravan" program at the Actors Church, 229 West Forty-eighth Street. Completing the bill are "Knight of the Trail,"

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 2 amounted to 523,489 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 49,463 cars, or 8.6 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 197,740 cars,

The undergraduate French society at City College, Le Cercle Jusserand, will present "Prenez Garde a la Peinture," the French version by R. Fauchois of "The Late Christopher Bean," tonight in the Pauline Edwards Theatre of the School of Business, Twentythird Street and Lexington Avenue.

President Roosevelt indicated today that he was not in sympathy with a suggestion in the report on the railroad problem by his special committee of Interstate Commerce Commissioners that the government should guarantee or underwrite newly issued bonds of roads resorting to financial reorganization as a means of reducing burdensome capital structures.

The complete story of the rise and fall of Richard Whitney was explored in public yesterday for the first time by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the last of the government agencies to question him.

Two attacks were made on dictatorships in talks at dedication ceremonies at the Louisiana State University here today in the presence of Marchese Fulvio Suvich, Italian Ambassador. One talk was by Secretary Wallace and the other by Walter Harrison, managing editor of The Daily Oklahoman-Times and former president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

Dr. John H. Denbigh, who will resign this Spring from Packer Collegiate Institute after twenty years as principal, was honored last night at a dinner given by the school's board of trustees in the Packer Library, 170 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn.

Units of the regular army, the National Guard and the organized reserve, with members of veterans' groups and patriotic societies, will parade in upper Fifth Avenue today to celebrate Army Day, which occurred on April 6, the twentyfirst anniversary of the entrance of the United States into the World War.

Spanish Insurgent legions drove a second swift spearhead toward the Mediterranean tonight, counterbalancing a government drive southwest of Madrid in which gains were reported along a twenty-five-mile front.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, guest of honor last night at a dinner tendered to him as new president of the National Lawyers Guild, deplored instances of "socalled leaders of the bar utilizing their positions" to advocate measures for the benefit of private clients, and called for "a bar which will stand four-square" behind progressive measures.

A consignment of $700,000 gold was engaged in England yesterday for shipment here, according to reports received by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This engagement brought the total of gold taken in England for shipment here since March 15 to $28,400,000 and made the total gold movement to this country from all sources since Feb. 24, $62,900,000.

The $47,000,000,000 old-age reserve, contemplated in the Federal Social Security Act, was denounced last night as a "dangerous delusion" calculated to hinder, rather than promote, genuine social security.

The New York Women's Auxiliary Bible Society presented its annual benefit entertainment yesterday in the ballroom of the Pierre. The principal feature of the program was a motion picture in color of the Oberammergau Passion Play, shown under the direction of Mark Haight.

The United States Army, as Colonel Oliver Lyman Spaulding has written, is "not a mere aggregation of men, not even an aggregation of regiments. It has a soul of its own over and above the souls of its component individuals."
Miss Betty Zeller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Zeller of this place, was married tonight to John Hunter Gage of Glen Ridge, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. Raymond Gage of Winchester, Mass.

The Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday in their annual statement for the year ended on Jan. 31 a net profit of $2,904,206 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and $226,064 surtax on undistributed profits.

Heidelback, Ickelheimer Co., 49 Wall Street, New York, have filed with the State Banking Department certificates and affidavits required in connection with the change in membership of the firm, it was announced today in the department's weekly bulletin.

74th St, 321 W, 5-story dwelling, 22x80; Central Hanover Bank Trust Co, execr, against Forhan Realty Corp, due $41,408, taxes. etc., $1,908; to plaintiff for $25,000. 13th St, 421 E, 3-story tenement, 25x115; Dry Dock Savings Institution, against Margaret White, due $10,326, taxes, , $75; to plaintiff for $1,000.

The tenth annual Fordham Block F dinner for winners of sports awards is to be held in Keating Hall on the university's uptown campus Saturday, April 30, it was announced yesterday by the Fordham Athletic Association.

The Newark Bears blanked the Toronto Maple Leafs in an exhibition game today, the Canadian team getting only three safeties off the hurling of Bonham and Strincevich of Manager Johnny Neun's staff. The score was 3 to 0.

Anthony Foster McKissick, president of Alice and Aerial Textile Mills at Easley, S. C., died tonight in his home in Greenville, S. C., at the age of 68. He was a brother of Dr. J. Rion McKissick, head of the University of South Carolina.
Arthur F. Miller, secretary and treasurer of the Connecticut Savings Bank, has been missing for two days and a general search was begun today with a seven-State broadcast.

Former President Herbert Hoover asserted tonight that it was the American people, rather than business, who were "scared" at the economic trend, and suggested that New Deal "planned economy" itself was "making the one-third illfed and ill-clothed."

Members of-the New York branch of the English-Speaking Union gave an anniversary tea yesterday afternoon in celebration of the union's first year's occupancy of its new headquarters at 30 Rockefeller Plaza. Mrs. Robert Bacon,
The Department of Commerce reported today that $53,224,817 of gold had come into the United States in the week ended on April 1, foreshadowing early resumption of gold sterilization by the Treasury.

Admitting that many difficulties would be faced in establishing a bona fide secondary market for round-lot trading in securities registered on the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges, officials of the Boston Stock Exchange again urged the Securities and Exchange Commission today to give them the opportunity to see what they could do in that direction.
The Guild shop, and preferential hiring were refused today in a final offer made to the Northern California Newspaper- Guild by publishers of five San Francisco Bay region newspapers.

Princess Elizabeth Windisch-Graetz, granddaughter of the late Emperor Franz Josef and daughter of the late Crown Prince Rudolf, who lives in a small castle on the outskirts of Vienna, has entered a new phase of her political career.

The governors of the Commodity Exchange, Inc., yesterday announced that the Exchange will be closed for all business on Good Friday and the following Saturday. The New York Produce Exchange will be closed on Good Friday, and the following markets of the Exchange will be closed on both Good Friday and the day following:

Laconia Ave, w s, 31 it n of Boston Post Rd; 2-story brick auto paint shop, 50x30: Rose Guarino, 1,113 E 212th St. owner; Frank J. Ross, architect; cost, $5,000. Faile St, w s, 275 ft n of Oak Point Ave; 11/2-story brick dwelling and garage, 22x 42; John Martarano, 643 Barretto St, owner; same architect; cost, $5,000.
The 1938 Brooklyn College football schedule, released yesterday by Louis R. Oshins, business manager of athletics, lists eight games, four of them at home.

The status of the mortgage moratorium and deficiency judgment legislation was clarified today when friends of Governor Lehman indicated the Governor's reason for his action yesterday in vetoing the Nunan bill which would have extended the ban on deficiency judgments until Jan. 1, 1943.

Governor Lehman signed today the Buckley bill, which drastically modifies the capital gains and losses provisions of thi State personal income tax. The bill will affect income for the year 1938, not the year 1937, for which returns are due on April 15.

Undeterred by such minor things as blizzards and cold rains, the oarsmen of Manhattan College, bundled up against the return of Winter, go cruising in the twilight in preparation for the opening of their season a week from today, when Columbia and Rutgers will row with them on the Harlem.

Bruised and battered but defiant, the Black Hawks limped into town today vowing they would "make it tough" for the Toronto Maple Leafs at the Stadium Sunday night in the third game of the Stanley Cup final hockey play-off.

Konrad Henlein, leader of the Sudeten German party, today denied rumors that members of the party would demonstrate Sunday in favor of the German plebsicite and warned followers to observe strict discipline.

Three hundred years after two small ships sailed up the Delaware River with a group of Swedish and Finnish colonists to found New Sweden, Pennsylvania gave thanks tonight for three centuries of "godly civilization."

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx, the Bronx Board of Trade and the Bronx Real Estate Board hailed yesterday the plan of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for a 120-acre "garden apartment community" in the Van Nest and Unionport sections of the borough.
In the Supreme Court of the United States today Henry Mannix and Zonola May Longstreth of New York were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

Five dwellings will be erected on the north side of Brunner Avenue, between Bussing and Pitman Avenues, the Bronx, where six lots have been sold by Charles A. Schrag to Philip Paglin. Louis Schrag, Inc., and V. C. Manzione were the brokers.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The approach of another baseball season still finds the writer trying to champion the cause of the cash customer. Justly founded complaints forwarded to your paper concerning prices and the lack of consideration of club owners have in the past been evasively commented upon or completely ignored..

Forest Hills has become one of the most active sections of Queens in the erection of new apartment houses and private homes. A visit to this community, which has been in the limelight recently because of its proximity to the forthcoming World's Fair, finds steam shovels busy on many new sites and new groups of interesting dwellings in various stages of construction.

President Roosevelt approved today an allotment by the Works Progress Administration of $24:031,863 for construction of a 162-mile superhighway in Pennsylvania, extending from Harrisburg to Pittsburg.

David McKelvy White, chairman of the Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade and former machine gunner in Spain, yesterday challenged the veracity of statements by John G. Honeycombe, contained in dispatches from France, regarding the fate of Americans serving with the Loyalist forces.

An hour before 400 children would have assembled in the forty-year-old Washington school building here this morning, a boy pupil discovered flames coming through the roof and turned in an alarm. Firemen worked four hours before the blaze was out. The entire third floor,

Houses that were held by savings banks passed into new control in deals announced yesterday. The Dry Dock Savings Institution sold to an investing client of Francis Ecker, attorney, the six-story house on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 224 East Seventy-fourth Street.
Winners of the Forbes Heermans prizes, awarded annually for the best writing of plays by undergraduates, are announced at Cornell University.

Major Frank M. Wandle, Yale's widely known football trainer, returned home today from a Florida sojourn apparently recovered from the effects of a cerebral hemorrhage he suffered last Fall while leading Eli players in calisthenics. Wandle,

Brooks Carlisle, carrying 120 pounds, captured the fifth race, cofeature at Montagu Park today. Victory in the seven-furlong test carried with it the distinction of the best Bahamian-bred horse in Nassau. The winner is owned by Mrs. Etienne Dupuch.

Exchange of checks at 194 clearing houses in this country in March totaled $25,258,493,756, an increase of 28.3 per cent over the returns in February and the largest since last December. However, the total for March showed a shrinkage of 21.6 per cent compared with March, 1937.

Fire department officials of this city were exonerated today by Dr. Amos O. Squire, medical examiner of Westchester County, in a decision dealing with the death on March 1 of four persons in a fire which swept a house at 43 Ogden Avenue. He recommended, however, that the city acquire more fire apparatus.

The most serious challenge to the authority of the Federal Commission of Fine Arts since it was created by Congress twenty-eight years ago to safeguard the beauty of the national capital, has resulted in an appeal to President Roosevelt by Gilmore D. Clarke, chairman of the commission,

Contracts awarded at the local quartermaster depot today included the following: Invitation 208, for 29,000 yards of heavyweight mercerized cotton bunting36 inches wide, went to Stewart Sparry, Inc., as follows:
The oldest charity fair in New York-the annual Kettledrum 'or the benefit of the Samaritan Home for the Aged-took place yesterday afternoon at the Plaza.

Musical organizations from Columbia and Harvard Universities will visit Vassar College this weekend. Tomorrow evening the Columbia orchestra will give a concert, with Paul Henry Lang conducting, and on Sunday evening the Harvard Glee Club will end its Spring tour by a joint concert with the Vassar choir.

As the result of a protest from Josef Hofmann, noted pianist, against the sale of tickets for his concerts tonight and tomorrow evening by speculators, Mayor La Guardia directed yesterday that police and plainclothes men be assigned to Carnegie Hall to stop such sales at both concerts.

Following are opinions of the press on the House vote on the Reorganizatino Bill: NEW YORK CITY From the Herald Tribune It has been a long, dark road the country has been travelling under the New Deal leadership. Nerves were taut and hopes were low.

Captain John J. Tobin (2), of Engine Co. 312 died April 7. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 52-71 Sixty-sixth Street, Maspeth, Queens, at 10:30 A. M., Saturday, April 9. Interment at Calvary Cemetery. The following funeral honors are ordered: The funeral escort will consist of a battalion of three companies, of twenty-four men each, to be commanded by Battalion Chief William R. Lanahan, 49th Battalion. The companies shall be commanded, respectively by:

Probably no town since the gold rush of the American West has grown so suddenly as this fascinating old city which serves as the capital of a State less than two years old. It had a population of 41,000 when the Spanish war began, but today it is twice that size, swollen by the establishment here of five of the nine Ministries of the government of Insurgent Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

With last February's visit of forty-seven seniors to Federal planning projects in the South a tested edunational success, fifteen boys and girls in the eleventh grade of Lincoln School, experimental unit of Teachers College, will start next Friday with two teachers on a tenday tour of the coal fields and steel foundries of West Virginia and Pennsylvania.

Dean John T. Madden of this city and Orange, N. J., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Annette Madden, to Bernard John J. Mooney of Chicago, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. John J. Mooney of Jersey City.

The Manhattan Railway Company applied to Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson yesterday for relief against the legal consequences of the city's action on April 8, when it began to advertise the sale of the company's real estate and special franchises because of non-payment of about $9,000,000 in back taxes. interest and penalties.

Jennings St (11-2962), n s, 293 ft e of Union Ave, 40x119; Virginia Schreiner to Lester H. Brown, 21st St and Boulevard, Kenilworth, N. J. Boynton Ave (14-3715), e s, 250 ft s of Watson Ave, 50x100; Clifton Properties, Inc, to Grace F. Brickman, 241 Morgan Ave: mtg $43,500.

Ward's later than Automotive Reports, in its weekly analysis of motor car plant activity, today placed the current week's output at 60,975 cars and trucks, compared with 57,500 units last week and 100,470 this week a year ago.

Marche Andre of Middletown, Ohio, was the outstanding kegler during a slow session of the American Bowling Congress tonight. Andre hit his best stride during the singles competition and toppled 710 pins.

Funeral services, with military honors, were held today in Monticello for -Levi Van Keuren, a Civil War veteran who died in New Paltz Tuesday night at the age of 92. He took his first airplane ride two years ago. Born in Napanoch, he served in the Fifty-sixth New York Infantry Regiment of the Union Army. Surviving are a son, Charles,

The Lindenhurst Village Board and the Town Board of Babylon have under consideration two resolutions submitted by the Knights of Columbus and the American Legion post accusing the German-American Bund of anti-church and anti-God activities in the village.

An injunction against price cutting in radio retailing was sought today in the Supreme Court here by two independent dealers who accused the Davega-City Radio Corporation and the Vim Radio and Sporting Goods Stores Corporation of selling radios at 30 to 50 per cent under the list prices set by manufacturers. Violations of the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act and of agreements with the manufacturers were alleged.

Arthur W. Dake of Portland, Ore., Pacific Coast chess champion and member of three of the victorious United States teams abroad, celebrated his twentyeighth birthday last night by winning his first game in the biennial championship of the National Chess Federation at the Marshall Chess Club.

Plans for a pump-priming recovery program, contemplating new Federal outlays in loans and direct spending amounting to several billions of dollars, were being pushed today by President Roosevelt and his aides preparatory to its submission to Congress next week.
Frederick G. Fischer, second vice president of the East River Savings Bank, died Thursday in his home at 35 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, after an illness of several weeks. He was 71 years old.

The volume of new bond financing this week fell off sharply from the preceding period and was restricted exclusively to tax-exempt issues. Activity even in that field was light, with five issues, aggregating only $2,342,000, placed on the market.

The match race between Samuel D. Riddle's War Admiral and Charles S. Howard's Seabiscuit for a p??rse of $100,000 to be run at Belmont Park during the Autumn meeting from Sept. 15 to Oct. 1 was practically clinched yesterday following a conference between Mr.
Oliver Lakin, a real estate broker for forty years at 101 West Fortysecond Street, Manhattan, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home at 4 Beverly Place, here. He was 66 years old.
Brazil's chief of the Department of General Investigations is en route to Buenos Aires to discuss what may become a general agreement for a South American "continental police."

Field Marshal Hermann Goering predicted tonight a 100 per cent vote in Sunday's plebiscite for Chancellor Adolf Hitler and unification with Austria. The occasion was the campaign's final speech in Berlin,. delivered in the Sportpalast.
Funeral services for William C. Mott, a member of the New York Produce Exchange since 1894, were held yesterday afternoon in the Central Baptist Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-second Street.
All sorts of questions naturally spring forward out of a story like that of day before yesterday about New York slum dwellers.

The list of the Italian motor ship Saturnia, leaving today for Mediterranean ports, includes Mr. and Mrs. Adloph C. Miller, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Longone, E. C. Kneece, Mrs. Maria Giannini, Mr. and Mrs. Morrill Wiggin, Mr. and Mrs. Carlo Tagliabue,

Mr. and Mrs. Herman D. Kountze, who had been at the Savoy-Plaza after returning from California, have gone to their country home in Bedford Village, N. Y. Mrs. Henry Benning Spencer of Washington is at the Ritz-Carlton.

Edward Bruce, who organized and directed the Public Works Art Project and now is head of the Treasury Department Section of Painting and Sculpture in Washington, received the Friedsam Medal last night at a ceremony in the Whitney Museum of American Art, at 10 West Eighth Street.

In the First Congregational- Church here this afternoon, Miss Nancy Trowbridge Barker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Barker, was married to Charles Noyes Loveland Jr. of Cumberland Mills, Me., son of Charles N. Loveland, Mayor of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., and Mrs. Loveland. The Rev. John Gratton, pastor of the church, performed the ceremony in a setting of white snapdragons and palms.

Thomas Russell, for many years a member of the Boston bar, died at his home here last night at the age of 79. Mr. Russell, a well-known sportsman, was born in Boston, son of William Goodwin Russell and Mary Ellen Hedge Russell.

The thirty-sixth annual Greek Games, a traditional contest in athletics, lyrics, costumes, music and dances of the classical festivals, between the freshmen and the sophomores at Barnard College will be held this afternoon at 3 o'clock in the gymnasium of Barnard Hall, on the campus at 116th Street and Broadway.

Mrs. Dorothy Dillon Strack, widow of Wallace Dohm Strack, a former vice president of the Borden Company of New York, was married to Louis Dejonge of Fitchburg, Mass., yesterday in a private suite at the Plaza.

George T. Dunlap Jr. of Pinehurst, the 1933 national amateur champion, and Frank Strafaci of Brooklyn, N. Y., former national public links champion, won difficult semifinal matches today and will meet over a thirty-six-hole route tomorrow for the North and South amateur golf championship.

William Harris Brown, president and treasurer of a New Haven bolt manufacturing company, died yesterday at his residence here. He was born in Newark, N. J., eighty years ago and had been a New Haven business man for sixty years.
Young men and women students rom thirty-one colleges and' univerities assumed roles as elder statesnen here today and undertook their own solution of the world's political and economic problems.

A field of eleven formidable candidates has been named for the inaugural running of the $10,000 added Tropical Handicap, which will feature the closing card here tomorrow. The event is for 3-yearolds and upward at a mile and a sixteenth, and the Ramsey and Coppage star, Mucho Gusto, carrying top weight of 124 pounds, is the pre-race favorite.

A wave of buying of cash wheat and futures swept prices in the world markets sharply higher today. The advance in North American markets was around 4 cents a bushel at the extreme on reports that the United Kingdom had purchased an estimated 10,000,000 bushels of cash wheat from Australia, the United States, Canada and Argentina, in addition to which the Continental European countries were said to have purchased substantial quantities.

Another stockholders' meeting of the embattled Chesapeake Corporation was adjourned here today, this time until April 15, postponing a major test in the financial struggle for control of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad.
Many parties were given last night at the third anniversary "Night in Capri" dinner dance held in the Embassy suite of the Ambassador for the benefit of La Margherita Society.

Apparently acting on the advice of their government, British millers bought 150,000 tons of wheat within three hours today in one of the biggest day's transactions ever known in peace time in this country.

Mrs. Davis Brooks of New York, the former Miss Adelaide Moffett, has been chosen "Queen Shenandoah XV" for the annual Apple Blossom Festival to be held at Winchester, Va., April 28 and 29. She is a daughter of James A. Moffett, former Federal Housing Administrator.
The Labor Office announced today that unemployment in Germany had been virtually halved during March and amounted to only 508,000. The drop last month was 439,000.

An agreement has been reached with Cable and Wireless, Ltd., which will enable a far-reaching scheme of reduction in telegraph rates between the countries of the British Empire to be introduced April 25.

The Rev. Dr. Arthur Young Beatie, director of the department of evangelism of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, will preside at the dawn service to be held at 6:45 o'clock on the Mall of Central Park, near Seventy-second Street, on Easter. The service,

The Pennsylvania Railroad increased its control of the Norfolk Western Railway in 1937 by the purchase, through a subsidiary, of 900 additional common shares, the annual report of the Norfolk Western to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday.

The Marquess of Milford Haven, second cousin of King George V and great-grandson of Queen Victoria, died today in a nursing home in London. He was 45 years old. A son of Prince Louis of Battenberg, he also had a naval career and his own son, the Earl of Medina, who succeeds him, is now a midshipman.

The current issue of "Life" magazine, containing pictures showing the birth of a child, was banned yesterday from circulation from newsstands in the Bronx and Nassau Counties, and in a large part of New Jersey, while reports of similar action, either taken or contemplated, came from other sections of the country.

Athletes representing Company K carried off team honors in the eighty-eighth annual closed indoor track and field meet of the Seventh Regiment Athletic Association at the Park Avenue armory last night. They ran up 42 points and, moreover, won the chief event of the evening, the George T. Simons Memorial 880-yard inter-company relay, in record-breaking time.

Marshall Field Co. operated at a profit in January and February, Frederick D. Corley, president, told stockholders today at the annual meeting. A year before, the company had a net loss of $1,654,451, including an operating loss of $5,679,209 on manufacturing operations.

Indoor polo play in the city ends for the season tonight when Winston Guest's Optimists face the New York A. C. in the third and deciding game of teh Eastern high-goal championship at Squadron a Armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has set a hearing for April 25 on an application by the Georgia Power Company, Atlanta, a subsidiary of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, asking exemption from filing a declaration on an issue of $2,301,000 of Georgia Power Company first and refunding 5 per cent mortgage bonds due on March 1, 1968.

The general assumption that the Stabilization Fund must be acquiring gold at the present time seems to be supported by the latest figures of the Department of Commerce on gold imports. In the week ended on April 1, more than $53,000,000 of gold imports entered the country,

Representatives of the livestock industry protested today against any reduction on tariffs on meat products in the renewal of the reciprocal trade agreement with Canada. Glen T. Stebbins of the United States Livestock Association, Kansas City, Mo., said the industry wanted the duty on pork products increased.

Estate, less than $5,000.-To Sylvia Palmer Bloomfield, widow, executrix, 315 Central Park West. CARR, GEORGE J. (March 16). Estate, more than $20,000. To John Carr Jr., cousin, 1,165 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, life estate in $35,000; Eleanor G. Burrows, 2,300 Sedgwick Ave., Bronx, $30,000; James R. Fitzgerald, 32 South Munn Ave.,

When a circus rolled into a small city in Vermont, Nebraska or South Carolina, a generation or so ago, it was an event with few peers and no superiors. For excitement it could hold its own with a fire, a cyclone or a flood. A circus in New York City in 1938 is a different story. New Yorkers,

Mrs. Harriet H. Keller, prominent business and club woman, died at her home in Ventnor this morning of a heart ailment. Her age was 56. Mrs. Keller and her husband, Jay E. Keller, operated the Hotel Kelton on South Tennessee Avenue.

It is learned that Baron Louis Rothschild, whose banking firm has- been taken over by the semi-official banking organization, is being held on charges of having acted against the State's interests and having had relations with circles hostile to the State, for he allegedly supported these circles financially.

The Chamber Music Guild of New York gave its third and final concert of the season last night at the Beethoven Association. As at the previous events in this series, the participating artists were- Elly Bontempo, piano; Roman Totenberg,
A tense House of Representatives tonight killed the Reorganization Bill by voting, 204 to 196, to recommit the measure to its special Committee on Reorganization.

Sales of printcloths yesterday reached 20,000,000 yards and brought the week's total to about 38,000,000 yards, the largest volume in about two months. Prices of one or two constructions advanced from the lows of the movement, which had been reached on Monday.
New York State paid $13,852,487.01 in unemployment insurance benefits during the first three months of 1938, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, reported to Governor Lehman today.

Members of the President's own party in the House of Representatives, many of whom owed their places to his great strength before the people in 1936, struck a blow at his prestige today in the defeat of the shreds of the Reorganization Bill which has not been equaled in intensity since the House insurgent Republican revolt against the Taft Administration in 1910.

President Roosevelt conferred with a delegation of Mayors headed by Mayor La Guardia on the relief situation and with President Pelley of the Association of American Railroads on the rail financial problem. He expressed opposition to Federal guarantee of railroad reorganization bonds.

Harvard's Hasty Pudding Club, the oldest college dramatic group in this country, presented "So Proudly We Hail," its ninety-second annual production, last night in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria before about 1,800 alumni, friends, relatives and debutantes.
Dr. William A. Hulse, dean of Suffolk County physicians, died here tonight at his home on Ocean Avenue after an illness which had confined him to the house for three years. He was 79 years old.

Any sound program of loans to business by government agencies must insure that loans are issued strictly on the basis of merit, and must have no place for political favoritism, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, declares in the current issue of Credit and Financial.Management.

Stagehand left today, bound for the Blue Grass State and a crack at the famed Kentucky Derby. The pride of Millionaire Maxwell Howard, the joy of Trainer Earl Sande and the adopted son, whether he likes it or not, of California, will reach Louisville Monday morning.

The application of the United May Day Provisional Committee for a permit to hold a May Day parade with a review in the north end of Union Square as a climax has been approved by. subordinate police authorities and is awaiting the signature of Police Commissioner Valentine, it was learned yesterday.
Turpentine firm, 231/4c; sales, 92 barrels; receipts, 211 barrels; shipments, 144 barrels; stock, 28.176 barrels. Resin, -firm; - sales, 368; receipts, 1,320; shipments, 24; stock, 68,792.

Harold L. Crane, Princeton, '40, won the individual championship of the H. Y. P. D. College Chess League by drawing his last game with Jules A. Marcus, Yale, '38, after a bitter struggle of seventytwo moves last, night at the Marshall Chess Club.
The Indianapolis Speedway Association, which sponsors a 500-mile automobile racing classic each year on Decoration Day, held its annual dinner last night at Dinty Moore's Restaurant.
Delegates to the reorganized Pennsylvania State Federation of Labbr convention today condemned the Kennedy-Guffey-C. I. 0. slate of candidates in the Democratic primaries.

Prices moved upward in cheerful stock markets here today, recovery being general and in some cases substantial. Giltedge issues were bright, but German and Austrian bonds declined in the foreign list. Transatlantic stocks were stronger, with United States Steel and International Nickel prominent.

In a more active market, member trading in round lots for their own accounts on the New York Stock Exchange fell off sharply in the week ended on March 12, representing 16.90 per cent of total volume, compared with 19.07 per cent in the previous week. Total volume was 3,709,480 shares sold, compared with 2,852,570.

While Samuel Reshevsky outplayed Walter B. Suesman of Cranston, R. I., completely in the fifth round of the United States chess championship, Reuben Fine, who is keeping pace with him, faced a sterner task against Fred Reinfeld, undefeated in four rounds.

With another widespread storm threatening to curtail receipts next week, traders actively bought the week-end cattle crop today, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. No choice steers arrived. Despite the storm there were too many hogs to maintain the recent advance and the same was partly true of fed lambs. Spring lambs arrived for the Easter trade, Colorado new croppers having reached $10.25.

New York State and municipal financing came to a standstill yesterday, not a single award of a new bond issue being made. However, several New England municipalities announced invitations for tenders of loans to be awarded during the next week or so.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for March 31 showed the ratio of the gold reserve to notes in circulation to be 118.81 per cent, compared with 119.45 per cent on March 15. The reserve ratio of gold to notes and sight liabilities, however, increased from 84.78 per cent on March 15 to 85.53 on March 31.

The managers of the New York Produce Exchange announced yesterday the appointment of the following committee to nominate officers and managers for election on June 6: Samuel Knighton, chairman; Herbert L. Bodman, Robert W. Capps, George R. Flach, William B. Fritz, L. G. Leverich, Howard E. Norris, Winchester Noyes and A. J. Zock.

Adopting an eleven-point program for presentation to the Constitutional Convention, the executive council of the State Federation of Labor today asked an amendment to the Constitution to give a five-day, forty-hour week to all persons employed by the State or its subdivisions;

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 6: COMMANDERS Flynn, C. W., the Vega, to 11th Naval District, San Diego, Calif., June 13. Johnson, E. R., the Dent, to Bureau of Engineering, Washington, D. C., June 26. Martin, C. F., 11th Naval District, to office of Judge Advocate General, Washington, June 15.

Miss Catherine Reiley gave a tea yesterday at her home, 131 East Eighty-eighth Street, for members of the junior committee aiding in the sale of tickets for the performance of "Bachelor Born," the night of April 20, at the Lyceum Theatre for the benefit of the Catholic Centre for the Blind. Mrs. William F.

A Paterson manufacturer of necktie fabrics and its New York sales agents have agreed to discontinue certain representations alleged by the Federal Trade Commission to be misleading, the commission announced today. John Hand Sons, Inc.,

Miss Lucille Niemeyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gustav H. Niemeyer of this city, has chosen the afternoon of April 20 for her marriage to William H. Hart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph L. Hart of East Orange, N. J.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, in a 4-to-1 decision, upheld yesterday a decision of Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin dismissing an injunction suit which sought to restrain the Holly Sugar Corporation from paying annual dividends in excess of $2 a share on its common stock.

Madison St. 186-188. 42.6x100: excrs will of Jonas Weil to Citizens Savings Bank. Rivington St, s w cor Lewis St, 20x60; Fannie Harris to Central Hanover Bank, as trustee will of George W. Jewett; mtg $11,475 held by grantee.

Sale last week of the "reading copies" which Dickens used in his public readings from his books recalls his tour of reconciliation with America 'seventy years ago. He arrived in Boston Nov. 19, 1867. He sailed home from New York on April 22, 1868. In city and country alike he was received with extraordinary warmth.

Tip's Manitoba Jake, a white and liver pointer dog, owned by Mrs. Edwin H. Vare of Merion, Pa., and handled by Mr. Vare, today was announced as the winner of the members' all-age stake in the annual field trial meeting of the English Setter Club of America.

Joseph A. Bower of Montclair, executive vice president of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company of New York, and Thomas N. McCarter of Rumson, president of the Public Service Corporation, were elected today to life membership on the Rutgers University board of trustees. Dr. Ralph C. Wright of New Brunswick, elected at the January meeting, was inducted.

Ohio State University rolled up 25 points to take a commanding lead in the national A. A. U. senior swimming championship team race tonight, the Buckeyes holding a 13-point edge over Michigan's Wolverines as the nation's aquatic stars took time out until tomorrow, when the remaining five events will be run off.

Mrs. John Ringling, in Hotel Ambassador, Park Ave and 51st St. Russell Owen, in 302 W 12th St; Samuel Fattman, in 2 Horatio St; Lieut. George K. G. Reilly, in 45 Christopher St; George W. Sasse, in 220 E 73d St; Bing Bing, Inc, broker.

The 1,373 bond issues listed on the New York Stock. Exchange, aggregating $48,360,358,911 par value as of April 1, had a total market value of $41,450,248,311, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday.

The Metropolitan Museum will open today its memorial exhibition of work by the American artist Walter Gay, who died last July. The group of thirty-four paintingsmost of which are oils-has been installed in Gallery E 15, and will remain on view there through May 30.

An imposing array of women skiers, headed by the favorites, Miss Marion McKean of Beverly, Mass., and Miss Betty Woolsey of New for the women's national downhill and slalom contests tomorrow and Sunday on Nose Dive Trail at Mount Mansfield.
Samuel T. Potts, religious editor of The Norfolk Virginian-Pilot died here today after a long illness. His age was 71.
Heinz Luawig, for many years the Rome corraspondent for the Vienna Reichspost a Catholic newspaper, has been expelled on a charge of spreading anti-Nazi propaganda.

There is little question that the markets were governed yesterday by a single topic, and the title was "inflation." Whether or not this designation aptly fits the situation is open to argument, but Wall Street certainly uses the broad term to include new governmental outlays for work relief irrespective of whether the money is to be distributed through loans or by means of direct grants.

Marking the third consecutive monthly decline, sales of leading mail order and chain store companies in March showed an average decrease of 11.6 per cent, the sharpest drop for any similar period since recovery began. Only two companies of those reporting had increases, while the declines for the individual concerns ranged to 27 per cent under 1936.

Testimony intended to show that high State taxes imposed under Governor George H. Earle were driving industrial companies out of Pennsylvania was presented by many business men at a hearing held today by the Industrial Tax Study Commission named by the Legislature.

Lieut. Col. David McCoach, army district engineer at New York, today was directed to make a field investigation of Manhasset Bay, N. Y., to determine whether the existing improvement project there should be modified.

A new translation of the preface of ex-Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's "My Austria" has been received in the Knopf office from Vienna. This version contains several paragraphs not included in the preface to the Austrian edition, bringing Schuschnigg's story of Austria down to last December.

Chick Evans, who won the national open golf title in 1916, believes the United States Golf Association is "missing a great bet" by not taking immediate action which would automatically qualify past winners for national open championship tournaments.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $17,474,084, to be represented by one State and forty-three municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $6,462,469 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $26,713,796.

GERALD WARNER BRACE'S "The Wayward Pilgrims"* is a serene and appealing novel that somehow- kept reminding me of Thornton Wilder's play, "Our Town." Probably that's only because they're both New England genre pieces And because they both resolutely avoid the, dour, incisive O'Neill point of view in favor of a more friendly, less disturbing attitude toward the country north of Boston.

The Senate, which moved swiftly yesterday in its consideration of the 1938 Revenue Bill, bogged down today when confronted by Senator Pope's amendment to add a processing tax on the finished products of the five basic commodities covered in the "ever-normal granary" act. The commodities are wheat, cotton, rice, tobacco and synthetic fibers.

Dr. Thomas W. Harvey, a former president of the New Jersey Medical Society, who practiced medicine here for nearly sixty years, died today at his home, 59 Main Street, after a month's illness, in his eighty-fifth year..

A demand by the British Government that the vast expropriated oil properties of its nationals in Mexico be returned on the ground that the seizure was "inherently unjust," was delivered to President Lazaro Cardenas personally at 1 P. M. today by the British Minister, Owen St. Clair O'Malley.

Corps, Hawali; to Fort Leavenworth, Kan., as instruction in the Command and General Staff School Aug. 1.

Well-stocked streams and good fishing conditions for those who go out on the opening day of-the New Jersey trout season are predicted by George C. Warren Jr., president of the State Fish and Game Com mission, so April 15 had better be warm and sunny.

The 139th session of the New York Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church will be held in Christ Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, beginning on April 21, and continuing through April 25.

The engagement of Miss Sherrard Willcox Pollard, daughter of Mrs. James J. Pollard of 787 Park Avenue and Richmond, Va., and the late Mr. Pollard, to William A. Mowry Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Mowry of Madison, Wis., has been announced by her mother.

Declaring that the incapacity of old age is not an "offense" calling for "punishment," the Appellate Division in a three-to-two decision yesterday ordered the city to pay a pension of $50 a month to.Patrick Cosgrove, 71 years old, of 1,702 Amsterdam Avenue. Mr. Cosgrove,

Meeting of the Metropolitan Chapter of the American Association of Teachers of French at the French Institute, 22 East Sixtieth Street, 10:15 A. M. "La vie et les ecrits de Leon Blum," Jean Prevost. Luncheon following, at which Dr. Theodore Huebener will speak on "Foreign Languages in the Elementary Schools."

Palm Sunday will be observed tomorrow in all churches. In Roman Catholic and most of the Protestant Episcopal churches palms will be given away at each service. In many edifices "The Palms," by Faure, will be sung.

By taking. the role of weather prophet, Mayor F. H. La Guardia was revealed yesterday afternoon at City Hall as having saved the city $320,000 in the unseasonal snow storm of Wednesday night and Thursday.

Mass meetings will be staged by some 500 State and local associations affiliated with the National Association of Retail Grocers on National Rally Day, which has been proclaimed for Tuesday, May 10, by the parent association, it was announced yesterday.
Irving L.Ernst, long a lawyer here and a partner in the firm of McManus, Ernst Ernst, 170 Broadway, died yesterday after a short illness in his apartment at the Hotel Pierre.

Part 1 of the library of the late Cortlandt F. Bishop, comprising 1,091 rare. books and manuscripts, brought a total of $325,932.50 in six auction sessions at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc. The last of the sessions, held last night, yielded $58,515.

Sheriff Daniel E.. Finn Jr. filed yesterday an inventory declaring that he had attached securities and cash with an aggregate value of $255,708 owned by Baron Louis von Rothschild, or S. M. von Rothschild, the Vienna banking house which he headed before Germany's annexation of Austria.
Mrs. Stephens Alke, the former Elizabeth Heil, artist, died suddenly today at her home at New Richmond, Ohio. She was 60 years old.

Business circles are urging the authorities to take steps to avoid the dumping of foreign merchandise here, it was announced tonight, in view of the fact that national industries are menaced by low-priced foreign goods to such an extent that many have curtailed their activities.

One of the most interesting meetings that Mr. Hoover had in his journey through Europe must have been that with Mr. Ulmanis of Latvia. The sometime orphan Iowa boy who became President of the United States there found a Latvian farmer's son who studied agriculture in the University of Nebraska and became the first' Prime Minister and organizer of independent Latvia and now its President.

Sales of General Motors cars in March to dealers in the United States and Canada, together with shipments overseas, totaled 109,555, compared with 260,965 in March a year ago, according to figures made public yesterday by the corporation. Sales in February were 94,449.
Mrs. Dorothy Lee Ward of Washington, gave a cocktail party this afternoon at her villa, Susette, for Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Brendel of Pittsburgh and their guest, Mrs. Roy St. Lewis.

Stimulation of private industry-through an enhanced competition so that it will produce a $90,000,000,000 annual income and distribute it more equitably among the people is the great need of the hour, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, today told the special Senate Committee on Unemployment and Relief.

Lectures by Herb Kopf, head coach of football at Manhattan College; Harvey Harman, mentor of the Rutgers eleven, and Chuck Ward, coach of the Rutgers baseball team, feature the program for the sixth annual Rutgers coaching clinic in the Rutgers gymnasium April 15 and 16.

Risking the possibility of being cited for contempt of court, Isaac Penner, electrical contractor, refused yesterday to reveal the name of one of his employes, although directed to do so by John Kirkland Clark, special master in the injunction suit against Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

The costs of trucking flour in New York City will be raised about $300,000 a year through union demands for the use of public loaders on railroad piers for which a loading fee of 3 cents a hundred pounds or 6 cents a barrel has been fixed, it was estimated yesterday.

The newly named steamship Puerto Rico will begin its first voyage for the Porto Rico Line at noon today. The Puerto Rico, formerly the Haiti of the Colombian Line, is starting a newly added eleven-day cruise service to San Juan, Ponce and Mayaguez in Puerto Rico, with fortnightly sailings.

Senator Lundeen of Minnesota proposed today that the government take over the railroads. A bill introduced by him would set up a "United States Railway Service" to take over "operation, control and ownership" of roads which had $1,000,000 or more gross income in 1935.

Deficiency of vitamin C, the scurvy-preventing substance found abundantly in citrus fruits, is prevtalent not only among the poor, who cannot afford orange juice, but also among the well-to-do, it was re- the ported yesterday before the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the American College of Physicians, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, by Professor Irving S. Wright, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University.
Frank Capra today completed the cast of "You Can't Take It With You" and announced that shooting will start April 15 in the old Schulberg studios recently acquired by Columbia.

The New York State Waterways Association has undertaken a campaign to obtain the support of trade associations, canal carriers, shippers and receivers of water-borne freight, pleasure-boat owners and communities affected by the State waterways,

Preparations for the staging of the twelfth annual Morris and Essex Dog Show, the nation's famous outdoor fixture, which will be held at the Giralda Farms, Madison, N. J., on May 28, are rapidly being completed, according to an announcement by the show's officials yesterday.

That there is a growing feeling that the government's program of defense works is insufficient appears indicated by a stream of spontaneous gifts from private individuals reaching the responsible department daily with requests to speed up defense measures.

Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved upward yesterday almost $1 a bale in sympathy with the rise in outside markets on inflationary possibilities in the proposed resumption of heavy government spending.

The 2,100 employes of Abraham Straus, Brooklyn, one of the city's leading department stores, overwhelmingly refused yesterday to have the Department Stores Organizing Committee of the C. I. O. represent them as their collective bargaining agency.

W.W. Hastings, former Representative from Oklahoma, died in a hospital here today. He underwent an operation Tuesday. Mr. Hastings, a Democrat, served in Congress 1915-21 and 1923-34. He was 71 years old.

At least eight persons perished today in one of the worst snowstorms ever known in the normally sunny Texas Panhandle. Hundreds of school children, residents and travelers were marooned by drifts up to twenty feet high left by two days of constant snowfall.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Field--Against JOHN E. ELLIS GOWNS, INC., 64 W. 48th St., by Arnold Fabrics Co. for $242; Abraham Shapiro, $265; Cell-Martin Fabrics Corp., $26. SAMUEL J. MEISELMAN, furs, 237 W. 29th St., by Herzig Hart, Inc., for $250; Louis A. Cohen, Inc., $250; Essenfeld Sons, Inc., $250.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Capt. Herbert V. Ryan, C.A.-Res., 270 Stephan St., Belleville, N. J., is relieved from assignment to the Second Coast Artillery District. 2d Lt. Hugh H. Smith, Inf.-Res., 132 Prospect Ave., Gloversville, N. Y., is relieved from assignment to the 1st Division (not eligible for assignment, active duty or promotion).

A light session today concluded workouts for two Eastern entries in the indoor polo championship tournament, which opens tomorrow night. Ridgewood, N. J., defending champion in the junior division and carrying the maximum of twelve goals,
The Ellis Parkers, father and son, lost an important skirmish today in their fight against standing trial in New York for the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendell.
Twentyseveu deaths and scores of injuries were counted in the South today as the result of floods and- tornadoes which devastated parts of Georgia, Alabama and Mississippi.

MEISELMAN, furs, 237 W. 29th St., by Herzig Hart, Inc., for $250; Louis A. Cohen, Inc., $250; Essenfeld Sons, Inc., $250.
