Smith, Inf.-Res., 132 Prospect Ave., Gloversville, N. Y., is relieved from assignment to the 1st Division (not eligible for assignment, active duty or promotion).

A light session today concluded workouts for two Eastern entries in the indoor polo championship tournament, which opens tomorrow night. Ridgewood, N. J., defending champion in the junior division and carrying the maximum of twelve goals,
The Ellis Parkers, father and son, lost an important skirmish today in their fight against standing trial in New York for the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendell.
Twentyseveu deaths and scores of injuries were counted in the South today as the result of floods and- tornadoes which devastated parts of Georgia, Alabama and Mississippi.

The Kentucky Derby eligible, Sun Egret, who annexed three stakes at Santa Anita and then captured the opening-day feature here, will get an Eastern test over a distance of ground tomorrow when he goes to the post in the mile and seventy yards of the Bowie Handicap.

Furniture and decorations assembled by Mrs. Leonard Elmhirst, the late Mrs. S. K. Pendleton, Mrs. Nathan Straus and others brought $9,813 yesterday afternoon at the first of two auction sessions at the Parke-Bernet Galleries.

William Kennedy, one of the pioneers in the advertising business in this country and for eight years secretary of the Camden, N. J., Chamber of Commerce, died today of a heart attack at his home here.

Carlisle S. Harris has been elected a director of the City Ice and Fuel Company. Directors of the National Cylinder Gas Company will meet on Monday to consider possible dividend action. Edmund C. Stone, formerly assistant to the president of the Philadelphia Company, has been elected vice president and general manager of the Duquesne Light Company.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Viscount Halifax, the Foreign Secretary, made rallying speeches in provincial cities today after the Conservative party's defeat in the West Fulham by-election had thrown doubt on the popularity of the government's foreign policy.

Another milestone was marked today in the decline of the horse as a means of transportation Governor Lehman signed the Steingut bill removing from the qualifications of prospective State troopers the requirement that they be able to ride.

T. O. M. Sopwith, British aircraft manufacturer and yachtsman, is searching for a Galapagos penguin that flopped overboard from the yacht Philante in the early hours of the morning and has not been seen since.

The Posse Gymnasium swimmers defeated the girls' swimming team of New York University. 34 to 23, tonight. It was the New York girls' first defeat this season and the Posse team preserved its record of two years without a defeat.

The most important election in the annals of this historic village will be held on Tuesday from noon to 9 P. M. A proposition involving adoption of a city charter, thirteen questions calling for appropriations of $195,000 and the filling of four public offices will confront the voters.

The State Department of Welfare was urged yesterday by the Milk Consumers Protective Committee to resume its contributions toward the cost of free milk in this city, which charity will cease next Saturday.

An agreement between 400 employes operating 156 buses that transport physically handicapped and other children to and from school in outlying districts and the owner, Children's Bus Service, Inc., over working hours and conditions was reached yesterday in a conference at the City Hall, it was announced by Nathan Frankel, labor counsel to Mayor La Guardia.

East and West broke even tonight in the first round of the national indoor polo championships. Chicago's 124th Field Artillery team swamped Ridgewood, N. J., defending champion in the junior division, 13 to 5.

Frank Strafaci, a Brooklyn boy who once won the national public links golf championships, defeated d George T. Dunlap Jr. of Pinehurst today and became the 1938 North r and South amateur golf champion.
George (Kiddo) Davis, laughing of his recent announcement he was through forever with baseball as "just one big mistake," said tonight he will rejoin the Cincinnati Reds at Winston-Salem. N. C.

The Frick Collection, 1 East Seventieth Street, has acquired from the private collection of Lord Duveen of Milbank a painting by the sixteenth century Venetian artist Tintoretto. The canvas, which will go on exhibition today, portrays a Venetian Senator.
Workers brought theb odies of four explosion victims from the Lorado No. 2 mine tonight after digging

House leaders held up final action today on the War Department Appropriation Bill, passed in different forms by both branches of Congress, because of the $43,000,000 which the Senate voted for seacoast and anti-aircraft defense. The House approved a total of $447,000,000. The Senate raised it to $490,000,000.
The engagement has been announced of Miss Bobbie Witzling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Witzling of this city, to Dr. Harold A. Lentz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Lentz of Clifton, N. J.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Waters, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Waters of West Hartford, to George L. Ray, son of Mrs. George A. Ray, also of West Hartford, took place here this afternoon in the South Congregational Church. The Rev. Warren S. Archibald performed the ceremony.

Antiques Exposition. Hotel Commodore, April II to 16. Antique furniture, silver, glass. pottery, bedspreads, hooked rugs, prints and early American portraits from leading collectors of New York and other States.
Officers of the Second Corps Area headquarters on Governors Island announced yesterday that 500 more New York State youths are wanted as candidates for this Summer's Citizens Military Training Camps.

Contracts to supply the Navy Department with 11,500 tons of ferromanganese, produced entirely from United States ores, recently awarded to two domestic manganese-producing companies, reveal two significant points regarding the situation of the industry in this country.
Rising rivers tonight threatened additional damage in flood torn Alabama, Georgia and Mississippi, drove thousands from their homes, and ruined crops and property in many localities.

The home of James Speyer at 1,058 Fifth Avenue will be the setting tomorrow for a recital to be given by Kirsten Flagstad of the Metropolitan Opera and Bruno Eisner, Viennese composer and pianist, to advance the humane work of the New York Women's League for Animals.

Thomas J. Healey's Tatterdemalion, ridden by Eddie Arcaro, raced to a clean-cut victory in the $10,000 added Tropical Handicap, feature of the program that brought the ninety-six-day Florida racing campaign to a close at Tropical Park today.

Dr. Clarence J. Hicks will discuss "Industrial Relations Between Employer and Employe" before members of the art section of the Manor Club of Pelham, at a luncheon meeting on Tuesday. The civic section will hear a talk on "The Invisible Tax" Wednesday at 3 P. M., by Mrs. Robert Griffith of the Westchester County Tax Payers Association.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended April 6, aggregated $8,841,000,000, or 24 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 11 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

More than 90 per cent of the floor space at the Long Island National Home Show, to be held at the Jamaica Armory from April 30 to May 7, has been taken by a wide variety of exhibitors, Edward F. Hosinger, general chairman of the show, announced yesterday.

The demand for modern apartments continues to take its toll of interesting old edifices linked to New York's past. The Homestead established by Colonel James C. Church on Fort Hamilton Parkway between 100th and 101st Streets in Brooklyn more than a century ago is the latest historic structure to fall prey to progress.

The hopes and fears of the two major parties in this State when they contemplate the Governorship campaign this Autumn are all bound up with the outcome of the Constitutional Convention which opened at the Capitol on Tuesday and will arrive at its working stage when it reassembles the day after Easter.
Two officials of the Pullman Company urged the Interstate Commerce Commission today to approve a 10 per cent increase in the company's rates.

A benefit tea and amateur dog show will be held on the afternoon of April 21 at the Merry-Go-Round, 49 East Fifty-fourth Street, under the auspices of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association, which conducts a widespread program to increase the tidiness of city streets.
Snowplows "worked" up-State roads tonight in unseasonable snow that created a slush hazard for motor traffic in some sections and drifted rapidly before high winds in others.
WEATHER conditions, as might be expected, played hob with Easter trade in the week. Volume was drawing near last year's levels but suffered sharp setbacks where storms were most severe.
In the capable hands of Mrs. Mary Stewart Fickett, blonde and dynamic, rests the selection of the 35,000 men and women who will comprise the New York World's Fair personnel.

London Terrace, the 1,700-apartment development with a normal population of more than 4,000 persons in the block bounded by Ninth and Tenth Avenues, Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Streets, has a diversified ownership, according to an analysis of the first mortgage issue on the property.

With the first court hearing on the Robinson-Patman law in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here last week attracting nation-wide attention, Felix H. Levy, attorney for Oliver Brothers, Inc., and others, who submitted a brief as amicus curiae in the Biddle case, yesterday declared that portions of the law were definitely unconstitutional for several reasons.

Fast-stepping Dale Hanover, current favorite for the 1938 Hambletonian Stakes, showed the class that made him the champion 2-year-old trotter last year to win both heats of the Little Hambeltonian today.

Radio listeners in Lithuania were dumbfounded today to hear Adolf Hitler's Vienna speech rebroadcast by the nation's government controlled station. Heretofore his speeches were banned because of the dispute over Memel.

Adherence to a religion of healthy mindedness was urged by Rabbi Nathan Stern in a sermon at West End Synagogue, 160 West Eightysecond Street, yesterday. Other rabbis preached on democracy and education, the message of Passover and the need for national unity.

A group of executives of Swedish and Finnish pulp manufacturing concerns is en route for New York to negotiate with American customers on the question of price revisions, it was learned here yesterday. American buyers, it was said,

Clear but wintry weather greeted the Giants on their arrival in Colonel Bill Terry's home city, and as a result their attack remained congealed an exasperatingly long time, but eventually it thawed out, and by springing a three-run rally in the seventh while towering Cliff
THE author of this book has long been a specialist in foreign news and the interpretation of it. In that apacity he has served THE NEW YORK TIMES for many years.

About 150 alumnae of Oberlin College, Oberlin, Ohio, attended yesterday in Essex House the annual luncheon' of New York graduates. Miss Marguerite Woodworth, dean of women, told the graduates that she was sorry college curricula no longer contained as much study of classical writers, which, she added, developed "liberality of mind, moderation and perspective."

This tiny principality-the only purely German State remaining outside Germany and the last of all the once-numerous German monarchies--now is aiming to get the powers, and above all Germany, to extend to it the pledge given Switzerland: to respect its territorial integrity, independence and neutrality.

A Treasury check for $619,062.19 received here today ended the eight year litigation of the estate of Henry E. Huntington, California financier, the longest case ever tried before the Federal Board of Tax Appeals.

LONG before Germany annexed Austria, before the Free City of Danzig fell victim to Nazi infiltration, even before the Nazis acceded to power, there were in circulation throughout Germany propaganda maps indicating in red the areas in Central and Eastern Europe which the National Socialists considered "German."
Fire tonight damaged the medieval Norwich Cathedral. The fire broke out during the evensong service. The congregation filed out in an orderly manner and then aided firemen.

Period furniture and other art property belonging to Mrs. Paul Warburg and to several other New York collectors, as well as to Paul Watkins of Winona, Minn., and others, will be offered at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., on Wednesday and Thursday afternoons.
Telegraph companies reported today that they had handled more messages about the Reorganization Bill than were ever sent here on any previous issue.

An automobile hospital where broken radiators will be soldered, bent fenders straightened and sputtering motors made to hum like new is to be opened this Fall under the auspices of the Board of Education.
Mrs. May A. Parkhurst of 307 East Forty-fourth Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Margaret Parkhurst, to Rawson Atwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. George D. Atwood of Brooklyn.

Now that Governor James H. Price has signed the bill appropriating $450,000 toward the new $1,000,000 State Library Building at Richmond, that sorely needed structure is assured. When it is completed some years hence Virginia will have for the first time an adequate repository for the State's priceless collection of original manuscripts and documents, certainly one of the two or three largest and most valuable such collections in the country.

To the Drama Editor: I just had the pleasure of reading Conrad Seller's criticism of my production of his play "Censored" in THE TIMES last Sunday, which is just the alibi of a disgruntled author because his play failed.

YESTERDAY the Metropolitan Museum opened its memorial show of paintings by Walter Gay, who died last Summer. The thirty-four oils and water-colors (mostly oils, however) have been hung in the small gallery known as E-15. Though small,

Rain again cut a wide swath through college baseball yesterday as games all along the Eastern front were canceled or postponed. The steady downpour also cut into other outdoor collegiate activities but the diamond sport was the principal sufferer.

A substantial increase in student participation in useful campus activities at the University of Pennsylvania is being sought by the administrative staff and the student board of governors of Houston Hall, the oldest student union in the country.

Flowers play an important part in the rites of Spring that Easter symbolizes. Women who like to dress up to the spirit of the day turn the trick with a nice finality by pinning a special corsage at the shoulder of the new suit or topcoat.
THE popularity of "Anthony Adverse" in this country as well as in its native land insured that its successor would not lack attention either from the English press or from the English public. .

John Davis, Brooklyn, competing unattached, broke all metropolitan and New York State records with a performance of 803 1/2 pounds in capturing the heavyweight title in the metropolitan -A. A. U. weightlifting championships at the German-American Athletic Club- last night.

HOW an original settler of this so-called "Evangeline Country" of Louisiana brought a shipload of spiders from China so that his two daughters might be married beneath a canopy of goldsprinkled webs has been disclosed in old records discovered by Andre Olivier, self-appointed historian of this area and decorated by the French Government. ent.

The Works Progress Administration will start construction tomorrow of a community center for Harlem at Seventh Avenue and 151st Street, it was announced yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon Somervell, local WPA administrator.

Governor Lehman signed today the Moran bill extending for two years the fivecent fare for the city's independent subway system. It was the only general transit legislation passed by this year's Legislature.

PERRY MASON is back in these United States after a vacation trip to the Orient, and he hasn't changed a bit. He is still a headache to prosecuting attorneys and he still delights to skate over exceedingly thin legal ice.

LONDON.--One of the numerous branches of the British Postoffice is in its hundredth year, though no great fuss is being made about the centenary. It was in 1838 that the postoffice took over the moneyorder system.
Five tapestries were sold yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association - Anderson Galleries, Inc., for a total of $10,750. They were part of a one-session auction which realized $34,128.
THE recent season of Ted Shawn and his company of men dancers at the Majestic Theatre served to reveal as expert an ensemble as has been seen hereabouts in many a day.

ARTURO TOSCANINI and the NBC Symphony Orchestra Will give at least two public concerts in Carnegie Hall next season. The first intimation of the fact comes rather indirectly by special announcements received by mail order purchasers of tickets to this season's concerts.

Mr. and Mrs. Royal Rook of Garden City, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Victoria Rook, to Chauncey Brewster Garver of this city. Miss Rook is a graduate of the Cathedral School of St. Mary, Garden City.
April is the month of field-trial sport for pointers and setters along the Eastern seaboard and more meetings have been scheduled than in any past year in the history of the sport.

WEATHER permitting, eight more or less anonymous men in blue will stand behind the home plate in as many major-league baseball parks this week. They will be waiting, majestically. Surrounding them, in the eight grandstands, will be a total of some hundreds of thousands of citizens, also waiting, but impatiently. impatiently.

Fred Bird, veteran of forty-two years in the steamship passenger business, will retire at the end of this month as assistant passenger traffic manager of the United States lines in charge of the Panama Pacific Line's passenger service.

ALTHOUGH William the Con queror was born more than nine centuries ago, the castle in which he saw the light of day still exists and is the magnet that draws tourists to Falaise. Indeed, Falaise is among the most visited towns of Western France.

Miss Elizabeth Sumner and Miss Nancy Bissell are co-chairmen of a junior committee now being formed to assist with the plans for a bridge party and tea to be given on April 19 in the roof garden of the St. Regis for the benefit of the Church Mission of Help.

The battle of the Lung-Hai Railway has lasted now for nearly three months. Along an immense front about Suchow, marked on the south by the Hwai River, and on the north by the Grand Canal and the gigantic Yellow River, Chinese forces have defeated all Japanese attempts to cross any of these waterways.

Bonds called last week for redemption prior to maturity were in relatively small volume, with few large individual retirements among those ordered. Institutional issues and small lots of foreign bonds featured the week's announcements, which were principally for payment in future months.

The 1938 campaign is already under way in Maine. Monday, the 18th, is the final day for the filing of nomination papers. The primaries will be held on June 20. Maine will vote as usual, about two months before the other States, on Sept. 12, for the election of a Governor and other State officers. Three members of Congress will be chosen in November.

As a result of the sharp rally in share prices on Friday and the even greater recovery yesterday, THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks was able to finish the week with a net gain of 6.50 points. This was the largest gain of any week since the first week in January.

The New York racing season, richest as well as longest in the United States, will get under way on Saturday at Jamaica when the Metropolitan Jockey Club inaugurates its nineteen-day meeting. The Paumonok, a six-furlong sprint for older horses, will be the opening day feature, as it has been for years.

The present ratio of the Reichsbank's reserve to its outstanding circulation, 1.4 per cent, compares with 1.4 a week ago, 1.6 two weeks ago and 1.5 a month ago. The highest ratio in 1937 was 1.7 per cent, reached on June 25; the ratio of 1.4, first touched on Oct. 2, was the lowest.

MEXICO CITY. MEXICO, thrilled and frightened, proud but uncertain, is watching itself undergo metamorphosis at the hands of an enigmatic President who has visions of re-establishing an Indian nation based upon socialism.

AL-QUR'AN, better known in the West as the Koran, is the sacred book of the Moslems, which the faithful believe to be a direct revelation from Allah through the angel Gabriel. The entire revelation was delivered to Mohammed over a period of twenty years.
MISSING a street car was the real beginning of Mr. Fletcher's career as an American advertising man. It was in Birmingham, England, where he was looking for a job, and he was two seconds late.

DETROIT. FIRST real manifestations of a Spring upturn. were felt in the automotive industry the the past week when production of cars and trucks rose 10,000 units to 62,345, as compared with 52,753 in the preceding week.

New Jersey took the lead at the end of the first day's play in the national basketball tournament for schools for the deaf at the Warner gymnasium yesterday with two victories. In the afternoon the leaders defeated Minnesota, 40-30, and at night they conquered Mississippi, 34-24.

Scoring his third straight best in show as he ran his all-time string to eleven, Champion Nornay Saddler, smooth fox terrier from the Wissaboo Kennels of Westbury, L. I., tonight took the premier award in the nineteenth annual all-breed exhibition staged on the Steel Pier by the Kennel Club of Atlantic City.
The thirtieth anniversary of the founding of the Girls Service League of America will be celebrated Tuesday night, April 26, with a dinner at the Hotel Plaza, at which Mrs. Alexander M Hadden.

Assurances have been given to foreign holders of bonds of electric power companies in Japan that every effort has been made to protect their interests under a bill recently passed by the Japanese Diet whereby the government is taking over control of the generation and primary transmission of electric power throughout the country.

THE circus again is in town. Up at the Garden these frantic nights swing the daring young men from flying trapezes, gallop the beautiful young ladies on snowy horses. Also, around the ring, with noise and laughter and the sound of revelry--as well as with a kick for the pantaloons--race the clowns. A congress of clowns. Fat clowns. Fat clowns.

INVITATIONS to play in the masters' individual tournament, which will take place at the Park Central Hotel on April 23, 24 and 25, are first sent out to players who have earned thirty-six or more master points of the American Contract Bridge League.

Henry Armstrong, world's featherweight champion, came to Hot Springs today "to get away from it all." Scheduled for one of the most important fights of his young career with Welterweight Champion Barney Ross May 26 at New York

The foreign exchange market was quiet yesterday, although gains were scored by the more important European currencies. The pound sterling advanced 3-16 cent to $4.96 7-16. while the French franc strengthened a point to close at 3.07 1/4 cents.

WHILE thousands of new annuals and herbaceous plants have been added to the lists grown in this country in recent years, comparatively few "new" woody plants have been grown in numbers sufficient to permit them to become widely available. This is understandable,

Dr. Laurens Hi Seelye, president of St. Lawrence University, tonight criticized colleges which offer specialized training and asserted that "thinking people will be found only in a college which provides a general or liberal education."

A Passover plan to American Jews to support the United Palestine Appeal for $4,500,000 to settle distressed foreign Jews in Palestine was made yesterday by Dr. Israel Goldstein, national co-chairman of the appeal.

Amawalk Quickstep, merry moving black, white and tan bitch owned and handled by Frank Wise of Carmel, N. Y., gave a splendid exhibition today to carry off the top award in the fifteen-inch derby class, feature of the second day's competition in the Long Island Beagle Club's fifth annual Spring trials.
Charles Michelson, director of publicity for the Democratic National Committee, said this in his weekly release, "Dispelling the Fog," for publication tomorrow:
Bristol, whence the Great Western, said to be the first holder of the Atlantic blue ribbon, set forth on one of the first steam crossings of the Atlantic, is celebrating the centenary of that voyage.

The army and its friends took over upper Fifth Avenue yesterday In the usual Army Day parade. Rain that threatened through most of the marching fell as the last of the 20,000 marchers were preparing to pass the reviewing stand. Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia, Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy,

THE World's Fair, said Grover Whalen recently, is going to "take art off Olympus" and make it "part of the warp and woof of the streets." But this is happening already. There are now scores of decorated walls in New York, and scores more being made. They are there because the artists themselves have propagandized so successfully that murals have become
Haile Selassie sent personal protests today to President Kemal Ataturk of Turkey and King George II of Greece against their recognition of the Italian conquest of Ethiopia.

PARIS.-One of the best sellers in France for the past few weeks has been the copy of the French Government's Official Journal containing the new law which modifies the status of the married woman under the Civil Code.

FRANCE has added Dr. Jean Baptiste Charcot to philately's gallery. A portrait of the veteran French physician, scientist and explorer, who perished with thirty-two of his men when his famous polar research ship Pourquoi-Pas (Why Not) was battered to pieces on Iceland rocks on Sept.
Stocks up 2 to 6 points on defeat of Reorganization Bill in most enthusiastic trading of the recession; turnover, 1,410,000 shares, heaviest since Oct. 23, 1937. 937.

Led by Grandin Wise, who scored 10 points, the powerful Princeton track team today added a 72-54 victory over Duke University to the one it scored over the University of North Carolina by 76-50 earlier in the week. Hubert Reavis, Duke's brilliant runner, was the day's high scorer with 16 markers.
Twenty-six parcels of real estate in Brooklyn and on Long Island have been sold recently by the East New York Savings Bank of Brooklyn.

RADIO stations throughout the country will open earlier than usual next Sunday morning for broadcasting of Easter sunrise services. In the event that Pope Plus XI decides to broadcast his annual Easter benediction,

It became clear tonight that the visit here of Jose Maria Cantilo, the Argentine Foreign Minister, was leading to a possible understanding with Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, the Brazilian Foreign Minister, for the close cooperation in Pan-American affairs of the two leading South American countries.

A Palm Sunday Musicale will be presented by the William and Mary Chapel choir tomorrow evening in the auditorium of the Phi Beta Kappa Memorial Hall. The choir, directed by George M. Small, head of the Music Department, will sing the cantata by J. H. Maunder, "Olivet to Calvary."

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Cecil Hardingham of Plainfield have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maude Elizabeth Hardingham, to George Alvin Cowee Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George Alvin Cowee of Brookline, Mass.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustment.

Word was received yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art of the death in Amsterdam of S. C. Bosch Reitz, who was curator of Far Eastern Art at the museum from 1912 until his retirement and return to his home in The Netherlands in 1927. He was 78 years old.
Edward J. Bradley of 125-02 133d Avenue, South Ozone Park, died yesterday in the Adelphi Hospital, Brooklyn, where he was taken on March 28 following a stroke. His age was 53.

Two sessions of play in the sixth round of the championship tournament of the National Chess Federation in the Assembly Hall of the R. C. A. Building, Rockefeller Center, yesterday saw holders of the first two places retain their leadership.
Pensioned On his own application-To take effect 12 Midnight, April 17: PATROLMAN-John F. Redmond, 101st Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Feb. 5, 1912.

The United May Day Provisional Committee shaped its plans for a huge May Day parade on Saturday, April 30, at a meeting yesterday afternoon of 3,000 representatives of trades unions and other organizations at the Manhattan Opera House.

ATLANTIC CITY.--Today the "fifty best-dressed women on the Boardwalk" are to be chosen and honored, as the highlight of the traditional Palm Sunday, fashion promenade that brings Spring-garbed visitors from all over the East.

The problem of juvenile delinquency will not be solved until "the social sciences and economics keep abreast of the physical sciences," Professor Robert Ferrari of the New York Law School declared yesterday at a public forum conducted by the Leonardo da Vinci Art School, 149 East Thirty-fourth Street.

Editorial principles upon which The Commonweal, Catholic weekly review of literature, the arts and public affairs, was founded in 1924, are reasserted in a leading editorial appearing in the April 15 issue of the magazine, the first under its new publishers, the Commonweal Publishing Company.

The National Labor Relations Board, in a decision made public today, held the Republic Steel Corporation guilty of violating the Wagner act during the futile "little steel" strike of the C. I. O. in July and responsible for the deaths of three strikers at Massillon, Ohio, in rioting during the strike.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward P. Simon of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Esten Simon, to Robert Irving Stevenson, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Robert Stevenson of Waterbury, Conn.
The Dodgers "can be pushed just so far." So today they broke their seven-game losing streak by staggering and walking to a 12-9 victory over Bobby Smith's Jacksonville Tara in ten innings.

NEVER mind how the ball clubs will finish. That's a long way off. How will they start? That's more important at the moment. Even those master minds closest to the fighting front, the team managers, don't know The best most of them can offer is a vague promise or a veiled threat.

The superlative performances put forth by Josef Hofmann at his recital yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall were those of an artist whose goal was so lofty that nothing short of absolute perfection could satisfy him. Perfection of the sort is beyond human power.

The world champion Yankees, snowbound for the past two days, returned to the task of playing baseball today in the frigid air that enveloped Travelers Field and, through no fault of their own, enjoyed the pleasant experience of winning.

THIS is the slack season in movie production but no slackening has been observed in the daily volume of tourists who are turned away from or reluctantly admitted through the stern gates of Hollywood's studios.

MAN confronts the universe equipped with two square inches of sensitive retina, a hearing organ that can be packed into a thimble, hands that feel a nose that smells a palate that tastes--and a brain. With this apparatus he must make inferences. Are all these stars, trees, rocks, houses,

Setting the pace from the start, Tres Bon carried the green and orange silks of Manton B. Metcalf Jr., Rumson, N. J., to victory in the Deep Run Hunt Cup race today before 5,000 persons on the sluggish Curles Neck course.

Shipments of finished steel products by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation totaled 572,199 tons in March, compared with 474,723 tons in February, a gain of 97,476 tons, and to 1,414,399 tons in March, 1937, a decrease of 842,200 tons.

With the end of the Lenten season approaching, members of society are directing their attention to several Spring fetes arranged for the latter part of this month and early in May in behalf of various philanthropic projects.

A "crazy world" was portrayed by the Gridiron Club at its semi-annual dinner tonight with President Roosevelt, Cabinet officers, foreign diplomats and political leaders as the guests of the organization of Washington newspaper correspondents.

Freak weather was costly to retailers last week, when blizzards and cold rain swept across a vast section of the country in a week normally pulling the best volume of the Spring season. Declines from a year ago ranged as high as an estimated 30 to 40 per cent in Chicago, where some stores closed early and sent clerks home. A few increases were reported,
Carrickmacross, chestnut gelding owned by Miss Diana Bolling of Greenwich and ridden throughout by her sister, Miss Patricia Bolling, captured the hunter championship at the Round Hill Club tonight.

It dies hard-this notion that inventions are willfully suppressed by wicked corporations. Here comes Representative W. D. McFarlane of Texas with a bill (H. R. 9259) "to provide for the compulsory licensing of patents." If Representative McFarlane has his way, anybody may apply to the Commissioner of Patents for a license to make, sell and use an invention disclosed in a patent which has not been "worked" during the first three years of its life.

ADLER--Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Adler (nee Phyllis Levey), announce the arrival of Robert's sister, Barbara Ruth, on April 6, at Harkness Pavilion. BERNHEIM--Mr. and Mrs. Alvin (Lillian Rettinger), joyfully announce the arrival of Jerome Frank, on April 2. at Rockaway Beach Hospital.

Bernie Miller, 133 3/4, of Harlem, defeated his neighborhood rival, Frank Terranova, 134, in the main bout of six rounds last night at the Rockland Palace. In the six-round semi-final Fred Fitzgerald, 161, New Brunswick, N. J., outpointed Seaborn Ashley, 152, Bayonne, N. J.

The proposed $100,000 match race between War Admiral and Seabiscuit, current rulers of the American turf, moved a step nearer realization yesterday when Charles F. Howard, owner of Seabiscuit, accepted the conditions set forth for the projected contest at Belmont Park in the Fall.

Many of the thrift shops in this city-permanent marts offering for resale a wide variety of useful household articles and clothing as a means to assist financially in the support of numerous charitable endeavors-are now planning annual Spring sales or entertainments to increase their welfare funds and to elicit a wider public interest in their philanthropic work.

A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Irland McK. Beckman of Germantown, Pa., on April 8, at the Harkness Pavilion, Medical Center, in this city. Mrs. Beckman is known professionally as Dr. Elizabeth Hurlock and is a member of the staff of the Psychology Department of Columbia University.
The number "23" has no terrors for the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, apparently, for that is the number of tournaments, including championships, it has arranged for its members this season.

James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx, has appealed to Mayor La Guardia to induce the WPA to provide labor for repairs and alterations on charitable institutions that receive some support from the city.

THE Coolidge Quartet, composed of William Kroll, Nicolas Moldavan, viola, and Victor Gottlieb, 'cello, will give a series of seven concerts, April 18-30, at the Library of Congress, Washington, D. C., under the auspices of the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation. Frank Sheridan,

The annual meeting of the American Women's Club was held Monday when Mrs. Herbert French was elected president, Mrs. James B. Mennell, first vice president, and Mrs. L. C. Beecroft, second vice president. Five new directors elected were Mrs. E. S. Daniells, Mrs. Robert Horne, Mrs. James B. Mennell, Mrs. Warren Pearl and Mrs. Thomas Tyson.

A Negro woman photographically "caught" asleep over her washing while her baby slumbers earned Walter Simonds, a Negro clerk, of 321 Edgecombe Avenue, a $300 merchandise certificate. His photograph, "End of Day," was judged the winning shot from among 5,000
Annual communion breakfast of Knickerbockers Council 221, Knights of Columbus, Hotel Astor, 9 A. M. Speakers: the Rev. Edward Lodge Curran, John DeAngeli, Louis Buffler.
Students in the marketing course at Upsala College here will spend the coming week in local department stores to see in actual operation many of the theories learned in the classroom.

The French-Canadian team of Henri LePage and Fernand Wambst rode to victory tonight in the Indianapolis six-day bicycle race, withstanding a brilliant last-hour drive by the Canadian-Swiss team of Jules Audy and Ernst Buhler.
TO learn something about the radio listening habits of students, a questionnaire was circulated among 350 members of the classes in written English at New York University. .

Technological improvements in the last decade have required relatively small capital outlays but have resulted in the displacement of many workers, thus throwing a double burden on government, Corrington Gill, Assistant WPA Administrator, declared today in transmitting a WPA study on the subject to Harry L. Hopkins, Administrator.
A contract for thirty-seven Douglas C-33 transport planes to cost $2,327,724 was awarded by the War Department today to Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., of Santa Monica.

Bernard H. Sandler, attorney, of 151 West Fortieth Street, and executor of the estate of the late Leo Newman, denied yesterday that Newman's Theatre Ticket Office, at 1,502 Broadway, had charged $7.70 for $2.75 seats for Josef Hofmann's piano recitals yesterday and tonight, as alleged by the pianist in a telegram to Mayor La Guardia, which the Mayor made public on Friday. Mr. Sandler said the agency .
The Cambridge University Rugby football team completed its tour of the United States yesterday with another crushing victory in the mud at the Polo Grounds.

LYNCHING comnitted the first of its historic injustices when it appropriated the name of the real Judge Lynch. a mild-mannered Virginia Quaker who had considerable difficulty in overcoming his scruples against war before he took his place among the Revolutionary patriots as Colonel Lynch of the home guard militia As a historian of lynching Mr. Shay does justice to the probity and reputation of Colonel Charles Lynch,

New York University won the women's intercollegiate fencing championship tonight by defeating Hunter College of New York, 5 to 4, in the final match. The tournament was held at the College of William and Mary all day, with the Northern teams showing top form.

To the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, into whose hands Congress has placed the task of making loans in the aggregate amount of $1,500,000,000 to business men, the role of large-scale banking is nothing new.

Henry Ikeler, Assistant Coroner, said tonight that Max Wolf had asserted his father's admiration for Adolf Hitler lay back of the quarrel that resulted in the slaying of the youth's mother, Elsa Wolf, 46, and that attempted suicide of the father, Oswald E. Wolf, 59. a grocer.

WINSTON-SALEM, N. C. "The Lord is risen! The Lord is risen indeed!" Clear on the morning air these words ring out, beginning the Moravian litany that has been read from the steps of the Home Moravian Church in Winston - Salem, N. C., every Easter morning for 167 years.

BETTE DAVIS and the Warner Brothers have gone into the second round of their annual battle. Miss Davis seems to be at a disadvantage just now, having been suspended by the studio for refusing to appear in "Comet Over Broadway."

IN this brief novel, vitally concerned with the clash of two opposing social theories, the reader is given the opportunity of watching a most exciting drama develop before his very eyes--he almost hurries to see whether it is possible that the solution can turn out to be so amazingly logical;
FOUR artists working in mediums that for exhibition purposes are generally grouped together, stand out among the week's arrivals.
With Congress again in session, Colonel Fulgencio Batista, chief. of staff of the constitutional army, is preparing to push forward the enactment of the legislation proposed in his Three-Year Plan.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Leonard of New York were among those entertaining at Tropical Park for the close of the horse racing season today. Mr. and Mrs. W. W. Martin of Spring Lake, N. J., were hosts to Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bauer of Montclair.

Among the forces tending to bring about a change in architectural and industrial design and the related arts is technological invention with its subsequent development, according to Alexander Stavenitz, artist.

The same day on which the Washington New Deal received a large wallop in the defeat of the Administration's Reorganization Bill marked a distinct setback for the Paris New Deal. Again the Popular Front met defeat when the Senate turned down Premier Blum's demand for extraordinary powers which would have given him the right to take important fiscal steps without consulting Parliament. And Blum, who epitomizes the New Deal in France, had to resign again.
Successful printing of a daily newspaper on paper manufactured from black gum pulpwood was announced today by Dr. Charles H. Herty, chemist who first developed newsprint from slash pine.

Formal organization of the National Real Estate Foundation is announced by the National Association of Real Estate Boards, following a recent meeting in Washington, D. C., of its board of trustees appointed a short time ago to draw up final plans.

A new system of television synchronization, the designers of which claim positive solution of the problem of keeping the images on the receiver's screen in exact electrical step with the sending station, thereby preventing flickers and distortion of the views, was demonstrated yesterday in New York by the National Television Corporation, 52 Vanderbilt Avenue.
Watchers on the docks awaiting the arrival of the 10,000-ton Moore McCormick liner Moormachee tonight were horrified to see her crash into the tug Seipner, which had been nosing her into the harbor.

The engagement of Miss Kathryn Heidgerd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. D. W. F. Heidgerd of this place, to James McRobbie Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McRobbie, also of Sloatsburg, has been announced by her parents.

NEARLY every one longs to jump from concrete pavements onto springy turf when Spring brings the first days of warm and enervating sunshine, and a golden splash of forsythia in an apartment courtyard tantalizes rather than satisfies. s.

A green and white seal, marked "Peace is the New Patriotism," the newest anti-war sticker designed to further pacific ideals throughout the world, is now carrying its message on letters sent out by metropolitan organizations. Mrs. Charles F. Robbins of West Orange, N. J., originator of the new sticker,
