Gerard, wartime Ambassador of the United States to Germany, is convinced that Chancellor Adolf Hitler has not only revived the former Kaiser's policy of penetration down through the Balkans, but is achieving it on a much firmer basis.

BARBER-Katherine, beloved wife of H. Forrest Barber. suddenly, on Friday, April 8, at 406 Central Park West, New York City. Services at Walter B. Cooke's Funeral Home, 117 West 72d St., city, Monday, April 11, at 3 P. M. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.
Farmers spend more than their wives for clothes until they move to town and then it is the reverse, according to a cost-of-living survey being tabulated by the Bureau of Home Economics.
The City Planning Commission's East Side rezoning proposal was criticized yesterday by Langdon W. Post, former chairman of the City Housing Authority, in a radio address over station WNEW.

Despite a slight increase in the number of foreclosures on Manhattan real estate during March, following February's advance, the totals for the first quarter of this year reveal a marked improvement over the same period of 1937 and the two previous years, according to the monthly foreclosure report of the Real Estate Board of New York, released yesterday.

Off-shore fishermen who take their sports cruisers out beyond Sandy Hook for tuna and perhaps for a chance at a marlin will have safer going this season, thanks to a new protection by the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey

Japanese and Chinese are fighting in widespread suburbs of Tsinan, the capital of Shantung, following a revolt yesterday by two battalions of Chinese who had surrendered when the invaders occupied the city.

Although the trend among undergraduates is away from the teaching profession, an occupational survey of the 2,607 alumnae of New Jersey College for Women shows far more alumnae in the teaching profession than in any other.

C. I. 0. leaders, charging that 300 of their allies in the gold country had been banished from- their homes: by "violence and lawlessness" in a citizens' "purge," demanded State and Federal protection today.
The impression is very widespread in ecclesiastical circles in Rome that the future of relations between the Vatican and Germany will be decided soon.

Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Moore Cleaver of Bronxville, N. Y., gave a luncheon here yesterday at Sherry's at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Elizabeth Cleaver, to James T. Sundquist of San Francisco, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester R. Sundquist of Norfolk, Va.
Spanish Insurgents announced advances tonight against a Government army fighting desperately to protect its lifeline Mediterranean coast highways.

From New Brunswick, Canada, comes word that the ice in the Miramichi River is weakening, and guides are preparing for an early "ice out." One old guide, who has quite a reputation as a prophet, says only a sharp drop in the temperature will prevent the river from breaking loose over the week-end.

Manufacturers of railway equipment in. this country received orders for ten locomotives, 682 freight cars and one passenger car in March, compared with seventeen locomotives, 109 freight cars and fifty passenger cars in February, according to Railway Age.

SKIPPING right over the Summer, which might not be a bad idea, observe that Gilbert Miller's first Broadway show next season could very well be "The Gardener," by Frederick Lonsdale. The producer had previously planned it first for London, but now a reliable report says that Metro-Goldwyn Mayer will be interested in a Miller presentation of it here in September. This assumes, of course,

Fred Mounts and Harry Wheeler of Indianapolis scored a 1,335 series and took first place in the doubles standings of the American Bowling Congress tonight. They supplanted Richard Kriese and Sam Vanini of Buffalo, who had held the top since March 25. with a score of 1.322.

The Supreme Court considered today whether to pass on Dr. Francis E. Townsend's appeal from a 30-day jail sentence imposed for contempt of a House committee. He was convicted for walking out on the committee while it was investigating his proposal to pay $200 a month to the aged.

A "Declaration of Independence" From The Sun (Ind. Rep.) By defeating the Reorganization Bill the House of Representatives declared its independence of Franklin D. Roosevelt and gave heartening notice to the country that it would not allow itself to be utilized as a rubber stamp for the Executive.

The mediation commission, which convened here on Feb. 23 to settle the boundary dispute between Nicaragua and Honduras, adjourned today until June 9. In the meantime members of the commission will study the claims and documents of both sides and prepare a plan for final settlement.
Postmaster General Farley has announced a revision of the program for the coming series of postage stamps, which are to present portraits of the twenty-nine Presidents who are no longer living.

GLENDALE, Calif. USE of Handley-Page wing slots and flaps has given the new Timm transport plane an unusual performance for getting into and out of small landing fields, according to Vance Breese, who recently completed test flight of the machine.

According to a recent poll supported by The Brown Daily Herald and conducted by The Quadrangle, Manhattan College undergraduate weekly newspaper, Manhattan students show a distinct interest in world affairs.

A special committee of the New York State Medical Society has formulated a public health program, calling on the government to provide medical care for those too poor to pay for it, regardless of whether they are on relief,

Britons, who themselves vote sadly and unwillingly and then mostly only in a crisis, are watching with amused interest the visit of a German floating polling booth, the Wilhelm Gustloff at Tilbury tomorrow.

Evidence that acute infantile paralysis can be treated by injection of a hypotonic salt solution into the blood stream has been found in a series of experiments, first on monkeys and later on humans, by Dr. George M. Retan of the College of Medicine at Syracuse University. The experiments were started in 1935.

Robert E. Strawbridge Jr., chairman of the 1938 Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army, announced last fight the receipt of an anonymous gift of $45,000. The fourth week of solicitation of a city-wide fund of $600,000 to maintain the army's welfare and institutional services begins today.

" Who's Who in New York," tenth edition, has just been published. The previous edition was issued in 1929, and in the intervening years many changes have taken place among the leaders in all phases of life in the city and State.
THE current "craze" of setting old-time tunes to swing tempo proves, perhaps better than any commentary on the subject, that there is nothing new under the sun.

President Clarence P. McClelland of MacMurray College announced today the gift of a library building to the college from Mrs. Annie and Henry Pfeiffer of New York City. The gift is made conditional on the obtaining of $100,000 for endowment of the library.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Eron of 418 Central Park West have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Shirley Eron, to Sidney Sukoenig, son of Mrs. Abraham Sukoenig of this city and the late Rev. Mr. Sukoenig.

DURING his first visit to New York since he was appointed director of the Federal Bureau of Air Commerce, Denis Mulligan last week told the Air Board the government probably will soon begin a nationwide airport survey to determine the adequacy of the nation's landing fields for the growth of air travel.

A COUNTRY-WIDE poll of book reviewers and literary editors has been taken by The Saturday Review of Literature in answer to the question; "What books of 1937 do you nominate for this year's Pulitzer Prize awards?"

BALAGUR--BLOCK--Mr. and Mrs. Max Block announce the marriage of their daughter, Sylvia, to Mr. Emanuel Balagur, Sunday, April 10, 1938. DONNER-GABEL-Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Gabel, 749 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, announce the marriage of their daughter, Judith R., to Mr. Aaron Donner, son of Mrs. Ida Donner, 1,436 Carroll St., Brooklyn, on April 9, 1938.

Mayor La Guardia congratulated 105 firemen, members of the Fire Department Academy, yesterday on their graduation from a special engineering course. The Mayor attended the ceremony in the Arsenal in Central Park after witnessing the Army Day parade.
WASHINGTON CONGRESS, which lost its backbone in 1933, has found it again. That backbone is not yet quite as good as new, but it is mending rapidly.

Despite Britiain's sharp note yesterday demanding Mexico's return of expropriated oil companies, the Mexican Eagle (Aguila) Company, local parent of all British petroleum entities in Mexico, today took final steps toward breaking up its entire organization in this country, indicating that Downing Street has little hope of the return of the properties in the near future.

During the first quarter of this year Levitt Sons, builders of the Long Island developments of Strathmore at Manhasset and Strathmore at Rockville Center, sold seventynine new homes, more than were sold during a similar period in any year since the firm's inception, the Levitt interests announced yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Alonzo B. Sherow of Mahwah, N. J., have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Norma Duke Sherow, to Thomas B. Kennedy, son of Mrs. Norman S. White of Short Hills, N. J. The wedding will take place the morning of April 22 in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Suffern, N. Y.

THIS is a high-colored panorama of thirteen years of sport, a summing up of the success and sob stories, the ballyhoo and gags and great moments of that period when Ruth was setting his home-run record, when Jones was readying for his "grand slam" in golf, when Dempsey was a supposedly unbeatable champion, and Rickard was promoting million-dollar gates.

The graphic art division of the WPA Federal Art Project announced yesterday that seven prints by division artists had been selected for the exhibition "Fifty American Prints." which will be opened April 19 in the galleries of the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.

The total business volume transacted by the FHA's three insuring offices in and around New York City during the first quarter of this year represented $13,127,000 in mortgage values, Thomas G. Grace, New York State director of the FHA, announced yesterday.

Fifty-six leading chain, specialty shop and department store companies had an average increase of 5 per cent in sales aggregating more than $5,000,000,000 last year, while net profits declined 13.2 per cent under the 1936 figures, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Josephine Holzman, daughter of Mrs. Julius Holzman of Chicago and the late Mr. Holzman, to Edwin L. Demuth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leopold Demuth of this city.

Defeat of the Government Reorganization Bill has ended prospects that Congress will pass any highly controversial legislation at this session. This was obvious as leaders sought today to assess the legislative and political situation following recommital of the Reorganization Bill by the House last night.

*100-Yard Free-Style -- Peter Fick, N. Y. A. C. 220-Yard Free-Style - Ralph Flanagan, Miami Biltmore Club. 500-Yard Free-Style-Flanagan. 150-Yard Back-Stroke--Albert Vande Weghe, Princeton. 220-Yard Breast-Stroke-Jack Kasley. Michigan.

A benefit luncheon and bridge party will be held on April 28 in the roof garden of the St. Regis under the auspices of the entertainment committee of Stony Wold Sanatorium, Auxiliary No. 6. Members of the committee will discuss plans for the event at a tea to be given tomorrow by Mrs. Duncan R. Linsley at her home, 101 East Seventy-fourth Street.

While Samuel Reshevsky, titleholder, and Reuben Fine, most famous of America's younger generation of chess internationalists, are setting the pace, as expected, in the United States championship of the National Chess Federation, George N. Treysman and Albert C. Simonson are giving promise of repeating their brilliant performances in the tournament of two years ago, in which both were prize winners.

Leon Blum's second defeat by the Senate since the Left Popular Front was elected less than two years ago may, in the opinion of many, prove an important turning point in the political development of France.

Charles Noto, 55 years old, owner of a grocery store at 405 East Sixteenth Street, Manhattan, was shot in the left shoulder by one of four youthful hold-up men at 10 o'clock last night as he was reaching for his own pistol, for which he has a Permit.

Miss Helen Downes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Almon Downes of Montclair, was married this evening in the home of her parents to Donald Willis Light, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee R. Light of Dillon, Mont.

In the wake of the defeat of the Reorganization Bill Wall Street prices soared yesterday. Shares gained from 2 to 6 points in a 1,414,000-share day, the heaviest two-hour session since Oct. 23, in the midst of the Autumn collapse.
SO effortless is the handling of today's motor car that the average driver continually is tempted to forget the impact potentials of the vehicle of which he is in control.
Holy Week ceremonies which always bring thousands of pilgrims to Rome will open tomorrow with the traditional blessing of the palms.

Welsh's boy won the annual Spring Derby in field trials sponsored by the Irish Setter Club of America near here today. The son of Terry Welsh and Welsh's Lady is owned by Bert Welsh of Buckingham, Pa., and was handled by Thomas Carmody of Lambertville.

EMMA BROCK'S "The Run away Sardine," "To Market to Market," "The Hen That Kept House," and others, with their folk-tale flavor, have long been popular. This, her latest book, contains stories about real children and the things they do.

The 135th Street Y. M. C. A. of Harlem, New York, captured the State Y. M. C. A. basketball championship tonight by defeating Mount Vernon in the final event of the tournament. The score was 48 to 45, the closest of the session.

A lively interest in the children's museum idea as evidenced by progress in plans for two new centers in the metropolitan area is reported by Mrs. Dean C. Osborne, chairman of the children's museum section of the American Association of Museums, organized less than a year ago in New Orleans.

THREE post-season performances of opera, consisting of a special non-subscription performance Wednesday night, and a Good Friday matinee of "Parsifal," and "Tristan and Isolde" Saturday afternoon, will be given this week by the Metropolitan.

MANHATTAN night life in late Lent being fully as exciting as playing polo with a hearth broom, suffer, if you will, an abrupt plunge into the realm of trivia, or, as very conceivably parlayed by Tecumseh at adjoining typewriter, into the department of flotsam, jetsam and sowhatsam.

Styles in hardware, points out an interior decorator, have changed in recent years in a manner very similar to the changes in home design. In Colonial-type houses the choice ranges from the wrought-iron thumb latches to the brass and silver cutwork plates with graceful drop handles.

Every automobile club in New York State will be represented at a conference called for April 18 just before the reconvening of the Constitutional Convention and which will have as its chief topic of discussion the proposed clause in the State Constitution to devote all motor vehicle registration fees and gasoline taxes by the State to highway purposes only.

THE exacting task of making a picture about the Spanish civil war without disclosing on which side the hero is fighting nor identifying the enemy has been completed by Walter Wanger. Starting out as "Castles in Spain."
French counter-espionage agents arrested today two soldiers, two contractors and an engineer on charges of selling to Germany plans of fortifications under construction for the French Army.

Recommitment of President Roosevelt's Reorganization Bill by the House of Representatives was interpreted here yesterday by representatives of business interests and politicians as a victory for public opinion and a defeat for President Roosevelt.

Charges that "Trotskyism was interfering with a WPA project and that the Workers Alliance helped only members of the Communist party created a heated scene on the meeting floor of the annual convention of the Workers Alliance of Greater New York yesterday.
Pasquelina Tripodi, 14 years old, won a medal yesterday in recognition of her fight for better homes for East Side residents. It came about this way:
Leonard Barron, one of the foremost authorities on dahlias and roses in the East, died of pneumonia today in the Meadowbrook Hospital, East Hempstead, after an illness of two weeks.

While the fate of the world theoretically hung in the balance in the chapel of Rutgers University today, a young Japanese woman student from Swarthmore College nearly disrupted the meeting of the Model League of Nations Assembly with an excoriating speech denouncing democracy and defending the "realistic" philosophy of the fascist powers.

THE ROYAL PHOTOGRAPHIC SOCIETY of Great Britain has announced its eighty-third Annual Exhibition. The exhibition is of importance to serious photographers, and every amateur who has visions of some day signing "F. R. P. S" after his name is studying the announcement.

As a preparation for the "holy plebiscite" on the Austrian Anschluss tomorrow, Germany as well as Austria observed today as the "Day of the Greater German Reich." It was proclaimed by the National Socialist regime which has turned it into an apotheosis of national unity and of national discipline but also of national power and of the right of might.
Squadron after squadorn of Loyalist fighting planes roared over Barcelona today. There were new planes in that lot and the people below went wild with joy on seeing them.

The battered Chicago Black Hawks, hockey's perennial underdogs, who fought their way into the Stanley Cup finals against the powerful Toronto Maple Leafs, will "come out fighting" again tomorrow night.

THIS book is not a biography of Dwight L. Moody: it is a portrait. And it is the portrait not primarily of a man who was a famous preacher and evangelist, but of a sturdy-spirited, dynamic, unpredictable, surprisingly sensitive and tolerant and amusingly whimsical American whom everybody loved.
Owners of homes at this season of the year particularly should be on guard against possible damage to the foundations and lower sills of their dwellings by termites
EXTENSION of radio's guest star invitations is adding many dabs of color to the pattern of broadcasting. Some of the tints are brilliant,

With orchestras in constant rehearsal, waiting lists for individual practice rooms and the stages crowded with ballet dancers, the university of Rochester's Eastman School of Music is preparing for its annual music festival.

Robert E. Sherwood's "Idiot's Delight" has settled down into the town's biggest success. It has played to capacity at matinee and evening performances since its opening, and the library deal (ticket "buy") equals the one made at the Apollo for Elisabeth Bergner's "Ecape Me Never!"

Joe Cox, 233, Kansas City, threw George Koverly, 220, California, in 29:30 of the feature wrestling exhibition at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last. night. A crowd of 2,000 saw Cox end the contest in 29:30. Four other bouts on the card were thirty-minute tests.
JOHN APPY, an Englishman of French Huguenot birth, came to the American colonies in 1756 as secretary to the British commander-in-chief, Lord Loudoun. .
President Roosevelt, according to close friends, is considering a Summer fishing trip which would take him by warship to one of three areas far from the United States.

A will disposing of a fortune left by Mrs. Hegula W. Albertus, "bird woman" of San Anselmo, which bequeathes $250,000 to the Audubon Society of New York, to be used for the betterment of birds, was filed today.

THERE is the old saw, familiar to every one, about the man who prayed to be delivered from his friends. Mr. Barbirolli must have invoked it mentally at a dinner recently given in his honor in this city, when one of the speakers praised him by inferentially belittling his predecessor at the Philharmonic-Symphony concerts. That predecessor,

All but "six or sixteen" members of the crew of the Greek freighter Mount Kyllene were believed to be safe on board rescuing ships last night after a violent explosion had severed the vessel amidships and sent the two halves drifting in the mid-Atlantic Ocean about 200 miles north of the Azores.

Miss Marion McKean of Beverly, Mass., today won the women's national downhill ski race on Mount Mansfield's Nose Dive Trail. Her time was 2 minutes 56 seconds. Second was Mrs. Grace Carter Lindley of the Sun Valley Ski Club, Idaho, in 3:42.3. The next three in 3:42.3.

Herbert L. Martin, Bergen County editor of The Hudson Dispatch, Union City, died today of coronary thrombosis. His age was 58. Born in Elizabeth, he began his newspaper career in his youth and served successively on The Plainfield Courier-News, Jersey Journal, Bayonne Times, Newark Star Eagle, Trenton True American, Philadelphia Public Ledger, Paterson Press Guardian and The Hudson Dispatch.

Endorsed by the Federal Commissioner of Education, about eighty college communities and other cities will observe the fifteenth annual "Guide Right" Week, beginning April 24, under the auspices of Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity, Negro Greek-letter society.

IN a great passage in a great book E. M. Forster once wrote: "An old, old trouble eats the heart out of every civilization: snobbery, the desire for possessions, creditable appendages; and it is to escape this rather than the lusts of the flesh that the saints retire into the Himalayas."

The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 8: MAJOR GENERAL Blanding. A. H., chief of the National Guard Bureau, one day leave, April 11. COLONEL King, J. C., Cav., Des Moines, Iowa, to organized reserves, Philadelphia, Pa., July 5.

SOME mighty disquieting news has been coming out of England ?? late. In the face of a vastly troubled Europe, old John Bull has apparently been scratching his head. Members of Parliament have been calling one another all sorts of impolite names;
In the University of Rochester's Medical School is a gait laboratory. Here reigns Dr. R. Plato Schwartz whose main interest in life is feet in motion-horse's feet, dog's feet, but chiefly human feet.

In an effort to emphasize literature's relation to art, the Department of Modern Languages and Literatures in Princeton University has reorganized its undergraduate curriculum along lines set by the institution's recent experiments in humanistic education.

THINGS are at sixes and sevens between Shaftesbury Avenue and Broadway. After paying his second visit to New York at the holiday season, Ivor Brown, critic of The London Observer, has been writing petulant pieces about the Gotham theatre in The Observer and The Illustrated London News, and J. B. Priestley,

The Fifteenth (International] Brigade received the news this morning that Battalion Commissar Fred Keller, Milton Wolff and Leonard Lamb, three of its five commanders lost in the Insurgent break through at Gandesa, had found their way back to the Loyalist lines after having wandered for six days in Rebel territory.
The ninth anniversary luncheon meeting of the Twenty-third Street Association will be held on April 21 in the George Washington Hotel. Congressman Bruce Barton will be the chief speaker.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Goodrich Crane gave a dance tonight at Model Farm, Dalton, in honor of Major and Mrs. Horace Harding, who are leaving tomorrow for Honolulu. Major Harding has been assigned to an army post in Hawaii for two years.

The National Council of the Socialist party, after a lengthy night session, decided near 4 o'clock this morning against participation in a government headed by Edouard Daladier, the Premier-designate.

It is reported tonight that, in addition to gradually building a six-month supply of wheat to run parallel with its rearmament program, the British Government secretly has appointed a food controller at a salary of o10,000 a year.

Emulating the little Dutch boy who saved his city from destruction by plugging a hole in the dike with his finger, the City Council last week rammed a $10,000,000 plug into the emergency tax structure built by the city four years ago to keep its flood of relief cases in check.

The marriage of Miss Mary James Kent, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Frederic H. Kent of Haddon Hall, Tudor City, to Philip Burdette Booth, son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Booth of Orange, N. J., took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.

FOUR interesting exhibitions of work by sculptors figured in the attractions opening last week and still current. One of these was of work by an American woman; another, of work by one of our foremost ceramists; a third, by a Scandinavian sculptor already known in our museums and galleries, and the fourth, of drawings and photographs of monumental work by a Russian. ussian.

One of the busiest localities in the Nassau County suburban section of Long Island from a realty standpoint is Manhasset and the immediate vicinity, judging by reports from builders and developers in that area.

Senator Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire asserted -tonight that the Republican party was "the only-available force of sufficient national strength which may be mobilized to return our government to the people and give us once again a government by laws and not by men."

THE return of the Fifteenth United States Infantry from Tientsin, China, after more than twenty-five years' continuous service there, eliminates from our army's foreign service stations the post that nine out of ten officers ordered on foreign service would have selected in preference to any other.
LATEST of the strange animals to be brought to this country from far-off lands is the giant panda, known until recently only by professional naturalists and cross-word puzzle addicts.

Kicks and queries from the cornfields are already beginning to cause headaches in local administrative offices of the AAA, although the new program has as yet been advanced to the point of individual acreage allotments in comparatively few counties. Most of the trouble so far anticipated arises from the number and variety of relationships existing between landlords and tenants.

In the next to last weekend of the long Winter dinghy sailing, the first of two sessions of which was held today at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, Frank Campbell in his B boat Felix and Mrs. Helen Hill in her Class X craft Dunker, both from Larchmont, were leaders, as was Leonard Romagna of the local fleet in his D boat Jenny.

Eighty-two students have been pledged to membership in twenty-five Hunter College sororities this semester, it was announced by Miss Marjorie L. Langenbahn, faculty adviser of the Pan-Hellenic Association of the college.

P. S. A. L. elementary school swimming championships in two divisions remained in the possession of the reigning teams as some 300 youngsters vied for honors in the 75-foot C. C. N. Y. pool yesterday. Public School 51 of Manhattan retained the seventh and eighth year title, while Public School 82 of Manhattan continued to rule the fifth and sixth year group.

Mrs. Jacob Solis Carvalho of Lawrence, L. I., an active member of Clio for forty-seven years, will receive the first life membership ever bestowed by that organization at its fiftieth anniversary luncheon at the Hotel Astor tomorrow. Mrs. E. George Payne will preside.

Boys are studying farming in New York City, an activity of the Board of Education unknown by many until public announcement last week that a prize for flower identification had been awarded by the Garden Center to William Dalton, 15 years old, a sophomore in the Agricultural Division of the Newtown High School, Queens.

In a mood of national exaltation over a great national victory which crowds into the background both the disapproval of its details and misgivings over the future, 50,000,000 men and women of Germany and Austria will go or be brought to the polls tomorrow to ratify by their votes Chancellor Hitler's Anschluss of Austria to Germany and to elect the first Reichstag of "the Holy Germanic Reich of Teutonic Nationality" created thereby.
Miss Mary Peyton Herren was married to Read Mecleary yesterday morning in the chapel of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church by the associate pastor, the Rev. James A. Paul.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Virginia Ryder Shannahan, daughter of Mrs. Richard J. Shannahan of this city and the late Dr. Shannahan, to John E. Cornyn of Chicago and San Francisco, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John E. Cornyn.

Another toy typewriter, similar to the one believed to have been used by the sender of the first note in the Levine kidnapping case, was found shortly before noon yesterday in the course of a search in Westchester and near Greenwich, Conn., by about 2,000 Boy Scouts.

Problems relating to both the car and its control in the cause of safety were brought sharply before the Connecticut Highway Safety Conference at New Haven last week by the Research Associate in Transportation of Yale University. Parts of his presentation which aroused marked interest appear below.

Carroll Glenn, violinist, a native of South Carolina, will be the only musician presented in a New York debut recital next season under the auspices of the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation, it was announced yesterday.

Many political observers are expecting the approaching Democratic primaries to provide important tests for President Roosevelt's New Deal Administration. They foresee sharp intra-party contests, with President Roosevelt's prestige at stake.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

Twenty horses hitched to peddlers' wagons, filled with flowers, fruit and vegetables, stood wearily in 100th Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues last night while their owners or lessees were temporarily incarcerated in the Twenty - fourth Precinct station house, charged with peddling without licenses.

The promotion and appointment of 130 undergraduate students enrolled as commissioned officers in the City College unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps was announced yesterday by Major Roy S. Gibson, acting chairman of the Department of Military Science and Tactics.

ROCKY MOUNT, N. C.-This State's Garden Fortnight, which began yesterday, promises to unfold historical and botanical beauties to rival any in the South. Although vacationists and garden lovers have long been aware of the annual Spring glory of Charleston, Natchez and Williamsburg, this is the first time that North Carolina has sponsored an open house for her gardens and historical sites. sites.

Mrs. Emma Louise Felton Lyon died yesterday at St. Elizabeth's Hospital, Fort Washington Avenue and West 190th Street, after an illness of two weeks. She was 85 years old and lived at 506 West 170th Street.

THE mood of a purposeful trek through the city's markets may not be so provocative as the mood of a slow meander along Fifth Avenue, but one comes home from either expedition with at least one conclusion lodged firmly in mind: Winter is past.

A group of young women headed by Miss Catherine Reiley is aiding Mrs. William F. Cogswell and members of the executive committee in the sale of seats for the performance of "Bachelor Born," the night of April 20 at the Lyceum Theatre to raise funds for the Catholic Center for the Blind.

THE STORY OF ALASKA. By Clarence L. Andrews. By Caldwell, Idaho: The Caxton Printers. $4. A history of its development. LETTERS OF QUEEN VICTORIA. Edited by Hector Bolitho. 8vo. New Haven. Conn.: Yale University Press. $3. Letters from the archives of the house of Brandenburg-Prussia. Translated from the German.
WASHINGTON. "COMPOSITE" television is a newly invented system for which a patent (No. 2113473) has been granted to John C. Batchelor of New York.

The official closing occurred Thursday of the exhibition of Bolshevist atheist and anti-religious propaganda organized at the Pontifical Russian College to enlighten public opinion on bolshevism's methods both in Russia and in other countries in its fight against religion generally and against Catholicism particularly.

An elaborate setting reflecting. the luxury of a ballroom in old Vienna has been devised by members of the National Arts Club and some of their friends for a Viennese ball to be given at the club, 15 Gramercy Park, on the night of April 20. Mrs. Nevil Monroe Hopkins is chair-man of the ball committee.

PROBABLY the most conspicuous representative of Hollywood's obscurest profession: that of the voice double, who sweetly sings while your favorite stars soundlessly open and shut their pretty mouths, Virginia Verrill (who has a pretty mouth herself) is rejecting bona fide screen offers these days, and not caring if she has to spend the rest of her life, at a handsome salary, of course, in radio.

NEW field of entertainment for sightless persons is being explored by the American Foundation for the Blind which last week completed a Talking Book translation of Walt Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs."

While squadrons of planes droned overhead 20,000 men in uniform, including the personnel of the city's ancient military units, marched through mid-town Philadelphia today in a parade in observance of Army Day and of the tercentenary

WHEN, on Tuesday evening, seven Mayors and four Governors stand up in Washington, D. C., to receive for their States and cities first prize awards in the various divisions of the National Traffic Safety Contest, the ceremony will hold a message to the nation that there is an answer to the traffic problem.

THE Boston Symphony, under Serge Koussevitzky, will give its annual five evening and five afternoon concerts next season in Carnegie Hall. As usual, the concerts are scheduled for Thursday nights and Saturday afternoons, except the first concert of the third pair, which will be offered on a Friday night. night.

All the things said about Sun Egret's mud-running ability Were sustained today, when he led from start to finish of the Bowie Spring Handicap to score by two and a half lengths at the end of a mile and seventy yards.

Recommendations for improving the relations between landlords and tenants are contained in the preliminary report submitted last week by the committee on housing management of the Citizen's Housing Council. Abraham Goldfeld, manager of Lavanburg, Houses, is the chairman of the committee.

The following Foreign Service changes since April 1 were announced today by the State Department: Raymond H. Geist of Cleveland, now serving as Consul at Berlin, designated First Secretary of Embassy there to serve in the dual capacity. John H. McVeagh of New York, Second Secretary of Embassy at Mexico City, assigned Second Secretary of Legation at Dublin.

The recent protest by such men as Charles P. Taft, William Allen White, Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick and some 500 others against the "blueprint of dictatorship" proposed by the May bill, now pending before the House, should arouse public opinion to a realization of the perils to democracy implicit in another war.

Weetamoe, trial horse of America's Cup yacht race contenders, today was granted a ten-day "stay of execution" before going to the junk pile. Albert A. List, treasurer of the Merits Corporation, which purchased the sloop from Chandler Hovey,

Obesity may be the result of mere mood, according to Drs. Mark F. Lesses and Abraham Myerson of the Boston State Hospital's division of psychiatric research. "People who are restless because their lives are unsatisfied may be seen nibbling candy, nuts, crackers and the like," they write in The NewEngland Journal of Medicine.
The annual Spring session of the Eastern Section of the American Congress of Physical Therapy will be held Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital, 100th Street and Fifth Avenue.
Defeat of the Reorganization Bill was a personal blow to Representative Boland, the Democratic whip, because it marred his record as a legislative prophet.

COPENHAGEN.--The Aland Islands, in the Baltic Sea, whose status the world hoped to have settled seventeen years ago, are again agitating Northern Europe. The reason is a renewal of demands that the island group, under Finnish sovereignty, be fortified.

The department of government and legal status of women of the New Jersey League of Women Voters, of which Mrs. A. J. Steelman is chairman, will conduct a second "jury school" tomorrow at 1:30 P. M. at the New Jersey College for Women, New Brunswick.
Robert Schaper of Brown University, Miss Jeanne Laupheimer of Brooklyn and Miss Virginia Schakel of Indianapolis tonight were crowned national A. A. U. swimming champions in three events.

THE end of the war in Spain will be welcome, for the people are weary of conflict. Many times recently I have traveled through the country, on General Franco's side and in Loyalist territory, and everywhere I have seen a growing desire for peace.

Charges of "bungling" and broken promises were flung at officials of the New York World's Fair Corporation yesterday afternoon as the State of Oregon, through Thomas F. Gunn, vice chairman of Oregon's World's Fair Commission, announced its withdrawal from participation in the exposition.

AN attempt will be made to settle sixteen major issues related to superpower broadcasting when the Federal Communications Commission holds a hearing on May 16. The FCC has requested all interested parties to file notice of intention to testify within fifteen days. .

In sympathy with a buoyant stock market and improvement in most other commodities, cotton gained 7 to 8 points yesterday. Increased activity in goods quarters, which swelled sales to the largest business for any single week in several months, and a delay in planting operations due to excessive rainfall and unseasonably low temperatures, stimulated buying in several directions.

Miss Louise Wynne West, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Harry West of Guilford, Baltimore, and Harold Braff of Montreal, son of Mrs. A. Louis Braff of California, formerly of Quebec, were married this afternoon by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Harris E. Kirk, in the Franklin Street Presbyterian Church. A reception was held at the home of the bride's parents.

Dr. Henry Fleischman has retired after thirty-two years as director of the Educational Alliance, one of the largest neighborhood centers in the city, at 197 East Broadway, and Samuel Fishzohn has been appointed as his successor,

Dr. George Gaylord Simpson, a curator at the American Museum of Natural History in New York, received a divorce from Lydia Pedroja Simpson of New Haven on grounds of intolerable cruelty in a memorandum of decision handed down today by Judge Edward J. Quinlan in Superior Court.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:
THE opening a few weeks hence of the northbound highway through Inwood Hill Park, connecting the newly constructed upper deck of the Henry Hudson Bridge with the West Side Express Highway,

There are three great industries in this country which, individually, can start a recovery-building, automobiles and railroads. Full prosperity can be sustained only when all three are simultaneously making their full influence felt as buyers of billions of dollars' worth of goods.

Arturo Toscanini, who came to Palestine to conduct a series of concerts with the Palestine Orchestra, arrived in Haifa by plane this afternoon, accompanied by his wife. He was met by an orchestra committee, officials, Dr. H. Simon, general manager of the orchestra; H. W. Steinberg, conductor, who rehearsed the orchestra in the program selected

ONE of the dogmas of the faithful is that from the Reconstruction period to the Bryan explosion in 1896 American political history is meaningless and uninteresting. There were no issues, nothing but squabbles over candidates. Meaningful history took a sleep between the Civil War and the Populist alarm bell.

Bobby Pacho, sturdy Mexican welterweight, and Pete De Ruzzi of Mamaroneck will collide in the star bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace tomorrow night. The semi-final will show Vince Dell'Orto, clever Italian light-weight, against Eddie Hess of the East Side.

Purchase of more than $50,000 worth of quicksilver here in the last ten days-in sharp contrast with the previous dull market mystified California mine operators today. The orders were placed through local banks instead of the customary channels.

The special feature of the concert given last night in Radio City by Artur Rodzinski and the NBC Symphony Orchestra was Dmitri Shostakovitch's Fifth Symphony, then performed for the first time outside of Russia.

SCHUBERT'S share of the chamber music recorded by Victor from The New Friends of Music series may not be so impressive as the Mozart listed here last week, but in its choice and performance are evidence of the same fine taste, and the recording is equally good.

" THE STRONGEST SON, a new novel by Barbara B. Stevens, takes its title from a quotation from George Meredith, "change. the strongest son of life." A simple, moving tale, it tells the story of change in the life of Christopher Cardinal and in the town to which his forefathers brought their strength and their weakness 300 years ago. ago.

The fifteen largest banks in this city held nearly one-third of their total assets in the form of cash on March 31, a compilation of their statements of condition shows. The banks resumed their sales of government securities in the first quarter of this year after having been buyers in the final quarter of last year and sellers for five successive quarters prior to that.

WASHINGTON.-With so many nations rearming, the work of the thirty-two officers serving as military attaches at twenty foreign capitals has become increasingly important to the War Department. Through these officers the general staff receives most of its information on military developments abroad.

The reports of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the New York Telephone Company, its principal subsidiary, for February and the first two months of the current year were made public yesterday and showed sharp decreases in net income

Miss Elizabeth Marie Bryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan J. Bryan of this place, was married here this afternoon in St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church to Stuart Selick Richardson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles King Richardson of Glen Ridge.
Judge Harry S. McDevitt ruled today in a decision affecting more than 150 local movie theatres that "bank night," bingo and similar games of chance were illegal because they were "lotteries."

Some time next week-probably just after Parliament adjourns for the Easter recess-the British and Italian Governments will bring forth an agreement that has been in prospect ever since the abandonment of sanctions in the Summer of 1936.

Plans were announced yesterday by Wood-Hopkins, Inc., owners of extensive acreage in upper Westchester County, for a development to be known as Overlook Lake Country Homes. The site is about a mile from Yorktown Heights and six miles from Katonah. It is near Mohansic Park.
THE sheers are here, those darlings of the Summer. They hang limply alluring on the racks, awaiting the selection of the wise woman who sets forth early to do her shopping while the stock is fresh.

The National Labor Relations Board issued a complaint today against the Western Union Telegraph Company accusing it of violating the Wagner Labor Relations Act by discharging employes who had joined the American Radio Telegraphists' Association.

Alice Rogers, a 9-year-old farm girl, was the heroine of an airplane crash Friday in which two men were badly injured. She rode a horse bareback six miles to telephone for an ambulance after a light biplane plunged 500 feet into a plowed field near Millet, thirty miles south of Edmonton.

Governor Lehman was urged yesterday in a letter signed by Jeremiah F. Cross, acting State commander of the American Legion, and thirteen other representatives of allied organizations to reverse his veto of the McNaboe-Devaney bill to bar Communists from holding civil service positions.

About 200 guests attended the fifth annual Junior Bal Masque tonight in the 'rose garden of the Bellevue Stratford The beneficiary of the event was the Craft Workers Guild, of which Dr. John P. Chapman is chairman.
The Radnor Hunt Club team, ridden by Harry, Alex C. and John R. Stokes, retired the Buttonwood DChallenge Trophy at the fifth

To take "guesswork" out of determining soil character and foundation conditions under buildings, highways and bridges, students of the University of New Hampshire, aided by National Youth Administration funds, are completing and equipping their own laboratory.

A new group method of teaching it, developed by the WPA's Federal Music Project, has brought music into the lives of large new groups, according to a report today by Dr. Nicola Solokoff, music project director.

Installation ceremonies for the newly formed Adolph S. Ochs Memorial Post of the American Legion were conducted last night at the Concourse Plaza Hotel in the Bronx. Congratulatory messages were received from Governor Lehman, Governor Gordon Browning of Tennessee, Mayor La Guardia and others.

Three Columbia Spring sports outfits are scheduled to see action this week. The Light Blue crew will race in its opening regatta against Manhattan and Rutgers Saturday on the Harlem River, while the baseball and tennis teams each have two contests carded.

As an improved method of teaching English to foreigners, the Adult Education Program of New York City's Board of Education is planning to bring miniature subways, street scenes, markets and banks into the classroom, George H. Chat-field, director of the Bureau of Attendance, announced yesterday.

Forty thousand Scotsmen traveled north today, enthusiastic over their country's first soccer triumph at Wembley since 1928. Playing in bitter weather, Scotland defeated England, 1 to 0, in the concluding match of the international series before 93,000 spectators.

Under the patronage of several hundred men and women of prominence, the performance of "Parsifal" on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera will be given to augment the scholarship fund of the Henry Street Settlement Music School and to help maintain that institution.

Adam K. Geiger of Scarsdale, vice president of the Chase National Bank of New York City, has purchased a residence on a plot of about one acre on Evandale Road, Fort Hill Estates, in the Scarsdale area of Greenburgh, Westchester County.

As a result of the severe drop in production, industry has cut down the use of management and industrial engineers by 50 to 60 per cent under a year ago since the start of 1938, executives of these organizations reported yesterday.

To curb foreign propaganda in schools and especially to combat nazism, the Federal .Administrator of the State of Rio Grande do Sul has issued a decree nationalizing education in the State and forbidding the teaching of any language but Portuguese in public schools.

The chamber of the House of Representatives in the United States Capitol was crowded last Friday afternoon. Most members were on the floor. Visitors packed the galleries. Speaker Bankhead, standing at his desk, put the question: Should the controversial Reorganization Bill, product of so much storm and stress, be returned to a committee for further study? An affirmative vote would kill the bill.

The contrasting requirements of metropolitan daily and local weekly newspapers were cited by newspaper men in discussions on college publicity today at the second district conference of the American College Publicity Association at Drew University.

The National Labor Relations Board today ordered the Empire Worsted Mills of Jamestown, N. Y., to cease recognizing a company union as negotiating representative of its employes and to offer reinstatement with back pay to Angelina Conti, whom it found was discharged for

The Women's New Jersey Golf Association schedule for 1938, just issued, reveals an ambitious program beginning on April 29 with a one-day tournament at the Echo Lake Country Club, Westfield, and ending on Oct. 28 with a one-day tourney at the Upper Montclair Country Club.

The marriage of Miss Majel Keith Brooks, daughter of Mrs. Charles Alvin Brooks of New York and the late Dr. Brooks, to William Irving Miller of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., son of Mrs. Elmer E. Miller of Sewickley, Pa., and the late Mr. Miller, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Riverside Church.
Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. R. Crooks of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet. Gale Crooks, to C. Roderic Gibbins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert C. Gibbins of South Orange.

WHATEVER Noel Coward is to the British, Sacha Guitry is even more to the French. The Gallic author-actor, at whose plays audiences have howled and hissed, has been a phenomenon in the theatre since the beginning of the century. .

Mrs. Isabel Howell Browning, daughter of Harry LaFitte Howell of Rockville Center, L. I., and the late Mrs. Howell, was married to Francis Firth Pickslay Jr., son of Francis F. Pickslay of Baltimore and Mrs. Gwladys Tenne Pickslay of Babylon, L. I., this afternoon in the Prospect Presbyterian Church here by the pastor, the Rev. Arthur N. Butz.

Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Houk Law of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Katharine Law, to Richard Hiller Amberg of Oil City, Pa., son of Mrs. Max W. Amberg of this city, and the late Mr. Amberg.

CARDIFF. VIEWED from the vantage point of South Wales, the social significance of the coal problem and the new scheme for solving it take on a vividness which could not be imparted by all the official blue books and royal commission reports of the last twenty years.

A local boy, Herbert Spiselman of Columbia, who captained the Evander Childs High School team last year, came through in brilliant fashion last night to top a strong field and win the Intercollegiate Fencing Association freshman foils championship and the famous Clemens Medal on the strips of the Fencers Club.

A venture into high finance, carried on through some of the most difficult years for banking institutions, has proved definitely successful for a woman who started out as an actress in a minor role in "East Lynne."

" Advanced" ideas in planning of home interiors, as devised by certain modern European architects, are being adapted to houses in various parts of this country, or are being studied with interest here.

Mr. and Mrs. L. Carbery Ritchie have returned from their Winter home at Fort Sewall, Fla., and are at the Savoy-Plaza. Mrs. Norman E. Ditman will return from Palm Beach tomorrow, and will be at the Pierre.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. - Eight hundred miles of. Berkshire brooks and rivers will be open to trout fishermen starting next Friday for four months. Excellent sport is expected, especially in such streams as Konkapot River in New Marlboro and Hop Brook in Tyringham.
A high source said tonight that present plans call for trying Kurt Schuschnigg, the last Chancellor of an independent Austria and a foe of Nazism, before a People's Court early next Fall.

President Roosevelt will take up in detail with his fiscal and relief advisers Monday his plans for a pump-priming recovery program which contemplates new outlays in loans and direct spending possibly running into billions of dollars.

American manufacturers experiencing a shrinkage in sales as a result of the current recession are concentrating more ??ales efforts on export markets now than in any similar season in the last five years, officials of foreign trade groups said here yesterday.

THE endemic interest in the curious and chromatic past of California in gold rush days has multiplied the reprints of the diaries and books of the early adventurers. They remind us of the courage, fortitude and gambling spirit of the pioneers-and of the differences between their lives and ours.

ABEL--ROTHSTEIN-Mr. and Mrs. Leonard L. Rothstein of 151 Central Park West announce the engagement of their daughter. Sara Hinda, to Jacob Wallman Abel of Washington, D. C., son of Mrs. Milton S. Abel and the late Mr. Abel.

Playing on a soft field and in rain for the larger part of the time, Navy routed Harvard at lacrosse, 13 to 2, today. The Navy stickmen scored six times before Halstead shot truly for the Crimson late in the first quarter.

To obtain closer identification of coloring materials used in cosmetics, questionnaires have been sent to members of the Toilet Goods Association asking for a complete list of such materials being used and those which the manufacturers consider they have "a right to continue using;"

An order delaying burial of a body taken from the Delaware River near Philadelphia was issued today by Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis as a new development in the Morris J. Felzener murder case.

The pushcart fruit and vegetable venders of Paddy's Market, under the elevated on Ninth Avenue, between Thirty-seventh and Fortysecond Streets, lost yesterday for a second time their legal battle to avoid being ousted by the city to make way for an approach to the new Lincoln Tunnel.

Work on the under-river sections of the twin tubes of the Queens Midtown Tunnel will start tomorrow at 2:30 P. M., when Mayor La Guardia turns the valve that will let into the bulkheads of the boring shields the compressed air required to hold back the waters of the East River.

Army's lacrosse team exhibited a fast attack in spite of a heavy snow which fell during the entire game to defeat Penn State today, 10 to 2. Scoring in the first minute of play and amassing a 7-to-0 half-time lead, the victors were never pressed.

A special House committee will study a proposal to free Tom Mooney from the San Quentin prison. The committee was created today by Chairman Summers of the House Judiciary Committee, who named Representative Celler as chairman

THE individual does not matter at all. The only thing that matters is the nation. And the nation feels itself not only pressed by economic need to expansion but called by divine right to leadership. It must hasten to catch up with other nations and move on ahead; to that end it is advancing with unparalleled efficiency.

The fifth educational conference of the Connecticut State Federation of the American Association of University Women will be held Wednesday at the New Haven Woman's Club. The topic will be "Does Connecticut Provide Equitable Educational Opportunities for Its Youth?"

A movement to persuade industry and labor to settle their differences, and give joint backing to legislation acceptable to both sides, gets under way this week under the guidance of Edward F. McGrady, one-time ace "trouble shooter" of the U. S. Department of Labor and at present in charge of labor relations for the Radio Corporation of America.

The legislative committee of the City Fusion party, on report of its subcommittee on milk, headed by Mrs. Ellen Olson, called yesterday for the removal of the A and B classifications on milk sold in New York City, as serving no useful purpose.

WASHINGTON. AS part of the country-wide observance of National Air Mail Week, May 15 through 21, the Postoffice Department will release on May 14 a tri-colored six-cent air-mail stamp to displace the current air item of that denomination. omination.

Grocery manufacturers will grant floor stock price protection to sub-warehouses maintained by chains, provided several retail outlets are serviced from such warehouses, it was learned here yesterday.

Sewell L. Avery, president and chairman of Montgomery Ward Co., who joined the board in January, was elected yesterday a director of the Pure Oil Company at a meeting of stockholders in Columbus, Ohio, it was announced here.
Illinois is within forty-eight hours of the end of a broiling ?? campaign in which the warring Democratic leaders, Governor Henry Horner and Mayor Edward J. Kelly of Chicago,

As evidence that the recession has augmented the demands on social welfare and health agencies, the Social Service Exchange reported yesterday to the Greater New York Fund that it had cleared 654,560 cases in 1937, an Increase of 195.094 over 1936.

IT would be natural to call the social settlement a typically American institution if it hadn't been invented in England. America has at least furnished a ripe opportunity for it, and because of an astounding variety of human material in huge, polyglot cities has given it a typically American atmosphere. .

One of the largest realty transactions for several months in the Morristown (N. J.) home area has just been closed in the purchase by a New York investor of six new homes and several unimproved plots in the Spring Brook Estates under development by a syndicate known as Suburban National as a high-class residential community.

Perennial national and Pacific Coast track and field champions, the University of Southern California's Trojans got off to a flying start for 1938 honors today with a 741 1/4-56 3/4 victory over the University of California's Bears.
Many of the recent purchasers of plots in the Highland Lakes community, near Stockholm, in the upper Sussex County area of New Jersey, are planning to construct log cabins for Summer occupancy.

Harbors and channels will look different this season to cruising yachtsmen once they finish their fitting-out and steer from their moorings. Boat owners may hibernate from October to April, but the Lighthouse Service never does, and Superintendent J. T. Yates of the Third District headquarters on Staten Island has kept his fleet of tenders on the move installing new buoyage and changing the characteristics of lights and beacons to conform to new conditions.

The protracted debate over the Administration's Government Reorganization Bill--ending with recommitment in the House-and President Roosevelt's denial of "dictatorship" leanings which that measure inspired sent many people scurrying through the legislative record of the past five years to learn how much authority the Chief Executive already had and the circumstances under I which it was conferred.

On all fronts but one--the psychological sector of the depression-the President and his Administration began to move this week as it was reported last week that they would. "Loans," as distinguished from admitted gifts and grants, were expanded from the $1,500,000,000 proposed for aid to business of all sizes to about $5,000,000,000, of which WPA will have $2,000,000,000 and PWA $1,500,000,000 if Congress goes along with the President. .

The marriage of Miss Patricia A. Yuill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lionel Shirley Yuill of Montreal, to Edward V. Molson, son of Mrs. H. S. S. Molson, also of that city, and the late Mr. Molson, took place here yesterday morning in the Church of the Transfiguration.

Although the Home Owners Loan Corporation has become the largest home-owning institution in the country, the number of residential properties in the corporation's ownership in proportion to its total of mortgage loans represents a lower ratio than that of private -lending institutions, Charles A. Jones, general manager, declared yesterday. ay.

CORRECTION: In bankruptcy court Richard Whitney, former Stock Exchange head, listened last week to an inventory of his belongings. Clothing included forty-seven suits, eight pairs of shoes, twelve canes, four pairs of riding boots and four red, fox-hunting coats. Items concerning his liquor supply called for correction.

An election to determine whether the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's agents in New York City, Westchester County and Long Island wish to be represented in collective bargaining by the Industrial Insurance Agents Union, Local 30, C. I. O.
Two New York dancers and musicians, Misses Ruth and Zina Dickstein, sisters, who recently were arrested in the little town of Zbaszin, were allowed to leave the country today.

Reports from many of the leading builders and developers of small and medium-priced home centers in Queens and other parts of Long Island reveal a steady increase in both building and selling activity.

The police of the West Thirtieth Street station moved to put an end to violence in the strike of 15,000 fur workers yesterday when they notified manufacturers in the district that the police would supply escorts for employers and loyal workers upon request.

Search for the torture slayers of Mrs. Weston G. Frome and her daughter, Nancy, swung tonight to the international border region at Del Rio, where reports of a man and woman in an automobile answering the description of the killers' car spurred authorities to feverish activity.
Five games were completed yesterday in the women's national chess championship tournament at Rockefeller Center without disturbing the positions of the three leaders.
A spokesman for the Department of Justice said tonight that the Criminal Division was studying a report of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on activities of the GermanAmerican Bund.

ALTHOUGH we have known all along that Lenin didn't have horns, we had begun to suspect--from passing references to him in several Russian films-that a golden nimbus hung over his head and that he spoke only in manifestoes. toes.

The marriage of Mrs. Eleanor Bartlett Phelps, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Pomeroy Bartlett of this city, to William Converse Skinner of Farmington, Conn., son of the late Colonel and Mrs. William Skinner of Hartford, Conn., took place here yesterday in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.
Four foreign educators have been appointed to the faculty of Columbia University for the academic year 1938-39, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, announced yesterday.

The Columbia and City College fencing teams battled to a 13 1/2-13 1/2 deadlock on the Lion strips yesterday in their final dual match of the season. The Lion sabermen won by 6 to 3 to equalize the slight superiority of the Lavender fencers with the other weapons.

DESPITE the loss by fire or structural failure of nearly all big airships of recent design, inquiry made last week shows the consensus of America's leading technicians favors continuance of dirigible development by the United States for commerce and national defense.
Taking its cue from the spectacular rise in stocks, the market for domestic corporation bonds soared yesterday under the leadership of convertible industrial and secondary railroad issues.

The marriage of Miss Louise Yim, president of the Central Kindergarten Normal School of Seoul, Korea, to Soon Kyo Hahn, director of the school, took place yesterday afternoon in Riverside Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Eugene Carder, associate pastor.

Miss Kathryn Louisa Teller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Howard Teller of Maplewood, was married this afternoon in Morrow Memorial Methodist Episcopal Church here, to Harry Charles Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Brown, also of this place.

Because of the large number of students who have applied for positions in Summer camps through the Occupational Bureau at Barnard College, the Physical Education Department has announced a course in camp training for the Spring term this year.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe signed an order yesterday authorizing William J. Wardell, who was required to furnished a bond of $10,000, to act as receiver in bankruptcy for the Broad Street Hospital and to continue operation of that institution for fifteen days.

Garden beginners who were hopefully counting on an extra early Spring as a result of the spell of unusually warm weather in March have been rudely shocked by the sudden comeback staged by Old Man Winter. More experienced growers, however, were not greatly surprised.

The marriage of Miss Jean Lovell Gregory, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Dymond Gregory of Montacute, Oakville, Ont., to William Dunn Richmond of New York, son of Mrs. Arthur L. Walker of Dongan Hills, S. I., and the late Stacy C. Richmond, took place here yesterday in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

The Browns, who had won fifteen straight exhibition games from minor league, semi-pro and university teams, learned today at the expense of their winning streak that major league opposition is different.

IF I were to approach you without warning and, in a muted contralto gurgle, were to observe irrelevantly, "That's all there is; there isn't any more," you might think it odd of me, but at least you would know what I was up to.

Battleships larger, mightier, more costly than anything the world has known may soon be on the ways in American shipyards if Congress approves the recommendation Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations, made last week to the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs.

The beginning of heavy nation-wide Spring rains and the early rising of China's rivers, which the Chinese forces may utilize by cutting dikes and flooding enormous areas, threaten further delays and setbacks to the Japanese military plans.

Rexford G. Tugwell, former Under-Secretary of Agriculture and head of the Resettlement Administration, will become the new chairman of the City Planning Commission, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday. He will succeed A. A. Berle Jr., who resigned March 7 to assume the position of Assistant Secretary of State.

A new unit in Scharfft's restaurant group will be opened on Friday at 566 Main Street, New Rochelle, Westchester County, Gerald Shattuck, president of the Frank G. Shattuck Company, operators of the Schrafft's stores, announced yesterday.

Postmaster General Farley today asked for bids on six new air mail routes, adding about 2,500 miles to the system. Bids are to be opened on May 3. The longest route will be from Tampa to Tallahassee and thence to Memphis and Atlanta via intermediate points, a distance of 948 miles.
Police 'were reinforced today to safeguard against possible disorders in connection with demonstrations tomorrow by the "Tural," an extremist student organization.

The first authoritative survey of the military importance of Anschluss to Germany appears in the Military Weekly, styled "an independent periodical for the German armed forces" but naturally issued in very close collaboration with the War Ministry.

CHICAGO. TEN years ago Chicago admiringly called Frank J. Loesch "The Spirit of '76" because he was 76 years old and fighting for freedom of a peculiar brand. Yesterday he reached 86, and now Chicago affectionately calls him its Grand Old Man because his fight is over, and won. nd won.

San Quentin Prison authorities disclosed today that Albert Kessell, sentenced to death in the State's new lethal gas chamber, had bequeathed the cornea of his left eye to the Rev. U. E. Harding of Portland, Ore.
The first helium sold by the government to private interests for medical purposes has been shipped from the plant at Amarillo, Texas, Secretary Ickes announced today.
The Bey of Tunis tonight proclaimed a state of siege over this capital of French-governed Tunisia while French troops fought to restore order as a result of day-long riots.

Homewood Flying Dutchman, white, liver and ticked pointer dog owned by the Homewood Kennels of H. L. Curry of Pittsburgh and handled by Fred E. Bevan, carried off top honors today in the junior all-age stake, a leading event in the annual Spring field trial meeting of the English Setter Club of America.

Concrete mixers replaced steam shovels this week at the site of the new Recreation Building on the Wellesley College campus as President McAfee promised undergraduates their first swim in the completed sports center by January.

MONTICELL, a. PLANS of the national government to memorialize Thomas Jefferson by isuing a three cent stamp, by minting a new five-cent piece and by constructing a $3,000,000 shrine in Washington, have served to direct new interest toward Monticello, his mountaintop home in Albemarle County.

The committee on Federal legislation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York has disapproved, as a possible threat to the independence of the judiciary, the Sumners bill, which provides a method for removal of Federal judges.

The plight of the Jewish child in Nazi countries will be discussed at the annual donor luncheon of the New York Chapter of Hadassah at the Waldorf-Astoria on Tuesday. As the sole American agency of the Youth Aliyah movement, which is concerned with immigration, the Zionist organization is interested in the transfer of Jewish children from Germany, Austria and Poland and their settlement in Palestine.
Lyndon E. Adams, president of the Anchor Packing Company, died of a heart ailment today at his Winter home in Southern Pines, N. C. His age was 67.
IT is seldom that garden literature offers a work ably thought out and executed, beautifully illustrated and bound, and yet planned and written for the gardener of moderate means.

Finance Minister Benjamin Roca in an address today urged a scaling down of Peru's foreign debts commensurate with the depreciation of Peruvian currency. He indicated Peru would resume service on her foreign debts, amounting to approximately $85,000,000, if the bondholders accepted the proposed reduction.

The second day of the ninth annual convention of the National Federation of Jewish Men's Clubs of the United Synagogue of America was marked by special services yesterday at Temple Shaare Zedek, 212 West Ninety-third Street,

Mason Lindsay, senior chemical engineering student in the New York University College of Engineering, has been awarded a thousand-dollar fellowship by Tau Beta Pi, national honorary engineering society.

WASHINGTON.-Since Congress made its first appropriation for the introduction and distribution of reindeer in Alaska, the reindeer herds of the Territory have increased from a few hundred to an estimated 700,000 or 800,000,

An attractive 20-year-old brunette was a "Lady in the Royal Court of Hoboes" today, "knighted" personally by Jeff Davis, King and Emperor of the Knights of the Road. "I knight the lady," pronounced "King" Jeff in solemn ceremony last night at the lodge of the Unemployed Brotherhood of America,

The Saar Territory, separated from Germany at the end of the World War and returned three years ago, has undergone a period of readjustment which becomes of timely significance for the future of Austria, where the same assimilation is being attempted on a much larger scale and under the same Reich commissioner who managed the Saar.

Stuyvesant High School's swordsmen successfully defended their Public Schools Athletic League city championship yesterday morning by turning back New Utrecht High, 7 to 5, in a fence-off on the strips of Washington Irving High School.

Barnard College sophomores won the thirty-sixth annual Greek Games, held yesterday afternoon, for the thirty-second time from the freshman class by an unprecedented high score of 60 1/2 points out of a possible 100. More than 350 students participated in this traditional contest in the athletics, lyrics, costumes, music and dance of the classic Greek festivals, presented in Barnard Hall on the campus at 117th Street and Broadway.

ONE of the best-known landmarks in the East, the historic Chesapeake and Ohio Canal, extending 186 miles from Washington to Cumberland, Md., is to be acquired by the Department of the Interior, so that the canal and adjoining land can be developed by the National Park Service for recreational purposes.

BELMONT--Un Carnet de Bal: Harry Baur, Francoise Rosay. CAMEO--Lenin in October, Russian drama. CAPITOL--Judge Hardy's Children: Mickey Rooney. CENTRAL--Silks and Saddles and Code of the Rangers. CONTINENTAL--Lenin in October; To the Victor: Will Fyffe, John Loder, opening Tuesday night. CRITERION-The Stadium Murders: Neil Hamilton.

Outmoded dwellings, still structurally sound but no longer in demand by reason of excessive size, dated architecture, or neighborhood changes, may be converted into revenue-producing apartments with funds available under the property improvement credit plan of the Federal Housing Administration.

Four outdoor courses in horticulture conducted by staff members begin this week at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. A circular describing these and other courses will be mailed on request to the secretary, 1,000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, N. Y.
Supply contracts valued at $2,976,955 were awarded in the week ended on April 7 by twelve Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor announced today.

In testimony this week before the special Senate Committee on Unemployment and Relief, Works Progress Administrator Harry L. Hopkins, while urging expansion of Federal projects to give work to all the unemployed who needed it, emphasized also that the great need of the hour was stimulation of private industry to create a greater national income.
The 32-month-old wire foxterrier, Glynhir Golden, owned and shown by W. L. Lewis of New York City, was judged best of the 546 dogs entered in Springfield's annual all-breed fixture tonight.

The problem of how the Dionne quintuplets are to be educated is puzzling at least to three Canadians. Until recently the educational program of the babies had been in the hands of Dr. W. E. Blatz of Toronto.

A new aspect has been given to the mystery of a British skier's disappearance in Japanese mountains in February by the discovery of his personal property on the frozen' corpse of a Japanese who had made his acquaintance at a mountain inn.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Cecile Bausman Dunlap, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Dunlap of this city, to Edwin A. McAlpin 3d, son of Mrs. Edwin A. McAlpin of Madison, N. J., and the late Rev. Dr. McAlpin.

Computation of the ratio between sales and inventories is offered as a possible means of gauging business prospects. Richard S. Conway, vice president of Bernstein-Macaulay, Inc., investment counsel, has compiled these ratios for a limited number of industrial companies, which are plotted in the adjoining chart and shown with The Annalist index of business activity.

A small but constant decline in maternal mortality over recent years was conceded for the first time yesterday by public health authorities as establishing a definite trend and as proof that a measure of victory is rewarding the national crusade against preventable deaths of American mothers. hers.

Colonel E. H. R. Green's island home in Biscayne Bay, on which Florida officials pin their hopes of collecting a $4,496,651 inheritance tax, was ready today for inspection by a special master for the United States Supreme Court.

Current labor developments, notably the Consumers Power Company strike in Michigan and the National Labor Relations Board's decision in the Inland Steel Company case, have again stimulated discussion of the Committee for Industrial Organization and its future.

WHAT A LIFE--Wednesday evening at the Biltmore Theatre. A comedy of high-school life and the work of Clifford Goldsmith. In the cast are Ezra Stone, Betty Field, Vaughan Glaser, Ruth Matteson, Arthur Pierson, Joyce Arling, Eddie Bracken, Leah Penman; Jack Byrne and Edith Van Cleve.

A grant by the W. W. Kellogg Foundation of Michigan has been made to the Health Section of the World Federation of Education Associations and will be used to promote the health of school children throughout the world.

William Goldman, philanthropist, expert on the wool industry and president of the clothing firm of Cohen, Goldman Co., died early yesterday in his home at 635 Park Avenue after a brief illness. He was in his seventieth year.

The National Society Daughters of the Union will hold their twenty sixth annual congress Tuesday and Wednesday at the Hotel McAlpin. Mrs. Theodore R. Ramage of Springfield, Mass., president-general, will open the meeting at 10:30 A. M. with delegates from fifteen

IT might be more disconcerting to this reviewer of Miss Stevenson's charming third novel if it were not told in the first person. The rather wonderful heroine is named Charlotte Dean, but since she tells the story herself her name does not occur with too startling frequency. .

The boy and his bicycle are becoming an increasingly serious traffic hazard, statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company reported yesterday. Deaths caused by collisions between automobiles and bicycles were twice as numerous in both 1936 and 1937 as in 1935.

PLANS for Easter holidays are keeping travel bureaus and steamship lines busy. Both two and three week vacations and shorter jaunts to Bermuda, Nassau, Miami or New Orleans are expected to prove popular.
