Dr. Carl G. Schluederberg, vice president and general manager of the Ford Instrument Company of Long Island City, N. Y., died in a hospital here today after an illness of five weeks. His age was 57.
PLEASANTLY optimistic atmosphere pervades Gosata Gustav-Jansen's "With Open Arms," a new novel telling of the vicissitudes of a large family falling heir to a trust fund.

The Providence Reds tonight scored their second straight victory over the Syracuse Stars in their play-off for the InternationalAmerican League hockey championship, defeating the Western division champions, 2 to 1, in a 79-minute overtime game before nearly 6,000 fans.

A recital of original monologues by Mrs. Francis Rogers and songs by Earle Spicer, baritone, will be given on the afternoon of May 4 in the Embassy Room of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Prosperity Shop, a mart at 1,279 Third Avenue, which for several years has contributed funds to seven charitable organizations.

A bridge party will be held the evening of April 22 by the Pelham branch of the Westchester County Children's Association at the Pelham Country Club here. Mrs. Lucius M. Bush is chairman and Mrs. Nelson W. Cornell is cochairman.
Members of the rules committee and other representatives of National Football League clubs gathered tonight to dress up the game for next Fall.
Driven almost to distraction by a flood of applications from home, Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy has decided to end the presentations of debutantes from the United States at the British court.

Leading all the way, Grim Reaper, owned by W. E. Boeing of Seattle, won the $6,000-added California Derby at Bay Meadows today, scoring by six lengths over the favorite, Lavengro. Wing and Wing was third.

The Board of Education will hold its regular meeting Wednesday at 4 P. M. at the board headquarters, 500 Park Avenue. A regular meeting of the board of delegates and board of directors of the New York City Teachers Association will be held Wednesday at 4:15 P. M. at the Hotel McAlpin.

MEMORY OF YOUTH" introduces to the English reading public a novelist of high repute in his native Sweden, Vilhelm Moberg, who has projected a trilogy of which this novel is the first unit. "Memory of Youth" is, however, complete in itself, and so may be taken as an independent story.

For four hours yesterday afternoon 100 boyish heads were bent low in deep concentration over checkerboards, and all one heard at rare intervals was "Your move!" and the quick answer, "Keep yer shirt on!"

The merger of the West Jersey Trust Company and the Camden Safe Deposit and Trust Company was effected today with the transfer of $5,000,000 in cash and negotiable bonds and securities from the West Jersey Bank, at Third and Market Streets, to the Camden Safe Deposit Company's building, at Broadway and Market.

A memorandum was filed in General Sessions yesterday by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, asking a "substantial and punitive sentence" for Richard Whitney tomorrow, and revealing many new features of the misuse of securities and funds that he has already admitted.

The business and assets of the former Automatic Machine Company have been taken over by the b Automatic Machinery Manufacturing Corporation, following court approval of the reorganization of the former company,

New York's pleasure boatmen this week-end find themselves betwixt the devil and the deep, blue sea. They've gone off watch and there'll be precious little fitting-out work today although the season was supposed to start.

LONDON. AN incident occurred recently during a contemporary music concert here which has attracted much attention. The players of the Philharmonic String Trio were taking part in an evening of modern "attractions" which included, among other things, a trio by Anton von Webern.

The prediction by Professor Walter B. Pitkin in The Columbia Alumni News that 450 of 745 colleges and universities in the United States will pass away by 1960 if they continue their present policies has brought a backfire.

Plans for cancer control, the national program of venereal disease control, reduction of pneumonia mortality and the trichinosis problem will be the chief topics for discussion when the Annual Conference of State and Territorial Health Officers with the Public Health Service convenes here on Monday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I refer to a letter from Albert Whelan appearing in your issue of March 2? As a reporter I am not interested in controversy but in fact, and so, perhaps, I may be excused in noticing the controversial as well as the personal aspects of that letter.
ABOUT three years ago this reviewer had occasion to talk to Harry Hopkins on the problem of giving work relief and other forms of relief to the millions of Americans who were in need.

A poster contest to signalize National Air Mail Week, May 15 to 22, for boys and girls in grammar and high schools and institutions having similar courses of study, was announced yesterday by the United States Postoffice Department.

Reorganization of a group of studies, which will permit qualified juniors and seniors to take up their major work in the field of history, arts and letters, and expansion of the program in English for freshmen, are features of curriculum changes at Yale, which will add forty new full-time courses in the Fall.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Scott Hutton of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Hutton, to Charles Shorey Butler Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles S. Butler of Boston and Rockport,

Education through the ages will be portrayed in a pageant, with a cast of nearly 1,000 high school students, when the National Education Association meets here the last week in June. Entitled "Skylines,"

Senorita Carola Panerai was married to Leon Mandel of Chicago this morning at the home of the bride here. A brief civil ceremony was performed by Dr. Gustavo Angulo in the presence of members of the bride's family and a few friends.

Dr. George W. Worcester, Newburyport, Mass., physician, died suddenly here today at the age of 77. He was stricken while returning with members of his family from Phoenix, Ariz. Dr. Worcester helped to found the Newburyport Homeopathic Hospital, of which he served as president. .

There was a marked shrinkage in trading in wheat today and while there were reports that the United Kingdom had purchased an additional 1,500,000 bushels of Australian grain, the average speculator was disposed to await further developments.

In the whole history of the Roosevelt Administration there has been no counterpart for the defeat last week of the Reorganization Bill in the House of Representatives. To be sure, the President has met with defeat before, on an issue of his own choosing.

As a part of the program to be presented by the Department of Fine Arts of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Astor on Thursday afternoon. "The Dance as Shown on Greek Vases" will be the subject of an illustrated lecture by Miss Lillian B. Lawlor of Hunter College.
The New Deal's vast hydroelectric power program on the Columbia. River suffered what some observers regard as a major setback this week.

With the release May 1 of "Spindlewood and Pine," a printed anthology of poems written by more than thirty members of the Joyce Kilmer Poetry Society of Georgian Court College, one of the outstanding student projects ever conducted here will have been completed.

Although cold weather and snow disappointed retailers who had anticipated substantial gains in volume last week over figures for the corresponding week a year ago, nevertheless stores showed increases for the week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

The House vote which defeated the Reorganization Bill, in the face of every compromise short of actual withdrawal of the bill, represented, in effect, a declaration that the Congress must remain a coordinate branch of government and would not become merely an instrument for the working of the Presidential will.

The gradual return of public confidence in the residential building field is being brought about largely by the FHA's insistence on careful planning, sound building practices and the use of good materials in she homes offered as security for insured mortgages,' Administrator Stewart McDonald declared yesterday.
ON an eleven-acre site on Old Mill Road, in Greenwich, Conn., an imposing residence in Norman style is being erected by the Home Guild, Inc., for Joseph B. Terbell.

IF you wish to know what T. S. Stribling's latest novel is really like you will have to read it. No description, or even a good deal of direct quotation, could convey more than a faint idea of its quality. No one including Mr. Stribling himself, has written anything quite like it before.
For the first time in the history of Pennsylvania an attempt will be made to establish a scientific basis for the evolution of a State history program for the public schools.

Official relations of the Governments of Mexico and the United States have emerged unimpaired from the storm caused by the expropriation of American oil property below the Rio Grande, although for a time the issue was in doubt.

Honor graduates of colleges do succeed in later life, according to an article by A. V. McClain, assistant to the president of Washington and Jefferson College, in the "Gambolier," student literary publication.

A fashion revue, entitled "Fashions Around the Clock," will be held April 23 in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center for the benefit of the charitable enterprises of the Junior Aid League of the Lenox Hill Hospital. The showing of the latest costumes for Spring and Summer wear will follow a bridge tournament which will take place in the Rainbow Grill. Already there has been an encouraging subscription for the event.

There are now solid grounds for hope that the campaign for establishment of an enlarged Mount Olympus National Park, with its consequent preservation of magnificent stands of virgin timber and of the Winter feeding grounds of the-diminished Roosevelt Elk, waged by the Emergency Conservation

New York's huge transient population was swelled yesterday by 685 elementary school children, who arrived from nine rural communities in Middlesex County, Conn., for a one-day educational tour of the city. Most of them found the city far inferior to their own countryside.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday regulations governing the revised emergency relief taxes on utility services, restaurant checks of $1 or more, alcoholic beverages and business establishments. They will be effective as soon as Mayor La Guardia signs the new tax bills tomorrow after the public hearing he will hold in City Hall at 9 o'clock.

THE season has arrived for Boy Scout circuses, merit badge expositions and hobby shows. In towns and cities throughout the land lads in khaki are showing the public what Scouting is all about and what they have learned as troops and as individuals.

On most home grounds there is at least one spot, on the north side of a building, perhaps, or under large hard maple or other dense foilage trees, where even "shady" lawn grass will not grow. It is always a problem what to plant in such a location.

The contribution of building management to public safety will be one of the topics discussed at the ninth annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council, which will be held on April 21 at the Hotel Astor.

THE big annual exhibition arranged by advertising art directors is current in the mezzanine galleries of the. International Building at Rockefeller Center. Like the proverbial circus, it is bigger and better than last year.
APRIL festivity of two centuries ago, which accompanied the sessions of King George's Court and Assembly, rules again in this reconstructed capital of Colonial Virginia.

The marriage of Miss Theodora Douglas MacGregor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore D. MacGregor of White Plains, to Lewis Foster Day, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Day of Greenwich, took place this afternoon in the Second Congregational Church here.

THAT the fundamental principle of group instruction is the Federal Music Project's outstanding achievement is the consensus of opinion voiced in the replies from the project's teaching staff incorporated into a study of the advantages of group training recently received from Dr. Nikolai Sokoloff, director of the project, by Mrs. Ellen S. Woodward, assistant WPA Administrator, and made public by her.
Representatives from five Eastern colleges will discuss "Rearmament and Peace" at the annual Intercollegiate Forum sponsored by Lehigh University debaters on Wednesday.

Shooting conditions were anything but ideal at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. As a result, only twenty-three gunners came to the firing line and they found considerable difficulty in hitting the blue rocks.

The long reign of the New York Athletic Club over the senior division of indoor polo ended at the Squadron A Armory last night, when the Optimists, strengthened by the addition of Michael Phipps and playing superb polo through a brilliant game, won the third and deciding match of the Eastern championship.
John Quincy Adams Johnson, a descendant of the second and sixth Presidents of the United States, died here tonight in his home at 87 High Street of a heart ailment. He was 80 years old.
W. I. Martin, lone survivor from asphyxiation of eight persons who sought warmth in a snow-bound oil field home, regained consciousness today and physicians said he probably would recover.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler closed his campaign for tomorrow's plebiscite with a speech here tonight in which he greeted a huge audience with frequent references to the Deity. Pleading submission to Divine Will as the keynote for his actions he said:

ROME.-The constantly growing demand of the international shipping market for the chartering of merchantmen, and the increase of traffic through the Suez and Panama Canals, have prompted the Italian Government to devise a fouryear program for the expansion of its mercantile marine.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Patterson, daughter of Mrs. Edward James Patterson of this city and the late Mr. Patterson, to Morrill Wiggin, son of Mrs. Harry H. Wiggin of Brookline, Mass., and the late Mr. Wiggin, took place here this afternoon in the chapel of the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church.
Arsenal showed championship form today. The Gunners won by 1-0 at Leeds and now have a three-point margin at the top in the English Football League.

Joseph Haight, former Town Clerk and former Supervisor of the town of Rye, N. Y., and a former assistant controller of Westchester County, died today at the Norwalk Hospital, following a three weeks illness. His age was 78.

OUT of the African Gold Coast recently rich clouds of smoke have billowed to the sky, filling the air with a heavy, pungent odor. The fuel. feeding a fire of commercial wrath, was cocoa-good cocoa beans that might have been exported, ground up and later sold to American consumers.

After a session of ninety days, testimony in the Ford Motor Company-National Labor Relations Board case was closed today. The charges of unfair labor practices at the company's St. Louis assembly plant were preferred by the United Auto mobile Workers of America, a C. I. O. union.

To Dr. Gilbert Newton Lewis, dean of the College of Chemistry at the University of California, has been awarded the fifth Theodore William Richards Medal of the Northeastern Section of the American Chemical Society "for conspicuous achievement in chemistry."

Steel companies representing 90 per cent of the industry reported total earnings of $242,058,038 last year, representing a 6.1 per cent return on a $3,966,690,871 capitalization, compared with $167,954,226, or 4.4 per cent, for the same producers in 1936, according to an annual survey by the magazine Steel.
Early returns tonight from a farmer referendum gave overwhelming majorities for ,the AAA's proposal to impose marketing quotas on this year's burley tobacco crop.

Child study will become a morel vital part of the Connecticut College curriculum with the addition of a major field in child development and the establishment of a nursery school on the campus next year.

John Sanford and Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Sanford entertained tonight with a dinner at Villa Marina. Their guests included Mrs. Wesson Seyburn, Mrs. Michael Phipps, Mrs. Dodge Sloane, Miss Mary Munn, Charles A. Munn, Rodman de Heeren, Charles Munn Jr. Later Mrs. Sloane took the party to the Patio for dancing.

COHEN, ESTHER (March 28). Estate, $4,000. To May Cohen, daughter, 135 Eldridge St., Sylvia Lomars, daughter, 1,210 Sheridan Ave., Bronx, and Jeanette, Cohen, daughter, 261 Broome St., equal shares in residue. Isidore Raphael, 1,750 Grand Concourse. executor. DEMAREST, JANE A. (March 11). Estate, more than $10,000. To John B. Anderson, executor, Mount Vernon. N. Y., and Margaret Joralemon, cousin, East Orange. N. J.. in equal shares.

William A. Miller of 83 North Walnut Street, an assistant and general freight agent in the New York office of the Lackawanna Railroad, died today at Orange Memorial Hospital, following an operation. His age was 60.

Honors in the first series between the new International Class sloops of Long Island Sound and onedesign craft of the Bermuda fleet went to the former today, the United States team of two boats taking the final race for a victory on points.

Improved travel conditions to the Mediterranean were reported yesterday by officials of the Italian and American Export Lines, the principal operators on that route. The removal of doubt concerning Austro-German relations has been an important factor in the situation, it was said.

The American Cities Power and Light Corporation has declared an optional dividend on its convertible Class A stock, payable on May 2 to holders of record of April 12. A holder may receive for each share held one sixty-fourth share of Class B stock or 37 1/2 cents.
It is an axiom in meteorology that our weather is made at the poles. True as this is in a general sense, it does not mean that weather at the poles is made in a different way than elsewhere on earth.

Sale of Life magazine in Pennsylvania was forbidden yesterday by Governor George F. Earle because of the inclusion of pictures showing the birth of a baby, but support came from many other sources, including the Society for the Suppression of Vice.

Three patrolmen were dismissed from the department yesterday by Commissioner Valentine, making the number of men dropped during his term 217. All three men had been convicted at departmental trials of recommending attorneys to prisoners.

In a far-reaching "liberal" decision the State Supreme Court has upheld the act embodying the New Hampshire program for water storage with incidental benefits of stream flow regulation, flood control and power production projects on a self-liquidating basis.

The board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange has passed a resolution declaring that A dues of regular members are contributions toward the current expenses of the Exchange and may therefore be deducted from individual income tax returns for 1938.
Several luncheons, suppers and dinners were given by Greenwich residents in connection with the annual horse show of the Round Hill Club Stables held at the stables this afternoon and tonight.

The Senate passed its own version of the 1938 Tax Bill today without a record vote, after having included in the measure, in deference to frequent arguments, a provision that the income of future issues of Federal bonds should not be tax exempt. The measure provides for total levies of about $5,000,000,000.

Emerson High School of Union City, represented by Elizabeth Fitzgibbons and Lionel Zung, won the high school debating championship of the New Jersey Forensic League at Princeton University this afternoon, defeating a team from North Plainfield High School.

Charles Evans Hughes, Chief Justice of the United States, will be 76 years old on Monday. The tall, bearded jurist, who has presided over the Supreme Court during one of its most turbulent periods in history, apparently is in excellent health and has not missed a day because of illness since he was appointed Chief Justice in 1930 by President Hoover.
PALM BEACH, Fla.-With the advent of Spring, thoughts of the Town Council and Planning Commission turn again to further beautification of the island during the Summer.

With the Spring holidays the annual migration of teachers is on. There are those who are seeking their first jobs, those who have been dismissed and need new places and those who seek to better themselves. The agencies are having their Spring rush.

A jewel robbery, in which three men escaped with loot valued at more than $200,000 while dozens of boardwalk promenaders were near the scene, was reported to the police tonight by two jewelers operating establishments here and in New York City.
The Marquess of Ailsa, Scottish shipbuilder, died in his home, Culzean Castle, overlooking the Firth of Clyde, today at the age of 90.
Inventories of 175 principal industrial companies in the United States rose $694,000,000, or 18 per cent, in 1937, despite the decline in business activity in the final third of the year.

Hilda Kutsukian Kosta, contralto, a native of Turkey, who made her loaal debut in opera last year, was heard in recital last night at Town Hall. In a program that ranged widely and somewhat arbitrarily (Anton Rubinstein, Giuseppe Bamboschek, Frank Grey and Sibelius rubbed elbows in one group) Miss

With the European countries and their peoples holding a leading place in the news today it is of interest to note, in the photographs and news-reels of the events, the much more general use abroad than in this country of window-box gardening.

Another new development in Greenwich is revealed as a result of the sale of a three-acre tract of land facing Glenville Road, in Glenville, Greenwich, owned by .Frederic J. Horton, to James B. Maher and Joseph M. Maher of Greenwich, under a corporation known as the Glenville Realty. Corporation.

More extensive development of the residential community in Hewlett Harbor is in prospect as the result of the purchase of 175 acres in the Hewlett Harbor subdivision on the South Shore of Long Island by a group which will offer plots of a quarter-acre or more on part of the land for improvement with dwellings.

PINEHURST, N. C. - Tennis will occupy the center of attention at this Midsouth resort for the next two weeks. Starting tomorrow the twentieth annual United North and South Tennis Tournament will be held.
The memorandum in which District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey reviews the case against Richard Whitney, filed yesterday with the Court of General Sessions, follows:

Operators of office buildings in New York City cannot hope this year for any reduction in fixed charges and operating expenses and must depend upon increased occupancy or higher rents if the losses sustained by many such structures last year are to be avoided, J. Clydesdale Cushman, president of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., said yesterday.

The New Haven Republican League of Young Republicans today announced a five-point reorganization program which broke with the Old Guard of the party, accused it of lobbying to further its special interests, and of combining with a faction of the Democratic party to perpetuate a corrupt double-party machine.

THE Paris Opera recently staged a new ballet, "The Song of Songs," by Arthur Honegger, with scenario by Gabriel Boissy. Honegger's music for the biblical pastoral is said by Henry Bidou, the French critic, to be more in the nature of oratorio than ballet.

FOLLOWING recent advances of Rebel forces in Spain, the short-wave station at Madrid has increased its radio activities. In addition to the daily North American transmissions which run from 7:30 until 8 P. M., E. S. T., the Spanish station on 9.48 megacycles now sends a second broadcast each night between 8:40 and 9 o'clock. o'clock.
The Soviet freighter Kuznetstroye, detained with her crew and passengers for forty-eight days at Hakodate, Japan, has been released, dispatches said today.

PROMOTIONAL appointments and reassignments of execu tive personnel brought about by the elevation of A. van Der Zee to the vice presidency of the Chrysler Corporation were announced last week by W. M. Purves, general sales manager of the Dodge division.

A chorus of more than 100 voices will take part in the program in memory of Arthur Land to be given by the Oratorio and Festival Society of Yonkers on Tuesday evening in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church. George Rasely,

Some lenses magnify. But magnification must be paid for. The field of magnification should be flat. If it is flat at the edges it is a little blurred in the center; and if it is sharp at the center it is blurred at the edges.

Princeton's great medley relay team did the only record-breaking at the 1938 national A. A. U. senior swim meet tonight, but Ohio State University "stole the show" as the Buckeyes became the first college squad to take the team championship and Al Patnik, sensational sophomore, rounded out the first diving "grand slam" in history.
Professor W. D. Zinnecker of 71 Washington Square South has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Margaret Zinnecker, to Boyce Wesley Kerbin of Essex, Conn.

Peter Wynne, chief clerk of the Bronx office of the Board of Elections, wrote yesterday to William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, requesting a correction in the latter's recent report, which said that it appeared that "no employe of the Board of Elections made any attempt to verify the number of men used and the number of hours overtime they worked"

In two important respects the proposed Revenue Bill of 1938, as adopted by the Senate Finance Committee last- week, evidences a return to sounder and more rational principles in the taxation of business.

Golfing is one of the popular diversions of young women in society at Aiken, S. C. Those frequently seen on the links at the Palmetto Golf Club include Mrs. John Mortimer Schiff, Mrs. John R. Fell, Miss Edwina Atwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Atwell; Miss Barbara L. Bourne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Severin Bourne, and Miss Aerielle Frazer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Washington Frazer. .

When the League of Nations committee on the status of women met this afternoon Miss Alice Paul of the United States and Miss Dorothy Evans of Great Britain inquired whether it would not be possible to make an interim report to the Assembly on woman's

Confronted with the first business depression it has experienced since the industry was legalized in 1933, wine and liquor dealers as well as distillers are finding it difficult to adapt themselves to the current drop in sales volume. Distillers,

A new eye test which clears up unexplained headaches, indigestion, insomnia and even loss of memory was described here today in a paper by Dr. F. W. Marlow, in the archives of ophthalmology of the American Medical Association.

Threats of warfare between A. F. L. and C. I. O. forces gave way suddenly to peace efforts today after police had blockaded this striketorn town to isolate the opposing groups on their potential battle ground.

Fortune Gallo's San Carlo Opera Company will present a season of popular priced grand opera at the Center Theatre in Rockefeller Center, beginning on May 5 and continuing to May 15, it was announced yesterday. The season,

George Baskin, defending champion, from the Trinity Club, survived a three-game battle to beat Sam Feuer, a clubmate, by 21-19, 20-21, 21-16, in the quarter-final round of the New York State A. A. U. one-wall handball singles championship at Union Temple yesterday.

The report of American European Securities Company for March 31 shows net assets of $4,935,672 after allowing for $3,017,000 funded debt, equal to $98.71 a share on 50,000 preferred shares on which dividend arrears amount to $19 a share, compared with $7,006,277, or $140.13 a share on the preferred and $3.19 a share on the common stock at Dec. 31.

In his game with Milton Hanauer in the sixth round of the. United States chess championship, Samuel Reshevsky exploited to the utmost the weakness of two doubled pawns on the queen's bishop's file, both of which he succeeded in. winning in good time, without permitting any compensating positional advantage.

The Federal Power Commission today permitted the Power Authority of the State of New York to become a party to proceedings before the commission on the application of the Niagara Falls Power Company for diversion of an additional 275 cubic feet of Niagara River water.
The story of a mother who gave her blood to her ailing two-months-old baby in a transfusion and then fell ill of amnesia was revealed yesterday in Bellevue Hospital.

Princeton University students have earned 134 gold, silver and bronze medals for participation in the Intramural Athletic Association's Winter program of ten sports, according to an announcement today by William F. Halsey 3d of Pensasola, Fla., president of the association.

Sir Leonard Lionel Cohen, for years president of the Jewish Board of Guardians, the premier Jewish charity in England, who received a knighthood for his services in behalf of other philanthropic organizations, died today at the age of 79.
Senior students of the Coopers-town, N. Y., High School placed a wreath today on the grave of their fellow-townsman and the founder of American baseball, Major Gen. Abner Doubleday.

Several hundred executives in charge of manufacturing plants throughout the United States are scheduled to attend a two-day conference on current production problems to be held on April 20-21 at the Hotel William Penn,

Yihsien, twenty miles north of Taierhchwang, has become the major center of contention in Southern Shantung Province. Here the Chinese are attacking vigorously in their effort to eliminate the Japanese forces who retreated to Yihsien from Taierhchwang.

Southern California had considerably more building activity in the first quarter of this year than in the similar period of 1937. Seventy-six communities in the area reported $41,417,845 of construction for the three months, or $3,358,751 more than for the first quarter of 1937.

Fire wrecked a row of six stores on Nassau Road at Mollineaux Place here this afternoon, causing damage to the buildings and stocks estimated at $50,000 before Roosevelt firemen, assisted by members of the Freeport department, put it out.

Because they feel that the disbarment proceedings brought in Portsmouth, Ohio, against Edward Lamb, regional attorney for the C. I. O. and executive vice president of the National Lawyers Guild, are a "menace to the right of members of the bar to represent unpopular causes,"
Members of the National Lawyers Guild, described as liberal attorneys, have voted 10 to 1 in favor of lifting the arms embargo against Spain, the guild announced today.
Edouard Daladier has formed an anti-Communist Cabinet in France on the day of the German plebiscite. It is not the ideal Cabinet that was hoped for. Perhaps it is not even a durable Cabinet,

Despite high winds that swept n from Long Island Sound, satisfactory scores were returned at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. The highover-all scratch gunner was A. S. Cornhill, who broke 98 out of 100.

The general level of industrial activity continues high, but no evidence of fresh expansion has occurred such as would be normal for this season of the year. New orders in some industries have declined, and stocks consequently are accumulating, with production being curtailed.

Greta Garbo is reported to have been the purchaser of the huge "Half Regent" diamond sold here today for 800,000 kronor. Some quarters, however, thought that the diamond, one of the largest and finest discovered in recent years, had been bought by Mme.

A program for dealing with the situation created by the removal of families displaced by the demolition of old buildings will be outlined this afternoon at a meeting of the committee on rehousing of tenants of the Citizens' Housing Council at the Town Hall Club. Robert J. Elzy, chairman, will preside.
After a quiet opening the week's stock market became more active with rises among the chemicals on good dividend expectations. General firmness finally was the rule.
Stocks rallied sharply on defeat of Reorganization Bill and prices were higher for the second consecutive week; turnover, 4,424,050 shares.
A new first-mortgage loan of $525,000 at 4 per cent has been arranged by Brooks, Harvey Co. on the Sutton Place Apartments, 419-429 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The city's radio station, WNYC, broadcast a special program from 11 o'clock to noon yesterday in honor of the station's adoption of the hourly time signal service of the United States Naval Observatory at Arlington, Va.

One hundred and twenty-five prominent Americans of all faiths joined in an appeal made public yesterday to the peoples of democratic countries urging immediate cooperation in President Roosevelt's proposal for an international committee to provide a haven for religious and political refugees.
James M. Kieran, secretary to Mayor La Guardia, promised last night on behalf of the Mayor that "everything humanly possible" will be done to establish low-cost housing on the lower East Side.

So far as financial markets were concerned. last week's history was mostly colored by the defeat of the Bureau Reorganization Bill in Congress, and the resultant immediate week-end advance of stocks, running in many active shares from 3 points up to 6.

An early morning joyride in an automobile borrowed without the knowledge of its owner caused William Clark Jr., 19-year-old Columbia University freshman of 47 Nassau Boulevard here, to be held for the grand jury today on a charge of second-degree larceny.

An electric power strike was postponed at 11:50 o'clock tonight, minutes before it was scheduled to start in six important Mexican cities. The postponement was for twenty days, during which negotiations with employers are to be continued.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Gallatin of 7 East Sixty-seventh Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Almy Gallatin, to William Appleton Aiken, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Laurence Aiken of 115 East Sixty-seventh Street.

Orchestra, newly organized, will make its first appearance in a concert at the Town Hall on Monday evening, May 2. Eighteen musicians will comprise the group. The concert will be the American debut of Edvard Moritz.
The decision of Joseph P. Kennedy, the United States Ambassador here, to abolish the presentation of American debutantes "at Court" was front-page news in most London newspapers today.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,392,442,650. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

Setting aside a toy horse and wagon he had been playing with, Ronald James McKnight, 2 years old, ran in front of an automobile being driven by his mother, Mrs. Marie McKnight, into a private garage at 35-27 Sixty-second Street, Woodside, and was crushed between the coupe and the garage wall yesterday.
A luxury caravan escorted by Arabian noblemen on fiery steeds today wound its way over picturesque mountain roads toward Biskra, where tomorrow the Sheikh of Araby's favorite son will be wed.

American coal miners, although they work shorter hours, produce more coal per day than the miners of any European country, according to a report on the world coal industry now being prepared by the International Labor Office.

Southbound traffic on Eighth Avenue. at Thirty-sixth' Street was detoured last night and water seeped into the Independent System Subway and the cellar of a loft building when a main burst spurting water two feet into the air. The accident occurred at 7:20 P. M..

Christ's "triumph through failure" has helped to make His influence more lasting than that of any of our modern "heroes" will be, the Rev. Charles C. Cole, pastor of the Grace Methodist Church, 131 West 104th Street, predicted in his sermon yesterday.
Announcement was made here last night of the death Saturday in the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital, Boston, of Frederic N. Watriss, retired New York lawyer.

Murray Murdoch, who played twelve Birk Brol years with the New York Rangers Isaac without missing a game, and who Pabst Bhl during the past season captained Mystery the Philadelphia Ramblers, the Fred Me Rangers' farm club, was tonight napolis Richard announced by the Yale Athletic Steve Cze Association as head coach of Yale Mike Spo M. Pritcb hockey for next season.
WOMEN ARE LIKE THAT, based on a story by Albert H. Z. Carr: screen play by Horace Jackson; directed by Stanley Logan for Warner Brothers. At the Strand.

The World War has a new ending and its Versailles settlement has been revised, Joseph Buerckel, Nazi plebiscite commissioner, told Chancellor Adolf Hitler over the radio in announcing tonight Austria's overwhelming vote in favor of Anschluss.

Despite apprehension of damage to the new Winter wheat crop and the wild flurry in the grain market on Friday caused- by reports that the British Government had instructed mills in that country to accumulate
For forty years, Pietro DePascale, a retired barber, has sent birthday greetings to the former Kaiser of Germany and has received in turn an autographed photograph.
In his search for novelties for his Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra programs, John Barbirolli has revealed commendable zest as well as catholic taste. The law of averages

The Tax Bill just passed by the Senate has shortcomings, but it is in nearly every respect superior to existing tax provisions. It is in nearly every respect superior to the House bill, which itself was a substantial improvement over the measures now in force.
The Bourse was not disturbed by Premier Blum's financial program, but the trend was irregular. At the beginning of

The Jew has survived all his persecutors, and is now "passing through Hitlerism, which we hope and pray is soon to be left behind," the Rev. Dr. Louis Finkelstein, provost of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, Broadway and 122d Street, said at the unveiling of a bronze plaque presented to the seminary by the artist, William Rosenthal.

Considering the United States Treasury's estimate of the influx and efflux of foreign capital, it is obviously necessary to draw a distinct line between what may be termed "floating capital" and investment capital.

Four robbers, one armed with a pistol, at 9:30 o'clock last night held up the rectory of the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady Queen of Angels, at 226 East 113th Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, forcing three Capuchin friars attached to the church to give them $3.

Thousands of jobless workers who thought they had exhausted their benefit rights under the State Unemployment Insurance Law are eligible to receive additional compensation under an amendment to the' law, but the State Labor Department is finding it difficult to acquaint the workers with this fact.

Henry Ford and Clara Bryant Ford tomorrow will reach the fiftieth anniversary of the partnership they began in the parlor of a Greenfield village farmhouse on a day when Mr. Ford's parents expected him to become a farmer,...

Hallgarten Co. and Kidder, Peabody Co., fiscal agents for $9,000,000 of 6 1/2 per cent bonds of Medellin, Colombia, will appeal the recent decision handed down by Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church ordering them to make a full accounting of their acts concerning the issue to the Colombian Bondholders Protective Committee, it was disclosed yesterday.
THE ADOLESCENT, by Ada Hart Arlitt. (Whittlesey House, $2). Writen for parents whose children are between 12 and 21 years old.

James F. Fogarty, president of the North American Company, announced yesterday that output of electricity by subsidiaries in the North American system so far this year had reflected a continuation of lessened demand for power by industrial customers.

The 1938 edition of the Official City Directory of the City of New York, containing official information about city, State and Federal agencies, is to be published today. At his request Mayor La Guardia has been accorded the privilege of purchasing the first copy off the press.

Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company-For 1937: Net income, $1,899,661, before allowance for mine depletion, equal to $1.60 each on the 1,181,967 capital shares outstanding, compared with $353,722, or 30 cents a share, in 1936.

The semi-final brackets in the Metropolitan A. A. U. four-wall doubles handball championship tournament were completed yesterday at the Pastime A. C.; where four quarter-final round matches were contested.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 34 per cent of capacity, down 2 points from the week before, when there had been an increase of like amount.

Leonard Dettioff of Detroit captured fifth place in the all-events standings at the American Bowling Congress today with a grand total of 1,938 pins. A poor start in his A. B. C. schedule, with only. 576 in the team competition last night, cost Dettioff a chance to go into the all-events lead. e all-events lead.

Poland appealed for colonies today in nation-wide demonstrations and lectures sponsored by the Naval and Colonial League, an organization of 750,000 persons that has campaigned sixteen years in that cause.

All members of the crew of the on Greek freighter Mount Kyllene, sit which was cut in two by an explosion Saturday morning 200 miles Dr north of the Azores, were rescued NE except the radio operator, according to a message received yesterday by Radiomarine Corporation.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. David Crawford Clark of 810 Fifth Avenue and Bar Harbor, Me., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Zelina Therese Clark, to Donald Peabody Blagden of 14 East Sixtysixth Street, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Blagden of Upper Saranac, N. Y., formerly of Washington.

Emanuel M. Cohan, trustee of a mortgage on the Labor Temple, corner of Second Avenue and Fourteenth Street, announces a further interest distribution of 4 per cent to certificate holders. A payment of 7.072 per cent was made in December, 1937. Taxes have been paid to date.

The successes of dictators will be only temporary In any age, declared the Rev, Dr. Edward Niles, in a Palm Sunday sermon yesterday morning at the First Reformed Church of Newtown, Corona Avenue and Broadway, Elmhurst, Queens.

Sooner or later the great democracies will have to come to the defense of the victims of totalitarian rule, Colonel Josiah Clement Wedgwood, Laborite member in the British Parliament, said yesterday afternoon in an address at the Hotel Lombardy, 111 East Fifty-sixth Street, where he was guest of honor at a tea reception given by the American Jewish Congress.
The 2,768th yes-and-no plebiscite having taken place and no noes whatever having been found in the ballot boxes,

With almost all the nation's voters casting their ballots on the inclusion of Austria in the new empire only nine-tenths of 1 per cent voted "no." Austria did better than the rest of the Reich with 99.75 per cent "yes,"

THIS is to inform Mr. Ford Christopher Frick, President of the National League, that National League season pass No. 180 has arrived at its proper destination and is in good hands. This was revealed yesterday by none other than Isaac Newton Falk, the recipient of the aforesaid pass, a small, solemn gent who works in the "morgue" in this office and roots furiously for the Giants at all times.
Cold-storage holdings of frozen fish in the United States on March 15 amounted to 45,674,000 pounds, compared with 51,588,000 on March 15, 1937, and a five-year average of 32,480,000 for March.

The protective committee for holders of Derby Oil and Refining Corporation stock has reported to stockholders that it has been negotiating with competent oil executives and desirable directors who can be persuaded to take over the management.

Tom M. Girdler, chairman of the board of the Republic Steel Corporation, replied in a statement tonight to the findings of the National Labor Relations Board, which yesterday held the company guilty of violating the Wagner act.
Marga Waldron made her first appearance of the season in a dance recital at the Guild Theatre yesterday afternoon, and attracted an audience of good size and cordial disposition.

A blustering northwest wind that dug up Manhasset Bay into thrown, white-capped water prevented the holding today of the final session of the annual Spring sailing dinghy regatta at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.. After a wait until after noon, with no cessation of the blow, proceedings were called off.

A music building to seat 2,500 persons will be erected at the New York World's Fair as a center for the international music festival which will be one of the features of the entertainment. The music building will consist of an egg-shaped auditorium and box-like stage. It has been designed by Reinhard Hofmeister, architects of the Radio City Music Hall.

Victor Constant, anti-Communist candidate, was elected on the third ballot by a majority of 37 votes over his Communist opponent, Mayor Marraine of Ivry, in the Senatorial election of the Seine Department today.

Foreign and home developments combined this week to induce a more cheerful business sentiment, and securities generally recovered on the Boerse. Apprehensions over any immediate Reich move in Central Europe have abated.

Declaring that "cowardice is the chief of sins," the "most demoralizing, destructive of all human weaknesses," the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, preaching in All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street, yesterday, pointed to Dr. Arthur Morgan, dismissed recently by President Roosevelt as chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, as "one of the heroes of conscience" of this period.

The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching reports today some appalling findings and deductions, based on the study of high school and college students in Pennsylvania which it began in 1927. The tests,

Brown will play a nine-game varsity football schedule in 1939. Amherst, Brown's opponent in its first intercollegiate gridiron test in 1878, is returning to the list after a lapse of nineteen years. The schedules for 1938 and 1939 follow: after JERSEY RED, a lapse of nineteen years. Spahn, If..... The schedules for 1938 and 1939 Michelotti, rf.. follow: Benson, c.....

Dr. Walter Thomas Taggart, Emeritus Professor of Chemistry at the University of Pennsylvania, who was widely known in the inorganic and electrochemical industries, died of an embolism late last night at his home in the Mount Airy section of Philadelphia. He would have been 66 years old next Friday.

Electoral meetings and demonstrations for Sunday's plebiscite somewhat upset the course of this week's industry, particularly in the Southern Provinces, but, in general, the Spring revival is satisfactory.
The appointment of Bernhard Knollenberg of New York City, lawyer and writer, to be librarian of Yale University, was announced today by President Charles Seymour.
Casimir de Bruyn, father of Mrs. Warren Delano Robbins of New York and Washington, died here today at the age of 84. He was on an of- 84.

Miss Phyllis Jeannette Cave, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Cave of this city, was married yesterday afternoon to Herbert Irving Trask, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest A. Trask of Mechanic Falls, Me. The Rev. Dr. Frank B. Haggard performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.
The French wholesale price index on April 2 was at 617, compared with 617 and 619, respectively, a week before and two weeks before.
Today-the day of the German plebiscite on Austria-which had been expected both here and abroad to be the most critical of any since the annexation of Austria, passed off very peacefully.

The Syracuse Stars turned on their famed offensive tonight to defeat the Providence Reds, 4-3, in their International-American Hockey League play-off and throw the championship series into a fourth game on Syracuse ice.

Richard Whitney, former head of the bankrupt brokerage firm of Richard Whitney Co., will come up for sentence today- in General Sessions Court on guilty pleas to two indictments charging him with grand larceny in the misuse of securities left in his safe-keeping. He will appear before Judge Owen W. Bohan.
For the first time in two years France has a Government which excludes the support of the Communists and can count only on limited backing from the Socialists. The Popular Front has broken down.

Jose R. de Capriles, the willowy N. Y. U. graduate from the Salle Santelli, led the qualifiers into the semi-final round of the national epee championship as eliminations were completed yesterday at the New York A. C. The epee was the third and last blade od the local preliminary competition.

The Rev. Edward Felix Kloman, for ten years assistant rector. of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, New York, has accepted a call to become rector of historic old Christ Church in this city, founded in 1695. He will assume his new duties on June 1, succeeding the Rev, Dr. Louis C. Washburn, who resigned as rector in February, 1937, after thirty years of service here.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as trustee, has invited tenders of Indiana, Bloomington Western Railway Company preferred first mortgage 4 per cent bonds due on April 1, 1940, at not more than 105, to exhaust $10,871. Tenders will be accepted until noon on April 25.

In the more or less general gloom, Liberia appears, for the moment, as a bright spot. Last week a group of societies interested in that coastal republic which looks toward America (including the American Colonization Society, the Booker Washington Industrial Institute, certain American missionary societies
Brisk winds stirred palm leaves in the hands of thousands of churchgoers yesterday as Palm Sunday was celebrated in the churches throughout the city.

St. John's University defeated Long Island University, 2 to 1, at Dexter Park in Woodhaven yesterday for the Redmen's second victory in two starts against Metropolitan foes. It was the opening game for the Blackbirds.

Members of the auxiliary of the Brooklyn Children's Museum will hold their annual luncheon April 22 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The occasion will mark the twenty-third anniversary of the founding of the organization.

Tests made on rubber produced here at the experimental plantation of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company show the quality of the latex satisfactory, and President Cortes has received a set of tires made of Costa Rican rubber.
An army plane crashed -in a storm about 3 A. M. today, killing its pilot, who was identified as Lieutenant Eugene Brecht Jr. of Self-ridge Field. Mich.

A grant of $3,500 to continue his research on specialized problems in vision has been given to Professor Clarence H. Graham of the Department of Psychology at Brown University by the Carnegie Corporation of New York, it was announced today.
Two leaders in Congress in statements issued today assailed the Administration's fiscal policy as harmful to business and dangerous to the nation.

The British budget outlook is difficult, but less so than it first appeared when the acceleration of big armaments was decided upon. Leading industrialists, while cautious, are still asserting that no trade slump is to be feared.

Mrs. Ruth West Campbell, Headmistress of Greenwich Academy, was aroused at .4 A. M. today, when a burglar entered her bedroom, placed his hand over her mouth and ordered her to hand over her money. Mrs. Campbell gave the intruder $14 and he quickly disappeared through the window the had entered.

The Maritime Commission announced today that it had rejected all bids for the construction of eight of twelve steel cargo vessels on the ground that the costs quoted were so high as to make it impossible to operate

Picturing the ultimate destiny of civilization in our world today as the prize in a race between Christianity and catastrophe, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale said yesterday in his morning sermon at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, that it was the lay people of the church who must have a spiritual revival if Christ and democracy were to be victorious over chaos and evil.

Church membership has become far too cheap in many places today, it is. obtained too easily and retained without much spiritual responsibility, declared the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer in his sermon yesterday at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

An officially compiled analysis points out that the new greater Reich can expect only an insignificant export surplus. On the basis of 1937 figures and omitting a mutual Austro-German trade, imports of the enlarged Reich would be 5,947,000,000 marks and the exports 6,274,000,000 marks.

Although shut out of three free-style events, Ohio State held the National A. A. U. senior swimming championship today--the first college team ever to win the title--and the outlook for the continued reign of Coach Mike Peppe's charges was bright.

The Cambridge University Rugby team left New York yesterday afternoon after a tour of three weeks. The Cantabs went to Boston, from where they took a train to Halifax to catch the Cunard White Star liner Antonia, on the final leg of their trip home.
Lester Becker, 18 years old, a Troy parking lot attendant, encountered difficulty today in steering an automobile into a parking space. He asked Luigi Cristiano, 52, of Troy,
The second annual symphonic festival at Silvermine, Conn., will be held aug. 18, 19, 20 and 21 under the auspices of the local Guild of Artists and the local Guild Festival Association.

Secretary Perkins and Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, discussed in a radio forum last night what government and business could do to aid stabilization of employment. Their addresses were broadcast over the Mutual network from the New York studio of WOR.

Lawrence Groves, Philip T. Lawrence Co. (H. A. Caesar Co, factors) and Frederick T. Lawrence, two floors in Nelson Tower Building, 450 7th Ave, and additional space in same building to Industrial Collections Bureau, Lever Bros Co, Beaunit Mills, Inc, and Harry Schlanger; Michael E. Lipset Co., brokers.

Hugh K. Gaston, descendant of an old Somerset County family, died here today in the Somerset Hospital at the age of 79. Mr. Gaston was formerly a well-known lawyer in Somerset County but had not been active for several years.

About 3,500 organized laundry workers at a two-hour meeting at the Metropolitan Opera House today voted by acclamation for a general strike in the Philadelphia laundry industry, effective at midnight, April 19, unless a "sensible agreement" is reached with laundry owners in the meantime.

Mrs. Isabella Da Costa Fleming, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Da Costa of- this city,was married to Henry W. Sage Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sage of Jericho, L. I., on Thursday at the Villanova residence of the bride's aunt and uncle, Dr. and Mrs. William B. Cadwalader.

The Hon. Unity Freeman-Milford, who vies with her father, Lord Redesdale, in fervent loyalty to Chancellor Adolf Hitler, was severely handled in Hyde Park today when she wore a swastika badge, which had been presented to her by Hitler, in the midst of a mass meeting on behalf of Loyalist Spain.

New Jersey defeated Mississippi, 25 to 19, to win the national basketball tourney for schools for the deaf at the Warner Memorial gymnasium last night. In the final of the play-off series, New Jersey was led by Mike Gibo, center, who scored 16 points.

The Merchants Association announced yesterday that nearly a score of representatives of Eastern shippers and railroads had departed for Birmingham, Ala., to attend a hearing of the Interstate Commerce Commission which will open this morning on the application of a group of Southern Governors for a revision of rail rates.

A report of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, based on a ten-year survey of the secondary schools and colleges of Pennsylvania and made public yesterday, charged serious shortcomings in the educational system and made recommendations for its improvement.

Members of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., were urged at their April meeting yesterday in the Hotel Astor to impress again upon Senators and Representatives from their respective districts the opposition of the organization to any of the various bills now before Congress providing for a Federal Bureau of Fine Arts.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain is losing the confidence of the British people who are demanding a foreign policy that will actively oppose the dictatorial governments threatening the peace of Europe,

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Camp bell, former minister of the Central Avenue Reformed Church, Jersey City, N. J., was installed yesterday afternoon as minister of the First Reformed Church of Flushing, Bowne Street and Roosevelt Avenue, Queens.
Brian McTybe o'Cloisters was the outstanding dog in the open all-age stake sponsored by the Irish Setter Club of America near here today.
Completed liquidations of twenty-eight bank receiverships announced today by Marshall R. Diggs, Acting Controller of the Currency, included three institutions in the vicinity of New York.

A picture of neglect and decay, with even a threat of danger, in two popular public- institutions in Brooklyn has been drawn by the director of both, Philip N. Youtz, in his annual report on the condition of museums administered by the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences. The volume will be distributed to the membership this week.

The increasing use of advertising by an army of new advertisers with modest appropriations since 1932 is a development of importance to the publishing field, according to Albert Frank Guenther Law, Inc.,

Governor Lehman announced today his veto of a group of appropriation bills and in doing so stressed the fact that he does not regard the present time as the proper one for the State to make expenditures which are not absolutely mandatory.

Halbut vessels landed 25,306,450 pounds of fishery products valued at $2,130,431 at Seattle in 1937, the Department of Commerce has reported. This compares with 27,059,529 pounds valued at $2,201,774 in 1936,

In memory of William Winston Roper, long-time head football coach here, Princeton University has named the road from Prospect Avenue to the front entrance of Palmer Stadium Roper Lane, it was announced today by George C. Wintringer, controller of the university.
Tunis, still under martial law and patrolled by armored cars, was quiet today but authorities are expecting further troubles tomorrow. bles tomorrow.
Mrs. Herman L. Hoering of 36 Riverside Drive has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Georgia Straub, to George J. Hossenlopp, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. J. A. Hossenlopp of Rutherford, N. J.

The conquest of Austria by the Nazis "is a violation of the nature of history," Dr. Hans Kohn, .Professor of History at Smith College, declared yesterday before a meeting of the New York Society-for Ethical Culture under the auspices of the Women's Conference. Professor Kohn spoke at the meeting house, Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street.

Additional stars are due to be entered in an already brilliant field by Friday, closing day for supplementary nominations for the forty-eighth running of the Preakness Stakes, classic for 3-year-old thoroughbreds which Pimlico officials hope will be worth $80,000 this year.

Presentation of prizes to various winners in the recent metropolitan Catholic high schools' basketball tournament conducted by the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, featured a dinner tendered to the participants at the Brooklyn clubhouse last night. More than 100 persons attended.

Love is the only force that has sufficient strength to hold men and nations together; no ruler and no external force can do it, the Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. Farber, pastor of the Fourth Avenue Presbyterian Church, West End Avenue at Ninety-first Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

The amount of life insurance written by the fifty-seven legal reserve companies authorized to do business in New York State increased $1,023,147,494 from 1936 to 1937, Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance, announced today. In the same period,
Not only has Eddie Dowling deferred his one-act play project, "At Long Last," as had been indicated, but it now stands third on his schedule for next season. "Names,"

Charles A. Kidder of Southboro, retired member of Kidder, Peabody Co., bankers, died today in Concord at the age of 79. He was manager of the transfer department of-the banking house from 1901 until his retirement in 1929.

The chief obstacles to a revival of building in this country are high costs, bad organization and archaic legal restrictions, according to a pamphlet prepared by Miles L. Colean and titled "Can America Build Houses?"

During the break in stocks last Autumn, with the accompanying trade reaction, it was often asked whether large sales by foreign holders of American securities were not a primary influence. Such an idea seemed plausible;

Mrs. Adele Rivero, the titleholder; and Miss N. May Karff of Boston continued their victorious march in the tournament for the women's championship of the National Chess Federation and custody of the Hazel Allen trophy in the fifth round at Rockefeller Center yesterday.
A 24-year-old wife was found dead in the kitchen of her home here today 2-year-old son when they returned from an overnight visit to relatives in Brooklyn.
The Administration's recovery program is likely to replace reorganization as an issue on Capitol Hill this week, leaders studying the situation over the week-end believe.

Dr. Walter Damrosch and Burgess Meredith, respectively the leading attacker and the leading defender of the Coffee-Pepper Bill for the creation of a Bureau of Fine Arts, met on a public platform yesterday afternoon for the first time since controversy over the bill began.

Hendrik Willem Van Loon, according to his publishers, Simon Schuster, will accept no further lecture or radio engagements so that he may devote all his time to work on his next book, "The Story of the Average Man." It is scheduled to be published in the Fall of 1940.

Cardinal Hayes-was the principal figure in the Palm Sunday services at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. He blessed the palms, presided at solemn mass, walked through the church in the Procession of Palms and bestowed his blessing upon the 3,000 worshipers present.

The variable April climate apparently fosters the growth of late season exhibitions, for more than thirty new shows are on the calendar of the art world this week. Large groups and one-man exhibitions, museum attractions and annual events of various sorts are included.
The Newark Bears continued their winning streak at the expense of the Savannah Indians today, defeating the Sally League team, 5-4, by scoring two runs in the eighth and one in the ninth.

The car in which three bandits escaped. last night with $200,000 in jewelry taken at pistol point on the Boardwalk ramp from three New Yorker` was found abandoned today in the north end of the city, but failed to provide any. clues to the identity of the robbers. The car had been reported stolen by Frank Siracusa, Margate, N. J.

Police Commissioner Timilty said tonight that he would bar another magazine from Boston newsstands tomorrow, bringing the total number of publications placed under police ban in the past two months to fortytwo.

Mrs. Harriet Bishop Waters Christie, since 1934 president of the Woman's Press Club of New York, died unexpectedly yesterday morning of a heart attack while at breakfast in her suite in the Hotel Imperial, Broadway and Thirty-second Street.

The Yale Athletic Association today announced the award of the W. Leeming Jelliffe plaque, for the swimmer showing the greatest improvement during his four years at Yale, to John J. Macionis, '38, of Philadelphia, captain of this season's team.
Mrs. Grace Lindley of Sun Valley, Idaho, today won the women's national slalom championship by traversing two courses on the Nose Dive Trail of Mount Mansfield in a total of 2 minutes 32.6 seconds.

Christ's entry into Jerusalem was commemorated with elaborate Palm Sunday ceremonies today in the capital of Catholicism. At St. Peter's, Mgr. Luigi Campa, one of the Vatican canons, celebrated high mass and was the principal figure in the traditional Procession of the Palms through the huge bronze doorways of the edificd.

Charles F. Adams, chairman of the board of Suffolk Downs, tonight said that if owners of the horses were willing, his track would put on a $100,000 race on July 9 that would create a new vogue in the sport.

A proposal for the compulsory retirement of ministers at the age of 70 is one of the chief questions to be acted upon by the sesquicentennial General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, to be held here May 24 to June 1.

Arthur Charles Sanders of 1,815 Monroe Avenue, Bronx, for the last fifteen years chief projectionist-for the Twentieth Century-Fox Films, died of a heart attack Saturday afternoon in the Knickerbocker New Hospital at the age of 44 He was a veteran of Company K, 307th In- H fantry, Seventy-seventh Division, which formed part of the so-called "Lost Battalion."

For the second successive year the Rev. Daniel A. Lord, national director of Catholic sodalities and editor of the Queen's Work monthly, will conduct the annual Fordham College senior retreat, which begins this morning.

Claude G. Bowers, United States Ambassador to Spain, has accepted the honorary chairmanship of the Spanish Child Welfare Association, formed recently to supplement relief work of the American Friends Service Committee, it was announced yesterday at Association headquarters, 9 East Forty-sixth Street.
The first-place play-off game in the American Soccer League was won by the Scots-Americans today. After a 1-1 tie at half-time, the Scots rallied to defeat the Philadelphia Germans 4 to 2.

The American Bureau for Medical Aid to China will be the beneficiary of a group of ancient Chinese shadow plays to be presented by the Red Gate players the evening of April 20 in the ballroom of the Ambassador.

The American Institute of Chemists announced yesterday its annual medal for outstanding service to the science of chemistry or the profession of chemist had been awarded to Dr. Frederick G. Cottrell, consulting chemist, metallurgist and inventor.

The cotton market here was inclined to quietness last week, with occasional spurts of activity. The price trend was generally uncertain, and although fluctuations were not wide, the net changes were declines of 4 to 6 points.

Expenditure of at least $25,000,000 P( by. property owners for rehabilitation of old tenements and business min structures of the city within the next six months is hoped for by the and Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement, Joseph Platzker, the tom committee secretary, said yesterday.
James Nichols of Newark, N. J., business man and former minor league baseball player, died in a hospital here last night at the age of 52.
Effective today, the new offices and warehouse of the Merriam Paper Company will be located at 135 Hudson Street.
The AAA arranged today to apply marketing quotas to burley tobacco as the result of a referendum among growers yesterday.
The Ara Valley of Northeastern Spain, menaced by the Insurgent armies, is emptying its population into France through the mountain frontier post of Pont-du-Roi.

Two hundred and seventy-five goats between 5 and 6 weeks old arrived at the A. S. P. C. A. shelter shortly before noon yesterday, after a three-day journey from Georgia which led to the arrest of five men.

Bishop William T. Manning urged "the full help of our religion today in a world of great confusion and uncertainty" in his Palm Sunday sermon at St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, 128 West Sixty-ninth Street,. yesterday morning. He administered the sacrament of holy confirmation to a group of children.
Gene Venzke, the University of Pennsylvania's greatest miler, has accepted an invitation to meet Glenn Cunningham in a special mile race on April 30, the second day of the Penn relay carnival.

An event in a series commemorating the 110th anniversary of the founding of Abbot Academy in Andover, Mass., will take place the evening of April 19. Under the auspices of the New York Abbot Club, a dinner will be given at the Roosevelt for alumnae of the academy.

The Catholic Church was described as "the greatest union organizer in the history of the world" in an address yesterday at the Hotel Astor by the Rev. Edward Lodge Curran, president of the International Catholic Truth Society.

The Maloney bill for regulation of over-the-counter securities, as passed by the Senate, and the Lea bill, a companion in the House and now before the Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, do not as now worded meet the approval of State and municipal officials, according to Morris S. Tremaine, Controller of this State.
The American Academy in Rome announced yesterday that ten architectural students and seven students of landscape architecture had survived the academy's preliminary competitions for its Rome prizes.
Former President Wilhelm Miklas left his house at 7:30 A. M. today for the polls, respectfully followed by two policemen.

Releasing his annual pre-season odds for the major league pennant races, Jack Doyle, betting commissioner, yesterday installed the Yankees and Giants as favorites to set the pace in their respective leagues again.

Creation of a national movement to fight the "organized menace of Nazism in the United States" was voted by delegates of twenty-three trade unions, Catholic, Jewish and Protestant Church groups, at a meeting of the Non-Sectarian AntiNazi League at the Hotel Astor yesterday afternoon.

Blizzard conditions prevailed over the greater part of the Winter Wheat Belt last week, and while low temperatures developed in parts of the Southwest, where the plant was unusually advanced for this season,
The road to Tortosa is "sewed up" so tightly now that Loyalist commanders believe they can hold it and the entire stretch north to Mora against any attack that the Rebels can launch.

The money market here is still rather tight after the month-end, the rate for day loans being 2 1/4 per cent, against 2 3/4 per cent at the end of March and 1 7/8 per cent two weeks ago. Commercial acceptance are quoted at 3 3/8 per cent.

Announcement has been made here by Miss H. Alta Smith of Minneapolis and San Diego of the marriage of her niece, Miss Barbara Janet Smith, to James Lyndon Shanley, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Shanley of East Orange, N. J., which took place on Thursday in the rectory of St. Mary's Church, Evanston, Ill.

Porcelain penguins, ship models, mathematical problems, puppets, miniature stage settings and other spare-time indulgences of students and faculty members of Columbia University will be displayed today, tomorrow and Wednesday in the fifth annual Columbia Hobby Show in the lounge of John Jay Hall.

Miss Jane Laidlaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh A. Laidlaw of New York and San Francisco, and Russell E. Pierce, whose engagement was announced recently, will be married on Thursday at noon at the estate of Mrs. George E. Holmes in Amawalk, N. Y.

Horace Russell, general counsel of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board; De Coursey Fales of Cadwalader, Wickersham Taft, and William E. Frenaye Jr. of the Bank for Savings will be among the speakers at a meeting tomorrow to consider the need for reducing the cost and delay in foreclosure proceedings.
Cotton prices touched new low levels for the recent downward movement last week, but toward the close they recovered sharply and ended with only small net changes.

The long sought follow-up to RKO. Bernard McConville's "Nevada," portraying the rowdy days of Virginia City, when the Comstock lode was more than a name, has been purchased for Richard Dix and will be produced by Pandro S. Berman.

The Federal Trade Commission has announced hearings to be held in New York this week. A trade practice conference for the ribbon industry, to begin at 10 A. M. on Tuesday in the Hotel New Yorker, heads the list.

A program to help juniors and seniors determine the vocations they wish to pursue after graduation and to inform them on opportunities that exist has originated in the executive council of the School of Public and International Affairs of Princeton University.
The Long Island University and Queens teams scored in a Rugby double-header at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. The collegians defeated the Pilgrims, 11-0. and Queens halted St. Andrews, 6-0.

Still another victory--his sixth in seven games--was placed to the credit of Samuel Reshevsky, chess champion of the United States, yesterday afternoon, when he defeated George Shainswit of the Bronx in the seventh round of the National Federation tournament in thirty-seven moves.

The United States Engineer Office, Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street, will hold a hearing May 4 on the application of the Department of Parks for permission to construct, a 790-foot pedestrian bridge with lift span, from East 103d Street, Manhattan, to Wards Island, which the department is reclaiming for park and recreational purposes.

The amount paid on account of claims made for robbery of freight in transit by the railroads of the United States and Canada in 1937 was $532,939, the smallest for any year on record, according to the Association of American Railroads. This was an average of 1.3 cents for each car laden with revenue freight.

Yesterday's plebiscite marked the final humiliation of Austria. To be annexed by a powerful State is a bitter fate for a once-proud nation, but the ultimate insult is to be forced to go out and vote unanimously for your subjection.

The recent increase in international tension, the risks of war, fears about prospects of a capital levy, and the Treasury's investigation of the banks, have led some Frenchmen to withdraw their bank deposits and keep their funds in the form of notes.

A boycott of Austrian-made goods as a means of "halting the Nazi monster" was unanimously voted yesterday afternoon at the ninth annual convention of the National Federation of Jewish Men's Clubs of the United Synagogue of America, held at the Hotel Astor.
Dr. Ellen B. Scudder, retired medical missionary, died yesterday at the Clifton Springs Clinic, Clifton Springs, N. Y., after a short illness. She was 64 years old and lived at 547 Riverside Drive.

Although general business conditions showed slight change in February from the unsatisfactory level of January, total shipments of all types of hosiery increased 19.4 per cent from 8,463,967 dozen pairs in

The Brookhattan soccer team defeated the Paterson Caledonians, 2 to 1, at Starlight Park yesterday in the final game of the American League regular competition. This result gives the New York Americans the edge over the Caledonians.

Frank Boor, veteran singer and manager of the London Hippodrome, died here today. His age was 73. Starting his career as a stockbroker, Mr. Boor soon turned to the stage and in 1890 made his debut at Bremen with an English company in "Carmen Up-to-Date."
Professor and Mrs. Paul R. Evans of Newton, Pa., announced at a reception this afternoon the engagement of their daughter, Miss June Ruth Evans, to Floris Livingston Ferwerda of Princeton.

The election of Bishop Henry W. Hobson of the Episcopal Diocese of Southern Ohio (Cincinnati) as president of a movement for world Christianity was announced at the organization's annual meeting today.

The Sterling National Bank and Trust Company has reported that its total resources on March 31 were $31,115;395, compared to $30,971,286 on Dec. 31. Deposits were $27,232,716, against $27,136,292. Undivided profits were $153,829, against $141,133.

Franklyn Waltman, political columnist on The Washington Post, has been appointed director of publicity for the Republican National Committee, John D. M. Hamilton, the chairman, announced today. He will take over his duties soon.

OUT in Kansas our or five years ago, shortly after Alf Landon became Governor, there was a terrific scandal. A banker named Finney and his young broker son were convicted of bond forgery. The State Treasurer, the State Auditor and the State Attorney General were among those implicated.
The Park Department reminded residents of the city yesterday that they need not go to Washington toobserve flowering Japanese cherry trees.

If Mayor La Guardia should seek nomination for President of the United States he would have the almost unanimous support of the 750 men and women members of the senior class at Washington Square. College of New York University.

Skiing helped to increase passenger traffic on the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad in 1937, according to the annual report of H. A. Scandrett, president. Revenue from passengers in 1937 was $8,285,704, an increase of 10.5 per cent from 1936.

James C. Morton, vaudeville actor and variety man of another generation, died yesterday after a long illness at the Brunswick Home, near Islip, L.-I. He had been living until recently at the Percy Williams Home near by since 1930.

How they have succeeded in keeping primitive forms of life at a temperature of 300 degrees below zero for as long as 100 hours and then restored these to normal functions was told today by Dr. Alexander Goetz, California Institute of Technology physicist, and his wife, Mrs. Sylvia Goetz.

Prices of corn for future delivery fluctuated last week on the Board of Trade here within a range of less than 2 cents a bushel. While foreign demand was reported as relatively slow, a majority of traders expects that a considerable volume of business will be put through In the near future.
The government constituted by Edouard Daladier does not quite meet the hopes of French financial circles, which would have preferred a Ministry on lines more independent of political parties.

No new light was cast this week on the status of or prospects for the Reich's foreign loans. Owing to current uncertainties there was virtually no trading in dollars, and no recovery in the general level of quotations.

Howard Willets, commission merchant, descendant of an early American family and one - time owner of the 250-acre Gedney Farm of White Plains, now an exclusive residential subdivision, died last night in his home at 10 Oxford Road, Gedney Farm. He was 77 years old and had been ill for about three weeks.
Boulder Farm, in Stockbridge, Mass., has been purchaasd by Percy Morgan of New York from the estate of the late Professor Henry Wolcott Farnam of New Haven, according to Previews, Inc.

As far as the German voter was concerned yesterday's plebiscite decidedly suggested an anti-climax to the turbulent events of mid-March when Austro-German union was physically accomplished with weapons less peaceful than the ballot.
