Favorable health conditions continued in New York in February, low mortality from influenza and pneumonia being responsible for the lowest death rate ever recorded for the month, Dr. J. V. Deporte, director of the division of vital statistics of the State Health Department, announced today.
The aristocracy of hobodom opened its thirtieth annual convention in Trainmen's Hall today as "King" Jeff Davis with borrowed eyeglasses read communications from absent members.

While the exact sphere of authority of the new People's Advisory Council, created by the Kuomintang (Nationalist party] Congress to include representatives of all political factions, is not settled, it is indicated the council will have a role similar to that of the legislative Yuan.
Mrs. Josephine Gillespie Erskine, widow of Charles Wesley Erskine, shellac and gum importer, died yesterday at her home here after a long illness.
Because of advance borrowing by banks for subscription to the Reich loan, the money market was firm this week.

Dr. and Mrs. Egil Boeckmann, who returned recently from the Jekyl Island Club, Brunswick, Ga., and were at the Pierre, left yesterday for their home in St. Paul, accompanied by their daughters, the Misses Gertrude and Mary Boeckmann.

An announcement by Larry Mac-Phail yesterday disclosed many improvements made in or around Ebbets Field for the forthcoming campaign, which will have its preview next week-end when the Dodgers play hosts to the Yankees.

Brig. Gen. Leon A. Matile, U. S. A., retired, veteran of the Civil War, Indian campaigns in the West and the Spanish-American War, died this morning at Walter Reed Hospital. He was in his ninety-fourth year.
A warrant for the arrest of Archduke Otto of Habsburg,. claimant to the Austrian throne, on charges of high treason was issued on March 29. This action was revealed today by Dr. Franz Hueber,

At hearings to begin in Birmingham, Ala., on Monday before William E. Lee, a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, eight Southern States will protest against freight rate differentials which they contend are retarding the free movement of their products to consuming centers.

The Insurgent offensive to end the Spanish civil war became today a fivepronged fork that Generalissimo Francisco Franco jabbed into Northeastern Spain, from the French frontier region to the middle eastern coast.
Bishop Hirma Richard Hulse of the Protestant Episcopal Church of Cuba, died here this morning of a heart attack at the Anglo-American Hospital. His age was 69.

Sidney Goldberg, Newark lawyer and former Assemblyman, announced here tonight that he would fly to Washington tomorrow to lay before HOLC officials the plight of a family of fourteen evicted from a home at 401 Berryman Place here for failure to meet HOLC obligations.

Drastic curtailment of production of rayon woven cloths continues, according to the report on loom activity for the week ended April, issued for publication today by the National Rayon Weavers Association, Inc.

When the Emigrant Bank sold to Catherine Rigas the premises at 1,881-1,883 Lexington Ave for a consideration Indicated as $13,500 it took back a purchase money mortgage for $12,256, payable five years hence.
The securities markets here can at present be best described as existing on a daily or almost an hourly basis. At the moment their condition is one of firm inactivity.

Before the largest crowd ever to see a National Hockey League game, Chicago's fighting Black Hawks defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs by 2 to 1 tonight to take a two-to-one game advantage in their final best-of-five series for the Stanley Cup, emblematic of world hockey supremacy. The paid attendance was 18,496. ance was 18,496.

Coupons of the American tranche of the Dawes Loan stamped "USA Domicile Oct. 1, 1935" which will mature on April 15 will be bought at $25 for each $35 face amount of the coupon in the same manner as coupons of the same tranche which matured on Oct. 15, the German Consulate General in New York announced yesterday.

The rise of ??10,209,000 in the circulation of the Bank of England in the last fortnight was due almost entirely to normal end-of-quarter currency demands and to preparations by the banks for the approach of Easter business.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, has written to Chairman Meyer of Division 4 of the Interstate Commerce Commission a letter stating that a survey prepared by examiners of
Mrs. Helen about Almy, director of the Cambridge Neighborhood House, oldest settlement house in the world, died day in Cambridge.

The third and final session of the Long Island Beagle Club's annual Spring field trials was held today, with Amawalk Bob, owned and handled by Otto Partenheimer of Queens Village, scoring in a field of twenty-three in the thirteen-inch all-age combined stake.

The Korjena Medicine Company, Elmira, N. Y., has been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to cease certain methods of competition in connection with the sale of Korjena tablets, advertised as a cure for obesity.

Miss Margaretta du Pont. Tatnall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walker G. Tatnall Jr. of this city, was married yesterday afternoon in Westminster Presbyterian Church here to Robert Kennedy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew G. Kennedy.
Holy Week, which began yesterday, will be more widely observe in this city than ever before. More of the nonritualistic churches will hold daily services than in pas years.
Crossing Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn, near Tompkins Avenue, in the middle of the block, a 19-year-old girl was killed by a trolley car early this morning and her escort was injured critically.

A sharp difference of opinion that has arisen between Whidden Graham and T. John Tracy, on the one hand, and B. Charney Vladeck, majority leader of the City Council, on the other, regarding the proposed tax on banks for unemployment relief, prompts me to enter the. discussion with the hope of clarifying the situation.
Professional football put a strap to its out-of-bounds kickers today as the National League Rules Committee made five changes in playing regulations. laying regulations.

Drastic curtailment of production of rayon woven cloths continues, according to the report on loom activity for the week ended April, issued for publication today by the National Rayon Weavers Association, Inc.

When the Emigrant Bank sold to Catherine Rigas the premises at 1,881-1,883 Lexington Ave for a consideration Indicated as $13,500 it took back a purchase money mortgage for $12,256, payable five years hence.
The securities markets here can at present be best described as existing on a daily or almost an hourly basis. At the moment their condition is one of firm inactivity.

Before the largest crowd ever to see a National Hockey League game, Chicago's fighting Black Hawks defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs by 2 to 1 tonight to take a two-to-one game advantage in their final best-of-five series for the Stanley Cup, emblematic of world hockey supremacy. The paid attendance was 18,496. ance was 18,496.

Coupons of the American tranche of the Dawes Loan stamped "USA Domicile Oct. 1, 1935" which will mature on April 15 will be bought at $25 for each $35 face amount of the coupon in the same manner as coupons of the same tranche which matured on Oct. 15, the German Consulate General in New York announced yesterday.

The rise of ??10,209,000 in the circulation of the Bank of England in the last fortnight was due almost entirely to normal end-of-quarter currency demands and to preparations by the banks for the approach of Easter business.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, has written to Chairman Meyer of Division 4 of the Interstate Commerce Commission a letter stating that a survey prepared by examiners of
Mrs. Helen about Almy, director of the Cambridge Neighborhood House, oldest settlement house in the world, died day in Cambridge.

Anthony J. Kerin, treasurer of Tower Brothers Stationery Company of this city and governor of the National Stationery Association, has been appointed State director of that industry, according to announcement issued for publication today by Charles R. Haffenden
Professional football put a strap to its out-of-bounds kickers today as the National League Rules Committee made five changes in playing regulations. laying regulations.

The Jersey Reds took a 3-1 lead over the Brooklyn Jewels in the play-off series for the American Basketball League championship by winning last night's encounter, 26-24, before 3,000 persons at Arcadia Hall in Brooklyn. One more victory will give the Jersey Reds the crown.

A series of events of interest to all professions represented in the membership of the National Arts Club has been arranged for the remainder of this month. First of these is the annual dinner and meeting which will be held tomorrow night.

Confirming numerous past statements, Minister of Finance Francisco Garces Gana replied today to J. Reuben Clark Jr. of the Chilean Bondholders Committee of New York explaining that it is impossible under existing conditions to consider any improvement in the terms of the offer submitted some time ago by Chile's Government under terms of Law No. 5580.

A man, tentatively identified from a driver's license in his pocket as Max Willy Paust, 43 years old, of 528 Chauncey Street, Brooklyn, was found dead early today at-the wheel of a milk-tank truck on Route 25 in the Avenel section of Woodbridge. An autopsy revealed that he had died of heart disease.
A full day of running in the $1,000 free-for-all stake of the annual field trial meeting of the English Setter Club of America brought the main event near conclusion today.

The city of High Point, N. C., will advise today holders of its serial bonds maturing on Sept. 1, 1938, to April 1, 1948, except electric bonds, 6 and 5 1/4 Percent bonds, maturing on or after July 1, 1943, that it proposes to exchange a part of its outstanding serial bonds maturing each year in this period for new refunding bonds.

A body later identified as that of Henry Scharinghausen, 30 years old, of New York City, was found hanging from a tree in a patch of woods off the Indian Hill Road here today by two women who were searching for firewood.

In the last five days this correspondent has checked on a front extending from the shining snow slopes of the Pyrenees down to where the hard bright blue of the Mediterranean turns milky from the yellow flood of the Ebro and a single date palm marks the entrance into shattered Tortosa.
Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.9, which compares with 81.2 a week ago, 81.9 two weeks ago,

A crowd of 15,137, the largest ever to see an amateur hockey game in Boston. today packed the Garden to see the Boston Olympics shut out the Sherbrooke (Que.) Red Raiders, 2 to 0, and sweep their two-game series. The Olympics won last night, 6 to 3.

The weather was chilly today as the Dodgers made their farewell to Florida for another year, but Van Lingle Mungo and the rest of the Grimesmen were hot, so the Tars went down to a second straight defeat by the lop-sided score of 13-1.
Little change in employment and payrolls in New York State factories from Feb. 15 to March 15 was reported today by Elmer F.

All deliveries of oats, rye and soy beans dropped last week to the lowest price level of the season on the Board of Trade as the result of general liquidation, but there was a good rally from the low point.

Setting a whirlwind pace in the second period, Kildare overcame Mayo's 5-to-2 half-time lead to score by 7 points (1 goal and 4 points) to 5 points (1 goal and 2 points) at Innisfail Park yesterday before 1,500 fans.

The number of apparel buyers in the market last week declined as retailers concentrated on pre-Easter business. However, the volume- of mail orders increased. New early Summer lines of better dresses met with good response.

An end for all time to the Chaco dispute between Paraguay and Bolivia, lowering of immigration barriers to permit the entry of refugees fleeing European dictnatorships and a united front to make a practical success of the Pan-American conference meeting at Lima. Peru, in 1939 will be the chief topics discussed here tomorrow by representatives of five leading nations of America.

Negotiations toward settlement of the strike of employees of the Duluth Herald and News Tribune were halted today by threat of a jurisdictional dispute between the Lake Superior Newspaper Guild, a C. I. O. affiliate,
The Tigers concluded their annual stand in Lakeland today with a 7-to-6 victory over Montreal of the International League.

Miss Esther Schulman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Schulman of 350 Central Park West, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr., Samuel Frederick Groopman of 29 Fifth Avenue, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Groopman.
Some 2,000 German and Austrian residents in Great Britain were taken from London to sea beyond the three-mile limit today to cast their votes in the Anschluss poll.

Mrs. Henry W. Peabody will show colored motion pictures of the recent twentieth anniversary celebration of the Missionary Medical College at Vellore, India, to illustrate an address at 8 P. M., on April 26, in the Burrell Memorial Hall of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.
Carl Hubbell, for the first time this year, put himself to a full nine-inning test today and the result was so extraordinary it left a capacity crowd of 8,000 quite confounded.

Nationwide sales of department stores declined 14 per cent in March, according to figures released for publication today by the Federal Reserve Board. Reflecting the fact that Easter this year occurs three weeks later than was the case in 1937,

Use of the instruments of controlled economy to bring about credit and price inflation is recommended by Lawrence Dennis, economist of E. A. Pierce Co., in a booklet under the title "Washington and the Price Trend."

A movement to substitute the terms "export balance" and "import balance" for the less accurate "favorable trade balance" and "unfavorable trade balance" in the foreign trade figures of the United States has been started by the National Foreign Trade Week Committee,

The cleavage between left and right wing elements among school teachers widened yesterday with the formation of the American Education Association, organized to oppose "Communist" influences and the application of the progressive theory of education in the public schools.
Christ's life must be re-enacted by every one who wishes redemption, said the Rev. W. Dudley F. Hughes, precentor of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, in his sermon there yesterday morning.

The outdoor exhibition of the Sculptors Guild will be opened at 3 P. M. tomorrow on the lot at the northeast corner of Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street. The lot has been converted into a landscaped setting for the 100-odd pieces which will be shown by forty-six artists.
The active work of the Catholic Daughters of America against the subversive propaganda in magazines and newspapers was described by Miss Mary C. Duffy, Supreme Regent of the order.

As chairman of the committee seeking contributions toward the $1,000,000 required to complete the building program of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Mayor La Guardia issued a statement yesterday announcing that more than $240,000 has been raised to date in cash and pledges.

Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "How New York City Is Governed," Raymond V. Ingersoll. Round table luncheon, Town Hall Club. 12:30 P. M. "Bringing Back the Baby Panda;" Ruth Harkness.
Mrs. Thomas Pinckney Bryan has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Norma Stewart Bryan, to Francis Winslow Poe Brawley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marion Brawley of Greenville, S. C.
Extension into the up-State area of the organizing campaign of the Workers Alliance was voted yesterday at the closing session of the annual convention of the Workers Alliance of Greater New York.

A Spring concert will be given tonight at the Greenwich Academy by the Greenwich Choral Society. Featured will be a group of folk songs and choruses from "The Bartered Bride" by the upper school chorus of eighty-five girls from the academy.

The foreign exchange market here was extremely quiet last week, with the franc firmer in the first few days following the liquidation of speculative bear positions, but later some sales of francs occurred and the trend was easier.

Although anglers along the Willowemoc, five miles distant, reported poor catches, the brook and brown trout in the streams of the New York Trout and Skeet Club struck at flies and bucktails as if it were a bright, sunny day.

Miss Jane Turner, 17, daughter of Mrs. Terrill Vaningen of Round Hill, was injured this noon when she was thrown from her colt on John Street. She was taken to the Greenwich Hospital by Police Sergeant Robert H. Fitzroy and John McArthur, sexton of the Round Hill Community Church, and was found to be suffering from a concussion.
May lard and cottonseed oil sold at approximately the same price last week on the Board of Trade, a most unusual situation, as normally lard brings a premium of around 1 cent a pound.
Charley Ruffing shook the icicles from his fingers at Ponce de Leon Park today and gave the Yankees their third straight victory.

Cooperation of the United States with other nations for peace was urged as a substitute for world armament races by the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish in a sermon at Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal church, Clinton and Montague streets, Brooklyn,

The Anglo-Italian negotiations were formally declared closed after a forty-five-minute conversation between Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano and the Earl of Perth, British Ambassador here, shortly after noon today.

Taking up his naming-no-names "debate" with Mayor La Guardia, which began last Sunday over the question of radicals in public office and tolerance toward minorities, former Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley declared yesterday his opposition to giving representation to a minority group that was against "the principles of American government."
A concert will be given under the auspices of the Beethoven Association tonight at 8:30 o'clock in Town Hall. The participants will be Marjorie Lawrence, soprano, and the Roth Quartet.

The liner Queen Mary arrived from New York four hours late today after battling a twenty-fourhour storm that sent great waves crashing over her decks, injuring about forty persons, most of them slightly. It was the worst storm the big liner had encountered.
Mrs. Hope Norton Stevens received a divorce here today from George E. Stevens. The couple reached an agreement on the custody and support of their four children.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve in this district were notified yesterday by Owen D. Young, chairman of the board of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, that an election would be held next month to fill the vacancy in the office of Class A director of the bank caused

The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals granted a seven-day stay yesterday to Remington Rand, Inc., against a National Labor Relations Board order directing the company to recognize the Office Equipment Workers, an A. F. of L. union, pending an appeal for a review of the order by the Supreme Court.

Chile's proposal of a radical change in the calendar, to equal monthly divisions with numerous other modifications, which was presented some time ago to the League of Nations, has received whole-hearted support from Turkey, China and Afghanistan, according to a report given out today.
Edgar Jepson, novelist and one-time co-editor with Frank Harris of the English magazine Vanity Fair, died at his home in Hampstead today at the age of 74.

Increases in the power and prestige of the political officers of the Red army known as "military commissars" were shown today in pronouncements of a higher source of the Communist party and the Red army itself.

Miss Thora Anna Bird, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Viggo E. Bird of West Hartford, has chosen her two sisters, Mrs. Clement Clarke Moore and Miss Mary Parker Bird, as attendants at her wedding May 14 to Gordon Chase Streeter, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward C. Streeter of Red Brook, Stonington.

The circus, an enterprise long associated with the tradition that "the show must go on," encountered yesterday a threat by the American Federation of Actors to throw a picket line around Madison Square Garden through which no one remotely connected with the production would pass.
With displays ranging from a diamond-studded clock made for Marie Antoinette to old American hooked rugs, the Antiques Exposition was opened yesterday at the Hotel Commodore.

Charges of "nepotism" have often been "hurled" in the United States. In General Grant's Administrations they were especially frequent. In a milder form they are heard of sporadically in the Congress, the States and the cities. They never seem to have much effect.

Another shipment of gold, amounting to $5,800,000, has been dispatched here by Japan, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday. This swelled to $27,700,000 the total of gold engaged in Japan since Feb. 24 for shipment to this country.
The report of the probation officer of General Sessions, attempting to tell the court before sentence what sort of person Richard Whitney was and how he got that way, was made public yesterday.

Characterizing the Hitler plebiscite on Austria as "the most tragic hoax in the history of world politics," the American Committee for Protection of Minorities announced yesterday it would launch a campaign at Washington for an embargo of shipments of noncombative war materials, including helium, to Germany.

Laborite Arthur Henderson tonight asked the British Goverment to quit "hiding behind a barricade of official ignorance" and to give the House of Commons facts on Italo-German aid to the Spanish Insurgents.
Virginia's nine, which had registered ninth-inning victories over Vermont and Harvard, had to stem a last-inning rally by Michigan before turning back the Wolverines today, 5 to 4.

The PAUL Agricultural Adjustment Administration and the Farm Security Administration have agreed upon a plan for making loans to farmers in the wind-erosion or "dust-bowl" area of the Southern Great Plains to assist them in financing winderosion control practices.

Miss Halina Tomska of Detroit splashed to a new national record for the 100-yard free style swim tonight in the Senior Women's Indoor A. A. U. championship meet to dethrone Miss Claudia Eckert of Chicago.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Ernest S. Ballard of Hubbard Woods, Ill., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elisabeth Sloan Ballard, to Frank Fuller Fowle Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Fuller Fowle of Winnetka, Ill.

The Jersey City Giants were defeated by the Memphis Chicks of the Southern Association, 3 to 2, today. Glen Gabler went the route for the visitors, yielding seven safeties, while Willis and Zajac, who shared the mound assignment for the home team, parted with nine blows between them.
Joseph M. Cogan, one of Brooklyn's best-known newspaper men, died Sunday night in the Holy Family Hospital after a short illness. He was 79 years old.

Mayor La Guardia, after a perfunctory public hearing yesterday in his City Hall office, signed the three new city tax bills designed to raise $10,000,000 for unemployment relief. The Mayor took advantage of the occasion to renew his attacks upon Governor Lehman for the Governor's relief tax stand. The new taxes, he asserted, should be termed "State Neelizence Taxes."

The Home Thrift Association began yesterday a four-day Spring festival. The feature of the opening day was a musical contest at its Main House, 350 East Eighty-eighth Street. It was won by 11-year-old Ellen Hubbard, who sang "Bei Mir Bist du Schon."

There will be 813 Deputies in the new Reichstag, according to an announcement today. Each Deputy, officially speaking, represents 60,000 voters. Today's revised official returns in yesterday's plebiscite give the following figures:

Five Ministers presented their resignations to President Alberto Enriquez yesterday in order to permit him to reorganize his Cabinet, according to a report in Universo today. Dissatisfaction of the country with the reorganization of the Supreme Court is believed to be the probable cause.

Northern Ireland's Prime Minister Viscount Craigavon and members of his Cabinet came to London today to insist that Northern Ireland [Ulster] trade be not sacrificed by the impending commercial agreement with Ireland, the former Irish Free State.

Foreign investors in securities of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad increased their holdings in the last year, according to the annual report for 1937 filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission by the railroad. Holdings of the Swiss Bank Corporation were increased from 64,187 shares of common stock at the end of 1936 to 142,763 shares of common stock.

Properties on the west side of be Manhattan, from Greenwich Village to to Washington Heights, changed hands in deals reported yesterday by brokers. The heirs of the Edward Brown estate, after an ownership said to date back sixty years,
The general level of wholesale commodity prices declined last week to a new low point for the current recession, according to the index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association.

Cotton goods, one of the first products to suffer from overzealous advance buying and therefore to enter the recession, turned active yesterday on a broad front, giving rise to the belief in some quarters that an upturn of significant proportions was under way in that industry.

Jim Londos, 200, Greece, threw Jesse James, 190, Greece, in the feature wrestling bout at the New York Hippodrome before a crowd of 5,000 persons. last night. The winning hold, an airplane spin and body hold, came after 42:07.
The three-story banking building on the northeast corner of Maiden Lane and Nassau Street has been leased for occupancy by the Bankers Federal Savings and Loan Association.

The Bureau of Air Commerce is establishing a private flying section in its safety and planning division to study private aviation activity with a view to its encouragement, Colonel J. Monroe Johnson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, announced today.
The Art Students League, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, has awarded scholarships to ten winners in its annual out-of-town scholarship competition, it was announced yesterday.
Friends of Michael D. Aisenstein today reported that the former Oakland, Calif., hydraulic engineer and his artist wife were under arrest on undisclosed charges.

Members of the Distilled Spirits Institute, including representatives of practically every major distilling company, met yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in an attempt to dispose of the problem posed last year when buyers for monopoly States notified the trade that they would demand the same price concessions given by distillers in markets where more competitive conditions exist in the retailing of liquor.

Marcel Rochas, Inc., dressmakers, of 32 East Sixty-seventh Street, won a decision in the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday that voided a search warrant and directed the return of business records and merchandise seized as contraband by a customs agent.

Spencer Tracy, motion picture actor, arrived here yesterday in the S. S. Virginia of the Panama Pacific en route to Europe to recuperate from an operation. He was accompanied by his wife, the former Louise Treadwell, and his physician, Dr. Howard Dennis.

The death in Old Umtali, Rhodesia, on April 8, of the Rev. Dr. Eddy Horace Greeley, for fifty years missionary of the Methodist Episcopal Church in Africa, was announced yesterday in a cablegram to the church's Board of Foreign Missions, 150 Fifth Avenue. He was 80 years old.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Bancamerica-Blair Corporation obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $519,000 of various-purpose bonds of the city of Troy, N. Y., on their bid of 100.028 for 2.20s.

Fred Keller, political commissar of the American Lincoln-Washington Battalion, grinned happily and started eating four dishes of bean soup when newspaper men walked up to his cot in the International Brigade's new hospital near Barcelona this morning.

Charles Edward Bayliss Jr. is with the bond department of the Lee Higginson Corporation. Evar L. Linder has joined Jackson Curtis as a securities trader in their Chicago office. The April quarterly edition of the E-Z Telephone Directors is now being distributed.
Chester Bailey Fernald, 69 years old, an American-born dramatist and newspaper man, was drowned in Dover Harbor when he was knocked off the auxiliary cutter Florence by a boom last night.

The Knoedler Gallery, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, opened yesterday one of its major exhibitions of the season-a magnificent group of fifteenth and sixteenth century Venetian paintings, most of them lent by museums and private collectors.

New York City should set up a permanent rehousing bureau to aid those made homeless by new housing projects or by condemnation for public improvements or vacating of substandard buildings, the committee on rehousing of the Citizens Housing Council urged yesterday at a meeting at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street.
CRADLED IN MURDER, by Rudd Fleming. (Simon Schuster, $2.) A mystery novel. THE DAUGHTER, by Bessie Breuer. (Simon Schuster, $2.50.) A second novel by the author of "Memory of Love."
Pursuing the principle on which it based its decision in the Inland Steel Company case, the National Labor Relations Board today ruled that if the H. J. Heinz Company,

Three local savings banks, the East River Savings Bank, the Dry Dock Savings Institution and the Union Square Savings Bank, are now observing the ninetieth anniversary of their founding. The East River, of which Joseph A. Broderick is president,

The steel industry of the United States earned 6.2 per cent on the investment in 1937, according to a survey by the American Iron and Steel Institute covering ninetyeight companies which account for more than 90 per cent of the total output of the industry.

Madison St. 143, 25x100: Mortgage Commission Realty Corp to Mortgage Commission Trustee Corp. 346 Broadway. 65th St, 214-16 W, 50x100.5: Doudoux Realty Corp to A. G. S. O. Corp, 114 E 32d St; mtg $71,500 ($5.50). 74th St, n s., block from Broadway to Amsterdam Ave, 56.10 on former and 54.4 on latter; 201 West 74th St Corp, Oscar Wuerz, pres, to Emigrant Bank, which holds a mtg for $841,000 thereon.

The boxing program at the Hippodrome for tomorrow night has been canceled, it was announced yesterday by Promoter Mike Jacobs. Following two substitutions, the tenround final was to have pitted Frankie Wallace, Cleveland veteran, against Georgie Zengaras of the East Side.

In his railroad message to Congress the President follows an unusual course. He tells Congress that "some immediate legislation" on the railroads is necessary at this session, but he does not tell Congress what in his opinion that legislation ought to be.
REUNION, a play in a prologue and three acts, by Norman H. White Jr. Staged by Freeman Hammond. Produced by Norman H. White Jr. and Kenneth W. Robinson. At the Nora Bayes Theatre.

A man who described himself as Carlos Martinez, 27 years old, of 66 East 114th Street, was taken to Bellevue Hospital as a prisoner last night on charges of burglary and possession of burglar's tools, after he had been shot by detectives who pursued him through Amsterdam Avenue between Eighty-sixth and Eighty-seventh Streets.

Declaring that it believed the order issued to it last week by the National Labor Relations Board to be "erroneous," the Inland Steel Company today notified the Chicago regional director of the NLRB and the Steel Workers Organizing Committee,

GOVERNORS ISLAND Captain Martin E. Durham, Inf.-Res., 84 Elizabeth St., Plattsburg, N. Y., 389th Infantry. is ordered to active duty, April 17, at Plattsburg Barracks. N. Y. Date of rank, Sept. 11, 1935. He will be relieved from active duty April 30, on which date he will revert to an inactive sattus.

Edward A. Phoenix, assistant sales promotion manager of the Johns-Manville Corporation, was elected president of the Technical Publicity Association, Inc., last night at a meeting of the association at the Engineers Club, 32 West Fortieth Street.

Losing no time, Premier Edouard Daladier will go before Parliament tomorrow and present a demand for credits and liberty in financial matters that would enable him to dispense with parliamentary control for some weeks or months to come.
President Roosevelt conferred with Congressional leaders and other officials. on the proposed program of relief and pump-priming and had his usual Monday luncheon with Secretary Morgenthau.

Johnny Gaudes of St. Boniface, Manitoba, won a close decision over Norman (Baby) Yack of Toronto, Canadian bantamweight boxing champion, in a nontitle fight tonight. Gaudes weighed 120 pounds, Yack 119. A crowd of 11,380 saw the young Manitoba boxer register his second nontitle victory over the TOronto champion within three weeks. -The decision was unanimous.

As a result of Anschluss and its overwhelming popular ratification in yesterday's plebiscite, Germans for the first time are able to sing the national anthem, "Deutschland ueber Alles," with a consciousness that the frontiers outlined therein have been almost attained.

Archibald R. Watson, Clerk of New York County, announced yesterday that he had arranged for a series of radio broadcasts over Station WNYC to stimulate interest in jury service. There will be six addresses in the series.
After almost six years' delay an agreement with France on the interchange of literature will come into effect soon as a result of its ratification by the French Chamber of Deputies.

Uniform harbor charges for the national ports of Halifax, St. John, Chicoutimi, Quebec, Three Rivers and Montreal were announced today by the National Harbors Board. They will go into effect Thursday.
How the Weirton Steel Corporation spent $5,000,000 in sixteen months in order to retain old and loyal employes on the payroll was related today by Thomas E. Millsop, president of the corporation.

The Securities and Exchange Commission tonight announced the names of witnesses to appear tomorrow at the opening of its hearing here into the financial affairs of Richard Whitney, former president of the New York Stock Exchange, who has pleaded guilty and has been sentenced on grand larceny charges.

WITH THE INSURGENTS, on the Catalan Front, Spain, (by Courier to Saint - Jean - de - Luz, France), April 11.-By this weekend Generalissimo Francisco Franco's troops may reach the Mediterranean coast somewhere between Valencia and the French frontier if their great offensive continues to progress as it has thus far.

James J. Morton, vaudeville actor, died on Sunday at the Brunswick Home, Amityville, L. I., at the age of 76. It was reported incorrectly in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday that James C. Morton, also an actor, had died at the same place and at the same time.

Warned anew by Vice President Garner that Congressional opposition awaits a revival of large-scale, pump-priming government spending, President Roosevelt began preparations today to take his relief and recovery program straight to the country in a radio "fireside" chat.

A large audience in which local society was well represented attended a concert given by the Greenwich Choral- Society at the Greenwich Academy tonight. Irwin Dillon of New York, tenor, was soloist in Malipiero's composition, "Princess Ulalia."

A 26-year-old French clerk, Pierre Lombard, was sentenced today to five years' imprisonment after conviction in a secret trial by the Bordeaux military court on a charge of organizing an espionage ring.

In a world where many youths are skeptical, lack profound belief in anything and disdain traditional doctrines, perhaps the most striking aspect of the Spanish war for a foreign visitor is the spectacle of thousands of robust youngsters fighting machine guns and hand grenades in what to them is a religious crusade.

Dr. Bela Schick, discoverer of the Schick test for susceptibility to diphtheria, chief of the Pediatrics Department at Mount Sinai Hospital, New York, has received the award of the Addingham Gold Medal, a British honor for "the most valuable discovery for relieving pain and suffering in humanity," it was announced yesterday ??V Mount Sinai.
Although held to one hit, Manual Training's baseball team profited by seven errors to defeat Textile High, 5-2, yesterday at the Parade Grounds in a game limited to six innings by agreement.

The Standard Oil Company of California reports consolidated net profits of $41,254,778 for 1937, equal to $3.15 a share on the capital stock, compared to $23,310,224, or $1.78 a share, earned in 1936.

Dr. James Noble Rule, who served from 1931 to 1935 as State Superintendent of Public Instruction, died here today in his sixty-second year. He entered Washington Hospital on March 20 and underwent an operation three weeks ago. At his death Dr. Rule was principal of Langley High School in Pittsburgh.

Corporation Council William C. Chanler announced yesterday that the city had settled for $96,000 an action for which a $500,000 settlement had been recommended during the Walker and McKee administrations.

A two-run rally in the ninth inning enabled the Newark Bears ??o conquer the Binghamton club of the Eastern League, 10 to 9, today. The late attack climaxed an uphill battle staged by the International Leaguers -who made five runs in the fifth.

A sentence of thirty to sixty years in State prison was imposed in General Sessions yesterday on John Mahoney, 20 years old, of 112 West Sixty-first Street, for a hold-up on Sept. 22 last of the bar at 705 Third Avenue, in which the loot was $35 and a wrist watch.

With the imposing of a five to ten year prison sentence on Richard Whitney, for deliberate diversion to his own purposes of securities held by his banking house in trust, a melancholy story reached something like completion.

Jackie Coogan, known as the "kid" of motion pictures, is "broke" and has been deprived of his life's earnings of more than $4,000,000, he charged today in a suit filed in Superior Court against his mother and stepfather, seeking an accounting.
The Chaco dispute, immigration barriers, disarmament, peace and a league of American nations were discussed by representatives of five American States here today.

Crews of French workmen today hacked through huge snowdrifts into Andorra, clearing a path for evacuation of refugees swarming in from the mountains of government Spain. The flight from Spain's civil war, which already has seen more than 15,000 fugitives cross the frontier

Although held to a draw for the second time since the opening of the championship tournament of the National Chess Federation at Rockefeller Center, Samuel Reshevsky, titleholder, kept his hold on first place in the eighth round last night. His opponent was Israel A.

Poor weather throughout the country last week hampered retail trade and cut down the volume of orders for Easter selling coming into the local apparel markets yesterday, manufacturers and resident offices reported.
The Huntington police and Boy Scouts searched the woods near here today for what is possibly the most valuable animal ever to roam this district.

Illinois goes to the polls tomorrow in off-year primaries with public attention centered on the bitter war between two Democratic machines. One faction is headed by Mayor Edward J. Kelly of Chicago and Patrick A. Nash, Democratic National Committeeman, with its greatest strength concentrated in the metropolitan area.

Among today's concerts: Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor, and John Charles Thomas, soloist, tonight, Carnegie Hall; Marie Nabatoff, song recital, evening, Town Hall; Hellmut Baerwald, pianist, evening, Steinway Hall.

Frank E. Wheeler of White Plains, N. Y., died here suddenly last night, in his sixty-sixth year. Stricken with a heart attack while motoring with Mrs. Wheeler, he was rushed to a physician's office but was dead upon arrival. The Wheelers were spending a few days in Asheville on their way home from Florida.

In a day of acrimonious debate the Senate today voted a modified Civil Service Reform Bill for postmastership appointments as a substitute for a bill by Senator McKellar and then adopted the amended bill, 49 to 20. Senator McKellar's bill had been attacked as a "spoils system" measure.

Frank M. Ball, who was circulation manager of The New York Tribune in 1915, 1919 and 1921, died Saturday at his residence, 175 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, in his sixty-first year. Until its absorption on April 1 by the International Paper Company, he had been for seventeen years owner and manager of the Amalgamated Paper Company, which he organized.

On the eve of an important meeting of the Committee for Industrial Organization, it was learned today that the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union will not respond to the call for a convention to form a permanent organization if the C. I. O. should decide upon such a meeting.

John Brennan, 29 years old, a commercial artist, and his wife, Catherine, 28, were found dead last night in what- appeared to be a suicide compact in their home at 37-41 Seventy-eighth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, where they had moved three weeks ago after their marriage in January.

Dr. William H. Holden of 6 East Eighty-fifth Street, who has just finished a six-month expedition into British Guiana and Brazil, returned yesterday on-the Royal Netherlands liner Van Renn Selaer. Dr. Holden was the leader of a group of six men who left last August on an expedition under sponsorship of the American Museum of Natural History.

The House today passed the 1939 District of Columbia Revenue Bill after a two-hour debate ended in elimination of an amendment which provided for the collection of income taxes from all persons working in the District save members of Congress, their secretaries, Federal judges, Cabinet officers and the President.

No better evidence of the wide and divergent opinions regarding the report of the Interstate Commerce Commissioners providing for financial assistance to the nation's railroads could be offered than the statements of various interested governmental officials and advisers which President Roosevelt made public in transmitting the report to Congress yesterday.
Prospects for the best yield of Winter wheat since 1931 were indicated today in the survey as of April 1 gathered by the Crop Reporting Board of the Bureau of Agriculture Economics.

The report of the Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28, issued yesterday, shows a net income after all operating expenses and charges of $3,852,904, compared with $3,007,631 in the twelve months to Feb. 28, 1937. Gross operating revenues of the system for the twelve months were $52,499,020, against $48,593,502.

Week-end discussions between Postmaster General James A. Farley and local Democratic leaders are reported to have convinced them of the necessity of "drafting" United States Senator Robert F. t Wagner as the party candidate for Governor. They believe that Senator Wagner, despite his personal inclination to stay in the Senate, finally will agree to head the State ticket.

Selecting William McC. Martin Jr. as its choice for chairman of the board and twenty-seven recognized liberals to be members of that board, the nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday- confirmed and, within its powers, carried forward the reorganization policies sponsored and effected by the present administration under Charles R. Gay, president.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 6:

Charles L. Bradley and John P. Murphy, who are fighting Robert R. Young for control of the Van Sweringen railroad empire, carried their battle direct to the profitable Chesapeake Ohio Railway today by announcing that they were soliciting proxies for its April 19 meeting at Richmond, Va.

The necessity for providing a strong religious background for the modern soldier was stressed by Colonel William R. Arnold, chief of chaplains, United States Army, yesterday at the monthly luncheon of the New York Chapter of the Chaplains Association at the Hotel Taft.

The Beethoven Association closed its nineteenth season of concerts, which are presented annually "in a spirit of artistic fraternity," with one of the most attractive programs of the year at the Town Hall last night.

Lord Beaverbrook's Evening Standard today called on the British Government to abolish all customs examinations for American tourists in order to show them that "they have an altogether special place in our hearts."

To prove that Ambassador Kennedy's refusal invidiously to pick and choose among the American women who annually clamor for presentation to the Court of St. James has Administration approval, and to share in its democracy and popularity, the State Department issued Mr. Kennedy's letter to Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. as a public document.

In two decisions which have properly attracted wide attention, the National Labor Relations Board has found the Inland Steel Company and the Republic Steel Corporation guilty of having violated the Wagner act during last year's strike in "little steel."

The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today that it had received 423 individual protests against proposed ferry rate increases ordered by the West Shore Railroad between Weehawken, N. J., and New York City.
Thirteen thousand automobile plant workers, idle today during a company-union dispute in which one side charged "slow-down" and the other "speed-up," will go back to jobs as usual tomorrow morning.

Another note was received in Mexico City last week from the United States State Department, it was stated here yesterday. The contents of the document, which was received just before the British note demanding the return of the expropriated properties of British nationals, were not divulged.

Dr. David Mason Little, secretary of Harvard University, who serves virtually as assistant to President Conant, today was appointed new master of Adams House by the Harvard Corporation and confirmed by the board of overseers.

Speeding to a sick call, Dr. Robert Morton Jr., 27-year-old interne, was injured fatally yesterday afternoon when he was thrown from the rear of an ambulance on Bement Avenue near Clove Road, Staten Island. He died in St. Vincent's Hospital, Staten Island, shortly after 6 P. M.

Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson declined yesterday to prevent the city from attempting to collect some $8,000,000 in back taxes owed by the Manhattan Railway Corporation, owner of the elevated lines. Judge Patterson is presiding at Interborough Rapid Transit Company receivership hearings.
Henry Ford and Clara Bryant Ford tonight went to a party commemorating the fiftieth anniversary of their wedding and Mrs. Ford's seventyfirst birthday.

The council of the American Institute of Accountants, at its annual Spring meeting yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, ratified the recommendations of the institute's committee on Federal taxation, urging repeal of the tax on undistributed corporate profits and modification of the capital gains taxes.

The authority of the Secretary of Agriculture to allot the refined sugar quota for Puerto Rico among the individual mills in that Territory was challenged in the District of Columbia Court of Appeals today by Central Igualidad, one of the refineries on the island.

Narrow and mixed price movements ruled the course of domestic corporate bonds in relatively quiet trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The more speculative issues, which had soared sharply on Saturday, tempted profit takers to lighten commitments,

With one exception, favorites advanced easily today through the early rounds of the twentieth annual North and South tennis tournament. This year the tournament is being conducted on a no-expense-account basis. A field of sixty-four, the largest in the event's history, entered and Pinehurst officials predicted the new plan would stimu- the late amateur tennis in the Midsouth.

The search for an elusive blonde woman and her male companion, suspects in the torture-slaying of Mrs. Weston G. Frome and her daughter, Nancy, narrowed down tonight to the vicinity of Laredo on the Mexican border.
The accused chief of the Csar, secret armed military organization, told Surete Nationale inspectors today that one of the organization's members had been sent to the United States "on a mission."

Confirming statements that the authorities desire to aid civil aviation and to increase the number of pilots and later the number of machines in private use, orders were issued today that military air fields should deliver available airplanes of the smaller type not in actual service to the newly created civil clubs for training.

Fifty minutes after he had been suspended for intoxication and led to the third floor of the-East 126th Street station. Patrolman Joel L. Kashuck took a pistol from his locker and shot himself in the right templep He was removed to Harlem Hospital in a critical condition.

Standard practices, covering fundamentals which should apply to any approval of products by testing laboratories and other public endorsement agencies, will be set up by representatives of ten national organizations. These include consumers, producers, distributors and advertisers. Among the points suggested for inclusion are:
The State Department is expecting such a busy year because of troubled international conditions that it has included nearly 100,000 hours of overtime pay in its 1938-39 budget.

Mrs. Adela Goldstein, honorary president of Mizrachi Women's Organization, died on Sunday, it was announced yesterday by the organization. Mrs. Goldstein, whose home was at 1,162 St. John's Place, Brooklyn, was a founder of Mizrachi and well known in the Zionist movement.

Honorary membership in Clio, second oldest cultural club in New York City, was conferred yesterday on Mrs. Ogden Mills Reid, wife of the editor of The New York Herald Tribune, and in absentia, on Mrs. Vincent Astor, at a luncheon in the Hotel Astor celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of the group.

Responding to the week-end recovery in Wall Street, the stock market here was active and cheerful today, and virtually all its sections made fresh headway. Gilt-edged issues were in strong demand and foreign bonds were steady.

Something like 60,000 refugees have poured into this city from Aragon and Western Catalonia because of the advance of the Rebels. Naturally, the majority of them are women and children, because fathers were in the fighting line or had been slain or wounded.

The Hon. Unity Freeman-Mitford, daughter of Lord Redesdale and definitely pro-Hitler, rubbed her shin, bruised by anti-Nazi kicks in Hyde Park Sunday, and declared today "I didn't feel frightened one bit."

Feed steers and yearlings sold lower today when supplies proved too liberal, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Many sales showed declines of fully 50 cents compared with the high time last week. Hogs and lambs were lower also, due to increased supplies as compared with a week ago.

Reminding New Yorkers that daylight-saving time will become effective here at 2 A. M. on.Sunday, April 24, the Merchants Association of New York yesterday made public its annual daylight-saving survey on a nation-wide basis.

The total of bankers acceptance outstanding on March 31 was $292,742,315, a decrease of $14,372,997 in the month and a drop of $103,729,668 in the year, according to the monthly acceptance survey of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, issued yesterday.
Automobile production increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index moved upward to 52.7. The figure was 50.5 for the preceding week, and 85.5 for the week ended April 10, 1937.

The Treasury's offering of approximately $100,000,000 of ninety-one-day bills was sold today at an average price of 99.963, or 0.146 per cent, compared with 99.965, or 0.139 per cent, for the corresponding issue sold last week, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight.

Operations of the General Foods Corporation in the first three months of this year, resulted in net earnings of $3,375,727. This is equivalent to 64 cents each on 5,251,440 shares of common stock outstanding and compares with $4,089,988 or 77 cents a share on the same basis for the March quarter of 1937.

The report of General Public Service Corporation for March 31 shows a net asset value of $6,431,539, equal after $5,000,000 debentures to $63.54 a share on 22,320 preferred shares, comparing with $6,882,408, or $83.55 per share of preferred stock,
Teachers and students contribute to the fifth annual hobby show at Columbia University. It is time that the stern and

The Manufacturers Trust Company, as trustee for the certificate holders, has sold to a client of Kiralfy Koch, attorneys, the sixstory building for eighty-six families at 1,148 Boynton Avenue, the Bronx.

The struggle for control of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad reached the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday, which reserved decision on an application to restrain the Guaranty Trust Company from voting-more than 1,000,000 shares of stock of the

A. Murray Turner, vice president of the Chicago Regional Planning Commission, civic leader and former banker and utilities executive, died today at St. Margaret's Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 18 Glendale Park. Hammond.

Flanked by three attorneys, Roy E. Larsen, publisher of Life Magazine, made arrangements yesterday with District Attorney Samuel J. Foley to have himself arrested today to start a test case in the Bronx, where Mr. Foley has ordered all copies of the magazine confiscated.
The Supreme Court in a unanimous decision ruled today that "systematic and arbitrary exclusion" of Negroes from Kentucky jury lists had denied a fair trial to Joe Hale, a Negro convicted of murder.
The House Appropriations Committee today reported favorably the Legislative Establishment Supply Bill calling for $21,644,431 for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

Dr. George Bird Grinnell, author, naturalist and explorer, who often was called "the father of American conservation," died early yesterday at his home, 285 East Fifteenth Street, in his eighty-ninth year. He had been in failing health for several years.
The South clashed with the North and East today over freight rates which the Southern States contend are "discriminatory" and "strangling" to Southern industry.
Former State Supreme Court Justice Warren W. Duncan died here today at the age of 81. Judge Duncan began law practice here in 1885 after being graduated magna cum laude from the St. Louis Law School.

Concerts of Easter music will be presented in the rotunda of Wanamaker's Fashion Store this week, in keeping with a long tradition. The schedule follows: Today at noon, choir of the First Presbyterian Church; tomorrow noon, Albany All Saints Cathedral Choir;

The report of the Advisory Committee on Education to President Roosevelt recommending new Federal grants to States for educational purposes, to total $855,500,000 by 1944, was termed yesterday by Professor Edmund deS. Brunner of
Harry W. Kouwenhoven, 54 years old, formerly a well-known Brooklyn lawyer, pleaded guilty yesterday before Kings County Judge George W. Martin to a charge of petty larceny.
The White Sox scored their first triumph in four exhibition starts against the Pirates, 7 to 4, today by landing on Ken Heintzelmann in the sixth and seventh innings.

Ninety contented dogs and an equal number of contented cats that have been enjoying life in the Boulevard Gardens development at Woodside, Queens, drew a step nearer yesterday to the loss of their homes as George C. Meyer remained adamant in his ban on pets at the seven-acre model-housing community.

Wearing a sandhog's yellow composition helmet and a slicker, Mayor La Guardia yesterday went down 100 feet to the Manhattan end of the Queens Midtown Tunnel on an inspection tour that included turning the valve that let compressed air into the bulkheads of the boring shields that hold back the waters of the East River so that the tunnel work may go on.

The House of Representatives formally opened today the first session of the Seventeenth Congress, just one week behind schedule. The committee charged with receiving certifications of newly elected Representatives authorized the seating of five from Pinar del Rio Province, thus bringing the total membership up to 108, the number required for opening the lower house.

Strapping Ralph Guldahl, holder of both the United States and Western open championships, yesterday became a full-fledged representative of the metropolitan golf district. Having previously signed a contract to act as professional at the Braidburn Country Club in Madison, N. J.,

A. S. Hewitt's Affirmation, winner of only one race in eleven starts while in heap company, stepped up in 3-year-old allowance circles today and ran off with chief honors in the Lothair Purse, outstanding event on the program.

North American wheat markets made a poor response today to early strength in Liverpool. Prices were lifted fractionally on scattered local and commission house buying, but aside from the purchase of around 1,000,000 bushels of the May on the Board of Trade here,

Eighteen out of thirty-eight deapartments in New York City deapartment stores recorded increases in advertising linage in March, 1938, compared with the same month last year, according to the results of a compilation issued yesterday by Media Records.

Trainloads of Japanese troops and ammunition rolled into North Central Shantung Province today in a race against time as beleaguered Japanese at Yihsien continued to hold out against repeated Chinese attacks.

George S. Stevens has been named president of the Stevens-Eaton Company, operators of ten retail lumber yards, succeeding G. A. Mitchell, who has retired. Mr. Stevens, who is also treasurer of the company, has acquired the financial interest formerly held by White, Gratwick Mitchell, Inc.

The defense attorneys will begin summing up the evidence today in the General Sessions trial of five youths in the shooting and killing of Detective Michael J. Foley last Sept. 22 in the -holdup of a restaurant at 144 Second Avenue.

The right of the Board of Education to maintain separate eligible lists of men and women qualified for appointments as teachers was challenged yesterday in an action brought in Supreme Court by Mrs. Freda P. Lamar of 222 West Tenth Street.

Thomas F. Cummings, president of a wholesale and retail coal company in Newark, died yesterday at St. James Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 53 years old and lived at 295 Frelinghuysen Avenue. Mr. Cummings was a lifelong resident of Newark.

Richard J. Rice of Garden City, L. I., head of the insurance agency of his name at 80 Maiden .Lane, died yesterday of pneumonia in the Nassau County Hospital at Garden City, at the age of 47. He entered the insurance business thirty years ago in Hartford, Conn., with the Aetna Life Insurance Company.

Villa Artemis was the setting this afternoon for a musical and tea with which the Hon. Mrs. Frederick E. Guest entertained a large group, members of the Garden Club of Palm Beach and of the Romany Chorus. Glauco D'Attili, 16-yearold pianist of Rome and New York, was the artist.
The Interstate Commerce Commission today denied a petition by the American Trucking Associations, Inc., for reconsideration of its decision in a test case involving Scott Brothers, Inc., New York.

Plans for the mutualization and reorganization of the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., were approved at a stockholders' meeting yesterday, William B. Falconer, executive vice president, announced last night.
A plea for a British "war debts gesture" to the United States was made today by Sir Geoffrey Clarke, president of the Association of British Chambers of Commerce.

The Czechoslovak Cabinet decided today that the prohibition on all political meetings and demonstations, put into effect at the time of the Austrian Anschluss ballot, should be maintained until May 1.

Chancellor J. O. Wolcott has dismissed the bill of complaint to prevent the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, a Delaware corporation, from voting on a proposed amendment to a management stock-ownership plan of the old New Jersey Bethlehem Steel Corporation at the annual meeting tomorrow.

To meet the situation resulting from the impending closing of the Broad Street Hospital, a special meeting of the Security and Commodity Exchanges committee of the 1938 Beekman Street Hospital Fund will be held today at 40 Wall Street.

Mr. and Mrs. William Fitz Hugh Whitehouse are expected to arrive Thursday on the Ile de France. They will be at Carlton House. State Senator and Mrs. Walter Watson Stokes have come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Woodside Hall, their home in Cooperstown, N. Y.
The Brooklyn College Spring sports program was announced yesterday by Louis R. Oshins, business manager of athletics. Twelve tennis matches and seven track meets are listed.

Claims of former depositors of the Margate Trust Company, Margate City, will be accepted by representatives of the New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance, starting on Wednesday, Commissioner Louis A. Reilly announced today.

The government has decided to prohibit further alien immigration into the North Queensland sugargrowing district, which is worked chiefly by Italians. Minister of the Interior John McEwen said today it was not a discriminatory ban against Italians,

Private John D. Fero, 25, stationed at Fort Wayne here, was shot and killed today when he failed to obey a command to halt after he had escaped from the post hospital. Army officers said the shot was fired by a sentry.

Repeating his triumph of Saturday, Bill Cox today sailed Caryl Sayre and Walbridge Taft's International Class yacht Feather home first in the second of the free-forall series with Bermuda one-design craft. As in the opening race, there were seven competitors, Feather and Herbert Hanan's Elsalan,

The government's proposed measure against Jews continues to be the chief topic of discussion here. However, extreme Right groups reiterate that their satisfaction is tinged with regret because the percentage of Jews permitted to continue in the country's economic life should be "as high as 20 per cent."

Stocks turned reactionary and closed lower after the President's railroad message; turnover, 1,100,000 shares. United States Governmet and corporate bonds generally lower, Central European issues weakened sharply on Hitler's plebiscite victory; transactions, $6,654,000.

James G. Blaine, president of the Greater New York Fund, Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of George MacDonald as an honorary chairman of the campaign's sponsoring committee. Other honorary chairmen are Mayor La Guardia, Alfred E. Smith, John D. Rockefeller Jr., Percy Straus, Thomas S. Lamont and Walter S. Gifford.

Mrs. Edna Cratty of Valley Stream, L.I., was taken into police custody today after picketing the White House executive offices for more than two hours in an effort to talk to President Roosevelt about relief conditions in her home community.

Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, announced today that he would ask Congress to extend beyond. June 30 the corporation's authority to make loans for consolidating banks.

Steel operations for the current week are scheduled at 32.7 per cent of capacity, as compared to 32.6 per cent last week, a gain of 0.1 point or 0.3 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports. A month ago the rate was 32.1 per cent.

Herbert Hoover will speak at a civic dinner to be held at the BellevueStratford Hotel here on May 21 in connection with the formal dedication-of the Benjamin Franklin memorial at the Franklin Institute, it was announced today.

Within one game of winning the Stanley Cup and the hockey championship that goes with it, the Chicago Black Hawks battle the Toronto Maple Leafs tomorrow night in the fourth and perhaps final game of the series.

The board of directors of the Bank for International Settlements was notified officially today of the liquidation of the Austrian National Bank, but stated that no changes were made on the service of international loans to Austria under trusteeship of the B. I. S.

Farmers in Great Britain have received "a strong hint" that the government plans to take over the next wheat harvest and store it "for national emergency" according to The Daily Herald. It said that W. S. Morrison, Minister of Agriculture, already has discussed the project with farmers in East Anglia.

William Henry Jackson, whose "wet plate" photographs of the Old West influenced Congress to create Yellowstone National Park in 1872, refused to be drawn into reminiscences of the "old days" at a celebration of his ninety-fifth birthday, which the Adventures Club held yesterday in the Hotel Woodstock.

Harriet Hassell, whose first novel, "Rachel's Children,' will be published by Harper on April 28, is a special student of Hudson Strode at the University of Alabama. It was Mr. Strode who brought the manuscript to the attention of Harper Bros.

Gerardo Machado, former President of Cuba, who was overthrown in 1933, said today he would make Miami his home and had no plans to return to Havana. He expressed wishes for the republic's economic success.
That close and friendly cooperation now exists between the Spanish Loyalist Government and Catholic churchmen was asserted here today by Jose Bergamin, editor of the Madrid publication Cruz y Raya.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 8: VIC ADMIRAL Tarrant, W. T., commander Scouting Force, in June or July, to duty as Commandant First Naval Dist. and additional duty as Commandant of the Navy Yard, Boston, Mass
Yale today displayed batting power and nearly perfect fielding to beat Springfield College, 7-2, in opening its fifteenth baseball season under Joe Wood's coaching.

The Federal Court of Appeals upheld today a Federal Communications Commission order refusing to issue to the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company, Inc., a license to maintain radio and telegraph service between the United States and Norway.

Lamar (Skeeter) Newsome, shortstop, who was hit on the head by a pitched ball during the Philadelphia Athletics-Portsmouth baseball game Saturday, received a "moderately severe" brain injury, Dr. Robert L. Payne, his physician, said today.

Engineering construction awards for the thirteen-week first quarter of 1938 totaled $658,785,000, a gain of 17 per cent over the $519,062,000 reported for the twelve-week first quarter of 1937, according to Engineering News Record.
East- Br ern Utilities Associates of Boston, Mass.; the National Power and Light Company, the Lehigh Power Securities Corporation and the American Power and Light Company, all of New York,

A mortgage for $275,000 on 10 Cortlandt St held by the Mortgage Commission, as trustee, and the Title Guarantee and Trust Co from the North Block Realty Corporation, Ambrose C. Brady, president, was extended to Dec. 31, 1940, at 4 3/8 per cent, $1,031.25 to be paid off quarterly.

The ambulance drivers of the city's thirty private hospitals that maintain ambulance service reiterated yesterday that they would strike at midnight Friday unless their demands were met, according to E. J. Cohan, secretary-treasurer of the Funeral Chauffeurs Union, 643. This is an A. F.

A third of the 600-foot trolley bridge connecting this community with Ocean City was destroyed by fire this afternoon, cutting off surface-car service between Ocean City and Atlantic City. Parallel spans for motor traffic were not damaged.

Burleigh Grimes discovered today that he has at least one pitcher who can go nine innings and he may have found also that he has another hurler who can start for him when the National League checks are down.

The average shade temperature in March was 43.6 degrees, 5.3 above normal for the month, according to the monthly report of David R. Morris, meteorologist at the observatory in Central Park, which was made public yesterday.

The statement of convention as of March 31, issued yesterday by the Discount Corporation of New York, showed $463,241 of acceptance discounted, contrasted to $5,567,874 on Dec. 31, last. Holdings of United States Government securities were $72,225,402, against $89,319,073 at the end of last year.

Formation of a local organization of importers to be known as the New York Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers was announced here yesterday following a meeting of representatives of thirty local import houses at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria.

Mr. and Mrs. Martin Andrew Lanigan of Riverdale have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Virginia Lanigan, to Lieutenant Arthur William Oberbeck, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Oberbeck of Chicago.
A 19-year-old farmer who killed a deputy sheriff and wounded another critically in a running gun battle through a street filled with murdertrial spectators today was held tonight.

Young Maury Nee, Georgetown University golf captain, shot a four-over-par 74 today to take medal honors in the eighteenth annual Mason and Dixon amateur golf championship. He unfolded a consistent game out and back in 37's while the remainder of the field bucked the vagaries of sodden greens.

Just four more Broadway performances remain for "The Shoemakers' Holiday," and then the Mercury Theatre will send it touring around the Eastern key cities. Its final showings here will take place tonight and on the evenings of April 20, 21 and 22, the road trip being slated to start the week of April 25.
THE PEARLS OF THE CROWN, from a screen play by Sacha Guitry; directed by Mr. Guitry and Christian Jaque; a Serge Sandberg production: distributed by Lenauer International Films, Inc, At the Filmarte.
Forty-six days after Sir Arthur Grenfell Wauchope, the former British High Commissioner, had declared Tel Aviv Harbor open to passenger traffic, the first passenger debarked today.

Among the passengers aboard the North German Lloyd liner Europa, due here tonight, are Lord Rothermere, proprietor of The London Daily Mail, Daily Mirror and Evening News; Alvan T. Fuller, former Governor of Massachusetts; Mr. and Mrs. Henry P. Fletcher, Mrs. H. H. Dieckhoff, wife of the German Ambassador in Washington;
A gift to Radcliffe College of $30,000 from Mr. and Mrs. George R. Agassiz to establish a traveling fellowship in memory of Elizabeth Cary Agassiz, was announced by President Comstock today.

IT doesn't take Larry the Red MacPhail any time at all to come to bat when the Brooklyn Dodgers are mentioned, favorably or otherwise. In witness thereof the following testimony is herewith spread upon the minutes: "Sir: I was quite interested in the pros and cons about Camilli's hitting-as to whether or not he will hit at Ebbets Field and so forth.

The Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. Farber, pastor of the Fourth Presbyterian Church, West End Avenue and Ninety-first Street, was elected moderator of the Presbytery of New York yesterday at the annual meeting of the Presbytery in the Fifth Avenue Church at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

ACKERSON--Anna Valborg Beck, wife of Garret G. Ackerson, mother of Mrs. Charles Conyngham Gifford and Garret G. Ackereon Jr., on Sunday, April 10, 1938. Funeral services at her late residence, 251 Summit Ave., Hackensack, N. J., on Tuesday, April 12. at 2:30 P. M.

A plea that manufacturers guarantee to retailers the truth of any statements they make regarding their products was presented to officials of the Toilet Goods Association at a meeting with the vendor relations committee and associate council of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the latter's office yesterday.

The wisest decision made by the Charter Revision Commission headed by Thomas D. Thacher was that of retaining the Board of Estimate, Raymond V. Ingersoll, Borough President of Brooklyn, told the Women's National Republican Club yesterday in a discussion of the structure of city government.

George C. Mathews, commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission, urged a House Interstate Commerce Committee today to approve legislation by Senator Maloney of Connecticut for "cooperative regulation" of over-the-counter stock transactions.

Without the specific approval of the British Government, which is usual in such cases, the Mexican Government this evening released the text of the British note demanding the return of British-owned oil companies expropriated by Presidential decree on March 18.

Senator Wagner of New York offered today a resolution providing $50,000 for an investigation of national health problems directed toward possible Federal legislation for insurance against sickness for the indigent and for the low-salaried groups unable to lay aside money for illness.

Governor Lehman vetoed today six parkway construction appropriation bills, five of which were of immediate interest to New York City, and in doing so expressed "deep concern" over fiscal problems of the State.

After further examination yesterday at the Kings County Morgue, authorities determined that the body found recently in the Delaware River near Philadelphia was that of Louis Yasskey, Manhattan laundry owner, and gave permission for the burial.
Soviet Russia today sent a protest to Japan against a flight of eleven Japanese military planes over Soviet territory near the troubled frontier separating Siberia and Manchukuo.

Movable furniture instead of the fixed desks now common in classrooms, asphalt tile floors permitting decorative treatment and individual lockers for high school students will be included in all new public schools, it was announced yesterday at the Board of Education.

Richard Whitney spent last night in a cell in the Tombs prison and will be taken in handcuffs to Sing Sing by train today in the company of two extortioners who used to be lawyers, a gunman and a man convicted of rape.

The favorite son of the Sheikh of Araby today took a 22-year-old Arab girl as his bride in his father's palace in ancient Biskra amid all the splendor North Africa could muster for its ranking sheikh.
The observance of Passover will begin at sundown Friday in all the 116 hospitals, orphan asylums and other welfare agencies affiliated with the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities.

In response to the widespread public interest aroused by the sixroom miniature model house built and furnished -by fifteen children at Hudson Guild, 436 West Twentyseventh Street, the committee for Marian Anderson's recital at Carnegie Hall tomorrow night has decided to exhibit the little house in the main lobby of Carnegie Hall that evening.

A Spring card party will be given at the Plaza on April 28 to further the work of the Silver Cross Day Nursery which is located at 249 East 117th Street. Mrs. Daniel Daney Miller heads the bridge committee and Mrs. William Gage Brady will be in charge of a sale of useful and decorative articles and candy which will be held in connection with the card party.

Governor Lehman today signed the Piper bill, reorganizing the administration of the State Insurance Fund, under which employers insure themselves for workmen's compensation, and plating the fund under the control of eight commissioners appointed by the Governor.

Doctors, lawyers, educators, ministers and other specialists in the science of human relationships from fifteen States, are arriving today for the annual Conference on Conservation of Marriage and the Family, which will open tomorrow and continue through Friday at the University of North Carolina.

Details of the new 6-cent air-mail stamp were made public today by Postmaster General Farley. The stamp will be first put on sale May 14 at Dayton, Ohio, the home of the Wright brothers, and St. Petersburg, Fla.,

A survey by a committee of the Second District Dental Society to map out a feasible plan to provide adequate dental service for deserving children is under way, Dr. Charles A. Wilkie, president of the Second District Dental Society,

Consumption of apparel-class wool during February recorded a greater than seasonal advance of 19 per cent over January, the first such month-to-month increase since last August, according to an analysis of operating statistics issued yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers. Consumption for the month was the highest since last October.

The Senate Judiciary Committee authorized Senator King of Utah today to report favorably his joint resolution extending to the adjournment date of the first session of the next Congress the time when the Supreme Court's new rules of procedure for Federal District Courts may become effective.

Loring Pl (11-2879), w s, 417 ft s of Burnside Ave. 30x110: Joseph P. Reynolds. referee, to Mortgage Commission Realty Corp, trustee, 346 Broadway. Harper Ave (17-4946). n e cor of Connor St, 35x95; Arthur J. Martin to Carl F. Daum, 333 Mosholu Pkwy N. Amundson Ave (17-4989). e s 700 ft s of Edenwald Ave. 37x100; Bernard Masin to Frieda Kraemer, 4,014 Amundson Ave.

The eight civic associations working with the Mayor's Committee on City Planning to effect a rezoning of a large part of Manhattan below Thirty-fourth Street are expected to make a number of recommendations for changes in the proposed zoning map drafted by the committee.

Dr. Edith Summerskill, victorious Labor member for West Fulham, took her seat in the House of Commons today. For ten minutes she stood Just beyond the bar of the House with Sir Charles Edwards, chief Labor whip on her right and Sir Stafford

The number of deaths from traffic accidents during last week and the week-end declined, compared to the corresponding periods of last year, it was announced last night by the Police Department's safety bureau. There were eleven fewer fatalities during last week.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Warren Danforth of this place of the engagement of Mrs. Danforth's sister, Mrs. Emma Parmelee Townsend, also of East Orange, to Frank Wilmer Lawrence of Greenwich, Conn.

Those of you who plan to get up to Massachusetts for the opening of the trout season this Friday will find well-stoeked streams in every county in the State, according to word received yesterday from the State Division of Fisheries and Game.

If one stands between the central pillars of the Lincoln Memorial in Washington and looks eastward he sees the admirable pillar of the Washington Monument exactly bisecting the Capitol. A line drawn across this vista, through the monument, would intersect the White House on the north and run into the Tidal Basin on the south.

President Roosevelt proposed in a message to Congress today that legislation be enacted immediately to help the railroads by preventing "serious financial and operating difficulties between now and the reconvening of the next Congress," but left it entirely up to Congress to decide what should be done.
