Aided by twenty-three graduate fellowships, fifteen of which are provided by a general grant of the Automotive Safety Foundation and eight by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., Yale has established, effective in July, a bureau for street traffic research.

Finishing strongly after a slow start, Bobby Pacho, 145 1/2. Sacramento, Calif., earned an eight-round draw with Pete De Ruzzo, 143 3/4, Mamaroneck, in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace before a crowd of 2,500 last night.

Dr. Giuseppe Antonio Borgese, Professor of Romance Languages and Literature at the University of Chicago, will be among the first of the exiles from fascist Europe to become an American citizen. He will receive his final papers before Federal Judge John P. Barnes tomorrow morning.

The Communications Commission announced today that its investigation of chain broadcasting and charges of monopoly in the broadcasting industry would be made by a four-man committee headed by Chairman Frank McNinch.

Wilson Reynolds, actor and stage director for forty years, died last night in the Ossining Hospital after undergoing an abdominal operation after an illness of two years. Mr. Reynolds, whose age was 68, resided here.
Colonel Charles Nichols Swift of this place, Civil War veteran, died yesterday at Irvington Ceneral Hospital after a week's illness. His age was 95.

The Real Estate Owners Association of the Twelfth and Nineteenth Wards will meet tomorrow evening at the New York Turn Hall, Lexington Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street Arthur Holden, architect, will be the speaker.

Lefty Vernon Gomez pitched seven innings today for the first time this year and the Yanks scored their second victory over the Atlanta Crackers, 9 to 4, to stretch their winning streak to four straight games, a new high for their Spring campaign.
Liquidation of the Pierce-Arrow Motor Corporation was ordered by Federal Judge John Knight here today. The order followed presentation of an insolvency statement by trustees.

An independent committee of stockholders of the Consolidated Copper Mines has sent a letter. to stockholders- of the company attacking the management and requesting proxies in favor of the committee to be voted against the management at the annual meeting on May 3,

A series of applications filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by subsidiaries of the Assciated Gas and Electric Company, announced by the commission today, were believed to have possible si significance as moves to make the structure of the top comparly conform to requirements of the Holding Company Act.

Morris G. Manker of East Chicago, Ind., scheduled to graduate from Harvard College in June, must serve fourteen days in Jail imrnediately thereafter, Judge Arthur P. Stone ruled today in East Cambridge District Court.

Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange held yesterday within a narrow range and ended with gains of one to two points. Reports that business in wholesale cotton goods quarters reached the largest volume in several months encouraged support and the May was slightly above the previous closing figures throughout the session.

Apparently deluged by inquiries from shareholders pertaining to its recent announcement of proposals to make certain changes in its corporate structure, the Cities Service Company sent yesterday an additional letter to stockholders, explaining the situation in a hitherto unrevealed manner and urging that proxies be returned "as soon as possible"
Bill Rand's team of Chicago, hitting on two of its five cylinders, recorded a 3,014 game in the American Bowling Congress tonight, but missed landing among the first ten in the standings by six pins.

The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today an application of the Colorado Southern Railway for a loan of $525,500 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and found the carrier not in need of judicial reorganization.

Tom M. Girdler testified in the Common Pleas Court here late today that in June, 1930, as chairman of the Republic Steel of New Jersey, he appointed a committee to investigate a $1,500,000 loan to Republic of Delaware, a-subsidiary.

Dr. Benjamin White, noted biologist, who died at Southern Pines, N. C., on March 28, at the age of 59, bequeathed to his widow, Mrs. Genoa Solari White of 646 Park Avenue, his household, personal effects and the life income from his residuary estate.

Throwing caution to the four winds, the Giants hit four stirring home runs today as they resumed hostilities with the Indians in this quaint Kentucky town, and 3,500 fellow-townsmen of the distinguished Irvin S. Cobb applauded vociferously, for these blows did look like the payoff.

The 100th anniversary of the birth on April 12, 1838, of Dr. John Shaw Billings, famous Civil War surgeon and the first director of the New York Public Library, will be commemorated beginning today by a special exhibition at the library, : Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

Acquisition by the Louisiana Arkansas Railway Company of control of the Louisiana, Arkansas Texas Railway Company by acceptance of the latter's capital stock, and a merger of the properties into the Louisiana

B. Charney Vladeck, American Labor party leader in the City Council, announced yesterday that he would introduce today an amendment to the administrative housing code to provide for housing subsidies to be administered by the Municipal Housing Authority in construction of low-cost housing.

Mrs. Frederick Steinway gave a dinner last night in La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis for Mr. and Mrs. Anthony V. Barber, Mr. and Mrs. Peter C. Wright Clark, Mr. and Mrs. Francis Low, Mr. and Mrs. N. Lawrence Herrick, Mr. and Mrs. Irving Bunnell, Miss Jean Schwartz, Henri Deering and Thomas Barber.

An amendment to the State Constitution seeking an economical and effective program for the handling of prison-made goods will be proposed by .the City Club of New York, it was revealed yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Committee on Prisons and Prison Labor.

Francisco Vincenty, one of the pioneers of the American school system in Puerto Rico, was buried this afternoon with all representatives of educational activities paying honors. There was an address by Chancellor Juan B. Soto of the university.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The majority of people, excepting politicians, have a fair understanding of the fact that purchasing power derives from the production of goods and the performing of services.

The Metropolitan A. A. U. boxing championships opened at the New York A. C. last night with ninetyseven listed in the open division and fifty-one in the new-junior competition. The junior class, recognized for the first time this year, provides for youngsters between 16 and 18 years of age, previously barred under A. A. U. rules.

Bronx Radcliffe Ave, n e cor Duncan St, six 1story brick dwellings, 21x45; J. J. De Pasquale, 3.550 White Plains Ave, owner; A. C. Le Fante, architect; cost, $24,000. E 235 St, 679: 1-story concrete block garage, 34x18; Walfrey Holding Corp, 4,170 De Reimer Ave, owner; H. Nordhelm, architect; cost, $1,000.

Fifty-two awards at St. John's University were announced yester-. day by the athletic association. Varsity basketball men received major letters, minor insignia going to two assistant managers, the cheerleaders, and ten members of the soccer team.

Morris Maxon, 67 years old, of 200 Dyckman Street, was injured fatally yesterday when an unidentified person accosted him in the rear of his haberdashery store at 178 Dyckman Street, and presumably beat him over the head with the butt of a pistol.

Complying with the unanimous request of the members of the lower house of the Legislature Governor Blanton Winship has requested the resignation of Miss Emma Gelpi, the island's only woman district court clerk, from her post in the Mayaguez Court.

Creation of a subsidized government export monopoly to recapture Central and South American markets from the dictatorships and expansion of production of American goods to mitigate the- relief problem were advocated last night by Mayor La Guardia in a nation-wide broadcast as an individual contribution to a program for permanent recovery.

Stagehand, current Winter book favorite to win the Kentucky Derby, arrived in Louisville today ten hours late because he missed a train connection at Kansas City. With him, of course, was Trainer Earl Sande, annoyed at the railroad for going off without him and anxious for his horses.

The Administration's Naval Construction Bill, pending before the Senate Naval Affairs Committee, will be reported to the Senate before the end of this week. It is expected to provide for construction authorizations totaling $1,260,000,000, or about $140,000,000 in excess of the total carried in the bill as passed by the House.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 9: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Stelnkolk, F. B., Veterinary Corps. two months' leave, June 1, with permission to visit foreign countries. Stratemeyer. G. E., Air Corps, Hamilton Field, Calif., to Army War College, Fort Humphreys, D. C., as student in the 1938-39 course;

The State Juvenile Delinquency Commission reported today that 71 per cent of the men and boys in New Jersey penal institutions admitted they had associated with gangs of mischiefmaking youngsters when children and had taken part in breaking the law.

Paine Hall School, founded in 1849, will move. Friday from its present address at 147 West Fortysecond Street to new and larger quarters in the Greeley Square Building, 101 West Thirty-first Street, where it has leased approximately 10,000 square feet of space, Chauncey R. Porter, director, announced yesterday.
Ten forest fires, which spread over an area of 400 acres, raged in scattered points throughout New Jersey today, Acting State Forest Fire Warden Leroy S. Fales reported here tonight.
The board of trustees of the Lalor Foundation announced today the selection of winners of five awards from the Lalor Foundation for research in chemistry for the academic year 1938-39.

Two "jungle yachts," equipped with all the comforts and conveniences of a modern apartment, were shown in a preview yesterday at the showrooms of the International Harvester Company at Eleventh Avenue and Forty-second Street.
The World's Fair will provide a building to house an exhibition of contemporary American art, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair corporation.

The beef market was steady to higher in local markets yesterday. Lamb sold unevenly, plainer grades light weights strong to higher, others steady to weak. Fresh pork cuts also sold unevenly. The veal market was mostly steady. Trading was fair to slow.' Early trading In kosher meats was fairly active and indicated all classes to be stronger, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Special cables are now being installed to make television available to three radio stations in Southwestern France, according to a consular report from Paris made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Student actors of the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre will appear tonight at the Heckscher Theatre in a revival of "The Constant Nymph," the Margaret Kennedy-Basil Dean play produced here in 1926-27.

Sigrid Gurie, Samuel Goldwyn's Brooklyn-born Norwegian, was borrowed today by Walter Wanger for the feminine lead opposite Charles Boyer in "Algiers." "Algiers" will serve as the initial American vehicle for Hedy LaMarr, late of "Ecstasy."

Clutching her six-months-old baby daughter, Alice, in her arms, Mrs. Stella Resti, 20 years old, ran half a mile from 31 Allen Street to Gouverneur Hospital yesterday morning, only to learn on her arrival that her child was dead.

The passenger and freight ship men Virginia of the Panama Pacific Line completed her career in the intercoastal trade upon her arrival in port yesterday morning. She was officially withdrawn when she tied up at Pier 60, Hudson River, in line with the company's recent announcement of plans to discontinue the service.
The visitor to Rutgers this Spring has the feeling that the famous song of the Scarlet, "On the Banks of the Old Raritan," may have added meaning before school is out for another year.

Federal Judge Frederick Bryant, in awards announced today, slashed more than half from the $248,532 in fees asked for services in connection with the reorganization of the Rochester. lines of the New York State Railways.
The League of Nations published today a communication from the British Government asking that the question of Ethiopia be included in the agenda of the Council's next ordinary session opening May 9.

Wholesale distributors can maintain their place in industry only if they eliminate unnecessary costs and inefficient methods and make use of modern principles and practices of distribution, it was predicted last night by Guede Coghlan, distribution engineer, in a talk before the Society for the Advancement of Management at 31 East Thirty-ninth Street.

Premeir Maurice Duplessis announced today to the Public Accounts Committee, which has been investigating alleged scandals of the former Taschereau government in Quebec, that Charles Lanctot, assistant attorney general of the province for fifty-one years under Premier Alexander Taschereau, was under arrest at his home here.
Twenty-sixth annual congress, National Society Daughters of the Union, Hotel McAlpin, 10:30 A. M. Session to continue tomorrow.

THE "farewell" books are nearly as common as pigeons in the park. It has been farewell this and farewell that since at least 1929, when Ernest Hemingway came out with his little Italian romance. Poesy, Freedom, India, Youth, Women, Fifth Avenue, Revolution, Poverty, Argument, Passion-these and heaven only knows what else have been bid adieu by writers of varying talents.
A willingness to take up arms if the continental United States were invaded was indicated by 337 students through a peace poll under the auspices of The Campus, student newspaper at City College.

It was charged today by Senator Robert C. Hendrickson of Gloucester County, floor leader of the Republican majority in the upper house of the Legislature, that the $25,000,000 road project to which the Works Progress Administration allotted $20,000,000 for wages of men taken

Stanley P. Rostkowski, organist of St. Stephen's Church since 1905 and director of the church choir for thirty-one years, died here this morning of a heart attack. Born in Poland fifty-four years ago, Mr. Rostkowski studied music in Warsaw. He became associated with the church soon after his arrival in this country.
Evidently in fine health, Mayor Frank Hague spent several hours in his office in City Hall today after his return from Florida, where he had been vacationing since late in January.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended April 7 was 245 compared with 271 in the week preceding and 190 in the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Two men marooned in a rowboat on a marshy island in Jamaica Bay were rescued yesterday along with two policemen who had gone to their assistance after all four were trapped by choppy water and disabled craft.

A small band of sentimentalists seeking mementos of the late Sir James Matthew Barrie joined with the usual crowd of dealers at a further sale of the beloved Scotsman's manuscripts held at Sotheby's today.

Expenditures for recovery and relief which have been either authorized by Congress or are under consideration by the Administration were swelled to a total of more than $5,000,000,000 today in conferences held by President Roosevelt with Congressional and relief spokesmen on plans for breaking the back of the recession in the 1939 fiscal year.

Mrs. Amos Pinchot of New York said tonight that her son, Gifford Pinchot 3d of Los Angeles, and Miss Virginia Walker of Boston, a screen actress, were resting at her home after suffering minor bruises in an automobile accident near Gilda Bend, Ariz., Saturday.

With Major Frank Wandle, Yale's trainer who suffered a stroke in midseason last Fall, again present and directing the conditioning of the squad, Yale today opened its Spring football practice with sixty candidates.

For the second year in succession, Pampero, a bay gelding owned by John Hay Whitney of Manhasset, L. I., and shown by Barney Balding of New York, captured the best-in-show award at the Aiken polo pony exhibition today.

Directors of the Globe and Republic Insurance Company declared a quarterly dividend of 12 1/2 cents a share. Last year the company paid 20 cents and in the three following quarters a 5-cent extra disbursement was included with the 20-cent quarterly payments.

By being placed first today in the $1,000 free-for-all stake, Homewood Stardust, owned by the Homewood Kennels of H. M. Curry of Pittsburgh and handled by Fred E. Bevan of High Point, N. C., won $500 in cash and will have her name engraved on the famous River Lawn Trophy.
Thirty-one children were killed last night when they were trampled in a stampede of 2,500 spectators rushing in panic from an overcrowded motion picture theatre.
Mr. and Mrs. Henry Grant Meem of this city today announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Carroll Meem, to Edward Beale McLean Jr., son of Mrs. Ed- F ward Beale McLean.

Favorable responses have been received from Cuba and Norway regarding the formation of an international committee to facilitate the emigration of European political refugees, the State Department announced today.

Maynard Dodd, who retired last Fall as general superintendent of the Commercial Pacific Cable Company and assistant vice president of the Commercial Cable Company, died Sunday in the York Hospital of pernicious anemia.

The Royal and Ancient Golf Club, often accused of favoring "country club" talent, today, named an Irish bartender,,a St. Andrews cigar store clerk and a Welsh soldier among the nine selected to complete the British Walker Cup squad.

The text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress on the railroad problem was as follows: To the Congress of the United States: During the past month I have consulted with a large number of individuals on the increasingly difficult problem of our railroad transportation.
One issue in Washington is whether the memorial to Thomas Jefferson shall be classical with a dome or classical without a dome.
Notice was given to the London Register Office today of the impending marriage of Muriel Oxford, 23 years old, who was "Miss Great Britain" of 1936, to Gilbert A. Evans, 28, a London stock broker.

A bequest of $50,000 to Union Free School 1 of Le Roy, N. Y., for the maintenance and operation of the school library, was disclosed yesterday when the will of Mrs. Eleanore W. Vietor was filed in Surrogate's Court. Her estate was valued at upwardrd of $100.000."

Commander Charles E. Rosendahl urged before the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs today the authorization of at least two large lighter-than-air airships and the construction, mainly for experimental purposes, of a smaller metalclad ship of the same type.

The Court of Appeals upheld today in a five-toone decision the conviction of Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania on charges of compulsory prostitution and ruled that the sentence of thirty to fifty years which he is serving in Clinton Prison at Dannemora was legally imposed.

The Puget Sound Power and Light Company, Seattle, a subsidiary in the registered holding company system of the Engineers Public Service Company, Inc., has filed a declaration under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 covering

James Motto, who testified that he was a bookmaker and gambler from 1919 to 1935, asked a mixed jury in Supreme Court yesterday for a judgment for $10,000 against the National City Bank. The suit is based on a deposit Motto says he made in one of the bank's night depositories but which the bank savs it never received.

Broadening of the scope of the General Motors dealer council plan was announced yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the corporation, who, in a special message to dealers, revealed that under the new arrangement every dealer may make suggestions by letter to the dealer council.

Democracy, on trial today in many parts of the world, is safe in this country only as long as the principles of free education are maintained, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, warns in the thirty-ninth annual report of the New York City school system released yesterday.

Many colonists entertained with parties in their villas today. Mr. and Mrs. Wolcott Blair gave a dinner at their residence. At Villa Del Sarmiento, Mr. and Mrs. Jay O'Brien were hosts at a dinner, and Mr. and Mrs. Lumen O. Peck entertained with a dinner at their villa.

Mustang, a six-inch snapper from the plains of the Great Southwest, ruled the intercollegiate turtle racing world today. Carrying the red and blue colors of Southern Methodist University, Mustang won the first college turtle derby early today by showing his heels to eleven contestants.

The Department of Markets- has started a crusade against false and misleading advertising by retailers throughout the city, it was revealed yesterday by Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. after the conviction of five defendants in Special Sessions on Monday. The immediate drive is against cleaners and dyers.

Jerome C. Brady and Sartell Prentice, partners in the brokerage firm of Prentice Brady of 25 Wall Street, refused to testify yesterday in Attorney General Bennett's investigation of the concern's affairs.

Philippine military officials today launched an investigation into reports that twenty-two unidentified destroyers had been sighted manoeuvering in Davao Gulf off Mindanao Island where a large Japanese colony resides.
Acceptance of the resignation of Joseph Stubbs as Harvard varsity hockey coach was announced today by the committee on the regulation of athletic sports.

Mrs. Ruth Harkness, who feels "more at home on the China-Tibet border than in New York," Will leave in six weeks for Szechuan Province, China, to hunt a male giant panda cub, she said yesterday at the weekly round-table luncheon of the Town Hall Club.

The government is taking severe measures against the distribution of anti-government pamphlets by the Nazi Sickle Cross and Arrow Cross parties. These pamphlets not only attack the Jews and Leftist elements but Premier Koloman Daranyi himself.

Two thousand New York high school students and a group of Latin-American diplomats filled Columbia University's McMillin Academic Theatre yesterday afternoon to celebrate the eighth annual Pan-American Day.
The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the first two months of this year, issued yesterday, showed a net loss of $1,243,217 after operating expenses, taxes and other charges.

Mrs. Anna Bradt Sgiers, active worker for Catholic hospitals and charitable organizations, died in Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, Monday evening. She was born in Brooklyn and had lived for the last thirty years in Richmond Hill at 85-00 107th Street.

Rumors than the Dionne quintuplets would be exhibited at the World's Fair were spiked, emphatically and permanently, yesterday morning by Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe, their physician and most active guardian.

Charles M. Schwab, 76-year-old steel leader, successfully defended himself this afternoon at the annual meeting of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, defying minority stockholder hecklers, who demanded that he serve as chairman of the board either without pay or with a 10 per cent reduction in salary if the common stockholders receive no dividend in the next quarter.

Boats were loading over 800,000 bushels of corn at elevators here today and are expected to clear for Eastern ports, mainly Canadian, before the end of the week. There also were 650,000 bushels of wheat loaded out of elevators for Eastern shipment, but part of this grain may not clear until next week.
Fordham University conquered Manhattan College, 6 to 2, in the opening tennis match for both teams on the Maroon courts in the Bronx yesterday. The summaries:

Maury Nee of Georgetown, medalist in the qualifying play of the Mason and Dixon amateur golf tournament, fell today in the first round before the steady game of Charles Sheldon of New York, 4 and 3. Sheldon, playing out the bye holes, shot a par 70 over the 6,300-yard layout.

Dr. William Rankin Ward, medical director of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company here and an elder of the Elizabeth Avenue Presbyterian Church, was unanimously elected today moderator of the Newark Presbytery at the annual meeting in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church here.

The first questioning of New York Stock Exchange members by the Securities and Exchange Commission here today revealed twenty persons, so far, who knew that Richard Whitney, who began serving a five-to-ten-year sentence for grand larceny today, was borrowing in terms ordinarily recognized as "distress" almost two years before his collapse.

George Baskin gained the final in the New York State A. A. U. onewall handball singles championship by vanquishing William Lauro, unattached, last night at Union Temple. The winner, representing the Trinity Club, won in three games, 21-12, 10-21, 21-4.

A ten and one-half acre tract of land near the estate of Mrs. W. G. Fisher at Orient Point, L. I., has been purchased by Alfred N. Luce from a client of Butler Baldwin, Inc., broker in the deal. The property has a frontage of 475 feet on Long Island Sound.

A controversy between officials of the Philadelphia Orchestra and the National Broadcasting Company over three musicians who left the Philadelphia Orchestra to join the NBC ensemble was revealed yesterday with charges from Philadelphia that NBC was attempting to "raid" established orchestras for players.

Oscar Schachter of Brooklyn, second-year student in the Columbia University Law School, has been elected editor-in-chief of The Columbia Law Review, monthly publication of the school, it was announced yesterday. Bertram Diamond of the Bronx is the new business manager.

Mike Blazek of Conneaut, Ohio, rolled a perfect 300 game in the American Bowling Congress today. He became the fifth man in the thirtyeight-year history of bowling's world series to pitch twelve consecutive strikes.

Formation of the International Advertising Association "to coordinate and foster the practice of international advertising in all its phases," and election of Shirley F. Woodell, advertising manager of Packard Motors Export Corpora- t tion, as president of the new or- e ganization, was announced yesterday.

South African wine producers are planning another attempt to establish their products in the American market, Victor A. Bennett, acting manager of the African Associated Newspapers, Ltd., told members of the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc., at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday. Producers in South Africa,

With intimations from Representative Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, that Senate amendments will be thoroughly scrutinized before they are accepted or rejected by House conferees, the Tax Revision Bill was sent to conference today by the lower chamber.

Earnings of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation for the first quarter of this year will be substantially lower than those in the corresponding period of last year, Alfred Schoellkopf, president, told shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday.
In a report filed with Congress today army engineers rejected proposals for improving Rondout Creek in New York from Island Dock to Eddyville. Major Gen. Julian L.

The existing State Mortgage Law was characterized as "archaic" and "cumbersome" at a conference yesterday of more than 150 representatives of thirty-five civic, taxpayers and real estate owners associations at the Chamber of Commerce Building, 65 Liberty Street.

Miss Jane Andrews, daughter of Frank L. Andrews of this city and of the late Mrs. Margaret Colburn Andrews, has chosen April 29 as the date for her marriage to William A. Kirmse, son of Mrs. George Kirmse of Los Angeles. The wedding will take place in the Church of the Transfiguration.

The concert given by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall, was principally the triumph of a singer. For the soloist was John Charles Thomas, and the lion's share of attention and plaudits went to him.

Mayor La Guardia of New York City said today after a brief conference with Nathan Straus, administrator of the United States Housing Authority, that contracts for the city's $30,000,000 slum-clearance program would be ready "within two or three days."

The government today issued the first part of a press law which includes a prohibition of foreign financial support for any newspaper. Another provision is that publishers must report every three months their average circulation.

Chalmers Wood and H. Duncan Wood plan to retire from Johnson Wood on April 30, the New York Stock Exchange has been informed. The Stock Exchange has been notified by the General Tire and Rubber Company that its employes have been granted options to buy 1,200 shares of common stock at $10 a share, the options expiring at various dates in 1940.

According to the newspaper Esti Kurir, Archduke Albrecht of Habsburg intends to wed a young school teacher, Kathlin Bocskai, whom the 42-year-old pretender to the Hungarian crown met during a hunting party near Debrecsin.

St. John's University of Brooklyn pounded Dawson Farber and Bob Riddle for twelve hits and overwhelmed the Princeton baseball team, 10-2, on University Field today for its third straight victory. Seven errors afield counted heavily in the Nassau defeat, the second in five starts.

Bonds were lower yesterday in sharply curtailed trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Further study of the President's message on the railroad situation and the growing belief that Congress is likely to postpone indefinitely any action to relieve the problem served as a depressing influence

Thomas Mann, exiled German novelist, has received the Cardinal Newman award for 1937. This award is conferred annually on an individual who has made an outstanding contribution to the enrichment of human life in literature, art, science or humanitarianism.

Grey Nurse, a stablemate of C. S. Howard's Seabiscuit, annexed the four-furlong $1,500-added Golden Poppy Handicap for juveniles at Bay Meadows today, defeating Montecito by three lengths. Flossmoor was third.

The "natural science evenings" at the American Museum of Natural History were continued last night with a dinner and meeting, at which Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Hilles were hosts. After dinner, Dr. Robert C. Murphy, associate curator of oceanic birds, gave a talk on his recent Colombian Coastal Expedition.

Richard V. Rhode. of Langley.Field, Va., and engineer with the National Advisory Committtee on Aeronautics, became the tenth recipient of the Wright Brothers Medal at a meeting here tonight of the Metropolitan Section, Society of Automotive Engineers.

The Senate Banking and Currency Committee reported favorably today the Trust Indenture Bill of 1938 which requires that trust indentures filed as part of a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 conform to prescribed standards.

Bill Cox, one of the ablest of the Long Island Sound skippers, sailed Caryl Sayre and Walbridge Taft's International Class yacht Feather to a clean sweep today in the freefor-all series with one-design craft of the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club. Two races, the third and fourth of the series, were held and Cox brought Feather home first in both of them, just as he had in the first two.

The shipyards of the world, exclusive of Russia, were engaged in the construction of 2,894,696 tons of commercial ships on April 1, according to the quarterly report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, which was published yesterday.

Tilghman G. Pitts, for twenty-five years a member of the board of managers of the Bachelors Cotillon and twenty years its secretary, has resigned because he says the duties of secretary are too heavy and that a younger man should take it over.

President Roosevelt indicated today that people who get hit by whisky bottles thrown by CCC enrollees off duty may not collect damages from the government. He vetoed a bill to award $39.50 to Peter Sietsma of Monon, Ind., for the cost of a new windshield and medical attention necessitated by such an experience.
New York State's Court of Appeals decided unanimously today that Richard P. Limburg, nephew of Governor Lehman, is the duly elected Supervisor of the town of North Castle, Westchester County.

A brief ket. containing arguments for unification of the railroads of the United States into a single system was sent today by the White House to Senator Wheeler, chairman of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee.

Justin Callahan, '39, of this city, has been chosen captain of Columbia University's swimming team for next year, it was announced yesterday by Reynolds Benson, athletics manager. The consistent performance of the new leader has been a feature of the Blue and White team's work the past season.

The city was asked yesterday by the Wholesale Tobacco Distributors of New York City to set up an agency which would place the new stamps on packages of cigarettes, which were voted recently to help raise funds for unemployment relief.

Navy and Princeton crews will race over "smooth water" Saturday, Naval Academy officials decided today, even though several thousand spectators may be late to supper. Commander Andrew C. McFall, graduate manager of athletics at the academy, announced the starting time would be set back an hour and a half, with the first gun at 4:30 P. M. instead of 3 P. M.,as in past years.
The crews and yachts that will represent the United States in the six-meter competition with Bermuda starting next Wedesday sailed yesterday aboard the Furness Bermuda liner Queen of Bermuda.

In the auditorium of Henry Ford's reproduction of Independence Hall at Greenfield Village, the automobile manufacturer and-his wife received evidence tonight of the respect of their neighbors and of friends throughout the nation. Mr. Ford stood beside Mrs. Ford as 700 invited guests assembled to celebrate their golden wedding anniversary.

The Hon. W. J. Howard Trott and Mrs. Trott of Quickswood, Pembroke, Bermuda, have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Hutchings Trott, to Alan Neergaard Pope, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Foster Pope of Bronxville, N. Y.
General Wilhelm Zehner, who was Secretary of State for War and virtual War Minister in the Schuschnigg government, was reported to have committed suicide while in "protective custody."

Yoshino Shinji, Minister of Commerce, told the annual meeting of the Japanese Federation of Industry today that State control in the industries of national defense now is to be regarded as a permanent condition in Japanese industry.

Princeton's fleet, under new direction, heads this week toward the opening of a new season. Friday morning the varsity and junior varsity crews go south to Annapolis and race there Saturday against the Navy.

With fresh support promised from a number of sources, plans for participation in the merchandising campaign for Father's Day on June 19 were rounded out yesterday at a meeting attended by nearly 100 representatives of retailers and the manufacturing industries at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The House began consideration today of the 1939 Agricultural Department supply Bill, carrying $796,785,524 in appropriationss and reappropriaions, a decrease of $72,589,049 from he current fiscal year and $10,431,98 below budget estimates.

Chiefs of thirty-nine unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization, opening a two-day meeting here today, took two important steps toward broadening of the responsibility for the guidance of the organization.

Annual Spring meeting, Eastern Section, American Congress of Physical Therapy, Mount Sinai Hospital, 100th Street and Fifth Avenue, 10 A. M. Afternoon and evening sessions. Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Inside Nazi Germany," Julien Bryan.

Five hold-up men took possession of a branch office of the Prudential Insurance Company of America at 60 Graham Street in the Wil1iamsburg section of Brooklyn early yesterday morning and leisurely robbed forty-three collectors and other employes of the insurance company as they reported for work.

Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, national campaign chairman of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, appealed yesterday to all communities in the United States to raise funds for "tens of thousands of homeless, stateless and destitute" in Austria.

The Long Island Society of Real Estate Appraisers has been incorporated with George W. Gillies as president; W. H. Guardenier, vice president; Arthur M. Fuller, treasurer; R. G. Bedient, secretary, and E. Robert Willcox, counsel.

A protest against "unwise and unjustifiable burdens" upon the railroads and an appeal for fair rates for passenger and freight service and fair returns for investors were voiced today by A. J. County, vice president in charge of finance and corporate relations of the Pennsylvania Railroad.
The State Superintendent of Insurance has sold, to a group headed by William J. Waite, the Realty Mortgagee Servicing Corporation, one of the largest enterprises of its type in the State.
Mrs. T. Salisbury Woolsey announced today the engagement of her daughter, Miss Sara Pickett Woolsey, to Kenneth MacLean, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Charles Chalmers MacLean of Batavia, N. Y.

In spite of the gloomy picture of the condition of the Brooklyn Central Museum and the Brooklyn Children's Museum painted by-Philip N. Youtz, director of both, in his annual report to the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, Park Commissioner Robert Moses asserted yesterday that the two institutions had fared "very well" in obtaining maintenance and improvement funds.

Mayor La Guardia's plan for subsidizing exports to Central and South America was opposed today by Secretary Hull. Mr. Hull indicated that he thought it did not fit in with his "liberal" trade program.
The question whether 100 babies at the Infants Home of Brooklyn, 1,356 Fifty-sixth Street, are lulled to sleep by swing music was left unanswered in Flatbush Court yesterday.
The report of Adams Express Company for March 31 shows an asset value of $8.54 a share on 1,500,000 common shares, compared to $11.61 a share on Dec. 31,

Major Gen. Andrew Moses, until recently in command of the Havaiian Deapartment, will retire at the statutory age of 64 on June 30, the War Department announced today. He is now on his way to New York, where he will be on duty until his retirement.

The mother of Jackie Coogan said today that she was "deeply hurt" by his action in filing suit against her and his stepfather, Arthur L. Bernstein, demanding that they turn over $4,000,000 he said he made while a child film star.
Governor Lehman signed the Desmond bill today requiring applicants for a marriage license to take a seriological blood test for syphilis within twenty days prior to taking out license.

Central Pk West, n cor 92d St, 75.8 1/2x125; Howland Estates, Inc. to Chester Lane, Inc. 371 E 149th St, mtg $831,275, 2d mtg $46,000 ($48). Madison St. 327, 21x63.8; Samuel Goldberg to Minnie Holland, 1,711 Fillmore St, Bronx, who holds a mtg for $6,000. Ridge St, 112-114, 42.6x100; Frederick J. Groehl to Mortgage Commission Trustee Corp. consid. $1,000, foreclosure.

No better news could possibly come from Washington than the reports of rising opposition in Congress against any new plan for the Government to "spend its way out of the depression." To plunge this country farther into debt, in another rash gamble with the national credit, would be a policy of bankrupt statesmanship.

Leaders of Republic Steel Corporation independent unions announced tonight that they would fight the National Labor Relations Board's order for their abolishment and would seek to be recognized as exclusive collective bargaining agents.

Brooklyn E 34th St, 796-98; two 1-family brick homes and garages, 20x43; Silvameer Homes, 1.614 E 34th St, owner; 0. B. Almgren, architect; cost. $8,400. 84th St, 1,242; 2-family brick home and garage, 18x57; Ridgelawn Homes, Inc. 640 86th St, owner; Slee Bryson, architect; cost, $6,500.

The possibility of a "three-for-a- ti quarter" basis for cigars under the fair-trade contracts, instead of the L three-for-27-cents level which has been set up, is being considered by a committee of nine, comprised of an equal number of manufacturers, jobbers and retailers, it was learned here yesterday.

Miss Janet Fried, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emil Fried, will be married to Leo L. Haskell of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Haskell of Norfolk, Va., tomorrow afternoon at the home of her parents, 225 West Seventy-first Street.

John Irving Dillon, a political writer and commentator who for many years was editor and publisher of The Philadelphia Sunday Dispatch, died in Methodist Episcopal Hospital here last night. He was 67 years old.

Illiterates no longer may make their mark for a signature to notarial documents, according to a law now in force here, and all island notaries are taking instruction in the taking of fingerprints, which hereafter will be required.

Following the appointment of a former Communist weekly newspaper editor to a fellowship at Harvard University, the Massachusetts Senate today extended the life of a special commission investigating communism and fascism in this State.

Word was received here yesterday of the death in Echmiadzin, Soviet Armenia, of Khoren Katholicos, Supreme Patriarch of the Armenian Church, who was elected to the office in November, 1932. He was 59 years old.

ALTHEIMER-Mollie, widow of Samuel, beloved mother of Abram S. and Jesse. Funeral Rochester, N. Y. ATWELL--On Monday, April 11, 1938, at her residence, 606 West 116th St., Marion Gaylord Atwell. Funeral service at Community Church Center, 550 West 110th St., on Wednesday evening, April 13, at 8 o'clock.

What America needs is a thorough survey, biologically and socially, of its human resources, Dr. Norman E. Himes, Professor of Sociology at Colgate University, declared in an address tonight before the Conference on Conservation of Marriage and the Family, which opened today at the University of North Carolina.

Paintings by Frank Duveneck have been placed on view at the Whitney Museum. There was a preview yesterday afternoon, and beginning today the work of this nineteenth century American artist may be viewed until May 15 by the public.

RKO today purchased "Five Who Came Back," by Richard Carroll, as a probable vehicle for Cary Grant. The plot deals with eight people involved in a plane wreck in a jungle with the repaired craft unable to save more than five of the victims.

The one-family dwelling with twocar garage at 96 Glenwood Avenue, East Orange, N. J., was sold by the Society of the Propagation of the Faith of New York to the Arthur D. Crane Company of East Orange. Title to the property will be insured by the New Jersey Realty Title Insurance Company of Newark.

James Gamble Rogers of New York has been commissioned by the trustees of Western College to prepare plans for new buildings and remodeling of present ones on the campus. He will begin his studies immediately.

Miss Cecile Beatrice Paine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold William Paine of this place and West Dennis, Mass., was married here tonight to John Donovan Simmons of Canton, Mass., son of John George Simmons of Canton and Miami Beach, Fla.

While conceding that a substantial pick-up in advertising linage will probably not develop until the Fall, advertising agencies were encouraged in the last two weeks by the upward revisions in schedules made by several manufacturers as the result of improved-March sales.

Premier Edouard Daladier won his race last night and early this morning against the organized disorganization that had been begun in Parliament and among the workers of the Paris district. In the Chamber of Deputies he obtained an almost unanimous vote of confidence,

Six earth shocks cracked plaster in two elementary school buildings here today and toppled over Easter displays in some stores. The quakes came between 9:40 A. M. and 11:16 A. M., Eastern standard time. Tremors were felt elsewhere in Imperial Valley.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions NEW YORK TUBE AND SPOOL COTTON CO., INC., 24 W. 31st St.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $17,173, exclusive of capital stock, and assets of $5,968.

About 69 per cent of the common and 67 per cent of the preferred stock of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation were represented by proxy or person at the annual meeting in Wilmington yesterday, with estimates that about 100 persons made the trip from their homes to the Delaware city.

Two bills designed to eliminate from jury panels drawn for first-degree murder cases the names of those who have conscientious objections to the death penalty were signed today by Governor Lehman. The measures were sponsored by Assemblyman Schulman of Monroe.
For the second day in a row the Newark Bears of the International League defeated Binghamton of the Eastern League by the margin of a single run, winning today, 6-5.

Handcuffed to two petty racketeers, Richard Whitney, once a power in the financial world, arrived at Sing Sing a little after noon today to begin serving from five to ten years in prison for grand larceny.

Death and taxes became subjects of argument yesterday before the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals when Louise Foster, special assistant to the Attorney General, asserted that the Board of Tax Appeals had erred in denying the government its right to tax the profit of a cemetery corporation.
The following Reserve officers recently released to the 1st Military Area, are assigned as indicated:
Contracts totaling $98,685.60 were awarded by the War Department today for gun-mounting brackets and other auxiliary equipment incident to the mounting of ordnance on army bombing planes.

Dr. Herman Leroy Fairchild, 87, Professor Emeritus of Geology at the University of Rochester, was chosen today for the municipal museum commission's first civic achievement medal. The award is to be made annually to a Western New York resident prominent in science, medicine, literature, history, industry, education, art, music or law. Dr. Fairchild is a for.

Lily Pons was made an officer of the French Legion of Honor tonight during a charity concert which she gave before a large and enthusiastic audience in the Salle Pleyel. There was a friendly rivalry between Joseph Paul-Boncour, the retiring Foreign Minister, and former Ambassador Georges Bonnet, his successor, yesterday as to who should sign the decree according Mis: Pons this honor.

While three armed men covered the elevator operator and six passengers a confederate took a $1,300 payroll from Benjamin Klang, a partner in the Indiana Dress Company, as he was returning to his office on the ninth floor of 27 West Twenty-fourth Street soon after 3 P. M. yesterday.

The recent general increase in freight rates should yield $5,500,000 annually to the Erie Railroad on the basis of 1936 traffic, C. E. Denney, president, said at the annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday. However, he remarked later, traffic now was smaller than a year ago.

The building occupied by the American Art Association, Anderson Galleries, comprising the blockfront on the east side of Madison Avenue between Fifty-sixth and Fifty-seventh Streets, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms.

Mrs. Marion Gaylord Atwell, clubwoman and alumnae trustee of Mount Holyoke College, died on Monday in her home at 606 West 116th Street after an illness of three weeks. Mrs. Atwell had lectured extensively on current events before women's organizations.
Store leases were numerous among the business rental contracts announced yesterday. The concerns involved are engaged in retail enterprises of a varied nature.

To the millions who saw and heard him in the capitals of the world, to the multitude in all walks of life who had known the man as well as the artist, the death of Feodor Chaliapin comes with a special poignancy and sense of loss.

Demanding immediate wage increases, a preferential shop and a reduction of two hours in the work week, about 900 warehouse employes of four central city department stores went on strike today. Deliveries were held up when 300 truck drivers refused to go through the picket lines established by the warehousemen.

A report submitted yesterday to Harold L. Ickes, PWA director in Washington, by Colonel M. E. Gilmore, regional director of the eleven-State area that included New York, disclosed that in the five-year period of PWA activity to date, $904,029,836 had been expended on 2,152 projects, of which all but 271 had been completed and were in active use.

The Stadium Concerts, of which Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer is chairman, yesterday announced the engagement of three more conductors, two to make their debuts, for the coming season at Lewisohn Stadium to start Thursday evening, June 23.
Captain Arthur Stanley Wilson, one of the principal figures in the famous "Baccarat case," in which King Edward VII, then Prince of Wales, was a witness, died today at the age of 69.

The Big Smoky Mountains echoed the heaviest, noisiest exhibition of Yankee artillery of the Spring as the world champions mowed down Knoxville, 19 to 4, at Smithson Stadium today. A gathering of 3,336 witnessed the cannonading.

It should be remembered by many communities but especially by this community that John Shaw Billings was born a hundred years ago yesterday. The library at Forty-second Street is making an exhibition that is primarily biographical.

Rosmarie Fitzpatrick of Demarest High School, Hoboken, won first prize here tonight in an oratorical contest for New Jersey high school students held under the. sponsorship of Dean Alexander F. OrNsby of John Marshall College.
More than 1,500 members of the Industrial Insurance Agents Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, held a pre-election rally last night at the Manhattan Opera House, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street,

The junior division of the Greater New York Campaign of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee has raised about $13,000 toward its 1938 quota of $25,000, it was announced last night at a rally in Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixtyfifth Street.
Dr. C. Luther Fry of the University of Rochester, one of the country's leading sociologists, died of an internal hemorrhage today at Strong Memorial Hospital.

THE trim, sunburned fellow with the closely cropped curly gray hair said he thought he would have some tea and then he took a look at the tea-it was in one of those little linen bags dangling around the top of the teapot-and he changed his mind.
A Japanese Army spokesman declared today that the Chinese held not a single Japanese officer prisoner after more than nine months of bitter warfare. He predicted none would be taken alive.
Mr. and Mrs. David N. Mauger of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Helen Mauger, to Roger Edmund Kellogg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin M. Kellogg of Short Hills.
The Foundation for Better Homes, Inc., will open a model dwelling in Hartsdale Acres, Hartsdale, on Saturday at 1 P. M.

A mild flurry of buying in the final hour yesterday prevented the stock market from closing generally lower. As it was, final prices were irregular. Trading on the Stock Exchange was the slowest since last Thursday, with a turnover of only 600,000 shares; Monday's total was 1,100,000.

A rally in French exchange yesterday following an improved political situation and reports that a smaller acreage in India is likely this year, owing to prevailing low quotations, helped prices on the Cotton Exchange here.

Governor Lehman refused today to approve the Rapp bill, increasing from forty to fifty miles an hour the speed limit on State highways, beyond which the driver faces the presumption of reckless driving in case of accident.

Feast and famine receipts characterized the steer market so far this week, Monday's 17,000 head crop being followed by a very small run today, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. This curtailment led to 10 to 15 cents higher prices all through the list.

Trading was fair to slow. The lamb market was weak to lower and some veal hindsaddles 50c-S1 lower. Prices otherwise were little changed on traefa meats. Early trading in kosher meats was slow, with beef sharply lower, veal weak and lamb weak to slightly lower, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
Arthur W. Wellington of Boston, retired president of the United States Leather Company of Massachusetts, died at his Summer home here last night after a heart attack. His age was 69.
Charles P. Clarke, knit goods manufacturer of this city, died at his home here today at the age of 76. He founded the Fort Schuyler Knitting Company in 1899 and was its president until his death.

Cuba has extended to Canada its minimum tariff, the Dominion Government was informed today. For the past two years the maximum tariff, double the minimum impost, has been applied to most of the goods entering that country from the Dominion.
Sale of business property on East Flagler Street today at more than $7,000 a front foot established a new high price for downtown Miami real estate since the Florida boom.

The indomitable Chicago Black Hawks, one of the longest long shots in all sports history, scored in every period tonight to defeat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 to 1, to win the Stanley Cup and world hockey championship before 17,204 spectators at the Chicago Stadium.
Roy E. Larsen, publisher of Life Magazine, was arrested yesterday in the Bronx, where the current issue of the magazine has been banned. Charged with violating

Joe Mele turned in a no-hit performance as the Erasmus Hall High School nine beat John Adams High of Queens, 9 to 1, in a nonleague encounter at Erasmus Field yesterday. Mele, a southpaw, struck out five and issued three passes in seven innings.

A proposal to establish life tenure for teachers in the four city colleges and a plan to democratize" the administration of these institutions by establishing faculty councils will be recommended to the Board of Higher Education for adoption, it was announced last night.
With a cargo of 9,000 tons of No. 1 whale oil, valued unofficially at $990,000, the floating whale factory Ulysses arrived off Staten Island yesterday and anchored to await docking orders.

Ballyhoo, the stock in trade of Coney Island, has been banished by official decree from the Boardwalk. The raucous "come-on boys" who nightly during the Summer have shouted their wares from raised platforms in front of concessions have been outlawed under the licensing rules drawn up for the 1938 season, License Commissioner Paul Moss announced yesterday.
Manufacturers, "for their own protection" should lend their aid to prompt repeal of the fair trade laws now effective in forty-three States, because "if these laws are long continued,

George Balanchine, ballet master at the Metropolitan Opera House for the last three years, will not return next season, it became known last night. With him will go the American Ballet Ensemble, which has been the dancing troupe of the Metropolitan during that period.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today Paul R. Ames of New York was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had, Judge Jackson not participating in any cases argued.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 11: MAJOR GENERAL Moses, A., two months and eleven days leave, April 19. Relieved from duty at New York, N. Y., and to retirement, June 30.
Supplies that may enable the Barcelona Government to resist for six months more and perhaps even open a counteroffensive are reaching the Loylists from home factories and over the French frontier.

Three bandits with pistols arose from a table at the Club Howdy, 47 West Third Street, as the bar was closing at 4 A. M. yesterday and ordered the sixty employes and customers to "stick 'em up." A few minutes later the police arrived,

New York City will not have a school-garage facing the Yankee Stadium after all. The buildings and sites committee of the Board of Education voted yesterday to abandon the "garool" plan for P. S. 114, the Bronx, and to build the new school in one corner of McCombs Dam Park.

General John J. Pershing made definite plans tonight to leave the Desert Sanatorium Sunday by special car for New York to attend the marriage of his son Warren to Miss Muriel Bache Richards in St. Thomas Church on April 22.

The Providence Reds won the International-American Hockey League championship tonight by defeating the Syracuse Stars, 4-1, Providence thus captured the series, three games to one. The Reds, leaders of the Eastern Division after the regular season play, scored once in the second period and three times in the third.
The Court of Appeals today upheld the extension of the State Mortgage Moratorium Act when it affirmed lower court decisions which forbade Maguire Co. of New York City to foreclose on property in.

Andrew Ponzi increased his lead over Jimmy Caras, the world champion, in their 1,500-point exhibition pocket billiard match yesterday at the Fourteenth Street Academy by annexing the afternoon session, 125-108, in twelve innings, and the evening block, 125-78, in thirteen.

The $100,000 race between War Admiral and Seabiscuit, which had looked so nebulous when set tentatively for next Fall, became a reality yesterday when the board of directors of the Westchester Racing Association voted unanimously to put up the money for Memorial Day, May 30. Owner Samuel D. Riddle promptly accepted the new date for War Admiral.

Gover nor Earle's Anthracite Coal Indug try Commission in a final report today revealed that the Governor's appeal. for settlement of the anthracite problem by .the Federal Government had been rejected.

The appointment of Norman H. Davis as chairman of the American Red Cross was announced by President Roosevelt today. The President said he would not be expected to give up his diplomatic career as Ambassador at Large and adviser to the State Department on EuroPean affairs.

An eighth-inning home run by Catcher Al Lopez with a team-mate on base gave the Bees their fourth victory in five games against the Senators today. The score was 7 to 6. The blow, which landed in the James River, was hit off Bill Phebus during his first inning in the box. It wiped out a 6-to-5 Washington lead.

Miss Helen L. Michalis, chairman of the debutante committee for the Butterfly Ball dinner dance, which will take place on April 22 at the Ritz-Carlton, and several of her assistants yesterday afternoon visited the House of Rest, beneficiary of the annual dance, at Sprain Ridge, near Yonkers.

Twenty-three new members will be admitted to Macy's "Twenty-five Year Club" on the evening of April 26 at the annual banquet meeting of the club to be held in the restaurant of the store, it was announced yesterday.

Taxes generally are not popular with the people who pay them, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told several hundred staff members of the Division of Old-Age Assistance of the Department of Welfare yesterday, in an address at the City College building at Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.
The four-story apartment building at 1,086 Ocean Avenue, on the corner of Foster Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold subject to a mortgage of $135,000 by L. A. Pincus to Carpenter Equities, Inc.

The Union Oil Company of California reported yesterday for the first three months of this year a consolidated net profit of $2,300,000, after all charges, taxes and reserves, equal to 49 cents a share on 4,666,270 capital shares outstanding. This compared with $2,200,000,

Walter A. Carter's Clodion, making his first public appearance since he went wrong in the last Kentucky Derby, returned in fine form today to win the Meadowview Farm Purse, sixfurlong feature. The gelded son of Pharamond II, who wintered in Miami, clicked by a length and a half in 1:14 at 7 to 10.

A three-year program for Dartmouth's fraternities was announced today. It will eventually establish a maximum of fifty-five student members for each fraternity. At present some fraternities have as many as eightythree members.
A 41 per cent gain in the machine too index was reported for March yesterday by the National Machine Tool Builders Association.
Odell Hale, known to the boys in the trade as "Bad News," proved all of that and more to the Giants today when he literally walloped Bill Terry's troop single-handed.

The New York Academy of Public Education announced yesterday that its board of governors had chosen Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, as the recipient of its medal awarded annually for distinguished service to public education.

Much comment on recent reassertions by Congress of its coordinate place in the Federal Government seems to be based on a misapprehension. This misapprehension is that necessarily, in rebuffing the President on several important matters Congress has turned completely against him and against the New Deal and is sure to be conservative on all points of program.
President Roosevelt conferred at the White House tonight with members of his Cabinet and others on the relief and recovery message he expects to send to Congress on he a Thursday.

An Ontario Supreme Court jury tonight acquitted Vernon Spencer, 40, of Wixom, Mich., a former professional baseball player and once a member of the New York Giants, of a charge of murdering Helen Grier, his companion on a hunting trip in Northern Ontario last Fall.

In a communication published yesterday, the British Government requests the League of Nations to consider at the May meeting the "anomalous situation" arising from the fact that five of the States represented on the Council recognize Italian sovereignty over Ethiopia, whereas the others do not.

Twenty-one log cabins and cottages and twenty-nine building sites in the chain of Erskine Lakes, comprising Lake Erskine, Lake Cupshaw and Upper Lake in Passaic County, N. J., have been sold-within the last six weeks, according to the Ringwood Company, developers.
Pressed for a decision between "pump-priming" expenditures and outlays actually required for the relief of destitution as a help toward meeting the economic emergency,...
The recent Congressional elections gave the government of President Roberto M. Ortiz a clear majority in the Chamber of Deputies, according to the final count made public this morning.

William J. McDonald, renewal, in 1,045 Park Ave; Alfries Realty Corp, agent. Peter Lehman, through Byrne Bowman, Inc, in 49 E 96th. St; Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc. broker. Saul B. Shulman, In 40 W 67th St; Apartment Locating Bureau, broker. Tilly Losch, in Hotel Ambassador, Park Ave and 51st St.

169th St, 49 E (11-2839), Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Congregation Nusach Sfard of The Bronx, 49 E 169th St. Trinity Ave, 1,033 (10-2633), Antonio Scalone to Phillip Sullivan, 736 Hone St. Brook Ave, 1,464 (11-2895), John C. Spallone, referee, to Theresa Sidenberg, 27 W 72d St. Brook Ave, 1,478 (11-2895), Harlem Savings Bank to George Chiladakls, 1,476 Brook Ave.

Feodor Chaliapin died early this evening after an illness of only a few days. The celebrated basso was believed yesterday to be out of danger but his condition took a turn for the worse this morning. He was 65 years old.

Spanish government troops in heavy fighting today tried to drive a wedge between the northern and southern Insurgent forces closing in on Catalonia. Government attacks on the Central Catalonian front were said to have broken through Insurgent lines.
Ginger Foran, 130, Liverpool, England, gained a ten-round decision over Orville Drouillard, 135, Windsor, Ont., in the feature bout at the Broadway Arena before a capacity crowd of 4,000 last night.
Representative Charles W. Tobey announced today that he would be a candidate for the Republican nomination for the Senate in the September primaries.

Frank May of Beechhurst, L. I., was elected captain of the 1938-39 Lafayette College wrestling team today. William F. Toohey of Hartford, Conn., was named manager. May, Middle Atlantic States heavyweight champion, has never been thrown in two years of varsity competition and has lost only two decisions.

Richard Wagner's opera, "Parsifal," will be broadcast on Good Friday beginning at 12:55 P. M. over WJZ's network directly from the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House. Lauritz Melchior will sing the title role, assisted by Kirsten Flagstad, Friedrich Schorr, Norman Cordon, Emanuel List and others.
Realty transactions reported yesterday by brokers involved properties in scattered sections of the city. Most of the buildings changing hands were multi-family dwellings.

Joseph Blau, former president of the New York State Cleaners and Dyers Association, and Herman Warendorff, president of H. Warendorff, Inc., florists, have been named State group chairmen of the American Federation of Little Business, Inc., in the cleaning and dyeing and florist industries, respectively.

Flood control, navigation and electric power are the three chief objectives of the Tennessee Valley Authority. In the five years since it was established by Congress, this Federal agency has begun to put into effect a program for the unified development of the Tennessee River and its area, covering seven Southeastern States, and for the conservation and utilization of their natural resources.

A tie vote, an extremely unusual occurrence in the House of Commons, was decided this afternoon by the Speaker, Captain E. A. Fitzroy. who voted in favor of introducing a bill that would confer Palestinian citizenship upon oppressed Jews of Europe.

Five former officials of the Seacoast Trust Company of Asbury Park and the estate of a deceased former director have been ordered by Vice Chancellor Malcolm G. Buchanan to pay to Secretary of State Thomas A. Mathis,
Pleas for aid in rescuing Jewish children from Central Europe brought a flood of pledges yesterday at the annual donor luncheon of the New York chapter of Hadassah at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Simon Elmore, 57 years old, a former WPA house painter, won a new trial today through a decision by the New York Court of Appeals which reversed his conviction on first degree murder charges in the slaying of Joan Kuleba, 4, at South Beach, S. I., last August.

Mayor La Guardia's proposal to combat the depression by subsidizing our exports to Central and South America is not a happy one. The Mayor is sound in recognizing the importance of foreign trade. It is necessary to maintain or restore that trade as much as possible to prevent too great a disruption of the economic balance to which we have been adjusted.

Dr. Orando S. Ritch, a trustee of the New York Medical College and Flower Hospital, who a month ago received a gold medal for sixty years of service to this institution and to humanity, died yesterday morning in his home at 78 Halsey Street, Brooklyn, after an illness of several months. He was 79 years old.

Tip's Topsy Tap, a white and liver pointer owned by Raymond Hoagland of Cartersville, Ga., annexed the open subscription stake as the annual Spring meet of the Lambertville Field Trial Club started today. The event was run on the Barry estate, with beautiful Spring weather prevailing.

Faceca declining revenues and increasing expenses, S. T. Bledsoe, president of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway, announced today that the railroad would delay action on the payment of interest on its 4 per cent adjustment mortgage bonds of 1995, of which 2 per cent customarily is paid on May 1, until the future indicates whether the interest has been earned.
Dr. W. D. Fairchild, an Illinois educator, died here yesterday of heart disease at the age of 72. He was the father of Dr. R. W. Fairchild, president of Illinois State Normal University.

Miss Eleanor Neal Smith, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey F. Smith of this city, has completed plans for her marriage to Thomas Toby of Glen Ridge, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Simeon T. Toby of Elizabeth, N. J., which will take place on April 29 at the home of her parents.

Apparently Bill Posedel, Dodgers' recruit right-hander from Portland, is not going to allow Forest Pressnell, the other prominent newcomer on Burleigh Grimes's staff to be come a lone fixture in the limelight.

Turpentine firm, 22 3/4c; sales, 115 barrels: receipts, 622 barrels; shipments, 57 barrels; stock, 29.087 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 602; receipts, .1,831; shipments, 100; stock, 73,038. Quote: B. $3.50; D, $3.70; E, $3.75; F, $4.65; G, H, I, K, $4.67r; M, $4.72 1/2; N, $5.20; WG, $6SO WW, X, $6.50.

Brig. Gen. Sir William and Lady Alexander of Marlston House, Berks, England, who are at the Waldorf-Astoria, will give a reception and tea this afternoon in the Basildon Room of the hotel. Mr. and Mrs. Henry Evans Gray of 1,010 Fifth Avenue will sail Saturday on the Rex for a brief trip abroad.

The Mexican Government informed Britain flatly today that it would not return the British-owned petroleum companies expropriated by Presidential decree on March 18. The Mexican note, replying to the British Government's demand for a return of the properties, was delivered simultaneously to the British Legation here and to the Foreign Office in London. It will be published tomorrow.

Charles Donnelly, president of the Northern Pacific Railway, estimated yesterday at the company's annual meeting of stockholders here that the increased freight rates allowed recently by the Interstate Commerce Commission would add between 7 and 8 per cent to his company's earnings.

An "Afternoon of Fine Arts" will be held tomorrow by the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs at the Woodhouse Galleries of the Hotel Astor at 2 P. M. The program, which is under the direction of Mrs. Otto Hahn, chairman of the Fine Arts Division of the organization, will be devoted to the arts of England and Greece.

The State won a victory today in a drive to regulate the practice of medicine through injunction when the Court of Appeals, in a 5-to-2 decision, ordered a Special Term of Supreme Court to hear an injunction proceeding against Earl S. Laman, a Binghamton and Endicott City chiropractor.

A bearish construction placed on the United States Government's estimate, issued late yesterday, placing the Winter wheat crop at 726,000,000 bushels, led to free selling of futures in all markets today.

Mrs. Margaret Sealy Ladd, a trained nurse who served in the World War, died yesterday in the Presbyterian Hospital after a long illness. Mrs. Ladd, who had lived at 33 Washington Square West, was 56 years old.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,392,350 barrels, compared with 3,367,250 in the previous week, an increase of 25,100, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

BRIAN CURTIS'S "Life Story of the Fish"* is a book for those who like to go fishing, or to breed fish, or to read Fabre, Maeterlinck, Burroughs and Henry Williamson. Mr. Curtis (he is on the research staff of California's Game and Fish Bureau) is not in the Fabre-Maeterlinck class so far as literary accomplishment is concerned,
Despite early profit-taking, the stock market today made fresh headway as the session approached the close, and most sections finished slightly higher than yesterday.

Bronxwood Ave, 3,291, 50.7x234.1 irreg: North Side Savings Bank against Margaret Swearer; due, $1,805; taxes, etc, $154; to Giacomio Firpo for $3,000. By GEORGE J. KEARNS Virgil Pl. 2,121, 28.11x100; Home Owners Loan Corp against Della Henkel; due, $10,650; taxes, etc, $125; to plaintiff for $1,100.

President after President has asked Congress to pass a law putting first, second and third class postmasters under the merit system, the application of which to them rests at present on an executive order and might be upset by any future President of ill will.

Denying a defense motion to dismiss a nine- count indictment against former Mayor George J. Zimmermann, Supreme Court Justice George A. Larkin today ordered him to appear in court April 20 to re-enter a plea.

Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy and his staff were still investigating last night a small fire discovered about 1:40 P. M. yesterday in a room on the seventh floor of the new nine-story C and D building on the Bellevue Hospital grounds. Last January four fires occurred within a week in the hospital's buildings, the last two within eleven hours. The damage was slight.

A 10-year-old girl was seriously injured yesterday when she was thrown about thirty feet into the air by an explosion in a manhole at 119th Street and Third Avenue. The explosion, which injured two other pedestrians, was heard for blocks and drew nearly 500 persons to the scene. A paving block was hurled fifty feet through a plate-glass window.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended April 7 increased in four out of five trade groups as compared with the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

The incidence of measles, which has been increasing steadily since about Jan. 1, reached 1,933 new cases in this city for the week ended last Saturday, the highest in almost two years, Dr. John L. Rice, city Health Commissioner, reported yesterday.

ALTOONA, Pa.-Wm. F. Gable Co.; A. J. Ford, ready-to-wear; 50 W. 35th (Syndicate-Alliance) . ATLANTA-Rich's, Inc.: E. H. Etling, laces, embroideries, linens, fancy, gift goods: 128 W. 31st (Kirby, Block Co.).

After the doors of Sing Sing had closed yesterday on Richard Whitney, the extent of his failure and that of the brokerage house bearing his name was partly revealed in bankruptcy schedules filed in Federal court.

About 200 persons, representing twenty-five or more civic organizations, adopted a resolution last night at a meeting in the Queens County Courthouse protesting against the high tax rate in Queens and authorizing creation of a permanent council of taxpayers' groups to work for lower taxes.

Democrats won control of the municipal government in the biennial city election today, sweeping George J. Coyle into the Mayoralty by an unofficial plurality of 3,658. the highest ever given to a Democratic candidate.

Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, expressed today the opinion that price staability "should not be the principal objective of public policy," since it std not necessarily lead to economic stability.

A banking group composed of F. S. Moseley Co., Inc., Estabrook Co. and Hornblower Weeks was the successful bidder yesterday for a new issue of $1,000,000 of first mortgage bonds of the Cape and Vineyard Electric Company.

The vast new Federal program of spending to revive business probably will include liberal appropriations for more public housing work, according to realty interests in close touch with developments in Washington.

Alonzo J. Powers 2d, 30 years old, a Princeton graduate who, until about two years ago, had a $25,000 yearly income and is awaiting liquidation of his father's estate, was arraigned in General Sessions yesterday on an indictment charging thefts of more than $2,700 from the Arbor Inn Club on the campus at Princeton, of which he was the graduate treasurer.

Paul E. Clifford, at 273 Chatterton Parkway. White Plains, Westchester County, for Frederick M. Heath; Robert E. Farley Organization, broker. Edward H. Dexter, at Fordham Cottage, Remsenburg, L. I.; Butler Baldwin, Inc., broker. Frederick J. Reid, in 453 Palmer Ave, Yonkers; Cushman Wakefield, Inc, brokers.

Newbold Morris, president of the City Council and, in the absence from the city of Mayor La Guardia, the acting Mayor, was deposed temporarily from his presiding seat in the council yesterday in the course of a debate on a resolution to investigate the Municipal Courts.

Stocks, after drifting lower, improved moderately in final hour and closed irregular; turnover, 600,300 shares. United States Government and foreign bonds firm, corporate issues generally lower; transactions, $4,842,300.

The Bankamerica -Company and the American Trust Company of San Francisco have purchased an issue of $5,325,884 of general fund unemployment relief warrants of the State of California at 1 per cent, plus a premium of $1,017.24. The warrants will be dated April 13, and will become payable on or about Aug. 31, 1938.

To take effect 8 A. M., April 16: LIEUTENANTS-Thomas Maher, from 44th Precinct to First District Traffic, assignment changed from desk duty to supervisor of patrol in uniform. William J. Connor, from 7th Division to 44th Precinct, assignment to desk duty continued.

BAETTENHAUSSEN, THEODORE (June 21, 1934). Gross assets, $117,855; net, $79,949. To Jack A. (Julius A. Roth), nephew, three-sixths residue; Kurt W. Baettenhaussen, nephew, two-sixths residue; Lina E. Grey, niece, one-sixth residue. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $78,928. Burlingham, Veeder, Clark Hupper, attorneys, 27 William St.

The bitter battle in yesterday's offyear primary for political supremacy in Illinois between the KellyNash Chicago machine and the organization headed by Governor Henry Horner was apparently won by the Governor's forces,

Calling attention to the tremendous slowing down of consumer buying and industrial activity in the last few months, Edward G. Seubert, president of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, in the annual report for 1937, released for Br publication today, says "a new start of recovery waits on the reestablishment among business men of confidence that they can proceed with their operations with some hope of earning profits."

BERMAN, IRA A. (March 27). Estate, less than $1,000. To Hannah Berman, widow, executrix, 127 W. 79th St. BURDEN, HARRIETTE HART (April 3). Estate, more than $10,000. To Leila Howard Chapin, daughter, 215 E. 73d St.; Joseph W. Burden, Bedford Village, N. Y., and Chester G. Burden, 1,220 Park Ave., sons, executors, one-third residue each.

The town policemen's and firemen's pension commission rejected tonight the application of Mrs. Wilhelm Pearson, recently acquitted as the slayer of her patrolman husband, for a widow's pension of $1,000 a year.
Continuance of democratic government depends on freedom of discussion and criticism, a regard for human welfare, kindness and a individual spirit of responsibility,
High school football, banned for twenty-eight years by the Rochester Board of Education, was restored to the academic sports program tonight by vote of the board.

Plans to transform the grounds around sixteen incinerator plants of the Department of Sanitation from eyesores into attractive recreation spots were announced yesterday by the Works Progress Administration.

The British-owned Reina Cristina Hotel in Algeciras will soon be commandeered by the Spanish Insurgents for the purpose of quartering German instructors and experts who have been in Algeciras and neighboring Rebel towns for several months.
