The Biltmore Theatre tonight gets "What a Life," or Clifford Goldsmith's investigation into the lessserious side of high school activities. Ezra Stone, Betty Field, Vaughan Glaser, Ruth Matteson, Arthur Pierson, Joyce Arling,

Another challenge for the Scandinavian Gold Cup, one of the world's leading six-meter yachting trophies, came in yesterday, this one from the Royal Norwegian Yacht Club of Oslo, Norway. The challenge was received by Philip J. Roosevelt, president of the North American Yacht Racing Union.

Brewster Properties, Inc, Jesse H. Barkin, president, assigned to Everdale Realty Corporation a mortgage for $46,000 on the north corner of Central Park West and 92d St, 75.8 1/2x125. Two mortgages on the southwest corner of Sutton Place South and 57th St. 132.8x 106.6xirreg, were assigned to the Equitable Life Assurance Society;
The "greatest show on earth" gave something new in the way of circus performances at Madison Square Garden last night as the result of a last-minute strike of at least 200 non-performing employes.

Mayor La Guardia's warning that the United States position as chief supplier of goods to Latin America is menaced by activities of the dictator nations of Europe, won complete endorsement from foreign traders yesterday, but his proposal for subsidizing of exports, made in his radio address Monday night, found little support among exporters.

After holding out for eighty-four moves, Mrs. Mary Bain, fifth prize winner in the world tournament at Stockholm, resigned her fifth-round game in the National Chess Federation tournament for the Hazel Allen Trophy to Miss Edith Weart at the Marshall Chess Club last night.

Miss Ruth Anne Rensenhouse and Miss Jean K. Rensenhouse, daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Proctor D. Rensenhouse of 43 Dunham Road, will be married in a double wedding tomorrow afternoon at the home of their parents here.

Harold Morton of Providence, R. I., conceded defeat without further play last night in his adjourned game from the eighth round with Albert C. Simonson of the Manhattan Chess Club. This enabled Simonson to gain on Samuel Reshevsky, United States champion, the leader in the biennial tournament of the National Chess Federation.

The salt-water brotherhood will be pleased to learn that the unofficial opening of the season isn't far off. When word comes that big channel bass are being taken at Oregon Inlet, in North Carolina, good fishing can be expected here in the near future.
Seven foreign newspaper correspondents informed their own and other countries via short-wave radio yesterday of the progress they had seen at the World's Fair site.

While the Japanese positions in South Shantung Province were still awkward and insecure, it was widely felt here this morning that the Chinese had lost an opportunity of turning their Taierhchwang successes into a sweeping victory.

Dr. Fredreick C. Ferry, president of Hamilton College, announced today that S. Demarest Rumsey Jr., 18, of Ridgewood, N. J., a sophomore, had committed suicide. The body, he said, was found last night hanging from a tree in Root's Glen on the Elihu Root estate, adjoining the college campus.
Elections to Phi Beta Kappa at Mount Holyoke College were announced in assembly today by President Ham, with these eighteen seniors, added to five elected in November:

Despite the submission of a new Wages and Hours Bill to the House Labor Committee today by the majority members of its subcommittee, the prospects and nature of legislation on this issue remained as confused as ever.

A Czechoslovak bomber was forced to land yesterday in Northern Transylvania on its way from Moscow to Prague. The pilot explained that he had accepted hasty delivery of the bomber in Moscow without an opportunity to test it, land engine trouble had developed as a result.

Syndicate clients of Burnstine, Geist Netter, attorneys, have purchased the remodeled former bank building at 239-41 Beach 116th Street, Rockaway Park, L. I., from the receiver of the Rockaway Beach National Bank, and the store and apartment building on the southwest corner of Newport Avenue and Beach 116th Street.

Arrested in connection with a $35,000 fire at the Ideal Dairy and a $500 blaze at the Tuscan Dairy, both of which occurred here Sunday night, three dairy workers pleaded guilty this afternoon before Police Recorder Gustave H. Klein Jr. to arson charges.

A novel program of Russian entertainment, as well as other divertissements, will feature the supper dance to be given on April 28 at the Montparnasse for the benefit of children of impoverished Russian emigres.
Favorites without exception mowed down the opposition today in the second round of the Pinehurst tennis tournament-an event which this year boasts extreme amateur purity with expense accounts barred.

Miss Anne R. Truesdale gave a reception yesterday afternoon in the Carpenter. Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for a group of young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons aiding in the plans for the preview supper dance to be held April 21 in the main ballroom of the hotel to aid the Cooperative Committee of Big Sisters.

By a chance telephone call, Mrs. Carl G. Triest, 23-year-old member of a socially prominent family, was saved tonight from death by automobile fumes in the garage back of her home, 67 Redbrook Road, Kings Point, according to the police.

The National City Bank of New York, as trustee for a $10,000,000 twenty-year 7 per cent sinking-fund gold debenture issue of the General Electric Company of Germany, obgained yesterday from -Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler a warrant for the attachment of any funds of the German company which might be found in New York.

Nicholas G. Psaki, whose resignation as a deputy assistant on the staff of District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan was to take effect on Friday, died Monday night at his home, 2,114 Eighty-first Street, Brooklyn. He had suffered t a stroke earlier in the day.

Mrs. Annie Weiner, a retired foreign buyer for the McCreery Stores and the H. B. Claflin interests, died in a local hospital yesterday after a long illness. Born in Chicago seventy-five years ago, she came to New York as a young woman.

Sales of silver by the Government of India in the last three years under the London Silver Agreement which expired on Dec. 31 amounted to approximately 15,000,000 ounces, it was disclosed in a report from the American Trade Commissioner at Calcutta which the Department of Commerce made public today.
Daily average sales of variety stores in March were about 5 per cent above February, or more than the estimated seasonal amount, the Department of Commerce reported today. They were, however,

All commitments made by the B. F. Goodrich Company in its negotiations with the United Rubber Workers Union on wages and hours have been withdrawn, the company announced today in a letter to L. L. Callahan, president of the local union.

An autopsy performed yesterday morning at Bellevue on the body of Morris Maxton, 67 years old, haberdasher, disclosed that he had died of multiple fractures of the skull caused by blows "of the butt of a revolver." Dr. Philip Goldstein, assistant medical examiner, performed the autopsy.
Italy virtually has sealed in advance a British-Italian friendship pact, which diplomats said tonight "might avert

Viscount Rothermere, owner of The London Daily Mail, Daily Mirror, Evening News and other British newspapers, arrived last night on the North German Lloyd liner Europa accompanied by his son, the Hon. Esmond C. Harmsworth. He will be here for a week.
Johnny Morro, 135 1/2, New York, outpointed Johnny Bellus, 136, New Haven, in the star attraction of eight rounds before 9,500 at the New York Coliseum last night.
Japanese headquarters today issued a statement regarding a second request handed to foreign diplomatic officials concerning foreign properties and the use of foreign flags within areas of fighting.

The Rev. John Christian Pringle, recognized as one of the leading British authorities on the relief of distress, died in Blackheath today at the age of 65. He had lectured extensively in India, Japan and the United States.

Leo Arnstein, a leader in philanthropy here for more than thirtyfive years, was elected president of Mount Sinai Hospital at a meeting of the board of trustees last night. He succeeds George Blumenthal, whose retirement after twentyseven years as president and election as president emeritus were announced at a dinner in honor of his eightieth birthday on April 7.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In reply to Mr. Fichandler's letter of April 1, in which he expresses the opinion that the decline in foreign language registration is to be applauded, I should like to submit the following: He says: "It indicates that our high school students and their parents are beginning to realize the futility and wastefulness involved in a general study of foreign languages in our country."

The said House approved the $21,644,431 Legislative Appropriation Bill today, rejecting with loud noess" a motion to reduce the $221,000 mileage appropriation to the actual cost of transporting members to and from the session.

Chester Lane, Inc., of 371 East 149th Street was revealed yesterday as the new owner of the fifteenstory and penthouse apartment building at the north corner of Ninety-second Street and Central Park West, when deeds transferring the property were filed in the Register's office.
Speaker Bankhead, who said he expects to go down in history as "a rather obscure character," received the plaudits of the House of Representatives today on his sixty-fourth birthday.

Governor Lehman today vetoed the Quinn bill which would have opened the door for dog racing in four of the larger counties, Nassau, Westchester, Monroe and Erie. In a brief veto memorandum the Governor wrote:

This historic village of approximately 18,000 citizens voted today, in one of the most interesting local elections in many years, to become a city in 1940. At the same time the voters returned to office all Democrats, and by electing another Democrat as a new member to the Board of Trustees, gave the board a political line-up of three Republicans and three Democrats.
Murray Hill took on some of the airs of Montparnasse yesterday afternoon as the Sculptors Guild opened its outdoor exhibition at Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street.

Richard Whitney's seat on the New York Stock Exchange was sold yesterday for $59,000, an increase of $7,000 over the previous transaction. The buyer was Robert A. Haughey Jr., 27 years old, who has been employed by Hoppin Brothers Co., and will make his office with that firm.

Former President Agustin P. Justo has announced to friends that he is going to the United States in November. He plans to spend a month there, crossing the continent to San Francisco and returning to Argentina via Panama.

The City Council, after an hour and a half of acrimonious debate, voted down yesterday a motion by Councilman Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d, Manhattan Republican, to bring from committee his resolution calling for an investigation of the city's Municipal Courts.

The Foreign Office today issued another complaint against Russia, the grievance this time being the closing of consulates. Last Sunday the Soviet authorities ordered the Japanese consulates at Khabarovsk and Blagoveshchensk closed, and they have requested Japan to close three Japanese consulates in Russia.

The steel arch bridge wrecked by the ice jam of Jan. 27 sank out of sight in the Niagara River today. Throughout the morning until midafternoon the break-up went on at Intervals, until at 3:40 P. M. the last remnant of the structure, about one-third of the fallen mass, started downstream on its raft of ice.

King Farouk opened his first Parliament today, and it represented his greatest political triumph since his accession, for the membership was composed almost entirely of political elements favored by him.

What were believed to be the first convictions in the city for operating bingo games were obtained yesterday in the Bronx Court of Special Sessions when three men were found guilty of violating the lottery law by organizing these games in the North Side Republican Club,

Several luncheons were given yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. Charles Northam Lee had as her guests Mrs. Bartow S. Weeks, Mrs. M. Leach Shepherd, Mrs. Duane Armstrong, Mrs. Frank Edward Hopkins, Mrs. Irving Schmelzel,
Steel ingot output declined last week, countering the normal seasonal trend, and the adjusted index receded to 45.4 from 48.4. The figure was 124.1 for the week ended April 10, 1937.

The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, complained to the Supreme Court today that the National Labor Relations Board had abrogated its contract with the Consolidated Edison Company of New York "without due process of law."

The Memel Diet tonight adopted an urgent resolution calling on the Directorate to take measures to effect the abrogation of martial law and the removal of Lithuanian "safety police" from Memel territory.
The city will bid for a share of the rich Coney Island transit business by attempting to take over the Culver line and link it to the city independent system, it was disclosed yesterday.

Ashton Parker, town counsel of Yorktown and a former Assistant Corporation Counsel in New York, died in his home here last night at the age of 57. Born in Lachine, Quebec, he attended Columbia University and was admitted to the bar in 1905.

Twenty guards and three armored trucks today transferred $21,000,000 in currency and securities belonging to Mrs. Laura Corrigan of London, Eng., from the Union Trust Company to the National City Bank.

Truman H. Newberry, former Secretary of the Navy, and Mrs. Newberry are expected to arrive tomorrow at the Plaza from Hot Springs, Va., where they have been since leaving their Winter home in Belleair, Fla. Mrs. Darwin P. Kingsley and Miss Hope Kingsley have returned to the Beekman from Bermuda.

Manhattan Alterations 146th St, 271-3 W; to two 5-story tenements and stores; W. and A. Construction Corp, 17 W 56th St, owner; F. P. Platt Bro, architects; cost, $16,000. 50th St, 539 W; to 5-story tenements and stores; Gottfried Bay, premises, owner; J. M. Berlinger, architect; cost, $4,000.

Miss Constance Peabody Looram will have Miss Carolyn Whitman for maid of honor at her marriage to Theodore P. Dixon Jr., which will take place on June 4 in the chantry of St. Thomas Church. The rector, the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, will perform the ceremony, and will be assisted by the Rev.

At the request of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the New York Stock Exchange sent yesterday to all member firms questionnaires requesting information regarding stock in "street names" to be voted at shareholders'

Employer, the gelding Bryant Ott has been conditioning for the Kentucky Derby for his wife, the owner, was declared out of the classic today. Employer was the third nominee of any standing to be definitely withdrawn, the others being Teddy's Comet and Legal Light.

The names of eighteen undergraduate students at City College who were elected to positions on the Student Council and to official class posts were announced yesterday by Dr. John R. Turner, dean of men.

Otis A. Thompson, president of the National Bank and Trust Company of Norwich, Norwich, N. Y., has been nominated for the post of Class A director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to fill the unexpired term, ending on Dec. 31 next, of the late Edward K. Mills, formerly president of the Morristown Trust Company, Morristown, N.J.

The groundwork was laid today for American participation in the international effort to facilitate the emigration of political refugees from Austria and Germany at Meetings of a group of interested American citizens with President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull.
The first of the "Parsifal" performances to be given by the Metropolitan Opera Association in connection with the Easter season took place last night in the Metropolitan Opera House.

Commemorating the liberation of Israelites from servitude in Egypt more than 3,000 years ago, the festival of Passover, which begins tomorrow at sundown, emphasizes the need of "a twentieth century story of deliverance" for five million Jews in "virtual bondage in Central and Eastern Europe," Dr. Israel Goldstein, co-chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, said last night in a broadcast from radio station WNYC.

Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation and International Chamber of Commerce, speaking to economics classes at Vassar College today on foreign trade, declared that proper control of the movement of goods across borders of countries throughout the world would remove all need for soldiers ever to march across those borders.

The State Labor Department said today that 101 plans for industrial buildings to cost $1,697,745, submitted during March, were 42 per cent higher than the fourteen-year average of such plans for the month.

Once more Governor Horner has beaten the Chicago Democratic bosses. In '36 they fought his renomination in vain. He used to be a secluded probate judge. They, supposed to be remarkably clever politicians, learned nothing from defeat. They continued to beat their heads against a stone wall.

What is believed to be the first voluntary chain of men's clothing stores was announced here yesterday by Ray E. Bigelow, who made known the formation of Scotcraft, Ltd., a service corporation which will include numerous individually owned men's apparel stores throughout the country.

The text of President Roosevelt's letter to chairmen of the Senate Finance and House Ways and Means Committees today was as follows: The Revenue Bill as it passed the House and the Revenue Bill just adopted by the Senate differ in many particulars.

The Court of Appeals today denied to William Copeland Dodge, former District Attorney of New York County, the right to collect $13,515.97 deducted from his $20,000-a-year salary from Jan. 1, 1934, to June 30, 1937.

While the ordinary-sized man can have a pair of pants made by a tailor in less than a week, it takes Medusa Longevin, 34, of Munising, from three to four weeks to get them, and pants cost him just twice as much as for others.

Two mortgages held by the Emigrant Bank from the 1,432 Bryant Ave Realty Corp. Nathan Ribler, president, have been consolidated as a joint first lien for $48,000 on 340-342 W 25th St and extended to April 1, 1943, with quarterly amortization from $180 to $240, beginning July 1, 1939.

Speculative interest in the wheat market today was at a minimum, and a good part of the business was in the way of evening up by operators who believed the Easter holidays in Europe would result in a very limited export demand.
Smashing a 1-to-1 tie, Long Island University pushed over four runs in the eighth to vanquish Brooklyn College's baseball team, 5 to 1, at the Brooklyn College field yesterday.

Frank Pierce Carpenter, New Hampshire's outstanding philanthropist and a leading banker and industrialist, died in his home here today. He was 92 years old. It is estimated Mr. Carpenter gave away $4,000,000 to charities in the last twenty-five years.

Collection ratios on open credit accounts receivable of department stores showed a decrease of 2.7 per cent for February from the corresponding month last year, while a decrease of 8.7 per cent was shown from January of this year, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce reported today.
Senator McAdoo has asked President Roosevelt to pardon Dr. Francis E. Townsend, old age pension advocate, who faces a thirty-day jail term for contempt of a House committee.

The city's public golf links and clay tennis courts will be opened on Saturday, it was announced yesterday by the Department of Parks. Prices for the golf permits are scaled the same as last year. They range from $3 to $10, depending on the kind desired.

On their own application, to take effect 12 midnight. April 15: SERGEANT-Thomas J. J. Law, Harbor Precinct, at $1,750 per annum. Appointed May 24, 1910. To take effect 12 midnight, April 12: PATROLMAN-James B. Begley, 75th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 3, 1908.

Charles True Adams, trustee of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, has filed under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 an application for consideration .and approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission of amounts to be paid to himself and others for services in connection with reorganization of the corporation.
Walter D. Barker, a member of the law firm of Lindabury, Depue Faulks, died this afternoon of a heart attack in his office here. Mr. Barker, who was 47 years old, lived in South Orange.

The Airline Feeder System, Inc., of Floyd Bennett Airport and 420 Lexington Avenue, Manhattan, filed yesterday in the Federal court in Brooklyn a petition seeking reorganization under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The petition listed assets of $63,828 and current liabilities of $37,874.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses explained his $6,000,000 plan for the development and modernization of much of the Rockaway Beach waterfront yesterday at a meeting of the City Planning Commission at City Hall.

A second new draft of a wages and hours bill, fixing an absolute wage floor and putting administration of the law in the hands of the Secretary of Labor, was laid before the House Labor Committee today by its chairman, Representative Norton. Democrat, of New Jersey.
Stewart McDonald, Administrator, announced today that the FHA had transacted a gross business of more than $200,000,000 since the amended Housing Act was passed.

Lance Hannen, who has sold millions of pounds worth of pictures as head of Christie's, retired today after almost fifty years with the firm. He climbed into the rostrum after Thomas Hoade Woods and as senior partner had been in charge of every important picture dispersal held at Christie's since 1906.
The Sun Life Assurance Company Building, largest office structure in the British Empire although only twenty stories high, announced today that hereafter there will be no thirteenth floor.

Surrogate James A. Delehanty signed an order yesterday directing the issuance of citations to interested parties in the estate of Irving I. Bloomingdale, late vice president of Bloomingdale Brothers, to show cause why an application should not be granted to his widow, Mrs. Geanne Hughes Bloomingdale Butler of the Hotel Gotham, to set aside decrees settling two accountings in the estate.

Before a capacity house that included many standees, Marian Anderson, distinguished Negro contralto, last night gave-her season's fourth New York recital as the final event of the Hurok Carnegie Hall Series.

A bill to be introduced in the Legislature with bipartisan support will abolish the State Financial Assistance Commission and transfer its functions to the State Department of Institutions and Agencies, Governor Moore, Democrat, said today.
The Census Bureau reported today that cotton seed crushed in the eight-month period, Aug. 1 to March 31, amounted to 5,500,054 tons, compared with 4,101,930 in the corresponding period a year ago.

A general plan of reorganization for the Prudence Company, Inc., has beer formulated and proposed by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the company's largest single creditor, it was announced yesterday by Jerome Thralls, special representative of the RFC.

After spending two days and nights in a city dump, Sandy, a seven-and-a-half-foot wooden Scotsman, will return today to its former place on the sidewalk in front of S. Scharlin Son's snuff shop at 113 Division Street.

The ten golf courses and scores of clay tennis courts under the jurisdiction of the Department of Parks throughout the city will be opened to the public Saturday morning, it was announced yesterday. There are golf links in all boroughs except Manhattan and tennis courts in every borough.

Turpentine firm, 22 3/4 c; sales 90 barrels; receipts 924 barrels; shipments 294 barrels; stock 29,087 barrels. Resin firm: sales 492: receipts 1,487 shipments 311: stock 74,214. Quote: B, $3.50; D, $3.60; E, 3.65. F G, H, I, K, $4.62 1/2; M, $4.65; N, 45.10 ?? WG, $6.00: WW, X, $6.40.

Abraham Lipman, founder of the Lipman Paper Company of Brooklyn and the Mount Clemens Sanitarium in Mount Clemens, Mich., died Tuesday night of a heart ailment at the Brooklyn Hospital. He was 63 years old.
The Dodgers made fifteen hits today in beating Connie Mack's Athletics, 12 to 10, in a game featured by the home runs of Long Jack Winsett and Leo Durocher.

With Hal Auer and Ed Boell, sophomore pitchers, twirling shutout ball, N. Y. U. opened the intercollegiate portion of its baseball schedule at Ohio Field yesterday with a 5-to-O verdict over the previously unbeaten St. John's University squad of Brooklyn.

Oystermen were warned today in an announcement by the Bureau of Fisheries to take precautions against the oyster drill, destructive enemy of the oyster which is particularly active along the Atlantic Coast.

147th St (9-2292), n s, 502 ft w of Brook Ave., 27x100; Joseph Sebel to Annabelle Realty Corp, 70 W 40 St; mtge, $10,500. Holland Ave. 2,713 (16-4510); Bowery Savings Bank to Beatrice Millman, 2,910 Wallace Ave.

The Mexican Government based its refusal to return British oil properties to the companies principally upon Mexico's rights as a sovereign nation, it was revealed today with the publication of the text of the Mexican note replying to the British Government's demand for the return of the properties.

Behind the slugging of Mike Hearn, Ram center-fielder and lead-off man, the Fordham baseball team scored in all but two innings to submerge the Princeton nine, 18-1, on University Field today. It was the second straight for the visitors and the third consecutive loss for the Tigers.

Caution in dealing with problems of marriage and family life to avoid possible conflict with the laws govearning in cases involving birth control, divorce or the sterilization of the unfit, was advised by John S. Bradway of the Duke University Law School, in an address today before the University of North Carolina's annual conference on Conservation of Marriage and the Family.

A drastic curtailment of production in Southern cotton mills, involving virtual elimination on a permanent basis of third-shirt operations, and shut-downs averaging thirty days' duration for a majority of the mills, has been forced by market conditions and resulted in an official request that the Federal Administration prepare to handle a resultant sharp increase in relief disbursements in the South, it was learned here yesterday.

Most of the current concern about the effect upon banks of recent drops in bond prices is unwarranted, Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, declared last night in a speech before the bankers forum of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Banking in the Woolworth Building.

Imperial Oil, Ltd., of Canada reported yesterday in its annual statement for 1937 a total net instatement for 1937 a total net income of $26,452,157 after all charges and provision for all income taxes, including $4,425,990 for those in Canada. This is equivalent to 94 cents a share on 26,965,078 shares of no-par capital stock. It compares with $25,628,285, or 95 cents a share, reported for 1936.

Clarence M. Woolley, president of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday that he was entering his fiftieth year of service for the company and its predecessors.

There was so much emotion at Lily Pons's concert here last evening that Victor Boucher inadvertently made her an officer instead of a chevalier in the French Legion of Honor in thanking her on behalf of the
The report of the Northern States Power Company of Delaware and subsidiaries, controlled by the Standard Gas and Electric Company, for the twelve months ended

Turf followers marked time yesterday, except for discussion as to who would win the $100,000 race between War Admiral and Seabiscuit on May 30, while the air mail was carrying formal agreements to owners Samuel D. Riddle and Charles S. Howard.
Darius A. Marsh, assistant general counsel for the Brooklyn Manhattan Transit Company since 1923, died here today at his home after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

Panama Al Brown, who already has won the International Boxing Union bantamweight championship, tonight knocked out Valentin Angelmann of France, I. B. U. flyweight champion, in the eighth round of their ten-round bout. Brown weighed 119 1/4, Angelmann 1141/2.

George Abbott is feeling in better health. After a run-down condition lasting most of the season, he is back on Broadway with a cheerful production of Clifford Goldsmith's "What a Life," which kept an audience genially rocking in the Biltmore last evening.
Roy B. White, president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday that he has every reason to believe the company's business has reached its low point.

Nathan Bushnell 3d, University of Virginia freshman, bet classmates he could walk the seventy miles from Charlottesville to Richmond within twenty-four hours. Bushnell left Charlottesville at 7 P. M. yesterday and arrived here just before noon today, completing the trip in about seventeen. hours.

The Industrial Insurance Agents, Local 30, affiliated with the United Office and Professional Workers of America, a C. I. O. union, obtained a plurality of thirty-six votes in an election of industrial insurance agents of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company conducted by the State Labor Relations Board to determine the collective bargaining agency desired by the employes.

Brig. Gen. Walter G. Robinson, adjutant general of the State of New York, has ordered the Junior Naval Militia and the Junior Naval Reserve to discontinue "forthwith" the use of the terms "militia" and "naval," it was learned yesterday.

The plan of Mayor La Guardia of New York to promote trade with South America through an exporf subsidy was disapproved this afternoon by Secretary Roper. He stated at his press conference that the only way to promote South American trade was through the "good neighbor" and reciprocal trade agreement policies now being followed by the State Department.
The chiefs of thirty-eight international unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization dectded today to form a permanent organization.

Shell Petroleum Corporation at a conference here at the Palmer House, attended by 1,450 dealers of the Chicago metropolitan area, announced its Spring sales and advertising campaign. A national newspaper campaign in an unannounced number of papers will break April 25, to be supplemented by page ads in national magazines.

Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority and founder and former president of the Park Association of New York City, will receive the association's annual award as a notable friend of the parks at a dinner next Tuesday evening in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.
Bolivia today rejected proposals advanced by a five-power neutral commission to settle the Chaco dispute over which Paraguay and Bolivia warred from 1932 to 1935.
From the outside some of our city school buildings look forbidding. Even the newer ones, as some critics complain, do not always allow for enough light, air and play space.

J. Edward Davidson has been named president of James McCreery Co., according to announcement yesterday by Oswald W. Knauth, president of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, of which McCreery's is a unit. Mr. Davidson, who took up his new duties yesterday, succeeds Doddrick Olson.

Serafin Alvarez Quintero, Spanish playwright, died here yesterday. He was 67 years old. In collaboration with his younger brother, Joaquin, who survives, he wrote more than 200 works for the theatre. Their plays were particularly well known in Latin America.
Because Good Friday and the Passover Eve both fall on April 15, the deadline for filing State income tax returns was extended yesterday until next Monday, April 18.

William Loewenstein, importer and exporter of leather, who died on Jan. 7 at the age of 63, directed in his will, filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday, that his residuary estate, of undetermined value, be held in trust for the establishment in this city of cafeterias where cooked food may be obtained free or for a nominal charge by all orderly persons applying regardless of race, color or creed.

Securities held as investments in Federal trust funds and in accounts of certain governmental corporations and agencies on Feb. 23 were made public today by Secretary Morgenthau because of numerous inquiries concerning the Treasury's handling of these accounts.
34th St, 432 W, 5-story tenement, 29.4x 98.9; Greenwich Savings Bank against George A. Darrow; due, $54,737; to plaintiff for $50,000. By I. LINCOLN SEIDE

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today State wheat acreage allotments under the 1938 farm program. The allotments will serve as the basis for payments to wheat growers from the or $500,000,000 soil conservation fund Congress is authorized to appropriate.
Senator Wheeler of Montana asked representatives of railroad labor and management today- to confer with him on Friday on the chances of getting any rail legislation through this session of Congress.
Political diagnosticians here today interpreted the defeat of the Kelly-Nash machine by the Horner forces in Illinois as a setback for the national administration.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 11: COMMANDERS Godwin, D. G., Naval Academy, to the Mississippi, as Executive Officer. Haggert, R S., Naval R. O. T. C. Unit, Georgia Tech., Atlantic, to the Quincy, as Executive Officer.
The government is drafting a bill establishing 5,000 military training centers in the schools and universities. Training in the schools is to begin on Sept. 1 and in the universities Oct. 1.

The Spanish Insurgent campaign for Catalonia gained steadily today, despite sterner resistance. Only in the central. sector, where the Insurgents were trying to hold a precarious position across the Segre River from Balaguer,

New York City's 1,250,000 school children and 40,000 teachers will get an extra week of Summer vacation this year. The Board of Education, at its regular meeting yesterday afternoon, voted to close the public schools on June 24 instead of June 30 as originally scheduled.
Contracts for store, office and showroom space in buildings in the midtown section of Manhattan featured business' leases reported yesterday.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Kate Landon Rickey of this city, daughter of Mrs. Walter J. Rickey of Schenectady, N. Y., formerly of Helensburgh, Scotland, and the late Mr. Rickey, to Harold Alvin Ball, also of Boston.
During all the period that both the House and the Senate were framing, debating and passing their respective tax bills, the President gave no public indication of his attitude.

Federal regulation of rates on freight carried on the State Barge Canal was opposed by the Shippers Conference of Greater New York at its monthly meeting yesterday afternoon in the assembly room of the Merchants Association.

9th St, 429 E, 25x92.3; Quentin F. O'Connell to Bernard Janiger and Ida Galler, 222 E 10th St; mtg $2,000 ($3). 84th St, 11 E, 26x102.02; Sands Estate Corp to trustee will of Samuel S. Sands, care U. S. Trust Co; same property, trustee to Katharine S. Havemeyer, Brookville, L. I.; consideration $50,000.

Considerable disappointment was expressed in the cosmetics trade yesterday on the failure of the new tax measure as sent to the House conference committee to reduce or eliminate the 10 per cent levy on toilet goods.

The Financial Employes Organizing Committee of the United Office and Professional Workers of America, a C. I. 0. affiliate, will hold a conference at 11 o'clock this morning with E. A. Pierce, president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, to discuss unemployment in Wall Street, according to an announcement last night by the union.

On behalf of the New York Stock Exchange, the responsibility for continuing Richard Whitney in business four months after his solvency was brought into question was declared to the Securities and Exchange Commission here today to rest on his brother, George Whitney; a partner of J. P. Morgan Co.

Two hundred shop stewards of the Hotel Service Employes Union, Local 32-A, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, voted last night to call a strike today of service employes in resident clubs and furnished-room establishments operated by members of the Resident Club Owners Association, Incorporated.

Retracing at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday the halfcentury that he has spent with American Radiator or its predecessor companies, Clarence Woolley, chairman of the board, said that "a sound understanding of business problems as the result of actual knowledge on the part of our political leaders would remove suspicion and prejudice."

Evidence that the blood volume in all-individuals increases by 30 per cent in the Spring above its total volume in the Fall and Winter months was presented last night at the Spring meeting of the Eastern Section of the American Congress of Physical Therapy, it Mount Sinai Hospital, by Professor H. C. Bazett. of the- University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine.

The continued heavy expenditures for relief which have resulted in a diversion of a large part of the national income "to unproductive uses" constituted "a threat to all employment and may seriously impair the standard of living of all American families,

The initial successes of the Daladier government in France in obtaining from Parliament authority to govern by decree for the next three months and in settling the threatened strikes yesterday evoked a strong return flow of capital to France.

The Citizens Budget Commission yesterday urged Mayor La Guardia to veto, "as a matter of urgent publie necessity," the Nugent bill providing a five-day week for all city employes except teachers and members of the uniformed services that was adopted by an overwhelming vote of the City Council on Tuesday.

Mrs. Gustavus T. Kirby, president of the Daughters of the Cincinnati, entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Tapestry Room of the Ritz Tower for Miss Ruth Lawrence and Mrs. Russell Evans Tucker, past presidents of the society.

Workmen on a WPA highway project completed last night the installation of an iron fence, about four feet six inches high, in the center of the roadway. along Times Square. The fence is in three sections, running for a short space south of Forty-fourth Street, and between Forty-fourth and Fortyfifth, and Forty-fifth and Fortysixth Streets.

Warning labor that it must comply scrupulously with its contracts as the price for enforcing its own rights in the courts, Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook directed yesterday that Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs arbitrate

An assertion that the Republican party had gone into a "court of moral and political bankruptcy and applied for a receiver" was made by James A. Farley, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, in a radio address tonight over the Columbia Broadcasting System. Glenn Frank, he added, is the receiver but has found "nothing to receive."
Philip N. Youtz, director of the Brooklyn Museum for the last four years, resigned yesterday to take a position as consultant with the Golden Gate International Exposition in San Francisco.

Amid the ballyhoo the press is making to popularize Chancellor Hitler's approaching visit the Pope today struck a chilling note in a brief address he delivered to a group of Austrian Catholic students from Innsbruck.

Restoration of business confidence through creation by the Federal Government of cooperative relations with business was called for today at the annual Spring meeting of the executive council of the American Bankers Association in a report of the association's economic policy commission which was adopted by the council.
Reports received by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York from commercial paper dealers show a total of $296,600,000 of open market paper outstanding on March 31, the Reserve Bank announced yesterday.

HE is 60 years old, 5 feet 10 inches tall, partially bald, weighs 228 pounds and still looks fit enough, as they say up Dutchess County way, "to bunt a bull off'n a bridge," which should be enough to give the younger generation some idea of what George Hackenschmidt, the old Russian Lion, must have been in his day.

Marking the conclusion of "Colonial Week," demonstrations arranged by the Colonial and Maritime League occurred today throughout the country. Poland's claim to colonies and access to raw materials was reaffirmed and resolutions were voted "to make Poland's voice demanding colonies heard by all possessing them."

Archduke Albrecht himself confirmed rumors' of his forthcoming marriage today when he announced that he had visited Regent Nicholas Horthy several days ago for the purpose of announcing his intention to marry 22-year-old Kathlein Bocskai, former school teacher, in compliance with Hungarian law.

A new conflict between President Roosevelt and Congress, which may rival the struggle over the Reorganization Bill on which the President met defeat in the House, was forecast by some observers tonight as the tax bill leaders in the Senate instantly revolted against a request made today by Mr. Roosevelt that...

Alonzo J. Powers 2d, 30 years old, of 1,125 Park Avenue, who was committed to the Tombs on Tuesday on an indictment involving thefts of more than $3,271 at the Arbor Inn Club of Princeton University, of which he was graduate treasurer, pleaded not guilty in Special Sessions yesterday to the charge of having jumped a bill of $91.83 at the Roosevelt Hotel on Jan. 26.

Army circles report that a court of honor, composed of Field Marshal Hermann Goering, presiding, and Generals Walther von Brauchitsch and Wilhelm Keitel, completely exonerated Col. Gen. Werner von Fritsch of anonymous aspersions assailing his character.

Payroll taxes on employers brought more money into the State unemployment insurance fund in the first two months of benefit payments than went out in checks to the unemployed, Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews reported yesterday.

An attempt to extort $100,000 from W. P. Kenney, president of the Great Northern Railroad,'was disclosed today. Threats were reported to have been made to kidnap or kill him or damage railroad property if the money was not paid.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, Announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustment.
Knoxville rallied for two runs in the ninth today to defeat Jersey City of the International League, 3 to 2. Each side collected eight hits.
Traffic on the New York State Barge Canal was tied up in two places in this area tonight as melting snowfilled creeks turned the Genesee River into a turbulent, swiftrunning torrent.
Dr. David James of Belvidere, Ill., rolled into second place in the allevents of the American Bowling Congress today with 1,959 total for the only major change of the day.

Brazilian democracy under President Getulio Vargas has been greatly strengthened by the appointment of Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, former Ambassador to the United States, as Foreign Minister, according to Dr. J. J. Osuna, dean of the College of Education of the University of Puerto Rico, who has just returned from Brazil.

Ten Broeck M. Terhune, 58 years old, the one-time realty man who pleaded guilty recently to thefts of more than $50,000 in gems he obtained on memoranda from several jewelers, was sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday in General Sessions for eighteen months to three years.

The city of Cordoba, Argentina, through its New York representative, has sent a letter to holders of its 7 per cent external bonds due in 1957 urging them to await a plan of readjustment soon to be announced rather than take action requested by a bondholders' committee, which the city may deem hostile.

Nearly 1,200 persons paid visits yesterday to the outdoor show of the Sculptors Guild, which opened on a lot at Park Avenue and Thirtyninth Street on Tuesday. By 4 P. M. 1,183 persons had paid their dimes to enter the show.

Manhattan College seniors, 220 in number, who are largely Democratic in political views, named Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks of New York City, the "outstanding figure in New York City" in the annual senior poll conducted by the editorial board of the yearbook, The Manhattanite. To Franklin D.

Additional paring of RKO's contract list took place today when the studio settled its agreements with Herbert Marshall and Miriam Hopkins. The time element was a factor in each contract and with no stories ready for either star, cancellations were negotiated to allow them to take other assignments, thus freeing the studio from salary commitments.
The five-story studio building containing eleven apartments at 77 Washington Place was sold by the 77 Washington Place Holding Corporation to a client of Alberti Romano, brokers.

Publishers of five newspapers abruptly ended negotiations tonight with the North California Newspaper Guild for a 1938 contract. Negotiators discussed points at issue for several hours when the publishers asked for a caucus.
" That story is like a stage ghost making a second appearance;

Trading in most classes was affected by pre-Easter fast days and generally slow. Kosher business also slowed up in deference to coming Passover holidays. Liberal supplies of country dressed Spring lamb and kid goats are on the market for the Easter holiday and trading in these was fairly active. Beef sold steady, lamb sharply lower.

New Yorkers arriving today from Havre via Southampton on the French liner He de France include Mrs. J. Perry Tiffany, Mr. and Mrs. W. F. H. Whitehouse, Mrs. Lathrop Brown and Albert L. Miller. Others are Colonel Leslie Naftzger, H. R. Bain, Mr. and Mrs. Jules Michel,

Resources of the Norfolk Western Railway's employes' relief fund increased by $178,505 to $3,532,947 in 1937. Employes and members of their families received last year $694,070 in benefits from the fund. Receipts amounted to $872,576.
D. Roditi Sons, European buying organization, will open a Czechoslovak Merchandise Fair at 1,440 Broadway next Mbnday afternoon. The fair will continue to May 29.
American District Telegraph Company and Subsidiaries-For 1937: Net income $1,357,008, after expenses and charges, compared with $1,505,611 in 1936.

James F. Reilly, for thirty-five years associated with the Charles Frohman Company, was named yesterday as executive secretary of the League of New York Theatres, organization of producers and managers. He succeeds the late Dr. Henry Moskowitz, who died in December, 1936.

Silver, furnishings and other property of Mrs. Paul Warburg of this city, Paul Watkins of Winona, Minn., and others brought $10,715 yesterday afternoon at the first of two auction sessions at the ParkeBernet Galleries, Inc.

Charles Wissman, formerly vice president and secretary, has been elected president of the Prudential Savings Bank, Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday by the board of trustees. Mr. Wissman, who has been a trustee of the bank since 1911, will succeed the late Manasseh Miller and will be the institution's fourth president.

Within the last decade all countries have suffered from the devastating effects of an unparalleled depression. Under modern conditions of proximity and interdependence of nations, created through the increasing interchange of goods, services,

Party Spirit, with W. Robertson aboard, captured the sixth race, the feature event of six furlongs for a $1,000 purse at Bay Meadows today. The 5-year-old black gelding covered the distance in 1:11 and paid his backers $7.20, $4.40 and $3.20 across the board. Rock X. returned $4.40 for place and Our Crest $3 for show.

Reginald P. Ray, former banker and civic leader here, who headed a municipal welcoming committee when the King of Siam established a temporary residence in Westchester County several years ago, returned to his home today after serving nine months of a two-year sentence in the Federal penitentiary

Miss Ada M. Schochat, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David W. Schochat, was married to Sigmund J. Cumins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Cumins of the Bronx, yesterday morning at the home of her parents, 778 Riverside Drive,

AbgloAmerican diplomatic discussions are proceeding here and in London concerning the sovereignty of Canton and Enderbury islands in the Central Pacific Ocean, which because of their value as aviation bases and the uncertainty over their discovery and earlier occupation are claimed by both governments.

While Mrs. Adele Rivero, woman champion of the National Chess Federation, had a bye in the sixth round of the women's championship tournament at Rockefeller Center last night, Miss N. May Karff of Boston scored her sixth consecutive victory, thereby assuming the lead for the first time.

Attacking with renewed vigor the Chinese were steadily closing in yesterday from the south, east and west on Japanese forces, said to number more than 10,000, in and around Yihsien, about twenty-five miles northwest of Taierhchwang.

The Act of Congress passed in 1933 and amended in 1935, establishing the Tennessee Valley Authority, directed it to operate dams, reservoirs and streamflow primarily to promote navigation and control floods, but also to generate and sell electrie energy to aid in liquidating the, cost and in maintaining the dams and other projects.

The Navy Department revised today its estimate of the cost of the naval expansion program, raising the figure to more than $1,250,000,000. The revision was based on changes the department has asked the Senate Naval Committee to make in the House bill, which carried authorizations of $1,121,000,000.

The Rev. Dr. Charles N. Curtis, retired Methodist minister, died here last night at the age of 79. A native of Saratoga Springs, N. Y., Mr. Curtis was graduated from Dewey College, Springfield, Mo., and Yale Divinity School. Boston University gave him a Ph.D. degree.

The management of the Boston Maine Railroad does not anticipate receivership in the immediate future, President E. S. French said at the annual meeting today in reply to a stockholder's query. The president added that "it is very difficult to visualize what is going to happen even a month from today."

Professor Johannes W. Thienemann, ornithologist, died in Rossitten, East Prussia, today at the age of 75. He made elaborate studies of bird migration in cooperation with scientists throughout the world.

Finding that it cannot catch up with Germany quickly enough in the race for air supremacy, the British Government announced today that it had decided to make inquiries for military, aircraft across the Atlantic.
Several readers have hastened to point out that there are a good many more young people of high school age studying Greek
United States Ambassador Laurence A. Steinhardt tonight urged that American nations present a united front against Old World "predatory forces" seeking "new or lost fields to conquer."

While one interloper in the Levine kidnapping case was being sentenced in Newark, a fourth youth accused of pretending he was the kidnapper was held in $25,000 bail for attempted extortion yesterday in General Sessions here.

That the first real major test of the utility policy of the Securities and Exchange Commission in its application of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 is in the making and is expected to develop soon was learned yesterday.

After a ten-year silence, "The Merry Wives of Windsor" will be coming back to Broadway this evening, setting up shop at the Empire Theatre, with Estelle Winwood, Effie Shannon, Louis Lytton, Albert Carroll, Horace Sinclair, Joan of Storm,

With one of the finest match games ever shot in a Mason and Dixon amateur golf tournament today, Morton McCarthy of Norfolk, Va., eliminated Charley Sheldon of New York, 5 and 4, and became a favorite to win the title.

LEWIS MUMFORD has always been a bold writer and a difficult one, and his latest book, "The Culture of Cities,"* displays his qualities in high relief. Like "Technics and Civilization" (to which, indeed, it is complementary),

Application will be made to the Securities and Exchange Commission by the New York Stock Exchange for permission to strike from listing and registration the common stock of the Pierce Oil Corporation, which has been suspended from dealings since Feb. 19, 1936.

Reports of a mysterious visitation of a flotilla of twenty-two foreign destroyers, possibly Japanese, in the vicinity of Davao Gulf, in the southern Philippines; have occasioned an army and navy investigation.

Operations of the Glenn L. Martin Company of Baltimore in the first quarter of this year resulted in a net income, after all expenses, taxes and other charges, of $628,563, equal to 72 cents a share on the outstanding common stock. In the March quarter of last year the company earned $339,469, or 40 cents each on 858,458 shares then outstanding.
Differences between New York and foreign markets continued to favor straddle interests, and further moderate profit-taking caused prices on the-Cotton Exchange here to ease 5 to 6 points yesterday.

The gravest concern has been aroused throughout Denmark by an incident today during the Folketing's final sitting when a man rose in the visitors' gallery and fired two blanks at K. K. Steincke, Minister of Justice. Simultaneously pamphlets ridiculing the parliamentary system were showered down from the gallery on to the floor of the house.

One of Rembrandt's most famous etchings, "Christ Crucified Between Two Thieves" or "The Three Crosses," brought $2,850 last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries at the auction of etchings and engravings from the collections of Mrs. Robert Scoville of this city, the late John H. Wrenn of Chicago, Clifford Wallace of Philadelphia and others. The first session of the auction yielded $18,772.50.

Lawrenceville's nine was defeated by a hard-hitting Wardlaw team today, 6-2. The visitors garnered four runs in the first inning and two in the fourth. Perkins stopped a rally of the Laurentians, after two runs were scored in the sixth, by fanning two batters.
Transfer of the regular New York Curb Exchange membership of Seymour Blauner to John Granbery of Granbery, Marache Lord, and that of Eugene A. Hoffman to Charles M. Newman were approved yesterday.
Bill Stewart, the "Little General," who led his Chicago Black Hawks to the world hockey championship, will be off to the wars in another field of sports tomorrow.
An aluminum turtle-shaped automobile with an estimated speed of 400 miles per hour will attempt to establish a new land speed record on the salt flats at Bonneville, Utah, in August.

Charging that "a centralized Mafia of terrorists," consisting of agents of the Soviet "GPU" has been at work in various countries killing and kidnapping active opponents of the Stalin regime, Leon Trotsky has addressed a letter to the juridical section of the secretariat of the League of Nations demanding that the League investigate terrorist activities and offering to appear with "irrefutable proofs" as a witness in such an investigation.

After eighteen hours' deliberation, a jury this morning returned a ver dict for $22,000 in a property condemnation case contested by the Port of New York Authority. The case, heard in Circuit Court before Judge Thomas H. Brown, involved Mrs. Anna Bofird of 325 Thirty-second Street, Union City.

It was officially announced today that Germany would increase her imports from Bulgaria, which in 1937 were almost 50 per cent of this country's foreign trade. In this connection a bill will be introduced to prevent small companies and individual merchants from exporting to Germany unless they can guarantee to fill the German order completely.

Hope for a favorable settlement of the Nicaraguan-Honduran boundary dispute has increased considerably throughout Central America since Cordell Hull, United States Secretary of State, referred to the work of the Mediation Commission in his Pan-American Day speech.

Germany is said to be purchasing less cotton here in order to force Brazil to buy more German products. This technique worked in 1934, when Germany demanded Brazil grant her exchange contracts on long terms. that gave her advantages over other countries.

The State Board of Mediation intervened yesterday in an effort to avert the threatened strike of ambulance drivers in twenty-six private hospitals in this city, set to go into effect Saturday morning.

Norma de Marco, 26 years old, who had been questioned as a witness concerning the shooting of a patrolman during a hold-up Tuesday in the Howdy Club at 47 West Third Street, was found dead shortly before last midnight in the rear yard of 138 West Fifty-eighth Street.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has sold the four fourstory apartment and stores buildings at 2,026-40 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, to investing clients of Hy and D. Agar, Inc., brokers in the transaction.
Salaries paid to employes of the New York Stock Exchange will be cut 5 to 12 per cent, effective with the commencement of the pay period nearest April 16, the governing committee decided yesterday.

Retail prices in March declined 0.7 per cent from February and 4.1 per cent from March, 1937, according to the Fairchild Publications retail price index, issued yesterday. The index, at 90.6, was at the lowest point since November, 1936. March prices were only 3.1 per cent above the 1936 low, it was reported.

Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told the House banking committee today a further desterilization of gold would be psychologically inflationary. He discussed general monetary policies at a hearing on a bill for government ownership of the Federal Reserve Banks.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Henderson gave a tea today at Land's End in honor of Mrs. John Elliott. Other guests included Mr. and Mrs. Alfred B. Smith and their granddaughter, Miss Elizabeth Smith; Mr. and Mrs. Jules Vatable, Mr. and Mrs. Louis G. Kaufman, Prince and Princess Balthasar Odescalchi, and Mr. and Mrs. Chester Milton Williams.
BERLIOZ, by J. H. Elliot. (Dutton, $2.) A volume in the Dutton Master Musicians Series. THE CULTURE OF CITES, by Lewis Mumford. (Harcourt, Brace, $5.) A historical and critical study of architecture.
The Yankees' winning streak soared to six straight at the expense of their Class A Binghamton farm club today without any great manifestation of hitting power.

For all the talk of resort to inflationary measures to pull the nation out of the depression, the stock market gave little or no response yesterday to the idea. Industrial stocks gained irregularly, while rail shares, led by Santa Fe issues, were mostly lower.
A street campaign to raise $20,000 to buy a ton of quinine for Chinese civilians suffering with malaria will be started today by more than 100 Chinese students from leading Eastern universities.

President Roosevelt sent to conferees on the Tax Bill a letter urging retention of the undistributed profits tax and the graduated capital gains levy. He completed draft of his recovery program and Fead it to Congressional leaders.
Tropical Oil Company workers, still on strike yesterday, were advised to return to work after a conference between the Minister of Industries, company officials and union representatives.

Not the least significant part of the impending Anglo-Italian agreement will be Italy's recognition of the vast British protectorate stretching for 600 miles northeastward from Aden along the southern shore of Arabia.

The State government has refused the request of the German Consul General, Dr. Asmis, that the film, "Inside Germany," in the "March of Time" series, at present being shown here, be suppressed. Dr. Asmis protested on the ground that the film's commentary is unfriendly to Germany.

The New York State Mediation Board went to the circus last night and as a result there will be "business as usual" at the Ringling Brothers Barnum Bailey show in the Madison Square Garden today, because the strike of at least 200 non-performing employes was settled at 1:45 o'clock this morning.

A number of residential properties in Queens figured in the realty transactions reported yesterday. The six-story apartment house at 139-29 Thirty-fourth Road, Flushing, was sold by the East New York Savings Bank to an investing syndicate headed by Abraham Meitin.

With the arrest today of three men. accused of stripping copper leaders and gutters from new houses, police said they had uncovered a new racket in the scrap metal business. About a ton of copper had been stolen from houses in isolated parts of Harrison.

A life trust for Katherine J. Molitor of 148 East Forty-eighth Street, New York, widow of Colonel Molitor, civil and military engineer, who was a resident of Stamford, is created by his will filed for probate today. She is to receive $3,000 on taking charge of the estate.
The Giants, it seems, still retain that happy faculty of righting themselves when things look darkest.
Mrs. Martha Otis Munroe, widow of George Peabody Munroe of the Paris banking house of Munroe Co., died yesterday at her home in his Paris, according to word received of t here last night.

Oppenheim Collins, which now oprates stores in New York, Brooklyn, Buffalo and Philadelphia, will open a Garden City store at Franklin and Stewart Avenues, late in May, it was announced yesterday. Specializing in women's, misses' and juniors' apparel and access sories, the Garden City store will emphasize sports and country life clothes.

C. E. Adams, chairman of the Air Reduction Company, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that earnings for the first two months of 1938 declined 59 1/2 per cent from the 1937 period, while sales were off 28.8 per cent. Payroll for wage-earners in February was 23.8 per cent above last year, while the number of workers was 23.6 per cent lower, it said. On April 1,- salaries were cut 10 per cent.

Fed steers and yearlings sold strong today, with some sales 10-15c higher, moving prices back to late last week. The trade on lightweight steers, yearlings and heifers was active and most sales were at the high point of the season.

President Roosevelt will disclose to Congress and the country tomorrow his plans for breaking the present recession which, as outlined to Congressional leaders tonight, would involve the outlay of more than $4,000,000,000 in Federal funds for recovery and relief.

Gilbert S. Graves Jr, in 67 Park Ave: Paul Herold, Dr. Benjamin Price Riley, in 26 E 35th St; Ruth C. Reiner, in 150 E 53d St; Mrs. May Kennelly, in 751 3d Ave; Morris Levy, in 65 Central Park West; Potter, Hamilton Co, Inc, brokers.

The Associated Hospital Service of New York, which started less than three years ago with a fund of $30,000, today has assets of $1,968,903, is paying hospital bills at the rate of $350,000 a month and has hospitalized more than 65,000 persons. There are 660,000 subscribers of the 3-cents-a-day plan at present.

Edmund Van Dyke Cox, who was secretary of the New York Stock Exchange from 1919 to 1928, died yesterday at his home in Old Saybrook, Conn., according to word received here by his son, E. Van D. Cox Jr. Mr. Cox, who was in his seventy-sixth year, had been ill for several months.

More than $51,000 has been contributed to the Citizens Committee for Planned Parenthood in its campaign to raise $263,990 for the "democratizing" of birth control, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. William C. Potter, chairman of the committee.
His early training as a "Death Avenue jockey" served Detective Frank X. McFarland well yesterday morning, when he halted a runaway horse with considerable daring. He was slightly injured.
Wage scales for many classes of skilled workers will move sharply upward on city contracts under wage-rate schedules made public yesterday by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick.
Part 2 of the library of the late Cortlandt F. Bishop is to be sold at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries on April 25, 26 and 27, the galleries announced yesterday.

The Hoboken Bank for Savings has sold to the Erco Realty Corporation for investment the apartments at 749-51 Bergenline Avenue, West New York, N. J., through the Joseph J. Garibaldi Organization, brokers.

Governor Lehman has accepted an invitation to discuss State finances at a luncheon to be given at the Hotel Pennsylvania next Thursday by the members' council of the Merchants Association of New York, it was announced yesterday by Louis K. Comstock, president of the association. The Governor's speech will he broadcast.

A suit brought by three minority stockholders of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation to enjoin all stockholders from voting on a proposal to rescind a management stock ownership plan established in 1930 was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer.
Bobby Riggs of Chicago, the nation's second-ranked player, won the Atlanta invitation tennis tournament tonight by defeating David Jones of Atlanta, 6-3, 2-5, 6-4, 8-6.

The wellknown "non-Aryan" banking firm of Aarons Brothers announced its retirement from active business today. Its accounts and deposits will be taken over by the newly organized German Security and Discount Bank.
Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh is negotiating for the purchase of Illiec Island off the coast of Brittany, according to a special dispatch printed in the Paris Soir.

Several plans for safeguarding of investors are being considered by an informal committee of the New York Stock Exchange, headed by Phillip W. Russell of Fenner Beane. Under discussion is a plan for setting up a fund to guarantee brokerage accounts against failure of a firm.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "The Carolingian Period: Minor Arts," Harry D. M. Grier, 11 A. M.; Egyptian collection (general tour), 2 P.M. Luncheon, Bond Club of New York, at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway, 12:15 P. M. Address by Dr. Glenn Frank.
Winston Guest's Optimists from New York rolled over the Detroit Gold Hats, 16 to 6, tonight in the first game of their two out of three series for the national senior indoor polo title.
French Defense Adopted

The American Safety Razor Company will introduce its new Gemlectric Shaver on July 1 and, while no final decision has been reached on price, the initial range will be $15, the company made known yesterday. Advertising plans have not been determined as yet, nor has an agency been selected. In its regular safety razor advertising the company uses both newspapers and magazines extensively.
The market for railroad bonds was shaken yesterday by the announcement late on Tuesday of the

National Bond and Investment No Company has reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that, as of Dec. 31, Melville N. Rothschild, its president and treasurer, owned 50.87 per cent, or 311,680 shares, of its common stock.

The right of Mayor Clyde Potts of Morristown to veto the appointment of a town counsel by the Board of Aldermen was upheld today in a decision by Supreme Court Justice Thomas W. Trenchard. Mayor Potts refused to approve the appointment on Jan. 1, 1937, of C. Franklin Wilson as counsel for a five-year term.

The first open show of strength of the C. I. O. civil service employes' union was made last night when more than 2,500 city, State and county employes rallied at the Royal Windsor Palace, 69 West Sixty-sixth Street, to roar defiance at "clubhouse politicians" and to "demand from Mayor La Guardia legislation for collective bargaining."

To succeed George Blumenthal as president of the board of trustees of the Mount Sinai Hospital is itself an honor-but a difficult honor. This Leo Arnstein knows better than any one else, for he has been for many years at President Blumenthal's side-and for most of them as first vice president, often acting president and back of that the secretary of the board.

For the first time in sixty years Mrs. Lydia O. Stevens of Wellesley, Mass., visited New York yesterday. She arrived in spectacular style by plane, did the sights with celerity and was flying home again, a little out of breath, after five hours.

The American Newspaper Guild was condemned as having fallen into the hands of a belligerent leadership, blind to economic realities, and was defended as having won more real gains for newspaper men and women than could have been achieved except through a policy of force, in a debate last night at the Hotel Astor.

Louis Valentine of the SalemCrescent Athletic Club gained the final of the 118-pound senior division by defeating James Kemp of the Municipal Playground A. A. at the Metropolitan A. A. U. boxing championships at Ridgewood Grove, Brooklyn, last night.

Daily average sales of general merchandise in small towns and rural areas in March increased about 9 per cent from February, but were 15 per cent below March, 1937, sales,. the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce announced today.

Hard aground on a rocky ledge on the southern side of Fishers Island, at the outer end of Long Island Sound, the freighter City of St. Louis remained helpless last night with a Coast Guard cutter standing by in case of need.

Mrs. Susanne Watson Ward, Vice President General of the National Society of Daughters of the American Revolution, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital at the age of 63. She was the widow of William J. Ward, head of a New York wholesale jewelry firm.

Grey Owl, Indian naturalist and campaigner for animal conservation, died today in Prince Albert Hospital. He believed he was 48 or 49 years old. He first launched his conservation work seriously in Riding Mountain National Park, 180 miles northwest of Winnipeg, after spending his early life with an Indian band of trappers in Northern Quebec. Struck by wanton destruction of fur-bearing animals, Grey Owl turned to their protection.

The stock market here was well supported tolay and most sections advanced. Gilt-edge issues showed little change, but among the foreign bonds German and French loans were strong. Transatlantic stocks had a good day; International Nickel went ahead.

A protective committee has been formed to act for the twenty-year 5 per cent debentures, due in 1948, of Reynolds Investing Company, Inc., it was announced yesterday. Members of the committee will include Alexander Biddle, of Dixon CO.,

By a 508-to-12 vote in the Chamber of Deputies and 288-to-1 vote in the Senate Premier Edouard Daladier has been granted power to govern France by decree for the next three months. This is the nearest approach to unanimous parliamentary support that has been given to any French Government in recent years.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 12: COLONEL Capron, W. A., Ord. Dept., two months' leave, May 15, with permission to visit foreign countries. LIEUTENANT COLONELS Gibson, R. T., C.A.C., two months' leave, Sept. 2.

Although held to three hits by Jack Moller, Columbia University ace, Yale, the defending champion, capitalized on eight bases on balls to turn back the Lions, 4 to 3, in the opening game of the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League today.
The Federal Communications Commission rejected today by a vote of 5 to 2 a resolution by Commissioner Payne inviting a Congressional investigation of the commission.
Representative Martin J. Kennedy of New York announced today that he would seek the nomination for Senator if Senator Wagner agreed to head the Democratic State ticket this Fall.
The Senators downed the Bees today, 6 to 5, in a ten-inning exhibi tion game. Trailing, 5-2, in the ninth, Washington tied the score when Travis hit a triple with the bases loaded.

Manhattan College's veteran baseball team took advantage of the wildness of a C. C. N. Y. pitcher to notch its initial victory yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium. A threerun uprising in the eighth clinched the verdict for the Jaspers, 6 to 3.

The Quebec Government has refused to permit the export of pulpwood to foreign lands from Anticosti. This means the end, it is understood, of the efforts of German interests, backed by the German Government, to buy this huge freehold property from the Consolidated Paper Company.

Two United States Ambassadors voiced warnings to Fascist nations yesterday. In Berlin, centre of an effort toward economic self-sufficiency, Ambassador Wilson termed such an effort a "fallacy" and pointed to the American reciprocal trade policy as an aid to peace.

East Fife and Kilmarnock will clash in the Scottish Football Cup final at Hampden Park, Glasgow, on April 23. Thirty-five thousand spectators saw- the Fifeshire squad defeat St. Bernard's, 2 to 1, today in the third semi-final joust between the two second-division teams.

By every recognizable sign, there is more interest in what the President will say to Congress and to the radio audience tomorrow than in any words of his since the "emergency broadcast" of March 5, 1933.
Prince Bernhard is still abroad after a fortnight's absence from The Netherlands. It is said he will spend Easter in Rome, remaining in Italy for some time before returning to this country.

Governor Lehman today signed the Minkoff bill which will have the effect of barring increases in rent over the lowest amount paid in any month from Oct. 1 to March 1 in nearly all the 65,000 old law tenements in New York City.

Winthrop Rockefeller, executive vice chairman of the campaign committee of the Greater New York Fund, Inc., 52 Broadway, announced plans yesterday after-noon for a rally and community party in Madison Square Gardon on the night of May 11.

Brig. Gen. Sir William Alexander, the Scottish member of Parliament for Glasgow Central, and Lady Alexander of Marlston House, Newbury, England, gave a reception yesterday in the Basildon Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Princeton's varsity tennis team swept every match in straight sets to blank Rutgers, 9-0, in the season's opener for both teams on the Church courts today. Sydney Schwartz turned in the best performance for the visitors, holding Bill Winslow, Tiger No. 2, to a pair of 8-6 games.

A stockholders' committee, led by three former directors, failed tonight at the annual meeting of the Derby Oil and Refining Corporation to elect an opposition slate of directors. The company owns oil properties in Kansas, Oklahoma and Colorado.

A miracle was needed to change maritime and mercantile Haifa into a haven of musical worship, and Arturo Toscanini wrought this wonder today. Since morning trains, cars, and buses had been bringing music lovers from all cities and Jewish

By order of Supreme Court Justice Ralph W. E. Donges, who acted at the municipality's request, the State Municipal- Finance Commission assumed charge today of the fiscal affairs of Voorhees Township, Camden, County.
President Alberto Enriquez today appointed six army officers and one civilian to his new Cabinet and designated Commander Jorge Quintana, former Minister of Government, as military attache to Rome.

Tomorrow will be a big day for the trout fishermen in New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania, and also for thousands of New Yorkers who make annual pilgrimages to favorite streams in these three States.

Officials and zoning experts representing eight civic and trade associations whose activities take in the Manhattan district immediately below Thirty-fourth Street will meet next Tuesday in the Aldine Club to pass on the plan to rezone about 400 blocks in that section, including Greenwich Village.
Joe DiMaggio, the eminent San Francisco restaurant proprietor and baseball "no" man, got set for a first-class holdout siege today.
A contra-seasonal rise in electricpower output last week advanced the adjusted index to 92.9 from 91.5. The figure was 107.3 for the week ended April 10, 1937.

Demitrios Finale of 9,917 Shore Road, Brooklyn, honorary president of St. Constantine Greek Orthodox Church, the first Greek Orthodox Church in Brooklyn, and a leader in Greek-American communal activities, died of a heart ailment on Tuesday in the New York Hospital. He was 59 years old.

With more than 3,000 specimens of birds, small mammalian life, reptiles and plants in their collection, an expedition to "no man's land" in the interior of Venezuela has returned. Discovery of a waterfall 1,500 feet high was an incident of the exploration.

The Senate granted full financial powers to the government today by a vote of 288 to 1 and Parliament then adjourned until May 31. Premier Edouard Daladier thus has six weeks in which to work unhampered for the rehabilitation of the nation's finances.

Only foreigners of certain callings will be allowed to establish permanently in Chilean territory in the future if regulations drawn up by the Consular Department of the Foreign Office today are confirmed.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, City Controller, announced yesterday the allotment of an issue of $7,500,000 of special revenue bills of New York City at 0.50 per cent. The bills were allotted to twenty-six banks and trust companies and represent the usual tax anticipation borrowing. The bills are to be dated April 14, and will become payable on July 25, 1938. Payment will be made out of the proceeds of emergency taxes.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild will hold its annual meeting Tuesday afternoon in the ballroom of the Hotel Pierre, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. August Belmont, chairman of the guild. Edward Johnson, manager of the Metropolitan Opera, will speak of the company's recently completed tour.

The Plimpton Library of more than 20,000 rare books and manuscripts used by scholars of the last seven centuries, tracing the development of subjects now taught in of schools and universities, was opened to modern scholars yesterday afternoon by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, at a ceremony in Columbia's Low Memorial Iibrary.

An upset marred the smooth sailing of the North and South amateur tennis tournament today when Frank Farrell, ranked sixth on the University of North Carolina team, defeated George Dunn of Philadelphia, 6-3, 2-6, 6-2.

King Carol paid a surprise visit today to Oradea Mare, on the Hungarian border. He visited the offices of the prefect and military commander, inspecting official documents and the activities of civil servants.

Not since the Museum of Modern Art put on its housing exhibition several years ago have the evils of slum and tenement received such grim and graphic treatment as in the current show, called "Roofs for 40,000,000," presented by An American Group, Inc., and current the rest of the month at the Maison Francaise in Rockefeller Center.

ANDERSON, JOHN (May 1, 1933). Gross assets. $10,822; net, $7,289. To wife, Emma O. Anderson, and sons, John A. and Harry W. Anderson, one-third of residuary estate each. Chief assets, real estate, $3,554; stocks and bonds, $1,800; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $5,367; miscellaneous property, $100. Joseph J Robinson, attorney, 186 Front St., Manhattan.
