In a photo finish so close that many expected the dead-heat sign to be flashed, W. L. Brann's Challephen, a 27-to-1 shot, got up on the outside to nose out John A. Manfuso's Aneroid, conqueror of Seabiscuit last Winter, in the $5,000 added Southern Maryland handicap today.
The Senate Claims Committee decided today that the government owes $450 to Richard D. Krenix of Graham, Wash., because only twenty of his setting of 250 turkey eggs hatched out in 1936.

An entertainment entitled "An Afternoon in Old China" will be presented on April 27 at the Cosmopolitan Club in behalf of the Art Workers Club for Women, an organization providing women artists and models with opportunities for association and mutual benefit.

Feodor Chaliapin, who died last Tuesday in Paris, would have been an actor of world-wide reputation if he had been unable to sing, and a singer of international fame without his extraordinary gifts as a dramatic interpreter. He linked together, as few singers of any era, the potencies of drama and song.
Duke University's golfers, Southern Conference champions for the past three years, defeated the University of Pennsylvania team in a six-man match today, 191/2 to 71/2.
Sixto Escobar, world featherweight champion, is to have a park and stadium named for him, according to a measure sponsored by Senate President Martinez Nadal and passed by both houses.

Federal Judge William Clark refused today to disqualify himself from presiding at a hearing, scheduled for tomorrow, on the request of Brooklyn Federal authorities for the removal of Ellis H. Parker and his son, Ellis Jr.,

Max D. Steuer, lawyer, was appointed chairman of the Greater New York Campaign of the American ORT Federation, it was announced yesterday by B. Charney Vladeck, president of the federation. The announcement said Mr. Steuer would be in charge of a large group of men and women,

Within thirty days more than 200 union publications reaching members of the American Federation of Labor throughout the United States will serve as a medium through which Build America Inc. will conduct a survey to determine the market for new homes.

Fenton Ave (16-4476), w s, 577 ft s of Allerton Ave, 53x100; Crown Builders, Inc, to Bankers Federal Savings and Loan Association; due as per bond; $11,200. Fenton Ave (16-4476), w s, 377 ft s of Allerton Ave, 90X100; Brim Ideal Homes, Inc, to Bankers Federal Savings and Loan Association; due as per bond; $19,800.

Following is the text of the Mexican Government's note of yesterday to the British Government explaining Mexico's reasons for refusing to restore the British-owned petroleum properties as requested in the British note of last Friday.

Macmillan reports that the demand for "Macmillan's Modern Dictionary," published two weeks ago, was so great that a third printing was ordered before the second printing could be completed and delivered.

The world's seven great navies may now include about 715 submarines, a number far greater than the undersea flotillas which almost won the World War for Germany. This estimate of submarine forces was included in a general summary of naval strengths just compiled here from data in various countries.

Miss Ruth Anne Rensenhouse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Proctor D. Rensenhouse of this place, was married this afternoon to Clement Bower Haines of Atlanta, Ga.; and her sister, Miss Jean Rensenhouse, became the bride of Harry Diman Jr. of Portland,

Several developments indicating that the business recession showed definite signs of slackening in the first quarter of the current year are included in the Department of Commerce's Survey of Current Business, an advance announcement of which was made public today.

Division 5 of the Interstate Commerce Commission ordered today an investigation of trucking rates in the New England territory, including New York City and large parts of the States of New York and New Jersey.

Plans for the second annual military ball and massing of colors to be given by the Newsdealers Post, 1169, of the American Legion at the Hotel Center on April 23 were announced yesterday by Louis Sorrow, general chairman.

President Roosevelt took the final step toward opening up a new field of government credit operations today when he signed the bill allowing the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to make loans to business and industry.
The Manhattan College football squad ended six weeks of Spring practice with a one-hour scrimmage against City College yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Both teams used their reserves.

Limiting the opposition to one hit and striking out eleven men, John McDermott twirled St. John's Prep to a 5-1 triumph over Bishop Loughlin Memorial High in the opening Brooklyn C. H. S. A. A. contest of the season for both schools at the Parade Grounds yesterday.

With real Spring weather bringing out the faint green of the trees along the banks of the Schuylkill, Rusty Callow worked his University of Pennsylvania crews up along the shallow race course this afternoon and finished the day still with the final line-ups of the eights uncertain.

Estate, more than $20,000. To Leonora Baum, widow, executrix. 160 Central Park West, $200 per month and interest in residue; Sadie Mayer, sister, estate of brother, Aaron K. Baum, and estate of sister, Jennie Bernstein. residuary interests.

Rudolph J. Goerke, former president of City Stores, Inc., operator of a chain of department stores in the Southern States, died here today in his home after a short illness following a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 71 years old.

A considerable volume of fill-ins has been sought by retailers in the local coat market as mild weather has continued to aid retail turnover this week. Buyers from local stores yesterday sought fair quantities of garments for spot delivery to round out stocks.

A. I. Namm Son, in the annual report for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 29, report net sales of $9,632,027, a decrease of $138,921, or 1.4 per cent, from the preceding year. Net profit, however, was $154,405, compared with $65,502 in the year before, after taxes, depreciation and interest in each case.

Marcella Geon will give a lecturerecital on "Tristan und Isolde" tonight in-her studio at the Sherman Square Studios. A free program of Schumann's music will be heard tonight at the Music-Art Center, 1 West 123d Street. under the auspices of the Federal Music Project.

The fourth annual Tip Top Ball under the auspices of Auxiliary No. 5 of Stony Wold Sanatorium will be held on May 6 in the ballroom of the Plaza. The proceeds of the benefit will be used in the work of the organization, which was founded in 1901 by Mrs. James E.

FRANK BERTOLINO. bail bond agent, 230 Sullivan St.-Liabilities, 3,898; assets, $1.76. FLOYD M. CARDONA, building contractor, 220 Purchase St., Rye-Liabilities, $9,057; no assets. FRANK S. CUMMINGS, accountant, 125 Elliott Ave., Yonkers--Liabilities, $2,391; no assets.
Careful arrangements for Kuomintang domination of the new People's Political Council have been revealed in the organic law of that organization promulgated by the National Government at Chungking.

Suspended from dealings on the New York Stock Exchange on March 12 owing to technical questions, eight fully registered Erie Railroad bond issues will be restored to trading tomorrow. They are the first consolidated 4s of 1996, the general lien 4s of 1996, the convertible Series B and D 4s of 1953, the refunding and improvement 5s of 1967 and 1975, the Erie Jersey 6s of 1955 and the Genesee River 6s of 1957.
The Foreign Office denies reports that Japan has asked Britain to mediate. Observers here feel no hesitation in accepting the official denial.

A window depicting an angelic choir will be unveiled on Easter after the 9 A. M. service in St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. The window is the gift of Henry E. Felton in memory of his cousin, Anna M. Stiles.

John Clark Wood, executive vice president and director of publicity for B. Altman Co., described the intricacies of balancing the advertising budget for a large department store in a talk last night before 300 persons attending the advertising course sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES at The Times Annex. 229 West Forty-third Street.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: WOne of the things which makes the administration of relief so difficult is that so many intelligent people do not understand how it is being administered and do not take the time to find out, but constantly make statements which have little or no foundation in fact.

With real Spring weather bringing out the faint green of the trees along the banks of the Schuylkill, Rusty Callow worked his University of Pennsylvania crews up along the shallow race course this afternoon and finished the day still with the final line-ups of the eights uncertain.

Estate, more than $20,000. To Leonora Baum, widow, executrix. 160 Central Park West, $200 per month and interest in residue; Sadie Mayer, sister, estate of brother, Aaron K. Baum, and estate of sister, Jennie Bernstein. residuary interests.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,213,000 bales, against 1,190,000 a week ago, 1,203,000 two weekss ago, 1,203,000 three weeks ago and 994,000 a year ago; of which American 815,000 bales, against 794,000 a week ago, 797,000 two weeks ago, 794,000 three weeks ago and 438,000 a year ago.

Richard Whitney learned today that, for a man of his former position, obscurity cannot be achieved even in a prison. Convicts stepped aside to let him pass in the yard, some of them raising their caps in deferential, silent homage.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson charged today that efforts had been made to persuade him to sign the new city gas works lease in return for personal immunity from any action of the special October grand jury, which for six months has been investigatingtvice and crime in Philadelphia.

A RETURNED traveler, just off the boat, stood up at a luncheon at the New York A. C. yesterday and gave an account of his invasion of Egypt and his trip on the Nile. The sunburnt traveler, a symphony in brown-brown hair, brown suit, brown shirt, brown shoes-was Avery Brundage, member of the International Olympic Committee and president of the American Olympic Association.

The Pennsylvania Railroad will begin electrified freight service tomorrow on its through east and west freight routes between New York and Harrisburg, as well as between Harrisburg and Perryville, Md., where newly electrified rails meet those electrified earlier to Baltimore and Washington.
The Jewish Advocate, in an open "Easter Message" to Pope Pius XI, tonight suggested that Jews and Catholics "pool our- strength" against the "foes of our civilization."
Word was received here of the death today in Afton, N. Y., of John Hoffman, for many years a prominent figure in Suffolk County politics. He was 75 years old.

A collection of beach and sports apparel and accessories whose design were inspired by the gay motifs with which Adriatic fishermen decorate their small boats was presented yesterday under the sponsorship of Allied Stores Purchasing Corporation, at a fashion show held in the ballroom of the Roma, Pier 92, North River. About 500 retailers and fashion writers attended.

Miss Eugenie Gray Woodruff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Eastman Woodruff, was married to Sayre MacLeod Jr. of this city yesterday afternoon in the apartment of her parents at 829 Park Avenue. The Rev. Lyman Bleecker of St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., performed the ceremony in the presence of members of the two families.

Final contracts for space at the New York World's Fair 1939 have been signed by Eire or Ireland, Venezuela, Lithuania and Sweden, and preliminary- sketches for the Polish Pavilion approved by the fair's board of design, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair CorPoration.

With the strike at the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey circus settled, six white horses tugged Gargantua the gorilla around the arena at Madison Square Garden yesterday, instead of the varied assortment of giants, midgets, clowns and other performers who had been pinch-hitting for the roustabout drivers during the twoday walk-out of non-performing employes.

Mrs. Skinker Matthews is sailing today on a Caribbean cruise and will return early next month. Mr. and Mrs. Bradish G. Johnson, who have been at Hampshire House for several months, sailed yesterday on the Europa for their home in Paris.

Although Queen Elizabeth asked to see Falstaff in love she did not require him to woo in a straw hat nightmare. But that is what he has come to in the Spring of 1938. Taking advantage of Shakespeare's death, Robert Henderson has dumped old tub o' guts into a frantic production of "The Merry Wives of Windsor," which shattered the memories of the Empire Theatre last evening.
The Rev. Dr. Charles Henry Dickinson, clergyman and educator, died here tonight at the home of his son, Sidney E. Dickinson, 85 Washington Avenue, after an illness of six months. He was 80 years old.

Stocks of refined copper on March 31 in the United States, exclusive of consumers' stocks at their plants and warehouses, amounted to 342,785 tons, compared with 326,244 at the close of February, an increase of 16,541, according to the Copper Institute. Blister stocks declined

The House of Representatives passed a bill early today to permit wider and heavier trucks on South Carolina highways after the collapse of a one-man filibuster which kept the body in session all night.

APPLEBY, MATTHEW (Aug. 1). Estate, more than $10,000. To Nellie Lewis. daughter, Cross Rds., Britamer, West Town, Bristol, England, life estate in 25 per cent of residuary income and contingent interest in all of income: Florence May Appleby, widow, executrix, Herald Square Hotel,

James G. McDonald of the editrial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES was elected president of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences at a meeting of the institute's board of trustees yesterday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Lafayette Avenue and Ashland Place, Brooklyn.

Secretary Ickes, as administrator of the Public Works Administration, said today that it would require but a short time to put a new WPA program into operation in the event Congress enacted the relief legislation asked by President-Roosevelt.
The text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress on business and relief aids was as follows: To the Congress of the United States:
The Museum of Modern Art will close its present exhibition of drawings of the war in Spain, by Luis Quintanilla, and of paintings from the museum's own collection, on Monday evening.
Albert Bradley, vice president of General Motors, has purchased the estate of Mrs. Dorothy White on Mayfair Lane, Greenwich. The purchase price was approimately $160,000.

During the week ended April 13 member bank reserve balances increased $176.000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $103,000,000 in Treasury depositg with Federal Reserve Banks, $14,000,000 in money in circulation, $18,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts and $12,000,000 in Treasury cash, and increases of $6,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit and $22,000,000 in gold stock.

Tenants and tenement owners alike are studying with interest the possible effects of the new State law limiting rentals which may be charged in "old law" houses against which building violations are pending. They are watching, however, from opposite sides of the fence.
R. Randolph Johnson, turkey raiser, died yesterday at the Union Memorial Hospital, Baltimore, after an illness of several months. He was 45 years old.

Dr. Isidor Paul Strittmatter, gynecologist and surgeon, died of a heart ailment at his home here this afternoon, less than twenty-four hours after the annual presentation of the gold medal he established as a citation for local doctors for their achievements. He was 77 years old.
A survey of 300 years of American architecture is to be shown in Paris this Summer in an exhibition of American art arranged by the Museum of Modern Art, at the-request of the French Government.

Board of Trade figures for March as follows: Total imports, [pound]84,870,000; exports of British products, [pound]42,150,000; reexports, [pound]5,460,000; total exports, [pound]47,610,000, and excess of imports, [pound]37,260,000.

Mid-April pay checks for thirty-three employes of the marriage license bureaus of the five boroughs, all attaches of the City Clerk's office, were held up yesterday by degree of the Municipal Civil Service Commission.
Shooting par golf, Jack Ryerson of Cooperstown, N. Y., defeated his semi-final opponent, William Shea of Georgetown, today in the Mason and Dixon tournament. 3 and 2.
Alexander McCann, former director of James McCutcheon - Co. and a founder of the Irish Ulster Society, died Wednesday at his home, 410 Riverside Drive, at the age of 69.
William Russell Edson, a vice president of Mack Trucks, Inc., died yesterday at Doctors Hospital, 170 East End Avenue, after an illness of several months. He was 50 years old.

The United States liner Manhattan will arrive today from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh. Those on board include Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Livermore, Miss Mazo de la Roche, Princess Farid Khan Sadri of Iraq, Miss Sally Holmes, Joseph H. P. Martin, Dr. Alex Doysie, Mr. and Mrs. A. W. Atterholt, N. M. Schaum and Louis J. J. Schreiber.

Regardless of a starvation run, fed steers and yearlings sold slowly and barely steady today. Hogs got some action after supplies proved inadequate and prices were generally higher, about 20 cents above the low time at midweek, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

The seven-room private dwelling at 215 Jane Street, Weehawken, N. J., has been sold by the Hudson Trust Company to Elmer F. Ensmann, through J. I. Kislak, Inc., brokers. The new owner plans to modernize the house.

The 1940 Olympic Games, confirmed in their Tokyo site by the International, Olympic Committeeat Cairo in March, still can be held in London, Helsingfors or any other place, it was revealed yesterday by Avery Brundage, president of the American Olympic Committee and a delegate to the I. O. C., upon his return after almost two months abroad.

A total of 232 athletic awards and seven managerial appointments were announced tonight by the Board of Control of the Yale Athletic Association on recommendation of the Undergraduate Athletic Association. Members of Winter sports teams were rewarded for their work and minor Y's went to Eli representatives in outdoor polo durnig the 1937 campaign.

Action by the City Council to make it possible to punish "effectively" those guilty of littering the streets was urged yesterday by the Committee of Twenty on Street and Outdoor Cleanliness. The group suggested an ordinance that might be known as "the small offenses act."

An overflow attendance marked the opening yesterday afternoon of new and larger quarters for the Thrift Shop maintained by the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women at 1,262 Third Avenue.

Michael F. Walsh, widely known in Brooklyn Catholic lay circles, was nominated yesterday by President Roosevelt for the post of United States Attorney in the Eastern District, comprising Brooklyn, Queens, Nassau, Suffolk and Richmond, according to a dispatch from Washington. Mr. Walsh, who was

That the vast Electric Bond and Share Company has bowed to one of the major provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 was revealed yesterday in a letter to shareholders accompanying the quarterly earnings report by C. E. Groesbeck, chairman. He

In a unanimous decision the Appellate Division held yesterday that Councilman John Cashmore, Brooklyn Democrat, had been legally elected vice chairman of the City Council on Jan. 3 for a two-year term and that he could not be unseated until that term expired.

Joe McCarthy left Oriole Park today in quite a different frame of mind from the occasion of his last visit to that ball field. Not since 1925 had the Yankee pilot been in the park that stands as a monument to the late Jack Dunn.
James (Jeff) Burkitt, anti-Hague leader, was informed- tonight that an application to hold a mass meeting Saturday in Journal Square under the auspices of the Longo defense committee had been denied.

Henry R. Tatem, the first elected Mayor of Collingswood, died at his home here today in his seventy-seventh year. Mr. Tatem was the first president of the Collingswood National Bank, was postmaster for ten years and was a member of the New Jersey Legislature in 1909-10. He was Mayor in 1895 and 1896 and for the last thirty years had been engaged in the real estate and insurance business.

The marriage of Miss Beatrice Sulzberger, daughter of Mrs. Leo Sulzberger of this city and the late Mr. Sulzberger, to Dr. Leonard Jay Trilling, son of Mrs. Betty Trilling of Paterson, N. J., took place last evening at the home of the bride's uncle and aunt,

Discovery of a microscopic material which keeps-the human body working by holding each one. of its billions of cells together, was reported today. at the opening session of the semicentenial meeting of the American. Association of Anatomists.
Chinese dispatches from Hankow today told of a purge in the Chinese Army by orders of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

And still they come, the little cinemas, and the latest is the Showshop (formerly the Artef) on West Forty-eighth Street, which begins its career quietly with a slight English children's film, "Emil," based on Eric Kastner's "Emil and the Detectives."

Jim Crowley .permitted only two hits and fanned fourteen in a seveninning stay on the mound as Brooklyn Tech's baseball team shut out the Brooklyn Specialty Trades nine, 8-0, in a nine-inning game at Prospect Park Parade Grounds yesterday.

Once more the Roosevelt Administration has chosen to pour water down the well instead of mending the pump. As a solution for the breakdown of production in this country it proposes to borrow more money and to spend it. By this device it hopes to create additional purchasing power and to increase the nation's wealth.

Charles S. Howard's Seabiscuit, War Admiral's challenger in the $100,000 match race at Belmont Park May 30, will receive preliminary training at Pimlico and may race in the $20,000 Dixie Handicap there May 11.

In response to the request by President Roosevelt that it consider T simplification of regulations to assist and expedite the financing of small business enterprises, the Securities and Exchange Commission is working on a series of suggestions which will be made public soon. Details were with-
Today's major events: "Parsifal," afternoon, Metropolitan Opera House; "Requiem" of Brahms, Federal Opera Chorus and Greenwich Orchestra, Federal Music Theatre, evening.

Prices of commodities moved irregularly last week and The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices rose to 81.1 on Wednesday from 81.0 (revised) a week before. A year ago the index was 94.1.
The bubble of Japanese military efficiency has been pricked by Chinese bayonets, in the opinion of some American army and navy officers here.

The consumption of crude rubber by manufacturers in the United States in March amounted to 30,487 long tons, as compared with 23,868 in February and 54,064 in March, 1937, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association.

Annoyed by the publication of a report recommending that the New York City school. system establish an aviation training unit at North Beach, Queens, three members of the building committee of the Aeronautics Educational Commission, including the chairman of the commission, have resigned.
Conferees on the new revenue bill held their first formal meeting this morning, but in a little more than an hour reached a deadlock on the two main points at issue and adjourned until tomorrow.

Sandy, the once bonny Highlandman who has stood in front of a snuff shop in Division Street for sixty-five years less two days and nights, is home again. Carved in wood in Scotland, seven and a half feet of a man, he was fifteen when the great blizzard came.

The Interstate Commerce Commission, by its Division Four, approved today the method employed by the trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad for segregation of the road's earnings. They use "a constructive mileage block" method, with modifications to meet certain special cases.

" G LASS HOUSES."* by Carleton Beals, is a pretty turbulent book about a pretty turbulent decade. It is a narrative of his adventures between 1917 and 1928 -in Mexico (during a cycle of rebellions), Italy: (when the Blackshirts were smashing their way to power) and Spain (before it had both Blackshirts and rebellion). There is a furious, hot-headed drive to the writing, and it is frank and unafraid.

Dr. F. H. Reichel, vice president in charge of manufacture of the Sylvania Industrial Corporation, has been elected president. Dr. Roger N. Wallach, president since inception of company, has been elected chairman of the board. He will continue to share in the active management of the company.

Senator Burton K. Wheeler, chairman of the Senate's Interstate Commerce Committee, announced today that he would meet with labor executives next Thursday to start work on a legislative program to aid the country's railroads.

A house on Poplar Street, New Milford, Conn., has been sold by Ethel A. Keaveney to Anna May Galvin through the Housatonic Val ley Insurance Agency, which also arranged the sale of the farm property owned by Miss Galvin on Chestnut Lane to Joseph Strelez. The same agency sold for Richard

Brazilian importers and distributors of German-manufactured typewriters, adding machines, calculating machines and other mechanical office equipment, have been informed that effective April 1 prices would be increased 20 per cent, according to a report from Rio de Janeiro made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The Monroe Doctrine was reasserted by President Roosevelt today, on the inter-American basis envisaged at conferences at Montevideo and Buenos Aires, in an address before the governing board of the Pan American Union.

Out of a total of more than two hundred designs received from eighteen States and from Canada, thirteen were selected yesterday for awards in the portable lamp design competition sponsored by the American Institute of Architects, the American Institute of Decorators and the Illuminating Engineering Society.

The official list of the 813 Deputles in the new Reichstag shows that roughly threequarters of them earn their livings either as civil servants or as functionaries or employes of the National Socialist Party.

A policeman broke down the door of a tenement flat at 520 East Thirteenth Street yesterday afternoon and found Mrs. Anna La Russo and her five children unconscious on their bed, with gas escaping from the open jets of the kitchen stove.

Andrew Ponzi captured the seventh and eighth blocks of his twelve-block pocket billiard match with Jimmy Caras yesterday at the Fourteenth Street Academy. In the afternoon Ponzi beat the world champion, 125 to 17, in four innings, making a high run of 64.

Unsettled world conditions have caused Brazil to draft defense plans involving expenditures over a period of years for air, sea and land armaments. She has already placed orders worth several million dollars in the United States for airplanes, in Britain for six destroyers and in Germany, with the Krupp interests, for land weapons, mostly heavy artillery and tanks.
Tradition at Centenary Junior College-alma- mater of Bette Cooper, the "Miss America" who ran out on Atlantic City's parade of pulchritude--is built of aturdy stuff

Ed Fuller of Salem, Mass., a 22-yearold senior at the University of North Carolina, upset J. Gilbert Hall of East Orange, N. J., the defending champion, in the quarterfinals of the North and South amateur tennis tournament today. The score was 1-6, 6-4, 6-4.

Good Friday and also the beginning of the Jewish Passover holidays slowed up yesterday's business and trading was almost at a standstill in most classes. The beef market was steady, lamb weak to sharply lower, other classes steady to weak. There were practically no kosher markets as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

King Carol is manifestly enjoying his new self-imposed task of seeing things for himself. His second day of surprise visits took him to Cluj and Bloestui, where he inspected the local offices of several State departments.
James J. Caffrey, administrator of the Boston office of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was appointed today administrator of the New York regional office to succeed Ernest Angell.

The principal foreign exchanges rose strongly in terms of the dollar yesterday under the combined influence of the inflationary implications of the Federal spending program announced by President Roosevelt and the continued improvement in the French political situation.
Britain and Italy agreed yesterday to the signature of their accord in Rome tomorrow afternoon. The various documents will total about 7,000 words, going to the bottom of all outstanding issues.
The Newark Bears and the Norfolk Pilots, both Yankee chain-store teams, clashed today and the Bears won, 10 to 8, four runs in the seventh turning the tide.

The General Foods Corporation, New York City, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statementcovering the issuance and sale of 150,000 shares of no-par value cumulative preferred stock, the dividend rate
Irene Weiss, a 25-year-old German stenographer, was sentenced tonight to fifteen months in prison for espionage. She was tried at a secret session of the Paris criminal court.

WASHINGTON, April 14.-Switzerland turned a cold shoulder today to the suggestion of the United States that the first meeting of the intergovernmental committee to facilitate the emigration of political refugees from Austria and Germany be held in Switzerland.
Twenty-two scholarships and fellowships totaling $23,700- were awarded today for study and research at the Harvard Law School. The recipients were:

Oscar Lee, warden of the State Penitentiary here since 1924 and one of the outstanding penologists of the nation, died at his home here last night, aged 57 years. He had been in poor health for two years and was granted a six months' leave of absence March 1.

The senior-student at City College School of Business considers- him-: self a liberal, sees no acceptable reason.for a dictatorship and does -not think that President Roosevelt should run for a: third-term, acccording to a poll by Lexicon, senior year book. of the School of Business.

The following Marine Corps changes, dated April 13, were announced today: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Sebree, J. B. ordered to duty as officer in charge Western Recruiting Division, San Francisco, Calif., instead Los Angeles, Calif.

Mrs. Blanche Busey King, ethnologist, of Wickliffe, today reported what she termed "the greatest archaeological copper find ever made in Kentucky and one of the most remarkable ever found in the United States."
Offices of the Hoagland Allum Co., Inc., investment brokers, with offices here and in New York, were raided today by investigators for the blue sky division of the State's Attorney's Office.

The Federal Trade Commission today asserted the right of New York State milk producers to organize as they please by filing a complaint against Gold Medal Farms, Inc., wholesale milk dealers in New York City, charging the company with opposing the affiliation of dairymen in the area of Buskirk, N. Y., with the Metropolitan Cooperative Milk Producers Bargaining Agency, Inc.

Calgary Power Company, Ltd., and Subsidiaries-For 1937: Net income after taxes and charges, $399,576, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $1.13 a common share and comparing with a net of $388,158, or- 80 cents a common share, in 1938.

The imperative need for American Jews to use their resources and influences to break down the barriers that stand in the way of a larger Jewish immigration into Palestine was stressed last night by Louis Lipsky, co-chairman of the United Palestine Appeal.

Business leases reported yesterday included an important rental Farms and in the downtown insurance district where the Hellenic Bank Trust Company took the basement ground floor and second floor in 139 William Street, southeast corner of Fulton Street. The bank was established in 1930 and has been located at 51 Maiden Lane.
The House Interstate Commerce Committee today approved a committee substitute for the Copeland Pure Food and Drug Bill which passed the Senate some time ago.

The Swedish liquidators of Kreuger Toll Company filed on Monday with the City Court of Stockholm, Sweden, a petition for authority to pay an additional liquidation dividend of 10 1/2 per cent on all claims allowed in the Swedish bankruptcy proceedings.

Several sales by banks and the purchase of half interest in on old business building by a well-known Brooklyn family owning the other half of the property indicated a busy day in Brooklyn real estate transactions yesterday.
Dr. Charles P. White of Wilmington, Del., an eye, ear, nose and throat specialist, died last night in the Pennsylvania Hospital here. His age was 66.

Midsummer heat prevailed today as Bowie's twelve-day meeting, hampered in its early stages by cold and rain, came to a close. More than 8,000 fans, including Mayor Howard W. Jackson of Baltimore, were on hand for the getaway program.

Secretary Woodring stated today that 3,150 officers and men and 200 modern fighting planes would take part next month in what officials said would be the air corps' most extensive peacetime manoeuvres.

New York Stock Exchange memberships have been transferred from Edward E. MacCrone to Harold R. Colvin, from the late Charles E. Robertson to George H. Hogle oF J. A. Hogle Co., from Chester A. Braman to Robert F. Meffert; and from William Wallace Lanahan to Paul Victor Mravlag of W. W. Lanahan Co.

Ambassador Hugh R. Wilson's speech outlining Washington's trade and peace policy "contained no indication how the United States envisages solution of the difficulties now existing for German-American:, trade" the Lokalanzeiger declared today.

The dominant position of the Pennsylvania Railroad in New England was continued in 1937, according to the annual report of the Boston Maine Railroad to the Securities and Exchange Commission, made public yesterday. The list of

Trustees in bankruptcy for the Munson Steamship Line were authorized yesterday by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe to sell a vessel and several pieces of property owned by the line to the United Fruit Company for $2,050,000.

Legislation under which a Federal employee would lose his job if he took part in a political convention went down to defeat in the Senate today. The Administration forces, led by Majority Leader Barkley, brought about the rejection of the bill, 38 to 19.

Dr. Ernst F. S. Hanfstaengl, the Harvard graduate who had been the confidant of Chancellor Hitler until last year when he fled from Germany, arrived here quietly last night as a tourist-class passenger on the French liner Ile de France.
T. O. M. Sopwith, twice defeated challenger for the America's Cup, was in the city yesterday on- his way home to England from. his fishing trip in the Pacific on his large motor yacht Philante.

Tenders will be considered next Tuesday by officials of the Salt River Project Agricultural Improvement and Power District, Ariz., for a new issue of $4,135,000 of bonds. The issue will be dated June 1, 1938, and will mature serially from July 1, 1948 to 1964, optional on July 1, 1948. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 5 per cent.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today that inquiries concerning loans to industry totaling about $70,600,000 had been received by the RFC since it was authorized to resume lending on Feb. 18.

Confusion over existing world hurdles records was removed yesterday, The Associated Press reports, when Avery Brundage brought back the complete list of marks approved by the International Amateur Athletic Federation at its Paris congress in February.

An appeal by the American Committee on Maternal Welfare for an unrestricted license to show its edunational film "Birth of a Baby" to general audiences in this State was turned down yesterday by the State Board of Regents.
A strike against half the Canadian vessels on the Great Lakes was threatened tonight on the eve of the opening of navigation.

Music from "Parsifal," given in concert form, constituted the major part of the program given by John Barbirolli and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony last night in Carnegie Hall. The occasion was impressive. Stripped of the panoply of the stage, the music from the Prelude, the Processional of the first act and its closing scene greatly moved the audience.

Intervention by the State Mediation Board brought yesterday an indefinite postponement of the ambulance drivers' strike, originally set for midnight tonight. Fearful that a tie-up of ambulance service in the twenty-six private hospitals, against which the strike threat was directed, might jeopardize efficient service in accident and emergency cases, a committee of hospital superintendents conferred with Arthur S. Meyer and Jules S. Freund of the State board early yesterday at the board's offices, 366 Broadway.

Following similar action recently by the State Public Health Council, the New York City-Department of Health has forbidden the sale or breeding of parrots or parrakeets, including those commonly known as love birds, after-June 1, it was announced yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice. Health Commissioner.
Dr. Harlan S. Miner, for the last forty years chief chemist of the Welsbach Company here, died of a heart attack this afternoon while on a business trip to Bloomfield. He was 73 years of age.

A wages and hours bill following generally the principles urged by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor. was approved late today by the House Labor Committee by a vote of 14 to 4.

Death Announced Retired Fireman Stephen A. Madden. formerly a member of Engine 247, residing at 8 Laurel St., Floral Park, L. I., died April 5. Amendment to Official Action Guide On Page 34-35 of the Official Action Guide, under heading of Fire Alarm Box Report. strike out the words;

Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, who made tennis history in 1935 with a comeback for her seventh Wimbledon title, packed her favorite racquets today to battle for an eighth English championship. She sails from New York Wednesday.

In observance of Good Friday, the principal security and commodity markets throughout the world will be closed today. Although the banks in this city and State and most other States will be open for business as usual, those in a few States where the day is a legal holiday, will be closed. In most instances
Mrs. Minnie Ridgeway Bishop, lecturer, traveler and pioneer advocate of woman suffrage and temperance, died yesterday at her home here at the age of 77.
" Real estate is in a sound position for a major advance," Joseph W. Catherine, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, told realtors here today.

The Budd Wheel Company and the Budd Manufacturing Company plants were closed today after what company officials described as a sitdown strike involving eighty men in one department. About 2,100 employes were left idle.

The rally and community party to be held in Madison Square Garden the night of May 11, sponsored by the Greater New York Fund, was hailed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as an opportunity for New Yorkers to show a neighborly spirit and "give the lie" to those who say "that democracy is synonymous with dissension."

A plan of reorganization of the Nova Scotia Steel and Coal Company, Ltd., was adopted today by holders of first-mortgage bonds of the company, according to F. H. M. Jones, general manager of the Eastern Trust Company, liquidator of Nova Scotia Steel. Meetings of various classes of shareholders had approved the plan previousiy.
Sheriff William M. Eberhardt of Erie County: was indicted by a grand jury today for perjury and subornation of perjury.

After moving the $812,000,000 Agriculture Department's 1939 Supply Bill to a position for passage, the House decided late in the day to postpone final action until the Roads Committee could prepare amendments, including about $101,000,000 additional for the highway program in line with President Roosevelt's recommendation today.
Frederick Urling Smith, former controller of the Armour Institute of Technology, died here last night in his home, where he had lived since his retirement in 1920. He was 92 years old.

Dr. Alexander Goetz of the California Institute of Technology froze yeast cells for a hundred hours at minus 300 degrees F., thawed them out, whereupon they behaved as if nothing had happened to them. This is not astonishing news.

President Roosevelt today struck boldly at the business recession with an emergency program of spending, lending and credit expansion calling for an early Federal outlay which may be $5,000,000,000, but contemplating the eventual addition of less than one-third of that amount to the national debt.

The people of Hawaii'desire a sovereign status in the United States Government because of their financial and industrial contributions and also because of the position the territory occupies as a military and naval outpost, according to Lawrence M. Judd, former Governor of Hawaii.
The Tigers and Reds made thirty-seven hits and sent ten balls out of the park, as Cincinnati won an exhibition game today, 14 to 11. Hank Greenberg led in the homerun division.
Inflation talk and several unfavorable crop reports from Oklahoma and Texas resulted in a rather marked increase in speculative buying of wheat futures on the Board of Trade here today.
In expressing opposition to President Roosevelt's recovery program Senator Byrd asserted that it would create-a deficit of $5,000,000,000 for the 1939 fiscal year alone.
United Automobile Workers officials after an hour's conference with President Roosevelt today said his recovery-relief message was a "saving program" and not a "spending program."

One of the three. remaining probationary schools in the city's educational system will close this Sep tember it was annouced yesterday . A new educational philosophy which treats children in terms of their individual needs. and provides special adjustment and opportunity classes for the problem cases has proved effective in. reducing the number of "bad boys" and truants, according to school officials.
President Roosevelt sent to Congress a message advocating a $5,000,000,000 program designed to increase national income, aid business recovery and care .for relief needs.

From next Monday thorugh April 23, the Windsor Theatre will be occupied by an Easter children's show called "Uncle Don's Easter Circus" that will include Uncle Don of the radio; the Sue Hastings marionettes, a Punch and Judy show and other numbers. Continuous performances will be givendaily, starting at 11 A. M. and ending at 5:30 P. M.

The Treasury is still buying Mexican silver despite the discontinuance of the monthly purchase arrangements which existed until the current month, Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr. disclosed at his press conference today.

Dr. Charles Sherwood Farriss, who twice was acting president of Stetson University here during the forty-six years he served as vice president and Professor of Ancient Languages, died today at the age of 61.
Secretary Ickes, whose home is in Chicago, asserted today that the result of the Illinois Senatorial primary was not a New Deal rebuke.

Contributions for the aid of Spanish Loyalists from the United States during March exceeded $50,000, according to figures issued today by Madeleine Braun, general secretary of the International Coordinating Committee for Republican Spain.

Authorities here continue to deny reports that former Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg has been transferred to Dachau concentration camp or an Austrian prison. Nevertheless, such reports persist in the press of neighboring States.
The lateness of Easter plus the promise of continuance of mild weather over the week-end caused reservation and information desks in transport agencies yesterday to become swamped with inquiries.

Reductions of $10 in prices of bristol board were announced to distributors yesterday by some manufacturers and it was expected others would follow. The new mill prices brought quotations of $7.15 to $7.20 per hundred by distributors in carload lots, compared with previous quotations of $7.70.

This morning, long before you are out of bed (unless you are going fishing) we are scheduled to meet Commissioner Harry Armstrong of New Jersey and look over the trout situation in the northern area of that State.

The Census Bureau reported today cotton consumed during March totaled 510,941 bales of lint and 60,443 of linters, compared with 427,528 of lint and 47,888 of linters during February this year, and 776,942 of lint and 75,361 of linters during March last year.
While his rivals for chief honors were engaged in difficult contests, Albert C. Simonson, youthful member of the Manhattan Chess Club, wrested from his club-mate, Isaac I. Kashdan,

Word was received here yesterday of the death in London on Monday of William Kinross Knox of Greenwich, Conn., president of Knox Bros., Inc., oak stave exporters with offices at 52 Vanderbilt Avenue. Mr. Knox,

Libby, McNeil Libby, meat packers, in their annual report to shareholders for the year ended on Feb. 28 show a net income of $2,777,792 after all charges, including Federal income taxes and surtax on undistributed profits.

Main Man coasted home the winner of the Phoenix Handicap, inaugural day feature, as one of Central Kentucky's greatest crowds welcomed the horses back to the Bluegrass at the opening of the Keeneland Spring meeting today.
Columbia's varsity tennis team swept the three doubles matches to defeat New York University, 6 to 3, at South Field yesterday in the opening contest for both teams.

The Insurgents' drive for Vinaroz appears to have reached its climax, and the next day or two doubtless will tell whether they are going to break through to the sea or be held as they are now, near Tortosa. Tonight's Defense Ministry communique admits fighting occurred today "in the neighborhood of San Mateo and La Jana."
One hundred years to the day after the first modern archaeologist came on the site, the University of Chicago's field expedition reached bedrock at Armageddon.
Cornelius F. Lynch, Mayor of this city in 1904 and 1905 and first Commissioner of Public Safety under the present city charter, died today in his home. He would have been 75 years old on Sunday.
German and Austrian residents here today voted in the plebiscite on the Reich's annexation of Austria aboard the German steamer Orinoco outside the territorial waters of Cuba.

A picture of the tragic circumstances under which thousands of Spanish families are. being broken up-some of them forever-by the Spanish civil conflict, was brought here last night by John Reich, secretary of the committee on Spain of the American Friends Service Committee, who returned on the French liner Ile de France after conferring in London and Paris with welfare workers from both sides of the war.

Modern methods of testing ship models to determine the power facilities of proposed vessels were discussed by eight directors of laboratory and testing tanks yesterday at the start of a two-day session at the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken.

Railroads, airlines and hotels did a recordbreaking business today as Britons put aside their work and worry and prepared to celebrate the fourday Easter holiday. Both Good Friday and Easter Monday are legal holidays and little work will be done Saturday.

" What shall I buy for Sunday dinner?" is the question that most housewives-especially when there is a holiday at hand-ask themselves when they start out to do their week-end shopping. Usually they mean "What meat or poultry shall I get?"

The Pacific Finance Corporation of California and its subsidiaries showed net earnings of $287,778 for the first three months of 1938 after all charges, including estimated Federal taxes, according to F. S. Baer, president. After preferred dividends, this Is equal to 45 cents each on 430,956 shares of outstanding common stock and compares with $392,789 or 69 cents a common share in March quarter of 1937.

Jacob (Gurrah Jake) Shapiro, a poor immigrant boy who made his way to the top of a racketeering empire, gave himself up to Federal authorities yesterday after nearly a year of dodging a world-wide man-hunt in which rewards totaling $7,500 were offered for his arrest.
Representative Bruce Barton will speak on "More Jobs-A Fresh Viewpoint on Our Biggest Problem" at a luncheon forum of the Association- of - Buying Offices at the Hotel -Pennsylvania on May 2.

A rare etching and drypoint by Rembrandt, "Landscape With Three Cottages," was sold for $3,100 last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, at an auction of etchings and engravings from the collections of Mrs. Robert Scoville of this city, John Wrenn of Chicago, Clifford Wallace of Philadelphia and others.

Purchases of securities' in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in 9 the week ended on April 9 exceeded sales by a considerable margin, a 238,583 shares being bought on balance, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. The
Sentiment in wool goods markets this week was more cheerful, although actual business continued spotty, the New York. Wool Top Exchange Service declared yesterday in its weekly review.

The copper business generally is not good, James MacNaughton, president of the Calumet Hecla Consolidated Copper Company, said at the annual meeting of stockholders in Boston yesterday, and the company is selling very little copper.

The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today the Salt Lake Utah Railroad Corporation to obtain the authentication and delivery of $400,000 of its sinking fund first mortgage 4 per cent bonds to be pledged as collateral security for a $400,000 loan by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
Edward H. H. Simmons admitted under questioning here today before the Securities and Exchange Commission that he realized last November that Richard Whitney had spent trust funds in his keeping.

With approval given fourteen Group 1 rules and four Group 2 regulations, decision was reached yesterday at the trade practice conference of the ribbon industry to formally present to the Federal Trade Commission an amendment requiring that ribbons imported in the greige, but finished here, carry the mark of the country of origin.

Miss Jane Laidlaw and Russell E. Pierce were married here at noon today at the estate of Mrs. George E. Holmes. Yellow daffodils were used to decorate the east wing of the house, where the ceremony was performed by the Rev. W. Westley Williams.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Saltonstall of Milton, Mass., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Saltonstall, to Joseph Henry Bragdon, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Henry Brandon of New Rochelle.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 13: COLONELS Williams, R. H., C.A.C., four months' leave, July 1. Gibson, A., Chemical- Warfare Service, to duty as acting executive officer of the New York Chemical Warfare Procurement District, New York City, in addition to other duties, May 16 to Aug. 15.

Russ Fredericks, former Bloomfield High School hurler, made good in the role of relief pitcher today in Newark Academy's 12-to-6 victory over Rutgers Prep. Newark started with Ted Corcoran on the mound, but after he had forced two men home on passes Ben Morgan went in. He, too,

Charles F. MacNeil, who was suspended March 25 as police chief of Patchogue Village on five charges, was dismissed from the force tonight after the Village Board of Police Commissioners had found him guilty of three of the complaints.
The President did some "earmarking" himself in his message to Congress today, and many politicians concluded that he did so for two very practical reasons.

Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association of New York, made public yesterday a letter sent to Senators Harrison, King, Vandenberg, Walsh, Capper and George, members of the conference committee, which is now considering the Federal Revenue Bill, which read as follows:

The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that Federal Judge Arthur F. Lederle in the Eastern District of Michigan had enjoined permanently Cyrenius A. Newcomb 3d and John H. Barrett, trustees of the Founders Trust, from engaging in sales of debentures and participation units of the trust.

Patrolman William B. McAuliffe, attached to Traffic Division C since his appointment to the New York Police Department in 1925, died yesterday afternoon in Wyckoff Heights Hospital, Brooklyn, after an operation. Mr. McAuliffe, who was 39 years old, lived at 95-08 159th Avenue, Howard Beach, Queens.

Counsel for the Alleghany Corporation and the Guaranty Trust Company signed and filed yesterday a stipulation adjourning stockholder meetings of the Chesapeake Corporation and the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company until after the United States Circuit Court of Appeals has decided whether or not to enjoin the trust company from voting Chesapeake stock.

Mrs. Carol Falk Green, daughter of Mrs. Malcolm Falk of 210 East Sixty-eighth Street and the late Mr. Falk, was married to Stephen A. Koshland of this city yesterday noon in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building by First Deputy City Clerk Philip A. Hines.

An increase of $3,617,888 in notes in circulation was shown today in the Bank of Canada's statement for the week ended, yesterday. The ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities was 55.76 per cent, against 56.46 a week before.

The campus was still humming tonight with conversation regarding the remarkable occurrence in a at public- opinion class this morning, while, at the same time, three members of the class were still praising themselves and 190-odd others were self-congratulators each had a crisp $5 note gained in a most unusual way and the others had bitterly clear visions of what they should have done and did not.

The Bishop of Teruel is at present in Barcelona awaiting examination and trial. He is detained as a prisoner of war and is being treated with special consideration in view of his rank. There have been reports that he might be exchanged for a high ranking prisoner on the other side.
The L-1, a 123,000-cubic foot blimp just completed by the Goodyear-Zeppelin Corporation for the navy, went aloft today on its first test flight.

Workers in the nationalized airplane factories returned to work today as Premier Edouard Daladier moved to end the strike situation. Even those factories where workers yesterday voted to maintain the strike were able to resume operations.

Additional details of the report of the New York Stock Exchange's special committee on safeguarding of customers were made available yesterday. The document, filed on Wednesday night with Charles R. Gay, president of the institution, has not been made public, since it

Pump-priming may be the economic theme of the moment, but down on the streamlined farm it is getting out of style. "Many farms," said John W. Rockey, Agriculture Department engineer, "have automatic pumps and highly modernized equipment.

Positive assurance to business that ,the principles of the American system of free enterprise will be preserved would result in the flow of private capital into channels of production and trade and greatly reduce unemployment, Charles R. Hook, president of the American Rolling Mill Company and of the National Association of Manufacturers, told Massachusetts manufacturers at a meeting here today, The

In the $100,000 race between War Admiral and Seabiscuit at Belmont Park on Decoration Day it will be winner take all, according to a statement made yesterday by Samuel D. Riddle, owner of the Admiral, famous son of Man o' War.
A new law for the defense of the State was promulgated today, listing penalties for propaganda favoring a change in the regime or a redistribution of property or urging class warfare.

The Appellate Division of the Su-preme Court sustained yesterday in a unanimous decision the complaint in a suit brought by- two American depositors in the National Bank of Greece against the bank and its alleged New York subsidiary, the Hellenic Bank Trust Company.

Mrs. Stella Marek Cushing, interpreter of folk culture and an authority on folklore, legend and music, who received the Order of the White Lion from Czechoslovakia-last June in recognition of her folk festival work, died today in her home here.

A claim of the United States Government to a surplus of $1,080,399 remaining after the liquidation of the Moscow Fire Insurance Company and the payment of all policy holders and creditors was rejected yesterday by the Appellate Division in a four-to-one decision.
An enterprising Associated Press inquirer in Washington suggests that pump-priming is rather an Old Deal institution to be
Mrs. Elizabeth Irvine Bain, retired New York school teacher, died here today at the home of a sister, Mrs. Byron Ames, at the age of 56.

Here is the status of the Administration's. legislative program, three and a half months after Congress began its session: Crop Control-Enacted into law. Housing-Enacted into law. Tax Revision-Passed by Senate and House; now in conference.

With all classifications falling back, total advertising linage in newspapers of fifty-two cities declined 13.6 per cent in March, according to Media Records yesterday. Last month's-total was 108,918,845 lines as against 126,133,602 for the corresponding period of 1937.
The Lawyers Trust Company reported, as of March 31, total deposits of $43,380,323, and total assets of $47,473,580, compared, respectively, with $38,288,643 and $42,441,151 on Dec. 31 last. Cash on

Charles Dunning, Dominion Minister of Finance, closed his books on March 31 at the close of the government's fiscal year with substantial increases in the yield from income tax and customs and excise levies, according to a report today by the Department of National Revenue.

Secretary Ickes said today that the application of Germany for about 10,000,000 cubic feet of helium would not be approved unless conclusive evidence was submitted that the non-explosive gas was not to be used for military purposes.

WITH THE INSURGENTS, on the Eastern Spanish Front, April 13 (by courier to Saint-Jean-deLuz, France, delayed).-In a surprise manoeuvre the Nationalists [Insurgents] today shifted the main force of their drive toward the Mediterranean from the Tortosa to the Vinaroz sector.

With Premier Edouard Daladier safe against parliamentary accident for at least six weeks and probably until November and with Georges Bonnet at the Quai d'Orsay, many new departures are expected shortly in French foreign Dolicy.

Peter L. Waters, Manhattan track coach, has entered thirty-five men in the annual Penn relay carnival to be held in Philadelphia April 29 and 30, it was announced yesterday by Herbert M. Kopf, director of athletics.

56th St, 129 E, 4 and 5-story tenement and stores, 12;6x100.5; City Bank Farmers Trust Co, trustee, against Gerald N. Stanton: due, $22.684. taxes, etc, $2,357; to plaintiff for $20,000. By B. HOLLANDER SON 83d St. 327 E, 5-story tenement, 25x102.2; Bank for Savings against Henry Pregenzer; due, $25.647: taxes, etc, $1,280; to plaintiff for $5,000.

A young woman who began a career as a sculptress four years ago and has since had as a sitter the Vice President of the United States will open her first exhibition at the Jacques Seligmann Galleries, 3 East Fifty-first Street, next Wednesday, after a preview on Tuesday.

Thirty-eight students, in roundtable discussion today at the conference on "Conservation of Marriage and the Family," told what they wanted their colleges to provide in the way of education for marriage, and why.
" Lisa Vale," Olive Higgins Prouty's first novel in seven years, is scheduled for publication on May 3 by Houghton Mifflin.

Columbia supremely ruled the roost for the major part of its baseball game with N. Y. U. on the latter's Ohio Field yesterday, but suddenly, with two out in the fifth, the home forces found their batting stride and proceeded to slam their way to a 4-to-3 triumph over the Lions. It was N. Y. U.'s third victory in as many contests.

The Giant-Indian expedition plunged deep into the wooded mountain country of West Virginia today, but neither Colonel Bill Terry nor any of his men who have become old hands at this exploring business allowed themselves to go astray.

The Appellate Division ruled unanimously yesterday that the trustees of Masonic Hall and Asylum must pay New York City real estate taxes on the part of its property at Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue which is rented for commercial purposes.

The Stanley Cup, emblematic of world hockey supremacy, no longer is a battered old mug. Refurbished, all dents removed and with four rings added for engraving of championship winners, the cup that made its debut in 1892 arrived in Chicago today-bright and shiny.

A six-story apartment house contraining small suites will be erected at 313-15 West Twenty-first Street by the Sabog Construction Company, which has just purchased this property from Irving O. Freedman. Ackman Co. were brokers in the deal and Abraham and Sidney Leichter represented the purchaser.
Because of ill health, Charles of London, 12 West Fifty-sixth Street, well-known decorator, will retire at the end of this month after having been in business here for forty-five years.

Operators of interstate bus lines will be required to obtain franchises for use of the city streets, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday after conferring at City Hall with representatives ct bus operators, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine and John Scott; an agent of the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Among the 18,000 taxpayers who filed returns yesterday at the State Income Tax Bureau in 80 Center Street was one man who claimed an exemption of $400 for his dependent dog.
Cornell S. Franklin, American lawyer, was re-elected today chairman of the Shanghai Municipal Council, governing body of the International Settlement.

Following the announcement yesterday that Great Britain contemplated ordering military airplanes in this country, it was estimated that the United States industry could produce about 2,000 planes for export within twelve months, in adedition to orders now on hand, provided types now in production were ordered.

As a certain sign that the baseball season is just around the corner, the Yankees will inaugurate their three-game series against the Dodgers at Ebbets Field this afternoon in the annual prelude to the pennant races.

The application of the Eastern railroads for an increase in coach fares from 2 to 2.5 cents a mile was denied today by the Interstate Commerce Commission in a six-to-five decision. The increase would have increased the revenues of the railroads $29,961,080 annually if traffic continued at the 1936 rate. Spokes-

Holders of farm loan 6 per cent bonds of the German Central Bank for Agriculture, Series A, due on April 15, 1938, have received an offer of certain options in view of the inability of the bank to meet the bonds at maturity, according to a notice sent to the New York Stock Exchange.

The Federal grand jury handed yesterday to Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in the United States District Court in Brooklyn an indictment charging Robert F. Gammon, former radio operator at the Coast Guard Radio Direction Finder Station at Amagansett, L. I., with murder in the first degree.

Launcelot Winchester Andrews, Ph. D., former Professor of Chemistry at Iowa State College of Agriculture and at the State University of Iowa and later a research and consulting chemist, died today at his home, 18 Clarendon Road, Belmont. He was 81 years old.

First Congressional response to President Roosevelt's new recovery program today indicated fairly broad support by Democratic members of the House and Senate, who for the most part also said they understood very little about the program.
William Lycett, for more than forty years associated with the Methodist Book Concern of New York, died here yesterday at his home at the age of 75.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. William Lowe Rice of the engagement and approaching marriage of her youngest daughter,m Mrs. Helen Lowe Fiske, to John Guthrie Kilbreth of this city. The wedding will take place on May 12 in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church and will be followed by a reception at the Colony Club.

The Southern Association opened its 1938 season today and baseball fans of all four opening towns had a big time-their home teams won. In Atlanta the Crackers defeated Knoxville, 8 to 5, to get Paul Richards, their new manager, off to a fine start. Richards himself lent a big hand by hitting two homers.

Negotiations for the purchase of the Herculea Life Insurance Company, Chicago, by the Occidental Life Insurance Company of California, San Francisco, have been broken off, Hercules Life announced today.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had closed a proceeding which it instituted as a result of the Virginia Transportation Corporation, a subsidiary of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, acquiring control of the Erie Railroad. Under authority of...

Experts of the Tennessee Valley Authority are saying that just as its floodcontrol program will benefit the rest of the country by reducing Mississippi and Ohio River floods, its navigation improvement will be a national asset in linking up the Tennessee Valley with an integrated inland waterway system.

In clothes of the present day and in a streamlined two-act version, Ibsen's "The Wild Duck" gets its modernized production tonight at the Forty-ninth Street Theatre. It is Henry Forbes's popular-price revival ($2.20 top), and among the company are William Challee, Emerson Russell, Jane Lyon, Arlene Haber and Edgar Henning.

The sixth annual Rutgers University two-day clinic for New York, Pennsylvania and New Jersey high and prep school coaches opens tomorrow with an address by Dr. S. E. Bilick, physic-therapeutist of Bellevue Hospital, New York.

Mrs. Gertrude Barlow Talmage, widow of the Rev. Frank DeWitt Talmage, who was a son of the Rev. T. DeWitt Talmage, noted Brooklyn preacher, died yesterday at the Hotel Margaret in Brooklyn at the age of 64. Her husband,

The Giants to nose out the Chicago Cubs for the pennant, and the Cincinnati Reds to climb from the cellar to fifth place-that's the way major league baseball writers figure the 1938 National League race.

Guy A. Thompson, as trustee for the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company, filed today a suit in Common Pleas Court to recover $3,200,000 from the Alleghany Corporation, top holding company of the former Van Sweringen railroad empire.
Health insurance offers "an appropriate technique for dealing with the highly unpredictable risks of illness," in the opinion of Governor Lehman's Constitutional Convention Committee.

Inflationary implications of the financial programs presented yesterday to Congress stimulated more activity on the Cotton Exchange than had been witnessed in some time and prices rose $1.50 a bale to end with net gains of 25 to 27 points.

Possibly two more weeks will be required for the reorganization committee of the New York Curb Exchange to complete its preliminary investigation, Fred C. Moffatt, president, declared yesterday. A report is expected to follow completion of that part of its work in a reasonable time.

Reaching the second highest point of the year, engineering awards for the week total $79,373,000, which places them 101 per cent above last week and 70 per cent above the corresponding week last year, according to Engineering News-Record.

Mr. and Mrs. Rutherford Clark Thompson of Hempstead have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lorraine Byrd Thompson, to Dr. Frederick De Long Fister of Trexlertown, Pa., son of Herman Fister of Kutztown, Pa., and the late Mrs. Fister.

Earl Sande, trainer of Stagehand, said today he was going to build a fence to keep amateur photographers and the just plain curious away from the stable of the Kentucky Derby favorite, now quartered at Churchill Downs.

A report sharply criticizing the Patman chain-store tax bill now before the Ways and Means Committee of the House was adopted yesterday by the executive committee of the Merchants Association of New York. The report, made by

From The Herald Tribune (Ind. Rep.). It was a changed President who addressed Congress-and the voters yesterday. Message and speech seemed half-hearted in comparison with the exuberant boyishness, the gay scornfulness, the supreme confidence of happier days.

Reopening of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway under a revised equity receivership was proposed today by a bondholders' committee. In a brochure distributed to officials of Westchester communities, the committee contended the line could be operated profitably and benefit both the communities and the holders of $22,310.000 in bonds.

The $1,392,065,461 of gold which has accumulated in the Treasury's inactive gold fund since it was decided in December, 1936, to "sterilize" the incoming deluge of gold from abroad to keep it from inflating the credit structure of the nation was converted into spendable form this afternoon in accordance with President Roosevelt's recovery program.

A comprehensive list of the men and war materials allegedly sent to the Insurgent forces in Spain by Germany and Italy since the first of the year was made public last night by Fernando de los Rios, Spanish Ambassador in Washington Speaking at a pro-Loyalist rally of 2,000, at Windsor Hall, Sixty-sixth Street and Broadway, the Ambassador said he had received the information Wednesday night from Premier Juan Negrin in Barcelona.

There is something appropriate and at the same time sadly symbolic in the appointment of Mr. Norman Davis as head of the American Red Cross. It does not mean, as blithely interpreted by the German press, that America is staying at home.

Jose Bergamin, . Spanish writer who describes himself as a Catholic and a Loyalist sympathizer, addressed a group of more than fifty school and college teachers yesterday at a meeting enlivened by verbal clashes between Loyalist and Rebel sympathizers.

Governor Lehman signed today the bill of Assemblyman Wagner of New York, creating a special legislative commission to draft a long-range State health program. An appropriation of $15,000 is provided and-the commission is directed to submit its report to the 1939 Legislature by Feb. 15.
George Haight, who recently resigned from Samuel Goldwyn's production staff, today purchased the Bessie Breuer novel, "Memory of Love," for his initial venture at RKO.

Business in the stock markets here was restricted today by holiday influences, but there was a firm tone and most sections went ahead. Giltedge issues, after early strength, turned uncertain in the afternoon and prices weakened. Foreign bonds

Nation-wide fear of government and a growing sense of skeptical concern have developed recently because the "new liberalism in American politics," as exemplified, at least in part, by the Roosevelt Administration, has become authoritarian in spirit and deed,

Five young men from the lower East Side, one of whom only fourteen months ago was freed in a murder, were found guilty yesterday in General Sessions of firstdegree murder in the shooting of Detective Michael J. Foley of the Fifth Street station in a restaurant hold-up at 144 Second Avenue on April 10 last year.

The sweeping character of President Roosevelt's plans for expanding the credit base of the country and "priming the pump" by government spending took the financial community by surprise yesterday in spite of the advance intimations that such a plan was being laid.

The marriage of Miss Matilde Barbara Grode of Hackensack, N. J., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John O. Grode, to Harvey E. Runner of this city, son of the Mr. and Mrs. Evan G. Runner, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Marble Collegiate Church.

Mrs. Sally Shonk Smith, daughter of Mrs. Herbert Bronson Shonk of this city and Dublin, N. H., and the late Mr. Shonk, was married to James Provoost Smith, also of New York, yesterday afternoon at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Otto V. MacKenty Schmidt at 1,088 Park Avenue.

George Richards Murray, former general athletic treasurer at Princeton University, died here today of a heart attack at the age of 68. Mr. Murray died at the home of relatives. Mr. and Mrs. George A. Clarb on Nassau Street, where he was recuperating from a similar attack two months ago.

Business in the Pittsburgh district dedined a little more last week, according to the 'Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The drop was due partly to the setback in steel mill activity, but primarily to the counter-seasonal decrease in retail sales.

Navy's varsity flotilla put in its last hard workout tonight before the opening on Saturday of one of the longest seasons - the midshipmen have faced on the water in some years. Tomorrow 'afternoon the varsity and junior varsity eights of Princeton will arrive here in time to row from the handsome Navy boathouse and on Saturday at 4:30 they will open the East's rowing season with their regatta.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals, the following proceedings were had, Judge Jackson not partcipating: CUSTOMS 4121-American Import Company v. the United States. Argued.

The marriage of Miss Helen J. Ledman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ledman of this city, to Boris M. Duchowny, also of New York, and the late Mr. Duchowny, took place yesterday morning at the home of the Rev. Dr. Moishe Bick 689 East 169th Street. Dr. Bick performed the ceremony.

John J. Sullivan, frequently referred to as the "Czar of Wallabout Market," where he amassed a fortune as a watchman for the vehicles of farmers bringing produce to the wholesale dealers, was convicted yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, on an indictment charging him with willful failure to file income tax returns and failure to pay income taxes.

The Spier Company, Inc. as broker, has placed the following loans for ten years at 5 per cent on. multi-family dwellings in Brooklyn; $215,000 on the six-story house at 4,910 15th Ave for the G. R. Operating Corp; $125,000 on the building at 5,302 15th Ave for the M. R. Building Corp. and $290,000 on the structure at 888 Montgomery St for the Rich-Tab Realty Corp.

The action of President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull for establishing an intergovernmental committee to aid refugee immigration enshrines the spirit of Passover this year, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, chairman of the executive committee of the United Palestine Appeal, said last night over a national hook-up of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The Hartford Gas Company, Hartford, Conn., -has filed an application under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 for an order declaring that it is not a subsidiary of the United Gas Improvement Company or United Corporation.

Mrs. Louise Paine Benjamin, widow of John C. Benjamin of West Redding and daughter of the late Albert Bigelow Paine, author and biographer of Mark Twain, was married here this afternoon to John Hudson Moore of New York.

A further deflation of bank credit, including a sharp fall in brokers' loans to the lowest figure in five years, was reported yesterday in the condition statement for the week ended on Wednesday of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City. The

The general level of wholesale prices continued to decline in the week ended on April 9, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, was 78.5, compared with 78.8 on April 2 and 87.9 on April 10 last year.

While the warm weather this week brought a definite improvement in the volume of retail business on men's clothing and furnishings, the increase was below expectations, store executives reported yesterday.
H. R. H. Construction Company submitted the lowest estimate for the general construction contract of Public School 246 in Brooklyn, according to Brown's Letters, Inc.

For the second time within a month, New Yorkers were caught yesterday away from home with topcoats as the thermometer rose almost to midsummer heights. A high of 78 degrees at 4:30 P. M. broke all existing records for April 14 and the day's average of 66 degrees was 17 above the normal for the day.

In the first active trading in three weeks, sales of more than 78,000 hides have been made in the last two days, and prices were stronger on some numbers. Traders said that they saw evidence in the sales that packers were willing to do business at current levels, but were not willing to cut below them.
Jersey justice was in one of its severe moods tonight and halted a trip to Guatemala by two youths of socially prominent New York families. The law's instrument was Recorder Alfred Urffer.

Reuben H. Fleet, president, on March 1 owned 164,841 shares, or 28.7 per cent of Consolidated Aircraft Corporation's common stock, and 6,000 shares, or 25.3 per cent of its convertible preferred stock, according to a report of the corportion filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. On the same
Lumber production increased less than seasonally last week and the adjusted index dropped to 60.3 from 62.4. For the week ended April 10, 1937, the figure was 85.0.

181st St (11-3157); n w cor of Ryer Ave. 126x202; Davro Realty Corp to Ryecroft Realty Corp, 517 E 136th St: mtg $53,000. Edison Ave, 1,835 (154193); Edison Savings Loan Assn to Glacomina Insignia, 1,133 Beach Ave. Wyatt St (15-3906); s s at s e s of 177th St, 100x133, Harryirv Realty Corp to 1,110 Coliseum Corp, 1,018 E 103d St; mtg 198,000.
A serious crisis confronted the Japanese Cabinet today, and there were rumors Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye, unable to control warring factions, was preparing to resign.
Twelve teams will take part in the forty-fifth annual championships of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association that start this morning at the Hotel Astor.

The question of double jeopardy was raised today by counsel for Ellis H. Parker and his son, Ellis H. Parker Jr., as they fought the request of Federal authorities for the removal of the Parkers to Brooklyn for arraignment on indictments accusing them of the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel.

The Equity Corporation reported yesterday a net asset value of $3,872.55 for each $1,000 of assumed debentures as of March 31, and $36.64 a share on $3 convertible preferred stock, entitled to $50 a share in liquidation, compared with $4,833.61 for the debentures and S48.81 a share for the preferred stock on Dec. 31.

Industrial stocks advanced from fractions to 2 points, rails closed irregularly lower in more active trading; turnover, 1,009,480 shares. Bonds moved irregularly-rails lower, United States Government loans higher, industrials mixed in trends; transactions, $5,865,500.
