Mrs. Alice Margaret Bentley, 54 years old, this afternoon was found shot through the head in the dining room of the home of her daughter and son-in-law, Patrolman and Mrs. Harold Turnbull, at 559 Fifth Avenue, here. She died an hour later in Mount Vernon Hospital. According to police,

Japan met with her first great military reverse in modern times in the recent fighting around Taierhchwang, it became known yesterday. Military experts in Shanghai believe 42,000 men out of an army of 62,000 were killed when the Chinese cut the Japanese supply lines and struck a smashing blow at the trapped forces. [Page 1.]

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In all this welter of conflicting opinion, it seems to me clearly a confession of narrow vision and a convenient alibi for business to ascribe its low. ebb of confidence today to the policies of the present Administration.

Mrs. David Rumsey entertained at luncheon yesterday in the Louis Sherry Room of Sherry's for Mrs. Leslie Bliss Soper, Mrs. Noyes Hamilton, Mrs. Roderick D. O'Connor, Mrs. Harry Snowden, Miss Mary Rutherfurd Jay, Mrs. E. Martin Michalis, Mrs. Hardin Orvis, Mrs. Joseph Ferris Simmons, Mrs. Ten Eyck Wendell, Mrs. Thomas Jefferson Mumford, Mrs. Linn M. A. Evans, Miss Margaret H. Lawson, Mrs. Wright Barclay, Mrs. Charles G. Ayres and Mrs. Cleveland F. Bacon.

Richard Weil Jr. has been named executive assistant to William J. Wells, president of L. Bamberger Co., Newark, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Weil, who joined Bamberger's in the Summer ' of 1936 as advertising manager, was subsequently appointed executive vice president and publicity director.

A sword emblematic of the papal office of a Knight of St. Gregory arrived yesterday on the Italian liner Rex for presentation to former Governor Alfred E. Smith, who was recently named a Papal Count. The sword arrived in the custody of Captain Giorgio Cavallini, staff captain of the Rex who will make the presentation to Mr. Smith today as a special emissary from the Vatican.

Only mediocre totals were recorded by the five squads in action in singles and doubles competition in the American Bowling Congress today. Best score of the session was a 692 in the individual event by Stanley Selasek of La Salle, Ill. Charles Treuter of San Antonio, Texas, hit 657 in games of 236, 219 and 202.

Panama, with the lowest customs duties in Latin America, probably will make further reductions and increase the number of articles on the free list at the next session of the National Assembly, according to Secretary of Finance Ezequiel Fernandez Jaen.

Establishment of a central clearing house to be operated by a joint committee of retailers and jobbers to end chaotic conditions in the metropolitan liquor market was approved here yesterday and Gerald F. Dunne, president of the Federated Liquor Package Stores of Kings County, Inc.,

Bank clearings for the twenty-two leading cities of the country for the week ended.Wednesday dropped to the lowest for any full period since the week ended on Oct. 10, 1934. As a result, the gap -between the corresponding 1938 and 1937 positions grew wider in the twenty-second consecutive dip from the previous year's comparative figures.
Dr. Jack Rose, a white and liver pointer, today captured the amateur all-age, the concluding stake in the meeting sponsored by the Lambertville Field Trial Club.
Dr. Ellen Heise, one of the first women to practice medicine in the United States, died yesterday at the home of a daughter, Miss Bertha Heise, in Huntington Park, Calif. She was 90 years old.
Gerard F. Mallon of the Cone Export and Commission Company was elected president of the New York Chapter of the National Institute Credit at a meeting last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Other new

The Philharmonic - Symphony League of New York will give a luncheon at the Astor Hotel on Wednesday afternoon, April 27. It will be preceded by a reception to meet John Barbirolli, conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony. Guests of honor will be Dorothy Thompson, Olga Samaroff-Stokowski and Judge Joseph M. Proskauer, Mishel Piastro, the symphony's concertmaster, and Eugene List, pianist, will play.

President Roosevelt told Campfire Girls today that they should let people know what they are doing about long-term conservation in their home communities. With delegates to a national conservation rally gathered about him in their blue skirts, white middies and red ties, the President presented national honors to six of the group chosen for outstanding local work in caring for birds, planning soil erosion programs and other projectss.

A big Nazi rally at Haderslev, near the German border, was booed lustily today by counterdemonstrating Danish residents. While the rival demonstrations were under way, Copenhazen authorities made three more arrests in connection with a one-man Nazi

Turpentine firm, 23c; sales, 112 barrels; receipts, 199 barrels; shipments, 184 barrels; stock, 29,Resin, firm; sales, 289: receipts, 870; shipments, 450; stock, 74,634. Quote: B, $3.50; D, E. $3.60; F, G, H, I, K, $4.50; M. $4.60; N, $5; WG. $5.90; WW.
Dr. Frederic Jay Cotton, bone and joint surgeon and a founder and regent of the to board of governors of the American College of Surgeons, died of a heart attack today at his home, 239 Beacon Street.
Directors of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company yesterday voted a 60-cent dividend on the common and common B stock. A similar amount was paid on Feb. 15.
Vice President Garner has bought a big Texas cattle ranch. The ranch, 23,436 acres, is situated in the northern part of Webb County, about 100 miles southeast of Uvalde, Mr. Garner's home.

United States Government securities responded to a brisk demand yesterday following announcement of the President's proposals to utilize the nation's entire sterile gold supply, together with the 5220,000,000 of free gold currently held by the Treasury, supplemented by a decrease of about $750,000,000 in member bank reserve requirements,

Toll revenues of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania dropped sharply in the first quarter of this year, reflecting the recession in general business, P. C. Staples, president, said yesterday in a letter to shareholders accompanying quarterly preferred dividend checks.

A referendum among the members of the International Typographical Union disclosed here today that, while the majority want peace and unity in the trade union movement, they refused to accept or. support the centralized policy adopted by the American Federation of Labor at its last convention.

Responsibility for the withdrawal of free milk from 8,000 needy persons in the five boroughs was placed upon the city yesterday. by Victor F. Ridder, chairman of the State Board of Social Welfare. The last daily delivery of 8,500 quarts of Grade B milk will be made this tio morning.

Formation of a joint council on the Worth Street rules, to provide mechanism for adjusting the rules in line with changing conditions from time to time is now in process, it was learned yesterday. W. Ray

The statement by President Roosevelt that the Federal Reserve Board had agreed to liberalize reserve requirements of the members banks so as to add an additional $750,000,000 to the excess reserves which on April 13 were already about $1,723,000,000 was interpreted to mean that the board would in effect restore the reserve requirements which were applicable before May 1, 1937.
The Treasury procurement division today announced awards of contracts for a total of 285,200 yards of textiles, for shipment by May 10, from bids opened April 8. The awards are as follows:

The apple growers of this State, who produced last year more than 26,000,000 bushels, more than any year since 1925, decided that a little publicity might help to empty the storage warehouses. Accordingly a Big Apple contest for youngsters was held yesterday afternoon at the playground at Riverside Drive and Seventy-fourth Street.
Dr. Lester K. Ade, Superintendent of Public Instruction, estimated today that 1,000,000 Pennsylvanians were "functionally illiterate" as he completed plans for the first State-wide literacy test.

Although this correspondent has been unable to verify personally the actual positions and calibers of foreign fortifications between Algeciras and Tarifa there are many alleged witnesses who assert the whole seacoast facing the Rock and Strait of Gibraltar are strongly fortified, chiefly by heavy. German guns.

Peru's foreign trade in 1937 totaled 600,645,969 soles, an increase of 64,332,881 over 1936. Custom tariffs yielded 50,387,540 soles, against 49,235,697 in 1936. Exports totaled 365,440,446 soles and imports 235,205,523.

A treaty-for the adjustment of pending financial questions was signed today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Dr. Leon de Bayle, the Nicaraguan Minister. The treaty offsets two items and provides for the payment of $72,000 by the United States to Nicaragua.

The "new situation" created by the decision of the C. I. O. to set up a permanent organization will be considered by the general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union at its regular meeting next month, David Dubinsky, president of the union, announced yesterday.
The government announced today that Ireland would elect its new President May 31, with the Executive assuming office June 30.
It is said that the work of drafting the Angloas Italian agreement moved slowly toward the end because every word in the text, both English and Italian, was carefully weighed.

Representative Charles J. Colden of California died tonight in a hospital here. His age was 67. Mr. Colden, born in 1870, represented the Seventeenth Congressional District. A Democrat, he was elected to the House in 1932.

Hog prices again showed strength today, with small supplies late in the week favoring the selling side. Fat lambs, although comparatively plentiful, were moderately active and fully steady. Supplies of steers were. extremely small and market generally steady with undertone weak, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

The flashing blades of college duelists could not sever the knot of a tightly knit battle for seven championships yesterday as the forty-fifth annual title tournament of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association reached the half-way mark at the temporary salle d'armes of the Hotel Astor.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The demand for wool is rather broader, but no more intense. There appears to be some disposition on the part of the wool merchants to take on a little wool on the basis of the government wool loan.
Conferees on the tax bill met today for the fourth time and adjourned to report that no progress had been made toward ending differences concerning taxes on undistributed profits and capital gains.

It is of the highest importance to recognize at the outset the grave risk that the President's new spending program, now put forward as a temporary expedient, will, if adopted, become a permanent burden on private enterprise in this country.
John C. Palmateer, a member of the City Council of Asbury Park and former Mayor, died here suddenly tonight of a heart attack. was 70 years old. Driving home in his car, Mr. Palmateer was stricken.

The Department of Commerce said today that gold imports fell off to $3,677,811 in the week ended on April 8, compared with the sixmonth high of $53,224,817 in the preceding week. Most of last week's gold came from England and the Philippines.

The Giants and Indians arrived at the heart of America's steel-industry today, and on a spacious ball field flanked by mountains, packed by 6,000 fans and upon which not a blade of grass could be detected by the naked eye, Colonel Bill Terry's troops once again demonstrated their astonishing versatility.

139th St, 139-51 W, 5-story tenement, 175x 99.11; Shepro Realty Corp against Upton Construction Corp, due, $62,334, to plaintiff-for $5,000. By ROBERT FISHEL 48th St, 431 W, 4-story tenement, 25x100, 25x100.5; Fernando A. Wessell, Admr, against Jennie I. Thrush, due. $30,086, taxes, $157; to plaintiff for $5,000.

Pope Plus today interrupted his Good Friday meditations to visit an exhibit of Catholic charitable work. The Pontiff, saving his strength for the elaborate Easter mass and canonizations, had decided to spend the day in prayer in his apartments, but left for a few minutes to inspect the exhibit of the Italian Catholic Action in the Vatican.

The Holland Furnace Company will expand its 1938 campaign, with copy scheduled to break in newspapers and magazines early next month. Approximately 400 papers will be used, with full-page- and 1,000-line insertions planned for two roto groups and in black and white in large cities where group rotogravure is not available.
Mountain Ridge, one of two colts on whom Mrs. Ethel V. Mars has staked her Kentucky Derby hopes, today recorded the most impressive speed shown to date in the Derby training period.

The Reds beat the Tigers today, 10--7, for the fifth time in six exhibition games this season. Each team made four home runs. Lee Grissom and Johnny Vander Meer, southpaws, pitched for Cincinnati. Elden Auker started for Detroit and gave all of Cincinnati's twelve hits in his seven-inning tenure.

The annual Good Friday matinee performance of Wagner's consecrational festival play, "Parsifal," was given yesterday at the Metropolitan Opera House before a large audience that expressed its enthusiasm as much by silence as by unstinting ovations at the conclusions of the acts.

Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, urged the people of the United States yesterday to support the American ORT Federation's campaign to raise $450,000 "as a means of leading the victims of oppression into avenues of hope and providing them with an opportunity to make a livelihood."

Professor James Harvey Rogers of Yale called upon the nation's conservatives tonight to support President Roosevelt's recovery program, which he called "the soundest yet proposed" by the Administration.
Easter music in the form of oratorios, cantatas, carols and instrumental selections will be a feature of the services tomorrow in the city's churches. The programs will include:

By suddenly abandoning their attacks in the Tortosa zone and concentrating on the Vinaroz sector, the Nationalists [Insurgents] confounded their enemy today and reached the Mediterranean, thus finally dividing Republican Spain into two parts.
The American Cotton Cooperative Association was commended today by W. I. Myers, governor of the Farm Credit Administration, which has lent millions of dollars of Federal funds to the association.

The preview of the World-of-Tomorrow which the New-York World's Fair will offer for the city on April 30 will be marked by an early evening open-air show at the exposition site. The sky will be filled with stunting aerialists and fireworks, Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, announced yesterday.

With the not-too-pessimistic forecast of "probably showers and cooler" for Easter to spur them on the pre-Easter parade of visitors arriving and resident New Yorkers departing got under way yesterday. The prospects were for record travel both ways.

Samuel Cohen Jr., president of the Amshe-Sholem Synagogue here and deputy clerk of the Westchester County Children's Court, died tonight in the New Rochelle Hospital at the age of 49. He suffered a stroke on April 3.

JUST recently Phil Cavarretta, the lively first baseman of the Chicago Cubs, was hit on the head by a fast ball and carried to the repair shop. That incident sent James the Ripper Collins out to play first base again for the Cubs.

The 255th public playground for children to be added to the Park Departments system since January, 1934, will be opened for use today. It is at Lafayette and Marcy Avenues, Brooklyn, and will be Number 363 in the Department's chain.

A venezuelan executive decree, published in the Official Gazette on April 12, created an import quota system in retaliation against those foreign countries restricting the importation of Venezuelan products and attempting-to balance exports andimports, according to a cablegram received by the Department of Commerce.

Trading in round lots for their own account by members of the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on March 19 increased sharply as the market became more active, constituting 19.47 per cent of the total volume, compared with 16.90 per cent in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

" The police were winners of an "unpopularity contest" conducted by the New Jersey Juvenile Delinquency Commission among 1,394 youths in the nor State's correctional and penal institutions, according to the fourth section of a report submitted to Governor Moore today.

George A. Plimpton was by profession a publisher of books-and it was a profession, for it was not a purely commercial occupation. But his avocation was the gathering of books, chiefly textbooks, and manuscripts illustrating the part that they had in the education of generation after generation. To the number of 20.000,

At the request of several groups of security holders the Interstate Commerce Commission today postponed reorganization hearings of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railroad Company for six months from May 3 until Nov. 1.

The London publishing firm Victor Gollancz, Ltd., has contracted for the English publication of Dorothy Baker's "Young Man With a Horn." This novel, which centers around a "swing" musician, is scheduled for publication by Houghton Mifflin on June 1 and will be the fourth novel to appear under the Houghton Mifflin Literary Fellowship awards.

President Roosevelt will try out his arm at the opening game of the American League season on Monday. He promised Clark Griffith, presi- dent of the Washington Baseball Club, today that he would be on hand for the opening game with the Philadelphia Athletics. Mr. Roosevelt promised not only to be on hand but to throw out the first ball.

Establishment of a new Nash Motors sales area, to be known as the Great Lakes division, and appointment of A. C. Tiedemann, former director of business management as sales manager of the new division, was announced yesterday by C. H. Bliss, vice president and director of sales of the Nash Motors division of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation.
A hearing has been called for April 27 by the SEC on an application by New York State Electric and Gas Corporation of Ithaca, N. Y., a subsidiary of the Associated Gas and Electric Company
Mr. and Mrs. S. Worcester Sargent of Penn Valley have announced the engagement of Miss Ruth Virginia Sargent, daughter of Mrs. Sargent by a former marriage,
President Eduard Benes is to deliver in Parliament tomorrow a speech in connection with the annual "Red Cross political truce" lasting over Easter that will contain political allusions.
Iron and steel production in Sweden continued its upward swing last year, marking the fourth year that production has been on the rise, the Commerce Department reported today.

The Wisconsin Bankshares Corporation, excluding subsidiaries, has reported for 1937 a net income of $74,636 from operations, against $312,066 in 1936. Recoveries, increase in net worth of subsidiaries and other adjustments helped to increase total surplus from $3,322,857 to $10,729,782.

Ten scholarships to study at the Academy of International Law at The Hague this Summer have been awarded by the Division of International Law of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, the director has announced.
Top honors went to Ivornoll Nick, a white-and-liver pointer, in the junior all-age stake in the trials sponsored by the Mid-Jersey Field Dog Club near here today.

New Jersey anglers never had a more perfect day for the opening of their trout season. The weather was just right, flies were hatching on several of the larger streams, fish were plentiful and the fishermen turned out in thousands.
Seven undergraduates of New Jersey College for Women were tapped today by Philalethean, honorary literary society, in recognition of exceptional ability and interest along literary lines.

Joshua Reed Giddings, one of Pasadene's earliest residents and who was one of the sponsors of the Tournament of Roses parade fifty years ago, is dead here at the age of 80 He will be buried tomorrow in Mountain View Cemetery, which he helped to. lay out.

Net income of the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company in 1937 was $782,250, against $4,218,955 in 1936, although net sales increased from $89,631,402 in 1936 to $99,991,355 in 1937, according to a report issued yesterday.

Today's major events: "Tristan und Isolde," Metropolitan Opera House, afternoon; "Aida," Hippodrome Opera Company, evening. Music of India will be presented this morning at the Brooklyn Museum Center through the courtesy of H. Stefan Santesson, secretary of India Political Council.

JOHN DOS PASSOS' "Journeys Between Wars"* is stamped with half the visas of the world. It is an exceptionally good book, an omnium gatherum of the pieces he has written in the course of twenty years of restless and astoundingly observant wandering.
Growing anti-Semitic agitation in the Reich is reaching countries in Southeastern Europe where heretofore anti-Semitism was unknown or known only in an extremely mild form.

M. L. Wilson, Under-Secretary of Agriculture, was appointed today chairman of the United States delegation to the meeting of the general assembly of the International Institute of Agriculture at Rome on May 23.

More and better college courses on marriage and family life and the development in increasing numbers of specially qualified graduate instructors were predicted by Dr. Ernest R. Groves at the concluding

This capital's largest hotel-the Athenee Palace-has been ordered closed for ten years for "sanitary reasons." Behind the order lies the government's desire to end the activities of Dr. Juliu Maniu and his National Peasant party, which had its headquarters in that hotel.
Spanish Government authorities reported today the death of Captain Philip Detro of Texas, a member of the Lincoln-Washington battalion of the International Brigade.

August Hauser, 67 years old, a former newspaper man, of 603 West Sixth Avenue, here, died early today in the Zurbrugg Memorial Hospital, Riverside, of a fractured skull, suffered when he jumped or fell from a third-story window of his home late last night. Mr.

The noted Bulgarian scientist Methode Popoff, for many years Bulgarian Minister in Berlin, was unable to deliver a lecture today on racial theories and heredity when Nazis interfered because the lecturer opposes Chancellor Hitler's theories.

Stores to accommodate the tenants of the proposed 1,890-room Thorneycroft development in Queens will be erected as the result of the assembling yesterday of about 27,500 square feet of land facing north directly on the new housing project and fronting Queens Boulevard on the south.

The de Basil Pallet Russe and the recently organized World-Art Ballet, which has been under the direction of Leonide Massine, have merged, it was announced yesterday by S. Hurok, general manager of the united companies.

The Cubs withdrew support of the Hot Springs Club of the Cotton States League today in keeping with the ruling by Commissioner K. M. Landis that no major league club could be affiliated with two organizations in the same minor circuit.

Chinese forces reported they were closing in on Yihsien, northward of Taierhchwang, and said Japanese troops there were surrounded and facing starvation, although supplied with some food dropped by airplanes.

The Daily Metal Trade said today: '"The steel and nonferrous metals industries greet the President's pump-priming program with mixed emotions. Eventually, public works and highway construction create demand for materials and machinery.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 9 totaled 521,978 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 1,511 cars, or 0.3 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week;

Two stakes were completed today during the first program of the twentyseventh annual meeting of the Orange County Field Trial Club, contested over the preserves of the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club under varying conditions.

The indications are for mostly cloudy and much cooler weather today. Tomorrow will continue cool and probably will be showers, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

The Mayor of Hell, a gentle, pensive man with none of the attributes of the fabled overlord of the infernal regions, arrived yesterday on the Norway liner Stavangerfjord, to participate in a radio broadcast and look over the country that has sent so many tourists to his bailiwick.
Spokesmen for twenty standard railway unions flatly rejected today a proposal made by the carriers for joint conferences to discuss a voluntary wage deduction for nearly 1,000,000 railway employes.

Senators and Representatives who did not return to their homes after adjournment of the special session last Dec. 21 would lose the customary 20-cents-a-mile travel allowance under an amendment to the $21,658,587 legislative appropriation bill, reported today by the Senate Appropriations Committee.
The Bureau of Motor Vehicles sought to enlist the aid of the public today, in a campaign to eliminate unbonded taxicab operators.

Mr. and Mrs. Rezin Davis gave a dinner last night in La Maisonette Russe of the St, Regis for Miss Harriet Wardlaw of Greenville, S. C., and Mr. Davis's brother, Robert Rhodes Davis of Clarksburg, W. Va., whose marriage will take place today.

The new post at the Admiralty of Fifth Sea Lord and Chief of the Naval Air Services is to be filled by Vice Admiral Sir Alexander R. M. Ramsay, 56-year-old commander-inchief of the East Indies station.
A number of new low death reoords for March were reported yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, registrar of vital statistics in the city Health Department.

Grey Owl, author-naturalist, was buried here today. Grey Owl, who fought with the Canadian Expeditionary Forces in the Great War as Archibald Belaney and who often said his father was Scotch and his mother an Apache Indian, died Wednesday.

Miss Doris Burford Mentzendorff, daughter of Mr. And Mrs. Carl W. Mentzendorff of this place, was married this morning at the home of her parents to Robert Swan Goodlatte, son of Mr. And Mrs. Robert k. Goodlatte of Montclair.
Far-sighted landlords are giving more thought these days to the question of promoting a better feeling between owners of property and their tenants, particularly in the apartment-house field.

Reorganization of the Scott Stamp and Coin Company, one of the oldest and largest stamp concerns in the world, was announced yesterday by Hugh M. Clark, who recently purchased the .interests from Charles E. Hatfield, Boston.

Drastic changes in administrative policy intended to curtail the powers of presidents and heads of departments are being prepared for the four city colleges, it was disclosed yesterday by John T. Flynn, chairman of the Board of Higher Education's special committee of five.

The German Danubian fleet, consisting at present of the small units of the former Austrian flotilla, will be developed within a few years on a large scale, according to the Wiener Neueste Nachrichten.

The State Banking Department's weekly bulletin announced today that the Domestic Finance Corporation, 51 East Forty-second Street, New York, has received a license to transact business at 135-39 Northern Boulevard, Flushing on --

Five appointments to the Harvard Law School faculty for the coming academic year were announced today as follows: Hugh R. Jones of New Hartford, N. Y., second-year student, as chairman of the Board of Student Advisers;...

Bishop William T. Manning has taken active charge of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, the dean of the cathedral, who has been ill for the last five weeks in St. Luke's Hospital, has received a furlough until Oct. 15.

The "German Requiem" of Brahms was given last night at the Federal Music Theatre by the Federal Opera Chorus and the Greenwich Orchestra, both of the Federal Music Project, under the musical direction of Joseph Littau. The solo soprano part was taken by Margaret Stevenson, and Vincent Pesce sang the solo baritone part.
The Briggs Manufacturing Company informed its employes today that it would not sign a closed shop contract with the United Automobile Workers. Its posted announcement stated:
City Magistrates have been requested by Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. to give a written explanation hereafter for any sentences suspended by them, it was learned yesterday.

The "lost" Forty-third Division, which has been cut off in the Aran Valley from the main Spanish Loyalist army, will make a desperate stand against the Insurgents, disputing every inch of the fifty miles of road between Sort and the French frontier, its commander, Lieut. Col. Gomez Garcia, announced today to newspaper men.

Unusual importance is attached in well-informed circles here to the recent meeting of the Foreign Minsisters of Argentina and Brazil and also to the more general conference in Rio de Janeiro that included diplomatic representatives of other South American republics and the United States.

Governor Lehman signed the Supplemental Budget Bill today after eliminating from it items totaling $209,600. His vetoes of individual items thus brought the total down to $1,683,407. It brings the budget total to $388,048,022, or $12,000,000 under the record $400,000,000 for the current year.
The prospect of rain, choppy seas and tail winds tonight complicated preparations by the mighty crews of California and Washington for their annual race tomorrow.
Ernest C. Stout, attorney and former assistant editor of The Chicago Journal, died Tuesday in his home here, 4,017 Southport Avenue, at the age of 71.

Albania's Queen-to-be may not get all her trousseau because Hedi Raab, Vienna dressmaker who is preparing the trousseau for Countess Geraldine Apponyi's wedding April 27 to King Zog of Albania, cannot get permission to go to Tirana for the final fittings.

Edwin W. Dickinson, an artist whose work deserves to be more widely known, is having his first New York one-man show at the Georgette Passedoit Gallery, East Fifty-seventh Street. continue through the month.

The light cruiser St. Louis, fourth of the name in the navy, slid down the ways into the James River today to the din of whistles from harbor craft and the cheers of hundreds on the launching platform at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company.

Cardinal Hayes is the chief figure in a real estate deal by which he, as Archbishop of the New York Archdiocese of the Roman Catholic Church, has obtained full ownership of business properties here with an aggregate assessed valuation of about $1,000,000.

The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that Federal Judge Charles E. Woodward in Chicago had decided in its favor in a suit to enjoin the Universal Service Association, C. Franklin Davis,

It is most amazing to the that modern baseball scribes do not know their baseball history. Is it because they have come to believe that anything that happened before they were born never really happened, or at least never amounted to much?

Leo, the trade-mark lion, can stop yawning now and roar with some of his old enthusiasm, for Metro-oldwyn-Mayer has turned out a bang-up aviation drama (and we mean that literally as well as figuratively) in "Test Pilot," which opened at the Capitol yesterday.

Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye today faced the first genuine Japanese Government crisis since the start of the Sino-Japanese conflict, now in its tenth month. The Cabinet was sharply divided into two rival camps, and the Premier was reported threatening to resign over whether Japan should mobilize her full military strength in an effort to achieve a quick victory.

Jumping from a moving train near the Canadian National Railway station here just after noon as he was being deported back to the United States, Samuel Shadovitz of New York suffered a fractured skull and is in a hospital here in a serious condition.

Thomas A. Pratt, 70 years eld, retired New York silk broker and real estate operator, hanged himself this morning in the basement of his home at 25 Sickles Place, here, with a wire attached to a steam pipe, according to police. His widow, Mrs. Emma Hineline Pratt, found the body.

The report of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its principal operating subsidiaries for the three months ended on Feb. 28, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $36,242,620 after all operating expenses, taxes and charges.

Winning one of his adjourned games and drawing a second, Samuel Reshevsky, United States chess champion, regained the lead yesterday in the championship tournament of the National Chess Federation at the Marshall Chess Club. Albert C. Simonson, with one less game played, was right at his heels, with Isaao I. Kashdan and Reuben Fine almost on the same level.

The taste for expensive living that a racket leader acquires once he has attained a commanding position is the thing that trips him up when he tries to hide from the law, Special Deputy Attorney General John Harlan Amen said yesterday of the surrender of Jacob (Gurrah Jake) Shapiro.

Hal Price Headley's Menow joined Stagehand, Fighting Fox, Tiger and Nedayr as a topline favorite for the Kentucky Derby when he drove home an easy victor in the trial handicap in his 1938 debut today at Keeneland Park.

Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan said today he believed President Roosevelt's lending and spending program would stimulate recovery in the automotive industry. "I am convinced," he said, "that this program will mean the recovery of the automotive industry and when that gets going it will carry along with it other industries and business in general."

The volume of new bond financing this week dwindled to $1,313,000 and was restricted to the flotation of three relatively small municipal loans. Although the week was interrupted by the holiday yesterday it is doubtful if the volume would have been much larger even with a full period.

The whole WPA white-collar program, involving 30,000 workers in this city, must be re-drafted to conform with a new cost formula devised in Washington, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, disclosed yesterday.

Captain Byron R. Sackett and Lieutenant Louis M. Schauberger retired from the police department last midnight, it was announced by Commissioner Valentine. Captain Sackett was a member of the force for forty-two years.

The New York Central Railroad Company has applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to pledge certain securities as collateral for loans not exceeding $20,000,000 from banks "for corporate purposes, including the maintenance of adequate working fund."

The soil conservation and agricultural improvement program of the Tennessee Valley Authority is integrated with its other objectives in a comprehensive plan designed to bring a better way of living to the people of the valley.

State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to $19,934,501, against a revised total of $20,149,084 for this week, according to the Daily Bond Buyer. One State and fifty-three municipalities will be represented. The weekly average of new offerings in this field this year is $26,276,150.

Mrs. Antony A. Moray of this city and Orlando, Fla., has anbounced the marriage of her daughter, Miss Marian E. Alden, which took place in Elkton, Md., on Wednesday, to Eugene H. Burr of New York, associate editor and dramatic critic of The Billboard.

Still another of the games in the United States chess championship which may be entered for the Turover brilliancy prize is the notable victory scored by A. E. Santasiere over I. A. Horowitz in the tenth round. The former American Federation champion finally was outplayed by the ex-State champion.

The House Interstate Commerce Committee gave Congress a new Food, Drug and Cosmetic Bill today designed to close loopholes in a Public Health Protection Law which has been changed only slightly in the thirty-two years it has been on the statute books.

While Congressional leaders prepared to apply the greatest possible speed to the Administration's $5,000,000,000 recovery program, President Roosevelt stated today his intention to proceed immediately with other proposals suggested in his message yesterday, including elimination of tax-exempt securities for the future and curbs on monopolistic practice in business.
America's one-time "most beautiful blonde" divorced Hollywood's "handsomest producer" today. Mrs. Justine Johnstone Wanger complained that Walter Wanger was "abrupt, surly and discourteous."

Several hundred Passaio men, women and children, who had sallied forth Th with the rising sun to catch a Good 6 P. Friday meal on the opening day of the Jersey tro`ut season, caused have Mayor Benjamin F. Turner to be persi roused from his bed at 5:45 o'clock In this morning in the interest of good c sport and fair play.

Thirteen Congressmen representing dairy States urged the Committee for Reciprocity Information today to provide adequate tariff protection for the dairy industry in a revised reciprocal trade agreement with Canada.

In compliance with the request by President Roosevelt to consider simplification of regulations to assist and expedite the financing of industries, particularly small ones, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced to day some

The Federal Reserve Board announced today that "as a part of the government's program for encouragement of business recovery" it had reduced the reserve requirements on all classes of deposits of all member banks, effective at the opening of business tomorrow.

New York and most of the Atlantic coast basked in Summerlike weather yesterday as the thermometer here, repeating the action of the previous day, rose high enough to break all existing records for the date.
It may not have anything to do with the state of the nation, but it is a fact that the Senate has been prayed for but twice during the present session of Congress.
Bishop William T. Manning issued yesterday through The Diocesan Bulletin, the official monthly publication of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, the following Easter greeting to his clergy and laity:
Data compiled by the Central Statistical Board, a government agency, showed today that Federal relief outlays totaled $14,218,773,000 for the five-year period, 1933-37.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John E. Baxter of 159 Marlborough Road, Brooklyn, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Carroll Baxter, to John de Lacey Regan, son of Mrs. John F. Regan, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Regan.
King Carol's surprise visits to various parts of the kingdom to examine work done by government and other officials are producing serious results.

Charlotte Girl, daughter of Cohort, increased her undefeated record to five victories by outclassing five other juveniles in the twenty-sixth running of the Aberdeen Stakes, feature of today's opening program at this track. With Johnny Longden up, Charlotte Girl closed with speed in reserve and five lengths in advance of Star Runner as 10,000 fans looked on. Third was My Porter.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, who is now vacationing on the Island of St. Gildas, has purchased the small Island of Illiec, off the rocky north coast of Brittany. Illiec was formerly owned by the compose Ambroise Thomas.

FITZGERALD, AMELIA (July 26, 1937). Gross assets, $50,679; net, $46,036. To sons, Richard L., Frederic D. and John W. Fitzgerald, one-third of residuary estate each. Chief assets, real estate, $7,000; stocks and bonds, $18,800; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $24,269; miscellaneous property, $610. Lord, Day Lord, attorneys, 25 Broadway, Manhattan.

Some sales clerks at four midcity department stores joined members of the teamsters union today in refusing to pass through the picket lines of the striking warehousemen. Store deliveries remained at a standstill for the fourth day.

Roche's Beach, Inc., owner of the bathing pavilion property fronting 700 feet along the oceanfront from Beach Fourteenth to Beach Nineteenth Street, Far Rockaway, Queens, has leased it to Peter Tessler, who will make extensive alterations.
L. E. Douglass of Hutchinson, Kan., owner of fourteen oil wells, decided to treat his three children and their school friends to an Easter week-end holiday in Chicago this year. Result:

Herbert C. Hotaling, Minnesota weekly newspaper publisher and former president and executive secretary of the National Editorial Association, died at his home here tonight from uremic poisoning. His age was 72.

There has been a continued increase in motor car production, according to a summary today by Ward's Automotive reports. It placed the current week's production at 62,021 cars and trucks, compared with 60,975 last week, and 127,755 assemblies this week a year ago.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

All quiet on the Forty-Ninth Street Theatre front last evening. According to the. program, Ibsen's "The Wild Duck" was resting on the stage. From row C, which is not so far back, this correspondent could distinctly see a group of people huddling in a cloud of Ibsen gloom and at times perceptibly moving.

Unanimous endorsement of the campaign of the Greater New York Fund for $10,000,000 to finance private health and welfare work has been voted by the Central Trades and Labor Council, the fund announced yesterday.

The Park Association of New York City, Inc., appealed to Governor Lehman yesterday to recall his veto on at least two of the parkways appropriations bills- recently adopted by the Legislature and sponsored by the association.

The predominant color of Holy Week in Seville has always been black, for obvious reasons, but this year it has taken on added significance for the many families who mourn those fallen in Spain's bitter struggle.

J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, ruled today that bonds, notes or debentures issued by public housing agencies under the provisions of the United States Housing Act of 1937 and representing the 10 per cent local participation in

The inheritance factor in longevity and the effects of alcohol, tobacco and hard physical labor upon long life were discussed tonight by Dr. Raymond Pearl, Professor of Biology in Johns Hopkins University, in a lecture under the auspices of the Institute of Medicine of Chicago.

Mr. and Mrs. James T. Pettus have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Irene Pettus, to Philip K. Crowe of New York, son of Earle R. Crowe of Oakstone, Wilson Point, South Norwalk, Conn., and the late Mrs. Katharine McClellan Higgins Crowe.
Local unions of the rival A. F. of L. and C. I. O. in New York City made ready yesterday to submerge antagonisms in an effort to enforce organized labor's demands on the funeral industry.

The Graham Theatre, a moving to picture house at 279-81 Graham Avenue, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, was virtually destroyed by fire shortly before last midnight, just after the audience had filed out, when a film that Sidney Rothstein, the operator, was hi lowering from the projection booth

The Woods twins-Johnny, the "scientifically conditioned" one, and Jimmy, his "unconditioned" brother-are in the colt stage anyway, and, with-all the frikiness in them brought out yesterday by the balmy Spring weather, it was practically impossible-or at least highly hazardous-to get a pre-birthday interview with them.

Refrigerated human blood is being shipped to Spain for transfusions behind the lines because volunteer donors there are "half-starved and their blood is too thin for use," Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the Methodist Episcopal Church said today.

EATON, MINNIE (April 11). Estate, more than 10,000. To Marion Jones Kimbough, niece, care of Delta Cash Grocery Co., Tallulah, La., jewelry, household personal effects and one-half residue; Fred G. Jones, nephew, 815 No. Watkins St., Memphis, Tenn., one-half residue. Title Guarantee and Trust Co., 176 Broadway, executor; Georgia E. Johnson, sister, 246 So. Belvedere Blvd., Memphis, Tenn., petitioner.

Jascha Heifetz, Artur Rodzinski and the National Broadcasting Company Symphony Orchestra will participate in the concert to be given for the benefit of the Austrian refugees on Wednesday evening, April 27, at Carnegie Hall. Mr.

Plans for altering the apartment house at 2,303 Newkirk Avenue, Brooklyn, into modern suites of one and one-half and two and onehalf rooms were announced yesterday when the property was bought for cash by Alliger, Ratner Co., Inc.
The annual Spring tea dance of the Daughters of Maryland in New York will take place today in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Wilmer C. Gullette is president of the organization.

Fritz Grunscheder, local brewery employee, insisted today that Chancellor Hitler is seven years older than reference books indicate. Mr. Grunscheder said that the Fuehrer is 56 years old, although encyclopedias say he. will be 49 next Wednesday.

The Lokal Anzeiger, only morning newspaper to comment on President Roosevelt's radio speech, said today: "When President Roosevelt once more glorifies the democratic system in his crisis message, this is only a siren call with which he hopes to make an impression on Congress, which lately has not followed him obligingly."

The first nation-wide effort 'of the Federal Government to "bring back the road" for theatrical touring companies will be started within thirty days by the WPA Federal Theatre Project, it was disclosed at the close yesterday of a five-day meeting of the project's national policy board.

Senator Barkley told the Senate today that Federal expenditures totaling $17,000,000,000 showed "the present Administration has carried out the principle of Thomas Jefferson that we should unite for the common good."

Germany has formally asked the United States, through the American Embassy in Berlin, what it proposes to do about permitting exports of helium to Germany for inflation of the new dirigible now nearing completion.

The memory of a beautiful S. P. C. A. collie, "Nemo," together with their lifelong love of all animals, inspired two elderly sisters to bequeath close to $1,000,000 to the Massachusetts society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.
Archie Henderson, University of North Carolina graduate student, defeated Ed Fuller, a schoolmate, in the semi-finals of the North and South tennis tournament today, 6--4, 2--6, 3--6, 6--1, 6--0.

A bad lapse by Arsenal at Highbury today may cost the Londoners the championship of the English Football League. The Gunners had their colors lowered, 2-0, by Brentford and as a result are now only one point ahead of the Wolverhampton Wanderers and Preston North End in the race for the title.

Governor Lehman reiterated today his reasons for vetoing the McNaboe bill which would have barred from Civil Service persons believing in or teaching radical doctrines. He did so in a letter to Jeremiah F. Cross, State Commander of the American Legion, who last week asked the Governor to reconsider the veto.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Huntington entertained with a dinner tonight at their residence. For her son, John Heminway, Mrs. Jay O'Brien and Mr. O'Brien entertained a large group of the younger set for dinner at Villa Del Sarmiento.

President Roosevelt's influence was sought today by delegations from California and Ohio to straighten out political tangles in those States, especially in the crowded Gubernatrial primary contest in California, where Democratic leaders say present indications point to the nomination by Democrats of Culbert Olson, former manager of Upton Sinclair, and his probable election. Some of Mr. Olson's political foes attack him as a "Socialist."
The Rebels were almost down on the coast road when I was there this afternoon, and Loyalist Spain has now been divided in two.

Two veterans of the Loyalist army in Spain, both of whom had been discharged because of disabilities, returned on the United States liner Manhattan yesterday, having crossed the ocean in the ship's brig as stowaways.

Mrs. Kiliaen Van Rensselaer, who has just returned from Europe, and Mr. Van Rensselaer are at the Sherry-Netherland. Mr. and Mrs. Lincoln Isham of the Carlyle have gone to Manchester, Vt., for Easter.
William Bab, in 415 Central Park West; Edward W. Corson, in 380 Riverside Drive; Rose Silverman Simpson, in 140 E 53d St; Minnie Leveque, in 175 W 93d St; Henry Weinberger, in 250 W 104th St; Sharp

Clarence W. Robinson of 552 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, a Negro licensed lay reader of the Protestant Episcopal Church for forty years, died on Tuesday of a heart ailment during a visit to Bermuda, according to word received here yesterday. He was 69 years old.

Mrs. Mary Bain. and Mrs. Helen Kashdan were the winners in the two games adjourned from the sixth round of the women's tournament of the National Chess Federation and finished at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday.

The 24-year-old American, Steve Dudas, who will fight Max Schmeling here tomorrow night, was discovered on weighing-in today to be almost the German's physical twin. Schmeling weighed 194 pounds and Dudas 1941/2.

While. school holidays are expected to convert Madison -Square: Garden, where the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey show is playing, into a juvenile haven all next week, the underprivileged children of New York will have their special innings at the circus next Thursday and the following Monday, circus officials announced yesterday.
Ostend and Corn Dodger, two of the season's most promising timber horses, will go to the post as favorites in the eighteenth running of the $1,000 Middleburg Cup Steeplechase here tomorrow.

Stock Exchange was closed in observance of the Good Friday holiday. Banks remained open and what business was transacted was confined chiefly to commercial accounts. Quotations were unchanged for that type of loan.

Miss May Pershing left Tucson this morning for New York, where she will complete arrangements for the arrival of her brother, General John J. Pershing, next week. She was accompanied by Mrs. George Adamson, wife of the general's aide, Capson Adamson. tain Adamson.

Hopes of Westchester communities for renewal of service on the lines of the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad, on which operation was abandoned recently, were dealt a blow today when Governor Lehman vetoed the Williamson bill creating an eighteen-member State Authority, to be known as the Westchester and Bronx Railroad Authority, to operate the line.

A jury today awarded Mrs. Marnie Clark, 29, Chicago dancer, $6,500 for injuries received in an automobile accident near Coatesville, Pa., March 14, 1937, and awarded her nephew, Stafford J. Annon Jr., $5,000 for the death of his mother, who was killed in the same crash.

The Standard Commercial Tobacco Company, Inc., which acquired control of the Axton Fisher Tobacco Company two years ago in one of the largest deals in that industry in recent years, sought permission yesterday to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

Herb Kopf, Manhattan football coach, told 165 New York, Pennsylvania and New Jersey high and prep school athletic coaches today at the opening session of the two-day Rutgers University clinic that their job was to inspire confidence as well as to impart technical instruction.
Two moored steamers and cargo valued at $200,000 were menaced by flames which spread through creosote covered pilings today at Pier 48 on the waterfront.

Large increases in deposits inmutual savings banks in this State for the quarter ended on March 31, as well as for the sixmonths and the year, are revealed in figures released for publication today by the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.

A step toward peace in the combined lockout and strike of 15,000 workers in the fur industry of New York City was taken yesterday when Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, announced that two of the larger members of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc., had I agreed to discuss individual settlements.

The call of the Canadian Seamen's Union for a strike against seven large lake steamship companies was answered by 700 members in seven Canadian ports late tonight, union headquarters announced. About 250 seamen marched off twenty-five of the thirty-two ships in Toronto Harbor.

The Government's April crop report throws an interesting light on the farmers' own purposes for wheat-growing, regardless of such restrictions as the Agricultural Department may have placed upon acreage.

Thousands of Jews in New York City, in common with their coreligionists throughout the world, at sundown yesterday began observance of the festival of Passover, commemorating the deliverance of their ancestors from bondage in Egypt more than 3,000 years ago.

Award of four American Field Service fellowships for Americans to study in French universities, cartrying a stipend of $1,400 each, was announced yesterday by the Institute of International Education. Dr. Stephen Duggan is director of the institute.

The imminence of the signature of the Anglo-Italian agreements-tomorrow evening at about 6:30--prompts VirginioGayda, the Foreign Ministry mouthpiece, to declare very positively in tonight's Giornale d'Italia that the Rome-Berlin axis is and continues to be the fundamental guiding principle of Italian foreign policy.

Qualifying rounds for the United States open golf championship to be held at the Cherry Hills Club, Denver, June 9-11, will be played in thirty-one districts this year instead of thirty-two as was the case in a 1937.

Combining five bases on balls and four hits for all of their runs in the first two innings, the White Sox downed the Cubs, 5 to 4, today in the opening contest of a three-game city series duel. The battle was called in the last half of the eighth inning because of rain.
Political passions may sweep Capitol Hill in Washington, like the turbulent Winter winds that sometimes come whooshing across the Potomac. Old friends may arrive at a parting of the ways.

After kicking away twice a lump of waxy substance which had washed up on the shore, Clarence E. Miller, 42, of this city, a World War veteran employed on a WPA Moth Control Project on Plum Island, finally gave in and picked up what proved to be $5,000 worth of ambergris, which now reposes in the vault of the First National Bank.

The Daladier government obtained a virtual settlement of the strike in the aviation factories today, but the sit-down occupation of other metal plants will continue over Easter. Nationalized aviation plants were working today and, in accordance with the verdict of the arbitrator, collective contracts were signed for the entire industry, nationalized and private.
A new hope for correcting deformities in children which are due to bones failing to grow in unison was reported today before the American Association of Physical Anthropologists.

The Rev. Frederick B. Fisher, pastor of the Central Methodist Episcopal Church of Detroit and former Bishop of India, died today in Henry Ford Hospital at the age of 56, after an illness of a few hours.

A loan from the Railroad Credit Corporation to the Central Railroad of New Jersey which stood originally at $500,000 was reduced to $234,987 in 1937, according to the annual report for the period, issued yesterday by Edward W. Scheer, president.

The Soviet Government's concern over the chronic shortage of consumer goods and the exorbitant prices charged for almost every product, was shown again by attacks in the official press today on faults and abuses. Both the Commissariat of Light Industry, whose chief, I. E. Lubimoff, recently was removed, and the Commissariat of Local Industries are called to time for bad work.

Plans for a modern ballroom and amusement center in the midtown area were announced yesterday in connection with the transfer by the Central Savings Bank to the Dalu Corporation, Louis J. Brecker, president, of the former Red Ball Skating Rink at 239-41 and 261-63 West Fifty-second Street, running through to 242-64 West Fifty-third Street.
Colonel Alvin S. Perkins,' U.S.A., retired, died at Lakewood, Fla., yesterday at the age of 58, the War Department was informed today.
The Rev. Joseph Edward Simpson, a retired Methodist Episcopal minister, died of uremia yesterday in the Methodist Episcopal Hospital in this city, where he had been a patient since Feb. 15.

The Merchants Association of New York yesterday cabled the Secretary of the Treasury of Honduras requesting Dostponement for thirty days of an order, issued yes-terday, requiring certificates of origin on all merchandise arriving on and after April 21.

Frederick W. Smythe, florist and landscape architect, head of the New York firm of Wadley Smythe, florists, Madison Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, died here last night of a cerebral hemorrhage at his home, 385 Tuckahoe Road, after a week's illness.

Oley Nelson, Past National Commander of the Grand Army of the Republic, died at the home of his daughter here this afternoon after an Illness of several weeks. His age was 93. He 'served as National G. A. R. Commander from September, 1935, to September, 1936.

Alf M. Landon, dressed in oil field clothes, dropped into The Emporia Gazette office today on his way to visit one of his oil wells. "Governor," asked one of William Allen White's reporters, "what do you think about the President's radio speech last night?"

A client of Angell, Van Schaick Co., Inc., brokers, has purchased a plot of about an acre on Innes Avenue, Scarsdale, Westchester, from James Innes. The new owner plans to improve the site with an English-type residence for his own occupancy.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has asked permission of the Securities and Exchange Commission to withdraw a registration statement filed on March 30, last, Robert E. Gross, president, announced today.
Postmaster General Farley, ruling today that "bank nights" are a lottery, barred Affiliated Enterprise, Inc., of Denver, and its officers from further use of the mails.

Sale of a block in the Inlet beachfront section here to George S. Idell, Philadelphia architect and developer, for $125,000 has been approved by Judge Palmer M. Way. frame hotels and a row of Boardwalk back to Orientai Avenue, and from Massachusetts to Metropolitan Avenue.

Federal agents identified today about $75,000 worth of jewels found cached in a Negrb cemetery as the property of Albert Warner, motion-picture producer, whose Miami Beach home was robbed last February.

When the Central Savings Bank sold to the 245 East 39th Street Corp, Fanny Rosenblum, president, the three five-story tenements at 243-247 E 39th St, it took back two demand mortgages, a purchase money for $85,000 and a building loan for $35,000. the indicated selling price being $90,000.

Anti-labor activities by employer associations have become "a menace to democratic government," the Senate Civil Liberties Committee charged today in a report to the Senate, when $60,000 was asked to continue studies of "violations of free speech and the rights of labor."
Dr. George L. Wilcox, New York and New Rochelle dentist for fifty years, died suddenly of a! heart attack yesterday at his home here. His age was 82.

The rehabilitation of persons suffering from leprosy and additional provision for members of their families are two important factors in checking the spread of this disease, according to Mrs. Eunice Weaver, who represented the Brazilian Mission to Lepers at the recent International Congress of Leprosy held in Cairo, Egypt.
Mrs. Albert W. Beaven, wife of the president of the ColgateRochester Divinity School and a church and charity worker, died in a hospital here today at the age of 50.

Just as labor was given its "bill of rights" in the Wagner Act, so should industry protect and clarify its bill of rights, Allan Brown, director of public relations of the Bakelite Corporation and former chairman of the Association of National Advertisers, declared yesterday in an address before the advertising and marketing forum of the Advertising Club of New York.

The New York Maritime Council announced last night that it had asked Representative John J. O'Connor, chairman of the House Committee on Rules, to support a proposal for investigation of ship lines operating under United States registry. The council consists of nine unions affiliated with the C. I. 0.

Wholesale volume this week, helped by a jump in replacement orders resulting from increased consumer purchasing, rose 10 to 15 per cent over the preceding week, but was still 10 to 25 per cent below the corresponding period of 1937, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

Charles A. Lavery of this city, a member of the local Board of Alcoholic Beverage Control and former Democratic city chairman, died-today at Orange Memorial Hospital after an operation. His age was 45.

The City Department of Welfare accepted yesterday the suggestion of the State Department of Social Welfare that the city assume responsibility for the selection of free milk recipients, instead of leaving the choice to private social agencies.
Nine seniors were admitted into the Taft School Cum Laude Society tonight, when Dr. Claud M. Fuess, headmaster of Phillips Andover Academy, gave the principal address.

The New York racing season, foremost in the country for half a century, begins this afternoon at pared Jamaica with the Paumonok Handicap, traditional inaugural feature of the Metropolitan Jockey Club's meeting, heading the card. The $7,500 added, six-furlong sprint will be run as the fifth event on a program scheduled to begin at 2:30 P. M.

Word came from England today that Bradford Washburn, mountaineer and explorer, was to receive the Cuthbert Peek Prize of the Royal Geographic Society of London for his exploration and glacial studies in Alaska.
The Securities and Exchange Commission decided today to question three of the partners of J. P. Morgan Co. publicly next week on resuming its investigation into the failure of Richard Whitney Co.

New life insurance written in March amounted to $672,142,000, against $917,442,000 in March, 1937, a decrease of 26.7 per cent, the Association of Life Insurance Presidents reported yesterday to the Department of Commerce.

Vincent Mackay, 15-year-old student of Stuyvesant High School, was found dead of a bullet wound from a .22-caliber rifle late last night in his home at 77 Vermilyea Avenue, in the Inwood section of Washington Heights.

The Robert Henderson-Estelle Winwood revival of "The Merry Wives of Windsor" will close this evening. at the Empire TheatreBroadway's only closing of the night. Opening Thursday, a violent set of notices greeted it.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman General Motors Corporation, will be the guest speaker at the annual dinner of the National Automobile Dealers' Association in Detroit on April 27, speaking on "The Dealer, the Manufacturer and the Consumer."

For some years a topic has been: revived occasionally which always resulted in considerable discussion by trout fishermen and brought on verbal battles between various members of rod and gun clubs. This topic concerned the setting aside of certain streams for fly fishing and the necessity of buying a special license to fish these streams.

Mexico has agreed to remove the 3 per cent surtax on imports which was collectible by Mexican Consuls abroad before shipment of the articles to Mexico. A promise to this effect has been transmitted to Washington through diplomatic channels.

The Robert Henderson-Estelle Winwood revival of "The Merry Wives of Windsor" will close this evening. at the Empire TheatreBroadway's only closing of the night. Opening Thursday, a violent set of notices greeted it.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman General Motors Corporation, will be the guest speaker at the annual dinner of the National Automobile Dealers' Association in Detroit on April 27, speaking on "The Dealer, the Manufacturer and the Consumer."

For some years a topic has been: revived occasionally which always resulted in considerable discussion by trout fishermen and brought on verbal battles between various members of rod and gun clubs. This topic concerned the setting aside of certain streams for fly fishing and the necessity of buying a special license to fish these streams.

Department store sales for the week ended April 9 showed a decline of 7 per cent from those of the corresponding week one year ago, and for the four weeks ended April 9 a decline of 11 per cent as compared with the same four weeks in 1937, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Dr. Francis, E. Townsend, flying East to serve a thirty-day Jail term for contempt of a Congressional committee, criticized today what he termed "useless" efforts to gain for him a Presidential pardon.

Easter will be observed in all churches tomorrow. Everywhere prayers will be offered that before another Easter wars may have ended. Every edifice in the city has prepared for an overflow congregation at the morning service.

The formation of public opinion and the history of Austria since the World War are among the prob-lems "Behind and Beyond the hour, News," which will be discussed at had b Mount Holyoke's annual Alumnae stood College, June 13-17. The sessions Street will follow the college's 101st eommencement..
Burleigh Grimes, the only man in the major leagues to wear No. 13 on his uniform, will be hard to convince that his defiance of the ancient superstition is going to bring him ill fortune.

Oscar Wenderoth, former supervising architect of the Treasury Department at.Washington and a former associate of the architectural firm of Carrere Hastings, this city, died here yesterday after a brief illness at the age of 67.
The Legislature today had difficulty officially in observing Good Friday, the most carefully observed religious and official holiday of the calendar year here.

A five-year extension of the $4,500,000 mortgage on the thirty-six-story Ruppert Building has been arranged by Wood. Dolson Co, Inc, broker, with the New York Life Insurance Co for the Jacob Ruppart Realty Corp.

Mexico has agreed to remove the 3 per cent surtax on imports which was collectible by Mexican Consuls abroad before shipment of the articles to Mexico. A promise to this effect has been transmitted to Washington through diplomatic channels.
The Italian liner Rex, leaving today for Mediterranean ports, will have among her 900 passengers Mr. and Mrs. Homer P. Hargrave, Baroness Lili Hatvany, Mr. and Mrs. Ettore Panizza, Mr and Mrs.
Sheriff's officers of Los Angeles County crashed an electrically operated gate today and served papers on Jackie Coogan's mother and stepfather.

The experts can't see anybody but the New York Yankees in this year's American League pennant race. Of the sixty sports editors and writers who participated in the twelfth annual Associated Press pennant poll, fifty-two picked the champions to repeat. Six voted for the Detroit Tigers and two for the
Cotton-mill activity increased seasonally last week, and the adjusted index remained unchanged from the previous week's figure at 90.6. It was 136.9 for the week ended April 10, 1937.
The Rev. C. Everett Wagner will complete tomorrow service of ten years as pastor of the Union Methodist Church, Forty-eighth Street, west of Broadway, known as the "Protestant Actors' Church."

Rescuers, summoned by radio across a fogbound sea, picked up all nine members of the crew of the Boston fishing trawler Exeter thirty miles off the Nova Scotia coast on Brown's Banks late this afternoon after the men had abandoned their blazing craft and drifted for seven hours in open boats.
A new-born baby died in a hospital here last night after living for nearly seventeen hours without breathing.
The Pennsylania Railroad will put into service on June 15 nine new streamlined passenger trains, headed by two Broadway Limiteds, making the largest fleet of such trains on any Eastern road.

Most Congressional leaders appeared pessimistic today about the chances for passage of the revised Wage-Hour Bill at this session, principally because it made no provision for different standards in the North and South.

Henry J. Saunders of Washington, D. C., told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that operating costs on Southeastern carriers were less than on lines in the North where lower freight rates prevailed.

Professor O. M. W. Sprague of the Harvard Business School, expressed approval of President Roosevelt's spending program during a lecture today. "There is no fundamental objection to increased Federal expenditures during a depression or recession," he said, "if the government credit is strong and it is in this country today."

As the undeclared Sino-Japanese War enters its tenth month, the victory anticipated by the invaders seems more remote than ever. Despite nearly three months of intensive fighting on a front of several hundred miles,

If Councilman Michael J. Quill had not selected the end of December as a good time to go to Ireland and get married our City Council would be in a different position from that in which it has been left by a decision handed down Thursday by the Appellate Division.

Because the mood and aspect of the world is more suggestive of Calvary than the feast of Resurrection, any sign of reconciliation between nations is like a break in the black spell that hangs over Europe.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Regarding THE TIMES editorial entitled "Compulsory Patent Licensing," some of our 'Representatives, judging by their proposals, utterly fail to realize the commercial importance of the point you raise.
New Yorkers of all creeds gathered in great numbers yesterday in their churches and elsewhere to remember the agony of the first Good Friday.
Governor Hurley today praised President Roosevelt's proposed anti-depression spending and lending program, saying: "It is an optimistic sign and should be a good move for business."

1st Lt. John J. Ritter, MA.-Res., Harlem Hospital, New York, N. Y. (D) is ordered to active duty, effective April 19, at Headquarters Second Military Area, 641 Washington St., New York, N. Y., for duty In the office of the Medical Executive. Date of rank: March 7, 1938. He will revert to an inactive status on May 2.

The State Adjutant General's recent order depriving some 50,000 small boys of the coveted privilege of calling themselves junior "naval reservists" and "militiamen" was the result of a broad inquiry by that office into all kinds of quasimilitary groups functioning in the State, including such organizations as the German American Bund, he revealed yesterday.

The National Maritime Union, most powerful of the unions of licensed merchant marine personnel on the Atlantic Coast, voted last night to discontinue negotiations with the American Steamship Owners Association for a wage contract which would cover all ship lines operating from Atlantic ports.
An official investigation in the State of Rio Grande do Sul has disclosed that out of 2,845 German private schools in that State only twenty taught Portuguese, the official Brazilian language.

Gene Gagliardi of Mount Vernon, N. Y., failed in the defense of his singles championship at the American Bowling Congress today. He concluded his schedule with a disappointing 535 in the individual event. A year ago he totaled 749 to win.
Broadcasters traced along the nation-wide networks yesterday to find out where the mysterious bell originated to punctuate President Roosevelt's twelfth "fireside chat" on Thursday night.

President Roosevelt announced that he would forward to Congress next week additional messages dealing with reforms in tax-exempt issues and monopolistic practices. He signed a bill increasing authorized air-mail route mileage.

Two inquiries were in progress yesterday into the circumstances under which Detectives James Hayden and Eugene Canaveri of the Homicide Squad late last Wednesday night accompanied Miss Norma De Marco, an important witness in the Howdy Club hold-up in Greenwich Village, to a West Fifty-eighth Street apartment.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today it had ordered Robert Morris, Bordentown, N. J., trading as D. P. Pen Company, to discontinue certain representations the commission said were false and misleading.

The hope that some way can be found for a more liberal supply of war materials from the United States to China was expressed here yesterday in an interview by Wang Ching-wei, former Premier of China and newly designated deputy to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek as dictator of the Kuomintang, China's ruling party.

The signature tomorrow of the Anglo-Italian agreement finishes the first stage of the great offensive that Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain is planning for the appeasement of Europe by reconciling the pacific democracies and the dynamic dictatorships.

Five appointments to a Council on Public Service Training, created to assist the Education Department in planning public service training programs for municipal employes, were announced today by the State Board of Regents.

With Pat Brennan giving only three hits and striking out eight in going the full nine innings, Bushwick High School downed the Morris High baseball team, 7 to 3, in a non-league game at Sterling Oval yesterday. The setback was the first in two starts for Morris.

Dovercourt Citadel Band of the Salvation Army in Toronto, with forty-five musicians, will play Easter hymns tomorrow at the dawn service to be held in the Mall, Central Park, from 6:45 to 7:45 o'clock.

All studios having been advised by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey against the use of the prosecutor's name in connection with a film story, RKO has changed the title of "Smashing the Rackets" to "The Clean-Up."

AN OPEN LETTER TO JEWS AND CHRISTIANS, By John Cournos. (Oxford University Press, $2.50.) Mr. Cournos here ventures on a controversial theme dealing with the attitude of the Jews today toward their "greatest. prophet"-Christ.

Nelson W. Durham, editorial writer and editor emeritus of The Spokesman-Review, died of a heart ail ment today at the age of 78. A Pacific Northwest newspaper man for fifty-five years, the editor-historian was stricken twelve days ago.

Dr. William A. Wovsohin, a physician for many years in this city, died yesterday at Montefiore Hospital, Bainbridge Avenue and GunHill Road, the Bronx, at the age of 56. His offices were at 40 West Seventy-seventh Street.

Miss Audrey Hammond Madden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Jay Madden of Brookside Park, this place, has completed the plans for her marriage on May 12 to William Henry Chickering, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Lawrence Chickering of Piedmont, Calif.

Mayor La Guardia, commenting yesterday on the decision by the Appellate Division holding that Councilman John Cashmore, Brooklyn Democrat, was legally elected vice chairman, said the court had ample precedent for deciding the other way.

The Treasury, which is attempting to obtain lower cement prices for the government, received twentyfour bids today from manufacturers willing to sell the commodity at their mills. The practice in the cement industry up to this time has been to sell at destination prices.

Roy E. Larsen, vice president of Time, Inc., and publisher of Life, has purchased the Udo M. Fleishmann estate in Greenfield Hill, Fairfield, Conn., through the Burgoyne Hamilton Company, Inc., brokers.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
The intercollegiate rowing season will be formally opened in the metropolitan area today with a triangular regatta on the Harlem among crews from Columbia, Manhattan and Rutgers.

A grand jury today returned a no-bill on perjury charges which Governor Martin L. Davey brought against Lee Bradley,' Cleveland asphalt salesman. Mr. Davey said, however, that it is "my sacred duty" to "fight this case through to a proper conclusion by every legal means at my command."

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Molloy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Pierce Molloy, to John Munro Butler, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Fenwick Butler of Brooklyn, took place yesterday noon at the home of the bride's parents, 55 Eighty-third Street, Brooklyn.
THREE great wonders of Southwestern America -- the Grand Canyon, Boulder Dam and Lake Mead -- and many lesser wonders are now within easy view of travelers by air.

Francis J. Cronin of 22 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, a lawyer, was sworn in yesterday as an assistant attorney general. The oath was administered by Attorney General Bennett at the State Office Building, 80 Center Street, in the presence of about thirty friends and relatives of Mr. Cronin.

Japanese today clamped a rigid censorship on all dispatches dealing with military and shipping activities on the north Shantung coast. It became known, however, that reinforcements were moving toward Taierhchwang, where the Japanese suffered their most disastrous defeat of the nine-month-old war last week.

The City College varsity show "In the Groove;" which will be given at the Pauline Edwards Theatre, Thursday, Frirday and Saturday, will be the college Dramatic Society's semi-annual production to celebrate its golden jubilee year.

Dr. Celestin Bougle, director of 1'Ecole Normale Superieure of the University of Paris, will deliver the annual Julius and Rosa Sachs Foundation Lectures of Teachers College, Columbia University, next Wednesday and Friday and a week from tomorrow at 5:10 P. M. in the

The following Foreign Service changes since April 8 were announced today by the State Department: Howard K. Travers of Central Valley, N. Y., First Secretary of Legation and Consul at Budapest, appointed Consul General there to serve in a dual capacity.

The engagement of Miss Jane Gordon Hamersley, daughter of Mrs. Jewett Hamilton Scranton of this city, and the late William James Hamersley, to Douglas Brownell Wright, son of Mrs. Arthur B. Wright of West Hartford, and the late Dr. Wright, has been announced by her mother and stepfather.

The North End Kennel Club show, listed for May 21 at the Rialto Hall, is expected to attract one of the largest entry lists for a non-point dog event in the history of Montreal. Arrangements are being made to provide three large rings and capable ring stewards so that judging may be handled expeditiously.
Dr. and Mrs. Allen 0. Whipple of Fieldston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Allen Whipple, to Dr. Richard John Bing, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Bing of Munich, Germany.

A series of six public lectures on the subject "The History of Religion" will be held from April 25 to May 4 at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, Broadway and 122d Street. The lectures will take place at 8:15 P. M.

A BROADENING of the scope of the General Motors Dealer Council Plan was announced last week by Alfred P. Sloan, chairman of General Motors Corporation. The new arrangement, which will make it possible for General Motors dealers to make suggestions to the Dealer Council group by letter,
