Men of this Pictou County mining town, who sent the draegermen to Moose River after the Easter Sunday mine cave-in two years ago, did their Easter good turn again today.

Prime Minister and Mrs. Neville Chamberlain are spending this Easter Sunday and most of Easter Week in the Far North of Scotland as the guests of the Marquess and Marchioness of Londonderry at the castle of Viscount Chaplin, Lady Londonderry's brother.

WITH Salzburg gone the way of Baireuth, where shall the international music lover now turn in Europe for a festival with anything like the distinctive qualities these two possessed in a day before so much elevated art had been degraded to the service of politics?

Miss Estelle Follis of New York, daughter of Harvey Follis of Guelph, Ont., and. the late Mrs. Follis, was married to Raymond J. Ippolite, also of this city, yesterday noon in the chapel of the Riverside Church by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick.
Dr. James C. Clarke, who had practiced medicine for nearly fifty years, died here yesterday at his home at the age of 72.

The wedding of Miss Eleanor Anthony, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Anthony of South Orange, to Linton M. Solomon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon of Macon, Ga., took place this afternoon in the home of the bride's parents. Her grandfather, the Rev. Bascom Anthony of Macon, performed -the ceremony.

A BASIC unit in the. Boy Scout movement to build youthful character, develop leadership and train in citizenship is the patrol. There may be two or more patrols, of four to eight boys each, in the troop.
Production renowned of gold in Canada in February amounted to 340,838 ounces, cornpared with 361,086 in January and 310,074 in February, 1937, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reports.

Mr. Roosevelt went straight to the heart of things when he said in his fireside chat on Thursday night, "Bitterness is never a useful instrument in public affairs." This was putting it mildly. As the President's very next sentence admirably summed it up, bitterness is a good deal worse than useless in the governance of nations.

STATION EAR on the Madrid "radio front" has been heard broadcasting on a new extended schedule which runs continuously from 7 until 9 P. M. The programs have been confined for the most part to rapid-fire news reports in Spanish, with English reports near 7 and 8 P. M., Eastern standard time.

Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Kushner of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence Kushner, to Dr. Joseph S. Mansker, son of Mrs. Ann Mansker of the Bronx, formerly of Brockton, Mass.

When the Francis P. Garvan gold medal for outstanding achievement among women chemists is awarded this week to Dr. Emma Perry Carr of Mount Holyoke College, atonement for Mr. Garvan's skepticism when the Chemical Foundation was solicited for a contribution toward a survey of women in chemistry will be made.
The International League of Aviators today announced the selection of Henry T. (Dick) Merrill as the world championn aviator of 1937. Jean Batten of New Zealand was named the best aviatrix.

Officers of the Hoagland Allum Company, a brokerage with offices in Chicago and at 40 Exchange Place, this city, have been summoned to appear on Wednesday before Justice Frankenthaler in Supreme Court with all business records for examination by Attorney General Bennett, it was announced yesterday.

FORTUNE GALLO will present his SanCarlo Opera Company in an eleven-day season, opening May 5, at the Center Theatre. Thirteen operas will be given. The series of performances, sponsored by the Municipal Art Committee. will mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of the company's first activities in this city.
THE HUNDRED YEARS WAR was entering its final quarter when William Caxton was born, somewhere in the Weald of Kent. When about fifty years later he embarked on his literary career,

PRODUCTION schedule in automotive plants fail to reflect any reaction to the death of the Federal Reorganization Bill at the hands of the House last week and drastic revisions by the Senate of Federal taxes covering corporations.

SCOTLAND is expecting great things from the Empire Exhibition it is sponsoring here this Summer. Not only are plans being made to entertain more than 15,000,000 British visitors, but no effort has been spared to induce Americans to begin their European tours here "at the top of the map."

HUDSON would have liked much of this book. Many years ago he adjured us to "see birds emotionally," and this is exactly what Mr. Halle does. And he sees more than birds; he sees the forests and swamps and oceans, in and upon which birds live, with an unusual awareness of color,

The seriousness of the Japanese Government crisis was indicated today by the continuous stream of political leaders to the villa of Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye, who was reported to be threatening to resign.

Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Wildes Davis of Portland, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Davis, to Joseph Hale Johnson, son of the late Mrs. M. Griswold Johnson of Hartford, Conn.
Discovery of an electric thermostat in the brain which automatically governs body heat through Winter and Summer was announced today at the closing session of the American Associatin of Anatomists.
Twenty-seven Radcliffe students will assist the Lowell House Musical Society at Harvard in giving a production of Henry Purcell's seventeenth century opera "Dido and Aeneas" on Wednesday evening.

J. A. Sullivan, president of the Canadian Seamen's Union, today asserted that nearly forty steamships owned by seven Canadian steamship companies were tied up in Canada's first big strike on the Great Lakes.
The Spanish Insurgents opened today a fresh offensive east of Balaguer, in the center of the long Catalonian front, to crush the outlying defenses of Barcelona.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Carolyn Ward Potter, daughter of Mrs. Frederick Arthur Potter of this place and of Mr. Potter of Utica, to Dr. Le Roy Hamilton Wardner of Saranac Lake.

In the United States chess championship at Rockefeller Center, where the twelfth round will be contested this afternoon and evening, the games are becoming and longer and more stubbornly con- won tested. A notable one was the ninthround match between the champion, Samuel Reshevsky, and Arthur W. Dake of Portland, Ore., champion of the Pacific Coast.

BERNHARD BERENSON, as far back as the first edition of his "Venetian Painters" (and maybe before that), evinced great interest in not so much a factual, specific analogy between the Italian Renaissance and our own time, but rather the kindred feeling we are wont to experience in looking back

Upturns developed in the three primary markets last week, but in only one was there a strong statistical basis for recovery. Better sales of hides were made at higher prices and the position of the entire hide, leather and shoe industry was described as unusually firm.

The Park Department urges property owners to take advan-tage of the department's services in planting trees on streets in the city. The department has arranged for the private planting of nineteen trees-in Sixty-fourth Street, between Lexington and Third
French troops and mobile guards raided Nationalist headquarters in six towns and cities near the port of Susa today, closing the buildings and arresting a number of suspected agitators.

Word of the signing of the Anglo-Italian pact was received with satisfaction here as marking the successful conclusion of the first move in the realistic foreign policy of Britain's Prime Minister, Neville Chamberlain.

Operations in hosiery mills have been stepped up appreciably in the last two weeks as knitters have attempted to make up time lost during the wage discussions in the Philadelphia district. With sales of women's full-fashioned hosiery in branded lines still holding up well, producers were unable to make shipments on time during the labor tie-up and are now catching up on these deliveries.

Two large undeveloped tracts in Queens County, L. I., one being in Flushing and the other in Jackson Heights, ??re purchased by building syndicates last week for immediate improvement with medium-priced homes.

Miss Freda Evelyn Man-Hanzlik, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Henry Hanzlik of Chippewa Falls, Wis., was married to William Frederick Adler, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Andrew Adler of this city, yesterday noon in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

WHEN The Morning Post was devoured by The Daily Telegraph, Geoffrey Grigson, who had served it for several years as assistant literary editor, took up an appointment in the editorial office of a leading book publisher.

Dr. J. B. Rhine of Duke University believes the case for clairvoyance and telepathy (extra sensory perception) is now so strong that he can take the next step-find out whether or not the gift of prophecy resides in some of us.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska. WITH the Spring break-up a short way ahead, Alaskan aviation is bringing to a close another successful Winter's operation and preparing itself for the most difficult time of its annual contest with the natural hazards of the country.

Of the thirty-five American and Asiatio varieties of magnolia (besides the hybrids),, one -that is native to Japan's forests, the Stellata, has features that make it adaptedto the small garden. It is bushy, slow growing, never reaches a height greater than fifteen feet, and even when very young blossoms abundantly.
This year New York City, through its own agencies, will collect some $650,000,000 in tax money, including about $70,000,000 to be raised through the special taxes for unemployment relief.

Miss Mary Dorsey Forsyth, a descendant of Colonel Harry Dorsey of the Revolutionary Army and of Chief Justice John Marshall, was married here yesterday afternoon to Lewis Stanley Williams, who is connected with many old Virginia families.

To meet the demands of students who cannot go to college but want advanced training, the evening division of the New York City school system is planning to offer collegiate-grade courses to high school graduates in the Fall.

Many men and women interested in the welfare of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children have subscribed to the Spring fashion show to be given Thursday night at the Bergdorf Goodman salon, 754 Fifth Avenue, to raise funds for the infirmary.

Miss Beatrice L. Croft, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Croft of Yonkers, was married here this evening in Christ Church to Ralph Taft Farnum Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Farnum of Canaan, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward Thomas Taggard.

The talks recently delivered by nineteen lecturers at the public housing course conducted by the New York University division of general education have been published by the university in a book entitled "Public Housing Management."

Cornelius Francis Kelly, newspaper publisher and representative, died in his home here early today of a heart attack. He was 64 years old. Mr. Kelly, who was president of the Kelly-Smith Company, newspaper representative, of 420 Lexington Avenue.

Miss Evelyn Bird, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Orvil Bird of South Orange, was married to John Philip Colton, son of Mrs. Edgar L. Kendrick of El Paso, Texas, this afternoon in the House of Prayer of First Presbyterian Church, Orange.

Realty assets of ten closed New Jersey national banks will be offered at auction in a series of sales to be held this month under the supervision of Joseph P. Day, William A. White Sons and Albert M. Greenfield Co.. Inc.

Miss Elizabeth Surbrug, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Willard Surbrug of Verona, was married this afternoon in the First Congregational Church here to Joseph Simmons, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph I. Simmons of Montclair. The pastor, the Rev. Dr. Archibald Black, performed the ceremony.

William Nagle of the Manhattan Figure Skating Club carried off the men's senior singles crown at the Middle Atlantic figure-skating championships held at the Iceland rink last night. A crowd of 1,800 saw Nagle triumph.
Mr. and Mrs. George Angue Dobyne gave a farewell party tonight, abuffet dinner on their yacht Coconut.

Blasting Sugar Cain for four runs in each of the third and fifth innings the Cubs defeated the White Sox, 10 to 4, before 7,780 fans at Wrigley Field today and clinched Chicago's Spring baseball honors for the National League.

The death sentence imposed Dec. 9 on James Dalhover, last survivor of the Al Brady outlaw gang, for the murder of an Indiana State policeman, was affirmed today by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals in a two-toone decision.

THE steady demand for American-made airplanes was stimu lated again last week by the announcement that the British Government is sending a commission to this country to place orders for planes for national defense.

The body of a man tentatively identified as Joseph De Milt, about 52 years old, of 136 West Seventieth Street, New York, was found here tonight in an alleyway opposite 220 Ellison Street. He was found to have been the victim of a heart attack.

Ralph Marano captured the skeet event at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today with 50 in a row. G. B. Watts, and I. Richards tied at 48 for the second cup. Watts won the shoot-off by breaking 25 straight. Richards had 24. T.
The annual meeting of the Travelers Aid Society will be held on the afternoon of April 26 at the Cosmopolitan Club, with Dale Carnegie, author and lecturer, the speaker.

German clubs of seven institutions will present an all-German program at Bryn Mawr College next Saturday night. Begun by the Women's College of the University of Delaware, the annual festival is held on a different campus each year.
Mrs. Michael J. Cashman of 790 Riverside Drive has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Catherine Cashman, to Carl V. Johnson, son of Mrs. Peter Johnson of Brooklyn.

For outstanding workmanship on the two new wings of the New York Historical Society building, under construction on Seventy-sixth and Seventy-seventh Streets, adjoining the main building at 170 Central Park West, twenty workmen will receive certificates of superior craftsmanship and gold buttons from the New York Building Congress on Tuesday.

THIS volume of recollections by Julian Hawthorne is steeped in the memory of old Concord days and New England notables long since dead, with only the author, who had been a boy among them, marching sturdily down the years to become, in the words of Oliver Wendell Holmes (not the least of the notables whom he knew), "The last leaf on the tree."
THE NRF Press publishes two volumes of Jacques de Lacretelle: selections from his novels ("Morceaux Choisis," 332 pp., 21f.) and a collection of essays ("L'Ecrivain Public", 214 pp., 15f.).

THIS little book by Richard Freund, author of "Zero Hour," is a remarkably lucid and perspicacious presentation of the problem which seems to have caused world-wide insomnia. Mr. Freund holds that the conflict between Germany. and Czechoslovakia is inherent in the condition of Europe.
Facilities for parking or housing automobiles must be provided in the future for all private houses and apartments erected here under a recent amendment to the zoning laws.

At the conclusion of a day of trying competition, the judges in the open all-age stake of the Orange County Field Trial Club named Bill's Dr. Ricks the top dog. This white and liver pointer dog is owned by Clarence F. Gaines of Sherburne, N. Y., and was handled by George Crangle.

Charlie McCarthy has caused a change in church service schedules at Herb Lake. The Rev. Hugh R. Percy is holding services at 8 P. M. on Sunday now instead of 7 so that his congregation can listen to McCarthy.
Fire charged to an incendiary swept today through 250 acres of woodland near Magnolia, Burlington County, destroying a large amount of valuable timber.

Of $62,306 in net revenue received from its railway operations in 1937, the Fonda, Johnstown Gloversville Railroad paid $48,604, or 78 per cent, in taxes, according to the annual report of J. Ledlie Hees, trustee in bankruptcy. The company accrued $7,868 for pension law liabilities and $6,155 for New York State and Federal unemployment insurance in 1937.
Robert Kennedy Toaz, Superintendent of the Huntington public school system from 1906 until his retirement in 1933, died today in his home here of a heart attack. He was 68 years old.

Plans for enlisting the aid of builders, material manufacturers, schools of architecture, city planning authorities and allied interests in a vast program of housing will be presented this week in New Orleans at the seventieth convention of the American Institute of Architects.

The Knickerbocker Assemblies for this season will be concluded with the third dance in the series next Saturday night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The date for the party is in accordance with the tradition, established many years ago, of holding the third and last of the "Knickerbockers" on the Saturday following Easter.

Exports of iron and steel from the United States last year, 3,471,990 gross tons, set a high record for peacetime and were more than nine times the shipments of 378,415 tons, in 1932, the low mark for recent years, compilations by the American Iron and Steel Institute show.

The shift in the Treasury's inactive gold Thursday to a status by which it may be used for meeting current expenditures (one of the major features of the Administration's new recovery drive) resulted in an increase of the working balance in the Treasury's general fund to $2,364,947,330 from about $1,190,000,000 on the previous day.

The Right Rev. Robert E. Campbell, retired Bishop of Liberia, confirmed thirty-four persons yesterday afternoon at the annual Easter even confirmation service of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street.

Arthur Plaut Jr., of Long Beach, L. I., who has established himself as one of the best of the young riders, took another stride forward when he captured the honors in the Metropolitan Equestrian Club Challenge Trophy event tonight at that organization's horse show at Boulder Brook.

I am convinced that the 1938 baseball season which opens Monday will afford as keen and wholesome recreation as any year of its history and will attract increased thousands of spectators who enjoy clean, exciting sport.

Miss Elizabeth Schoonmaker Hiscox, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. G. Dudley Hiscox of East Orange, today became the bride of Philip Alexander Salmon of Elizabeth, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leon Trudeau Salmon of this place. The Rev. Dr. Victor M. Patterson, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Lambertville, N. J., performed the ceremony at the Salmon home.

Class 1. Junior Jumpers (for Riders 17 Years and Under)-First, Miss Patricia McCollum's ,ch. g. Prince Tuileries; second, Mrs. Milton Reiner's Lightning (ridden by Archie Dean); third, Mrs. E. Grahham Lewis's Sen Sing (ridden by Miss Peggy Carpenter); fourth, Miss Blanche Clarke's ch. g. Bachelor's Flower.

The report of the Continental Baking Corporation and its subsidiaries for the thirteen weeks ended on March 26, issued yesteriay, showed a net profit of $898,718 after interest, depreciation and estimated Federal income taxes but before the Federal surtax on unlistributed profits.

President of the National League (Written for The Associated Press). I feel that 1938 is going to be one of the most momentous years in baseball history. Maybe it's because this is baseball's hundredth year. When the curtain rings down next October we'll be looking back upon a complete century of our national sport's life since Abner Doubleday laid out the first baseball diamond on the Cooperstown (N. Y.) Commons in the Spring of 1839.

EASTER trade closed with a rush in some sections of the country last week, while in others the gap from last year's figures widened. In several large cities the gains in a few days were astonishing. Industrial areas, however, reported sharper losses.
Reports that Great Britain and France are purchasing, or trying to purchase, large numbers of war planes in the United States are being closely watched in high Nazi circles.

BECAUSE wood-pulp magazines, newspapers and books dissolve quickly into dust the New York Public Library is undertaking to preserve writings in manuscript and typescript. In the opinion of the director, Harry M. Lydenberg, posterity will view our time as not only a dark age but as an age of utter mystery.

WE get peculiar notions of Broadway in particular and of America in general--we in Britain and Ireland. I was warned not to come here by people who professed to know and a well-known British playwright wrote to me immediately before leaving Britain, warning me not to be sanguine,

BRAUNSTEIN--Mr. and Mrs. Jules Braunstein. Belle Harbor, joyfully announce the arrival of Sandra's brother, April 12, 1938. CHURCH--Dr. and Mrs. Cyril K., announce birth of a daughter, April 8, 1938, at Polyclinic Hospital.

The Justice Department reported late today its agents had arrested a man who wrote an extortion letter to Sonja Henie, the movie star. Officials said the letter was written by Fred Roger Cunningham, under the alias "Joe Cummings."

Scholarships donated by the Charles Hayden Foundation, providing for study at the New England Conservatory of Music, Boston, are offered for the academic year 1938-39 to young men of musical ability who are residents of New York City and are in need of financial assistance, it was announced yesterday by Wallace

The Museum of the City of New York has added some 500 World War items to its military gallery and the new exhibits are now open to the public. They range from a rolling kitchen to a "potato-masher" bomb and most are souvenirs of the war service of New York soldiers. There is also some German captured equipment.
Major Charles F. Hess, a SpanishAmerican War veteran and retired chief auditor of the Pennsylvania Railroad's coal freight department, died today at his home in Drexel Hill. His age was 79.

Tests being made in the Big Bend district of Texas of airplane delivery of supplies to a cavalry detachment have proved this method "an outstanding success," Brig. Gen. Ben Lear, commander of the First Cavalry Division at Fort Bliss, notified the War Department today.
A fire station designed to harmonize with the residential character of Fieldston, the Bronx, is being constructed at 4,536 Riverdale Avenue, the Department of Public Works announced yesterday.
The Interstate Commerce Commission today received a formal plea for suspension of proposed West Shore ferry rate increases. Irwin Rubenstein, Town Clerk of West New York, N. J.,

ACKERMAN--Emma F., April 15. in her ninety-second year, Service at Chapel of the Home, Amsterdam Ave. and 104th St., Monday, 11 A. M. AVIROM--Rev. Monis. Congregation Temple Gates of israel, 560 West 185th, announces with regret the death of dear father of our beloved cantor, Morris Avirom, and Clara Avfrom.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. M. Denniston Scism of Bayside, Queens, of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ina Estelle Scism, to H. Austin Weiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. H. Weiss of Cleveland, Tenn.

The ethnological collections on the American Indian which had been lent to the American Museum of Natural History and the Peabody Museum at Yale University were bequeathed to those institutions by the late Dr. George Bird Grinnell, author, naturalist and explorer, whose will was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.
Mr. and Mrs. Wendell Phillips Murray gave a tea at their home here this afternoon to announce the engagement of their daughter, Miss Amy Montgomery Murray, to William Lucius Fismer, son of Mr.
Harvey Harman, Rutgers football coach, outlined fundamentals of the single wing-back system to high and prep school coaches today at the closing session of the sixth annual Rutgers coaching clinic.

FOR some years past it has been the custom to start the major league baseball -season with a ball game in Washington, D. C., and nowhere else. This year there is a change and it may not be significant. Opinions differ.
The Justice Department announced today that Secondo Frank Conti had been charged at Salt Lake City, Utah, with attempting to extort $25,000 from the family of little Peter Levine.

The stock market was active and strong in the half-day trading period yesterday, and leading issues advanced 1 to 5 points. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was 1,057,000 shares, compared with 1,414,000 the Saturday before, when the market was up 2 to 6 points on the defeat of the government reorganization bill.

MAKE-UP experts who are suggesting special creams and pencils for television artists should "forget it," according to Albert F. Murray, engineer in charge of the development work of the Philco Radio and Television Corporation, who reports that ordinary make-up for women serves as well as grotesque shades of paint.

BANKS, whether formed by the terracing of a lawn or by the cut-out of a new road, may be gardened into beauty spots. Retaining walls of masonry and extensive grading may be kept to a minimum or entirely dispensed with if the proper plants are chosen for each location.

ENCOURAGING news in the broad field of traffic research and safety promotion on the highways was contained in the announcement last week by President Charles Seymour of Yale University of the establishment at New Haven of a bureau for street traffic research, which will become effective in July.

The semi-final and final round bouts in the Metropolitan Association's amateur boxing championship tournament will be held at the New York Athletic Club tomorrow night. A total of thirty-one bouts will be presented, with competition being offered in both the senior and junior classifications.

The establishment of a national sugar cooperative to handle all sugar refining in Mexico, to fix prices and generally to control the sugar industry was announced by the government tonight as it pushed forward its socialization campaign.

The agreement signed in Rome today not only promises to end the dangerous feud between Great Britain and Italy but also heralds a new effort on Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's part to restore confidence and security to all of Europe.
TRAVELERS to Denmark find, in the city of Aarhus on the Jutland Peninsula, an "Old Town" open-air museum which has some features different from the ordinary institution of a similar character.

For Jew and Christian alike these days of mid-April have been movingly associated with traditions reaching back many centuries. No one, even though he has lapsed from the old observances, can be indifferent to the religious and cultural memories, the immemorial yearnings, which these days bring to the surface of our lives.

Adapting radio television equipment in the electrical production of music, Ivan Eremeeff, physicist and engineer, has developed a machine which, he declared today, is capable of reproducing synthetically any conceivably sound.
For the present the door to peace between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization has been closed.
The conveniences of automatic hot water and steam heating are made available to home owners on the easy-payment plan as a result of the amendments recently made to the National Housing Act,

The Fordham College student council. which two years ago was, referred to as "that sleepy House of Lords" by a campus editor, has since awakened and gradually grown in stature until student selfgovernment has now become an ac-. tuality and not merely a name.

Despite efforts of the interfraternity council to raise the scholastic averages of Rutgers University's twenty fraternity groups, members of the Greek societies again were below the nonfraternity average, the registrar's report this week revealed.

Hedberg Koppisch, a New York Stock Exchange firm, was dissolved on April 14 and seven more brokerage houses will dissolve on April 30, according to an announcement yesterday by the Exchange. The seven are Berg, Eyre Kerr, E. J. Coulon Co., Morgan Davis Co., Henry B. Fuller Co., Emil J. Roth Co., Simmons Peckham and Charles V. Snedeker Co.

THE preview idea, which the broadcasters say they learned in Hollywood, is spreading. The comedians like it, because a "dress rehearsal" affords a chance to time their gags and study audience reaction. At the preview the set-up is the same from microphones to control room as during the actual broadcast, but the program does not go on the air.
Several Brooklyn properties were reported yesterday as having been sold through Sullivan, Kushner Company, Inc., broker, of that borough, to various clients.

NOW that seed and plant lists are being made up, amateur planters are open to suggestions on ways of adding variety to the garden. They will doubtless note the recent emphasis on South African daisies. These flowers carpet the high veldt and the low in their habitat with almost every color of the rainbow.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Kerr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clark Kerr of this city, to Charles Edward Simpson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Simpson, also of Paterson.
To aid in selection of work for final years in college, personality and interest examinations have been given to Wesleyan sophomores by Dr. T. A. Langlie of the Psychology Department.

Leslie Hore-Belisha, Secretary of State for War, arrived in a British military plane this afternoon on a visit that is expected to result in Malta's not only regaining its pre-war life and prosperity but becoming one of the most heavily fortified islands in the world.

Within the next few weeks three new destroyers will be added to the Pacific fleet or go to newly assigned stations. They will have in bold paint on their bows the numbers 391, 392 and 393. But, superseding the obsolete destroyers 39, 36 and 38, they will take over far more historic designations--the names of naval heroes of the long ago.
SEVERAL weeks ago Commissioner Valentine announced that for a thirty day period beginning April 4 Eighth and Ninth Avenues would be one-way southbound and northbound thoroughfares.

Corn Dodger, racing under the gray and yellow silks of Paul Mellon's Rokeby Stables, won the $1,000 Middleburg Cup steeplechase before a crowd of 8,000 today. Four horses went to the post. Colonel Wyndham Torr's Lassitude II was scratched.

IT was just five years ago that Presi dent Roosevelt, after a visit to Muscle Shoals, sent his message to Congress urging the creation of what has become known as the greatest long-view social and economic experiment of the New Deal-the Tennessee Valley Authority.

WITH Europe in its present state, Neville Chamberlain has become the grim enigma of the surviving democracies. What is back of his policies? What goes on in his mind ? Every new Prime Minister makes his first appearance on the world's stage as more or less a stranger. There is a sense in which he comes as a stranger even to his own House of Commons.
Remington Rand, Inc., challenged in the Supreme Court today the right of the National Labor Relations Board to order reinstatement of employes who participated in a 1936 strike.

The government of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and the Italian Government, animated by the desire to place relations between the two countries on a solid and lasting basis and to contribute to the general cause of peace and security, have decided to undertake conversations in order to reach an agreement on questions of mutual concern; ...

Those University of Washington Huskies went victory crazy today on the wind and rain lashed waters of Lake Washington to score their fourth successive grand slam over the University of California's Bears in their thirtyfifth annual Pacific Coast rowing duel.

ERNST, IRVING L. (April 8). Estate, more than $10.000. To Margaret O. Ernst, widow. 795 5th Ave.. household and personal effects; Marjorie R. Ernst, niece, 302 W. 92d St., $5,000; Milton L. Ernst. 302 W. 92d St.; Walter Ernst, executor, 1,324 North Ave., New Rochelle, and Alfred M. Ernst, 315 W. 86th St., brothers, equal shares in residue.
A collection of Renoir's later paintings, never before shown in America, went on view today at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. The exhibition will continue through May 29.

Confidence that the Olympic Games, scheduled to be held in Tokyo in 1940, will be staged, regardless of the Sino-Japanese conflict, was expressed yesterday by Dr. Jigoro Kano, Japanese member of the International Olympic Committee, in an interview at the Hotel Plaza, where he is stopping on his way home from the I. O. C. meeting at Cairo.

The Ministry of the Interior today announced discovery of a nation-wide plot against the government by the Nazi-inclined Iron Guard political organization. The Ministry said that in a surprise police search that continued throughout the night, arms and munitions depots were found in homes of the lieutenants of Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, party leader.

A price revision in its entire line of boilers and radiators was announced yesterday by Arthur R. Herske, vice president of the American Radiator Company, in an effort to encourage volume buying in these products. Most of the changes were downward but in some instances, increases were made on the smaller items.
The Smaller Business Association of the New York district announced yesterday that it would open its Small Loan Bureau on Tuesday at 10:30 A. M. in Suite 542 in the Hotel New Yorker.
Governor Earle tonight described President Roosevelt's proposed spending program as not Democratic nor Republican but "an American program that all Americans should follow in this hour of danger.

The Senate Labor Committee recommended today creation of a "Maritime Labor Board" to function in maritime labor relations in a manner similar to that of the National Mediation Board in railroad labor matters.

Two large historical murals, one showing the departure of the Huguenots from La Rochelle, France, and the other depicting their arrival in Echo Grove, near Davenport Point, New Rochelle, are the decorative feature of the new Schrafft's Restaurant and store which opened on Friday on MainStreet, New Rochelle.

When the Butterfly Ball dinner dance takes place on Friday night at the Ritz-Carlton the throng of several hundred guests will constitute a. reunion of members of society who have attended this annual party for many years.

While Governor Lehman has signed the bills extending the mortgage moratorium until Jan. 1, 1940, and the Deficiency Judgment Act until July 1, 1939, the joint legislative committee which has been studying the mortgage problem has been continued in existence for another year and will report to the Legislature on or before March 1, 1939, explained the legislation and taxation committee of the Brooklyn
The Congress of the National Society Daughters of the Union has approved the awarding of five scholarships to Lincoln Memorial University in Tennessee. Heretofore four scholarships have been awarded.
Many out-of-town guests attended the last Piccadilly dance of the season at the Bellevue Stratford tonight for the benefit of the Social Service Department of the Orthopaedic Hospital.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Eula Katherine Young, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Young of The Hermitage, near here, to Thomas Goode Moore, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Cabler Moore of Shippan Point, Stamford, Conn.

With Princeton and Yale graduates making important contributions to the result, the New York Rugby Club defeated a picked team representing the Quebec English Rugby Union yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. The score was 13 to 3.

What we call "coal smoke" is "silica black" to Professor C. A. Jacobson (West Virginia University) and his colleague, Loring R. Williams. The two chemists have found a way of making edible fats simply and cheaply with the aid of coal smoke or silica black.

A scholarship in aeronautics as a memorial to Amelia Earhart will be voted on at a two-day conference of Zonta Clubs of the Eastern district, opening Saturday at the Roosevelt Hotel. The aviatrix was a member of the local club at the time of her last flight.

Detectives of the Astoria police station began a search yesterday for a man accused by a 4-year-old girl of having attacked her in the basement of an apartment building at 41-06 Thirty-fourth Avenue, Astoria, Queens.
Sailing yesterday for Belgium on the steamship Westernland of the Red Star Line was Martinez Teller, Dutch acrobat and strong man, who is being deported to The Netherlands.
The capital is divided today in a debate over the relative virtues of the elegance of the Pantheon and the simplicity of the White House.

Saving much from what had promised to be a lean harvest, New York University swordsmen performed the unprecedented feat of winning the prized three-Weapon trophy for the fourth year in a row yesterday as the forty-fifth annual championships of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association came to a brilliant close on the strips of the Hotel Astor.
IT is now Jed Harris's plan--and probably nothing will intervene except another Jed Harris plan--to start his next Broadway season in the Fall with a production of Schnitzler's "Professor Bernhardi."

The value of building contracts for all types of construction awarded in the metropolitan area of New York during March rose sharply as compared with February, according to Emile Coene Jr., New York sales manager of the F. W. Dodge Corporation.

A guarantee on manufacturers' prices to retailers on all merchandise bought within the next ninety days was suggested yesterday as a method by which a buying movement could be stimulated, resulting in gains in factory employment without subjecting retailers to undue risk, by Paul E. Jackson of Jackson Co., textile advertising agency and publishers of The Worth Street Forecast.

Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman head the list of patrons for the Thirteenth Annual Military Ball of the New York University chapter of Scabbard and Blade, national honorary military fraternity, at the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Commodore Friday evening.

Tony Porcaro, 36 years old, of 2,317 Tiebout Avenue, the Bronx, and his brother Louis Porcaro, 24, of 2,037 First Avenue, were arraigned yesterday morning before Magistrate Matthew J. Troy in the Felony Court on a charge of attempted robbery preferred by their father, Dominick, 68, owner of a candy store at 2,037 First Avenue, where he lives in the rear of the shop.

With eight weeks of intensive training completed, sixteen major league clubs will launch another championship baseball campaign this week, with fourteen of them asked to believe that all they have done so far will prove in the end to have been in vain.

The Wheatley Stable's Snark, 16-to-5 favorite, carried top weight of 132 pounds to a decisive triumph in the Paumonok Handicap as 25,000, a record throng for a New York racing inaugural, jammed the Jamaica track. There was an extraordinary post delay of sixteen and a half minutes before Snark beat Rollin. Home by four lengths, with Clodion third.

The St. Nicholas. Society will celebrate its 103d annual Paas Festival at the Hotel Plaza tomorrow night. This colorful festival of the Easter season maintains customs which go back to the early Dutch settlers in New York.

ALTHOUGH for many of us, perhaps, the point itself needed no further proving, still the proof now furnished by the Sculptors Guild is convincing, conclusive, absolute. These adventurers, by setting up their First Membership Exhibition under the loftiest roof of all, have demonstrated that sculpture is an outdoor art-not sculpture of every sort it may be argued;
Nicaragua's present cotton crop, it is believed, will be reduced to about half of last year's because of the destruction by locusts, boll weevil and other pests.

The N. Y. U. nine blanked Lafayette by 11-0 today. It was the first defeat for the Maroons this season. Getting to Thon in the first inning, when Campione's home run scored two ahead of him, the Violets chased Lafayette's starting hurler from the mound in the second. The winners then proceeded to clout four other pitchers for eight more tallies.

Twenty-two Arabs and three Jews were killed today while a Jewish policeman and a British soldier were wounded in an outbreak of terrorism. This morning the military engaged a large band of armed Arabs in the mountains near Nablus.

Harvard's undefeated swimming team was given a setback today when its ace free-styler, William E. (Billy) Kendall of Australia, announced he would leave college at the end of his sophomore year in June.
L. A. Faunce, who has been in charge of sales for a number of years, has been elected to the board of directors of the Warner Aircraft Corporation.
Perhaps it is the environment. It may be the association or the changeable weather. But, whateve it is, the problem has plunged Marse Joe McCarthy deep in thought.

The marriage of Miss Dorothie Eileen Berry of Summit, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Berry of Sussex, N. B., Canada, to Ernest Andreas Knoblauch Jr., son of Mrs. Ernest A. Knoblauch of Miami, Fla., and Washington, and the late Mr. Knoblauch, took place last night in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Short Hills, N. J. The Rev. Herbert H. Cooper officiated.

MISS SHEPHARD has written an unusually interesting book on Whitman based on the theory that a great part of his life and work was a self-conscious pose. The charge itself is not a new one. A review printed in the appendix to Bucke's biography says Whitman was "a poser both in his poetry and in real life."

The "Medea" of Euripides has been selected for presentation May 14 by the Greek Department of Randolph-Macon Woman's College at Lynchburg, Va. This play, the twenty-fourth directed by Professor Mabel K. Whiteside, head of the department, will be given in Greek by undergraduates.
Senator McCarran of Nevada and Representative McCormack of Massachusetts today advocated a Presidential pardon for Dr. Francis E. Townsend, under sentence for contempt of a Congressional committee.

Following the lead of other shoe manufacturers in the district, five St. Louis shoe companies said today they planned a wage cut averaging about 10 per cent for all employes. In most cases the cut will have the effect of taking away increases granted in 1937.

THE Soviet Union's heralded Red Army commemoratives, in seven values and designs, reached New York last week. Dated "1918-1938" and inscribed "20 Let" (twenty years), they bear the Russian letters "R K K A"--initials of the words meaning Workers and Peasants Red Army, the decree for the formation of which was signed
Peace and plans for its continuance are the concern of many Smith students who are preparing for Peace Week, which will be observed on the campus from Wednesday next through Wednesday, April 27.

Bill Fallon's last-frame home run broke a deadlock and gave Princeton a 5-4 victory over Dartmouth in the first game of today's doubleheader with the Indians on University Field, but the visitors came back to pound Bob Riddle for thirteen hits and carry off the nightcap, 14-3. The seven-inning contests were Eastern Intercollegiate League openers for both nines.

MARCH winds from Washington blew news that the Federal Communications Commission plans a sweeping investigation of the broadcasting networks. April brings showers of comment from broadcasters welcoming the inquiry and defending the fairness of radio acting in the public interest.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Manchester Hobart of 195 Claremont Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joyce Marguerite Hobart, to Lawrence Mason Bullard, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. M. Bullard of Berlin, Mass.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Selma Edith Lebolt, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Matthew I. Lebolt of 327 Central Park West, to Dr. Harold evy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Levy, also of this city.

' Coated fabrics, or materials simulating leather, are being utilized now for both outdoor and indoor decorative coverings. A comparatively new use is for wall covering. A wide choice of colors and grains makes possible numerous decorative treatments.

The nation's capital was treated this week to the greatest show of recovery determination it has seen since March, 1933, when President Roosevelt, in taking office for the first time, initiated a series of dramatic manoeuvres to turn the tide of depression and start the country back on the road to prosperity.

A story in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday of the activiteis of junior naval groups, which the adjutant general has ordered to refrain from using the titles "naval," "reserve" or "militia" in connection with their names, said that William J. Siegrist, commandant of the Morrisania Naval Guard, was reached at a uniform supply house.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 15. LIEUTENANT COLONELS Callender. G. R. Med. Corps. three months' leave. June 1, with permission to visit foreign countries. Cox, W. C.. Med. Corps, three months' leave. June_1.
HIS Honor the Mayor of Studio City, Calif., breezed into town the other day and immediately set about transacting some more or less unofficial business.

The rise of the foreign exchanges against the dollar which was started on Thursday by President Roosevelt's announcement of a new credit expansion and government spending program was carried forward briskly yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES published last Sunday a letter from Professor Herbert Wright of the Catholic University of America criticising my views as to the Spanish embargo. The gist of his contention is that, since Germany and Italy have recognized Franco as the de facto government of Spain, they are legally free to "grant or withhold assistance to Franco."

Angling for trout rivaled football in popularity here today, when. about one of every six men, women and children in the city turned out in holiday mood for Passaic's first fishing tournament for children at Hughes Lake, in Third Ward Park.

In the course of an unheralded speech last Sunday, Dr. Franz Hueber, the newly appointed Minister of Justice in the German province of Austria, revealed several interesting and hitherto unpublished details of the Austrian coup.
Two accidents during the last week tend to prove that the Spanish Loyalists are receiving outside aid.

Stagehand spotted The Chief, his stablemate, two lengths and overtook him before the six-furlong mark today in a workout for the Kentucky Derby. The Derby favorite was clocked in 1:142-5, while The Chief was twofifths of a second slower.

Establishment of a government corporation, manned by officials conversant with selling in foreign markets, and soliciting orders for American products in such markets, was suggested yesterday by J. Anthony Marcus, formerly foreign trade marketing specialist for the government.

William Church Osborn, president of the.Children's Aid Society, in a foreword to the society's annual report, urges continued support of private welfare agencies, pointing out that their place never can be wholly taken by public agencies.

Miss Letitia Davison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Davison of this place, was married this afternoon to Charles S. Towle, son of Mrs. George S. Towle of Larchmont and the late Mr. Towle, in St. John's Episcopal Church, Larchmont.

An exhibition of one-room apartments, consisting of dining or sitting rooms easily convertible into bedrooms, will compose one section of the Polish Building to be erected in the international section of the World's Fair of 1939.

Signs of continuing interest in legal restriction of the work-week for domestics appear in the program of the biennial convention of the Y. W. C A.'s, opening Friday in Columbus, Ohio. Among the 2,000 representatives attending from every State will be a group of 500 young women who are slated to discuss means of obtaining for household workers hours comparable to those in other employment fields.
Senator Bennett C. Clark returned to Missouri this week to give formal status to his campaign for renomination; and formality it was.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended April 13, aggregated $6,539,000,000, or 26 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 26 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.
The annual Beaux Arts Ball, sponsored by the Westchester Arts and Crafts Guild, next Saturday night at the County Centre here will feature a "world cruise."

This city's Easter trade received a sharp setback today when between 800 and 1,400 union truck drivers went on strike for higher wages. The walk-out came early today when the Associated Trucking Industry refused to accept a new contract proposed by Local 118, Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers, an American Federation of Labor affiliate.

Mr. and Mrs. James Gillies of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ora Grace Gillies, to John Davey Gerhard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Zimmerman Gerhard of East Orange, N. J.

" COSTANZA E FORTEZZA," the most celebrated of the eighteen operas by Johann Josef Fux, Bach's Austrian contemporary, will have its first performance in this country, May 7, in Northampton, Mass., under the auspices of the Music Department of Smith College.

A NEW Constitution for the State of New York is in the making and for the next four months 168 delegates-ninety-two Republicans, seventy-five Democrats and one Fusionistunder the guidance of Frederick E. Crane, Chief Justice of New York's Court of Appeals, will draft a new instrument to supplant the one under which the machinery of the government of this State is now run.

PECULIARLY appropriate to the season is the "Lenten and Easter Art" exhibit at the Pierpont Morgan Library, in East Thirty-sixth Street, an exhibition that, by the way, has been extended through May 7.

Bertram Mills, Great Britain's "king of the sawdust ring," died today in his country home at Chalfont St. Giles, of pneumonia. He was 64 years old. Son of a famous London coach builder, he was first associated with Continental horse circuses and then brought one of his own to London.

A mediation committee named by the Philadelphia Building Trades Council continued today to seek a truce in the strike of warehouse employes at four department stores, although observance of the Easter holiday postponed any actual conferences until Monday.

William Henderson, 39 years old, of 255 Seventy-third Street, Brooklyn, was found dead yesterday in his Summer bungalow on Roosevelt Walk, Rockaway Point, Queens, after three friends who were searching for him had been severely burned in a gas explosion which occurred on their arrival.

Plans for post-Easter buying trips caused a decline in the volume of orders received in the wholesale market last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Wearing Howell, Co., resident buyers. Favorable weather stimulated consumer purchasing of Easter merchandise, and most of the requisitions received were for fill-ins and specials. The summary continues:

Don Johnson and Fonnie Snyder of Indianapolis took first place in the two-man team event at the American Bowling Congress today with a score of 1,337. By a margin of two pins they ousted Fred Mounts and Harry Wheeler, also of Indianapolis, from the top.

Easter lilies and smilax decorated the Brunswick Presbyterian Church here for the marriage this afternoon of Miss Barbara Sinclair Kelsey to Bleddyn Lloyd Griffith. The ceremony was performed by the castor, the Rev. John Hauenstern.

While conceding that the President's $5,000,000,000 spending program may turn the course of retail trade sharply upward in the late Summer and Fall months, retail merchandisers here yesterday warned against too-rapid price advances at wholesale.

Tres Bon, owned by Manton B. Metcalfe Jr., came from behind at the last fence today to capture the My Lady's Manor point-to-point race, opening-day feature of Maryland's Spring steeplechase season, before 5,000 fans.

An all-day conference for Little Theatre directors, high school teachers, women's club directors, and amateur and semi-professional theatre workers, stressing the practical in play direction, will be held at Temple University, April 30.

Distributing political pamphlets without a permit is now permitted in Jersey City, but making speeches without one is still taboo. James (Jeff) Burkitt, Mayor Hague's perennial political opponent, talked without permission in Journal Square tonight and was rudely
The first criminal prosecution in the Federal courts on charges of depriving workers of the rights assured them under the Wagner Labor Relations Act will go to trial in London, Ky., on May 16.

The Salvation Army's work with paroled and discharged women prisoners was praised by Magistrate Anna M. Kross in an address last night from Station WOR in connection with the organization's 1938 fund-raising campaign. Magistrate Kross was interviewed by Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, vice chairman of the appeal.

The United States Lines announced yesterday that August Falkenbach, paymaster of the lines, and head of its pursers' department, had been commissioned a lieutenant commander of the United States Naval Reserve, the first American merchant-ship purser to become a reserve officer. J. R.

In addition to raising revenue, one of the avowed purposes of enacting a new Federal Revenue Bill this year is to remedy some of the faults and inequities in present law. It is generally recognized that the present revenue laws contain features which hamper the orderly conduct of business, which deter expansion and discourage investment in new industrial enterprise, and which tend to destroy business confidence.

Reports from several builders who have recently started extensive small home developments in Westchester County indicate that construction of houses of that type will be one of the major features in the residential building field in that county this year.

Roses having started into growth, the annual Spring pruning, if not already attended to, need be no longer delayed, for even the inexperienced grower can now readily determine just what parts of the old wood may have been Winterkilled, and what is- plump, green and ready to thrive.

BERLIN. WITH characteristic German speed the years of anxiously holding aloof from virtually all foreign dramatic products have suddenly come to an end. Almost overnight the Berlin stage, which sets the pace for the province, has blossomed out extravagantly in alien garb.

A sound laboratory is under construction at Columbia University by engineers who plan the most modern scientific experiments on radio equipment in an effort to improve loudspeakers and microphones now in use, it was announced yesterday by the Department of Electrical Engineering. Research in the transmission of sound also will be undertaken.
The Rev. and Mrs. George C. Dangremond of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bernice Dangremond of Westfield N. J., to Robert J. Sieben-Morgen, also of Westfield.

THE departure of George Balanchine and his American Ballet from the Metropolitan Opera brings to an end an alliance that has been something less than ideally satisfactory to either side from the very beginning. There are likely to be few tears shed anywhere over the severance of the connection.

A mission of five officials of the Polish State Oil Refinery, Polmin, arrived yesterday on the Gdynia America liner Batory to study recent American developments in gas and oil production and refining.

Miss Rachel Judson Palmer, daughter of Mrs. Paul Smith Palmer and the late Mr. Palmer of this town, was married in the Congregational Church today to Grenville Jeffery, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Egerton Jeffery of Mount Vernon, N. Y., by the Rev. Albert R. Brown.
First steps in starting the new Federal spending program in an effort to end the depression were announced today by the Public Works Administration.

The New fork City Omnibus Bill was vetoed today by Governor Lehman at the request of Mayor La Guardia. No explanation of the request of the Mayor was made public here, except for this memorandum sent by the Mayor to the Governor:

A junior committee of debutantes of this season and former years, members of which will model Spring and Summer riding habits, has been appointed to assist with preparations for the fifth annual gift-horse party in aid of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work.
California scored an impressive 91-to-40 triumph over the Washington Huskies today in a track and field meet.

Your Excellency will remember that in the course of our recent conversations I gave Your Excellency certain assurances regarding the policy of the Italian Government in connection with Spain. I now wish to reaffirm those assurances and place them on record.

The Gross-Morton Corporation, builders of the Bayside Hills development and the Jamaica project at Union Turnpike and Utopia Parkway in Queens, announced yesterday that since Jan. 15 they had sold 204 new homes. They estimated that the volume of business transacted for the three months amounted to more than $1,300,000.

Inconsistent as it might appear in the light of orthodox finance, the Administration's latest fiscal proposals looking to renewed Federal spending to revive business activity have provided a tremendous stimulus to the market for United States Government obligations.

Dr. Frank Alexander Delabarre, specialist in child orthodontia, died Friday at Faulkner Hospital, Boston, after a short illness, according to word received here yesterday. He was 71,years old and lived in Greenbush, Mass. He maintained offices at 483 Beacon Street, Boston.
Dr. Smith Ely Jelliffe, neurologist and psychiatrist, will be guest of honor at an afternoon meeting and evening dinner next Friday at the New York Academy of Medicine:

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel P. Wetherill of Haverford, Pa., are at the Plaza. Mrs. Paul A. Shaw of Newton Center, Mass., has come to the RitzCarlton. Henry Theodore Leggett has joined Mr. and Mrs. Lyman Candee at Haddon Hall, Atlantic City. Mr. and Mrs. Mark L. Gerstle have arrived at the St. Regis from San Francisco.

The "apprentice boy" who once learned his trade between searches for lefthanded screwdrivers and other inventions of shop jokers, has become a key factor in New York's broadening program of vocational education.

SYDNEY, Australia. STRANGE treasure trove is being hunted by an expedition sent out by the Queensland State Government. It is an old and valuable tortoise-shell idol which was once worshiped by head-hunters. This idol is hidden somewhere on Moa Island, in Torres Strait, thirty miles northwest of Cape York. Today the island is under jurisdiction of the Queensland State aboriginal partment and is forbidden to white men.

Mrs. Grace W. Patrick, wife of Major Gen. Mason M. Patrick, U.S.A. (retired), former chief of the Army Air Service, died today in Walter Reed Hospital. Mrs. Patrick had been suffering from a heart ailment and had been in the hospital since March 4.

OCT. 2, 1918, the Seventy-seventh American Division attacked in the Argonne. One mixed battalion of companies from two regiments got as far as it could. Germans closed in the rear, surrounding 600 men. Six days later, after incredible hardships, the wounded and an unharmed 194 were relieved.

Although many trout fishermen in Eastern and Southern Connecticut returned home with heavy creels on one of the best opening days the State has had in many years, the second day was not as successful for many anglers in this area.

In that disconcerting way of theirs the French have turned over a new leaf just when nearly everybody, including themselves, had come to the conclusion that before they reached the end of the one on which they were writing their history there would be all kinds of terrible disasters to record. How long they will keep this new page clean and tidy is another matter.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Jane Hart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Spencer Hart of this place, to Paul Gannon Downey, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Downey of Chicago.

Mr. and Mrs. Howard Morrell Berg of this city have announced the engagement of their elder daughter, Miss Mary Hayes Berg, to Harold Cadmus Jr.. elder son of Mr. Cadmus, also of Montclair, and,the late Mrs. Laura Randall Cadmus.

WHAT is excessive laughter? What it is really is a contradition of terms, like "excessive health" or "excessive good-will." In a normal gathering of average minds, like a theatre audience, there can be no such thing as excessive laughter.
