Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William J. Regan of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gertrude Regan, to Dr. Vincent E. Maroney, son of Mrs. Edward Maroney also of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Maroney.
At a double wedding in Grace Methodist Episcopal Church here this afternoon, the Rev. Walter C. Brewer, the pastor, performed marriage ceremonies for his son and daughter.

VICTOR McLAGLEN, John Ford and Robert Sisk-the player-director-producer combination of the memorable "The Informer"-are being brought together again by RKO for its picturization of "The Coffin Ship." The story has to do with a sailing vessel infested with cholera and was written by Anthony Coldeway and Henry Robert Symonds.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt will attend Easter services at St. Thomas Episcopal Church tomorrow. They will be accompanied by their son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. James Roosevelt; Major Harry Hooker of New York, former law partner of the President;

The President's new proposals for an enlarged spending program by the government reflect the failure of industry to recover from its drop of almost one-third since last Summer and the rise during the same time of over four million in the number of the unemployed.

The body of Charles Greenhaggen, about 50 years old, of 916 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, was found yesterday afternoon in Sheepshead Bay at Emmons Avenue. Police of the Sheepshead Bay precinct listed the case as suicide although the body was found with heavy cord and murder at first had been suspected.
The leaders today in the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's first session of the final dinghy racing were Frank Campbell in his B Class boat Felix and Mrs. Helen Hill in her X craft Dunker.
Mr. and Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt entertained 500 children of their neighborhood at their annual Easter egg hunt, held on the lawns of Oakland Farm, their Portsmouth estate, this afternoon.

Howard Oxenberg of the Park Central A. A. won the New York State A. A. U. 500-yard free style swimming championship, the feature event of the program at the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. last night. Oxenber's time for the distance was 5:57.6.

The nine members of the crew of the Boston trawler Exeter who narrowly escaped death when their vessel burned and sank on Browns Bank, fifty miles south of Cape Sable, Nova Scotia, yesterday, arrived at Commercial Wharf late tonight acclaiming one of their number as a hero.

The Girls Service League will hold its thirtieth anniversary dinner at the Hotel Plaza on April 26. The dinner will be the first of a series of events extending through the year designed to bring the work of the league to the public's attention.

More than 300 persons are expected to attend the annual Spring formal dance of the Westchester in Undergraduate Club of the College of New Rochelle, sponsored by the Westchester Alumnae Chapter, which will be held at the Glen Island Casipo Saturday evening under the general chairmanship of Miss Virginia Cox of Larchmont.

UP from the lowlands of Rajputana, into arid, tawny mountains, climbed the train en route to Udaipur, "the jewel of India." Five young Hindu students sharing my compartment chattered about vacation plans in the capital of the Maharana of Udaipur.

Old Handicraft. Brooklyn Museum. until May 31. Rare antique pewter of Colonial times. Samplers from early days of this country and Europe. Techniques of Handcrafts. Brookiyn Museum, until May 31. Showing how old Chinese fabrics, pottery, metal crafts and pictures were produced.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis R. Henderson of Lucas Point, Old Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Louise Henderson, to George Wadsworth Cobb Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George Wadsworth Cobb of New York.

Influenced by the recent restoration of the many old and historic houses in Williamsburg, Va., sponsored by John D. Rockefeller Jr., an increased demand has appeared in many parts of the country for homes in the Georgian style, declares Travis G. Walsh, president of the Cleveland chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

An easy victory for Archie Henderson, graduate student of the University of North Carolina, in the singles, and an upset in the doubles, brought the North and South amateur tennis tournament to an end today.

An automobile out of control and driven by a 15-year-old boy mounted a sidewalk at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon in front of the rectory of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Frances of Rome, 4,307 Barnes Avenue, the Bronx, and crashed into a group of boys playing marbles. Eight of the boys were injured, one seriously.

TWELVE years ago the dreams of Florida boom-time promot ers transformed a million-dollar purse into a modern city. The collapse came, and Interocean City for a decade lay a heap of rotting timbers and careening walls of gaudy-toned stucco.

The first international photographic exposition will be opened tomorrow afternoon at Grand Central Palace at 2 o'clock. Some 3,000 prints will be shown, including the work of both amateurs and professionals and more than 200 camera clubs.

Let those who think that men are guided mainly by the hope of gain consider two enterprises that are on foot this Spring: the British expedition to Mount Everest in the Himalayas and the American Alpine Club's projected jaunt to the summit of Mount Godwin Austen in the Karakoram.

IN the Cote d'Azur Express between Marseilles and Nice.--So far we passed the British, French, Belgian and Dutch customs without opening one trunk, but all of them eyed our portable typewriter with considerable suspicion and disfavor. The climax came this morning with a very much goldbraided and moustachioed Frenchman, who triumphantly pulled the inoffensive

BASEBALL players slide back on the air this week to open the season of "swat" and to broadcast what they call "advance dope." Managers of the American and National Leagues have been invited to speak from the "baseball capitals of the nation" tonight at 8 o'clock when the WJZ network will air their comments on the outlook for the season.

With Samuel Reshevsky, the champion, taking his bye in the eleventh round yesterday, Reuben Fine, regarded as one of his chief rivals, made the most of his opportunity by winning his game with S. S. Cohen and equaling the score of the one-time boy prodigy in the biennial tournament of the National

In an all-age stake that was well above the average, Dr. Jack Rose was returned the winner today in a field including many of the outstanding bird dogs of the East. The test was the third on the program sponsored by the Mid-Jersey Field Dog Club and furnished keen competition.
Umpire assignments for the opening of the American League baseball season were announced today by President William Harridge.

An improvement in operations of the United States Employment Service last month was reported today by Secretary of Labor Perkins, who said there had been widespread gains in the number of the jobs filled and a slight lessening in the volume of workers registering for employment.

Patrolman Humbert Moruzzi of the Mercer Street police station, who was shot in the head early Tuesday when he interrupted a hold-up in the Howdy Club at 47 Wrest Third Street, died early this morning at Columbus Hospital.

DESPITE recent headshakings over the foreign scene, transatlantic bookings are mounting; several companies report reservations ahead of this time last year. And to add further gayety to the coming season two new liners will soon display their shining splen-' dor in world harbors:
The Indians will give up their Kitty League farm at Owensboro, Ky., and Milwaukee, a Cleveland affiliate,

THE traveler this year finds that Zamboanga has been placed on his itinerary, and this change in the routing of many world cruises allows more than the usual number to check on whether "the monkeys have no tails in Zamboanga."
Mr. and Mrs. Bascom Johnson of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Taber Johnson, to Hugh Kelsea Moore Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Moore of York Harbor, Me.

Breaking 97 out of 100 targets, L. F. Sanman won the high-overall scratch cup in a field of thirtyone gunners at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. F. Storms, a visitor, also had 97, but shot for targets only.

The text of the report to the Association of the Bar of the City ?? New York of its Special Committee on Plan and Personnel of the State Constitutional Convention follows: TO THE ASSOCIATION OF THE BAR OF THE CITY oF NEW YORK:

Faced with the estimate that fewer than 10 per cent of American public schools make systematic use of the film as a teaching aid, educators are expressing confidence that moat of the obstacles which for a quarter of a century have precluded any notable development in this field of visual education will be overcome within the next five years.

Mr. and Mrs. Harper Sibley gave a tea this afternoon at their home here at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Harper Sibley, to Gordon Auchincloss 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Coats Auchincloss of New York and Rumson. N. J.

The financial statement of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation for the ninemonth period ended March 31 reveals assets of $112,936,085, or nearly $13,000,000 more than the corportion's original capitalization by act of Congress in 1934, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced yesterday.

Captain George D. Burnside pushed his worn felt hat back on his head and attempted to philosophise on his forty-seven years at Grant's Tomb. "Philosophy?" he repeated, chewing on a stubby black cigar. "Why, I don't believe I've got one.

Union Street car and bus operators rejected early today a lastminute proposal to defer a threatened walkout on the city's transportation system and voted an immediate strike. Service actually had been suspended for nearly an hour before the local of the Amalgamated Association of Electric Street Railway and Motor Coach Employes ratified the move.

HOWARD DIETZ, who happens to be the publicity and advertising director for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and asks that you do not hold it against him, has written a reply, more in sorrow than in anger, to my columns of a few weeks back.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, after making arrangements with the Federal authorities, to whom Jacob (Gurrah Jake) Shapiro, boss racketeer, surrendered, announced yesterday that Shapiro would be arraigned before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora tomorrow at 2 P. M. on two indictments.

On a historic site in Scarsdale, Westchester County, fourteen small apartment buildings are to be erected under an unusual community plan designed to protect the choice private home center of which they will be a part.

Title insurance and all its ramifications will be discussed by speakers prominent in that field at the annual convention of the New York State Title Association at the Hotel Roosevelt Thursday and Friday.

Officials of foreign countries, members of the Huguenot Society of America and many clergymen will attend next Sunday afternoon a service to commemorate the 250th anniversary of the opening of the French Church of Saint-Esprit, the first Huguenot church in New York.

The engagement of Miss Margaret Frothingham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence P. Frothingham of this city, to Robinson Dudley Buck, son of Mrs. Henry R. Buck of Hartford and the late Mr. Buck, has been announced by her parents.

At the invitation of the British Government, Premier Edouard Daladier and Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet will go to London April 28, it was confirmed this evening, for a three-day visit, to which much importance is attached.

Navy's eight-oared fleet started off well on its cruise through a new season today. In the two-race regatta with Princeton that opened the season for both on a windswept Severn river, the midshipmen came paddling' home in front of varsity and junior varsity rivals at a mile and three-quarters, and they -had something to spare in each-event.

Dr. Lucy Wilson, professor of physics and dean of the senior class at Wellesley College, will serve as acting dean of the college during the next academic year while the trustees extend their search for a permanent successor to the present dean, Dr. Mary Lowell Coolidge.

DESPITE political alarms, the Paris season is getting gallantly into its stride. New night clubs are opening and old boites are bursting forth with new linings. Almost every night sees the dress rehearsal of a new play.

ADAM WOLAK was a Pole with the strength of a Giant in His arms and because of that strength he thought he could walk through life without fear. "Man's Courage" tells the grim and heartbreaking story of what happens to a man when he realizes that his strength is worthless and useless in a world which puts no value on it.

Total sales of furs by members of the American Fur Merchants Association for the four months from December through March were valued at $8,643,202, a decline of 54.4 per cent from aggregate sales of $18,973,987 for the same months of the previous year, according to figures issued yesterday by the organization.

The Queens rugby team annexed its sixth straight game to remain unbeaten for the season by vanquishing Princeton today by 11-3. The winners were the first to score on a try by Roy Ilowit and were never behind, leading 3-0 at the half.

Miss Mary Gibson, curator of the Cooper Union Museum for the Arts of Decoration, declares that a steadily increasing interest is being found throughout the country in wallpaper to enhance the beauty of the American home.

EXILE: Gerardo Machado, for eight years President of Cuba, fled before revolution in 1933, and since then has lived in exile, much of the time in New York. Last week the 67-year-old former President announced that henceforth he would live in tropical Miami. "As I grow older," he said, "my love for my country deepens. Just to return this near its shores is a great satisfaction."

Masked General, the 4-yearold chestnut gelding that tossed the scare of the year into the great War Admiral last Fall, left the famed Sun Egret far behind today and raced to victory over a fast track in the $5,000 added Harford Handicap before 15,000 fans.

THERE are more foreign correspondents in Hollywood than you could shake a stick at--which nobody does for fear of international complications. That the cinema capital is a fountain of news for the parched throats of picture addicts in every corner of the world is evidenced in the fact that periodicals and newspapers in no less than twenty-four countries maintain correspondents here.

The Winter wheat farmer had hardly more than wiped the mud off his boots after an April deluge of rain, hail, sleet and snow than he learned that he was in a fair way to produce this year a near-record crop.

Amid excitement almost unprecedented in the annals of the Metropolitan Opera Association, Wagner's "Tristan and Isolde" brought the 1937-38 season to a close yesterday afternoon at the Opera House. It was the ninth "Tristan" of the season.

A net asset value of $25,656,532 on March 31 is disclosed in the report for the quarter by the United States and Foreign Securities Corporation. This is equivalent to about $122 a share for the first preferred stock and compares with $30,850,588,

IN the discussion of foreign pictures versus Hollywood you should realize that the Hollywood producer is thoroughly sympathetic toward your desire to improve the films. At the same time, he asks a reciprocal sympathy for the problems of motionpicture production and toward the productions themselves.
Like the United States, Canada has a railroad problem, and a special committee of the Canadian Senate, with one eye on Washington's example, is pondering its solution.

Our own stock market had undisputed leadership yesterday in appraising the current "inflation psychology" in terms of prices. The Euorpean stock markets were closed, as were many foreign commodity markets and the Cotton Exchange and certain other commodity markets in the United States.

The engagement of Miss Jane Willis, daughter of Mrs. William Willis of 210 East Sixty-eighth Street, formerly of Flushing, Queens, and the late Mr. Willis, to Robert Van Cleve Whitehead Jr. of Trenton, N. J., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Whitehead, has been announced by her mother.

The christening of St. George Biddle Duke, infant son of Mr. and Mrs. Angier Biddle Duke, took place today at the Duke home here. The new rector of St. Mary's Episcopal Church, the Rev. Leon E. Cartmell, officiated.

Official Germany got away to an early start in its Easter recess and is determined to make a week of it. Chancellor Adolf Hitler has gone into seclusion in his Bavarian highland retreat and governmental and party headquarters in Berlin also are deserted.

Hunter College's twenty-second annual Sing will be held at the Center Theatre on May 6, with almost 800 students taking part in the traditional song-fest, reflecting humorous and satirical comment on contemporary life.

ALLAN JONES'S musical comedy career was dramatically terminated one night in Boston when, obeying a sudden impulse, he vaulted over the foot lights and chased J. J. Shubert, producer of his current vehicle, out of the theatre--J. J. frantically velling:

The nation's hoboes propose a new national holiday in honor of "soldiers of misfortune." The annual convention of itinerant workers, Hoboes of America, adopted a resolution calling on Congress to designate the first Sunday after Labor Day of each year as "soldiers of misfortune day."

Cleveland's first view of its highly touted 1938 Indians, with Ossie Vitt at the helm, left a gathering of 6,000 wondering today whether some of the outstanding experts haven't had their eyes crossed, or something.

Mr. and Mrs. David Raymond Reynolds of Plainfield have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diana Reynolds, to Louis McGill Adams of Washington, son of Mrs. Paul Bright of Ventnor, N. J., and the late Wilbur L. Adams, Representative from Delaware.

Herman von der Linden,for many years a sporting goods dealer and prominent Hudson River yachtsman, who died in his home At 76 Washington Street, Poughkepsie, on Thursday, was buried in Poughkeepsie Rural Cemetery following funeral services today. His age was 79. He was former commodore of the Poughkeepsie Yacht Club.
The Newark Bears today shattered the Phillies' ten-game winning streak by beating the National Leaguers, 7 to 2. Newark scored all its runs off Bucky Walters in the first three innings.

Russian Easter eggs made of stone are being exhibited by the American Museum of Natural History in Memorial Hall at the Seventy-seventh Street entrance to the museum during the Easterseason, according to an announcement yesterday.
The Exeter tennis team of Exeter, N. H., is booked to open its schedule on April 30 by playing at home against the Milton Academy netmen. Eight other matches are on the Exeter tennis program.

Only three more nela trials for pointers and setters remain to be contested in the section accessible to New York fanciers. This weekend there are two meetings, both starting Friday and continuing through Sunday.

The St. John's University tennis team downed the City College netmen, 5 to 4, in the opening match of the season for both teams on the Queens Community courts yesterday. The Redmen annexed three of the singles and two of the doubles engagements.

Delegates from the 200 clubs comprising the New York State Federation of Music clubs will participate in a music festival of impressive proportions this week at Binghamton, where the tenth annual convention opens on Wednesday to continue through Saturday.

ANDORRA, the midget land nestling in the Pyrenees between Spain and France, has become in recent days a clearing house for refugees from the war-stricken land to the south. But in spite of the fact that its population has been doubled by the 10,000 who have crossed its borders, the little republic remains an attraction for the tourist seeking the unusual-the only country in the world that specializes in one-day tourists.
Columbia's crews began a new season auspiciously yesterday by sweeping a four-race regatta on the Harlem against Rutgers and Manhattan.
To widen the scope of extracurricular work for the women students at SwarthmoreCollege a course in blacksmithing has been started at the suggestion of George A. Bourdelais, instructor in engineering.

Miss Eleanor Williams, '39, of Flemington has been elected editorin-chief of Campus News, the semiweekly newspaper at New Jersey College for Women. She succeeds Miss Josephine McLaughlin. '38, of Easton, Pa. Miss Irene Eby, '39, of Union City was re-elected as business manager.

WASHINGTON.-One of the government's most consistent moneymakers, the Copyright Office, has turned into the Treasury nearly a million dollars during the past forty years, representing the excess of receipts over expenditures.

Robert Stockwell Reynolds Hitt, retired diplomat, died of pneumonia this morning at his home, 2,244 S Street, after an illness of three weeks. He was 61 years old. With him at his death were his wife, the former Edith Romeyn Gray of New York, and his son, Robert Reynolds Hitt of New York.

SURELY, no mystery novel ever had a stronger beginning than this one. A professor in a Southern university is grading students' papers when he finds one that begins as follows: "My mother was murdered just after I was born and my father was murdered when I was 6 years old, so I know very little about them."
The Harvard fifteen routed the St. Andrews Rugby Club of South Orange, N. J., 31 to 0, today. Outstanding for Harvard were Austin Scott, John Harkness of wrestling fame, and Pepper Constable.

Many rentals are being made in the group of six-story elevator houses known as the River Parkway Apartments, occupying the frontage of Laurel Hill Terrace between 186th and 187th Street in the upper Washington Heights section.

Miss Sarah Tuttle Braman, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Braman of Portland, Me., was married to John Gardner Bridge of Allentown, Pa., son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Bridge of Portland, today in the First Presbyterian Church here by the Rev. Dr. John L. Caughey, the pastor.

James A. Dennessey, former head of the homicide squad of the Bureau of Criminal Investigation of the Boston Police Department, died today at City Hospital at the age of 72. He served in the bureau from the time of his appointment there in 1905 until his retirement in 1932.

Mrs. Walter Koempel of Old Greenwich has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jean Rowand Polhemus, to Joseph Antonio Reynes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. A. Reynes, also of Old Greenwich. The announcement was made this afternoon at a tea given at the home of Mrs. Koempel.
Harvard University, "no matter what occurs," will not withdraw the appointment of Granville Hicks, a Communist, as a fellow in American history.

A rigorous system of control of foreign exchange, designed to prevent the escape of capital in any form, has been clamped tightly around the territory that was Austria by Germany, the text of a foreign-currency decree which has just been received here shows.

Miss Helen Marie Gaede, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Robert Gaede of this place, was married tonight to Francis Dickey Allen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Mansfield Allen of Bangor, Me. The ceremony was performed at the bride's home by the Rev. Arthur M. Hughes, pastor of the West Side Presbyterian Church here.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Furniture: Period of Louis XIV" (tour of collections), Alfred Busselle Jr., 2 P. M.; "The Leaders of Impressionism," Edith R. Abbot. 2:30 P. M.; Motion Pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Color in Dress," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.; "Furniture: Period of Louis XV" (tour of collections), Alfred Busselle Jr., 3:15 P. M.

Savings, building and loan associations throughout the country during the past three years ending Jan. 1, 1938, disbursed $3,057,000,000, the United States Building and Loan League announced yesterday. This almost equals in volume, and also rivals, the $3,092,000,000 disbursed by the Home Owners Loan Corporation during the same period, the league points out.

Not to mention important private collections, like that of Lee M. Friedman in Boston and the late Alphonse Ochs in Paris, there are thousands of libraries all over the world with more or less exhaustive accumulations of Dreyfusianasources for future historians to draw upon. Obviously, these sources should be kept trustworthy.

Twenty-four WPA white-collar projects, employing 5,000 workers, will be abandoned this week because WPA officials have found it impossible to adapt them to the new cost formula prescribed by the heads of the Federal relief agency in Washington.

" COME back to the old Puritan morals," Julia Ward Howe implored her erring brother, Sam Ward. "Wake up, and find yourself all that you ever were--the honest son of an honest man." It was easy enough for Julia, married to the Chevalier and settled there in Boston,

The Amateur Comedy Club, an organization of amateur players well known in society, will conclude its current season with a presentation of "Good Morning," a play by John C. Gibbs, on Thursday, Friday and Saturday nights at the Heckscher Theatre.

Announcement has been made by Louis F. Blauvelt of this place of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Florence Graham Blauvelt, to John C. Cushman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Clydesdale Cushman, also of Upper Montclair.

Promptly at noon yesterday a medium-sized riot began at 206 Forsyth Street. Willie Marietta owns a candy shop at that address. It isn't much of a place. The floor is warped. The roof is tin. It leaks. The windows are dirty.

The marriage of Miss Rosamond Borland, daughter of Mrs. William Gibson Borland of this city, Beverly Farms, Mass., and 146 Beacon Street, Boston, and the late Mr. Borland, to Peter Desmond White, also of New York, took place yesterday at the home here of the bride's mother, 14 East Ninetieth Street.

NO less than seven exhibitions of of water-colors added an embarrassment of riches to the gallery attractions last week. Phil Dike, California artist, who was color coordinator and adviser on the Walt Disney staff while "Snow White" was being produced, is showing at the Ferargil.

WITH all plans and preparations for the fifteenth annual Shenandoah Apple Blossom Festival completed, the historic little city of Winchester, Va., is now confidently waiting for Mother Nature to do her share on April 28 and 29.

The Railroad Credit Corporation reduced the amount it owed to the Central Railroad of New Jersey from $313,316 to $234,987 in 1937. The railway contributed $979,541 to the loan pool administered by the corporation and reborrowed $500,000 of that sum.

In a statement issued yesterday, Ralph W. Crolly of the law firm of Cullen Dykman, counsel for the Brooklyn Trust Company, said that institution was "unalterably opposed" to the plan offered by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for reorganization of Prudence Company, Inc.,

The Soviet Union's food industry is more than fulfilling its production plan for this year, but all other industries are lagging behind their plans, according to reports of the first quarter's work laid before the Council of People's Commissars.

The vexing problem of naval officer promotion came closer to legislative adjudication last Tuesday when the House Naval Affairs Committee finally reported out the Scott bill which would modify stringently the present system of officer selection.
The extent of union organization in the coffin-manufacturing industry became a subject of debate yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Talbert W. Sprague of Pelham, N. Y., have announced the engagement of Mr. Sprague's daughter, Miss Barbara Sprague, to Louis G. K. Clarner, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Louis G. K. Clarner of Concord, N. H.

Behind the flawless hurling of Gene Bowe, Fordham's undefeated baseball team romped to a 10-to-0 triumph over Lehigh before a crowd of 1,500 at Fordham Field yesterday. The senior right-hander, making his first varsity start, gave Coach Jack Coffey a pleasant surprise by yielding only three hits and striking out eighteen batters.

Miss Clara Douglass McCullough, daughter of Mrs. Julia M. Smith of Little Rock, Ark., and the late Bernard E. McCullough, was married here this evening to Gerald H. B. Kane, son of Mrs. J. Fitzgerald Kane of Orange, N. J., and the late Mr. Kane.

Mr. and Mrs. Jerome R. Klarsfeld of 300 Central Park West have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sylvia Beatrice Klarsfeld, to Dr. Stanford Leland Hermann, son of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour M. Hermann of this city and Elizabeth, N. J.

Under a glare of arc lights so brilliant that it would have done credit to any Hollywood set and amid a clicking of camera shutters so continuous that it resembled the stuttering of a machine gun, Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, and the Earl of Perth, ...

The announcement that after not much more than a month of negotiation a final agreement between Italy and Great Britain has been concluded has been greeted in Italy with satisfaction whose-sincerity it is impossible to doubt.

THIS delightful reconstruction of a Scots-Irish Ulster community toward the end of the last century and the beginning of this comes from Australia and is a graceful tribute by a professor of St. Andrew's College, Sydney, to the Northern Ireland of his youth. Whether the central figure and those intimately connected with "the auld sinner,"

PRINCE SAIONJI KIM MOCHI is not only interesting because he is the last Elder Statesman, or Genro, of new Japan. He is vitally intertesting because his career has compassed the modernization and "westernization" of his country, has influenced its thought and activated its movement.
ASHEVILLE, N. C.--Mountain crafts and arts, the only means of livelihood for many families of the Southern Appalachians, are being revived on a large scale in the highlands of Western North Carolina.

In line with a growing spirit among professional women's clubs to honor leaders already established, or ambitious newcomers, in their respective fields, three metropolitan groups plan this week to announce prizes and scholarships.
The KellyNash Democratic faction has been routed on its own fortified frontChicago and Cook County.
Asserting that illegal employer influence had been used to persuade employes to vote to join one union as against

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Alix Searle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Holly Searle of Riverside, to John Carroll Caldwell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Sleeper Caldwell of Island Falls, Me., took place here this afternoon at the home of her parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Gerald A. Cunningham, rector of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stamford.

A decree of President Getulio Vargas amending the Mining Code so that agreements may be entered into with foreign companies to work the development of petroleum deposits is thought to indicate that the government wishes to show the tendency toward a more liberal policy by the gradual revision of ultranationalistic legislation.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Mangan of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Catherine Delamater Mangan, to Richard McGuire, son of Mrs. Richard K. Guire of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. McGuire.

Drawn matches by the three leading English Football League clubs left standings unchanged today. Arsenal, one point ahead of Wolverhampton and Preston North End, battled to a scoreless draw with Birmingham at Highbury. The Wolves and Preston also played ninety minutes without scoring,

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish.

Wheat traders were not impressed today by talk of inflation and the strength in securities and turned to the bear side of the market as the result of fairly general rains over a large part of the Winter and Spring wheat area. First trades in futures were a fraction of a cent a

THE death of Feodor Chaliapin last week recalled to many minds the great Russian basso's singing and acting of the title role in Moussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff," which was certainly his most famous impersonation and possibly his finest. The opera has not been done at the Metropolitan since Chaliapin was a member of the company in the Twenties.

Changes in the curriculum of the School of Liberal Arts at Manhattan College in which a greater stress will be placed upon the ethical problems of life, were disclosed yesterday by Brother Alphonsus, dean of the school, upon publication of the courses to be offered for the coming semester.

THE music editor of THE TIMES has been mildly taken to task for a remark in a recent article on American music festivals. In that article he said, en passant, that the Berkshire Symphonic Festival would have developed even more rapidly than it has if the wishes of Dr. Koussevitzky had been followed.

Governor Earle has less than nine months in which to solve the knotty problems of the anthracite industry if he is to realize his hope of finding a cure for its ailments before the end of his administration.
Dr. Edward Megarr, a retired physician, was found dead yesterday seated in a chair in the bedroom of his home at 402 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn.
Easter week will bring to the attention of society many notable weddings, plans for which have been announced during the last few months.

INVITATIONS have been sent to photographers residing outside of New York City in Southern New York and Connecticut to enter pictures in a Salon of Photography in conjunction with the first Southern New York and Connecticut Photographic Exposition to be held in the County Center, White Plains, from May 22 to 26.

Joe Giallombardo, University of Illinois junior, carried off the individual all-around championship of the first National Collegiate Athletic Association gymnastic meet tonight at the University of Chicago.

With city sales tax receipts far below expectations Philadelphia merchants today received a fifteen-day extension of the "deadline" for filing first-period returns. The date was put off until April 30.

The Riverdale fencing team successfully defended- its Private Schools Athletic Association championship by defeating St. John's Prep, 5-2, in the final round yesterday afternoon on the strips of the Columbia University Auxiliary gymnasium.

Petitions to nominate members of the New York Curb Exchange nominating committee are available. Nominations require twenty-five signatures and must be filed not later than April 29. Western Air Express Corporation rights have been admitted to whenissued dealings on the Curb Exchange.

Behind the superb pitching of Ed Spaulding, the Hill team won from the Princeton freshmen, 7-1, today. The home team made eight hits to the visitors' four. Vaughn Spaulding of Hill led his team with a triple and a double, while Cosby paced the visitors with a double and a single.

THOSE brought up in quieter times and places must have moments of dismay, and even of horror, at the sight and sound of the great modern city, of which New York is perhaps the most startling example. Its waste, its confusion, its denial of elemental human decencies-perhaps, worst of all, its complacency, as though it indeed represented the apex of 6,000 years of history--can be appalling.

Samuel Bell, 75-year-old retired real estate man of 1,504 Ocean Ave nue. Brooklyn, fell or jumped to his death yesterday morning from the seventh floor of the New York Hospital, Sixty-eighth Street and York Avenue, where he had been a patient since Feb. 9.

In 1936 and 1937 anthropologists dug up at Choukoutien, China, a miscellaneous lot of fossilized bones. These proved to be remnants of the famous Peking man, who roamed what is now China between 250,000 and 500,000 years ago.

An ovation of tremendous proportions greeted Arturo Toscanini tonight when he took up the baton to conduct his concert with the Palestine orchestra here. All the taxis and bus lines in the city could hardly cope with the enormous stream of people, for besides the 3,000 who obtained tickets, despite the exceptionally high

Deep in the mountains of Northern New Mexico tonight the "Brothers of the Blood of Christ" protected by guards armed with rocks, and rifles in some instances, concluded a Holy Week of self-torture in expiation of their sins, rituals of a fanatic cult born in the Spanish conquest of the Americas.
Cut off from the rest of Loyalist Spain, Catalonia prepared today to fight its hardest and strongest battle.

Cardinal Hayes paid a consideration of $332,000 for a half interest in the eight properties, full control of which he acquired by the purchase of a half interest from relatives of the late John Whalen, banker and lawyer, according to revenue stamps affixed to deeds recorded in the Register's Office yesterday.

Another Drilliant victory by the splendid white standard poodle Champion Blakeen Eiger, from the Blakeen Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt of Katonah, N. Y., tonight climaxed the thirteenth annual dog show conducted by the First Company Governor's Foot Guard Athletic Association in the State Armory.
Members of the Bay City Chevrolet local of the United Automobile Workers of America voted tonight to strike May 1 if any wage reductions were made.
Thirty-five children of former students who lived at International House, 500 Riverside Drive, at 123d Street, had an Easter party yesterday afternoon at the house.

Ingenious alibis, imaginative poetry and classroom bonerss" devised by New York City school children provide cheerful interludes in the life of the teacher, it is disclosed in an article in High Points, official high school publication of the Board of Education.

COLONIAL rooms often suggest to the decorator such requisites as candlesticks, pottery bowls, vases and needlework chair coverings; and some collectors specialize in these handicrafts. Both decorators and collectors therefore should find two exhibitions at the Brooklyn Museum, one of old pewter and the other of samplers,

Eduardo Suarez, Mexican Finance Minister, flew through Dallas tonight, en route, he said, to Chicago on a pleasure trip. His ticket, however, gave New York as his destination. "Do you happen to be going to see Mr. Rickett?" he was asked.

Industrial facilities provided in the Borough of Queens are explained, with additional information regarding its growth and recent improvements, in a booklet entitled "Industry Turns to Queens," just issued by ten real estate firms specializing in industrial properties.

The Bees turned back the Red Sox, 6 to 2, today before 8,400 fans. The victory gave the Bees a three-to-two advantage in the city series, with the final game billed for tomorrow. Casey Stengel's team collected nine hits, jumping into a three-run lead in the first inning on four singles off Fritz Ostermueller.

The organization of mineral wool manufacturers has changed its name to the National Mineral Wool Association. This group, organized in 1933 and representing the producers of nearly all mineral wool produced in this country for home and industrial insulation, formerly was known as the National Rock and Slag Wool Association.

OF all the labels. that have been attached to Jacob Riis, that given him by Theodore Roosevelt carries the greatest honor and the widest application--"New York's most useful citizen." Merely to call him a reformer would be to tell only a small part of the story.

Launching an aggressive selling and advertising campaign in the final quarter of last year when business started on the downgrade, the George S. May Company, Chicago, industrial engineers, has registered substantial sales increase since Jan. 1, George S. May, head of the company, reported here yesterday.

The engagement of Miss Constance Coleman of Princeton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Coleman of Hingham, Mass., to William V. Courtney, son of Mrs. Anne M. Courtney of Trenton, has been announced.

Six-inch shells from the Insurgent position, calculated as six miles away, were falling on the broad street running along the river when I visited Lerida two days ago. There had just been a heavy combat between Insurgent and Loyalist planes, more than 100 in all. More bombs had been dropped on the city to take new tolls of wrecked buildings.

Miss Audrey Wurdeman, 1934 recipient of the Pulitzer Prize for poetry, is candidate for president of the National League of American Pen Women, which will hold its biennial convention in Washington,. Friday through Wednesday.

The scenes behind the curtain in the dramatic seizure of the vast American and British oil properties in Mexico are gradually unfolding. PALM BEACH, Fla.-Now that large and elaborate entertaining has ended, residents are enjoying leisurely April weeks, spending their days on fishng cruises or on the beach, and their evenings in small, impromptu Affairs.

Recent bequests and grants, totaling $526,000, to McDonogh School for boys in Maryland emphasize the current interest in secondary schools with vocational and avocational guidance. While McDonogh pioneered in this type of education, an intensive long-range program, based on the study of democratic principles and their application in the school, is attempting to bring out inherent talents of each boy to prepare him for constructive citizenship.

Joint participation by the six New England States in New York's World's Fair next year was voted today at a meeting of the New England Governors' conference of which Governor Cross of Connecticut is chairman.

PARALLELING Europe's feverish armament race, buying of wheat, collection of scrap iron and the storage of gas masks is an unprecedented short-wave station building program through which each nation aims to have the loudest international voice in the "ehter."

The downward trend in credit mar conditions in Latin America, apparent in the closing months of 1937, was arrested and, to some degree, reversed in the opening three months of this year, Kenneth H. Campbell, manager of the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men, reported yesterday in issuing the bureau's quarterly survey of credit and collection conditions in South and Central America.

Federal grants to New York State, totaling $3,690,033, for oldage assistance and aid to the needy blind in the quarter ending June 30 have been approved by the Social Security Board, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the board, announced yesterday.

Savings in fuel may be effected by the use of automatic draft-regulation devices, which are installed in the smoke pipe of warm-air furnaces, hot-water or steam boilers. These devices make possible a controlled, even draft, which tends to assure uniform fuel consumption.

ROMAIN ROLLAND'S mother taught him music--a commonplace happening enough, but one that aimed and colored his creative work for the rest of his life. It determined him to make music his career, but his keen interest in Tolstoy and Shakespeare made him approach it from the literary angle.

The contents of the James A. Burden residence at 7 East Ninetyfirst Street will be offered at auction on the premises on Wednesday and Thursday under the management of the Parke-Bernet Galleries by order of the present owner, Mrs. Richard M. Tobin, formerly Mrs. James A. Burden.

On their own applications, to take effect 12 midnight. April 15: PATROLMEN-Charles Zeman, 71st Precinct. at $1,500 per annum. Appointed April 7, 1913. James J. Brenick, 18th Division. Manhattan Borough Detectives at $1.500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 30, 1902.

RECENTLY a leading manufacturer of photography material placed on the market a new and faster super-panchromatic press film. This was the second firm to offer such a film, the first film in this new superspeed class having been offered to the public last Fall.

One of the most active organizations endeavoring to have the East Harlem area improved is the East River Drive Property Owners, Inc., an association founded in January, 1937. and headed by Ralph Russo, president.

HOLLYWOOD. SOME concern is being expressed by the industry over the misrepresentation charges brought by the Federal Trade Commission against Grand National involving the film version of Dr. Charles M. Sheldon's Victorian best-seller, "In His Steps."

THE CIRCLE--Tomorrow evening at the Playhouse. A revival of Somerset Maugham's well-known comedy, with Grace George, Tallulah Bankhead, Dennis Hoey, John Emery, Bramwell Fletcher, Cecil Humphreys, Audrey Ridgwell, May Marshall and James E. Corbett in the company.
Mrs. Loretta Babcock, aged 19, was arraigned on a charge of first degree murder late this afternoon for the death of her husband, certified as a suicide several months ago. She pleaded innocent.

The measures for expanding excess bank reserve which were announced on Thursday by President Roosevelt will re-create the basis for a great credit inflation which existed early in 1936, prior to the action of the Federal Reserve Board in increasing reserve requirements.

Hamilton Phinizy, Augusta attorney and landowner, died suddenly today at the age of 73. He was president of the Augusta Herald Publishing Company. A native of Augusta, Mr. Phinizy had been in law practice there since 1886.

In the Biennial Survey of Education in the United States, covering the years 1934-36, one chapter, separately published, is devoted to Adult Education. It begins with a reference to the "recency" of the adult education movement and ends with a quotation from one of our highest educational authorities:

To help provide funds to meet Sydenham Hospital's 1937 deficit for services to the needy sick, a dinner will be held next Sunday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, Simon Bergman, dinner committee chairman, announced yesterday.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration reported today that refined sugar delivered to American markets in March totaled 397,990 short tons, raw value, compared with 1,156,477 short tons in the corresponding month last year.

With Avery Gould, star inside home and former Dartmouth player, leading the way with eight goals, -the Crescent Athletic Club lacrosse team inaugurated its season today by overpowering Colgate University, 17 to 6. The New Mooners enjoyed a lead of 10-3 at halftime. Otto Hilpl, with three markers, also stood out for the Crescents.

Verdi's "Aida" was given last night by the New York Hippodrome Opera Company before a moderatesized but well-disposed audience. Frances Alcorn sang the title role and Hilda Kutsukian Kosta had the role of Amneris.

The home and workshop of the Wright brothers, transplanted intact from Dayton to Henry Ford's Greenfield Village here, were dedicated today before an assemblage including more than 200 leaders in aviation, who came to pay tribute to Wilbur and Orville Wright, builders of the first successful airplane.

THERE was a time not so many years ago when an airline regarded completion of 80 per cent of its trips a fair record. A study of the postoffice reports for the last fiscal year reveal that 95.02 per cent of scheduled mail flights were completed.

Bruce Barton, Representative in Congress from the Seventeenth District, will be the honor guest and chief speaker at the ninth anniversary luncheon meeting of the Twenty-third Street Association at the George Washington. Hotel, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, on Thursday.

Seabiscuit, black bullet of the American turf, sounded his latest smashing challenge today with a convincing victory in the $15,000 added Bay Meadows Handicap. The time for the mile and a furlong was 1:49, a new track record.

Clothing manufacturers will start to show their Fall ranges tomorrow and, while changed constructions make generalizations on prices difficult, numerous ranges will show declines of $1.50 to $2.50 a unit under the Spring level. Chiefly because they believe that wool and piece goods prices have been stabilized at a low level and that the next movement will be upward, clothing manufacturers are looking for a good Fall season.

Members of the Pictorial Forum will open their third-annual photographic exhibition on May 5 at the National Arts Club. It will include 200 prints and will continue until May 31. The Forum, with a membership limited to 100, is composed of doctors, lawyers, bankers, sportsmen, art students and lecturers.

Revival of activity by the Public Works Administration, as provided for in President Roosevelt's spending program, was hailed here yesterday by building product and supply men as a definite stimulus to their industries.

Sponsorship of an alumni-student European tour next July and August has been announced by seven University of Pittsburgh fraternities. The itinerary will include London, Vienna, Heidelburg, Interlaken, Venice, Rome, Naples, Paris and The Hague.
Warren Ress, scoring five goals, led the Rutgers lacrosse team to a 9-to-6 victory over City College of New York on Neilson Field today before a crowd of 500.

Dr. L. W. Chubb, director of the Westinghouse Research Laboratories, announced today the selection of five research fellows for work in fundamental science. Chosen from a group of fifty research workers in the nation's universities, these are Robert O. Haxby, University of Minnesota;

The engagement of Miss Josephine Marie Shepard, daughter of William Edwin Shepard of the Bronx and Far Rockaway and the late Mrs. Shepard, to John Joseph Lucas Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lucas of Woodmere, L. I., has been announced by her father.

An extremely far reaching amnesty for political offenders, of which the chief beneficiaries will be the followers of Konrad Henlein, leader of the German Sudeten party, was announced today by President Eduard Benes in connection with the Easter season.
Cornell opened its home baseball season today by defeating Yale, last year's champions, 6-3, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game on Hoy Field.
Mrs. John Dows Mairs of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Dake Mairs, to John Francis Smith Jr., son of Mrs. John F. Smith of Frederick, Md., and the late Mr. Smith.

MID-APRIL has brought back racing to New York along with the Spring flowers. The horses were running at Jamaica yesterday. And from now on until November's blasts rattle the dry brown leaves-except in late July and August, when Saratoga stages her annual grand cavalcade-the crowds will be pouring out to the metropolitan tracks every weekday, rain or shine.

Last year the Quebec Legislature passed a law that in case of a difference between the French and the English texts of a Quebec statute or of the civil procedure and municipal codes the French text should prevail. That seemed just, since as a rule the English versions are translations from the French.

LITTLE man, with rucksack on his shoulders and climbing-irons at his belt, lifts a calculating eye this year to the two highest mountains in the world. Mount Everest and Mount Godwin Austen, in the skyline of Central Asia, are far from his beaten track. They do him no harm; they interfere in no way with his wars, his golf and his other civilized occupations.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It would have been desirable that the proposal for a Jefferson memorial in Washington should first have been discussed on its merits without the controversy as to jurisdiction and prestige injected by the statements of the Commission of Fine Arts, as quoted in THE TIMES recently.

The half-way mark as been reached in the drive for $25,000 for a window memorial to the Right Rev. Herbert Shipman, who was Suffragan Bishop of New York, to be installed in the Episcopal Church o the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue ad Ninetieth Street.

An Eastern intercollegiate Republican club conference with the immediate objective of drawing up a model platform for the Republican party will be held here April 29 and 30 under the sponsorship of Princeton University's Stephen K. Little Republican Club,

The signing of the Anglo-Italian accord was hailed here today as the second great step toward clarification and pacification of the European situation. Germans considered Chancellor Hitler's swift and bloodless union of Austria with Germany the first major move.

FOR the best novel submitted in the Harper Prize Novel Competition for 1938-39 Harper Brothers offer $7,500, of which $2,000 is an outright prize, independent of royalties and payable on the announcement of the winner, while $5,500 is a minimum guarantee of royalties to be paid six months after publication.
Thousands of Atlantic salmon are swimming in maritime waters marked with a "price tag" of $1 each. The Dominion Government will pay the dollar to any one catching them.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 14: COMMANDERS Bledsoe, A. M., Naval War College, Newport. R. I., to Bureau of Navigation, Washington, D. C.. May 14.

Miss Julia Gray Sears, daughter of Mrs. William Richards Sears of this city, was married here today in King's Chapel to Regiinald Henry Phelps of Cambridge, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Phelps of Southwick, by the Rev. Palfrey Perkins.

MOST Congressmen felt last week as though they had been dragged through a wringer. They experience such sensations after a longdrawn-out, controversial piece of legislation. such as the Reorganization Bill, has gone to a vote.
Steve Bloomer, who will probably go down in history as the greatest soccer football player of all time, died today in Derby, scene of many of his greatest triumphs, at the age of 64.

ABRA.IS-GORDON--Mr. and Mrs. Leo Gordon of 5 West 86th St. announce the marriage of their daughter, Yvette Jean, to Mr. Ralph Michael Abrams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Abrams of Springfield, Mass., on Sunday, April 10, 1938. BALAGUR--BLOCK-Mr. and Mrs. Max Block announce the marriage of their daughter, Sylvia, to Mr. Emanuel Balagur, Sunday, April 10, 1938.
ATLANTIC CITY,. N J.--In addition to being Easter and the occasion of the Board walk dress parade, today opens Canadian Week in Atlantic City.

The engagement of Miss Catherine Emily Fyfe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Archibald Fyfe of this place, to Ensign Frederic Archibald Chenault, U.S.N., son of Mrs. Lester Morton Huffman of Jacksonville, Fla., and of the late Archibald Cavins Chenault, has been announced by her parents.
Mr. and Mrs. John Christopher Kehioe of Pittson and Harding have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Grace Sara Kehoe, to Charles Augustus Shea Jr. of Nanticoke.

Charles Edison, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, and Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Steamship Owners Association, are scheduled to speak before the Marine Section

Prospects of new leaders being groomed for executive posts lend an anticipatory interest to the convention plans of a number of women's organizations this Spring, and the total of delegates instructed to record their votes for preferred candidates is expected to pile up a reord mileage before the season is over.

The first nation-wide exhibition of architecture and allied arts organized by the Architectural League of New York as its fifty-second annual exhibit, will open Wednesday at the Fine Arts Building, 125 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Having had her bye in the women's championship tournament of the National Chess Federation, Mrs. Adele Rivero, titleholder, resumed play yesterday in the seventh round at Rockefeller Center. Miss N. May Karff of Boston drew the bye and she was tied by Mrs. Rivero for first place when the latter defeated Mrs. Helen Kashdan in thirty-nine moves.

Brooklyn Woman's Club--Hobby day; auspices music and art department, 2:30 P. M. Carroll Club-Tea. Edgar H. Yolland, speaker on "Budapest," 5 P. M. College Club of Oranges (N. J.)Annual meeting and election, Trinity Congregational, E. Orange, 3 P. M.
Colonel Levi G. Nutt, organizer and first head of the Narcotics Enforcement Division of the Treasury Department; died here today at the age of 72.

The Social Security Board is giving special attention to the development of a more liberal seale of Federal old-age insurance benefits and to the payment of monthly benefits before 1942, the date now fixed in the Social Security Act, Wilbur J. Cohen, technical adviser to Arthur J. Altmeyer, chairman of the board, discloses in an article in the current issue of The American Labor Legislation Review.

To abandon our purpose of building a greater, a more stable and a more tolerant America, would be to miss th tide and perhaps to miss the ports. I propose to sail ahead. I feel surz. that your hopes and your help are with me. For to reach a port, we must sail-sail, not lie at anchor; sail, not drift.

Day, Stoddard Williams won yesterday the award of a new issue of $50,000 of school bonds of the town of Brookfield, Conn., on a bid of 102.111 for 2 3/4s. The bonds will mature serially from 1939 to 1963.

Active real estate brokers must now display outside of their offices a business sign reading, "Licensed Real Estate Broker," Frank S. O'Hare of Jackson Heights, president of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York, pointed out yesterday.

The success of Generalissimo Franco in driving through to the sea despite dogged Loyalist resistance compelled the capitals of Europe last week to weigh the political realities they will have to face if the Insurgent forces win in Spain. The situation is complicated by the support Franco has had from both Rome and Berlin.

THE Coast of pleasure, as such is garish, untraditioned, new. But all along the French Riviera, not only in the villages back in the hills but close to the new quarters in the fashionable resorts, there are scenes and stories that are centuries older than the oldest memories of pleasure-seeking on the Cote d'Azur.

Navy units have been "authorized to hunt for three college youths missing since Tuesday, when they set sail in a 20-foot sail boat from Balboa to Catalina Island, Senator McAdoo telegraphed Guido Orlando of Palm Springs today.

The International Student Service at Geneva has remitted $1,500 (Chinese) for the relief of Chinese students injured or deprived of their belongings in the recent Japanese bombing of Hanan University at Changsha.
Tom. Wootton of Atlantic City reached the, semi-finals of the sixteenth annual Wildwood Golf Club Easter tournament today with a 2up victory over the medalist, Jimmy Wilmeth of Philadelphia.

Ancient court minutes showing the creation of an American court system in Westchester County three years before the end of the Revolutionary War have been discovered in forgotten files of the court house here, it-was announced by County Clerk Harold Mercer.

The stake schedule at Belmont Park, which had to be revised sharply in order to make room for the $100,000 War Admiral-Seabiscuit race, was announced in full at a Jamaica yesterday on behalf of the Westchester Racing Association.

Hjalmar L. Petterson of Stockholm has devised a way to detect counterfeit coins with nothing but an electric spark. The coins are placed in a runnel. They roll down to a barrier. A spark passes between momentarily held coin and an electrode.

Dogs and cats donated by the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals will compete for prizes in a variety of classifications next Sunday at the annual pet show of the New York Women's League for Animals in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Roosevelt.

THE annual team-of-four tournament for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup begins tomorrow night at the Ambassador Hotel, with the largest field in the eleven years' history of this event expected to compete. Although the number of advance entries can seldom indicate the final total,

More than 100 guests attended the marriage this afternoon of Mrs. Hazel Forbes Richmond of Beverly Hills, Calif., to Harry Richman of New York and Miami Beach. The ceremony was performed before a floral altar on the lawn of his beach residence by County Judge W. F. Blanton of Miami.
A unique experiment was carried out by the Fashion Club of Skidmore College when it attempted to simulate a regular Paris opening and fashion show for the student body.

THE Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will include on its program this afternoon music from Act I of "Parsifal." The soloists are Richard Bonelli and Norman Cordon, and the orchestra will also have the assistance of the Schola Cantorum and the St. Paul's Choristers of Flatbush.

Except for the calling of several issues of Federal Land Bank bonds, notices last week for the payment of bonds before maturity were in small volume. Only one large industrial retirement was posted and almost all the calls were for payment in later months, mostly in May.

One of the factors that led President Roosevelt this week to propose an appropriation of $1,250,000,000 for work relief during the first seven months of the coming fiscal year was the picture of relief conditions that constantly had been kept before him by the United States Conference of Mayors.

Judges J. Whitaker Thompson and Victor B. Woolley retired today from active service in the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here. Judge Thompson, who is 76 and lives in this city, and Judge Woolley, 71, of Wilmington, Del., will receive their full pay of $12,500 a year under a Congressional
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow:

One of yachting's grandest and oldest customs may be ending its days, at least on the thousands of pleasure craft and especially power cruisers owned by skippers who are members of the United States Power Squadrons.

Steve Dudas fulfilled, in five unhappy rounds, the role of guinea pig for Max Schmeling before 20,000 in Hansa Hall tonight. When his towel went into the ring in the fifth the American was down on his knees for the seventh time in

The new home of the Lycee Francais de New York, school of secondary education in French, at 3 East Ninety-fifth Street, will be dedicated by Count de Saint-Quentin, French Ambassador to the United States, on April 25.

Members of the legislative committee of the joint committee of teachers' organizations will go to Albany tomorrow to "safeguard teachers' interests" at the Constitutional Convention, the association announced yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, city of elms, proud of being the welcoming gateway to New England, home of Yale University and seat of an industrial activity which has made it worldfamous, waits with not a little excitement its 300th birthday party.

An official Justice Department statement said today that Raymond M. Scruggs, vice president of the First National Bank and Trust Company of Oklahoma City, Okla., had confessed to special agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation embezzlements amounting to $750,000.

HAMILTON, Bermuda. --It is the Easter season, and this coral-hedged nest of Atlantic islands will again entertain a large influx of Americans, another annual contingent of those who contribute 75 per cent of the resort's yearly income for the privilege of basking in the southern sun,

A tract of 100 lots in Teaneck, Bergen County, N. J., fronting 1,200 feet on the west side of Teaneck Road, opposite the new armory recently completed, has been purchased by a development syndicate known as the Model Home Builders of which Elmar Blomkvest is president.

Governor A. Harry Moore of New Jersey will be among those to great Major Gen. Edward M. Markham, retired war-time commander of the 303d Engineers, who will be the guest of honor at the Seventy-eighth Division reunion in Union City, N. J., on April 30.
The Crucible Steel Company plants at Harrison and Jersey City, closed by strikes since March 14,

ON charity postal paper promised by The Netherlands, several persons will shortly emerge from relative obscurity to enter the stamp collector's expanding gallery. Their appearance will once more emphasize the educational value that attaches

Appointment of Granville Hicks, young and scholarly Communist, to a Harvard University teaching fellowship, and the resulting criticism to which the university's chief officers have been subjected, recalls the famous Laski Case which rocked the oldest university in America soon after the World War.

ONE hundred years ago next Friday, at 10 o'clock in the evening of April 22, 1838, the 178-foot steamship Sirius picked her way through the starlit darkness of New York harbor and dropped anchor off the Battery.

Albert D. Phelps, former president of the Bronx Real Estate Board, expresses the belief that the new apartment houses projected by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for the Inwood section of the Bronx will have a far-reaching and beneficial effect on that portion of the borough.

NOW that the fine Spring weather is coming along, books like this--light and pleasant reading--will be burgeoning. In the lazy setting of a New Hampshire lake it picks up one day's happenings in the lives of a vacation group.

Winston Guest's New York Optimists swept over the revamped Detroit Gold Hats, 15 to 8, tonight for their second straight victory and the championship in the senior division of the national indoor polo championships.

S. H. McKeagwho was elected president of the Lake Hopatcong Real Estate Board, N. J., organized last week, states that several new Summer cottages fronting the lake are under construction, and many recent buyers of building plots have given contracts for the immediate erection of cottages for Summer occupancy.

BLICKER-SCHRAGER-Mr. and Mrs. Herman M. Schrager of 50 West 96th St. announce the cogagement of their daughter. Babette Seena, to Mr. Sidney Blicker of Minneapolis, Minn. BLUMENFELD-CAPLAIN-Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Caplain announce the engagement of their daughter, Marion, to Mr. Bernhardt Blumenfeld of Braddock, Pa.

It is hard to determine what Grey Owl's real name was. His father called him Archibald McNeill, his Apache mother must have called him something else, and his Ojibway tribesmenby-adoption called him Wa-sha-quonasin. It was probably harder for him to determine whether he was a white man or a red man.

The model home on Topland Road in the Hartsdale Acres development at Hartsdale, Westchester County, which was built in conjunction with the Westchester Home Show for 1938, was officially opened yesterday afternoon, reports Leo H. Fuller, president of the Foundation for Better Homes.
The Rutgers baseball team came from behind in the last half of the ninth inning today to defeat Swarthmore, 5-4, before 1,000 fans on Neilson Field.

The casual clothes one wears in the country or at college this Spring can be colorful enough to outdo a basket of Easter eggs. Many of the new odd tweed jackets in the sports shops around town are in such bold mixtures of unusual colors that they fairly leap from the racks to smite the eye.

A special meeting of stockholders of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., has been called for May 20 to vote on -a plan to authorize $10,000,000 of cumulative preferred stock, of which $7,000,000 or more would be offered to common stockholders for subscription.

in France as is the financial problem. What will be done with respect to Spain in the event of a Franco victory will depend in the long run on the outcome of the fight for direction between the Left and the Right.

THE chamber music of Schumann in Victor's New Friends of Music series is limited to a single set--the piano quartet in flat (Op. 47), played by Hortense Monath and three members of the Kolisch Quartet.

Three gains more than offset three losses among the components of THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity for the week ended April 9. The number firmed to 78.2, which compared with 78.1 in the preceding week and 106.2 for the corresponding week last year.
The spirit of Easter visited the gashouse district of the East Side yesterday and triumphed over the competitive and possessive spirit of more than 500 youngsters seeking prizes in an egg hunt.

The Fortnightly Club of New York will be the guests of Mrs. Franklin, D. Roosevelt tomorrow at a White House luncheon. Following luncheon the group will hold its regular program of discussion of current events. One of the founders of the club was Mrs. William' Sheffield Cowles, wife of Rear Admiral Cowles, and an aunt of Mrs. Roosevelt.

The City Planning Commission, with Rexford G. Tugwell presiding as chairman at his first meeting, approved unanimously yesterday the $6,000,000 plan for the development and improvement of the Rockaway Beach waterfront proposed by Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks.
Mayor S. Davis Wilson of Philadelphia requested the Federal Government today to supervise the May 17 primary election in Philadelphia so as to assure a "fair and free" count of ballots.

Nearly 8,000 delegates are expected to attend the ninth annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council, Inc. Participating will be members of the Institute of Traffic Engineers, the International Association of Chiefs of Police and the Eastern Conference of Motor Vehicle Administrators and representatives of many educational, manufacturing and business organizations from more than twenty States.

Realty brokers in Spring Lake, N. J., reports B. Y. Paterson, president of the Spring Lake Realty Board, are experiencing the most active rental season that has been seen in that shore resort for several years.

MR. PRATT'S "The Navy--A History" is a "human interest" picture of our nautical past, with emphasis upon personalities; it is, at its best, history that glows, biography that lives. Through its sweeping pages the great sea rangers sail, the bugles sing "Boarders!" Paul Jones boots his lieutenant "in the breech several times": the guns roar; green water surges through every chapter, and spume and spray salt the paragraphs.

On April 23, 1838, two steam-driven vessels arrived unexpectedly from Great Britain at New York-the Sirius from Cork, the Great Western from Bristol. The American branch of the Newcomen Society has already celebrated this centenary; the Science Museum of South Kensington is commemorating it with an exhibition of historic ship models to last until midSeptember.

Joe (Ducky) Medwick was up to his old tricks today and smacked a home run in the ninth inning with the score tied to give the Cardinals a 10-to-7 victory over the Browns in the opening game of the 1938 city series.

Dirck Roosevelt's zest for adventure, inherited from his father, Major Kermit Roosevelt, and his grandfather, Theodore Roosevelt, late President, kept his family and that of his classmate at Groton School and runaway companion, Henry W. Distler, in turmoil yesterday even after they had been found after a fifteen-hour absence from school.

Forecasts of the chances of their teams were made yesterday for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the managers of the three local major league baseball clubs. The statements of Joe McCarthy of the Yankees, Bill Terry of the Giants and Burleigh Grimes of the Dodgers follow:
The Abraham Lincoln High baseball team recorded its fourth straight success of the season by downing the City College junior varsity, 8 to 3, in a nine-inning game at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday.

Spotty pitching, spottier and a batting order that was punchless at the extremities combined to bring about Columbia's third straight setback as Manhattan's well-balanced, alert baseball team smothered the Lions yesterday at Baker Field. The final count was 13--1 and just about testified as to the comparative strength of the clubs.

LONG before man began his long fight to live upon this planet the animals had been carrying on their struggle for existence. And from the lethal swing of a mighty club to the dreadful perfection of chemical warfare many of man's most effective weapons have been unconsciously copied from the beasts.
New electrical devices, in addition to the usual mechanical kitchen equipment which has become a part of most modern houses, have been perfected to save labor for the home owner and his family.

TANTAMOUNT to aerial stardom is the signing of a long-term contract with Rudy Vallee, who has come to be known as radio's star-maker, through his uncanny faculty of singling out a novel act or talent that is "different."

Announdement has been made by Mrs. Edwin M. Finletter of this place of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Sallie Merrick Kite, to Francis W. Dinsmore Jr. of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dinsmore of Princeton, N. J.

Henry G. Waltemade, president of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx, has sent letters to members of that body, urging them to support the plan for the formation of a "real estate union" to protect realty interests.

The Ruth Legislative Commission turned over to the special October grand jury today evidence which, its chief investigator declared, should provide "an airtight case against the real big shot in Philadelphia gambling" as well as about thirty others linked with gaming.
Princess Elizabeth, elder daughter of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth and heir-presumptive to Britain's throne, will celebrate her twelfth birthday next Thursday with a party at Windsor Castle.

With the promise of sunny skies and temperatures in the sixties, New York will put on its traditional Easter bonnet to celebrate today what may be its most colorful and crowded religious holiday of the last three years.
A robot "umpire" that calls strikes on the batter with never-erring accuracy is the latest development in baseball, it is revealed in a patent granted to John Oram of Dallas, Texas.

The Association for the Aid of Crippled Children, one of the best known philanthropic organizations in the -city, will be the beneficiary of this year's Gilbert and Sullivan production by the Blue Hill Troupe.
Brilliant Austrian students who are unable to continue their studies at home because of racial, religious or political persecution will be aided to come here by International Student Service.

DURING the latter part of March, in 1938, Merida (in Yucatan, land of the ancient Mayans), had its very first Chamber Music Festival. That it was enthusiastically received by the local audiences, composed of landed aristocrats, agraristas, students, laborers and troops from the local garrison, is due to the efforts of Samuel Marti, Mexico's outstanding violinist, and to his wife, Cristina Moya de Marti, archaeologist and writer.

In announcing two appointments to the Bryn Mawr faculty for next year from the ranks of Bryn Mawr alumnae President Park made it clear that the college's tendency was to look elsewhere for its teaching staff "lest we become ingrown."

Abe Pickus, president of a Cleveland oil company, arrived in town last night and somewhat disappointed greeters who had expected his first act after registering at the Governor Clinton Hotel to be a phone call to, say, Josef Stalin.

The closing of many of the markets here for the Easter holidays prevented any widespread reaction to President Roosevelt's "pump priming," but an immediate effect was produced on the foreign exchanges.
First-hand evidence as to the variety and vigor of intellectual interests among the students of Vassar College is offered in Volume XI of The Journal of Undergraduate Studies soon to be published.

The women's national championship at the Fencers Club will close the fencing season Friday. Although all the entries had not been received at this writing and American Fencers League officials were unable to tell how many competitors would be on hand, it is safe to say that the field will be large.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Kenyon Jr. of Jackson Heights, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Kenyon, to David C. Ewart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Ewart of Braintree, Mass.

Dizzy Dean has been famous ever since he started to pitch regularly for the Cardinals in 1932, for his bombastic utterances off the playing field and his fantastic performances on it. It is not too much to say that he is the most colorful pitcher since the days of Rube Waddell and Bugs Raymond, and with as much ability to back his boasting as either of those famed eccentrics.

IT has been another of those weeks--so filled with developments both in the galleries and in the broad realm stretching beyond them that one is hard pressed to know how, advantageously, to parcel out Sabbath space for comment on the profuse panorama.

New York University's track and field team opened its season yesterday by overwhelming Temple, 77 to 58. at Ohio Field and thereby evened the defeat suffered at the hands of the Owls last Spring in Philadelphia. The meet was also the first of the season for the visitors.

A gravel barge in tow got caught early yesterday morning in the draw of the Hammel Bridge, midway between Broad Channel and Rockaway Beach, disrupting traffic on the Rockaway Beach division of the Long Island Railroad for about three hours.
Charles Drake, assistant to P. K. Wrigley, president of the Cubs, said tonight the deal for Dizzy Dean came as a climax to three weeks of negotiations with the Cardinals.
Under the government's firm arbitration--somewhat aided perhaps by the temptations of the Easter holiday--France's sitdown strikes tonight are crumbling.

AN Inventory of menhirs, dolmens, and other Druidic relies is to be taken throughout Brittany during the next twelve months if the appeal of the Breton Folklore Society gets the response it hopes for.
George A. Sloan, chairman of the committee on firms of the Greater New York Fund, Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of additional divisional chairmen for the campaign.

Sales of Manhattan real estate declined in the first quarter of this year from the corresponding three months of 1937 in both the number and dollar volume of transactions in spite of an upturn in March, the monthly sales analysis of the Real Estate Board of New York indicates.

Stocks advanced vigorously and closed strong with gains of 1 to 5 points in third largest Saturday's trading f the year; turnover, 1,057,860 shares. United States Government bonds sharply higher in largest turnover since last April; other issues higher; transactions, $4,769,900.

The marriage of Miss Esther Madelyn Winroth, daughter of Mrs. Svante Victor Winroth of Crotonon-Hudson, N. Y., to Henry Loose Miller of Norwalk, Conn., son of Dr. and Mrs. Victor Davis Miller of Hagerstown, Md., took place here yesterday afternoon in the Marble Collegiate Church. The ceremony was performed by - the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale.

The engagement of Miss Betty Louise Hill, daughter of Professor Howard C. Hill of the Department of Education at the University of Chicago, and Mrs. Hill of this city, to Lionel Lightner, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Allan Lightner of Waterville, Me., and formerly of Mountain Lakes. N. J., has been announced.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Allardice, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Allardice of this place, to George Greg Bohrer Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. George G. Bohrer of New York, took place this afternoon in the Mountain Lakes Community Church.

With the minds of New York school children filled with thoughts of the circus, the Museum of the City of New York announces an exhibition to open Wednesday, "The Circus From Noah's Ark to New York."
