It illustrates the growing tendency of the nearly twoscore museums in New York to interrelate their facilities with the news of the day and the lives of the people.

Headed by Uncle Robert, twentysix parochial and public school children representing the five boroughs will call on Mayor La Guardia Tuesday at 2 P. M. to invite him and Mrs. La Guardia to the annual Parents Day celebration on the Central Park Mall May 8.

WHEN life included leisure and excluded the reporters, illustrious persons exchanged informal letters, written by hand. Of these letters--sometimes of far-reaching significance -- the senders seldom kept a copy and even the archives of Windsor Castle are thus incomplete.

Smashing his way between horses driving for the turn into the stretch, the top-weighted Snark from the Wheatley Stable gave a remarkable exhibition of courage and speed to win the Paumonok Handicap before a record New York inaugural crowd at Jamaica yesterday.

Last Message, Kentucky Derby eligible from the Tall Trees Stable of Mrs. F. J. Navin, widow of the late owner of the Detroit Tigers, moved a step nearer her engagement in the Churchill Downs feature when she led a fair band of 3-year-old fillies in today's Winona Purse at Keeneland Park.

The completion in the last seven years of seven major improvements making New Jersey more accessible, has had an effect on the transportation picture comparable to the "drying up" of the Hudson River, A. N. Lockwood, president of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards, declared yesterday.

Dizzy Lean and the Cardinals who nursed him through six stormy years parted company today. The big, eccentric right-hander was traded to the Cubs for three players and an unannounced amount of cash. The players were Pitchers Curt Davis and Clyde Shoun and Outfielder George Stainback.
Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin F. Hurd of this city have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Helen Elizabeth Reed, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Albert C. Reed,

Kaydik Farm, formerly owned by Elsie W. Johnson, on De Forest Road, between Wilton and New Canaan, Conn., has been sold to Robert C. Disereus of Larchmont, N. Y., reports Previews, Inc. David H. Batchelder of. Wilton, Conn., negotiated the transaction.

The campus of Cornell University will be the scene on April 29 and 30 of a cooperative intellectual enterprise in the form of a social science conference in which three colleges whose relationships heretofore have been primarily athletic, Cornell, Dartmouth and Pennsylvania, will participate.

WOMEN students of a New Jersey college are planning to submit their cooking skill to the approval of men. This timehonored proof of the pudding is announced from Georgian Court College, where girls majoring in home economics expect to stage a cooking contest which representatives from men's colleges will judge.

Coinciding with the announcement ot Generalissimo Francisco Franco's success in reaching the Mediterranean, the Spanish Loyalist submarine C4 has disappeared from her moorings at Verdon on the Gironde River, where she had been laid up since the beginning of the civil war.

The Fairfield County meeting of the Connecticut Federation of Women's Clubs on Thursday will hear a talk by the Rev. E. Knox Mitchell of Simsbury on "The Human Side of the Tobacco Industry." Hostess to the delegates will be the Woman's City Club of Norwalk and Mrs. L. A. Conklin will preside.
With an ordinary chandler and a seventy-five-watt bulb any chicken raiser can now tell whether or not eggs are fertile and hence likely to produce chicks.

The Benham, a 1-500-ton torpedo boat destroyer, one of three such vessels that had been on the ways at the yards of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company here, was launched in the Hackensack River this morning.

A unique "school of government," to be known-as the Green Mountain Boys State, is being planned by the American Legion, Department of Vermont, and cooperative agencies, to be held at Norwich University, June 19 to 26.

Twelve specific recommendations for constitutional changes, mostly affecting the judiciary, are made in the report of the special committee on plan and personnel of the State Constitutional Convention of the Bar Association of the City of New York, of which Paul Windels, former Corporation Counsel, is chairman.
The engagement has been announced of Miss Marie Mulle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Mulle of Merrick, L. I., to Robert English L. Hancock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Hall Hancock also of Merrick.

The final week of Easter shopping brought sharp gains in retail volume for the country. It seemed apparent from early figures, however, that the total for the six weeks prior to Easter this year may have averaged as much as 8 per cent in dollar volume below the six weeks prior to the earlier Easter of 1937.
Preparations for two ambitious "little theatre" productions at Harvard reveal the large student interest in serious dramatics which has been steadily gaining ground here for three years.

The Ninth District of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, which includes Bronx, New York, Westchester and Putnam Counties, is sponsoring a course for the study of flowers, their arrangement in the home and their presenstation in a flower show at the Contemporary Club, White Plains, on Monday and Tuesday, April 25 and 26.

THERE is a fine smell of oats and saddle soap about this tale of five English children on a trek through the New Forest on horseback, but its appeal will by no means be limited to boys and girls who ride, for it is a rattling good adventure story.

" The Passover message of freedom is a ringing call to- man to struggle to preserve his civic liberty and his freedom of thought, speech and conscience," said Rabbi David de Sola Pool at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Seventieth Street and Central Park West, yesterday.
MORE than thirty exhibitions fell to the lot of this harried reviewer last week. Limitations of space prevent the detailed consideration that a number of these shows might well be accorded.

Wilson College students chose their governing officers for the next academic year at an all-day election yesterday. Margaret Norcross of Haddonfield, N. J., was elected college government association president;
Forty homes already have been sold in Strathmore-at-Great-Neck, L. I., fifth residential community developed by Levitt Sons, which will have its formal Spring opening today.
MORE than thirty exhibitions fell to the lot of this harried reviewer last week. Limitations of space prevent the detailed consideration that a number of these shows might well be accorded.

Wilson College students chose their governing officers for the next academic year at an all-day election yesterday. Margaret Norcross of Haddonfield, N. J., was elected college government association president;
Forty homes already have been sold in Strathmore-at-Great-Neck, L. I., fifth residential community developed by Levitt Sons, which will have its formal Spring opening today.

The Czechoslovak State," an unofficial Czech authority on the minority situation told your correspondent today, "has already granted to its minorities all that a democratic State can, as the new minorities statute soon to be made public will reveal, although it has been condemned in advance by the Henleinists [Sudeten German Nazis].

Connecticut State won its opening baseball game today, defeating Wesleyan, 5-4, in the tenth inning. Connell, Nutmeg sophomore pitcher, held the Cardinals scoreless in the last seven frames and struck out eleven men. The winning run resuited from a Wesleyan error after Petersen had relinquished his mound duties to Cotter.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Kraemer of Port Washington, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eloese Fratces Kraemer, to Robert Firth Pickels of Waterbury, Conn., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Pickels of Lawrence, Mass.

The General Court of the National Society Sons and Daughters of the Pilgrims will hold an all-day session here next Saturday, with Representative Charles A. Eaton of New Jersey and Dr. Homer L. Shantz, chief of the division of Wild Life Management of the Federal Forest Service, as the principal speakers.

Leonard Barron, dean of American garden editors, died suddenly a week ago yesterday. In his passing the horticultural world loses one of its most dynamic and best beloved figures. While his name has been most closely associated with the rose, the dahlia and the delphinium, through his activities in the national societies connected with these flowers, his interest in every phase of amateur horticulture was keen.
Charles A. Meyer, breeder of pure bred Hereford cattle, died yesterday in the Jane Lamb Hospital in Clinton, at the age of 74.

" PRINTING IN THE AMIERICAS" has a vast amount of useful, carefully organized facts about printing on this continent, but it is more a dictionary ox information than it is a history in the modern sense. It answers questions such as who brought the first press into Nevada,

THE expansion of Communist influence and the change in the Communist program have been among the most important developments in China in the past year. The party and its leaders have forsaken the more radical agrarian policies and are now committed to a program which calls for establishment of a bourgeois-capitalist democracy in China, and they are resolutely backing a United Front Government with that objective in view.

Yale defeated Hofstra at Rugby today, 9-5, Henry Molina registering two tries and Clint Frank one. All of Yale's efforts to convert failed. Captain Keven- Rafferty, Gary and Towle played well for the Elis.

The price of prime Western.zinc yesterday was advanced 25 points to 4.25 cents a pound at East St. wi Louis. This is the largest single advance in the price of that metal in about a year. On April 5 there was a reduction of 10 points, which was followed by another of 15 points on April 8.

Artur Rodzinski, one of the best program makers who has conducted this season at the symphony concerts in Radio City, led the NBC Symphony Orchestra last night in a program of which the principal feature was the tone poem of Richard Strauss, after Nietzsche, "Also sprach Zarathustra."

IN this new book by Major Wren the adventure and courage are more on the psychological side than on the physical. There is a mystery. more than a touch of horror. a keen study of an odd 14-year-old boy, and as neat a plot as any one could wish, with every tiny thread caught up at the finish and tied in a beautiful knot.
The Sampson, 1,850-ton first-line destroyer, was launched today at the yards of the Bath Iron Works, Inc.

Two brothers who pleaded guilty last Monday to charges of possessing counterfeit $5 silver certificates were sentenced to prison terms yesterday by Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Federal Court, Brooklyn.

The report of the American Light and Traction Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $5,567,031 after all operating expenses, taxes and charges.

Rockefeller Center is joining the Easter parade this week, with thousands of flowers-tulips, hyacinths, azaleas-decking the buildings and courts. The "Channel" between the British Empire Building and La Maison Francaise is lined by standard pink azaleas, beneath which porcelain blue hyacinths are set.

William J. Morrison Jr. of Hackensack, president of the New Jersey Bar Association, will be a speaker at the second annual dinner of the Bergen County Associated Realtor Boards at the Swiss Chalet, Arcola, N. J., next Tuesday.

WITH Easter being a usually reliable portent of the end of the Winter schedule in the night club and hotel world, the thoughts of the genial hosts have been turning of late to Summer, daylight saving time, long drinks, roof gardens and suburban roadhouses.
' THE KID' GROWS UP: Twenty-one years ago, while the late John H. Coogan was entertaining at the Riverside Theatre on upper Broadway in

Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy's decision to present only the families of American officials or of those Americans who actually live in England at the coming royal courts has aroused an excited twittering among those circles who are primarily concerned just now with long trains and feathers, and has left most of Britain completely uninterested in the matter.

The magnetic storm which began early Friday was viewed yesterday by New York radio men not as a major disturbance but one of ordinary proportions, contrary to reports that the storm was one of the most severe of the twentieth century.

DR. TANSILL'S study of the events and controversies which culminated in the entry of the United States into the World War is distinguished. among other things, by its use of a considerable amount of important new source material.

The existence of seven plans under which employes are given assurance of a specified amount of employment or income by their employers has been disclosed by a survey conducted by the National Industrial Conference Board.

A strike of union operators halted Columbus street car and bus transportation early today and is continuing. Mayor Myron B. Gessaman quickly canceled all police leaves and began an effort toward mediation.

Sparrowbush, the three-and-onehalf-acre estate of Charles U. Caegar on Ridge Road, Rumson, N. J., has been purchased by George Dwight of Rumson through William H. Hintelmann, broker. The dwelling is of the New England farmhouse type of architecture and was erected in 1928 by Mr. Hintelmann for investment.
In a statement tonight the Quai d'Orsay confirmed official acceptance of the British invitation to Premier Edouard Daladier. and Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet to visit London on April 28.

Declaring that adversities in life are inevitable, the Rev. Dr. Paul Scherer, pastor of Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street, said in his Easter sermon yesterday that it is part of every prudent mind to steady itself against the facts. Almost 1,000 persons attended the Easter worship.

Once again the Intercollegiate Fencing Association is facing a crisis in its affairs. A movement several years ago to freeze out the non-ivy colleges in order to establish a strictly Ivy College competition died aborning. But that selfsame specter has been resurrected so that well-wishers of the future welfare of the association are patently worried.

Frau Eliza-beth Hertz, to whom Pope Pius recently made a gift of [Pound]250 in recognition of the work of her late husband the distinguished scientist Heinrich Hertz, is not living in poverty as reported in dispatches from Rome last month.

The upward movement in steel buying in March appears to have spent itself, and, while the April rate promises to equal the previous month, little evidence appears of a continued forward movement, the magazine Steel says this week.
Governor Lehman, who completed action today on all bills left by the Legislature except some forty claim bills and a handful of assorted items, has established an unusually high record of vetoes.

Elsie, one of the four large black bears at the Bear Mountain Zoo, is parading three cubs of recent birth, it was announced today by Major W. A. Welch, general manager of the Palisades Interstate Park.

Arthur Burns has turned a deaf ear to demands that he remove an electrically charged wire, a device to keep dogs away from his yard. "I'm tired of having my yard used as a rendezvous for the neighborhood dogs," Burns declares. "I put up the wire to protect-my property, as I have a right to do, and it's done pretty good."

The annual report of the Lumbermens Mutual Casualty Company of Chicago for 1937 shows premiums at $26,566,766, a new high record and a gain of $4,347,151 over 1936. Underwriting earnings were $4,644,290, an increase of $427,590 over the previous high mark in 1936.
The Browns fought from behind, as they did in most of their Spring training games, to defeat the Cardinals, 6 to 4, today and square the city series at one each.

Beer suits, the satirical Springtime garb of Princeton University seniors since 1912, have appeared on the Nassau campus to usher in two months of traditional activities of the graduating class. This year's cartoon, stamped on the shoulder of the white overall suit, pokes fun at the unsuccessful 1937 football campaign.
The Reds came through in the pinches today to win a ten-inning thriller, 7 to 6, from the Tigers in the final game of the exhibition series.

Activity eased off in the wholesale apparel and accessories markets last week, as retailers concentrated on last-minute Easter business. With many buyers planning to make trips to town this week, volume of mail orders subsided.

Common sense has played a greater part in the maintenance of peace between the United States and Canada for the last century and a quarter than legal precautions of an institutional nature, Dr. James T. Shotwell, director of the Division of Economics and History of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, declared in his annual report, made public yesterday.

Inclusion of a modern Bill of Rights in the draft of the new State Constitution to meet present-day social and economic conditions is proposed in a report made public yesterday by Osmond K. Fraenkel as chairman of the Committee on

Christ abolished death, the annihilator, and vanquished its power, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street, said in his Easter sermon there yesterday. More than 3,000 persons attended the services, the throng overflowing into the adjoining chapel, where a public address system had been installed.
Coleman B. McGovern has been admitted as a general partner in Gude, Winmill Co. Edwin A. Garretson is with Campbell Co. Englander co. have moved to 40 Exchange Place.

The Cubs defeated the White Sox, 7 to 5, before a crowd of 15,000 at Comiskey Park today to end the clubs' California-to-Chicago exhibition "city series." The National Leaguers won ten of sixteen Spring training games from their city r rivals.

Joseph P. McCluskey, former Fordham star and national 3,000-meter indoor steeplechase champion, will be one of the opponents of Don Lash, Indiana two-miler, in the 3,000-meter special race at the fortyfourth annual Penn Relay Carnival April 29 and 30, university officials announced today.
Despite improvement in the internal and external political situations, the money market continues somewhat tight.
At the week's beginning the Bourse and the foreign exchange market were cautious.

Harvard and Cornell, winning their opening games in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League, paced the circuit through its first week of play. Yale, Dartmouth and Princeton are tied for second with an even break in two games, while Columbia and Penn have lost their only games, The Associated Press reports.

Mrs. Ivy L. Lee Jr., heads the committee in charge of the plans for a May Day bicycling party to be held the morning of May 1 under the auspices of the New York Wellesley Club. A breakfast at Armando's will follow the tour.

Miss Frances Hall Rousmaniere, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Rousmaniere of 115' East Sixtyfifth Street, has chosen her sister, Mrs. Albert H. Gordon, for her matron of honor at her marriage to Richard Salter Storrs Jr. of this city on the afternoon of April 27 in St. James's Church, Seventy-first Street and Madison Avenue.

Tenpounds off weight, but feeling "much better" after an appendectomy, Bryan M. Grant Jr.,. mighty atom of tennis, said today: "My big-time days in tennis aren't over; they're just halted temporarily."
The annual report of the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor showed yesterday that the organization spent $1,548,716 in 1937 to aid 40,054 persons in 19,147 families.

A flood of proposals designed to bring the State Constitution into line with present-day economic and social conditions will be presented tomorrow night to the State's Eighth Constitutional Convention when it reassembles here after a two-week recess for completing organization.

APPE-William H., beloved husband of Clara (nee Heine). Reposing at Park West Memorial Chapel, 79th St. and Columbus Ave. Funeral Wednesday, April 20, 10 A. M. Interment Baron Hirsch Cemetery. AVIROM-Rev. Monis. Congregation Telmpie Gates of Israel, 560 West 185th, announces with regret the death of dear father of our beloved cantor, Morris Avirom. and Clara Avirom.

A 100 per cent increase in building activity for the early part of 1938, as compared with the same period last year at Lake Mohawk, Sparta, N. J., is reported by the Arthur D. Crane Company, developers.

Senator Josh Lee, Oklahoma Democrat, arrived back in the Capital tonight moneyless. While he slept on a train bringing him back from a speaking trip to Jackson, Miss., a thief removed $104 from his wallet. He had to borrow money for breakfast.

The manner in which a modern grand master at chess breaks up a position and forces an opponent to the wall, if given the slightest encouragement through the employment of inadequate moves, was demonstrated by Reuben Fine in his eleventh-round game in the United States championship at Rockefeller Center.

Attacking "totalitarian religion," Rabbi Stephen S. Wise declared in a sermon yesterday morning before the Free Synagogue congregation in Carnegie Hall that Jews cannot believe in "the Christ of dogma" in order "to be saved or to be safe."

After leading in Class B all Winter and taking the national championship, Frank Campbell concluded the dinghy racing season today at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club by totaling an even 200 points for the last two days' competition.

The resurrection of Jesus Christ to defeat the forces of intolerance, bigotry and greed on Easter changed Calvary from a disaster to a coronation, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo declared yesterday morning. He spoke at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas,

Invitations nave been sent out for the marriage on May 14 of Miss Nancy Holcomb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Wainwright Holcomb of this city and Fisher's Island, N. Y., to Ernest Arthur Anderson Jr. of Waterbury. The ceremony will be performed in St. John's Church here by the Rev. Dr. John N. Lewis.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Virginia MacDonald Prout, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Peck Prout of 55 East Seventy-second Street and of Summit, N. J., to Frederick Gilbert, son of Mrs. Dudley Gilroy of Chantilly, France, and of Albert Chatfield Gilbert of Utica. N. Y.

Dissatisfaction with the operation of the State Unemployment Insurance Law was expressed yesterday by the heads of five major unions in this city. Speaking as warm partisans of the principle of unemployment insurance,

Owing to the approach of Easter, business in the last week was inclined to be dull. With General Franco's armies now on the Mediterranean Coast, Spain returned to the foreground as a keystone in current international interest.

In an urgent effort to save the life of 29-year-old George Cestaro, who has been suffering from a rare blood disease since last November, Dr. Louis A. Lanzetta of 312 East 116th Street, renewed his appeal yesterday for a blood donor who has recovered from the same disease.

William E. Yerks of 180 Hudson Terrace, a retired lumber merchant and formerly active in business circles and organizations here, died, today of a heart ailment in St. John's Riverside Hospital at the age of 70.
Miss Rose Elizabeth Squire, the first woman to attain high rank in English civil service, died on Friday at Ingatestone, Essex, at the age of 78.

The recent "purges" in two of the most important armies of Europethe German and the Russian-have, in the light of after events, scarcely affected the one, but have severely affected the fighting efficiency of the other, according to recent reports received here.

Fort Mifflin, where the British were held at bay in the Revolutionary War, and Philadelphia was guarded during the Civil War, may become a public park. Mayor S. Davis Wilson said today that he would ask the Federal Government, which owns the fort, either to convert it into a national park
Dr. Isaac Palmer Patch, poet, Civil War veteran and former president of Redfield College, Redfield, S. D., died last night at the age of 90.

Mrs. Genevieve B. Earle, Brooklyn Fusion member of the City Council, explained yesterday that her vote last week against the bill to provide a five-day week for all city employes but teachers and members of the uniformed services was cast not because she did not consider the bill desirable but because the committee in reporting out the measure had made no attempt to estimate the probable cost. The Council passed the bill 21 to 3.

O. Agathon and R. Fawcett tied at 97 for the high-over-all scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday, then broke 25 straight each in a shoot-off. Agathon captured the second extra string, 24-23.
John A. Ford, vice principal of Pittsfield High School, died tonight of a coronary thrombosis at his home at the age of 58. He had been on the faculty since 1914.
President Roosevelt heard an Easter sermon today for the troubled world to solve its problems by accepting the philosophy of Christ.

The purge of "wreckers" in industry and the replacement of dismissed executives by tens of thousands of young people, presumably ardent Stalinists, are credited in part by the Soviet official press today with the first quarter's increased production over the same period of last year.

A suit that will test in the United States Supreme Court the legality of a New Jersey law permitting building and loan associations to restrict the amount of money they allow shareholders to withdraw was planned here today.

Stanley Brown, 27 years old, of 290 Glenwood Avenue, Bridgeport, Conn., was arrested yesterday morning and charged with burglary after he was found prowling about in the living room at the home of Patrolman Walter H. Harrington, 142- 22 231st Street, Rosedale, Queens.

The engagement of Miss Georgia Geddes Conrad, daughter of Colonel Bryan Conrad, U. S. A., retired, of Winchester and Richmond and the late Mrs. Conrad, to E. Taylor Pierce of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Earl C. Pierce, has been announced by her father.

When Leonardo da Vinci, standing at the edge of a precipice on Mount Albano, saw the monster flying machine of his designing crash in the valley below, he cried to the winds, so one of his biographers states:
All over the twenty-six counties of Ireland imposing parades were held today in commemoration of the Easter Week rising of 1916.

Patrolman Joseph Kostik, 40 years old, was killed and his companion, Patrolman Albert Liptak, 30, was seriously injured when their radio patrol car overturned on Nepperhan Avenue hill about 1 P. M. today after Kostik, the driver, swerved to avoid striking a pedestrian.

Industry in Germany is active, particularly the building, automotive and engineerig lines. Building, however, connues to depend on public orders, which , according to a new compilaon, accounted for almost 80 per ent of the value of all of last ear's construction, including roads nd underground work.
Whether the President's plan to spend our way out of the depression is likely to work must obviously depend upon the soundness of the economic theory on which it is based.

Isolation of the first crystalline hormone from the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland, and its identification as prolactin, the hormone of mother love, was disclosed here tonight by the American Chemical Society, on the eve of the opening here of the society's annual Spring meeting.

The American Labor party through Alex Rose, State executive secretary, announced yesterday its program for refraining the State constitution and the selection of Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti as its official spokesman at the constitutional convention.
Only one piece of major legislation is scheduled for discussion on the floors of Congress this week, the $1,121,546,000 Naval Expansion Bill, on which the Senate is to start debate Tuesday.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, Representative Jack Nichols of Oklahoma and United States Attorney Lamar Hardy will be the speakers at the annual Jefferson Day dinner of the National Democratic Club at the Hotel Commodore Saturday night. Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President will be a guest.

Despite a decrease of thirty-three in the number of murders and manslaughter committed in New York City last year, the annual report of Police Commissioner Valentine, made public yesterday, revealed an increase in other major crimes.

Miss Anne Veronica Steckler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Steckler of Scarsdale, was married this afternoon in the Church of St. James the Less to John H. Lynn, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Lynn of Mount Vernon. The Rev. Alan Reid Chalmers officiated.

A schedule of fifty-eight feature pictures and 102 shorts will be produced by Paramount during the season of 1938-39, according to an announcement made yesterday by Neil F. Andrews, vice president in charge of distribution, at the company's annual sales meeting in Washington and released here.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress, during the period April 9 to 15, are given in the following tabulation:

The marriage of Miss Ida McGiffert Lampman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Lampman of 115 West Eighty-ninth Street, to William H. Hunt of this city, son of-Mr. and Mrs. William Hunt, took place yesterday afternoon in the Chureh of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue at Eighty-sixth Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Christopher Jeffares McCombe.

General John J. Pershing left Tucson at 11:20 A. M. today on a special car for New York. He will attend the wedding on April 22 of his son, Warren, and Miss Muriel B. Richards in St. Thomas Church; but the general said that he would not act as best man, his strength being unequal to that.
President Roosevelt's program for recovery was assailed and defended on the radio tonight in a debate between Senators Vandenberg and Hill.
Louis Meyer of Huntington Park, Calif., only three-time winner of the 500mile race, officially became the new "iron man" of the Indianapolis motor speedway today.

Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons commented today that the Australian Government is convinced that the Anglo-Italian agreement will make a material contribution to the alleviation of tension and a general appeasement in Europe.

Two men, both with criminal records, were arrested by New York detectives at 6 A. M. yesterday in a parked automobile at Eightysixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue and held as fugitives from justice in connection with the hold-up on April 7 of the First National Bank in Allendale, N. J., by four gunmen who escaped with $10,500.
Eighteenth century churches here and in the near-by fishing port of Benicarlo were reconsecrated in time for Easter services today.

The Cunard White Star Line did even better business last year than in 1936 and found it possible for the first time to set aside more than [Pound]1,000,000 to cover depreciation on its fleet, the board of directors reported tonight.
The Cubs' prize pitching acquisition, Jerome (Dizzy) Dean, breezed into the cityand out again today in almost the same time it takes his fast ball to hop across the plate.

To many newspaper readers the great experiment on the Tennessee River which we call for short the TVA has come to mean controversy. Disputes over the power policy and the split in the directorship which led to the Presidential dismissal of Chairman Arthur E. Morgan have demanded the headlines.

The prevailing wage scale set last week by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick for work on city contracts stands as "an inexcusable raid on the city treasury by organized labor, acting in concert with contractors," Richard C. Patterson Jr., chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, charged yesterday.

Harry Handler and Joseph Sanson won the Metropolitan A. A. U. four-wall doubles handball championship at the Pastime A. C. yesterday by defeating Roy See and Vincent Martinelli in straight games, 21--7, 21--13.

The Federal Land Bank System will not issue refunding bonds to replace the more than $22,000,000 of 4 per cent bonds called for redemption by the banks on last Friday, according to an announcement yesterday by Charles R. Dunn, fiscal agent of the Land Banks and Federal intermediate credit banks.

The five WPA Federal Arts Projects will have to adapt their operations after June 30 to the new WPA cost formula limiting total expenditures on any white-collar project to $1,000 a year for each employee, Paul Edwards, administrative officer in charge of the arts projects in this city, disclosed last night.

The Compania Hispano-Americana de Electricidad has announced that its general meeting this year will be held in Zurich, Switzerland, on May 2, when the results for the fiscal year 1937 will be presented to shareholders.
Willis Van Devanter, retired associate justice of the Supreme Court, observed his seventy-ninth birthday today by visiting his farm near Ellicott City, Md. He appeared to be in excellent health.

Although since the conquest of Jerusalem by Titus the Jewish community rarely has experienced a period of greater oppression than at present, nevertheless "we shall survive this period too, no matter how much sorrow, no matter how heavy a loss in life it may bring," Professor Albert Einstein told 3,000 of his coreligionists at the Hotel Astor last night.

At the end of a long ceremony in St. Peter's for the canonization of three new saints, Pope Pius shortly before 1:30 P. M. [7:30 A.M., E. S. T.] today appeared on the outer balcony of the Basilica and imparted the apostolic benediction urbi et orbi-to the city and to the world.
Clarence (Spike) Fisher, home club champion, scored a 7-and-5 victory over a clubmate, Terry Fitzgerald, today to capture the sixteenth annual Wildwood Golf Club Easter tournament.

Tokyo regarded the conclusion of the Anglo-Italian accord as reducing the triple anti-Comintern pact to a German-Japanese agreement against Russia. The Foreign office was represented as seriously concerned since the agreement may affect Britain's Far Eastern policy.

Eight persons, including Dr. Charles E. Beury, president of Temple University, and Edward G. Budd, manufacturer, asked in Common Pleas Court yesterday a charter for the "Foundation for Clinical and Medical Research."

The problem of prices lies in the prices of particular commodities and for various industries, and these are as sharply different as the persons in a play, it is held in a book titled "Price and Price Policies," published today by the McGrawHill Book Company.

Nation wide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 34 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the preceding week. March, with an average of 33.84 per cent, was the highest month since last November.

While Mrs. Adele Rivero, women's champion of the National Chess Federation, adjourned her game with Mrs. B. W. McCready of Hackensack in the eighth round, both of her chief rivals, Miss N. May Karff of Boston and Mrs. Mary Bain

Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Ward Malley of this city announced today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Ward Malley, to William Ranulf Compton, son of Major and Mrs. Ranulf Compton of Madison, Conn.

New York's first city-wide milk cooperative and the first direct partnership between consumers and dairy farmers in the East will begin operation soon, selling milk to its members at the lowest prevailing market price, it was learned yesterday.

Dartmouth's speedy ski team flashed over a slalom course in Tuckerman's Ravine at Pinkham Notch today to capture the annual Edson Memorial Cup race. The Big Green finished with a total time of 4:49. Second was Harvard with 6:08.

Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah J. Geagan have announced the engagement of Mrs. Geagan's daughter, Miss Elizabeth Caroline Moran, to Edward A. Kennedy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kennedy of Jackson Heights. The announcement was made at a tea given yesterday at the Geagan home. 420 West End Avenue.

As the studio which once hired a chorus of forty to do the quartet from "Rigoletto," the Warners obviously had no qualms about inventing a twin brother, or more accurately a double, for Booth Tarkington's Penrod.

The week following Easter is traditionally less prolific of exhibitions in the local galleries. Nevertheless, a number of events of more than passing interest are on the calendar and a variety of new attractions are opening.

Becaise of the suspension of business in financial London for the Easter holidays, no immediate reactions to President Roosevelt's new financial policies can be obtained. Opinions that have been expressed, however, are both favorable and unfavorable.

Tension of international unrest relieved, the lesser anxieties temporarily forgotten, Britons today threw themselves into the celebration of Easter-tide with the deepest reverence and most carefree gaiety in years.
The Works Progress Administration, which has planned increased purchases of cotton textiles for use in WPA sewing rooms throughout the country, will place orders soon, it was stated today.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will be the speaker at the annual dinner of the American Booksellers Association on May 17, at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The dinner, which will be attended by booksellers, publishers and literary figures, will be the closing feature of the booksellers convention, to be held on May 15, 16 and 17.
Everything is lovely now. It is definitely the sort- of weather when good fellows get together. Spring at last is on the wing.

The Governors of Connecticut, New Hampshire, Vermont, Massachusetts and Rhode Island received today a copy of a trust indenture, drawn by the Pennsylvania Railroad, which, a spokesman said, might assure the future control of the New York, New Haven' Hartford Railroad by New England rather than outside interests.

Karastan Rugs Mills are today launching a contest for the best promotion by department stores, which is unusual in the fact that it demands that participating retailers run a certain amount of newspaper advertising linage during the period they select for their promotion.

Rational mergers are the one hope of the railroads, according to an analysis by J. A. Emery, vice president of Ford, Bacon Davis, Inc., engineers. He said that the need for competitive railway service for every town, if it ever existed, had been eliminated by the Interstate Commerce Commission and highway vehicles.

THERE aren't many originals among American writers. Jesse Stuart of Greenup County, Ky., is one of the few. That was indicated in 1934, when his "Man With a Bull-Tongue Plow" appeared. It was proved in 1936, with a collection of short stories called "Head o' W-Hollow." It is still evident today, with the autobiographical "Beyond Dark Hills."*

Last week's markets were again wholly dominated by the course of events at Washington. When Europe's war scare was dominant, an event of such high significance as the Anglo-Italian pact would have had effect.

In a closely contested game, during which the lead changed hands twelve times, the Jersey Reds defeated the Brooklyn Jewels, 30 to 28, at Arcadia Hall, Brooklyn, last night, to capture the American Basketball League title. The victory was the Reds' fourth in six stars in the play-off 'series.

The American Bowling Congress, fast tapering off for the wind-up Tuesday night, failed to explode any fireworks today. Scores, both in- doubles and singles, were low, and no changes were made in the standings.

Alberta continues to bear high the torch of financial reform. Having "adjusted" the interest on her public obligations, she is now preparing to adjust private debts. Mr. Lucien Maynard, Minister of Municipal Affairs, has introduced into the House of the Provincial Legislature an interesting
The new organ and the new chancel in the Russell Sage Memorial Chapel on the Campus of Northfield Seminary for Girls were dedicated this afternoon.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Arthur Stem of 34 Gramercy Park and of Cincinnati, of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Clarissa Halstead Stem, to E.,Fontaine Broun Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Broun of Charleston. W. Va.

Minimum requirements for the admission of private social and health agencies to the Greater New York Fund, which will appeal next month to business establishments and their employes for $10,000,000, were announced yesterday in Better Times, weekly publication of the Welfare Council.
Members of the Electrical Trades Union, voting to strike at three movie production studios in support of an operators' walkout, tonight issued a call for nation-wide closing of picture houses.
The Title Guarantee and Trust Company reported for March 31 total deposits of $17,574,219 and total assets of $40,788,549, compared, respectively,
Dr. Francis E. Townsend arrived here by plane today to submit to a thirty-day. jail sentence for contempt of the House of Representatives.
Eduardo R. Suarez, the Mexican Finance Minister, is coming to Washington to discuss renewal of the American agreement to purchase Mexican silver, high officials indicated today.

Up and down New York City from Spuyten Duyvil to the Battery, from the Bronx to Staten Island, surged yesterday a mighty magnificat of prayer and praise as the Christian world celebrated once more the Feast of the Resurrection. It was the city's most radiant and most fervent Easter in recent years, according to authorities in both fields-the stylists and the clergy.

H. Higgs took the honors in the first fifty at the North Jersey Gun Club's traps today. The handicap winners were H. A. McLean, L. F. Sanman, A. Best, D. P. Earle, A. B. Blood, F. A. Landis and Mrs. Mary Conde.

The domestic trade situation presents a rather patchwork appearance at this time. Taking Great Britain as a whole, the business recession has been moderate. It appears to have increased in some directions and to have halted in others.

With Isaac I. Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, once more leading by the narrowest mar gin and with three of his chief ri vals close at his heels, the twelfth round of the United States cham pionship tournament under the aus pices of the National Chess Federa tion was concluded at the R. C. A Building in Rockefeller Center lasi night.
Current press comments on the business picture in the United States, influenced, as usual, by Wall Street's gyrations, are in less gloomy vein than were the summaries at the end of March.
By a vote of 243 to 22, the Northern California Newspaper Guild today accepted a 1938 contract covering wages and working conditions on five newspapers.

Firemen dragged the swift and treacherous waters of Hannacroix Creek tonight for the bodies of two youths, chance acquaintances, whose overturned canoe was found near the bank here. The victims, State police said, were Burton Kolb Jr., 19, of Coeymans and Hans Anderson, 18, of Brooklyn.

The crucifixion of Christ was accomplished by rabble-rousing tactics akin to those used by politicians today, asserted the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, rector, in advising the Easter congregation at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, to "be of good courage" despite the "trials and tribulations" of business and public life.

The commissioner of baseball, K. M. Landis, announced today the Giant and Indian teams each had been fined $200 following investigation of two disputes involving the clubs in their recent exhibition swing in Texas.
Because of an increase of rabid dogs in Brooklyn, the Board of Health has extended its emergency quarantine on dogs running at large in that borough for three months, it was announced yesterday.
Vitally expressive singing set forth with conviction and zeal was heard from the Workmen's Circle Chorus, under Lazare Weiner, at its annual concert in Town Hall yesterday afternoon.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Best gave a tea at their home in Lawrence Park West today at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjory Best, to Gifford Montague Mabie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund G. Mabie, also of Bronxville.

The Federal' Trade Commission has issued three announcements affecting companies in New York. One order closed a case brought against W. A. Taylor Co., liquor importers, 15 Laight Street. The commission announced that it found insufficient evidence to support the charges that the concern had been guilty of unfair competition through maintenance of fixed uniform prices, discounts and mark-ups.

The Nationalist (Insurgent) left wing under General Garcia Valino this morning moved up the coast from Alcanar, five miles north of Vinaroz, toward San Carlos de la Rapita, the southernmost point of the Ebro River's broad delta below Tortosa.

At least 100 members of the dissolved Iron Guard [Fascist organization] were arrested throughout the country today including, it is reported, "Captain" Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, in connection with that organization's, renewed terroristic activity.

The American Academy in Rome announced yesterday that two of the three Rome prizes in classical studies had been won by women. This competition is the only one of six conducted by the academy that is even open to women.

Five young men, selected for their promise of contribution to knowledge, will join the Society of Fellows at Harvard University next September as junior fellows, devoting themselves to independent research and study for three years at the expense of the university, it was announced here tonight.

A possibility that The Players might have to abandon the fifteenth annual Spring revival because the group cannot obtain "important names" for the leading roles was admitted yesterday by one of the committee in charge of the proposea production.

The Merchants Association of New York announced yesterday that, subject to two conditions, it had voted to support a proposal for a constitutional amendment authorizing the city to borrow outside the debt limit, so rapid transit lines required for the consummation of a unification plan can be purchased or recaptured.

Two paintings ascribed to Vincent van Gogh have been discovered in a Breda farmhouse attic. They were bought at a recent fair-for 5 Netherlands cents each. A visiting art dealer bought them from a farmer for 750 florins.

The Goldman Band, directed by Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman, will give its annual series of Daniel Guggenheim Memorial Concerts on the Mall in Central Park and at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, June 15 to Aug. 15.

There were indications today that the imperial palace was concerned by Japan's serious political situation. Marquis Yasumasa Matsudaira, Chief Secretary to the Lord Keeper of the Privy Seal, called upon 88 year-old Prince Kimmochi Saionji,...

Membersoof the Spence Alumnae Association will give their annual Silver Spoon dinner dance to aid their Adoption Nursery on May 4 on the St. Regis Roof. Mrs. Richardson Pratt heads the committee in charge, and Mrs. William M. Mather is vice chairman. Their aides include Mrs. S. Sloan Colt, Mrs. E. Lloyd Sanderson, Mrs. Louis F. Bishop Jr. and Miss Lois McCall.

National Cup Championship Spartas (Chicago) 3, St. Mary's Celtics (B'klyn) 0. American League Playoffs Irish-Americans 3, N. Y. Americans 1. Newark Scots-Americans 8, Philadelphia German-Americans 4. Boston Celts A Worcester Scandinavians 1.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,392,603,650. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestearing discount bills. The list follows:

With President Roosevelt filling the role of America's No. 1 baseball fan, the season which will see the country's national pastime come up to the century mark gets under way today. To the American League goes the distinction of ushering in the season of 1938. Appropriately enough,...

The twenty-second anniversary of the Easter Week rebellion in Ireland was marked last night at a meeting of the Clan-na-Gael of New York at the Hotel Astor, attended by 600 persons. Daniel F. Cohalan, former Supreme Court Justice, and James McGurrin, president of the Irish American Historical Society, were the speakers. John J. Sheahan presided.

Columbia University's budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1 will total $14,806,021, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the institution. This amount, in which are included appropriations for all the corporations in the university's educational system,
A series of explosions, followed by fire, damaged the thirty-acre plant of the Barrett Company in the Frankford section of Philadelphia tonight.

The Easter hope of salvation must be held by man if he would retain his sanity and faith in a world of pain, the Rev. Dr. Christopher Jeffares McCombe said yesterday in his first Easter sermon as minister of the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue at Eighty-sixth Street.

Miss Marjorie Manning, daughter of the Rev. Stanley Manning and Mrs. Manning of this city, was married to Otto Postma, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter O. Postma, in. the Church of the Redeemer yesterday afternoon. The bride's father performed the ceremony.

Mrs. Joseph Chuckrow of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Esther L. Chuckrow, to Raymond Ellenbogen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Ellenbogen of Rensselaer. The bride-elect, daughter of the late Rev. Mr. Chuckrow, was graduated from New York State College for Teachers at Albany. Mr. Ellenbogen attended Temple University.

The Newark Bears outclassed the Phillies both at the plate and on the pitcher's mound to score an easy 12-to-1 victory today. While Bithorn, Russo and Makosky held the National Leaguers to four scattered hits, the Bears pounded Pete Sivess and Tommy Reis for fourteen and were never behind.

The engagement of Miss Helen Fox Pumphrey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Pumphrey of this place, to Edward Harrison Tener Jr. of Pittsburgh, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Tener, has been announced, by her parents.

Three years after she played her last big tournament match, to defeat Miss Helen Jacobs in the final of the British championship at Wimbledon, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody has resurrected her tennis racquet and turned her face toward the East again.

Six days late as a result of a breakdown in the port engine at Callao, the Grace Line motor ship Santa Maria arrived yesterday afternoon from Chile and Peru via the Panama Canal after beating up the coast from Colon on her starboard engine only.
Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "The Influence of New York State in National Affairs," William S. Murray; "The FBI 'and its Fight Against Crime," R. F. Vetterli.
Two months to the day after launching their arduous training campaign the Giants brought their long Indian war to a triumphant close today by upsetting Ossle Vitt's Tribe, 5 to 3.

Contracts for supplies valued at $3,845,490 were awarded in the week ended-on April 14 by ten Federal agencies under the- provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor has announced.
Even more enthusiastic than last night's was the ovation accorded Arturo Toscanini tonight when he conducted the Palestine orchestra before an audience of thousands of Jewish laborers.

Mr. and Mrs. Clifford w. Micner will give a dinner in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador on Wednesday for Mrs. Michel's sister, Miss Muriel Bache Richards, and her fiance, Francis Warren Pershing, who will be married Friday in St Thomas Church.

Marse Joe McCarthy has new wrinkles in his brow and probably a gray hair or two in spite of the fact that his champion Yankees yesterday finished their three-game exhibition series with the Dodgers at Ebbets Field by beating them, 14 to 13, after losing the first two contests.

Henry Longhi, 35 years old, of 2 Adrian Avenue, who is alleged to have "saved" thousands of dollars for gas and electric consumers in the Washington Heights section in the last twenty years by "fixing" meters, was held in $2,000 bail for examination 'April 27 when arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Anna M. Kross in Washington Heights Court.
One Arab was killed and six Arabs and a Jew were wounded today as two bombs were thrown into an Arab cafe in the center of Haifa from a passing automobile. The terrorists escaped.

The Easter parade of finery, "pride and self-sufficiency" was contrasted with the "resurrectionists' parade" of "righteousness, humility and the love of God" by the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, in his Easter sermon yesterday morning.
Reports from Belgrade indicate that the authorities consider Austria's disappearance a favorable development for Yugoslavia's consolidation.
Excerpts from Wagner's "Parsifal" formed the culmination of yesterday afternoon's 'program of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli.

Completion of a new building at the southwest corner of Wilshire Boulevard and Peck Drive, Beverly Hills, involving investment of about $1,000,000 for building and lease, prepares the way for the opening there of a new Saks-Fifth Avenue store a week from tomorrow.

Christ through His Resurrection gave "visible witness" that the grave has no victory and death no sting, that "life is the law of nature and death a natural means to a better life," the Rev. Dr. Edgar Tilton said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Eighty-ninth Street Reformed Church, between Park and Madison Avenues. Dr. Tilton is pastor emritus.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions FU MANCHU'S RESTAURANT, INC., 108 W. 49th St.--Voluntary proceeding under section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law, listing liabilities of $31,051 and assets of $37,385.
Boston's six-game city baseball series that started in the South ended in a draw today when the Red Sox tripped the hustling Bees, 2 to 1, before a crowd of 10,120.

Easter dawned in New York with a warming sun ascending in a clear sky to gladden the hearts of fully 24,000 early worshipers in the five boroughs. The response of ideal conditions was gratifying for -those who in the last few years have contended with wind, rain and even snow.
Funds obtained concert for Austria
Assembling at 2 P. M. today at the Hotel Algonquin, the Drama Critics Circle will select what at least twelve of them agree is "the best new American play" of the season.
A sensation was caused in the Hong Kong General Postoffice this afternoon when a mail bag burst into flames following a dull explosion in which a Chinese sorter was injured.

Murry M. Singer, vice president of the Bergdorf Goodman Fur Corporation, described as inaccurate yesterday the announcement by the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board on Friday that the company would start negotiations today for an independent agreement with the Furriers' Joint Council.

With the Anglo - Italian agreement safely signed and almost universally approved, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain arrived in the far north of Scotland this morning to spend a vacation of almost a week as the guest of the Marquess of Londonderry.
Forty thousand persons, some of whom began arriving by 3 A. M., assembled at Temple University Stadium today for an Easter sunrise service, the largest held in the Philadelphia area.

The first decrees issued by the new government of Premier Edouard Daladier will tend, principally, to cover the Treasury's needs and increase funds available to industrial and commercial' enterprises.

Mrs. Sarah Frank Katzenstein, for many years active in philanthropic work here, died last night at her home in the Esplanade Apartments. Mrs. Katzenstein, a founder of the Daughters in Israel, was a former president of the organization.

This village's entire fire-fighting force fought a blaze which swept four stores and adjoining apartments in the business district early today. George Buchhardt, assistant fire chief, estimated damage at nearly $50,000.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that four hearings would be conducted in New York this week on various charges. On Monday at 10 A. M., at Room 500, 45 Broadway, William G. Reeves, trial examiner,

Joint and cooperative action by the Transit Commission and the La Guardia administration is all that is needed to make possible an early agreement on a plan of rapid-transit unification, representatives of the principal groups of private traction securities holders indicated yesterday.

A sixfoot Paschal candle, the only one sent to this country for Easter by Pope Pius, was lighted in St. Patrick's Cathedral here today before the pontifical high mass, at which Archbishop-elect Thomas J. Walsh was celebrant.

Inflation talk as the result of a change in Washington's fiscal policy injected a new factor into the world wheat market last week, and, while it caused a sharp upturn in the North American markets on Thursday, the program was not announced until dealings on the European and the Argentine exchanges had been suspended for the Easter holidays.

Cotton prices reversed their downward trend last week and final quotations were about $1.50 a bale above those at the end of the previous week. The belief that the program announced by President Roosevelt on Thursday had inflationary implications spurred a rise of 25 to 27 points that day on the New York Cotton Exchange.

The Resurrection of Christ signifies the joy of certainty; it is the only thing that makes the intelligent Christian sure of his faith and his creed, the Rev. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street, declared in his Easter sermon yesterday morning. "The certainty of the Resurrection fills a great mental want," Dr.

BEYOND DARK HILLS, by Jesse Stuart. (Dutton, $3.50.) A volume of recollections by the Kentucky mountain writer. BURGOS JUSTICE, by Ruiz Vilaplana. (Knopf, $2.) An account of conditions in Rebelheld Spain.

Despite sympathetic cooperation from democratic nations which afford asylum for Jewish refugees, the salvation of the Jewish people from oppression and persecution in certain countries depends largely on the faith and liberty-loving principles of the Jews themselves, Louis Lipsky, national co-chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, declared last night in a Passover broadcast.
Members of the Russian Choir of Paris tomorrow will pay special honors to their celebrated compatriot, Feodor Chaliapin.

Threat of a fruit and perishable vegetable shortage- confronted the Rochester district tonight as a strike of about 1,200 truck drivers moved into its third day, crippling week-end deliveries of produce, general merchandise and freight.
Entries for the Boston marathon, one of the nation's sports classics, rose to 204 today, assuring one of the wildest scrambles for victory in the event's forty-two-year history.

Mrs. Alice Howard Harding, horticulturist, wife of Edward Harding, New York lawyer, died here today at her home, Burmley Farms, on Terrill Road, after a brief illness. A resident of Plainfield for thirty years, she had developed on her estate a garden of unusual size and beauty. She had a special fondness for peonies, lilacs and irises, and was a recognized authority on these flowers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES iS quite correct in calling attention to the high wages paid to railroad operatives as a logical place for the bankrupt industry to seek relief. These wages, however, are not nearly so absurd, in view of the crisis of the industry. as are the short hours in which train and engine employes earn their money.

There are several excellent streams in this area of the State, but an Easter calm prevailed over most of them this morning. During the afternoon, however, some fishermen could be seen along the banks of the occasional State-leased stream, but most of the unposted waters were barren of life.
The stock market (closed yesterday and today) was relatively active in its four-day week, and, excepting on Tuesday, the list generally was firm.

Disputing charges that the specially enacted legislation which has been in force since January, 1935, for the settlement of Chile's foreign-debt obligations, is an inadequate arrangement and has been unsatisfactory in actual practice, well-informed circles close to the government maintained today that the specific law does not warrant such criticism, because the country already has redeemed more than $60,000,000 worth of outstanding bonds.

Rose Marie Lyons. 3-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Lyons of 426 Rector Street, was drowned this afternoon when she fell into Staten Island Sound from a dock of the General Cable Corporation.

The mechanical failure of a signal light, with the resultant halting of traffic, was blamed by New York Central System officials in this city for the railroad wreck eleven miles from Hudson, N. Y., shortly before 2 A. M. yesterday in which ten passengers and a brakeman were injured, most of them slightly.
Easter was celebrated today in four warscarred Protestant Churches by about 1,000 persons who, the pastors reported, had regularly attended services since the war began twenty-one months ago.

Shortly before the Ethiopian war started, Premier Mussolini and Sir Eric Drummond, now the Earl of Perth, British Ambassador to Italy, had a long and grave conversation one sultry evening in the Palazzo Venezia.

The Hippodrome Opera Company opened its special Easter performances with a presentation of a double bill consisting of "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" at the Hippodrome last night before a large and responsive house.

The far-reaching amnesty that President Eduard Benes proclaimed yesterday and his "Easter peace" speech both met a discouraging reception in the Sudeten German press. The intention is apparently to use the amnesty as a lever to extort fresh concessions.

Exports from Russian ports on the Black Sea passing Istanbul in January and February, amounting to 308,094 long tons, made a decline of 67 per cent from the corresponding period of 1937, the American commercial attache at Istanbul has reported to the Department of Commerce.
Hurling and Gaelic football championships at Innisfail Park yesterday drew 3,000 fans who witnessed contests packed with action from start to finish.

AKRON, Ohio--Akron D. G. Co.: L. C. Bronstein, gen. Mdse. mgr.: Miss M. Cross. sportswear: Miss N. Taylor, children's, junior wear: 218 W. 40th (B. F. Levis). BALTIMORE--Julius Gutman Co.: Miss M. Pearlman, jobs, cotton dresses, silk underwear: 119 W. 40th (F. Litenthal Co.).

The report of the official survey of German crops as of April 1 summarizes all Winter cereals and fodder plants as being materially better than on the same date in 1937. Wheat stands best, registering 2.3 on an index basis of 2, meaning good, and 3 meaning middling.

Out of a total of $3,737,794.32 allotted by the Social Security Board to New York, Vermont and New Mexico for public assistance during the current quarter, $3,690,032.66 went to New York, according to an announcement by the board today.

Properties in Harlem figured in realty transactions reported in the city over the week-end. Savings banks were among the sellers. The North River Savings Bank sold to an investing client of Schimmer, Kerner Feder, brokers, the two buildings containing a furniture store, loft and hotel rooms at 2,238-40 Third Avenue, southwest corner of East 122d Street.

Before 2,500 persons who overflowed the opened part of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, filled the seats in the ambulatory and occupied several hundred chairs in the unopened nave, Bishop William T. Manning preached his Easter sermon yesterday morning on "Jesus Christ, the Same Yesterday, Today and Forever."

" Give and Take," a story of a prizefighter from the slums, will be the next- for Robert Taylor at Metro. It will precede his appearance in Kenneth Roberts's "Northwest Passage." Joining Taylor will be Maureen O'Sullivan as leading woman, Frank Morgan as his father and Guy Kibbee and Nat Pendleton.

Mrs. Frances J. Kelly, wife of George T. Kelly, former'Assemblyman from Albany, died yesterday at her home, 619 West 140th Street, after a long illness. During her residence in Albany Mrs. Kelly was active in charities there, aiding especially the hospital for tuberculous patients.

Mrs. Mary Whitman Bartholow, wife of the- Rev. Dr. Otho F. Bartholow, pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church, died here tonight at her home, 114 South Eighth Avenue, after an illness of several months. She was born in Urbana, Ill., sixty-eight years ago. Besides her husband,

In one of the best shooting dog stakes seen around the circuit this Spring, Donvale's Judy, a white and liver pointer, was declared the winner today as the trials sponsored by the Mid-Jersey Field Dog Club were concluded.

A prediction that Congress would not give President Roosevelt a free hand in spending new relief and pump-priming funds was made tonight by John Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, in a nation-wide radio address.

France's general wholesale price index has hardened slightly, being 618 on April 9, against 617 in the two previous weekly reports. The gold index of raw materials was 40.6, against 41 and 41.9 on the same dates.

Lard futures fluctuated erratically last week on the Board of Trade, breaking early only to rally sharply later in sympathy with cottonseed oil and other commodities, and closed yesterday with net gains of 5 to 10 cents a 100 pounds, the May being $8.42, July $8.62, September $8.90 and January $9.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 81.1, which compares with 80.9 a week ago, 81.2 two weeks ago, 81.9 three weeks ago and 82.3 four weeks ago.

Intensified Japanese aerial bombardments have been made in the past few days in South China, including repeated raids on Amoy. Kwangtung Province railways have been intensely bombed, and Sheklung Bridge has been damaged heavily, halting all freight traffic between Kowloon [part of Greater Hong Kong, British Crown colony] and Canton.

Alexander A. Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, attacked anti-Semitism in an address yesterday afternoon in the Manhattan Opera House, in Thirtyfourth Street, near Eighth Avenue, where the tenth anniversary of the establishment of the Jewish autonomous territory of Birobidjan in Eastern Siberia was celebrated.

The American Coordinating Committee for International Studies has received a $24,000 grant from the Rockefeller Foundation to carry on the committee's work in economic analyses, President Henry M. Wriston, chairman, reported tonight. President Wriston, newly elected head of the organization, succeeds Professor James T. Shotwell of Columbia.

Wisconsin's old-age pension system, which now is taking care of about 40,000 persons more than 65 years of age, is not cutting down the number of dependents in county houses as early supporters of social security legislation predicted it would.

Despite a slightly better demand in the dress goods section, with an accompanying scarcity of certain cloths, rayon fabric loom activity for the week ended April 9 was virtually without change from the preceding week, according to the survey issued for publication today by the National Rayon Weavers' Association, Inc.

Mrs. Mary Whitman Bartholow, wife of the- Rev. Dr. Otho F. Bartholow, pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church, died here tonight at her home, 114 South Eighth Avenue, after an illness of several months. She was born in Urbana, Ill., sixty-eight years ago. Besides her husband,

In one of the best shooting dog stakes seen around the circuit this Spring, Donvale's Judy, a white and liver pointer, was declared the winner today as the trials sponsored by the Mid-Jersey Field Dog Club were concluded.

A prediction that Congress would not give President Roosevelt a free hand in spending new relief and pump-priming funds was made tonight by John Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, in a nation-wide radio address.

France's general wholesale price index has hardened slightly, being 618 on April 9, against 617 in the two previous weekly reports. The gold index of raw materials was 40.6, against 41 and 41.9 on the same dates.

Lard futures fluctuated erratically last week on the Board of Trade, breaking early only to rally sharply later in sympathy with cottonseed oil and other commodities, and closed yesterday with net gains of 5 to 10 cents a 100 pounds, the May being $8.42, July $8.62, September $8.90 and January $9.

The Douglas Aircraft Company reported yesterday that in the three months ended on Feb. 28 its net oprating profit was $491,633 before taxes, and consolidated net income after normal Federal tax only was $406,771, or 71 cents each on 570,683 shares, compared with $237,351, or 42 cents each on 560,883 shares, last year.

Checking back on the activities of the three gunmen who were shot in an unsuccessful hold-up of the Club Howdy, 47 West Third Street, last Tuesday, detectives announced yesterday that they had arrested five more men and said they had cleared up at least a dozen recent robberies.

The Financial News's index of thirty industrial stocks, based on the average on July 1, 1935, as 100, was 90.9 on April 14, compared with 87.1 a week before, 86.3 a month ago, 116.9 a year ago, 95.9 at the beginning of 1938, and with the high record of 124.9 reached on Nov. 18, 1936, and the lbw mark of 41.6 touched in June, 1932.

A horse show ball will be given Saturday night at the Squadron A Armory, Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street, to climax the three-day Spring horse show which will open at the armory Thursday night. The guests of honor at the ball will include the exhibitors and judges for the show.

Alexander A. Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, attacked anti-Semitism in an address yesterday afternoon in the Manhattan Opera House, in Thirtyfourth Street, near Eighth Avenue, where the tenth anniversary of the establishment of the Jewish autonomous territory of Birobidjan in Eastern Siberia was celebrated.

The American Coordinating Committee for International Studies has received a $24,000 grant from the Rockefeller Foundation to carry on the committee's work in economic analyses, President Henry M. Wriston, chairman, reported tonight. President Wriston, newly elected head of the organization, succeeds Professor James T. Shotwell of Columbia.

Wisconsin's old-age pension system, which now is taking care of about 40,000 persons more than 65 years of age, is not cutting down the number of dependents in county houses as early supporters of social security legislation predicted it would.

In connection with plans of the League of Composers for its forthcoming sixteenth season, Mrs. Myron Taylor, chairman of the organization's auxiliary board, has asked her committee to meet at her home, Wednesday at 4:30 P. M., to discuss an elaborate program of musical events to be scheduled at the World's Fair.

The most encouraging recovery of recent months is taking place quietly in the security markets of Great Britain. There is nothing spectacular or hasty in the movement, but it appears to have more behind it than any previous rallies in this depression.

The organized efforts to prevent blindness received great impetus in 1937 from the unusual progress of wood the drive against syphilis, which is one of the important causes of blindness, according to the annual the Prevention of Blindness, made public yesterday.

Spending continues at a high level in Great Britain. Currency demands for Easter have been exceptionally heavy, and this explains a rise of [Pound]7,555,000 in the Bank of England's circulation in the last week, making a gain of [Pound]17,764,000 for the last three weeks, compared with only [Pound]10,000,000 in the same period preceding Easter last year.
The Society for Seamen's Children which in 1937 became associated with the Seamen's Church Institute of New York will give a benefit garden and tea party and art exhibit tomorrow.

Rolling 629, A. Killeen of New York City stepped into the lead today in the Class A individual competition as singles and doubles bowlers monopolized the alleys in the New York State pin t-urnament. Killeen put together games of 224, 196 and 209 for his 629 count.

Seabiscuit's smooth triumph in the $15,000 added Bay Meadows Handicap left Owner Charles S. Howard more convinced than ever today that his black racer would beat War Admiral in their race at Belmont Park on May 30.

A proposed set of trade practice rules for the hosiery industry, prepared by a committee of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers and other trade groups, was sent to members of the industry at the week-end with a request that they attend a conference
The Anglo-Italian agreement is unquestionably an event of great international importance. It may mark a turning point in the dark tides that in recent months have all been running in one direction.

With Cardinal Hayes presiding, Bishop Stephen J. Donahue sang pontifical mass yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral. As the mass ended, the Cardinal bestowed the papal benediction upon a kneeling congregation, estimated at 6,000 to 8,000 persons.

An unexplained trip by Andrew Carnegie Whitfield, 28-year-old nephew of Mrs. Andrew Carnegie, caused several aerial searching parties to comb Long Island today in search of his silver plane, which left this airport Friday noon.

An all-Brahms concert was given by the Federal Symphony Orchestra, directed by Chalmers Clifton, at the WPA Theatre of Music yesterday afternoon, with Selma Kramer, pianist, as soloist, and Sigmund Spaeth as commentator.

As a by-product of its larger activities and as part of an effort to show that public administration can be conducted on a businesslike basis, the Tennessee Valley Authority has developed a series of tests and surveys in office management which have attracted much interest in the business world.

Trading in oats, rye and soy bean futures on the Board of Trade here last week was relatively slow. A feature was the strength in May oats, which acted congested because of the small amount of contract grains available for delivery on future contracts on the Board of Trade.

Faithful Maud, taking command at the turn for home, raced to a two-length victory over eleven rivals in the $2,500 added Speed Handicap today. Sir Ridgway was second, a length ahead of Indiantown, and Boss Martin was fourth. Faithful Maud paid $8, $5.20 and $3 for $2 across the board; Sir Ridgway $6.20 and $3.40 and Indiantown $3. The time was 1:11 for six furlongs.

After having regarded the impending budget with fear, the City is now viewing this particular matter with something approaching complacency. This attitude may be wrong and it may suffer some rude shocks, but the budgetary prospects are considered in the light of a calmer international atmosphere.

Dr. Edward S. Godfrey Jr., State Health Commissioner, announced today the dates for a series of one-day institutes on syphilis. The meetings will be attended by physicians, who will have an opportunity to study theory and observe the practice of modern methods of diagnosis and treatment.

The certificate of approval of the American Hospital Association will be awarded to the 3-cents-a-day plan of the Associated Hospital Service of New York at a luncheon meeting today at the Hotel Commodore. Thirty-nine other similar plans throughout the United States will be similarly approved. Their membership totals 1,600,000.

Merchandise bearing designs and motifs conceived for the World's Fair will be placed on sale today in shops in the New York area, Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, announced last night. One hundred and fifteen articles already have been licensed to use the fair motifs,

Real estate foreclosures on urban property in the United States in February were 3.8 per cent less than in January and 21.9 per cent below February, 1937, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today.

Unable to provide bail of $1,000, James (Jeff) Burkitt, long a political opponent of Mayor Frank Hague, was still in the city prison today awaiting arraignment tomorrow on a charge of being a disorderly person.

William Ross Eisenhower, chairman of the board of directors of J. E. Caldwell Co., Philadelphia jewelers, died in Ventnor, N. J., yesterday after an illness of several months. He was about 65 years old.

By doing all the work he ought to do, Chicora Citation repeated today his victory of a year ago. This white, black, tan and ticked setter dog received first place in the armateur all age stake, the concluding number in the twenty-seventh annual field trial meeting of the Orange County Field Trial Club.
Four persons were killed and sixty-eight injured today in rioting in Bombay among Hindus and Moslems.
William L. Mead, for many years a newspaper man in New York and Connecticut, died here today at the age of 68.

The Board of Trade's index of British wholesale prices, based on the average for 1930 as 100, was 104.1 in March, compared with 105.8 in the preceding month and with 107.3 in March, 1937, a decline of 1.6 per cent for the month and of 3 per cent for the year.

Sports figures known the world over will gather here Wednesday night for a testimonial dinner to William (Big Bill) Dinneen, a veteran of forty years of continuous service as a player and umpire in major league baseball. Dinneen was one of the few pitchers to win three world series games, including a shutout in the deciding contest.
Special theatrical productions for children are being given this week and next week, as follows: "Uncle Don's Easter Circus," at the Windsor Theatre.

NOW the ball boys are getting ready to go after their bread and butter. That's when the hits count. There is still plenty of guessing going on about the strength of the rival clubs. The Giants are the favorites to repeat in the National League.

The fact that Detective Joseph Downey of the pickpocket squad has a strictly unprofessional manner and dresses along ultra-collegiate lines has frequently contributed to his record as a foe of "lush" workers.

Mrs. Anna C. Murphy Markham, wife of Edwin Markham, the poet, died during her sleep Saturday night at their home, 92 Waters Avenue, Westerleigh, Staten Island. She was 78 years old. An invalid since suffering a paralytic stroke in 1934, Mrs. Markham had been confined to the house for the last two years, and had been unable to leave her bed for three months.

The American Institute of Architects announced today the award of its highest honor to Paul Philippe Cret of Philadelphia. The gold medal award, presented for "most distinguished service to the architectural profession," will go to a man who conceived many notable buildings in this country and elsewhere.

The opening of navigation on the lower Great Lakes last week resulted in fairly liberal shipments of cash corn to Eastern ports, and a good part of the grain will be dropped immediately from the domestic visible supply, as the corn went largely to Canada for export by way of Montreal.
