The Sparta eleven of Chicago continued its undefeated march toward national soccer honors today by turning back the St. Mary's Celtics of Brooklyn, 3 to 0, in the first of their two-game total-goal series for the Dewar Trophy.

New waterfront difficulties cropped out today, stopping all shipping at this port, when the C. I. O. clerks' union demanded the complete unionization of all shipping workers not covered in the stevedores' union, excepting only chief executives.

A poll of seven faculty members of the History, Economics and Politics Departments of Princeton University, conducted by The Daily Princetonian, undergraduate newspaper, on the advisability of a Japanese boycott, has resulted in a 5-to-2 decision against a popular ban on the Oriental merchandise.
Prospects of fair weather brought predictiions from Reds' officials today at 34,000 persons might jam Crosley Field tomorrow for the season's opener against the cubs.

Elmer Blauvelt, head of the Comfort Coal and Lumber Company of Hackensack, N. J., and a director of the Hackensack Water Company and the Hackensack Trust Company, died in his home-here today. He. was 71 years old.

Severin Winterscheid, 34 years old, of 64 Himrod Street, Brooklyn, a lieutenant of Fritz Kuhn in the Nazi movement centering around the German-American Bund, and formerly an editorial contributor to the Deutscher Weckruf und Beobachter, New York organ of the Nazi movement, was arrested last Thursday afternoon in the Empire Theatre, Quincy Street and Ralph Avenue, Brooklyn, on disorderly conduct charges, it was revealed yesterday.
April showers drenched children gathered on the White House grounds today for the annual Easter Monday egg rolling. The rain cut attendance to the lowest figure in several years. 44.166.

The five-year struggle between the United Association of Journeymen Plumbers and Steamfitters, an A. F. of L. organization, and the Alteration Plumbers, Steamfitters and Helpers Union, an independent organization with a membership of more than 3,500, ended last night, when members of the lastmentioned union voted to affiliate with the A. F. of L. body.
The Senate Lobby Committee summoned Sumner Gerard of New York City today, directing him to bring records of the. National Committee to Uphold the Constitution, of which he is treasurer.

A supplemental report of transactions in equity securities in February by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Prospects of reopening of the Allen A Company factory building here for the production of hosiery under the supervision of a citizens' committee with local capital depended today on the report of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation engineers who have just completed a survey and investigation of the properties and the project.

An immediate start on new Summer lines of millinery in preparation for the industry's "first definite Summer season," the stressing of style over price, and cooperation among manufacturers to maintain prices through the season, were urged by speakers last night at a meeting of about 125 producers at the Hotel McAlpin, sponsored by the Eastern Women's Headwear Association and the Millinery Stabilization Commission, Inc.
Mayor La Guardia took an hour from his executive duties yesterday to join the Syrian colony of the lower West Side at a funeral service for one of the neighborhood'smost promising youths.
Share prices closed yesterday around the low levels of the day, with most of the leading issues off fractions to 2 points and a few down more than 3 points.

The Republic Steel Corporation filed in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals today an appeal from the National Labor Relations Board decision which found the company in violation of the Wagner Labor Disputes Act in last Summer's strike.

The Smaller Business Association of the New York District, Inc., expects such a rush of applicants when it opens its small loans bureau at the Hotel New Yorker this morning at 10:30 o'clock that it has changed its reservation for a suite to the grand ballroom.

W. S. Shipley, president of the York Ice Machinery Corporation said yesterday that the company's registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission was withdrawn because present conditions made it impossible to refinance on favorable terms.

New York's three-cents-a-day hospitalization plan received the official stamp of approval yesterday of the American Hospital Association, which represents 7,000 hospitals in the United States and Canada.
While the German critical appraisal of the Anglo-Italian accord still awaits the end of the five-day Easter recess, such comment as was available tonight was decidedly optimistic.
Seabiscuit will not remain idle until May 30 when he meets War Admiral in a $100,000 race at Belmont Park, Owner Charles S. Howard said today.

If the C. I. O. persists in its refusal to make peace with the American Federation of Labor by establishing a rival permanent national organization,' David Dubinsky will lead his 260,000 International Ladies Garment Workers out of the John L. Lewis confederation in October, he indicated here today.
Joe DiMaggio, hold-out outfielder of the Yankees, stood pat today on his demand for more than $25,000 while his club was taking an opening-day beating from the Red Sox.

Isaac I. Kashdan and Albert C. Simonson, both specialists in position play, were well matched when they met in the eleventh round of the United States chess championship tournament, the result being a draw. Kashdan made some attempt at a king's side attack, but had to abandon it. A dominating factor was Simonson's strongly posted knight in the center of the board.

The only one of the four leaders to finish his game in last night's session of four hours, Samuel Reshevsky, chess champion of the United States, went into the lead by defeating A. E. Santasiere, former New York State champion, in the thirteenth round of the National Chess Federation tournament in the Assembly Hall of the R. C. A. Building, Rockefeller Center.

Memories of Mark Twain were revived yesterday by the announcement that the four-story dwelling at 14 West Tenth Street had passed into new ownership after having been held by the Farr family for twenty years.

Tearfully and hesitatingly, but without a trace of bitterness in her voice, the mother of Jackie Coogan told today why her son had not shared in the millions he earned. There are two reasons why the "Kid" of silent movie fame has not come into any of the estimated $4,000,000 he amassed, Mrs. Lillian Coogan Bernstein testified in a deposition hearing preparatory to trial of her son's suit for an accounting.
T. Claude Ryan, president of the Ryan Aeronautical Company, announced today the closing of a contract with the government of Honduras for an undisclosed number of military planes.

Formation of Standard Marketing Company, Inc., marketing and merchandising representatives with temporary offices at 26 Broadway, was announced yesterday by A. S. Pawling, president, general manager and director of the new company. Mr. Pawling was formerly
A strike called by the C. I. O. United Automobile Workers of America curtailed activities today at the Wilmington assembly plant of the Ford Motor Company. The plant employs about 660 men.
By BRYAN FEILD

Chinese troops in Shansi Province have taken advantage of the removal of Japanese troops from that province for service in South Shantung and in a series of counter-attacks have recaptured many cities in Western and Northern Shansicities that had been occupied by the Japanese for many weeks.

The in Treasury's issue of ninety-one-day bills brought an average price today of 99.985, or 0.061 per cent, com pared with 99.963, or 0.146 per cent, a week ago, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight.

It's the cold truth that J. D. Bartlett, who opened his home at Ventnor today after an absence of several weeks, can't figure out how his refrigerator happened to become the home of a mother cat and six kittens less than a week old.

Nearly 5,000 men and women employes of General Motors were thrown out of work today when pickets of the United Automobile Workers of America forced the Fisher Body No. 1 plant to close and halted operations of the assembly line at the Buick Motor Company.

Expansion and advancement of the Y. W. C. A. of the City of New York during 1937 extended to practically all departments, reports presented yesterday at the annual meeting of the association showed, the figures as of Jan. 1, 1938, revealing a balance in income over expenditures of $10,233.
Chart well," Winston Churchill's magnificent country place in Kent, has been withdrawn from the market less than three weeks after he announced that he was "prepared to consider" its sale.

Eight Brooklyn lathing contractors who recently pleaded guilty to violating the State Workmen's Compensation Law as part of an alleged city-wide compensation insurance fraud said to have cost the State Insurance Fund and private insurance companies about $1,000,000 annually, were sentenced to pay fines yesterday in Special Sessions Court, Brooklyn.

Loans and discounts of the 13,795 insured commercial banks throughout the country amounted to $16,717,467,000 on Dec. 31, an increase of $777,745,000, or 5 per cent, over the aggregate a year earlier, while deposits declined to $47,191,415,000 from $49,257,984,000 on Dec. 31, 1936, according to a survey made public today by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

Young Dirck Roosevelt and his companion, Henry W. Distler, who gave their families and school authorities fifteen hours of anxiety when they ran away from Groton School Friday night, will be kept on the anxious seat "for a while" before it is decided whether they will be permitted' to return to their classes, Dr. Endicott Peabody, Groton rector, said tonight.
Republicans have not yet learned "how to operate an opposition party," in the opinion of William Allen White, veteran Kansas Republican and editor of The Emporia Gazette.. This the party must learn,

Officials of Greater New York and the 1939 World's Fair Commission joined today in urging the Board of Army Engineers to approve an expansion of a program enlarging Flushing Bay Channel at an additional cost of $411,000.

The fiscalagency contract for the $85,000,000 issue of Treasury bonds to meet the island republic's defaulted public works obligations,-was affirmed today by the Cuban Government and the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York.

Jockey Charles Kurtsinger, scheduled to ride Menow in the Kentucky Derby May 7 and War Admiral in the $100,000 match race against Seabiscuit May 30, has been indefinitely suspended for disobedience, it became known yesterday.

A sample of the amount of effort required to fulfill all the functions of an organization such as the United States Golf Association is gained from the list of subcommittees of the executive group as announced yesterday by A. M. Reid, president of the body which controls golf in America.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange here moved upward again yesterday and ended with net gains of 4 to 8 points. Active mill price-fixing and

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Spiers Walker have sent out invitations for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Kilborn Walker, to Franklin Eberly Newbery, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Newbery. The wedding will take place on May 7 in St. John's Episcopal Church. A reception will be held at the Walker home.
Harold Bower was elected a director to fill a vacancy on the board of the Graham-Paige Motors Corporation at the annual stockholders' meeting yesterday.

The late Oscar W. Underwood always compared to a poker game a conference over disputed legislation between members of the Senate and the House. He said that a good bluffer was usually a successful conferee. In his day these

Tonight at the Artists Housing Exhibition, in La Maison Francaise, Rockefeller Center, the National Public Housing Conference will offer a special program, consisting of an exhibition of the London County Council's housing film and addresses by Louis H. Pink and Alfred Rheinstein.

Henry Wynell, oldest member of the Queens County Democratic Committee, whose career included piano playing in old-time Bowery beer gardens, trouping with Shakespearean road companies and custodian of City Hall, died at his home, 33-22 Twenty-eighth Street, Astoria, yesterday morning.

Two Libyan- women and a child were killed last night when a plane in which four Italians were trying for a new London-Cape. Town record crashed into a military encampment at Zuara, on the coast west of Tripoli.

The irrigation ditch was full of this year's crop of frogs. As you splashed forward they scattered, jumping wildly. A line of boys lay behind a railroad track, each having dug himself a little shelter in the gravel below the rails, and their bayonets pointed above the shiny rails that would be rusty soon. On all their faces was the look of men-boys become men in one afternoon-who are awaiting combat.
Although general business activity continues low as compared with the volume of trading a year ago, real estate sales for the country as a whole appear to be holding near the level of last Spring.
The Legis lature reconvened tonight after a three-week recess and then adjourned until next Monday without furthering action on any of the more important pending bills.

The Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act, passed by the Legislature to compel retailers to adhere to list prices fixed by manufacturers, has collapsed in the radio industry and dealers are entitled to sell radios at any prices they desire, Supreme Court Justice Mortimer B. Patterson ruled here today.
Jobs rivaled judicial interpretations in interest pr as the Constitutional Convention got down to business this evening.

The first one-man show of paintings by Jonas Lie since 1934 (when he exhibited at the Macbeth) will open with an invitation preview this afternoon at -the Gran Central (Fifth Avenue) Galleries: Mr. Lie for many years. has. figured prominently in the Ne York art world.

The quality of true sportsmanship is unlike Shakespeare's "mercy." It often is "strained" to the utmost, as the members of several rod and gun clubs in a certain section of New Jersey have fittingly illustrated.

Miss Elise L. Grace was married this afternoon at The Crossroads, the Summer home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Russell Grace, to Augustus Silliman Blagden Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Blagden of Ambler, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas J. Delehanty of the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue, New York.

The Armstrong Cork Company of Lancaster, Pa., has completed negotiations for the purchase of the three glass plants of the Whitall Tatum Company and 'will take over the properties on June 20, according to H. W. Prentis, president of the Pennsylvania concern. The purchase price was not disclosed.

While retail sales gained -5 per cent and profits declined about 14 per cent last year, the showing thus far this year, with the Easter milestone now passed, has been on the basis of a 10 per cent drop in sales and about a 20-25 per cent drop in profits from the 1937 levels, according to estimates here yesterday.

The campaign of the Greater New York Fund to raise $10,000,000 to supplement the finances of private health and welfare services in the five boroughs of the city will be started on May 2 at a dinner to be held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, it was announced last night.

Discovery proceedings in which Mrs. Myrtle B. Cassino, widow of Anthony Cassino, is seeking to recover assets of her husband's estate were dismissed yesterday by Surrogate James A. Foley. Mr. Cassino died on Feb. 9, 1936.

The continued buoyancy in the market for United States Government securities featured yesterday's otherwise dull and routine trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange, as well as over-the-counter dealings. Under persistent accumulation by banking and other of

2d Lt. Henry P. Luna, Air-Res., care Amerlean Airlines, Newark Airport, Newark, N. J., 302d Observation Squadron, is ordered to active duty, effective April 24, at Mitchel Field, L. I., N. Y. Date of rank, Aug. 28, 1937. He will be relieved

The New York Drama Critics Circle, the association of newspaper and magazine play reviewers, designated John Steinbeck's "Of Mice and Men" yesterday as the best American play of the current season. At the same time Paul Vincent Carroll's "Shadow and Substance" won a citation as the best theatrical importation of the year. Both plays are running .on Broadway.
THE CIRCLE, a comedy in three acts, by W. Somerset Maugham. Staged by Bretaigne Winduet; revived by William A. Brady. At The Playhouse.

The super-yacht Savarona, which is about to leave here to become the gift from the -Turkish people to their President, Kemal Ataturk, nearly created an international incident involving Germany, Turkey and the United States. The Germans are annoyed at the American Maritime Commission and the Turks at the Germans, whom they accuse of trying to squeeze them.

The Order of the White Lion, the highest decoration awarded to foreigners by Czechoslovakia, was presented to George Boochever, chairman of the board of the American Czechoslovak Chamber of Commerce and international lawyer, at a private ceremony last evening at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lewis Gillespie of this city arid Newport have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis I. R. Gillespie, to Alan T. Schumacher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Schu-, macher of 1,148 Fifth Avenue.

An order to cease and desist from certain unfair methods of competition has been entered against Dermay Perfumers, Inc., 347 Fifth Avenue, New York, by the Federal Trade Commission, the commission announced today.

In a telegram to . Attorney General Margiotti, Mayor Wilson called tonight for an investigation to determine whether or not Governor Earle had received from Matthew H. McCloskey Jr., co-leader of the Philadelphia Democratic organization, 'the sum of $30,000."

Pre-Easter Trade Reported Good With retail trade generally good last week in those sections in which mild weather prevailed, a fair amount of fill-in business was placed in the local apparel markets yesterday, manufacturers and resident offices reported. Men's, women's and children's Poods moved
A woman contributed to the most impressive Easter gift of the season. This would be the treaty of friendship between Great Britain and Italy.

The New York State Automobile Association renewed today its drive to get a constitutional ban on diversion of gasoline tax revenues from highway purposes, and replied to Governor Lehman's declaration that "the problem of. highway
Superior Court Justice Albert Believeau granted a divorce today to Helen Caldwell of Mount Vernon, Me., from her author-husband, Erskine Caldwell.

Vice Admiral Sidney J. Meyrick, Commander-in-Chief of the America and West Indies Squadron of the British Navy, ran in hot pursuit of a runaway horse drawing a carriage bearing his wife today, but the vehicle was stopped only when it crashed into a wall. Mrs. Meyrick was not, hurt.

The marriage of Mrs. Marjorie Hughes Walsh, daughter of Mrs. Grenville Parker of New York, and of the late Thomas P. Hughes, to Sherman Ewing, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ewing, also of New York, took place here at noon today in the Smithfield Church. The ceremony was performed in the presence of relatives by the Rev. Arthur James.
Senator Holt declared in a radio address tonight that "government-inspired propaganda is growing at lightning speed."

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of an issue of $4,000,000 of notes of the city of Boston, Mass., at 0.90 per cent, plus a premium of $135. The notes will be dated April 21 and will be due on April 12, 1939.

New York City has never had a Community Chest. Perhaps it will have one some day. There would be many advantages, both tangible and intangible, in a united front against those social and economic problems with which only private charity can deal.

Operators of part of the 4,000 taxicabs of which the drivers were locked out March 6 after a controversy with the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. 0. affiliate, have reorganized, and their equipment will be returned to operation today on an open-shop basis, it was announced last night.

United action by dress manufturers and the dress labor unions to counteract, the trend toward "informality" in dress, as reflected in the popularity of housecoats, slacks, playsuits, culottes and similar garments, was urged in a statement issued yesterday by Mortimer Lanzit, executive director of the National Dress Manufacturers Association. DANA AND THE SUN, by Candace Stone. (Dodd, Mead, $3.50.) A study of the newspaper's editorial policy under the editorship of Charles A. Dana.. EUROPEAN SUMMER,, by Emma Gelders Sterne. (Dodd, Mead, $2.50.) The story of a European tour made by the author and four college girls.

Johnny Appleseed, born John Chapman, is one of those original, queer and lovable pioneer Americans that fancy is fond of dwelling on. Brave and humorous, missionary and mystic, traveling .Heaven knows

Reports of a rift in the Netherlands royal family were revived tonight as Prince Bernhard headed for home after a holiday in Southern Europe, without his wife, Crown Princess Juliana. Official sources in The Netherlands declined to comment on the reports.
Business declines in the hotel business this year are much smaller than those reported in many other industries, Horwath Horwath, hotel accountants, reported yesterday. Except in this city,
Dr. James V. Clarken, specialist in eye, ear and throat diseases and also for years active in Catholic charities, died yesterday at his home in Homeland at the age of 51.

A motion asking Congress to send a message to President Lazaro Cardenas of Mexico congratulating him on the expropriation of British and American oil companies was presented to the House of Representatives today.
The purchase of the Eastern Air Lines properties from North American Aviation, Inc., for $3,500,000 by a group which includes Harold S. Vanderbilt was announced yesterday.

The Postoffice Department today set May 5 for mailing "first day covers" with the new 1 1/2-cent Martha Washington postage stamp. This stamp will be brown, and will conform in size and design to -the recent 1-cent George Washington

Representatives of the SalemCrescent A. C. of Harlem captured the Metropolitan A. A. U. senior team championship for the tenth successive year as they scored 33 points in the annual tournament last- night at the New York A. C.

A sharp drop in traffic fatalities was shown yesterday in the weekly report of the Safety Bureau of: the Police Department, comparing accidents, deaths and injuries with those of the corresponding period last year. For the week the figures read:

It may be significant that, for at least a brief moment yesterday, President Roosevelt had the united approval of the politicians, the legislators, the citizens and taxpayers of this country in the action he was taking. He was throwing out the first ball for the opening game in Washington between the Senators and the Philadelphia Athletics. It was the official start

William P. Taulbee, 30 years old, was killed instantly last night when a private plane he was piloting crashed at Vicosa, in the State of Minas Geraes, where he had gone to attend the opening of an airport.

Two men leaped from the New Jersey end of the George Washington Bridge within an hour this morning. The body of the first suicide was not recovered. Shad fishermen saw him jump about 7 A. M. The tide was swift and all they could retrieve was his gray fedora hat.
Sale of electrical goods during February declined 26 per cent from February, 1937, according to reports from 316 wholesalers on which the Department of Commerce issued a statement today.
The Bureau of -Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 15: COMMANDERS Paddock, It. E., the Lamson, to Georgia School of Technology, Atlanta, Ga., June 18.

Amid a modified manifestation of the customary pomp and enthusiasm, the Yankees pried the lid off the 1938 American League baseball season at Fenway Park today and, with amazing early speed, immediately went in a direction opposite to a third straight pennant which has been so generously predicted for them.

State, navy and insular affairs officials conferred with President Roosevelt today on the question of sovereignty of several small islands in the Pacific Ocean, including Canton and Enderbury, recently claimed by the United States.

Judge Albert L. Reeves closed a record day in the series of Federal vote fraud trials here today with a suggestion that "other conspirators" step down "from their high places" and confess "that they conceived, that they planned these atrocious crimes."
The eighteen private utilities which joined in litigation against the Tennessee Valley Authority, appealed to the Supreme Court today to halt the regional planning and public power development.

The Treasury was quick to benefit by the Administration's latest manoeuvres in fostering an easymoney policy by reducing memberbank reserve requirements, as reflected in the sale yesterday of $100,000,000 of 91-day bills.
General Hospital here on Saturday it the age of 60, the War Departnent announced today.
The Seamen's Church Institute of New York provided lodging for more than 200,000 seamen actively engaged in the seafaring trade in 1937, according to the 103d annual report, published yesterday.

Miss Elizabeth Dorothy Sullivan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Sullivan of Douglaston, Queens, was married to William Beasley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Beasley of Manhasset, L. I., yesterday afternoon in St. Anastasia's Church, Douglaston. The Rev. John A. Bohag officiated.
President Manuel L.. Quezon has proposed to the Philippine National Assembly the overhauling of the country's system of public education.

The withdrawal of European "hot money" from this market, which was set in motion last week by the announcement of the government's new spending and creditexpansion program, continued yesterday to depress the dollar.

One of the strongest fields in the ten-year history of the event, headed by Oswald Jacoby's defending Four Aces, began qualifying play last night in the National Knockout Team-of-Four Contract Bridge Championships for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup at the Hotel Ambassador.

Rumors that Prince Fumimaro Konoye was contemplating resigning as Premier were dispelled today by a statement declaring his intention of resuming active duties on Friday. He has been mildly ill since April 2 with influenza and tonsilitis and, while refraining...

The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, a C. I. O. affiliate, announced yesterday that it had filed charges of unfair labor practices with the Labor Relations Board against Moore McCormack, Inc.,

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today she approved of the "Birth of a Baby" pictures in Life Magazine and hoped to see soon the movie from which the pictures were taken.The magazine published the pictures in its issue of April 8. In some boroughs of New York City and elsewhere copies of the issue were ordered seized on the grounds they violated statutes against sale of obscene literature and pictures.
Bertram M. Aufsesser of Albany, New York regional chairman of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, announced yesterday that the region had been
William Empson, one of the younger English critics. associated with the Auden-Spender group, has written a book called "English Pastoral Poetry," to be published Saturday by Norton.

The House approved and sent to the White House today legislation to build a regular army reserve of about 75,000 men in four years. The measure is part of the Administration's national defense program.

Ninth annual convention, Greater New York Safety Counoil, will begin at the Hotel Astor this morning at 10 o'clock and, continue tomorrow and Thursday. Morning and afternoon sessions. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Color in Dress," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.;

Shareholders of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey were informed at their annual meeting yesterday at Newark that the common stock dividend would be reduced from the present $2.60 annual rate to between $2 and $2.40.

Jose Bergamin, editor of the Madrid publication Cruz y Raya, was quoted in a Washington dispatch published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on April 12 as having said that Dr. Anselmo Polanco Fonseco, Bishop of Teruel, who was rescued from prison by the capture of that city, had "sought asylum with the Loyalists when the city was again lost."

Two mortgages held by the Bowery Savings Bank from the 1,021 Park Avenue Corp, J. Frederick Eagle, pres. have been consolidated as a single first lien for $1,000,000 on the 14-story apartment on the northeast corner of Park Ave and 85th St and extended to May 1, 1943, at 4 per cent, to be amortized $5,000 on next Aug 1 and d; $5,000 quarterly beginning Aug 1, 1939.

Of the machine tools purchased by industry in the last two years, about 60 per cent were for expansion, and the other 40 per cent for replacement of old machines, according to a survey on the obsolescence of machine tools conducted by Warner Swasey Company, Cleveland, results of which were issued yesterday.

President Roosevelt stood erect in a lower stand box at Griffith Stadium today and, while thousands of fans shouted wildly, flipped a brand-new baseball to mark the opening of the 1938 American League season.

Herbert Morrison, Laborite member of the British Parliament and chairman of the London City Council, told 2,500 members of the American Labor party at Mecca Temple last night that the newly awakened social consciousness of America still lags far behind that of even the British Conservative party.
