The G. Heileman Brewing Company declared a dividend of 25 cents a share. This is the same amount the company was paying each quarter until Feb. 15, 1938, when the payment was omitted.

A bullet missing for thirty-three years was displayed proudly today by James Sutton, retired keeper at the Passaic County jail, with the explanation that it finally was found because he got a pain in the chest.
Speakers called on Daughters of the American Revolution today to defend democracy through an improved civil service, a corrected

Approval of an employes' benefit plan that has been in operation since Sept. 1 will be asked of shareholders of the Amerada Corporation at their meeting here on May 2. Under the scheme, employes are al, lowed to contribute 2 to 12 per cent of their, salaries. according to

A spokesman of the German Embassy said tonight that registration of former Austrian citizens living in England is progressing "satisfactorily" and predicted that all who are required to do so would comply with the regulations.
Otken Holding Company, Charles F. Otken, president, sold to the Kearny Housing Corporation the three flats at 115-19 Magnolia Ave nue, Jersey City.

President Roosevelt has taken under personal advisement the question whether helium may be exported to Germany, a problem which has caused a rift between the State Department and the Department of the Interior.

Miss Jessie Byrnes Clark, a granddaughter of the late Inspector Thomas Byrnes, for many years Superintendent of Police of this city, and a great-great-granddaughter of Jacob A. Westervelt, Mayor of New York from 1853 to 1855, was married at noon yesterday

Postmaster General Farley was under fire over postage stamps again today, this time when Ely Jacques Kahn of New York, chairman of the Committee on Allied Arts of the American Institute of Architects, declared the designs on new stamps were so, inartistic that it argued against the establishment of a Federal Departmnent of Fine Arts.

Five American six-meter yachts and one Bermudian craft sailed a tune-up race today preliminary to the Prince of Wales Trophy series, which begins Wednesday. Briggs Cunningham of the United States, sailing in Fun, triumphed over the 1937 Prince of Wales cup champion yacht Lulu, sailed by her designer, Olin Stephens of the United States. The margin was 1 minute 32 seconds.

Senator Robert F. Wagner, assuming his role of leader of the Democratic minority when the Constitutional Convention reassembled here tonight after a recess of two weeks, warned that the convention-would have to go beyond a mere affirmation

Spokesmen for foreign trade interests of the port district here urged fast and frequent service to foreign ports and freight rate schedules low enough to meet for-eign competition at the opening yesterday morning of a two-day hearing before the Maritime Commission.
Automobile production increased less than seasonally last week and the adjusted index eased to 52.3, compared with 52.7 in the previous week and 105.7 in the week ended April 17, 1937.

Councilman James A. Burke of Queens, whose designation as vice chairman of the Council by the coalitionists was upset last week by an Appellate Division decision naming John Cashmore as vice chairman, said last night that he would take an appeal to the Court of Appeals.

Declines in dollar volume in grocery retailing ranged from 5 to 10 per cent last week compared with the corresponding week a year ago, the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc., reported yesterday. The sharpest declines were in the large cities where intense price competition has served to cut down retail sales.

General Sessions Judge Wallace reserved decision yesterday until Monday on memoranda from lawyers for five groups suggesting dismissal of the indictment charging Robert Edward Edmondson, elderly pamphleteer, with criminally libeling Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor; Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard, and the Jewish religion in his publication.

Negotiations begun last May in Hollywood by Alexander Korda and Samuel Goldwyn to obtain control of the United Artists Corporation from Mary Pickford, Douglas Fairbanks and Charlie Chaplin were successfully closed last week in London, it was learned here yesterday. The meetings at which details

A report went yesterday that Dwight Deere Wiman'st "I Married an Angel" might come to town the week of May 9, taking up residence at the Shubert or Imperial Theatre-all depending on how the show looks in Boston, where it opens tonight for an engagement ending April 30, and in Philadelphia, where it will spend a week beginning May 2.

Frederick D. Foote has resigned from the United States Steel Corporation and has become president of the Alloys Development Corporation of New York, in which he will be associated with Beram D. Saklatwalla. The new company is a successor to the United States Rustless Steel and Iron Corporation.

Housing, a subject not mentioned in the Constitution of 1894, under which the State is operating, came to the fore tonight in the 1938 Constitutional Convention as Republicans, Democrats and American Labor party leaders submitted programs.

Numerous national advertisers in the men's wear field will either run special advertising campaigns for Father's Day, June 19, or mention the event in their current copy. These ads will be part of the widespread campaign - in which manufacturers and retailers are joining to make celebration of the day a profitable one for the industry.
The War Department released the following orders to-day, dated April 16: MAJOR GENERAL Sunderland, A. H., Chief of Coast Artillery, two days leave, April 19.
Dr. G. Edward Roehrig, widely known in medical circles here, died yesterday after four months' illness. His age was 73.

Johnny Faunce of California upset George Lott of Boston today in the second round of the $1,000 North and South professional tennis tournament. The scores were 2--6, 2-6, 8-6, 6-1, 6-0. Faunce appeared to gain confidence as the match progressed.

While conceding that pre-Easter business last week exceeded expectations in many sections of the country, retail store buyers and dry goods wholesalers indicated yesterday that they would continue to operate cautiously for the time being. In some instances, they said,

A profit of $2,048,000 for the first quarter of 1938, compared with $1,993,000 for the first three months of 1937, is reported by the Atlantic Refining Company and subsidiary companies. Both figures are after interest, depreciation, taxes and other charges. No provision has been made for any surtax on undistributed earnings.

There can be no general agreement as to the exact speed at which an automobile becomes a menace. As the traffic experts tell us, twenty miles an hour may be too fast under some circumstances and sixty miles perfectly safe under other circumstances. It is probably more important to enforce such speed restrictions as we have than to make new ones.
Work on the two new floors to be added to the present twelve-story building housing Bonwit Teller Co. at 721 Fifth Avenue and 1-5 East Fifty-sixth Street will begin May 1, Mrs. Hortense M. Odlum.

A military court today sentenced sixteen persons of whom four were Italians to various prison sentences - and fines for having participated in the April 9 riots. After the riots in which a number of civilians and one French gendarme were killed, a state of siege had to be declared.

A regular television schedule of five hours a week, for at least a month, begins today under the auspices of the National Broadcasting Company. Programs from Radio City will be telecast from aerials atop the Empire State Building, and are expected to cover a radius of aboutt fifty miles.

A brief opposing the petition of Ernest Ballard of Chicago for an additional $25,000 for drafting and presenting a reorganization plan for the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway Company was filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission by Donald Gallagher, one of the attorneys of the Consumers Counseel, National Bituminous Coal Commission.
The Paterson Clearing House Association announced today that- its eleven member banks would reduce interest on savings accounts from 2 to 11/2 per cent on June 1.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are April 18 unless specified: At Navy Yard, Mare Island: Bridge, Sirius. Chaumont, San Francisco to San Pedro. Dallas, at San Diego. Guam, at Wuhu. April 17. Herbert, at New London, April 17. Kanawha, at San Pedro.

The Cardinals will start the 1938 National League season at Sportsman's Park tomorrow against the Pirates. Club officials say the trade of Dizzy Dean to the Cubs had no effect on opening day ticket sales and that a crowd of 20,000 is expected. Bob Weiland; St. Louis,

ON the word of Edward Aloysiun McGonigle Brannick, secretary of the Giants, everything has been arranged for the baseball opening at the Polo Grounds today except the weather. A brass band, of course. And a parade.

A bit of earth brought from the banks of the Volga River was taken from a silver container and thrown on Feodor Chaliapin's simple oak coffin as it was lowered into a grave in Batignolles Cemetery today. Thousands of persons representing all walks of life stood silently in the chilly April wind as the "greatest of Volga boatmen" was lowered into the grave.

A blanket denial that any tie-up. between the Intercollegiate Fencing Association and the Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Atlletics would result- in the "freezing out" of N. Y. U., C. C. N. Y. or any other colleges was made yesterday by Asa S. Bushnell, executive-director of the Central Office.

Woodruff Randolph, secretarytreasurer of the International Typographical Union, announced today results of the recent referendum vote by the membership on five points of "basic policy." Four dealt with the union's connection with the American Federation of, Labor.

The directors of the Dunbar National Bank adopted yesterday a resolution for the liquidation of the bank, according to an announcement issued last night. A meeting of stockholders has been called for May 23 to ratify the decision.

While balanced precariously on a narrow girder in the elevator shaft on the tenth floor of the Hotel Cardinal, .243 West End Avenue, Dr. David Wasserman of City Hospital yesterday amputated the right leg of a handyman caught in the cable drum of the service elevator.

Jacob (Gurrah Jake) Shapiro, reputed head of the former garment and bakery rackets, was unable to appear yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora to answer indictments obtained by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey when he was special prosecutor. Shapiro had no clothes; his only suit was being fumigated at the Federal House of Detention, where he surrendered last week.

A new drive, reputedly Administration supported, to substitute a "quarantine" of treaty-violating nations through an unofficial boycott for the present Neutrality Act's "hands off" policy was started today by Representative Scott, Democrat, of California.
Henry Sohn, 67 years old, of 560 Monroe Avenue, this city, was injured fatally here today when his automobile collided with a dirt truck. He was hurled through the windshield.

Paintings and water-colors by members of the music and art department of the Brooklyn Women's Club predominated in the organization's annual "Hobby Day" exhibit yesterday in the clubhouse at 114 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn. Collections of oriental jade and wood carving were also on view in the exhibit, which included two specimens of needlecraft.

Miss Elizabeth Binney Roper, daughter of Mrs. William Winston Roper of Chestnut Hill and the late Mr. Roper, wax married this afternoon to William Edgar Parker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar F. H. Parker of Montreal. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles E. Eder in Grace Church, Mount Airy.

The Silver Cross Day Nursery will be the beneficiary of a Spring card party April 28 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. In conjunction with the benefit there will be a sale of useful and decorative articles and candy.

The H. J. Heinz Company today had filed an appeal from the National Labor Relations Board decision orduring the company to bargain collectively with the Canning and Pickle Workers Union Local 325, American Federation of Labor.

It would not be too much to say that the whole present situation in Washington is summed up in two committee rooms. In one of these rooms drafts are being prepared of a new spending program which would throw more borrowed billions into the scale in an effort to stimulate the recovery of business.

Paul V. McNutt, High Commissioner to the Philippines, who has been mentioned as a possible Presidential candidate in 1940, wants Congress to keep funds available to bring him and his family home if he should resign.

With traditional ceremonies which date back to the Revolutionary period, about 400 representatives of New York's oldest families gathered--at the Hotel Plaza last night to mark the 103d annual celebration of the St. Nicholas Society's Paas Festival. The society was founded by Washington Irving.

Hilton Ave (15-4062), s w cor of Deane Pl, 100x38; Shelton Holding Corp to Alice M. O'Donnell, 2,544 Lurting Ave. 217th St (16-4699), s s, 250 ft e of 6th Ave, 75x109; Seymour Mork, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp.

Homeward-bound office workers were drenched by a series of. April downpours. resembling cloudbursts between 4:15 and 6 P. M. yesterday. Umbrellas bloomed in the darkened streets and thousands sought refuge in doorways as the fury of the storm broke.

With timely hitting by Bill Conlon featuring its attack, the St. John's University baseball team gained its fourth victory in five starts this season, by conquering the Dartmouth College nine, 8 to 1, in an abbreviated contest at Dexter Park yesterday.
Francis Vaux Wilson, illustrator and artist, died yesterday at his home in the Cadwallader Apartments here after a long illness. His age was 63.

A small group of tennis enthusiasts, including a number of representatives of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, gathered at the Sutton Place Tennis Club, East River and Fifty-fifth Street, yesterday, for the first scheduled practice session of Mrs. Helen Wills Moody preparatory to her departure for England tomorrow.

The Niagara Share Corporation and subsidiaries report net assets on March 31 equal to $2,353.01 for each $1,000 of debenture, to $506.03 for each share of Class A preferred and to $8.30 for each Class B common share. This compares with
Sir Stephen Killick, who, like the fabled Dick Whittington, rose from poor boy to be Lord Mayor of London, died at his home in London today at the age of 77.

The three gunmen who attempted to hold up the Howdy Club, 47 West Third Street, a week ago, and were shot down by policemen, were indicted on charges of first-degree murder yesterday for the death of Patrolman Humbert Moruzzi.

The adjutant general released the following orders today: These officers, having qualified, are placed on duty. They are to report to the commanding officer, 245th C. A., for assignment: Coleman, Capt. Frank Leroy, to Battery H. Heesch, 1st Lt. Walter A.. to Battery L.

Alfred Garner Camwell, 45 years old, former customers' man in Wall Street of 16 Norden Street, Dongan Hills, S. I., and his wife Anna, 43, ended their lives in a suicide pact in their home yesterday, according to the police.

By a swift dash past mountains the Spanish Insurgents reached the outskirts of Tortosa, but destruction of bridges across the Ebro River and strong defenses halted them. A correspondent found the Loyalists had retreated in good order from a dangerous salient.

Turpentine firm, 23 1/2c; sales, 143 barrels; receipts, 272 barrels; shipments, 131 barrels; stock, 29,-300 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 441; receipts, 1,570; shipments, 1,250; stock, 76,439. Quote: B, $3.50; D, E, $3.70; F, G, H, I., $4.52 1/2-$4.60; K, $4.60; M, $4.70; N, $5.10; WG, $5.90-$6; WW, X, $6.50. 0.

Operations in the steel industry for the week beginning yesterday are scheduled at 32.4 per cent of capacity, according to telegraphic advices received by the American Iron and Steel Institute. This represents a decrease of 0.3 point, or 0.9 per cent, from the preceding week, when the rate was 32.7 per BOND ISSUES cent.

Settlement of the $2,000,000 suit brought by Carl W. Hamilton, art collector, against Lord Joseph Duveen of Milbank, internationally known art expert and others, was urged yesterday in Supreme Court by Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo. To give counsel an opportunity to seek a compromise the trial was adjourned yesterday until Oct. 3.
Surgeon Vice Admiral Sir Robert Hill, principal medical officer of the grand fleet during the World War, died today at his home at Henley. His age was 72.

With four clubs already away from the barrier, major league baseball moves into high gear today with the four remaining entries in the American League and the entire National League field swinging into action.
Representative Nichols, Democrat of Oklahoma, announced today that he was drafting legislation to extend the principles of the Federal Housing--Act to the farm tenant problem.

With more than eighty manufacturers exhibiting apparatus to promote safety and with about 8,000 delegates expected for its three-day sessions, the ninth annual convention of the. Greater. New York Safety Council will get under way at the Hotel Astor this morning.
The Rev. Charles Luke Wells, dean of the theological school and Professor of Ecclesiastical History at the University of the South, Sewanee, died here today at the age of 79.

Huntington House, owned and maintained at 94 Fifth Avenue by Grace. Episcopal Church, will benefit by a dinner dance which will mark the opening of the Garden of the Ambassador on May 3. A part of the proceeds will augment a fund which provides attractive housing facilities for young girls at minimum rates.

More than a score of maritime workers were injured today in a waterfront battle involving 1,000 C. I. O. longshoremen and members of the independent Sailors Union of the Pacific. Fist fights broke out when a battle of words over a loudspeaker system failed to adjust a jurisdictional dispute involving the Shepard Line freighter Sea Thrush.

Wayne University's team took a lead of 21/2 to 11/2 over Brooklyn College, with one match adjourned, in the first of a series of three contests at the Marshall Chess Club last night. Wayne's victors were

ALTHER--At Yonkers, N. Y., on April 18, 1938, Annie, beloved mother of Philip F., Charles W. and Clarence A. Alther. Services at the Burr Davis Mortuary, 15 Fourth Ave., Mount Vernon, N. Y., on Thursday, 2 P. M.
Sol C. Eppenstein, former president of the Illinois Watch Case Company of Elgin, Ill., died Saturday in Los Angeles at the age of 74.

Some new stories of the stage were added to the living legend of Daniel Frohman by friends of the 86-year-old producer who gathered around him yesterday at the invitation of the Daughters of Ohio in New York.
The Interior Department is going to give Ned Hillyard, 100-year-old Negro, his chance to make good and play his part in the winning of the West.
The exhibition of paintings by B. J. O. Nordfeldt at the Lilienfeld Galleries has been extended through April 23.

The whole blockfront on the east side of Church Street, between Murray and Warren Streets, consisting of a five-story loft and store building, known as 125 Church Street, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. It was bought in by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as plaintiff for $95.000.

The $49.000 mortgage covering the property at 785 E Tremont Ave, Bronx, has been extended for five years at 5 per cent. Nehring Brothers, Inc, brokers, negotiated the extension for the Eileen Realty Corp, C. Bertram Plante, president.

Martin (Buggsy) Goldstein and his bodyguard, Seymour Magoon, Brooklyn gangsters, were sentenced yesterday to serve indeterminate terms in the New York County penitentiary for conspiring with sixteen contractors to maintain a $1,500,000 monopoly of painting...

The 1937 annual report of the Cities Service Company and subsidiaries, which is being mailed to shareholders today, shows a consolidated net income after all oper eating expenses, -taxes and prior charges, of $9,615,714, as compared with a net of $6,965,496 in 1936, an increase of $2,650,218, or approximately 38 per cent.

Miss Christine Blair Long, daughter of S. M. Breckinridge Long, former United States Ambassador to Italy, and Mrs. Long, was married to Arnold Augur Willcox of Washington this afternoon at Montpelier Manor, home of the bride's parents, near Laurel, Md., by the Rev. Dr. F. Bland Tucker, rector of St. John's Church, Georgetown.
Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe, once the fallen hero of the Tigers, is about to get his pitching job back.

Margaret Bondfield, Minister of Labor in the British Cabinet from 1929 to 1931 and the only woman to have held that position, arrived yesterday on the steamship American Trader of the United States Lines from London. She will go to Columbus, Ohio, to attend the Y. W. C. A. Conference as a delegate from England.

Sparrows and pigeons in Greenwich Village got an unexpected treat yesterday when three tons of fine canary seed were tossed into the street from a burning truck. The birds in the neighborhood were not long in finding out about the windfall.
The Treasury has abandoned its policy of "sterilizing" gold by discontinuing its inactive gold fund, Secretary Morgenthau announced this afternoon at his press conference.
Colonel John H. Read, retired regular army officer, died at Walter Reed General Hospital here yesterday, the War Department announced today. His age was 65.

The Reading Company has appropriated $1,120,000 from 1937 earnings or enough to pay full dividends in 1938 on its first preferred 4 per cent stock and $1,260,000 for payment of dividends on its second preferred 4 per cent stock, for which the annual requirement is $1,680,000, Edward W. Scheer, president, said in his annual report yesterday.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 13: Decreases of $27,000,000

The National Brotherhood Council of the Confessional Synod reported today that ten Protestant pastors were imprisoned, seventy-one expelled from their pulpits by the State, through Church Minister Hanns Kerrl, ninety forbidden to preach by the police and thirty-four confined to their residences by police ordinance.

Miss Ruth Caroline Margrett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Arthur Margrett of this place, was married tonight to Stewart Thames, son of Mrs. G. B. Thames of Mobile, Ala., and the late Mr. Thames. The ceremony, which was performed in St. James Episcopal Church here by the acting rector, the Rev. Clifford R. Stanley, was followed by a reception at the Montclair Athletic Club.

A reflection of the business recession was seen yesterday in vocational school attendance figures for the first half of the Spring term. Morris E. Siegel, director of evening and continuation schools of the Board of Education, announced that

The Rev. Dr. John Krantz, dean of the Newark conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, who had not missed a conference meeting in sixty years, died here tonight at his home, 657 East Twenty-sixth Street, from the effects of a stroke suffered on April 7. He was 85 years old.

Word has been received by relatives here of the marriage of Miss Muriel Chase Rasmussen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Whitney Rasmussen of Westport, to Clifford Kemp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Kemp of Mount Eden, Auckland, New Zealand, which took place at noon today in the Royal Poinciana Chapel, Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Dr. William Edward Biederwolf, minister of the chapel performed the ceremony.

A new form of annual report, made to employes instead of stockholders, was issued yesterday by L. A. Downs, president of the Illinois Central Railroad. It was issued in advance of the annual statement to stockholders. The more important figures in it already had been made public by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Fat lambs closed sharply lower and hog prices were weakened at the close after a higher opening. Fed steers and yearlings sold generally steady to strong on a slow trade, with shipping demand extremely narrow, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

UNITED STATES JUNIOR AUDITOR, INCOME TAX UNIT, $2,600 a year, (Internal Revenue Agent), Bureau of Internal Revenue, Treasury Department. Optional branches. Applications must be on file not later than May 12, if received from Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming and not later than May 9 from all other States.
President Roosevelt pardoned Dr. Francis E. Townsend, old age pension advocate sentenced to thirty days in jail for contempt of a House Committee.

A lastminute pardon from President Roosevelt, delivered as the convicted man sat in the office of the United States marshal awaiting conduct to the District jail, today saved Dr. Francis E. Townsend, old-age pension leader, from a thirty-day term for contempt of a House committee investigating his organization.

Ninety-eight persons who received summonses over the week-end charging them with permitting unmuzzled dogs to roam the streets were fined from $1 to $5 yesterday by Magistrate George H. Folwell in Coney Island Court, Brooklyn.

The engagement of Miss Laura M. Walts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Conrad Walts of this place, to Daniel Pyzel 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Pyzel of New York and The Hague, has been announced by her parents.
Arthur Rothstein of 44 Arleigh Road, Great Neck, L. I., a lawyer, died yesterday morning in Mount Sinai Hospital of a kidney ailment after an illness of several weeks. He was 44 years old.

The afternoon preview music festival to be held at the site of the New York World's Fair 1939 at 3:30 o'clock Sunday, May 1, will symbolize the nations of the world as represented in America and will emphasize the great resources of the City of New York, it was announced yesterday by Grover A, Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.

Miss Eleanor R. Walsh of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married to William J. Ford, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Ford of Perth Amboy, N. J., this morning in Holy Trinity Church here by the Rev. H. J. Watterson.

Most of the persons engaged in the sale of narcotics in this country are Americans and the peddlers usually have some other connection with the criminal world, John K. Carroll, Assistant United States Attorney, told the Women's National Republican Club yesterday.

Defeated for the second time by Brentford in the Easter holiday series, Arsenal today was forced into a tie with Preston North End and the Wolverhampton Wanderers for the lead in the English Football League.
Provisional plans of the chemical industry, third largest in American manufacturing, to spend $100,000,000 to expand production plants were reported today to the American chemical Society.

Wheat prices in North American markets declined early today as the trade lost its fear of inflation and relatively little selling was needed on the Board of Trade to bring about a decline of around 1 cent a bushel from Saturday's finish.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended April 14 numbered 278, compared with 245 in the week preceding and 189 in the corresponding week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet. Inc.

A search that extended through eight States and to the high seas yielded no clue yesterday to the whereabouts of Andrew Carnegie Whitfield, 28-year-old nephew of Mrs. Andrew Carnegie, who disappeared Friday from Roosevelt Field in his silver-winged power glider.
Works Progress Administrator Harry L. Hopkins announced today that the WPA would buy 35,000,000 yards of cotton textiles for sewing-room projects.
Governor A. Harry Moore on Thursday will toss out the first ball at the opening game ceremonies for New Jersey's two International League baseball clubs, the Newark Bears and the Jersey City Giants.
Transfer To take effect 8 A. M., April 19: LIEUTENANT Michael E. J. Ledden, from 16th Division to 109th Precinct, aasignment to desk duty continued. Temporary Assigments PATROLMEN
Many of the firms listed among t the lessees of new business space in yesterday's leasing report are engaged in various branches of the fur business.

Semi-insane and semi-responsible persons are found in every walk of life "from the highest-social and political offices to the ranks of the unemployed and delinquent," Professor David Kennedy Henderson, eminent psychiatrist of the University of Edinburgh, told a gathering of physicians last night at the New York Academy. of Medicine.

A Foreign Office spokesman asserted today that Russia had detained a Japanese Army plane forced down in Suifenho, north of Vladivostok, last Monday. Nine planes had been patrolling the border and eight returned.

The Browns offered the Yankees about $150,000 for Joe DiMaggio but failed to swing the deal, it was learned tonight. Colonel Jacob Ruppert, owner of the world champions, was quoted by The Globe-Democrat as saying in a telephone conversation that his star outfielder "is not for sale at any -price."

88th St, 146 W, 18x100.81/2; Elizabeth J. Allin to Edna M. Elliott, 146 W 88th St (dower release dated Oct 28, 1936). Riverside Drive, n cor 88th St, 103.7x 122.11; Geneve Courts, Inc. Samuel Greenberg, pres. to Vanderbilt Estates, Inc, 342 Madison Ave, care D. L. Wolfson ($2.50).

SOME genius ought to write a book telling radicals and liberals not to tire so easily. The world today is full of those who are tired. Ten, fifteen, twenty years ago they were boiling with energy and whipping things up into a fine lather. Now-ten, fifteen or twenty years later-they utter groans of pain when others go through precisely the same process.
The circus went to the Museum of the City of New York last nightnot the flesh and blood circus of Madison Square Garden, but the circus as enshrined in the handbills and posters of other days.

Mrs. Charles U. Caesar of New York City has taken residence here preparatory to filing a suit for divorce. The marriage of Mr. Caesar and Miss Virginia Lansdale Gibson was in St. Bartholomew's Church Oct. 1, 1923. Mrs. George Rodney

At the moment it is impossible to say what Congress will do, if anything, regarding the urgent railway problem. No definite move in any direction has as yet been proposed in either house, in response to the definite recommendations of the three Interstate Commerce Commissioners, or the comments on them by numerous experts-all submitted to Congress last Tuesday by the President.
The Birk Brothers Brewing Company team of Chicago clinched the 1938' American Bowling Congress five-man team championship early today.

Responding to requests by the Japanese Government, the United States today forwarded an informal communication to Tokyo itemizing specifically the damages claimed for destruction of the gunboat Panay, which was sunk by Japanese bombers last Dec. 12.

President Roosevelt's pump-priming recovery program moved another step forward today when the House Appropriations Committee reported the War Department Civil Functions Bill carrying an additional $37,000,000 of Presidentially recommended funds for flood control and reclamation works.

Eddie Shore of the Boston Bruins, one of the National Hockey League's all-time stars, was named to receive the Dr. David A. Hart Trophy today as the most valuable player to his club during the 1937-38 season.

The long uninterrupted decline in 9:25 A. values of cotton textiles has been arrested and, with all bearish factors fully discounted, textile markets are ready to "quit the role of martyrdom and commence the more proper role of leadership by meeting the situation," Sidney Scheuer, head of Scheuer Co., textile brokers, said last night.

MANATTAN HORKIMER, ISAAC (Oct. 4). Estate, less than $5,000. To Frlda and Martha Horkimer, daughters, excutrices, 58 W. 72d St., residue equally. PERRY, EWARD DELAVAN (March 28). Estate, more than $10,000. To Columbia University, decedent's library, including books, pamphlets and maps, except 75 volumes to be selected and distributed according to memo left with will; Sarah F.

Miss Catherine O'Rourke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tierney A. O'Rourke of the Bronx, was married to Alexander F. Whelan of this city yesterday in the Church of the Holy Spirit, the Bronx, by the Rev. Thomas J. Keogh.

Outclassing his rival, Mike Belloise, 1311/4, Bronx, former featherweight champion of the world, conquered Young Chappie, 1341/4, Albany, in the principal bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

The four-story tenement house at 159 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, on a F. plot 40 by 100 feet, was sold to an investing client of M. MorgenthauSeixas Company, Inc., broker in the transaction. Sale was for cash

Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Steamship Owners Association, denied last night that the owners had refused to cooperate with a committee of the National Maritime Union in an effort to draft a wage agreement to govern Atlantic ship lines in American flag operation.

Howard Smith of Tracy Smith, selling agents for the Jamestown Worsted Mills, will join with F. W. Tipper in a partnership, effective May 1. The new firm will act as sales representative for a group of mills. Jamestown Worsted Mills

Sir Richard Runciman Terry, who as director of music at Westminster Cathedral, 1901-24, gave impetus to the revival of pre - Reformation polyphonic music in both Roman Catholic and Anglican Churches, died tonight at the age of 72.

Published reports that Governor Lehman and Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. had been "snubbed" by failure of the National Democratic Club to include them among the speakers at the Jefferson Day dinner at the Hotel Commodore Saturday. evening were denied yesterda by Benjamin F. Schreiber, president of the club.

Mayor John Francis Dore of Seattle died at his home here tonight after a lingering illness. His age was 56. His duties as Mayor had been performed the past week by Council President James Scavatto, whom the city council had named acting mayor.

Members of Long Island women's clubs were urged yesterday to "take action now" and ask for a hearing on a Federal bill to regulate and control firearms, which is in the hands of the House Ways and Means Committee.

Barcelona hospitals are being searched for Vernon Selby, former West Point athlete, reported wounded while fighting with the Loyalists in Spain, Owen Selby, a brother, said he had been notified by the State Department.
Varied divertissements are being planned for the Spring supper dance under the auspices of the Almoners which will take place Saturday at Sherry's, to aid the New York Foundling Hospital.

In a radio speech tonight outlining for the first time the details of the Federal Government's new business lending program, Chairman Jesse Jones of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation declared that the RFC would not compete with private lending agencies and called upon bankers to make a greater effort to meet the borrowing requirements of business.

The 1938 session of the Legislature, one of the least controversial in years, passed into history today as Governor Lehman completed action on the bills left in his hands when the Senate and Assembly adjourned a month ago.
The danger attached to a voluntary return to Germany to participate in the recent plebiscite was shown by the fate of Franz Linauer and his wife, residents of Aussig, Czechoslovakia.

William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, will appear tomorrow morning before the deadlocked conference on the 1938 revenue bill to go over with the members the amendment to the Senate Tax Bill exempting from the capital gains tax

W. McNeil Kennedy, regional director of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that he planned to start Federal prosecution this week in connection with the collapse of the Hoagland Allum Company, Inc., La Salle Street inInvestment house.

Tomorrow, when the revamped Dodgers and the Phillies start the National League season at Baker Bowl, Van Lingle Mungo, erstwhile ailing ace of Burleigh Grimes' hurling corps, will be facing pretty much of an acid test.

Stocks declined and closed moderately lower in less active trading; turnover, 857,160 shares. United States Government issues continued to advance irregularly, corporate bonds were mixed, foreign loans higher; transactions, $5,590,975.

Retired Lieutenant George Polsenakf, formerly a member of H. L. Co. 45, residing at 29 Adrian Ave., Bronx, died April 13. Retired Engineer of Steamer Casper Kraft, formerly a member of Engine Co. 252, residing at 132-09 Metropolitan Ave., Jamaica, Queens, died April 15. Funeral will take place from Funeral Parlor of George Werst, 71-41 Cooper Ave., Glendale, Queens, at 1:30 P. M., April 19. Interment at Fresh Pond

Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe, who passed the season at Cherokee Plantation, their place at Yemassee,. S. C., are in Hot Springs, Va. They will return to New York later this week before going to Planting Fields, their country home in Oyster Bay.

The annual Mother's Day luncheon, under the auspices of the Maternity Center Association, will be held April 28 at the Park Lane. Before the luncheon talks will be given by Miss Hazel Corbin, general director of the association; Dr. Howard Haggard, Professor of Physiology at Yale University, and Dr. Edwin F. Daily, director of the Maternal and Child Health Division of the Federal Children's Bureau.
The Cubs paid $185,000 in cash, second largest sum ever-- paid for a baseball star, for Jerome Herman (Dizzy) Dean.
Appointments to the thirty-four standing committees of the Constitutional Convention were announced tonight by Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane of the Court of Appeals, president of the convention.

America is facing a crucial period for the third time in its history, and on the decisions of its citizens rests the "preservation of representative democracy and of our free institutions," Colonel Theodore Roosevelt warned last night at a forum meeting of the New York Credit Men's Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The police established today that it was the intention of Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, arrested Iron Guard chief, to march on the capital on the Orthodox Easter Sunday, May 1. They discovered his plan, however, in time to take the necessary repressive measures.

Carl Helm, in 329 E 37th St; Walter Samuels, inc., broker. Frank A. Ready Jr., in 139 W 82d St; James Rosthal, in 201 W 89th St: Zeke Manners, in 25 Central Pk W: A. Goldman, in 309 W 109th St; Apartment Renting Co, Inc, broker.

The average senior in engineering at Columbia University is slightly over 23 years old, 5.83 feet tall, weighs 158.2 pounds and expects an annual salary of $3,900 in five years, according to the senior ballot of the University School of Engineering, published in the 1938

A two-year fight to establish a coordinated rail and bus service in California was won today by the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railroad in a 100-page decision handed down by the State Railroad Commission. Under the terms of the

Miss Elizabeth Roderick Cole, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martyn S. Cole of Kew Gardens, Queens, was married to Richard Este Gooch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Claiborne W. Gooch of Lynchburg, VA., yesterday afternoon in the Protestant Episcopal Church

The general level of wholesale commodity prices was higher last week, according to the index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association. This index in the week ended April 16 rose to 75.1 from 75.0 in the preceding week, which was the low point to date in the present recession.

Four members of the student council of the National Farm School disclosed tonight that they had been- expelled permanently for "disloyalty" in a strike last month opposing Dean Cletus L. Goodling. All took jobs on a near-by farm pending appeal to the trustees.

Miss Elizabeth Claire Rowe and James Edward Hosac, whose marriage will take place Friday in Westbury, L. I., were guests of honor last night at a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Rubicam in the Persian Room of the Plaza.

An agreement between seven large shipping companies and the Canadian Seamen's Union went into effect today, ending Canada's first major strike on the Great Lakes and sending what union officials said were 1,000 men back to work aboard fifty vessels.
Total short interest on the New York Stock Exchange on March 31 was 1,097,858 shares, the Exchange reported yesterday. The corresponding figure for Feb. 28 was 1,142,482 shares.

About 90 per cent of the normal trucking business of this city of 350,000 persons was halted today by a strike of truckmen. While business men drove their own trucks, and customers took home their purchases, the drivers and their employers seemed hopelessly deadlocked.

County fairs and circuses give free passes for use of poster space on barns and fences, so why shouldn't the New York World's Fair management give passes to New York State motorists, who Ma are advertising the exposition on their automobile license plates?
A telegram in which Pope Pius sent the apostolic blessing to General Francisco Franco, Spanish Insurgent leader, was published today in the Osservatore Romano, the Vatican newspaper.

The passenger list of the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, due to arrive today from Southampton via. Cherbourg, includes Sir Arthur Sutherland, Captain David C. Hanrahan and Mrs. Hanrahan, Dr. and Mrs. Friedrich Lehmann, J. E. Meyer Ranneft, Dutch naval attache at Washington, and Mrs. Ranneft, C. M. Rudell, the Hon.

Four men, who are accused of extorting $21,000 from a retired school teacher in the last ten months under the pretense that they were Federal internal revenue agents, were held in bail yesterday by Federal authorities. They are formally charged with violating the Federal impersonation statute.

Eager camera fans caused the First International Photographic Exposition to open slightly ahead of schedule yesterday afternoon. Shortly before 2 o'clock, when the first visitors were supposed to be admitted, they had massed so thickly on the sidewalks around Grand Central Palace that the police asked exposition officials to open the show to expedite traffic.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions FRANKLIN'S APPAREL, INC., retail women's wear, 225 W. 34th St., with shops or departments at 660 Penn St., Reading, Pa., 222 E. Main St., Rochester, 582 Main St., Buffalo, and 226 S. Salina St., Syracuse-Voluntary proceedings for recrganization under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Laws with debts of $34,689 and assets of $37.004.
The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at the northeast corner of Riverside Drive and Eighty-eighth Street, known as 160 Riverside Drive, has been

More than 10,000 returns were filed yesterday at the local State tax office, 80 Centre Street, by individuals who made full or partial income tax payments. Because of Good Friday and the beginning of Passover on April 15,

Following -a public hearing. in City Hall yesterday before the Rules Committee of the City Council on removal of the Fulton Street elevated in Brogklyn, the committee named a special subcommittee of nine Brooklyn Councilmen to conduct further public hearings on the matter.
Three matches wound up all even as Princeton's varsity golfers tied an undefeated Virginia outfit, 41/241/2 in-the rain on the Springdale course today.

Dr. George Gray Ward of the Woman's Hospital was honored yesterday at a reception marking his twenty years of service as chief surgeon of the institution. The reception, held at the hospital, 141 West 109th Street, was attended by the board of governors, the assistant board and the entire surgical staff.
Tonight's major events: Dessoff Choirs, Carnegie Hall; Helen Fogel, pianist, Town Hall; Lillian Lefkofsky, pianist, Barbizon Hotel.

Howland S. Davis, chairman of the business conduct committee of the New York Stock Exchange, responsible for the financial condition of its members, testified before the Securities and Exchange Committee today that he was not told that Richard Whitney had to go to his brother, George, partner of J. P. Morgan Co., to make up

C. R. Fleischmann's West Coast campaigner, Parmelee T., outclassed his opposition on a sloppy track today in the Walbrook Purse, at a mile and a sixteenth. Having chased Sun Egret home in two stakes at Bowie, Parmelee T. was a lukewarm favorite and paid $6.10 for $2.

One of the first large charity parties of the post-Lenten season took place in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria last night, when a supper dance was given for the benefit of the Church Mission of Help, a social casework agency of the Episcopal Church which provides a confidential counseling service for young women of any denomination who are in need of advice on personal problems of family relationship.
Ernest C. Moore, consulting engineer, died today at his home here after an illness of about two weeks. Death was caused by a stroke which aggravated a cardiac ailment. He was 67 years old.

Tomorrow's opening game between the Indians and Browns may provide an inkling as to which club got the better deal in the Winter swap between the clubs. Cleveland sent Catcher Billy Sullivan and Second
Charles Farrell will return to the screen in a minor role in a remake of a picture which brought him fame. "Sunny Side Up," the talkie

Wages of American steel employes in 1937 were further above the wages of steel workers in foreign countries than they were a year before. A study by the American Iron and Steel Institute discloses that increases in pay to American steel workers raised their hourly earnings last year 22 per

A drive for enactment by early May of President Roosevelt's recovery and relief program, with the aim also of closing this session of Congress not later than June 1, was planned by Congressional leaders today after a conference at the White House.

The Senate Committee on Naval Affairs, in urging prompt passage of the Administration's $1,156,546,000 Naval Expansion Bill, filed in the Senate today a report in which it asserted that without a navy capable of controlling the..sea areas against an

House approval sent to the White House today legislation ordering the government to pay General John J. Pershing $19,490 to meet losses suffered in foreign countries because of the appreciation of foreign currencies.

MANHATTAN ADLER, MARTIN M. (Sept. 19, 1937). Gross assets, $3,281 net, $1,970. To Beatrice M. Adler, widow, residue; one other bequest. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $3,281. Jacobs and Blumenstiel, attorneys, 225 Broadway.
The At organization and conduct of the business of the Columbia Engineering Corporation as a subsidiary service company of the Columbia
Permits for construction issued during the first quarter of 1938 were evaluated by the State Labor Department today at $131,018,000, about 50 per cent over the same period in 1937.

The report of the United Corporation for the first three months of this year, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $2,123,331 after all expenses and tax charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements,

The fifty-second annual exhibition of the Architectural League of New York was opened last night at 215 West Fifty-seventh Street with a preview, at which medals and prizes were awarded. The show, illustrating recent architectural developments throughout the country, will be open to the public from today to May 12.
Henry S. Morgan's Djinn today won the final tune-up race before the start tomorrow of the six-meter yachting series for the Prince :of Wales Trophy.

Miss Rita Therese McDonald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. McDonald of this city, was martried here to Charles D. McGratty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. McGratty of Brooklyn, yesterday morning in the chapel of Our Lady of Lourdes.

The entire question of relief will be thrashed out on the floor of the Constitutional Convention, leaders predicted today. They based their statement on the knowledge that there will be a determined effort by "liberals" in the convention to write into the Constitution the actual authority

Circuit Judge Wilfred H. Jayne upheld today the 1933 act under which banks reorganize. He ruled it was an adequate defense for the Equitable Trust Company, Atlantic City, against Theresa McSweeney's attempt to collect $195,558 in deposits.

Italy, blaving reached an accord with Britain, accepted yesterday a French proposal to negotiate for an agreement. Rome, confident that the negotiations will succeed, visualizes itself at the center of a four-power system-including Berlin-but Paris is chary of such a line-up. It was reported that Italy would seek also an Adriatic alliance with Yugoslavia. [Page 1.]

With obvious reference to fusion with the American Labor party and other elements supporting Mayor La Guardia in the last city campaign, former Supreme Court Justice John R. Davies declared last night that Republicans were weary

Awards of the seventh annual architectural competition sponsored jointly by the Illuminating Engineering Society and the Beaux-Arts Institute or Design of New York City, were announced last night at the Beaux-Arts Institute, 304 East Forty-fourth Street. Twenty-seven architects and illuminating engineers were the judges.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will make the seventieth anniversary address at Hampton Institute Thursday. A special party of 150 persons will leave New York City tomorrow morning over the Baltimore Ohio Railroad to attend the exercises.

Henceforth university students will not be free to read "On Liberty," by John Stuart Mill; "Roads to Freedom," by Bertrand Russell; "The Private Papers of Henry Ryecroft," by George Gissing, and other works hitherto in use in connection with the study of English literature.

The trucking strike here which has cut haulage operations to about 10 per cent of normal was partially settled this morning by ratification of an agreement reached at a conference yesterday afternoon between merchants and truck drivers.

Mrs. Jennie Green, 31 years old, was found dead yesterday in the apartment of her brother, Dr. Victor H. Kugel, at 230 East Severityfirst Street. She apparently had slashed her throat with a razor blade. The police listed the case as a suicide. They said she had been separated from her husband.

There was a strong disposition in racing circles yesterday to believe that Charles Kurtsinger, suspended jockey, would be restored to good standing in time to handle War Admiral in the $100,000 match race against Seabiscuit at Belmont Park on May 30.

Fermented malt liquors produced in the United States in March amounted to 4,997,855 barrels, 58,422 barrels less than in the same month last year, the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Treasury announced today.

The steamship companies today advised the striking clerks and longshoremen that if they were not back at work at 7 o'clock tomorrow morning all negotiations under last February's arbitration agreement were off.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,385,400 barrels, compared with 3,392,350 in the previous week, a decline of 6,950, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 23,700 barrels more than the calculation of 3,361,700 daily by the Bureau of Mines for April.
A new operating company has been formed to run the Ritz Tower, skyscraper apartment hotel at the northeast corner of Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, it was learned yesterday.

A split in the Netherland Socialist party became apparent at the Easter Congress when a large majority voted against the moderate policies that prominent party leaders had adopted recently. While these leaders were willing to collaborate with the government in matters of national defense and

Natalie Hays Hammond, daughter of the late John Hays Hammond, has leased to Walter W. Birge Jr., son of the industrialist and former secretary to Alexander Weddell, United States Ambassador to the Argentine, her duplex apartment in the cooperative house at 322 East Fifty-seventh Street.

A majority of German officers on the retired list, living abroad or serving in foreign armies, have been recalled during the last few weeks, the Prager Mittag reports in a dispatch from Berlin. In Berlin, the paper learned, the official reason given was a shortage of qualified officers for the new German Army.

Alonzo J. Powers 2d, 30 years old, of 1,125 Park Avenue, who was indicted a week ago in the alleged theft of $3,271 from the Arbor Inn Club at Princeton University, of which he had been the graduate treasurer since July, 1936,

John J. Sullivan. once known as the "czar of Wallabout Market," where for many years he acted as watchman for farmers who brought their produce for sale, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Clarence G. Galston in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to serve nine months in the Federal detention prison in Manhattan and to pay a fine of $10,000.

It is definite now that Joseph Losey will be next Fall's producer of "The Fifth Column," or the play about the Spanish war by Ernest Hemingway. Contracts have been signed, and there is talk in the Losey office of persuading Gary Cooper to play the leading role and of obtaining the services of Margo for one of the other important roles.

Governor Earle's admission that he borrowed large amounts of money from Matthew H. McCloskey, building contractor and co-leader of the Philadelphia Democratic organization, had prompt reaction today in a demand that he resign or face impeachment proceedings.

Rudolph Spreckels, of the California sugar family, offered today to turn over "all the worldly goods" he possessed to the government to satisfy a $648,000 income tax deficiency incurred in 1927-28. The Federal Attorney's office said the proposal would be forwarded to Washington.

Although in control of the Constitutional Convention, the Republicans were crowded out of the limelight at its first working session last night and at a brief session today by delegates from the Democratic minority.
R. E. Goes, export manager of Calvert Distillers Corporation, will sail for England today on the Aquitania. While abroad Mr. Goes plans to engage in promotional work for the Calvert line.
The Rev. Henry C. Van Haagen, retired Congregationalist minister, died Sunday at the home of his brother, Herbert J. Van Haagan, in Narberth, after a week's illness. He was 66.

The prosecution lost an admittedly vital point yesterday in the Bronx Court of Special Sessions in its attempt to prove that pictures of the birth of a baby in the April 11 issue of Life Magazine were indecent and that the publisher, Roy E. Larsen, violated Section 1141 of the Penal Code when he sold a copy of the publication.

A drive to find and treat Harlem's estimated 20,000 sufferers from venereal diseases began yesterday afternoon at the Central Harlem Health Center, Fifth Avenue and 136th Street, when twentyfive members of the Youth Opportunity Club of the New York Urban League submitted voluntarily to blood tests.
The Indians got the hits in their opener today but the revived Browns got the runs and sent Johnny Allen down to a 6-to-2 defeat.
Al efforts by Congressional leaders to write legislation to "take the profit out of war" have been pigeonholed for this session of Congress.

Almost a score of American volunteers who fought with Spanish Government forces in the civil war are stranded in Mediterranean ports awaiting passage home. Eleven are at Marseilles, France, four are at Algiers and several others have found their way to Bordeaux, France.

Although the Committee for Industrial Organization has opposed separation of a steel company's employes into more than one group, the National Labor Relations Board today divided the employes of the Falk Corporation of Milwaukee into two groups for election purposes.

A. M. Castle Co. A. M. Castle Co. declared a dividend of 25 cents a share, or half the quarterly dividend paid on Feb. 10. Century RibbEn Mills Directors of the Century Ribbon Mills Company took no action on the common dividend. On Feb. 15, last. 10 cents a share was paid to common shareholders.

Dr. John M. Thomas resigned today as vice president of the National Life Insurance Company. He explained that after forty-five years as a clergyman, college president and insurance executive, he wished time to devote to less confining duties. He retains his position as director of the company.

Accused of testifying that his wife had disappeared and he thought her dead when actually he knew she was living in East Orange, N. J., Stephen D. Cossey of Tottenville, S. I., was indicted for firstdegree perjury today by the Westchester County grand jury.

After joining forces with troops that had been slowly battling their way down the Ebro Valley for the last fifteen days, Navarre brigades under General Garcia Valino this morning closed in on Tortosa from the south. As soon as another Nationalist [Insurgent] column moves down from the other side of the Ebro River, the conquest of the city can be completed.

Appointment of six educators in anthropology, medicine and classical languages to professorships in Columbia University, effective next September, and the designation of five others as visiting scholars for 1938-39 were announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

Failing to win for the first time in seven games, Mrs. Adele Rivero, women's National Chess Federation champion and custodian of the Hazel Allen Trophy, drew her adjourned game from the eighth round of the annual championship at the Marshall Chess Club last night.

F. D. OMMANNEY'S story of his Antarctic experiences makes good reading from start to finish. There aren't many books of the sort about which that can be said flatly. The title is "Below the Roaring Forties."*

A few months ago the Secretary of the Treasury came to this city to deliver an address on the fiscal policies of the Roosevelt Administration. In that address he said that he was "aware that some persons contend that another great spending program is desirable to ward off the risk of another business depression."

Miss Maria Virginia Zimbalist, daughter of Efrem Zimbalist, noted violinist and Mrs. Zimbalist (Alma Gluck), was married to Ogden Goelet of this city and Newport yesterday afternoon at the New York home of her parents. The Rev. Philip C. Jones of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony.

With the approval of a loan of $5,200 to John J. Schmitt, on a new dwelling on Roosevelt Avenue, Malverne, L. I., the Prudential Insurance Company has completed its first transaction as an approved mortgagee for FHA mortgage insurance in the New York territory.

The adjourned annual meeting of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, scheduled to be held tomorrow in Wilmington, Del., has been postponed further until May 5. It will be held at noon, Eastern daylightsaving time, the company announced yesterday.

Algernon R. Clapp, Philadelphia attorney, was killed shortly before 1 A. M., today when his automobile plunged sixty feet from the City Line Bridge over the Schuylkill River to the tracks of the Reading Railroad. He wore only pajamas and a bathrobe.

The Manhattan Railway Company, owner of New York's main elevated lines, has opened negotiations with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a Federal loan to pay back taxes and buy new equipment with which to operate independently, presumably. at an increased fare, it was learned today.

In recognition of his work in behalf of international cooperation, Professor James T. Shotwell of the History Department of Columbia University and president of the League of Nations Association was decorated yesterday at a private luncheon in the Hotel WaldorfAstoria with the Order of the White Lion by the Czechoslovak Government.

Jesus Hernandez, a high-ranking Communist who was left out of Premier Juan Negrin's reorganized Cabinet, returned to a position of power today. General Jose Miaja announced that Sefior Hernandez, formerly Minister of Education,

Metropolitan Museum of Art- "Environment of Sculpture," Edwin L. M. Taggart, 11 A.M.; Medieval Collection (general tour), 2 P. M., Seventeeth annual luncheon, National Council of American Importers and Traders, Hotel Astor, 1 P. M. "Business Recovery and the Expansion of Foreign Trade." Professor Oliver M. W. Sprague.

Fred H. Johnson, 365 Hart Ave., West Brighton, S. I., N. Y., a prospective graduate of the R. O. T. C., University of New Hampshire, Durham, N. H., is assigned as a Reserve officer to the 5th Coast Artillery (HD) (RA), effective upon acceptance of appointment in the Officers Reserve Corps, as second lieutenant, Coast Artillery Corps Reserve.
