MANHATTAN CAHN, HENRIETTA (Dec. 17, 1937). Gross assets, $33,077; net, $26,701. To Emile Cahn, husband, life estate in residue: Elsie N. Cahn, Arthur M. Cahn and Jeanette C. Collier, children, remainders in residue. Chief assets, real estate, $20,000. Spellman Spellman, attorneys, 115 Broadway.

Certificates of commendation were awarded to four United States air lines yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor by the National Safety Council in recognition of millions of passenger miles flown without fatal accidents. The awards went to American Airlines, Inc.; Eastern Air Lines, Northwest Airlines, Inc., and Pennsylvania-Central Airlines.
Two women, one of them a 71-yearold convalescent, were shot and critically wounded here this afternoon as they sat talking in the parlor of the invalid woman's home at 1 Lincoln Court.

A revival in large-scale air-conditioning jobs by Fall was predicted yesterday by L. R. Boulware, vice president and general manager of the Carrier Corporation, in an address before the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Investigations by the Maritime Commission into the need for subsidies to ship lines operating to South Africa and the service requirements of traffic moving to and from the Port of New York were closed here yesterday mornings.
James (Jeff) Burkett, anti-Hague leader here, was released from jail today b when a $1,000 bond was posted pending his arraignment tomorrow in First Criminal Court before Judge Anthony Botti.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt gave a dinner and musical in the White House this evening. Eight Senators, headed by Senator Hale of Maine, who escorted Mrs. Roosevelt, and seven members of the House of Representatives,

John H. Doeg of Rumson, former national tennis singles champion, obtained a Chancery Court order today temporarily restraining his wife, Mrs. Dorothea S. Doeg, from taking their two children out of the State.
Tonight's major events: Frederick Bristol, pianist, Town Hall; Busoni Society, Steinway Hall; Composers' Forum-Laboratory, free concert, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall.

Although the Riegelman constitutional proposals merit consideration as a sincere effort to solve the housing problem, they would not meet with approval of the people of New York State because in their present form they constitute a their menace to real estate as an investment, according to Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York.

A tie for first place between Samuel Reshevsky, national champion, and Reuben Fine at ten points won and two lost was brought about yesterday when Fine won his adjourned game from the thirteenth round with Isaac I. Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Club, in the biennial title tournament of the National Chess Federation at the Marshall Club.

Retired Captain Henry F. Shanahan, formerly a member of Engine Co. 156, residing at 21-48 Richmond Terrace, Richmond, died April 16. Funeral will take place from his late residence at 9:30 A. M. Wednesday, April 20. Interment at Holy Name Cemetery, Jersey City, N. J. The deputy chief of the 8th Division shall detail one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen as funeral escort.

The Rev. Arthur H. Halfmann, pastor of St. John's Lutheran Church, College Point, since 1910, died yesterday afternoon in the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital after a brief illness at the age of 61. He preached his last sermon on Palm Sunday.

The appointment of Dr. Russell L. Carpenter, assistant professor of anatomy at the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University, as Professor of Zoology to take the place of Dr. Herbert V. Neal, who is retiring in June, was announced today by Acting President George S. Miller.

For the second consecutive day U. A. W. A. pickets seeking to compel workers to pay union dues forced Fisher Body Plant No. 1 and the final assembly line of the Buick Motor Company to shut down today.

Elder Arthur Bruce, head of the Shaker colony in Canterbury, N. H., for many yearn and senior elder of the parent ministry at Mount Lebanon, N. Y., a Shaker community, died last 'night. He was 79 years old.

The board of directors of Abraham Straus, Inc., were re-elected at the annual stockholders meeting yesterday, and they re-elected the officers of the corporation. Directors are Edward C. Blum, Walter N. Rothschild, Hugh Grant Straus,

Lewin B. Barringer of Philadelphia landed his sailplane here today after a flight from Wichita Falls, Tex., and said he believed he had bettered the American distance record for sailplanes. Barographs are to be sent to Washington.

George G. Brown, former employe of the New York City Board of Education for thirty-five years and deputy superintendent of the Bureau of Supplies when he retired two years ago, died here yesterday at his home at the age of 72. He was born in Brooklyn.

Although the gross revenue of the Waldorf-Astoria rose from $7,633,912 in 1936 to $7,752,967 in 1937, the profit available for interest and additional rental, after expenses, including taxes and basic rental, was $63,260 last year, as against $227,125 in 1936, according to Amott, Baker Co., Inc.

F. Abbot Goodhue, chairman of the Greater New York Fund's finance section, which includes 2,000 financial firms, insurance companies and security and commodity exchanges, announced yesterday that organization of his section was more than 80 per cent complete.

Senator Bridges of New Hampshire, a leader in the fight for an investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority, contended tonight that "the Roosevelt Administration" had kept him from being a member of a joint Congressional investigating committee.

The Massachusetts Investors Trust reported yesterday a net asset value of $15.56 a share on 5,400,267 shares on March 31, compared with $18.64 a share on 5,240,684 shares on Dec. 31. By April 16, however, the report adds, the net asset value had recovered to $18.48 a share.

The New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners approved today an application of the Erie Railroad to discontinue six westbound and five eastbound trains of the line's northern division, from Jersey City to Nyack, N. Y.

Railroads reporting yesterday showed decreased gross and net returns. These companies were representative of different regions, as they comprised the Erie, Kansas City Southern, Southern Pacific and Union Pacific.

Reminiscent of the dull and dispirited markets of a fortnight ago, before the inflation topic was introduced and before the Government Reorganization Bill was defeated, share prices drifted lower yesterday in slow trading.

Leslie Pawson, 34-year-old Pawtucket, R. I., playground instructor, today became the fourth "repeater" in the forty-two-year history of the famous Boston A. A. marathon by defeating Pat Dengis of Baltimore, regarded as the country's greatest long distance runner, by almost a fifth of a mile.

As prospective owners of most of the nation's private wealth, women are rapidly taking the "burden of benevolence" from the shoulders of men, Dr. William E. Weld, president of Wells College, said yesterday.

Failures in the wholesale trade for the week ended April 14, totaling thirty-six, were the highest for any week during 1938, according to the results of a compilation issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

The body of a man who fell or jumped from George Washington Bridge yesterday was identified by two sons early today as that of William Grower, 63 years old, Paterson silk manufacturer. Mr. Grower, president and owner of the Grower Silk Company,
Major Charles F. Schisane, Italian World War ace and escort to General John J. Pershing on the Italian front, died last night at a hospital. He had been ill a year.

The Italian Government's expenditure on its entire exhibit at the New York World's Fair in 1939 is expected to exceed $1,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday when Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, announced that the board of design had approved the plans for Italy's exhibit building.

Stocks continued to drift downward and closed from fractions to 3 points lower in smallest trading since April 7; turnover, 571,680 shares. United States Government issues firm and less active, other bonds irregularly lower; transactions, $4,941,000.

Acting on the complaints of teachers and supervisors, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, yesterday appointed a committee of three associate superintendents to study the problem of "extra-curricular" teaching engaged in by directors, heads of departments, administrators and other members of the New York City educational department.

To commemorate its 1,100 members who have died in the service of their country, the 107th Infantry (old Seventh Regiment) will erect a Gothic shrine housing a "Book of Remembrance" containing the names of the dead,. at its armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

A campaign to acquaint investors with the need for careful investigation of the brokers with whom they deal was begun today by the Chicago Stock Exchange following the disclosure of the large losses incurred by investors in the failure of the Hoagland Allum Company, Inc.

Walter N. Walmsley, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., in 1,088 Park Ave: Gus Grismann, through Pease Elliman, Inc. in 480 Park Ave; Harry Horner, in 122 E 76th St; Frances R. Jaffin, broker. Genevieve Henderson, through Pease Elliman, Inc, in 255 W 108th St; Cross Brown Co, brokers.

The thirty-five-acre estate with an eleven-room house, formerly owned by Daniel J. Schoonmaker of New York, in the Codfish Hill section of Bethel, Conn., was sold to Gail Borden, also of New York, reports Previews, Inc.
The Bangor Aroostook Railroad Company was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to assume liability for $1,500,000 of 2% per cent equipment trust certificates, Series L. 1938.

J. Theus Munds, senior partner in the firm of Munds, Winslow Potter, 40 Wall Street, members of the New York Stock Exchange and the principal commodity exchanges, died on Monday night at Doctors Hospital. He had undergone an abdominal operation on Thursday.

Members of the coalition group in the City Council decided yesterday to appeal to the Court of Appeals from the Appellate Division ruling that John Cashmore, Brooklyn Democrat, had been elected vice chairman of the Council on Jan. 3 for a two-year term.

Thais Giroux, 25-year-old dancer who appeared in a Broadway cabaret in 1936 as Thelma Thais, died early yesterday in Bellevue Hospital after plunging five stories to her death from her room in the Hotel Lincoln, Eighth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street. The police after an investigation, listed the case as a suicide.

The New York University golf team opened its season today by tying Lehigh, 3 to 3, at the Hickory Country Club, the Violet's home course. Four matches were halved, while each team scored one victory. Jack Carringer of Lehigh defeated Bill Gerek, 3 and 2, but N. Y. U.

With the reopening of foreign financial markets yesterday for the first time since the announcement last Thursday of the government's new spending and credit-expansion program, the dollar recovered a part of its losses of the past few days.

The signing of the Anglo-Italian agreement and the news of President Roosevelt's new pump-priming schemes caused an all-around strengthening as the stock market here reopened today after the long holiday week-end.

After having been held for six beer weeks as helpless prisoners of the Nazis inside Austria, a group of Jews have been stripped of all their possessions and thrust across the border by Storm Troopers, only to be forced out of Czechoslovakia and Hungary in turn, according to reports received today from the frontier province of Burgenland.

The answer to the question-raised by several of the millions of citizens who write to the Treasury regarding its "baby bonds," as to why the Treasury does not convey information in its "baby-bond" announcement leaflets comparable with that required of corporations under the Securities Act of 1933, is that no corporation issues a daily statement comparable with the Treasury's daily statement, James William Bryan, chief of the information section, Division of Savings Bonds, said today.

The sinking of the United States gunboat Panay in the Yangtze River-which will go down in Japanese history as an unfortunate accident-is being commemorated in Japan by a modest foundation designed to convert this disastrous event into permanent machinery for strengthening Japanese-American friendship.
A heavy liquid compound was put to work today as a "breaker boy" to glean high-grade anthracite from the mine refuse camp.

H. Hobart Porter, chairman of the board of the American Water Works and Electric Company, told shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday that earnings of the company for the first quarter of the current year were "well below" the same period in 1937, principally owing to a falling off in the sales of power to industrial consumers throughout the system.

WASHINGTON, April 19.-The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 18: COLONELS Wright, J. W., Inf., six days leave, April 19. Pearce, E. D., C.A.C., two months and two days leave, April 28.

The United States Rubber Company about broke even during the first quarter of 1938, William de Krafft, chairman of the finance committee, said at the annual meeting of stockholders held in Jersey City yesterday, with business volume running at an annual rate of about $120,000,000.

Henry W. Collins, who has served the company since 1923, when he left Fordham University, was elected yesterday a vice president of the Celotex Corporation, it was announced by Bror G. Dahlberg, president of the company.
Forty-one per cent of the common stock of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway rallied today to the support of the company's management, which Robert R. Young is fighting to maintain in office.

With magazine linage declining, not only has the establishment of new publications, so prevalent last year, been halted, but many are rapidly passing out, according to comment in magazine circles yesterday.

A portrait of Dr. James Carroll Flippin, dean of the department of medicine in the University of Virginia, was presented to the -university this afternoon by the men who graduated in medicine since Dr. Flippin has been dean.

Federal Judge John M. Woolsey dismissed yesterday complaints in six suits brought' by receivers of five closed national banks and one trust company against the Chase National Bank for a total of $6,051,771.

This is the center of the TVA defense program. In wartime Nitrate Plant No. 2, now devoted to the peacetime production of fertilizer to restore the fertility of the soil of the Tennessee Valley, could be converted to the manufacture of war material.

Sales of Gimbel Brothers and subsidiaries for February and March, the first two months of the fiscal year, were 12 per cent below the same months last year, Bernard Gimbel, president, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders, while sales this month to April 18, Inclusive,

Miss Mary Martin of 1 West Seventy-second Street, who won many honors for her relief work in France during and after the World War, died in her home yesterday after an illness of three months. Two sisters, Mrs. J. Kilbourne Hayward and Mrs. Hubert E. Rogers, survive.
Mayor La Guardia will leave late this afternoon on the first leg of an eight-day trip to the West, where he will make several speeches.

The best proof that tax relief has not been discounted as a recovery factor is to be found in the effects on certain industrial stocks of the President's intervention, and the growing concern of business men lest the House-Senate deadlock prevent new tax legislation.

Charges were made on the House floor today that Horace Russell, general counsel of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, had sought legal business involving the agency for a subordinate who recently resigned. Within two hours John H. Fahey, HOLC chairman, announced that Mr. Russell had resigned.

Steel ingot output was unchanged last week when a seasonal increase was looked for, and the adjusted index declined to 44.3 from 45.4. The figure for the week ended April 17, 1937, was 121.6. THE NEW YORK TIMES held its estimate at 34 per cent of capacity, which compared with 91 per cent for the corresponding week last year.

Miss Helen Shumway of Greenwich, Conn., gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Marguerite Sykes and Walter P. Chrysler Jr., whose marriage will take place April 29 in St. Bartholomew's Church.

Mr. and Mrs. John Arthur Brown of Chestnut Hill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Draper Brown, to James G. B. Perkins Jr., son of Mrs. J. Gerritt B. Perkins of Boston and of the late Mr. Perkins. Miss Brown is a member of the Philadelphia Cricket Club and attended Springside School. She is a niece of Dr. Henry P. Brown of Chestnut Hill. Mr. Perkins attended Penn Charter School.

The Rev. Dr. Edward Niles, pastor of the Newtown Dutch Reformed Church, Elmhurst, Queens, was elected president of the North Classis of Long Island of the Reformed Church of America yesterday at the Spring meeting at the Community Church of Douglagton, Main Street and Douglaston Parkway.

An Easter prank resulted in injuries to four persons in the mining township of Gwalia, West Australia. An Italian miner, while drinking with a woman boardinghouse keeper and another miner, thought he would put alum into their wine to see them make wry

The Foreign Ministry at noon today through a high official presented apologies to the German Legation for an incident occurring two hours earlier. Construction laborers working in the suburb of Device saw a large
Two sisters of the Dionne quintuplets have arrived here to enter the old Convent of the Ursuline Sisters as pupils, the Sister Superior said today.

Ten United States Army bombers landed at Ilopango Air Field at noon today after a non-stop flight from France Field, C. Z. Lieut. Col. George L. Lovell commands the squadron, composed of twenty officers and twenty enlisted men.

" The recently completed tour of the Metropolitan Opera Association has broken all records," said Edward Johnson, general manager, who was guest of honor of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, speaking yesterday afternoon at its annual meeting in the ballroom of the Hotel Pierre.

Fordham's rifle team placed first among colleges from New York, New Jersey and Delaware in the national intercollegiate rifle match, it was announced yesterday at the United States Army Second Corps Area headquarters at Governors Island.

Representatives of eight trade and civic associations held a luncheon meeting yesterday in the Aldine Club to study recommendations they might make on the tentative program drafted by the Mayor's Committee on City Planning for rezoning about 400 blocks in Manhattan below Thirty-fourth Street, and including Greegnwich Village.

Eduardo Suarez, Minister of Finance of Mexico, who has been at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria for several days, expects to leave this morning for Washington, where he is expected to take up the question of resumption by the United States Treasury of its monthly commitments for the purchase of Mexican silver.

Miss. B. Jameson's Irish Stew today won the Great Metropolitan Stakes, defeating the Aga Khan's Dahrampur by a length. H. Lester's Holne Chase, a neck behind Dahrampur, was third in the field of thirteen.
Henry Ford, a reliable source said tonight, has accepted an invitation to discuss business conditions with President Roosevelt at the White House on April 27.

The Good Roads Engineering and Construction Company of Wantagh, L. I., was the low bidder yesterday for the fourth and last major contract involving construction of the ten-mile Wantagh State Parkway extension in Nassau County. The Good Roads company offered to grade, pave and install drainage in a three-mile stretch between Union Avenue and Hempstead Turnpike for $864,640.
A. B. Filson young, author and war correspondent, who had been adviser on programs to the British Broadcasting Corporation since 1926, died here today at the age of 61.

Robert Taylor, captain of the Columbia varsity wrestling team last season, was the recipient of two trophies at a dinner tendered the squad by the Grapplers Society at the Castleholm Restaurant last night.

A suit for $75,000 damages brought by Miss Gertrude Ederle, first woman to swim the English Channel, against the Justine Apartments, Inc., of Hempstead has been set. tiled out of court, it was learned here today.

A conspiracy to violate United States neutrality in the Spanish civil war, by shipping fighting planes from California to the Loyalists through Mexico, was indicated in a Federal Grand Jury indictment issued today.
Hope that loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to railroads would stimulate the purchase of railway equipment was expressed at the annual meeting

Brigadier Helen Purviance of the Salvation Army, who cooked no fewer than 1,000,000 doughnuts for the United States fighting forces in France during the World War, yesterday afternoon demonstrated her culinary skill at a "doughnut fry" at the Hotel Savoy-Plaza.
The thirty-eighth American bowling congress rolled to a close tonight with Middle Westerners claiming first money in all four events.

The report of the Commonwealth Southern Company and.subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses and charges, of $13,684,019.

The four-story brownstone dwelling at 244 East Fifteenth Street, adjoining the corner of Second Avenue and overlooking Stuyvesant Square, has been purchased by. John A. Kennedy and associates through Van Vliet Place, brokers.

" Great Germany," which puts its new name in the same proud juxtaposition with Great Britain as Rome does its imperial title with the British Empire, has been mobilized to celebrate tomorrow the forty-ninth birthday of its creator, Adolf Hitler, with greater pomp and ceremony than ever marked the birthday celebration of either a German or an Austrian emperor.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 16: COMMANDER Comstock, M., Washington, D. C., to instruction Naval War College, Newpart, R. I., in June.

Under what the citizens here called a Spring sun, and with a man in the coaching launch who conjured up memories of a great figure of American sport, Syracuse's crews left their new boathouse tonight for a brisk workout on Onondaga Lake. With little wind, the men paddled down to the start of the excellent mile-and-three-quarter course and came back at a racing clip.

The good luck of the Wheatley Stable and of Trainer Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons failed to stand up in the featured Briarwood Purse at Jamaica yesterday when Merry Lassie, a 7-to-10 chance, could not last the six furlongs of the main event.

The question what is the minimum amount of statistical information essential to good operation of smaller volume stores in the department, dry goods and specialty store field, took first place among the subjects suggested by these stores for study by the newly

The German Government has finally decided to strike a decisive blow at the independence of the Protestant Church. Germany'sProtestant pastors henceforth will be forced to take the civil servants' oath of obedience to Chancellor Adolf Hitler or suffer expulsion from their charges and dismissal without pension.

The Maritime Association obtained 127 new members and improved its financial status last year, H. W. Warley, its president, reported yesterday at the annual meeting in the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street. Mr. Warley has been renominated for the presidency.

The city of Roanoke, Va., awarded yesterday to a banking group headed by The First Boston Corporation $5,000,000 of water works bonds on a bid of 99.3099 for 2 3/4s, or at a net interest cost basis of 2.7883 per cent.

The Rev. Dr. Francis Alonzo Gray, retired Universalist minister, who had held pastorates in Boston, Philadelphia and New York State, died today at the home of his son, Malcolm Gray of Newton Center. He was 80.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has distributed to local investment banking houses the first of a new series of weekly questionnaires designed to provide the central banking authorities with more complete and timely information on the state of the capital market, it was announced yesterday at the bank.

Consent of the United States Maritime Commission for transfer of the American registry of the yacht Savarona at Hamburg, Germany, to Turkish registry was given, it was said today, when the Turkish purchasers stated precisely for what purposes they intended to use the craft.

The Interior Ministry announced tonight that another 1,500 Iron Guard members were under arrest after a search of their homes and barracks had disclosed plans to capture King Carol and set up a Fascist State.
Secretary Ickes conferred with President Roosevelt today regarding the proposal to sell helium to Germany and told reporters a decision might be expected this week.

Dr. Ada L. Comstock, president of Radcliffe College, will address the New Jersey Radcliffe alumnae and their guests on the "Coordinate College" at the Kent Place School here Friday afternoon at 3:30 o'clock,

EVERY so often some fan brings up the matter of Rube Marquard's record of nineteen straight victories on the big league pitching mound. Was it nineteen--straight, as the record books have it, or twenty straight, as Rube and many of his rooters claim?
A special commission, remembering how thousands stood in the rain to hear President Roosevelt's second inaugural address, recommended to Congress today a $9,000,000 auditorium for the capital.

235th St (12-3366), n s, 100 ft w of Oneida Ave. 31x100; Hattie B. Bolsseau to Friend L. Tuttle, 94 Landscape Ave, Yonkers; mtg $14,500. 219th St (16-4666), a s, 313 it e of White Plains Rd, 33x114; Railroad Federal Savings and Loan Assn to Grace Blasucci, 31-15 Brighton 4th St, Brighton Beach, N.Y.
BELOW THE ROARING FORTIES, by F. D. Ommanney. (Longmans, Green, $3.( The adventures of a young scientist in the Antarctic.

The House passed the Agricultural Department and Farm Credit Administration Appropriation Bill today with a total of $903,084,000, including an increase of $62,000,000 in Federal-aid highway funds to a total of $125,000,000. Another $10,000,000 was added to the bill as reported from committee for the construction of feeder roads.

The engagement of Miss Dorothea Liebmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Liebmann of 885 Park Avenue, to Roger W. Straus Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Straus of 6 East Ninety-third Street, has been announced by her parents.

Not much can be said of the Government's complete abandonment of its "gold-sterilizing" policy, announced at the Treasury on Monday, except that it is virtual admission of a futile course of action after 1936.

Miss Catherine Conway Reiley, who heads the junior committee assisting Mrs. William F. Cogswell and the executive committee in the sale of seats for the performance of "Bachelor Born" tonight at the-Lyceum Theatre for the benefit of the Catholic Center for the Blind,

Warning that it would be a "tragic mistake" to ruin the park and parkway program In the Jamaica Bay area by "objectionable disposal operations," Park. Commissioner Robert Moses has asked Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey for full details concerning his plans for dumping garbage and ashes on the bay meadowland.

The murderer and the suicide, the alcoholic and the narcotic addict, the socially maladjusted and the genius are all manifestations of "psychopathic states" in which the individual seeks to compensate for an inadequacy in his personality make-up, the New York Academy of Medicine was told last night by Professor David Kennedy Henderson, noted psychiatrist of the University of Edinburgh.
The longclawed Tigers, despite two booming home runs, had their tails twisted, 4 to 3, by the scrappy White Sox today in the American League epener at Comiskey Park before 18,000 spectators.

The German reaction to the Anglo-Italian treaty continues entirely friendly but purely diplomatic, avoiding any issues that might affect this country. The Diplomatische Korrespondenz, which speaks for the Foreign Office, issued today a statement in diplomatic phrases from which no conclusions can be drawn. It says:

The population of Sing Sing prison reached an all-time high today, with a total of 2,766 prisoners, officials of the institution announced. This overload of prisoners taxed the housing and dining facilities of the prison to the utmost.

Edwin Strawbridge and company appeared yesterday afternoon at Mecca Auditorium in a "danceplay" based on the children's classic, "Pinocchio," under the auspices of Junior Programs, Inc. The dramatic version of the story was made by Dorothy Coit and the score composed by M. Wood Hill.
Universal announced today that Deanna Durbin will offer "Cinderella" as the first film of her new season; it will be produced by Joe Pasternak and directed by Henry Koster.

The first important result of the great massing of Japanese troops in Southern Shantung Province was announced this morning. when the Japanese officially claimed that the town of Lini, about 80 miles northeast of Suchow, had been completely occupied.

With initial copy releases indicating that all forms of transportation, resort and vacation centers, and States and communities will launch aggressive advertising drives for patronage this Summer, general merchandise trades will probably again suffer from this competition
New discoveries as to cancer found through a new kind of chemistry were reported to the American Chemical Society here today by Dr. A. Keith Brewer of the United States Bureau of Chemistry and Soils.

" We have won the war," Generalissimo Franco proclaimed yesterday in a broadcast. The Insurgent leader said further resistance was futile, charged 400,000 had been assassinated by the Loyalists, and warned they would have to answer for their crimes. [Page 1.]

Members of the Service Club of St. Thomas Church held their annual card party and tea for the benefit of the Church Mission of Help yesterday in the Roof of the St. Regis. The Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, rector of the church, and Mrs. Brooks were guests of honor. Miss Ruth Belsterling, president of the organization, headed the bridge committee.

The close of the 1937-38 course in advertising conducted by the Advertising Women of New York, Inc., was celebrated last night at a scholarship dinner at the Advertising Club, at which four scholarships, three honorable mentions and seventy-one diplomas were presented to members of the class.

Trading continued slow. The beef market was mostly steady to higher, other classes were weak to lower. Early trading in kosher meats was slow; beef opened steady to weak, veal weak, lamb lower, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

As the opening day crowd was moving toward the exits feeling the Cardinals had come from behind to win, Arky Vaughan stepped up in the ninth and hit to the roof of the right field pavilion for a home run with one on to give the Pirates a 4-to-3 victory today.
Premier Maurice Duplessis of Quebec left tonight for Toronto, where he will confer with Premier Hepburn of Ontario about newsprint prices.

Supreme Court Justice Perskie granted here today an application by the Mayor and City Council of Asbury Park for permission to become defendants with a group of boardwalk concessionaires in litigation brought by the State-appointed commission in control of Asbury Park's beach front.
Martin Schultz of Brooklyn, Cornell University sophomore, was in Memorial Hospital today suffering from severe lacerations and possible fractures received after a tumble into Fall Creek Gorge.

The New Windsor, seven-story apartment house at 294-95 Central Park West, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street Salesrooms. The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as plaintiff, bought it in for $100,000.
Senator Wheeler declared today that large salaries drawn by some corporation officials and others were a "direct threat to institutions of our country."

Thomas Mann, writer and Nobel prize winner, telegraphed from California his interest in the benefit concert to be given at Carnegie Hall on April 27 for Austrian refugees, it was announced yesterday by Countess Mercati, head of the executive committee.

230th St, s s, 204 ft e Carpenter Ave; 3story tenement. 20x66: Mason R. Escher, 638 E 230th St. owner; Erick Kaeyer, architect; cost $12,000. Schofield St, e s, 265 ft w City Island Ave; 2-story brick fire station, 36x96; Fire Department, Municipal Bldg, owner; James T. Treacy, architect; cost $80,000.

Paced by Billy Nicholls, who accounted for six goals, the New York Athletic Club polo team tonight eliminated the 124th Field Artillery of Chicago in a semi-final of the national open indoor tournament, 14 to 8.

The council of Actors Equity rejected yesterday the plea of the League of New York Theatres for a modification of the rule prohibiting a producer's substituting one performer for another to reduce salary expenses during a New York engagement.
Nathan Mann, the New Haven heavyweight who failed in his bid for Joe Louis's heavyweight championship last February, will appear in the feature bout of ten rounds at the New York Hippodrome tonight.

On his return from Washington yesterday, Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, said the Foreign Trade Zone committee of the Board of Estimate would receive proposals at 10 A. M. next Monday for a joint city and private operation of the Foreign Trade Zone on Staten Island.

The recommendation by the Senate Finance Committee that the Federal excise tax on book matches be quadrupled was protested as an "unjust imposition" upon the small retail tobacconist in a statement issued yesterday by Joseph Kolodny, executive secretary of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors.

The sale of "The Beeches," once the home of Calvin Coolidge, to Mr. and Mrs. Sidney A. Bailey of this city was confirmed here tonight by Ralph W. Hemenway, attorney for the former President's widow, Mrs. Grace Coolidge.

In a decision endered tonight Henri Giraud, who had been called in to arbitrate the metal workers' strike, rejected the Laborers' demand for a wage inrease and recommended that national defense factories adopt the forty-five-hour week.
The sixth and seventh chiselerss" in the Levine kidnapping case-men seeking to collect the ransom of $30,000 without knowing the whereabouts of the missing boy-came to grief yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The President's speech was completely devitalized and the advice given to the people was bad. To propose that we go forward and duplicate the mistakes of the past is cruel and futile. We must "sail, not drift," but the right boat must be taken this time or we will be scuttled again.

Completing their final exhibition before the opening of the International League season tomorrow, the Newark Bears, "little world series champions," smothered the Columbia University team with an avalanche of hits yesterday to win by 17 to 1.

As illuminating as any effect of the Anglo-Italian accord is the news that the Czechoslovak Minister in Rome, M. Chvalkovsky, informed the Italian Foreign Office yesterday that his Government henceforth accredits him to the King of Italy and the Emperor of Ethiopia.

Mr. and Mrs. John J. Watson will return to the Plaza today from Hickory Grove, their Winter home in Leesburg, Ga. Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Gleason Tenney will give a dinner dance May 7 in the Cottage Suite of Hampshire House for Miss Joan P. Lusk of Ridgefield, Conn., and their son, Charles Henry Tenney,

Viscount Rothermere, proprietor of The London Daily Mail, Daily Mirror, Evening News and other British newspapers, is sailing today for England on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, accompanied by his son, the Hon. Esmond Harmsworth, and his two grandchildren.

Helpless for two frames, the pennantinspired Cubs walloped three Cincinnati pitchers today and, aided by two homers, came from behind to win the National League opener here, 8 to 7, before a crowd of 34,148.

Children in this era of depression are no more free from care and worry than adults, according to the findings of a psychological study made by WPA research workers under the direction of Dr. Rudolph Pintner of Teachers College, Columbia University. The findings were made public yesterday.

A funeral service for Dr. Max Mueller, manufacturing chemist, said to be the first to manufacture saccharin in commercial quantities in the United States, was held today at 160 Clinton Avenue here. Cremation followed at Rosehill Cemetery, Linden, N. J.

Admitting that "heretofore authorities have winked at bingo," Judge Bernard A. Kozicke, who was the presiding judge in the Bronx Court of Special Sessions yesterday, described bingo as a gambling game, and therefore sentenced three members. of a Republican club who were found guilty of operating such a game to thirty days in the workhouse.

The Labor Department today postponed deportation proceedings against Harry Bridges, the West Coast waterfront labor leader, pending an appeal from a Circuit Court of Appeals decision holding that membership in-the Communist party is not grounds for deportation.

Several hundred owners of small businesses, about fifty of them women, sought Reconstruction Finance Corporation loans at the opening of a special bureau for this purpose yesterday under the auspices of the Smaller Business Association of New York District, Inc.

Henry Ford and Thomas E. Dewey, District Attorney of New York County, will speak at the dinner of the Bureau of Advertising in connection with the American Newspaper Publishers Association's annual convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on April 28.
Four Boston Athletic Association marathon officials were injured today when a beach wagon in which they were riding was in a collision and overturned.

Edgar Percy Lawson of Breakwater House, Southport, Conn., chairman of the board of directors of the E. P. Lawson Company, Inc., 426 West Thirty-third Street, sales representatives for firms manufacturing bookbinding machinery, died on Monday at Safety Harbor,- Fla.
Thomas Black, an evangelist in this country and Canada for the last fifty years, died last night at his home here after a short illness. He would have been 74 years old tomorrow.

The new influences now at work in the market for United States Government securities, notably the increase in excess bank reserves and the possibility that the Treasury will retire maturing discount bills in cash from the proceeds of the gold "desterilization" program, continues a major topic of discussion in financial circles.
The Yankees fashioned their first victory of the 1938 campaign this morning at Fenway Park while holiday celebrants were dawdling over late breakfasts.

ALTHER-At Yonkers, N. Y.. on April 18, 1938, Annie, beloved mother of Philip F., Charles W. and Clarence A. Alther. Services at the Burr Davis Mortuary, 15 Fourth Ave., Mount Vernon, N. Y., on Thursday, 2 P. M. BANKS-Joseph H., on Tuesday, April 19, 1938, beloved husband of Kate, father of John R., Samuel R., Edmond R. and Edith E. Broman.

The first allocations from $30,000,000 in Federal funds earmarked for additional low-cost housing projects in New York City probably will be made today by President Roosevelt, it was announced here last night by Nathan Strauss, United States Housing Administrator.

President Roosevelt discussed the coming Federal Communications Commission investigation of radio broadcasting with Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the commission, and the situation involving sale of helium to Germany with Secretary Ickes.

Rubin Kirsch, 21 years old, a homeless glazier, who said he had been unemployed for three years, gave himself up to police of the East Twenty-second Street station last night. He said he was conscience-stricken- and afraid that hunger and the success of a holdup he had committed on Saturday night would lead him to attempt another.

Max friedman, 33 years old, of 250 East 176th Street, the Bronx, former assistant cashier, at $45 a week, for Butler, Herrick Marshall, brokers, at 30 Broad Street, was sentenced by General Sessions Judge Bohan yesterday from three to six years in Sing Sing for the specific theft of $3,000 from the firm last month.

The American delegates' campaign for worldwide adoption of the New York State Athletic Commission's "nofoul" rule failed today when the World Boxing Conference voted to allow each federation to make its own regulations.
Boston at New York-Turner vs. Schumacher. Brooklyn at Philadelphia-Fitzsimmons vs. Passeau. Chicago at Cincinnati-Dean vs. Grissom. Pittsburgh at St. Louis-Tobin vs. Johnson.

The average American boy is superior in physical type to his British cousin, Howard Evans, headmaster of the Betteshanger School d of Dover, England, declared here yesterday. Mr. Evans arrived sixteen days ago with nine of his students to illustrate the importance of physical education.

There is nothing arbitrary in the city's plan to make Eighth and Ninth Avenues one-way thoroughfares, Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel ruled yesterday in denying the application of the Eighth Avenue Coach Company for a temporary injunction to restrain the city from putting the new regulations into effect.
ATWELL, MARION GAYLORD (April 11). Estate, more than $10,000. To Isabelle Gaylord Williams, sister, executrix, 606 W. 116th St., residue. John N. Trainer, 233 E. 62d St. executor.
Edgar Appleby, playing for 300, defeated Hugo Doob, needing 125, 300 to 100, in thirty innings in the Poggenburg 18.2 balkline billiard tournament at the Lawler Manhattan Academy last night.

The old Pathe motion-picture studio building at 1,988-94 Park Avenue, at the southwest corner of 134th Street, which was the scene of a spectacular fire in 1929 in which eleven persons lost their lives, has been leased for ten years by the H. C. Oswald Supply Company, Inc., distributors of steam and hot-water boilers.

Funeral services for Cornelius F. Kelly, newspaper publisher and advertising representative, were attended here today by 500 persons, many of them publishers from cities as distant as Fargo, N. D. The services were at St. Augustine's Catholic Church.

Officials of the Department of Hospitals of New York City and of Bellevue Hospital were unwilling to comment yesterday on a published report that State Senator John J. McNaboe's Legislative Committee on Law Enforcement would begin an investigation on Monday of Bellevue's psychiatric department, which Senator McNaboe characterized as a "cesspool of inefficiency."

Plans for the expenditure of $1,000,000 by the end of the year to rehabilitate and beautify the eroded or unimproved grounds of fifty-one schools throughout the city were announced yesterday by the Works Progress Administration.

The Commercial Credit Company announced yesterday that its consolidated net income from operations for consolidated interest and discount charges in the first quarter of 1938 was $4,446,239 after providing ample reserves for doubtful items. This compared with $4,792,743 for the first three months of last year.

The Methuselah of marathon, 85-year-old Peter W. Foley of Winchester, whose wife didn't know he was running, "although she was suspicious," today completed the long Boston grind, "just to show 'em there's life in the old dogs yet."

The increase in cases of measles, which has been in progress since Jan. 1, continued during the week ended last Saturday, with 2,281 new patients in this city reported by physicians, it was announced yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner.

The search for Andrew Carnegie Whitfield, missing since he took off from Roosevelt Field last Friday in his two-seated power glider on a fifteen-minute flight to Brentwood, continued yesterday, but hope that he might have landed alive began to falter.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor will arrive here tomorrow for a two-day visit, when it is expected the Duke will sign a lease on the Chateau La Croe, the property of Sir Pomeroy Burton, at Cap d'Antibes.

A number of leases for space in buildings in the financial district were among the commercial rentals announced yesterday by brokers and agents. In 42 Broadway, Hoffer Co., security dealers, leased quarters through Casimir C. Patrick, agent; Louis E. Stern, attorney, rented through Cushman Wakefield,

The former Charles A. Stoneham estate at 141 Kensico Road, in Greenburgh, Westchester County, has been sold to Herbert C. Parris, publisher of New York, who will improve the place and occupy it, according to Gerety Blackwell, Inc., brokers.

Mexico, whose oil exports in the first month of government control of the industry were-about 250,000 barrels, as against 2,000,000 barrels a year ago, is ready to conclude the first important sale to foreign buyers.

Mrs. Lillian Coogan Bernstein, mother of Jackie Coogan, filed an affidavit in court late today declaring her son earned only $1,300,000 in the movies and in vaudeville as a minor, instead of $4,000,000 as he claims. She also stated he had earned between $30,000 and $40,000 in the last two years.

A muddle-headed beaver from Connecticut that apparently mistook Long Island Sound for a New England brook was rescued yesterday morning at Hogs Neck Beach, near Port Jefferson, L. I., after an exhausting seventeenmile paddle across the choppy Sound.
Mrs. Anne Archbold has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Moira Archbold, to Nicol Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hays Smith of the Crossways, Burlingame, Calif.

Herbert Morrison, outstanding figure in the British Labor movement, and a frequent visitor here, has a great admiration for Mr. Roosevelt. Among other things, he praises the President for teaching us that government must accept responsibility "for combating social insecurity."

The right to seek unlisted trading in securities, a privilege which registered national securities exchanges now have, was granted today by the Securities andExchange Commission to the Minneapolis-St. Paul, Seattle and Wheeling Stock Exchanges, which have been exempted from registration with the commission because of their limited volume of transactions.

Plans were completed yesterday for the first game of the season at the Yankee Stadium on Friday, when the New Yorkers will clash with the Senators. The customary opening day ceremonies will take place before the contest, which will begin at 3:15 P. M.

Mayor Thomas L. Holling, head of the city of Buffalo's recently elected nonpartisan business administration, told members of the Municipal Bond Club of New York at a luncheon meeting at the Bankers Club yesterday that no city's financial picture was any sounder than the attitude of its taxpayers.

Boston will have a new water freight service line to Portland and Bangor beginning next Monday. It will cover the route operated for nearly a century by the Eastern Steamship Company and its predecessors, but discontinued in 1935.

The Otis Elevator Company will modernize nineteen of the old escalators at the R. H. Macy Co. store. The work will include new steps with metal treads and closely spacedccleats, new nickel silver comb plates, new tread wheels and other replacements of the mechanical equipment to provide for more quiet operation.
Mike Stehnach held Harvard to five scattered hits and struck out seven today as Cornell blanked the Crimson, 3-0. Tom Healey of the visitors also fanned seven and gave four hits.

The success of the National Labor Relations Board in the New York region in averting and settling strikes and other disputes between employers and employes since the validation of the National Labor Relations Act by the Supreme Court was settled yesterday in a report made public by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the NLRB.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-By GEORGE MATHUE BREAKEY SR., engineer, 45 W. 86th St.-Liabilities, $8,078; assets, $410. HERMAN FLORANT, also known as Florsheimer, stylist, 114 E. 52d St.-Liabilities, $126,133; no assets, except insurance, an automobile and stock in. Herman Florshelmer, Inc., listed as of no value.

At a special meeting yesterday of the directors of the Borden Company, an interim dividend of 30 cents a share was declared, payable on June 1 to stockholders of record of May 16. It compared with the quarterly dividend of 40 cents a share paid on March 1.
President Getulio Vargas today signed a decree forbidding foreign political propaganda in Brazil.

Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, told shareholders at their annual meeting held yesterday at Schenectady that sales billed by the company for the first quarter of this year amounted to $65,086,557,

For improvement with two sixroom colonial-style dwellings the vacant plat, 75 by 100 feet, on the southwest corner of Nineteenth and Seventh Avenues, Whitestone, L. I., has been purchased by the Agate Homes Company. Judge James J. Conroy and Laurence B. Halleran, executors of the estate of Eugene A. Fallonm, were the sellers. William Wiesener was the broker in the deal.

An Immature Spirits act, modeled on those of Great Britain and Canada, will be sought by the Distilled Spirits Institute at the January session of Congress, according to plans worked out here last week and disclosed yesterday.

Bills dealing with air transport and with the merchant marine were reported favorably today by the Senate Commerce Committee stripped of amendments giving the Maritime Commission authority to grant subsidies to overseas air transport companies for construction and operation of

Three sergeants, one corporal and two privates were sentenced to three-year prison terms and one. sergeant to two years by a court-martial for conspiracy against the government, military headquarters announced tonight. Three were acquitted.

In a Jules Verne perspective of the future the automobile was visualized last night at the ninth annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council in the Hotel Astor as a vehicle with photo-electric cells to prevent running through red lights, rear-end engines to afford greater visibility, threewheels for 90-degree turns and electrio energy drawn from the air.

While surveyors and engineers are buss on the Catholic Protectory property in the Bronx, preparing this site for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's vast residential community, real estate brokers, operators and prospective investors may be seen daily now inspecting near-by property with a view to purchase or sale.

Reinhard Heydrich, acting head of the secret political police, points out in Schwarze Korps, the Elite Guard organ, that his Gestapo has now taken over the direction of the International Criminal Police Commission. The latter organization is a central body to control and combat criminal activities internationally. He says:

Monroe Miller has arranged for Jesberger Brothers six FHA loans aggregating $31,000 on new homes sold in their development on Sydney and Morris Avenues, Malverne, L. I. The buyers of the homes swere Thomas F. McCaul, Frank R. Crotty, Charles Reynolds,

American Airlines, Inc., Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., and United Air Lines announced today that effective Sunday their Chicago-New York flights would be operated in 3 hours and 59 minutes, a cut of sixteen minutes from previous schedules.

Having gained the upper hand through superior position play, Samuel Reshevsky, the United States chess champion, indulged in a bit of fireworks to bring to a decisive conclusion his thirteenthround game with A. E. Santasiere in the National Chess Federation tournament.

Sergeant Leroy A. Davison of the 110th Cavalry became "Paul Revere" this morning and tonight he was glad to get back in the modern army after a nerve-racking ride. Sergeant Frederick Greene of. the same detachment spent part of the day as "William Dawes" and he too was glad when it was over.
Donald MacMillan, veteran character actor, died Monday at his home, 146 West Sixteenth Street, of heart disease. He was in his sixtieth year.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had authorized the Consolidated Edison Company of New York to issue $60,000,000 of ten-year 3 1/2 per cent debentures dated April 1, 1938, to be used on June 1 for the redemption of Consolidated Gas Company twenty-year 41/4 per cent gold debenture bonds in the same amount due on June 1, 1951.

With Hank Borowy, sophomore speed ball ace, invulnerable with men on the bases, Fordham shut out Boston College, 12--0, before 4,000 fans at Alumni Field today. Dominic Principe, Brockton boy, led the Maroon hitters with a single, double and triple and preserved Borowy's shut-out with a great one-handed shoestring catch of Tash Goode's liner to right in the seventh. Boston College runners were on first and third at the time.

The Constitutional Convention continues to show promise of getting at its important work in an orderly manner. Two weeks ago it listened to an inspiring keynote speech by Judge Crane, its presiding officer.

Dr. Jacob Winer, Professor of Economics at the University of Chicago and special assistant to the Secretary of the Treasury since 1934, has rerigned his government post and returned to the university campus. "I got tired of the job," was all he would say tonight.

Carroll G. Walter, New York counsel for the Puerto Rico Railway, Light and Power Company, a Canadian corporation, began the presentation of testimony today in an injunction suit before United States District Judge Robert A. Cooper whereby the utility company hopes to prevent the extension into San Juan of. government power lines to serve the Federal and Insular Government agencies.
Mrs. William A. Becker, retiring president-general of the Daughters of the American Revolution, declared today that the "quickest way to create a totalitarian State in America is to get into a war."

Dauber, the 3-year-old chestnut colt that ran second to Stagehand in the Santa Anita Derby, led a field that included four Kentucky Derby eligibles under the wire today to win the $1,500 Hampton Roads Purse.

The sale of utility securities and of utility assets owned by public utility holding companies was brought today directly under the supervision of the Securities and Exchange Commission by the promulgation of a new rule under Section 12 (d) of the Public Utility Holding Company Act. This section authorizes the SEC to make such rules and regulations felt to be necessary in this regard to public interest.

The refusal of Paterson's School Board to pay nine teachers who would not release the board from paying contractual salaries was held illegal today by Dr. Charles H. Elliott, State Commissioner of Education.

Although the National Committee to Uphold Constitutional Government spent $328,707 from Feb. 15, 1937, to March 15, 1938, only fourteen persons, whose donations totaled $14,250, contributed more than $500 each, Frank E. Gannett, its chairman, announced yesterday in reply to the charge that persons of great wealth had financed the committee's opposition to "Court packing" and government reorganization bills.

The Right Rev. Ernest M. Stires, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, officiated last night at the dedication of St. Andrew's Church, Thirty-first Avenue and Forty-seventh Street, Astoria, Queens.

In a statement issued yesterday in London and released here through the local office of United Artists, it was announced officially that plans put forward in England at a recent meeting of the ownerproducers had "resulted in a completely unanimous decision" to reorganize the operating set-up of the company.
Dr. William Franklin Elgin, associate of the late Dr. Walter Reed and producer of smallpox yaccines, died yesterday. He was 76 years old.
